Keci panāhu – ‘‘nimmānaratiparanimmitavasavattino te devā’’ti. Khiḍḍāpadussanamatteneva hete khiḍḍāpadosikāti vuttā. Sesamettha purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
45-46. Because they are corrupted and ruined by indulgence in play, they are called "khiḍḍāpadosikā". Some write *padūsikā* in the Pāli, but that is not in the commentary (*aṭṭhakathā*).

*Ativelaṃ* means *atikālaṃ*, meaning "too long" or "too late."

"Possessed of laughter, play, delight, and the law (or qualities)" means they are devoted to and engaged in laughter, delight in the law, play, delight, and the law. They are devoted to pleasure in sport and laughter, and to pleasure in bodily and verbal play. The meaning is that they live associated with the qualities of delight and the law, as described above.

"When mindfulness is confused" means mindfulness is confused regarding edibles and foods.

These gods, it is said, celebrate a festival in honor of their own great beauty and splendor, attained through their distinguished merit (*puṇyaviseṣādhigatena*). They then become so absorbed in their great enjoyment that they do not even know whether or not they have eaten – "āhāraṃ paribhuñjimha, na paribhuñjimhā" – or not.

But when they have passed up the time even for a single meal, though they eat and drink immediately afterwards, they pass away (*cavanti*) and cannot remain.

Why? Because of the strength of their karma-born heat element (*kammajatejassa balavatāya*) and the delicacy of their material bodies (*karajakāyassa mandatāya*). For humans, the karma-born heat element is delicate and the material body strong.

Because of the delicacy of their heat element and the strength of their material bodies, they can subsist for even seven days, having taken warm water, clear gruel, etc.

But in the case of gods (*devānaṃ*), the heat element (*tejo*) is strong and the body (*karajaṃ*) delicate.

If they pass up the time even for a single meal (ekaṃ āhāravelaṃ), they cannot endure (*saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkonti*).

Just as a red lotus (*padumaṃ*) or blue lotus (*uppalaṃ*) placed on a heated rock (*tattapāsāṇe*) at midday in the hot season (*gimhānaṃ majjhanhike*) would not be able to resume its original condition in the evening even if one were to pour a hundred jars of water over it, but would only perish (*vinassatiyeva*),

in the same way, though they eat and drink immediately after, these gods pass away (*cavanti*) and cannot remain.

Therefore he said, "Through confusion of mindfulness, those gods pass away (*cavanti*) from that body (*kāyā*)."

What gods are these? The commentary (*aṭṭhakathā*) does not investigate "these are the gods (*ime devāti*)". But since it is said without making any distinction, "In the case of gods, the karma-born heat element (*kammajatejo*) is strong and the body (*karajaṃ*) delicate," we can understand that all gods living on material food who act thus, those very ones pass away (*cavanti*), so it should be understood.

Some, however, say, "Those gods are the Nirmāṇarati and Paranirmitavaśavartin gods – *nimmānarati-paranirmita-vaśavartino te devā*."

They are called "khiḍḍāpadosikā" simply by the fact of corruption through play (*khiḍḍāpadussanamatteneva*).

The rest should be understood here by the same method as above (*purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ*).

mula_pali: 47. ‘‘Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti? Santi, bhikkhave, manopadosikā nāma  devā, te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā . Te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti.
mula_english: 47. "Furthermore, venerable monks, relying on what, based on what, do some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the self and the world to be partly eternal, partly not eternal, or one aspect eternal, one aspect not eternal? There are, monks, gods called the Mind-Corrupters (manopadosikā), who spend an excessive amount of time regarding each other. As a result, their minds become corrupted by anger towards one another (aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsenti). On account of their corrupted minds (paduṭṭhacittā), they become weary in body (kilantakāyā) and mind (kilantacittā). And consequently, they pass away from that plane (te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti)."
commentary_pali: 47-48. Tatiyavāre manena padussanti vinassantīti manopadosikā, ete cātumahārājikā. Tesu kira eko devaputto – nakkhattaṃ kīḷissāmīti saparivāro rathena vīthiṃ paṭipajjati, athañño nikkhamanto taṃ purato gacchantaṃ disvā – ‘bho ayaṃ kapaṇo’, adiṭṭhapubbaṃ viya etaṃ disvā – ‘‘pītiyā uddhumāto viya bhijjamāno viya ca gacchatī’’ti kujjhati. Purato gacchantopi nivattitvā taṃ kuddhaṃ disvā – kuddhā nāma suviditā hontīti kuddhabhāvamassa ñatvā – ‘‘tvaṃ kuddho, mayhaṃ kiṃ karissasi, ayaṃ sampatti mayā dānasīlādīnaṃ vasena laddhā, na tuyhaṃ vasenā’’ti paṭikujjhati. Ekasmiñhi kuddhe itaro akuddho  rakkhati, ubhosu pana kuddhesu ekassa kodho itarassa paccayo hoti. Tassapi kodho itarassa paccayo hotīti ubho kandantānaṃyeva orodhānaṃ cavanti. Ayamettha dhammatā. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
47-48. On the third occasion, they are corrupted and destroyed by mind; therefore, they are called the "corrupted by mind" (*manopadosikā*) gods. These are the Cātumahārājika gods.

It is said that among them, one young god, thinking, "I will play at the festival!" sets out by chariot with his retinue on the road. Then another, going out, sees him going ahead and exclaims, "Hey, this miserable fellow! As if he has never seen a festival before!" Seeing this, he gets angry, thinking, "He goes along puffed up with joy, as if he's about to burst!"

The first, even while going ahead, turns back, sees that the other is angry, and realizing his angry state, because angry people are easily recognized, he retorts, "You are angry, but what will you do to me? This prosperity has been gained by me through giving, virtue, and so on (*dāna-sīlādi*), not through you!"

Now, when one is angry, the other, if not angry, protects [them]. But when both are angry, the anger of one becomes the condition (*paccayo*) for the anger of the other.

And if the anger of one becomes the condition for the anger of the other, both pass away with their harems weeping.

This is the natural law (*dharmatā*).

The remainder should be understood in the way already described.

mula_pali: 48. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati. Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati. Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya  sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte taṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ nānussarati. ‘‘So evamāha – ‘ye kho te bhonto devā na manopadosikā, te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyanti. Te nātivelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni nappadūsenti. Te aññamaññaṃ appaduṭṭhacittā akilantakāyā akilantacittā. Te devā tamhā kāyā na cavanti, niccā dhuvā sassatā avipariṇāmadhammā sassatisamaṃ tatheva  ṭhassanti. Ye pana mayaṃ ahumhā manopadosikā, te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyimhā. Te mayaṃ ativelaṃ aññamaññaṃ upanijjhāyantā aññamaññamhi cittāni padūsimhā, te mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ paduṭṭhacittā kilantakāyā kilantacittā. Evaṃ mayaṃ tamhā kāyā cutā aniccā addhuvā appāyukā cavanadhammā itthattaṃ āgatā’ti . Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
48. Now, bhikkhus, this comes to pass, that a certain being, after passing away from that plane, takes rebirth in this world.

Having come to this world, he goes forth from home to homelessness.

Having gone forth from home to homelessness, by means of effort (ātappa), exertion (padhāna), application (anuyoga), earnestness (appamāda) and right attention (sammāmanasikāra) he attains to such a degree of mental concentration (cetosamādhi) that with his mind (citte) thus concentrated he recollects his immediately preceding life (pubbenivāsa), but none previous to that.

‘He speaks thus: “Those honourable gods (devā) who are not corrupted by mind (manopadosikā) do not contemplate each other with excessive envy.

As a result, their minds (cittāni) do not become corrupted by anger towards one another,

their bodies (kāyā) and minds (cittā) do not become exhausted,

and they do not fall from that state. They are permanent (niccā), stable (dhuvā), eternal (sassatā), not subject to change (avipariṇāmadhammā), the same for ever and ever.

But we, who are corrupted in mind (manopadosikā)…

and as a result our minds (cittāni) became corrupted by anger towards one another. When our minds (cittā) were corrupted by anger, our bodies (kāyā) and minds (cittā) became exhausted.

have fallen from that state, we are impermanent (aniccā), unstable (addhuvā), short-lived (appāyukā), fated to fall away (cavanadhammā), and we have come to this world.”’

This, bhikkhus, is the third case, which some ascetics (samaṇa) and Brahmins (brāhmaṇā), partly Eternalists (ekaccasassatikā) and partly Non-Eternalists (ekaccaasassatikā), partly eternal (sassataṃ) and partly non-eternal (asassataṃ), proclaim the self (attānaṃ) and the world (loka).
commentary_pali: 47-48. Tatiyavāre manena padussanti vinassantīti manopadosikā, ete cātumahārājikā. Tesu kira eko devaputto – nakkhattaṃ kīḷissāmīti saparivāro rathena vīthiṃ paṭipajjati, athañño nikkhamanto taṃ purato gacchantaṃ disvā – ‘bho ayaṃ kapaṇo’, adiṭṭhapubbaṃ viya etaṃ disvā – ‘‘pītiyā uddhumāto viya bhijjamāno viya ca gacchatī’’ti kujjhati. Purato gacchantopi nivattitvā taṃ kuddhaṃ disvā – kuddhā nāma suviditā hontīti kuddhabhāvamassa ñatvā – ‘‘tvaṃ kuddho, mayhaṃ kiṃ karissasi, ayaṃ sampatti mayā dānasīlādīnaṃ vasena laddhā, na tuyhaṃ vasenā’’ti paṭikujjhati. Ekasmiñhi kuddhe itaro akuddho  rakkhati, ubhosu pana kuddhesu ekassa kodho itarassa paccayo hoti. Tassapi kodho itarassa paccayo hotīti ubho kandantānaṃyeva orodhānaṃ cavanti. Ayamettha dhammatā. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
47-48. They are called *manopadosikā* because in the third turn, they are corrupted and destroyed by mind; these are the Cātumahārājika gods.

It is said that among them, one young *devaputta*, thinking "I will play at the *nakkhatta* festival," sets out on the road in a chariot with his retinue. Then another, going out, sees him going ahead and, seeing this, exclaims, "Hey, this wretch! As if he has never seen one before!" and gets angry, "He goes along puffed up with rapture, as if about to burst!"

The first one, turning around and seeing that the other is angry—for angry people are easily recognized—recognizing his angry state of mind, retorts, "You are angry! What will you do to me? This prosperity has been obtained by me through giving, virtuous conduct, and so on (*dāna-śīlādi*), not through you!"

Indeed, when one is angry, the other, being unangered, protects. But when both are angry, the anger of one becomes a condition for the other.

Even his anger becomes a condition for the anger of the other, and both, along with their harems, pass away weeping.

This is the natural law (*dharmatā*).

The rest should be understood in the way already described.

mula_pali: 49. ‘‘Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī. So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ evamāha – ‘yaṃ kho idaṃ vuccati cakkhuṃ itipi sotaṃ itipi ghānaṃ itipi jivhā itipi kāyo itipi, ayaṃ attā anicco addhuvo asassato vipariṇāmadhammo. Yañca kho idaṃ vuccati cittanti vā manoti vā viññāṇanti vā ayaṃ attā nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo sassatisamaṃ tatheva ṭhassatī’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
49. “And in the fourth case, reverends, owing to what, with reference to what, do some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the self and the world to be partly eternalist ( *ekaccasassatikā*) and partly non-eternalist (*ekaccaasassatikā*), partly eternal (*sassataṃ*) and partly non-eternal (*asassataṃ*)? Here, mendicants, some ascetic or Brahmin is a logician, an investigator.

Hammering it out by reason (*takkapariyāhataṃ*), following his own line of thought (*vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ*), he argues from his own intuition (*sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ*): “Whatever is called eye (*cakkhuṃ*) or ear (*sotaṃ*) or nose (*ghānaṃ*) or tongue (*jivhā*) or body (*kāyo*), that self (*attā*) is impermanent (*anicco*), unstable (*addhuvo*), non-eternal (*asassato*), and subject to change (*vipariṇāmadhammo*).

But that which is called thought (*cittaṃ*) or mind (*mano*) or consciousness (*viññāṇaṃ*)—that self (*attā*) is permanent (*nicco*), stable (*dhuvo*), eternal (*sassato*), not subject to change (*avipariṇāmadhammo*), and it will remain the same just like eternity itself!”

This, mendicants, is the fourth basis, owing to which, with reference to which, some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the self and the world to be partly eternalist (*ekaccasassatikā*) and partly non-eternalist (*ekaccaasassatikā*), partly eternal (*sassataṃ*) and partly non-eternal (*asassataṃ*).
commentary_pali: 49-52. Takkīvāde ayaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ bhedaṃ passati, cittaṃ pana yasmā purimaṃ purimaṃ pacchimassa pacchimassa paccayaṃ datvāva nirujjhati, tasmā cakkhādīnaṃ bhedato balavatarampi cittassa bhedaṃ na passati. So taṃ apassanto yathā nāma sakuṇo ekaṃ rukkhaṃ jahitvā aññasmiṃ nilīyati, evameva imasmiṃ attabhāve bhinne cittaṃ aññatra gacchatīti gahetvā evamāha. Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
49-52. The rationalist (takkīvāde) sees the dissolution (bhedaṃ) of the eye (cakkhu), and so on; but because each preceding (purimaṃ purimaṃ) thought (cittaṃ), in ceasing, gives (datvā) rise to (paccayaṃ) its successor (pacchimassa pacchimassa), he does not see the dissolution (bhedaṃ) of thought (cittassa), even though the latter is more powerful (balavataraṃ) than the dissolution (bhedato) of the eye (cakkhādīnaṃ), and so on.

Since he does not see (apassanto) that dissolution (taṃ), he assumes that when this (imasmiṃ) body (attabhāve) breaks up (bhinne), the consciousness (cittaṃ) goes elsewhere (aññatra), just as (yathā nāma) a bird (sakuṇo) leaves (jahitvā) one (ekaṃ) tree (rukkhaṃ) and settles (nilīyati) on another (aññasmiṃ). Thus (evameva) he takes it (gahetvā) and declares (āha) this to be his view (evam).

The remainder (sesam) here (ettha) should be understood (veditabbaṃ) in the way already described (vuttanayena eva).

mula_pali: 50. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti catūhi  vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ekaccasassatikā ekaccaasassatikā ekaccaṃ sassataṃ ekaccaṃ asassataṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
mula_english:
50. "It is on these four grounds, monks, that those ascetics and Brahmins who are partial-eternalists and partial-non-eternalists proclaim the self (ātman) and the world to be partly eternal (śāśvata) and partly non-eternal (aśāśvata).

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins there may be who are partial-eternalists and partial-non-eternalists, and proclaim the self (ātman) and the world to be partly eternal (śāśvata) and partly non-eternal (aśāśvata), all of them do so on these very four grounds, or on one or another of these; there is nothing outside of this.
commentary_pali: 49-52. Takkīvāde ayaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ bhedaṃ passati, cittaṃ pana yasmā purimaṃ purimaṃ pacchimassa pacchimassa paccayaṃ datvāva nirujjhati, tasmā cakkhādīnaṃ bhedato balavatarampi cittassa bhedaṃ na passati. So taṃ apassanto yathā nāma sakuṇo ekaṃ rukkhaṃ jahitvā aññasmiṃ nilīyati, evameva imasmiṃ attabhāve bhinne cittaṃ aññatra gacchatīti gahetvā evamāha. Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
49-52. The rationalist (*takkīvāda*) sees the disintegration of the eye (*cakkhu*) and the other sense faculties; but because each preceding moment of consciousness (*citta*), in ceasing, conditions the arising of its successor, he does not perceive the disintegration of consciousness, even though that is more pronounced than the disintegration of the eye and the other sense faculties.

Since he does not see the disintegration of consciousness, he assumes that when the body (*attabhāva*) breaks up the consciousness goes elsewhere, in the same way a bird leaves one tree (*rukkha*) and settles on another. This he declares as his view.

The remainder should be understood in the manner already stated (*vuttanaya*).

mula_pali: 51. ‘‘Tayidaṃ , bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti – ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā  evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti. Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā. Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
mula_english:
51. "This, monks, the *Tathāgata* (Thus Gone One) understands: 'These viewpoints, thus grasped and thus misapprehended, lead to such a future destination, to such a state in the world beyond.'

The *Tathāgata* (Thus Gone One) understands this, and even more than this; yet he does not cling to that understanding. And because he is free from clinging, he has realized within himself *nirvāṇa* (extinction).

Having understood as they really are the arising and passing away of feelings (*vedanā*), their satisfaction, their unsatisfactoriness, and the escape from them, the *Tathāgata* (Thus Gone One), monks, is emancipated through non-clinging."
commentary_pali: 49-52. Takkīvāde ayaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ bhedaṃ passati, cittaṃ pana yasmā purimaṃ purimaṃ pacchimassa pacchimassa paccayaṃ datvāva nirujjhati, tasmā cakkhādīnaṃ bhedato balavatarampi cittassa bhedaṃ na passati. So taṃ apassanto yathā nāma sakuṇo ekaṃ rukkhaṃ jahitvā aññasmiṃ nilīyati, evameva imasmiṃ attabhāve bhinne cittaṃ aññatra gacchatīti gahetvā evamāha. Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
49-52. The rationalist sees the disintegration of the eye (cakkhu) and the other sense faculties. But because each preceding consciousness, upon ceasing, conditions the subsequent one, he does not see the disintegration of consciousness (citta), even though it is more powerful than the disintegration of the eye and the other sense faculties.

Since he does not see that disintegration, he assumes that when the body (attabhāva) breaks up, the consciousness (citta) goes elsewhere, just as a bird leaves one tree (rukkha) and settles on another. Having grasped this, he declares his view thus.

The remainder should be understood in the way already described.

mula_pali: 52. ‘‘Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ  abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english: 52. "These, monks, are those *dharmas* that are profound (*gambhīrā*), difficult to see (*duddasā*), difficult to understand (*duranubodhā*), peaceful (*santā*), excellent (*paṇītā*), beyond the sphere of reasoning (*atakkāvacarā*), subtle (*nipuṇā*), comprehensible only to the wise (*paṇḍitavedanīyā*), which the *Tathāgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*), propounds; and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak."
commentary_pali: 49-52. Takkīvāde ayaṃ cakkhādīnaṃ bhedaṃ passati, cittaṃ pana yasmā purimaṃ purimaṃ pacchimassa pacchimassa paccayaṃ datvāva nirujjhati, tasmā cakkhādīnaṃ bhedato balavatarampi cittassa bhedaṃ na passati. So taṃ apassanto yathā nāma sakuṇo ekaṃ rukkhaṃ jahitvā aññasmiṃ nilīyati, evameva imasmiṃ attabhāve bhinne cittaṃ aññatra gacchatīti gahetvā evamāha. Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
49-52. The rationalist ( *takkīvāde*) sees the breakup of the eye (**cakkhādīnaṃ**) etc.; but because every preceding act of consciousness (*cittaṃ*), in ceasing, conditions the arising of its successor, he does not see the breakup of consciousness, even though the latter is more prominent than the breakup of the eye, etc.

Since he does not see the breakup of consciousness, he assumes that when the bodily frame (*attabhāve*) breaks up, the consciousness goes elsewhere, in the same way a bird leaves one tree (*rukkhaṃ*) and settles on another. This he declares as his view.

The rest should be understood in the way already described (*vuttanayeneva*).

mula_pali: 53. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
53. "Monks, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who are Finitists and Infinitists (antānantikā), and who propound the finitude and infinitude (antānantaṃ) of the world (lokassa) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi).
And what is it, venerable ascetics and Brahmins, by resorting to what, by undertaking what, that they are Finitists and Infinitists (antānantikā), and propound the finitude and infinitude (antānantaṃ) of the world (lokassa) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi)?
commentary_pali: 53.Antānantikāti  antānantavādā, antaṃ vā anantaṃ vā antānantaṃ vā nevantānānantaṃ vā ārabbha pavattavādāti attho.
commentary_english: 53. "Endless-enders" (antānantikā) are those who assert doctrines of the end and the endless (antānantavādā), that is, doctrines arising in reference to the end (antaṃ), or the endless (anantaṃ), or the end and the endless (antānantaṃ), or neither the end nor the endless (nevantānānantaṃ); this is the meaning (attho).

mula_pali: 54. ‘‘Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite  citte antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati. ‘‘So evamāha – ‘antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi. Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi – yathā antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
mula_english:
54. "Here, *bhikkhus*, a certain *śramaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa*, through zeal (*ātappa*), exertion (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attains such a concentration of mind (*cetosamādhi*) that, with his mind thus concentrated, he dwells perceiving the world as finite (*antasaññī*).

He speaks thus: 'The world is finite (*antavā*) and bounded (*parivaṭumo*).'

What is the reason for that? Because I, through zeal (*ātappa*), exertion (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right reflection (*sammāmanasikāra*), attain such a concentration of mind (*cetosamādhi*) that, with his mind thus concentrated, I dwell perceiving the world as finite (*antasaññī*).

Therefore I know that this world is finite (*antavā*) and bounded (*parivaṭumo*).'

This, *bhikkhus*, is the first ground (*ṭhāna*) based upon which some ascetics and Brahmins proclaim the world to be finite and infinite (*antānantikā*), or finite-infinite (*antānanta*).
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite (*antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati*): Without having extended the counterpart sign (*paṭibhāga-nimitta*) to the boundaries of the world-sphere (*cakkavāḷa-pariyantaṃ*), apprehending it as the world, he abides perceiving the world as finite. But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image to the boundaries of the world-sphere perceives the world to be infinite (*anantasaññī hoti*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite in the upward and downward directions, and infinite across.

The rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādo*) should be understood by the method stated.

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves.

mula_pali: 55. ‘‘Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ  phusati, yathāsamāhite citte anantasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati. ‘‘So  evamāha – ‘ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto. Ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo’’ti, tesaṃ musā. Ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi , yathāsamāhite citte anantasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi. Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi – yathā ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ  ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
mula_english:
55.

“And furthermore, venerable ascetics and Brahmins, what is the reason, what is the basis, for some to propound that the world is finite and infinite? Here, mendicants, some ascetic or brahmin, by striving, endeavoring, practicing, being diligent, and rightly focusing their mind, attains such a concentration of heart (**ceto-samādhi**) that, with their heart settled, they abide perceiving the world as infinite (anantasaññī).

“They say thus: ‘The world (loko) is infinite (ananto) and boundless (apariyanto).’

Those ascetics and Brahmins who declared, "The world (loko) is finite (antavā) and bounded (parivaṭumo)," speak falsely.

The world is infinite and boundless.

What is the reason for that? Because I, by striving, endeavoring, practicing, being diligent, and rightly focusing my mind, attain such a concentration of heart that, with my heart settled, I abide perceiving the world as infinite.

Therefore, I know this: the world is infinite and boundless."

This, mendicants, is the second case; that is the reason, that is the basis, for some ascetics and Brahmins to propound that the world is finite and infinite.
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite (*antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati*): Without extending the counterpart sign (*paṭibhāganimitta*) to the boundaries of the world-sphere (*cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ*), apprehending it as the world, he abides perceiving the world as finite. But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image to the boundaries of the world-sphere, having extended the *kasiṇa* (*vaḍḍhitakasiṇo*), perceives the world to be infinite (*anantasaññī*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite in the upward and downward directions, and infinite across.

The rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādo*) should be understood by the method already stated (*vuttanayeneva veditabbo*).

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past (*pūrvāntakalpikā*) because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves (*attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā*).

mula_pali: 56. ‘‘Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte uddhamadho antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. ‘‘So evamāha – ‘antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto ca. Ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo’’ti, tesaṃ musā. Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto’’ti, tesampi musā. Antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto ca. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusāmi, yathāsamāhite citte uddhamadho antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharāmi, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Imināmahaṃ etaṃ jānāmi – yathā antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto cā’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
mula_english:
56.

Furthermore, venerable ascetics and Brahmins, based on what, relying on what, do [some] propound the world as both finite and infinite? Here, monks, some ascetic or Brahmin, through ardour, through exertion, through application, through non-negligence, through proper attention, attains such concentration of mind (ceto-samādhi) that, with his mind thus concentrated, he dwells perceiving the world as finite (anta-saññī) upwards and downwards, and as infinite (ananta-saññī) across.

He speaks thus: ‘The world is both finite (antavā) and infinite (ananto).’

Those ascetics and Brahmins who declare, “The world is finite (antavā) and bounded (parivaṭumo),” speak falsely.

And those ascetics and Brahmins who declare, “The world is infinite (ananto) and unbounded (apariyanto),” also speak falsely.

The world is both finite (antavā) and infinite (ananto).

What is the reason for that? Because I, through ardour, through exertion, through application, through non-negligence, through proper attention, attain such concentration of mind (ceto-samādhi) that, with my mind thus concentrated, I dwell perceiving the world as finite (anta-saññī) upwards and downwards, and as infinite (ananta-saññī) across.

Therefore I know that the world is both finite (antavā) and infinite (ananto).’

This, monks, is the third case, based on which, relying on which, some ascetics and Brahmins propound the world as both finite and infinite.
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite (*antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati*): Without having extended the counterpart sign (*paṭibhāganimitta*) to the boundaries of the world-sphere (*cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ*), apprehending it as the "world" (*loko*), he abides perceiving the world as finite. But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image to the boundaries of the world-sphere perceives the world to be infinite (*anantasaññī*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite in the upward and downward directions, and infinite across.

The rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādo*) should be understood by the method stated (*vuttanayeneva veditabbo*).

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves.

mula_pali: 57. ‘‘Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco  samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī. So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ evamāha – ‘nevāyaṃ loko antavā, na panānanto. Ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘antavā ayaṃ loko parivaṭumo’’ti, tesaṃ musā. Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā  evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘ananto ayaṃ loko apariyanto’’ti, tesampi musā. Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘antavā ca ayaṃ loko ananto cā’’ti, tesampi musā. Nevāyaṃ loko antavā , na panānanto’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave , catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti.
mula_english:
57. “And in the fourth case, owing to what, with reference to what, are some honorable *śramaṇas* (samaṇa) and *brāhmaṇas* (brāhmaṇa) extensionists, proclaiming the world (*loka*) to be finite (*antavat*) or infinite (*ananta*)? Here, *bhikkhus*, some *śramaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa* is a reasoner, an investigator.

He declares his view—hammered out by reason, deduced from his investigations, following his own flight of thought—thus: ‘This world is neither finite nor infinite.’

Those *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* who declare the world to be finite and bounded speak falsely;

and those *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* who declare the world to be infinite and boundless also speak falsely.

and those *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* who declare it to be both finite and infinite—all these speak falsely.

This world is neither finite nor infinite.”

This, *bhikkhus*, is the fourth case, owing to which, with reference to which, some *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* are extensionists, proclaiming the world to be finite or infinite.
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite ( *antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati*), means not extending the counterpart sign (*paṭibhāganimittaṃ*) to the boundary of the world-sphere (*cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ*), apprehending it as the world. He abides perceiving the world as finite. But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image (*vaḍḍhitakasiṇo*) to the boundary of the world-sphere perceives the world to be infinite (*anantasaññī*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite in the upward and downward directions, and infinite across.

The rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādo*) should be understood by the method already stated (*vuttanayeneva veditabbo*).

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past (*pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā*) because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves.

mula_pali: 58. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā antānantikā antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti, sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena; natthi ito bahiddhā.
mula_english:
58. "It is on these four grounds, *bhikkhus*, that those ascetics and Brahmins who are Finitists and Infinitists ( *antānantikā*), proclaim the world to be finite or infinite (*antānantaṃ lokassa paññapenti catūhi vatthūhi*).

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins there may be who proclaim the world to be finite or infinite, all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none.
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite, [is when] without having extended the counterpart sign (paṭibhāga-nimitta) to the boundaries of the world-sphere (cakkavāḷa-pariyanta), apprehending it as the world (loka), he abides perceiving the world as finite (anta-saññī). But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image to the boundaries of the world-sphere (cakkavāḷa-pariyanta) perceives the world to be infinite (*ananta-saññī*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite (*anta-saññī*) in the upward and downward directions, and infinite (*ananta-saññī*) across.

The rationalist doctrine (takkī-vāda) should be understood by the method stated.

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past (pubbantakappikesu), because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves.

mula_pali: 59. ‘‘Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti – ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti. Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā. Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
mula_english:
59. "This, monks, the *Tathāgata* (thus-gone one) understands: 'These viewpoints, thus grasped and thus adhered to, lead to such and such destinations in another life.' (*ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti*)
The *Tathāgata* (thus-gone one) understands this, and even more than this; however, he does not cling to that understanding. Because of this non-clinging, he has realized *nirvāṇa* (extinguishment) within himself.
Having truly understood the arising (*samudaya*) and passing away (*atthaṅgama*), the attraction (*assāda*) and peril (*ādīnava*), and the deliverance (*nissaraṇa*) from feelings (*vedanānaṃ*) as they really are, the *Tathāgata* (thus-gone one), monks, is liberated through non-clinging (*anupādāvimutto*).
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite, means without having extended the counterpart sign (paṭibhāganimittaṃ) to the boundary of the world-sphere (cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ), apprehending it as the world, he abides perceiving the world as finite. But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image, that has been increased, to the boundary of the world-sphere perceives the world to be infinite (*anantasaññī*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite in the upward and downward directions, and infinite across.

The rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādo*) should be understood by the method already stated.

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves.

mula_pali: 60. ‘‘Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā gambhīrā duddasā  duranubodhā santā paṇītā atakkāvacarā nipuṇā paṇḍitavedanīyā, ye tathāgato sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti, yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english: 60. "These, monks, are the *dharmas* that are profound (*gambhīrā*), difficult to see (*duddasā*), difficult to understand (*duranubodhā*), peaceful (*santā*), excellent (*paṇītā*), beyond the sphere of reasoning (*atakkāvacarā*), subtle (*nipuṇā*), and comprehensible only to the wise (*paṇḍitavedanīyā*), which the *Tathāgata*, having realized for himself with direct knowledge (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*), proclaims (*pavedeti*); and it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality (*yathābhuccaṃ*) would speak.
commentary_pali: 54-60.Antasaññīlokasmiṃ viharatīti paṭibhāganimittaṃ cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ avaḍḍhetvā taṃ – ‘‘loko’’ti gahetvā antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati, cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ katvā vaḍḍhitakasiṇo pana anantasaññī hoti, uddhamadho avaḍḍhetvā pana tiriyaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uddhamadho antasaññī, tiriyaṃ anantasaññī. Takkīvādo vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ime cattāropi attanā diṭṭhapubbānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
54-60. Abiding perceiving the world as finite (*antasaññī lokasmiṃ viharati*): Without having extended the counterpart sign (*paṭibhāganimitta*) to the boundaries of the world-sphere (*cakkavāḷapariyantaṃ*), apprehending it as the world, he abides perceiving the world as finite. But he who has extended the *kasiṇa*-image to the boundaries of the world-sphere perceives the world to be infinite (*anantasaññī*). Not extending the sign in the upward and downward directions, but extending it across, he perceives the world as finite in the upward and downward directions, and infinite across.

The rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādo*) should be understood by the method stated.

These four theorists are included among the speculators about the past because they apprehend their view as a consequence of what was previously seen by themselves.

mula_pali: 61. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
61. "There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are endless equivocators (amarāvikkhepikā). When asked about this or that matter, they resort to evasive statements (vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti) and to endless equivocation (amarāvikkhepaṃ) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi).
And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honourable ascetics and Brahmins, who are endless equivocators (amarāvikkhepikā), when asked about this or that matter, resort to evasive statements (vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti) and to endless equivocation (amarāvikkhepaṃ) on four grounds (catūhi vatthūhi)?
commentary_pali: 61. Na maratīti amarā. Kā sā? Evantipi me notiādinā nayena pariyantarahitā diṭṭhigatikassa diṭṭhi ceva vācā ca. Vividho khepoti vikkhepo, amarāya diṭṭhiyā vācāya ca vikkhepoti amarāvikkhepo, so etesaṃ atthīti amarāvikkhepikā, aparo nayo – amarā nāma ekā macchajāti, sā ummujjananimujjanādivasena udake sandhāvamānā gahetuṃ na sakkāti, evameva ayampi vādo itocito ca sandhāvati, gāhaṃ na upagacchatīti amarāvikkhepoti vuccati. So etesaṃ atthīti amarāvikkhepikā.
commentary_english:
61. *Na maratīti amarā.* "It does not die, thus it is *amarā* (undying/immortal)."

What is that? It is the view and speech of one whose views are endless (*pariyantarahitā*) in the manner of "yes" and "no," etc.

"Tossing back and forth in diverse ways" is *vikkhepo* (equivocation). "*Amarāya diṭṭhiyā vācāya ca vikkhepo* (equivocation through endless views and speech)" is *amarāvikkhepo* (endless equivocation). *So etesaṃ atthīti amarāvikkhepikā* (it belongs to them, thus they are endless equivocators). Another method: *amarā* is the name of a kind of fish. Because they roam about in the water diving in and out, it is impossible to catch hold of them. Analogously, this doctrine roams about here and there and is impossible to catch hold of, therefore it is called *amarāvikkhepo* (eel-wriggling).

*So etesaṃ atthīti amarāvikkhepikā* (therefore it is called "eel-wriggling").

mula_pali: 62. ‘‘Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti. Tassa evaṃ hoti – ‘ahaṃ kho ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’’nti  yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi. Ahañce kho pana ‘‘idaṃ  kusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, ‘idaṃ kusala’nti vā byākareyyaṃ, ‘idaṃ akusala’nti vā byākareyyaṃ, taṃ mamassa musā. Yaṃ mamassa musā , so mamassa vighāto. Yo mamassa vighāto so mamassa antarāyo’ti. Iti so musāvādabhayā musāvādaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ – ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me  no; no notipi me no’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
mula_english:
62.

“Here, *bhikkhus*, a certain *samaṇa* or *brāhmaṇa* does not truly understand what is *kusala* (wholesome) and what is *akusala* (unwholesome).

He thinks: ‘I do not truly know what is *kusala* (wholesome) and what is *akusala* (unwholesome).'

If, without truly understanding what is *kusala* (wholesome) and what is *akusala* (unwholesome), I were to declare something as "*kusala* (wholesome)" or "*akusala* (unwholesome)," that would be a lie for me.

If it were a lie for me, that would be distressing for me.

If that were distressing for me, that would be an obstacle for me."

Thus, out of fear of lying and loathing of lying, he does not declare anything to be *kusala* (wholesome) or *akusala* (unwholesome). But when questioned about this or that matter, he resorts to evasive statements and endless equivocation: "I don’t say this, I don’t say that. I don’t say it is otherwise. I don’t say it is not. I don’t not say it is not."

This, *bhikkhus*, is the first basis, resorting to which and on account of which, some *samaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* are eel-wrigglers, and when questioned about this or that matter, they resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation.
commentary_pali: 62.‘‘Idaṃkusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātīti dasa kusalakammapathe yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātīti attho. Akusalepi dasa akusalakammapathāva adhippetā. So mamassa vighātoti ‘‘musā mayā bhaṇita’’nti vippaṭisāruppattiyā mama vighāto assa, dukkhaṃ bhaveyyāti attho. So mamassa antarāyoti so mama saggassa ceva maggassa ca antarāyo assa. Musāvādabhayā musāvādaparijegucchāti musāvāde ottappena ceva hiriyā ca. Vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjatīti vācāya vikkhepaṃ āpajjati. Kīdisaṃ? Amarāvikkhepaṃ, apariyantavikkhepanti attho. Evantipi me notiādīsu evantipi me noti aniyamitavikkhepo . Tathātipi me noti ‘‘sassato attā ca loko cā’’ti vuttaṃ sassatavādaṃ paṭikkhipati. Aññathātipi me noti sassatato aññathā vuttaṃ ekaccasassataṃ paṭikkhipati. Notipi me noti – ‘‘na  hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’’ti vuttaṃ ucchedaṃ paṭikkhipati. No notipi me noti ‘‘neva hoti na na hotī’’ti vuttaṃ takkīvādaṃ paṭikkhipati. Sayaṃ pana ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti vā ‘‘akusala’’nti vā puṭṭho na kiñci byākaroti. ‘‘Idaṃ kusala’’nti puṭṭho ‘‘evantipi me no’’ti vadati. Tato ‘‘kiṃ akusala’’nti vutte ‘‘tathātipi me no’’ti vadati. ‘‘Kiṃ ubhayato aññathā’’ti vutte ‘‘aññathātipi me no’’ti vadati. Tato ‘‘tividhenāpi na hoti, kiṃ te laddhī’’ti vutte ‘‘notipi me no’’ti vadati. Tato ‘‘kiṃ no noti te laddhī’’ti vutte ‘‘no notipi me no’’ti evaṃ vikkhepameva āpajjati, ekasmimpi pakkhe na tiṭṭhati.
commentary_english:
62. He does not understand as they really are, thus: “This is wholesome ( *idaṃ kusala*)” which refers to not understanding as they really are the ten courses of wholesome action ( *dasa kusalakammapatha*), this is the meaning.
And unwholesome (*akusala*) actions also, the ten courses of unwholesome action (*akusalakammapatha*) are intended.
“That would distress me”: it might distress me by producing remorse (*vippaṭisāru*) over having spoken falsely ( *musā*). The meaning is that it would be painful ( *dukkhaṃ*).
“That distress would be an obstacle for me”: i. e., an obstacle to attaining heaven (*sagga*) or the path ( *magga*).
“Out of fear and loathing of making a false statement (*musāvāda*)”: due to moral dread (*ottappa*) and shame (*hirī*).
He resorts to equivocation ( *vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati*), that is, he equivocates in his speech.
What kind of equivocation? Endless (*apariyanta*) equivocation, that is the meaning.
“I do not take it thus (evantipi me no)” : this is indeterminate equivocation (*aniyamitavikkhepo*).
“I do not take it in that way (tathātipi me no)” : he rejects the eternalist doctrine (*sassatavāda*) that the self ( *attā*) and the world (*loka*) are eternal ( *sassato*).
“Nor do I take it in some other way (aññathātipi me no)” : i. e., in some way other than eternalism; by this he rejects partial-eternalism (*ekaccasassataṃ*).
“I do not say that it is not (notipi me no)” : he rejects the annihilationist doctrine (*ucchedaṃ*) that “the *Tathāgata* does not exist after death ( *na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*)”.
“Nor do I say that it is neither this nor that (no notipi me no)” : he rejects the rationalist doctrine (*takkīvādaṃ*) that “the *Tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist ( *neva hoti na na hotī*) after death.”
When asked, he does not himself declare anything as wholesome (*kusala*) or unwholesome (*akusala*) ( sayaṃ pana ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti vā ‘‘akusala’’nti vā puṭṭho na kiñci byākaroti).
When asked: “Is this wholesome (*idaṃ kusala*)”, he says: “I do not take it thus (*evantipi me no*)”.
Asked: “What, is it then unwholesome (*akusala*)?”, he says: “I do not take it that way (*tathātipi me no*)”.
Asked: “Is it then something other than these two (*kiṃ ubhayato aññathā*)?”, he says: “Nor do I take it in some other way (*aññathātipi me no*)”.
Asked: “If it is neither of these three, what is your opinion ( *kiṃ te laddhī*)?”, he says: “I do not say that it is not (*notipi me no*)”.
Asked: “In your opinion is it neither this nor that ( *kiṃ no noti te laddhī*)?”, he says: “Nor do I say that it is neither this nor that ( *no notipi me no*).” Thus he resorts to equivocation ( *vikkhepameva āpajjati*) and does not take a stand on any single side ( *ekasmimpi pakkhe na tiṭṭhati*).

mula_pali: 63. ‘‘Dutiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti. Tassa evaṃ hoti – ‘ahaṃ kho ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi. Ahañce kho pana ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto, ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti vā byākareyyaṃ, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’nti vā byākareyyaṃ, tattha me assa chando vā rāgo vā doso vā paṭigho vā. Yattha yo (?) me assa chando vā rāgo vā doso vā paṭigho vā, taṃ mamassa upādānaṃ. Yaṃ mamassa upādānaṃ, so mamassa vighāto. Yo mamassa vighāto, so mamassa antarāyo’ti. Iti  so upādānabhayā upādānaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ – ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi  me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā  tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
mula_english:
63. Furthermore, what is the basis and reason for some ascetics and Brahmins, when questioned on various points, to resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation? Here, monks, some ascetic or Brahmin does not truly understand what is wholesome (*kusala*) or what is unwholesome (*akusala*).

They think: "I do not truly know what is good (*kusala*), nor do I truly know what is bad (*akusala*)."

If, without truly understanding what is wholesome (*kusala*) or unwholesome (*akusala*), I were to declare something to be wholesome (*kusala*) or unwholesome (*akusala*), desire (*chanda*), lust (*rāga*), hatred (*dosa*), or aversion (*paṭigha*) might arise in me.

If desire (*chanda*), lust (*rāga*), hatred (*dosa*), or aversion (*paṭigha*) were to arise in me, that would be my clinging (*upādāna*).

If there were clinging (*upādāna*) on my part, that would distress (*vighāta*) me.

If I were distressed (*vighāta*), that would be an obstacle (*antarāya*) for me."

Therefore, out of fear of clinging (*upādāna*), and loathing of clinging (*upādāna*), they do not declare anything to be wholesome (*kusala*) or unwholesome (*akusala*). When questioned about this or that point, they resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation: "I don’t say it is this; I don’t say it is that; I don’t say it is otherwise; I don’t say it is not; I don’t not say it is not."

Monks, this is the second reason why some ascetics and Brahmins, when questioned on various points, resort to evasive statements and endless equivocation.
commentary_pali: 63.Chando vā rāgo vāti ajānantopi sahasā kusalameva ‘‘kusala’’nti vatvā akusalameva ‘‘akusala’’nti vatvā mayā asukassa nāma evaṃ byākataṃ, kiṃ taṃ subyākatanti aññe paṇḍite pucchitvā tehi – ‘‘subyākataṃ, bhadramukha, kusalameva tayā kusalaṃ, akusalameva akusalanti byākata’’nti vutte natthi mayā sadiso paṇḍitoti evaṃ me tattha chando vā rāgo vā assāti attho. Ettha ca chando dubbalarāgo, rāgo balavarāgo. Doso vā paṭigho vāti kusalaṃ pana ‘‘akusala’’nti, akusalaṃ vā ‘‘kusala’’nti vatvā aññe paṇḍite pucchitvā tehi – ‘‘dubyākataṃ tayā’’ti vutte ettakampi nāma na jānāmīti tattha me assa doso vā paṭigho vāti attho. Idhāpi doso dubbalakodho, paṭigho balavakodho. Taṃmamassa upādānaṃ, so mamassa vighātoti taṃ chandarāgadvayaṃ mama upādānaṃ assa, dosapaṭighadvayaṃ vighāto. Ubhayampi vā daḷhaggahaṇavasena upādānaṃ , vihananavasena vighāto. Rāgo hi amuñcitukāmatāya ārammaṇaṃ gaṇhāti jalūkā viya. Doso vināsetukāmatāya āsīviso viya. Ubhopi cete santāpakaṭṭhena vihananti yevāti ‘‘upādāna’’nti ca ‘‘vighāto’’ti ca vuttā. Sesaṃ paṭhamavārasadisameva.
commentary_english:
63. "Desire and lust might arise in me": Even without understanding, one might hastily declare the wholesome to be "wholesome" and the unwholesome to be "unwholesome." Then afterward, they ask other wise individuals: "I explained thus to so and so. Was my explanation right?" If they should say: "You explained rightly, good sir, you declared the wholesome to be wholesome and the unwholesome to be unwholesome," they might think: "There is no wise person equal to me"—thus "desire and lust might arise in me." This is the meaning.

Here, *chanda* is weak attachment, *rāga* is strong attachment.

"Or hatred and aversion might arise in me": If one declares the wholesome to be unwholesome and the unwholesome to be wholesome, and asks wise people about their reply, they will say: "You explained wrongly." Then they will think: "I do not even know this much"—thus "hatred and aversion might arise in me."

Here also, *dosa* is weak anger, *paṭigha* is strong anger.

"That would be clinging on my part. Such clinging would distress me..." The pair, desire (*chanda*) and lust (*rāga*), would be clinging (*upādāna*) on my part; the pair, hatred (*dosa*) and aversion (*paṭigha*), would cause distress (*vighāta*).

Or both pairs are clinging (*upādāna*) because they are forms of holding firmly, and both cause distress (*vighāta*) because they cause harm.

For lust (*rāga*) takes hold of the object like a leech, not desiring to let go of it.

And hatred (*dosa*) takes hold of it like a poisonous snake (*āsīvisa*), desiring to destroy it.

And both pairs cause distress, in the sense that they are afflicting. Thus they are called both "clinging" (*upādāna*) and "distress" (*vighāta*).

The rest is the same as the first time.

mula_pali: 64. ‘‘Tatiye ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā ‘idaṃ kusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ‘idaṃ akusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti. Tassa evaṃ hoti – ‘ahaṃ kho ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmi. Ahañce kho pana ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto ‘‘idaṃ akusala’’nti yathābhūtaṃ appajānanto ‘‘idaṃ kusala’’nti vā byākareyyaṃ, ‘‘idaṃ akusala’’nti vā byākareyyaṃ. Santi hi kho samaṇabrāhmaṇā paṇḍitā nipuṇā  kataparappavādā vālavedhirūpā, te bhindantā vobhindantā (sī. pī.) maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni, te maṃ tattha samanuyuñjeyyuṃ samanugāheyyuṃ samanubhāseyyuṃ. Ye maṃ tattha samanuyuñjeyyuṃ samanugāheyyuṃ samanubhāseyyuṃ, tesāhaṃ na sampāyeyyaṃ. Yesāhaṃ na sampāyeyyaṃ, so mamassa vighāto. Yo mamassa vighāto, so mamassa  antarāyo’ti. Iti so anuyogabhayā anuyogaparijegucchā nevidaṃ kusalanti byākaroti, na panidaṃ akusalanti byākaroti, tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ – ‘evantipi me no; tathātipi me no; aññathātipi me no; notipi me no; no notipi me no’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha  eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
mula_english:
64. Furthermore, venerable monks, what is the basis for those ascetics and Brahmins who are eel-wrigglers, who, when questioned on this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation? Here, monks, some ascetic or Brahmin does not truly understand what is *kusala* (wholesome) and what is *akusala* (unwholesome).

He thinks: "I do not truly know what is *kusala* (wholesome) and what is *akusala* (unwholesome)."

"If, without truly knowing what is *kusala* (wholesome) and what is *akusala* (unwholesome), I were to declare: “This is *kusala* (wholesome),” or “This is *akusala* (unwholesome),”

Now, there are ascetics and Brahmins who are wise, clever, experienced in controversy, like archers who can split hairs, who go around destroying others’ views with their wisdom, and they might cross-examine me, demanding my reasons and arguing.

If they should cross-examine me, demanding my reasons and arguing, I might not be able to reply.

If I could not reply, that would distress me.

And if I were distressed, that would be an obstacle for me."

Therefore, out of fear and loathing of being cross-examined, he does not declare anything to be *kusala* (wholesome) or *akusala* (unwholesome). But, when questioned about this or that point, he resorts to evasive statements and to endless equivocation: "I do not take it thus, nor do I take it in that way, nor do I take it in some other way. I do not say that it is not, nor do I say that it is neither this nor that."

This, monks, is the third basis for those ascetics and Brahmins who are eel-wrigglers, who, when questioned on this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation.
commentary_pali: 64.Paṇḍitāti  paṇḍiccena samannāgatā. Nipuṇāti saṇhasukhumabuddhino sukhumaatthantaraṃ paṭivijjhanasamatthā. Kataparappavādāti viññātaparappavādā ceva parehi saddhiṃ katavādaparicayā ca. Vālavedhirūpāti vālavedhidhanuggahasadisā. Te bhindantā maññeti vālavedhi viya vālaṃ sukhumānipi paresaṃ diṭṭhigatāni attano paññāgatena bhindantā viya carantīti attho. Te maṃ tatthāti te samaṇabrāhmaṇā maṃ tesu kusalākusalesu. Samanuyuñjeyyunti ‘‘kiṃ kusalaṃ, kiṃ akusalanti attano laddhiṃ vadā’’ti laddhiṃ puccheyyuṃ. Samanugāheyyunti ‘‘idaṃ nāmā’’ti vutte ‘‘kena kāraṇena etamatthaṃ gāheyyu’’nti kāraṇaṃ puccheyyuṃ. Samanubhāseyyunti ‘‘iminā nāma kāraṇenā’’ti vutte kāraṇe dosaṃ dassetvā ‘‘na tvaṃ idaṃ jānāsi, idaṃ pana gaṇha, idaṃ vissajjehī’’ti evaṃ samanuyuñjeyyuṃ. Na sampāyeyyanti na sampādeyyaṃ, sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkuṇeyyanti attho. So mamassa vighātoti yaṃ taṃ punappunaṃ vatvāpi asampāyanaṃ nāma, so mama vighāto assa, oṭṭhatālujivhāgalasosanadukkhameva assāti attho. Sesametthāpi paṭhamavārasadisameva.
commentary_english:
64. "Paṇḍitā": endowed with intelligence (*paṇḍicca*).

"Nipuṇā": of refined and subtle intellect (*saṇhasukhumabuddhi*), capable of penetrating subtle meanings (*sukhumaatthantaraṃ paṭivijjhanasamatthā*).

"Kataparappavādā": having knowledge of others' doctrines (*viññātaparappavādā*), and familiar with engaging in discussions with others (*parehi saddhiṃ katavādaparicayā ca*).

"Vālavedhirūpā": like a skilled archer (*vālavedhidhanuggahasadisā*).

It means (*attho*) that those who destroy (*bhindantā*) are regarded as piercing even subtle hairs (*vālaṃ sukhumānipi*) with their knowledge (*paññāgatena*), like a hair-splitting archer (*vālavedhi viya*), and wander (*caranti*) destroying the fixed views (*diṭṭhigatāni*) of others (*paresam*).

"Te maṃ tatthāti": those *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s in those wholesome and unwholesome things may question me (*maṃ tesu kusalākusalesu*).

"Samanuyuñjeyyunti": they might cross-examine me (*samanuyuñjeyyuṃ*), asking, "What is wholesome ( *kusalaṃ*)? What is unwholesome (*akusalaṃ*)? State your opinion (*attano laddhiṃ vadā*)!" They might inquire about my opinion (*laddhiṃ puccheyyuṃ*).

"Samanugāheyyunti": they might press me for reason (*samanugāheyyuṃ*), saying, "This is my opinion (*idaṃ nāmā*)," and then ask, "For what reason do you hold this (*kena kāraṇena etamatthaṃ gāheyyu*)?" They might inquire about the reason (*kāraṇaṃ puccheyyuṃ*).

"Samanubhāseyyunti": they might refute my statements (*samanubhāseyyunti*), saying, "For this reason (*iminā nāma kāraṇenā*)," and pointing out errors (*dosaṃ dassetvā*) in the reason (*kāraṇe*), examine me thus (*evaṃ samanuyuñjeyyuṃ*): "You do not understand this (*na tvaṃ idaṃ jānāsi*). Accept this (*idaṃ pana gaṇha*). Answer this (*idaṃ vissajjehī*)!"

"Na sampāyeyyanti": I might not be able to bring it to completion (*na sampādeyyaṃ*), meaning (*attho*) that having completed it, I might not be able to explain it (*sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkuṇeyyaṃ*).

"So mamassa vighātoti": that would be my ruin (*so mama vighāto assa*), meaning (*attho*) that what is called incompletion (*asampāyanaṃ nāma*) even when repeatedly spoken (*yaṃ taṃ punappunaṃ vatvāpi*), that would be my ruin (*so mama vighāto assa*), it would only be suffering (*dukkhaṃ eva*) due to dryness (*sosana*) of the lips, palate, tongue and throat (*oṭṭhatālujivhāgala*).

"Sesametthāpi paṭhamavārasadisameva": the rest is the same as the first instance (*paṭhamavārasadisameva*).

mula_pali: 65. ‘‘Catutthe ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā mando hoti momūho. So mandattā momūhattā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṃ – ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti ce me  assa, ‘atthi paro loko’ti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ, ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti. ‘Natthi paro loko…pe… ‘atthi ca natthi ca paro loko…pe… ‘nevatthi na natthi paro loko…pe… ‘atthi sattā opapātikā  …pe… ‘natthi sattā opapātikā…pe… ‘atthi ca natthi ca sattā opapātikā…pe… ‘nevatthi na natthi sattā opapātikā…pe… ‘atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ sukaṭadukkaṭānaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ.) kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe… ‘natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe… ‘atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe… ‘nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe… ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā…pe… ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā…pe… ‘hoti ca na ca hoti na hoti ca (sī. ka.) tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā…pe… ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti ce me assa, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ, ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ.
mula_english:
65. Furthermore, monks, on what grounds do some ascetics and Brahmins, being eel-wrigglers, when questioned about this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation? Here, monks, some ascetic or Brahmin is dull and stupid.

Due to his dullness and stupidity, when he is questioned he resorts to evasive statements and wriggles like an eel: “If you ask me whether there is another world—if I thought so, I would say there is another world. But I don’t say so. And I don’t say otherwise. And I don’t say it is not, and I don’t not say it is not.”

“Is there no other world? …” “Is there both another world and no other world? …” “Is there neither another world nor no other world? … “Are there beings spontaneously reborn? … “Are there no beings spontaneously reborn? …” “Are there both beings spontaneously reborn and no beings spontaneously reborn? … “Are there neither beings spontaneously reborn nor no beings spontaneously reborn? …” “Is there fruit and result of good and bad actions? …” “Is there no fruit and result of good and bad actions? …” “Is there both fruit and result of good and bad actions and no fruit and result of good and bad actions? …” “Is there neither fruit and result of good and bad actions nor no fruit and result of good and bad actions? …” “Does the *Tathāgata* exist after death? …” “Does the *Tathāgata* not exist after death? …” “Does the *Tathāgata* both exist and not exist after death? …“Does the *Tathāgata* neither exist nor not exist after death?” If you ask me, ‘Does the *Tathāgata* neither exist nor not exist after death?’ if I thought so, I would say so. But I don’t say so. And I don’t say otherwise. And I don’t say it is not, and I don’t not say it is not.”

This, monks, is the fourth case where some ascetics and Brahmins, being eel-wrigglers, when questioned about this or that point, resort to evasive statements and to endless equivocation.
commentary_pali: 65-66.Mandoti mandapañño apaññassevetaṃ nāmaṃ. Momūhoti atisammūḷho. Hotitathāgatotiādīsu satto ‘‘tathāgato’’ti adhippeto. Sesamettha uttānameva. Imepi cattāro pubbe pavattadhammānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
65-66. "Slow" means slow of wisdom; this is a designation for the unwise.

"Bewildered" means utterly confused.

In such expressions as "he is a *tathāgata*," *sattva* is intended by "*tathāgata*."

The rest is evident here.

These four, too, are included among those who speculate about the past, because their view is apprehended in accordance with a *dhamma* occurring in the past.

mula_pali: 66. ‘‘Imehi  kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā amarāvikkhepikā  tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ catūhi vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amarāvikkhepikā tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭhā samānā vācāvikkhepaṃ āpajjanti amarāvikkhepaṃ , sabbe te imeheva catūhi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito bahiddhā…pe… yehi tathāgatassa yathābhuccaṃ vaṇṇaṃ sammā vadamānā vadeyyuṃ.
mula_english:
66. "It is on these grounds, *bhikkhus*, that those ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* who are endless equivocators (*amarāvikkhepikā*) resort to evasive statements (*vācāvikkhepaṃ*) and to endless equivocation (*amarāvikkhepaṃ*) when questioned about this or that point.

Whatever ascetics (*samaṇā*) or *brāhmaṇas* there may be who are endless equivocators (*amarāvikkhepikā*), when questioned about this or that matter, resort to evasive statements (*vācāvikkhepaṃ*) and to endless equivocation (*amarāvikkhepaṃ*), all of them do so on these four grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none... it is concerning these that those who would rightly praise the *Tathāgata* in accordance with reality would speak.
commentary_pali: 65-66.Mandoti mandapañño apaññassevetaṃ nāmaṃ. Momūhoti atisammūḷho. Hotitathāgatotiādīsu satto ‘‘tathāgato’’ti adhippeto. Sesamettha uttānameva. Imepi cattāro pubbe pavattadhammānusāreneva diṭṭhiyā gahitattā pubbantakappikesu paviṭṭhā.
commentary_english:
65-66. "One with dull wisdom" (mandapañño) means this is just a name for one without wisdom (apaññassa).

"Extremely confused" (atisammūḷho) means "completely bewildered" (momūho).

Among terms beginning with "becomes a *tathāgata*" (*hotitathāgatoti*), a being (*satto*) is intended by "*tathāgata*."

The rest here is evident.

These four endless equivocators are included among the speculators about the past because they apprehend their view as a consequence of some dhamma occurring in the past.

mula_pali: 67. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi. Te ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā  kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi?
mula_english:
67. “There are, monks, some ascetics and Brahmins who are Chance-Originationists, and who proclaim the chance origin of the self (*ātman*) and the world on two grounds.

And owing to what, with reference to what, do these honourable ascetics and Brahmins proclaim their views of chance origination concerning the self (*ātman*) and the world on two grounds?
commentary_pali: 67. ‘‘Adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko cā’’ti dassanaṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ. Taṃ etesaṃ atthīti adhiccasamuppannikā. Adhiccasamuppannanti akāraṇasamuppannaṃ.
commentary_english:
67. The view that "the self (*ātmā*) and the world (*loka*) originate fortuitously ( *adhiccasamuppanna*)" is *adhiccasamuppanna*.

That which exists for them is called *adhiccasamuppannikā*.

"To originate fortuitously (*adhiccasamuppanna*)" means to originate without a cause (*akāraṇasamuppannaṃ*).

mula_pali: 68. ‘‘Santi, bhikkhave, asaññasattā nāma devā. Saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavanti. Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati, yaṃ aññataro satto tamhā kāyā cavitvā itthattaṃ āgacchati. Itthattaṃ āgato samāno agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati. Agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno ātappamanvāya padhānamanvāya anuyogamanvāya appamādamanvāya sammāmanasikāramanvāya tathārūpaṃ cetosamādhiṃ phusati, yathāsamāhite citte saññuppādaṃ anussarati, tato paraṃ  nānussarati. So evamāha – ‘adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko ca. Taṃ kissa hetu? Ahañhi pubbe nāhosiṃ, somhi etarahi ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca  lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
68. "There are, monks, certain gods called 'non-percipient beings' (*asaññasattā nāma devā*).

When perception arises in them (*saññuppādā*), those gods pass away from that realm (*kāyā cavanti*).

And it can happen, monks, that a being falls from that state (*kāyā cavitvā*) and arises in this world (*itthattaṃ āgacchati*).

Having arisen in this world (*itthattaṃ āgato*), he goes forth from the household life into homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati*).

Having gone forth from home to homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito*), by means of effort (*ātappa*), exertion (*padhāna*), application (*anuyoga*), diligence (*appamāda*), and right attention (*sammāmanasikāra*), he attains to such a degree of mental concentration (*cetosamādhiṃ phusati*) that with his mind thus concentrated (*yathāsamāhite citte*) he recalls the arising of perception (*saññuppādaṃ anussarati*), but recalls none before that (*tato paraṃ nānussarati*).

He speaks thus: ‘The self (*attā*) and the world (*loko*) originate fortuitously (*adhiccasamuppanno*).’

What is the reason for that (*taṃ kissa hetu*)? Because previously I did not exist (*pubbe nāhosiṃ*), but now I am (*etarahi*). Not having been, I sprang into continuous being (*ahutvā santatāya pariṇato’ti*)."

This, monks, is the first ground (*paṭhamaṃ ṭhānaṃ*) by which some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaṇabrāhmaṇā*) who hold the theory of fortuitous origination (*adhiccasamuppannikā*) propound that the self (*attānaṃ*) and the world (*lokaṃ*) originate fortuitously (*adhiccasamuppannaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 68-73.Asaññasattāti desanāsīsametaṃ, acittuppādā rūpamattakaattabhāvāti attho. Tesaṃ evaṃ uppatti veditabbā – ekacco hi titthāyatane pabbajitvā vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ katvā  catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā jhānā vuṭṭhāya – ‘‘citte dosaṃ passati, citte sati hatthacchedādidukkhañceva  sabbabhayāni ca honti, alaṃ iminā cittena, acittakabhāvova santo’’ti, evaṃ citte dosaṃ passitvā aparihīnajjhāno kālaṃ katvā asaññasattesu nibbattati, cittamassa cuticittanirodhena idheva nivattati, rūpakkhandhamattameva tattha pātubhavati. Te tattha yathā nāma jiyāvegakkhitto saro yattako jiyāvego, tattakameva ākāse gacchati. Evameva jhānavegakkhittā upapajjitvā yattako jhānavego, tattakameva kālaṃ tiṭṭhanti, jhānavege pana parihīne tattha rūpakkhandho antaradhāyati, idha pana paṭisandhisaññā uppajjati. Yasmā pana tāya idha uppannasaññāya tesaṃ tattha cuti paññāyati, tasmā ‘‘saññuppādā ca pana te devā tamhā kāyā cavantī’’ti vuttaṃ. Santatāyāti santabhāvāya. Sesamettha uttānameva. Takkīvādopi vuttanayeneva veditabboti.
commentary_english:
68-73. "Non-percipient beings": this is the heading of the teaching. Because they arise without mind, their individual forms consist of mere materiality, this is the meaning.

Their origin is explained as follows. Someone who has gone forth into a sectarian order practices the preliminary work of meditation on the wind *kasiṇa* and develops the fourth *jhāna*. After emerging from the *jhāna* he sees the fault in mind thus: “When there is mind, one is exposed to the suffering of having one’s hands mutilated, etc., and to all kinds of perils. Enough with mind! The unconscious state alone is peaceful.” Having thus seen the fault in mind, if he passes away without having fallen from his *jhāna*, he is reborn in the *asaññasatta* realm. His mind ceases with the cessation of the dying consciousness, and it reverts right there. Only the aggregate of material form manifests there.

Just as an arrow driven by the propulsive force of the bow-string travels through space to a distance exactly proportional to the propulsive force of the string,

in the same way this being, taking rebirth through the propulsive force of the *jhāna*, remains in that realm for a time exactly proportional to the propulsive force of the *jhāna*. When the force of the *jhāna* is exhausted, the aggregate of material form disappears there and a rebirth-linking perception (*pratisaṃdhi-saññā*) arises here.

Because their passing away from the non-percipient realm is discerned through the arising of perception here, it is said: “When perception arises in them, those gods pass away from that plane.”

*Santatayā* means to continuous existence.

The rest is evident.

The sophist's doctrine, too, should be understood in the manner stated above.

mula_pali: 69. ‘‘Dutiye  ca bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kimāgamma kimārabbha adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā takkī hoti vīmaṃsī. So takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ evamāha – ‘adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko cā’ti. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, yaṃ āgamma yaṃ ārabbha eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti.
mula_english:
69. “And furthermore, venerable ascetics and Brahmins, relying on what, depending on what, do the proponents of chance origin declare the self and the world to have arisen by chance? Here, mendicants, some ascetic or Brahmin is a logician, an investigator.

He declares his view—hammered out by reason (takkapariyāhataṃ), deduced from his investigations (vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ), following his own flight of thought (sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ)—thus: ‘The self (attā) and the world (loko) originate fortuitously (adhiccasamuppanno).’

This, mendicants, is the second ground, relying on which, depending on which, some ascetics and Brahmins declare the self and the world to have arisen by chance."

mula_pali: 70. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā adhiccasamuppannikā adhiccasamuppannaṃ attānañca lokañca paññapenti dvīhi vatthūhi. mula_english:

mula_pali: 71. ‘‘Imehi kho te, bhikkhave, samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti aṭṭhārasahi  vatthūhi. Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā pubbantānudiṭṭhino pubbantamārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva aṭṭhārasahi vatthūhi, etesaṃ vā aññatarena, natthi ito  bahiddhā.
mula_english:
71. “And these, monks, are the eighteen grounds on which those ascetics and Brahmins who are speculators about the past and hold fixed views about the past assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past.

Whatever ascetics or Brahmins are speculators about the past, hold settled views about the past, and assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past, all of them do so on these eighteen grounds or on a certain one of them. Outside of these there is none.

mula_pali: 72. ‘‘Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato pajānāti – ‘ime diṭṭhiṭṭhānā evaṃgahitā evaṃparāmaṭṭhā evaṃgatikā bhavanti evaṃabhisamparāyā’ti. Tañca tathāgato pajānāti, tato ca uttaritaraṃ pajānāti, tañca pajānanaṃ na parāmasati, aparāmasato cassa paccattaññeva nibbuti viditā. Vedanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ viditvā anupādāvimutto, bhikkhave, tathāgato.
mula_english:
72. "This, monks, the *tathāgata* understands: ‘These viewpoints (*dṛṣṭi-sthānāḥ*), thus grasped and thus misapprehended, lead to such destinations and such a future state.’

The *tathāgata* understands this, and even more than this, yet he does not cling to that understanding. Because he is free from clinging, he has realized peace (*nirvṛti*) within himself.

Having understood as they really are the origination (*samudaya*), passing away (*atthaṅgama*), satisfaction (*assāda*), unsatisfactoriness (*ādīnava*), and the escape (*nissaraṇa*) from feelings (*vedanānāṃ*), the *tathāgata*, monks, is liberated through non-clinging (*anupādāvimutto*)."
