Now, in this context, *bhikkhus*, those recluses and *brāhmaṇas* who are eternalists and propound the self (*ātman*) and the world to be eternal based on four grounds, and those recluses and *brāhmaṇas* who gather together all the feelings of views according to the method beginning with the partial-eternalists, etc.

Why? In order to relate them once more to contact.

How? All of them experience these feelings only by repeated contacts through the six sense-bases (*phassāyatana*).

Therein, the six sense-bases (*phassāyatana*) are: the eye as a sense-base (*cakkhuphassāyatana*), the ear as a sense-base, the nose as a sense-base, the tongue as a sense-base, the body as a sense-base, and the mind as a sense-base. These are the six.

The word "base" (*āyatana*) occurs in the texts with four meanings: place of origin (*sañjāti*), place of convergence (*samosaraṇa*), cause (*kāraṇa*), and as a mere designation of place (*paṇṇattimatta*).

For example, in the statement: “Kamboja is the base for horses, the southern region the base for cows,” it signifies place of origin; that is, the meaning is place of origin.

“The birds resort to that delightful base” signifies place of convergence.

“When there is a basis” signifies cause.

“They dwell in leaf huts in the forest base” signifies a mere designation.

In the present case, the first three meanings apply.

For the pentad of contact originates in and converges upon the sense faculties, and these latter are its cause; thus they are called "bases" (*āyatana*).

Here, the bases of contact, etc., are mentioned in order to show the succession of conditions, making contact the starting point and arranging the teaching under the heading of contact, in accordance with the method of the following passage: “Dependent on the eye and visible forms (*rūpa*), eye-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact (*phassa*),” etc.

"They experience these feelings by repeated contacts" means they experience these feelings by contacting again and again.

Although the statement "by repeated contacts through the six bases of contact" gives the impression that the six bases themselves exercise the function of contacting, this would be a wrong interpretation.

For it is not the bases (*āyatana*) that contact, rather, it is contact (*phassa*) itself that contacts the various objects (*ārammaṇa*). The bases (*āyatana*) are shown as incorporated within contact. Therefore, the meaning of the present passage should be understood thus: "All these recluses and *brāhmaṇas* experience the feeling of views by contacting objects such as visible forms (*rūpa*), etc., by means of contact (*phassa*) originating through the six sense-bases (*phassāyatana*)."

With feeling (*vedanā*) as condition, there arises in them craving (*taṇhā*). "Feeling" (*vedanā*) is here the feeling originating through the six sense-bases (*phassāyatana*).

It is a condition for craving (*taṇhā*)—divided into craving for visible forms (*rūpa*), etc.—under the crest of decisive support condition.

Thus it is said: "With feeling (*vedanā*) as condition, there arises in them craving (*taṇhā*)."

Craving (*taṇhā*) in turn is a condition for the four types of clinging (*upādāna*) under the crests of decisive-support and co-nascence.

Clinging (*upādāna*) is a condition for existence (*bhava*) in the same way.

Existence (*bhava*) is a condition for birth (*jāti*) under the crest of decisive-support.

"Birth" (*jāti*) here is the five aggregates (*pañcakkhandha*) together with their alterations. Birth (*jāti*) is a condition for aging (*jarā*) and death (*maraṇa*), and for sorrow (*śoka*), etc., under the crest of decisive-support.

This is a brief explanation. The detailed explanation can be found in the discussion of dependent origination (*paṭiccasamuppāda*) in the *Visuddhimagga*.

But what is given here is sufficient.

When he gives an exposition of the round, the Exalted One sometimes discusses it under the heading of ignorance (*avidyā*), as when he says: “No first beginning of ignorance (*avidyā*) is made known, *bhikkhus*, before which there was no ignorance (*avidyā*), and after which there came to be ignorance (*avidyā*). And while it is said thus, *bhikkhus*, nevertheless it is made known that ignorance (*avidyā*) has its specific condition”;
61) Thus, or under the heading of ignorance (*avijjāsīsena*), bhikkhus, no first limit (*purimā koṭi*) of craving for existence (*bhavataṇhāya*) is discernible…etc.… "Craving for existence has this as its condition (*idappaccayā bhavataṇhā*)” (A.
N.
10)
62) Thus, or under the heading of craving (*taṇhāsīsena*), bhikkhus, no first limit (*purimā koṭi*) of views about existence (*bhavadiṭṭhiyā*) is discernible…etc.… "Views about existence have this as their condition (*idappaccayā bhavadiṭṭhī*)” Thus, or under the heading of views (*diṭṭhisīsena*), he spoke.

Here, discussing under the heading of views (*diṭṭhisīsena*), having spoken of the views (*diṭṭhiyo*) that arise from lust for feeling (*vedanārāgena*), he spoke of dependent origination (*paṭiccasamuppādaṃ*) rooted in feeling (*vedanāmūlakaṃ*).

Therefore, he shows this: “These adherents to views (*diṭṭhigatikā*), having taken up this view (*dassanaṃ gahetvā*), wander and transmigrate (*sandhāvantā saṃsarantā*) through the three existences (*tīsu bhavesu*), the four modes of generation (*catūsu yonīsu*), the five destinations (*pañcasu gatīsu*), the seven abodes of consciousness (*sattasu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu*), and the nine abodes of beings (*navasu sattāvāsesu*), from here to there and from there to here, like an ox yoked (*yuttagoṇo*) to a yoke, like a dog tied (*upanibaddhakukkuro*) to a post (*thambhe*), or like a ship with a broken mast (*vippannaṭṭhanāvā*) in the wind, they revolve in the round of suffering (*vaṭṭadukkhameva anuparivattanti*), and are not able (*na sakkontī*) to lift their heads (*sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ*) out of the round of suffering (*vaṭṭadukkhato*)."

mula_pali: 145. ‘‘Yato  kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ imehi sabbeheva uttaritaraṃ pajānāti.
mula_english: “When, O monks, a monk truly understands the arising (samudayañca) and passing away (atthaṅgamañca) of the six sense bases (channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ), their allure (assādañca), their danger (ādīnavañca), and the escape from them (nissaraṇañca), then he understands beyond all these.
commentary_pali: 145. Evaṃ diṭṭhigatikādhiṭṭhānaṃ vaṭṭaṃ kathetvā idāni yuttayogabhikkhuadhiṭṭhānaṃ katvā vivaṭṭaṃ dassento – ‘‘yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhū’’tiādimāha. Tattha yatoti yadā. Channaṃ phassāyatanānanti  yehi chahi phassāyatanehi phusitvā paṭisaṃvedayamānānaṃ diṭṭhigatikānaṃ vaṭṭaṃ vattati, tesaṃyeva channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ. Samudayantiādīsu avijjāsamudayā cakkhusamudayotiādinā vedanākammaṭṭhāne vuttanayena phassāyatanānaṃ samudayādayo veditabbā. Yathā pana tattha ‘‘phassasamudayā phassanirodhā’’ti vuttaṃ, evamidha, taṃ cakkhādīsu – ‘‘āhārasamudayā āhāranirodhā’’ti veditabbaṃ. Manāyatane ‘‘nāmarūpasamudayā nāmarūpanirodhā’’ti. Uttaritaraṃ pajānātīti diṭṭhigatiko diṭṭhimeva jānāti. Ayaṃ pana diṭṭhiñca diṭṭhito ca uttaritaraṃ sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttinti  yāva arahattā jānāti. Ko evaṃ jānātīti? Khīṇāsavo jānāti, anāgāmī, sakadāgāmī, sotāpanno, bahussuto, ganthadharo bhikkhu jānāti, āraddhavipassako jānāti. Desanā pana arahattanikūṭeneva niṭṭhāpitāti.
commentary_english:
145. Having discussed the round in terms of the theorists' foundation ( *diṭṭhigatikādhiṭṭhānaṃ vaṭṭaṃ kathetvā*), the Exalted One now shows the ending of the round, establishing it in terms of a *bhikkhu* devoted to meditation (*yuttayogabhikkhuadhiṭṭhānaṃ katvā vivaṭṭaṃ dassento*), beginning with, "When, *bhikkhus*..."

There, "whence" means "when."

“The six bases of contact (*channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ*)”: the same six bases of contact as those on account of which the theorists, experiencing feelings by means of contact, revolve in the round; those same six bases of contact.

The origin (*samudaya*), etc., should be understood in relation to the origination of ignorance (*avijjāsamudayā*), the origination of the eye (*cakkhusamudayo*), etc., in accordance with the method stated in the meditation subject of feeling (*vedanākammaṭṭhāne*).

Just as it was said above that feeling arises and ceases through the origination (*phassasamudayā*) and cessation (*phassanirodhā*) of contact, so here it should be understood that the eye and the other physical sense bases originate and cease through the origination (*āhārasamudayā*) and cessation (*āhāranirodhā*) of nutriment.

In the mind-base (*manāyatane*), it is said that origination (*samudayā*) and cessation (*nirodhā*) arise with mentality-materiality (*nāmarūpa*).

“He understands what transcends all these views (*uttaritaraṃ pajānāti*)": the theorist (*diṭṭhigatiko*) knows only his view (*diṭṭhimeva jānāti*).

But this *bhikkhu* understands these views and also what transcends these views, namely, virtue (*sīla*), concentration (*samādhi*), wisdom (*paññā*), and emancipation (*vimutti*), culminating in arahatship (*arahattā*).

Who understands thus? The one with destroyed cankers (*khīṇāsavo*) understands, the non-returner (*anāgāmī*), the once-returner (*sakadāgāmī*), the stream-enterer (*sotāpanno*), the learned (*bahussuto*), the *bhikkhu* who is a master of the scriptures (*ganthadharo bhikkhu*), and the *bhikkhu* who has aroused insight (*āraddhavipassako*).

But the teaching is concluded with its culmination in arahatship (*arahattā*).

mula_pali: 146. ‘‘Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā, ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho kevaṭṭo vā kevaṭṭantevāsī vā sukhumacchikena jālena parittaṃ udakadahaṃ udakarahadaṃ (sī. syā. pī.) otthareyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ye kho keci imasmiṃ udakadahe oḷārikā pāṇā, sabbe te antojālīkatā. Ettha sitāva ummujjamānā  ummujjanti; ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva  ummujjamānā ummujjantī’ti; evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā pubbantakappikā vā aparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantakappikā vā pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṃ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti, sabbe te imeheva dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi antojālīkatā ettha sitāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti, ettha pariyāpannā antojālīkatāva ummujjamānā ummujjanti.
mula_english:
146.

"Whatever ascetics or *brāhmaṇas*, *bhikkhus*, are speculators about the past (*pūrvānta*), speculators about the future (*aparantakalpika*), speculators about the past and the future together (*pūrvāntāparāntakalpikā*), hold settled views about the past and the future and assert various conceptual theorems referring to the past and the future—all are trapped in this net with its sixty-two divisions. Whenever they emerge, they emerge caught within this net, trapped and contained within this very net.

"Just as, *bhikkhus*, a skillful fisherman or a fisherman’s apprentice, after spreading a fine-meshed net over a small pool of water, might think: ‘Whatever sizeable creatures there are in this pool, all are trapped within this net, trapped and contained in this very net’—in the same way, all those recluses and *brāhmaṇas* are trapped in this net with its sixty-two divisions. Whenever they emerge, they emerge caught within this net, trapped and contained within this very net.
commentary_pali: 146. Evaṃ  vivaṭṭaṃ kathetvā idāni ‘‘desanājālavimutto diṭṭhigatiko nāma natthī’’ti dassanatthaṃ puna – ‘‘ye hi keci, bhikkhave’’ti ārabhi. Tattha antojālīkatāti imassa mayhaṃ desanājālassa antoyeva katā. Ettha sitā vāti etasmiṃ mama desanājāle sitā nissitā avasitāva. Ummujjamānā ummujjantīti kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Te adho osīdantāpi uddhaṃ uggacchantāpi mama desanājāle sitāva hutvā osīdanti ca uggacchanti ca. Ettha pariyāpannāti ettha mayhaṃ desanājāle pariyāpannā, etena ābaddhā antojālīkatā ca hutvā ummujjamānā ummujjanti, na hettha asaṅgahito diṭṭhigatiko nāma atthīti. Sukhumacchikenāti saṇhaacchikena sukhumacchiddenāti attho. Kevaṭṭo viya hi bhagavā, jālaṃ viya desanā, parittaudakaṃ viya dasasahassilokadhātu, oḷārikā pāṇā viya dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatikā. Tassa tīre ṭhatvā olokentassa oḷārikānaṃ pāṇānaṃ antojālīkatabhāvadassanaṃ viya bhagavato sabbadiṭṭhigatānaṃ desanājālassa antokatabhāvadassananti evamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
146. Having spoken thus about the ending of the round, now, in order to show that "there is no theorist ( *dṛṣṭhigatiko*) freed from the net of teaching (*desanājāla*)," [the Buddha] began again, "Those, O monks..."

There, *antojālīkatā* means simply made inside this net of my teaching (*desanājāla*).

Here, "sitā" means in this net of mine (*desanājāla*), they are dependent, they are confined.

What does "rising up, rising up" mean? Whether they sink downwards or rise upwards, they sink and rise caught within the net of my teaching (*desanājāla*).

Here, *pariyāpannā* means here, in my net of teaching (*desanājāla*) they are contained, bound by this, having become *antojālīkatā*, rising up they rise up; there is no theorist (*dṛṣṭhigatiko*) unincluded here.

*Sukhumacchikena* means with a fine-meshed net, with a fine-holed net, is the meaning.

The Exalted One is like the fisherman ( *kevaṭṭo*); the teaching (*desanā*) is like the net (*jālaṃ*); the ten-thousandfold world system (*dasasahassilokadhātu*) is like the small pool of water (*parittaudakaṃ*); the theorists (*dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatikā*) are like the sizable creatures (*oḷārikā pāṇā*).

Just as the fisherman (*kevaṭṭo*), standing on the shore surveying the net (*jālaṃ*), sees the *antojālīkatabhāvadassanaṃ* of all the sizable creatures (*oḷārikānaṃ pāṇānaṃ*), so the Blessed One (*bhagavato*) sees the *antokatabhāvadassanaṃ* of all the theorists (*sabbadiṭṭhigatānaṃ*) within the net of this teaching (*desanājālassa*); thus here, the application of the simile (*opammasaṃsandanaṃ*) is to be understood.

mula_pali: 147. ‘‘Ucchinnabhavanettiko, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati. Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā. Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ambapiṇḍiyā vaṇṭacchinnāya yāni kānici ambāni vaṇṭapaṭibandhāni vaṇṭūpanibandhanāni (sī. pī.), vaṇḍapaṭibaddhāni (ka.), sabbāni tāni tadanvayāni bhavanti; evameva kho, bhikkhave, ucchinnabhavanettiko tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati, yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā, kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā’’ti.
mula_english:
147. “Monks, the body of the *Tathāgata* stands, its connection to becoming severed (*ucchinnabhavanettiko tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati*).

As long as his body remains, gods and humans will see him (*yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati, tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā*).

But with the breaking up of the body and the exhaustion of the life-span, gods and humans will see him no more (*kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā*).

“Just as, monks, when the stalk of a bunch of mangoes has been cut, whatever mangoes are connected to the stalk, all of them follow it; in the same way, monks, the body of the *Tathāgata* stands, its connection to becoming severed. As long as his body remains, gods and humans will see him. But with the breaking up of the body and the exhaustion of the life-span, gods and humans will see him no more."
commentary_pali: 147. Evaṃ imāhi dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīhi sabbadiṭṭhīnaṃ saṅgahitattā sabbesaṃ diṭṭhigatikānaṃ etasmiṃ desanājāle pariyāpannabhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni attano katthaci apariyāpannabhāvaṃ dassento – ‘‘ucchinnabhavanettiko, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa kāyo’’tiādimāha. Tattha nayanti etāyāti netti. Nayantīti gīvāya bandhitvā ākaḍḍhanti, rajjuyā etaṃ nāmaṃ. Idha pana nettisadisatāya  bhavataṇhā nettīti adhippetā. Sā hi mahājanaṃ gīvāya bandhitvā taṃ taṃ bhavaṃ neti upanetīti bhavanetti. Arahattamaggasatthena ucchinnā bhavanetti assāti ucchinnabhavanettiko. Kāyassa bhedā uddhanti kāyassa bhedato uddhaṃ. Jīvitapariyādānāti jīvitassa sabbaso pariyādinnattā parikkhīṇattā, puna appaṭisandhikabhāvāti attho. Na taṃ dakkhantīti taṃ tathāgataṃ. Devā vā manussā vā na dakkhissanti, apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ gamissatīti attho. Seyyathāpi, bhikkhaveti, upamāyaṃ pana idaṃ saṃsandanaṃ. Ambarukkho viya hi tathāgatassa kāyo, rukkhe jātamahāvaṇṭo viya taṃ nissāya pubbe pavattataṇhā. Tasmiṃ vaṇṭe upanibaddhā pañcapakkadvādasapakkaaṭṭhārasapakkaparimāṇā ambapiṇḍī viya taṇhāya sati taṇhūpanibandhanā hutvā āyatiṃ nibbattanakā pañcakkhandhā dvādasāyatanāni aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo. Yathā pana tasmiṃ vaṇṭe chinne sabbāni tāni ambāni tadanvayāni honti, taṃyeva vaṇṭaṃ anugatāni, vaṇṭacchedā chinnāni yevāti attho; evameva ye bhavanettivaṇṭassa anupacchinnattā āyatiṃ uppajjeyyuṃ pañcakkhandhā dvādasāyatanāni aṭṭhārasadhātuyo, sabbe te dhammā tadanvayā honti bhavanettiṃ anugatā, tāya chinnāya chinnā yevāti attho. Yathā pana tasmimpi rukkhe maṇḍūkakaṇṭakavisasamphassaṃ āgamma anupubbena sussitvā mate – ‘‘imasmiṃ ṭhāne evarūpo nāma rukkho ahosī’’ti vohāramattameva hoti, na taṃ rukkhaṃ koci passati, evaṃ ariyamaggasamphassaṃ āgamma taṇhāsinehassa pariyādinnattā anupubbena sussitvā viya bhinne imasmiṃ kāye, kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā na taṃ dakkhanti, tathāgatampi devamanussā na dakkhissanti, evarūpassa nāma kira satthuno idaṃ sāsananti vohāramattameva bhavissatīti anupādisesanibbānadhātuṃ pāpetvā desanaṃ niṭṭhapesi.
commentary_english:
147. Thus, having shown that because their views are all included in these sixty-two views, all the theorists are included in the net of this teaching, the Exalted One, showing that he himself is not contained anywhere, makes the above statement: “The body of the *Tathāgata*, monks, has the 'leash of existence' cut off."

There, they lead by this, thus it is called a *netti* (leash).

Because they lead [an animal] along after tying it around his neck, it is called by this name, *rajju*.

Here, craving for existence (*bhava-taṇhā*) is intended by the word “leash” (*netti*), since such craving is similar to a leash.

That which, having bound a great mass of people by the neck, leads them to various states of existence, that is why it is called "leash of existence" (*bhava-netti*).

Because the *Tathāgata* has the "leash of existence" (*bhava-netti*) cut off with the sword of the path of *arhatship*, therefore, [his body] is "with the leash of existence cut off" (*ucchinnabhavanettiko*).

"Ascending from the dissolution of the body" means ascending beyond the dissolution of the body.

“The exhaustion of the life-faculty (*jīvita-pariyādāna*)” means because of the total exhaustion and cessation of the life faculty, there is no further rebirth-linkage; this is the meaning.

"They shall see him no more" means they will not see that *Tathāgata*.

"Gods or humans shall see him no more" because he will go to the state of non-apprehension; this is the meaning.

Just as, monks, this application is an analogy.

The body of the *Tathāgata* is like the mango tree. The craving that occurred in the past supported by that body is like the great stalk (*mahāvaṇṭa*) growing on the tree.

Like the bunch of mangoes (*amba-piṇḍī*) connected to the stalk (*vaṇṭa*), numbering five, twelve, or eighteen fruits, are the five aggregates (*pañcakkhandhā*), twelve bases (*dvādasāyatanāni*), and eighteen elements (*aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo*) connected with craving (*taṇhā*), which would have been produced in the future if craving were to continue to exist.

But just as, when the stalk (*vaṇṭa*) is cut, all those mangoes (*ambāni*) follow along with and accompany the stalk, and with the cutting off of the stalk are also cut off; this is the meaning. In the same way, all those *dharmas*—the five aggregates (*pañcakkhandhā*), twelve bases (*dvādasāyatanāni*), and eighteen elements (*aṭṭhārasadhātuyo*)—that would have arisen in the future if the stalk (*vaṇṭa*) of the "leash of existence" (*bhava-netti*) were not cut off, all follow along with and accompany the "leash of existence" (*bhava-netti*); when the leash is cut, they also are cut; this is the meaning.

Just as, when the tree is gradually withered and killed by contact with a poisonous *maṇḍuka* thorn, no one sees the tree anymore, but people say; “In this place such and such a tree stood," using the word “tree” as a mere expression. In the same way, when the body of the *Tathāgata*, brought into contact with the noble paths, is gradually withered and broken up through the exhaustion of the moisture of craving (*taṇhā-sineha*), with the breakup of the body and the exhaustion of the life- faculty (*jīvita-pariyādāna*), they shall see him no more. Neither gods nor men shall see that *Tathāgata*. "This is the teaching of such and such a teacher," there will be only a mere expression. Having led [the audience] to the element of *Nirvāṇa* without remainder, he concluded the discourse.

mula_pali: 148. Evaṃ  vutte āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, ko nāmo ayaṃ, bhante, dhammapariyāyo’’ti? ‘‘Tasmātiha tvaṃ, ānanda, imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ atthajālantipi naṃ dhārehi, dhammajālantipi naṃ dhārehi, brahmajālantipi naṃ dhārehi, diṭṭhijālantipi naṃ dhārehi, anuttaro  saṅgāmavijayotipi naṃ dhārehī’’ti. Idamavoca bhagavā.
mula_english:
148. When this was said, the venerable Ānanda said this to the Blessed One: "It is wonderful, venerable sir! It is marvelous, venerable sir! What, venerable sir, is the name of this teaching?" "Therefore, Ānanda, you should remember this teaching as the 'Net of Meaning' (*arthajāla*), remember it as the 'Net of Doctrine' (*dhammajāla*), remember it as the 'Net of Brahma' (*brahmajāla*), remember it as the 'Net of Views' (*dṛṣṭijāla*), remember it as the 'Unexcelled Victory in Battle' (*anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo*)."
Thus spoke the Blessed One.
commentary_pali: 148.Evaṃvutte āyasmā ānandoti evaṃ bhagavatā imasmiṃ sutte vutte thero ādito paṭṭhāya sabbaṃ suttaṃ samannāharitvā evaṃ buddhabalaṃ dīpetvā kathitasuttassa na bhagavatā nāmaṃ gahitaṃ, handassa nāmaṃ gaṇhāpessāmīti cintetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca. Tasmātiha tvantiādīsu ayamatthayojanā – ānanda, yasmā imasmiṃ dhammapariyāye idhatthopi paratthopi vibhatto, tasmātiha tvaṃ imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ ‘‘atthajāla’’ntipi naṃ dhārehi; yasmā panettha bahū tantidhammā kathitā, tasmā ‘‘dhammajāla’’ntipi naṃ dhārehi; yasmā ca ettha seṭṭhaṭṭhena  brahmaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ vibhattaṃ, tasmā ‘‘brahmajāla’’ntipi naṃ dhārehi; yasmā ettha dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyo vibhattā, tasmā ‘‘diṭṭhijāla’’ntipi naṃ dhārehi; yasmā pana imaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ sutvā devaputtamārampi khandhamārampi maccumārampi kilesamārampi  sakkā maddituṃ, tasmā ‘‘anuttaro saṅgāmavijayotipi naṃ dhārehī’’ti. Idamavoca bhagavāti idaṃ nidānāvasānato pabhuti yāva ‘‘anuttaro saṅgāmavijayotipi naṃ dhārehī’’ti sakalaṃ suttantaṃ bhagavā paresaṃ paññāya alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭhaṃ paramagambhīraṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pakāsento sūriyo viya andhakāraṃ diṭṭhigatamahandhakāraṃ vidhamanto avoca.
commentary_english:
148. When this had been said, the venerable Ānanda said, "When this Sūtra had been spoken by the Blessed One, the Elder, having gathered together the entire Sūtra from beginning to end, and having revealed the power of the Buddha in this way, the Blessed One did not take the name of the Sūtra that had been spoken. Thinking, 'Now, I will cause Him to take the name,' he said this to the Blessed One."

Therefore, in "[tvantihādi]...", this is the connection of meaning: "Ānanda, because in this *dharma-pariyāya* (exposition of the Dharma) both *idhattha* (welfare in this world) and *parattha* (welfare in the next world) are distinguished, therefore, Ānanda, remember this *dharma-pariyāya* as the 'Net of Meaning' (*arthajāla*); and because many tenets of the *tantras* have been spoken of in it, therefore, remember it as the 'Net of the Dharma' (*dhammajāla*); and because in it the supreme *brahman*, the all-knowing knowledge (*sarvajñuta-jñāna*), has been distinguished through excellence, therefore, remember it as the 'Net of Brahman' (*brahmajāla*); and because in it sixty-two views (*dvāsaṭṭhi-diṭṭhi*) have been distinguished, therefore, remember it as the 'Net of Views' (*diṭṭhijāla*); and because, having heard this *dharma-pariyāya*, it is possible to subdue even *devaputta-māra* (the Māra who is the son of a god), *khandha-māra* (the Māra of the aggregates), *maccu-māra* (the Māra of death), and *kilesa-māra* (the Māra of defilements), therefore, remember it as 'The Unexcelled Victory in Battle' (*anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo*)."

"This the Blessed One said." This entire *sūtrānta* (discourse), from the beginning of the introduction up to "remember it as 'The Unexcelled Victory in Battle' (*anuttaro saṅgāmavijayo*)", the Blessed One, revealing the knowledge of omniscience (*sarvajñuta-jñāna*), which has a foundation that cannot be obtained by the wisdom of others, and which is supremely profound, dispelling the darkness, the great darkness consisting of adherence to views, like the sun dispelling the darkness, spoke.

mula_pali: 149. Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti. Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne dasasahassī sahassī (katthaci) lokadhātu akampitthāti.
mula_english:
149.
Elated, those *bhikkhus* (monks) delighted in the Blessed One’s statement.
And as this exposition was being proclaimed, the ten-thousand world-system shook.
commentary_pali: 149.Attamanā te bhikkhūti te bhikkhū attamanā sakamanā, buddhagatāya pītiyā udaggacittā hutvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Bhagavato bhāsitanti evaṃ vicitranayadesanāvilāsayuttaṃ idaṃ suttaṃ karavīkarutamañjunā kaṇṇasukhena paṇḍitajanahadayānaṃ amatābhisekasadisena brahmassarena bhāsamānassa bhagavato vacanaṃ. Abhinandunti anumodiṃsu ceva sampaṭicchiṃsu ca. Ayañhi abhinandasaddo – ‘‘abhinandati abhivadatī’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 3.5) taṇhāyampi āgato. ‘‘Annamevābhinandanti, ubhaye devamānusā’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 1.43) upagamanepi. Ādīsu sampaṭicchanepi. ‘‘Abhinanditvā anumoditvā’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.205) anumodanepi. Svāyamidha anumodanasampaṭicchanesu yujjati. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘abhinandunti anumodiṃsu ceva sampaṭicchiṃsu cā’’ti. Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasminti imasmiṃ niggāthakasutte. Niggāthakattā hi idaṃ veyyākaraṇanti vuttaṃ. Dasasahassīlokadhātūti dasasahassacakkavāḷaparimāṇā lokadhātu. Akampitthāti na suttapariyosāneyeva akampitthāti veditabbā. Bhaññamāneti hi vuttaṃ. Tasmā dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhigatesu viniveṭhetvā desiyamānesu  tassa tassa diṭṭhigatassa pariyosāne pariyosāneti dvāsaṭṭhiyā ṭhānesu akampitthāti veditabbā. Tattha aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi pathavīkampo veditabbo – dhātukkhobhena, iddhimato ānubhāvena, bodhisattassa gabbhokkantiyā, mātukucchito nikkhamanena, sambodhippattiyā, dhammacakkappavattanena, āyusaṅkhārossajjanena, parinibbānenāti. Tesaṃ vinicchayaṃ – ‘‘aṭṭha kho ime, ānanda, hetū aṭṭha paccayā mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāyā’’ti evaṃ mahāparinibbāne āgatāya tantiyā vaṇṇanākāle vakkhāma. Ayaṃ pana mahāpathavī aparesupi aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu akampittha – mahābhinikkhamane, bodhimaṇḍūpasaṅkamane, paṃsukūlaggahaṇe, paṃsukūladhovane, kāḷakārāmasutte, gotamakasutte, vessantarajātake, imasmiṃ brahmajāleti. Tattha mahābhinikkhamanabodhimaṇḍūpasaṅkamanesu vīriyabalena akampittha. Paṃsukūlaggahaṇe  dvisahassadīpaparivāre cattāro mahādīpe pahāya pabbajitvā susānaṃ gantvā paṃsukūlaṃ gaṇhantena dukkaraṃ bhagavatā katanti acchariyavegābhihatā akampittha. Paṃsukūladhovanavessantarajātakesu akālakampanena akampittha. Kāḷakārāmagotamakasuttesu – ‘‘ahaṃ sakkhī bhagavā’’ti sakkhibhāvena akampittha. Imasmiṃ pana brahmajāle dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhigatesu vijaṭetvā niggumbaṃ katvā desiyamānesu sādhukāradānavasena akampitthāti veditabbā. Na kevalañca etesu ṭhānesuyeva pathavī akampittha, atha kho tīsu saṅgahesupi mahāmahindattherassa imaṃ dīpaṃ āgantvā jotivane nisīditvā dhammaṃ desitadivasepi akampittha. Kalyāṇiyavihāre ca piṇḍapātiyattherassa cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ sammajjitvā tattheva nisīditvā buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā imaṃ suttantaṃ āraddhassa suttapariyosāne udakapariyantaṃ katvā akampittha. Lohapāsādassa pācīnaambalaṭṭhikaṭṭhānaṃ nāma ahosi. Tattha nisīditvā dīghabhāṇakattherā brahmajālasuttaṃ ārabhiṃsu, tesaṃ sajjhāyapariyosānepi udakapariyantameva katvā pathavī akampitthāti.
commentary_english:
149.
"The monks were delighted," means those monks were joyous and content, filled with uplifting joy directed toward the Buddha.

"Spoken by the Blessed One," means this *sūtra*, endowed with diverse methods of exposition and charming display, is the word of the Blessed One, resounding with a *brahmassarena* sweet to the ear, delightful, like an anointment of immortality to the hearts of the wise.

They rejoiced, they approved, and they accepted it.

Here, the word *abhinandati* appears in passages such as, "He rejoices, he greets respectfully," (Saṃ. Ni. 3.5) and also in connection with craving.

It also appears in passages such as, "Both gods and humans rejoice in food," (Saṃ. Ni. 1.43) and in connection with approaching.

It also appears in connection with approval in passages such as, "Having rejoiced and approved," (Ma. Ni. 1.205).

Therefore, here, it is fitting to connect it with approval and acceptance.

Therefore, it was said, "They rejoiced, they approved, and they accepted it."

Moreover, in this explanation, [it refers to] this *niggāthaka sūtra*.

Because of the *niggāthaka*, this is called an explanation.

"The ten-thousandfold world-system" means a world-sphere the size of ten thousand *cakkavāḷa*s.

*Akampittha* means it should not be understood that it shook only at the conclusion of the *sūtra*.

For it is said, "While it was being spoken."

Therefore, it should be understood that as the sixty-two speculative views were being disentangled and taught, it shook in sixty-two places, at the conclusion of each of those speculative views.

There, the earth tremor should be understood by eight causes: by disturbance of the elements (*dhātukkhobha*), by the power (*ānubhāva*) of one with psychic powers (*iddhi*), by the entry into the womb (*gabbhokkanti*) of a *bodhisattva*, by the emergence from the mother's womb (*mātukucchi*), by the attainment of perfect enlightenment (*sambodhi*), by the turning of the wheel of the Dharma (*dharmacakra*), by the relinquishing of the life force (*āyusaṅkhāra*), and by final *nirvāṇa* (*parinirvāṇa*).

We will explain their decision in the section on the Great Final *Nirvāṇa* (*Mahāparinirvāṇa*), "There are these eight causes, Ānanda, eight conditions for the appearance of a great earthquake."

Moreover, this great earth (*mahāpathavī*) shook on eight other occasions: at the Great Renunciation (*mahābhinikkhamana*), at the approach to the *bodhimaṇḍa*, at the taking of rags from a dust heap (*paṃsukūlaggahaṇa*), at the washing of the rags from a dust heap (*paṃsukūladhovana*), at the *Kāḷakārāma Sūtra*, at the *Gotamaka Sūtra*, at the *Vessantara Jātaka*, and in this *Brahmajāla*.

There, at the Great Renunciation and at the approach to the *bodhimaṇḍa*, it shook through the power of energy (*vīryabala*).

At the taking of rags from a dust heap, with its retinue of two thousand islands, abandoning the four great continents, going forth, going to the charnel ground, and taking the rags from a dust heap, it shook, struck by the impact of wonder, as the Blessed One did something difficult (*dukkaram*).

At the washing of rags from a dust heap and in the *Vessantara Jātaka*, it shook through the shock of untimely trembling.

At the *Kāḷakārāma Sūtra* and the *Gotamaka Sūtra* – "I am a witness, Blessed One" – it shook as a way of bearing witness (*sakkhibhāva*).

Moreover, in this *Brahmajāla*, as the sixty-two speculative views were being disentangled, unravelled and taught, it should be understood that it shook as a sign of applause (*sādhukāradānavasena*).

It was not only in these places that the earth (*pathavī*) shook, but also at the three councils (*saṅgaha*s), and on the day when the Elder Mahinda the Great, after coming to this island (*dīpa*) and sitting down in the Grove of Light (*Jotivana*), taught the Dharma (*dhamma*), it shook.

Moreover, in the Kalyāṇī *Vihāra*, after the Elder Piṇḍapātiya swept the terrace of the shrine (*cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ*), and sitting down right there, and taking joy (*pīti*) with the Buddha as his object of meditation (*buddhārammaṇaṃ*), it shook at the conclusion of the recital of this *Sūtra* (*suttantaṃ*), having made the boundary of water (*udakapariyantaṃ*).

East of the Brazen Palace (*Lohapāsāda*) was a place called "Place of the Mango Shoot" (*Pācīnaambalaṭṭhikaṭṭhānaṃ*).

There, sitting down, the Elders who were reciters of the Dīgha Nikāya began the *Brahmajāla Sūtra*, and at the conclusion of their recitation, the earth shook, having made the boundary of water.

mula_pali: 359. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ. Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā vesāliyaṃ paṭivasanti kenacideva karaṇīyena. Assosuṃ kho te kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā – ‘‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī’’ti.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was living at Vesali in the Great Wood in the Hall with the Peaked Roof.

And at that time a large number of Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and Magadha were staying at Vesali on some business.

And they heard say: ‘The ascetic Gotama, son of the Sakyans, who has gone forth from the Sakya clan, is staying at Vesali, at the Gabled Hall in the Great Forest.

And concerning that Blessed Lord Gotama a good report had been spread about: ‘Indeed, the Blessed One is an *arhat* (worthy one), a fully enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), perfected in knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a Well-Farer (*sugato*), Knower of the worlds (*lokavidū*), unequalled Trainer of men to be tamed (*anuttaro purisadammasārathi*), Teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a Buddha, a Blessed Lord (*bhagavā*).’

He, having realised it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*), proclaims this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its Māras (*samārakaṃ*), and its Brahmās (*sabrahmakaṃ*), this generation with its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ*), its rulers and people (*sadevamanussaṃ*).

He teaches the Dharma (*dhammaṃ*) that is good at the beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), and good at the end (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*); he reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaṃ*) that is utterly perfect (*kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ*) and pure (*parisuddhaṃ*), with its true meaning (*sātthaṃ*) and proper expression (*sabyañjanaṃ*).

It is good to see such *arahants* (worthy ones)."
commentary_pali: 359.Evaṃme sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyanti mahālisuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Vesāliyanti punappunaṃ visālabhāvūpagamanato vesālīti laddhanāmake nagare. Mahāvaneti bahinagare himavantena saddhiṃ ekābaddhaṃ hutvā ṭhitaṃ sayaṃ jātavanaṃ atthi, yaṃ mahantabhāveneva mahāvananti vuccati, tasmiṃ mahāvane. Kūṭāgārasālāyanti tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe saṅghārāmaṃ patiṭṭhapesuṃ. Tattha kaṇṇikaṃ yojetvā thambhānaṃ upari kūṭāgārasālāsaṅkhepena devavimānasadisaṃ pāsādaṃ akaṃsu, taṃ upādāya sakalopi saṅghārāmo ‘‘kūṭāgārasālā’’ti paññāyittha. Bhagavā taṃ vesāliṃ upanissāya tasmiṃ saṅghārāme viharati. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāya’’nti. Kosalakāti kosalaraṭṭhavāsino. Māgadhakāti magadharaṭṭhavāsino. Karaṇīyenāti avassaṃ kattabbakammena. Yañhi akātumpi vaṭṭati, taṃ kiccanti vuccati, yaṃ avassaṃ kātabbameva, taṃ karaṇīyaṃ nāma.
commentary_english:
Thus have I heard: At one time the Blessed One was staying near Vesālī in the Mahālisutta.

Herein is an explanation of the unfamiliar terms.

"Vesālī": in the city called Vesālī, which repeatedly approached a state of expansiveness.

"Mahāvana": Outside the city, connected to the Himalayas, there exists a self-grown forest that remains. Because of its great size, it is called the Great Wood (mahāvana). In that Great Wood.

"Kūṭāgārasālā": In that forest grove, they established a monastery (saṃghārāma).

There, having joined a pinnacle (kaṇṇika) and above the pillars, in brief, like a palace of the gods (devavimāna), they made a mansion (pāsāda). Relying on that, the entire monastery (saṃghārāma) was known as "the Hall with the Peaked Roof (kūṭāgārasālā)."

The Blessed One, depending on that Vesālī, was dwelling in that monastery (saṃghārāma).

Therefore, it was said: "He dwells in Vesālī, in the Great Wood, in the Hall with the Peaked Roof."

"Kosalakā": inhabitants of the Kosala country.

"Māgadhakā": inhabitants of the Magadha country.

"Karaṇīyena": with actions that must necessarily be done.

Indeed, that which is proper even if not done, that is called "kicca"; that which must necessarily be done, that is called "karaṇīya."

mula_pali: 360. Atha kho te kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā yena mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu. Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nāgito bhagavato upaṭṭhāko hoti. Atha kho te kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā yenāyasmā nāgito tenupasaṅkamiṃsu. Upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāgitaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘kahaṃ nu kho, bho nāgita, etarahi so bhavaṃ gotamo viharati? Dassanakāmā hi mayaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotama’’nti. ‘‘Akālo  kho, āvuso, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, paṭisallīno bhagavā’’ti. Atha kho te kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā tattheva ekamantaṃ  nisīdiṃsu – ‘‘disvāva mayaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ gamissāmā’’ti.
mula_english:
And then those Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and Magadha went to the Great Forest, to the Gabled Hall (mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā).

Now at that time, the venerable Nāgita was the Blessed One's (bhagavato) attendant (upaṭṭhāko).

And then those Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and Magadha went to the venerable Nāgita.

Approaching the venerable Nāgita, they said this: "Where now, reverend Nāgita, is the esteemed Gotama staying? For we desire to see the esteemed Gotama."

"It is the wrong time, friend, to see the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ dassanāya); the Blessed One (bhagavā) is in solitary retreat."

And then those Brahmin emissaries from Kosala and Magadha sat down to one side, saying: "Only when we have seen the esteemed Gotama will we go."
commentary_pali: 360.Paṭisallīno bhagavāti nānārammaṇacārato paṭikkamma sallīno nilīno, ekībhāvaṃ upagamma ekattārammaṇe jhānaratiṃ anubhavatīti attho. Tatthevāti tasmiññeva vihāre. Ekamantanti  tasmā ṭhānā apakkamma tāsu tāsu rukkhacchāyāsu nisīdiṃsu.
commentary_english:
The Blessed One, withdrawing from wandering with various objects, secluded and withdrawn, having approached oneness, experiences the delight of absorption with a single object; this is the meaning.

"There itself" means in that very dwelling (*vihāra*).

"To one side" means withdrawing from that place, they sat down in the shade of various trees.

mula_pali: 361. Oṭṭhaddhopi  licchavī mahatiyā licchavīparisāya saddhiṃ yena mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā yenāyasmā nāgito tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāgitaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho oṭṭhaddhopi licchavī āyasmantaṃ nāgitaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘kahaṃ nu kho, bhante nāgita, etarahi so bhagavā viharati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dassanakāmā hi mayaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddha’’nti. ‘‘Akālo kho, mahāli, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, paṭisallīno bhagavā’’ti. Oṭṭhaddhopi licchavī tattheva ekamantaṃ nisīdi – ‘‘disvāva ahaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ gamissāmi arahantaṃ sammāsambuddha’’nti.
mula_english:
361. Then Oṭṭhaddha, the Licchavi, together with a large company of Licchavis, went to the Gabled Hall in the Great Wood, where the venerable Nāgita was. Having approached, he greeted the venerable Nāgita and stood to one side.

Standing to one side, Oṭṭhaddha, the Licchavi, said this to the venerable Nāgita: "Where, venerable Nāgita, is the Blessed One (bhagavā) now staying, the worthy one (arahaṃ), the fully enlightened Buddha (sammāsambuddho)? For we desire to see that Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ), the worthy one (arahantaṃ), the fully enlightened Buddha (sammāsambuddha)."

"It is the wrong time, Mahāli, to see the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ), the Blessed One (bhagavā) is in seclusion."

Oṭṭhaddha, the Licchavi, then sat down to one side, saying: "Only when I have seen that Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ), the worthy one (arahantaṃ), the fully enlightened Buddha (sammāsambuddha), will I go."
commentary_pali: 361.Oṭṭhaddhoti addhoṭṭhatāya evaṃladdhanāmo. Mahatiyā licchavīparisāyāti purebhattaṃ buddhappamukhassa bhikkhusaṅghassa dānaṃ datvā bhagavato santike uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhahitvā gandhamālādīni gāhāpetvā ugghosanāya mahatiṃ licchavirājaparisaṃ sannipātāpetvā tāya nīlapītādivaṇṇavatthābharaṇavilepanapaṭimaṇḍitāya  tāvatiṃsaparisasappaṭibhāgāya mahatiyā licchaviparisāya saddhiṃ upasaṅkami. Akālo kho mahālīti  tassa oṭṭhaddhassa mahālīti mūlanāmaṃ, tena mūlanāmamattena naṃ thero mahālīti ālapati. Ekamantaṃ nisīdīti patirūpāsu rukkhacchāyāsu tāya licchaviparisāya saddhiṃ ratanattayassa vaṇṇaṃ kathayanto nisīdi.
commentary_english:
361. Oṭṭhaddha, because of his being "half-lipped," thus he obtained his name.

"To the great assembly of the Licchavis": Having given alms consisting of the morning meal to the Saṃgha of monks with the Buddha at its head, and having undertaken the *uposatha* vows in the presence of the Blessed One, and having caused perfumes, garlands, and so on to be taken, having convened a great assembly of Licchavi kings for proclamation, adorned with garments, ornaments, and unguents of various colors such as blue and yellow, resembling the assembly of the Tāvatiṃsa gods, he approached the great assembly of the Licchavis.

"It is the wrong time, Mahāli": Mahāli was the original name of Oṭṭhaddha; therefore, the elder addressed him by his original name, Mahāli.

"Sit down on one side": He sat down in a suitable tree shade, and together with that assembly of Licchavis, he sat recounting the virtues of the Triple Gem (*ratnatraya*).

mula_pali: 362. Atha kho sīho samaṇuddeso yenāyasmā nāgito tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nāgitaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sīho samaṇuddeso āyasmantaṃ nāgitaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ete, bhante kassapa, sambahulā kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā idhūpasaṅkantā bhagavantaṃ dassanāya; oṭṭhaddhopi licchavī mahatiyā licchavīparisāya saddhiṃ idhūpasaṅkanto bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, sādhu, bhante kassapa, labhataṃ esā janatā bhagavantaṃ dassanāyā’’ti. ‘‘Tena hi, sīha, tvaññeva bhagavato ārocehī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bhante’’ti kho sīho samaṇuddeso āyasmato nāgitassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ  ṭhito kho sīho samaṇuddeso bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ete, bhante, sambahulā kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā idhūpasaṅkantā bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, oṭṭhaddhopi licchavī mahatiyā licchavīparisāya  saddhiṃ idhūpasaṅkanto bhagavantaṃ dassanāya. Sādhu, bhante, labhataṃ esā janatā bhagavantaṃ dassanāyā’’ti. ‘‘Tena hi, sīha, vihārapacchāyāyaṃ āsanaṃ paññapehī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bhante’’ti kho sīho samaṇuddeso bhagavato paṭissutvā vihārapacchāyāyaṃ āsanaṃ paññapesi.
mula_english:
362. Then the novice Sīha approached the venerable Nāgita; having approached, having greeted the venerable Nāgita, he stood to one side.

Standing to one side, the novice Sīha said this to the venerable Nāgita: "Venerable sir, these many *brāhmaṇa* emissaries from Kosala and *brāhmaṇa* emissaries from Magadha have come here to see the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ darśanāya); Otthaddha the Licchavi, too, has come with a large company of Licchavis to see the Blessed One. It would be well, venerable Kassapa, if this populace might be allowed to see the Blessed One."

"Well then, Sīha, you yourself announce them to the Blessed One."

"Yes, venerable sir," said the novice Sīha in reply to the venerable Nāgita; then he approached the Blessed One; having approached, having greeted the Blessed One, he stood to one side.

Standing to one side, the novice Sīha said this to the Blessed One: "Venerable sir, these many *brāhmaṇa* emissaries from Kosala and *brāhmaṇa* emissaries from Magadha have come here to see the Blessed One; Otthaddha the Licchavi, too, has come with a large company of Licchavis to see the Blessed One.

It would be well, venerable sir, if this populace might be allowed to see the Blessed One."

"Well then, Sīha, prepare a seat in the shade of the dwelling (vihārapacchāyāyaṃ āsanaṃ paññapehi)."

"Yes, venerable sir," said the novice Sīha in reply to the Blessed One; then he prepared a seat in the shade of the dwelling.
commentary_pali: 362.Sīho samaṇuddesoti āyasmato nāgitassa bhāgineyyo sattavassakāle pabbajitvā sāsane yuttapayutto ‘‘sīho’’ti evaṃnāmako sāmaṇero, so kira taṃ mahāparisaṃ disvā – ‘‘ayaṃ parisā mahatī, sakalaṃ vihāraṃ pūretvā nisinnā, addhā bhagavā ajja imissā parisāya mahantena ussāhena dhammaṃ desessati, yaṃnūnāhaṃ upajjhāyassācikkhitvā bhagavato mahāparisāya sannipatitabhāvaṃ ārocāpeyya’’nti cintetvā yenāyasmā nāgito tenupasaṅkami. Bhante kassapāti theraṃ gottena ālapati. Esā janatāti eso janasamūho. Tvaññeva bhagavato ārocehīti sīho kira bhagavato vissāsiko, ayañhi thero thūlasarīro, tenassa sarīragarutāya uṭṭhānanisajjādīsu ālasiyabhāvo īsakaṃ appahīno viya hoti. Athāyaṃ sāmaṇero bhagavato kālena kālaṃ vattaṃ karoti. Tena naṃ thero ‘‘tvampi dasabalassa vissāsiko’’ti vatvā gaccha tvaññevārocehīti āha. Vihārapacchāyāyanti vihārachāyāyaṃ, kūṭāgāramahāgehacchāyāya pharitokāseti attho. Sā kira kūṭāgārasālā dakkhiṇuttarato  dīghā pācīnamukhā, tenassā purato mahatī chāyā patthaṭā hoti, sīho tattha bhagavato āsanaṃ paññapesi.
commentary_english:
362.

Sīha was a novice ( *sāmaṇuddesa*) named Sīha, the nephew (*bhāgineyya*) of the venerable Nāgita. He had gone forth at the age of seven, diligently applying himself to the teachings (*sāsana*). Seeing that large assembly (*mahāparisa*) he thought, "This assembly is large, filling the entire monastery (*vihāra*) as they are seated. Surely today, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*) will teach the Dharma (*dhamma*) to this assembly with great enthusiasm (*ussāha*). Why don't I inform my preceptor (*upajjhāya*) and announce the gathering of the great assembly of the Blessed One?" Thinking this, he approached the venerable Nāgita.

"Venerable Kassapa," he addressed the elder (*thera*) by his clan (*gotta*).

"This is a crowd (*janatā*)," meaning, "This is a multitude of people (*janasamūho*)."

"You yourself should announce it to the Blessed One." Sīha was, it seems, trusted (*vissāsika*) by the Blessed One. Furthermore, this elder was stout (*thūlasarīra*), so due to the heaviness (*garutā*) of his body, his laziness (*ālasiyabhāvo*) in rising, sitting, and so on, was not easily overcome, it seemed.

Then this novice (*sāmaṇera*) performed his duties (*vattaṃ karoti*) for the Blessed One at the proper times (*kālena kālaṃ*).

Therefore, the elder said to him, "You too are trusted by the Ten-Powered One (*dasabala*)." Saying this, he said, "Go, you yourself should announce it."

"Vihārapacchāyāyanti" means "in the shadow (*chāyā*) of the monastery (*vihāra*)", meaning "in the open space shaded by the shadow of the upper room (*kūṭāgāra*) or great house (*mahāgeha*)".

It seems that hall (*sālā*) with an upper room (*kūṭāgāra*) was long from south to north and faced east (*pācīnamukhā*), therefore a great shadow (*mahatī chāyā*) stretched out in front of it. There, Sīha prepared a seat (*āsanaṃ paññapesi*) for the Blessed One.

mula_pali: 363. Atha  kho bhagavā vihārā nikkhamma vihārapacchāyāyaṃ paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho te kosalakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā māgadhakā ca brāhmaṇadūtā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā  ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Oṭṭhaddhopi licchavī mahatiyā licchavīparisāya saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mula_english:
Then, the Blessed One, emerging from his dwelling, sat down on a prepared seat in the shade of the dwelling.

Then, the Kosalan and Magadhan Brahmin messengers approached the Blessed One; having approached, they exchanged greetings with the Blessed One.

Having concluded their conversation of courteous greetings, they sat down to one side.

Then Oṭṭhaddha, the Licchavi, together with a large assembly of Licchavis, approached the Blessed One; having approached, he paid homage to the Blessed One and sat down to one side.
commentary_pali: 363. Atha kho bhagavā dvārantarehi ceva vātapānantarehi ca nikkhamitvā vidhāvantāhi vippharantīhi chabbaṇṇāhi buddharasmīhi saṃsūcitanikkhamano valāhakantarato puṇṇacando viya kūṭāgārasālato nikkhamitvā paññattavarabuddhāsane nisīdi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā vihārā nikkhamma vihārapacchāyāya paññatte āsane nisīdī’’ti.
commentary_english:
363. Then, the Blessed One, having exited through the openings between the doors and windows, his exit heralded by the six-colored rays of the Buddha ( *buddharasmi* ) darting and flashing about, like the full moon (*pūrṇacandra*) from behind the clouds, having emerged from the hall of the peaked house, sat down on the excellent Buddha-seat (*paññattavarabuddhāsana*) prepared for him.

Therefore, it was said: "Then, the Blessed One, having left the monastery (*vihāra*), sat down on the seat (*āsana*) prepared in the shadow of the monastery (*vihārapacchāyā*)."

mula_pali: 364. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho oṭṭhaddho licchavī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni sunakkhatto licchaviputto yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ etadavoca – ‘yadagge ahaṃ, mahāli, bhagavantaṃ upanissāya viharāmi, na ciraṃ tīṇi vassāni, dibbāni hi kho rūpāni passāmi piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, no ca kho dibbāni saddāni suṇāmi piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyānī’ti. Santāneva nu kho, bhante, sunakkhatto licchaviputto dibbāni saddāni nāssosi  piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, udāhu asantānī’’ti?
mula_english:
364.

Then Oṭṭhaddha the Licchavi, having sat down to one side, said this to the Blessed One: "Some days ago, venerable sir, Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son came to me, and having come, said this to me: 'Since the time I have been living in dependence on the Blessed One, not long—three years—I have seen heavenly forms (divyāni rūpāṇi), which are pleasing forms (piyarūpāṇi), connected with sensual pleasure (kāmūpasaṃhitāni), and delightful (rajanīyāni), but I have not heard heavenly sounds (dibbāni saddāni) which are pleasing forms (piyarūpāṇi), connected with sensual pleasure (kāmūpasaṃhitāni), and delightful (rajanīyāni).'

"Now, venerable sir, are there in reality such heavenly sounds (dibbāni saddāni) which Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son has not heard, which are pleasing forms (piyarūpāṇi), connected with sensual pleasure (kāmūpasaṃhitāni), and delightful (rajanīyāni), or are there not?"
commentary_pali: 364-365.Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarānīti ettha hiyyo divasaṃ purimaṃ nāma, tato paraṃ purimataraṃ. Tato paṭṭhāya pana sabbāni purimāni ceva purimatarāni ca honti. Yadaggeti mūladivasato paṭṭhāya yaṃ divasaṃ aggaṃ parakoṭiṃ katvā viharāmīti attho, yāva vihāsinti vuttaṃ hoti. Idāni tassa parimāṇaṃ dassento ‘‘naciraṃ tīṇi vassānī’’ti āha. Atha vā yadaggeti yaṃ divasaṃ aggaṃ katvā naciraṃ tīṇi vassāni viharāmītipi attho . Yaṃ divasaṃ ādiṃ katvā naciraṃ vihāsiṃ tīṇiyeva vassānīti vuttaṃ hoti. Ayaṃ kira bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ gaṇhanto tīṇi saṃvaccharāni bhagavantaṃ upaṭṭhāsi, taṃ sandhāya evaṃ vadati. Piyarūpānīti piyajātikāni sātajātikāni. Kāmūpasaṃhitānīti kāmassādayuttāni. Rajanīyānīti rāgajanakāni. No ca kho dibbāni saddānīti kasmā sunakkhatto tāni na suṇāti? So kira bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dibbacakkhuparikammaṃ yāci, tassa bhagavā ācikkhi, so yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipanno dibbacakkhuṃ uppādetvā devatānaṃ rūpāni disvā cintesi ‘‘imasmiṃ sarīrasaṇṭhāne saddena madhurena bhavitabbaṃ, kathaṃ nu kho naṃ suṇeyya’’nti bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dibbasotaparikammaṃ pucchi. Ayañca atīte ekaṃ sīlavantaṃ bhikkhuṃ kaṇṇasakkhaliyaṃ paharitvā  badhiramakāsi. Tasmā parikammaṃ karontopi abhabbo dibbasotādhigamāya. Tenassa na bhagavā parikammaṃ kathesi. So ettāvatā bhagavati āghātaṃ bandhitvā cintesi – ‘‘addhā samaṇassa gotamassa evaṃ hoti – ‘ahampi khattiyo ayampi khattiyo, sacassa ñāṇaṃ vaḍḍhissati, ayampi sabbaññū bhavissatī’ti usūyāya mayhaṃ na kathesī’’ti. So anukkamena gihibhāvaṃ patvā tamatthaṃ mahālilicchavino kathento evamāha.
commentary_english:
364-365. “*Purimāni*, *bhante*, *divasāni purimatarānīti*”—here, "yesterday" (*hiyyo divasaṃ*) is called "*purimaṃ*", and after that, "*purimataraṃ*."
From that point onwards, however, all are both "*purimāni* *ceva* " and "*purimatarāni* *ca* " .
The meaning of "*yadaggeti*" is: from the original day, making that day the most excellent, having spent the ultimate limit, I lived (*mūladivasato paṭṭhāya yaṃ divasaṃ aggaṃ parakoṭiṃ katvā viharāmīti attho*), so it is said, “as long as I lived (*yāva vihāsinti vuttaṃ hoti*)."
Now, showing its extent, he said, "Not long, three years (*naciraṃ tīṇi vassānīti āha*)."
Or, alternatively, the meaning of "*yadaggeti*" is: making that day the most excellent, not long, I lived three years (*yaṃ divasaṃ aggaṃ katvā naciraṃ tīṇi vassāni viharāmītipi attho*).
It is said, "Making that day the beginning, not long, I lived only three years (*yaṃ divasaṃ ādiṃ katvā naciraṃ vihāsiṃ tīṇiyeva vassānīti vuttaṃ hoti*)."
It is said that this person, taking the bowl-robe of the Blessed One (*ayaṃ kira bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ gaṇhanto*), attended upon the Blessed One for three years (*tīṇi saṃvaccharāni bhagavantaṃ upaṭṭhāsi*), referring to that, he speaks thus (*taṃ sandhāya evaṃ vadati*).
"*Piyarūpānīti*" means having a beloved nature (*piyajātikāni*), having a pleasant nature (*sātajātikāni*).
"*Kāmūpasaṃhitānīti*" means joined with the taste of desire (*kāmassādayuttāni*).
"*Rajanīyānīti*" means producing passion (*rāgajanakāni*).
But why does Sunakkhatta not hear the divine sounds (*no ca kho dibbāni saddānīti kasmā sunakkhatto tāni na suṇāti*)? It is said that he approached the Blessed One and asked for the preliminary act for the divine eye (*so kira bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dibbacakkhuparikammaṃ yāci*), the Blessed One told him (*tassa bhagavā ācikkhi*), he, practicing according to the instruction (*so yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipanno*), having produced the divine eye (*dibbacakkhuṃ uppādetvā*), seeing the forms of the deities (*devatānaṃ rūpāni disvā*), thought, “In this bodily formation, there must be sweet sounds (*imasmiṃ sarīrasaṇṭhāne saddena madhurena bhavitabbaṃ*), how then could I hear them (*kathaṃ nu kho naṃ suṇeyya*)?” Approaching the Blessed One, he asked about the preliminary act for the divine ear (*bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dibbasotaparikammaṃ pucchi*).
And in the past, he struck a virtuous *bhikkhu* on the ear-hole (*ayañca atīte ekaṃ sīlavantaṃ bhikkhuṃ kaṇṇasakkhaliyaṃ paharitvā*), making him deaf (*badhiramakāsi*).
Therefore, even doing the preliminary act (*tasmā parikammaṃ karontopi*), he is incapable of attaining the divine ear (*abhabbo dibbasotādhigamāya*).
Therefore, the Blessed One did not tell him the preliminary act (*tenassa na bhagavā parikammaṃ kathesi*).
He, thus harboring resentment towards the Blessed One (*so ettāvatā bhagavati āghātaṃ bandhitvā*), thought, “Indeed, it is like this for the *samaṇa* Gotama (*cintesi – addhā samaṇassa gotamassa evaṃ hoti*)—'I am also a *khattiya*, and he is also a *khattiya* (*ahampi khattiyo ayampi khattiyo*), if his knowledge increases (*sacassa ñāṇaṃ vaḍḍhissati*), he also will become all-knowing (*ayampi sabbaññū bhavissatī’ti*)’—out of envy, he did not tell me (*usūyāya mayhaṃ na kathesī’’ti*)."
He, gradually attaining the state of a householder (*so anukkamena gihibhāvaṃ patvā*), while telling that matter to the great Licchavi (*tamatthaṃ mahālilicchavino kathento*), spoke thus (*evamāha*).

mula_pali: 365. ‘‘Santāneva kho, mahāli, sunakkhatto licchaviputto dibbāni saddāni nāssosi piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, no asantānī’’ti. ‘‘Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena santāneva sunakkhatto licchaviputto dibbāni saddāni nāssosi piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, no asantānī’’ti?
mula_english:
‘There are such sounds, Mahāli, that Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son does not hear, which are heavenly sounds, pleasant, delightful, enticing, and not the opposite.’

‘Then, Lord, what is the reason (hetu), what is the cause (paccayo) why Sunakkhatta the Licchavi's son does not hear those heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, delightful, enticing, and not the opposite?'

commentary_english:
364-365. "Earlier, venerable sir, the days were earlier," means that yesterday was called 'earlier', and the day before that, 'more earlier'.

From then on, however, all days are both 'earlier' and 'more earlier'.

"Yadaggeti" means: "From the root day onwards, the day I made the best, the highest point, living," this is the meaning; it is said to mean "as long as I lived."

Now, showing its extent, he said, "Not long, three years."

Or, "Yadaggeti" means: "The day I made the best, not long, three years I lived," this is also the meaning.

"The day I made the beginning, not long I lived, just three years," this is said to be the meaning.

This one, it is said, taking the bowl and robe of the Blessed One, attended upon the Blessed One for three years. Referring to that, he speaks thus.

"Piyarūpānīti" means things are "of a beloved nature" and "of a pleasant nature."

"Kāmūpasaṃhitānīti" means things "connected with the taste of desire."

"Rajanīyānīti" means things "generating passion (rāga)."

"No ca kho dibbāni saddānīti," but not heavenly sounds, why does Sunakkhatta not hear them? It is said that he approached the Blessed One and asked for the preliminary work (parikamma) for the divine eye (divyacakṣus). The Blessed One told him. He, practicing according to the instruction, having produced the divine eye, seeing the forms of the deities, thought, "In this bodily structure, there must be sweet sounds; how now can I hear them?" Approaching the Blessed One, he asked about the preliminary work (parikamma) for the divine ear (divyasrotra).

And this one, in the past, striking a virtuous monk on the ear socket (karṇasakkhaliya), made him deaf (badhira).

Therefore, even doing the preliminary work (parikamma), he is incapable (abhabbo) of attaining the divine ear (divyasrota).

Therefore, the Blessed One did not tell him the preliminary work (parikamma).

He, thus, harboring malice (āghātaṃ) toward the Blessed One, thought, "Truly, Samaṇa Gotama thinks thus: 'I am also a Kṣatriya, and this one is also a Kṣatriya. If his knowledge increases, this one will also become all-knowing (sarvajñū),' out of envy (īrṣyā), he did not tell me."

He, gradually attaining the state of a householder (gihibhāvaṃ), telling that matter to the Mahāli Licchavi, spoke thus.

So puratthimāya disāya ekaṃsabhāvite samādhimhi dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ, no ca kho dibbānaṃ saddānaṃ savanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ. Puratthimāya disāya dibbāni rūpāni passati piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, no ca kho dibbāni saddāni suṇāti piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni. Taṃ kissa hetu? Evañhetaṃ, mahāli, hoti bhikkhuno  puratthimāya disāya ekaṃsabhāvite samādhimhi dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ, no ca kho dibbānaṃ saddānaṃ savanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ.
mula_english:
366.

‘Here, Mahāli, a monk, facing east, develops a one-sided *samādhi* (concentration) for seeing heavenly forms (*dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ*), which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, but not for hearing heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing.

From the east, he sees heavenly forms (*dibbāni rūpāni*), which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, but does not hear heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing.

What is the reason for that? Because this is how it is, Mahāli, for a monk: facing east, in one-sided developed *samādhi*, he sees heavenly forms (*dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ*), which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, but does not hear heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing.

Ubhayaṃsabhāvitoti ubhayaṃsāya ubhayakoṭṭhāsāya bhāvitoti attho. Ayaṃ kho mahāli hetūti ayaṃ dibbānaṃyeva rūpānaṃ dassanāya ekaṃsabhāvito samādhi hetu. commentary_english:
366-371.
*Ekaṃsabhāvito* means cultivated for one portion, for one division. It is cultivated for the sake of seeing divine forms or for the sake of hearing divine sounds; this is the meaning.

They go sideways in all directions.

*Ubhayaṃsabhāvito* means cultivated for both portions, for both divisions; this is the meaning.

"This, Mahāli, is the cause" means this concentration (*samādhi*) cultivated for one portion, just for the sake of seeing divine forms, is the cause.

Having heard this matter, that Licchavi thought: "This hearing of sounds with the divine ear, I think, is the highest attainment in this dispensation. Surely for this purpose these monks live the undefiled holy life for fifty or sixty years. Why don't I ask the Ten-Powered One about this matter?"

mula_english:
Again, Mahāli, a monk facing south… and so on… west… north… upwards, downwards, or across, cultivates one-sided concentration (ekaṃsabhāvito samādhi). This *samādhi* leads to the seeing of heavenly sights (dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanāya), which are pleasant (piyarūpānaṃ), connected with sensual pleasure (kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ), and enticing (rajanīyānaṃ), but not to the hearing of heavenly sounds (dibbānaṃ saddānaṃ savanāya) that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing.

He, upwards, downwards, or across, in that one-sided cultivated concentration (*ekaṃsabhāvite samādhimhi*), sees heavenly sights (dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanāya) that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing, but does not hear heavenly sounds that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing.

Upwards, downwards, or across, he sees heavenly sights (dibbāni rūpāni passati) that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing, but does not hear heavenly sounds (dibbāni saddāni suṇāti) that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing.

What is the reason for this (taṃ kissa hetu)? It is because of this, Mahāli, that for a monk, upwards, downwards, or across, in that one-sided cultivated concentration (*ekaṃsabhāvite samādhimhi*), there is the seeing of heavenly sights (dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanāya) that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing, but not the hearing of heavenly sounds (dibbānaṃ saddānaṃ savanāya) that are pleasant, connected with sensual pleasure, and enticing.

Ubhayaṃsabhāvitoti ubhayaṃsāya ubhayakoṭṭhāsāya bhāvitoti attho. Ayaṃ kho mahāli hetūti ayaṃ dibbānaṃyeva rūpānaṃ dassanāya ekaṃsabhāvito samādhi hetu. Imamatthaṃ sutvā so licchavī cintesi – ‘‘idaṃ dibbasotena saddasuṇanaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane uttamatthabhūtaṃ maññe imassa nūna atthāya ete  bhikkhū paññāsampi saṭṭhipi vassāni apaṇṇakaṃ brahmacariyaṃ caranti, yaṃnūnāhaṃ dasabalaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyya’’nti.
commentary_english:
366-371.

*Ekaṃsabhāvito* means brought into being in a one-sided way, brought into being for one portion or aspect, that is, brought into being for the purpose of seeing divine forms or hearing divine sounds; this is the meaning.

They spread out in all directions (*anudisāya*).

*Ubhayaṃsabhāvito* means brought into being in a two-sided way, brought into being for two portions or aspects; this is the meaning.

"This, indeed, Mahāli, is the cause" means this one-sided concentration (*samādhi*) that is brought into being just for the sight of divine forms is the cause (*hetu*).

Having heard this matter, that Licchavi thought: "This hearing of sounds with the divine ear, I consider it to be the highest attainment in this doctrine. Surely, for this purpose, these monks live the undefiled Brahmachariya for fifty or sixty years. Why don't I ask the Ten-Powered One (*dasabala*) about this matter?"

mula_english:
368.
"Here, Mahāli, a monk, with regard to the eastern direction, develops one-sided *samādhi* (concentration) for hearing celestial sounds, which are pleasant, delightful, enticing, but not for seeing celestial sights, which are pleasant, delightful, enticing.

commentary_english:
366-371.

Again, Mahāli, a monk, facing south… west… north… upwards, downwards, or across, cultivates one-sided *samādhi* (ekaṃsabhāvito samādhi) for hearing heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing, but not for seeing heavenly sights, which are pleasant, delightful, and enticing.

commentary_english:
366-371.

*Ekaṃsabhāvito* means cultivated through a single portion or constituent (*ekaṃsāya ekakoṭṭhāsāya bhāvito*), that is, cultivated for the purpose of seeing divine forms (*dibbānaṃ rūpānaṃ dassanatthāya*) or for the purpose of hearing divine sounds (*dibbānaṃ saddānaṃ savanatthāya*).

mula_english:
370.

"Here, Mahāli, a monk facing east enters into two-sided *samādhi*, and both sees heavenly forms (*divyāni rūpāṇi*), pleasing forms, connected with desire, enticing, and hears heavenly sounds (*divyāni śabdāni*), pleasing sounds, connected with desire, enticing.

366-371.

So uddhamadho tiriyaṃ ubhayaṃsabhāvite samādhimhi dibbānañca rūpānaṃ dassanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ dibbānañca saddānaṃ savanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ. Uddhamadho tiriyaṃ dibbāni ca rūpāni passati piyarūpāni  kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, dibbāni ca saddāni suṇāti piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni. Taṃ kissa hetu? Evañhetaṃ, mahāli, hoti bhikkhuno uddhamadho tiriyaṃ ubhayaṃsabhāvite samādhimhi dibbānañca rūpānaṃ dassanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ, dibbānañca saddānaṃ savanāya piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ. Ayaṃ kho mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena santāneva sunakkhatto licchaviputto dibbāni saddāni nāssosi piyarūpāni kāmūpasaṃhitāni rajanīyāni, no asantānī’’ti.
mula_english:
371. Furthermore, Mahāli, a *bhikkhu* (monk) in the southern direction…etc… western direction… northern direction… upwards, downwards, and across, develops a two-sided *samādhi* (concentration) for the sight of heavenly forms (*divyānāṃ rūpāṇāṃ darśanāya*), which are pleasant (*piyarūpānaṃ*), associated with desire (*kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ*), and delightful (*rajanīyānaṃ*), and for the hearing of heavenly sounds (*divyānāṃ saddānaṃ śravaṇāya*), which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful.

He, upwards, downwards, and across, in that two-sided *samādhi* (concentration), for the sight of heavenly forms, which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful, and for the hearing of heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful.

Upwards, downwards, and across, he sees heavenly forms, which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful, and he hears heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful.

What is the reason for that? Because, Mahāli, it happens that a *bhikkhu* (monk) upwards, downwards, and across, develops a two-sided *samādhi* (concentration) for the sight of heavenly forms, which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful, and for the hearing of heavenly sounds, which are pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful.

This, Mahāli, is the cause (*hetu*), this is the condition (*paccayo*), by which Sunakkhatta, the Licchavi son, while present, did not hear heavenly sounds that were pleasant, associated with desire, and delightful, but not when absent."
commentary_pali: 366-371.Ekaṃsabhāvitoti ekaṃsāya ekakoṭṭhāsāya bhāvito, dibbānaṃ vā rūpānaṃ dassanatthāya dibbānaṃ vā saddānaṃ savanatthāya bhāvitoti attho. Tiriyanti anudisāya. Ubhayaṃsabhāvitoti ubhayaṃsāya ubhayakoṭṭhāsāya bhāvitoti attho. Ayaṃ kho mahāli hetūti ayaṃ dibbānaṃyeva rūpānaṃ dassanāya ekaṃsabhāvito samādhi hetu. Imamatthaṃ sutvā so licchavī cintesi – ‘‘idaṃ dibbasotena saddasuṇanaṃ imasmiṃ sāsane uttamatthabhūtaṃ maññe imassa nūna atthāya ete  bhikkhū paññāsampi saṭṭhipi vassāni apaṇṇakaṃ brahmacariyaṃ caranti, yaṃnūnāhaṃ dasabalaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyya’’nti.
commentary_english:
366-371.
*Ekaṃsabhāvito* means cultivated in a single portion, in one division; or cultivated for the sake of seeing divine forms (*divyānāṃ rūpāṇāṃ darśanatthāya*), or cultivated for the sake of hearing divine sounds (*divyānāṃ vā śabdānāṃ śravaṇatthāya*). This is the meaning (*attho*).
They spread in all directions (*tiriyanti anudisāya*).
*Ubhayaṃsabhāvito* means cultivated in a double portion, in a double division. This is the meaning.
"This, Mahāli, is the cause" (*ayaṃ kho mahāli hetūti*) means this concentration (*samādhi*) cultivated in one portion for the sake of seeing divine forms only (*divyānāṃyeva rūpānaṃ dassanāya*) is a cause (*hetu*).
Having heard this matter, that Licchavi thought: “This hearing of sounds with the divine ear (*dibbasotena saddasuṇanaṃ*) in this teaching (*sāsane*), I consider to be the highest attainment (*uttamatthabhūtaṃ maññe*). Surely, for this purpose, these monks (*bhikkhū*) live the undefiled (*apaṇṇakaṃ*) holy life (*brahmacariyaṃ caranti*) for fifty or sixty years. Why don't I ask the Ten-Powered One (*dasabalaṃ*) about this matter (*etamatthaṃ puccheyya*)?”

mula_pali: 372. ‘‘Etāsaṃ nūna, bhante, samādhibhāvanānaṃ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carantī’’ti. ‘‘Na kho, mahāli, etāsaṃ samādhibhāvanānaṃ sacchikiriyāhetu  bhikkhū mayi  brahmacariyaṃ caranti. Atthi kho, mahāli, aññeva dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca, yesaṃ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṃ carantī’’ti.
mula_english:
“Surely, venerable sir, it is for the sake of the direct realization (sacchikiriyāhetu) of such cultivation of *samādhi* states (*samādhibhāvanānaṃ*) that monks lead the holy life (*brahmacariyaṃ caranti*) under the Blessed One (bhagavati)?”

“No, Mahali, it is not for the sake of the direct realization (sacchikiriyāhetu) of such cultivation of *samādhi* states (*samādhibhāvanānaṃ*) that monks lead the holy life (*brahmacariyaṃ caranti*) under me.”

“There are other states (dhammā), Mahali, higher (uttaritarā) and more sublime (paṇītatarā), for the sake of the direct realization (sacchikiriyāhetu) of which monks lead the holy life (*brahmacariyaṃ caranti*) under me.”
commentary_pali: 372. Tato tamatthaṃ pucchanto ‘‘etāsaṃ nūna, bhante’’tiādimāha. Samādhibhāvanānanti ettha samādhiyeva samādhibhāvanā, ubhayaṃsabhāvitānaṃ samādhīnanti attho. Atha yasmā sāsanato bāhirā etā samādhibhāvanā, na ajjhattikā. Tasmā tā paṭikkhipitvā yadatthaṃ bhikkhū brahmacariyaṃ caranti, taṃ dassento bhagavā ‘‘na kho mahālī’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
372.
Then, questioning about that matter, he said, "Indeed, are these, venerable sir," and so on.

*Samādhibhāvanānaṃ* means here that *samādhi* itself is *samādhibhāvanā*; the meaning is "of *samādhis* cultivated by both aspects."

Now, because these *samādhi-bhāvanās* are external to the teaching (*śāsana*), they are not internal (*ādhyātmika*).

Therefore, having rejected those, the Blessed One, showing the purpose for which the monks (*bhikkhū*) lead the holy life (*brahmacariya*), said, "It is not, indeed, Mahali," and so on.

mula_pali: 373. ‘‘Katame pana te, bhante, dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca, yesaṃ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carantī’’ti? ‘‘Idha, mahāli, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo. Ayampi kho, mahāli, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro  ca, yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṃ caranti. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahāli, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva sakiṃdeva (ka.) imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti. Ayampi kho, mahāli, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca, yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṃ caranti. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahāli, bhikkhu pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti, tattha parinibbāyī, anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā. Ayampi kho, mahāli, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca, yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṃ caranti. ‘‘Puna  caparaṃ, mahāli, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati. Ayampi kho, mahāli, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca, yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṃ caranti. Ime kho te, mahāli, dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca, yesaṃ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṃ carantī’’ti.
mula_english:
“But what, venerable sir, are those states that are higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under the Blessed One?”

“Here, Mahāli, a monk, with the utter destruction of the three fetters, is a stream-enterer, ( *sotāpanna* ) not liable to fall away, assured, destined for enlightenment. This, too, Mahāli, is a state higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me.

“Again, Mahāli, a monk, with the utter destruction of the three fetters, and with the lessening of greed, hatred, and delusion, is a once-returner, ( *sakadāgāmī* ) who, on returning only once more to this world, will make an end of suffering. This, too, Mahāli, is a state higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me.

“Again, Mahāli, a monk, with the utter destruction of the five lower fetters, is one who arises spontaneously (in the Pure Abodes), ( *opapātika* ) there to attain final *Nirvāṇa*, not liable to return from that world. This, too, Mahāli, is a state higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me.

“Again, Mahāli, a monk, with the destruction of the defilements, has realized here and now with his own insight the undefiled deliverance of mind, deliverance through wisdom, and abides (therein). This, too, Mahāli, is a state higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me.

“These, Mahāli, are those states that are higher and more sublime, for the sake of realizing which monks lead the holy life under me.”
commentary_pali: 373.Tiṇṇaṃsaṃyojanānanti sakkāyadiṭṭhiādīnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ bandhanānaṃ. Tāni hi vaṭṭadukkhamaye rathe satte saṃyojenti, tasmā saṃyojanānīti vuccanti. Sotāpannohotīti maggasotaṃ āpanno hoti. Avinipātadhammoti catūsu apāyesu apatanadhammo. Niyatoti dhammaniyāmena niyato. Sambodhiparāyaṇoti uparimaggattayasaṅkhātā sambodhi paraṃ ayanaṃ assa, anena vā pattabbāti sambodhiparāyaṇo. Tanuttāti pariyuṭṭhānamandatāya ca kadāci karahaci uppattiyā ca tanubhāvā. Orambhāgiyānanti heṭṭhābhāgiyānaṃ, ye hi baddho upari suddhāvāsabhūmiyaṃ nibbattituṃ na sakkoti. Opapātikoti sesayonipaṭikkhepavacanametaṃ. Tattha parinibbāyīti tasmiṃ uparibhaveyeva parinibbānadhammo. Anāvattidhammoti tato brahmalokā puna paṭisandhivasena anāvattanadhammo. Cetovimuttinti cittavisuddhiṃ, sabbakilesabandhanavimuttassa arahattaphalacittassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Paññāvimuttinti etthāpi sabbakilesabandhanavimuttā arahattaphalapaññāva paññāvimuttīti veditabbā. Diṭṭheva dhammeti imasmiṃyeva attabhāve. Sayanti sāmaṃ. Abhiññāti abhijānitvā. Sacchikatvāti paccakkhaṃ katvā. Atha vā abhiññā sacchikatvāti abhiññāya abhivisiṭṭhena ñāṇena sacchikaritvātipi attho. Upasampajjāti patvā paṭilabhitvā. Idaṃ sutvā licchavirājā cintesi – ‘‘ayaṃ pana dhammo na sakuṇena viya uppatitvā, nāpi godhāya viya urena gantvā sakkā paṭivijjhituṃ , addhā pana imaṃ paṭivijjhantassa pubbabhāgappaṭipadāya bhavitabbaṃ, pucchāmi tāva na’’nti.
commentary_english:
373. *Tiṇṇaṃsaṃyojanānanti* means the three fetters (*bandhana*) are the view of self (*sakkāyadiṭṭhi*) and so forth.

Those bind (*saṃyojenti*) beings in a chariot made of the suffering of the round (*vaṭṭadukkhamaye rathe satte*); therefore, they are called fetters (*saṃyojanānīti vuccanti*).

*Sotāpannohotīti* means he is one who has entered the stream of the path (*maggasotaṃ āpanno hoti*).

*Avinipātadhammoti* means his nature is not to fall into the four woeful states (*catūsu apāyesu apatanadhammo*).

*Niyatoti* means he is certain by the certainty of the Dharma (*dhammaniyāmena niyato*).

*Sambodhiparāyaṇoti* means the highest awakening (*sambodhi*) is his final aim (*paraṃ ayanaṃ assa*), that is to say, the awakening (*sambodhi*) is to be attained (*pattabbāti*) by the three superior paths enumerated (*uparimaggattayasaṅkhātā*); therefore, he is one who has awakening as his final aim (*sambodhiparāyaṇo*).

*Tanuttāti* means due to the slowness of their arising (*pariyuṭṭhānamandatāya*) and due to their occasional appearance (*kadāci karahaci uppattiyā ca*), they are of a subtle nature (*tanubhāvā*).

*Orambhāgiyānanti* means those pertaining to the lower realms (*heṭṭhābhāgiyānaṃ*), for he who is bound (*baddho*) is not able (*na sakkoti*) to be reborn (*nibbattituṃ*) in the Pure Abodes (*suddhāvāsabhūmiyaṃ*) above (*upari*).

*Opapātikoti* means this is a statement rejecting the remaining wombs (*sesayonipaṭikkhepavacanametaṃ*).

*Tattha parinibbāyīti* means in that existence itself, there is the cessation of becoming (*tasmiṃ uparibhaveyeva parinibbānadhammo*).

*Anāvattidhammoti* means from that Brahma world (*brahmalokā*) he does not return (*anāvattanadhammo*) again by way of rebirth (*paṭisandhivasena*).

*Cetovimuttinti* means liberation of mind (*cittavisuddhiṃ*); this is a designation (*adhivacanaṃ*) for the mind (*cittassa*) that is the fruit of Arhatship (*arahattaphala*) and is liberated (*vimuttassa*) from all the bonds of defilements (*sabbakilesabandhana*).

*Paññāvimuttinti* means here also, it should be understood (*veditabbā*) that liberation by wisdom (*paññāvimuttīti*) is the wisdom (*paññāva*) that is the fruit of Arhatship (*arahattaphala*) and is liberated (*vimuttā*) from all the bonds of defilements (*sabbakilesabandhana*).

*Diṭṭheva dhammeti* means in this very existence (*imasmiṃyeva attabhāve*).

They lie down themselves (*sayanti sāmaṃ*).

*Abhiññāti* means having directly known (*abhijānitvā*).

*Sacchikatvāti* means having made it visible (*paccakkhaṃ katvā*).

Or alternatively, *abhiññā sacchikatvāti* means having realized directly (*sacchikaritvātipi*) with knowledge (*ñāṇena*) that is superior (*abhivisiṭṭhena*) to direct knowledge (*abhiññāya*); this is the meaning (*attho*).

*Upasampajjāti* means having attained (*patvā*) and having received (*paṭilabhitvā*).

Having heard this, the Licchavi king thought (*idaṃ sutvā licchavirājā cintesi*) – “This teaching (*ayaṃ pana dhammo*) cannot (*na sakkā*) be penetrated (*paṭivijjhituṃ*) by flying up (*uppatitvā*) like a bird (*sakuṇena viya*), nor (*nāpi*) by going with the chest (*urena gantvā*) like a monitor lizard (*godhāya viya*). Indeed (*addhā pana*), for one penetrating this (*imaṃ paṭivijjhantassa*), there must be a preliminary practice (*pubbabhāgappaṭipadāya bhavitabbaṃ*). I will ask (*pucchāmi*), then.” (*tāva na’’nti*).
