Tato punadeva so cintesi ‘‘sudūrampi gantvā satthu santikeva nikkaṅkho bhavissati . Atthi ceva puggalo nāmesa, thokaṃ tāva āhiṇḍanto kilamatu pacchā jānissatī’’ti. Tato taṃ ‘‘ahampi kho’’tiādimāha. Brahmayāniyopi devayāniyasadisova. Devayāniyamaggoti vā brahmayāniyamaggoti vā dhammasetūti vā ekacittakkhaṇikaappanāti vā sanniṭṭhānikacetanāti vā mahaggatacittanti vā abhiññāñāṇanti vā sabbametaṃ iddhividhañāṇasseva nāmaṃ.
commentary_english:
491-493. Now, regarding the distinction, Śakra, the lord of the gods, thought: “This question is within the Buddha's domain; it cannot be answered by anyone else. And this *bhikṣu* (monk), abandoning the fire, fans a firefly; abandoning the drum, plays on his belly; in the world, abandoning the foremost person, the *sammāsambuddha* (perfectly enlightened Buddha), he wanders about questioning deities. I shall send him to the Teacher's presence.”

Then again, he thought: “Even having gone a very long distance, he will be free from doubt only in the Teacher's presence.

There is indeed a person named such-and-such; having wandered about a little while, let him grow weary; afterwards, he will know."

Then he spoke to him beginning with, "I too..."

The *brahmayāna* is similar to the *devayāna*.

Whether it is called the *devayāniyamagga* (path of the gods), or the *brahmayāniyamagga* (path of Brahmā), or the *dhammasetū* (bridge of dharma), or *ekacittakkhaṇikaappanā* (one-moment appanā), or *sanniṭṭhānikacetanā* (determined consciousness), or *mahaggatacitta* (great consciousness), or *abhiññāñāṇa* (super-knowledge), all of this is simply a name for *iddhi-vidha-ñāṇa* (the knowledge of the kinds of psychic power).

mula_pali: 494. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena so mahābrahmā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ mahābrahmānaṃ etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’’ti? Evaṃ vutte, kevaṭṭa, so mahābrahmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca – ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī  issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyāna’nti. ‘‘Dutiyampi  kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu taṃ mahābrahmānaṃ etadavoca – ‘na khohaṃ taṃ, āvuso, evaṃ pucchāmi – ‘‘tvamasi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyāna’’nti. Evañca kho ahaṃ taṃ, āvuso, pucchāmi – ‘‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’’’ti? ‘‘Dutiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca – ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyāna’nti. Tatiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu taṃ mahābrahmānaṃ etadavoca – ‘na khohaṃ taṃ, āvuso, evaṃ pucchāmi – ‘‘tvamasi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū  anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyāna’’nti. Evañca kho ahaṃ taṃ, āvuso, pucchāmi – ‘‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’’’ti?
mula_english:
494. Then, Kevaṭṭa, that *bhikkhu* went to where the Great Brahmā was, and having gone there, said this to the Great Brahmā: ‘Where, friend, do these four great elements ( *cattāro mahābhūtā* )—namely, the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātū*)—cease without remainder?’ When this was said, Kevaṭṭa, the Great Brahmā said this to that *bhikkhu*: ‘I am, *bhikkhu*, Brahmā, Great Brahmā, the Overcomer, the Unovercome, the All-seeing, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker, the Creator, the Best, the Disposer, the Ruler, the Father of beings who have been and will be.’

A second time, Kevaṭṭa, that *bhikkhu* said this to the Great Brahmā: ‘Friend, I am not asking you this: “Are you Brahmā, Great Brahmā, the Overcomer, the Unovercome, the All-seeing, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker, the Creator, the Best, the Disposer, the Ruler, the Father of beings who have been and will be?”’

‘But I am asking you this, friend: “Where, friend, do these four great elements (*cattāro mahābhūtā*)—namely, the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātū*)—cease without remainder?”’ A second time, Kevaṭṭa, the Great Brahmā said this to that *bhikkhu*: ‘I am, *bhikkhu*, Brahmā, Great Brahmā, the Overcomer, the Unovercome, the All-seeing, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker, the Creator, the Best, the Disposer, the Ruler, the Father of beings who have been and will be.’

A third time, Kevaṭṭa, that *bhikkhu* said this to the Great Brahmā: ‘Friend, I am not asking you this: “Are you Brahmā, Great Brahmā, the Overcomer, the Unovercome, the All-seeing, the Controller, the Lord, the Maker, the Creator, the Best, the Disposer, the Ruler, the Father of beings who have been and will be?”’

‘But I am asking you this, friend: “Where, friend, do these four great elements (*cattāro mahābhūtā*)—namely, the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātū*)—cease without remainder?”’
commentary_pali: 494.Pubbanimittanti āgamanapubbabhāge nimittaṃ sūriyassa udayato aruṇuggaṃ viya. Tasmā idāneva brahmā āgamissati, evaṃ mayaṃ jānāmāti dīpayiṃsu. Pāturahosīti pākaṭo ahosi. Atha kho so brahmā tena bhikkhunā puṭṭho attano avisayabhāvaṃ ñatvā sacāhaṃ ‘‘na jānāmī’’ti vakkhāmi, ime maṃ paribhavissanti, atha jānanto viya yaṃ kiñci kathessāmi, ayaṃ me bhikkhu veyyākaraṇena anāraddhacitto vādaṃ āropessati. ‘‘Ahamasmi bhikkhu brahmā’’tiādīni pana me bhaṇantassa na koci vacanaṃ saddahissati. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ vikkhepaṃ katvā imaṃ bhikkhuṃ satthusantikaṃyeva peseyyanti cintetvā ‘‘ahamasmi bhikkhu brahmā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
494. *Pubbanimitta* means a sign in the part preceding the arrival, like the arising of the dawn (*aruṇugga*) from the rising of the sun (*sūriyassa udayato*).

"Therefore, Brahmā will come right now; thus we know," they declared (*dīpayiṃsu*).

"*Pāturahosi*" means he became manifest (*pākaṭo ahosi*).

Then, Brahmā, questioned by that monk (*bhikkhunā puṭṭho*), knowing his own state of being beyond comprehension (*attano avisayabhāvaṃ ñatvā*), [thought:] "If I say, 'I do not know' (*na jānāmī*), these [monks] will despise me (*paribhavissanti*). But if, pretending to know, I say anything (*yaṃ kiñci kathessāmi*), this monk of mine, with a mind not initiated in grammar (*anāraddhacitto*), will bring up an argument (*vādaṃ āropessati*)."

“If I say, ‘I am a monk, Brahmā,’ etc. (*‘‘ahamasmi bhikkhu brahmā’’tiādīni*), no one will believe my words (*vacanaṃ saddahissati*."

"What if I were to cause a disturbance and send this monk to the Teacher himself?" Thinking thus (*cintetvā*), he said, "I am a monk, Brahmā," etc. (*‘‘ahamasmi bhikkhu brahmā’’tiādimāha*).

mula_pali: 495. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā taṃ bhikkhuṃ bāhāyaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ apanetvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca  – ‘ime kho maṃ, bhikkhu, brahmakāyikā devā evaṃ jānanti, ‘‘natthi kiñci brahmuno aññātaṃ, natthi kiñci brahmuno adiṭṭhaṃ, natthi kiñci brahmuno aviditaṃ, natthi kiñci brahmuno asacchikata’’nti. Tasmāhaṃ tesaṃ sammukhā na byākāsiṃ. Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāmi yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu  vāyodhātūti. Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, tuyhevetaṃ dukkaṭaṃ, tuyhevetaṃ aparaddhaṃ, yaṃ tvaṃ taṃ bhagavantaṃ atidhāvitvā bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhiṃ āpajjasi imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya. Gaccha tvaṃ, bhikkhu, tameva bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā imaṃ pañhaṃ puccha, yathā ca te bhagavā byākaroti, tathā naṃ dhāreyyāsī’ti.
mula_english:
Then, Kevatta, the Great Brahmā (*mahābrahmā*) took that monk by the arm, led him aside, and said to him: “These Brahmā-group (*brahmakāyikā*) gods know me thus: ‘There is nothing unknown to Brahmā, nothing unseen by Brahmā, nothing unperceived by Brahmā, nothing unrealized by Brahmā.’”

That is why I did not explain in their presence.

And I, monk, do not know where these four great elements (*cattāro mahābhūtā*) cease without remainder, namely, the earth element (*pathavīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātu*).

Therefore, monk, this is your own misdeed, your own offense, that you have gone beyond that Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*), seeking an answer to this question elsewhere.

Go now, monk, approach that very Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*), and ask him this question, and as the Blessed One (*bhagavā*) explains it to you, so should you remember it."
commentary_pali: 495-496.Ekamantaṃapanetvāti kasmā evamakāsi? Kuhakattā. Bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhinti telatthiko vālikaṃ nippīḷiyamāno viya yāva brahmalokā bahiddhā pariyesanaṃ āpajjati.
commentary_english:
495-496. Why did you act thus, having removed [him] to one side? Because of hypocrisy.

Searching outside, like an oil-seeker crushing sand, he encounters a search outside as far as the Brahmā worlds.

mula_pali: 496. ‘‘Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu – seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya evameva brahmaloke antarahito mama purato pāturahosi. Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi, ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, kevaṭṭa, so bhikkhu maṃ etadavoca – ‘kattha nu kho, bhante, ime cattāro  mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
mula_english:
‘Then, that monk, just as a strong man might extend his flexed arm or flex his extended arm, vanished from the Brahma-world and appeared before me.

Then, that monk, Kevatta, after paying homage to me, sat down to one side. Seated to one side, Kevatta, that monk said to me: "Where, sir, do these four great elements (mahābhūta) – namely, the earth element (pathavīdhātu), the water element (āpodhātu), the fire element (tejodhātu), and the air element (vāyodhātu) – cease completely without remainder?"’
commentary_pali: 495-496.Ekamantaṃapanetvāti kasmā evamakāsi? Kuhakattā. Bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhinti telatthiko vālikaṃ nippīḷiyamāno viya yāva brahmalokā bahiddhā pariyesanaṃ āpajjati.
commentary_english:
495-496. Why did he remove it to one side? Because of deceitfulness (kuhakattā).

Searching outside, like an oil-seeker pressing sand, he encounters a search that extends even to the Brahmā worlds outside.

mula_pali: 497. ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, kevaṭṭa, taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhu, sāmuddikā vāṇijā tīradassiṃ sakuṇaṃ gahetvā nāvāya samuddaṃ ajjhogāhanti. Te atīradakkhiniyā nāvāya tīradassiṃ sakuṇaṃ muñcanti. So gacchateva puratthimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ disaṃ, gacchati anudisaṃ. Sace so samantā tīraṃ  passati, tathāgatakova tathāpakkantova (syā.) hoti. Sace pana so samantā tīraṃ na passati, tameva nāvaṃ paccāgacchati. Evameva kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, yato yāva brahmalokā  pariyesamāno imassa pañhassa  veyyākaraṇaṃ nājjhagā, atha mamaññeva santike paccāgato. Na kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho evaṃ pucchitabbo – ‘kattha nu kho, bhante, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṃ – pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
mula_english:
497.
When this had been said, I, Kevatta, replied to that monk: "Once upon a time, monk, seafaring merchants took a land-sighting bird on their ship when they set sail on the ocean.

When they could not see the land, they released this land-sighting bird.

The bird flew to the east, to the south, to the west, to the north, it flew to the zenith and to the intermediate points of the compass.

If it saw land anywhere, it would go in that direction, becoming just like a *tathāgata*.

But if it saw no land anywhere, it returned to the ship.

In the same way, monk, you have searched as far as the Brahma world for an answer to your question and, not finding it, you have come back to me.

But, monk, the question should not be asked in this way: 'Where do the four great elements — the earth element (*pṛthivīdhātu*), the water element (*āpodhātu*), the fire element (*tejodhātu*), and the air element (*vāyodhātu*) — cease without remainder?'"
commentary_pali: 497.Sakuṇanti kākaṃ vā kulalaṃ vā. Na kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho evaṃ pucchitabboti  idaṃ bhagavā yasmā padesenesa pañho pucchitabbo, ayañca kho bhikkhu anupādinnakepi gahetvā nippadesato pucchati, tasmā paṭisedheti. Āciṇṇaṃ kiretaṃ buddhānaṃ, pucchāmūḷhassa janassa pucchāya dosaṃ dassetvā pucchaṃ sikkhāpetvā pucchāvissajjanaṃ. Kasmā? Pucchituṃ ajānitvā paripucchanto duviññāpayo hoti. Pañhaṃ sikkhāpento pana ‘‘kattha āpo cā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
497. They augur from a crow or a kulala.

"No, monk, that question should not be asked in that way." Because the Blessed One said, "This question should be asked with a basis," but this monk, even taking what is without basis, asks without a basis, therefore he forbids it.

It is customary for Buddhas, having shown the fault in questioning to a person confused about questioning, and having taught questioning, (to teach) answering questions.

Why? Because without knowing how to ask a question, asking repeatedly leads to unintelligibility.

When teaching a question, however, he says, "Where are the waters, and so on?"

mula_pali: 498. ‘‘Evañca kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho pucchitabbo –
mula_english:
498.

"And this is how the question should be asked, *bhikkhu* (mendicant),"
commentary_pali: 498. Tattha na gādhatīti na patiṭṭhāti, ime cattāro  mahābhūtā kiṃ āgamma appatiṭṭhā bhavantīti attho. Upādinnaṃyeva sandhāya pucchati. Dīghañca rassañcāti saṇṭhānavasena upādārūpaṃ vuttaṃ. Aṇuṃ thūlanti khuddakaṃ vā mahantaṃ vā, imināpi upādārūpe vaṇṇamattameva kathitaṃ. Subhāsubhanti subhañca asubhañca upādārūpameva kathitaṃ. Kiṃ pana upādārūpaṃ subhanti asubhanti atthi? Natthi. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇaṃ paneva kathitaṃ. Nāmañca rūpañcāti nāmañca dīghādibhedaṃ rūpañca. Uparujjhatīti nirujjhati, kiṃ āgamma asesametaṃ nappavattatīti. Evaṃ pucchitabbaṃ siyāti pucchaṃ dassetvā idāni vissajjanaṃ dassento tatra veyyākaraṇaṃ bhavatīti vatvā – ‘‘viññāṇa’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
498.
There, because it does not plunge, it does not stand firm. What having come, do these four great elements (catvāro mahābhūtā) become unstable? This is the meaning.
He asks, referring to what is taken up.
"Long and short" is said as form (rūpa) that is clung to, in terms of shape.
"Subtle and gross," or small or large; by this also, only color (vaṇṇa) is said in the form that is clung to.
"Auspicious and inauspicious," both auspicious (śubha) and inauspicious (aśubha), only form (rūpa) that is clung to is said.
But is there form (rūpa) that is clung to that is auspicious or inauspicious? There is not.
Indeed, only desirable and undesirable object is said.
“Name and Form (nāma-rūpa),” both name (nāma) and form (rūpa), which is the distinction of long, etc.
Because it ceases, it is stopped. What having come, does all of this not proceed?
Having shown the question, "Thus it should be asked," now, showing the explanation, he says, having said, "There, there is clarification" -- "consciousness (vijñāna)," etc., he said as the beginning.

mula_pali: 499. ‘‘Tatra veyyākaraṇaṃ bhavati –
mula_english: 499. And the answer is:
commentary_pali: 499. Tattha viññātabbanti viññāṇaṃ nibbānassetaṃ nāmaṃ, tadetaṃ nidassanābhāvato anidassanaṃ. Uppādanto vā vayanto vā ṭhitassa aññathattanto vā etassa natthīti anantaṃ. Pabhanti panetaṃ kira titthassa nāmaṃ, tañhi papanti etthāti papaṃ, pakārassa pana bhakāro kato. Sabbato pabhamassāti sabbatopabhaṃ. Nibbānassa kira yathā mahāsamuddassa yato yato otaritukāmā honti, taṃ tadeva titthaṃ, atitthaṃ nāma natthi. Evameva aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu yena yena mukhena nibbānaṃ otaritukāmā honti, taṃ tadeva titthaṃ, nibbānassa atitthaṃ nāma natthi. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘sabbatopabha’’nti. Ettha āpo cāti ettha  nibbāne idaṃ nibbānaṃ āgamma sabbametaṃ āpotiādinā nayena vuttaṃ upādinnaka dhammajātaṃ nirujjhati, appavattaṃ hotīti. Idānissa nirujjhanūpāyaṃ dassento ‘‘viññāṇassa nirodhena etthetaṃ uparujjhatī’’ti āha. Tattha viññāṇanti carimakaviññāṇampi abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇampi , carimakaviññāṇassāpi hi nirodhena etthetaṃ uparujjhati. Vijjhātadīpasikhā viya apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ yāti. Abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassāpi anuppādanirodhena anuppādavasena uparujjhati. Yathāha ‘‘sotāpattimaggañāṇena abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassa nirodhena ṭhapetvā sattabhave anamatagge saṃsāre ye  uppajjeyyuṃ nāmañca rūpañca etthete nirujjhantī’’ti sabbaṃ cūḷaniddese vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
499.
There, that which may be known is consciousness ( *viññāṇaṃ*), this is a name for nirvāṇa; but this is unmanifest due to the absence of manifestation.

That which is arising, ceasing, or the alteration of that which is abiding, this does not exist for it; therefore, it is endless (*anantaṃ*).

Indeed, they say that this shines as a name for a sacred bathing place (*tīrthassa nāmaṃ*); because one goes down into it, therefore it is *papaṃ*; moreover, the letter "pa" becomes the letter "bha."

Because it shines in every way, therefore it is all-shining (*sabbatopabhaṃ*).

It is said that just as for nirvāṇa, from whichever place one wants to descend into the great ocean (*mahāsamuddassa*), that is the sacred bathing place (*tīrthaṃ*); there is no non-bathing place (*atitthaṃ*).

Just so, in the thirty-eight objects of meditation (*aṭṭhatiṃsāya kammaṭṭhānesu*), by whichever means one wants to descend into nirvāṇa, that is the sacred bathing place (*tīrthaṃ*); there is no non-bathing place for nirvāṇa (*nibbānassa atitthaṃ*).

Therefore, it was said, "all-shining" (*sabbatopabhaṃ*).

Here, "water" and "ca," here in nirvāṇa, having come to this nirvāṇa, all this aggregate of phenomena (*dhammajātaṃ*) that is spoken of by way of "water," etc., ceases; it does not continue, so it is said.

Now, showing the means of cessation, he said, "By the cessation (*nirodhena*) of consciousness (*viññāṇassa*), this ceases here."

There, consciousness (*viññāṇanti*) means both the final consciousness (*carimakaviññāṇampi*) and the consciousness associated with karmic formations (*abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇampi*); indeed, by the cessation (*nirodhena*) of even the final consciousness (*carimakaviññāṇassāpi*), this ceases here.

It goes to a state of non-appearance, like the flame of an extinguished lamp (*vijjhātadīpasikhā viya apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ yāti*).

Even the consciousness associated with karmic formations (*abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassāpi*) ceases by the cessation of non-arising, by virtue of non-arising.

As he said, "By the knowledge of the path of stream-entry (*sotāpattimaggañāṇena*), by the cessation (*nirodhena*) of the consciousness associated with karmic formations (*abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassa*), having established [that], in the seven existences (*sattabhave*), in the cycle of existence (*saṃsāre*) whose beginning is not known (*anamatagge*), those name and form (*nāmañca rūpañca*) that would arise, these cease here," all this should be understood in the same way as it is stated in the Cūḷaniddesa.

The rest is clear everywhere.

mula_pali: 500. Idamavoca  bhagavā. Attamano kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mula_english:
Five hundred.
Thus it was said by the Blessed One.
The householder's son Kevatta, being delighted, rejoiced at the Blessed One's words.

mula_pali: 150. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi. Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe pannarase komudiyā cātumāsiniyā puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā rājāmaccaparivuto uparipāsādavaragato nisinno hoti. Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe udānaṃ udānesi – ‘‘ramaṇīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, abhirūpā vata bho dosinā ratti, dassanīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, pāsādikā vata bho dosinā ratti, lakkhaññā vata bho dosinā ratti. Kaṃ nu khvajja samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā payirupāseyyāma, yaṃ no payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti?
mula_english:
Thus have I heard: On one occasion the Blessed One (Bhagavā) was dwelling at Rājagṛha, in Jīvaka Komārabhacca's Mango Grove, together with a large company of twelve hundred and fifty monks (bhikkhu-saṅgha).

At that time, King Ajātaśatru (Ajātasattu) of Magadha, the son of Queen Videhi, was sitting on the upper terrace of his palace, surrounded by his ministers, on the fifteenth-day Uposatha, the full-moon night of the Komudi festival in the fourth month.

Then King Ajātaśatru of Magadha, the son of Queen Videhi, on that Uposatha day, uttered this joyful exclamation: "How delightful, friends (bho), is this moonlit night (dosinā ratti)! How beautiful is this moonlit night! How lovely is this moonlit night! How tranquil is this moonlit night! How auspicious is this moonlit night!"

"Is there any ascetic (śamaṇa) or Brahmin (brāhmaṇa) that we could visit tonight, whose visit might bring peace to my mind (cittaṃ)?"
commentary_pali: 150.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… rājagaheti sāmaññaphalasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā – rājagaheti evaṃnāmake nagare. Tañhi mandhātumahāgovindādīhi pariggahitattā rājagahanti vuccati. Aññepi ettha pakāre vaṇṇayanti, kiṃ tehi? Nāmamattametaṃ tassa nagarassa. Taṃ panetaṃ buddhakāle ca cakkavattikāle ca nagaraṃ hoti, sesakāle suññaṃ hoti yakkhapariggahitaṃ, tesaṃ vasanavanaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhati. Viharatīti avisesena iriyāpathadibbabrahmaariyavihāresu aññataravihārasamaṅgiparidīpanametaṃ. Idha pana ṭhānagamananisajjasayanappabhedesu iriyāpathesu aññatarairiyāpathasamāyogaparidīpanaṃ. Tena ṭhitopi gacchantopi nisinnopi sayānopi bhagavā viharati ceva veditabbo. So hi ekaṃ iriyāpathabādhanaṃ aññena iriyāpathena vicchinditvā aparipatantaṃ attabhāvaṃ harati pavatteti, tasmā viharatīti vuccati. Jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavaneti idamassa yaṃ gocaragāmaṃ upanissāya viharati, tassa samīpanivāsanaṭṭhānaparidīpanaṃ. Tasmā – rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavaneti rājagahasamīpe jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane viharatīti evamettha attho veditabbo. Samīpatthe hetaṃ bhummavacanaṃ. Tattha  jīvatīti jīvako, kumārena bhatoti komārabhacco. Yathāha – ‘‘kiṃ bhaṇe, etaṃ kākehi samparikiṇṇanti? Dārako devāti. Jīvati bhaṇeti? Jīvati, devāti. Tena hi, bhaṇe taṃ dārakaṃ amhākaṃ antepuraṃ netvā dhātīnaṃ detha posetunti. Tassa jīvatīti jīvakoti nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Kumārena posāpitoti komārabhaccoti nāmaṃ akaṃsū’’ti (mahāva. 328) ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārena pana jīvakavatthukhandhake āgatameva. Vinicchayakathāpissa samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttā. Ayaṃ  pana jīvako ekasmiṃ samaye bhagavato dosābhisannaṃ kāyaṃ virecetvā siveyyakaṃ dussayugaṃ datvā vatthānumodanāpariyosāne sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya cintesi – ‘‘mayā divasassa dvattikkhattuṃ buddhupaṭṭhānaṃ gantabbaṃ, idañca veḷuvanaṃ atidūre, mayhaṃ pana ambavanaṃ uyyānaṃ āsannataraṃ, yaṃnūnāhaṃ ettha bhagavato vihāraṃ kāreyya’’nti. So tasmiṃ ambavane rattiṭṭhānadivāṭhānaleṇakuṭimaṇḍapādīni sampādetvā bhagavato anucchavikaṃ gandhakuṭiṃ kārāpetvā ambavanaṃ aṭṭhārasahatthubbedhena tambapaṭṭavaṇṇena pākārena parikkhipāpetvā buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sacīvarabhattena santappetvā dakkhiṇodakaṃ pātetvā vihāraṃ niyyātesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – ‘‘jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane’’ti. Aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehīti aḍḍhasatena ūnehi terasahi bhikkhusatehi. Rājātiādīsu rājati attano issariyasampattiyā catūhi saṅgahavatthūhi mahājanaṃ rañjeti vaḍḍhetīti rājā. Magadhānaṃ issaroti māgadho. Ajātoyeva rañño sattu bhavissatīti nemittakehi niddiṭṭhoti ajātasattu. Tasmiṃ kira kucchigate deviyā evarūpo dohaḷo uppajji – ‘‘aho  vatāhaṃ rañño dakkhiṇabāhulohitaṃ piveyya’’nti, sā ‘‘bhāriye ṭhāne dohaḷo uppanno, na sakkā kassaci ārocetu’’nti taṃ kathetuṃ asakkontī kisā dubbaṇṇā ahosi. Taṃ rājā pucchi – ‘‘bhadde, tuyhaṃ attabhāvo na pakativaṇṇo, kiṃ kāraṇa’’nti? ‘‘Mā puccha, mahārājāti’’. ‘‘Bhadde, tvaṃ attano ajjhāsayaṃ mayhaṃ akathentī kassa kathessasī’’ti tathā tathā nibandhitvā kathāpesi. Sutvā ca – ‘‘bāle, kiṃ ettha tuyhaṃ bhāriyasaññā ahosī’’ti vejjaṃ pakkosāpetvā suvaṇṇasatthakena bāhuṃ phālāpetvā suvaṇṇasarakena lohitaṃ gahetvā udakena sambhinditvā pāyesi. Nemittakā taṃ sutvā – ‘‘esa gabbho rañño sattu bhavissati, iminā rājā haññissatī’’ti byākariṃsu. Devī sutvā – ‘‘mayhaṃ kira kucchito nikkhanto rājānaṃ māressatī’’ti gabbhaṃ pātetukāmā uyyānaṃ gantvā kucchiṃ maddāpesi, gabbho na patati. Sā punappunaṃ gantvā tatheva kāresi. Rājā kimatthaṃ ayaṃ  abhiṇhaṃ uyyānaṃ gacchatīti parivīmaṃsanto taṃ kāraṇaṃ sutvā – ‘‘bhadde, tava kucchiyaṃ puttoti vā dhītāti vā na paññāyati, attano nibbattadārakaṃ evamakāsīti mahā aguṇarāsipi no jambudīpatale āvibhavissati, mā tvaṃ evaṃ karohī’’ti nivāretvā ārakkhaṃ adāsi. Sā gabbhavuṭṭhānakāle ‘‘māressāmī’’ti cintesi. Tadāpi ārakkhamanussā dārakaṃ apanayiṃsu. Athāparena samayena vuḍḍhippattaṃ  kumāraṃ deviyā dassesuṃ. Sā taṃ disvāva puttasinehaṃ uppādesi, tena naṃ māretuṃ nāsakkhi. Rājāpi anukkamena puttassa oparajjamadāsi. Athekasmiṃ  samaye devadatto rahogato cintesi – ‘‘sāriputtassa parisā mahāmoggallānassa parisā mahākassapassa parisāti, evamime visuṃ visuṃ dhurā, ahampi ekaṃ dhuraṃ nīharāmī’’ti. So ‘‘na sakkā vinā lābhena parisaṃ uppādetuṃ, handāhaṃ lābhaṃ nibbattemī’’ti cintetvā khandhake āgatanayena ajātasattuṃ kumāraṃ iddhipāṭihāriyena pasādetvā sāyaṃ pātaṃ pañcahi rathasatehi upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchantaṃ ativissatthaṃ ñatvā ekadivasaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca – ‘‘pubbe kho, kumāra, manussā dīghāyukā, etarahi appāyukā, tena hi tvaṃ kumāra, pitaraṃ hantvā rājā hohi, ahaṃ bhagavantaṃ hantvā buddho bhavissāmī’’ti kumāraṃ pituvadhe uyyojeti. So – ‘‘ayyo devadatto mahānubhāvo, etassa aviditaṃ nāma natthī’’ti ūruyā potthaniyaṃ bandhitvā divā divassa bhīto ubbiggo ussaṅkī utrasto antepuraṃ pavisitvā vuttappakāraṃ vippakāraṃ akāsi. Atha naṃ amaccā gahetvā anuyuñjitvā – ‘‘kumāro ca hantabbo, devadatto ca, sabbe ca bhikkhū hantabbā’’ti sammantayitvā rañño āṇāvasena karissāmāti rañño ārocesuṃ. Rājā ye amaccā māretukāmā ahesuṃ, tesaṃ ṭhānantarāni acchinditvā, ye na māretukāmā, te uccesu ṭhānesu ṭhapetvā kumāraṃ pucchi – ‘‘kissa pana tvaṃ, kumāra, maṃ māretukāmosī’’ti? ‘‘Rajjenamhi, deva, atthiko’’ti. Rājā tassa rajjaṃ adāsi. So  mayhaṃ manoratho nipphannoti devadattassa ārocesi. Tato naṃ so āha – ‘‘tvaṃ siṅgālaṃ antokatvā bheripariyonaddhapuriso  viya sukiccakārimhīti maññasi, katipāheneva te pitā tayā kataṃ avamānaṃ cintetvā sayameva rājā bhavissatī’’ti. Atha, bhante, kiṃ karomīti? Mūlaghaccaṃ ghātehīti. Nanu, bhante, mayhaṃ pitā na satthavajjhoti? Āhārupacchedena naṃ mārehīti. So pitaraṃ tāpanagehe pakkhipāpesi, tāpanagehaṃ nāma kammakaraṇatthāya kataṃ dhūmagharaṃ. ‘‘Mama mātaraṃ ṭhapetvā aññassa daṭṭhuṃ mā dethā’’ti āha. Devī suvaṇṇasarake bhattaṃ pakkhipitvā ucchaṅgenādāya pavisati. Rājā taṃ bhuñjitvā yāpeti. So – ‘‘mayhaṃ pitā kathaṃ yāpetī’’ti pucchitvā taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā – ‘‘mayhaṃ mātu ucchaṅgaṃ katvā  pavisituṃ mā dethā’’ti āha. Tato paṭṭhāya devī moḷiyaṃ pakkhipitvā pavisati. Tampi sutvā ‘‘moḷiṃ bandhitvā pavisituṃ mā dethā’’ti. Tato suvaṇṇapādukāsu bhattaṃ ṭhapetvā pidahitvā pādukā āruyha pavisati. Rājā tena yāpeti. Puna ‘‘kathaṃ yāpetī’’ti pucchitvā tamatthaṃ sutvā ‘‘pādukā āruyha pavisitumpi mā dethā’’ti āha. Tato paṭṭhāya devī gandhodakena nhāyitvā sarīraṃ catumadhurena makkhetvā pārupitvā pavisati. Rājā tassā sarīraṃ lehitvā yāpeti. Puna pucchitvā taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā ‘‘ito paṭṭhāya mayhaṃ mātu pavesanaṃ nivārethā’’ti āha. Devī dvāramūle ṭhatvā ‘‘sāmi, bimbisāra, etaṃ daharakāle māretuṃ na adāsi, attano sattuṃ attanāva posesi, idaṃ pana dāni te pacchimadassanaṃ, nāhaṃ ito paṭṭhāya tumhe passituṃ labhāmi, sace mayhaṃ doso atthi, khamatha devā’’ti roditvā kanditvā nivatti. Tato  paṭṭhāya rañño āhāro natthi. Rājā maggaphalasukhena caṅkamena yāpeti. Ativiya assa attabhāvo virocati. So – ‘‘kathaṃ, me bhaṇe, pitā yāpetī’’ti pucchitvā ‘‘caṅkamena, deva, yāpeti; ativiya cassa attabhāvo virocatī’’ti sutvā ‘caṅkamaṃ dānissa hāressāmī’ti cintetvā – ‘‘mayhaṃ pitu pāde khurena phāletvā loṇatelena makkhetvā khadiraṅgārehi vītaccitehi pacathā’’ti nhāpite pesesi. Rājā te disvā – ‘‘nūna mayhaṃ putto kenaci saññatto bhavissati, ime mama massukaraṇatthāyāgatā’’ti  cintesi. Te gantvā vanditvā aṭṭhaṃsu. ‘Kasmā āgatatthā’ti ca puṭṭhā taṃ sāsanaṃ ārocesuṃ. ‘‘Tumhākaṃ rañño manaṃ karothā’’ti ca vuttā ‘nisīda, devā’ti vatvā ca rājānaṃ vanditvā – ‘‘deva, mayaṃ rañño āṇaṃ karoma, mā amhākaṃ kujjhittha, nayidaṃ tumhādisānaṃ dhammarājūnaṃ anucchavika’’nti vatvā vāmahatthena gopphake gahetvā dakkhiṇahatthena khuraṃ gahetvā pādatalāni phāletvā loṇatelena makkhetvā khadiraṅgārehi vītaccitehi paciṃsu. Rājā kira pubbe cetiyaṅgaṇe saupāhano agamāsi, nisajjanatthāya paññattakaṭasārakañca adhotehi pādehi akkami, tassāyaṃ nissandoti vadanti. Rañño balavavedanā uppannā. So – ‘‘aho buddho, aho dhammo, aho saṅgho’’ti anussarantoyeva cetiyaṅgaṇe khittamālā viya milāyitvā cātumahārājikadevaloke vessavaṇassa paricārako janavasabho nāma yakkho hutvā nibbatti. Taṃ divasameva ajātasattussa putto jāto, puttassa jātabhāvañca pitumatabhāvañca nivedetuṃ dve lekhā ekakkhaṇeyeva āgatā. Amaccā – ‘‘paṭhamaṃ puttassa jātabhāvaṃ ārocessāmā’’ti taṃ lekhaṃ rañño hatthe ṭhapesuṃ. Rañño taṅkhaṇeyeva puttasineho uppajjitvā sakalasarīraṃ  khobhetvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca aṭṭhāsi. Tasmiṃ khaṇe pituguṇamaññāsi – ‘‘mayi jātepi mayhaṃ pitu evameva sineho uppanno’’ti. So – ‘‘gacchatha, bhaṇe, mayhaṃ pitaraṃ vissajjethā’’ti āha. ‘‘Kiṃ vissajjāpetha, devā’’ti itaraṃ lekhaṃ hatthe ṭhapayiṃsu. So taṃ pavattiṃ sutvā rodamāno mātusamīpaṃ gantvā – ‘‘ahosi nu, kho, amma, mayhaṃ pitu mayi jāte sineho’’ti? Sā āha – ‘‘bālaputta, kiṃ vadesi, tava daharakāle aṅguliyā pīḷakā uṭṭhahi. Atha taṃ rodamānaṃ saññāpetuṃ asakkontā taṃ gahetvā vinicchayaṭṭhāne nisinnassa tava pitu santikaṃ agamaṃsu. Pitā te aṅguliṃ mukhe ṭhapesi. Pīḷakā mukheyeva bhijji. Atha kho pitā tava sinehena taṃ lohitamissakaṃ pubbaṃ aniṭṭhubhitvāva ajjhohari. Evarūpo te pitu sineho’’ti. So roditvā paridevitvā pitu sarīrakiccaṃ akāsi. Devadattopi  ajātasattuṃ upasaṅkamitvā – ‘‘purise, mahārāja, āṇāpehi, ye samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ jīvitā voropessantī’’ti vatvā tena dinne purise pesetvā sayaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ āruyha yantena silaṃ pavijjhitvā nāḷāgirihatthiṃ muñcāpetvāpi kenaci upāyena bhagavantaṃ māretuṃ asakkonto parihīnalābhasakkāro pañca vatthūni yācitvā tāni alabhamāno tehi janaṃ saññāpessāmīti saṅghabhedaṃ katvā sāriputtamoggallānesu parisaṃ ādāya pakkantesu uṇhalohitaṃ mukhena chaḍḍetvā navamāse gilānamañce nipajjitvā vippaṭisārajāto – ‘‘kuhiṃ etarahi satthā vasatī’’ti pucchitvā ‘‘jetavane’’ti vutte mañcakena maṃ āharitvā satthāraṃ dassethāti vatvā āhariyamāno bhagavato  dassanārahassa kammassa akatattā jetavane pokkharaṇīsamīpeyeva dvedhā bhinnaṃ pathaviṃ pavisitvā mahāniraye patiṭṭhitoti. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārakathānayo khandhake āgato. Āgatattā pana sabbaṃ na vuttanti. Evaṃ ajātoyeva rañño sattu bhavissatīti nemittakehi niddiṭṭhoti ajātasattu. Vedehiputtoti ayaṃ kosalarañño dhītāya putto, na videharañño. Vedehīti pana paṇḍitādhivacanametaṃ. Yathāha – ‘‘vedehikā gahapatānī (ma. ni. 1.226), ayyo ānando vedehamunī’’ti (saṃ. ni. 2.154). Tatrāyaṃ vacanattho – vidanti etenāti vedo, ñāṇassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Vedena īhati ghaṭati vāyamatīti vedehī. Vedehiyā putto vedehiputto. Tadahūti tasmiṃ ahu, tasmiṃ divaseti attho. Upavasanti etthāti uposatho, upavasantīti  sīlena vā anasanena vā upetā hutvā vasantīti attho. Ayaṃ panettha atthuddhāro – ‘‘āyāmāvuso, kappina, uposathaṃ gamissāmā’’tiādīsu pātimokkhuddeso uposatho. ‘‘Evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato kho, visākhe, uposatho upavuttho’’tiādīsu (a. ni. 8.43) sīlaṃ. ‘‘Suddhassa ve sadā phaggu, suddhassuposatho sadā’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.79) upavāso. ‘‘Uposatho nāma nāgarājā’’tiādīsu (dī. ni. 2.246) paññatti . ‘‘Na, bhikkhave, tadahuposathe sabhikkhukā āvāsā’’tiādīsu (mahāva. 181) upavasitabbadivaso. Idhāpi soyeva adhippeto. So panesa aṭṭhamī cātuddasī pannarasībhedena tividho. Tasmā sesadvayanivāraṇatthaṃ pannaraseti vuttaṃ. Teneva vuttaṃ – ‘‘upavasanti etthāti uposatho’’ti. Komudiyāti kumudavatiyā. Tadā kira kumudāni supupphitāni honti, tāni ettha santīti komudī. Cātumāsiniyāti cātumāsiyā, sā hi catunnaṃ māsānaṃ pariyosānabhūtāti cātumāsī. Idha pana cātumāsinīti vuccati. Māsapuṇṇatāya  utupuṇṇatāya saṃvaccharapuṇṇatāya puṇṇā sampuṇṇāti puṇṇā. Mā iti cando vuccati, so ettha puṇṇoti puṇṇamā. Evaṃ puṇṇāya puṇṇamāyāti imasmiṃ padadvaye ca attho veditabbo. Rājāmaccaparivutoti evarūpāya rajataghaṭaviniggatāhi khīradhārāhi dhoviyamānadisābhāgāya viya, rajatavimānaviccutehi muttāvaḷisumanakusumadāmasetadukūlakumudavisarehi samparikiṇṇāya viya ca, caturupakkilesavimuttapuṇṇacandappabhāsamudayobhāsitāya rattiyā rājāmaccehi parivutoti attho. Uparipāsādavaragatoti pāsādavarassa uparigato. Mahārahe samussitasetacchatte kañcanāsane nisinno hoti. Kasmā nisinno? Niddāvinodanatthaṃ. Ayañhi rājā pitari upakkantadivasato paṭṭhāya – ‘‘niddaṃ okkamissāmī’’ti nimīlitamattesuyeva akkhīsu sattisataabbhāhato viya kandamānoyeva pabujjhi. Kimetanti ca vutte, na kiñcīti vadati. Tenassa amanāpā niddā, iti niddāvinodanatthaṃ nisinno. Api ca tasmiṃ divase nakkhattaṃ saṅghuṭṭhaṃ hoti. Sabbaṃ nagaraṃ sittasammaṭṭhaṃ vippakiṇṇavālukaṃ pañcavaṇṇakusumalājapuṇṇaghaṭapaṭimaṇḍitagharadvāraṃ samussitadhajapaṭākavicitrasamujjalitadīpamālālaṅkatasabbadisābhāgaṃ vīthisabhāgena racchāsabhāgena nakkhattakīḷaṃ anubhavamānena mahājanena samākiṇṇaṃ hoti. Iti nakkhattadivasatāyapi nisinnoti vadanti. Evaṃ pana vatvāpi – ‘‘rājakulassa nāma sadāpi nakkhattameva, niddāvinodanatthaṃyeva panesa nisinno’’ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ kataṃ. Udānaṃudānesīti udāhāraṃ udāhari, yathā hi yaṃ telaṃ mānaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti, vissanditvā gacchati, taṃ avasekoti  vuccati. Yañca jalaṃ taḷākaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti, ajjhottharitvā gacchati, taṃ oghoti vuccati; evameva yaṃ pītivacanaṃ hadayaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti, adhikaṃ hutvā anto asaṇṭhahitvā bahinikkhamati, taṃ udānanti vuccati. Evarūpaṃ pītimayaṃ vacanaṃ nicchāresīti attho. Dosināti dosāpagatā, abbhā, mahikā, dhūmo, rajo, rāhūti imehi pañcahi upakkilesehi virahitāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tasmā ramaṇīyātiādīni pañca thomanavacanāni. Sā hi mahājanassa manaṃ ramayatīti ramaṇīyā. Vuttadosavimuttāya candappabhāya obhāsitattā ativiya surūpāti abhirūpā. Dassituṃ yuttāti dassanīyā. Cittaṃ pasādetīti pāsādikā. Divasamāsādīnaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ bhavituṃ yuttāti lakkhaññā. Kaṃ nu khvajjāti kaṃ nu kho ajja. Samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vāti samitapāpatāya samaṇaṃ. Bāhitapāpatāya brāhmaṇaṃ. Yaṃ no payirupāsatoti vacanabyattayo esa, yaṃ amhākaṃ pañhapucchanavasena payirupāsantānaṃ madhuraṃ dhammaṃ sutvā cittaṃ pasīdeyyāti attho. Iti rājā iminā sabbenapi vacanena obhāsanimittakammaṃ akāsi. Kassa akāsīti? Jīvakassa. Kimatthaṃ? Bhagavato dassanatthaṃ. Kiṃ bhagavantaṃ sayaṃ dassanāya upagantuṃ na sakkotīti? Āma, na sakkoti. Kasmā? Mahāparādhatāya. Tena hi bhagavato upaṭṭhāko ariyasāvako attano pitā mārito, devadatto ca tameva nissāya bhagavato bahuṃ anatthamakāsi, iti mahāparādho esa, tāya mahāparādhatāya sayaṃ gantuṃ na sakkoti. Jīvako pana bhagavato upaṭṭhāko, tassa piṭṭhichāyāya bhagavantaṃ passissāmīti obhāsanimittakammaṃ akāsi. Kiṃ jīvako pana – ‘‘mayhaṃ idaṃ obhāsanimittakamma’’nti jānātīti? Āma jānāti. Atha kasmā tuṇhī ahosīti? Vikkhepapacchedanatthaṃ. Tassañhi parisati channaṃ satthārānaṃ upaṭṭhākā bahū  sannipatitā, te asikkhitānaṃ payirupāsanena sayampi asikkhitāva. Te mayi bhagavato guṇakathaṃ  āraddhe antarantarā uṭṭhāyuṭṭhāya attano satthārānaṃ guṇaṃ kathessanti, evaṃ me satthu guṇakathā pariyosānaṃ na gamissati. Rājā pana imesaṃ kulūpake upasaṅkamitvā gahitāsāratāya tesaṃ guṇakathāya anattamano  hutvā maṃ paṭipucchissati, athāhaṃ nibbikkhepaṃ satthu guṇaṃ kathetvā rājānaṃ satthu santikaṃ gahetvā gamissāmīti jānantova vikkhepapacchedanatthaṃ tuṇhī ahosīti. Tepi amaccā evaṃ cintesuṃ – ‘‘ajja rājā pañcahi padehi rattiṃ thometi, addhā kiñci samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchitvā dhammaṃ sotukāmo, yassa cesa dhammaṃ sutvā pasīdissati, tassa ca mahantaṃ sakkāraṃ karissati, yassa pana kulūpako samaṇo rājakulūpako hoti, bhaddaṃ tassā’’ti.
commentary_english:
150. Thus have I heard…pe… the Sāmaññaphala Sutta at Rājagaha.

Here is an explanation of the first word: Rājagaha is the name of a city.

It is called Rājagaha because it was embraced by Mandhātu, Mahāgovinda, and others.

Others also explain it in other ways, but what is the use of that? This is merely the name of that city.

In the time of the Buddha and the time of the *cakravartin* (wheel-turning monarch) it was a city, but at other times it was empty, possessed by *yakṣas* (spirits), and remained a forest dwelling place for them.

“Was living” signifies, without distinction, a possessor of one or other of the abidings consisting of the four postures and the three abidings consisting in the heavenly, the divine and the Noble Ones’ abidings.

But here it signifies occupation with one or other of the postures among those classed as standing, walking, sitting, and lying down.

So it can be understood that the Blessed One was so abiding either when standing or walking or seated or lying down.

For by terminating the discomfort of one posture by replacing it with one of the others, he carried his selfhood on, made it proceed onwards, without letting it fall; therefore it is called "was living".

"Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s Mango Grove" signifies that he was living depending on a village that was his place of alms resort and signifies the place of dwelling near.

Therefore, "the Exalted One was dwelling at Rājagaha, in Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s Mango Grove" means it should be understood thus: he was living in Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s Mango Grove which was near Rājagaha.

The locative case is in the sense of ‘ vicinity’.

There, *jīvati* means *jīvaka* (living), raised by a prince, *kumārena bhata* means *komārabhacca*.

As he said: “I say, is this crowded with crows? Is the boy a god?"

“I say, is he alive?” “Yes, he’s alive.”

“Well then, take him to our compound and give him to the wet-nurses to feed.”

Because it was said of him, “He’s alive,” they gave him the name ‘Jīvaka’ One who is alive.

“Thus, as he was raised by the prince, they gave him the name Komārabhacca.”

328) Here is a brief explanation.

The story of Jīvaka is related at length in the Khandhakas

and explained in the Samantapāsādikā, the commentary to the Vinaya.

Once, when the Exalted One’s body was afflicted by a disorder of the humors, Jīvaka treated him with a purgative. He then gave the Buddha a pair of Siveyyaka cloths, and at the conclusion of the thanksgiving talk for the cloths, he was established in the fruit of stream-entry. Thereupon he thought: “I should go to wait upon the Buddha two or three times a day, but the Bamboo Grove is too far away. My park, the Mango Grove, is closer. Let me build a dwelling there for the Exalted One.”

He set up night- quarters, day-quarters, caves, huts, pavilions, etc, built a Fragrant Cottage suitable for the Exalted One, and erected a copper-colored wall eighteen yards high surrounding the Mango Grove. He treated the Sangha of *bhikkhus* (monks) headed by the Buddha to an offering of a meal and robes, and after pouring the gift-water, presented the dwelling.

That was referring to – "Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s Mango Grove".

“With thirteen hundred and a half *bhikkhus*,” means with thirteen hundred *bhikkhus* less half a hundred.

Among the words beginning with "king," "king" means one who pleases and increases the great multitude by his own majesty and the four bases of sympathy.

The lord of Magadha is called *māgadha* (Magadha).

The astrologers predicted: “Even while he is as yet unborn , he will be the king’s enemy ”; thus Ajātasattu, “unborn enemy.”

It is said that when he was still in his mother’s womb, the queen developed the compulsive urge to drink blood from the king’s right arm.She considered: “This compulsive urge that has arisen is terrible; I should not report it to anyone.” Being unable to express it, she became thin and pale.

The king asked her: “Dear, your body has become pallid. What is the reason?” “Don’t ask, great king.”

—“Dear, if you don’t express your thoughts to me, to whom will you express them?” Urging her in various ways, he convinced her to speak.

Having heard, he said: “Dear, why do you regard this as terrible? ” He then sent for his physician, had him make an incision in his arm with a golden knife, collected the blood in a golden vessel, mixed it with water, and made her drink it.

The astrologers, hearing this, declared: “This child in her womb will be the king’s enemy.He will kill the king.”

The queen heard this and thought: “They say that when the child comes out from my belly he will kill the king.” Wishing to have an abortion, she went to the park and had her belly trampled upon, but abortion did not take place.

She went again and again and did the same thing.

The king inquired: “Why do you go to the park so often? ” Having learned the reason he said: “Dear, we do not even know whether you have a son or a daughter in your womb. If we do this to a child begotten by ourselves, a great calamity will appear in our land of India.Do not do so.” Having thus dissuaded her, he set a guard over her.

When the child took birth she thought: “I will kill him,”

but guards took the child away from her.

Some time later, after the prince had attained to growth, they showed him to the queen.
When she saw him, maternal affection arose within her and she could not have him killed.
Eventually the king appointed his son viceroy.
One time Devadatta, while in seclusion, thought to himself: “Sāriputta has an assembly of followers, Mahāmoggallāna has an assembly of followers, Mahākassapa has an assembly of followers. Thus each of these maintains his own following. I, too, will gather a following.”
He considered: “It won’t be possible to acquire an assembly without gain. So let me obtain gain.” Then, as related in the Khandhakas, by means of the miracle of supernormal power he won the confidence of Prince Ajātasattu. The prince came to wait upon him morning and evening with five hundred chariots. Aware of his great trust, one day Devadatta approached the prince and said: “In the past, O prince, men lived long; now they are short-lived. Therefore, prince, you should kill your father and become king, and I will kill the Buddha and become a Buddha.” Thus he incited the prince to patricide.
The prince thought: “Master Devadatta has great spiritual power. There is nothing he does not know.” He fastened a dagger to his thigh and entered the inner palace in the middle of the day, but being fearful, apprehensive, alarmed and anxious, he muddled up the instructions he was given.
Then the ministers, having arrested him and interrogated him, deciding that the prince should be killed along with Devadatta and all the *bhikkhus*, they reported the matter to the king intending to do whatever the king commanded.
The king demoted those ministers who wanted to kill the prince and Devadatta, and promoted those ministers who did not want to kill them. He asked the prince: “Prince, why do you want to kill me?” “Because, your majesty, I desire the kingdom.”
The king gave him his kingdom.
When the prince reported to Devadatta that his wish had been granted,
Then he said to him: “Like a man who beats the kettledrums after caging a jackal, you imagine you have finished your work. Within a few days your father, considering the contempt you have shown him, will himself become king.”
“Then what should I do, venerable sir?” “Kill him at the root.”
“But isn’t it true, venerable sir, that my father should not be killed by a weapon?” “Kill him by cutting off his food.”
The prince had his father thrown into the torture chamber, a smokehouse built for the purpose of inflicting punishment.
He said: “Do not let anyone see him except my mother.”
The queen put rice in a golden vessel and entered, bringing the vessel on her hip.
The king ate the rice and continued to live.
The prince asked him: “My father, how do you continue to live?” Having learned how, he ordered: “Do not let my mother enter bringing anything on her hip.”
From then on the queen entered putting the vessel in her topknot.
Having learned about this, he ordered: “Do not let her enter with her hair bound in a topknot.”
Then she put rice inside a pair of golden shoes, sealed the shoes, put them on, and entered.
In this way the king continued to live.
Again, the prince asked how he lived, and having learned how, he ordered: “Do not let her enter wearing shoes.”
From then on the queen bathed with scented water, anointed her body with the four sweets (curd, honey, ghee, and molasses), dressed, and entered.
The king continued to live by licking her body.
Again the prince asked, and having heard the report, he ordered: “From now on prevent my mother from entering.”
The queen stood behind the door and cried out: “O, my husband Bimbisāra! You did not let me kill him in his infancy. You yourself nurtured your own enemy. This is the last time I will see you. From now on I will never see you again. If I have done anything wrong, please forgive me, my lord!” Weeping and wailing, she departed.
From then on the king did not receive any food.
The king continued to live by walking back and forth in the happiness of the path and fruit.
His body became extremely radiant.
The prince asked: “Father, how do you continue to live?” Learning that he continued to live by walking back and forth, and seeing that this body had become extremely radiant, the prince thought: “Now I will prevent him from walking back and forth.” He ordered his barbers: “Cut open my father’s feet with a razor, smear them with salt and oil and roast them over flameless coals of acacia wood.”
When the king saw the barbers, he thought: “Someone must have informed my son; they have come to trim my beard.”
They went to him, bowed down before him, and stood up.
He asked: “Why have you come here?” They reported their instructions.
He said: “You should do what your king commands.” They asked him to sit down, bowed to him, and said: “Your majesty, we are doing what the king has ordered us to do. Do not be angry at us. This isn’t proper for a righteous king such as yourself.” Then with the left hand they grabbed his ankles, with the right they took a razor, cut open his feet, smeared them with salt and oil, and roasted them over flameless coals of acacia wood.
It is said that the king, before, used to go to the *cetiya* terrace wearing shoes, and he stepped with unwashed feet on the *kaṭasāraka* mat that was laid out for sitting, therefore this happened.
The king experienced severe pain.
While recollecting the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha he withered up like a garland of flowers thrown upon the terrace of a *cetiya*, and was reborn in the heavenly world of the Four Great Kings as a spirit named Janavasabha in the retinue of Vessavaṇa.
That same day a son was born to Ajātasattu. Two letters reached him simultaneously, one telling him of the birth of his son, the other of his father’s death.
The ministers, thinking: “First we will report to him the birth of his son,” handed him that letter.
The moment love for his newborn son arose in the king, shook his entire body, and penetrated through to the marrow of his bones.
At that moment he understood what it means to be a father, realizing, “When I was born, my own father felt such love for me.”

He said, “Go, men, release my father.”

They said, “How can we release him, your majesty?” and handed him the other letter.

As soon as he learned the news, he went weeping to his mother and asked her: “Mother, did my father feel love for me when I was born?” She said: “My foolish son, why do you say that? When you were a small child, a boil arose on your finger.

You kept on weeping and they couldn’t quiet you down, so they took you to your father, who was sitting in the judgement hall.

Your father put your finger in his mouth,

and the boil broke open right in his mouth.

He couldn’t spit out the pus and blood, so out of love for you, he swallowed them.

Such was your father’s love for you.”

Weeping and lamenting, he disposed of his father’s body.

Devadatta then approached Ajātasattu and told the king to order some men to assassinate the Buddha. He sent the men given to him . Then Devadatta ascended Vulture’s Peak himself and with a sling hurled a rock at the Buddha . He even had the elephant Nālāgiri let loose , but no matter what method he used, he could not kill the Exalted One. When his gains and honor had been lost, he asked the Buddha to accept his five proposals. 19 The Buddha did not agree, and Devadatta thought to use those points

He asked, “Where does the Teacher dwell now?” When they said, “In Jetavana,” he said, “Bring me there on a stretcher so I can see the Teacher.” As he was being carried , because he had not done a deed worthy of seeing the Blessed One, near the pond in Jetavana the earth split into two, he sank into the great hell.

This is a brief explanation.

A detailed account is related in the *Khandhakas*.

But since it can all be construed in the way already stated, the detail is not given here.

Thus the king was named Ajātasattu because the astrologers predicted: “Even while he is as yet unborn, he will be the king’s enemy.”

Vedehiputta means that he was the son of the daughter of King Kosala, not of the King of Videha.

But *Vedehī* is a term for a wise woman.

As it is said: “Vedehikā the headwoman (MN.

226), Venerable Ānanda, the sage of Videha” (SN.

2.
154).

Here is the meaning of the expression: because one knows by it, it is called *veda*, that is, a term for knowledge.

Because she strives, exerts herself, and perseveres with knowledge, therefore she is *Vedehī*.

The son of Vedehī is Vedehiputta.

*Tadahūti* means on that day, that is, on that day.

*Uposatha* means that one dwells near to, meaning that one dwells possessing virtue or refraining from food.

This is the extraction of the meaning here: “Come, friend Kappina, let us go to the *uposatha*,” etc., the recitation of the Pāṭimokkha is the *uposatha*.

“Thus the *uposatha* undertaken and observed with its eight factors,” etc. (AN 8.43), is virtue (*sīla*).

“For the pure one there is always success, for the pure one the *uposatha* is always fruitful,” etc. (MN 1.79) is fasting (*upavāsa*).

“*Uposatha* is the name of a Nāga king,” etc. (DN.
2.
246) Description (paññatti).
“Monks, dwellings should not be fully occupied with monks on that uposatha day,” etc. (Mahāva.
181) A day for observing the fast.
Here, too, the same is intended.
But this is threefold through the distinction of the eighth, fourteenth, and fifteenth days.
Therefore, it is said "fifteenth" in order to prevent the exclusion of the two remaining days.
It was said thus: "Because one observes the fast here, it is called *uposatha*."
"Komudī" means belonging to the *kumuda* water lilies.
At that time, it is said, the *kumuda* water lilies are in full bloom; because they exist here, it is *komudī*.
"Cātumāsinī" means belonging to the four months; because it is the end of four months, it is *cātumāsī*.
Here, however, it is called *cātumāsinī*.
Because of the fullness of the month, because of the fullness of the seasons, because of the fullness of the year, it is full, completely full, therefore full (puṇṇā sampuṇṇāti puṇṇā).
The moon is called *mā*; because it is full here, it is the full moon (puṇṇamā).
Thus, in these two terms, puṇṇāya puṇṇamāyāti, the meaning should be understood.
“Surrounded by the king’s ministers” means, the meaning is: surrounded by the king’s ministers in a night resembling this, with the quarters being washed by streams of milk issuing forth from silver pitchers, resembling silver palaces scattered with multitudes of garlands of pearls, excellent jasmine flowers, white cloths, and *kumuda* water lilies, resembling the full moon’s light, free from the four corruptions, illuminating the rising of the *prabhā*.
“Gone above the best palace” means gone above the best palace.
He sits on a valuable, gold seat with a raised, white umbrella.
Why is he sitting? For the purpose of warding off sleep.
For this king, from the day he killed his father, "I will lie down and sleep," as soon as his eyes were closed, he woke up crying as if struck by a hundred spears.
When asked, "What is this?", he says, "Nothing."
Thus, sleep is unpleasant for him; therefore, he sits for the purpose of warding off sleep.
Moreover, on that day, a festival (nakkhatta) was proclaimed.
The entire city was sprinkled and swept, scattered with sand, the door of every house adorned with pitchers full of five-colored flowers and parched grain, every direction was beautified with raised flags and banners of various designs and rows of brightly shining lamps, crowded with a great mass of people experiencing the pleasure of the festival games in every street and at every crossroads.
Thus, they say that he sits because of the day of the festival.
However, even after saying this, the conclusion was made: "For the royal family, it is always a festival, but he is sitting only for the purpose of warding off sleep."
"He exclaimed the joyful exclamation" means he uttered an exclamation, just as when oil cannot hold its measure, it drips away, that is called dripping away (avaseko).
And as water cannot be contained by a pond, it overflows, that is called a flood (ogho); just so, when a joyful statement cannot be contained by the heart, having become excessive, without remaining inside, it bursts forth, that is called a joyful exclamation (udāna).
The meaning is, he utters a joyful statement of this kind.
"Dosina" means free from faults; it means free from these five corruptions: clouds (abbhā), mist (mahikā), smoke (dhūmo), dust (rajo), and Rāhu.
Therefore, the five words of praise beginning with "ramaṇīyāti".
Because it delights the mind of the great multitude, it is delightful (ramaṇīyā).
Because of being illuminated by the light of the moon free from the aforementioned faults, it is exceedingly beautiful, therefore, exquisite (abhirūpā).
Because it is proper to see, it is worth seeing (dassanīyā).
Because it pleases the mind, it is pleasing (pāsādikā).
Because it is proper for the characteristics of days and months to come into existence, it is characterized by such (lakkhaññā).
"Who will I eat today?" means "Who will I feed today?"
A *śramaṇa* or a *brāhmaṇa* means a *śramaṇa* because of calming demerit.
A *brāhmaṇa* because of dispelling demerit.
"Whom do you serve?" This is an expression of words, meaning: by hearing the sweet Dhamma from those who serve us by means of asking questions, the mind would be pleased.
Thus, the king gave a hint by this entire statement, performing an act to indicate a sign ( *obhāsanimittakammaṃ akāsi*).

To whom does he give it? To Jīvaka.

For what purpose? In order to see the Exalted One (*bhagavato dassanatthaṃ*).

But couldn’t he go to the Exalted One on his own to see him? Yes, he cannot.

Why? Because of his great crimes (*mahāparādhatāya*).

For his own father, who was a noble disciple (*ariyasāvako*) and a supporter (*upaṭṭhāko*) of the Exalted One, was killed, and he himself, relying on Devadatta, did much harm (*anatthamakāsi*) to the Exalted One. Thus, this is a great crime (*mahāparādho*), and because of this great crime (*mahāparādhatāya*) he cannot go on his own.

But Jīvaka was a supporter (*upaṭṭhāko*) of the Exalted One, so he gave a hint (*obhāsanimittakammaṃ akāsi*), thinking: “I will see the Exalted One, like his shadow.”

Did Jīvaka understand that the king was giving him a hint (*obhāsanimittakammaṃ*)? Yes, he understood.

Then why did he remain silent? In order to cut off interruptions (*vikkhepapacchedanatthaṃ*).

For in that assembly there were many supporters (*upaṭṭhākā bahū sannipatitā*) of the six teachers, and since those on whom they attend are untrained (*asikkhitānaṃ*), they themselves are not properly trained (*asikkhitāva*).

If I should begin to speak about the virtues (*guṇakathaṃ*) of the Exalted One (*bhagavato*), they would rise up, interrupt me, and speak about the virtues (*guṇaṃ kathessanti*) of their own teachers (*satthārānaṃ*). Thus, my talk on the virtues (*guṇakathā*) of the Teacher (*satthu*) will not reach its conclusion (*pariyosānaṃ na gamissati*).

But as the king, having approached those supporters of families (*kulūpake*) and finding their account of virtues to be substanceless (*gahitāsāratāya*), will be dissatisfied (*anattamano hutvā*) with their account of virtues (*guṇakathāya*), he will question me (*paṭipucchissati*). Then, without being interrupted (*nibbikkhepaṃ*), I will explain the virtues (*guṇaṃ kathetvā*) of the Teacher (*satthu*) and, knowing such talk to be substanceless, take the king along with me to meet the Teacher (*satthu santikaṃ gahetvā gamissāmi*). Thus he remained silent in order to cut off interruptions (*vikkhepapacchedanatthaṃ tuṇhī ahosīti*).

Those ministers also thought: “Today the king extols the night in five ways (*pañcahi padehi rattiṃ thometi*). Surely he wishes to approach some recluse (*samaṇaṃ*) or Brahmin (*brāhmaṇaṃ*), question him, and hear the Dhamma (*dhammaṃ sotukāmo*). He will show great honor (*mahantaṃ sakkāraṃ karissati*) to the one whose Dhamma inspires his confidence (*pasīdissati*). And it will be fortunate (*bhaddaṃ*) for the one whose recluse (*samaṇo*) wins the support of the royal family (*rājakulūpako hoti*).”

mula_pali: 151. Evaṃ vutte, aññataro rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, deva, pūraṇo kassapo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto. Taṃ devo pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mula_english:
151.
When this was said, one of the king's ministers said to King Ajātaśatru (Ajātasattu), the son of Vaidehī, of Magadha: "Sire, there is Pūraṇa Kassapa, the head of an order, the leader of a group, the teacher of a group, well-known, famous, a founder of a sect, highly esteemed by many people, experienced, long gone forth, advanced in years, and has reached old age.
Your Majesty should visit this Pūraṇa Kassapa.
Perhaps by visiting Pūraṇa Kassapa, your Majesty’s mind might find peace."
When this was said, King Ajātaśatru (Ajātasattu), the son of Vaidehī, of Magadha, remained silent.
commentary_pali: 151-152. Te evaṃ cintetvā – ‘‘ahaṃ attano kulūpakasamaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ vatvā rājānaṃ gahetvā gamissāmi, ahaṃ gamissāmī’’ti attano attano kulūpakānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ kathetuṃ āraddhā. Tenāha – ‘‘evaṃ vutte aññataro rājāmacco’’tiādi. Tattha pūraṇoti tassa satthupaṭiññassa nāmaṃ. Kassapoti gottaṃ. So kira aññatarassa kulassa ekūnadāsasataṃ pūrayamāno jāto, tenassa pūraṇoti nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Maṅgaladāsattā cassa ‘‘dukkaṭa’’nti vattā natthi, akataṃ vā na katanti. So ‘‘kimahaṃ ettha vasāmī’’ti palāyi. Athassa corā vatthāni acchindiṃsu, so paṇṇena vā tiṇena vā paṭicchādetumpi ajānanto jātarūpeneva ekaṃ gāmaṃ pāvisi. Manussā taṃ disvā ‘‘ayaṃ samaṇo arahā appiccho, natthi iminā sadiso’’ti pūvabhattādīni gahetvā upasaṅkamanti. So – ‘‘mayhaṃ sāṭakaṃ anivatthabhāvena idaṃ uppanna’’nti tato paṭṭhāya sāṭakaṃ labhitvāpi na nivāsesi, tadeva pabbajjaṃ aggahesi, tassa santike  aññepi aññepīti pañcasatamanussā pabbajiṃsu. Taṃ sandhāyāha – ‘‘pūraṇo kassapo’’ti. Pabbajitasamūhasaṅkhāto saṅgho assa atthīti saṅghī. Sveva gaṇo assa atthīti gaṇī. Ācārasikkhāpanavasena tassa gaṇassa ācariyoti gaṇācariyo. Ñātoti paññāto pākaṭo. ‘‘Appiccho  santuṭṭho. Appicchatāya vatthampi na nivāsetī’’ti evaṃ samuggato yaso assa atthīti yasassī. Titthakaroti laddhikaro. Sādhusammatoti ayaṃ sādhu, sundaro, sappurisoti evaṃ sammato. Bahujanassāti assutavato andhabālaputhujjanassa. Pabbajitato paṭṭhāya atikkantā bahū rattiyo jānātīti rattaññū. Ciraṃ pabbajitassa assāti cirapabbajito, acirapabbajitassa hi kathā okappanīyā na hoti, tenāha ‘‘cirapabbajito’’ti. Addhagatoti addhānaṃ gato, dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe atītoti adhippāyo. Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ anuppatto. Idaṃ ubhayampi – ‘‘daharassa kathā okappanīyā na hotī’’ti etaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tuṇhīahosīti suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ madhurarasaṃ ambapakkaṃ khāditukāmo puriso āharitvā hatthe ṭhapitaṃ kājarapakkaṃ disvā viya jhānābhiññādiguṇayuttaṃ tilakkhaṇabbhāhataṃ madhuraṃ dhammakathaṃ sotukāmo pubbe pūraṇassa dassanenāpi anattamano idāni guṇakathāya suṭṭhutaraṃ anattamano hutvā tuṇhī ahosi. Anattamano samānopi pana ‘‘sacāhaṃ etaṃ tajjetvā gīvāyaṃ gahetvā nīharāpessāmi, ‘yo yo kathesi, taṃ taṃ rājā evaṃ karotī’ti bhīto aññopi koci kiñci na kathessatī’’ti amanāpampi taṃ kathaṃ adhivāsetvā tuṇhī eva ahosi. Athañño – ‘‘ahaṃ attano kulūpakassa vaṇṇaṃ kathessāmī’’ti cintetvā vattuṃ ārabhi. Tena vuttaṃ – aññataropi khotiādi. Taṃ sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Ettha pana makkhalīti tassa nāmaṃ. Gosālāya jātattā gosāloti dutiyaṃ nāmaṃ. Taṃ kira sakaddamāya bhūmiyā telaghaṭaṃ  gahetvā gacchantaṃ – ‘‘tāta, mā khalī’’ti sāmiko āha. So pamādena khalitvā patitvā sāmikassa bhayena palāyituṃ āraddho. Sāmiko upadhāvitvā dussakaṇṇe aggahesi. So sāṭakaṃ chaḍḍetvā acelako hutvā palāyi. Sesaṃ pūraṇasadisameva.
commentary_english:
151-152.

Having thought thus: “I will praise the recluse I support and, taking the king, I will go; I will go,” they began to describe the virtues of the recluses they each supported.

Therefore, he said: “Thus spoken, another royal minister," etc.

There, *pūraṇoti* is the name of his teacher's claim.

*kassapoti* is the clan (*gotta*).

It is said that he was born fulfilling ninety-nine in a certain family of slaves; therefore they gave him the name Pūraṇa.

And because he was an auspicious slave, there was no one to say to him, “This is badly done (dukkaṭa),” or “This is not done, or is done.”

He thought, "Why should I live here?" and fled.

Then thieves stole his clothes; not even knowing how to cover himself with leaves or grass, he entered a certain village naked.

People, seeing him, thought, "This is a *śramaṇa* (samaṇa), an *arhat* (arahā), with few wishes, there is none like him," and approached him, taking cakes, rice, etc.

He—"This arose for me because of going without clothes (anivatthabhāvena)," from then on, even having obtained a cloak (*sāṭaka*), he did not wear it; he accepted that very nakedness as his going forth (*pabbajja*), near him five hundred men went forth.

Referring to that, he said, "Pūraṇa Kassapa."

He is called *saṃghī* because he has an assembly (*saṃgha*) reckoned as a community of renunciates.

He is called *gaṇī* because he has a group (*gaṇa*).

Because of teaching conduct (*ācārasikkhāpanavasena*) he is the teacher (*ācariya*) of that group (*gaṇa*), therefore a *gaṇācariya*.

Known (*ñāto*) means understood (*paññāto*), manifest (*pākaṭo*).

"Having few wishes (*appiccho*), content (*santuṭṭho*)."

Because of having few wishes (*appicchatāya*) he does not even wear clothes (*vatthampi na nivāseti*)," thus, because he has fame (*yaso*) that has risen up (*samuggato*), he is *yasassī*.

*titthakaro* means one who makes a doctrine (*laddhikaro*).

Approved by the virtuous (*sādhusammatoti*) means this one is good (*sādhu*), beautiful (*sundaro*), a good person (*sappuriso*), thus esteemed (*evam sammato*).

Belonging to many people (*bahujanassa*) means of the untaught, blind, foolish, ordinary person (*assutavato andhabālaputhujjanassa*).

He knows (*jānāti*) many nights (*bahū rattiyo*) that have passed (*atikkantā*) since going forth (*pabbajitato paṭṭhāya*), therefore he is *rattaññū*.

Because he has been long gone forth (*ciraṃ pabbajitassa*), therefore he is *cirapabbajito*; for the talk of one recently gone forth (*acirapabbajitassa*) is not convincing (*okappanīyā na hoti*), therefore he said "*cirapabbajito*."

Having gone the road (*addhagatoti*) means he has gone the road (*addhānaṃ gato*), the meaning (*adhippāyo*) is that two or three royal cycles (*dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe*) have passed (*atīto*).

Having attained age (*vayoanuppattoti*) means having attained the final age (*pacchimavayaṃ anuppatto*).

Both of these—"the talk of a young person (*daharassa kathā*) is not convincing (*okappanīyā na hoti*)"—is said referring to this (*etaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ*).

He was silent (tuṇhīahosīti): As a man, desiring to eat a ripe mango (ambapakkaṃ) of golden color (suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ) and sweet taste (madhurarasaṃ), having brought and placed in his hand a kājara fruit (kājarapakkaṃ), seeing it as if (viya) devoid of (*guṇayuttaṃ*) *jhānas* (*jhāna*) and direct knowledges (*abhiññā*), struck by the three characteristics (tilakkhaṇabbhāhataṃ), wishing to hear (*sotukāmo*) sweet (*madhuraṃ*) *dharma* talk (*dhammakathaṃ*), previously displeased (*anattamano*) even by the sight (*dassanena*) of Pūraṇa (pūbbē), now even more displeased (*suṭṭhutaraṃ anattamano*) by the talk about his virtues (*guṇakathāya*), having become (*hutvā*) silent (*tuṇhī*) he was (*ahosi*).

Although having the same mind but "If I rebuke him, grab him by the neck, and expel him, 'the king does this to whoever speaks' so he will be afraid and no one else will say anything," even though unpleasant, having endured that talk, he was utterly silent.

Then another, thinking, “I will speak of the virtues of the recluse I support (*kulūpakassa vaṇṇaṃ kathessāmī*),” began to speak (*vattuṃ ārabhi*).

Therefore, it was said, "Another also," etc.

All that (*taṃ sabbaṃ*) should be understood (*veditabbaṃ*) in the way stated (*vuttanayeneva*).

Here, *makkhalīti* is his name (*nāmaṃ*).

Because he was born in Gosāla (*gosālāya jātattā*) his second name is Gosāla (*gosāloti dutiyaṃ nāmaṃ*).

It is said that while he was taking a pot of oil (*telaghaṭaṃ*) across muddy ground (*sakaddamāya bhūmiyā*), the master (*sāmiko*) said, “Dear, don’t stumble (*mā khalī*)!”

He, because of carelessness (*pamādena*) stumbling (*khalitvā*) and falling (*patitvā*), seized by fear (*bhayena*) of his master (*sāmikassa*), began (*āraddho*) to flee (*palāyituṃ*).

The master, having run up (*upadhāvitvā*), grabbed (*aggahesi*) the edge of his cloak (*dussakaṇṇe*).

He, having thrown off (*chaḍḍetvā*) the cloak (*sāṭakaṃ*), naked (*acelako hutvā*) fled (*palāyi*).

The rest (*sesaṃ*) is just like the story of Pūraṇa (*pūraṇasadisameva*).

mula_pali: 152. Aññataropi kho rājāmacco  rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, deva, makkhali  gosālo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto. Taṃ devo makkhaliṃ gosālaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa makkhaliṃ gosālaṃ payirupāsato  cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mula_english:
Another minister, a royal official, said to King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videhas, of Magadha: "Sire, there is Makkhali Gosāla, who has a following, a group, a teacher of a group, well-known, famous, a founder of a doctrine, esteemed by good people, experienced by many people, long a renunciate, advanced in years, reached old age.

May Your Majesty visit Makkhali Gosāla.

Perhaps, by visiting Makkhali Gosāla, peace may come to Your Majesty's heart."

When this was said, King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videhas, of Magadha, was silent.
commentary_pali: 151-152. Te evaṃ cintetvā – ‘‘ahaṃ attano kulūpakasamaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ vatvā rājānaṃ gahetvā gamissāmi, ahaṃ gamissāmī’’ti attano attano kulūpakānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ kathetuṃ āraddhā. Tenāha – ‘‘evaṃ vutte aññataro rājāmacco’’tiādi. Tattha pūraṇoti tassa satthupaṭiññassa nāmaṃ. Kassapoti gottaṃ. So kira aññatarassa kulassa ekūnadāsasataṃ pūrayamāno jāto, tenassa pūraṇoti nāmaṃ akaṃsu. Maṅgaladāsattā cassa ‘‘dukkaṭa’’nti vattā natthi, akataṃ vā na katanti. So ‘‘kimahaṃ ettha vasāmī’’ti palāyi. Athassa corā vatthāni acchindiṃsu, so paṇṇena vā tiṇena vā paṭicchādetumpi ajānanto jātarūpeneva ekaṃ gāmaṃ pāvisi. Manussā taṃ disvā ‘‘ayaṃ samaṇo arahā appiccho, natthi iminā sadiso’’ti pūvabhattādīni gahetvā upasaṅkamanti. So – ‘‘mayhaṃ sāṭakaṃ anivatthabhāvena idaṃ uppanna’’nti tato paṭṭhāya sāṭakaṃ labhitvāpi na nivāsesi, tadeva pabbajjaṃ aggahesi, tassa santike  aññepi aññepīti pañcasatamanussā pabbajiṃsu. Taṃ sandhāyāha – ‘‘pūraṇo kassapo’’ti. Pabbajitasamūhasaṅkhāto saṅgho assa atthīti saṅghī. Sveva gaṇo assa atthīti gaṇī. Ācārasikkhāpanavasena tassa gaṇassa ācariyoti gaṇācariyo. Ñātoti paññāto pākaṭo. ‘‘Appiccho  santuṭṭho. Appicchatāya vatthampi na nivāsetī’’ti evaṃ samuggato yaso assa atthīti yasassī. Titthakaroti laddhikaro. Sādhusammatoti ayaṃ sādhu, sundaro, sappurisoti evaṃ sammato. Bahujanassāti assutavato andhabālaputhujjanassa. Pabbajitato paṭṭhāya atikkantā bahū rattiyo jānātīti rattaññū. Ciraṃ pabbajitassa assāti cirapabbajito, acirapabbajitassa hi kathā okappanīyā na hoti, tenāha ‘‘cirapabbajito’’ti. Addhagatoti addhānaṃ gato, dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe atītoti adhippāyo. Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ anuppatto. Idaṃ ubhayampi – ‘‘daharassa kathā okappanīyā na hotī’’ti etaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tuṇhīahosīti suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ madhurarasaṃ ambapakkaṃ khāditukāmo puriso āharitvā hatthe ṭhapitaṃ kājarapakkaṃ disvā viya jhānābhiññādiguṇayuttaṃ tilakkhaṇabbhāhataṃ madhuraṃ dhammakathaṃ sotukāmo pubbe pūraṇassa dassanenāpi anattamano idāni guṇakathāya suṭṭhutaraṃ anattamano hutvā tuṇhī ahosi. Anattamano samānopi pana ‘‘sacāhaṃ etaṃ tajjetvā gīvāyaṃ gahetvā nīharāpessāmi, ‘yo yo kathesi, taṃ taṃ rājā evaṃ karotī’ti bhīto aññopi koci kiñci na kathessatī’’ti amanāpampi taṃ kathaṃ adhivāsetvā tuṇhī eva ahosi. Athañño – ‘‘ahaṃ attano kulūpakassa vaṇṇaṃ kathessāmī’’ti cintetvā vattuṃ ārabhi. Tena vuttaṃ – aññataropi khotiādi. Taṃ sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Ettha pana makkhalīti tassa nāmaṃ. Gosālāya jātattā gosāloti dutiyaṃ nāmaṃ. Taṃ kira sakaddamāya bhūmiyā telaghaṭaṃ  gahetvā gacchantaṃ – ‘‘tāta, mā khalī’’ti sāmiko āha. So pamādena khalitvā patitvā sāmikassa bhayena palāyituṃ āraddho. Sāmiko upadhāvitvā dussakaṇṇe aggahesi. So sāṭakaṃ chaḍḍetvā acelako hutvā palāyi. Sesaṃ pūraṇasadisameva.
commentary_english:
151-152. Having thought thus: "I will praise the *śramaṇa* recluse of my family and take the king and go, I will go," they began to tell the praises of their own family *śramaṇas*.

Therefore, it was said: "Thus spoken, another royal minister," and so on.

There, Pūraṇa was the name of his teacher's order.

Kassapa was the clan.

It is said that he was born completing ninety-nine slaves of a certain family, therefore they gave him the name Pūraṇa.

Because he was an auspicious slave, no one ever said to him "This is badly done (dukkaṭa)," or "This is undone, or not done."

He thought, "Why should I live here?" and fled.

Then thieves stole his clothes, and not knowing how to cover himself with leaves or grass, he entered a village naked, just as he was born.

People saw him and thought, "This is a *śramaṇa*, an *arhat*, with few desires, there is no one like him," and taking cakes, rice, etc., they approached him.

He—"Because of not wearing clothes (anivatthabhāvena), this (sāṭakaṃ) has arisen for me"—from then on, even having obtained a cloak (sāṭakaṃ), he did not wear it, he accepted that very nakedness as his going forth (*pravrajyā*), near him, others and others, five hundred men went forth.

Referring to that, he said: "Pūraṇa Kassapa."

He is called *saṃghī* because he has an assembly (*saṃgha*) known as an assembly of those who have gone forth (*pravrajitasamūhasaṅkhāta*).

He is called *gaṇī* because he has his own group (*gaṇa*).

Because of teaching conduct, the teacher of that group (*gaṇa*) is called *gaṇācāriya*.

Known (ñāto) means understood (paññāto), manifest (pākaṭo).

"With few desires (appiccho), content (santuṭṭho)."

Because of having few desires (*appicchatāya*), he does not even wear clothes (*vatthaṃ*), thus he has fame (*yaso*) that has risen, therefore he is famous (*yasassī*).

A *tīrthaka* is a maker of gains (*laddhikaro*).

*Sādhusammatoti:* This one is good (*sādhu*), beautiful (*sundaro*), a good person (*sappuriso*), thus agreed upon (*sammato*).

For the many (*bahujanassa*), that is, for the unlearned (*assutavato*), blind, childish, ordinary person (*andhabālaputhujjanassa*).

Because he knows (*jānāti*) many nights (*bahū rattiyo*) that have passed since he went forth (*pravrajita*), he is a knower of nights (*rattaññū*).

He is called a long-term renunciate (*cirapabbajito*) because he has long been a renunciate; because the talk of a recently renunciated person (*acirapabbajita*) is not trustworthy, therefore he said, "long-term renunciate (*cirapabbajito*)."

Addhaga means gone (*gato*) to the road (*addhānaṃ*), the meaning is that two or three royal eras (*rājaparivaṭṭe*) have passed.

*Vayoanuppattoti:* having attained the final age (*pacchimavayaṃ anuppatto*).

Both of these—"the talk of a young person (*daharassa*) is not trustworthy (*okappanīyā na hotī*)"—were said referring to this.

*Tuṇhīahosīti:* Because he wanted to eat a ripe mango (*ambapakkaṃ*) with a golden color (*suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ*) and sweet taste (*madhurarasaṃ*), a man brought a *kājara* fruit and placed it in his hand, seeing it like that, he wished to hear the sweet *dharma* talk joined with the qualities (*guṇa*) of *jhāna* and *abhijñā*, struck with the three characteristics (*tilakkhaṇaabbhāhataṃ*), previously he was not pleased (*anattamano*) even by the sight of Pūraṇa, now he became even more displeased (*anattamano*) by the talk of qualities (*guṇakathāya*), and remained silent (*tuṇhī ahosi*).

Although he was equal (*samāno*) in his displeasure (*anattamano*), he thought, "If I threaten him, grab him by the neck and drive him out, ‘the king does this to whoever speaks,’ so fearing, no one else will say anything," thus enduring even that unpleasant (*amanāpampi*) talk (*kathaṃ*) he remained completely silent (*tuṇhī eva ahosi*).

Then another minister, thinking, "I will speak the praise (*vaṇṇaṃ kathessāmī*) of my own family supporter (*kulūpakassa*)," began to speak (*vattuṃ ārabhi*).

Therefore, it was said: "Another, indeed," and so on.

All that should be understood in the same way as stated (*vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ*).

Here, Makkhalī is his name.

Gosāla is the second name, because he was born in Gosāla.

It is said that while he was going carrying a pot of oil (*telaghaṭaṃ*) on muddy ground, his master said, "Dear, do not stumble (*mā khalī*)."

He, by carelessness (*pamādena*), having stumbled (*khalitvā*) and fallen (*patitvā*), began to flee (*palāyituṃ ārabdho*) out of fear (*bhayena*) of his master (*sāmikassa*).

The master, running after (*upadhāvitvā*), grabbed the edge (*kaṇṇe*) of his cloak (*dussa*).

He, discarding the cloak (*sāṭakaṃ chaḍḍetvā*), became naked (*acelako hutvā*) and fled (*palāyi*).

The rest is the same as in the story of Pūraṇa (*pūraṇasadisameva*).

mula_pali: 153. Aññataropi  kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, deva, ajito kesakambalo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto. Taṃ devo ajitaṃ kesakambalaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa ajitaṃ kesakambalaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mula_english:
Another minister said to King Ajātaśatru, son of Videha, of Magadha: ‘Sire, there is Ajita Kesakambala, who has a following, a teacher of a group, well-known, famous, a founder of a school, esteemed by many, long experienced, long gone forth, advanced in years, and aged.

May Your Majesty visit Ajita Kesakambala.

Perhaps by visiting Ajita Kesakambala, the mind of Your Majesty might be pleased.’

When this was said, King Ajātaśatru, son of Videha, of Magadha, was silent.
commentary_pali: 153.Ajitoti tassa nāmaṃ. Kesakambalaṃ dhāretīti kesakambalo. Iti nāmadvayaṃ saṃsanditvā ajito kesakambaloti vuccati . Tattha kesakambalo nāma manussakesehi katakambalo. Tato paṭikiṭṭhataraṃ vatthaṃ nāma natthi. Yathāha – ‘‘seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici tantāvutānaṃ vatthānaṃ, kesakambalo tesaṃ paṭikiṭṭho akkhāyati. Kesakambalo, bhikkhave, sīte sīto, uṇhe uṇho, dubbaṇṇo duggandho dukkhasamphasso’’ti (a. ni. 3.138).
commentary_english:
Ajita was his name (Ajito tassa nāmaṃ).
Because he wore a hair blanket (kesakambalaṃ dhāretīti), he was called Kesakambala (kesakambalo).
Thus, combining the two names, he is called Ajita Kesakambala (ajito kesakambaloti vuccati).
There, a *kesakambala* is a blanket made of human hair (manussakesehi katakambalo).
Indeed, there is no garment more repulsive than that (tato paṭikiṭṭhataraṃ vatthaṃ nāma natthi).
As it is said: "Just as, monks, of all woven cloths, a hair blanket (kesakambalo) is known to be the most repulsive.
A hair blanket (kesakambalo), monks, is cold in the cold, hot in the heat, ugly, foul-smelling and unpleasant to the touch" (dukkhasamphasso).

mula_pali: 154. Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, deva, pakudho pakuddho (sī.) kaccāyano saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto. Taṃ devo pakudhaṃ kaccāyanaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa pakudhaṃ kaccāyanaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mula_english:
Another minister said to King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videhis, of Magadha: ‘Sire, there is Pakudha Kaccāyana, who has a following, a group, is the teacher of a group, well-known, famous, a founder of a doctrine, esteemed by good people, experienced, long gone forth, advanced in years, and has reached old age.

Your majesty should visit Pakudha Kaccāyana.

Perhaps by visiting Pakudha Kaccāyana, your majesty's mind might be pleased.’

When this was said, King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videhis, of Magadha, remained silent.
commentary_pali: 154.Pakudhoti tassa nāmaṃ. Kaccāyanoti gottaṃ. Iti nāmagottaṃ saṃsanditvā pakudho kaccāyanoti vuccati. Sītudakapaṭikkhittako esa, vaccaṃ katvāpi udakakiccaṃ na karoti, uṇhodakaṃ vā kañjiyaṃ vā labhitvā karoti, nadiṃ vā maggodakaṃ vā atikkamma – ‘‘sīlaṃ me bhinna’’nti vālikathūpaṃ katvā sīlaṃ adhiṭṭhāya gacchati. Evarūpo nissirīkaladdhiko esa.
commentary_english:
154. Pakudha was his name (nāmaṃ).
Kaccāyana (Kaccāyana) was his clan (gottaṃ).
Thus, combining the name and clan (nāmagottaṃ saṃsanditvā), he is called Pakudha Kaccāyana.
He refused to use cool water (sītudaka). Even after moving his bowels (vaccaṃ katvāpi), he did not wash with water (udakakiccaṃ na karoti), but only with warm water (uṇhodakaṃ) or rice water (kañjiyaṃ). If he passed through a river (nadiṃ) or puddle water (maggodakaṃ), he thought: “My moral discipline (sīlaṃ) has been broken (bhinnaṃ).” He then re-established his moral discipline (sīlaṃ adhiṭṭhāya) by building a mound of sand (vālikathūpaṃ katvā) and continued on his way (gacchati).
Such was his wretchedness.

mula_pali: 155. Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ  vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, deva, sañcayo sañjayo (sī. syā.) belaṭṭhaputto bellaṭṭhiputto (sī.), velaṭṭhaputto (syā.) saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto. Taṃ devo sañcayaṃ belaṭṭhaputtaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa sañcayaṃ belaṭṭhaputtaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mula_english: Another minister said to King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videhas, of Magadha: “Sire, there is Sañcaya Belatthaputta… a leader of a group, a teacher of a group, renowned, famous, a founder of a sect, esteemed by many, long experienced, long gone forth, advanced in years, and aged. May Your Majesty visit Sañcaya Belatthaputta.
