Perhaps by visiting Sañcaya Belatthaputta, the mind of Your Majesty might be pleased.” When this was said, King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videhas, of Magadha, was silent.
commentary_pali: 155.Sañcayoti tassa nāmaṃ. Belaṭṭhassa puttoti belaṭṭhaputto.
commentary_english:
155.
Sañcaya was his name. (sañcayoti tassa nāmaṃ)
He was the son of Belaṭṭha, therefore Belaṭṭhaputta. (belaṭṭhassa puttoti belaṭṭhaputto)

mula_pali: 156. Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ayaṃ, deva, nigaṇṭho  nāṭaputto nāthaputto (sī.), nātaputto (pī.) saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto. Taṃ devo nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa nigaṇṭhaṃ  nāṭaputtaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mula_english: Another minister said to King Ajātaśatru, son of Videha, of Magadha: "Sire, there is Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, who has a following, a group, a teacher of a group, well-known, famous, a founder of a school (*tīrthakara*), esteemed by good people, experienced by many people, long a renunciate, advanced in years, and has reached old age. May Your Majesty associate with Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta. Perhaps, by associating with Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, the mind of Your Majesty will be pleased." When this was said, King Ajātaśatru, son of Videha, of Magadha, was silent.
commentary_pali: 156. Amhākaṃ gaṇṭhanakileso palibandhanakileso natthi, kilesagaṇṭharahitā mayanti evaṃvāditāya laddhanāmavasena nigaṇṭho. Nāṭassa putto nāṭaputto.
commentary_english: He is called Nigaṇṭha because he proclaimed the doctrine: “We have no knots of defilements (*kleśa*), no ties of defilements (*kleśa*); we are free from the bonds of defilements (*kleśa*).” He was the son of Nāta, thus Nātaputta. (*nāṭassa putto nāṭaputto*)

mula_pali: 157. Tena  kho pana samayena jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre tuṇhībhūto nisinno hoti. Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘tvaṃ pana, samma jīvaka, kiṃ tuṇhī’’ti? ‘‘Ayaṃ, deva, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho amhākaṃ ambavane viharati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi. Taṃ kho pana bhagavantaṃ bhagavantaṃ gotamaṃ (sī. ka. pī.) evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo  abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti. Taṃ devo bhagavantaṃ payirupāsatu. Appeva nāma devassa bhagavantaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’ti.
mula_english:
157. At that time, Jīvaka Komārabhacca was sitting silently not far from King Ajātasattu, the son of Vedehī, of Magadha.

Then King Ajātasattu of Magadha, the son of Vedehī, said this to Jīvaka Komārabhacca: "Why are you silent, friend Jīvaka?"

"Your majesty, the Blessed One, the worthy one, the perfectly enlightened one, is staying in our mango grove with a large Saṅgha of monks, with thirteen and a half hundred monks.

This is the good report that has spread about that Blessed One Gotama: 'Indeed, that Blessed One is an *arhat* (worthy one), a *sammāsambuddha* (perfectly enlightened one), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a *sugata* (well-gone one), a knower of the world (*lokavidū*), an unsurpassed guide for those who need taming (*anuttaro purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a *buddha* (enlightened one), a *bhagavā* (blessed one).'

Your majesty should visit the Blessed One. Perhaps by visiting the Blessed One, your majesty's mind might find peace."
commentary_pali: 157.Athakho rājāti rājā kira tesaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā cintesi – ‘‘ahaṃ yassa yassa vacanaṃ na sotukāmo, so so eva  kathesi. Yassa panamhi vacanaṃ sotukāmo, esa nāgavasaṃ pivitvā ṭhito supaṇṇo viya tuṇhībhūto, anattho vata me’’ti. Athassa etadahosi – ‘‘jīvako upasantassa buddhassa bhagavato upaṭṭhāko, sayampi upasanto, tasmā vattasampanno bhikkhu viya tuṇhībhūtova nisinno, na esa mayi akathente kathessati, hatthimhi kho pana maddante hatthisseva pādo gahetabbo’’ti tena saddhiṃ sayaṃ mantetumāraddho. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘atha kho rājā’’ti. Tattha kiṃ tuṇhīti kena kāraṇena tuṇhī. Imesaṃ amaccānaṃ attano attano kulūpakasamaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ kathentānaṃ mukhaṃ nappahoti . Kiṃ yathā etesaṃ, evaṃ tava kulūpakasamaṇo natthi, kiṃ tvaṃ daliddo, na te mama pitarā issariyaṃ dinnaṃ, udāhu assaddhoti pucchati. Tato jīvakassa etadahosi – ‘‘ayaṃ rājā maṃ kulūpakasamaṇassa guṇaṃ kathāpeti, na dāni me tuṇhībhāvassa kālo, yathā kho panime rājānaṃ vanditvā nisinnāva attano kulūpakasamaṇānaṃ guṇaṃ kathayiṃsu, na mayhaṃ evaṃ satthuguṇe kathetuṃ yutta’’nti uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavato vihārābhimukho pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā dasanakhasamodhānasamujjalaṃ añjaliṃ sirasi paggahetvā – ‘‘mahārāja, mā maṃ evaṃ cintayittha, ‘ayaṃ yaṃ vā taṃ vā samaṇaṃ upasaṅkamatī’ti, mama satthuno hi mātukucchiokkamane, mātukucchito nikkhamane, mahābhinikkhamane, sambodhiyaṃ, dhammacakkappavattane ca, dasasahassilokadhātu kampittha, evaṃ yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ akāsi, evaṃ devorohaṇaṃ, ahaṃ satthuno guṇe kathayissāmi, ekaggacitto suṇa, mahārājā’’ti vatvā – ‘‘ayaṃ deva, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho’’tiādimāha. Tattha taṃ kho pana bhagavantanti itthambhūtākhyānatthe upayogavacanaṃ, tassa kho pana bhagavatoti attho. Kalyāṇoti kalyāṇaguṇasamannāgato, seṭṭhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Kittisaddoti kittiyeva. Thutighoso vā. Abbhuggatoti sadevakaṃ lokaṃ ajjhottharitvā uggato. Kinti? ‘‘Itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… bhagavā’’ti. Tatrāyaṃ padasambandho – so bhagavā itipi arahaṃ itipi sammāsambuddho…pe… itipi bhagavāti. Iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha ārakattā arīnaṃ, arānañca hatattā, paccayādīnaṃ arahattā, pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvāti, imehi tāva kāraṇehi so bhagavā  arahanti veditabbotiādinā nayena mātikaṃ nikkhipitvā sabbāneva cetāni padāni visuddhimagge buddhānussatiniddese vitthāritānīti tato nesaṃ vitthāro gahetabbo. Jīvako pana ekamekassa padassa atthaṃ niṭṭhāpetvā – ‘‘evaṃ, mahārāja, arahaṃ mayhaṃ satthā, evaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… evaṃ bhagavā’’ti vatvā – ‘‘taṃ, devo, bhagavantaṃ payirupāsatu, appeva nāma devassa taṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā’’ti āha. Ettha ca taṃ devo payirupāsatūti vadanto ‘‘mahārāja, tumhādisānañhi satenapi sahassenapi satasahassenapi puṭṭhassa  mayhaṃ satthuno sabbesaṃ cittaṃ gahetvā kathetuṃ thāmo ca balañca atthi, vissattho upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi mahārājā’’ti āha. Raññopi bhagavato guṇakathaṃ suṇantassa sakalasarīraṃ pañcavaṇṇāya pītiyā nirantaraṃ phuṭaṃ ahosi. So taṅkhaṇaññeva gantukāmo hutvā – ‘‘imāya kho pana velāya mayhaṃ dasabalassa santikaṃ gacchato na añño koci khippaṃ yānāni yojetuṃ sakkhissati aññatra jīvakā’’ti cintetvā – ‘‘tena hi, samma jīvaka, hatthiyānāni kappāpehī’’ti āha.
commentary_english:
157. Then, the king of kings, having heard their words, thought: "I do not wish to hear the words of those who are speaking.

But the one whose words I wish to hear, he is silent like a *supaṇṇa* bird who has drunk *nāga* poison. This is useless to me."

Then it occurred to him: "Jīvaka is a supporter of the Exalted Buddha (buddha bhagavato), the peaceful one. He himself is peaceful. Therefore, like a *bhikkhu* endowed with vows (*vattasampanno*), he sits silently. He will not speak unless I speak. The foot of the elephant must be grabbed while the elephant is trampling.” Thus he himself took the initiative in consulting him.

Therefore it was said: "Then, the king..."

There, what is the silence? For what reason is he silent?

While each of these ministers praises the recluse (*samaṇa*) he supports, you do not even open your mouth.

Don’t you support some recluse as they do? Are you poor? Didn’t my father give you royalties? Or do you lack faith in anyone?” he asks.

Then Jīvaka thought: "The king wants me to speak about the virtues (*guṇa*) of the recluse I support. This is not the time for me to remain silent. I should not speak about the virtues of the Teacher (satthu) in the way these ministers speak about the virtues of their recluses—by first bowing to the king and then sitting down.” So he rose up from his seat, bowed down to the ground in the direction where the Exalted One (bhagavato) was dwelling, lifted his hands to his head in reverential salutation (*añjaliṃ*), and said: “Great king (*mahārāja*), do not think of me thus, ‘This one approaches any recluse.’ For the ten-thousand world-system trembled at my Teacher’s descent into his mother’s womb, at his emergence from his mother’s womb, at his Great Renunciation (*mahābhinikkhamane*), at his perfect awakening (*sambodhiyaṃ*), and at the turning of the Wheel of the Dharma (*dharmacakrapravartane*). Thus, he performed the Twin Miracle (*yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ*), thus, he descended from the *deva* world. I will speak of the virtues (*guṇa*) of the Teacher (satthuno). Listen with a focused mind, great king (*mahārāja*)," and having said, "This, O king (*deva*), is the Exalted One (bhagavā), the worthy one (*arahaṃ*), the perfectly awakened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*)..." and so on.

There, that indeed, the Exalted One (bhagavantaṃ), is a word of employment in the sense of describing suchness; the meaning is, indeed, of that Exalted One (bhagavato).

"Kalyāṇo" means endowed with good qualities (*kalyāṇaguṇasamannāgato*), "seṭṭho" is said.

*Kittisaddo* means fame itself.

Or praise and proclamation.

*Abbhuggato* means having risen, pervading the world together with the *deva*s.

What is it like? "Thus, that Exalted One (bhagavā) is the Worthy One (*arahaṃ*), the Perfectly Awakened One (*sammāsambuddho*)..." and so on "...the Exalted One (bhagavā)."

There, this is the connection of words: "That Exalted One (bhagavā) is thus the Worthy One (*arahaṃ*), is thus the Perfectly Awakened One (*sammāsambuddho*)..." and so on "...is thus the Exalted One (*bhagavā*)."

It is said to be for this reason and for this reason.

There, because of being far from enemies, and because of destroying spokes, because of worthiness of requisites, etc., because of absence of secrecy in evil deeds, therefore, by these reasons, that Exalted One (bhagavā) is to be known as the Worthy One (*arahaṃ*) and so on. In this way, having established the matrix, all of these words have been expanded in the *Visuddhimagga*, in the section on recollection of the Buddha (*buddhānussatiniddese*). Therefore, their expansion should be taken from there.

Then Jīvaka, having finished the meaning of each word, said: "Thus, great king (*mahārāja*), the worthy one (*arahaṃ*) is my Teacher (satthā), thus the Perfectly Awakened One (*sammāsambuddho*)...thus the Exalted One (bhagavā)," and having said: "May you, O king (*deva*), visit that Exalted One (bhagavantaṃ), perhaps the mind of the king (*deva*) may be calmed by visiting that Exalted One (bhagavantaṃ)."

And here, saying "May you, O king (*deva*), visit that Exalted One (bhagavantaṃ)," he says: "Great king (*mahārāja*), the Teacher (satthuno) has the power and ability to grasp the minds of all and to speak, even when questioned by hundreds, thousands, or hundreds of thousands of persons like yourself; approach him confidently, great king (*mahārāja*)."

When the king also heard this talk about the virtues (*guṇa*) of the Exalted One (bhagavato), his entire body was immediately suffused with the five grades of rapture (*pītiyā*).

At that very moment he became desirous to go to the Exalted One. Thinking, “If I am to go to the Buddha at this time there is no one apart from Jīvaka who can get the vehicles prepared quickly enough,” he said: “Then get the elephant vehicles prepared, friend Jīvaka.”

mula_pali: 158. ‘‘Tena hi, samma jīvaka, hatthiyānāni kappāpehī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, devā’’ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭissuṇitvā pañcamattāni hatthinikāsatāni kappāpetvā rañño ca ārohaṇīyaṃ nāgaṃ, rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭivedesi – ‘‘kappitāni kho te, deva, hatthiyānāni, yassadāni kālaṃ maññasī’’ti.
mula_english:
“Then, friend Jīvaka, have the elephant vehicles ( *hathiyānāni*) made ready.”

“Very well, your majesty ( *deva*)!” said Jīvaka Komārabhacca. Having assented to King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videha princess, of Magadha, and having had five hundred she-elephants and the king’s own riding elephant (*ārohaṇīyaṃ nāgaṃ*) prepared, he reported to King Ajātaśatru, son of the Videha princess, of Magadha: “The elephant vehicles ( *hathiyānāni*) are ready for you, your majesty ( *deva*); now is the time as you deem fit.”
commentary_pali: 158. Tattha tena hīti uyyojanatthe nipāto. Gaccha, samma jīvakāti  vuttaṃ hoti. Hatthiyānānīti anekesu assarathādīsu yānesu vijjamānesupi hatthiyānaṃ uttamaṃ; uttamassa santikaṃ uttamayāneneva gantabbanti ca, assayānarathayānāni sasaddāni, dūratova tesaṃ saddo suyyati, hatthiyānassa padānupadaṃ gacchantāpi saddaṃ na suṇanti. Nibbutassa pana kho bhagavato santike nibbuteheva yānehi gantabbanti ca cintayitvā hatthiyānānīti āha. Pañcamattāni hatthinikāsatānīti pañca kareṇusatāni. Kappāpetvāti ārohaṇasajjāni kāretvā. Ārohaṇīyanti ārohaṇayoggaṃ, opaguyhanti attho. Kiṃ panesa raññā vuttaṃ akāsi avuttanti? Avuttaṃ. Kasmā? Paṇḍitatāya. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi – rājā imāya velāya gacchāmīti vadati, rājāno ca nāma bahupaccatthikā. Sace antarāmagge koci antarāyo hoti, mampi garahissanti – ‘‘jīvako rājā me kathaṃ gaṇhātīti akālepi rājānaṃ gahetvā nikkhamatī’’ti. Bhagavantampi garahissanti ‘‘samaṇo gotamo, ‘mayhaṃ kathā vattatī’ti kālaṃ asallakkhetvāva dhammaṃ kathetī’’ti. Tasmā yathā neva mayhaṃ, na bhagavato, garahā uppajjati; rañño ca rakkhā susaṃvihitā hoti, tathā karissāmī’’ti. Tato  itthiyo nissāya purisānaṃ bhayaṃ nāma natthi, ‘sukhaṃ itthiparivuto gamissāmī’ti pañca hatthinikāsatāni kappāpetvā pañca itthisatāni purisavesaṃ gāhāpetvā – ‘‘asitomarahatthā rājānaṃ parivāreyyāthā’’ti vatvā puna cintesi – ‘‘imassa rañño imasmiṃ attabhāve maggaphalānaṃ  upanissayo natthi, buddhā ca nāma upanissayaṃ disvāva dhammaṃ kathenti. Handāhaṃ, mahājanaṃ sannipātāpemi, evañhi sati satthā kassacideva upanissayena dhammaṃ desessati, sā mahājanassa upakārāya bhavissatī’’ti. So tattha tattha sāsanaṃ pesesi, bheriṃ carāpesi – ‘‘ajja rājā bhagavato santikaṃ gacchati, sabbe attano vibhavānurūpena rañño ārakkhaṃ gaṇhantū’’ti. Tato mahājano cintesi – ‘‘rājā kira satthudassanatthaṃ gacchati, kīdisī vata bho dhammadesanā bhavissati, kiṃ no nakkhattakīḷāya, tattheva gamissāmā’’ti. Sabbe gandhamālādīni gahetvā rañño āgamanaṃ ākaṅkhamānā magge aṭṭhaṃsu. Jīvakopi rañño paṭivedesi – ‘‘kappitāni kho te, deva, hatthiyānāni, yassa dāni kālaṃ maññasī’’ti. Tattha yassa dāni kālaṃ maññasīti upacāravacanametaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ‘‘yaṃ tayā āṇattaṃ, taṃ mayā kataṃ, idāni tvaṃ yassa gamanassa vā agamanassa vā kālaṃ maññasi, tadeva attano ruciyā karohī’’ti.
commentary_english:
158. Therefore, *tena hi* is a particle in the sense of concluding.

"Go, good Jīvaka," this is what was said.

*Hatthiyānāni* means that among the many vehicles such as horse-drawn chariots, elephant vehicles (*hatthiyāna*) are the best; to the vicinity of the best person, one should go only in the best vehicle. Moreover, horse-drawn vehicles and chariots are noisy, and their sound is heard from afar, but even when an elephant vehicle (*hatthiyāna*) proceeds step by step, one does not hear a sound.

Thinking that one should approach the peaceful, quiescent Blessed One in peaceful, quiet vehicles, he said, "Elephant vehicles."

"Five hundred elephant brigades" means five hundred female elephants (*kareṇusatāni*).

*Kappāpetvā* means having them made ready for mounting.

*Ārohaṇīyanti* means suitable for mounting; the meaning is "they are approachable."

Did he do what was said by the king, or not said? It was not said.

Why? Through prudence.

Thus it occurred to him: "The king says, 'I am going at this time,' and kings have many enemies."

If some obstacle should arise along the way, they will blame me, saying, "How does Jīvaka take the king, taking the king out even at an improper time?"

They will also blame the Blessed One, saying, "The *śramaṇa* Gautama, thinking that ‘my talk is valid,’ gives a *dharma* talk without regard for the time."

Therefore, I should act so that blame does not arise for me, nor for the Blessed One; and so that the king's protection is well arranged."

Then, relying on women, there is no fear for men, thinking, "I will go happily surrounded by women," having prepared five hundred elephant brigades, having five hundred women dressed as men, saying, "Those with swords and spears in their hands should surround the king," then he thought again, "This king does not have the supporting conditions for gaining the paths and fruits in this present existence. The Buddhas explain the *dharma* only after seeing the supporting conditions.

"Come now, let me assemble a great multitude of people. For when this is done, the Teacher, having seen someone with the supporting conditions, will teach the *dharma*, and that will be beneficial to the great multitude."

So he sent out announcements here and there, and had it proclaimed: "Today the king is going to the vicinity of the Blessed One. Let everyone protect the king according to his means."

Then the great multitude thought: "The king is going to see the Teacher. What kind of *dharma* talk will there be? What is the use of our festive games? We will go there."

Taking all kinds of garlands and perfumes, waiting for the king's arrival, they stood on the road.

Jīvaka also announced to the king: "The elephant vehicles are prepared for you, Your Majesty. Now is the time, as you think fit."

There, "Now is the time, as you think fit" is a polite expression.

This is what was said: "What was ordered by you, that was done by me. Now, whatever time you think fit for going or not going, do just that according to your pleasure."

mula_pali: 159. Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcasu hatthinikāsatesu paccekā itthiyo āropetvā ārohaṇīyaṃ nāgaṃ abhiruhitvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu rājagahamhā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena, yena jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavanaṃ tena pāyāsi. Atha kho rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre ambavanassa ahudeva bhayaṃ, ahu chambhitattaṃ, ahu lomahaṃso. Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu  vedehiputto bhīto saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto  jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘kacci maṃ, samma jīvaka, na vañcesi? Kacci maṃ, samma jīvaka, na palambhesi? Kacci maṃ, samma jīvaka, na paccatthikānaṃ desi ? Kathañhi nāma tāva mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa aḍḍhateḷasānaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ neva khipitasaddo bhavissati, na ukkāsitasaddo na nigghoso’’ti. ‘‘Mā bhāyi, mahārāja, mā bhāyi, mahārāja. Na taṃ deva, vañcemi; na taṃ, deva, palambhāmi ; na taṃ, deva, paccatthikānaṃ demi. Abhikkama, mahārāja, abhikkama, mahārāja, ete maṇḍalamāḷe dīpā padīpā (sī. syā.) jhāyantī’’ti.
mula_english:
159.
Then, King Ajātaśatru, the son of the Videha princess, of Magadha, having placed each of his women on five hundred female elephants, mounted his own royal elephant, and surrounded by attendants carrying torches, he issued forth from Rājagaha in great royal pomp, proceeding towards Jīvaka Komārabhacca's Mango Grove.

Then, when King Ajātaśatru, the son of the Videha princess, of Magadha, was not far from the Mango Grove, fear arose in him, trepidation arose, and his hair stood on end.

Then, King Ajātaśatru of Magadha, the son of the Videha princess, frightened, agitated, his hair standing on end, said this to Jīvaka Komārabhacca: "Surely, dear Jīvaka, you are not deceiving me? Surely, dear Jīvaka, you are not betraying me? Surely, dear Jīvaka, you are not handing me over to the enemy? How can it be that in such a large community of monks, of thirteen hundred and fifty monks, there is neither the sound of clearing the throat, nor the sound of coughing, nor any noise?”

“Do not fear, great king, do not fear, great king."

"I am not deceiving you, your majesty; I am not betraying you; I am not handing you over to enemies."

"Approach, great king, approach, great king. These are lamps and lights burning in the round pavilion."
commentary_pali: 159.Paccekā itthiyoti pāṭiyekkā itthiyo, ekekissā hatthiniyā ekekaṃ itthinti vuttaṃ hoti. Ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsūti daṇḍadīpikāsu dhāriyamānāsu. Mahacca rājānubhāvenāti mahatā rājānubhāvena. Mahaccātipi pāḷi, mahatiyāti attho, liṅgavipariyāyo esa. Rājānubhāvo vuccati rājiddhi. Kā panassa rājiddhi? Tiyojanasatānaṃ dvinnaṃ mahāraṭṭhānaṃ issariyasirī. Tassa hi asukadivasaṃ rājā tathāgataṃ upasaṅkamissatīti paṭhamataraṃ saṃvidahane asatipi taṅkhaṇaññeva pañca itthisatāni purisavesaṃ gahetvā paṭimukkaveṭhanāni aṃse āsattakhaggāni maṇidaṇḍatomare gahetvā nikkhamiṃsu. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – ‘‘paccekā itthiyo āropetvā’’ti. Aparāpi soḷasasahassakhattiyanāṭakitthiyo rājānaṃ parivāresuṃ. Tāsaṃ pariyante khujjavāmanakakirātādayo. Tāsaṃ pariyante antepurapālakā vissāsikapurisā. Tesaṃ pariyante vicitravesavilāsino saṭṭhisahassamattā mahāmattā. Tesaṃ pariyante vividhālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitā nānappakāraāvudhahatthā  vijjādharataruṇā viya navutisahassamattā raṭṭhiyaputtā. Tesaṃ pariyante satagghanikāni  nivāsetvā pañcasatagghanikāni ekaṃsaṃ katvā sunhātā suvilittā kañcanamālādinānābharaṇasobhitā dasasahassamattā brāhmaṇā dakkhiṇahatthaṃ ussāpetvā jayasaddaṃ ghosantā gacchanti. Tesaṃ pariyante pañcaṅgikāni tūriyāni. Tesaṃ pariyante dhanupantiparikkhepo. Tassa pariyante hatthighaṭā. Hatthīnaṃ pariyante gīvāya gīvaṃ paharamānā assapanti. Assapariyante aññamaññaṃ saṅghaṭṭanarathā. Rathapariyante bāhāya bāhaṃ paharayamānā yodhā. Tesaṃ pariyante attano attano anurūpāya ābharaṇasampattiyā virocamānā aṭṭhārasa seniyo. Iti yathā pariyante ṭhatvā khitto saro rājānaṃ na pāpuṇāti, evaṃ jīvako komārabhacco rañño parisaṃ saṃvidahitvā attanā rañño avidūreneva gacchati – ‘‘sace koci upaddavo hoti, paṭhamatara rañño jīvitadānaṃ dassāmī’’ti. Ukkānaṃ pana ettakāni satāni vā sahassāni vāti paricchedo natthīti evarūpiṃ rājiddhiṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – ‘‘mahaccarājānubhāvena yena jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavanaṃ, tena pāyāsī’’ti. Ahudeva bhayanti ettha cittutrāsabhayaṃ, ñāṇabhayaṃ, ārammaṇabhayaṃ, ottappabhayanti catubbidhaṃ bhayaṃ, tattha ‘‘jātiṃ paṭicca bhayaṃ bhayānaka’’ntiādinā nayena vuttaṃ cittutrāsabhayaṃ nāma. ‘‘Tepi tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjantī’’ti (saṃ. ni. 3.78) evamāgataṃ ñāṇabhayaṃ nāma. ‘‘Etaṃ nūna taṃ bhayabheravaṃ āgacchatī’’ti (ma. ni. 1.49) ettha vuttaṃ ārammaṇabhayaṃ nāma. Idaṃ ottappabhayaṃ nāma. Tesu idha cittutrāsabhayaṃ, ahu ahosīti attho. Chambhitattanti chambhitassa bhāvo. Sakalasarīracalananti attho. Lomahaṃsoti lomahaṃsanaṃ, uddhaṃ ṭhitalomatāti attho. So panāyaṃ lomahaṃso dhammassavanādīsu pītiuppattikāle pītiyāpi hoti . Bhīrukajātikānaṃ sampahārapisācādidassanesu bhayenāpi. Idha bhayalomahaṃsoti veditabbo. Kasmā panesa bhītoti? Andhakārenāti eke vadanti. Rājagahe kira dvattiṃsa mahādvārāni, catusaṭṭhi khuddakadvārāni. Jīvakassa ambavanaṃ pākārassa ca gijjhakūṭassa ca antarā hoti. So pācīnadvārena nikkhamitvā pabbatacchāyāya pāvisi, tattha pabbatakūṭena cando  chādito, pabbatacchāyāya ca rukkhacchāyāya ca andhakāraṃ ahosīti, tampi akāraṇaṃ. Tadā hi ukkānaṃ satasahassānampi paricchedo natthi. Ayaṃ pana appasaddataṃ nissāya jīvake āsaṅkāya bhīto. Jīvako kirassa uparipāsādeyeva ārocesi – ‘‘mahārāja appasaddakāmo bhagavā, appasaddeneva upasaṅkamitabbo’’ti. Tasmā rājā tūriyasaddaṃ nivāresi. Tūriyāni kevalaṃ gahitamattāneva honti, vācampi uccaṃ anicchārayamānā accharāsaññāya gacchanti. Ambavanepi kassaci khipitasaddopi na suyyati. Rājāno ca nāma saddābhiratā honti. So taṃ appasaddataṃ nissāya ukkaṇṭhito jīvakepi āsaṅkaṃ uppādesi. ‘‘Ayaṃ jīvako mayhaṃ ambavane aḍḍhateḷasāni bhikkhusatānī’’ti āha. Ettha ca khipitasaddamattampi na suyyati, abhūtaṃ maññe, esa vañcetvā maṃ nagarato nīharitvā purato balakāyaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā maṃ gaṇhitvā attanā chattaṃ ussāpetukāmo. Ayañhi pañcannaṃ hatthīnaṃ balaṃ dhāreti. Mama ca avidūreneva  gacchati, santike ca me āvudhahattho ekapurisopi natthi. Aho vata me anattho’’ti. Evaṃ bhāyitvā ca pana abhīto viya sandhāretumpi nāsakkhi. Attano bhītabhāvaṃ tassa āvi akāsi. Tena vuttaṃ. ‘‘Atha kho rājā…pe… na nigghoso’’ti. Tattha sammāti vayassābhilāpo esa, kacci maṃ vayassāti vuttaṃ hoti. Na palambhesīti yaṃ natthi taṃ atthīti vatvā kacci maṃ na vippalambhayasi. Nigghosoti kathāsallāpanigghoso. Mā bhāyi, mahārājāti jīvako – ‘‘ayaṃ rājā maṃ na jānāti ‘nāyaṃ paraṃ jīvitā voropetī’ti; sace kho pana naṃ na assāsessāmi, vinasseyyā’’ti  cintayitvā daḷhaṃ katvā samassāsento ‘‘mā bhāyi mahārājā’’ti vatvā ‘‘na taṃ devā’’tiādimāha. Abhikkamāti abhimukho kama gaccha, pavisāti attho. Sakiṃ vutte pana daḷhaṃ na hotīti taramānova dvikkhattuṃ āha. Ete maṇḍalamāḷe dīpā jhāyantīti mahārāja, corabalaṃ nāma na dīpe jāletvā tiṭṭhati, ete ca maṇḍalamāḷe dīpā jalanti. Etāya dīpasaññāya yāhi mahārājāti vadati.
commentary_english:
159.
*Paccekā itthiyo* means *pāṭiyekkā itthiyo*; it means that each elephant cow has one female.
*Ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu* means *daṇḍadīpikāsu dhāriyamānāsu* (while torches are being carried means while torches on poles are being carried).
*Mahacca rājānubhāvena* means *mahatā rājānubhāvena* (with the great power of the king).
*Mahaccātipi pāḷi*, the meaning is *mahati*, this is a change of gender.
*Rājānubhāvo* is called *rājiddhi* (kingly power is called kingly success).
What is his *rājiddhi*? The glory of sovereignty over two great kingdoms of three hundred yojanas.
"On such and such a day, the king will approach the *tathāgata*," even if the preparations were not complete beforehand, at that very moment five hundred women, having taken the guise of men, with their veils removed, swords fastened to their shoulders, and holding jeweled staffs and *tomaras*, went out.
What was spoken with reference to that is: "Having made each woman mount."
Moreover, sixteen thousand dancing Kṣatriya women surrounded the king.
Around them were hunchbacks, dwarfs, Kirātas, and so on.
Around them were palace guards and trusted men.
Around them were sixty thousand great ministers, adorned with various costumes and finery.
Around them were ninety thousand royal sons, adorned with various ornaments and decorations, holding various kinds of weapons, like young *vidyādharas*.
Around them, having put on hundred-fold garments and having made five hundred-fold garments into a single shawl, well-bathed, well-anointed, adorned with various ornaments such as golden garlands, ten thousand *brāhmaṇas*, raising their right hands, went along shouting cries of victory.
Around them were five-piece orchestras.
Around them was a line of bows.
Around them were elephant troops.
Around the elephants, they snorted, striking neck against neck.
Around the horses were chariots colliding with each other.
Around the chariots were warriors striking arm against arm.
Around them were eighteen armies, shining with the wealth of ornaments corresponding to their own status.
Just as an arrow, shot having stood at the limit, does not reach the king, so Jīvaka Komārabhacca, having arranged the king's retinue, went along not far from the king himself, thinking: "If any danger arises, I will be the first to give the king the gift of life."
But there is no limit to the number of torches, whether hundreds or thousands, having referred to such kingly power, it was said: "With the great power of the king, by which he went to the mango grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca, he was successful."
Here, "he was suddenly gripped by fear" refers to fear as mental anxiety, fear as knowledge, fear as a fearful object, and fear as moral dread, four kinds of fear. Among these, fear as mental anxiety is referred to in the passage: "In dependence on birth there arises fear, fright," etc.
“Those, having heard the Tathāgata’s teaching of the Dhamma, generally fall into fear, a sense of urgency, and terror” (Saṃ.
Ni.
3.
78) This is called knowledge of fear.
“Is this the fear and dread that is coming?” (Ma.
Ni.
1.
49) Here, what is spoken of is the fear of fearful objects.
This is called moral dread.
Among these, here fear as mental anxiety, happened, it means it happened.
*Chambhitatta* means the state of being startled.
*Sakalasarīracalana* means the movement of the whole body.
*Lomahaṃso* means *lomahaṃsanaṃ*, the hairs standing upwards, that is the meaning.
But that *lomahaṃso* also occurs through joy at the time of the arising of joy in hearing the Dharma and so on.
Also through fear in the visions of fearful kinds of ghosts and so on.
Here, it should be understood, signifies fear and bristling of the hair.

Why then is he afraid? Some say it is because of the darkness.

In Rājagaha, it is said, there are thirty-two great gates and sixty-four small gates.

Jīvaka’s Mango Grove is between the rampart and the Gijjhakūṭa (Vulture Peak).

He, having left by the eastern gate, entered into the shadow of the mountain. There, the moon was covered by the peak of the mountain, and because of the shadow of the mountain and the shadow of the trees, it was dark, but that too was without reason.

At that time, indeed, there was no limit even to hundreds of thousands of torches.

Because of the quietness, however, he was afraid, suspecting Jīvaka.

Jīvaka, it is said, had already announced to him in the upper terrace of the palace: “Great king, the Blessed One (bhagavā) is fond of quietness. He should be approached quietly.”

Therefore the king prohibited the sound of musical instruments (tūriyasaddaṃ).

The musical instruments (tūriyāni) were merely taken along. Also, they did not speak aloud, but went along giving signals with a snap of the fingers.

In the Mango Grove not even the sound of sneezing was heard.

And kings generally delight in sound.

Because of that quietness, he became uneasy, and he aroused suspicion even regarding Jīvaka.

“This Jīvaka told me there are twelve hundred and fifty monks (bhikkhus) in the Mango Grove,” he said.

And here not even the slightest sound of sneezing is heard. I think it is unreal. Wishing to deceive me, he has led me out of the city, set up an army in front, and intends to arrest me and raise his own umbrella, desiring kingship for himself.

For he has the strength of five elephants (hatthīnaṃ balaṃ dhāreti).

And he is going along not far from me, and there is not even a single armed man (āvudhahattho) near me.

“O, what harm has befallen me!”

Having become so much afraid, he could not conduct himself fearlessly.

He revealed his own fearfulness to him.

Therefore it has been said.

"Then the king…pe… no noise."

There, this is a friendly address, and it is as if it was said, "Are you well, friend?"

"You do not deceive," that is, saying that what is not, is, will you not deceive me?

"Noise" means the noise of friendly conversation (kathāsallāpanigghoso).

Jīvaka [said]: "Do not be afraid, great king (mahārāja)—this king does not know me; he does not know that I do not deprive another of life; but if I do not reassure him, he will perish," thinking thus, and making firm, reassuring him, and saying: "Do not be afraid, great king," he spoke beginning with "Not the gods..."

"Go forward" means go face to face, enter, is the meaning.

He says "Go forward" twice, hurrying along, because if he had said this once it would not be firm.

“These lamps are burning in the pavilion hall, great king (mahārāja). A group of thieves does not stay where lamps are burning. And these lamps are burning in the pavilion hall."

He says: "Go by this sign of the lamps, great king (mahārāja)."

mula_pali: 160. Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā, nāgā paccorohitvā, pattikova padikova (syā.) yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘kahaṃ pana, samma jīvaka, bhagavā’’ti? ‘‘Eso, mahārāja, bhagavā; eso, mahārāja, bhagavā majjhimaṃ thambhaṃ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisinno purakkhato bhikkhusaṅghassā’’ti.
mula_english:
Then, King Ajātaśatru, son of Vaidehī, having gone by elephant as far as the elephant's terrain (nāgassa bhūmi) extended, dismounted from the elephant (nāgā paccorohitvā), and approached on foot (pattikova padikova) the gate of the circular pavilion (maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṃ); having approached, he said to Jīvaka Komārabhacca, "Where, friend Jīvaka, is the Blessed One (bhagavā)?"
"Here, great king (mahārāja), is the Blessed One (bhagavā); here, great king, is the Blessed One (bhagavā), seated facing east, leaning against the central pillar (majjhimaṃ thambhaṃ nissāya), surrounded by the community of monks (bhikkhusaṅghassā)."
commentary_pali: 160.Nāgassa bhūmīti yattha sakkā hatthiṃ abhirūḷhena gantuṃ, ayaṃ nāgassa bhūmi nāma. Nāgā paccorohitvāti vihārassa bahidvārakoṭṭhake hatthito orohitvā. Bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhitasamakālameva  pana bhagavato tejo rañño sarīraṃ phari. Athassa tāvadeva sakalasarīrato sedā mucciṃsu, sāṭakā pīḷetvā apanetabbā viya ahesuṃ. Attano aparādhaṃ saritvā mahābhayaṃ uppajji. So ujukaṃ bhagavato santikaṃ gantuṃ asakkonto jīvakaṃ hatthe gahetvā ārāmacārikaṃ caramāno viya ‘‘idaṃ te samma jīvaka suṭṭhu kāritaṃ idaṃ suṭṭhu kārita’’nti vihārassa  vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamāno anukkamena yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami, sampattoti attho. Kahaṃ pana sammāti kasmā pucchīti. Eke tāva ‘‘ajānanto’’ti vadanti. Iminā kira daharakāle pitarā saddhiṃ āgamma bhagavā diṭṭhapubbo, pacchā pana pāpamittasaṃsaggena pitughātaṃ katvā abhimāre pesetvā dhanapālaṃ muñcāpetvā mahāparādho hutvā bhagavato sammukhībhāvaṃ na upagatapubboti asañjānanto pucchatīti. Taṃ akāraṇaṃ, bhagavā hi ākiṇṇavaralakkhaṇo anubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍito chabbaṇṇāhi rasmīhi sakalaṃ ārāmaṃ obhāsetvā tārāgaṇaparivuto viya puṇṇacando bhikkhugaṇaparivuto maṇḍalamāḷamajjhe nisinno, taṃ ko na jāneyya. Ayaṃ pana attano issariyalīlāya pucchati. Pakati hesā rājakulānaṃ, yaṃ jānantāpi ajānantā viya pucchanti. Jīvako pana taṃ sutvā – ‘ayaṃ rājā pathaviyaṃ ṭhatvā kuhiṃ pathavīti, nabhaṃ ulloketvā kuhiṃ candimasūriyāti, sinerumūle ṭhatvā  kuhiṃ sinerūti vadamāno viya dasabalassa purato ṭhatvā kuhiṃ bhagavā’ti pucchati. ‘‘Handassa bhagavantaṃ dassessāmī’’ti cintetvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ‘‘eso mahārājā’’tiādimāha. Purakkhatoti parivāretvā nisinnassa purato nisinno.
commentary_english:
160.
"Nāga’s ground" means a place where it is possible to go having mounted an elephant; this is called Nāga’s ground.
"Having dismounted from the nāga" means having dismounted from the elephant at the outer gatehouse of the monastery.
As soon as the king dismounted and set foot on the ground, the splendor of the Exalted One suffused his body.
Immediately, his entire body broke out into a sweat, and his clothes felt as though they should be removed, as if they were oppressing him.
Remembering his own crime, great fear arose in him.
He could not go directly to the Exalted One, but took Jīvaka by the hand and walked around as if touring the monastery grounds, saying: “You have built this well, Jīvaka, you have built this well.” Thus, praising the monastery, he gradually approached the door of the pavilion hall, meaning he arrived.
Why does he ask: “Where is the Exalted One?”
Some say: "Because he did not know."
They say that in his youth he had seen the Exalted One when he came along with his father; but afterwards, as a result of associating with evil friends, he killed his father, sent assassins, set the elephant Dhanapāla loose, and having thus become a great criminal, he did not meet the Exalted One face to face. Because of this, they say, he did not recognize him.
That is not the reason. For the Exalted One, sitting in the middle of the pavilion hall surrounded by the company of monks, appeared like the full moon surrounded by the host of stars. Marked with the most excellent bodily characteristics (ākiṇṇavaralakṣaṇo), adorned with the special features of physical beauty (anubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍito), he illuminated the entire monastery with his six-colored rays (chabbaṇṇāhi rasmīhi). Who would not have known him?
The king asks this as a mannerism of sovereignty.
For this is the nature of those of royal family; though knowing something, they ask as if they do not know.
But Jīvaka, having heard this question, thought to himself: “This king, standing on the earth, asks, ‘Where is the earth?’; or as if someone looking up at the sky were to ask, ‘Where are the sun and moon?’; or as if someone standing at the foot of Mount Meru were to ask, ‘Where is Meru?’; so, standing in front of the Ten-Powered One (dasabalassa), he asks, ‘Where is the Exalted One?’”
Thinking, "I will show him the Exalted One," making a reverential salutation (añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā) towards the Exalted One, he said: “That is the Exalted One, great king,” etc.
*Purakkhato* means one who is surrounded, sat in front of the one seated.

mula_pali: 161. Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā rahadamiva vippasannaṃ udānaṃ udānesi – ‘‘iminā me upasamena udayabhaddo udāyibhaddo (sī. pī.) kumāro samannāgato hotu, yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato’’ti. ‘‘Agamā kho tvaṃ, mahārāja, yathāpema’’nti. ‘‘Piyo me, bhante, udayabhaddo kumāro. Iminā me, bhante, upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato’’ti.
mula_english:
Then King Ajātaśatru, son of Videhi, of Magadha, approached the Blessed One; having approached, he stood to one side.

Standing to one side, King Ajātaśatru, son of Videhi, of Magadha, having surveyed the Saṅgha of monks in utter silence, as serene as a clear lake, exclaimed: "May Prince Udayabhadda be endowed with such tranquility as the Saṅgha of monks is endowed with now!"

"Do your thoughts, great king, follow the call of your affection?"

"Lord, Prince Udayabhadda is dear to me. May Prince Udayabhadda be endowed with such tranquility as the Saṅgha of monks is endowed with now!"
commentary_pali: 161.Yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamīti yattha bhagavā tattha gato, bhagavato santikaṃ upagatoti attho. Ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsīti bhagavantaṃ vā bhikkhusaṃghaṃ vā asaṅghaṭṭayamāno attano ṭhātuṃ anucchavike ekasmiṃ padese bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekova aṭṭhāsi. Tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtanti yato yato anuviloketi, tato tato tuṇhībhūtamevāti attho. Tattha hi ekabhikkhussapi hatthakukkuccaṃ vā pādakukkuccaṃ vā khipitasaddo vā natthi, sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ  nāṭakaparivāraṃ bhagavato abhimukhe ṭhitaṃ rājānaṃ vā rājaparisaṃ vā ekabhikkhupi na olokesi. Sabbe bhagavantaṃyeva olokayamānā nisīdiṃsu. Rājā tesaṃ upasame pasīditvā vigatapaṅkatāya vippasannarahadamiva upasantindriyaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ punappunaṃ anuviloketvā udānaṃ udānesi. Tattha imināti yena kāyikena ca vācasikena  ca mānasikena ca sīlūpasamena bhikkhusaṅgho upasanto, iminā upasamenāti dīpeti. Tattha ‘‘aho vata me putto pabbajitvā ime bhikkhū viya upasanto bhaveyyā’’ti nayidaṃ sandhāya esa evamāha. Ayaṃ pana bhikkhusaṅghaṃ disvā pasanno puttaṃ anussari. Dullabhañhi laddhā acchariyaṃ vā disvā piyānaṃ ñātimittādīnaṃ anussaraṇaṃ nāma lokassa pakatiyeva. Iti bhikkhusaṅghaṃ disvā puttaṃ anussaramāno esa evamāha. Api ca putte āsaṅkāya tassa upasamaṃ icchamāno pesa evamāha. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi, putto me pucchissati – ‘‘mayhaṃ pitā daharo. Ayyako me kuhi’’nti. So ‘‘pitarā te ghātito’’ti sutvā ‘‘ahampi pitaraṃ ghātetvā rajjaṃ kāressāmī’’ti maññissati. Iti putte āsaṅkāya tassa upasamaṃ icchamāno pesa evamāha. Kiñcāpi hi esa evamāha. Atha kho naṃ putto ghātessatiyeva. Tasmiñhi vaṃse pituvadho pañcaparivaṭṭe gato. Ajātasattu bimbisāraṃ ghātesi, udayo ajātasattuṃ . Tassa putto mahāmuṇḍiko nāma udayaṃ. Tassa putto anuruddho nāma mahāmuṇḍikaṃ. Tassa putto nāgadāso nāma anuruddhaṃ. Nāgadāsaṃ pana – ‘‘vaṃsacchedakarājāno ime, kiṃ imehī’’ti raṭṭhavāsino kupitā ghātesuṃ. Agamā kho tvanti kasmā evamāha? Bhagavā kira rañño vacībhede akateyeva cintesi – ‘‘ayaṃ rājā āgantvā tuṇhī niravo ṭhito, kiṃ nu kho cintesī’’ti. Athassa cittaṃ ñatvā – ‘‘ayaṃ mayā saddhiṃ sallapituṃ asakkonto bhikkhusaṅghaṃ  anuviloketvā puttaṃ anussari, na kho panāyaṃ mayi anālapante kiñci kathetuṃ sakkhissati, karomi tena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpa’’nti. Tasmā rañño vacanānantaraṃ ‘‘agamā kho tvaṃ, mahārāja, yathāpema’’nti āha. Tassattho – mahārāja, yathā nāma unname vuṭṭhaṃ udakaṃ yena ninnaṃ tena gacchati, evameva tvaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā yena pemaṃ tena gatoti. Atha rañño etadahosi – ‘‘aho acchariyā buddhaguṇā, mayā sadiso bhagavato aparādhakārako nāma natthi, mayā hissa aggupaṭṭhāko ghātito, devadattassa ca kathaṃ gahetvā abhimārā pesitā, nāḷāgiri mutto, maṃ nissāya devadattena silā paviddhā, evaṃ mahāparādhaṃ nāma maṃ ālapato dasabalassa mukhaṃ nappahoti; aho bhagavā pañcahākārehi tādilakkhaṇe suppatiṭṭhito. Evarūpaṃ nāma satthāraṃ pahāya bahiddhā na pariyesissāmā’’ti so somanassajāto bhagavantaṃ ālapanto ‘‘piyo me, bhante’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
161.
Because he approached the Blessed One means: where the Blessed One was, there he went; the meaning is that he went into the presence of the Blessed One.

Standing to one side means that, without obstructing the Blessed One or the monastic community, he stood in a suitable place, respectfully saluted the Blessed One, and stood alone.

"Being silent" means that wherever he looked around, he was simply silent, this is the meaning.

There, not even one *bhikkhu* played with his hands (*hatthakukkuccaṃ*) or feet (*pādakukkuccaṃ*) or made a cracking sound. Not even one *bhikkhu* looked at the king or his assembly standing in front of the Blessed One, or at the retinue of nautch-girls adorned with all their ornaments (*sabbālaṅkāra-paṭimaṇḍitaṃ nāṭaka-parivāraṃ*).

All sat there, looking only at the Exalted One ( *bhagavantaṃ*).

The king, gaining confidence in such peace, again and again surveyed the company of *bhikkhus* sitting there with calm faculties, like a clear lake free from mud, and then uttered his joyful exclamation ( *udānaṃ udānesi*):

There, "by this" means that the monastic community is peaceful through bodily, verbal, mental, and ethical peace; "by this peace" is what is indicated.

There, he did not say this intending: “O, may my son go forth and become peaceful like these *bhikkhus*!”

Rather, having gained confidence seeing the company of *bhikkhus*, he remembered his son.

For that is the nature of people in the world: when they have gained something rare or seen something wonderful, they remember their dear relatives and friends (*ñātimittādīnaṃ*).

Thus, having gained confidence seeing the monastic community, he remembered his son, and spoke thus.

Moreover, he said this because he was apprehensive about his son and desired peace for him.

For he thought: “My son will ask: ‘My father is young.

Where is my grandfather?’"

Hearing ‘Your father killed him’, he might think: ‘Then I shall kill my father and rule the kingdom!’

Thus, apprehensive about his son, he spoke thus desiring this peace for him.

Yet though he said this,

his son eventually killed him.

In that dynasty parricide took place in five generations.

Ajātaśatru killed Bimbisāra; Udaya killed Ajātaśatru;

Udayi was killed by his own son, Mahāmuṇḍika;

Mahāmuṇḍika was killed by his son Anuruddha;

and Anuruddha was killed by his son Nāgadāsa.

But the citizens became angry and thinking, “These kings destroy their own lineage; what do we need them for?” they killed Nāgadāsa.

Why did he speak thus, “You have come well”? It is said that before the king uttered his exclamation, the Exalted One had thought: “The king, having come, stands here silent and speechless. What is he thinking?”

Having read his mind, he reflected: “Being unable to converse with me, he surveys the monastic community and remembers his son. Since he will be unable to say anything if I do not speak to him first, I will start a conversation with him.”

Therefore, immediately after the king uttered his joyful exclamation, the Exalted One spoke the above words.

This is the meaning: “Great king, as rain water, falling upon the highlands, flows down to the plain, so as you survey the company of *bhikkhus*, your affection goes towards your son.”

Thereupon the king thought: “O, how wonderful are the virtues of the Buddha! There is no one who has committed such crimes towards the Exalted One as I have. I killed his chief supporter; I accepted the request of Devadatta and sent assassins to kill him; I released the elephant Nālāgiri against him; with my support Devadatta hurled a stone at him. The Buddha should not even open his mouth towards such a criminal as myself, yet he freely addresses me. O, the Exalted One is well-established in the five aspects of suchness (*pañcahākārehi tādilakkhaṇe suppatiṭṭhito*).

I should not abandon such a teacher and search for a teacher elsewhere.” Filled with joy (*somanassajāto*), addressing the Exalted One (*bhagavantaṃ ālapanto*), he said: “Venerable sir (*bhante*), I love my son,” etc.

mula_pali: 162. Atha  kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā, bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā , ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ  nisinno kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘puccheyyāmahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ kiñcideva desaṃ kiñcideva desaṃ lesamattaṃ (syā. kaṃ. ka.); sace me bhagavā okāsaṃ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā’’ti. ‘‘Puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī’’ti.
mula_english:
162. Then King Ajātaśatru, son of Videhi, having respectfully saluted the Blessed One and saluted the Order of Monks with joined hands, sat down to one side.

Having sat down to one side, King Ajātaśatru, son of Videhi, said this to the Blessed One: "Venerable sir, I would like to ask the Blessed One about a certain point, a trifling matter; if the Blessed One would grant me the opportunity to explain my question."

"Ask, great king, whatever you wish."
commentary_pali: 162.Bhikkhusaṅghassaañjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti evaṃ kirassa ahosi bhagavantaṃ vanditvā itocito ca gantvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ vandantena ca bhagavā piṭṭhito kātabbo hoti, garukāropi cesa na hoti. Rājānaṃ vanditvā uparājānaṃ vandantenapi hi rañño agāravo kato hoti. Tasmā bhagavantaṃ vanditvā ṭhitaṭṭhāneyeva bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Kañcideva desanti kañci okāsaṃ. Athassa  bhagavā pañhapucchane ussāhaṃ janento āha – ‘‘puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī’’ti. Tassattho – ‘‘puccha yadi ākaṅkhasi, na me pañhavissajjane bhāro atthi’’. Atha vā ‘‘puccha, yaṃ ākaṅkhasi, sabbaṃ te vissajjessāmī’’ti sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavāresi, asādhāraṇaṃ paccekabuddhaaggasāvakamahāsāvakehi. Te hi yadākaṅkhasīti na vadanti, sutvā vedissāmāti vadanti. Buddhā  pana – ‘‘puccha, āvuso, yadākaṅkhasī’’ti (saṃ. ni. 1.237), vā ‘‘puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī’’ti vā, Tena hi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sake āsane nisīditvā puccha, yadākaṅkhasīti vā, Tesaṃ tesaṃ yakkhanarindadevasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakānaṃ sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavārenti. Anacchariyañcetaṃ, yaṃ bhagavā buddhabhūmiṃ patvā etaṃ pavāraṇaṃ pavāreyya. Yo bodhisattabhūmiyaṃ padesañāṇe ṭhito – Evaṃ sakkādīnaṃ atthāya isīhi yācito – Evaṃ  sarabhaṅgakāle. Sambhavajātake ca sakalajambudīpaṃ tikkhattuṃ vicaritvā pañhānaṃ antakaraṃ adisvā suciratena brāhmaṇena, pañhaṃ puṭṭhuṃ okāse kārite jātiyā sattavassiko rathikāya paṃsuṃ kīḷanto pallaṅkamābhujitvā antaravīthiyaṃ nisinnova –
commentary_english:
162. "Having bowed to the Order of Monks": Thus, it occurred to him, "Having bowed to the Blessed One, and then having gone here and there, if one bows to the Order of Monks, the Blessed One would be behind [them], and this would not be showing due respect."

Having bowed to the king, even when bowing to the sub-king, disrespect has been shown to the king.

Therefore, having bowed to the Blessed One, and remaining in the same place, having bowed to the Order of Monks, he sat down to one side.

They teach some teaching, some opportunity.

Then, the Blessed One, generating enthusiasm for asking a question, said to him: "Ask, great king, whatever you wish (yadākaṅkhasī)."

Its meaning is: "Ask if you wish (ākāṅkhasi); there is no burden to me in answering questions."

Or, "Ask, whatever you wish (yaṃ ākaṅkhasi), I will answer everything (sabbaṃ te vissajjessāmī)," thus, the Blessed One extended the invitation of the all-knowing (sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ), uncommon to individual Buddhas, chief disciples and great disciples.

For they do not say, "Ask whatever you wish (yadākaṅkhasīti)," but they say, "Having heard, we will try to answer."

But Buddhas say: "Ask, friend (āvuso), whatever you wish (yadākaṅkhasī)" (Saṃ. Ni. 1.237), or "Ask, great king, whatever you wish (yadākaṅkhasī)" or, "Therefore, you, *bhikkhu*, having sat down on your own seat, ask, whatever you wish (yadākaṅkhasī)," they extend the invitation of the all-knowing (sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ) to those *yakṣas*, kings of men, gods, *śramaṇas*, *brāhmaṇas*, and wanderers (*parivrājakas*).

It is not wonderful that the Blessed One, having attained the Buddha-ground (*buddhabhūmiṃ*), would extend this invitation (*pavāraṇaṃ*).

He who is situated in the knowledge of a region (*padesañāṇe*) on the Bodhisattva-ground (*bodhisattabhūmiyaṃ*) - thus, requested by seers (*ṛṣis*) for the benefit of Śakra and others - thus, at the time of Sarabhaṅga.

And in the Sambhava Jātaka, having travelled three times through the whole Jambudvīpa, not seeing an end to the questions, after a long time, by a *brāhmaṇa*, having caused an opportunity for asking a question, a seven-year-old by birth, while playing with dust on the road, folding his legs, was seated in the middle of the street -

mula_pali: 163. ‘‘Yathā nu kho imāni, bhante, puthusippāyatanāni, seyyathidaṃ – hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā nahāpikā (sī.), nhāpikā (syā.) sūdā mālākārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṃgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti; te tena attānaṃ sukhenti  pīṇenti pīnenti (katthaci), mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu samaṇesu brāhmaṇesu (ka.) uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ. Sakkā nu kho, bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’’nti?
mula_english: “Venerable sir, just as there are these various diverse crafts, such as elephant trainers (*hatthārohā*), horse trainers (*assārohā*), charioteers (*rathikā*), archers (*dhanuggahā*), standard bearers (*celakā*), camp marshals (*calakā*), army caterers (*piṇḍadāyakā*), champions and senior officers (*uggā rājaputtā*), front-line soldiers (*pakkhandino mahānāgā*), heroes (*sūrā*), cuirassiers (*cammayodhino*), slaves’ sons (*dāsikaputtā*), confectioners (*āḷārikā*), barbers (*kappakā*), bath attendants (*nhāpakā*), cooks (*sūdā*), garland-makers (*mālākārā*), laundrymen (*rajakā*), weavers (*pesakārā*), basket-makers (*naḷakārā*), potters (*kumbhakārā*), calculators (*gaṇakā*) and accountants (*muddikā*)—and whatever other skills there are of a similar nature: they enjoy here and now the visible fruits of their skills (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ*); they delight and gratify themselves thereby, they delight and gratify their mothers and fathers, they delight and gratify their children and spouses, they delight and gratify their friends and colleagues, they establish an uplifting donation among ascetics and Brahmins, conducive to heaven, resulting in happiness, and leading to heaven. Is it possible, venerable sir, to point out any fruit of the ascetic life (*sāmaññaphalaṃ*) that is similarly visible here and now (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ*)?”
commentary_pali: 163. Evaṃ bhagavatā sabbaññupavāraṇāya pavāritāya attamano rājā pañhaṃ pucchanto – ‘‘yathā nu kho imāni, bhante’’tiādimāha. Tattha sippameva sippāyatanaṃ. Puthusippāyatanānīti bahūni sippāni. Seyyathidanti katame pana te. Hatthārohātiādīhi ye taṃ taṃ sippaṃ nissāya jīvanti, te dasseti. Ayañhi assādhippāyo – ‘‘yathā imesaṃ sippūpajīvīnaṃ taṃ taṃ sippaṃ nissāya sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ paññāyati. Sakkā nu kho evaṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññāpetu’’nti. Tasmā sippāyatanāni āharitvā sippūpajīvino dasseti. Tattha hatthārohāti sabbepi hatthācariyahatthivejjahatthimeṇḍādayo dasseti. Assārohāti sabbepi  assācariyaassavejjaassameṇḍādayo. Rathikāti sabbepi rathācariyarathayodharatharakkhādayo. Dhanuggahāti dhanuācariyā issāsā. Celakāti ye yuddhe jayadhajaṃ gahetvā purato gacchanti. Calakāti idha rañño ṭhānaṃ hotu, idha asukamahāmattassāti evaṃ senābyūhakārakā. Piṇḍadāyakāti sāhasikamahāyodhā. Te kira parasenaṃ pavisitvā parasīsaṃ piṇḍamiva chetvā chetvā dayanti, uppatitvā uppatitvā niggacchantīti attho. Ye vā saṅgāmamajjhe yodhānaṃ bhattapātiṃ gahetvā parivisanti, tesampetaṃ nāmaṃ. Uggārājaputtāti uggatuggatā saṅgāmāvacarā rājaputtā. Pakkhandinoti ye ‘‘kassa sīsaṃ vā āvudhaṃ vā āharāmā’’ti  ‘‘vatvā asukassā’’ti vuttā saṅgāmaṃ pakkhanditvā tadeva āharanti, ime pakkhandantīti pakkhandino. Mahānāgāti mahānāgā viya mahānāgā, hatthiādīsupi abhimukhaṃ āgacchantesu anivattitayodhānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sūrāti ekantasūrā, ye sajālikāpi sacammikāpi samuddaṃ tarituṃ sakkonti. Cammayodhinoti ye cammakañcukaṃ vā pavisitvā saraparittāṇacammaṃ vā gahetvā yujjhanti. Dāsikaputtāti balavasinehā gharadāsayodhā. Āḷārikāti pūvikā. Kappakāti nhāpikā. Nhāpakāti ye nhāpenti. Sūdāti bhattakārakā. Mālākārādayo pākaṭāyeva. Gaṇakāti acchiddakapāṭhakā. Muddikāti hatthamuddāya gaṇanaṃ nissāya jīvino. Yāni vā panaññānipīti ayakāradantakāracittakārādīni. Evaṃgatānīti evaṃ pavattāni. Te diṭṭheva dhammeti te hatthārohādayo tāni puthusippāyatanāni dassetvā rājakulato mahāsampattiṃ labhamānā sandiṭṭhikameva sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti. Sukhentīti sukhitaṃ karonti. Pīṇentīti pīṇitaṃ thāmabalūpetaṃ karonti. Uddhaggikādīsu upari phalanibbattanato uddhaṃ aggamassā  atthīti uddhaggikā. Saggaṃ arahatīti sovaggikā. Sukho vipāko assāti sukhavipākā. Suṭṭhu agge rūpasaddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbaāyuvaṇṇasukhayasaādhipateyyasaṅkhāte dasa dhamme saṃvatteti nibbattetīti saggasaṃvattanikā. Taṃ evarūpaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ dānaṃ patiṭṭhapentīti attho. Sāmaññaphalanti ettha paramatthato maggo sāmaññaṃ. Ariyaphalaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ. Yathāha – ‘‘katamañca, bhikkhave, sāmaññaṃ? Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo. Seyyathidaṃ, sammādiṭṭhi…pe… sammāsamādhi. Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, sāmaññaṃ. Katamāni ca, bhikkhave, sāmaññaphalāni? Sotāpattiphalaṃ…pe… arahattaphala’’nti (saṃ. ni. 5.35). Taṃ esa rājā na jānāti. Upari āgataṃ pana dāsakassakopamaṃ sandhāya pucchati. Atha bhagavā pañhaṃ avissajjetvāva cintesi – ‘‘ime bahū aññatitthiyasāvakā rājāmaccā idhāgatā, te kaṇhapakkhañca sukkapakkhañca dīpetvā kathīyamāne amhākaṃ rājā mahantena  ussāhena idhāgato, tassāgatakālato paṭṭhāya samaṇo gotamo samaṇakolāhalaṃ samaṇabhaṇḍanameva  kathetīti ujjhāyissanti, na sakkaccaṃ dhammaṃ sossanti, raññā pana kathīyamāne ujjhāyituṃ na sakkhissanti, rājānameva anuvattissanti. Issarānuvattako hi loko. ‘Handāhaṃ raññova bhāraṃ karomī’ti rañño bhāraṃ karonto ‘‘abhijānāsi no tva’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
163. Thus, when the Exalted One had invited him to ask with the invitation of an Omniscient One, the elated king asked his question, beginning with, "Just as these, venerable sir..."
There, skill itself is a place of skill (*śilpāyatana*).
"Various places of skill" means many skills.
"Namely this" means which ones are they?
He indicates those who live by relying on that particular skill, beginning with elephant trainers (*hatthāroha*).
For this is his intention: "Just as a visible fruit of skill is discerned for those who live by these skills by relying on that particular skill."
"Is it possible to point out any visible fruit of recluseship (*sāmaññaphala*) in this way?"
Therefore, having brought forward the places of skill, he indicates those who live by those skills.
There, *hatthāroha* means he indicates all of the elephant trainers, elephant doctors, and elephant tamers, and so forth.
*Assāroha* means all of the horse trainers, horse doctors, and horse tamers, and so forth.
*Rathika* means all of the chariot trainers, chariot warriors, and chariot protectors, and so forth.
*Dhanuggaha* means bow masters and archers (*iṣvāsa*).
*Celaka* means those who go in front, taking the victory banner in battle.
*Calaka* means those who arrange the battle array, [saying,] "Let there be a place for the king here; let there be [a place] for such-and-such a great minister here."
*Piṇḍadāyaka* means courageous great warriors.
It means that they enter the enemy's army and strike down the enemy's leaders, cutting them down as if [they were] morsels, leaping up and leaping up, and going out.
Or, those who, in the midst of battle, take a food bowl and serve the warriors—this is their name.
*Uggārājaputta* means the princes who are fierce and have access to battles.
*Pakkhandino* means those who, having said, "Let us bring the head or weapon of whomever," and having been told, "of so-and-so," leap into battle and bring just that, these are called *pakkhandino* because they leap.
*Mahānāga* means great warriors, like great elephants; this is a designation for warriors who do not turn back when facing elephants and so forth as they approach.
*Sūra* means those who are completely brave, who are able to cross the ocean even with nets and hides.
*Cammayodhino* means those who enter a leather coat of mail or fight taking a shield of hide that protects from arrows.
*Dāsikaputta* means household slave warriors who are strong and affectionate.
*Āḷārika* means cooks.
*Kappaka* means barbers (*nhāpika*).
*Nhāpaka* means those who shave (*nhāpenti*).
*Sūda* means makers of food (*bhattakāraka*).
Garland makers (*mālākāra*) and so forth are well-known.
*Gaṇaka* means uninterrupted reciters.
*Muddika* means those who live by relying on calculation with hand seals.
Or, whatever other [skills there may be], such as ironworkers, ivory workers, and painters (*cittakāra*), and so forth.
"Being thus gone" means being thus proceeded.
They, in the very visible *dharma*, those elephant trainers and so forth, having shown those various places of skill, and obtaining great wealth from the royal family, live by just the visible fruit of skill.
"They gladden" means they make [others] happy.
"They strengthen" means they make [others] strong and endowed with power and strength.
Among *uddhaggika* and so forth, because the top of it has fruit produced above, [and] the top of it exists, it is called *uddhaggika*.
Because it is worthy of heaven (*svarga*), it is called *sovaggika*.
Because its result (*vipāka*) is pleasant, it is called *sukhavipāka*.
Because it well converts and produces the ten *dharmas* that are called form (*rūpa*), sound (*śabda*), smell (*gandha*), taste (*rasa*), touch (*spoṭṭhabba*), life (*āyu*), color (*varṇa*), happiness (*sukha*), fame (*yaśas*), and sovereignty (*ādhipateyya*) at the top, it is called *svargasaṃvartanika*.
That is, they establish such a দক্ষিণা *dakkhiṇā* offering or gift; this is the meaning.

“*Sāmaññaphala*”—here, in the ultimate sense, *magga* (the path) is *sāmañña* (recluseship).

*Ariyaphalaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*: and the noble fruit is the fruit of recluseship.

As he said: “What, monks, is *sāmañña* (recluseship)? It is just this noble eightfold path (*ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo*), that is, right view (*sammā-diṭṭhi*)…pe… right concentration (*sammā-samādhi*).

This, monks, is called *sāmañña* (recluseship).

What, monks, are the fruits of recluseship (*sāmaññaphalāni*)? The fruit of stream-entry (*sotāpattiphalaṃ*)…pe… the fruit of *arahat* (arahattaphala)…” (Saṃ.
Ni.
5.
35).

The king does not know that.

He asks, referring to the simile of the servant and the farmer who came above.

Then, the Blessed One, without answering the question, thought: "These many disciples of other sects, royal ministers, have come here. If, while they are speaking, I were to explain the dark side (*kaṇhapakkha*) and the bright side (*sukkapakkha*), they would complain, 'Our king has come here with great enthusiasm, but from the time he arrived, the ascetic Gotama only speaks of the quarrels and disputes of ascetics.' They will not listen respectfully to the Dharma, but if it is spoken by the king, they will not be able to complain and will follow the king.

For in the world (*loko*), people follow those in power (*issara*).

'So, let me give the burden to the king,' thinking thus, while giving the burden to the king, he said, "Do you remember, great king, ever asking other recluses and brahmins this question?" etc.

mula_pali: 164. ‘‘Abhijānāsi no tvaṃ, mahārāja, imaṃ pañhaṃ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā’’ti ? ‘‘Abhijānāmahaṃ, bhante, imaṃ pañhaṃ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā’’ti. ‘‘Yathā kathaṃ pana te, mahārāja, byākariṃsu, sace te agaru bhāsassū’’ti. ‘‘Na kho me, bhante, garu, yatthassa bhagavā nisinno, bhagavantarūpo vā’’ti cāti (sī. ka.). ‘‘Tena  hi, mahārāja, bhāsassū’’ti.
mula_english:
164.
“Do you remember, great king, ever asking other *śramaṇa* mendicants and *brāhmaṇa* priests this question?” “Yes, venerable sir, I remember asking other *śramaṇa* mendicants and *brāhmaṇa* priests this question.”
“If it isn’t troublesome for you, great king, please tell us how they answered.”
“It is not troublesome for me, venerable sir, when the Exalted One (*bhagavā*) or anyone like him is present.”
ka.
"Well then, great king, tell me."
commentary_pali: 164. Tattha abhijānāsi no tvanti abhijānāsi nu tvaṃ. Ayañca no-saddo parato pucchitāti padena yojetabbo. Idañhi vuttaṃ hoti – ‘‘mahārāja, tvaṃ imaṃ pañhaṃ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā nu, abhijānāsi ca naṃ puṭṭhabhāvaṃ, na te sammuṭṭha’’nti. Sace te agarūti sace tuyhaṃ yathā  te byākariṃsu, tathā idha bhāsituṃ bhāriyaṃ na hoti, yadi na koci aphāsukabhāvo atthi, bhāsassūti attho. Na kho me bhanteti kiṃ sandhāyāha? Paṇḍitapatirūpakānañhi santike kathetuṃ dukkhaṃ hoti, te pade pade akkhare akkhare dosameva vadanti. Ekantapaṇḍitā pana kathaṃ sutvā sukathitaṃ pasaṃsanti, dukkathitesu pāḷipadaatthabyañjanesu yaṃ yaṃ virujjhati, taṃ taṃ ujukaṃ katvā denti. Bhagavatā ca sadiso ekantapaṇḍito nāma natthi. Tenāha – ‘‘na kho me, bhante, garu; yatthassa bhagavā nisinno bhagavantarūpo vā’’ti.
commentary_english:
164.
There, do you recognize or not? Do you recognize, indeed?
And this particle "no" should be connected with the word "questioned" later on.
For it was said: "Great king, did you ask other *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s this question? And do you recognize the state of being questioned? You are not confused."
If it is not troublesome for you—if as they explained to you, so to speak here is not burdensome—if there is no discomfort, the meaning is, speak!
Why did he say, "It is not troublesome for me, venerable sir?" For it is difficult to speak in the presence of those who merely resemble wise men, for they only find fault in every word and every syllable.
But how do the truly wise men, having heard, praise what is well-spoken? And when something contradicts the meaning and phrasing of the Pāli texts in what is wrongly spoken, they correct it and give it straightforwardly.
And there is no truly wise man equal to the Blessed One (Bhagavat).
Therefore he said, "It is not troublesome for me, venerable sir, where the Exalted One (*bhagavā*), or one resembling the Exalted One, is seated."

mula_pali: 165. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena pūraṇo kassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā pūraṇena kassapena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kassapa, puthusippāyatanāni, seyyathidaṃ – hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā  celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālākārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṃgatāni puthusippāyatanāni- te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti; te tena attānaṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ. Sakkā nu kho, bho kassapa, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ  paññapetu’nti?
mula_english:
“Once, venerable sir, I approached Pūraṇa Kassapa; having approached him, I exchanged greetings with Pūraṇa Kassapa. After exchanging courteous greetings and amiable talk, I sat down to one side.

Having sat down to one side, venerable sir, I said this to Pūraṇa Kassapa: ‘Just as there are these various crafts, good Kassapa, such as elephant trainers (*hatthārohā*), horse trainers (*assārohā*), charioteers (*rathikā*), archers (*dhanuggahā*), standard bearers (*celakā*), camp marshals (*calakā*), army caterers (*piṇḍadāyakā*), champions and senior officers (*uggā rājaputtā*), scouts (*pakkhandino*), heroes (*mahānāgā*), brave fighters (*sūrā*), cuirassiers (*cammayodhino*), slaves’ sons (*dāsikaputtā*), cooks (*āḷārikā*), barbers (*kappakā*), bathmen (*nhāpakā*), bakers (*sūdā*), garland-makers (*mālākārā*), bleachers (*rajakā*), weavers (*pesakārā*), basket-makers (*naḷakārā*), potters (*kumbhakārā*), calculators (*gaṇakā*) and accountants (*muddikā*) — and whatever other skills there are: they enjoy here and now the visible fruits of their skills (*diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti*); by these means they gladden and gratify themselves, gladden and gratify their mothers and fathers, gladden and gratify their children and wives, gladden and gratify their friends and associates, and they establish an uplifting offering for ascetics and Brahmins, conducive to heavenly results of happiness, and leading to heaven.

Is it possible, good Kassapa, to point out any fruit of recluseship (*sāmaññaphalaṃ*) visible here and now (*diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ*) in just the same way?"
commentary_pali: 165.Ekamidāhanti ekaṃ idha ahaṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvāti sammodajanakaṃ saritabbayuttakaṃ kathaṃ pariyosāpetvā.
commentary_english:
165.
"One" means, "I strike one here."
How, after completely concluding what is agreeable, what should be made to run, what should be removed, what generates joy, and what is connected to what should flow?

mula_pali: 166. ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo maṃ etadavoca – ‘karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato socayato, socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātāpayato, adinnaṃ ādiyato, sandhiṃ chindato, nillopaṃ harato, ekāgārikaṃ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṃ gacchato, musā bhaṇato, karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ. Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo. Dakkhiṇaṃ cepi  gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya hananto ghātento chindanto chedāpento pacanto pācāpento, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo. Uttarañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya dadanto dāpento yajanto yajāpento, natthi tatonidānaṃ puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo. Dānena  damena saṃyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo’ti. Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṃ byākāsi. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya , labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya; evameva kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṃ byākāsi. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti. So kho ahaṃ, bhante, pūraṇassa kassapassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ. Anabhinanditvā appaṭikositvā  anattamano, anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto anikkujjento (syā. kaṃ. ka.) uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ pakkāmiṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.).
mula_english:
166.

When this was said, venerable sir, Pūraṇa Kassapa said this to me: 'Great king, in acting or causing to act, in mutilating or causing to mutilate, in torturing or causing to torture, in inflicting sorrow or causing to inflict sorrow, in oppressing or causing to oppress, in intimidating or causing to intimidate, in taking life, in taking what is not given, in breaking into houses, in plundering, in highway robbery, in committing adultery, in speaking falsehood, in acting, no evil is done.

If with a razor-sharp wheel one were to make the living beings on this earth into one mass of flesh, into one heap of flesh, there would be no evil resulting from that, no coming of evil.

If one were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, slaughtering, mutilating, causing to mutilate, torturing, causing to torture, there would be no evil resulting from that, no coming of evil.

If one were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving, causing to give, sacrificing, causing to sacrifice, there would be no merit resulting from that, no coming of merit.

By giving, self-control, restraint and truthfulness there is no merit, there is no coming of merit.'

Thus, venerable sir, when I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the visible fruit of the ascetic life, he explained the inefficacy of action.

Just as, venerable sir, if asked about a mango, one would speak about a breadfruit, or if asked about a breadfruit, one would speak about a mango; even so, venerable sir, when I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the visible fruit of the ascetic life, he explained the inefficacy of action.

Then it occurred to me, venerable sir: 'How could one like me think of disparaging a *śramaṇa* or a *brāhmaṇa* living in my territory?'

So I, venerable sir, neither rejoiced at Pūraṇa Kassapa's words nor did I reject them.

Without rejoicing, without rejecting, displeased, without expressing my displeasure, holding back that speech, not overturning it, not overturning it (it would be).

kaṃ.
