commentary_pali: 166.‘‘Karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato’’tiādīsu karototi sahatthā karontassa. Kārayatoti āṇattiyā kārentassa. Chindatoti paresaṃ hatthādīni chindantassa. Pacatoti pare daṇḍena pīḷentassa. Socayatoti parassa bhaṇḍaharaṇādīhi socayato. Socāpayatoti sokaṃ sayaṃ karontassapi parehi kārāpentassapi . Kilamatoti āhārupacchedabandhanāgārappavesanādīhi sayaṃ kilamantassapi parehi kilamāpentassapi. Phandato phandāpayatoti paraṃ phandantaṃ phandanakāle sayampi phandato parampi phandāpayato. Pāṇamatipātāpayatoti pāṇaṃ hanantassapi hanāpentassapi. Evaṃ sabbattha karaṇakāraṇavaseneva attho veditabbo. Sandhinti  gharasandhiṃ. Nillopanti mahāvilopaṃ. Ekāgārikanti ekameva gharaṃ parivāretvā viluppanaṃ. Paripantheti āgatāgatānaṃ acchindanatthaṃ magge tiṭṭhato. Karoto na karīyati pāpanti yaṃ kiñci pāpaṃ karomīti saññāya karotopi pāpaṃ na karīyati, natthi pāpaṃ. Sattā pana pāpaṃ karomāti evaṃsaññino hontīti dīpeti. Khurapariyantenāti  khuraneminā, khuradhārasadisapariyantena vā. Ekaṃ maṃsakhalanti ekaṃ maṃsarāsiṃ. Puñjanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Tatonidānanti ekamaṃsakhalakaraṇanidānaṃ. Dakkhiṇanti dakkhiṇatīre manussā kakkhaḷā dāruṇā, te sandhāya ‘‘hananto’’tiādimāha. Uttaratīre sattā saddhā honti pasannā buddhamāmakā dhammamāmakā saṅghamāmakā, te sandhāya dadantotiādimāha. Tattha yajantoti mahāyāgaṃ karonto. Damenāti indriyadamena uposathakammena vā. Saṃyamenāti sīlasaṃyamena. Saccavajjenāti saccavacanena. Āgamoti āgamanaṃ, pavattīti attho. Sabbathāpi pāpapuññānaṃ kiriyameva paṭikkhipati. Ambaṃ puṭṭho labujaṃ byākaroti nāma, yo kīdiso ambo kīdisāni vā ambassa khandhapaṇṇapupphaphalānīti vutte ediso labujo edisāni vā labujassa khandhapaṇṇapupphaphalānīti byākaroti. Vijiteti āṇāpavattidese. Apasādetabbanti viheṭhetabbaṃ. Anabhinanditvāti ‘‘sādhu sādhū’’ti evaṃ pasaṃsaṃ akatvā. Appaṭikkositvāti bāladubbhāsitaṃ tayā bhāsitanti evaṃ appaṭibāhitvā. Anuggaṇhantoti sārato aggaṇhanto. Anikkujjantoti sāravaseneva idaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, ayaṃ paramatthoti hadaye aṭṭhapento. Byañjanaṃ pana tena uggahitañceva nikkujjitañca.
commentary_english:
166.
"’Doing, indeed, great king, causing to do,’” in these and other instances, "doing" means doing with one's own hand.
"Causing to do" means causing (someone) to do through command.
"Cutting off" means cutting off the hands and other (limbs) of others.
"Tormenting" means tormenting others with a stick.
"Grieving" means causing grief to another through the taking away of goods and other things.
"Causing to grieve" means oneself doing sorrow, and causing others to do (it) as well.
"Fatiguing" means oneself becoming exhausted by the cutting off of food, imprisonment, entering a house, and other things, and causing others to become exhausted as well.
"Shaking, causing to shake" means shaking another person, and at the time of shaking, oneself also shaking, and causing another to shake as well.
"Causing to destroy life" means oneself killing a living being, and causing (another) to kill as well.
In this way, the meaning should be understood everywhere according to the basis of cause and effect.
*Sandhi* means house-breaking.
*Nillopa* means total destruction.
*Ekāgārika* means plundering after surrounding just one house.
*Paripantha* means standing in the road for the purpose of intercepting those coming and going.
"Doing, evil is not done," is when, with the thought, "I am doing some evil," even doing, evil is not done, there is no evil.
"Beings have the idea, ‘We are doing evil,’" this he shows.
*Khurapariyantena* means with a razor’s edge, or with an edge similar to a razor’s edge.
*Ekaṃ maṃsakhalanti* means a single mass of meat.
*Puñjanti* is a synonym of that itself.
*Tatonidānaṃ* means having as its origin a single mass of meat.
*Dakkhiṇaṃ* means on the southern bank the people are rough and cruel; referring to them, he says, "killing," and so on.
On the northern bank, beings are faithful, pleased, regarding the Buddha as their own, regarding the Dharma as their own, regarding the *Saṃgha* as their own; referring to them, he says, "giving," and so on.
*Tattha yajanti* means performing a great sacrifice (mahāyāgaṃ).
*Damena* means by the restraint of the senses (indriya-damena), or by the *uposatha* observance.
*Saṃyamena* means by the restraint of morality (*śīla*).
*Saccavajjenāti* means by truthful speech.
*Āgamo* means arrival; *pavatti* means outcome.
In every way, he rejects the doing of evil and also of merit (*puṇya*).
Asked about a mango (*amba*), he explains about a breadfruit (*labuja*), namely, when asked, "What sort of thing is a mango, what sort of things are the trunk, leaves, flowers, and fruits of a mango?" he explains, "This sort of thing is a breadfruit, these sorts of things are the trunk, leaves, flowers, and fruits of a breadfruit."
*Vijiteti* means in a place where his command is carried out.
*Apasādetabbaṃ* means should be injured.
*Anabhinanditvā* means without doing praise saying, "Good, good," in this way.
*Appaṭikkositvā* means without rejecting in this way, "That which was spoken by you is foolish ill-speaking."
*Anuggaṇhanto* means not taking the essence.
*Anikkujjanto* means establishing in the heart, "This is the release, this is the ultimate meaning" only through the force of the essence.
However, the expression (*byañjana*) is both taken up by him and rejected.

mula_pali: 167. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena makkhali gosālo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā makkhalinā gosālena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, makkhaliṃ gosālaṃ etadavocaṃ – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho gosāla, puthusippāyatanāni…pe… sakkā nu kho, bho gosāla, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’nti?
mula_english:
“On one occasion, venerable sir, I approached Makkhali Gosāla; having approached Makkhali Gosāla, I exchanged greetings with him.

After exchanging courteous and amiable talk, I sat down to one side.

Having sat down to one side, venerable sir, I said to Makkhali Gosāla: ‘Just as there are these various crafts and occupations… is it possible, venerable Gosāla, in just the same way to explain a fruit of the ascetic life visible in this very life?’
commentary_pali: 167-169. Makkhalivāde  paccayoti hetuvevacanameva, ubhayenāpi vijjamānameva kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ saṃkilesapaccayaṃ, kāyasucaritādīnañca visuddhipaccayaṃ paṭikkhipati. Attakāreti attakāro. Yena attanā katakammena ime sattā  devattampi mārattampi brahmattampi sāvakabodhimpi paccekabodhimpi sabbaññutampi pāpuṇanti, tampi paṭikkhipati. Dutiyapadena yaṃ parakāraṃ parassa ovādānusāsaniṃ nissāya ṭhapetvā mahāsattaṃ avaseso jano manussasobhagyataṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, taṃ parakāraṃ paṭikkhipati. Evamayaṃ bālo jinacakke pahāraṃ deti nāma. Natthi purisakāreti yena purisakārena sattā vuttappakārā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti , tampi paṭikkhipati. Natthi balanti yamhi attano bale patiṭṭhitā sattā vīriyaṃ katvā tā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti, taṃ balaṃ paṭikkhipati. Natthi vīriyantiādīni sabbāni purisakāravevacanāneva. ‘‘Idaṃ no vīriyena idaṃ purisathāmena, idaṃ purisaparakkamena pavatta’’nti evaṃ pavattavacanapaṭikkhepakaraṇavasena panetāni visuṃ ādiyanti. Sabbe sattāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhādayo anavasese pariggaṇhāti. Sabbe pāṇāti ekindriyo pāṇo, dvindriyo pāṇotiādivasena vadati. Sabbe bhūtāti aṇḍakosavatthikosesu bhūte sandhāya vadati. Sabbe jīvāti sāliyavagodhumādayo sandhāya vadati. Tesu hi so virūhanabhāvena jīvasaññī. Avasā abalā avīriyāti tesaṃ attano vaso vā balaṃ vā vīriyaṃ vā natthi. Niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatāti ettha niyatīti niyatā. Saṅgatīti channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Bhāvoti sabhāvoyeva. Evaṃ niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena ca pariṇatā nānappakārataṃ pattā. Yena hi yathā bhavitabbaṃ, so tatheva bhavati. Yena na bhavitabbaṃ, so na bhavatīti dasseti. Chasvevābhijātīsūti chasu eva abhijātīsu ṭhatvā sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedenti. Aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthīti dasseti. Yonipamukhasatasahassānīti pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ  cuddasasatasahassāni aññāni ca saṭṭhisatāni aññāni ca chasatāni. Pañca ca kammunosatānīti pañcakammasatāni ca. Kevalaṃ takkamattakena niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpeti. Pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammānītiādīsupi eseva nayo. Keci panāhu – ‘‘pañca ca kammānīti pañcindriyavasena bhaṇati. Tīṇīti kāyakammādivasenā’’ti. Kamme ca upaḍḍhakamme cāti ettha panassa kāyakammañca vacīkammañca kammanti laddhi, manokammaṃ upaḍḍhakammanti. Dvaṭṭhipaṭipadāti dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadāti vadati. Dvaṭṭhantarakappāti ekasmiṃ kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappā nāma honti. Ayaṃ pana aññe dve ajānanto evamāha. Chaḷābhijātiyoti kaṇhābhijāti, nīlābhijāti, lohitābhijāti, haliddābhijāti, sukkābhijāti, paramasukkābhijātīti imā cha abhijātiyo vadati. Tattha orabbhikā, sākuṇikā, māgavikā, sūkarikā, luddā, macchaghātakā corā, coraghātakā, bandhanāgārikā, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā, ayaṃ kaṇhābhijātīti (a. ni. 6.57) vadati. Bhikkhū nīlābhijātīti vadati, te kira catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti. ‘‘Bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā’’ti (a. ni. 6.57) ayañhissa pāḷiyeva. Atha vā  kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitāti vadati. Lohitābhijāti nāma nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadati. Ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā. Gihī odātavasanā acelakasāvakā haliddābhijātīti vadati. Evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare karoti. Ājīvakā ājīvakiniyo sukkābhijātīti vadati. Te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā. Nando, vaccho, kiso, saṅkiccho, makkhaligosālo, paramasukkābhijātīti (a. ni. 6.57) vadati. Te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā. Aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi, khiḍḍābhūmi, padavīmaṃsabhūmi, ujugatabhūmi, sekkhabhūmi, samaṇabhūmi , jinabhūmi, pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadati. Tattha jātadivasato paṭṭhāya sattadivase sambādhaṭṭhānato nikkhantattā sattā mandā honti momūhā, ayaṃ mandabhūmīti vadati. Ye pana duggatito āgatā honti, te abhiṇhaṃ rodanti ceva viravanti ca, sugatito āgatā taṃ anussaritvā hasanti, ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma. Mātāpitūnaṃ hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ padanikkhipanaṃ padavīmaṃsabhūmi nāma. Padasā gantuṃ samatthakāle ujugatabhūmi nāma. Sippāni sikkhitakāle  sekkhabhūmi nāma. Gharā nikkhamma pabbajitakāle samaṇabhūmi nāma. Ācariyaṃ sevitvā jānanakāle jinabhūmi nāma. Bhikkhu ca pannako jino na kiñci āhāti evaṃ alābhiṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadati. Ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti ekūnapaññāsaājīvakavuttisatāni. Paribbājakasateti paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni. Nāgāvāsasateti nāgamaṇḍalasatāni. Vīse indriyasateti vīsatindriyasatāni. Tiṃse nirayasateti tiṃsa nirayasatāni. Rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni, hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni sandhāya vadati. Satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya vadati. Satta asaññīgabbhāti sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati. Nigaṇṭhigabbhāti gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati. Satta devāti bahū devā. So pana sattāti vadati. Manussāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati. Sattapisācāti pisācā mahantamahantā sattāti vadati. Sarāti mahāsarā, kaṇṇamuṇḍarathakāraanotattasīhappapātachaddantamandākinīkuṇāladahe gahetvā vadati. Pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā. Papātāti mahāpapātā. Papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni. Supināti mahāsupinā. Supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ. Tattha  ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati. Evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi. Paṇḍitopi kira antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti. Bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati. Sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci. Vatenāti tādiseneva vatena. Tapenāti tapokammena. Aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo ‘‘ahaṃ paṇḍito’’ti antarā visujjhati. Paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo ‘‘ahaṃ bālo’’ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti. Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi. Tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā  kātunti dīpeti. Doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya. Sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ. Pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyante. Natthihāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni. Na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā. Hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi nāmā’’tiādimāha. Tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati. Evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
[Garuda Purana 167-169]

In the doctrine of Makkhali, the word *paccaya* is just a synonym for *hetu* (cause). With both words, he rejects the real condition for defilement, i.e. wrong bodily conduct, etc., and the real condition for purification, i.e. right bodily conduct, etc.

*Attakāra* means personal determination.

He rejects also the *karma* (action) by reason of which beings attain the state of a god (*devattaṃ*), the state of Māra (*mārattaṃ*), the state of Brahmā (*brahmattampi*), the enlightenment of a disciple (*sāvakabodhiṃ*), the enlightenment of a *paccekabuddha* (*paccekabodhiṃ*), or omniscience (*sabbaññutaṃ*).

By the second expression, he rejects that other-determination (*parakāraṃ*) through reliance on the exhortation and instruction of another person (*parassa ovādānusāsaniṃ nissāya*), apart from a Great Being (*mahāsattaṃ*), the remaining people attain from good fortune in the human state (*manussasobhagyataṃ*) up to arahatship (*arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti*).

Thus, this fool strikes a blow at the Wheel of the Conqueror (*jinacakke pahāraṃ deti*).

"No personal determination" (*natthi purisakāreti*): he rejects the personal determination (*purisakārena*) through which beings attain the aforementioned kinds of success (*vuttappakārā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti*).

“No power” (*natthi balanti*): he denies that beings can establish themselves upon their own power (*attano bale patiṭṭhitā*), arouse their energy (*vīriyaṃ katvā*), and attain those kinds of success (*tā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti*).

"No energy," etc. are all just synonyms for personal determination (*purisakāravevacanāneva*).

They are brought in separately in order to reject the claim: "This has occurred through our energy (*idaṃ no vīriyena*), this through personal strength (*purisathāmena*), and this through personal fortitude (*purisaparakkamena pavatta*)."

"All sentient beings" (*sabbe sattā*): he includes camels, oxen, donkeys, etc., without exception (*anavasese pariggaṇhāti*).

"All living beings" (*sabbe pāṇā*): he says this with reference to creatures having one faculty (*ekindriyo pāṇo*) or two faculties (*dvindriyo pāṇo*), etc.

"All creatures" (*sabbe bhūtā*): this refers to beings born from eggs (*aṇḍakosa*) or from the womb (*vatthikosesu bhūte sandhāya vadati*).

"All souls" (*sabbe jīvā*): this refers to rice, barley, wheat, etc. (*sāli yava godhumādayo sandhāya vadati*).

Because they undergo growth (*virūhanabhāvena*), he regards them as having souls (*jīvasaññī*).

"Are helpless (*avasā*), powerless (*abalā*), devoid of energy (*avīriyā*)": they have no self-control (*attano vaso*), power (*balaṃ*), or energy (*vīriyaṃ*).

"*Niyatisangatibhāvapariṇatā* (destiny, connection, nature and change)": here, *niyati* means fixed.

“Circumstance (*saṅgatīti*)": going here and there among the six classes of men (*channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ tattha tattha gamanaṃ*).

"Nature (*bhāvo*)": the inner nature itself (*sabhāvoyeva*).

Thus, through destiny (*niyatiyā*), circumstance (*saṅgatiyā*), and nature (*bhāvena*), they have attained various kinds of change (*nānappakārataṃ pattā*).

Whatever will be will be (*yena hi yathā bhavitabbaṃ*), so that is how it is (*so tatheva bhavati*).

Whatever will not be will not be (*yena na bhavitabbaṃ, so na bhavati*), this he shows (*dasseti*).

"The six classes of men" (*chasvevābhijātīsūti*): abiding in the six classes of men (*chasu eva abhijātīsu ṭhatvā*), they experience pleasure and pain (*sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedenti*).

He shows that there is no other plane of pleasure and pain (*aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthi*).

“Hundreds of thousands of beginnings of wombs (*yonipamukhasatasahassāni*)”: fourteen hundred thousand of the main and best wombs (*pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ cuddasasatasahassāni*), plus six hundred others (*aññāni ca saṭṭhisatāni*) and six hundred others (*aññāni ca chasatāni*).

"Five hundred kinds of *kamma* (*pañca ca kammunosatāni*)" means five hundred *kamma-sata* (*pañcakammasatāni*).

He explains a senseless view (*niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpeti*) devised solely by mere reasoning (*kevalaṃ takkamattakena*).

The same principle applies in the case of five kinds of *kamma* (*pañca ca kammāni*), three kinds of *kamma* (*tīṇi ca kammāni*), etc.

But some say: "He speaks of five kinds of *kamma* (*pañca ca kammāni*) by way of the five sense faculties (*pañcindriyavasena bhaṇati*)."

"Three" means by way of bodily *kamma*, etc. (*kāyakammādivasenā*).

“Full *kamma* and half *kamma* (*kamme ca upaḍḍhakamme ca*)”: here his theory is that bodily *kamma* (*kāyakammañca*) and verbal *kamma* (*vacīkammañca*) are full *kamma* (*kammanti laddhi*), and mental *kamma* (*manokammaṃ*) is half *kamma* (*upaḍḍhakammanti*).

“Sixty-two pathways (*dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā*)” means he speaks of sixty-two pathways (*dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadāti vadati*).

"Sixty-two sub-aeons (*dvaṭṭhantarakappā*)": in a single great aeon (*ekasmiṃ kappe*) there are sixty-four sub-aeons (*catusaṭṭhi antarakappā nāma honti*).

But since he does not know about two of these (*aññe dve ajānanto*), he says thus (*evamāha*).

He declares that there are six classes of men (*chaḷābhijātiyo*): the black (*kaṇhābhijāti*), the blue (*nīlābhijāti*), the red (*lohitābhijāti*), the yellow (*haliddābhijāti*), the white (*sukkābhijāti*), and the ultimate white (*paramasukkābhijāti*).

The black class (*kaṇhābhijāti*) is made up of butchers (*orabbhikā*), hunters (*sākuṇikā*), trappers of wild beasts (*māgavikā*), butchers of pigs (*sūkarikā*), hunters (*luddā*), fishermen (*macchaghātakā*), thieves (*corā*), executioners (*coraghātakā*), prison wardens (*bandhanāgārikā*), and those in other cruel lines of work (*ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā*) (A.

N.

6.
57). He says (*vadati*).

The blue class (*nīlābhijāti*) is made up of *bhikkhus* (*bhikkhū nīlābhijātīti vadati*). For *bhikkhus*, he says, eat having thrown thorns (*kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti*) into the four requisites (*catūsu paccayesu*).
“The monks have thorny behavior” ( *bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā*)— (a.
ni.
6.
57) This very thing is indeed the text.
Or alternatively, he says that some who have gone forth are named as having thorny behavior ( *kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitāti vadati*).
The red class is made up of the one-robed he Nigaṇṭhas ; ( *lohitābhijāti nāma nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadati*).
for these are purer than the former two. ( *ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā*).
He says, "Lay followers in white robes are of the yellow class," ( *gihī odātavasanā acelakasāvakā haliddābhijātīti vadati*)
Thus he makes his own lay supporters superior even to the Nigaṇṭhas. ( *evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare karoti*).
He says, "The Ājīvakas and Ājīvakinīs are of the white class." ( *ājīvakā ājīvakiniyo sukkābhijātīti vadati*).
for these, he says, are purer than the previous four. ( *te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā*).
The ultimate white class is made up of Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkiccha, and Makkhali Gosāla ( *nando, vaccho, kiso, saṅkiccho, makkhaligosālo, paramasukkābhijātīti*) (a.
ni.
6.
57) He says. ( *vadati*)
for they are the purest of all. ( *te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā*).
He declares that there are eight stages in the life of man: the stage of feebleness (*mandabhūmi*); the stage of play (*khiḍḍābhūmi*); the stage of learning to walk (*padavīmaṃsabhūmi*); the erect stage (*ujugatabhūmi*); the stage of training (*sekkhabhūmi*); the recluse stage (*samaṇabhūmi*); the conqueror stage (*jinabhūmi*); and the prostrate stage (*pannabhūmi*). ( *aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi, khiḍḍābhūmi, padavīmaṃsabhūmi, ujugatabhūmi, sekkhabhūmi, samaṇabhūmi , jinabhūmi, pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadati*).
The stage of feebleness: this lasts for seven days following the day of birth; for after coming out from the womb beings are feeble and dull. He calls this the stage of feebleness ( *ayaṃ mandabhūmīti vadati*).
The stage of play: those who have come from an evil destination often cry and howl; those who come from a good destination remember it and laugh. This is called the stage of play. ( *ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma*).
The stage of learning to walk: this is the stage when the child takes hold of its parents’ hands or feet, or a bed or chair, and places its feet on the ground. This is called the stage of learning to walk. ( *padavīmaṃsabhūmi nāma*).
The erect stage: this is the stage when it is able to walk on its feet. ( *ujugatabhūmi nāma*).
The stage of training: this is the stage when one has been trained in a craft. ( *sekkhabhūmi nāma*).
The recluse stage: this is the time when one has renounced the household life and gone forth. ( *samaṇabhūmi nāma*).
The conqueror stage: this is the time when, having served a teacher, one knows. ( *jinabhūmi nāma*).
The *bhikṣu*, wise, victorious, says nothing; thus the ascetic does not obtain the stage of wisdom (*pannabhūmīti vadati*).
Forty-nine hundreds of Ājīvakas (*ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti*)—[that is,] forty-nine hundred Ājīvaka means of subsistence (*ekūnapaññāsaājīvakavuttisatāni*).
Hundreds of wanderers (*paribbājakasateti*)—[that is,] hundreds of the wanderers’ going forth (*paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni*).
Hundreds of abodes of *nāgas* (*nāgāvāsasateti*)—[that is,] hundreds of circles of *nāgas* (*nāgamaṇḍalasatāni*).
Twenty hundreds of faculties (*vīse indriyasateti*)—[that is,] twenty hundred faculties (*vīsatindriyasatāni*).
Thirty hundreds of hells (*tiṃse nirayasateti*)—[that is,] thirty hundreds of hells (*tiṃsa nirayasatāni*).
"Thirty-six realms of dust": places where dust accumulates; he says this referring to the backs of the hands, bottom of the feet, etc. (*rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni, hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni sandhāya vadati*).
“Seven spheres of percipient beings”: he says this referring to camels, oxen, donkeys, goats, cattle, deer, and buffaloes. ( *satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya vadati*).
“Seven spheres of non-percipient beings”: he says this referring to rice, paddy, barley, wheat, millet, beans, and *kudrūsaka*. (*satta asaññīgabbhāti sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati*).
“Seven kinds of jointed plants”: plants grown from joints; he refers to sugarcane, bamboo, reeds, etc. (*nigaṇṭhigabbhāti gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati*).
“Seven kinds of gods”: there are many kinds of gods, (*satta devāti bahū devā*).
but he says there are seven (*so pana sattāti vadati*).
Human beings, too, are of infinite kinds, but he says there are seven (*manussāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati*).
“Seven kinds of demons”: there are numerous kinds of demons, but he says there are seven. (*sattapisācāti pisācā mahantamahantā sattāti vadati*).
“Seven great lakes”: he says this mentioning the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, Rathakāra, Anotatta, Sìhappapāta, Chaddanta, Mandākinī, and Kuṇāladaha. (*sarāti mahāsarā, kaṇṇamuṇḍarathakāraanotattasīhappapātachaddantamandākinīkuṇāladahe gahetvā vadati*).
The toggle is allowable. (*pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā*).
papātāti mahāpapātā.
It falls; it is a great fall.

papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni.
Hundreds of falls; it is a small hundred of falls.

supināti mahāsupinā.
It dreams; it is a great dream.

supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni.
Hundreds of dreams; it is a small hundred of dreams.

mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ.
Of a great aeon; it is of great aeons.

tattha ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati.
There, he describes a great aeon as the time it would take to drain a single great lake seven times by removing a single drop of water with the tip of a blade of *kusa*-grass once every hundred years.

evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi.
His theory asserts that when eighty-four hundred thousand of such great aeons have passed, the foolish (*bāle*) and the wise (*paṇḍite*) make an end to suffering (*duḥkhassāntaṃ*).

paṇḍitopi kira antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti.
The wise man, he says, cannot purify himself before this.

bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati.
and the fool does not continue on beyond.

sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci.
By this moral discipline of the naked ascetics or by any other.

vatenāti tādiseneva vatena.
“Observance” should be understood similarly.

tapenāti tapokammena.
By austerity, it is through deeds of asceticism.

aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo ‘‘ahaṃ paṇḍito’’ti antarā visujjhati.
That the one who considers himself a wise man should “ripen unripened *kamma*” i.e. that he should purify himself beforehand,

paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo ‘‘ahaṃ bālo’’ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti.
or “eliminate ripened *kamma* whenever it comes up,” or that the one who considers himself a fool should continue on beyond the time stated to be the limits —

hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi.
“that cannot be,”

tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti.
i.e. neither is able to do that.

doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya.
Measured by a *doṇa*; it is as if measured by a *doṇa*.

sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ.
Pleasure and pain; it is pleasure and pain.

pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyante.
With a limit made; it is with a limit made by the stated measure of time.

natthihāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni.
There is no decrease or increase; there are no decreases or increases.

na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho.
“Saṃsāra’s limits … . can neither be shortened nor extended”: *saṃsāra* is not shortened for the wise man (*paṇḍitassa*), nor extended for the fool (*bālassa*).

ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā.
Superiority and inferiority; they are superiorities and inferiorities.

hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
This is a designation for decrease and increase.

idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi nāmā’’tiādimāha.
Now, to demonstrate that meaning with a simile, he said, "Just as, for example..." and so forth.

tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe.
There, a ball of thread; it is a ball of thread made by wrapping [it].

nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati.
Just as it unrolls, it flees; having stood on a mountain or at the top of a tree, something thrown unrolls as it goes according to the thread's measure, and when the thread is exhausted, it stands right there and does not go [further].

evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti.
Just so, he shows that [one] does not go beyond the stated time.

mula_pali: 168. ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, bhante, makkhali gosālo maṃ etadavoca – ‘natthi mahārāja hetu natthi paccayo sattānaṃ saṃkilesāya, ahetū ahetu (katthaci) apaccayā sattā saṃkilissanti. Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā, ahetū apaccayā sattā visujjhanti. Natthi attakāre, natthi parakāre, natthi purisakāre, natthi balaṃ, natthi vīriyaṃ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo . Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṃ sukhañca dukkhañca (syā.) paṭisaṃvedenti. Cuddasa  kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā dvaṭṭhantarakappā  chaḷābhijātiyo aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate vīse indriyasate tiṃse nirayasate chattiṃsa rajodhātuyo satta saññīgabbhā satta asaññīgabbhā satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā satta devā satta mānusā satta pisācā satta sarā satta pavuṭā sapuṭā (ka.), pabuṭā (sī.) satta pavuṭasatāni satta papātā satta papātasatāni satta supinā satta supinasatāni cullāsīti mahākappino mahākappuno (ka. sī. pī.) satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karissanti. Tattha natthi  ‘‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṃ vā kammaṃ paripācessāmi, paripakkaṃ vā kammaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karissāmī’ti hevaṃ natthi. Doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṃsāre , natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṃsāvakaṃse. Seyyathāpi nāma suttaguḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānameva paleti, evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karissantī’ti.
mula_english:
168. “When this had been said, venerable sir, Makkhali Gosāla said this to me: ‘Great king, there is no cause ( *hetu* ) or condition ( *paccaya* ) for the defilement ( *saṃkilesa* ) of beings; beings are defiled without cause or condition.

There is no cause or condition for the purification ( *visuddhi* ) of beings; beings are purified without cause or condition.

There is no self-determination ( *attakāre* ), no determination by others ( *parakāre* ), no human determination ( *purisakāre* ). There is no power ( *balaṃ* ), no energy ( *vīriyaṃ* ), no human strength ( *purisathāmo* ), no human endeavor (*purisaparakkamo* ).

All beings ( *sabbe sattā* ), all living things ( *sabbe pāṇā* ), all creatures ( *sabbe bhūtā* ), all souls ( *sabbe jīvā* ) are powerless ( *avasā* ), devoid of strength ( *abalā* ), devoid of effort ( *avīriyā* ); subject to the changes of fate ( *niyati* ), circumstance ( *saṅgati* ), and nature ( *bhāva* ), they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of birth ( *chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṃ* ).

There are fourteen hundred thousand principal kinds of generation, and sixty hundred kinds, and six hundred kinds; there are five hundred kinds of action ( *kamma* ), and five kinds of action, and three kinds of action, and action and half-action; there are sixty-two pathways ( *dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā* ), sixty-two sub-aeons ( *dvaṭṭhantarakappā* ), six classes of men ( *chaḷābhijātiyo* ), eight stages in the life of man ( *aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo* ), forty-nine hundred modes of livelihood ( *ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate* ), forty-nine hundred kinds of wanderers ( *ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate* ), forty-nine hundred abodes of *Nāgas* ( *ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate* ), two thousand faculties ( *vīse indriyasate* ), three thousand hells ( *tiṃse nirayasate* ), thirty-six realms of *rajodhātuyo*, seven sentient beings in the womb ( *satta saññīgabbhā* ), seven non-sentient beings in the womb ( *satta asaññīgabbhā* ), seven *nigaṇṭhi* beings in the womb ( *satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā* ), seven gods ( *satta devā* ), seven humans ( *satta mānusā* ), seven *pisācas* ( *satta pisācā* ), seven *saras* ( *satta sarā* ), seven *pavuṭas* ( *satta pavuṭā* ), seven hundred *pavuṭas* ( *satta pavuṭasatāni* ), seven chasms ( *satta papātā* ), seven hundred chasms ( *satta papātasatāni* ), seven dreams ( *satta supinā* ), seven hundred dreams ( *satta supinasatāni* ), eighty-four hundred thousand great aeons ( *cullāsīti mahākappino mahākappuno satasahassāni* ), through which fools and the wise, running and wandering, will make an end to suffering ( *dukkhassantaṃ karissanti* ).

There is none of this: “By this virtue ( *sīlena* ) or observance ( *vatena* ) or asceticism ( *tapena* ) or holy life ( *brahmacariyena* ) I shall make unripened action ( *kamma* ) ripen or annihilate ripened action as it comes."

Pleasure ( *sukha* ) and pain ( *dukkha* ) are measured out. The round of rebirths ( *saṃsāre* ) is limited, there is no shortening or extending it, no increasing or decreasing it.

Just as a ball of string when thrown goes as far as the string unwinds, so too, by running and wandering through the round of rebirths, fools and the wise both will make an end to suffering.’
commentary_pali: 167-169. Makkhalivāde  paccayoti hetuvevacanameva, ubhayenāpi vijjamānameva kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ saṃkilesapaccayaṃ, kāyasucaritādīnañca visuddhipaccayaṃ paṭikkhipati. Attakāreti attakāro. Yena attanā katakammena ime sattā  devattampi mārattampi brahmattampi sāvakabodhimpi paccekabodhimpi sabbaññutampi pāpuṇanti, tampi paṭikkhipati. Dutiyapadena yaṃ parakāraṃ parassa ovādānusāsaniṃ nissāya ṭhapetvā mahāsattaṃ avaseso jano manussasobhagyataṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti, taṃ parakāraṃ paṭikkhipati. Evamayaṃ bālo jinacakke pahāraṃ deti nāma. Natthi purisakāreti yena purisakārena sattā vuttappakārā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti , tampi paṭikkhipati. Natthi balanti yamhi attano bale patiṭṭhitā sattā vīriyaṃ katvā tā sampattiyo pāpuṇanti, taṃ balaṃ paṭikkhipati. Natthi vīriyantiādīni sabbāni purisakāravevacanāneva. ‘‘Idaṃ no vīriyena idaṃ purisathāmena, idaṃ purisaparakkamena pavatta’’nti evaṃ pavattavacanapaṭikkhepakaraṇavasena panetāni visuṃ ādiyanti. Sabbe sattāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhādayo anavasese pariggaṇhāti. Sabbe pāṇāti ekindriyo pāṇo, dvindriyo pāṇotiādivasena vadati. Sabbe bhūtāti aṇḍakosavatthikosesu bhūte sandhāya vadati. Sabbe jīvāti sāliyavagodhumādayo sandhāya vadati. Tesu hi so virūhanabhāvena jīvasaññī. Avasā abalā avīriyāti tesaṃ attano vaso vā balaṃ vā vīriyaṃ vā natthi. Niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatāti ettha niyatīti niyatā. Saṅgatīti channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Bhāvoti sabhāvoyeva. Evaṃ niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena ca pariṇatā nānappakārataṃ pattā. Yena hi yathā bhavitabbaṃ, so tatheva bhavati. Yena na bhavitabbaṃ, so na bhavatīti dasseti. Chasvevābhijātīsūti chasu eva abhijātīsu ṭhatvā sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedenti. Aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthīti dasseti. Yonipamukhasatasahassānīti pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ  cuddasasatasahassāni aññāni ca saṭṭhisatāni aññāni ca chasatāni. Pañca ca kammunosatānīti pañcakammasatāni ca. Kevalaṃ takkamattakena niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpeti. Pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammānītiādīsupi eseva nayo. Keci panāhu – ‘‘pañca ca kammānīti pañcindriyavasena bhaṇati. Tīṇīti kāyakammādivasenā’’ti. Kamme ca upaḍḍhakamme cāti ettha panassa kāyakammañca vacīkammañca kammanti laddhi, manokammaṃ upaḍḍhakammanti. Dvaṭṭhipaṭipadāti dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadāti vadati. Dvaṭṭhantarakappāti ekasmiṃ kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappā nāma honti. Ayaṃ pana aññe dve ajānanto evamāha. Chaḷābhijātiyoti kaṇhābhijāti, nīlābhijāti, lohitābhijāti, haliddābhijāti, sukkābhijāti, paramasukkābhijātīti imā cha abhijātiyo vadati. Tattha orabbhikā, sākuṇikā, māgavikā, sūkarikā, luddā, macchaghātakā corā, coraghātakā, bandhanāgārikā, ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā, ayaṃ kaṇhābhijātīti (a. ni. 6.57) vadati. Bhikkhū nīlābhijātīti vadati, te kira catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti. ‘‘Bhikkhū kaṇṭakavuttikā’’ti (a. ni. 6.57) ayañhissa pāḷiyeva. Atha vā  kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitāti vadati. Lohitābhijāti nāma nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadati. Ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā. Gihī odātavasanā acelakasāvakā haliddābhijātīti vadati. Evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare karoti. Ājīvakā ājīvakiniyo sukkābhijātīti vadati. Te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā. Nando, vaccho, kiso, saṅkiccho, makkhaligosālo, paramasukkābhijātīti (a. ni. 6.57) vadati. Te kira sabbehi paṇḍaratarā. Aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi, khiḍḍābhūmi, padavīmaṃsabhūmi, ujugatabhūmi, sekkhabhūmi, samaṇabhūmi , jinabhūmi, pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadati. Tattha jātadivasato paṭṭhāya sattadivase sambādhaṭṭhānato nikkhantattā sattā mandā honti momūhā, ayaṃ mandabhūmīti vadati. Ye pana duggatito āgatā honti, te abhiṇhaṃ rodanti ceva viravanti ca, sugatito āgatā taṃ anussaritvā hasanti, ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma. Mātāpitūnaṃ hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ padanikkhipanaṃ padavīmaṃsabhūmi nāma. Padasā gantuṃ samatthakāle ujugatabhūmi nāma. Sippāni sikkhitakāle  sekkhabhūmi nāma. Gharā nikkhamma pabbajitakāle samaṇabhūmi nāma. Ācariyaṃ sevitvā jānanakāle jinabhūmi nāma. Bhikkhu ca pannako jino na kiñci āhāti evaṃ alābhiṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadati. Ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti ekūnapaññāsaājīvakavuttisatāni. Paribbājakasateti paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni. Nāgāvāsasateti nāgamaṇḍalasatāni. Vīse indriyasateti vīsatindriyasatāni. Tiṃse nirayasateti tiṃsa nirayasatāni. Rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni, hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni sandhāya vadati. Satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya vadati. Satta asaññīgabbhāti sālivīhiyavagodhūmakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati. Nigaṇṭhigabbhāti gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati. Satta devāti bahū devā. So pana sattāti vadati. Manussāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati. Sattapisācāti pisācā mahantamahantā sattāti vadati. Sarāti mahāsarā, kaṇṇamuṇḍarathakāraanotattasīhappapātachaddantamandākinīkuṇāladahe gahetvā vadati. Pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā. Papātāti mahāpapātā. Papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni. Supināti mahāsupinā. Supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ. Tattha  ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati. Evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi. Paṇḍitopi kira antarā visujjhituṃ na sakkoti. Bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati. Sīlenāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci. Vatenāti tādiseneva vatena. Tapenāti tapokammena. Aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma, yo ‘‘ahaṃ paṇḍito’’ti antarā visujjhati. Paripakkaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karoti nāma yo ‘‘ahaṃ bālo’’ti vuttaparimāṇaṃ kālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti. Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi. Tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā  kātunti dīpeti. Doṇamiteti doṇena mitaṃ viya. Sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ. Pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyante. Natthihāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni. Na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā. Hāyanavaḍḍhanānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi nāmā’’tiādimāha. Tattha suttaguḷeti veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati, na gacchati. Evameva vuttakālato uddhaṃ na gacchatīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
[From sections] 167-169:

In the doctrine of Makkhali, the word *paccaya* means only *hetuvevacana*. By both words, he rejects the real condition for defilement, i.e. wrong bodily conduct (*kāyaduccarita*) etc., and the real condition for purification, i.e. right bodily conduct (*kāyasucarita*) etc.

"Self-determination" (*attakāra*) means self-determination (*attakāro*).

He rejects also that, is the *karma* by which beings on their own, attain the state of a god (*devatta*), the state of Māra (*māratta*), the state of Brahmā (*brahmata*), the enlightenment of a disciple (*sāvakabodhi*), the enlightenment of a *paccekabuddha*, or omniscience (*sabbaññuta*).

"Determination by others" is the exhortation and instruction given by others, in dependence upon which all people, except for the Great Beings (*mahāsatta*), attain ranging from good fortune in the human state (*manussasobhagyata*) up to *arahatship* (*arahatta*). He rejects this determination by others (*parakāra*).

Thus this fool strikes a blow at the Wheel of the Conqueror (*jinacakka*).

"No personal determination" (*purisakāra*): he rejects the personal determination through which beings attain the aforementioned kinds of success (*sampatti*).

"No power" (*bala*): he denies that beings can establish themselves upon their own power (*bala*), arouse their energy (*viriya*), and attain success (*sampatti*).

"No energy (*viriya*)": all these terms are merely synonyms for personal determination (*purisakāra*).

They are brought in separately in order to reject the claim: “This has occurred through our energy (*vīriya*), personal strength (*purisathāma*), and personal fortitude (*purisaparakkama*)."

"All sentient beings" (*sabbe satta*): he includes camels (*oṭṭha*), oxen (*goṇa*), donkeys (*gadrabha*), etc., without exception.

“All living beings” (*sabbe pāṇa*): he says this with reference to creatures having one faculty (*ekindriya pāṇa*), or two faculties (*dvindriya pāṇa*), etc.

"All creatures" (*sabbe bhūta*): this refers to beings born from eggs (*aṇḍakosa*) or from the womb (*vatthikosa*).

“All souls” (*sabbe jīva*): this refers to rice (*sāli*), barley (*yava*), wheat (*godhuma*), etc.

because they undergo growth (*virūhana*), he regards them as having souls (*jīvasaññī*).

"Are helpless (*avasā*), powerless (*abalā*), devoid of energy (*avīriya*)": they have no self-control (*vaso*), power (*bala*), or energy (*vīriya*).

*Niyatisangatibhāvapariṇatā*: here, *niyati* means fixed (*niyatā*).

"Circumstance" (*saṅgati*): going here and there among the six classes of men (*abhijāti*).

"Nature" (*bhāva*): the inner nature (*sabhāva*).

Thus, conditioned by destiny (*niyati*), circumstance (*saṅgati*), and nature (*bhāva*), they attain diversity (*nānappakārata*).

Whatever will be will be (*yathā bhavitabbaṃ*), that is how it is (*tatheva bhavati*).

Whatever will not be will not be (*na bhavitabbaṃ*)," he shows.

“The six classes of men” (*chasvevābhijāti*): abiding in the six classes of men (*abhijāti*), they experience pleasure (*sukha*) and pain (*dukkha*).

He shows that there is no other plane of pleasure and pain (*sukhadukkhabhūmi*).

"Hundreds of thousands of wombs" (*yonipamukhasatasahassāni*): fourteen hundred thousand of the principal wombs (*pamukhayoni*) of the highest wombs (*uttamayoni*), and also sixty hundred, and also six hundred.

"Five hundred kinds of *kamma* (*pañca kammunosatāni*)": and also five hundred *kamma* (*pañcakammasatāni*).

He explains a senseless view devised solely by mere reasoning (*takka*).

The same principle applies in the case of five kinds of *kamma* (*pañca kammāni*), three kinds of *kamma* (*tīṇi kammāni*), etc.

But some say: "He speaks of five kinds of *kamma* (*pañca kammāni*) by way of the five sense faculties (*pañcindriya*).

and three kinds by way of bodily action (*kāyakamma*) etc."

"Full *kamma* (*kamma*) and half-*kamma* (*upaḍḍhakamme*)": here his theory is that bodily action (*kāyakamma*) and verbal action (*vacīkamma*) are full *kamma* (*kamma*) and mental action (*manokamma*) is half-*kamma* (*upaḍḍhakamme*).

"Sixty-two pathways" (*dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā*): he speaks of sixty-two pathways (*dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadā*).

"Sixty-two sub-aeons (*dvaṭṭhantarakappa*)": in a single great aeon (*kappa*) there are sixty-four sub-aeons (*antarakappa*).

but since he does not know about two of these, he says .

He declares that there are six classes of men (*abhijāti*): the black (*kaṇhābhijāti*), the blue (*nīlābhijāti*), the red (*lohitābhijāti*), the yellow (*haliddābhijāti*), the white (*sukkābhijāti*), and the ultimate white (*paramasukkābhijāti*).

The black class (*kaṇhābhijāti*) is made up of butchers (*orabbhika*), hunters (*sākuṇika*), trappers of wild beasts (*māgavika*), pork butchers (*sūkarika*), hunters (*ludda*), fishermen (*macchaghātaka*), thieves (*cora*), executioners (*coraghātaka*), prison wardens (*bandhanāgārika*), and those in other cruel lines of work (*kurūrakammanta*).
