mula_pali: 180. ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto maṃ etadavoca – ‘atthi paro lokoti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, atthi paro lokoti iti ce me assa, atthi paro lokoti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ. Evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me  no, no notipi me no. Natthi paro loko…pe… atthi ca natthi ca paro loko…pe… nevatthi na natthi paro loko…pe… atthi sattā opapātikā…pe… natthi sattā opapātikā…pe… atthi ca natthi ca sattā opapātikā…pe… nevatthi na natthi sattā opapātikā…pe… atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe…  natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe…atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe… nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko…pe… hoti tathāgato paraṃ  maraṇā…pe… na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā…pe… hoti  ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā…pe… neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti ce me assa, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ. Evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
mula_english:
180.
“When this was said, venerable sir, Sañjaya Belatthaputta said this to me: ‘If you ask me, “Is there another world ( *paro loko*)?”, if I thought there was another world, I would explain to you that there is another world.

I don’t say it is thus. I don’t say it is like that. I do not say it is otherwise. I do not say it is not so, nor do I say it is not not so.

There is no other world…and so on… there both is and is not another world…and so on… there neither is nor is not another world…and so on… there are beings who arise spontaneously ( *sattā opapātikā*)…and so on… there are no beings who arise spontaneously…and so on… there both are and are not beings who arise spontaneously…and so on… there neither are nor are not beings who arise spontaneously…and so on… there is fruit and result (*phalaṃ vipāko*) of good and bad actions (*sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ*)…and so on… there is no fruit and result of good and bad actions…and so on…there both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad actions…and so on… there neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad actions…and so on… the *Tathāgata* exists after death (*hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*)…and so on… the *Tathāgata* does not exist after death…and so on… the *Tathāgata* both exists and does not exist after death…and so on… the *Tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death, if you ask me, “The *Tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death,” if I thought so, I would explain to you that the *Tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death.’

I don’t say it is thus. I don’t say it is like that. I do not say it is otherwise. I do not say it is not so, nor do I say it is not not so.”
commentary_pali: 179-181. Sañcayavādo amarāvikkhepe vuttanayo eva.
commentary_english: The principle of *sañcayavāda* (accumulation argument) has been stated in the context of *amarāvikkhepa* (unfruitful discussion).

mula_pali: 181. ‘‘Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṃ byākāsi. Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya; evameva kho me, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṃ byākāsi. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘ayañca imesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sabbabālo sabbamūḷho. Kathañhi nāma sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṃ byākarissatī’ti. Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi – ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti. So kho ahaṃ, bhante, sañcayassa belaṭṭhaputtassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ. Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ  anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mula_english:
181. "Thus, venerable sir (bhante), when I asked Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta about the visible fruit of recluseship (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ), he answered evasively (vikkhepaṃ byākāsi).

Just as, venerable sir (bhante), if asked about a mango (ambaṃ), one would speak of a breadfruit (labujaṃ), or if asked about a breadfruit (labujaṃ), one would speak of a mango (ambaṃ); in the same way, venerable sir (bhante), when I asked Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta about the visible fruit of recluseship (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ), he answered evasively (vikkhepaṃ byākāsi).

Then, venerable sir (bhante), it occurred to me: 'This Saṃjaya is the most foolish and deluded of these ascetics and Brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sabbabālo sabbamūḷho).'

'How indeed, when asked about the visible fruit of recluseship (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ), could one answer evasively (vikkhepaṃ byākarissati)?'

Then, venerable sir (bhante), it occurred to me: 'How could one like myself think of disparaging an ascetic (samaṇaṃ) or a Brahmin (brāhmaṇaṃ) living in my territory (vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyya)?'

So, venerable sir (bhante), I neither rejoiced in nor rejected the statement of Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta (sañcayassa belaṭṭhaputtassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ).

Without rejoicing or rejecting it, displeased and without expressing my displeasure, without accepting his doctrine, without embracing it, I got up from my seat and left (anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ)."
commentary_pali: 179-181. Sañcayavādo amarāvikkhepe vuttanayo eva.
commentary_english: The same principle applies to the discussion of accumulation in the case of *amarāvikkhepa*.

mula_pali: 182. ‘‘Sohaṃ, bhante, bhagavantampi pucchāmi – ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bhante, puthusippāyatanāni seyyathidaṃ – hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā  celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālākārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṃgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti, te tena attānaṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ. Sakkā nu kho me , bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’nti?
mula_english:
“So, venerable sir, I ask the Exalted One: Just as there are these various crafts (*puthusippāyatanāni*), such as elephant trainers (*hatthārohā*), horse trainers (*assārohā*), charioteers (*rathikā*), archers (*dhanuggahā*), standard bearers (*celakā*), camp marshals (*calakā*), alms-food providers (*piṇḍadāyakā*), high-ranking officers (*uggā*), princes (*rājaputtā*), front-line soldiers (*pakkhandino*), great warriors (*mahānāgā*), heroes (*sūrā*), leather-armored warriors (*cammayodhino*), sons of slave women (*dāsikaputtā*), confectioners (*āḷārikā*), barbers (*kappakā*), bath attendants (*nhāpakā*), cooks (*sūdā*), garland-makers (*mālākārā*), laundrymen (*rajakā*), weavers (*pesakārā*), basket-makers (*naḷakārā*), potters (*kumbhakārā*), statisticians (*gaṇakā*), accountants (*muddikā*), and whatever other various crafts there are, they live enjoying here and now the visible fruits of their skills (*diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti*); through that, they gladden and gratify themselves, they gladden and gratify their parents, they gladden and gratify their children and spouses, they gladden and gratify their friends and associates, they establish an uplifting offering to ascetics and brahmins, which leads to heaven, resulting in happiness, conducive to heaven.

Is it possible for me, venerable sir, to describe a visible fruit of the life of a recluse (*sāmaññaphalaṃ*) here and now (*diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ*) in the same way?"
commentary_pali: 182.Sohaṃ, bhanteti so ahaṃ bhante, vālukaṃ pīḷetvā telaṃ alabhamāno viya titthiyavādesu sāraṃ alabhanto bhagavantaṃ pucchāmīti attho.
commentary_english: So, O venerable one, just as one who, pressing sand (vālukaṃ pīḷetvā), does not obtain oil (telaṃ alabhamāno), similarly, not finding essence (sāraṃ alabhanto) in the doctrines of the heretics (titthiyavādesu), I ask the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ pucchāmi). This is the meaning (attho).

mula_pali: 183. ‘‘Sakkā, mahārāja. Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te  khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi. Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, idha te assa puriso dāso kammakāro kammakaro (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako mukhullokiko (syā. kaṃ. ka.). Tassa evamassa – ‘acchariyaṃ, vata bho, abbhutaṃ, vata bho, puññānaṃ gati, puññānaṃ vipāko. Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso ; ahampi manusso. Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe. Ahaṃ panamhissa dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako. So vatassāhaṃ puññāni kareyyaṃ. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya’nti. So aparena samayena kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya. So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṃvuto vihareyya, manasā saṃvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke. Taṃ ce te purisā evamāroceyyuṃ – ‘yagghe deva jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso yo te puriso (sī. ka.) dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako; so, deva, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito. So evaṃ pabbajito  samāno kāyena saṃvuto viharati, vācāya saṃvuto viharati, manasā saṃvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti. Api nu tvaṃ evaṃ vadeyyāsi – ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako’ti?
mula_english:
183.
"I can, Your Majesty."
Well then, great king, I will question you about this same matter.
Answer as you see fit.
What do you think, great king? Suppose you have a man who is a slave, a worker...
... rising before you, retiring after you, doing whatever you want, acting always for your pleasure, speaking politely to you, and is ever on the lookout to see that you are satisfied.
He might think: “It is wonderful and marvellous, the destiny and result of meritorious deeds! (puññānaṃ vipāko.)
This King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha is a man, and I too am a man.
Yet King Ajātasattu Vedehiputta of Magadha enjoys himself fully endowed and supplied with the five strands of sense pleasure as if he were a god, I think.
While I am his slave, his workman— rising before him, retiring after him, doing whatever he wants, acting always for his pleasure, speaking politely to him, ever on the lookout to see that he is satisfied.
I ought to do something meritorious. (puññāni kareyyaṃ.)
What if I were to shave off my hair & beard, put on the ochre robes, and go forth from the household life into homelessness?’
After some time he shaves off his hair and beard, puts on saffron robes, and goes forth from home to homelessness.
And he, having thus gone forth might dwell, restrained in body, speech and thought, satisfied with the minimum of food and clothing, content, in solitude.
And if people were to tell you this: “Sire, you remember that slave who worked in your presence...
... and who shaved off his hair and beard and went forth into homelessness?
He is living restrained in body, speech and thought, ... in solitude” —
Would you say: ‘Bring that man back to me, men. Let him again become my slave, my workman, rising before me, retiring after me, doing whatever I want, acting always for my pleasure, speaking politely to me, ever on the lookout to see that he is satisfied.’?”
commentary_pali: 183.Yathā te khameyyāti yathā te rucceyya. Dāsoti antojātadhanakkītakaramarānītasāmaṃdāsabyopagatānaṃ aññataro. Kammakāroti analaso kammakaraṇasīloyeva. Dūrato disvā paṭhamameva uṭṭhahatīti pubbuṭṭhāyī. Evaṃ uṭṭhito sāmino āsanaṃ paññapetvā pādadhovanādikattabbakiccaṃ katvā pacchā nipatati nisīdatīti pacchānipātī. Sāmikamhi vā sayanato avuṭṭhite pubbeyeva vuṭṭhātīti pubbuṭṭhāyī. Paccūsakālato paṭṭhāya yāva sāmino rattiṃ niddokkamanaṃ, tāva sabbakiccāni katvā pacchā nipatati, seyyaṃ kappetīti pacchānipātī. Kiṃ karomi, kiṃ karomīti evaṃ kiṃkārameva paṭisuṇanto vicaratīti kiṃ kārapaṭissāvī. Manāpameva kiriyaṃ karotīti manāpacārī. Piyameva vadatīti piyavādī. Sāmino tuṭṭhapahaṭṭhaṃ mukhaṃ ullokayamāno vicaratīti mukhullokako. Devo maññeti devo viya. Sovatassāhaṃ puññāni kareyyanti so vata ahaṃ evarūpo assaṃ, yadi puññāni kareyyanti attho. ‘‘So vatassa’ssa’’ntipi pāṭho, ayamevattho. Yaṃnūnāhanti sace dānaṃ dassāmi, yaṃ rājā ekadivasaṃ deti, tato satabhāgampi yāvajīvaṃ na sakkhissāmi dātunti pabbajjāyaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā evaṃ cintanabhāvaṃ dasseti. Kāyena saṃvutoti kāyena pihito hutvā akusalassa pavesanadvāraṃ thaketvāti attho. Eseva nayo sesapadadvayepi. Ghāsacchādanaparamatāyāti ghāsacchādanena paramatāya uttamatāya, etadatthampi anesanaṃ pahāya aggasallekhena santuṭṭhoti attho. Abhirato paviveketi ‘‘kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ, cittaviveko ca nekkhammābhiratānaṃ, paramavodānappattānaṃ upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ visaṅkhāragatāna’’nti evaṃ vutte tividhepi viveke rato; gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ  pahāya kāyena eko viharati, cittakilesasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya aṭṭhasamāpattivasena eko viharati, phalasamāpattiṃ vā nirodhasamāpattiṃ vā pavisitvā nibbānaṃ patvā viharatīti attho. Yaggheti codanatthe nipāto.
commentary_english:
183.

*   *Yathā te khameyyāti yathā te rucceyya*: "As may be pleasing to you," means "as may be agreeable to you."

*   *Dāsoti antojātadhanakkītakaramarānītasāmaṃdāsabyopagatānaṃ aññataro*: A *dāsa* (slave) is one who is born in the house, is bought with wealth, is enslaved by deed, is brought as a captive, is a slave by choice, or is one of others who have come under such conditions.

*   *Kammakāroti analaso kammakaraṇasīloyeva*: A *kammakāra* (worker) is one who is not lazy and whose nature is to work.

*   *Dūrato disvā paṭhamameva uṭṭhahatīti pubbuṭṭhāyī*: One who sees from afar and rises up first is called a *pubbuṭṭhāyī* (early riser).

*   *Evaṃ uṭṭhito sāmino āsanaṃ paññapetvā pādadhovanādikattabbakiccaṃ katvā pacchā nipatati nisīdatīti pacchānipātī*: Having risen thus, preparing a seat for his master, performing the duties of washing the feet and so on, afterward he lies down or sits; therefore, he is a *pacchānipātī* (one who retires late).

*   *Sāmikamhi vā sayanato avuṭṭhite pubbeyeva vuṭṭhātīti pubbuṭṭhāyī*: Or, one who rises even before the master has risen from his bed is a *pubbuṭṭhāyī* (early riser).

*   *Paccūsakālato paṭṭhāya yāva sāmino rattiṃ niddokkamanaṃ, tāva sabbakiccāni katvā pacchā nipatati, seyyaṃ kappetīti pacchānipātī*: From the time of dawn, until the master's sleep at night, having done all the work, afterward he lies down, preparing the bed; therefore, he is a *pacchānipātī* (one who retires late).

*   *Kiṃ karomi, kiṃ karomīti evaṃ kiṃkārameva paṭisuṇanto vicaratīti kiṃ kārapaṭissāvī*: "What shall I do, what shall I do?" Thus, he wanders around, responding only "What is to be done?"; therefore, he is a *kiṃ kārapaṭissāvī* (one who asks what to do).

*   *Manāpameva kiriyaṃ karotīti manāpacārī*: He does only what is pleasing; therefore, he is a *manāpacārī* (one who acts agreeably).

*   *Piyameva vadatīti piyavādī*: He speaks only what is dear; therefore, he is a *piyavādī* (one who speaks affectionately).

*   *Sāmino tuṭṭhapahaṭṭhaṃ mukhaṃ ullokayamāno vicaratīti mukhullokako*: He wanders around, looking up at the master's delighted and pleased face; therefore, he is a *mukhullokako* (one who watches the face).

*   *Devo maññeti devo viya*: He thinks, "He is like a god."

*   *Sovatassāhaṃ puññāni kareyyanti so vata ahaṃ evarūpo assaṃ, yadi puññāni kareyyanti attho*: "May I also perform meritorious deeds, so that I may be of such a form, if I should perform meritorious deeds." This is the meaning.

*   *"So vatassa'ssa'ntipi pāṭho, ayamevattho*: "So vatassa'ssa" is also a reading, and this is the meaning.

*   *Yaṃnūnāhanti sace dānaṃ dassāmi, yaṃ rājā ekadivasaṃ deti, tato satabhāgampi yāvajīvaṃ na sakkhissāmi dātunti pabbajjāyaṃ ussāhaṃ katvā evaṃ cintanabhāvaṃ dasseti*: "Let me then shave off my hair and beard. If I were to practice giving, in my whole life I would not be able to give even a hundredth part of what the king gives in a single day." He shows the thought behind the eagerness to go forth to be as follows:.

*   *Kāyena saṃvutoti kāyena pihito hutvā akusalassa pavesanadvāraṃ thaketvāti attho*: "Guarded in body" means that having closed off the door of entry for unwholesome (*akuśala*) actions by being restrained in body, this is the meaning.

*   *Eseva nayo sesapadadvayepi*: The same method applies in the other two remaining cases.

*   *Ghāsacchādanaparamatāyāti ghāsacchādanena paramatāya uttamatāya, etadatthampi anesanaṃ pahāya aggasallekhena santuṭṭhoti attho*: “Content with the simplest food and shelter” means content through the highest effacement (*aggasallekha*), through the excellence of the simplest food and shelter, abandoning improper ways of seeking even for this purpose. This is the meaning.

*   *Abhirato paviveketi ‘‘kāyaviveko ca vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ, cittaviveko ca nekkhammābhiratānaṃ, paramavodānappattānaṃ upadhiviveko ca nirupadhīnaṃ puggalānaṃ visaṅkhāragatāna’’nti evaṃ vutte tividhepi viveke rato; gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ  pahāya kāyena eko viharati, cittakilesasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya aṭṭhasamāpattivasena eko viharati, phalasamāpattiṃ vā nirodhasamāpattiṃ vā pavisitvā nibbānaṃ patvā viharatīti attho*: Delighting in solitude. He delights in the three kinds of solitude stated thus: “There is bodily solitude (*kāyaviveka*) for those dwelling in physical solitude; there is mental solitude (*cittaviveka*) for those delighting in renunciation (*naikṣammya*), for those who attain to the highest cleansing (*paramavodāna*); and there is ultimate solitude (*upadhiviveka*) for those persons free from the acquisitions (*nirupadhi*), for those who have gone beyond formations (*visaṅkhāragata*)”. One person dwells alone in body, having abandoned the company of a group. One dwells alone by way of the eight meditative attainments, having abandoned the company of mental defilements (*cittakileśa*). Or, having entered the fruition attainment (*phalasamāpatti*) or the cessation attainment (*nirodhasamāpatti*), he dwells having attained nirvāṇa. This is the meaning.

*   *Yaggheti codanatthe nipāto*: *Yagghe* is a particle in the sense of urging.

mula_pali: 184. ‘‘No hetaṃ, bhante. Atha  kho naṃ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi , paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma, abhinimanteyyāmapi naṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi, dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidaheyyāmā’’ti.
mula_english:
Certainly not, venerable sir.
Furthermore, we would pay homage to him, rise in his presence, invite him to sit on a seat, and request that he accept robes (cīvara), alms-food (piṇḍapāta), lodging (senāsana), medicine for the sick (gilānappaccaya-bhesajja), and other requisites. And we would arrange righteous (dhammika) protection, defense, and security for him.
commentary_pali: 184.Āsanenapinimanteyyāmāti nisinnāsanaṃ papphoṭetvā idha nisīdathāti vadeyyāma. Abhinimanteyyāmapi nanti abhiharitvāpi naṃ nimanteyyāma. Tattha duvidho abhihāro – vācāya ceva kāyena ca. Tumhākaṃ icchiticchitakkhaṇe amhākaṃ cīvarādīhi vadeyyātha yenatthoti vadanto hi vācāya abhiharitvā nimanteti nāma. Cīvarādivekallaṃ sallakkhetvā idaṃ gaṇhāthāti tāni dento pana kāyena abhiharitvā nimanteti nāma. Tadubhayampi sandhāya abhinimanteyyāmapi  nanti āha. Ettha ca gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāroti yaṃ kiñci gilānassa sappāyaṃ osadhaṃ. Vacanattho pana visuddhimagge vutto. Rakkhāvaraṇaguttinti rakkhāsaṅkhātañceva āvaraṇasaṅkhātañca guttiṃ. Sā panesā na āvudhahatthe purise ṭhapentena dhammikā nāma saṃvidahitā hoti. Yathā pana avelāya kaṭṭhahārikapaṇṇahārikādayo vihāraṃ na pavisanti, migaluddakādayo vihārasīmāya mige vā macche vā na gaṇhanti, evaṃ saṃvidahantena dhammikā nāma rakkhā saṃvihitā hoti, taṃ sandhāyāha – ‘‘dhammika’’nti.
commentary_english:
184. Thinking, "Let us invite them with a seat," having clapped the prepared seat, we would say, "Please, sit here."

Even after directly inviting them, they do not; even after bringing [seats], we would invite them.

There are two kinds of bringing ( *abhihāro* ): by speech ( *vācāya* ) and by body ( *kāyena* ).

At the moment you desire something, saying with robes etc. of ours, "Speak so that there is purpose," thus speaking, indeed, by speech, having brought [offerings], he invites, it is said.

Having considered the suitability of robes etc., giving those, saying, "Take this," indeed, by body, having brought [offerings], he invites, it is said.

Having considered both of those, even directly inviting, he does not, [it] is said.

Here, "requisites for medicine for the sick" means whatever is suitable as medicine for the sick.

But the meaning of the word ( *vacanattho* ) has been stated in the Path of Purification ( *Visuddhimagga* ).

"Protection ( *rakkhā* ), screen ( *āvaraṇa* ), and guard ( *gutti* )" means both that which is reckoned as protection and that which is reckoned as screen and guard.

But that protection, named "righteous" (*dhāmmikā*), is arranged by one who prevents men from holding weapons in their hands.

Just as, at the wrong time, those who bring firewood and leaves etc. do not enter the monastery ( *vihāraṃ* ), and hunters etc. do not catch deer or fish within the boundary of the monastery, so, by arranging [things] in this way, a protection named "righteous" is arranged. Considering that, he said, “Righteous” (*dhammikā*).

mula_pali: 185. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadi evaṃ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ no vā’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphala’’nti. ‘‘Idaṃ kho te, mahārāja, mayā paṭhamaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññatta’’nti.
mula_english:
“What do you think, great king? If such is the case, is there or is there not a visible fruit of recluseship ( *sāmaññaphala*)?”

“Indeed, venerable sir, if such is the case, there is a visible fruit of recluseship ( *sāmaññaphala*).”

“This, great king, is the first fruit of recluseship ( *sāmaññaphala*), visible here and now, that I point out to you.”
commentary_pali: 185.Yadi evaṃ santeti yadi tava dāso tuyhaṃ santikā abhivādanādīni labheyya. Evaṃ sante. Addhāti ekaṃsavacanametaṃ. Paṭhamanti bhaṇanto aññassāpi atthitaṃ dīpeti. Teneva ca rājā sakkā pana, bhante, aññampītiādimāha.
commentary_english:
185.
"If this is so," means, if your slave (dāsa) should obtain respectful greetings (abhivādanādīni) from your presence (santika).
When this is so.
"Certainly," this is a statement of certainty (ekaṃsavacanametaṃ).
Speaking, they proclaim the existence of another also.
And with that the king (rājā) was able to, O venerable one (bhante), say "something else, etc." (aññampītiādimāha).

mula_pali: 186. ‘‘Sakkā  pana, bhante, aññampi evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetu’’nti? ‘‘Sakkā, mahārāja. Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi. Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako. Tassa evamassa – ‘acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, puññānaṃ gati, puññānaṃ vipāko. Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso. Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe. Ahaṃ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako. So vatassāhaṃ puññāni kareyyaṃ. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya’nti. ‘‘So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ  vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya, appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā  anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya. So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṃvuto vihareyya, manasā saṃvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke. Taṃ ce te purisā evamāroceyyuṃ – ‘yagghe, deva jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso yo te puriso (sī.) kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako; so deva kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito. So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto viharati, vācāya saṃvuto viharati, manasā saṃvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya  santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’’ti. Api nu tvaṃ evaṃ vadeyyāsi – ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako’ti?
mula_english:
186.
"Is it possible, venerable sir, to point out any other fruit of recluseship visible here and now, a fruit visible in this very life ( *sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*)?"

"It is possible, great king.

Well then, great king, I will question you about this very matter.

Answer as you think fit.

What do you think, great king? Suppose there is a man in your service, a farmer ( *kassako*), a householder ( *gahapatiko*), a tax-collector (*karakārako*), one who increases the royal revenue (*rāsivaḍḍhako*).

The thought might occur to him: “It is wonderful, it is marvelous, the destiny ( *gati*) and result (*vipāko*) of meritorious deeds ( *puññānaṃ*)!

This King Ajātaśattu, son of Vedehi, of Magadha is a man, and I too am a man.

Yet King Ajātaśattu, son of Vedehi, of Magadha enjoys himself fully endowed and supplied with the five strands of sense pleasure as if he were a god, I think.

While I am a farmer ( *kassako*), a householder ( *gahapatiko*), a tax-collector (*karakārako*), one who increases the royal revenue (*rāsivaḍḍhako*).

I ought to do something meritorious (*puññāni kareyyaṃ*).

Suppose I were to shave off my hair & beard, put on the ochre robes (*kāsāyāni vatthāni*), and go forth from the household life into homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya*)’ti.

“After some time, he abandons his accumulation of wealth, be it large or small, abandons his circle of relatives, be it large or small; he shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the ochre robes (*kāsāyāni vatthāni*), and goes forth from home to homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya*).

And he, having thus gone forth might dwell restrained in body ( *kāyena saṃvuto*), speech ( *vācāya saṃvuto*), and thought ( *manasā saṃvuto*), satisfied with the barest necessities of food and clothing ( *ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho*), delighting in solitude ( *abhirato paviveke*).

And if people were to tell you this: ‘Sire, you should know that the man who was in your service,

the farmer ( *kassako*), householder ( *gahapatiko*), tax-collector (*karakārako*), one who increases the royal revenue (*rāsivaḍḍhako*), that man, sire, has shaved off his hair and beard, put on the ochre robes (*kāsāyāni vatthāni*), and gone forth from home into homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito*).

He is living restrained in body ( *kāyena saṃvuto*), speech ( *vācāya saṃvuto*) and thought ( *manasā saṃvuto*), satisfied with the barest necessities of food and clothing ( *ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho*), delighting in solitude (*abhirato paviveke*)’—

would you then say: ‘Let that man come back to me, men, let him again become a farmer ( *kassako*), a householder ( *gahapatiko*), a tax-collector (*karakārako*), one who increases the royal revenue (*rāsivaḍḍhako*)’?”
commentary_pali: 186-188. Kasatīti kassako. Gehassa pati, ekagehamatte jeṭṭhakoti gahapatiko. Balisaṅkhātaṃ karaṃ karotīti karakārako. Dhaññarāsiṃ dhanarāsiñca vaḍḍhetīti rāsivaḍḍhako. Appaṃvāti parittakaṃ vā antamaso taṇḍulanāḷimattakampi. Bhogakkhandhanti bhogarāsiṃ. Mahantaṃ vāti vipulaṃ vā. Yathā hi mahantaṃ pahāya pabbajituṃ dukkaraṃ, evaṃ appampīti dassanatthaṃ ubhayamāha. Dāsavāre pana yasmā dāso attanopi anissaro, pageva bhogānaṃ. Yañhi tassa dhanaṃ, taṃ sāmikānaññeva hoti, tasmā bhogaggahaṇaṃ na kataṃ. Ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo.
commentary_english:
186-188.
Because he ploughs, he is a farmer (*kassaka*).
The master of a house, a *gahapati* is one who owns one house, or a *jeṭṭhakoti*.
Because he makes an offering after calculating tribute, he is a tax collector (*karakāraka*).
Because he increases a heap of grain and a heap of wealth, he is an increaser of heaps (*rāsivaḍḍhaka*).
A little is called insignificant (*parittaka*), even if it is as little as a measure of rice grains (*taṇḍulanāḷimattaka*).
They pile up a heap of enjoyments; therefore, it is a heap of enjoyments (*bhogarāsi*).
It is great or abundant (*vipula*).
Just as it is difficult to renounce the great, so even a little [is difficult]; in order to show this, he said both.
In the case of a slave (*dāsa*), since a slave is not his own master, how much less so of enjoyments (*bhogānaṃ*)?
Since his wealth (*dhana*) belongs only to the owners, therefore the taking of enjoyment is not done.
A relative (*ñāti*) is indeed a circle of relatives (*ñātiparivaṭṭa*).

mula_pali: 187. ‘‘No hetaṃ, bhante. Atha kho naṃ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi, paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma, abhinimanteyyāmapi naṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi, dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidaheyyāmā’’ti.
mula_english:
"No, venerable sir."

Rather, we would pay homage to him, rise up out of respect for him, invite him to a seat, and invite him to accept from us robes (cīvara), almsfood (piṇḍapāta), dwelling (senāsana), and medicinal requirements for the sick (gilānappaccayabhesajja). And we would provide him with righteous protection, defense, and security.
commentary_pali: 186-188. Kasatīti kassako. Gehassa pati, ekagehamatte jeṭṭhakoti gahapatiko. Balisaṅkhātaṃ karaṃ karotīti karakārako. Dhaññarāsiṃ dhanarāsiñca vaḍḍhetīti rāsivaḍḍhako. Appaṃvāti parittakaṃ vā antamaso taṇḍulanāḷimattakampi. Bhogakkhandhanti bhogarāsiṃ. Mahantaṃ vāti vipulaṃ vā. Yathā hi mahantaṃ pahāya pabbajituṃ dukkaraṃ, evaṃ appampīti dassanatthaṃ ubhayamāha. Dāsavāre pana yasmā dāso attanopi anissaro, pageva bhogānaṃ. Yañhi tassa dhanaṃ, taṃ sāmikānaññeva hoti, tasmā bhogaggahaṇaṃ na kataṃ. Ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo.
commentary_english:
186-188.
Because he cultivates, therefore he is a farmer (*kassako*).
The master of the house, a householder (*gahapatiko*) with a chief's estate in one house.
Because he makes a tax (*kara*) which is fixed as tribute (*bali*), therefore he is a tax-maker (*karakārako*).
Because he increases a heap of grain (*dhaññarāsi*) and a heap of wealth (*dhanarāsi*), therefore he is a heap-increaser (*rāsivaḍḍhako*).
Even a little, or a small amount, or even as little as a *taṇḍulanāḷimattaka* (a measure) of rice.
They heap up a mass of possessions (*bhogarāsiṃ*).
It is great or vast.
Just as it is difficult to renounce something great and go forth [into homelessness], so too [is it difficult to renounce] even a little; he speaks of both to illustrate this.
In the case of a slave, since a slave is not master of even himself, how much less of his possessions (*bhogānaṃ*)?
For that wealth (*dhanaṃ*) belongs to the owners themselves; therefore, there is no taking of possessions (*bhogaggahaṇaṃ*).
It is just relatives, a circle of relatives (*ñātiparivaṭṭo*).

mula_pali: 188. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja? Yadi evaṃ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ no vā’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphala’’nti . ‘‘Idaṃ kho te, mahārāja, mayā dutiyaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññatta’’nti.
mula_english:
“What do you think, great king (mahārāja)? If such is the case, is there or is there not a visible fruit (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ) of the ascetic life?” “Indeed, venerable sir (bhante), if such is the case, there is a visible fruit (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ) of the ascetic life.”

“This, great king (mahārāja), is the second visible fruit (sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ), that I have described, in this very life (diṭṭheva dhamme).”
commentary_pali: 186-188. Kasatīti kassako. Gehassa pati, ekagehamatte jeṭṭhakoti gahapatiko. Balisaṅkhātaṃ karaṃ karotīti karakārako. Dhaññarāsiṃ dhanarāsiñca vaḍḍhetīti rāsivaḍḍhako. Appaṃvāti parittakaṃ vā antamaso taṇḍulanāḷimattakampi. Bhogakkhandhanti bhogarāsiṃ. Mahantaṃ vāti vipulaṃ vā. Yathā hi mahantaṃ pahāya pabbajituṃ dukkaraṃ, evaṃ appampīti dassanatthaṃ ubhayamāha. Dāsavāre pana yasmā dāso attanopi anissaro, pageva bhogānaṃ. Yañhi tassa dhanaṃ, taṃ sāmikānaññeva hoti, tasmā bhogaggahaṇaṃ na kataṃ. Ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo.
commentary_english:
186-188. Because one plows, therefore one is a farmer (*kassako*).

The master of the house, a leading one in one house, is a householder (*gahapatiko*).

Because one makes a tax that is known as an offering (*bali*), therefore one is a tax-maker (*karakārako*).

Because one increases a heap of grain and a heap of wealth (*dhana*), therefore one is a heap-increaser (*rāsivaḍḍhako*).

Even a little, a small amount, or even just a handful of rice.

They amass a heap of enjoyment; that is a heap of enjoyment (*bhogarāsiṃ*).

Whether it is great, vast, or extensive.

Just as it is difficult to renounce the great, so too [it is difficult to renounce] the small; thus, to show this, he said both.

In the case of a slave, however, because a slave is not his own master, how much less so of enjoyments (*bhogānaṃ*)!

Because whatever wealth (*dhanaṃ*) he has belongs to his master, therefore, taking enjoyment is not done.

A relative, indeed, is a change of relatives.

mula_pali: 189. ‘‘Sakkā  pana, bhante, aññampi diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetuṃ imehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañcā’’ti? ‘‘Sakkā, mahārāja. Tena hi, mahārāja, suṇohi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bhante’’ti kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato paccassosi.
mula_english:
“But, venerable sir, is it possible to point out another fruit of the monastic life, visible here and now (dṛṣṭe eva dharme sandṛṣṭikaṃ *sāmaññaphalaṃ*), more excellent and sublime than these visible fruits of the monastic life?” “It is possible, great king."

"Then, great king, listen and carefully pay attention, and I will speak."

“Yes, venerable sir,” replied King Ajātaśatru (Ajātaśattu), son of Videha, the king of Magadha, to the Blessed One (bhagavato).
commentary_pali: 189.Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi diṭṭheva dhammeti idha evamevāti na vuttaṃ. Taṃ kasmāti  ce, evamevāti hi vuccamāne pahoti bhagavā sakalampi rattindivaṃ tato vā bhiyyopi evarūpāhi upamāhi sāmaññaphalaṃ dīpetuṃ. Tattha kiñcāpi etassa bhagavato vacanasavane pariyantaṃ nāma natthi, tathāpi attho tādisoyeva bhavissatīti cintetvā  upari visesaṃ pucchanto evamevāti avatvā – ‘‘abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañcā’’ti āha. Tattha abhikkantataranti abhimanāpataraṃ atiseṭṭhataranti attho. Paṇītataranti uttamataraṃ. Tena hīti uyyojanatthe nipāto. Savane uyyojento hi naṃ evamāha. Suṇohīti abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca sāmaññaphalaṃ suṇāti. Sādhukaṃ manasikarohīti ettha pana sādhukaṃ sādhūti ekatthametaṃ. Ayañhi sādhu-saddo āyācanasampaṭicchanasampahaṃsanasundara daḷhīkammādīsu dissati. ‘‘Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetū’’tiādīsu (saṃ. ni. 4.95) hi āyācane dissati. ‘‘Sādhu, bhanteti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 3.86) sampaṭicchane. ‘‘Sādhu sādhu, sāriputtā’’tiādīsu (dī. ni. 3.349) sampahaṃsane. Ādīsu sundare. ‘‘Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇohi sādhukaṃ manasi karohī’’tiādīsu (a. ni. 5.192) sādhukasaddoyeva daḷhīkamme, āṇattiyantipi vuccati . Idhāpi assa ettheva daḷhīkamme ca āṇattiyañca veditabbo. Sundarepi vaṭṭati. Daḷhīkammatthena hi daḷhamimaṃ dhammaṃ suṇāhi, suggahitaṃ gaṇhanto. Āṇattiatthena mama āṇattiyā suṇāhi, sundaratthena sundaramimaṃ bhaddakaṃ dhammaṃ suṇāhīti evaṃ dīpitaṃ hoti. Manasi karohīti āvajja, samannāharāti attho, avikkhittacitto hutvā nisāmehi, citte karohīti adhippāyo. Api cettha suṇohīti sotindriyavikkhepanivāraṇametaṃ. Sādhukaṃ manasi karohīti manasikāre daḷhīkammaniyojanena manindriyavikkhepanivāraṇaṃ. Purimañcettha byañjanavipallāsaggāhavāraṇaṃ, pacchimaṃ atthavipallāsaggāhavāraṇaṃ. Purimena ca dhammassavane niyojeti, pacchimena sutānaṃ dhammānaṃ dhāraṇūpaparikkhādīsu. Purimena ca sabyañjano ayaṃ dhammo, tasmā savanīyoti dīpeti . Pacchimena sattho, tasmā sādhukaṃ manasi kātabboti. Sādhukapadaṃ  vā ubhayapadehi yojetvā yasmā ayaṃ dhammo dhammagambhīro ceva desanāgambhīro ca, tasmā suṇāhi sādhukaṃ, yasmā atthagambhīro ca paṭivedhagambhīro ca, tasmā sādhukaṃ manasi karohīti evaṃ yojanā veditabbā. Bhāsissāmīti sakkā mahārājāti evaṃ paṭiññātaṃ sāmaññaphaladesanaṃ vitthārato bhāsissāmi. ‘‘Desessāmī’’ti hi saṅkhittadīpanaṃ hoti. Bhāsissāmīti vitthāradīpanaṃ. Tenāha vaṅgīsatthero – Evaṃ vutte ussāhajāto hutvā – ‘‘evaṃ, bhante’’ti kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato paccassosi bhagavato vacanaṃ sampaṭicchi, paṭiggahesīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
189.
But, venerable sir, it is not said here that another fruit of the homeless life is possible in this very life in just this way.

And why is that? Because, if it were said, “It is just like this,” the Blessed One could spend the entire day and night, or even longer, revealing the fruits of the homeless life with such comparisons.

There, although there is no limit to the Blessed One's words, thinking that the meaning would be just the same, when asked for a further distinction, instead of saying "It is just like this," he said, "More excellent and more sublime."

There, "more excellent" means more pleasing and supremely superior.

"More sublime" means more excellent.

"Tena hi" is a particle in the sense of urging.

Because he is urging to listen, he says this.

"Listen" means he hears the more excellent and more sublime fruit of the homeless life.

Here, "sādhukaṃ manasikarohi" means that "sādhukaṃ" and "sādhu" have the same meaning.

Indeed, this word "sādhu" is seen in the senses of requesting, acknowledging, delighting, excellence, strengthening, etc.

In contexts such as " ‘Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetū’tiādīsu (Saṃ. Ni. 4. 95)," it is seen in the sense of requesting.

In contexts such as " ‘Sādhu, bhanteti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā’tiādīsu (Ma. Ni. 3. 86)," it is in the sense of acknowledgement.

In contexts such as "‘Sādhu sādhu, sāriputtā’tiādīsu (Dī. Ni. 3. 349)," it is in the sense of delighting.

It is in the sense of excellence in contexts such as these.

In contexts such as "‘Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇohi sādhukaṃ manasi karohī’tiādīsu (A. Ni. 5. 192)," the word "sādhuka" is used for strengthening, and it is also said to be an instruction.

Here also, it should be understood in the sense of strengthening and instruction.

It also applies to excellence.

By "strengthening," it means, "Listen to this Dhamma firmly, taking it up well."

By "instruction," it means, "Listen by my instruction." By "excellence," it means, "Listen to this excellent and auspicious Dhamma." Thus it is shown.

"Manasi karohi" means "attend," the meaning is to bring together, listen without a distracted mind, the intention is to put it in your mind.

Moreover, "suṇohi" here is to prevent distraction of the ear faculty.

"Sādhukaṃ manasi karohi" is to prevent distraction of the mind faculty by applying strengthening attention.

The former here is the prevention of a distorted grasp of the phrasing, the latter is the prevention of a distorted grasp of the meaning.

By the former, he enjoins one to listen to the Dharma; by the latter, to retention in mind, examination, etc., of the Dharmas that have been heard.

By the former, it is shown that this Dharma possesses phrasing; therefore, it should be heard.

By the latter, it is shown that it possesses meaning; therefore, it should be carefully attended to.

Or, connecting the word sādhukaṃ with both phrases, since this Dharma is deep in doctrine (dhammagambhīro) and deep in teaching (desanāgambhīro), therefore, listen carefully (suṇāhi sādhukaṃ); since it is deep in meaning (atthagambhīro) and deep in penetration (paṭivedhagambhīro), therefore, attend to it carefully (manasi karohi sādhukaṃ). Thus, the connection should be understood.
I shall expound that path of purification, thus the great king has promised: "I shall extensively explain the teaching on the fruits of the ascetic life ( *sāmaññaphaladesanaṃ*)."

"I shall teach" implies a concise explanation.

"I shall expound" implies an extensive explanation.

Therefore, Vaṅgīsa Thera said: When this was said, having become full of enthusiasm, King Ajātasattu, the Māgadha, the son of Vedehi, replied to the Blessed One, "So it is, venerable sir," he accepted the word of the Blessed One, he received it; thus it is said.

mula_pali: 190. Bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘idha, mahārāja, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā. So imaṃ  lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mula_english:
190. The Blessed One said this: "Here, O great king, a *Tathāgata* arises in the world, a worthy one (*arahaṃ*), a fully enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a Well-Farer (*sugato*), a Knower of the Worlds (*lokavidū*), an unsurpassed Trainer of those who can be tamed (*anuttaro purisadammasārathi*), a Teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), an enlightened and blessed being (*buddho bhagavā*).

Having directly known and realized this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its *Māras* (*samārakaṃ*), and its *Brahmās* (*sabrahmakaṃ*), this generation with its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ*), its princes and people (*sadevamanussaṃ*), he makes it known.

He teaches the *Dharma*, which is good in the beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), and good in the end (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*), with its meaning (*sātthaṃ*) and with its phrasing (*sabyañjanaṃ*). He reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaṃ*) which is perfectly complete (*kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ*) and purified (*parisuddhaṃ*)."
commentary_pali: 190. Athassa bhagavā etadavoca, etaṃ avoca, idāni vattabbaṃ ‘‘idha mahārājā’’tiādiṃ sakalaṃ suttaṃ avocāti attho. Tattha idhāti desāpadese nipāto, svāyaṃ katthaci lokaṃ upādāya vuccati. Yathāha – ‘‘idha tathāgato loke uppajjatī’’ti. Katthaci sāsanaṃ yathāha  – ‘‘idheva, bhikkhave, paṭhamo samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo’’ti (a. ni. 4.241). Katthaci okāsaṃ. Yathāha – Katthaci padapūraṇamattameva. Yathāha ‘‘idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhuttāvī assaṃ pavārito’’ti (ma. ni. 1.30). Idha pana lokaṃ upādāya vuttoti veditabbo. Mahārājāti yathā paṭiññātaṃ desanaṃ desetuṃ puna mahārājāti ālapati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ‘‘mahārāja imasmiṃ loke  tathāgato uppajjati arahaṃ…pe… buddho bhagavā’’ti. Tattha tathāgatasaddo brahmajāle vutto. Arahantiādayo visuddhimagge vitthāritā. Loke uppajjatīti ettha pana lokoti – okāsaloko sattaloko saṅkhāralokoti tividho. Idha pana sattaloko adhippeto. Sattaloke uppajjamānopi ca tathāgato na devaloke, na brahmaloke, manussalokeva uppajjati. Manussalokepi na aññasmiṃ cakkavāḷe, imasmiṃyeva cakkavāḷe. Tatrāpi na sabbaṭṭhānesu, ‘‘puratthimāya disāya gajaṅgalaṃ nāma nigamo tassāparena mahāsālo, tato parā paccantimā janapadā  orato majjhe, puratthimadakkhiṇāya disāya salaḷavatī nāma nadī. Tato parā paccantimā janapadā, orato majjhe, dakkhiṇāya disāya setakaṇṇikaṃ nāma nigamo, tato parā paccantimā janapadā, orato majjhe, pacchimāya disāya thūṇaṃ nāma brāhmaṇagāmo, tato parā paccantimā janapadā, orato majjhe, uttarāya disāya usiraddhajo nāma pabbato, tato parā paccantimā janapadā orato majjhe’’ti evaṃ paricchinne āyāmato tiyojanasate, vitthārato aḍḍhateyyayojanasate, parikkhepato navayojanasate majjhimapadese uppajjati. Na kevalañca tathāgato, paccekabuddhā, aggasāvakā, asītimahātherā, buddhamātā, buddhapitā, cakkavattī rājā aññe ca sārappattā brāhmaṇagahapatikā etthevuppajjanti. Tattha  tathāgato sujātāya dinnamadhupāyāsabhojanato yāva arahattamaggo, tāva uppajjati nāma, arahattaphale uppanno nāma. Mahābhinikkhamanato vā yāva arahattamaggo. Tusitabhavanato vā yāva arahattamaggo. Dīpaṅkarapādamūlato vā yāva arahattamaggo, tāva uppajjati nāma, arahattaphale  uppanno nāma. Idha sabbapaṭhamaṃ uppannabhāvaṃ sandhāya uppajjatīti vuttaṃ. Tathāgato loke uppanno hotīti ayañhettha attho. So imaṃ lokanti so bhagavā imaṃ lokaṃ. Idāni vattabbaṃ nidasseti. Sadevakanti saha devehi sadevakaṃ. Evaṃ saha mārena samārakaṃ, saha brahmunā sabrahmakaṃ, saha samaṇabrāhmaṇehi sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ. Pajātattā pajā, taṃ pajaṃ. Saha devamanussehi sadevamanussaṃ. Tattha sadevakavacanena pañca kāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Samāraka – vacanena chaṭṭhakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ. Sabrahmakavacanena brahmakāyikādibrahmaggahaṇaṃ. Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇīvacanena sāsanassa paccatthikapaccāmittasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇaṃ, samitapāpabāhitapāpasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇañca. Pajāvacanena sattalokaggahaṇaṃ. Sadevamanussavacanena sammutidevaavasesamanussaggahaṇaṃ. Evamettha tīhi padehi okāsalokena saddhiṃ sattaloko. Dvīhi pajāvasena sattalokova gahitoti veditabbo. Aparo nayo, sadevakaggahaṇena arūpāvacaradevaloko gahito. Samārakaggahaṇena cha kāmāvacaradevaloko. Sabrahmakaggahaṇena rūpī brahmaloko. Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇādiggahaṇena catuparisavasena sammutidevehi vā saha manussaloko, avasesasabbasattaloko vā. Api cettha sadevakavacanena ukkaṭṭhaparicchedato sabbassa lokassa sacchikatabhāvamāha. Tato  yesaṃ ahosi – ‘‘māro mahānubhāvo cha kāmāvacarissaro vasavattī, kiṃ sopi etena sacchikato’’ti, tesaṃ  vimatiṃ vidhamanto ‘‘samāraka’’nti āha. Yesaṃ pana ahosi – ‘‘brahmā mahānubhāvo ekaṅguliyā ekasmiṃ cakkavāḷasahasse ālokaṃ pharati, dvīhi  …pe… dasahi aṅgulīhi dasasu cakkavāḷasahassesu ālokaṃ pharati. Anuttarañca jhānasamāpattisukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, kiṃ sopi sacchikato’’ti, tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamanto sabrahmakanti āha. Tato ye cintesuṃ – ‘‘puthū samaṇabrāhmaṇā sāsanassa paccatthikā, kiṃ tepi sacchikatā’’ti, tesaṃ vimatiṃ vidhamanto sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajanti āha. Evaṃ ukkaṭṭhukkaṭṭhānaṃ sacchikatabhāvaṃ pakāsetvā atha sammutideve avasesamanusse ca upādāya ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena sesasattalokassa sacchikatabhāvaṃ pakāsento sadevamanussanti āha. Ayamettha bhāvānukkamo. Porāṇā panāhu sadevakanti devehi saddhiṃ avasesalokaṃ. Samārakanti mārena saddhiṃ avasesalokaṃ. Sabrahmakanti brahmehi saddhiṃ avasesalokaṃ. Evaṃ sabbepi tibhavūpage satte tīhākārehi tīsu padesu pakkhipitvā puna dvīhi padehi pariyādiyanto sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussanti āha. Evaṃ pañcahipi padehi tena tenākārena tedhātukameva pariyādinnanti. Sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedetīti ettha pana sayanti sāmaṃ aparaneyyo hutvā. Abhiññāti abhiññāya, adhikena ñāṇena ñatvāti attho. Sacchikatvāti paccakkhaṃ katvā, etena anumānādipaṭikkhepo kato hoti. Pavedetīti bodheti viññāpeti pakāseti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ…pe… pariyosānakalyāṇanti so bhagavā sattesu kāruññataṃ paṭicca hitvāpi anuttaraṃ vivekasukhaṃ dhammaṃ deseti. Tañca kho appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā desento ādikalyāṇādippakārameva deseti. Ādimhipi, kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā deseti, majjhepi, pariyosānepi, kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā desetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha atthi desanāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ, atthi sāsanassa. Desanāya tāva catuppadikāyapi gāthāya paṭhamapādo ādi nāma, tato dve majjhaṃ nāma, ante eko pariyosānaṃ nāma. Ekānusandhikassa suttassa nidānaṃ ādi, idamavocāti pariyosānaṃ, ubhinnamantarā  majjhaṃ. Anekānusandhikassa  suttassa paṭhamānusandhi ādi, ante anusandhi pariyosānaṃ, majjhe eko vā dve vā bahū vā majjhameva. Sāsanassa pana sīlasamādhivipassanā ādi nāma. Vuttampi cetaṃ – ‘‘ko cādi kusalānaṃ  dhammānaṃ? Sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ diṭṭhi ca ujukā’’ti (saṃ. ni. 5.369). ‘‘Atthi, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā’’ti evaṃ vutto pana ariyamaggo majjhaṃ nāma. Phalañceva nibbānañca pariyosānaṃ nāma. ‘‘Etadatthamidaṃ, brāhmaṇa, brahmacariyaṃ, etaṃ sāraṃ, etaṃ pariyosāna’’nti (ma. ni. 1.324) hi ettha phalaṃ pariyosānanti vuttaṃ. ‘‘Nibbānogadhaṃ hi, āvuso visākha, brahmacariyaṃ vussati, nibbānaparāyanaṃ nibbānapariyosāna’’nti (ma. ni. 1.466) ettha nibbānaṃ pariyosānanti vuttaṃ. Idha desanāya ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ adhippetaṃ. Bhagavā hi dhammaṃ desento ādimhi sīlaṃ dassetvā majjhe maggaṃ pariyosāne nibbānaṃ dasseti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘so dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇa’’nti. Tasmā aññopi dhammakathiko dhammaṃ kathento – Sātthaṃ sabyañjananti yassa hi yāgubhattaitthipurisādivaṇṇanānissitā desanā hoti, na so sātthaṃ deseti. Bhagavā pana tathārūpaṃ desanaṃ pahāya catusatipaṭṭhānādinissitaṃ desanaṃ deseti. Tasmā sātthaṃ desetīti vuccati. Yassa pana desanā ekabyañjanādiyuttā vā sabbaniroṭṭhabyañjanā vā sabbavissaṭṭhasabbaniggahītabyañjanā vā, tassa damiḷakirātasavarādimilakkhūnaṃ bhāsā viya byañjanapāripūriyā abhāvato abyañjanā nāma desanā hoti. Bhagavā pana – Evaṃ  vuttaṃ dasavidhaṃ byañjanaṃ amakkhetvā paripuṇṇabyañjanameva katvā dhammaṃ deseti, tasmā sabyañjanaṃ dhammaṃ desetīti vuccati. Kevalaparipuṇṇanti ettha kevalanti sakalādhivacanaṃ. Paripuṇṇanti anūnādhikavacanaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti sakalaparipuṇṇameva deseti, ekadesanāpi aparipuṇṇā natthīti. Upanetabbaapanetabbassa abhāvato kevalaparipuṇṇanti veditabbaṃ. Parisuddhanti nirupakkilesaṃ. Yo hi imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ nissāya lābhaṃ vā sakkāraṃ vā labhissāmīti deseti, tassa aparisuddhā desanā hoti. Bhagavā pana lokāmisanirapekkho hitapharaṇena  mettābhāvanāya muduhadayo ullumpanasabhāvasaṇṭhitena cittena deseti. Tasmā parisuddhaṃ dhammaṃ desetīti vuccati. Brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti ettha panāyaṃ brahmacariya-saddo dāne veyyāvacce pañcasikkhāpadasīle appamaññāsu methunaviratiyaṃ sadārasantose vīriye uposathaṅgesu ariyamagge sāsaneti imesvatthesu dissati. Imasmiñhi puṇṇakajātake dānaṃ brahmacariyanti vuttaṃ. Imasmiṃ  aṅkurapetavatthumhi veyyāvaccaṃ brahmacariyanti vuttaṃ. ‘‘Evaṃ, kho taṃ bhikkhave, tittiriyaṃ nāma brahmacariyaṃ ahosī’’ti (cūḷava. 311) imasmiṃ tittirajātake pañcasikkhāpadasīlaṃ brahmacariyanti vuttaṃ. ‘‘Taṃ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ neva nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya…pe… yāvadeva brahmalokūpapattiyā’’ti (dī. ni. 2.329) imasmiṃ mahāgovindasutte catasso appamaññāyo brahmacariyanti vuttā. ‘‘Pare abrahmacārī bhavissanti, mayamettha brahmacārī bhavissāmā’’ti (ma. ni. 1.83) imasmiṃ sallekhasutte methunavirati brahmacariyanti vuttā. Mahādhammapālajātake sadārasantoso brahmacariyanti vutto. ‘‘Abhijānāmi  kho panāhaṃ, sāriputta, caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ brahmacariyaṃ caritā, tapassī sudaṃ homī’’ti (ma. ni. 1.155) lomahaṃsanasutte vīriyaṃ brahmacariyanti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ nimijātake attadamanavasena kato aṭṭhaṅgiko uposatho brahmacariyanti vutto. ‘‘Idaṃ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya…pe… ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo’’ti (dī. ni. 2.329) mahāgovindasuttasmiṃyeva ariyamaggo brahmacariyanti vutto. ‘‘Tayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsita’’nti (dī. ni. 3.174) pāsādikasutte sikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sakalasāsanaṃ brahmacariyanti vuttaṃ. Imasmimpi ṭhāne idameva brahmacariyanti adhippetaṃ. Tasmā brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti so dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ…pe… parisuddhaṃ. Evaṃ desento ca sikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sakalasāsanaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti  evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Brahmacariyanti seṭṭhaṭṭhena brahmabhūtaṃ cariyaṃ. Brahmabhūtānaṃ vā buddhādīnaṃ cariyanti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
190. Then the Blessed One said this, he said this, now it should be said, "Here, great king," and so on, the meaning is that he spoke the entire discourse.

There, *idha* means a particle indicating place and location, and it is used with reference to the world in some instances.

As he said, "Here, the *tathāgata* arises in the world."

In some instances, regarding the teaching, as he said, "Here, monks, is the first ascetic, here is the second ascetic" (A.
Ni.
4.
241).

In some instances, regarding opportunity.

As he said, "In some instances, it is merely to fill the line."

As he said, "Here, monks, I have eaten and am satisfied" (M.
Ni.
1.
30).

Here, however, it should be understood as being said with reference to the world.

*Mahārāja*, to teach the teaching as promised, he addresses him again as *mahārāja*.

This is what was said: "Great king, in this world the *tathāgata* arises, the *arhat*…pe… the Buddha, the Blessed One."

There, the word *tathāgata* is mentioned in the *Brahmajāla*.

*Arhat* and so on are explained in detail in the *Visuddhimagga*.

Here, regarding "arises in the world," the world (*loka*) is threefold: the world of space (*okāsaloka*), the world of beings (*sattaloka*), and the world of formations (*saṅkhāraloka*).

Here, however, the world of beings (*sattaloka*) is intended.

And though the *tathāgata* arises in the world of beings, he does not arise in the world of gods (*devaloka*), nor in the *brahmaloka*, but only in the world of humans (*manussaloka*).

Even in the world of humans (*manussaloka*), not in another *cakravāḷa*, but only in this *cakravāḷa*.

Even there, not in all places, "In the eastern direction is a town called Gajaṅgala, beyond that is Mahāsāla, beyond that are the outlying districts, inside that is the middle region. In the southeast direction is a river called Salalavatī.

Beyond that are the outlying districts, inside that is the middle region. In the southern direction is a town called Setakaṇṇika, beyond that are the outlying districts, inside that is the middle region. In the western direction is a *brāhmaṇa* village called Thūṇa, beyond that are the outlying districts, inside that is the middle region. In the northern direction is a mountain called Usiraddhaja, beyond that are the outlying districts, inside that is the middle region." Thus, within these defined boundaries, the *tathāgata* arises in the middle region, which is 300 *yojanas* in length, 250 *yojanas* in width, and 900 *yojanas* in circumference.

Not only the *tathāgata*, but also the *paccekabuddhas*, chief disciples (*aggasāvakā*), eighty great elders (*asītimahātherā*), the Buddha's mother (*buddhamātā*), the Buddha's father (*buddhapitā*), the wheel-turning monarch (*cakkavattī rājā*), and other worthy *brāhmaṇa* householders (*gahapatikā*) also arise here.

There, the *tathāgata*, from the time of receiving the meal of honey-rice (*madhupāyāsa*) offered by Sujātā up to the path of *arhatship* (*arahattamagga*), is said to "arise," and with the attainment of the fruit of *arhatship* (*arahattaphala*), he is said to have "arisen."

Or alternatively, from the time of his great renunciation (*mahābhinikkhamana*) up to the path of *arhatship* (*arahattamagga*).

Or from the time in the Tusita heaven (*tusitabhavana*) up to the path of *arhatship* (*arahattamagga*).

Or from the base of Dīpaṅkara's feet up to the path of *arhatship* (*arahattamagga*), is said to "arise," and with the attainment of the fruit of *arhatship* (*arahattaphala*), he is said to have "arisen."

Here, "arises" is said with reference to the state of having arisen first of all (*sabbapaṭhamaṃ uppannabhāvaṃ sandhāya*).

The meaning here is, "The *tathāgata* has arisen in the world (*loke uppanno hoti*)."

"He, this world" means he, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), this world.

Now, he indicates what should be said.

"*Sadevaka*" means with the gods (*devehi*), *sadevaka*.

Likewise, with Māra (*mārena*), *samāraka*; with Brahmā (*brahmunā*), *sabrahmaka*; with ascetics and *brāhmaṇas* (*samaṇabrāhmaṇehi*), *sassamaṇabrāhmaṇim*.

*Pajātattā pajā*, that *pajaṃ*.

With gods and humans (*devamanussehi*), *sadevamanussaṃ*.

There, by the term "*sadevakavacanena*," the five abodes of the gods in the desire realm (*kāmāvacaradeva*) should be understood.

By the term "*samāraka vacanena*," the sixth abode of the gods in the desire realm (*chaṭṭhakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ*) is [meant].
By the phrase "its Brahmās" (*sabrahmaka*), the Brahmās such as those of Brahmā's retinue, etc., are included.
The phrase “with its recluses and brahmins,” (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇīvacanena*) includes both those recluses and *brāhmaṇas* who are hostile and opposed to the Buddha’s dispensation, and those who have truly stilled and expelled evil.
By the expression *pajā*, there is the taking of the world of living creatures.
By the expression *sadevamanussa*, there has been taken the conventional gods (*sammuti deva*) and the remaining human beings.
Thus, by the first three phrases here, the world of beings along with the physical world is included.
By the word "generation" (*pajā*) with its two qualifying phrases, the world of beings only is included; thus, it should be understood.
Another method: By mentioning "with its gods" (*sadevaka*), the gods of the immaterial world (*arūpāvacara*) are included.
By mentioning "its Māras" (*samāraka*), the gods of the six sense-sphere heavenly worlds (*cha kāmāvacara*) are included.
By mentioning "its Brahmās" (*sabrahmaka*), the fine-material Brahma-world (*rūpī brahmaloko*) is included.
By mentioning “with its recluses and *brāhmaṇas*,” etc., the human world with its conventional gods and its four social orders, or all the rest of the world of beings, is included.
And also, by the expression "with its gods" (*sadevaka*), He indicates the state of realization of the entire world, through delimitation by way of the most excellent.
Then some might think: “Māra is very powerful—he is the ruler and master of the six sense-sphere heavens. What, has he realized him, too?” Dispelling their doubts, he says: “its Māras (*samāraka*)."
Still others might think: "Brahmā is very powerful. With one finger he illuminates a thousand world-systems; with two …pe… with ten fingers he illuminates ten thousand world-systems.
And he experiences the unsurpassed bliss of the *jhānasamāpatti* attainments. What, has he realized him, too?” Dispelling their doubts, he says: “its Brahmās (*sabrahmaka*)."
Then some think: “There are many recluses and *brāhmaṇas* opposed to the dispensation. What, has he realized them, too?” Dispelling their doubts, he says: “With its recluses and *brāhmaṇas* (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajanti*)."
Thus, having revealed his realization of the most excellent states, with the phrases "with its rulers and its people" (*sadevamanussa*) he reveals his realization of the rest of the world of beings, delimiting it by way of its most excellent members with the reference to conventional gods and the rest of humanity.
This is the sequence of states here.
But the Ancients say that the phrase "with its gods" (*sadevaka*) indicates the rest of the world together with the gods.
"Its Māras" (*samāraka*) means the rest of the world together with Māra.
And "its Brahmās" (*sabrahmaka*) means the rest of the world together with Brahmā.
Thus, with these three phrases, he includes all beings found in the three planes of existence, presenting them under three different aspects, and with the next two phrases—"this generation with its recluses and *brāhmaṇas*, its rulers and people" (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussa*)—he again exhaustively treats the world.
Thus, with these five phrases, the three realms of existence are exhaustively presented under different aspects.
"Having directly experienced it himself through higher knowledge, he declares it." Here, "himself" means having become one who is independent.
"Higher knowledge" (*abhiññā*) means knowing through higher, additional knowledge (*adhikena ñāṇena ñatvāti attho*).
"Having realized" (*sacchikatvā*) means having made it directly known; by this, inferential knowledge is rejected.
"Declares" (*pavedeti*) means awakens, informs, reveals.
He teaches the *dharma* that is good in the beginning…pe… good in the end (*so dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ…pe… pariyosānakalyāṇanti*); that Blessed One, out of compassion for beings, even abandons the unsurpassed bliss of solitude and teaches the *dharma*.
And whether he teaches little or much, the *dharma* he teaches has the quality of being good in the beginning, etc. (*ādikalyāṇādippakārameva deseti*).
He teaches, making it good, lovely, faultless, in the beginning, in the middle, and in the end; this is what is meant (*ādimhipi, kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā deseti, majjhepi, pariyosānepi, kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā desetīti vuttaṃ hoti*).
There, a teaching has a beginning, a middle, and an end, and the dispensation (*sāsana*) as a whole has a beginning, a middle, and an end.
With regard to a teaching, even in a verse of four lines, the first line is the beginning, the two lines following it the middle, and the last line the end.
In a *sūtra* with a single sequence of meaning, the introduction (*nidāna*) is the beginning, the phrase "Thus spoke the Exalted One" (*idamavocāti*) is the end, and what comes in between these is the middle.
In a *sūtra* with several sequences of meaning, the first sequence (*paṭhamānusandhi*) is the beginning, the final sequence (*anusandhi*) is the end, and what comes in between—whether one, two, or many—is the middle.
With regard to the dispensation (*sāsana*), moral discipline (*sīla*), concentration (*samādhi*), and insight (*vipassanā*) are the beginning.
And it was said, "What is the beginning of wholesome qualities? Moral conduct that is very pure and a view that is upright (*sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ diṭṭhi ca ujukā*)" (Saṃ.
Ni.
5.
369).
"There is, monks (*bhikkhave*), a middle way awakened to by the *Tathāgata* (*tathāgatena*)"—thus it is said; the Noble Path (*ariyamaggo*) is the middle.
The fruit (*phala*) and *Nirvāṇa* (*nibbāna*) are the end.
“This is the goal of the holy life, this is its essence, this is its end”—(M.I,324) for here, the fruit is called the end.

“Friend Visākha, the holy life plunges into Nibbāna, Nibbāna is its final resort, Nibbāna is its end”—(M.I,466) and here, Nibbāna is called the end.

Here, the beginning, middle, and end intended are those of the teaching (desanā).

For when the Exalted One teaches the Dhamma, he teaches it showing moral discipline (sīla) in the beginning, the path (magga) in the middle, and Nibbāna in the end.

Thus it is said: “He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning (ādikalyāṇaṃ), good in the middle (majjhekalyāṇaṃ), and good in the end (pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ).”

Therefore, another Dhamma speaker, when speaking the Dhamma, [should do so] possessing meaning (sātthaṃ) and phrasing (sabyañjanaṃ). For if the teaching is based on descriptions of gruel, cooked rice, women, men, and so on, he does not teach with meaning.

But the Exalted One, having abandoned such kinds of teaching (desanā), presents a teaching concerned with the four foundations of mindfulness (catusatipaṭṭhānādinissitaṃ), etc.

Therefore he is said to teach the Dhamma “possessing meaning” (sātthaṃ).

One whose teaching lacks the complete variety of phrases, or who confuses the various kinds of sounds—like the language of the Tamil, Kirata, Savara, and other barbarians—is said to have a teaching that is “without phrasing” (abyanjanā), due to the absence of complete phrasing.

But the Exalted One, without slurring together the ten kinds of sounds mentioned, teaches the Dhamma making it complete in phrasing (paripuṇṇabyañjanaṃ), therefore he is said to teach the Dhamma "possessing phrasing" (sabyañjanaṃ).

Here, in "entirely complete" (kevalaparipuṇṇanti), "entirely" (kevalaṃ) means all-inclusive (sakalādhivacanaṃ).

"Complete" (paripuṇṇanti) means neither deficient nor excessive (anūnādhikavacanaṃ).

This means that he teaches only what is entirely complete, and there is no teaching which is incomplete.

It should be understood as "entirely complete" (kevalaparipuṇṇanti) due to the absence of what should be introduced or removed.

"Purified" (parisuddhanti) means without corruption (nirupakkilesaṃ).

In the case of one who teaches his Dhamma teaching (dhammadesanā) with the intention of obtaining honor (sakkāra) and gain (lābhaṃ), the teaching is impure (aparishuddha).

But the Exalted One teaches without regard for worldly ends (lokāmisanirapekkho), with a heart made gentle by the development of loving kindness (mettābhāvanāya), suffused with the welfare of others (hitapharaṇena), with a mind established in delivering others i.e. with a mind of compassionate intention fixed in the mode of lifting others up from all defilements and from the suffering of the round (ullumpanasabhāvasaṇṭhitena cittena).

Therefore he is said to teach a purified Dhamma (parisuddhaṃ dhammaṃ).

He reveals the holy life (brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti): Here, the word “holy life” (brahmacariya-saddo) is found with the following meanings: giving (dāne), service (veyyāvacce), the moral discipline of the five precepts (pañcasikkhāpadasīle), the four immeasurable states (appamaññāsu), abstinence from sexual intercourse (methunaviratiyaṃ), contentment with one’s own marital partner (sadārasantose), energy (vīriye), the factors of the Uposatha observance (uposathaṅgesu), the noble path (ariyamagge), and the entire dispensation (sāsane).

For in this Puṇṇaka Jātaka, giving (dānaṃ) is called the holy life (brahmacariyanti).

In this Aṅkura Peta Vatthu, service (veyyāvaccaṃ) is called the holy life (brahmacariyanti).

“In this way the spiritual life called Tittiriya came to be”—(Cūḷava. 311): In this Tittira Jātaka, the moral discipline of the five precepts (pañcasikkhāpadasīlaṃ) is called the holy life (brahmacariyanti).

“However, Pancasikha, that holy life does not lead to dis-enchantment, to dispassion, to cessation…pe… but only to birth in the Brahma-world” (D.II,329): In this Mahāgovinda Sutta, the four immeasurable states (catasso appamaññāyo) are called the holy life (brahmacariyanti).

“Others will be uncelibate; we shall be celibate here”—(M.I,83): In this Sallekha Sutta, abstinence from sexual intercourse (methunavirati) is called the holy life (brahmacariyanti).

In the Mahādhamma Pāla Jātaka, contentment with one's own marital partner (sadārasantoso) is called the holy life (brahmacariyanti).

“Sariputta, I recall having lived a holy life (brahmacariyaṃ) possessing four factors, I have practised asceticism (tapassī sudaṃ homī)” (M.I)
1.155) In the Lomahaṃsana Sutta, *vīriyaṃ* (effort) is said to be *brahmacariyaṃ* (brahmacarya, the holy life).

Similarly, in the Nimi Jātaka, the eight-factored *uposatho* (observance day) performed through self-control is said to be *brahmacariyaṃ*.

"This, Pañcasikha, is my *brahmacariyaṃ*, entirely for aversion, for detachment, for cessation…pe… this is the Noble Eightfold Path" (Dīgha Nikāya 2.329). In the Mahāgovinda Sutta itself, the Noble Path is said to be *brahmacariyaṃ*.

"This *brahmacariyaṃ* has become successful and prosperous, extended, popular, widespread, well proclaimed among devas and humans" (Dīgha Nikāya 3.174). In the Pāsādika Sutta, the entire dispensation comprised of the threefold training is said to be *brahmacariyaṃ*.

In this place also, this same thing is intended as *brahmacariyaṃ*.

Therefore, *brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti* (he reveals a holy life) means he teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning…pe… fully complete and purified.

And teaching it thus, he reveals the holy life, the entire dispensation comprised in the threefold training. Thus, the meaning here should be understood.

*Brahmacariyaṃ* means conduct (cariyaṃ) that has become Brahman (brahmabhūtaṃ) in the sense of being excellent (seṭṭhaṭṭhena).

Or it means the conduct of the Buddhas and others who have become Brahman (brahmabhūtānaṃ).

mula_pali: 191. ‘‘Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto. So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā  tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati. So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati – ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā. Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ  pabbajeyya’nti.
mula_english:
For as the saying goes:
“A householder or a householder's son or one reborn in some other clan hears that Dharma (dhammaṃ).
Having heard this Dharma (dhammaṃ), he gains faith (saddhaṃ) in the Tathāgata.
Endowed with such gain of faith (saddhāpaṭilābhena), he reflects: ‘Household life (gharāvāso) is crowded, a path of dust (rajopatho). Going forth (pabbajjā) is like the open air (abbhokāso).
It is not easy for one dwelling at home (agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā) to lead the perfectly complete (ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ), perfectly purified (ekantaparisuddhaṃ) holy life (brahmacariyaṃ), bright as a polished conch (saṅkhalikhitaṃ).
Let me then shave off my hair and beard (kesamassuṃ ohāretvā), put on saffron robes (kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā), and go forth from home (agārasmā) to homelessness (anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya).’”
commentary_pali: 191.Taṃ dhammanti  taṃ vuttappakārasampadaṃ dhammaṃ. Suṇāti gahapati vāti kasmā paṭhamaṃ gahapatiṃ niddisati? Nihatamānattā, ussannattā ca. Yebhuyyena hi khattiyakulato pabbajitā jātiṃ nissāya mānaṃ karonti. Brāhmaṇakulā pabbajitā mante nissāya mānaṃ karonti. Hīnajaccakulā pabbajitā attano attano vijātitāya patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Gahapatidārakā pana kacchehi sedaṃ muñcantehi piṭṭhiyā loṇaṃ pupphamānāya bhūmiṃ kasitvā tādisassa mānassa abhāvato nihatamānadappā honti. Te pabbajitvā  mānaṃ vā dappaṃ vā akatvā yathābalaṃ sakalabuddhavacanaṃ uggahetvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karontā sakkonti arahatte patiṭṭhātuṃ. Itarehi ca kulehi nikkhamitvā pabbajitā nāma na bahukā, gahapatikāva bahukā. Iti nihatamānattā ussannattā ca paṭhamaṃ gahapatiṃ niddisatīti. Aññatarasmiṃ vāti itaresaṃ vā kulānaṃ aññatarasmiṃ. Paccājātoti patijāto. Tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhatīti parisuddhaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā dhammassāmimhi tathāgate – ‘‘sammāsambuddho vata so bhagavā’’ti saddhaṃ paṭilabhati. Iti paṭisañcikkhatīti evaṃ paccavekkhati. Sambādho gharāvāsoti sacepi saṭṭhihatthe ghare yojanasatantarepi vā dve jāyampatikā vasanti, tathāpi nesaṃ sakiñcanasapalibodhaṭṭhena gharāvāso sambādhoyeva. Rajopathoti rāgarajādīnaṃ uṭṭhānaṭṭhānanti mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Āgamanapathotipi vadanti. Alagganaṭṭhena abbhokāso viyāti abbhokāso. Pabbajito hi kūṭāgāraratanapāsādadevavimānādīsu pihitadvāravātapānesu paṭicchannesu vasantopi neva laggati, na sajjati, na bajjhati. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘abbhokāso pabbajjā’’ti. Api ca sambādho gharāvāso kusalakiriyāya okāsābhāvato. Rajopatho asaṃvutasaṅkāraṭṭhānaṃ viya rajānaṃ kilesarajānaṃ sannipātaṭṭhānato. Abbhokāso pabbajjā kusalakiriyāya yathāsukhaṃ okāsasabbhāvato. Nayidaṃsukaraṃ…pe… pabbajeyyanti etthāyaṃ saṅkhepakathā, yadetaṃ sikkhattayabrahmacariyaṃ ekampi divasaṃ akhaṇḍaṃ katvā carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ, caritabbaṃ ekadivasampi ca kilesamalena amalīnaṃ katvā carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparisuddhaṃ . Saṅkhalikhitanti likhitasaṅkhasadisaṃ dhotasaṅkhasappaṭibhāgaṃ caritabbaṃ. Idaṃ na sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā agāramajjhe vasantena ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ…pe… carituṃ, yaṃnūnāhaṃ kese ca massuñca ohāretvā kasāyarasapītatāya kāsāyāni brahmacariyaṃ carantānaṃ anucchavikāni vatthāni acchādetvā paridahitvā agārasmā nikkhamitvā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyanti. Ettha ca yasmā  agārassa hitaṃ kasivāṇijjādikammaṃ agāriyanti vuccati, tañca pabbajjāya natthi, tasmā pabbajjā anagāriyanti ñātabbā, taṃ anagāriyaṃ. Pabbajeyyanti paṭipajjeyyaṃ.
commentary_english:
191.
*Taṃ Dhamma* means that Dhamma which possesses the qualities that have been described.
Why does he mention householders first, saying, "A householder hears," or (simply) "hears?" Because they are humble and predominant.
Generally, when those from noble *kṣatriya* families go forth, they become conceited because of their birth (*jātiṃ nissāya mānaṃ karonti*).
When those from brahmin families go forth, they become conceited because of their knowledge of the *mantras* (*mante nissāya mānaṃ karonti*).
When those from low-class families go forth, they are not able to establish themselves well because of their low birth (*attano attano vijātitāya patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkonti*).
But householders’ boys, who plough the earth with sweat flowing from their armpits and backs glistening with perspiration, lack such conceit; thus they are humble and free from pride (*tādisassa mānassa abhāvato nihatamānadappā honti*).
When they go forth, they do not become proud and conceited; rather, to the best of their ability, they learn the entire word of the Buddha, do the work of insight (*vipassanāya kammaṃ karontā*), and establish themselves in *Arhatship* (*arahatte patiṭṭhātuṃ*).
And those who renounce and go forth from other families are not numerous, whereas those from householder families are.
Thus, because they are humble and because they are predominant, householders are mentioned first (*iti nihatamānattā ussannattā ca paṭhamaṃ gahapatiṃ niddisatīti*).
Either in one or another, or in another of the other families.
*Paccājāto* means *patijāto*.
He obtains faith in the *Tathāgata*, meaning that having heard the purified Dhamma, in the *Tathāgata*, the master of the Dhamma, he obtains faith, thinking, "Indeed, that Blessed One is a perfectly enlightened Buddha" (*‘‘sammāsambuddho vata so bhagavā’’ti saddhaṃ paṭilabhati*).
*Iti paṭisañcikkhati* means thus, he reflects (*evaṃ paccavekkhati*).
The household life is crowded, meaning that even if a couple, husband and wife, live in a house sixty cubits on an estate of a hundred *yojanas*, household life is still “crowded” in the sense that it involves obstacles such as lust, etc. and impediments such as fields, land, etc. (*sakiñcanasapalibodhaṭṭhena gharāvāso sambādhoyeva*).
"It is a path of dust" means that it is the place of the arising of the dust of lust, etc. (*rāgarajādīnaṃ uṭṭhānaṭṭhānanti mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ*).
They also say that it is a path of access.
Going forth is like the open air, meaning that it is like the open air due to its characteristic of non-attachment. (*alagganaṭṭhena abbhokāso viyāti abbhokāso*)
For even if one gone forth is living in a gabled cottage, a jewel-ornamented mansion, or a celestial palace, etc, with closed doors and windows, covered by a roof, he is unhindered, unattached, unbound (*pabbajito hi kūṭāgāraratanapāsādadevavimānādīsu pihitadvāravātapānesu paṭicchannesu vasantopi neva laggati, na sajjati, na bajjhati*).
Therefore, it was said, “Going forth is like the open air” (*‘‘abbhokāso pabbajjā’’ti*).
Further, household life is crowded because it gives little opportunity for wholesome activity (*kusalakiriyāya okāsābhāvato*).
And it is a path of dust because, like an unchecked dust-heap, it is a place where dust collects, i.e. the dust of the defilements (*rajānaṃ kilesarajānaṃ sannipātaṭṭhānato*).
Going forth is like the open air in that it gives opportunity for wholesome activity as much as one pleases (*kusalakiriyāya yathāsukhaṃ okāsasabbhāvato*).
“This is not easy…pe…let me go forth,” here is a summary of the matter: this three-fold training (*sikkhattaya*) and holy life (*brahmacariya*) must be perfectly fulfilled, even for one day without a break, so as to bring about the final state of mind (*carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ*), and it must be lived, even for one day, without being soiled by the impurities of defilements (*kilesamalena amalīnaṃ katvā*) so as to bring about the final state of mind (*carimakacittaṃ pāpetabbatāya ekantaparisuddhaṃ*).
*Saṅkhalikhita* means that it should be lived like a conch that has been written on, similar to a washed conch, of like appearance. (*likhitasaṅkhasadisaṃ dhotasaṅkhasappaṭibhāgaṃ caritabbaṃ*)
It is not easy to live in a house (*agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā*) dwelling amidst a house (*agāramajjhe vasantena*), being utterly perfect…pe… to live, what if I were to shave off my hair and beard, and having dressed in robes, dyed the color of astringent juice (*kasāyarasapītatāya kāsāyāni*), fitting for those who live the holy life (*brahmacariyaṃ carantānaṃ anucchavikāni vatthāni*), having covered myself and put them on, having gone forth from the house, I would go forth into homelessness? (*agārasmā nikkhamitvā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyanti*)
Here, because that activity such as agriculture, trade, and so forth, that is beneficial to a house is called ‘belonging to a house’ (*agāriyanti vuccati*), and that does not exist for going forth, therefore, going forth should be known as ‘not belonging to a house' (*pabbajjā anagāriyanti ñātabbā*); that is, homelessness (*taṃ anagāriyaṃ*).
"Let me go forth" means "I should undertake it." (*pabbajeyyanti paṭipajjeyyaṃ*)

mula_pali: 192. ‘‘So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mula_english: After some time, he relinquishes a small or large fortune (bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya), abandons a small or large circle of relatives (ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya), shaves off his hair and beard (kesamassuṃ ohāretvā), dons saffron robes (kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā), and goes forth from the householder's life into homelessness (agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati).
commentary_pali: 192-193.Appaṃ vāti sahassato heṭṭhā bhogakkhandho appo nāma hoti, sahassato paṭṭhāya mahā. Ābandhanaṭṭhena ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo. Sopi vīsatiyā heṭṭhā appo nāma hoti, vīsatiyā paṭṭhāya mahā. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti pātimokkhasaṃvarena samannāgato. Ācāragocarasampannoti ācārena ceva gocarena ca sampanno. Aṇumattesūti appamattakesu. Vajjesūti akusaladhammesu. Bhayadassāvīti bhayadassī. Samādāyāti sammā ādiyitvā. Sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti sikkhāpadesu taṃ taṃ sikkhāpadaṃ samādiyitvā sikkhati. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge vutto. Kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvoti ettha ācāragocaraggahaṇeneva ca kusale kāyakammavacīkamme gahitepi yasmā idaṃ ājīvapārisuddhisīlaṃ nāma na ākāse vā rukkhaggādīsu vā uppajjati, kāyavacīdvāresuyeva pana uppajjati; tasmā tassa uppattidvāradassanatthaṃ kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalenāti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana tena samannāgato, tasmā parisuddhājīvo. Samaṇamuṇḍikaputtasuttantavasena  (ma. ni. 2.260) vā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha hi ‘‘katame ca, thapati, kusalā sīlā? Kusalaṃ  kāyakammaṃ, kusalaṃ vacīkammaṃ, parisuddhaṃ ājīvampi kho ahaṃ thapati sīlasmiṃ vadāmī’’ti vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana tena samannāgato, tasmā parisuddhājīvoti veditabbo. Sīlasampannoti brahmajāle vuttena tividhena sīlena samannāgato hoti. Indriyesu guttadvāroti manacchaṭṭhesu indriyesu pihitadvāro hoti. Satisampajaññena samannāgatoti abhikkante paṭikkantetiādīsu sattasu ṭhānesu satiyā ceva sampajaññena ca samannāgato hoti. Santuṭṭhoti catūsu paccayesu tividhena santosena santuṭṭho hoti.
commentary_english:
192-193.

"Appaṃ vāti sahassato heṭṭhā bhogakkhandho appo nāma hoti, sahassato paṭṭhāya mahā": A collection of wealth less than a thousand is called little ( *appa*); from a thousand onwards, it is great ( *mahā*).

"Ābandhanaṭṭhena ñātiyeva ñātiparivaṭṭo": A circle of relatives is like relatives because of the characteristic of binding together.

"Sopi vīsatiyā heṭṭhā appo nāma hoti, vīsatiyā paṭṭhāya mahā": Even that which is less than twenty is called little; from twenty onwards, it is great.

"Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvutoti pātimokkhasaṃvarena samannāgato": "Restrained by the restraint of the Pātimokkha" means endowed with the restraint of the Pātimokkha.

"Ācāragocarasampannoti ācārena ceva gocarena ca sampanno": "Endowed with proper conduct and resort" means endowed with both proper conduct (*ācāra*) and resort (*gocara*).

"Aṇumattesūti appamattakesu": "In minute matters" means in small matters.
