Pattopi tena udakaṃ uddharitvā nhānakāle kuṭiparibhaṇḍakaraṇakāle ca kāyaparihāriko hoti. Āhāraṃ gahetvā bhuñjanakāle kucchiparihāriko. Vāsipi tāya dantakaṭṭhacchedanakāle mañcapīṭhānaṃ aṅgapādacīvarakuṭidaṇḍakasajjanakāle ca kāyaparihārikā hoti. Ucchuchedananāḷikerāditacchanakāle kucchiparihārikā. Sūcipi cīvarasibbanakāle kāyaparihārikā hoti. Pūvaṃ vā phalaṃ vā vijjhitvā khādanakāle kucchiparihārikā. Kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā vicaraṇakāle kāyaparihārikaṃ. Ucchuādīni bandhitvā gahaṇakāle kucchiparihārikaṃ. Parissāvanaṃ tena udakaṃ parissāvetvā nhānakāle, senāsanaparibhaṇḍakaraṇakāle ca kāyaparihārikaṃ. Pānīyaṃ parissāvanakāle, teneva tilataṇḍulaputhukādīni gahetvā khādanakāle ca kucchiparihāriyaṃ. Ayaṃ tāva aṭṭhaparikkhārikassa parikkhāramattā. Navaparikkhārikassa  pana seyyaṃ pavisantassa tatraṭṭhakaṃ paccattharaṇaṃ vā kuñcikā vā vaṭṭati. Dasaparikkhārikassa nisīdanaṃ vā cammakhaṇḍaṃ vā vaṭṭati. Ekādasaparikkhārikassa pana kattarayaṭṭhi vā telanāḷikā vā vaṭṭati. Dvādasaparikkhārikassa chattaṃ vā upāhanaṃ vā vaṭṭati. Etesu ca aṭṭhaparikkhārikova santuṭṭho, itare asantuṭṭhā mahicchā mahābhārāti na vattabbā. Etepi hi appicchāva santuṭṭhāva subharāva sallahukavuttinova. Bhagavā pana na yimaṃ suttaṃ tesaṃ vasena kathesi, aṭṭhaparikkhārikassa vasena kathesi. So hi khuddakavāsiñca sūciñca parissāvane pakkhipitvā pattassa anto ṭhapetvā pattaṃ aṃsakūṭe laggetvā ticīvaraṃ kāyapaṭibaddhaṃ katvā yenicchakaṃ  sukhaṃ pakkamati. Paṭinivattetvā gahetabbaṃ nāmassa na hoti. Iti  imassa bhikkhuno sallahukavuttitaṃ dassento bhagavā – ‘‘santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarenā’’tiādimāha. Tattha kāyaparihārikenāti kāyapariharaṇamattakena. Kucchiparihārikenāti kucchipariharaṇamattakena. Samādāyeva pakkamatīti aṭṭhaparikkhāramattakaṃ sabbaṃ gahetvāva kāyapaṭibaddhaṃ katvāva gacchati. ‘‘Mama vihāro pariveṇaṃ upaṭṭhāko’’ti āsaṅgo vā bandho vā na hoti. So jiyā mutto saro viya, yūthā apakkanto madahatthī viya ca icchiticchitaṃ senāsanaṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ vanapabbhāraṃ paribhuñjanto ekova tiṭṭhati, ekova nisīdati. Sabbiriyāpathesu ekova adutiyo. Evaṃ vaṇṇitaṃ khaggavisāṇakappataṃ āpajjati. Idāni  tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento – ‘‘seyyathāpī’’tiādimāha. Tattha pakkhī sakuṇoti pakkhayutto sakuṇo. Ḍetīti uppatati. Ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho – sakuṇā nāma ‘‘asukasmiṃ padese rukkho paripakkaphalo’’ti ñatvā nānādisāhi āgantvā nakhapattatuṇḍādīhi tassa phalāni vijjhantā vidhunantā khādanti. ‘Idaṃ ajjatanāya, idaṃ svātanāya bhavissatī’ti tesaṃ na hoti. Phale pana khīṇe neva rukkhassa ārakkhaṃ ṭhapenti, na tattha pattaṃ vā nakhaṃ vā tuṇḍaṃ vā ṭhapenti. Atha kho tasmiṃ rukkhe anapekkho hutvā, yo yaṃ disābhāgaṃ icchati, so tena sapattabhārova uppatitvā gacchati. Evameva ayaṃ bhikkhu nissaṅgo nirapekkho yena kāmaṃ pakkamati. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘samādāyeva pakkamatī’’ti.
commentary_english:
215.
Here, great king, when it is said that a *bhikkhu* is content, it means that the content is endowed with contentment regarding the conditions, one after the other.

But that contentment is twelvefold; that is to say, threefold with regard to robes ( *cīvara*): contentment with whatever robes one obtains (*yathālābhasantoṣa*), contentment with the strength (to obtain robes) (*yathābalasantoṣa*), and contentment with what is befitting regarding robes (*yathāsāruppasantoṣa*).

And similarly in the cases of alms food (*piṇḍapāta*), and so on.

Here is a commentary on the divisions of it. Here a *bhikkhu* obtains a robe (*cīvara*), and whether it is a fine one or not,

he makes do with only that, wishing for no other, and he does not use any other even if he gets one: this is his ‘contentment with what one gets’ in the case of the robe (*cīvara*).

On the other hand, he may be naturally weak, or overcome by sickness and old age, and then he is wearied when wearing a heavy robe (*garucīvaraṃ*).

Then he is quite content to exchange it for a light one with a *bhikkhu* who is in communion and to live using that one: this is his ‘contentment with one’s own strength’ in the case of the robe (*cīvara*).

Another is the one who obtains requisites that are excellent (*paṇītapaccayalābhī*).

He may obtain a valuable bowl-robe, or many bowl-robes. He gives these away, thinking, "May this bowl-robe belong to those elder monks who have long been ordained, may this belong to those who have learned much, may this be fitting for the sick, may this belong to those who gain little." Then, either taking their old robes or picking out unwanted rags from a rubbish heap, he makes an outer robe (*saṅghāṭi*) from them and wears it, being content.

This is his ‘contentment with what is befitting’ in the case of the robe (*cīvara*).

Here again a *bhikkhu* obtains alms food (*piṇḍapāta*), and whether it is coarse (*lūkhaṃ*) or superior (*paṇītaṃ*), he uses only that, and, wishing for no other, he does not use any other even if he gets it: this is his ‘contentment with what one gets’ in the case of the alms food (*piṇḍapāta*).

On the other hand, if he gets alms food (*piṇḍapāta*) that is against his nature or against his illness, by which he becomes uncomfortable when he has eaten it,

then he is content to give it to a *bhikkhu* who is in communion and to accept congenial food (*sappāyabhojanaṃ*) at his hands and so be able to do his work upon the monks’ True Ideal. This is his ‘contentment with one’s own strength’ in the case of the alms food (*piṇḍapāta*).

Another obtains much alms food (*piṇḍapāta*) that is superior (*paṇītaṃ*).

He gives it away, like robes, to those elder monks who have long been ordained, who have learned much, who gain little, or who are sick, and he is content to live on whatever they give him in return, or having gone for alms and eating mixed food.

This is his ‘contentment with what is befitting’ in the case of the alms food (*piṇḍapāta*).

Here again a *bhikkhu* obtains a resting-place (*senāsanaṃ*), and whether it is pleasing (*manāpaṃ*) or unpleasing (*amanāpaṃ*), he does not arouse joy (*somanassaṃ*) or displeasure (*domanassaṃ*); he is satisfied with even a grass mat (*tiṇasanthārakenapi*) that he has obtained.

This is his ‘contentment with what one gets’ in the case of the resting-place (*senāsanaṃ*).

On the other hand, if he gets a resting-place (*senāsanaṃ*) that is against his nature or against his illness, where he is uncomfortable living, then he is quite content to give it to a *bhikkhu* who is in communion, and to live in a congenial resting-place (*sappāyasenāsane*) that the other possesses.

This is his ‘contentment with one’s own strength’ in the case of the resting-place (*senāsanaṃ*).

Another, greatly meritorious, obtains many superior resting-places (*paṇītasenāsanāni*), such as caves, open halls, and peaked houses (*leṇamaṇḍapakūṭāgārādīni*).

He gives them away, like robes, to those elder monks who have long been ordained, who have learned much, who gain little, or who are sick, and he is content to live wherever he may be.

This is his ‘contentment with what is befitting’ in the case of the resting-place (*senāsanaṃ*).

Even the one who does not accept even a lodging that he has obtained, reflecting that "a superior lodging is a place of heedlessness; drowsiness overtakes one who is sitting there, and sensual thoughts arise in one who is overcome by sleep when one wakes up again".

Having rejected that, he is content to live in the open air, at the foot of a tree (*abbhokāsarukkhamūlādīsu*), and so on.

This is his ‘contentment with what is befitting’ in the case of the lodging.

Here again a *bhikkhu* obtains medicine (*bhesajjaṃ*), and whether it is coarse (*lūkhaṃ*) or superior (*paṇītaṃ*), he is satisfied with whatever he obtains, wishing for no other, and he does not use any other even if he gets it:

this is his ‘contentment with what one gets’ in the case of the requisite of medicine (*gilānapaccaye*).

On the other hand, he may get molasses (*phāṇitaṃ*) when he is in need of oil (*telena*).

Then he is quite content to give that to a *bhikkhu* who is in communion, and after taking oil (*telaṃ*) at his hands and seeking out something else, he is content to make up a medicine.

This is his ‘contentment with one’s own strength’ in the case of the requisite of medicine (*gilānapaccaye*).

Another, greatly meritorious, obtains much superior medicine (*paṇītabhesajjaṃ*), such as oil, honey, molasses, and so on (*telamadhuphāṇitādipaṇītabhesajjaṃ*).

He gives it away, like robes, to those elder monks who have long been ordained, who have learned much, who gain little, or who are sick, and he is content to live using whatever they give him in return.

On the other hand, if someone places a myrobalan fruit preserved in urine (*muttaharīṭakaṃ*) in one bowl and the four sweets (*catumadhuraṃ*) in another, saying, “Take whichever you want, *bhante*,” and if his illness subsides by means of any one of them, then, thinking that only the myrobalan fruit preserved in urine (*muttaharīṭakaṃ*) is praised by the Buddhas, he rejects the four sweets (*catumadhuraṃ*) and is exceedingly content to make medicine only with the myrobalan fruit preserved in urine (*muttaharīṭakeneva*).

This is his ‘contentment with what is befitting’ in the case of the requisite of medicine (*gilānapaccaye*).
Furthermore, a *bhikkhu* endowed with this twelvefold "contentment with requisites of any kind" may make use of eight requisites: three robes (*cīvara*), an almsbowl (*patta*), a knife for cutting toothwood (*dantakaṭṭhacchedanavāsi*), a needle (*sūci*), a waistband (*kāyabandhanaṃ*), and a water-strainer (*parissāvana*).

It has also been said: all these have the purpose of "protecting one's body" (*kāyaparਿਹārīka*) and "sustaining one's belly" (*kucchiparihārika*).

How so? If, when one travels about, one wears the three robes, one sustains and protects the body; thus these are for protecting the body (*kāyaparਿਹārīkaṃ hoti*).

If, when drinking, one first strains the water with a corner of a robe (*cīvarakaṇṇena*), or uses a robe to accept fruits to be eaten, one sustains and protects the belly; thus these are for sustaining the belly (*kucchiparihārikaṃ hoti*).

The almsbowl (*patto*) is for protecting the body (*kāyaparਿਹārīka*) if one uses it to draw water when bathing or making plaster for one’s hut.

It is for sustaining the belly (*kucchiparihāriko*) when one uses it to receive food at meal time.

The knife (*vāsi*) is for protecting the body (*kāyaparਿਹārīka*) if one uses it to cut toothwood or to smoothen the legs and surface of one’s bed and chair or the poles of a tent.

It is for sustaining the belly (*kucchiparihārika*) if one uses it to cut sugarcane or to open a coconut, etc. (*ucchuchedananāḷikerāditacchanakāle*).

The needle (*sūci*) is for protecting the body (*kāyaparਿਹārīka*) when one uses it to sew robes.

It is for sustaining the belly (*kucchiparihārika*) if, at the time of eating, one uses it to pick up a piece of fruit or cake.

The waistband (*kāyabandhanaṃ*) is for protecting the body (*kāyaparਿਹārīkaṃ*) when one wears it while travelling.

It is for sustaining the belly (*kucchiparihārikaṃ*) if one binds sugarcane etc. (*ucchuādīni*) when accepting it.

The water-strainer (*parissāvana*) is for protecting the body (*kāyaparਿਹārīka*) when one strains water with it at the time of bathing or making plaster for one’s dwelling.

It is for sustaining the belly (*kucchiparihāriyaṃ*) when one uses it to strain drinking water (*pānīyaṃ*) or to accept sesame seeds, rice grains, or honey-tree fruits while eating.

This is the limit of requisites for one using eight requisites (*aṭṭhaparikkhārika*).

But for one using nine requisites (*navaparikkhārika*), when he stays in a bedroom, a bedspread situated there or a key is allowed.

For one using ten requisites (*dasaparikkhārika*), a sitting couch or a piece of leather is allowed.

For one using eleven requisites (*ekādasaparikkhārika*), a walking stick or an oil tube is allowed.

For one using twelve requisites (*dvādasaparikkhārika*), an umbrella or a pair of sandals is allowed.

It should not be said that, of these *bhikkhus*, only the one who uses eight requisites (*aṭṭhaparikkhārika*) is content, and that the others are not content, have many desires (*mahiccha*), and are difficult to support (*mahābhārā*).

For they, too, are content, have few desires (*appiccha*), are easy to support (*subhara*), and light in their mode of living (*sallahukavutti*).

However, the Exalted One did not explain this discourse by way of those *bhikkhus*; he explained it by way of the one who uses eight requisites (*aṭṭhaparikkhārika*).

For this one wraps up his small knife and needle in his water strainer, puts the strainer inside his almsbowl, hangs the bowl over his shoulder, clothes himself in his three robes and waistband, and sets out happily wherever he wishes.

There is nothing at all he has to turn back for and take.

Thus, showing such a *bhikkhu*'s light mode of living (*sallahukavuttitaṃ*), the Exalted One says: "A *bhikkhu* is content with robes to protect his body and almsfood to sustain his belly," etc.

There, "with robes to protect his body" means with only as much as is needed to protect his body.

"To sustain his belly" means with only as much as is needed to sustain his belly.

He sets out taking only along with him— He goes taking all his minimal eight requisites, carrying them on his body.

He has no attachment or bondage to "my monastery (*vihāra*), my cell (*pariveṇaṃ*), my attendant (*upaṭṭhāko*)."

He is like an arrow released from the bow or like an elephant in rut which has left the herd. Using whatever dwelling he likes—a jungle thicket (*vanasaṇḍaṃ*), the foot of a tree (*rukkhamūlaṃ*), a wooded slope (*vanapabbhāraṃ*)—he stands alone and sits alone.

In all postures, he is alone, without a companion.

Thus he conducts himself in a manner similar to that of the rhinoceros, as explained.

Now, to illustrate that meaning by means of a simile, [the text] begins "Just as...".

There, a bird (*pakkhī*) is a creature with wings (*pakkhayutto*), a bird (*sakuṇo*).

"It flies" means it soars up.

This, in brief, is the meaning: Having learned that in such and such a region there is a tree with ripened fruits, birds (*sakuṇā*) come from various directions and eat those fruits, picking and tearing at them with their claws, wings, and beaks.

It never occurs to them, "This is for today's meal, that is for tomorrow's meal."

When the fruits are finished they do not set up a guard around that tree, nor do they set up a feather, claw mark, or beak mark there.

Rather, they lose their concern for that tree, and each bird goes in whatever direction it wishes, flying off with its wings as its only burden.
In the same way, this *bhikṣu* (monk) sets out wherever he wishes, without attachment (*nissaṅga*) and without concern (*nirapekṣa*).
Hence it is said: “He sets out taking only along with him.”

mula_pali: 216. ‘‘So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ. So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mula_english:
“Endowed with this noble aggregate of moral discipline (śīlakkhandha), this noble restraint over the senses (indriyasaṃvara), this noble mindfulness and clear comprehension (satisampajañña), and this noble contentment (santuṭṭhi), he resorts to a secluded dwelling—a forest (araññaṃ), the foot of a tree (rukkhamūlaṃ), a mountain (pabbataṃ), a glen (kandaraṃ), a hillside cave (giriguhaṃ), a cremation ground (susānaṃ), a jungle grove (vanapatthaṃ), the open air (abbhokāsaṃ), a heap of straw (palālapuñjaṃ).

Then, having eaten after his return from the alms-round (piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto), he sits down cross-legged (pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā), holding his body erect (ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya), and establishes mindfulness before him (parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā).
commentary_pali: 216.Soiminā cātiādinā kiṃ dasseti? Araññavāsassa paccayasampattiṃ dasseti. Yassa hi ime cattāro paccayā natthi, tassa araññavāso na ijjhati. Tiracchānagatehi vā vanacarakehi vā saddhiṃ vattabbataṃ āpajjati. Araññe adhivatthā devatā – ‘‘kiṃ  evarūpassa pāpabhikkhuno araññavāsenā’’ti bheravasaddaṃ sāventi, hatthehi sīsaṃ paharitvā palāyanākāraṃ karonti. ‘‘Asuko bhikkhu araññaṃ pavisitvā idañcidañca pāpakammaṃ akāsī’’ti ayaso pattharati. Yassa panete cattāro paccayā atthi, tassa araññavāso ijjhati. So hi attano sīlaṃ paccavekkhanto kiñci kāḷakaṃ vā tilakaṃ vā apassanto pītiṃ uppādetvā taṃ khayavayato sammasanto ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati. Araññe adhivatthā devatā attamanā vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanti. Itissa udake pakkhittatelabindu viya yaso vitthāriko hoti. Tattha vivittanti suññaṃ, appasaddaṃ, appanigghosanti attho. Etadeva hi sandhāya vibhaṅge – ‘‘vivittanti santike cepi senāsanaṃ hoti, tañca anākiṇṇaṃ gahaṭṭhehi pabbajitehi. Tena taṃ vivitta’’nti vuttaṃ. Seti ceva āsati ca etthāti senāsanaṃ mañcapīṭhādīnametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tenāha – ‘‘senāsananti mañcopi senāsanaṃ , pīṭhampi, bhisipi, bimbohanampi, vihāropi, aḍḍhayogopi, pāsādopi, hammiyampi, guhāpi, aṭṭopi, māḷopi leṇampi, veḷugumbopi, rukkhamūlampi, maṇḍapopi, senāsanaṃ, yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamanti, sabbametaṃ senāsana’’nti (vibha. 527). Api ca – ‘‘vihāro aḍḍhayogo pāsādo hammiyaṃ guhā’’ti idaṃ vihārasenāsanaṃ nāma. ‘‘Mañco pīṭhaṃ bhisi bimbohana’’nti idaṃ mañcapīṭhasenāsanaṃ nāma. ‘‘Cimilikā cammakhaṇḍo tiṇasanthāro paṇṇasanthāro’’ti idaṃ santhatasenāsanaṃ nāma. ‘‘Yattha vā pana bhikkhū paṭikkamantī’’ti idaṃ okāsasenāsanaṃ nāmāti. Evaṃ catubbidhaṃ senāsanaṃ hoti, taṃ sabbaṃ senāsanaggahaṇena saṅgahitameva. Idha panassa sakuṇasadisassa cātuddisassa bhikkhuno anucchavikasenāsanaṃ dassento araññaṃ rukkhamūlantiādimāha. Tattha araññanti nikkhamitvā  bahi indakhīlā sabbametaṃ araññanti. Idaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ vasena āgataṃ. ‘‘Āraññakaṃ nāma senāsanaṃ pañcadhanusatikaṃ pacchima’’nti (pārā. 654) idaṃ pana imassa bhikkhuno anurūpaṃ. Tassa lakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge dhutaṅganiddese vuttaṃ. Rukkhamūlanti yaṃ kiñci sandacchāyaṃ vivittarukkhamūlaṃ. Pabbatanti selaṃ. Tattha hi udakasoṇḍīsu udakakiccaṃ katvā sītāya rukkhacchāyāya nisinnassa nānādisāsu khāyamānāsu sītena vātena bījiyamānassa cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Kandaranti kaṃ vuccati udakaṃ, tena dāritaṃ, udakena bhinnaṃ pabbatapadesaṃ. Yaṃ nadītumbantipi, nadīkuñjantipi  vadanti. Tattha hi rajatapaṭṭasadisā vālikā hoti, matthake maṇivitānaṃ viya vanagahaṇaṃ, maṇikhandhasadisaṃ udakaṃ sandati. Evarūpaṃ kandaraṃ oruyha pānīyaṃ pivitvā gattāni sītāni katvā vālikaṃ ussāpetvā  paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ paññapetvā nisinnassa samaṇadhammaṃ karoto cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Giriguhanti dvinnaṃ pabbatānaṃ antare, ekasmiṃyeva vā umaggasadisaṃ mahāvivaraṃ susānalakkhaṇaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Vanapatthanti gāmantaṃ atikkamitvā manussānaṃ anupacāraṭṭhānaṃ, yattha na kasanti na vapanti, tenevāha – ‘‘vanapatthanti dūrānametaṃ senāsanānaṃ adhivacana’’ntiādi. Abbhokāsanti acchannaṃ. Ākaṅkhamāno panettha cīvarakuṭiṃ katvā vasati. Palālapuñjanti palālarāsi. Mahāpalālapuñjato hi palālaṃ nikkaḍḍhitvā pabbhāraleṇasadise ālaye karonti, gacchagumbhādīnampi upari palālaṃ pakkhipitvā heṭṭhā nisinnā samaṇadhammaṃ karonti. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Pacchābhattanti bhattassa pacchato. Piṇḍapātapaṭikkantoti piṇḍapātapariyesanato paṭikkanto. Pallaṅkanti samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ. Ābhujitvāti bandhitvā. Ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyāti uparimaṃ sarīraṃ ujuṃ ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṭṭhike koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādetvā. Evañhi nisinnassa cammamaṃsanhārūni na paṇamanti. Athassa yā tesaṃ paṇamanapaccayā khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjeyyuṃ, tā nuppajjanti. Tāsu anuppajjamānāsu cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ na paripatati, vuḍḍhiṃ phātiṃ vepullaṃ upagacchati. Parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ satiṃ ṭhapayitvā. Mukhasamīpe  vā katvāti attho. Teneva vibhaṅge vuttaṃ – ‘‘ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti sūpaṭṭhitā nāsikagge  vā mukhanimitte vā, tena vuccati parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā’’ti (vibha. 537). Athavā parīti pariggahaṭṭho. Mukhanti niyyānaṭṭho. Satīti upaṭṭhānaṭṭho. Tena vuccati – ‘‘parimukhaṃ sati’’nti. Evaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayenapettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepo – ‘‘pariggahitaniyyānasatiṃ katvā’’ti.
commentary_english:
216. What does *soiminā cātiādinā* indicate? It indicates the accomplishment of the requisites for forest dwelling (*araññavāsa*).

For one who lacks these four requisites, his forest life does not succeed.

He would fall under the same category as animals or forest wanderers.

The deities residing in the forest would think, “What is the use of living in the forest for such an evil *bhikkhu*?” They would make frightful sounds, strike him on the head with their hands, and make him flee.

A bad reputation would also spread about concerning him: “Such and such a *bhikkhu*, having entered the forest, did this and that evil deed.”

But one who has achieved these four requisites succeeds in his forest life.

Reviewing his own moral discipline (*sīla*), he does not see any stain or blemish, and he arouses rapture (*pīti*). Exploring that rapture by way of its destruction and falling away, he enters upon the plane of the noble ones (*ariyabhūmi*).

The deities residing in the forest are satisfied and speak praise of him.

His fame spreads widely, like a drop of oil put onto water.

Therein, “secluded” (*vivitta*) means empty (*śūnya*), that is, quiet (*appasadda*) and noiseless (*appanigghosa*).

It is referring to this that it is said in the *Vibhaṅga*: “Secluded (*vivitta*)”: even if a dwelling (*senāsana*) is nearby, if it is not crowded with householders (*gahaṭṭha*) and monks (*pabbajita*),

then it is secluded.

A dwelling (*senāsana*) is a place where one lies down and sits; it is a designation for bed, chair and so on (*mañcapīṭhādīnam*).

Thus it is said: “'Dwelling (*senāsana*)': a bed (*mañca*) is a dwelling, a chair (*pīṭha*) is a dwelling, a cushion (*bhisi*), a pillow (*bimbohana*), a dwelling place (*vihāra*), a building with a sloping roof (*aḍḍhayoga*), a rectangular building with a gabled roof (*pāsāda*), a flat-roofed building (*hammiya*), a natural cave (*guhā*), a multi-storeyed mansion (*aṭṭa*), a circular house (*māḷa*), a rock cave (*leṇa*), a bamboo thicket (*veḷugumba*), the foot of a tree (*rukkhamūla*), a pavilion (*maṇḍapa*)— these are also dwellings. Or any place to which *bhikkhus* return, all this is a dwelling".

Moreover, dwellings become fourfold as follows: A dwelling place (*vihāra*), a building with a sloping roof (*aḍḍhayoga*), a rectangular building with a gabled roof (*pāsāda*), a flat-roofed building (*hammiya*), a natural cave (*guhā*)—these are called dwelling-place dwellings.

A bed (*mañca*), a chair (*pīṭha*), a cushion (*bhisi*), a pillow (*bimbohana*)— these are called bed-and-chair dwellings.

A rug (*cimilika*), a piece of leather (*cammakhaṇḍa*), a straw mat (*tiṇasanthāra*), a mat of leaves (*paṇṇasanthāra*)—these are called spread dwellings.

“Or any place to which *bhikkhus* return”—this is called a living space dwelling.

Thus dwelling (*senāsana*) is fourfold; all that is included by the term dwelling (*senāsanaggahaṇena*).

Here, however, the Buddha is showing the dwelling appropriate for a *bhikkhu* who is similar to a bird, at home in all four quarters of the world; then he says “he resorts to a forest (*arañña*), the foot of a tree (*rukkhamūla*) and so on.”

Forest (*arañña*): having gone out beyond the boundary post (*indakhīlā*), all that is forest.

\- in the case of *bhikkhunis*,

but for the *bhikkhu* described here, it is fitting for his forest dwelling to be at least five hundred bow-lengths distant.

Its characteristics are explained in the *Visuddhimagga*, in the “Description of the Ascetic Practices”.

“The foot of a tree (*rukkhamūla*)” is the foot of any secluded tree (*vivittarukkhamūla*) having cool shade (*sandacchāyaṃ*).

“A mountain (*pabbata*)” is a rock mountain (*selaṃ*).

For when one has bathed and drunk in a rock tank and sits down in the cool shade of a tree, fanned by a cool breeze, the various quarters all visible, the mind (*citta*) becomes one-pointed (*ekagga*).

“A glen (*kandara*)” is a mountainous region (*pabbatapadesaṃ*) divided by water; what is called water (*udakaṃ*) is divided (*dāritaṃ*) by it, divided (*bhinnaṃ*) by water (*udakena*).

some say it is a place where rivers rush and roar.

For there the sand is like silver foil; the jungle thicket overhead is like a jewel-studded canopy, and the water flows like a mass of jewels.

Having entered such a glen, drunk and cooled one’s limbs, heaped up sand and prepared a seat from rag-robes (*paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ*), when one sits down and does the work of a recluse (*samaṇadhammaṃ*), the mind (*citta*) becomes one-pointed (*ekaggaṃ*).

“A hillside cave (*giriguha*)” is a large fissure (*mahāvivaraṃ*) between two mountains or in a single mountain similar to a tunnel (*umaggasadisaṃ*). The characteristics of a cremation ground (*susānalakkhaṇaṃ*) are explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.

“A jungle grove (*vanapattha*)” is a place beyond the outskirts of a village, a place not frequented by men, where they do not sow and plough. Thence it is said: “'A jungle grove (*vanapattha*)': this is a designation for remote dwellings (*senāsanānaṃ*).”

“The open air (*abbhokāsa*)”: an uncovered place (*acchannaṃ*).

One wishing to may make a tent and live here.

“A heap of straw (*palālapuñja*)”: a pile of straw (*palālarāsi*).

For having collected straw (*palālaṃ*) from a large heap of straw (*mahāpalālapuñjato*), they build an abode similar to a hillside cave (*pabbhāraleṇasadise ālaye*). They also throw straw (*palālaṃ*) over bushes and brush, etc., sit beneath it, and do the work of a recluse (*samaṇadhammaṃ*).
This was said with reference to him (taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ).
"After the meal" means after the food.
"Returned from alms-seeking" means returned from the search for alms.
"Crosswise" (pallaṅkaṃ) means the sitting position with the thighs fully locked (samantato ūrubaddhāsanaṃ).
Folded: having locked (ābhujitvā ti bandhitvā).
"Having straightened the body" (ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya) means setting the upper body straight, aligning the eighteen vertebrae end to end (uparimaṃ sarīraṃ ujuṃ ṭhapetvā aṭṭhārasa piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṭṭhike koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādetvā).
For when one sits in such a way, the skin, flesh, and sinews do not bend forward (evañhi nisinnassa cammamaṃsañhārūni na paṇamanti).
And so the feelings that would arise moment by moment because of their being bent forward do not arise (athassa yā tesaṃ paṇamanapaccayā khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjeyyuṃ, tā nuppajjanti).
As those feelings do not arise, the mind becomes one-pointed, the meditation subject does not collapse, [but] attains to growth, success, and maturity (tāsu anuppajjamānāsu cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ na paripatati, vuḍḍhiṃ phātiṃ vepullaṃ upagacchati).
"Having established mindfulness in front of him" (parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā) means having placed mindfulness facing the meditation subject (kammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃ satiṃ ṭhapayitvā).
Or, having made it near the mouth, is the meaning (mukhasamīpe vā katvāti attho).
Thus it is said in the *Vibhaṅga*: “This mindfulness is set up, set up well, at the tip of the nose or at the sign of the mouth, hence it is said 'having established mindfulness in front of him'" (teneva vibhaṅge vuttaṃ – "ayaṃ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti sūpaṭṭhitā nāsikagge vā mukhanimitte vā, tena vuccati parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā"ti).
Or, *pari* has the sense of embracing (*pariggahaṭṭho*).
*Mukhaṃ* has the sense of outlet (*niyyānaṭṭho*).
*Sati* has the sense of establishment (*upaṭṭhānaṭṭho*).
Therefore, it is said: "Mindfulness in front" (tena vuccati – "parimukhaṃ sati"nti).
Thus, in the *Paṭisambhidā*, the meaning should be understood in the manner that has been stated (evaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayenapettha attho daṭṭhabbo).
Here, in brief: "Having made mindfulness the grasping of the outlet" (tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepo – "pariggahitaniyyānasatiṃ katvā"ti).

mula_pali: 217. ‘‘So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti. Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto  viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti. Thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī, sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti. Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati, ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti. Vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati, akathaṃkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mula_english:
217. Abandoning covetousness ( *abhijjhaṃ*) for the world, he dwells with a mind free from covetousness; he purifies his mind from covetousness (*abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti*).

Abandoning ill will and hatred (*byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya*), he abides with a mind free from ill will, compassionate for the welfare of all living beings; he purifies his mind from ill will and hatred (*byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti*).

Abandoning sloth and torpor (*thinamiddhaṃ pahāya*), he abides free from sloth and torpor, percipient of light (*ālokasaññī*), mindful and fully aware; he purifies his mind from sloth and torpor (*thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti*).

Abandoning restlessness and remorse (*uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya*), he abides unagitated, with a mind inwardly peaceful; he purifies his mind from restlessness and remorse (*uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti*).

Abandoning doubt (*vicikicchaṃ pahāya*), he abides having gone beyond doubt, unperplexed about wholesome states; he purifies his mind from doubt (*vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti*).
commentary_pali: 217.Abhijjhaṃ loketi ettha lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena pañcupādānakkhandhā loko, tasmā pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu rāgaṃ pahāya kāmacchandaṃ vikkhambhetvāti ayametthattho. Vigatābhijjhenāti vikkhambhanavasena pahīnattā vigatābhijjhena, na cakkhuviññāṇasadisenāti attho. Abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodhetīti abhijjhāto cittaṃ parimoceti. Yathā taṃ sā muñcati ceva, muñcitvā ca na puna gaṇhati, evaṃ karotīti attho. Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāyātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Byāpajjati iminā cittaṃ pūtikummāsādayo viya purimapakatiṃ vijahatīti byāpādo. Vikārāpattiyā padussati, paraṃ vā padūseti vināsetīti padoso. Ubhayametaṃ kodhassevādhivacanaṃ . Thinaṃ cittagelaññaṃ. Middhaṃ cetasikagelaññaṃ, thinañca middhañca thinamiddhaṃ. Ālokasaññīti rattimpi divādiṭṭhālokasañjānanasamatthāya vigatanīvaraṇāya parisuddhāya saññāya samannāgato. Sato sampajānoti satiyā ca ñāṇena ca samannāgato. Idaṃ ubhayaṃ ālokasaññāya upakārattā vuttaṃ. Uddhaccañca kukkuccañca uddhaccakukkuccaṃ. Tiṇṇavicikicchoti vicikicchaṃ taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhito. ‘‘Kathamidaṃ kathamida’’nti evaṃ nappavattatīti akathaṃkathī. Kusalesu dhammesūti anavajjesu dhammesu. ‘‘Ime nu kho kusalā kathamime kusalā’’ti evaṃ na vicikicchati. Na kaṅkhatīti attho. Ayamettha  saṅkhepo. Imesu pana nīvaraṇesu vacanatthalakkhaṇādibhedato yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
217.

"The world through covetousness": here, the five aggregates of clinging ( *pañcupādānakkhandhā*) are the world, due to their nature of decay and disintegration. Therefore, the meaning here is: having abandoned lust ( *rāga*) for the five aggregates of clinging, having suppressed sensual desire (*kāmacchanda*).

“He dwells with a mind free from covetousness” (*vigatābhijjhena*): with a mind free from covetousness through its being abandoned by way of suppression, not like eye-consciousness which is naturally devoid of covetousness. This is the meaning.

"He purifies his mind from covetousness" (*abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti*): he releases his mind from covetousness ( *abhijjhā*); he liberates the mind (*cittaṃ parimoceti*).

He acts in such a way that he lets go of it and does not grasp it again. This is the meaning.

The same method applies in the cases of abandoning ill-will and hatred (*byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya*), and so forth.

“Ill will” (*byāpādo*): the mind (*cittaṃ*) is made ill by this, and abandons its original nature (*purimapakatiṃ vijahati*), like spoiled gruel.

“Hatred” (*padoso*): one is defiled by undergoing deformation ( *vikārāpattiyā padussati*), or one defiles and destroys others ( *paraṃ vā padūseti vināseti*).

Both these words are designations for anger ( *kodha*).

“Dullness” (*thinaṃ*) is sickness of the mind (*cittagelaññaṃ*).

“Drowsiness” (*middhaṃ*) is sickness of mental factors (*cetasikagelaññaṃ*); together dullness (*thinañca*) and drowsiness (*middhañca*) are called "dullness and drowsiness" (*thinamiddhaṃ*).

“Perceiving light” (*ālokasaññī*): he is endowed with a purified perception (*parisuddhāya saññāya samannāgato*) free from the hindrances (*vigatanīvaraṇāya*), capable of perceiving, whether by day or by night, a light previously seen (*divādiṭṭhālokasañjānanasamatthāya*).

“Mindful and clearly comprehending” (*sato sampajānoti*): he is endowed with mindfulness ( *satiyā*) and knowledge ( *ñāṇena*).

These two are mentioned because they are both helpful to the perception of light (*ālokasaññāya upakārattā vuttaṃ*).

Excitement (*uddhaccañca*) and remorse (*kukkuccañca*) are excitement and remorse (*uddhaccakukkuccaṃ*).

He has “passed beyond doubt” (*tiṇṇavicikiccho*) in that he lives having crossed over and transcended doubt (*vicikicchaṃ taritvā atikkamitvā ṭhito*).

He does not waver, thinking, "How is this? How is this?" (*kathamidaṃ kathamidaṃ*). Therefore he is free from doubt (*akathaṃkathī*).

He is “unperplexed about wholesome states” (*kusalesu dhammesu*) because, in regard to blameless states ( *anavajjesu dhammesu*),

he does not doubt: “Are these wholesome? How is it that these are wholesome?" (*ime nu kho kusalā kathamime kusalā*)

The meaning is, he does not waver (*na kaṅkhati*).

This is a brief explanation (*ayamettha saṅkhepo*).

Whatever has to be said concerning these five hindrances (*imesu pana nīvaraṇesu*)—the analysis of their word derivations, characteristics, etc.—all has been said in the *Visuddhimagga*.

mula_pali: 218. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , mahārāja, puriso iṇaṃ ādāya kammante payojeyya. Tassa te kammantā samijjheyyuṃ. So yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni, tāni ca byantiṃ kareyya byantīkareyya (sī. syā. kaṃ.), siyā cassa uttariṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ dārabharaṇāya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe iṇaṃ ādāya kammante  payojesiṃ. Tassa  me te kammantā samijjhiṃsu. Sohaṃ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni, tāni ca byantiṃ akāsiṃ, atthi ca me uttariṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ dārabharaṇāyā’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english: 218. "Just as, great king, a man might take a loan (*iṇa*) and apply it to business (*kammanta*), and his business were to succeed, so that he might pay off his old debts (*iṇamūla*) and have enough extra left over to maintain a wife (*dārabharaṇa*). He might think: 'Before, I developed my business by borrowing. My businesses have prospered. I have paid back all my old debts, and I have enough extra left over to maintain a wife.' And as a result, he would obtain joy (*prāmojja*) and experience gladness (*saumanassa*).
commentary_pali: 218. Yā panāyaṃ seyyathāpi mahārājāti upamā vuttā. Tattha iṇaṃ ādāyāti vaḍḍhiyā dhanaṃ gahetvā. Byantiṃ kareyyāti vigatantaṃ kareyya , yathā tesaṃ kākaṇikamattopi pariyanto nāma nāvasissati, evaṃ kareyya; sabbaso paṭiniyyāteyyāti attho. Tato nidānanti āṇaṇyanidānaṃ. So hi ‘‘aṇaṇomhī’’ti āvajjanto balavapāmojjaṃ labhati, somanassaṃ adhigacchati, tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassa’’nti.
commentary_english:
218.
Now, the comparison that was spoken, "just as a great king."
There, taking a debt means taking wealth with increase.
Making an end means making an absence of end, as if even the measure of a *kākaṇika* of theirs will not remain as a limit; thus he should do; the meaning is: he should completely deliver it back.
From that cause means the cause of being debtless.
For he, recollecting "I am debtless," obtains strong joy, he attains gladness; therefore it was said: "He might obtain joy, he might attain gladness."

mula_pali: 219. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā. So aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā mucceyya; bhattaṃ cassa chādeyya, siyā cassa kāye balamattā. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṃ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi na cassa me (ka.) kāye balamattā. Somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto; bhattañca me chādeti, atthi ca me kāye balamattā’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
219. Just as, great king, a man might be sick (*ābādhiko*), suffering (*dukkhito*), and gravely ill (*bāḷhagilāno*), such that he could not enjoy his food, and his body would have no strength (*bālamattā*).

Later, he might recover from that sickness (*ābādhā*), enjoy his food, and his body would regain strength (*bālamattā*).

He would then think, “Before, I was sick (*ābādhiko*), suffering (*dukkhito*), and gravely ill (*bāḷhagilāno*), such that I could not enjoy my food, and my body had no strength (*bālamattā*).”

"But now, I am free from that sickness (*ābādhā*), I enjoy my food, and there is strength (*bālamattā*) in my body."

From that cause, he would obtain joy (*pāmojjaṃ*), he would experience happiness (*somanassaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 219. Visabhāgavedanuppattiyā kakaceneva catuiriyāpathaṃ chindanto ābādhatīti ābādho, svāssa atthīti ābādhiko. Taṃ samuṭṭhānena dukkhena dukkhito. Adhimattagilānoti bāḷhagilāno. Nacchādeyyāti adhimattabyādhiparetatāya na rucceyya. Balamattāti balameva, balañcassa kāye na bhaveyyāti attho. Tatonidānanti ārogyanidānaṃ. Tassa hi – ‘‘arogomhī’’ti āvajjayato tadubhayaṃ hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassa’’nti.
commentary_english:
219. Because it afflicts by cutting off the four postures with what is like a saw, due to the arising of dissimilar feelings, it is affliction (ābādha). One who has that is afflicted (ābādhiko).

He is made miserable by the pain (dukkha) that arises from that.

"Adhimattagilāno" means severely ill (bāḷhagilāno).

"Nacchādeyya" means he would not approve due to being overcome by severe illness (adhimattabyādhiparetatāya na rucceyya).

"Balamattā" means just strength (balameva), the meaning (attho) is that strength would not exist in his body (kāye na bhaveyya).

"Tatonidānaṃ" means the cause of health (ārogyanidānaṃ).

For him, both of those things occur when reflecting, "I am healthy" (‘‘arogomhī’’ti āvajjayato tadubhayaṃ hoti).

Therefore it was said, "He would obtain joy (pāmojjaṃ), he would attain gladness (somanassaṃ)" (‘‘labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassa’’nti).

mula_pali: 220. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso bandhanāgāre baddho assa. So aparena samayena tamhā bandhanāgārā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena ubbayena (sī. ka.), na cassa kiñci bhogānaṃ vayo. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe bandhanāgāre baddho ahosiṃ, somhi etarahi tamhā bandhanāgārā mutto  sotthinā abbhayena. Natthi  ca me kiñci bhogānaṃ vayo’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
220. Just as, great king, a man might be bound in a prison (bandhanāgāre baddho assa).

After some time, he would be released from that prison, safe and secure (bandhanāgārā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena), without any loss of his possessions (bhogānaṃ vayo).

He might think: “Before this, I was imprisoned in a prison (bandhanāgāre baddho ahosiṃ), but now I am released from that prison, safe and secure (tamhā bandhanāgārā mutto sotthinā abbhayena).

There is no loss to my possessions (natthi ca me kiñci bhogānaṃ vayo).”

And as a result, he would become glad (pāmojjaṃ) and experience joy (somanassaṃ).
commentary_pali: 220.Na cassa kiñci bhogānaṃ vayoti kākaṇikamattampi bhogānaṃ vayo na bhaveyya. Tatonidānanti bandhanāmokkhanidānaṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayeneva sabbapadesu yojetabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
220. Moreover, there would not be any loss to his possessions, not even the value of a *kākaṇikā*.

*Tatonidānanti* means the cause of release from bondage.

The rest should be applied to all instances in the manner previously stated.

mula_pali: 221. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso dāso assa anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṃgamo. So aparena samayena tamhā dāsabyā mucceyya attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṃgamo. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe dāso ahosiṃ anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṃgamo. Somhi etarahi tamhā dāsabyā mutto attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṃgamo’ti. So tatonidānaṃ  labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
Just as, great king, a man might be a slave (*dāsa*), not his own master (*anattādhīna*), dependent on another (*parādhīna*), unable to go where he liked.

After some time he would be released from that slavery, become self-dependent (*attādhīna*), independent of others (*aparādhīna*), a free man (*bhujissa*) able to go where he wants.

He might think: “Before this I was a slave (*dāsa*), not self-dependent (*anattādhīna*), dependent on another (*parādhīna*), unable to go where I liked.

Now, at this time, I am freed from that slavery, self-dependent (*attādhīna*), independent of others (*aparādhīna*), a free man (*bhujissa*) able to go where I want.”

And as a result, he would gain joy (*prāmojja*) and experience gladness (*saumanasya*).
commentary_pali: 221-222.Anattādhīnoti na attani adhīno, attano ruciyā kiñci kātuṃ na labhati. Parādhīnoti paresu adhīno parasseva ruciyā vattati. Na yena kāmaṃ gamoti yena disābhāgenassa gantukāmatā hoti, icchā uppajjati gamanāya, tena gantuṃ na labhati. Dāsabyāti  dāsabhāvā. Bhujissoti attano santako. Tatonidānanti bhujissanidānaṃ. Kantāraddhānamagganti  kantāraṃ addhānamaggaṃ, nirudakaṃ dīghamagganti attho. Tatonidānanti khemantabhūminidānaṃ.
commentary_english:
221-222.
*Anattādhīna* means not dependent on the self ( *attani adhīno*); one cannot do anything according to one's own inclination (*attano ruciyā kiñci kātuṃ na labhati*).

*Parādhīna* means dependent on others (*paresu adhīno*); one behaves according to the inclination of another (*parasseva ruciyā vattati*).

"One cannot go as one pleases" means that whichever direction one wishes to go (*yena disābhāgenassa gantukāmatā hoti*), the desire arises to go (*icchā uppajjati gamanāya*), one is not able to go there (*tena gantuṃ na labhati*).

*Dāsabyā* means the state of being a slave (*dāsabhāvā*).

*Bhujisso* means belonging to oneself (*attano santako*).

*Tatonidāna* means because of being a free man (*bhujissanidānaṃ*).

*Kantāraddhānamagga* means a desert road (*kantāraṃ addhānamaggaṃ*), a waterless, long road (*nirudakaṃ dīghamagganti attho*).

*Tatonidāna* means because of a safe and secure place (*khemantabhūminidānaṃ*).

mula_pali: 222. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṃ paṭipajjeyya dubbhikkhaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ. So aparena samayena taṃ kantāraṃ nitthareyya sotthinā, gāmantaṃ anupāpuṇeyya khemaṃ appaṭibhayaṃ. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṃ paṭipajjiṃ dubbhikkhaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ. Somhi etarahi taṃ kantāraṃ nitthiṇṇo sotthinā, gāmantaṃ anuppatto khemaṃ appaṭibhaya’nti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english: 222. "Just as, great king, a man with wealth and possessions might set out on a desert road, a journey through a barren land fraught with peril. After some time, he might safely cross that desert and reach the edge of a village, a place of safety, free from danger. He might think, 'Formerly, I, possessing wealth and goods, set out on a desert road, a journey through a barren and perilous land. Now, I have safely crossed that desert and reached the edge of a village, a safe place, free from danger.' And because of that, he would gain joy and experience gladness.
commentary_pali: 221-222.Anattādhīnoti na attani adhīno, attano ruciyā kiñci kātuṃ na labhati. Parādhīnoti paresu adhīno parasseva ruciyā vattati. Na yena kāmaṃ gamoti yena disābhāgenassa gantukāmatā hoti, icchā uppajjati gamanāya, tena gantuṃ na labhati. Dāsabyāti  dāsabhāvā. Bhujissoti attano santako. Tatonidānanti bhujissanidānaṃ. Kantāraddhānamagganti  kantāraṃ addhānamaggaṃ, nirudakaṃ dīghamagganti attho. Tatonidānanti khemantabhūminidānaṃ.
commentary_english:
221-222.

*Anattādhīno* means not dependent on oneself ( *attani adhīno*); one cannot do anything according to one's own desire (*attano ruciyā kiñci kātuṃ na labhati*).

*Parādhīno* means dependent on others (*paresu adhīno*); one behaves according to the desire of another (*parasseva ruciyā vattati*).

*Na yena kāmaṃ gamo* means one cannot go as one wishes; one cannot go in the direction in which one desires to go, in which the wish to go arises (*yena disābhāgenassa gantukāmatā hoti, icchā uppajjati gamanāya, tena gantuṃ na labhati*).

*Dāsabyāti* means the state of a slave (*dāsabhāvā*).

*Bhujisso* means belonging to oneself (*attano santako*).

*Tatonidānanti* means having freedom as its cause (*bhujissanidānaṃ*).

*Kantāraddhānamagganti* means a desert road, a long road without water (*kantāraṃ addhānamaggaṃ, nirudakaṃ dīghamagganti attho*).

*Tatonidānanti* means having a safe place as its cause (*khemantabhūminidānaṃ*).

mula_pali: 223. ‘‘Evameva  kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṃ yathā rogaṃ yathā bandhanāgāraṃ yathā dāsabyaṃ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṃ, evaṃ ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
mula_english: "In the same way, great king (*mahārāja*), a *bhikkhu* sees these five hindrances, when unabandoned within himself, as a debt (*iṇaṃ*), as a disease (*rogaṃ*), as a prison (*bandhanāgāraṃ*), as slavery (*dāsabyaṃ*), as a road through a desert (*kantāraddhānamaggaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 223.Ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīneti ettha bhagavā appahīnakāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ iṇasadisaṃ, sesāni rogādisadisāni katvā dasseti. Tatrāyaṃ sadisatā. Yo hi paresaṃ iṇaṃ gahetvā vināseti, so tehi iṇaṃ dehīti vuccamānopi pharusaṃ vuccamānopi bajjhamānopi vadhīyamānopi  kiñci paṭibāhituṃ na sakkoti, sabbaṃ titikkhati. Titikkhākāraṇaṃ hissa taṃ iṇaṃ hoti. Evameva yo yamhi kāmacchandena rajjati, taṇhāsahagatena taṃ vatthuṃ gaṇhati, so tena pharusaṃ vuccamānopi bajjhamānopi vadhīyamānopi sabbaṃ titikkhati, titikkhākāraṇaṃ hissa so kāmacchando hoti, gharasāmikehi vadhīyamānānaṃ itthīnaṃ viyāti, evaṃ iṇaṃ viya kāmacchando daṭṭhabbo. Yathā pana pittarogāturo madhusakkarādīsupi dinnesu pittarogāturatāya tesaṃ rasaṃ na vindati, ‘‘tittakaṃ tittaka’’nti uggiratiyeva. Evameva byāpannacitto hitakāmehi ācariyupajjhāyehi appamattakampi ovadiyamāno ovādaṃ na gaṇhati. ‘‘Ati viya me tumhe upaddavethā’’tiādīni vatvā vibbhamati. Pittarogāturatāya so puriso madhusakkarādīnaṃ viya kodhāturatāya jhānasukhādibhedaṃ sāsanarasaṃ na vindatīti. Evaṃ rogo viya byāpādo daṭṭhabbo. Yathā pana nakkhattadivase bandhanāgāre baddho puriso nakkhattassa neva ādiṃ na majjhaṃ na pariyosānaṃ passati. So dutiyadivase mutto aho hiyyo nakkhattaṃ manāpaṃ, aho naccaṃ, aho gītantiādīni sutvāpi paṭivacanaṃ na deti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Nakkhattassa ananubhūtattā. Evameva  thinamiddhābhibhūto bhikkhu vicittanayepi dhammassavane pavattamāne neva tassa ādiṃ na majjhaṃ na pariyosānaṃ jānāti. Sopi uṭṭhite dhammassavane aho dhammassavanaṃ, aho kāraṇaṃ, aho upamāti dhammassavanassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇamānānaṃ sutvāpi paṭivacanaṃ na deti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Thinamiddhavasena dhammakathāya ananubhūtattā. Evaṃ bandhanāgāraṃ viya thinamiddhaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā pana nakkhattaṃ kīḷantopi dāso – ‘‘idaṃ nāma accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ atthi, sīghaṃ tattha gacchāhi. No ce gacchasi, hatthapādaṃ vā te chindāmi kaṇṇanāsaṃ vā’’ti vutto sīghaṃ gacchatiyeva . Nakkhattassa ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ anubhavituṃ na labhati, kasmā? Parādhīnatāya, evameva vinaye apakataññunā vivekatthāya araññaṃ paviṭṭhenāpi kismiñcideva  antamaso kappiyamaṃsepi akappiyamaṃsasaññāya uppannāya vivekaṃ pahāya sīlavisodhanatthaṃ vinayadharassa santikaṃ gantabbaṃ hoti, vivekasukhaṃ anubhavituṃ na labhati, kasmā? Uddhaccakukkuccābhibhūtatāyāti. Evaṃ dāsabyaṃ viya uddhaccakukkuccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā pana kantāraddhānamaggappaṭipanno puriso corehi manussānaṃ viluttokāsaṃ pahatokāsañca disvā daṇḍakasaddenapi sakuṇasaddenapi ‘‘corā āgatā’’ti ussaṅkitaparisaṅkitova hoti, gacchatipi tiṭṭhatipi nivattatipi, gataṭṭhānato agataṭṭhānameva bahutaraṃ hoti. So kicchena kasirena khemantabhūmiṃ pāpuṇāti vā na vā pāpuṇāti. Evameva yassa aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vicikicchā uppannā hoti, so – ‘‘buddho nu kho, no nu kho buddho’’tiādinā nayena vicikicchanto adhimuccitvā saddhāya gaṇhituṃ na sakkoti. Asakkonto maggaṃ vā phalaṃ vā na pāpuṇātīti. Yathā kantāraddhānamagge – ‘‘corā atthi natthī’’ti punappunaṃ āsappanaparisappanaṃ apariyogāhanaṃ chambhitattaṃ cittassa  uppādento khemantapattiyā antarāyaṃ karoti, evaṃ vicikicchāpi – ‘‘buddho nu kho, na buddho’’tiādinā nayena punappunaṃ āsappanaparisappanaṃ apariyogāhanaṃ chambhitattaṃ cittassa uppādayamānā ariyabhūmippattiyā antarāyaṃ karotīti kantāraddhānamaggo viya vicikicchā daṭṭhabbā.
commentary_english:
223. When these five hindrances are unabandoned, here the Exalted One shows the unabandoned hindrance of sensual desire (*kāmacchanda-nīvaraṇa*) as similar to a debt (*iṇa-sadisaṃ*), and the remaining hindrances as similar to sickness, etc.

The similarity (*sadisatā*) is as follows.

One who has taken a debt (*iṇaṃ*) from others and squandered it cannot defend himself when they tell him to pay back his debt (*iṇaṃ dehi*), speak to him harshly, bind him and beat him; he must endure this all.

His debt (*iṇaṃ*) is the reason he must endure it.

Similarly, if someone becomes excited by sensual desire (*kāmacchanda*) towards someone else and takes that person as an object of a mind associated with craving (*taṇhā-sahagatena*), then he must endure it all when that person—the object of his sensual desire (*kāmacchanda*)—speaks to him harshly, binds him and beats him; his sensual desire (*kāmacchanda*) is the reason he must endure it. An example is the case of women being beaten by the house-owners, their sensual desire being the reason they must endure it. Thus sensual desire (*kāmacchando*) should be regarded as a debt (*iṇaṃ viya*).

One who is afflicted with a bile disease, if he is given such things as honey and sugar, will not enjoy their taste because of his bile disease. He will spit them out thinking they are bitter.

Similarly, if one with a mind of ill will (*byāpannacitto*) is exhorted even slightly by his benevolent preceptor (*ācariya*) or teacher (*upajjhāya*), he will not accept the exhortation.

He will reject it, saying “You oppress me too much! ” and depart.

Just as the man afflicted with a bile disease cannot enjoy the taste of honey and sugar, so one afflicted with anger cannot enjoy the flavor of the Buddha’s dispensation (*sāsana-rasaṃ*), that is, the happiness of *jhāna*, etc.

Thus ill will (*byāpādo*) should be regarded as a sickness (*rogo viya*).

On a festival day a man bound in prison cannot see either the beginning (*ādiṃ*), middle (*majjhaṃ*), or end (*pariyosānaṃ*) of the festival.

If he is released the next day, and he hears, “Oh, there was a delightful festival yesterday! Oh, such dances and songs! ” he cannot give a reply.

Why? Because he did not experience the festival (*nakkhattassa ananubhūtattā*).

Similarly, if a *bhikkhu* is overcome by dullness and drowsiness (*thinamiddhābhibhūto*) when a preaching of the Dhamma (*dhamma-ssavane*) through variegated methods is taking place, he cannot understand its beginning (*ādiṃ*), middle (*majjhaṃ*), or end (*pariyosānaṃ*).

When the preaching is over he hears others speaking praise of it, “Oh, what a preaching of the Dhamma! Such arguments (*kāraṇaṃ*) and similes (*upamā*)! ” but he cannot give a reply.

Why? Because he was overcome by dullness and drowsiness (*thinamiddha-vasena*) and did not enjoy the Dhamma talk (*dhamma-kathāya ananubhūtattā*).

Thus dullness and drowsiness (*thinamiddhaṃ*) should be regarded as confinement in prison (*bandhanāgāraṃ viya*).

A slave, even when playing at a festival (*nakkhattaṃ kīḷanto*), may be told: “There is some urgent task (*accāyikaṃ karaṇīyaṃ*) for you to do. Go there quickly!

If you don’t go, I’ll cut off your hands (*hattha-pādaṃ*) and feet, your ears (*kaṇṇa*) or your nose (*nāsaṃ*)! ” Thus he goes quickly.

He is unable to experience the beginning (*ādi*), middle (*majjha*) and end (*pariyosānaṃ*) of the festival. Why? Because he is subservient (*parādhīnatāya*). Similarly, when one who is unskilled in the *Vinaya* (*apakataññunā*) has entered the forest for seclusion (*vivekatthāya araññaṃ paviṭṭhena*), he may incur some minor disciplinary offense, even perceiving unallowable meat (*akappiya-maṃsa-saññāya*) as allowable (*kappiya-maṃsepi*). Then he has to abandon his seclusion (*vivekaṃ pahāya*) and approach a master of the *Vinaya* (*vinayadharassa santikaṃ*) to purify his moral discipline (*sīla-visodhanatthaṃ*). Thus he does not get to enjoy the happiness of seclusion (*viveka-sukhaṃ*). Why? Because he is overcome by restlessness and worry (*uddhacca-kukkucca-ābhibhūtatāyāti*).

Thus restlessness and worry (*uddhacca-kukkuccaṃ*) should be regarded as slavery (*dāsabyaṃ viya*).

A man traveling along a desert road (*kantāraddhānamaggappaṭipanno*), having seen the opportunity for thieves (*corehi*) to plunder and kill people, becomes anxious and frightened even by the sound of a twig (*daṇḍaka-saddena*) or a bird (*sakuṇa-saddena*), thinking “Thieves have come (*corā āgatā*)!” He goes forward a little, stops because of his anxiety and fear, and turns back thinking, “Who knows what will happen if one travels in such a desert?”. The places in which he stops are more numerous than those in which he walks.

He reaches a place of safety with trouble and difficulty, or he may not reach it at all.

Similarly, if doubt (*vicikicchā*) about the eight cases has arisen in someone, he will go on doubting “Is the *Buddha* an Enlightened One or not? ” and will not be able to resolve and accept it in faith (*saddhāya gaṇhituṃ*).

Not being able to do so, he does not reach the path (*maggaṃ*) or fruit (*phalaṃ*).

Thus, just as the traveler on the desert road (*kantāraddhānamagge*), by doubting whether or not there are thieves (*corā atthi natthī*), repeatedly arouses wavering and vacillation (*āsappana-parisappanaṃ*), lack of conviction and consternation (*chambhitattaṃ*), and creates an obstacle (*antarāyaṃ karoti*) to his reaching a place of safety (*khemanta-pattiyā*), so by doubting whether or not the *Buddha* is an Enlightened One, one repeatedly arouses wavering and vacillation (*āsappana-parisappanaṃ*), lack of conviction and consternation (*chambhitattaṃ*), and creates an obstacle to one’s reaching the plane of the noble ones (*ariya-bhūmi-pattiyā antarāyaṃ karotīti*). Thus doubt (*vicikicchā*) should be regarded as a desert road (*kantāraddhānamaggo viya*).

mula_pali: 224. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, yathā āṇaṇyaṃ yathā ārogyaṃ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṃ yathā bhujissaṃ yathā khemantabhūmiṃ; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
mula_english: 224. Just as, great king, (it is) like being free from debt (*āṇaṇyaṃ*), like being healthy (*ārogyaṃ*), like being released from bondage (*bandhanāmokkhaṃ*), like being free from slavery (*bhujissaṃ*), like being in a safe place (*khemantabhūmiṃ*); in the same way, great king, when a *bhikkhu* sees these five hindrances (*pañca nīvaraṇe*) abandoned within himself (*attani*), he perceives (it thus).
commentary_pali: 224. Idāni – ‘‘seyyathāpi, mahārāja, āṇaṇya’’nti ettha bhagavā pahīnakāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ āṇaṇyasadisaṃ, sesāni ārogyādisadisāni katvā dasseti. Tatrāyaṃ sadisatā, yathā hi puriso iṇaṃ ādāya kammante payojetvā samiddhataṃ patto – ‘‘idaṃ iṇaṃ nāma palibodhamūla’’nti cintetvā savaḍḍhikaṃ iṇaṃ niyyātetvā paṇṇaṃ phālāpeyya. Athassa tato paṭṭhāya neva koci dūtaṃ peseti, na paṇṇaṃ. So iṇasāmike disvāpi sace icchati, āsanā uṭṭhahati, no ce na uṭṭhahati, kasmā? Tehi saddhiṃ nillepatāya alaggatāya. Evameva bhikkhu – ‘‘ayaṃ kāmacchando nāma palibodhamūla’’nti cintetvā cha dhamme bhāvetvā kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ pajahati. Te pana cha dhamme mahāsatipaṭṭhāne vaṇṇayissāma. Tassevaṃ pahīnakāmacchandassa  yathā iṇamuttassa purisassa iṇassāmike disvā neva bhayaṃ na chambhitattaṃ hoti. Evameva paravatthumhi neva saṅgo na baddho hoti. Dibbānipi rūpāni passato kileso na samudācarati. Tasmā bhagavā āṇaṇyamiva kāmacchandappahānaṃ āha. Yathā  pana so pittarogāturo puriso bhesajjakiriyāya taṃ rogaṃ vūpasametvā tato paṭṭhāya madhusakkarādīnaṃ rasaṃ vindati. Evameva bhikkhu ‘‘ayaṃ byāpādo nāma mahā anatthakaro’’ti cha dhamme bhāvetvā byāpādanīvaraṇaṃ pajahati. Sabbanīvaraṇesu cha dhamme mahāsatipaṭṭhāneyeva vaṇṇayissāma. Na kevalañca teyeva, yepi thinamiddhādīnaṃ pahānāya bhāvetabbā, tepi sabbe tattheva vaṇṇayissāma. So evaṃ pahīnabyāpādo yathā pittarogavimutto puriso madhusakkarādīnaṃ rasaṃ sampiyāyamāno paṭisevati, evameva ācārapaṇṇattiādīni  sikkhāpadāni sirasā sampaṭicchitvā sampiyāyamāno sikkhati. Tasmā bhagavā ārogyamiva byāpādappahānaṃ āha. Yathā so nakkhattadivase bandhanāgāraṃ pavesito puriso aparasmiṃ nakkhattadivase – ‘‘pubbepi ahaṃ pamādadosena baddho, tena nakkhattaṃ nānubhaviṃ. Idāni appamatto bhavissāmī’’ti yathāssa paccatthikā okāsaṃ na labhanti, evaṃ appamatto hutvā nakkhattaṃ anubhavitvā – ‘aho nakkhattaṃ, aho nakkhatta’nti udānaṃ udānesi, evameva bhikkhu – ‘‘idaṃ thinamiddhaṃ nāma mahāanatthakara’’nti cha dhamme bhāvetvā thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ pajahati, so evaṃ pahīnathinamiddho yathā bandhanā mutto puriso sattāhampi nakkhattassa ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ anubhavati, evameva dhammanakkhattassa ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ anubhavanto saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā bhagavā bandhanā mokkhamiva thinamiddhappahānaṃ āha. Yathā pana dāso kiñcideva mittaṃ upanissāya sāmikānaṃ dhanaṃ datvā attānaṃ bhujissaṃ katvā tato paṭṭhāya yaṃ icchati, taṃ karoti. Evameva bhikkhu – ‘‘idaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ nāma mahā anatthakara’’nti cha dhamme bhāvetvā uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pajahati. So evaṃ pahīnauddhaccakukkucco yathā bhujisso puriso yaṃ icchati, taṃ karoti, na taṃ koci balakkārena tato nivatteti , evameva yathā sukhaṃ nekkhammapaṭipadaṃ paṭipajjati, na taṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ balakkārena tato nivatteti. Tasmā bhagavā bhujissaṃ viya uddhaccakukkuccappahānaṃ āha. Yathā balavā puriso hatthasāraṃ gahetvā sajjāvudho saparivāro kantāraṃ paṭipajjeyya, taṃ corā dūratova disvā palāyeyyuṃ. So sotthinā taṃ kantāraṃ nittharitvā khemantaṃ patto haṭṭhatuṭṭho assa. Evameva bhikkhu ‘‘ayaṃ vicikicchā nāma mahā anatthakārikā’’ti cha dhamme bhāvetvā vicikicchaṃ pajahati . So evaṃ pahīnavicikiccho yathā balavā puriso sajjāvudho saparivāro nibbhayo core tiṇaṃ viya agaṇetvā sotthinā nikkhamitvā khemantabhūmiṃ pāpuṇāti, evameva bhikkhu  duccaritakantāraṃ nittharitvā paramaṃ khemantabhūmiṃ amataṃ mahānibbānaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā bhagavā khemantabhūmiṃ viya vicikicchāpahānaṃ āha.
commentary_english:
224. Now, just as the Exalted One, in the passage "Suppose, O great king, [a man free from debt...]," shows the abandoning of the hindrance of sensual desire as similar to freedom from debt (āṇaṇya), and the abandoning of the remaining hindrances as similar to good health (ārogya), etc.

Herein lies the similarity: just as a man, having taken a loan (iṇaṃ ādāya), applies it to his business (kammante payojetvā) and achieves success (samiddhataṃ patto), thinks, "This debt (iṇaṃ) is a root impediment (palibodhamūla)," so he pays back the loan (iṇaṃ) together with the interest (savaḍḍhikaṃ) and has the promissory note (paṇṇaṃ) torn up (phālāpeyya).

From then on, no one sends him a messenger (dūtaṃ peseti) or a letter (paṇṇaṃ).

When he sees his creditors (iṇasāmike disvāpi), he may rise up from his seat (āsanā uṭṭhahati) or remain seated (no ce na uṭṭhahati), as he wishes. Why? Because of his detachment (nillepatāya) and non-attachment (alaggatāya) towards them.

Just so, a bhikkhu (bhikkhu) thinks, "This sensual desire (kāmacchando) is a root impediment (palibodhamūla)," so he develops (bhāvetvā) six things (cha dhamme) and abandons (pajahati) the hindrance of sensual desire (kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ).

We shall describe (vaṇṇayissāma) those six things (cha dhamme) in the Great Frames of Reference (mahāsatipaṭṭhāne).

When he has thus abandoned sensual desire (pahīnakāmacchandassa), then just as a man free from debt (iṇamuttassa purisassa) experiences no fear (bhayaṃ) or consternation (chambhitattaṃ) when he sees his creditor (iṇassāmike disvā),

so the bhikkhu experiences no attachment (saṅgo) or bondage (baddho) towards any external object (paravatthumhi).

Even if he sees divine forms (dibbāni rūpāni passato), no defilement (kileso) assails him (na samudācarati).

Therefore (tasmā), the Exalted One (bhagavā) says that the abandonment of sensual desire (kāmacchandappahānaṃ) is like freedom from debt (āṇaṇyamiva).

Just as a man (puriso) afflicted with a bile disease (pittarogāturo) suppresses (vūpasametvā) that disease (rogaṃ) with a preparation of medicines (bhesajjakiriyāya). From then on (tato paṭṭhāya) he enjoys (vindati) the taste (rasaṃ) of such things as honey (madhu) and sugar (sakkara), etc. (ādīnaṃ).

Just so (evameva), a bhikkhu (bhikkhu) thinks (cintetvā), "This ill will (byāpādo) is a major cause of harm (mahā anatthakaro)," so he develops (bhāvetvā) six things (cha dhamme) and abandons (pajahati) the hindrance of ill will (byāpādanīvaraṇaṃ).

We shall describe (vaṇṇayissāma) those six things (cha dhamme) in all the hindrances (sabbanīvaraṇesu) in the Great Frames of Reference (mahāsatipaṭṭhāneyeva).

Not only (na kevalañca) those alone (teyeva), but also (yepi) those which should be developed (bhāvetabbā) for the abandoning (pahānāya) of dullness and drowsiness (thinamiddhādīnaṃ), etc., all (sabbe) of those (tepi) we shall describe (vaṇṇayissāma) there (tattheva).

When he has thus abandoned ill will (pahīnabyāpādo), then just as a man (puriso) who has recovered from bile disease (pittarogavimutto) eats (paṭisevati) such things as honey (madhu) and sugar (sakkara) and relishes (sampiyāyamāno) their taste (rasaṃ), so the bhikkhu (bhikkhu), having respectfully received (sirasā sampaṭicchitvā) the training rules (sikkhāpadāni) such as the promulgations concerning conduct (ācārapaṇṇattiādīni), etc., trains himself (sikkhati) in them and relishes them (sampiyāyamāno).

Therefore (tasmā), the Exalted One (bhagavā) says that the abandonment of ill will (byāpādappahānaṃ) is like good health (ārogyamiva).

Just as a man (puriso) who was placed (pavesito) in prison (bandhanāgāraṃ) on a festival day (nakkhattadivase), on a later festival day (aparasmiṃ nakkhattadivase) thinks, "Previously (pubbepi), I was bound (baddho) due to my own heedlessness (pamādadosena), and thence (tena) I did not enjoy (nānubhaviṃ) the festival (nakkhattaṃ).

Now (idāni) I will be heedful (appamatto bhavissāmi)." Thus (yathāssa) he becomes heedful (appamatto hutvā), so that his foes (paccatthikā) do not get the chance (okāsaṃ na labhanti). Having enjoyed (anubhavitvā) the festival (nakkhattaṃ), he utters (udānesi) the joyful exclamation (udānaṃ), "Oh, what a festival (aho nakkhattaṃ)! Oh what a festival (aho nakkhattaṃ)!" Just so (evameva), a bhikkhu (bhikkhu) thinks, "This dullness and drowsiness (thinamiddhaṃ) are a major cause of harm (mahāanatthakara)," so he develops (bhāvetvā) six things (cha dhamme) and abandons (pajahati) the hindrance of dullness and drowsiness (thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ). When he has thus abandoned dullness and drowsiness (pahīnathinamiddho), then just as a man (puriso) freed from imprisonment (bandhanā mutto) enjoys (anubhavati) the beginning (ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ), middle, and end of even a week (sattāhampi) of the festival (nakkhattassa), so the bhikkhu (bhikkhu), experiencing (anubhavanto) the beginning (ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ), middle, and end of the festival of the Dhamma (dhammanakkhattassa) together with the discriminations (paṭisambhidāhi), attains (pāpuṇāti) arahantship (arahattaṃ).

Therefore (tasmā), the Exalted One (bhagavā) says that the abandonment of dullness and drowsiness (thinamiddhappahānaṃ) is like release from prison (bandhanā mokkhamiva).

Just as a slave (dāso), with the help of (upanissāya) a friend (mittaṃ), gives (datvā) money (dhanaṃ) to his masters (sāmikānaṃ) and frees himself from slavery (attānaṃ bhujissaṃ katvā). From then on (tato paṭṭhāya) he can do (karoti) whatever (yaṃ) he wishes (icchati).

Just so (evameva), a bhikkhu (bhikkhu) thinks, "This restlessness and worry (uddhaccakukkuccaṃ) are a major cause of harm (mahā anatthakara)," so he develops (bhāvetvā) six things (cha dhamme) and abandons (pajahati) restlessness and worry (uddhaccakukkuccaṃ).

When he has thus abandoned restlessness and worry (pahīnauddhaccakukkucco), then just as a free man (bhujisso puriso) can do (karoti) whatever (yaṃ) he wishes (icchati), and no one (koci) can forcibly (balakkārena) prevent him from doing so (tato nivatteti), so the bhikkhu (bhikkhu) happily (yathā sukhaṃ) practices (paṭipajjati) the way of renunciation (nekkhammapaṭipadaṃ), and restlessness and worry (uddhaccakukkuccaṃ) cannot forcibly (balakkārena) prevent him from doing so (tato nivatteti).

Therefore (tasmā), the Exalted One (bhagavā) says that the abandonment of restlessness and worry (uddhaccakukkuccappahānaṃ) is like freedom from slavery (bhujissaṃ viya).

Just as a strong man (balavā puriso), having taken his valuables (hatthasāraṃ gahetvā) in hand, might travel (paṭipajjeyya) through a desert (kantāraṃ) fully armed (sajjāvudho), accompanied by his retinue (saparivāro). Thieves (corā), having seen (disvā) him even from afar (dūratova), would flee (palāyeyyuṃ).

He (so), safely (sotthinā) crossing (nittharitvā) that desert (taṃ kantāraṃ), reaching (patto) a place of safety (khemantaṃ), would be joyful and delighted (haṭṭhatuṭṭho assa).

Just so (evameva), a bhikkhu (bhikkhu) thinks, "This doubt (vicikicchā) is a major cause of harm (mahā anatthakārikā)," so he develops (bhāvetvā) six things (cha dhamme) and abandons (pajahati) doubt (vicikicchaṃ).

When he has thus abandoned doubt (pahīnavicikiccho), then just as a strong man (balavā puriso) fully armed (sajjāvudho), accompanied by his retinue (saparivāro), fearless (nibbhayo), taking no more account of thieves (core) than of grass (tiṇaṃ viya agaṇetvā), safely (sotthinā) leaving (nikkhamitvā), arrives (pāpuṇāti) at a place of safety (khemantabhūmiṃ), so the bhikkhu (bhikkhu), crossing (nittharitvā) the desert of misconduct (duccaritakantāraṃ), arrives (pāpuṇāti) at the supreme (paramaṃ) place of safety (khemantabhūmiṃ), the deathless (amataṃ), the great Nibbāna (mahānibbānaṃ).

Therefore (tasmā), the Exalted One (bhagavā) says that the abandonment of doubt (vicikicchāpahānaṃ) is like a place of safety (khemantabhūmiṃ viya).

mula_pali: 225. ‘‘Tassime  pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
mula_english: 225. "When someone perceives that these five hindrances have been abandoned within themselves, gladness (*prāmojyaṃ jāyati*) arises. When gladdened, rapture (*prīti jāyati*) arises. When the mind is filled with rapture, the body becomes tranquil (*kāyo passambhati*). With a tranquil body, one experiences happiness (*sukhaṃ vedeti*). Being happy, the mind becomes concentrated (*cittaṃ samādhiyati*)."
commentary_pali: 225.Pāmojjaṃ jāyatīti tuṭṭhākāro jāyati. Pamuditassa pīti jāyatīti tuṭṭhassa sakalasarīraṃ khobhayamānā pīti jāyati. Pītimanassa kāyo passambhatīti pītisampayuttacittassa puggalassa nāmakāyo passambhati, vigatadaratho hoti. Sukhaṃ vedetīti kāyikampi cetasikampi sukhaṃ vedayati. Cittaṃ samādhiyatīti iminā nekkhammasukhena sukhitassa upacāravasenapi appanāvasenapi cittaṃ samādhiyati.
commentary_english:
225.
“Pāmojjaṃ arises": gladness arises.
“When he is gladdened (pamuditassa), rapture (pīti) arises”: for one who is joyous (tuṭṭhassa), rapture arises, shaking his entire body (sakalasarīraṃ).
"When his mind is filled with rapture, his body becomes tranquil": for a person (puggalassa) whose mind (cittassa) is associated with rapture (pītisampayutta), his mental body (nāmakāyo) becomes tranquil (passambhati); he becomes free from disturbance (vigatadaratho hoti).
“He experiences happiness (sukhaṃ)”: he experiences bodily (kāyikaṃ) and mental (cetasikaṃ) happiness.
“His mind becomes concentrated (cittaṃ samādhiyati)”: for one who is gladdened (sukhitassa) by this happiness of renunciation (nekkhamma-sukhena), the mind becomes concentrated by way of access (upacāravasena) and by way of absorption (appanāvasena).

mula_pali: 226. ‘‘So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva  kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mula_english:
226. Secluded from sensual pleasures (kāmehi), secluded from unwholesome states (akusalehi dhammehi), he enters and remains in the first *jhāna* (paṭhamaṃ *jhānaṃ*), which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought (*savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ*), with rapture and pleasure (*pītisukhaṃ*) born of seclusion (*vivekajaṃ*).

He drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this body (*kāyaṃ*) with the rapture and happiness (*pītisukhena*) born of seclusion (*vivekajena*), so that there is no part of his entire body (*kāyassa*) which is not suffused by this rapture and happiness (*pītisukhena*).
commentary_pali: 226.So vivicceva kāmehi…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatītiādi pana upacārasamādhinā samāhite citte uparivisesadassanatthaṃ appanāsamādhinā samāhite citte tassa samādhino pabhedadassanatthaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Imameva kāyanti imaṃ karajakāyaṃ. Abhisandetīti temeti sneheti, sabbattha pavattapītisukhaṃ karoti. Parisandetīti samantato sandeti. Paripūretīti vāyunā bhastaṃ viya pūreti. Parippharatīti samantato phusati. Sabbāvato kāyassāti assa bhikkhuno sabbakoṭṭhāsavato kāyassa kiñci upādinnakasantatipavattiṭṭhāne chavimaṃsalohitānugataṃ  aṇumattampi ṭhānaṃ paṭhamajjhānasukhena aphuṭaṃ nāma na hoti.
commentary_english:
226. Quite secluded from sense pleasures… He enters and dwells in the first *jhāna*.

This is said to show the higher distinctions when the mind is concentrated by access concentration (*upacārasamādhi*), and to show the divisions of concentration when the mind is concentrated by absorption concentration (*appanāsamādhi*).

“This very body” means this body composed of the elements (*karajakāya*).

"He drenches" means he moistens and suffuses; he extends rapture and happiness (*pavattapītisukhaṃ*) everywhere.

"He steeps" means he applies all around.

"He saturates" means he fills as if filling a bellows with air.

"He suffuses" means he pervades all around.

"There is no part of his entire body": In this *bhikkhu*'s body, with all its parts, in the place where the karmically acquired material continuity occurs, there is not even the slightest place consisting of skin (*chavi*), flesh (*maṃsa*), and blood (*lohita*) which is not suffused by the happiness of the first *jhāna* (*paṭhamajjhānasukha*).

mula_pali: 227. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , mahārāja, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṃsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṃ paripphosakaṃ sanneyya, sāyaṃ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā snehaparetā santarabāhirā phuṭā snehena, na ca paggharaṇī; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
227. “Just as, great king, a skilled bath attendant or his apprentice, having poured bath powder into a metal bowl, sprinkles it with water little by little and kneads it, so that the ball of bath powder becomes permeated with moisture, saturated with moisture, suffused inside and out with moisture, yet does not drip; even so, great king, a *bhikṣu* drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this very body with the rapture and happiness born of seclusion, so that there is no part of his entire body untouched by the rapture and happiness born of seclusion.

This, great king, is a visible fruit of the life of a recluse (*sāmaññaphala*) more excellent and sublime than the previous ones.
commentary_pali: 227.Dakkhoti cheko paṭibalo nhānīyacuṇṇāni kātuñceva payojetuñca sannetuñca. Kaṃsathāleti yena kenaci lohena katabhājane. Mattikabhājanaṃ pana thiraṃ na hoti. Sannentassa bhijjati. Tasmā taṃ na dasseti. Paripphosakaṃparipphosakanti siñcitvā siñcitvā. Sanneyyāti vāmahatthena kaṃsathālaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇahatthena pamāṇayuttaṃ udakaṃ siñcitvā siñcitvā parimaddanto piṇḍaṃ kareyya. Snehānugatāti udakasinehena anugatā. Snehaparetāti udakasinehena pariggahitā. Santarabāhirāti saddhiṃ antopadesena ceva bahipadesena ca sabbatthakameva udakasinehena phuṭāti attho. Na ca paggharaṇīti na ca bindu bindu udakaṃ paggharati, sakkā hoti hatthenapi dvīhipi tīhipi aṅgulīhi gahetuṃ ovaṭṭikāyapi kātunti attho.
commentary_english:
227.
He is skilled, clever, capable of making, using, and mixing bathing powders.

"In a metal bowl," means in a vessel made of some kind of metal.

However, an earthenware vessel is not sturdy.

For one who is mixing, it breaks.

Therefore, he does not show it.

Sprinkling and sprinkling, having sprinkled and sprinkled.

When mixing, having taken a metal bowl (kaṃsathāla) with the left hand, and sprinkling and sprinkling water (udaka) of appropriate measure with the right hand, while kneading, one should make a ball (piṇḍa).

"Accompanied by moisture," means accompanied by the moisture of water (udaka).

"Surrounded by moisture," means embraced by the moisture of water (udaka).

"Inner and outer," means together with inner instruction and outer instruction, the meaning is that it is entirely permeated by the moisture of water (udaka).

"Not dripping," means the water (udaka) does not drip drop by drop, it is possible to take it with the hand, or with two or three fingers, or even to make it into a pellet; this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 228. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja  viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa  kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mula_english:
228. “Furthermore, O Great King, with the subsiding of applied thought and sustained thought (vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā), a monk (bhikkhu) enters and remains in the second *jhāna* (dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ), which is characterized by inner tranquility (ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ) and unification of mind (cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ), is without applied thought (avitakkaṃ) and sustained thought (avicāraṃ), and is filled with delight (pīti) and joy (sukhaṃ) born of concentration (*samādhijaṃ*).

He drenches (abhisandeti), steeps (parisandeti), saturates (paripūreti), and suffuses (parippharati) this very body (kāyaṃ) with the delight (pīti) and joy (sukhaṃ) born of concentration (*samādhijena*), so that no part of his entire body (sabbāvato kāyassa) remains untouched (apphuṭaṃ hoti) by the delight (pīti) and joy (sukhaṃ) born of concentration (*samādhijena*).
commentary_pali: 228-229. Dutiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ ubbhidodakoti ubbhinnaudako, na heṭṭhā ubbhijjitvā uggacchanakaudako. Antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti attho. Āyamukhanti āgamanamaggo. Devoti megho. Kālena kālanti kāle kāle, anvaddhamāsaṃ vā anudasāhaṃ vāti attho. Dhāranti vuṭṭhiṃ. Na anuppaveccheyyāti na ca paveseyya, na vasseyyāti attho. Sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvāti sītaṃ dhāraṃ uggantvā rahadaṃ pūrayamānaṃ ubbhijjitvā. Heṭṭhā uggacchanaudakañhi uggantvā uggantvā bhijjantaṃ udakaṃ khobheti, catūhi disāhi pavisanaudakaṃ purāṇapaṇṇatiṇakaṭṭhadaṇḍakādīhi udakaṃ khobheti, vuṭṭhiudakaṃ dhārānipātapubbuḷakehi udakaṃ khobheti. Sannisinnameva pana hutvā iddhinimmitamiva uppajjamānaṃ udakaṃ imaṃ padesaṃ pharati, imaṃ padesaṃ na pharatīti natthi, tena aphuṭokāso nāma na hotīti. Tattha rahado viya karajakāyo. Udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
228-229.

"*Ubbhidodaka*" means "*ubbhinnodaka*," water that springs up; it does not mean water that rises up after bursting from below.

But *antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti* means water that springs up from within.

*Āyamukha* means the path of arrival (*āgamanamagga*).

*Deva* means cloud (*megha*).

"*Kālena kāla*" means at various times, either every half month (*anvaddhamāsaṃ*) or every ten days (*anudasāhaṃ*).

"*Dhāranti*" means [they] pour rain (*vuṭṭhiṃ*).

"*Na anuppaveccheyya*" means one should not let [it] enter, nor should [one] cause [it] to rain (*na vasseyya*).

"*Sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā*" means having sprung up, the cold stream (*sītaṃ dhāraṃ*) bursts forth, rising up and filling the lake (*rahadaṃ pūrayamānaṃ ubbhijjitvā*).

For, the water that springs up from below (*heṭṭhā uggacchanaudakaṃ*) disturbs the water by bursting forth repeatedly (*uggantvā uggantvā bhijjantaṃ udakaṃ khobheti*). The water that enters from the four directions (*catūhi disāhi pavisanaudakaṃ*) disturbs the water with old leaves, grass, wood, sticks, and so on (*purāṇapaṇṇatiṇakaṭṭhadaṇḍakādīhi udakaṃ khobheti*). The rainwater (*vuṭṭhiudakaṃ*) disturbs the water with showers, downpours, and bubbles (*dhārānipātapubbuḷakehi udakaṃ khobheti*).

But, having just settled down (*sannisinnameva pana hutvā*), the water arises as if created by magical power (*iddhinimmitamiva uppajjamānaṃ udakaṃ*) and pervades this area (*imaṃ padesaṃ pharati*). [The statement] "it does not pervade this area (*imaṃ padesaṃ na pharati*)" is not the case; therefore, it is not called "unobstructed space" (*aphuṭokāso nāma na hoti*).

There, the body (*karajakāyo*) is like a lake (*rahado viya*).

The happiness of the second *jhāna* is like the water (*udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ*).

The remainder should be understood in the same way as previously (*sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ*).

mula_pali: 229. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, udakarahado gambhīro ubbhidodako ubbhitodako (syā. kaṃ. ka.) tassa nevassa puratthimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, na pacchimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, devo ca na kālenakālaṃ sammādhāraṃ anuppaveccheyya. Atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṃ sītena vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa. Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti  paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ  hoti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english: 229. "Just as, great king, there is a deep lake (*udakarahada*) fed by a spring (*ubbhidodaka*), with no inlet for water (*udakassa āyamukhaṃ*) from the east (*puratthimāya disāya*), no inlet for water from the south (*dakkhiṇāya disāya*), no inlet for water from the west (*pacchimāya disāya*), no inlet for water from the north (*uttarāya disāya*), and the rain-god (*devo*) does not send moderate showers (*sammādhāraṃ*) from time to time (*kālenakālaṃ*).
