Then, cool streams (*sītā vāridhārā*) well up from that very lake (*udakarahadā*) and drench (*abhisandeyya*), steep (*parisandeyya*), fill (*paripūreyya*), and pervade (*paripphareyya*) that very lake (*udakarahadaṃ*) with cool water (*sītena vārinā*), so that there would be no part of the whole lake (*sabbāvato udakarahadassa*) untouched (*apphuṭaṃ*) by the cool water (*sītena vārinā*). In the same way (*evameva kho*), great king (*mahārāja*), a *bhikkhu* drenches (*abhisandeti*), steeps (*parisandeti*), fills (*paripūreti*), and pervades (*parippharati*) this very body (*kāyaṃ*) with the rapture and pleasure (*pītisukhena*) born of concentration (*samādhijena*), so that there is no part of his whole body (*sabbāvato kāyassa*) untouched (*apphuṭaṃ*) by the rapture and pleasure born of concentration (*samādhijena pītisukhena*). This (*idaṃpi kho*), great king (*mahārāja*), is a visible fruit (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*) of the ascetic life, more excellent (*abhikkantatarañca*) and sublime (*paṇītatarañca*) than the previous visible fruits of the ascetic life (*purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi*)."
commentary_pali: 228-229. Dutiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ ubbhidodakoti ubbhinnaudako, na heṭṭhā ubbhijjitvā uggacchanakaudako. Antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti attho. Āyamukhanti āgamanamaggo. Devoti megho. Kālena kālanti kāle kāle, anvaddhamāsaṃ vā anudasāhaṃ vāti attho. Dhāranti vuṭṭhiṃ. Na anuppaveccheyyāti na ca paveseyya, na vasseyyāti attho. Sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvāti sītaṃ dhāraṃ uggantvā rahadaṃ pūrayamānaṃ ubbhijjitvā. Heṭṭhā uggacchanaudakañhi uggantvā uggantvā bhijjantaṃ udakaṃ khobheti, catūhi disāhi pavisanaudakaṃ purāṇapaṇṇatiṇakaṭṭhadaṇḍakādīhi udakaṃ khobheti, vuṭṭhiudakaṃ dhārānipātapubbuḷakehi udakaṃ khobheti. Sannisinnameva pana hutvā iddhinimmitamiva uppajjamānaṃ udakaṃ imaṃ padesaṃ pharati, imaṃ padesaṃ na pharatīti natthi, tena aphuṭokāso nāma na hotīti. Tattha rahado viya karajakāyo. Udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
228-229.
*Ubhidodaka* means that the water bursts forth, meaning *ubbhinnodaka*, it is not water that rises up having burst forth from below.
But *antoyeva pana ubbhijjanakaudakoti attho* means that the water bursts forth from within.
*Āyamukha* means the path of arrival (*āgamanamārga*).
*Deva* means a cloud (*megha*).
*Kālena kālaṃ* means at different times, either every half-month or every ten days, such is the meaning.
*Dhāranti* means they bear or bring rain (*vṛṣṭi*).
*Na anuppaveccheyyāti* means one should not let it enter, nor should one cause it to enter; *na vasseyyāti attho* means one should not cause it to rain, such is the meaning.
*Sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvāti* means that a cool stream of water, having sprung up, bursts forth, filling the lake (*rahadaṃ pūrayamānaṃ ubbhijjitvā*).
Indeed, water that rises from below (*heṭṭhā uggacchanaudakaṃ*) having risen again and again, agitates the water; water that enters from the four directions (*catūhi disāhi pavisanaudakaṃ*) agitates the water with old leaves, grass, wood, sticks, and so on; rainwater (*vṛṣṭiudakaṃ*) agitates the water with streams of falling drops and bubbles.
But, having just settled down, water arising as if created by *iddhi* pervades this region; it is not that it does not pervade this region, therefore it is called un-scattered or un-separated.
There, the body of the *karaja* is like a lake (*rahado viya karajakāyo*).
The happiness of the second *dhyāna* is like water (*udakaṃ viya dutiyajjhānasukhaṃ*).
The remainder should be understood in the same manner as previously (*sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ*).

mula_pali: 230. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti – ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mula_english:
230. “Furthermore, great king, with the fading away of rapture ( *pītiyā ca virāgā*), a *bhikṣu* dwells in equanimity (*upekkhako*), mindful (*sato*) and clearly comprehending (*sampajāno*), and experiences happiness (*sukhaṃ*) with the body (*kāyena*). Thus he enters and dwells in the third *jhāna* ( *tatiyaṃ dhyānaṃ*), of which the noble ones (*ariyā*) declare: ‘He dwells happily with equanimity and mindfulness (*upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī*)’.

And with this joy devoid of rapture (*nippītikena sukhena*), he drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this very body (*kāyaṃ*) so that there is no part of his entire body (*sabbāvato kāyassa*) which is not suffused by this happiness devoid of rapture (*nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti*).
commentary_pali: 230-231. Tatiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ  uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Ettha ca setarattanīlesu yaṃ kiñci uppalaṃ uppalameva. Ūnakasatapattaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ, satapattaṃ padumaṃ. Pattaniyamaṃ vā vināpi setaṃ padumaṃ, rattaṃ puṇḍarīkanti ayamettha vinicchayo. Udakānuggatānīti udakato na uggatāni. Anto nimuggaposīnīti udakatalassa anto nimuggāniyeva hutvā posīni, vaḍḍhīnīti attho. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
230-231. Because there are lotuses (*uppala*) here similar to the happiness of the third *jhāna* (tritiyajjhāna), therefore it is called "Uppalinī."

And the same rule applies to the other two sections.

Here, any lotus (*uppala*) whether it is white (śeta), red (ratta), or blue (nīla), is simply a lotus (*uppala*).

A *puṇḍarīka* is a *padma* lotus (*paduma*) with fewer than a hundred petals; a *paduma* is a lotus with a hundred petals.

Or, without restriction of the petals, a white (śeta) one is a *paduma* lotus, and a red (ratta) one is a *puṇḍarīka*: this is the distinction here.

"Not risen out of the water" means not risen from the water (udakato).

"Grows submerged inside" means having become submerged inside the water surface (udakatalassa), they grow; that is the meaning (attho).

The remainder should be understood in the same manner as above (purimanayeneva).

mula_pali: 231. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā  udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni abhisandāni parisandāni (ka.) paripūrāni paripphuṭāni paripphuṭṭhāni (pī.), nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṃ uppalānaṃ vā padumānaṃ vā puṇḍarīkānaṃ vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ  sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
231. "Just as, great king, in a pond of *utpala* (blue lotus), or *padma* (red lotus), or *puṇḍarīka* (white lotus), there might be some blue lotuses, red lotuses, or white lotuses, born in the water, grown in the water, thriving without rising from the water, nourished immersed within; and cool water would drench, steep, saturate and pervade them from their tips to their roots, so that there would be no part of all those lotuses untouched by the cool water; in the same way, great king, a *bhikkhu* (monk) drenches, steeps, saturates and suffuses this very body with joy devoid of rapture, so that there is no part of his whole body untouched by the joy devoid of rapture.

Furthermore, great king, this is a visible fruit of the contemplative life (*sāmaññaphala*), more excellent and sublime than the previous visible fruits of the contemplative life."
commentary_pali: 230-231. Tatiyajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ  uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Ettha ca setarattanīlesu yaṃ kiñci uppalaṃ uppalameva. Ūnakasatapattaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ, satapattaṃ padumaṃ. Pattaniyamaṃ vā vināpi setaṃ padumaṃ, rattaṃ puṇḍarīkanti ayamettha vinicchayo. Udakānuggatānīti udakato na uggatāni. Anto nimuggaposīnīti udakatalassa anto nimuggāniyeva hutvā posīni, vaḍḍhīnīti attho. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
230-231.

*Uppalinī* means that there are *uppala* lotuses here similar to the pleasure of the third *dhyāna*.

And the same rule applies to the other two sections.

Here, whatever *uppala* lotus is white, red, or blue, is simply an *uppala* lotus.

*Puṇḍarīka* is a *padma* lotus with fewer petals than one hundred; *paduma* is a *padma* lotus with one hundred petals.

Or, regardless of the number of petals, a white one is a *paduma* lotus, and a red one is a *puṇḍarīka* lotus; this is the distinction here.

*Udakānuggatāni* means that they do not emerge from the water.

*Anto nimuggaposīnī* means that they are submerged within the surface of the water, thus nourished and grown; this is the meaning.

The rest should be understood according to the previous method.

mula_pali: 232. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, mahārāja, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, so imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā  nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti.
mula_english: “Furthermore, great king, with the abandoning of pleasure (*sukha*) and the abandoning of pain (*dukkha*), and with the previous disappearance of joy (*saumanasya*) and grief (*daurmanasya*), a *bhikkhu* enters and dwells in the fourth *jhāna*, which is neither painful nor pleasant and features the purity of mindfulness due to equanimity (*upekkhā-sati-pārisuddhi*). He sits having suffused this very body with a pure, bright mind, so that there is no part of his entire body that is not suffused with a pure, bright mind.
commentary_pali: 232-233. Catutthajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātenāti ettha nirupakkilesaṭṭhena parisuddhaṃ, pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātanti veditabbaṃ. Odātena vatthenāti idaṃ utupharaṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiliṭṭhavatthena hi utupharaṇaṃ na hoti, taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena utupharaṇaṃ balavaṃ hoti. Imissāya hi upamāya vatthaṃ viya karajakāyo, utupharaṇaṃ viya catutthajjhānasukhaṃ. Tasmā yathā sunhātassa purisassa parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa sarīrato utu sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati. Na koci vatthassa aphuṭokāso hoti. Evaṃ catutthajjhānasukhena bhikkhuno  karajakāyassa na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti. Evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ anupadavaṇṇanā ca bhāvanānayo ca visuddhimagge vuttoti idha na vitthārito. Ettāvatā cesa rūpajjhānalābhīyeva, na arūpajjhānalābhīti na veditabbo. Na hi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu cuddasahākārehi ciṇṇavasībhāvaṃ vinā upari abhiññādhigamo hoti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana rūpajjhānāniyeva āgatāni. Arūpajjhānāni āharitvā kathetabbāni.
commentary_english:
232-233.

In the simile of the bliss of the fourth *jhāna*, regarding "with a perfectly pure mind, exceedingly bright," here "perfectly pure" should be understood in the sense of being free from defilements, and "exceedingly bright" in the sense of being radiant.

The white cloth is mentioned for the purpose of showing suffusion by heat.

For there is no suffusion by heat with a soiled cloth; with a clean cloth that has just been washed the suffusion by heat is strong.

For in this simile the material body is like the cloth and the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* is like the suffusion by heat.

Therefore, just as when a man has bathed well and is sitting covered from the head down by a clean cloth, the heat from his body suffuses the entire cloth

so that there is no part of the cloth not suffused by heat,

similarly, there is no part of the *bhikkhu*'s material body that is not suffused by the happiness of the fourth *jhāna*.

It is in this way that the meaning should be seen here.

A step-by-step explanation of the four *jhānas*, and of the method of developing them, is given in the *Visuddhimagga*. Thus they are not explained in detail here.

It should not be thought that at this point only the one who gains the material-form *jhānas* has been shown, but not the one who gains the immaterial *jhānas*.

For there can be no achievement of the higher direct knowledges (*abhijñā*) without achieving mastery in fourteen ways over the eight meditative attainments (*samāpatti*).

In the text only the material-form *jhānas* have come down,

but the immaterial *jhānas* should be brought in and explained.

mula_pali: 233. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , mahārāja, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṃ assa; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi  sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
“Just as, great king, a man might sit having covered his head with a white cloth, such that no part of his whole body would be untouched by the white cloth; just so, great king, a *bhikkhu* sits, having pervaded this very body with a pure, bright mind (*parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena*), such that no part of his whole body is untouched by the pure, bright mind.

This, great king, is a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*), more excellent (*abhikkantatarañca*) and more sublime (*paṇītatarañca*) than the previous visible fruits of the ascetic life.
commentary_pali: 232-233. Catutthajjhānasukhūpamāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātenāti ettha nirupakkilesaṭṭhena parisuddhaṃ, pabhassaraṭṭhena pariyodātanti veditabbaṃ. Odātena vatthenāti idaṃ utupharaṇatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Kiliṭṭhavatthena hi utupharaṇaṃ na hoti, taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena utupharaṇaṃ balavaṃ hoti. Imissāya hi upamāya vatthaṃ viya karajakāyo, utupharaṇaṃ viya catutthajjhānasukhaṃ. Tasmā yathā sunhātassa purisassa parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa sarīrato utu sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati. Na koci vatthassa aphuṭokāso hoti. Evaṃ catutthajjhānasukhena bhikkhuno  karajakāyassa na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti. Evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ anupadavaṇṇanā ca bhāvanānayo ca visuddhimagge vuttoti idha na vitthārito. Ettāvatā cesa rūpajjhānalābhīyeva, na arūpajjhānalābhīti na veditabbo. Na hi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu cuddasahākārehi ciṇṇavasībhāvaṃ vinā upari abhiññādhigamo hoti. Pāḷiyaṃ pana rūpajjhānāniyeva āgatāni. Arūpajjhānāni āharitvā kathetabbāni.
commentary_english:
232-233.

In the simile of the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* (catutthajjhāna), "with a pure mind, perfectly white" (*parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena*)—here, "pure" (*parisuddhaṃ*) should be understood in the sense of being without defilement (*nirupakkilesaṭṭhena*), and "perfectly white" (*pariyodātaṃ*) in the sense of being radiant (*pabhassaraṭṭhena*).

"With a white cloth" (*odātena vattheṇa*)—this was said for the purpose of showing suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇatthaṃ*).

For there is no suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇaṃ*) with a soiled cloth (*kiliṭṭhavatthena*); with a clean cloth (*taṅkhaṇadhotaparisuddhena*) that has just been washed, the suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇaṃ*) is strong (*balavaṃ hoti*).

For in this simile (*imissāya hi upamāya*), the material body (*karajakāyo*) is like the cloth (*vatthaṃ viya*), and the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* (catutthajjhānasukhaṃ) is like the suffusion by heat (*utupharaṇaṃ viya*).

Therefore, just as when a man (*purisassa*) has bathed well (*sunhātassa*) and is sitting covered from the head down (*sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinnassa*) by a clean cloth (*parisuddhaṃ vatthaṃ*), the heat (*utu*) from his body (*sarīrato*) suffuses the entire cloth (*sabbameva vatthaṃ pharati*),

so that there is no part of the cloth (*vatthassa*) not suffused by heat (*aphuṭokāso hoti*),

similarly, there is no part of the *bhikkhu*'s material body (*karajakāyassa*) that is not suffused by the happiness of the fourth *jhāna* (*catutthajjhānasukhena*) (*na koci okāso aphuṭo hotīti*).

It is in this way (*evamettha*) that the meaning (*attho*) should be seen (*daṭṭhabbo*).

A step-by-step explanation (*anupadavaṇṇanā*) of these four *jhānas* (*imesaṃ pana catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ*), and of the method of developing them (*bhāvanānayo ca*), is given in the *Visuddhimagga*, thus they are not explained in detail here (*idha na vitthārito*).

It should not be thought (*na veditabbo*) that at this point (*ettāvatā*) only the one who gains the material-form *jhānas* (*rūpajjhānalābhīyeva*) has been shown, but not the one who gains the immaterial *jhānas* (*na arūpajjhānalābhīti*).

For there can be no achievement of the higher direct knowledges (*upari abhiññādhigamo hoti*) without achieving mastery (*vasībhāvaṃ vinā*) in fourteen ways (*cuddasahākārehi*) over the eight meditative attainments (*aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu*).

In the text (*pāḷiyaṃ pana*) only the material-form *jhānas* (*rūpajjhānāniyeva*) have come down (*āgatāni*),

but the immaterial *jhānas* (*arūpajjhānāni*) should be brought in and explained (*āharitvā kathetabbāni*).

mula_pali: 234. ‘‘So puna caparaṃ mahārāja bhikkhu so (ka.) evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So evaṃ pajānāti – ‘ayaṃ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādana-parimaddana-bhedana-viddhaṃsana-dhammo; idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddha’nti.
mula_english:
"Furthermore, great king, when a monk's mind is thus well-composed ( *samāhite citte*), purified ( *parisuddhe*), bright ( *pariyodāte*), without blemish ( *anaṅgaṇe*), free from defilements ( *vigatūpakkilese*), malleable ( *mudubhūte*), workable ( *kammaniye*), firm ( *ṭhite*), and has attained imperturbability ( *āneñjappatte*), he directs and applies his mind to knowledge and vision ( *ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti*).

He understands thus: ‘This is my body ( *kāyo*), having material form ( *rūpī*), composed of the four great elements ( *cātumahābhūtiko*), originating from mother and father ( *mātāpettikasambhavo*), built up out of rice and gruel ( *odanakummāsūpacayo*), impermanent ( *anicca*), subject to rubbing, pressing, breaking, and destruction ( *ucchādana-parimaddana-bhedana-viddhaṃsana-dhammo*); and this is my consciousness ( *viññāṇaṃ*), supported by it and bound up with it.’"
commentary_pali: 234.So evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatteti so cuddasahākārehi aṭṭhasu samāpattīsu ciṇṇavasībhāvo bhikkhūti  dasseti . Sesamettha visuddhimagge vuttanayena veditabbaṃ. Ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharatīti ettha ñāṇadassananti maggañāṇampi, vuccati phalañāṇampi, sabbaññutaññāṇampi, paccavekkhaṇañāṇampi, vipassanāñāṇampi. ‘‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso, ñāṇadassanavisuddhatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’’ti (mahāni. 1.257) ettha hi maggañāṇaṃ ñāṇadassananti vuttaṃ. ‘‘Ayamañño uttarimanussadhammo alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro’’ti (ma. ni. 1.328) ettha phalañāṇaṃ. ‘‘Bhagavatopi kho ñāṇadassanaṃ udapādi sattāhakālaṅkato āḷāro kālāmo’’ti (mahāva. 10) ettha sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ. ‘‘Ñāṇañca pana me dassanaṃ udapādi akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jātī’’ti (mahāva. 16) ettha paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ idha pana ñāṇadassanāya cittanti idaṃ vipassanāñāṇaṃ ñāṇadassananti vuttanti. Abhinīharatīti vipassanāñāṇassa nibbattanatthāya tanninnaṃ tappoṇaṃ tappabbhāraṃ karoti. Rūpīti ādīnamattho vuttoyeva. Odanakummāsūpacayoti odanena ceva kummāsena ca upacito vaḍḍhito. Aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammoti hutvā abhāvaṭṭhena aniccadhammo. Duggandhavighātatthāya tanuvilepanena ucchādanadhammo. Aṅgapaccaṅgābādhavinodanatthāya khuddakasambāhanena parimaddanadhammo. Daharakāle vā ūrūsu sayāpetvā gabbhāvāsena dussaṇṭhitānaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ aṅgānaṃ saṇṭhānasampādanatthaṃ añchanapīḷanādivasena parimaddanadhammo. Evaṃ pariharitopi bhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo bhijjati ceva vikirati ca, evaṃ sabhāvoti attho. Tattha rūpī cātumahābhūtikotiādīsu chahi  padehi samudayo kathito. Aniccapadena saddhiṃ pacchimehi dvīhi atthaṅgamo. Ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddhanti ettha cātumahābhūtike kāye nissitañca paṭibaddhañca.
commentary_english:
86. When his mind is thus concentrated … and attained to imperturbability, he shows that the *bhikkhu* has achieved mastery over the eight meditative attainments in fourteen ways.

The rest should be understood by the method explained in the *Visuddhimagga*.

"He directs and inclines it to knowledge and vision": Here, "knowledge and vision" can mean path knowledge (*maggañāṇa*), fruition knowledge (*phalañāṇa*), the knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutañāṇa*), reviewing knowledge (*paccavekkhaṇañāṇa*), or insight knowledge (*vipassanāñāṇa*).

In the passage, "What, friend, is the holy life lived under the Blessed One for the sake of purification of knowledge and vision?" (Mahāni. 1.257), path knowledge (*maggañāṇa*) is called “knowledge and vision.”

In the passage, “This is another superhuman state, a distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable dwelling that has been achieved” (Ma. Ni. 1.328), knowledge and vision is fruition knowledge (*phalañāṇa*).

In the passage, "Then the knowledge and vision arose in the Exalted One that Āḷāra Kālāma had died seven days ago" (Mahāva. 10), it is the knowledge of omniscience (*sabbaññutañāṇa*).

In the passage, "And the knowledge and vision arose in me, ‘Unshakable is my liberation, this is my last birth’" (Mahāva. 16), it is reviewing knowledge (*paccavekkhaṇañāṇa*). But here, when it is said, "He directs and inclines to knowledge and vision," it is insight knowledge (*vipassanāñāṇa*) that is called "knowledge and vision."

“He directs and inclines it”: he makes his mind slant, slide, and slope in order to produce insight knowledge (*vipassanāñāṇa*).

The meaning of "corporeal" (*rūpī*) etc., has already been stated.

"Nourishment from rice gruel":  nourished and grown by means of rice and gruel.

It is "subject to impermanence, rubbing and pressing, dissolution and dispersion" because it is impermanent in the sense of not being after having been.

It is "subject to rubbing" because it is anointed with light perfume etc. in order to remove its bad smell.

It is "subject to pressing" because it is massaged to dispel ailments of the limbs.

Also, when children have limbs that have been misshapen during their stay in the womb, during infancy they are made to lie between the thighs and are pulled and pushed in order that their limbs may acquire the proper shape.

It is "subject to dissolution and dispersion" because, though maintained in such ways, it is its very nature to break up and be scattered.

Therein, six terms signify origination, beginning with "corporeal" (*rūpī*) and "composed of the four great elements."

The last two terms together with impermanence signify passing away.

"Here it is based, here it is bound": here it is based and bound in the body composed of the four great elements (*cātumahābhūtike kāye*).

mula_pali: 235. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatrāssa suttaṃ āvutaṃ nīlaṃ vā pītaṃ vā lohitaṃ vā pītakaṃ vā lohitakaṃ vā (ka.) odātaṃ vā paṇḍusuttaṃ vā. Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya – ‘ayaṃ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno; tatridaṃ suttaṃ āvutaṃ nīlaṃ vā pītaṃ vā lohitaṃ vā odātaṃ  vā paṇḍusuttaṃ vā’ti. Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So evaṃ pajānāti – ‘ayaṃ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo; idañca  pana me viññāṇaṃ ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddha’nti. Idampi kho, mahārāja , sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
235. Just as, great king, there were a beautiful beryl gem (*veḷuriya maṇi*) of finest quality, cut into eight facets, well-polished, clear, limpid, unflawed, endowed with all excellent qualities.

And through it, a thread were strung, be it blue (*nīlaṃ*), yellow (*pītaṃ*), red (*lohitaṃ*), yellowish (*pītakaṃ*), or reddish (*lohitakaṃ*), or white (*odātaṃ*), or brown (*paṇḍusuttaṃ*).

A man with good sight, taking it in his hand, might inspect it thus: “This is a beautiful beryl gem (*veḷuriya maṇi*) of purest water, eight-faceted, well cut, clear, limpid, flawless, endowed with all excellent qualities. And through it runs a blue, yellow, red, white, or brown thread."

In the same way, great king, when a *bhikkhu*'s mind is thus concentrated (*samāhite citte*), purified (*parisuddhe*), cleansed (*pariyodāte*), without blemish (*anaṅgaṇe*), rid of defilements (*vigatūpakkilese*), softened (*mudubhūte*), workable (*kammaniye*), firm (*ṭhite*), having attained imperturbability (*āneñjappatte*), he directs and inclines his mind towards knowledge and vision (*ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti*).

He understands thus: ‘This body of mine (*kāyo*), having material form (*rūpī*), composed of the four great elements (*cātumahābhūtiko*), originating from mother and father (*mātāpettikasambhavo*), built up out of rice and gruel (*odanakummāsūpacayo*), is subject to impermanence (*anicca*), to being worn and rubbed away (*ucchādana-parimaddana*), to dissolution and disintegration (*bhedana-viddhaṃsana-dhammo*); and this consciousness of mine (*viññāṇaṃ*) is supported by it and bound up with it.’

This, too, great king, is a visible fruit of the life of a recluse (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*), more excellent (*abhikkantatarañca*) and sublime (*paṇītatarañca*) than the previous ones.
commentary_pali: 235.Subhoti sundaro. Jātimāti parisuddhākarasamuṭṭhito. Suparikammakatoti suṭṭhu kataparikammo apanītapāsāṇasakkharo. Acchoti tanucchavi. Vippasannoti suṭṭhu pasanno. Sabbākārasampannoti dhovanavedhanādīhi sabbehi ākārehi sampanno. Nīlantiādīhi vaṇṇasampattiṃ dasseti. Tādisañhi āvutaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti. Evameva khoti ettha evaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Maṇi viya hi karajakāyo. Āvutasuttaṃ  viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Cakkhumā puriso viya vipassanālābhī bhikkhu, hatthe karitvā paccavekkhato ayaṃ kho maṇīti maṇino āvibhūtakālo viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ, abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno cātumahābhūtikakāyassa āvibhūtakālo, tatridaṃ suttaṃ āvutanti suttassāvibhūtakālo viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ, abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tadārammaṇānaṃ phassapañcamakānaṃ vā sabbacittacetasikānaṃ vā vipassanāñāṇasseva vā āvibhūtakāloti. Idañca vipassanāñāṇaṃ maggañāṇānantaraṃ. Evaṃ santepi yasmā abhiññāvāre āraddhe etassa antarāvāro natthi tasmā idheva dassitaṃ. Yasmā ca aniccādivasena akatasammasanassa dibbāya sotadhātuyā bheravaṃ saddaṃ suṇato, pubbenivāsānussatiyā bherave khandhe anussarato, dibbena cakkhunā bheravampi rūpaṃ passato bhayasantāso uppajjati, na aniccādivasena katasammasanassa tasmā abhiññaṃ pattassa bhayavinodanahetusampādanatthampi idaṃ idheva dassitaṃ. Api ca yasmā vipassanāsukhaṃ nāmetaṃ maggaphalasukhasampādakaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ  tasmāpi āditova idaṃ idha dassitanti veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
235. Subhoti Sundara.

"Jātimāti parisuddhākarasamuṭṭhito" means (that it) originates from a perfectly pure mine.

"Suparikammakato" means well-worked, carefully crafted, with gravel and stones removed.

"Accho" means with thin skin.

"Vippasanno" means very clear.

"Sabbākārasampanno" means complete in all respects, complete in all ways, such as washing and piercing etc.

"Nīlantiādīhi" indicates the perfection of color, beginning with blue.

Indeed, such a thread is visible when threaded.

"Evameva kho" here, the application of the simile should be understood in this way.

The material body is like a gem.

Insight knowledge is like the thread running through it.

The bhikkhu who gains insight is like a man with keen sight; insight knowledge is like the time when the man takes the gem in his hand, reviews it, and it becomes clear to him, "This is a gem"; the manifestation of the body composed of the four great elements to the bhikkhu who is sitting, having directed his mind (there), is like the time when the man takes it out; insight knowledge is like the manifestation of the thread: and the manifestation of the sense impressions with the five kinds of sense object, or all the thoughts and mental factors, or even just insight knowledge, to the bhikkhu who is sitting, having directed his mind (there), is like the time when the man takes it out.

And this insight knowledge immediately precedes the path knowledge.

Even so, it is shown here because there is no intermediate section for it once the section on direct knowledges (abhiññā) has begun.

And also, because fear and terror arise in one who has not contemplated impermanence etc., when hearing a frightening sound with the divine ear, or recollecting frightening aggregates with the recollection of past lives, or seeing a frightening form with the divine eye, but not in one who has contemplated impermanence etc., therefore it is also shown here in order to help one who has attained direct knowledge acquire the means for dispelling fear.

Furthermore, it should be understood that it is shown here at the beginning because the happiness of insight (vipassanāsukha), so-called, is a separate visible fruit of recluseship (sāmaññaphalaṃ), leading to the acquisition of the happiness of the paths and fruits (magga-phala-sukha).

mula_pali: 236. ‘‘So  evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmānāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmināti rūpiṃ manomayaṃ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ.
mula_english:
236.
"When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, softened, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind towards creating a mind-made body (manomayaṃ kāyaṃ).
From this body, he creates another body, having form, mind-made, complete in all its parts, lacking no faculty (rūpiṃ manomayaṃ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ)."
commentary_pali: 236-237.Manomayanti manena nibbattitaṃ. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅginti sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi ca samannāgataṃ. Ahīnindriyanti saṇṭhānavasena avikalindriyaṃ. Iddhimatā nimmitarūpañhi sace iddhimā odāto tampi odātaṃ. Sace aviddhakaṇṇo tampi aviddhakaṇṇanti evaṃ sabbākārehi tena sadisameva hoti. Muñjamhā īsikantiādi upamāttayampi hi sadisabhāvadassanatthameva vuttaṃ. Muñjasadisā eva hi tassa anto īsikā hoti. Kosisadisoyeva asi, vaṭṭāya kosiyā vaṭṭaṃ asimeva pakkhipanti, patthaṭāya patthaṭaṃ . Karaṇḍāti idampi ahikañcukassa nāmaṃ, na vilīvakaraṇḍakassa. Ahikañcuko hi ahinā sadisova hoti. Tattha kiñcāpi ‘‘puriso ahiṃ karaṇḍā uddhareyyā’’ti hatthena uddharamāno viya dassito, atha kho cittenevassa uddharaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ayañhi ahi nāma sajātiyaṃ ṭhito, kaṭṭhantaraṃ vā rukkhantaraṃ vā nissāya, tacato sarīraṃ nikkaḍḍhanappayogasaṅkhātena  thāmena, sarīraṃ khādayamānaṃ viya purāṇatacaṃ jigucchantoti imehi catūhi kāraṇehi sayameva kañcukaṃ pajahati, na sakkā tato aññena uddharituṃ, tasmā cittena uddharaṇaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Iti muñjādisadisaṃ imassa bhikkhuno sarīraṃ, īsikādisadisaṃ nimmitarūpanti. Idamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ. Nimmānavidhānaṃ panettha parato ca iddhividhādipañcaabhiññākathā sabbākārena visuddhimagge vitthāritāti tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Upamāmattameva hi idha adhikaṃ.
commentary_english:
236-237.

"Made of mind" (manomayanti) means brought into being by mind (manena nibbattitaṃ).

“Not lacking any faculties” (sabbaṅgapaccaṅginti) means complete with all limbs and lesser limbs (sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi ca samannāgataṃ).

Lacking no faculty (ahīnindriyanti) refers to an unimpaired faculty by way of shape (saṇṭhānavasena avikalindriyaṃ).

For if the possessor of supernormal power (iddhimatā) is white, then the form he creates (nimmitarūpañhi) will also be white (sace iddhimā odāto tampi odātaṃ).

If his earlobes are unpierced (sace aviddhakaṇṇo), the form will also have earlobes which are unpierced (tampi aviddhakaṇṇanti). Thus it is similar to him in all respects (evaṃ sabbākārehi tena sadisameva hoti).

The three similes beginning with "from the *muñja* reed, the reed" (muñjamhā īsikantiādi) are stated to show the similarity (sadisabhāvadassanatthaṃ).

For the reed (*īsika*) inside the sheath (*muñja*) is similar to its sheath (muñjasadisā eva hi tassa anto īsikā hoti).

the sword (*asi*) is similar to its scabbard (*kosi*), since they put a round sword (*vaṭṭaṃ asi*) into a round scabbard (*vaṭṭāya kosiyā*), and a flat [sword] (*patthaṭaṃ*) into a flat [scabbard] (kosisadisoyeva asi, vaṭṭāya kosiyā vaṭṭaṃ asimeva pakkhipanti, patthaṭāya patthaṭaṃ).

*Karaṇḍā* means this is also a name for a snake’s slough (ahikañcukassa nāmaṃ), not for a *vilīvakaraṇḍaka* (na vilīvakaraṇḍakassa).

The snake’s slough (ahikañcuko) is similar to the snake (ahinā sadisova hoti).

Though in the text it is said, "Suppose a man were to pull a snake (ahiṃ karaṇḍā) out from its slough (‘‘puriso ahiṃ karaṇḍā uddhareyyā’’ti)," as if he were to pull it out with his hand (hatthena uddharamāno viya dassito), we should understand that he extracts it mentally (atha kho cittenevassa uddharaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ).

For no one can pull a snake out from its slough (ayañhi ahi nāma sajātiyaṃ ṭhito). A snake abandons its slough by itself alone, through four means: by abiding in the law of its species; by supporting itself against a log or a tree (kaṭṭhantaraṃ vā rukkhantaraṃ vā nissāya); by its strength, that is, the effort of dragging its body out from the skin (tacato śarīraṃ nikkaḍḍhanappayogasaṅkhātena  thāmena); and by feeling disgust towards the old skin as if it were devouring its body (śarīraṃ khādayamānaṃ viya purāṇatacaṃ jigucchantoti). Thus the statement of the text should be understood to refer to the mental extraction of the snake (imehi catūhi kāraṇehi sayameva kañcukaṃ pajahati, na sakkā tato aññena uddharituṃ, tasmā cittena uddharaṇaṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ).

Thus, the bhikkhu’s body (imassa bhikkhuno śarīraṃ) is similar to the sheath, etc. (*muñjādi* -sadisaṃ), and the created form (*nimmitarūpa*) is similar to the reed, etc. (ītīsikādi -sadisaṃ).

This is the application of the similes here (idamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ).

But the method of creation here (nimmānavidhānaṃ panettha) and the following five kinds of direct knowledge—the modes of supernormal power, etc. (*iddhi-vidhādi-pañca-abhiññā-kathā*)—have been explained in full detail in the *Visuddhimagga* (sabbākārena visuddhimagge vitthāritā). Thus they should be understood by the method stated there (tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā).

Here, only the similes are additional (upamāmattameva hi idha adhikaṃ).

mula_pali: 237. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso muñjamhā īsikaṃ pavāheyya pabbāheyya (syā. ka.). Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ muñjo, ayaṃ īsikā, añño muñjo, aññā īsikā, muñjamhā tveva īsikā pavāḷhā’ti pabbāḷhāti (syā. ka.). Seyyathā vā pana, mahārāja, puriso asiṃ kosiyā pavāheyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ asi, ayaṃ kosi, añño asi, aññā kosi, kosiyā tveva asi pavāḷho’’ti. Seyyathā vā pana, mahārāja, puriso ahiṃ karaṇḍā uddhareyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ ahi, ayaṃ karaṇḍo. Añño ahi, añño karaṇḍo, karaṇḍā tveva ahi ubbhato’ti uddharito (syā. kaṃ.). Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmānāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmināti rūpiṃ manomayaṃ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca  paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
237. Just as, great king, a man might draw a reed (*īsika*) from its sheath (*muñja*).

He might think, "This is the *muñja* reed, this is the *īsika* sheath; the *muñja* reed is one thing, the *īsika* sheath another, and the *īsika* has been drawn from the *muñja*."

Or again, great king, a man might draw a sword (*asi*) from its scabbard (*kosi*).

He might think, "This is the sword (*asi*), this is the scabbard (*kosi*); the sword (*asi*) is one thing, the scabbard (*kosi*) another, and the sword (*asi*) has been drawn from the scabbard (*kosi*)."

Or again, great king, a man might draw a snake (*ahi*) from its slough (*karaṇḍa*).

He might think, "This is the snake (*ahi*), this is the slough (*karaṇḍa*); the snake (*ahi*) is one thing, the slough (*karaṇḍa*) another, and the snake (*ahi*) has been drawn from the slough (*karaṇḍa*)."

In the same way, great king, when a *bhikkhu*’s mind is thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the creation of a mind-made body (*manomayaṃ kāyaṃ*).

He creates from this body another body, having form (*rūpiṃ*), mind-made (*manomayaṃ*), complete in all its parts, lacking no faculty (*sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ*).

This, too, great king, is a fruit of the ascetic life, visible here and now (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*), more excellent and sublime than the previous ones.

commentary_english:
236-237.
"Mind-made" means brought into being by the mind.

“Not lacking any faculties” ( *sabbaṅgapaccaṅginti*) means complete with all limbs and secondary limbs (*sabbehi aṅgehi ca paccaṅgehi ca samannāgataṃ*).

Lacking no faculty (*ahīnindriyaṃ*) means lacking no sense faculty by way of shape (*saṇṭhānavasena avikalindriyaṃ*).

For if the possessor of supernormal power (*iddhimatā*) is white (*odāta*), then the form he creates (*nimmitarūpaṃ*) will also be white (*tampi odātaṃ*).

If his earlobes are unpierced (*aviddhakaṇṇo*), the form will also have earlobes which are unpierced (*tampi aviddhakaṇṇanti*). Thus it is similar to him in all respects (*evaṃ sabbākārehi tena sadisameva hoti*).

The three similes beginning with "the reed from the *muñja* grass" (*muñjamhā īsikantiādi*) are stated to show the similarity (*sadisabhāvadassanatthaṃ*).

For the reed (*īsikā*) inside the sheath is similar to its *muñja* sheath (*muñjasadisā eva hi tassa anto īsikā hoti*).

The sword (*asi*) is similar to its scabbard (*kosisadiso*), since they put a round sword (*vaṭṭaṃ asi*) into a round scabbard (*vaṭṭāya kosiyā*) and a flat [sword] into a flat [scabbard] (*patthaṭāya patthaṭaṃ*).

*Karaṇḍā* means this is also a name for the snake’s slough (*ahikañcukassa nāmaṃ*), not for a *vilīvakaraṇḍaka* basket.

The snake’s slough (*ahikañcuko*) is similar to the snake (*ahinā sadisova hoti*).

Though in the text it is said, “Suppose a man were to pull a snake (*ahiṃ*) out from its slough (*karaṇḍā uddhareyyā*) ,” as if he were to pull it out with his hand (*hatthena uddharamāno viya dassito*), we should understand that he extracts it mentally (*atha kho cittenevassa uddharaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ*).

For the snake (*ahi*), abiding in its own species (*sajātiyaṃ ṭhito*), relying on a log or a tree (*kaṭṭhantaraṃ vā rukkhantaraṃ vā nissāya*), by its strength (*thāmena*) that is, the effort of dragging its body (*sarīraṃ*) out from the skin (*tacato*) and by feeling disgust towards the old skin (*purāṇatacaṃ*) as if it were devouring its body (*sarīraṃ khādayamānaṃ viya jigucchantoti*) abandons its slough (*kañcukaṃ pajahati*) by itself alone (*sayameva*) through these four means (*imehi catūhi kāraṇehi*). No one else can pull it out from that (*na sakkā tato aññena uddharituṃ*). Thus, the statement of the text (*idaṃ vuttaṃ*) should be understood to refer to the mental extraction of the snake (*tasmā cittena uddharaṇaṃ sandhāya veditabbaṃ*).

Thus, the bhikkhu’s body (*imassa bhikkhuno sarīraṃ*) is similar to the sheath (*muñjādisadisaṃ*), and the created form (*nimmitarūpaṃ*) is similar to the reed (*īsikādisadisaṃ*).

This is the application of the similes here (*idamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ*).

But the method of creation (*nimmānavidhānaṃ*) here and the following five kinds of direct knowledge (*iddhividhādipañcaabhiññākathā*) have been explained in full detail in the *Visuddhimagga* (*visuddhimagge vitthāritāti*). Thus they should be understood by the method stated there (*tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbā*).

Here only the similes are additional (*upamāmattameva hi idha adhikaṃ*).

mula_pali: 238. ‘‘So  evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti . So anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti – ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāvaṃ tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse. Pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti seyyathāpi udake. Udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati abhijjamāno (sī. ka.) seyyathāpi pathaviyā . Ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo. Imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati. Yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti.
mula_english:
238. When his mind is thus concentrated, pure, bright, unblemished, free from defilements, malleable, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and applies his mind to the development of supernormal powers.

He experiences various kinds of supernormal power ( *iddhi-vidha*): being one, he becomes many; being many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through walls, ramparts, and mountains as if through space (*ākāśa*).

He dives in and out of the earth (*pṛthavī*) as if it were water (*udaka*).

He walks on water without sinking as if it were earth (*pṛthavī*).

He travels in space (*ākāśa*) cross-legged, like a bird with wings (*pakṣī sakuṇo*).

He touches and strokes with his hand (*pāṇinā*) even the moon (*candima*) and sun (*sūriya*), so mighty and powerful.

He wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā-world (*brahmaloka*).
commentary_pali: 238-239. Tattha chekakumbhakārādayo viya iddhividhañāṇalābhī  bhikkhu daṭṭhabbo. Suparikammakatamattikādayo viya iddhividhañāṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Icchiticchitabhājanavikatiādikaraṇaṃ viya tassa bhikkhuno vikubbanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
238-239.
Therein, the skilled potter, etc., is like the *bhikkhu* who gains the knowledge of the modes of supernormal power.
The well-prepared clay, etc., is like the knowledge of the modes of supernormal power.
And the making of whatever kind of vessel, etc., he might desire is like the *bhikkhu*'s transformations.

mula_pali: 239. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, dakkho kumbhakāro vā kumbhakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatāya mattikāya yaṃ yadeva bhājanavikatiṃ ākaṅkheyya, taṃ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya. Seyyathā vā pana, mahārāja, dakkho dantakāro vā dantakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṃ dantasmiṃ yaṃ yadeva dantavikatiṃ ākaṅkheyya, taṃ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya. Seyyathā vā pana, mahārāja, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṃ suvaṇṇasmiṃ yaṃ yadeva suvaṇṇavikatiṃ ākaṅkheyya, taṃ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya. Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya  cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti – ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāvaṃ tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse. Pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti seyyathāpi udake. Udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyā. Ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo. Imepi candimasūriye evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve  pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati. Yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
239.

“Just as, great king, a skilled potter or his apprentice, with well-prepared clay, could make and fashion whatever kind of vessel (*bhājana-vikati*) he might desire.

Or just as, great king, a skilled ivory-worker or his apprentice, with well-prepared ivory, could make and fashion whatever kind of ivory object (*danta-vikati*) he might desire.

Or just as, great king, a skilled goldsmith or his apprentice, with well-prepared gold, could make and fashion whatever kind of gold article (*suvarṇa-vikati*) he might desire.

In the same way, great king, a monk, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, become pliant, workable, firm, and attained to imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind to the manifestation of psychic powers (*iddhi-vidhā*).

He experiences various kinds of psychic power (*iddhi-vidha*): having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through a rampart, through a mountain, as though through space (*ākāśa*).

He dives in and out of the earth (*pathavī*) as though it were water (*udaka*).

He walks on water without sinking as though it were earth (*pathavī*).

He travels cross-legged through the sky (*ākāśa*) like a winged bird (*pakkhī sakuṇo*).

He touches and strokes with his hand even the moon (*candima*) and sun (*sūriya*), so mighty and powerful.

He exercises mastery with his body even as far as the Brahmā world (*brahmaloka*).

This too, great king, is a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sāmaññaphala*), more excellent and sublime than the previous visible fruits of the ascetic life (*sāmaññaphala*)."
commentary_pali: 238-239. Tattha chekakumbhakārādayo viya iddhividhañāṇalābhī  bhikkhu daṭṭhabbo. Suparikammakatamattikādayo viya iddhividhañāṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Icchiticchitabhājanavikatiādikaraṇaṃ viya tassa bhikkhuno vikubbanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
238-239.

Therein, the skilled potter, etc., is like the *bhikkhu* who gains the knowledge of the modes of supernormal power.

The well-prepared clay, etc., is like the knowledge of the modes of supernormal power.

And the making of whatever kind of vessel, etc., he might desire is like the *bhikkhu’s* transformations.

mula_pali: 240. ‘‘So  evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca.
mula_english:
And he, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of imperfections, made pliant, workable, firm, and having attained imperturbability, directs and applies his mind to the divine ear-element (*divyā śrotradhātu*).

With the divine ear-element (*divyā śrotradhātu*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, divine and human, those which are far and near.
commentary_pali: 240-241. Dibbasotadhātuupamāyaṃ yasmā kantāraddhānamaggo sāsaṅko hoti sappaṭibhayo. Tattha ussaṅkitaparisaṅkitena ‘ayaṃ bherisaddo’, ‘ayaṃ mudiṅgasaddo’ti na sakkā vavatthapetuṃ, tasmā kantāraggahaṇaṃ akatvā khemamaggaṃ dassento addhānamaggappaṭipannoti āha. Appaṭibhayañhi khemamaggaṃ sīse sāṭakaṃ katvā saṇikaṃ paṭipanno vuttappakāre sadde sukhaṃ vavatthapeti. Tassa savanena tesaṃ tesaṃ saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo viya yogino dūrasantikabhedānaṃ dibbānañceva mānussakānañca saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo veditabbo.
commentary_english:
240-241. In the simile of the divine ear-element (*dibbasotadhātu*), since a desert road (*kantāraddhānamagga*) is fearful (*sāsaṅko*) and dangerous (*sappaṭibhayo*).

There, one who is anxious and frightened cannot distinguish, 'This is the sound of a kettledrum (*bherisaddo*)', 'This is the sound of a *mudiṅga* (a type of drum) (*mudiṅgasaddo*)'. Therefore, not mentioning a desert road, but showing a safe road (*khemamagga*) he speaks of one who has set out on a highway (*addhānamaggappaṭipanno*).

For when one is travelling leisurely on a safe road (*khemamagga*) free from dangers (*appaṭibhaya*), having placed a cloth (*sāṭaka*) over one’s head, one can easily distinguish the aforesaid sounds (*sadde sukhaṃ vavatthapeti*).

The time when the sounds being heard by that person become clear to him, is like the time when the divine (*dibbānañceva*) and human (*mānussakanāca*) sounds, both distant and near, become clear to the *yogin* (meditator).

mula_pali: 241. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , mahārāja, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno. So suṇeyya bherisaddampi mudiṅgasaddampi mutiṅgasaddampi (sī. pī.) saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddampi saṅkhapaṇavadeṇḍimasaddampi (sī. pī.), saṅkhasaddaṃpi paṇavasaddaṃpi dendimasaddaṃpi (syā. kaṃ.). Tassa evamassa – ‘bherisaddo’ itipi, ‘mudiṅgasaddo’ itipi, ‘saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddo’ itipi saṅkhasaddo itipi paṇavasaddo itipi dendimasaddo itipi (syā. kaṃ.). Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte dibbāya sotadhātuyā  cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
“Great king, suppose a man travelling along a long road were to hear the sounds of kettledrums (bherisadda), small drums (mudiṅgasadda), conches (saṅkha), cymbals (paṇava), and tomtoms (dindima). It would occur to him, ‘That is the sound of kettledrums, that is the sound of small drums, that is the sound of conches, cymbals, and tomtoms.’

In the same way, great king, when a *bhikkhu*’s mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, spotless, rid of defilements, malleable, workable, firm, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the divine ear-element (*dibbāya sotadhātuyā*). With the divine ear-element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, divine and human, those which are distant and those which are near.

This too, great king, is a visible fruit of the ascetic life (*sāmaññaphalaṃ*) more excellent and sublime than the previous ones.
commentary_pali: 240-241. Dibbasotadhātuupamāyaṃ yasmā kantāraddhānamaggo sāsaṅko hoti sappaṭibhayo. Tattha ussaṅkitaparisaṅkitena ‘ayaṃ bherisaddo’, ‘ayaṃ mudiṅgasaddo’ti na sakkā vavatthapetuṃ, tasmā kantāraggahaṇaṃ akatvā khemamaggaṃ dassento addhānamaggappaṭipannoti āha. Appaṭibhayañhi khemamaggaṃ sīse sāṭakaṃ katvā saṇikaṃ paṭipanno vuttappakāre sadde sukhaṃ vavatthapeti. Tassa savanena tesaṃ tesaṃ saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo viya yogino dūrasantikabhedānaṃ dibbānañceva mānussakānañca saddānaṃ āvibhūtakālo veditabbo.
commentary_english: 240-241. In the simile of the divine ear-element (dibbasotadhātuupamāyaṃ), since a desert road (kantāraddhānamaggo) is fearful (sāsaṅko) and dangerous (sappaṭibhayo), and one who becomes anxious (ussaṅkita) and frightened (parisaṅkite) there cannot distinguish the sounds of kettledrum (bherisaddo) and tambours (mudiṅgasaddo), the Buddha does not mention a desert road (kantāraggahaṇaṃ akatvā), but with the word “highway” (khemamaggaṃ dassento addhānamaggappaṭipanno) shows a safe road (khemamaggaṃ dassento). For when one is travelling leisurely (saṇikaṃ paṭipanno) on a safe road (khemamaggaṃ), free from dangers (appaṭibhayaṃ), having placed a cloth (sāṭakaṃ katvā) over one’s head, one can easily distinguish (sukhaṃ vavatthapeti) the aforesaid sounds (vuttappakāre sadde). The time when the sounds being heard (tassa savanena) by the man become clear to him is like the time when the divine (dibbānañceva) and human sounds (mānussakānañca), both distant (dūra) and near (santika), become clear to the yogin (yogino āvibhūtakālo veditabbo).

mula_pali: 242. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti – sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘sarāgaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vītarāgaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, sadosaṃ  vā cittaṃ ‘sadosaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vītadosaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, samohaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘samohaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vītamohaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vītamohaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘saṅkhittaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vikkhittaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, mahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ ‘mahaggataṃ citta’nti pajānāti, amahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ ‘amahaggataṃ citta’nti pajānāti, sauttaraṃ vā cittaṃ ‘sauttaraṃ citta’nti pajānāti, anuttaraṃ vā cittaṃ ‘anuttaraṃ citta’nti pajānāti, samāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘samāhitaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, asamāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘asamāhitaṃ citta’nti pajānāti , vimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vimuttaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘avimuttaṃ citta’nti pajānāti.
mula_english:
And he, when his mind is thus well-concentrated (samāhite citte), purified (parisuddhe) and cleansed (pariyodāte), unblemished (anaṅgaṇe), free from the corruptions (vigatūpakkilese), malleable (mudubhūte), workable (kammaniye), steady (ṭhite), and attained to imperturbability (āneñjappatte), directs (abhinīharati) and inclines (abhininnāmeti) it to the knowledge of encompassing the minds (cetopariyañāṇa).

He understands with his mind (cetasā) the minds (ceto) of other beings (parasattānaṃ) and other persons (parapuggalānaṃ), having encompassed them (paricca pajānāti). He understands a mind with lust (sarāgaṃ cittaṃ) as a mind with lust, and a mind without lust (vītarāgaṃ cittaṃ) as a mind without lust; he understands a mind with hatred (sadosaṃ cittaṃ) as a mind with hatred, and a mind without hatred (vītadosaṃ cittaṃ) as a mind without hatred; he understands a mind with delusion (samohaṃ cittaṃ) as a mind with delusion, and a mind without delusion (vītamohaṃ cittaṃ) as a mind without delusion; he understands a contracted mind (saṅkhittaṃ cittaṃ) as a contracted mind, and a distracted mind (vikkhittaṃ cittaṃ) as a distracted mind; he understands an exalted mind (mahaggataṃ cittaṃ) as an exalted mind, and an unexalted mind (amahaggataṃ cittaṃ) as an unexalted mind; he understands a surpassable mind (sauttaraṃ cittaṃ) as a surpassable mind, and an unsurpassed mind (anuttaraṃ cittaṃ) as an unsurpassed mind; he understands a concentrated mind (samāhitaṃ cittaṃ) as a concentrated mind, and an unconcentrated mind (asamāhitaṃ cittaṃ) as an unconcentrated mind; he understands a liberated mind (vimuttaṃ cittaṃ) as a liberated mind, and an unliberated mind (avimuttaṃ cittaṃ) as an unliberated mind.
commentary_pali: 242-243. Cetopariyañāṇūpamāyaṃ daharoti taruṇo. Yuvāti yobbannena samannāgato. Maṇḍanakajātikoti yuvāpi samāno na ālasiyo na kiliṭṭhavatthasarīro, atha kho maṇḍanapakatiko, divasassa dve tayo vāre nhāyitvā suddhavatthaparidahanaalaṅkārakaraṇasīloti attho. Sakaṇikanti kāḷatilakavaṅgamukhadūsipīḷakādīnaṃ aññatarena sadosaṃ. Tattha yathā tassa mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhato mukhe doso pākaṭo hoti, evaṃ cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno paresaṃ soḷasavidhaṃ cittaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
242-243. *Dahara* or *taruṇa* means young in the simile for the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others (ceto-pariya-ñāṇa).

*Yuva* means endowed with youth.

*Maṇḍanakajātika* means even when young, one is not lazy, nor does one have soiled clothes or body, but rather one is by nature decorative, bathing two or three times a day, and is in the habit of wearing clean clothes and adorning oneself; this is the meaning.

*Sakaṇika* means having blemishes (sadosa) with any one of black *tilaka* marks, *vaṅga* marks on the face, *dūsi* (blemishes), *pīḷaka* (pimples), and so on.

There, just as the mark on a young man’s face would become evident to him when he examines his facial reflection, so the sixteen kinds of minds of others become evident to the *bhikkhu* sitting with his mind directed to the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others (*ceto-pariya-ñāṇa*); this should be understood.

mula_pali: 243. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , mahārāja, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā  maṇḍanajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udakapatte sakaṃ mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhamāno sakaṇikaṃ vā ‘sakaṇika’nti jāneyya, akaṇikaṃ vā ‘akaṇika’nti jāneyya; evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti – sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘sarāgaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vītarāgaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, sadosaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘sadosaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vītadosaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, samohaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘samohaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vītamohaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vītamohaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘saṅkhittaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vikkhittaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, mahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ ‘mahaggataṃ citta’nti pajānāti, amahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ ‘amahaggataṃ citta’nti pajānāti, sauttaraṃ vā cittaṃ ‘sauttaraṃ citta’nti pajānāti, anuttaraṃ  vā cittaṃ ‘anuttaraṃ citta’nti pajānāti, samāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘samāhitaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, asamāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘asamāhitaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, vimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘vimuttaṃ citta’’nti pajānāti, avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘avimuttaṃ citta’nti pajānāti. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
243. “Just as, great king, a woman or a man, a young person, fond of adornment, looking at his own face in a clear and pure mirror or in a bowl of water, would know whether there was a spot ( *kaṇika*) or not; just so, great king, a *bhikkhu*, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilement, made pliant, workable, steady, attained to imperturbability, directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others.

He understands with his mind the minds of other beings and other persons, he knows a mind with lust (*sarāgaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a mind with lust (*sarāgaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a mind without lust (*vītarāgaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a mind without lust (*vītarāgaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a mind with hatred (*sadosaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a mind with hatred (*sadosaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a mind without hatred (*vītadosaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a mind without hatred (*vītadosaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a mind with delusion (*samohaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a mind with delusion (*samohaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a mind without delusion (*vītamohaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a mind without delusion (*vītamohaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a constricted mind (*saṅkhittaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a constricted mind (*saṅkhittaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a scattered mind (*vikkhittaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a scattered mind (*vikkhittaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a lofty mind (*mahaggataṃ cittaṃ*) to be a lofty mind (*mahaggataṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a not lofty mind (*amahaggataṃ cittaṃ*) to be a not lofty mind (*amahaggataṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a surpassable mind (*sauttaraṃ cittaṃ*) to be a surpassable mind (*sauttaraṃ cittaṃ*), he knows an unsurpassed mind (*anuttaraṃ cittaṃ*) to be an unsurpassed mind (*anuttaraṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a concentrated mind (*samāhitaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a concentrated mind (*samāhitaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows an unconcentrated mind (*asamāhitaṃ cittaṃ*) to be an unconcentrated mind (*asamāhitaṃ cittaṃ*), he knows a liberated mind (*vimuttaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a liberated mind (*vimuttaṃ cittaṃ*), and he knows a not liberated mind (*avimuttaṃ cittaṃ*) to be a not liberated mind (*avimuttaṃ cittaṃ*).

This, too, O great king, is an immediate fruit of the life of a recluse, more excellent and sublime than the previous ones (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*).
commentary_pali: 242-243. Cetopariyañāṇūpamāyaṃ daharoti taruṇo. Yuvāti yobbannena samannāgato. Maṇḍanakajātikoti yuvāpi samāno na ālasiyo na kiliṭṭhavatthasarīro, atha kho maṇḍanapakatiko, divasassa dve tayo vāre nhāyitvā suddhavatthaparidahanaalaṅkārakaraṇasīloti attho. Sakaṇikanti kāḷatilakavaṅgamukhadūsipīḷakādīnaṃ aññatarena sadosaṃ. Tattha yathā tassa mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhato mukhe doso pākaṭo hoti, evaṃ cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno paresaṃ soḷasavidhaṃ cittaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.
commentary_english:
242-243. *Daharo* means *taruṇa*, young, in the simile for the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others (*cetopariyañāṇa*).

*Yuva* means one endowed with youth.

*Maṇḍanakajātiko* means a *yuva* who, being the same, is neither lazy nor has soiled clothes and body, but is by nature decorative, accustomed to bathing two or three times a day, putting on clean clothes, and adorning himself. This is the meaning.

*Sakaṇika* means having faults, with one of such things as black marks, moles, blemishes, pimples, and so on.

There, just as when a young man examines the mark on his face, a fault becomes evident on his face, so it should be understood that the sixteen kinds of minds of others become evident to the *bhikkhu* sitting with his mind directed towards the knowledge of encompassing the minds of others (*cetopariyañāṇa*).

mula_pali: 244. ‘‘So  evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ – ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto  evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī  evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mula_english:
244. When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfections, malleable, wieldy, steady, and has attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind towards the knowledge of the recollection of past lives (pūrvnivāsānusmṛti-jñāna).

He recollects his manifold past lives, that is to say, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many aeons of world-contraction, many aeons of world-expansion, many aeons of world-contraction and expansion: ‘There I was so named (evaṃ-nāma), of such a clan (evaṃ-gotra), with such an appearance (evaṃ-varṇa), such was my nutriment (evaṃ-āhāra), such my experience of pleasure and pain (evaṃ-sukha-duḥkha-pratisaṃvedī), such my life-term (evaṃ-āyu-paryanta). Passing away from that, I arose there. There too I was so named (evaṃ-nāma), of such a clan (evaṃ-gotra), with such an appearance (evaṃ-varṇa), such was my nutriment (evaṃ-āhāra), such my experience of pleasure and pain (evaṃ-sukha-duḥkha-pratisaṃvedī), such my life-term (evaṃ-āyu-paryanta). Passing away from that, I was reborn here.’

Thus, with details and modalities, he recollects his manifold past lives (pūrva-nivāsa).
commentary_pali: 244-245. Pubbenivāsañāṇūpamāyaṃ  taṃ divasaṃ katakiriyā pākaṭā hotīti taṃ divasaṃ gatagāmattayameva gahitaṃ. Tattha gāmattayagatapuriso viya pubbenivāsañāṇalābhī daṭṭhabbo, tayo gāmā viya tayo bhavā daṭṭhabbā, tassa purisassa tīsu gāmesu taṃ divasaṃ katakiriyāya āvibhāvo viya pubbenivāsāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu katakiriyāya pākaṭabhāvo daṭṭhabbo.
commentary_english:
244-245. Just as the actions done that day become clear in the simile of the knowledge of remembering past lives, so only the three villages gone to on that day are taken.

Therein, the man who has gone to the three villages is to be seen as like one who has gained the knowledge of the recollection of past lives ( *pubbenivāsañāṇalābhī*), the three villages like three existences (*bhava*). Just as the manifestation of the actions done that day in the three villages is clear to that man, so the clear manifestation of the actions done in the three existences (*bhava*) is to be seen in the *bhikṣu* who is sitting having directed his mind to the recollection of past lives.

mula_pali: 245. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṃ gāmaṃ gaccheyya, tamhāpi gāmā aññaṃ gāmaṃ gaccheyya. So tamhā gāmā sakaṃyeva gāmaṃ paccāgaccheyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho sakamhā gāmā amuṃ gāmaṃ agacchiṃ agañchiṃ (syā. kaṃ.), tatrāpi evaṃ aṭṭhāsiṃ, evaṃ nisīdiṃ, evaṃ  abhāsiṃ, evaṃ tuṇhī ahosiṃ, tamhāpi gāmā amuṃ gāmaṃ agacchiṃ, tatrāpi evaṃ aṭṭhāsiṃ, evaṃ nisīdiṃ, evaṃ abhāsiṃ, evaṃ tuṇhī ahosiṃ, somhi tamhā gāmā  sakaṃyeva gāmaṃ paccāgato’ti. Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ – ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti, iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english:
245. "Just as, great king, a man might go from his own village to another village, and from that village to yet another village.

Then from that village, he might return to his own village.

He might think to himself: 'I went from my own village to that village, and there I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, and remained silent in such a way. From that village I went to still another village. There too I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, and remained silent in such a way. From that village I have now returned to my own village.'

In the same way, great king, when a monk's mind is thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, softened, workable, steady, and has attained immovability, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the recollection of past lives (pūrvānivāsānusmṛti-jñāna).

He recollects his numerous past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three, four, or five births; ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty births; a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births; many aeons of world contraction, many aeons of world expansion, many aeons of world contraction and expansion, (saṃvaṭṭa-kappa, vivaṭṭa-kappa, saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭa-kappa): 'There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance; such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life-term. Passing away from that existence, I was reborn in such and such a place. There I was so-and-so... such was my life-term. Passing away from there, I have been reborn here.' Thus, with their aspects and details, he remembers many past lives.

This too, great king, is a visible fruit of the life of a recluse (sāmaññaphala), more excellent and sublime than the previous ones.
commentary_pali: 244-245. Pubbenivāsañāṇūpamāyaṃ  taṃ divasaṃ katakiriyā pākaṭā hotīti taṃ divasaṃ gatagāmattayameva gahitaṃ. Tattha gāmattayagatapuriso viya pubbenivāsañāṇalābhī daṭṭhabbo, tayo gāmā viya tayo bhavā daṭṭhabbā, tassa purisassa tīsu gāmesu taṃ divasaṃ katakiriyāya āvibhāvo viya pubbenivāsāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu katakiriyāya pākaṭabhāvo daṭṭhabbo.
commentary_english:
244-245. In the simile of the knowledge of past lives, "the actions done that day become clear" means that only the three villages gone to that day are taken.

Therein, the man who has gone to the three villages is to be seen as like one who gains the knowledge of recollecting past lives ( *pubbenivāsañāṇalābhī*), the three villages like three existences (*tayo bhavā*). Just as the appearance of the actions done that day in the three villages becomes clear to that man, so the manifestation of the actions done in the three existences becomes evident to the *bhikkhu* sitting with his mind directed to the knowledge of recollecting past lives.

mula_pali: 246. ‘‘So  evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne  hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti – ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa  bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena  satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mula_english:
246. When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, free from imperfections, malleable, wieldy, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

With the divine eye ( *dibba cakkhu*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearing—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate—and he understands how beings fare according to their *kamma*, thus: ‘These beings—who were endowed with bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, who reviled the noble ones (*ariya*), held wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhi*), and undertook actions governed by wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhikammasamādāna*)—

at the break-up of the body, after death, have reappeared in a plane of deprivation (*apāya*), a bad destination (*duggati*), a lower realm (*vinipāta*), hell (*niraya*).

But these beings—who were endowed with good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not revile the noble ones (*ariya*), held right views (*sammādiṭṭhi*), and undertook actions governed by right views (*sammādiṭṭhikammasamādāna*)—with the breakup of the body, after death, have reappeared in the good destination (*sugati*), in the heavenly world (*sagga loka*).’

Thus, with the divine eye (*dibba cakkhu*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and he understands how beings fare according to their *kamma*.
commentary_pali: 246-247. Dibbacakkhūpamāyaṃ vīthiṃ sañcaranteti aparāparaṃ sañcarante. Vīthiṃ carantetipi pāṭho. Ayamevattho. Tattha nagaramajjhe siṅghāṭakamhi pāsādo viya imassa bhikkhuno karajakāyo daṭṭhabbo, pāsāde ṭhito cakkhumā puriso viya ayameva dibbacakkhuṃ patvā ṭhito bhikkhu, gehaṃ pavisantā viya paṭisandhivasena mātukucchiyaṃ pavisantā, gehā nikkhamantā viya mātukucchito nikkhamantā, rathikāya vīthiṃ sañcarantā viya aparāparaṃ sañcaraṇakasattā, purato abbhokāsaṭṭhāne majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnā viya tīsu bhavesu tattha tattha nibbattasattā, pāsādatale ṭhitapurisassa tesaṃ manussānaṃ āvibhūtakālo viya dibbacakkhuñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu nibbattasattānaṃ āvibhūtakālo daṭṭhabbo. Idañca desanāsukhatthameva vuttaṃ. Āruppe pana dibbacakkhussa gocaro natthīti.
commentary_english:
246-247. Those who wander along the street are like the simile of the divine eye; they repeatedly wander.

There is also a reading: *vīthiṃ carantetipi pāṭho.*

This is the meaning.

There, in the middle of the city, in the square, the material body (karajakāya) of this *bhikkhu* should be seen as like a palace (pāsāda). The *bhikkhu* who has attained the divine eye (*dibba cakkhu*) and stands firm is like a man with keen sight standing in the palace. Those entering a house are like those entering the mother's womb (*mātukucchi*) by way of relinking (*patisandhi*); those leaving the house are like those leaving the womb. Those walking along the streets are like those beings who repeatedly wander in *saṃsāra*; those sitting in front, in the open air in the central square (*siṅghāṭaka*), are like the beings who are born here and there in the three realms of existence (tīsu bhavesu). The time of appearance of those humans to the man standing at the foot of the palace is like the time of appearance of beings born in the three realms of existence to the *bhikkhu* who, having directed his mind towards the knowledge of the divine eye (*dibbacakkhuñāṇa*), is sitting.

This statement is made only for ease of teaching (*desanāsukhattha*).

But the immaterial realm (*āruppe*) is not within the range (*gocara*) of the divine eye (*dibbacakkhussa*).

mula_pali: 247. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, majjhe siṅghāṭake pāsādo. Tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya manusse gehaṃ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikāyapi vīthiṃ sañcarante rathiyāpī rathiṃ sañcarante (sī.), rathiyāya vithiṃ sañcarantepi (syā.) majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnepi. Tassa evamassa – ‘ete manussā gehaṃ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikāya vīthiṃ sañcaranti, ete majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnā’ti. Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati  cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti – ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime  vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate; yathākammūpage satte pajānāti. ‘Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
mula_english: 247. "It is just as if, great king, there were a palace in the middle of a crossroads ( *siṅghāṭaka* ). A person with sight, standing there, could see people entering and leaving houses, walking along the streets (*rathikā* and *vīthi*), or sitting in the middle of the crossroads (*siṅghāṭaka*). He would think: 'These people are entering houses, these are leaving, these are walking along the street, these are sitting in the middle of the crossroads.' Just so, great king, when a monk's mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, spotless, free from defilements, malleable, ready to act, firm, and unshakeable, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings. With the divine eye (*dibba cakkhu*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and he understands beings according to their actions (*yathākammūpage sattā*): ‘These beings, who were characterized by misconduct of body (*kāyaduccarita*), misconduct of speech (*vacīduccarita*), and misconduct of mind (*manoduccarita*), revilers of the noble ones (*ariyānaṃ upavādakā*), holding wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhika*), and engaging in actions conditioned by wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā*), upon the dissolution of the body, after death, have arisen in a state of deprivation (*apāya*), in a bad destination (*duggati*), in the nether world (*vinipāta*), in hell (*niraya*). But these beings, who were characterized by good conduct of body (*kāyasucarita*), good conduct of speech (*vacīsucarita*), and good conduct of mind (*manosucarita*), not revilers of the noble ones (*ariyānaṃ anupavādakā*), holding right views (*sammādiṭṭhika*), and engaging in actions conditioned by right views (*sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā*), upon the dissolution of the body, after death, have arisen in a good destination (*sugati*), in the heavenly world (*sagga loka*).' Thus, with the divine eye (*dibba cakkhunā*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate; and he understands beings according to their actions (*yathākammūpage satte pajānāti*). This, great king, is a visible fruit of the monastic life (*sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ*), more excellent and sublime than the previous visible fruits of the monastic life (*sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca*)."
commentary_pali: 246-247. Dibbacakkhūpamāyaṃ vīthiṃ sañcaranteti aparāparaṃ sañcarante. Vīthiṃ carantetipi pāṭho. Ayamevattho. Tattha nagaramajjhe siṅghāṭakamhi pāsādo viya imassa bhikkhuno karajakāyo daṭṭhabbo, pāsāde ṭhito cakkhumā puriso viya ayameva dibbacakkhuṃ patvā ṭhito bhikkhu, gehaṃ pavisantā viya paṭisandhivasena mātukucchiyaṃ pavisantā, gehā nikkhamantā viya mātukucchito nikkhamantā, rathikāya vīthiṃ sañcarantā viya aparāparaṃ sañcaraṇakasattā, purato abbhokāsaṭṭhāne majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnā viya tīsu bhavesu tattha tattha nibbattasattā, pāsādatale ṭhitapurisassa tesaṃ manussānaṃ āvibhūtakālo viya dibbacakkhuñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharitvā nisinnassa bhikkhuno tīsu bhavesu nibbattasattānaṃ āvibhūtakālo daṭṭhabbo. Idañca desanāsukhatthameva vuttaṃ. Āruppe pana dibbacakkhussa gocaro natthīti.
commentary_english:
246-247. "Wandering along the street" in the simile of the divine eye means repeatedly wandering.

Alternatively, the reading could be *vīthiṃ carantetipi*.

This is the meaning.

There, in the middle of the city, the upper-terraced building (*pāsāda*) in the central square (*siṅghāṭaka*) is to be seen as like the material body (*karajakāya*) of this *bhikkhu*. The man with keen sight (*cakkhumā puriso*) standing in the building is like the *bhikkhu* who has attained the divine eye (*dibbacakkhuṃ*).
