The Blessed One said, "I too will go," and having said this, he addressed the venerable Ānanda, "Ānanda, announce to the twenty thousand who possess the six superknowledges that the Blessed One will go to Tissa the novice, a forest dweller."

Then, on the second day, a retinue of twenty thousand whose defilements were destroyed arose in the sky, and descending at the gateway of the village that was the range of his alms-seeking, at a distance of one hundred and twenty *yojana*, he put on his robe.

People going to that workplace, seeing this, said, "Our Teacher has come! Do not go to work!" and having said this, having prepared seats, having given rice gruel, and while making their morning meal, the young monks asked, "Where, venerable sir, is the Blessed One going?"

The lay followers [said,] "The Blessed One is not going anywhere else; he has come here to see Tissa the novice."

They were delighted, saying, "The Teacher has come to see our family supporter, the Elder! Surely our Elder is not insignificant!"

Then, at the end of the Blessed One’s meal, the novice, having gone for alms in the village, asked, "Lay followers, [where is] the great community of monks?"

Then they announced to him, "Teacher, venerable sir, has come!"

He approached the Blessed One and inquired about alms.

The Teacher, taking his bowl in his hand, said, "Enough, Tissa, the meal is finished."

Then, having taken leave of his preceptor, having sat down on his own seat, he made his meal.

Then, at the end of the meal, the Teacher, having spoken a blessing, having departed, and having stood at the village gate, said, "Which, Tissa, is the path you take to your dwelling place?"

"This is the Blessed One!"

Showing the path, [the Buddha said], "Go ahead, Tissa!"

The Blessed One, even though he was the path-shower of the world with its gods, thinking, "I will see the novice," made him the path-shower on the entire three-*gāvuta* path.

He, having gone to his dwelling place, performed his duties for the Blessed One.

Then the Blessed One [asked] him, "Which, Tissa, is your promenade?" and having asked this, having gone there, having sat down on the stone seat of the novice, he asked, "Tissa, do you live happily in this place?"

He said, "Yes, venerable sir, to one living in this place, hearing the sound of lions, tigers, elephants, deer, peacocks, and so on, an awareness of the wilderness arises. With that, I live happily."

Then the Blessed One said to him, "Tissa, assemble the community of monks! I will give you the inheritance of the Buddha!" and having said this, having fully ordained [him] in the assembled community of monks, he went to his own dwelling place.

This is called a hurried tour.

That going, however, by means of the regular sequence of villages and market towns, daily, in terms of one or two *yojana*, bestowing favor on the world by means of the conduct of alms-seeking and so on, this is called an unhurried tour.
Furthermore, while the Blessed One was wandering on *cārika*, he would travel in one of these three regions: the great *maṇḍala*, the middle *maṇḍala*, and the inner *maṇḍala*.

There, the great *maṇḍala* was nine *yojana*s in circumference, the middle *maṇḍala* was six *yojana*s, and the inner *maṇḍala* was three *yojana*s.

Whenever he wanted to travel on *cārika* in the great *maṇḍala*, he would conclude the great *pravāraṇā*, and on the first day after the new moon, he would set out surrounded by a great community of monks.

All around, for a hundred *yojana*s, there would be a single uproar.

Those who arrived earlier were able to extend invitations.

In the other two *maṇḍala*s, offerings would flow into the great *maṇḍala*.

There, the Blessed One, dwelling for a day or two in those various villages and market towns, would favor the great multitude by accepting material gifts, and by teaching the Dharma, he would increase their wholesome qualities that were connected with detachment, and in nine months he would conclude the *cārika*.

But if, during the rains retreat, the *samatha* and *vipassanā* of the monks were weak, then, having postponed the great *pravāraṇā*, having given the *pravāraṇā-saṅgaha*, having concluded the *pravāraṇā* on the full-moon day of Kattika, on the first day after the new moon of Migasira, he would set out surrounded by a great community of monks and would enter into the middle *maṇḍala*.

For some other reason as well, wanting to travel on *cārika* in the middle *maṇḍala*, he would dwell there for four months and then set out.

Just as stated, in the other two *maṇḍala*s, offerings would flow into the middle *maṇḍala*.

The Blessed One, just as before, would favor the world, and in eight months he would conclude the *cārika*.

But if, even after the rains retreat of four months, the beings who were to be trained by the Blessed One had faculties that were not yet mature, then, waiting for the ripening of their faculties, having dwelt there for another month, or two, or three, or four months, he would set out surrounded by a great community of monks.

Just as stated, in the other two *maṇḍala*s, offerings would flow into the inner *maṇḍala*.

The Blessed One, just as before, would favor the world, and in seven or six or five or four months he would conclude the *cārika*.

Thus, in these three *maṇḍala*s, while wandering on *cārika* wherever he might, he would not travel for the sake of robes, etc.

Then those who were poor, young, old, and sick, when would they come and see the *tathāgata*?

But when I am wandering on *cārika*, the great multitude will obtain a sight of the *tathāgata*.

There, some will gladden their minds, some will honor him with garlands, etc., some will give a spoonful of alms, some, abandoning wrong views, will become those with right view.

That will be for their welfare and happiness for a long time.

Thus, he wanders on *cārika* out of compassion for the world.

Moreover, for four reasons the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, travel on *cārika*: for the sake of the ease of the body by means of walking, for the sake of the opportunity to gain material support at the right time, for the sake of establishing the training rules for the monks, and in order to awaken beings who are to be awakened whose faculties have matured in various places.

Furthermore, for four other reasons the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, travel on *cārika*: thinking, “They will go for refuge to the Buddha,” or “They will go for refuge to the Dharma, the *saṅgha*,” or thinking, “With a great rain of Dharma, I will satisfy the four assemblies.”

Furthermore, for five other reasons the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, travel on *cārika*: thinking, “They will abstain from killing living beings,” or “from taking what is not given, from sexual misconduct, from false speech, from negligence due to intoxicants and liquor.”

Furthermore, for eight other reasons the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, travel on *cārika*: thinking, “They will attain the first *jhāna*,” or “the second *jhāna*…pe… the attainment of neither perception nor non-perception.”

Furthermore, for eight other reasons the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, travel on *cārika*: thinking, “They will attain the path of stream-entry,” or “the fruit of stream-entry…pe… they will realize the fruit of *arhat*ship.”

This unhurried *cārika* is what is intended here by *cārika*.

But that is twofold: unconfined *cārika* and confined *cārika*.

There, that which one travels in succession from village to market town to city, that is called unconfined *cārika*.

That which one travels for the sake of just one being who is to be awakened, that is called confined *cārika*.

This is what is intended here.

At that time, it is said, at the end of the Blessed One’s task in the last watch of the night, having spread his net of knowledge throughout the ten-thousand world-systems, while he was looking at those who were to be awakened, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti entered into the interior of the net of omniscient knowledge.

Then the Blessed One thought, “This Brahmin appears in my net of knowledge; is there a basis for him?” and while investigating, having seen the basis for the path of stream-entry, he thought, “When I have gone to that country, he will send Ambaṭṭha, a resident student, to me for the sake of investigating the marks, and he, having engaged in debate and counter-debate with me, will speak various kinds of uncivil words, and I, having tamed him, will make him free from dependence.

He will tell his teacher, and then his teacher, having heard that speech, will come to me and will investigate my marks, and to him I will teach the Dharma.

He will be established in the fruit of stream-entry at the conclusion of the teaching.

The teaching will be fruitful for the great multitude,” and surrounded by a community of five hundred monks, he set out for that country.

Therefore it was said, “While wandering on *cārika* in Kosala with a great community of monks, with about five hundred monks.”

“Yena Icchānaṅgalanti” means by whatever direction one should approach Icchānaṅgala.

Or, in whatever region Icchānaṅgala is located.

"Ijjhānaṅgalantipi pāṭho."

“Tadavasarīti” means he approached it, or he approached that.
The meaning is that he went in that direction or went to that place.

He dwells at Icchānangala, that is, in the Icchānangala grove. Relying on Icchānangala, in the Icchānangala grove, having established the encampment of morality (*śīlakhandhāvāraṃ bandhitvā*), having raised the banner of concentration (*samādhikontaṃ ussāpetvā*), the Dharma-king (*dhammarājā*), turning the stream of omniscient knowledge (*sabbaññutaññāṇasaraṃ parivattayamāno*), dwells with a dwelling as he pleases (*yathābhirucitena vihārena viharati*).

mula_pali: 255. Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ukkaṭṭhaṃ pokkharasātī (sī.), pokkharasādi (pī.) ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ. Assosi kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti – ‘‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi icchānaṅgalaṃ anuppatto icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ bhagavāti (syā. kaṃ.), uparisoṇadaṇḍasuttādīsupi buddhaguṇakathāyaṃ evameva dissati. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ  pakāseti. Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī’’ti.
mula_english:
Thus [it is said].

255. Now at that time, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti was living in Ukkaṭṭha, a place that was populous, with grass, timber, and water, rich in grain, a royal possession, granted by King Pasenadi of Kosala as a royal gift, a *brahmadeyya* grant (a grant to a Brahmin).

The Brahmin Pokkharasāti heard: "The ascetic Gotama, son of the Sakyans, who went forth from the Sakyan clan, while wandering in the Kosala region with a large community of monks, with about five hundred monks, has arrived at Icchānaṅgala and is staying in the grove in the forest near Icchānaṅgala.

Now, concerning the venerable Gotama, such an auspicious report has spread: 'Indeed, the Blessed One is an *arahaṃ* (worthy one), a *sammāsambuddho* (fully enlightened one), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a *sugato* (well-gone one), a knower of the world (*lokavidū*), an unsurpassed (*anuttaro*) trainer of those to be tamed (*purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a Buddha, a Blessed One (*bhagavā*)'.

In the Uparisoṇadaṇḍa Sutta and other texts, the same is seen in the discussion of the qualities of the Buddha.

He, having realized it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*), proclaims this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its *Māras* (*samārakaṃ*) and *Brahmās* (*sabrahmakaṃ*), its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ*), its princes and people (*sadevamanussaṃ*).

He teaches the *Dhamma*, which is lovely in its beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), lovely in its middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), lovely in its ending (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*), with the spirit and the letter (*sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ*); he reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaṃ*) that is perfectly complete (*kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ*) and purified (*parisuddhaṃ*).

'It is good to see such worthy *arahats* (*arahataṃ*)'."
commentary_pali: 255.Tena kho pana samayenāti yena samayena bhagavā tattha viharati, tena samayena, tasmiṃ samayeti ayamattho. Brahmaṃ aṇatīti brāhmaṇo, mante sajjhāyatīti attho. Idameva hi jātibrāhmaṇānaṃ niruttivacanaṃ. Ariyā pana bāhitapāpattā brāhmaṇāti vuccanti. Pokkharasātīti  idaṃ tassa nāmaṃ. Kasmā pokkharasātīti vuccati. Tassa kira kāyo setapokkharasadiso, devanagare ussāpitarajatatoraṇaṃ viya sobhati. Sīsaṃ panassa kāḷavaṇṇaṃ indanīlamaṇimayaṃ viya. Massupi candamaṇḍale kāḷamegharāji viya khāyati. Akkhīni nīluppalasadisāni. Nāsā rajatapanāḷikā viya suvaṭṭitā suparisuddhā. Hatthapādatalāni ceva mukhadvārañca katalākhārasaparikammaṃ viya sobhati, ativiya sobhaggappatto brāhmaṇassa attabhāvo. Arājake ṭhāne rājānaṃ kātuṃ yuttamimaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ. Evamesa sassiriko. Iti naṃ pokkharasadisattā pokkharasātīti sañjānanti. Ayaṃ  pana kassapasammāsambuddhakāle tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū dasabalassa dānaṃ datvā dhammadesanaṃ sutvā devaloke nibbatti. So tato manussalokamāgacchanto mātukucchivāsaṃ jigucchitvā himavantapadese mahāsare padumagabbhe nibbatti. Tassa ca sarassa avidūre tāpaso paṇṇasālāya vasati. So tīre ṭhito taṃ padumaṃ disvā – ‘‘idaṃ padumaṃ avasesapadumehi mahantataraṃ. Pupphitakāle naṃ gahessāmī’’ti cintesi. Taṃ sattāhenāpi na pupphati. Tāpaso kasmā nu kho idaṃ sattāhenāpi na pupphati. Handa naṃ gahessāmīti otaritvā gaṇhi. Taṃ tena nāḷato chinnamattaṃyeva  pupphitaṃ. Athassabbhantare suvaṇṇacuṇṇapiñjaraṃ viya rajatabimbakaṃ padumareṇupiñjaraṃ setavaṇṇaṃ dārakaṃ addasa. So mahāpuñño esa bhavissati. Handa naṃ paṭijaggāmīti paṇṇasālaṃ netvā paṭijaggitvā sattavassakālato paṭṭhāya tayo vede uggaṇhāpesi. Dārako tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāraṃ gantvā paṇḍito byatto jambudīpe aggabrāhmaṇo ahosi. So aparena samayena rañño kosalassa sippaṃ dassesi. Athassa sippe pasanno rājā ukkaṭṭhaṃ nāma mahānagaraṃ brahmadeyyaṃ adāsi. Iti naṃ pokkhare sayitattā pokkharasātīti sañjānanti. Ukkaṭṭhaṃ ajjhāvasatīti ukkaṭṭhanāmake nagare vasati. Abhibhavitvā vā āvasati. Tassa nagarassa sāmiko hutvā yāya mariyādāya tattha vasitabbaṃ, tāya mariyādāya vasi. Tassa kira nagarassa vatthuṃ ukkā ṭhapetvā ukkāsu jalamānāsu aggahesuṃ, tasmā taṃ ukkaṭṭhanti vuccati. Okkaṭṭhantipi pāṭho, soyevattho. Upasaggavasena panettha bhummatthe upayogavacanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tassa anupayogattā ca sesapadesu. Tattha lakkhaṇaṃ saddasatthato pariyesitabbaṃ. Sattussadanti sattehi ussadaṃ, ussannaṃ bahujanaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ. Posāvaniyahatthiassamoramigādianekasattasamākiṇṇañcāti  attho. Yasmā panetaṃ nagaraṃ bahi āvijjhitvā jātena hatthiassādīnaṃ ghāsatiṇena ceva gehacchādanatiṇena ca sampannaṃ. Tathā dārukaṭṭhehi ceva gehasambhārakaṭṭhehi ca. Yasmā cassabbhantare vaṭṭacaturassādisaṇṭhānā bahū pokkharaṇiyo jalajakusumavicittāni ca bahūni anekāni taḷākāni udakassa niccabharitāneva honti, tasmā satiṇakaṭṭhodakanti vuttaṃ. Saha dhaññenāti sadhaññaṃ pubbaṇṇāparaṇṇādibhedaṃ bahudhaññasannicayanti attho . Ettāvatā yasmiṃ nagare brāhmaṇo setacchattaṃ ussāpetvā rājalīlāya vasati, tassa samiddhisampatti dīpitā hoti. Rājato laddhaṃ bhoggaṃ rājabhoggaṃ. Kena  dinnanti ce? Raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ. Rājadāyanti rañño dāyabhūtaṃ, dāyajjanti attho. Brahmadeyyanti seṭṭhadeyyaṃ, chattaṃ ussāpetvā rājasaṅkhepena bhuñjitabbanti attho. Atha vā rājabhogganti sabbaṃ chejjabhejjaṃ anusāsantena nadītitthapabbatādīsu suṅkaṃ gaṇhantena setacchattaṃ ussāpetvā raññā hutvā bhuñjitabbaṃ. Raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyanti ettha taṃ nagaraṃ raññā dinnattā rājadāyaṃ dāyakarājadīpanatthaṃ panassa ‘‘raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinna’’nti idaṃ vuttaṃ. Brahmadeyyanti seṭṭhadeyyaṃ. Yathā dinnaṃ na puna gahetabbaṃ hoti, nissaṭṭhaṃ pariccattaṃ. Evaṃ dinnanti attho. Assosīti suṇi upalabhi, sotadvārasampattavacananigghosānusārena aññāsi. Khoti avadhāraṇatthe padapūraṇamatte vā nipāto. Tattha avadhāraṇatthena assosi eva, nāssa koci savanantarāyo ahosīti ayamattho veditabbo. Padapūraṇena pana padabyañjanasiliṭṭhatāmattameva. Idāni yamatthaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti assosi, taṃ pakāsento – ‘‘samaṇo khalu bho gotamo’’tiādimāha. Tattha samitapāpattā samaṇoti veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ – ‘‘samitāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā’’tiādi (ma. ni. 1.434). Bhagavā ca anuttarena ariyamaggena samitapāpo. Tenassa yathābhūtaguṇādhigatametaṃ nāmaṃ, yadidaṃ samaṇoti. Khalūti anussavanatthe nipāto. Bhoti brāhmaṇajātisamudāgataṃ ālapanamattaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ – ‘‘bhovādī nāma so hoti, sace hoti sakiñcano’’ti (dha. pa. 55). Gotamoti bhagavantaṃ gottavasena parikitteti. Tasmā samaṇo khalu bho gotamoti ettha samaṇo kira bho gotamagottoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Sakyaputtoti  idaṃ pana bhagavato uccākulaparidīpanaṃ . Sakyakulā pabbajitoti saddhāpabbajitabhāvaparidīpanaṃ. Kenaci pārijuññena anabhibhūto aparikkhīṇaṃyeva  taṃ kulaṃ pahāya saddhāya pabbajitoti vuttaṃ hoti. Tato paraṃ vuttatthameva. Taṃ kho panātiādi sāmaññaphale vuttameva. Sādhu kho panāti sundaraṃ kho pana. Atthāvahaṃ sukhāvahanti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathārūpānaṃ arahatanti yathārūpo so bhavaṃ gotamo, evarūpānaṃ yathābhūtaguṇādhigamena loke arahantoti laddhasaddhānaṃ arahataṃ. Dassanaṃ hotīti pasādasommāni akkhīni ummīletvā dassanamattampi sādhu hotīti, evaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ katvā.
commentary_english:
255. Thus, what is the meaning of "at that time"? It means, "at the time when the Lord dwells there, at that time, in that circumstance." This is the meaning.

A *brāhmaṇa* is so called because he studies Brahman; it is because he recites *mantras* that he is so called. This is the meaning.

Indeed, this itself is the etymological explanation for *brāhmaṇas* by birth.

Moreover, noble ones are called *brāhmaṇas* because they have banished evil.

"Pokkharasāti" — this is his name.

Why is he called Pokkharasāti?

It is said that his body is like a white lotus (*śvetapadma*); he shines like a silver arch raised in a celestial city.

His head is the color of dark blue like an *indranīlamaṇi* jewel.

His beard appears like a row of dark clouds on the surface of the moon.

His eyes are like blue lotuses (*nīlotpala*).

His nose is like a silver pipe, well-rounded and very pure.

Indeed, the state of being of a *brāhmaṇa* whose palms and soles of his feet and also the entrance of his mouth shine like the work done with *katalākhā* resin, is exceedingly endowed with beauty.

In a place without a king, it is fitting to make this *brāhmaṇa* the king.

Thus, he is glorious.

Thus, they recognize him as Pokkharasāti because of his likeness to a lotus (*pokkhara*).

Furthermore, during the time of the Buddha Kaśyapa, having gone to the other shore of the three *Vedas*, having given a gift to the one with ten powers (*daśabala*), having heard the teaching of the Dharma, he was reborn in the world of the gods.

Having passed away from there and coming to the world of humans, disgusted with dwelling in a mother's womb, he was reborn in a lotus womb in a great lake in the region of the Himalayas.

Not far from that lake, a hermit dwells in a leaf hut (*parṇaśālā*).

Standing on the bank, he saw that lotus and thought, "This lotus is much larger than the other lotuses.

I will take it when it blooms," he thought.

But it did not bloom even after a week.

The hermit [thought]: "Why does this not bloom even after a week?"

"Come, I will take it," and descending [into the lake], he grasped it.

As soon as he had cut it from the stem, it bloomed.

Then, inside it, he saw a boy the color of gold powder (*suvarṇacuṇa*), like a silver image (*rajatabimbaka*), the color of lotus pollen (*padmareṇu*), of white color.

"He will be of great merit (*mahāpuṇya*."

"Come, I will take care of him," taking him to his leaf hut (*parṇaśālā*) and raising him, from the age of seven years he taught him the three *Vedas*.

The boy, having gone to the other shore of the three *Vedas*, became a learned scholar (*paṇḍita*) and an eminent *brāhmaṇa* in Jambudvīpa.

Then, at another time, he showed his skill (*śilpa*) to King Kosala.

Then, pleased with his skill (*śilpa*), the king gave him a great city named Ukkaṭṭha as a royal grant (*brahmadeyya*).

Thus, they recognize him as Pokkharasāti because he slept in a lotus (*pokkhara*).

He dwells in a city named Ukkaṭṭha because he dwells in Ukkaṭṭha.

Or, he dwells there having overcome [others].

Having become the lord of that city, he lived according to the custom by which one should live there.

It is said that they established the site of that city by placing torches (*ukkā*) and grasping [the ground] as the torches blazed; therefore, it is called Ukkaṭṭha.

Okkaṭṭha is also a reading; the meaning is the same.

Here, it should be understood that the statement about use is in the sense of abundance, due to the force of the prefix (*upasarga*).

And because of its non-use, also in the remaining places.

There, the characteristic (*lakṣaṇa*) should be sought from grammar (*śabdaśāstra*).
Being crowded means being teeming with seated people, filled with a multitude, and thronged with humans.

The meaning is: crowded with many beings such as elephants, horses, peacocks, deer, and other animals that are fed and protected.

Because this city is well-supplied outside with grass and timber for the fodder of elephants and horses, as well as timber for roofing houses.

And also with wood for construction and wood for building materials for houses.

Because inside it there are many ponds with round, square, and other shapes, beautiful with aquatic flowers, and also many various lakes that are always full of water, therefore it is said to have grass, wood, and water.

"Together with grain" means possessing grain, having various kinds of early and late crops, and being an accumulation of much grain.

Thus, the prosperity and wealth of the city where a *brāhmaṇa* dwells, raising a white umbrella and living in royal splendor, are shown.

What is received from the king as wealth is royal wealth (*rājabhoggaṃ*).

If asked, "By whom was it given?", it was given by King Pasenadi of Kosala.

Royal inheritance (*rājadāya*) means what is rightfully belonging to the king, that is, an inheritance.

*Brahmadeyya* means the best gift, which is enjoying with royal authority by raising an umbrella.

Or alternatively, royal wealth (*rājabhogga*) means that it should be enjoyed by ruling all that should be cut and broken, collecting taxes at river crossings, bathing places, mountains, and so on, raising a white umbrella, and being a king.

Because the city was given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, therefore, in "Given by King Pasenadi of Kosala," this is said to illuminate that the royal inheritance (*rājadāya*) is a gift from the king.

*Brahmadeyya* means the best gift.

Just as what has been given should not be taken back, it is relinquished and abandoned.

Thus, the meaning is "given."

He heard means he listened and perceived, he understood according to the sound of the word reaching the ear-door.

*Kho* is a particle in the sense of emphasis or merely filling out the line.

There, with emphasis, he heard indeed, there was no obstruction to his hearing, this meaning should be understood.

Merely by filling the line, it is only for the elegance of the words.

Now, revealing the meaning that the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti heard, he said, "The *samaṇa* Gotama, indeed, sir," and so on.

There, *samaṇa* should be understood as one who has calmed evil.

This was said, "Evil, unwholesome things are calmed for him," and so on.

And the Blessed One has calmed evil with the unsurpassed noble path (*ariyamagga*).

Therefore, this name came to be applied to him as one who has attained qualities as they really are, that is, *samaṇa*.

*Khalu* is a particle in the sense of subsequent hearing.

*Bho* is merely a form of address arising from the *brāhmaṇa* caste.

This was also said, "He is called 'one who says *bho*', if he has something (*sakiñcano*)," (Dha. Pa. 55).

"Gotama" means he praises the Blessed One in terms of lineage (*gottavasena*).

Therefore, in "The *samaṇa* Gotama, indeed, sir," here, the meaning should be seen as "The *samaṇa* is said to be of the Gotama lineage, sir."

"*Sakyaputta*" this reveals the Blessed One's eminent family.

"*Sakyakulā pabbajito*" reveals the state of having gone forth due to faith (*saddhā*).

It is said that he went forth in faith, abandoning that family without being overcome by any distress, while it was not diminished at all.

After that, it is only the meaning that has been said.

That which is said beginning with "*taṃ kho pana*," is only in the fruit of commonality.
Indeed, it is good, indeed it is beautiful.

It is said to bring benefit and bring happiness.

"Such worthy ones": Just as the venerable Gotama is, so are those in the world who, through the attainment of qualities in accordance with reality, are worthy ones; those who have gained faith are worthy ones (arhat).

"Seeing is good": Having opened the pleasant and gentle eyes, even just the mere sight is good; thus, having made this intention.

mula_pali: 256. Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa ambaṭṭho nāma māṇavo antevāsī hoti ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ bedānaṃ (ka.) pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ  itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo anuññātapaṭiññāto sake ācariyake tevijjake pāvacane  – ‘‘yamahaṃ jānāmi, taṃ tvaṃ jānāsi; yaṃ tvaṃ jānāsi tamahaṃ jānāmī’’ti.
mula_english: At that time, Pokkharasāti the *brāhmaṇa* had a student named Ambaṭṭha, a young man who was a reciter, a holder of *mantras*, perfected in the Three *Vedas*, along with their *nighaṇḍu* (glossary), *keṭubha* (commentary), and variations of letters; fifthly, with the *itihāsa* (tradition); skilled in *pada* (grammar) and *veyyākaraṇa* (etymology), and not deficient in *lokāyata* (natural philosophy) and the *mahāpurisalakkhaṇa* (marks of a great man), admitted and accepted by his teacher among the "three-knowing" *brāhmaṇas* with the words: "What I know, you know; what you know, I know."
commentary_pali: 256.Ajjhāyakoti idaṃ – ‘‘na dānime jhāyanti, na dānime jhāyantīti kho, vāseṭṭha, ajjhāyakā ajjhāyakā tveva tatiyaṃ akkharaṃ upanibbatta’’nti, evaṃ paṭhamakappikakāle jhānavirahitānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ garahavacanaṃ. Idāni pana taṃ ajjhāyatīti ajjhāyako. Mante parivattetīti iminā atthena pasaṃsāvacanaṃ katvā voharanti. Mante dhāretīti mantadharo. Tiṇṇaṃ vedānanti iruvedayajuvedasāmavedānaṃ. Oṭṭhapahatakaraṇavasena pāraṃ gatoti pāragū. Saha nighaṇḍunā ca keṭubhena ca sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ. Nighaṇḍūti nighaṇḍurukkhādīnaṃ vevacanapakāsakaṃ satthaṃ. Keṭubhanti kiriyākappavikappo kavīnaṃ upakārāvahaṃ satthaṃ. Saha akkharappabhedena sākkharappabhedānaṃ. Akkharappabhedoti sikkhā ca nirutti ca. Itihāsapañcamānanti āthabbaṇavedaṃ catutthaṃ katvā itiha āsa, itiha āsāti īdisavacanapaṭisaṃyutto purāṇakathāsaṅkhāto itihāso pañcamo etesanti itihāsapañcamā, tesaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ vedānaṃ. Padaṃ tadavasesañca byākaraṇaṃ adhīyati vedeti cāti padako veyyākaraṇo. Lokāyataṃ vuccati vitaṇḍavādasatthaṃ. Mahāpurisalakkhaṇanti  mahāpurisānaṃ buddhādīnaṃ lakkhaṇadīpakaṃ dvādasasahassaganthapamāṇaṃ satthaṃ. Yattha soḷasasahassagāthāparimāṇā buddhamantā nāma ahesuṃ, yesaṃ vasena iminā lakkhaṇena samannāgatā buddhā nāma honti, iminā paccekabuddhā, iminā dve aggasāvakā, asīti mahāsāvakā , buddhamātā, buddhapitā, aggupaṭṭhāko, aggupaṭṭhāyikā, rājā cakkavattīti ayaṃ viseso paññāyati. Anavayoti  imesu lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anūno paripūrakārī, avayo na hotīti vuttaṃ hoti. Avayo nāma yo tāni atthato ca ganthato ca sandhāretuṃ na sakkoti. Anuññātapaṭiññātoti anuññāto ceva paṭiññāto ca. Ācariyenassa ‘‘yaṃ ahaṃ jānāmi, taṃ tvaṃ jānāsī’’tiādinā anuññāto. ‘‘Āma ācariyā’’ti attanā tassa paṭivacanadānapaṭiññāya paṭiññātoti attho. Katarasmiṃ adhikāre? Sake ācariyake tevijjake pāvacane. Esa kira brāhmaṇo cintesi ‘‘imasmiṃ loke ‘ahaṃ buddho, ahaṃ buddho’ti uggatassa nāmaṃ gahetvā bahū janā vicaranti. Tasmā na me anussavamatteneva upasaṅkamituṃ yuttaṃ. Ekaccañhi upasaṅkamantassa apakkamanampi garu hoti, anatthopi uppajjati. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ mama antevāsikaṃ pesetvā – ‘buddho vā, no vā’ti jānitvāva upasaṅkameyya’’nti, tasmā māṇavaṃ āmantetvā ayaṃ tātātiādimāha.
commentary_english:
256.

“Ajjhāyaka” means this: “Now, these do not meditate; now, these do not meditate.” Thus, Vāseṭṭha, the term "ajjhāyaka, ajjhāyaka" has arisen as the third syllable. In this way, in the early aeon, it was a term of reproach for Brahmins devoid of meditation (jhāna).

Now, because he studies that, he is an "ajjhāyaka".

Because he recites mantras, they speak praising words with this meaning.

Because he holds mantras, he is a *mantadhara*.

"Of the three Vedas" means of the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, and Sāmaveda.

Because he has gone to the further shore by means of effort struck by the lips, he is a *pāragū*.

Together with *nighaṇḍu* and with *keṭubha*, [they are called] *sanighaṇḍukeṭubhāna*.

*Nighaṇḍu* means a treatise revealing the synonyms of trees (rukkhādi) and so forth.

*Keṭubha* means a treatise that differentiates the activities and possibilities of poets and brings benefit.

Together with the divisions of letters, [they are called] *sākkharappabhedāna*.

"Divisions of letters" means *śikṣā* and *nirukti*.

"Having the *itihāsa* as fifth" means having made the Atharvaveda the fourth. *Itihāsa* was connected with such words as "Thus it was; thus it was," is reckoned as ancient stories, and is the fifth of these. Therefore, [they are called] "having the *itihāsa* as fifth," of those Vedas.

Because he studies and knows the words, their residues, and grammar, he is a *padako veyyākaraṇo*.

*Lokāyata* is said to be a treatise on destructive criticism (vitaṇḍavāda).

*Mahāpurisalakkhaṇa* means a treatise that illuminates the characteristics of great men (mahāpurisa) such as Buddhas and has a measure of twelve thousand *ganthas*.

Where there were sixteen thousand verses measuring the Buddha-mantras by name, by the power of which the Buddhas are endowed with these characteristics, by this [characteristic are endowed] the *paccekabuddhas*, by this, the two foremost disciples, the eighty great disciples, the Buddha's mother, the Buddha's father, the foremost attendant, the foremost female attendant, the wheel-turning monarch (rājā cakkavattī): this distinction is known.

"Anavaya" means not inferior, a fulfiller in these *lokāyata* and *mahāpurisalakkhaṇa*; it is said that "there is no *avaya*."

*Avaya* is the name of one who is not able to maintain those [texts] in meaning and in text.

"Anuññātapaṭiññāta" means both *anuññāta* and *paṭiññāta*.

He is *anuññāta* by the teacher with "[Whatever] I know, that you know," and so forth.

"Yes, teacher," by himself, with the *paṭiññā* of giving a reply to that, [he is] *paṭiññāta*: this is the meaning.

In which authority? In his own teaching, in the three knowledges (*tevijjaka*), in the transmitted word (*pāvacana*).

That Brahmin thought, "In this world, many people wander about, taking the name of one who is eminent, saying, 'I am Buddha, I am Buddha.'"

Therefore, it is not fitting for me to approach him merely by hearsay.

Indeed, for one approaching, even retreating is serious; and also, misfortune arises.

"What if I were to send my student, and after knowing whether he is Buddha or not, then I would approach?" Therefore, having addressed the youth, he said, "This, father," and so forth.

mula_pali: 257. Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘ayaṃ, tāta ambaṭṭha, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi icchānaṅgalaṃ anuppatto icchānaṅgale viharati icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍe. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ, sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotīti. Ehi tvaṃ tāta ambaṭṭha, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā  samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ jānāhi, yadi vā taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ tathāsantaṃyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vā no tathā. Yadi vā so bhavaṃ gotamo tādiso, yadi vā na tādiso, tathā mayaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ vedissāmā’’ti.
mula_english:
257. Then the Brahmin Pokkharasāti addressed the young Brahmin Ambaṭṭha: “This, dear Ambaṭṭha, is the renunciate Gotama, son of the Sakyans, who has gone forth from the Sakya clan, wandering in Kosala with a large community of monks, with about five hundred monks, has arrived at Ichānangala, and is staying in the Ichānangala forest grove.

And concerning that Venerable Gotama, such a good report has spread about: ‘Indeed, that Blessed One is an *arhat*, a perfectly enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjā-caraṇa-sampanno*), a Well-Farer (*sugato*), Knower of the Worlds (*lokavidū*), unsurpassed trainer of those who can be tamed (*anuttaro purisa-damma-sārathi*), teacher of gods and humans (*satthā deva-manussānam*), the Buddha, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*)’.

He, having realized it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*), declares this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its Māras (*samārakaṃ*), and its Brahmās (*sabrahmakaṃ*), this generation with its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇa-brāhmaṇiṃ*), its princes and people (*sadeva-manussaṃ*).

He teaches the Dharma (*dhammaṃ*) that is good in the beginning (*ādi-kalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhe-kalyāṇaṃ*), and good in the end (*pariyosāna-kalyāṇaṃ*), with its meaning and its phrasing (*sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ*); he reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaṃ*) that is perfectly complete (*kevala-paripuṇṇaṃ*) and pure (*parisuddhaṃ pakāseti*).

It is good to see such *arahats* (*tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotīti*).”

“Come, dear Ambaṭṭha, go to where the renunciate Gotama is; having gone, find out about the renunciate Gotama: whether the report that has spread about the Venerable Gotama is actually true, or whether it is not so.

Whether the Venerable Gotama is such, or whether he is not such, in that way we will know the Venerable Gotama."
commentary_pali: 257.Taṃ bhavantanti tassa bhoto gotamassa. Tathā santaṃ yevāti tathā satoyeva. Idhāpi hi itthambhūtākhyānatthavaseneva upayogavacanaṃ.
commentary_english:
257.
Regarding this venerable Gotama.
Thus, while he exists, so he exists.
Here, too, the statement of application is in accordance with the purpose of describing it as such.

mula_pali: 258. ‘‘Yathā kathaṃ panāhaṃ, bho, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ jānissāmi – ‘yadi vā taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ tathāsantaṃyeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vā no tathā. Yadi vā so bhavaṃ gotamo tādiso, yadi vā na tādiso’’’ti? ‘‘Āgatāni kho, tāta ambaṭṭha, amhākaṃ mantesu dvattiṃsa mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni, yehi samannāgatassa mahāpurisassa dveyeva gatiyo bhavanti anaññā. Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, rājā hoti cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato . Tassimāni satta ratanāni bhavanti. Seyyathidaṃ – cakkaratanaṃ, hatthiratanaṃ, assaratanaṃ, maṇiratanaṃ, itthiratanaṃ, gahapatiratanaṃ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ. Parosahassaṃ kho panassa puttā bhavanti  sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā. So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasati. Sace kho pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati , arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado. Ahaṃ kho pana, tāta ambaṭṭha, mantānaṃ dātā; tvaṃ mantānaṃ paṭiggahetā’’ti.
mula_english:
258. 'Sir, how am I to know the truth about the esteemed Gotama? Is the report that has spread about the esteemed Gotama actually true, or is it not? Is the esteemed Gotama such as they say, or is he not?'

"Indeed, Ambaṭṭha, in our *mantras* (sacred verses), there are thirty-two marks of a great man (*mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni*). A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.

If he lives the household life, he becomes a ruler, a *cakravartin* (wheel-turning monarch), a righteous king who rules by the *Dhamma* (law), master of the four quarters, all-victorious, who has established the security of his country and is possessed of the seven treasures (*satta ratanāni*).

He has these seven treasures.

These are: the *cakkaratana* (wheel treasure), the *hatthiratana* (elephant treasure), the *assaratana* (horse treasure), the *maṇiratana* (jewel treasure), the *itthiratana* (woman treasure), the *gahapatiratana* (householder treasure), and the *pariṇāyakaratana* (counselor treasure) as the seventh.

Moreover, he has more than a thousand sons who are heroes, of heroic stature, conquerors of the hostile army (*parasenappamaddanā*).

He dwells having conquered this earth bounded by the ocean, without stick or sword, by the *Dhamma* (law).

But if he goes forth from the household life into homelessness, he becomes an *arahant* (worthy one), a *sammāsambuddha* (fully enlightened Buddha), one who draws back the veil in the world.

And I, Ambaṭṭha, am the giver of the *mantras* (sacred verses); you are the receiver of them."
commentary_pali: 258.Yathā kathaṃ panāhaṃ, bho, tanti ettha kathaṃ panāhaṃ bho taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ jānissāmi, yathā sakkā so ñātuṃ, tathā me ācikkhāhīti attho. Yathāti vā nipātamattamevetaṃ. Kathanti ayaṃ ākārapucchā. Kenākārenāhaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ jānissāmīti attho. Evaṃ vutte kira naṃ upajjhāyo ‘‘kiṃ tvaṃ, tāta, pathaviyaṃ  ṭhito, pathaviṃ na passāmīti viya; candimasūriyānaṃ obhāse ṭhito, candimasūriye na passāmīti viya vadasī’’tiādīni vatvā jānanākāraṃ dassento āgatāni kho, tātātiādimāha. Tattha mantesūti vedesu. Tathāgato kira uppajjissatīti paṭikacceva suddhāvāsā devā vedesu lakkhaṇāni pakkhipitvā buddhamantā nāmeteti brāhmaṇaveseneva vede vācenti. Tadanusārena mahesakkhā sattā tathāgataṃ jānissantīti. Tena pubbe vedesu mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni  āgacchanti. Parinibbute pana tathāgate anukkamena antaradhāyanti. Tenetarahi natthīti. Mahāpurisassāti paṇidhisamādānañāṇakaruṇādiguṇamahato purisassa. Dveyeva gatiyoti dveyeva niṭṭhā. Kāmañcāyaṃ gatisaddo ‘‘pañca kho imā, sāriputta, gatiyo’’tiādīsu (ma. ni. 1.153) bhavabhede vattati. ‘‘Gati migānaṃ pavana’’ntiādīsu (pari. 399) nivāsaṭṭhāne. ‘‘Evaṃ adhimattagatimanto’’tiādīsu paññāyaṃ. ‘‘Gatigata’’ntiādīsu visaṭabhāve. Idha pana niṭṭhāyaṃ vattatīti veditabbo. Tattha  kiñcāpi yehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgato rājā cakkavattī hoti, na teheva buddho hoti; jātisāmaññato pana tāniyeva tānīti vuccanti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘yehi samannāgatassā’’ti. Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasatīti yadi agāre vasati. Rājā hoti cakkavattīti catūhi acchariyadhammehi, saṅgahavatthūhi ca lokaṃ rañjanato rājā, cakkaratanaṃ vatteti, catūhi sampatticakkehi vattati, tehi ca paraṃ vatteti, parahitāya ca iriyāpathacakkānaṃ vatto etasmiṃ atthīti cakkavattī. Ettha ca rājāti sāmaññaṃ. Cakkavattīti visesaṃ. Dhammena caratīti dhammiko. Ñāyena samena vattatīti attho. Dhammena rajjaṃ labhitvā rājā jātoti dhammarājā. Parahitadhammakaraṇena vā dhammiko. Attahitadhammakaraṇena dhammarājā. Caturantāya issaroti cāturanto, catusamuddaantāya, catubbidhadīpavibhūsitāya pathaviyā issaroti attho. Ajjhattaṃ  kopādipaccatthike bahiddhā ca sabbarājāno vijetīti vijitāvī. Janapadatthāvariyappattoti janapade dhuvabhāvaṃ thāvarabhāvaṃ patto, na sakkā kenaci cāletuṃ. Janapado vā tamhi thāvariyappatto anuyutto sakammanirato acalo asampavedhīti janapadatthāvariyappatto. Seyyathidanti nipāto, tassa cetāni katamānīti attho. Cakkaratanantiādīsu cakkañca, taṃ ratijananaṭṭhena ratanañcāti cakkaratanaṃ. Esa nayo sabbattha. Imesu pana ratanesu ayaṃ cakkavattirājā cakkaratanena ajitaṃ jināti, hatthiassaratanehi vijite yathāsukhaṃ anucarati, pariṇāyakaratanena  vijitamanurakkhati, avasesehi upabhogasukhamanubhavati. Paṭhamena cassa ussāhasattiyogo, pacchimena mantasattiyogo, hatthiassagahapatiratanehi pabhusattiyogo suparipuṇṇo hoti, itthimaṇiratanehi tividhasattiyogaphalaṃ. So itthimaṇiratanehi bhogasukhamanubhavati, sesehi issariyasukhaṃ. Visesato cassa purimāni tīṇi adosakusalamūlajanitakammānubhāvena sampajjanti, majjhimāni alobhakusalamūlajanitakammānubhāvena, pacchimamekaṃ amohakusalamūlajanitakammānubhāvenāti veditabbaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthāro pana bojjhaṅgasaṃyutte ratanasuttassa upadesato gahetabbo. Parosahassanti atirekasahassaṃ. Sūrāti abhīrukajātikā. Vīraṅgarūpāti devaputtasadisakāyā. Evaṃ tāva eke vaṇṇayanti. Ayaṃ panettha sabbhāvo. Vīrāti uttamasūrā vuccanti, vīrānaṃ aṅgaṃ vīraṅgaṃ, vīrakāraṇaṃ vīriyanti vuttaṃ hoti. Vīraṅgarūpaṃ etesanti vīraṅgarūpā, vīriyamayasarīrā viyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Parasenappamaddanāti sace paṭimukhaṃ tiṭṭheyya parasenā taṃ parimaddituṃ samatthāti adhippāyo. Dhammenāti ‘‘pāṇo na hantabbo’’tiādinā pañcasīladhammena . Arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchadoti ettha rāgadosamohamānadiṭṭhiavijjāduccaritachadanehi  sattahi paṭicchanne kilesandhakāre loke taṃ chadanaṃ vivaṭṭetvā samantato sañjātāloko hutvā ṭhitoti vivaṭṭacchado. Tattha paṭhamena padena pūjārahatā. Dutiyena tassā hetu, yasmā sammāsambuddhoti, tatiyena buddhattahetubhūtā vivaṭṭacchadatā vuttāti veditabbā. Atha vā vivaṭṭo ca vicchado cāti vivaṭṭacchado, vaṭṭarahito chadanarahito cāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tena arahaṃ vaṭṭābhāvena, sammāsambuddho chadanābhāvenāti evaṃ purimapadadvayasseva hetudvayaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, dutiyena vesārajjena cettha purimasiddhi, paṭhamena dutiyasiddhi, tatiyacatutthehi tatiyasiddhi hoti. Purimañca dhammacakkhuṃ, dutiyaṃ buddhacakkhuṃ, tatiyaṃ samantacakkhuṃ sādhetīti veditabbaṃ. Tvaṃ mantānaṃ paṭiggahetāti iminā’ssa mantesu sūrabhāvaṃ janeti.
commentary_english:
258.
"How then, sir, can I know the Venerable Gotama here? Please tell me how he can be known," is the meaning.

Or, "yathā" is merely a particle.

What does "how?" mean? This is a question of appearance.

The meaning is, "By what appearance can I know the Venerable Gotama?"

When this was said, his teacher, after saying things like, "Why do you, dear one, standing on the earth, say 'I do not see the earth'?; standing in the light of the moon and sun, say 'I do not see the moon and sun'?", showed the manner of knowing, saying, "These have come, dear one," etc.

There, "in the *mantras*" means in the *vedas*.

"The *Tathāgata* will arise": anticipating this, the gods of the Pure Abodes, inserting the characteristics in the *vedas*, cause the *buddha-mantras* to be named, causing the *vedas* to be recited in the guise of Brahmins.

According to that, beings of great power will know the *Tathāgata*.

Therefore, previously the characteristics of a great man appear in the *vedas*.

But when the *Tathāgata* has attained final *nirvāṇa*, they gradually disappear.

Therefore, now they do not exist.

"*Mahāpurisa*": [this refers to] a person who is great due to qualities such as vows, undertakings, knowledge, compassion, etc.

"*Dve yeva gatiyo*": there are only two destinies, only two ends.

Indeed, this word *gati* occurs in verses beginning "*Pañca kho imā, Sāriputta, gatiyo*," (M.
Ni.
1.
153) referring to difference in existence.

It [also] occurs in verses beginning "*Gati migānaṃ pavana*," (Pari.
399) referring to a dwelling place.

It [also] occurs in verses beginning "*Evaṃ adhimattagatimanto*," referring to wisdom (*prajñā*).

It [also] occurs in verses beginning "*gatigata*," referring to a scattered state.

Here, however, it should be understood as referring to the end (*niṭṭhā*).

There, although a king is a wheel-turning monarch (*cakravartin*) because he possesses certain characteristics, he is not a Buddha because of those very characteristics; however, due to generic similarity, they are called the same.

Therefore it was said: "*yehi samannāgatassa*."

"*Sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasati*" means if he dwells in a house.

"*Rājā hoti cakkavattīti*": because he pleases the world with four wondrous qualities (*acchariyadhamma*) and objects of generosity (*saṅgahavatthū*), he is a king (*rājā*); he turns the wheel-jewel (*cakkaratana*); he behaves with four wheels of accomplishment (*sampatticakka*); and he turns others with them; and because the turner of the wheels of deportment (*iriyāpathacakka*) for the welfare of others exists in this, he is a wheel-turner (*cakravartin*).

And here, *rājā* is the general characteristic.

*Cakkavattī* is the specific characteristic.

"*Dhammena carati*" means he acts according to *dharma*, therefore he is *dhāmmiko* (righteous).

The meaning is: he behaves with justice and evenness.

Having obtained the kingdom by means of *dharma*, he is born as a king; therefore, he is a *dharmarājā* (righteous king).

Or, *dhāmmiko* [means] one who performs *dharma* for the welfare of others.

*Dhammarājā* [means] one who performs *dharma* for his own welfare.

"*Caturantāya issaro*" means *cāturanto* (ruler of the four boundaries), lord of the earth adorned with the four oceans, with the four kinds of islands, is the meaning.

Because he conquers internal enemies like anger, etc., and all external kings, he is a conqueror (*vijitāvī*).

"*Janapadatthāvariyappatto*" means having obtained a stable state (*dhuvabhāva*) and a firm state (*thāvarabhāva*) in the country (*janapada*), he cannot be shaken by anyone.

Or, *janapadatthāvariyappatto* [means] one who is attached to that country (*janapada*), is engaged, is devoted to his own work, is immovable, and is not agitated.

"*Seyyathidam*" is a particle; the meaning is, "what are these?"

"*Cakkaratanantiādīsu*": *cakkañca*, and *ratanañcāti cakkaratanaṃ* because of its nature of generating pleasure.
This method applies to the other cases .
Among these gems, this wheel-turning monarch, by means of the wheel-gem, conquers the unconquered, follows the conquered at will with the elephant-gem and horse-gem, protects the conquered with the counselor-gem, and experiences the pleasure of enjoyment with the remaining ones.
For him, the power of effort is through the first, the power of counsel is through the last, the power of dominion is fully complete through the elephant-gem, horse-gem, and householder-gem, and the fruit of the threefold power is through the woman-gem and jewel-gem.
He experiences the pleasure of enjoyment through the woman-gem and jewel-gem, and the pleasure of sovereignty through the remaining ones.
In particular, it should be understood that the first three arise by means of the karmic result produced by the root of non-aversion, the middle ones by means of the karmic result produced by the root of non-greed, and the last one by means of the karmic result produced by the root of non-delusion.
This is a brief explanation.
The detailed explanation, however, should be taken from the instruction of the *ratanasutta* in the *bojjhaṅgasaṃyutta*.
"More than a thousand" means an excess of a thousand.
"*Sūrā*" means one who is by nature fearless (*abhīrukajātikā*).
"*Vīraṅgarūpā*" means having a body similar to that of a divine being (*devaputtasadisakāyā*).
Thus, some describe it.
However, this is the real meaning here.
"*Vīrāti uttama sūrā* are called heroes," the word *vīraṅga* means "*vīrānaṃ aṅgaṃ*," and *vīriya* is said to be the cause of heroism (*vīrakāraṇaṃ*).
"*Vīraṅgarūpaṃ etesa* means *vīraṅgarūpā*, shaped by energy," it is said.
"*Parasenappamaddana*" means the intention is that if the enemy army were to stand face to face, he would be capable of crushing that enemy army.
"*Dhammena*" means by the five precepts (*pañcasīladhammena*) beginning with "one should not kill living beings" (*pāṇo na hantabbo*).
"*Arahaṃ hoti sammāsambuddho loke vivaṭṭacchado*" means here, having uncovered the covering (*chadanaṃ*) in the world (*loke*) which is covered (*paṭicchanne*) by the darkness of defilements (*kilesandhakāre*) with seven coverings (*sattahi*) such as the covering (*chadanehi*) of *rāga* (lust), *dosa* (aversion), *moha* (delusion), *māna* (pride), *diṭṭhi* (wrong view), *avijjā* (ignorance), and *duccarita* (misconduct), and having become one whose light (*āloko*) is entirely (*samantato sañjāta*) manifest, he stands, therefore he is *vivaṭṭacchado*.
There, by the first word, [it means] worthy of veneration (*pūjārahatā*).
By the second, its cause, because [he is] a perfectly enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), by the third, it should be understood that *vivaṭṭacchadatā*, the cause of Buddhahood, is stated.
Or, alternatively, *vivaṭṭo ca vicchado ca* therefore *vivaṭṭacchado*, [meaning] both without covering and without obstruction, thus it is said.
Therefore, *arahaṃ* by the absence of covering, *sammāsambuddho* by the absence of obstruction, thus, in this way, indeed, both of the previous terms have a dual cause, by the second, there is the former accomplishment, by the first, the second accomplishment, by the third and fourth, there is the third accomplishment.
It should be understood that the first, the eye of the *dharma* (*dharmacakkhuṃ*), the second, the Buddha-eye (*buddhacakkhuṃ*), and the third, the all-seeing eye (*samantacakkhuṃ*) are accomplished.
By "*tvaṃ mantānaṃ paṭiggaheta*," he generates heroism among the *mantas*.

mula_pali: 259. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā brāhmaṇaṃ pokkharasātiṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā vaḷavārathamāruyha  sambahulehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ yena icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍo tena pāyāsi. Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ārāmaṃ pāvisi. Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti. Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca – ‘‘kahaṃ nu kho, bho, etarahi so bhavaṃ gotamo viharati? Tañhi mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya idhūpasaṅkantā’’ti.
mula_english:
259. "So be it, sir," said the youth Ambaṭṭha in reply to the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, and rising from his seat, he respectfully circumambulated the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, mounted his chariot drawn by a mare, and set out with a large number of young men towards the dense grove of Icchānaṅgala.

He went by chariot as far as the ground was suitable for vehicles, then alighting from the chariot, he entered the park on foot.

At that time, a large number of monks were doing walking meditation in the open air.

Then the youth Ambaṭṭha approached those monks and said to them: "Where, pray tell, is the esteemed Gotama currently residing? For we have come here to see the esteemed Gotama."
commentary_pali: 259. Sopi  tāya ācariyakathāya lakkhaṇesu vigatasammoho ekobhāsajāte viya buddhamante sampassamāno evaṃ bhoti āha. Tassattho – ‘yathā, bho, tvaṃ vadasi, evaṃ karissāmī’ti. Vaḷavārathamāruyhāti vaḷavāyuttaṃ rathaṃ abhirūhitvā. Brāhmaṇo kira yena rathena sayaṃ vicarati, tameva rathaṃ datvā māṇavaṃ pesesi. Māṇavāpi pokkharasātisseva antevāsikā. So kira tesaṃ – ‘‘ambaṭṭhena saddhiṃ gacchathā’’ti saññaṃ adāsi. Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmīti yattakaṃ sakkā hoti yānena gantuṃ, ayaṃ yānassa bhūmi nāma. Yānā paccorohitvāti ayānabhūmiṃ, dvārakoṭṭhakasamīpaṃ gantvā yānato paṭiorohitvā. Tena kho pana samayenāti yasmiṃ samaye ambaṭṭho ārāmaṃ pāvisi. Tasmiṃ pana samaye, ṭhitamajjhanhikasamaye. Kasmā pana tasmiṃ samaye caṅkamantīti? Paṇītabhojanapaccayassa thinamiddhassa vinodanatthaṃ, divāpadhānikā vā te. Tādisānañhi pacchābhattaṃ caṅkamitvā nhāyitvā  sarīraṃ utuṃ gāhāpetvā nisajja samaṇadhammaṃ karontānaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti. Yena te bhikkhūti so kira – ‘‘kuhiṃ samaṇo gotamo’’ti pariveṇato pariveṇaṃ anāgantvā ‘‘pucchitvāva pavisissāmī’’ti vilokento araññahatthī viya mahācaṅkame caṅkamamāne paṃsukūlike bhikkhū disvā tesaṃ santikaṃ agamāsi. Taṃ sandhāya yena te bhikkhūtiādi vuttaṃ. Dassanāyāti daṭṭhuṃ, passitukāmā hutvāti attho.
commentary_english:
259. And so, with that teacher's discourse, his confusion about the characteristics having disappeared, seeing the Buddha's teachings as if they were of a single light, he said, "Indeed, sir."
Its meaning: "As you say, sir, I will do so."
"Having mounted the mare-drawn chariot" means having ascended the chariot yoked with mares.
The *brāhmaṇa*, it is said, gave that very chariot by which he himself was traveling and sent the young man.
The young men were also residents in the vicinity of Pokkharasāti.
He, it is said, gave them the signal, "Go together with Ambaṭṭha."
"As far as the ground for a vehicle" means as far as it is possible to go by vehicle; this is called the ground for a vehicle.
"Having descended from the vehicle" means having gone to a place unsuitable for vehicles, having gone near the gate tower, having descended from the vehicle.
"At that time" means at the time when Ambaṭṭha entered the ārāma.
At that time, at the fixed midday time.
Why at that time do they walk back and forth (*caṅkamanti*)? It is for the sake of dispelling dullness and drowsiness caused by rich food. Or they are those who make effort during the day.
For those of such kind, indeed, having walked back and forth after the meal, having bathed, having exposed their bodies to the outside temperature, sitting down, and doing the duties of a *śramaṇa*, their minds become one-pointed.
"By which those monks" means he, it is said, without coming from one enclosure to another, thinking, "I will ask and then enter," looking around, like a forest elephant, seeing the monks wearing robes collected from dust heaps walking back and forth in the great cloister, he went to their presence.
Referring to that, it was said, "By which those monks," and so forth.
"For the sake of seeing" means to see, having the desire to see, is the meaning.

mula_pali: 260. Atha kho tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ etadahosi – ‘‘ayaṃ kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo abhiññātakolañño ceva abhiññātassa ca brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa antevāsī. Agaru kho pana bhagavato evarūpehi kulaputtehi saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo hotī’’ti. Te ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘eso ambaṭṭha vihāro saṃvutadvāro, tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno āḷindaṃ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭehi, vivarissati te bhagavā dvāra’’nti.
mula_english:
260. Then the monks had this thought: "This Ambaṭṭha is a *māṇava* (youth) well-known for his lineage and a student of the well-known *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) Pokkharasāti.

The Lord would not mind having a conversation with such a young man of good family."

They said to Ambaṭṭha, the *māṇava* (youth): "That is the dwelling of Ambaṭṭha, with the door closed. Go there quietly, and without haste enter the porch, clear your throat, and knock on the bolt. The Blessed One, *bhagavā*, will open the door for you."
commentary_pali: 260.Abhiññātakolaññoti pākaṭakulajo. Tadā kira jambudīpe ambaṭṭhakulaṃ nāma pākaṭakulamahosi . Abhiññātassāti rūpajātimantakulāpadesehi pākaṭassa. Agarūti abhāriko. Yo hi ambaṭṭhaṃ ñāpetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya, tassa tena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo garu bhaveyya. Bhagavato pana tādisānaṃ māṇavānaṃ satenāpi sahassenāpi  pañhaṃ puṭṭhassa vissajjane dandhāyitattaṃ natthīti maññamānā – ‘‘agaru kho panā’’ti cintayiṃsu. Vihāroti gandhakuṭiṃ sandhāya āhaṃsu. Ataramānoti aturito, saṇikaṃ padappamāṇaṭṭhāne padaṃ nikkhipanto vattaṃ katvā susammaṭṭhaṃ muttādalasinduvārasantharasadisaṃ vālikaṃ avināsentoti attho. Āḷindanti pamukhaṃ. Ukkāsitvāti ukkāsitasaddaṃ katvā. Aggaḷanti dvārakavāṭaṃ. Ākoṭehīti agganakhehi saṇikaṃ kuñcikacchiddasamīpe ākoṭehīti vuttaṃ hoti. Dvāraṃ kira atiupari amanussā, atiheṭṭhā dīghajātikā koṭenti. Tathā anākoṭetvā majjhe chiddasamīpe koṭetabbanti idaṃ dvārākoṭanavattanti dīpentā vadanti.
commentary_english:
260. abhiññātakolaññoti pākaṭakulajo. Known as being of good family, that is, born in a distinguished family.

tadā kira jambudīpe ambaṭṭhakulaṃ nāma pākaṭakulamahosi. At that time, it seems, in Jambudīpa, there was a well-known family named Ambaṭṭha.

abhiññātassāti rūpajātimantakulāpadesehi pākaṭassa. "Of the well-known," meaning well-known because of its lineage of handsome form and good birth.

agarūti abhāriko. Agarūti means not heavy.

yo hi ambaṭṭhaṃ ñāpetuṃ na sakkuṇeyya, tassa tena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo garu bhaveyya. Indeed, anyone who could not make Ambaṭṭha understand, conversation and discussion with him would be difficult.

bhagavato pana tādisānaṃ māṇavānaṃ satenāpi sahassenāpi pañhaṃ puṭṭhassa vissajjane dandhāyitattaṃ natthīti maññamānā – ‘‘agaru kho panā’’ti cintayiṃsu. But, thinking that there was no slowness in answering questions asked of the Blessed One by hundreds or even thousands of such youths, they considered, "Indeed, he is not heavy."

vihāroti gandhakuṭiṃ sandhāya āhaṃsu. Vihāra means they spoke referring to the perfumed chamber (gandhakuṭi).

ataramānoti aturito, saṇikaṃ padappamāṇaṭṭhāne padaṃ nikkhipanto vattaṃ katvā susammaṭṭhaṃ muttādalasinduvārasantharasadisaṃ vālikaṃ avināsentoti attho. Ataramānoti means not hurried; that is, not rushing, carefully placing his foot in a suitable place, making a path, not destroying the sand resembling a well-smoothed surface strewn with pearls and *sinduvāra* flowers; this is the meaning.

āḷindanti pamukhaṃ. Āḷinda means the front (pamukhaṃ).

ukkāsitvāti ukkāsitasaddaṃ katvā. ukkāsitvā means having made a coughing sound.

aggaḷanti dvārakavāṭaṃ. aggaḷa means the door panel (dvārakavāṭaṃ).

ākoṭehīti agganakhehi saṇikaṃ kuñcikacchiddasamīpe ākoṭehīti vuttaṃ hoti. "Knock," means it is said that he should knock gently with the tips of his nails near the keyhole (kuñcikacchiddasamīpe).

dvāraṃ kira atiupari amanussā, atiheṭṭhā dīghajātikā koṭenti. It seems that non-humans (amanussā) knock very high up on the door, and those of tall stature (dīghajātikā) knock very low.

tathā anākoṭetvā majjhe chiddasamīpe koṭetabbanti idaṃ dvārākoṭanavattanti dīpentā vadanti. Thus, not knocking high or low, but knocking in the middle, near the hole, this is called the practice of knocking on the door, say the interpreters.

mula_pali: 261. Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yena so vihāro saṃvutadvāro, tena appasaddo upasaṅkamitvā ataramāno āḷindaṃ pavisitvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭesi. Vivari bhagavā dvāraṃ. Pāvisi ambaṭṭho māṇavo. Māṇavakāpi pavisitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ambaṭṭho pana māṇavo caṅkamantopi nisinnena bhagavatā kañci  kañci kiñci kiñci (ka.) kathaṃ  sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāreti, ṭhitopi nisinnena bhagavatā kiñci kiñci kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāreti.
mula_english:
Then Ambaṭṭha, the young Brahmin, went quietly and unhurriedly to the dwelling (vihāra) with the closed door, entered the porch (āḷinda), cleared his throat, and knocked on the door (aggaḷaṃ ākoṭesi).
The Blessed One (bhagavā) opened the door (dvāraṃ).
Ambaṭṭha, the young Brahmin, entered (pāvisi).
The young men also entered, exchanged courtesies with the Blessed One (bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu), and after exchanging polite and courteous greetings (sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā), sat down to one side (ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu).
But Ambaṭṭha, the young Brahmin, while walking up and down, uttered some vague words of politeness (kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāreti) to the seated Blessed One (nisinnena bhagavatā), and then, while standing, uttered some vague words of politeness (kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāreti) to the seated Blessed One (nisinnena bhagavatā).
commentary_pali: 261.Vivari bhagavā dvāranti na bhagavā uṭṭhāya dvāraṃ vivari. Vivariyatūti pana hatthaṃ pasāresi. Tato ‘‘bhagavā tumhehi  anekāsu kappakoṭīsu dānaṃ dadamānehi na sahatthā dvāravivaraṇakammaṃ kata’’nti sayameva dvāraṃ vivaṭaṃ. Taṃ pana yasmā bhagavato manena vivaṭaṃ, tasmā vivari bhagavā dvāranti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsūti yathā khamanīyādīni pucchanto bhagavā tehi, evaṃ tepi bhagavatā saddhiṃ samappavattamodā ahesuṃ. Sītodakaṃ viya uṇhodakena sammoditaṃ ekībhāvaṃ agamaṃsu. Yāya ca ‘‘kacci, bho gotama, khamanīyaṃ; kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci bhoto ca gotamassa sāvakānañca appābādhaṃ, appātaṅkaṃ, lahuṭṭhānaṃ, balaṃ, phāsuvihāro’’tiādikāya kathāya sammodiṃsu, taṃ pītipāmojjasaṅkhātasammodajananato sammodituṃ yuttabhāvato ca sammodanīyaṃ, atthabyañjanamadhuratāya sucirampi kālaṃ sāretuṃ nirantaraṃ pavattetuṃ arahabhāvato saritabbabhāvato ca sāraṇīyaṃ. Suyyamānasukhato sammodanīyaṃ, anussariyamānasukhato ca sāraṇīyaṃ. Tathā byañjanaparisuddhatāya sammodanīyaṃ, atthaparisuddhatāya sāraṇīyaṃ. Evaṃ anekehi pariyāyehi sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā pariyosāpetvā niṭṭhapetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ambaṭṭhopana māṇavoti so kira bhagavato rūpasampattiyaṃ cittappasādamattampi akatvā ‘‘dasabalaṃ  apasādessāmī’’ti udare baddhasāṭakaṃ muñcitvā kaṇṭhe olambetvā ekena hatthena dussakaṇṇaṃ gahetvā caṅkamaṃ abhirūhitvā kālena bāhuṃ, kālena udaraṃ, kālena piṭṭhiṃ dassento, kālena hatthavikāraṃ, kālena bhamukavikāraṃ karonto, ‘‘kacci te bho, gotama, dhātusamatā, kacci bhikkhāhārena na kilamatha, akilamathākāroyeva pana te paññāyati; thūlāni hi te aṅgapaccaṅgāni, pāsādikattha gatagataṭṭhāne. ‘te bahujanā rājapabbajitoti ca buddho’ti ca uppannabahumānā paṇītaṃ ojavantamāhāraṃ denti. Passatha, bho, gehaṃ, cittasālā viya, dibbapāsādo viya. Imaṃ mañcaṃ passatha, bimbohanaṃ passatha, kiṃ evarūpe ṭhāne vasantassa samaṇadhammaṃ kātuṃ dukkara’’nti evarūpaṃ uppaṇḍanakathaṃ anācārabhāvasāraṇīyaṃ katheti, tena  vuttaṃ – ‘‘ambaṭṭho pana māṇavo caṅkamantopi nisinnena bhagavatā kiñci kiñci kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāreti, ṭhitopi nisinnena bhagavatā kiñci kiñci kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretī’’ti.
commentary_english:
261.

“The Blessed One opened the door,” but the Blessed One did not get up and open the door.

He stretched out his hand, saying, “Open it!”

Then, because the Blessed One had not, in the course of many hundreds of thousands of eons, while giving alms, performed the act of opening doors with his own hand, the door opened by itself.

Since it opened by the Blessed One’s intention, it is fitting to say, “The Blessed One opened the door.”

They exchanged courteous greetings with the Blessed One, and the Blessed One, while asking them about their well-being, and so forth, in this way, they too were full of joy, having had amicable conversation with the Blessed One.

Like cool water mixed with warm water, they reached a state of oneness.

Moreover, they exchanged courteous greetings with the Blessed One with such conversation as, “I hope, Master Gotama, that you are well; I hope that you are keeping well; I hope that you and your disciples are free from illness, free from affliction, are quick to rise, have strength, and live in comfort.” Because it generated joy and delight, because it was fitting to exchange courteous greetings, it was a cause for rejoicing. Because of the sweetness of its meaning and phrasing, and because it was worthy of being prolonged for a long time, of being continuously maintained, and of being remembered, it was worthy of recollection.

It was a cause for rejoicing because of the happiness experienced in hearing it, and it was worthy of recollection because of the happiness experienced in remembering it.

Likewise, it was a cause for rejoicing because of the purity of its phrasing, and it was worthy of recollection because of the purity of its meaning.

In this way, having dismissed, concluded, and finished the talk that was a cause for rejoicing and was worthy of recollection by means of various approaches, they sat down to one side.

Then Ambaṭṭha the student, without showing even a little mental satisfaction in the Blessed One’s perfection of form, thinking, “I will disparage the one with the ten powers,” untied the cloth tied around his stomach, hung it around his neck, and taking hold of the edge of the cloth with one hand, climbed up and down the walkway, showing his arm at one time, his stomach at another time, his back at another time, making a gesture with his hand at one time, making a gesture with his eyebrow at another time, [saying,] “I hope, Master Gotama, that your humors are balanced; I hope that you are not tired from the alms food. But indeed, an appearance of not being tired is evident in you, for your major and minor limbs are robust, and you are pleasing to see in every place you go and stay.

‘These many people give exquisite, nutritious food to the king, the renunciate, and the Awakened One,’ and they give with great respect.

Look, sir, at the house, like a picture gallery, like a divine palace!

Look at this couch, look at this headrest! Why is it difficult to practice the monastic life while living in such a place?” In this way he tells such a boastful talk that is worthy of recollection as a state of misconduct. Therefore, it was said, “Ambaṭṭha the student, even while walking up and down, dismisses the talk worthy of recollection with the Blessed One who is sitting, and even while standing, dismisses the talk worthy of recollection with the Blessed One who is sitting.”

mula_pali: 262. Atha kho bhagavā ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘evaṃ nu te, ambaṭṭha, brāhmaṇehi vuddhehi mahallakehi ācariyapācariyehi saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo hoti, yathayidaṃ caraṃ tiṭṭhaṃ nisinnena mayā kiñci kiñci kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretī’’ti?
mula_english: Then, the Blessed One said this to the young man Ambaṭṭha: "Now then, Ambaṭṭha, would your conversation and discussion be like this with venerable and elder Brahmins, teachers of teachers, as it is with me—walking and standing while I am sitting—and passing the time with trifling talk?"
commentary_pali: 262.Atha kho bhagavāti atha bhagavā – ‘‘ayaṃ māṇavo hatthaṃ pasāretvā bhavaggaṃ gahetukāmo viya, pādaṃ pasāretvā avīciṃ vicaritukāmo viya, mahāsamuddaṃ taritukāmo viya, sineruṃ ārohitukāmo viya ca aṭṭhāne vāyamati, handa, tena saddhiṃ mantemī’’ti ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca. Ācariyapācariyehīti ācariyehi ca tesaṃ ācariyehi ca.
commentary_english:
Then, indeed, the Blessed One—then the Blessed One [thought]: "This young man, as if stretching out his hand, desires to grasp the summit of existence (bhavaggaṃ); as if stretching out his foot, he desires to roam through Avīci; as if he desires to cross the great ocean; and as if he desires to climb Mount Sumeru, he strives in an improper place (aṭṭhāne vāyamati). Come now, I will converse with him," thus he spoke to the young man Ambaṭṭha.

"By teachers and teachers of teachers (ācariyapācariyehīti)" means by teachers and by their teachers.

mula_pali: 263. ‘‘No  hidaṃ, bho gotama. Gacchanto vā hi, bho gotama, gacchantena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ sallapitumarahati, ṭhito vā hi, bho gotama, ṭhitena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ sallapitumarahati, nisinno vā hi, bho gotama, nisinnena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ sallapitumarahati, sayāno vā hi, bho gotama, sayānena brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ sallapitumarahati. Ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā kiṇhā (ka. sī. pī.) bandhupādāpaccā, tehipi me saddhiṃ evaṃ kathāsallāpo hoti, yathariva bhotā gotamenā’’ti. ‘‘Atthikavato kho pana te, ambaṭṭha, idhāgamanaṃ ahosi, yāyeva kho panatthāya āgaccheyyātha āgaccheyyātho (sī. pī.), tameva atthaṃ sādhukaṃ manasi kareyyātha manasikareyyātho (sī. pī.). Avusitavāyeva kho pana bho ayaṃ ambaṭṭho māṇavo vusitamānī kimaññatra avusitattā’’ti.
mula_english:
263.
“No, Master Gotama.

Indeed, Reverend Gotama, a *brāhmaṇa* should converse with a *brāhmaṇa* who is walking, stand with a *brāhmaṇa* who is standing, sit with a *brāhmaṇa* who is sitting, and lie down with a *brāhmaṇa* who is lying down.

But as for those shaven little ascetics, menials, black scourings from Brahma’s foot, with them it is fitting to speak just as I do with the Reverend Gotama”.

“But, Ambattha, you came here seeking something. Whatever it was you came for, you should carefully keep that purpose in mind.

Ambattha, you have not perfected your training. Your conceit of being trained is due to nothing but inexperience.”
commentary_pali: 263.Gacchanto vāti ettha kāmaṃ tīsu iriyāpathesu brāhmaṇo ācariyabrāhmaṇena saddhiṃ sallapitumarahati. Ayaṃ pana māṇavo mānathaddhatāya kathāsallāpaṃ karonto cattāropi iriyāpathe yojessāmīti ‘‘sayāno vā hi, bho gotama, sayānenā’’ti āha. Tato  kira taṃ bhagavā – ‘‘ambaṭṭha, gacchantassa vā gacchantena, ṭhitassa vā ṭhitena, nisinnassa vā nisinnenācariyena saddhiṃ kathā nāma sabbācariyesu labbhati. Tvaṃ pana sayāno sayānenācariyena saddhiṃ kathesi, kiṃ te ācariyo gorūpaṃ, udāhu tva’’nti āha. So kujjhitvā – ‘‘ye ca kho te, bho gotama, muṇḍakā’’tiādimāha. Tattha muṇḍe muṇḍāti samaṇe ca samaṇāti vattuṃ vaṭṭeyya. Ayaṃ pana hīḷento muṇḍakā samaṇakāti āha. Ibbhāti gahapatikā. Kaṇhāti kaṇhā, kāḷakāti attho. Bandhupādāpaccāti ettha bandhūti brahmā adhippeto. Tañhi brāhmaṇā pitāmahoti voharanti. Pādānaṃ apaccā pādāpaccā, brahmuno piṭṭhipādato  jātāti adhippāyo. Tassa kira ayaṃ laddhi – brāhmaṇā brahmuno mukhato nikkhantā, khattiyā urato, vessā nābhito, suddā jāṇuto, samaṇā piṭṭhipādatoti. Evaṃ kathento ca panesa kiñcāpi aniyametvā katheti. Atha kho bhagavantameva vadāmīti katheti. Atha kho bhagavā – ‘‘ayaṃ ambaṭṭho āgatakālato paṭṭhāya mayā saddhiṃ kathayamāno mānameva nissāya kathesi, āsīvisaṃ  gīvāyaṃ gaṇhanto viya, aggikkhandhaṃ āliṅganto viya, mattavāraṇaṃ soṇḍāya parāmasanto viya, attano pamāṇaṃ na jānāti. Handa naṃ jānāpessāmī’’ti cintetvā ‘‘atthikavato kho pana te, ambaṭṭhā’’tiādimāha. Tattha āgantvā kattabbakiccasaṅkhāto attho, etassa atthīti atthikaṃ, tassa māṇavassa cittaṃ. Atthikamassa atthīti atthikavā, tassa atthikavato tava idhāgamanaṃ ahosīti attho. Kho panāti nipātamattaṃ. Yāyeva kho panatthāyāti yeneva kho panatthena. Āgaccheyyāthāti mama vā aññesaṃ vā santikaṃ yadā kadāci āgaccheyyātha. Tameva atthanti idaṃ purisaliṅgavaseneva vuttaṃ. Manasi kareyyāthāti citte kareyyātha. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – tvaṃ ācariyena attano karaṇīyena pesito, na amhākaṃ paribhavanatthāya, tasmā tameva kiccaṃ manasi karohīti. Evamassa aññesaṃ santikaṃ āgatānaṃ vattaṃ dassetvā mānaniggaṇhanatthaṃ ‘‘avusitavāyeva kho panā’’tiādimāha. Tassattho passatha bho ayaṃ ambaṭṭho māṇavo ācariyakule avusitavā  asikkhito appassutova samāno. Vusitamānīti ‘‘ahaṃ vusitavā sikkhito bahussuto’’ti attānaṃ maññati. Etassa hi evaṃ pharusavacanasamudācāre kāraṇaṃ kimaññatra avusitattāti ācariyakule asaṃvuddhā asikkhitā appassutāyeva hi evaṃ vadantīti.
commentary_english:
263.

Here, when walking, a *brāhmaṇa* may gladly converse with a teacher-*brāhmaṇa* in the three postures.

But this youth, due to arrogance, while engaging in conversation, [thinks,] "I will apply all four postures," thus he said, "Indeed, Master Gotama, while lying down, [I spoke] while lying down."

Then, the Blessed One [said] to him: "Ambaṭṭha, conversation with a teacher is obtained among all teachers, whether walking with one who is walking, standing with one who is standing, or sitting with one who is sitting.

But you, while lying down, spoke with your teacher while lying down. What, is your teacher ox-shaped, or are you?"

He, becoming angry, said, "Those shavelings, Gotama,..." and so on.

There, it is fitting to say, "shaven in regard to the shaven, a *śramaṇa* in regard to the *śramaṇa*."

But this one, disparaging [them], says, "shavelings, little *śramaṇas*."

"Ibbha" means householders.

"*Kāṇhā*" means black, dark is the meaning.

Regarding "*bandhupādāpacca*," here "*bandhu*" is understood as Brahmā.

For *brāhmaṇas* call him "*pitāmaha*."

"*Pādānaṃ apaccā pādāpaccā*," the meaning is, "born from the back-foot of Brahmā."

The view of that one is this: *brāhmaṇas* issued from the mouth of Brahmā, *kṣatriyas* from the chest, *vaiśyas* from the navel, *śūdras* from the knee, *śramaṇas* from the back-foot.

And while speaking thus, he speaks without any regulation.

Then, he says, "I speak only to the Blessed One."

Then, the Blessed One [said]: "This Ambaṭṭha, having begun to converse with me from the time he arrived, relies only on pride in his speaking, like one seizing a venomous snake by the neck, like one embracing a mass of fire, like one touching a rutting elephant's trunk with his hand; he does not know his own measure.

Come, I will make him know," thinking thus, he said, "*Atthikavato kho pana te, Ambaṭṭha*," and so on.

There, the meaning is that the thing to be done is known as a task; having that is "*atthika*," [that is] the mind of that youth.

Having a need is "*atthikavā*," the meaning is, "your coming here, Ambaṭṭha, was for a purpose."

"*Kho pana*" is merely a particle.

"*Yāyeva kho panatthāyā*" means, "by whatever purpose."

"*Āgaccheyyātha*" means, "you might come to my presence or to the presence of others at any time."

"*Tameva atthaṃ*" this was said merely in terms of the masculine gender.

"*Manasi kareyyātha*" means, "you might do it in your mind."

This was said: "You were sent by your teacher for your own task, not for the sake of disparaging us; therefore, do that task in your mind."

Thus, having shown the conduct of those who have come to the presence of others, to suppress pride, he said, "*Avusitavāyeva kho pana*," and so on.

The meaning of that is, "Look, sirs, this Ambaṭṭha youth, being one who has not lived in a teacher's family, is uneducated, unlearned."

"*Vusitamānī*" means, "He thinks of himself, 'I have lived [there], I am educated, very learned.'"

Indeed, the cause of his harsh speech and conduct is none other than his not having lived [there]; indeed, it is because they have not grown up in a teacher's family that they speak thus, being uneducated, unlearned.

mula_pali: 264. Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavatā avusitavādena vuccamāno kupito anattamano bhagavantaṃyeva khuṃsento bhagavantaṃyeva vambhento bhagavantaṃyeva upavadamāno – ‘‘samaṇo ca me, bho, gotamo pāpito bhavissatī’’ti bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘caṇḍā, bho gotama, sakyajāti; pharusā, bho gotama, sakyajāti; lahusā, bho  gotama, sakyajāti; bhassā, bho gotama, sakyajāti; ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti, na brāhmaṇe garuṃ karonti garukaronti (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.), na brāhmaṇe  mānenti, na brāhmaṇe pūjenti, na brāhmaṇe apacāyanti. Tayidaṃ, bho gotama, nacchannaṃ, tayidaṃ nappatirūpaṃ, yadime sakyā ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti, na brāhmaṇe garuṃ karonti, na brāhmaṇe mānenti, na brāhmaṇe pūjenti, na brāhmaṇe apacāyantī’’ti. Itiha ambaṭṭho māṇavo idaṃ paṭhamaṃ sakyesu ibbhavādaṃ nipātesi.
mula_english:
264. Then Ambaṭṭha, the student, being addressed by the Blessed One with the accusation of being untrained, became angry and displeased, and he rebuked the Blessed One, reviled the Blessed One, disparaged the Blessed One, thinking, "The ascetic Gotama will bear me ill will." He said this to the Blessed One: "The Śākyan clan, reverend Gotama, is fierce; the Śākyan clan, reverend Gotama, is rough; the Śākyan clan, reverend Gotama, is impulsive; the Śākyan clan, reverend Gotama, is abusive. Though being of base origin ( *ibbhā santā ibbhā samānā* ), behaving as if they are base, they do not honor ( *na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti* ) Brahmins, they do not respect ( *na brāhmaṇe garuṃ karonti* ) Brahmins, they do not esteem ( *na brāhmaṇe mānenti* ) Brahmins, they do not revere ( *na brāhmaṇe pūjenti* ) Brahmins, they do not pay homage ( *na brāhmaṇe apacāyanti* ) to Brahmins. This, reverend Gotama, is not proper ( *nacchannaṃ* ), this is unseemly ( *nappatirūpaṃ* ), that these Śākyans, being of base origin, behaving as if they are base, do not honor Brahmins, do not respect Brahmins, do not esteem Brahmins, do not revere Brahmins, do not pay homage to Brahmins."

Thus, indeed, Ambaṭṭha, the student, made this first accusation of baseness ( *ibbhavādaṃ* ) against the Śākyans.
commentary_pali: 264.Kupitoti kuddho. Anattamanoti asakamano, kiṃ pana bhagavā tassa kujjhanabhāvaṃ ñatvā evamāha udāhu añatvāti? Ñatvā āhāti. Kasmā ñatvā āhāti? Tassa mānanimmadanatthaṃ. Bhagavā hi aññāsi – ‘‘ayaṃ mayā evaṃ vutte kujjhitvā mama ñātake akkosissati. Athassāhaṃ yathā nāma kusalo bhisakko dosaṃ uggiletvā nīharati, evameva gottena gottaṃ, kulāpadesena kulāpadesaṃ , uṭṭhāpetvā bhavaggappamāṇena viya uṭṭhitaṃ mānaddhajaṃ mūle chetvā nipātessāmī’’ti. Khuṃsentoti ghaṭṭento. Vambhentoti hīḷento. Pāpito bhavissatīti caṇḍabhāvādidosaṃ pāpito bhavissati. Caṇḍāti  mānanissitakodhayuttā. Pharusāti kharā. Lahusāti lahukā. Appakeneva tussanti vā dussanti vā udakapiṭṭhe alābukaṭāhaṃ viya appakeneva uplavanti. Bhassāti bahubhāṇino. Sakyānaṃ mukhe vivaṭe aññassa vacanokāso natthīti adhippāyeneva vadati. Samānāti idaṃ santāti purimapadassa vevacanaṃ. Na sakkarontīti na brāhmaṇānaṃ sundarenākārena karonti. Na garuṃ karontīti brāhmaṇesu gāravaṃ na karonti. Na mānentīti na manena piyāyanti. Na pūjentīti mālādīhi nesaṃ pūjaṃ na karonti. Na apacāyantīti abhivādanādīhi nesaṃ apacitikammaṃ nīcavuttiṃ na dassenti tayidanti taṃ idaṃ. Yadime sakyāti yaṃ ime sakyā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti…pe… na apacāyanti, taṃ tesaṃ asakkārakaraṇādi sabbaṃ na yuttaṃ, nānulomanti attho.
commentary_english:
264.

*Kupitoti* means *kuddho*: being angry.

*Anattamanoti* means *asakamano*: being displeased. Why, when the Blessed One knew his state of anger, did he speak in this way, or did he not know? He spoke knowing.

Why did he speak knowing? In order to subdue his pride.

The Blessed One, indeed, understood: "When I have spoken thus, this person, being angry, will insult my relatives.

Then I, just as a skilled physician expels and removes the provoked *doṣa* (fault), so too, with lineage against lineage, with designation of family against designation of family, having raised up the banner of pride that has arisen like the height of existence (*bhavaggappamāṇena*), having cut it off at the root, I will strike it down."

*Khuṃsentoti* means *ghaṭṭento*: colliding, shaking.

*Vambhentoti* means *hīḷento*: despising.

*Pāpito bhavissatīti* means *caṇḍabhāvādidosaṃ pāpito bhavissati*: he will be brought to a state of fierceness.

*Caṇḍāti* means *mānanissitakodhayuttā*: fierce, endowed with anger dependent on pride.

*Pharusāti* means *kharā*: rough, harsh.

*Lahusāti* means *lahukā*: light.

*Appakeneva tussanti vā dussanti vā udakapiṭṭhe alābukaṭāhaṃ viya appakeneva uplavanti*: they are pleased or displeased by little, just as a gourd shell floats on the surface of the water with very little.

*Bhassāti* means *bahubhāṇino*: speaking much.

*Sakyānaṃ mukhe vivaṭe aññassa vacanokāso natthīti adhippāyeneva vadati*: He speaks with the intention that there is no opportunity for another's word when the mouths of the Śākyas are open.

*Samānāti idaṃ santāti purimapadassa vevacanaṃ*: *Samānāti* means "this is," a synonym of the preceding word.

*Na sakkarontīti na brāhmaṇānaṃ sundarenākārena karonti*: *Na sakkarontīti* means they do not show honor to the *brāhmaṇas* in a beautiful manner.

*Na garuṃ karontīti brāhmaṇesu gāravaṃ na karonti*: *Na garuṃ karontīti* means they do not show respect to the *brāhmaṇas*.

*Na mānentīti na manena piyāyanti*: *Na mānentīti* means they do not endear with respect.

*Na pūjentīti mālādīhi nesaṃ pūjaṃ na karonti*: *Na pūjentīti* means they do not make an offering to them with garlands, etc.

*Na apacāyantīti abhivādanādīhi nesaṃ apacitikammaṃ nīcavuttiṃ na dassenti tayidanti taṃ idaṃ*: *Na apacāyantīti* means they do not show a respectful act, a humble demeanor, with salutations, etc. This is that.

*Yadime sakyāti yaṃ ime sakyā na brāhmaṇe sakkaronti…pe… na apacāyanti, taṃ tesaṃ asakkārakaraṇādi sabbaṃ na yuttaṃ, nānulomanti attho*: Because these Śākyas do not honor the *brāhmaṇas*...and do not show respect, all of that, such as their not showing honor, is not fitting, not in accordance with, is the meaning.
