"It is by abandoning talk of caste-bonds (*jātivādavinibaddha*), talk of clan-bonds (*gottavādavinibaddha*), talk of conceit-bonds (*mānavādavinibaddha*), and bonds of marriage alliances (*āvāhavivāhavinibaddha*), that there is realization of the unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct (*anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya sacchikiriyā hoti*)."
commentary_pali: 278. Imāya pana gāthāya vijjācaraṇasampannoti idaṃ padaṃ sutvā ambaṭṭho cintesi – ‘‘vijjā nāma tayo vedā, caraṇaṃ pañca sīlāni, tayidaṃ amhākaṃyeva atthi, vijjācaraṇasampanno  ce seṭṭho, mayameva seṭṭhā’’ti niṭṭhaṃ gantvā vijjācaraṇaṃ pucchanto – ‘‘katamaṃ pana taṃ, bho gotama, caraṇaṃ, katamā ca pana sā vijjā’’ti āha. Athassa bhagavā taṃ brāhmaṇasamaye siddhaṃ jātivādādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ vijjācaraṇaṃ paṭikkhipitvā anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇaṃ dassetukāmo – ‘‘na kho ambaṭṭhā’’tiādimāha. Tattha jātivādoti jātiṃ ārabbha vādo, brāhmaṇassevidaṃ vaṭṭati, na suddassātiādi vacananti attho. Esa nayo sabbattha. Jātivādavinibaddhāti jātivāde vinibaddhā. Esa nayo sabbattha. Tato ambaṭṭho – ‘‘yattha dāni mayaṃ laggissāmāti cintayimha, tato no samaṇo gotamo mahāvāte thusaṃ dhunanto viya dūrameva avakkhipi. Yattha pana mayaṃ na laggāma, tattha no niyojesi. Ayaṃ no vijjācaraṇasampadā ñātuṃ vaṭṭatī’’ti cintetvā puna vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ pucchi. Athassa  bhagavā samudāgamato pabhuti vijjācaraṇaṃ dassetuṃ – ‘‘idha ambaṭṭha tathāgato’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
278. Furthermore, upon hearing the phrase "endowed with wisdom and conduct" in this verse, Ambaṭṭha thought: "Wisdom ( *vidyā*) means the three Vedas (*veda*), and conduct (*caraṇa*) means the five precepts (*śīla*). These are present in us. If being endowed with wisdom and conduct is what makes one superior, then we are the most superior." Reaching this conclusion and questioning about wisdom and conduct, he asked: "But what is that conduct (*caraṇa*), venerable Gotama, and what is that wisdom (*vidyā*)?"

Then, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), wishing to reject that wisdom and conduct (*vidyācaraṇa*) which was considered established in the Brahminical (*brāhmaṇa*) tradition, connected with discussions of caste (*jātivāda*), etc., and wishing to reveal the unsurpassed wisdom and conduct (*anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇaṃ*), began by saying, "Not so, Ambaṭṭha."

Here, "discussions of caste (*jātivāda*)" means discussions (*vāda*) concerning birth (*jāti*), [saying] "This is fitting for a Brahmin (*brāhmaṇa*), not for a Śūdra," etc.; such is the meaning of the statement (*attha*).

This method applies in every instance.

"Bound up with discussions of caste (*jātivādavinibaddhā*)" means bound up with discussions of caste (*jātivāde vinibaddhā*).

This method applies in every instance.

Then Ambaṭṭha [thought]: "Where we thought we might get a hold, the ascetic Gotama shook us off from even afar, like chaff in a great wind.

Where we cannot get a hold, there he directs us.

Is this our endowment of wisdom and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampadā*) fit to be known?" Thinking thus, he again asked about the endowment of wisdom and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ*).

Then the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), from the point of complete arising onwards, in order to show wisdom and conduct (*vijjācaraṇaṃ*), began by saying, "Here, Ambaṭṭha, the Tathāgata (*tathāgata*)."

mula_pali: 279. ‘‘Katamaṃ pana taṃ, bho gotama, caraṇaṃ, katamā ca sā vijjā’’ti? ‘‘Idha, ambaṭṭha, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto. So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate  saddhaṃ paṭilabhati. So tena  saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati…pe… (yathā 191 ādayo anucchedā, evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ).… ‘‘So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…pe… idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṃ. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…pe… idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṃ. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti – ‘‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…pe… idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṃ. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…pe… idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṃ. Idaṃ kho taṃ, ambaṭṭha, caraṇaṃ. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya  cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe… idampissa hoti vijjāya…pe…  nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti, idampissa hoti vijjāya. Ayaṃ kho sā, ambaṭṭha, vijjā. ‘‘Ayaṃ vuccati, ambaṭṭha, bhikkhu ‘vijjāsampanno’ itipi, ‘caraṇasampanno’ itipi, ‘vijjācaraṇasampanno’ itipi. Imāya ca ambaṭṭha vijjāsampadāya caraṇasampadāya ca aññā vijjāsampadā ca caraṇasampadā ca uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā natthi.
mula_english:
279.

"But what is that conduct (*caraṇa*), Master Gotama? And what is that knowledge (*vijjā*)?"

"Here, Ambaṭṭha, a Tathāgata arises in the world, an Arhat, a perfectly enlightened Buddha, endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a Sugata, a knower of the world (*lokavidū*), unsurpassed, a charioteer for those who need taming (*purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, a Blessed One (*bhagavā*).

He, having realized it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*), proclaims this world with its gods (*devas*), its Māras, and its Brahmās, this generation with its recluses (*s समṇa*) and Brahmins (*brāhmaṇi*), its princes and its people.

He teaches the Dhamma that is good at the beginning, good in the middle, and good at the end; he expounds the holy life (*brahmacariya*) both in its particulars & in its essence, entirely perfect, surpassingly pure.

A householder or householder’s son or one born in some other clan hears that Dhamma.

Having heard this Dhamma, he gains faith (*saddhā*) in the Tathāgata.

Endowed with this acquisition of faith, he reflects thus…pe… (as in 191, etc., the sections should be expanded).

… "Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, he enters upon and abides in the first *jhāna*, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion…pe… This too is part of his conduct (*caraṇasmiṃ*).

"Again, Ambaṭṭha, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a *bhikkhu* enters upon and abides in the second *jhāna*, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration (*samādhi*)…pe… This too is part of his conduct (*caraṇasmiṃ*).

"Again, Ambaṭṭha, a *bhikkhu* abides in equanimity (*upekkhako*) with the fading away of rapture (*pītiyā*), and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third *jhāna*, on account of which noble ones (*ariyā*) announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful (*upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī*)’…pe… This too is part of his conduct (*caraṇasmiṃ*).

"Again, Ambaṭṭha, with the abandoning of pleasure (*sukha*) and pain (*dukkha*), and with the previous disappearance of joy (*somanassa*) and grief (*domanassa*), a *bhikkhu* enters upon and abides in the fourth *jhāna*, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity (*upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ*)…pe… This too is part of his conduct (*caraṇasmiṃ*).

This, Ambaṭṭha, is conduct (*caraṇaṃ*).

"He, with his mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, without blemish, rid of defilements, softened, suitable, steadfast, and having attained imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge and vision (*ñāṇadassanāya*)…pe… This too is part of his knowledge (*vijjāya*)…pe… ‘There is nothing further beyond this state’ he knows. This too is part of his knowledge (*vijjāya*).

This, Ambaṭṭha, is knowledge (*vijjā*).

"This, Ambaṭṭha, is what is called a *bhikkhu* ‘endowed with knowledge’ (*vijjāsampanno*), ‘endowed with conduct’ (*caraṇasampanno*), and ‘endowed with knowledge and conduct’ (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*)."

And beyond this development of knowledge (*vijjāsampadāya*) and development of conduct (*caraṇasampadāya*), Ambaṭṭha, there is no further development of knowledge (*vijjāsampadā*) or development of conduct (*caraṇasampadā*) that is higher or more perfect.
commentary_pali: 279. Ettha ca bhagavā caraṇapariyāpannampi tividhaṃ sīlaṃ vibhajanto ‘‘idamassa hoti caraṇasmi’’nti  aniyyātetvā ‘‘idampissa hoti sīlasmi’’nti sīlavaseneva niyyātesi. Kasmā? Tassapi hi kiñci kiñci sīlaṃ atthi, tasmā caraṇavasena niyyātiyamāne ‘‘mayampi caraṇasampannā’’ti tattha tattheva laggeyya. Yaṃ pana tena supinepi na diṭṭhapubbaṃ, tasseva vasena niyyātento paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Idampissa hoti caraṇasmiṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, idampissa hoti caraṇasmintiādimāha. Ettāvatā aṭṭhapi samāpattiyo caraṇanti niyyātitā honti, vipassanā ñāṇato pana paṭṭhāya aṭṭhavidhāpi paññā vijjāti niyyātitā.
commentary_english:
279.
Here, the Blessed One, dividing morality (śīla) into three kinds, which is included in conduct (*caraṇa*), designated it with morality itself, saying, "This is for him in conduct," without designating it, but saying, "This is for him in morality," with morality itself.
Why? Because even for him there is some morality. Therefore, when [morality] is designated by way of conduct, [others] might cling [to the idea], "We are also accomplished in conduct."
Moreover, that which was never seen by him even in a dream, by means of that very [morality], developing, he attains and abides in the first meditative absorption (*dhyāna*).
"This is for him in conduct…," and so on… he attains and abides in the fourth meditative absorption (*dhyāna*), "This is for him in conduct," and so forth, he said.
To this extent, the eight attainments (*samāpatti*) are designated as conduct (*caraṇa*), but beginning from insight (*vipaśyanā*) knowledge (*jñāna*), the eight kinds of wisdom (*prajñā*) are designated as knowledge (*vidyā*).

mula_pali: 280. ‘‘Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya  cattāri apāyamukhāni bhavanti. Katamāni cattāri? Idha, ambaṭṭha, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imaññeva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno khārividhamādāya khārivividhamādāya (sī. syā. pī.) araññāyatanaṃ ajjhogāhati – ‘pavattaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’ti. So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati. Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṃ paṭhamaṃ apāyamukhaṃ bhavati. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, ambaṭṭha, idhekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā  imañceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kudālapiṭakaṃ kuddālapiṭakaṃ (sī. syā. pī.) ādāya araññavanaṃ ajjhogāhati – ‘kandamūlaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’ti. So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati. Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṃ dutiyaṃ apāyamukhaṃ bhavati. ‘‘Puna  caparaṃ, ambaṭṭha, idhekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imañceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno gāmasāmantaṃ vā nigamasāmantaṃ vā agyāgāraṃ karitvā aggiṃ paricaranto acchati. So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati. Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṃ tatiyaṃ apāyamukhaṃ bhavati. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, ambaṭṭha, idhekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā imaṃ ceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno aggipāricariyañca anabhisambhuṇamāno cātumahāpathe  catudvāraṃ agāraṃ karitvā acchati – ‘yo imāhi catūhi disāhi āgamissati samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā, tamahaṃ yathāsatti yathābalaṃ paṭipūjessāmī’ti. So aññadatthu vijjācaraṇasampannasseva paricārako sampajjati. Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya idaṃ catutthaṃ apāyamukhaṃ bhavati. Imāya kho, ambaṭṭha, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya imāni cattāri apāyamukhāni bhavanti.
mula_english:
280.

“But, Ambaṭṭha, in the pursuit of this unexcelled attainment of knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampadā*) there are four paths of failure ( *apāyamukhāni*).

What are the four? Here, Ambaṭṭha, some ascetic (*samaṇa*) or Brahmin (*brāhmaṇa*), being unable to fully attain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct, takes a sickle and a basket and enters a forest dwelling, thinking, ‘I will live on windfall fruits ( *pavattaphalabhojano* ).’

But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampanna*).

This is the first path of failure (*apāyamukha*) in the pursuit of this unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampadā*).

Again, Ambaṭṭha, some ascetic (*samaṇa*) or Brahmin (*brāhmaṇa*), being unable to fully attain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct and being unable to live on windfall fruits, takes a spade and basket and enters a forest, thinking, ‘I will live on tubers, roots and fruits ( *kandamūlaphalabhojano*).’

But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampanna*).

This is the second path of failure ( *apāyamukha*) in the pursuit of this unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampadā*).

Again, Ambaṭṭha, some ascetic (*samaṇa*) or Brahmin (*brāhmaṇa*), being unable to fully attain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct, being unable to live on windfall fruits, and being unable to live on tubers, roots, and fruits, makes a fire-hut near a village or town, and sits tending the fire ( *aggiṃ paricaranto acchati*).

But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampanna*).

This is the third path of failure ( *apāyamukha*) in the pursuit of this unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampadā*).

Again, Ambaṭṭha, some ascetic (*samaṇa*) or Brahmin (*brāhmaṇa*), being unable to fully attain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct, being unable to live on windfall fruits, being unable to live on tubers, roots, and fruits and being unable to tend the fire, constructs a four-doored house at the crossroads thinking: ‘Whatever ascetic (*samaṇa*) or Brahmin (*brāhmaṇa*) arrives from the four directions, I will honor to the best of my ability.’

But in this way, he only becomes an attendant on one who has attained knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampanna*).

This is the fourth path of failure ( *apāyamukha*) in the pursuit of this unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampadā*).

These are the four paths of failure ( *apāyamukhāni*) in the pursuit of this unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampadā*).
commentary_pali: 280.Apāyamukhānīti vināsamukhāni. Anabhisambhuṇamānoti asampāpuṇanto, avisahamāno vā. Khārividhamādāyāti  ettha khārīti araṇī kamaṇḍalu sujādayo tāpasaparikkhārā. Vidhoti kājo. Tasmā khāribharitaṃ kājamādāyāti attho. Ye pana khārivividhanti paṭhanti, te ‘‘khārīti kājassa nāmaṃ, vividhanti bahukamaṇḍaluādiparikkhāra’’nti vaṇṇayanti. Pavattaphalabhojanoti patitaphalabhojano. Paricārakoti kappiyakaraṇapattapaṭiggahaṇapādadhovanādivattakaraṇavasena paricārako. Kāmañca guṇādhikopi khīṇāsavasāmaṇero puthujjanabhikkhuno vuttanayena paricārako hoti, ayaṃ pana na tādiso guṇavasenapi veyyāvaccakaraṇavasenapi lāmakoyeva. Kasmā pana tāpasapabbajjā sāsanassa vināsamukhanti vuttāti? Yasmā gacchantaṃ gacchantaṃ sāsanaṃ tāpasapabbajjāvasena osakkissati. Imasmiñhi sāsane pabbajitvā tisso sikkhā pūretuṃ asakkontaṃ lajjino sikkhākāmā – ‘‘natthi tayā saddhiṃ uposatho vā pavāraṇā vā saṅghakammaṃ vā’’ti jigucchitvā parivajjenti. So ‘‘dukkaraṃ khuradhārūpamaṃ sāsane paṭipattipūraṇaṃ dukkhaṃ, tāpasapabbajjā pana sukarā ceva bahujanasammatā cā’’ti vibbhamitvā tāpaso hoti. Aññe taṃ disvā – ‘‘kiṃ tayā kata’’nti pucchanti. So – ‘‘bhāriyaṃ tumhākaṃ sāsane kammaṃ, idha pana sachandacārino maya’’nti  vadati. Sopi, yadi evaṃ ahampi ettheva pabbajāmīti tassa anusikkhanto tāpaso hoti. Evamaññepi aññepīti kamena tāpasāva bahukā honti. Tesaṃ uppannakāle sāsanaṃ osakkitaṃ nāma bhavissati. Loke evarūpo buddho nāma uppajji, tassa īdisaṃ nāma sāsanaṃ ahosīti sutamattameva bhavissati. Idaṃ sandhāya bhagavā tāpasapabbajjaṃ sāsanassa vināsamukhanti āha. Kudālapiṭakanti  kandamūlaphalaggahaṇatthaṃ kudālañceva piṭakañca. Gāmasāmantaṃ vāti vijjācaraṇasampadādīni anabhisambhuṇanto, kasikammādīhi ca jīvitaṃ nipphādetuṃ dukkhanti maññamāno bahujanakuhāpanatthaṃ  gāmasāmante vā nigamasāmante vā aggisālaṃ katvā sappiteladadhimadhuphāṇitatilataṇḍulādīhi ceva nānādārūhi ca homakaraṇavasena aggiṃ paricaranto acchati. Catudvāraṃ agāraṃ karitvāti catumukhaṃ pānāgāraṃ katvā tassa dvāre maṇḍapaṃ katvā tattha pānīyaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā āgatāgate pānīyena āpucchati. Yampissa addhikā kilantā pānīyaṃ pivitvā parituṭṭhā bhattapuṭaṃ vā taṇḍulādīni vā denti, taṃ sabbaṃ gahetvā ambilayāguādīni katvā bahutaraṃ āmisagahaṇatthaṃ kesañci annaṃ deti, kesañci bhattapacanabhājanādīni. Tehipi dinnaṃ āmisaṃ vā pubbaṇṇādīni vā gaṇhati, tāni vaḍḍhiyā payojeti. Evaṃ vaḍḍhamānavibhavo gomahiṃsadāsīdāsapariggahaṃ karoti, mahantaṃ kuṭumbaṃ saṇṭhapeti. Imaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ – ‘‘catudvāraṃ agāraṃ karitvā acchatī’’ti. ‘‘Tamahaṃ yathāsatti yathābalaṃ paṭipūjessāmī’’ti idaṃ panassa paṭipattimukhaṃ. Iminā hi mukhena so evaṃ paṭipajjatīti. Ettāvatā ca bhagavatā sabbāpi tāpasapabbajjā niddiṭṭhā honti. Kathaṃ? Aṭṭhavidhā hi tāpasā – saputtabhariyā, uñchācariyā, anaggipakkikā, asāmapākā, asmamuṭṭhikā, dantavakkalikā, pavattaphalabhojanā, paṇḍupalāsikāti. Tattha ye keṇiyajaṭilo viya kuṭumbaṃ saṇṭhapetvā vasanti, te saputtabhariyā nāma. Ye  pana ‘‘saputtadārabhāvo nāma pabbajitassa ayutto’’ti lāyanamaddanaṭṭhānesu vīhimuggamāsatilādīni saṅkaḍḍhitvā pacitvā paribhuñjanti, te uñchācariyā nāma. Ye ‘‘khalena khalaṃ vicaritvā vīhiṃ āharitvā koṭṭetvā paribhuñjanaṃ nāma ayutta’’nti gāmanigamesu taṇḍulabhikkhaṃ gahetvā pacitvā paribhuñjanti, te anaggipakkikā nāma. Ye pana ‘‘kiṃ pabbajitassa sāmapākenā’’ti gāmaṃ pavisitvā pakkabhikkhameva gaṇhanti , te asāmapākā nāma. Ye  ‘‘divase divase bhikkhāpariyeṭṭhi nāma dukkhā pabbajitassā’’ti muṭṭhipāsāṇena ambāṭakādīnaṃ rukkhānaṃ tacaṃ koṭṭetvā khādanti, te asmamuṭṭhikā nāma. Ye pana ‘‘pāsāṇena tacaṃ koṭṭetvā vicaraṇaṃ nāma dukkha’’nti danteheva ubbāṭetvā khādanti, te dantavakkalikā nāma. Ye ‘‘dantehi ubbāṭetvā khādanaṃ nāma dukkhaṃ pabbajitassā’’ti leḍḍudaṇḍādīhi paharitvā patitāni phalāni paribhuñjanti, te pavattaphalabhojanā nāma. Ye pana ‘‘leḍḍudaṇḍādīhi pātetvā paribhogo nāma asāruppo pabbajitassā’’ti sayaṃ patitāneva pupphaphalapaṇḍupalāsādīni khādantā yāpenti, te paṇḍupalāsikā nāma. Te tividhā – ukkaṭṭhamajjhimamudukavasena. Tattha ye nisinnaṭṭhānato anuṭṭhāya hatthena pāpuṇanaṭṭhāneva patitaṃ gahetvā khādanti, te ukkaṭṭhā. Ye ekarukkhato aññaṃ rukkhaṃ na gacchanti, te majjhimā. Ye taṃ taṃ rukkhamūlaṃ gantvā pariyesitvā khādanti, te mudukā. Imā pana aṭṭhapi tāpasapabbajjā imāhi catūhiyeva saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Kathaṃ? Etāsu hi saputtabhariyā ca uñchācariyā ca agāraṃ bhajanti. Anaggipakkikā ca asāmapākā ca agyāgāraṃ bhajanti. Asmamuṭṭhikā ca dantavakkalikā ca kandamūlaphalabhojanaṃ bhajanti. Pavattaphalabhojanā ca paṇḍupalāsikā ca pavattaphalabhojanaṃ bhajanti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘ettāvatā ca bhagavatā sabbāpi tāpasapabbajjā niddiṭṭhā hontī’’ti.
commentary_english:
280. "The mouths of downfall" means the entrances to destruction.

"Not fully comprehending" means not fully attaining, or being unable to bear.

"Having taken a *khāri* and a *vidha*," here, *khāri* means the implements of an ascetic, such as a water pot (*kamaṇḍalu*) and an *araṇī.*

*Kāja* means a wooden hammer.

Therefore, the meaning is, "having taken a *kāja* filled with a *khāri*."

Those, however, who read it as *khārivividha*, explain it thus: "'*Khārī*' is the name of the *kāja*; *vividha* means many implements such as water pots (*kamaṇḍalu*)."

*Pavattaphalabhojana* means eating fallen fruit.

*Paricāraka* means an attendant by way of doing what is allowable, receiving bowls, washing feet, and doing similar duties.

Moreover, even a *sāmaṇera* whose outflows are destroyed, who possesses greater qualities, can be an attendant for an ordinary *bhikkhu* in the manner described. However, this one is inferior, and is simply base even by way of possessing qualities and by way of performing service.

But why is the ascetic life said to be the mouth of the destruction of the Teaching (*sāsana*)? It is because as the Teaching goes on, it will decline by way of the ascetic life.

For in this Teaching, those who have gone forth, being unable to fulfill the three trainings, are ashamed and desirous of the training: "There is no *uposatha*, *pavāraṇā*, or *saṃghakamma* with you," and so they despise [those ascetics] and avoid them.

He, having become confused, thinking, "Fulfilling the practice in the Teaching is difficult and like the edge of a razor, but the ascetic life is easy and agreed upon by many people," becomes an ascetic.

Others, seeing him, ask, "What have you done?"

He says, "Work in the Teaching is burdensome for you, but here, we are self-willed."

He too, if it is so, thinking, "I too will go forth right here," following his instruction, becomes an ascetic.

Thus, in due order, others and others too, ascetics, become many.

When they have arisen, the Teaching will be called "declined."

"In the world, a Buddha named such-and-such arose, his Teaching was named such-and-such" — there will be only this much that is heard.

With this in mind, the Blessed One said that the ascetic life is the mouth of the destruction of the Teaching (*sāsana*).

*Kudālapiṭaka* means both a spade (*kudāla*) and a basket (*piṭaka*) for the sake of gathering roots, bulbs, and fruits.

Or, without fully comprehending the attainment of the perfections of learning and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampadādi*), thinking, "It is difficult to produce a living by farming etc.," for the sake of deceiving many people, having made a fire hall either in the vicinity of a village or in the vicinity of a town, tending the fire by way of making offerings with ghee (*sarpi*), oil, yogurt, honey, molasses (*phāṇita*), sesame seeds, rice, etc., and also with various kinds of wood, he lives.

"Having made a four-doored dwelling" means having made a four-faced drinking house, having made a pavilion (*maṇḍapa*) at its door, having set up water there, he greets those who come and go with water.

Whatever weary travelers drink the water and are satisfied, and give him a packet of food or rice etc., having taken all of that and having made sour gruel (*ambilayāguādi*), for the sake of gaining more material, he gives food to some and utensils for cooking food etc. to others.

Even the material that was given by them or early grain etc., he takes and uses it for growth.

Thus, one whose wealth is growing makes a collection of cows, buffaloes, female slaves, and male slaves, and establishes a large household.

With this in mind, this was said: "Having made a four-doored dwelling, he lives."

"I will honor him as I am able, as I have strength" — this is the entrance to his practice.

Indeed, he practices thus by this entrance.

And thus, the Blessed One has completely indicated all the ascetic lives.

How? For ascetics are of eight kinds: those with wives and children (*saputtabhariyā*), those who glean (*uñchācariyā*), those who do not cook with fire (*anaggipakkikā*), those who do not cook their own food (*asāmapākā*), those who use a stone as a bowl (*asmamuṭṭhikā*), those who use bark for teeth (*dantavakkalikā*), those who eat fallen fruit (*pavattaphalabhojanā*), and those who eat fallen leaves (*paṇḍupalāsikā*).

There, those who live maintaining a household like the ascetic Keṇiya, are called "those with wives and children (*saputtabhariyā*)."

Those, however, who, thinking, "The state of having wives and children is unsuitable for one who has gone forth," gleaning grains of rice, green gram (*mudga*), kidney beans (*māsa*), sesame, etc. in places where there are threshing floors and places for treading out grain, cook and consume [them], are called *uñchācariyā*.

Those who, thinking, "To roam about the threshing floor gathering rice, to pound and consume is unsuitable," taking rice as alms in villages and towns, cook and consume [it], are called *anaggipakkikā*.

Those who, thinking, "What is the use of cooking one's own food for one who has gone forth?" entering a village, only take cooked alms, are called *asāmapākā*.

Those who, thinking, "The search for alms day after day is suffering for one who has gone forth," pounding the bark of trees such as mangoes (*ambāṭaka*) with a stone pestle, eat [it], are called *asmamuṭṭhikā*.

Those who, thinking, "To pound bark with a stone and roam about is suffering," uprooting [the bark] with their teeth, eat [it], are called *dantavakkalikā*.

Those who, thinking, "To uproot and eat with the teeth is suffering for one who has gone forth," striking [trees] with clods, sticks, etc., consume the fallen fruits, are called *pavattaphalabhojanā*.

Those who, thinking, "To cause [fruit] to fall with clods, sticks, etc. and to enjoy [it] is unsuitable for one who has gone forth," eating only the flowers, fruits, dry leaves etc. that have fallen by themselves, live, are called *paṇḍupalāsikā*.

They are of three kinds: superior, middling, and inferior.
There, those who, without rising from their sitting place, take and eat what has fallen within reach of their hand are the *ukkaṭṭhā*.

Those who do not go from one tree to another are the *majjhimā*.

Those who go to that very root of a tree, search around, and eat, are the *mudukā*.

Moreover, these eight kinds of ascetics' renunciations are included in these four ways.

How? Among these, those who live in a house with their sons and wives are *uñchācariyā*.

Those who cook without fire and who do not cook themselves go to a house with a fire (agyāgāraṃ).

Those who eat stones (asmamuṭṭhikā), those who eat bark (dantavakkalikā), and those who eat roots, tubers, and fruits enjoy food.

Those who enjoy fallen fruits (pavattaphalabhojanā) and those who have yellow leaves also enjoy fallen fruits.

Therefore, it was said: "Thus, all the renunciations of ascetics have been indicated by the Blessed One."

mula_pali: 281. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, apinu tvaṃ imāya anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya sandissasi sācariyako’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘Kocāhaṃ, bho  gotama, sācariyako, kā ca anuttarā vijjācaraṇasampadā? Ārakāhaṃ, bho gotama, anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya  sācariyako’’ti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, apinu tvaṃ imañceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno khārividhamādāya araññavanamajjhogāhasi sācariyako – ‘pavattaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, apinu tvaṃ imañceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kudālapiṭakaṃ ādāya araññavanamajjhogāhasi sācariyako – ‘kandamūlaphalabhojano bhavissāmī’’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Taṃ  kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, apinu tvaṃ imañceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno gāmasāmantaṃ vā nigamasāmantaṃ vā agyāgāraṃ karitvā aggiṃ paricaranto acchasi sācariyako’’ti? ‘‘No  hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, apinu tvaṃ imañceva anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ anabhisambhuṇamāno pavattaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno kandamūlaphalabhojanatañca anabhisambhuṇamāno aggipāricariyañca anabhisambhuṇamāno cātumahāpathe catudvāraṃ agāraṃ karitvā acchasi sācariyako – ‘yo imāhi catūhi disāhi āgamissati samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā, taṃ mayaṃ yathāsatti yathābalaṃ paṭipūjessāmā’’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
281. “What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Do you and your teacher live in accordance with this unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *anuttarā vijjācaraṇasampadā*)?” “No, Gotama.”

‘Who are my teacher and I, Gotama, and what is unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *anuttarā vijjācaraṇasampadā*)? Far from unexcelled knowledge and conduct ( *anuttarā vijjācaraṇasampadā*) are my teacher and I, Gotama.’

“What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ*), go with carrying-poles into the depths of the forest, intending to live on windfalls ( *pavattaphalabhojano bhavissāmī* )?” “No, Gotama.”

“What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ*), being unable to live on windfalls, go with your carrying-bowl into the depths of the forest, intending to live on tubers, roots, and fruits ( *kandamūlaphalabhojano bhavissāmī*)?” “No, Gotama.”

“What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ*), being unable to live on windfalls, being unable to live on tubers, roots, and fruits, dwell near a village or town, building a fire-hut and tending the fire?” “No, Gotama.”

“What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Could you and your teacher, being unable to gain this unexcelled knowledge and conduct (*anuttaraṃ vijjācaraṇasampadaṃ*), being unable to live on windfalls, being unable to live on tubers, roots, and fruits, being unable to tend the fire, build a four-doored alms-hall at the intersection of four great roads, thinking, ‘Whatever ascetic or brahmin comes from these four directions, we will honor and serve them according to our ability and strength’?” “No, Gotama.”
commentary_pali: 281-282. Idāni  bhagavā sācariyakassa ambaṭṭhassa vijjācaraṇasampadāya apāyamukhampi appattabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ taṃ kiṃ maññasi ambaṭṭhātiādimāha. Taṃ uttānatthameva. Attanā āpāyikopi aparipūramānoti attanā vijjācaraṇasampadāya āpāyikenāpi aparipūramānena.
commentary_english:
Now, the Bhagavan, to show that Ambaṭṭha, together with his teacher, has not attained even the entrance to the path of ruin with the accomplishment of knowledge and conduct, said, "What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?" etc.

The rest is clear.

By oneself, even though not fulfilling the characteristics of the path of ruin, [is superior to] oneself, who is not fulfilling [the path of ruin] even with the accomplishment of knowledge and conduct.

mula_pali: 282. ‘‘Iti kho, ambaṭṭha, imāya ceva tvaṃ anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya parihīno sācariyako. Ye cime anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya cattāri apāyamukhāni bhavanti , tato ca tvaṃ parihīno sācariyako. Bhāsitā kho pana te esā, ambaṭṭha, ācariyena brāhmaṇena pokkharasātinā vācā – ‘ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā bandhupādāpaccā, kā ca tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ sākacchā’ti attanā āpāyikopi aparipūramāno. Passa, ambaṭṭha, yāva aparaddhañca te idaṃ ācariyassa brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa.
mula_english:
"And so, Ambaṭṭha, not only are you and your teacher incapable of attaining this unsurpassed perfection of knowledge and conduct ( *anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya*),
but even the four paths of failure (*cattāri apāyamukhāni*) are beyond you and your teacher.
And yet these words were spoken to you, Ambaṭṭha, by your teacher, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti: “These shaven ascetics, menials, dark fellows born from the feet of a slave – what discussion (*sākacchā*) can they have with Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ*)?” – even though he himself does not fulfill the duties of one who has failed.
See, Ambaṭṭha, how your teacher, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, has let you down!"
commentary_pali: 281-282. Idāni  bhagavā sācariyakassa ambaṭṭhassa vijjācaraṇasampadāya apāyamukhampi appattabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ taṃ kiṃ maññasi ambaṭṭhātiādimāha. Taṃ uttānatthameva. Attanā āpāyikopi aparipūramānoti attanā vijjācaraṇasampadāya āpāyikenāpi aparipūramānena.
commentary_english:
Now, to show Ambaṭṭha, together with his teacher, that even the gateway to misfortune is an unattained state with respect to the perfection of knowledge and conduct, the Blessed One said, "What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?" etc.

The rest is clear.

By oneself, even one subject to misfortune is not fulfilled; that is, by oneself, with respect to the perfection of knowledge and conduct, even by one subject to misfortune, [one] is unfulfilled.

mula_pali: 283. ‘‘Brāhmaṇo  kho pana, ambaṭṭha, pokkharasāti rañño pasenadissa kosalassa dattikaṃ bhuñjati. Tassa rājā pasenadi kosalo sammukhībhāvampi na dadāti. Yadāpi tena manteti, tirodussantena manteti. Yassa kho pana, ambaṭṭha, dhammikaṃ payātaṃ bhikkhaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, kathaṃ tassa rājā pasenadi kosalo sammukhībhāvampi na dadeyya. Passa, ambaṭṭha, yāva aparaddhañca te idaṃ ācariyassa brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa.
mula_english:
283.

"Indeed, Ambaṭṭha, the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti lives on the royal grant (*dattikaṃ*) of King Pasenadi of Kosala.

Yet, King Pasenadi of Kosala does not grant him an audience (*sammukhībhāva*).

When he consults with him, he does so behind a curtain (*tirodussantena*).

Now, Ambaṭṭha, how could King Pasenadi of Kosala not grant an audience (*sammukhībhāva*) to someone who accepts a righteous offering (*dhammikaṃ bhikkhaṃ*) bestowed upon him?

See, Ambaṭṭha, how far your teacher, the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti, has failed you."
commentary_pali: 283.Dattikanti dinnakaṃ. Sammukhībhāvampi na dadātīti kasmā na dadāti? So kira sammukhā  āvaṭṭaniṃ nāma vijjaṃ  jānāti. Yadā rājā mahārahena alaṅkārena alaṅkato hoti, tadā rañño samīpe ṭhatvā tassa alaṅkārassa nāmaṃ gaṇhati. Tassa rājā nāme gahite na demīti vattuṃ na sakkoti. Datvā puna chaṇadivase alaṅkāraṃ āharathāti vatvā, natthi, deva, tumhehi brāhmaṇassa dinnoti vutto, ‘‘kasmā me dinno’’ti pucchi. Te amaccā ‘so brāhmaṇo sammukhā āvaṭṭanimāyaṃ jānāti. Tāya tumhe āvaṭṭetvā gahetvā gacchatī’ti āhaṃsu. Apare raññā saha tassa atisahāyabhāvaṃ asahantā āhaṃsu – ‘‘deva, etassa brāhmaṇassa sarīre saṅkhaphalitakuṭṭhaṃ nāma atthi. Tumhe etaṃ disvāva āliṅgatha parāmasatha, idañca kuṭṭhaṃ nāma kāyasaṃsaggavasena anugacchati, mā evaṃ karothā’’ti. Tato paṭṭhāya tassa rājā sammukhībhāvaṃ na deti. Yasmā pana so brāhmaṇo paṇḍito khattavijjāya kusalo, tena saha mantetvā katakammaṃ nāma na virujjhati, tasmā sāṇipākārassa anto ṭhatvā bahi ṭhitena tena saddhiṃ manteti. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ ‘‘tiro dussantena mantetī’’ti. Tattha tirodussantenāti tirodussena. Ayameva vā pāṭho. Dhammikanti anavajjaṃ. Payātanti abhiharitvā dinnaṃ. Kathaṃ tassa rājāti yassa rañño brāhmaṇo īdisaṃ bhikkhaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, kathaṃ tassa brāhmaṇassa so rājā sammukhībhāvampi na dadeyya. Ayaṃ pana adinnakaṃ māyāya gaṇhati, tenassa sammukhībhāvaṃ rājā na detīti niṭṭhamettha gantabbanti ayamettha adhippāyo. ‘‘Idaṃ pana kāraṇaṃ ṭhapetvā rājānañceva brāhmaṇañca na añño koci jānāti. Tadetaṃ evaṃ rahassampi paṭicchannampi addhā sabbaññū samaṇo gotamoti niṭṭhaṃ gamissatī’’ti bhagavā pakāsesi.
commentary_english:
283. "Dattikanti" means "given."

"Why does he not give even an audience?" Why does he not give? It is said that he knows a science called *āvaṭṭaniṃ* face to face.

When the king is adorned with a great and precious ornament, he stands near the king and takes the name of that ornament.

When his name, the king, is mentioned, he is not able to say, "I will not give."

Having given it, and then on a festive day saying, "Bring the ornament," and being told, "Lord, it was given by you to the *brāhmaṇa*," he asks, "Why was it given to me?"

The ministers say, "That *brāhmaṇa* knows *āvaṭṭanimāyaṃ* face to face.

He will turn you around and take you and go."

Others, unable to bear his very friendly relations with the king, say, "Lord, there is a *saṅkhaphalitakuṭṭhaṃ* disease on this *brāhmaṇa*'s body.

You, having seen this, embrace and touch him, and this disease goes along by contact with the body. Do not do this!"

From then on, the king does not give him an audience.

Since that *brāhmaṇa* is learned, wise, and skilled in the science of the stars, his actions, after consulting with him, do not fail. Therefore, he consults with him while standing inside the rampart, with him standing outside.

Referring to that, it was said, "He consults secretly with Dussanta."

There, "with *tirodussantena*" means "with *tirodussena*."

Or this is the reading.

"Dhammikanti" means "blameless."

"Payātanti" means "given by bringing near."

How is he a king, if a *brāhmaṇa* of that king should accept such alms, how should that king not give even an audience to that *brāhmaṇa*?

But this one takes what is not given by trickery. Therefore, the king does not give him an audience. This is the conclusion to be reached here; this is the intention here.

"Leaving aside this reason, no one else knows this, neither the king nor the *brāhmaṇa*.

The Blessed One revealed: "Thus, even this secret and concealed matter, the *sabbaññū* (*sarvajñū*, all-knowing) *śramaṇa* (*śramaṇa*, ascetic) Gotama will bring to a conclusion."

mula_pali: 284. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, idha rājā pasenadi kosalo hatthigīvāya vā nisinno assapiṭṭhe vā nisinno rathūpatthare vā ṭhito uggehi vā rājaññehi vā kiñcideva mantanaṃ  manteyya. So tamhā padesā apakkamma ekamantaṃ tiṭṭheyya. Atha āgaccheyya suddo vā  suddadāso vā, tasmiṃ padese ṭhito tadeva mantanaṃ manteyya – ‘evampi rājā pasenadi kosalo āha, evampi rājā pasenadi kosalo āhā’ti. Apinu so rājabhaṇitaṃ vā bhaṇati rājamantanaṃ vā manteti? Ettāvatā so  assa rājā vā rājamatto vā’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
284.

"What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Suppose King Pasenadi Kosala were sitting on the neck of an elephant (*hastigīvā*) or on horseback (*aśvapiṭṭhe*) or standing on a chariot mat (*rathūpatthare*), conferring with his officers (*uggehi*) or princes (*rājanyehi*) about something.

And suppose he were to step aside from that place (*padesā*) and stand to one side (*ekamantaṃ tiṭṭheyya*).

Then, suppose a *śūdra* or a *śūdra* servant were to come along and, standing in his place, were to discuss the same matter, saying, "Thus spoke King Pasenadi Kosala, thus spoke King Pasenadi Kosala."

Would he be speaking the king's words (*rājabhaṇitaṃ*), or discussing the king's business (*rājamantanaṃ*)? To that extent, would he be the king (*rājā*) or a royal minister (*rājamatto*)?"

"No, indeed, venerable Gotama."
commentary_pali: 284. Idāni  ayañca ambaṭṭho, ācariyo cassa mante nissāya atimānino. Tena tesaṃ mantanissitamānanimmadanatthaṃ uttari desanaṃ vaḍḍhento taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, idha rājātiādimāha. Tattha rathūpatthareti rathamhi rañño ṭhānatthaṃ attharitvā sajjitapadese. Uggehi vāti uggatuggatehi vā amaccehi. Rājaññehīti anabhisittakumārehi. Kiñcideva mantananti asukasmiṃ dese taḷākaṃ vā mātikaṃ vā kātuṃ vaṭṭati, asukasmiṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā nagaraṃ vā nivesetunti evarūpaṃ pākaṭamantanaṃ. Tadeva mantananti yaṃ raññā mantitaṃ tadeva. Tādisehiyeva sīsukkhepabhamukkhepādīhi ākārehi manteyya. Rājabhaṇitanti yathā raññā bhaṇitaṃ, tassatthassa sādhanasamatthaṃ. Sopi tassatthassa sādhanasamatthameva bhaṇitaṃ bhaṇatīti attho.
commentary_english:
284.
And now, this Ambaṭṭha is an arrogant teacher who relies on his *mantras*.

Therefore, in order to eliminate their conceit based on *mantras*, while increasing the superior teaching, what do you think, Ambaṭṭha? Here, he spoke beginning with "a king," and so on.

There, they spread out a chariot-covering in a prepared place on the chariot for the king to stand.

With uplifted cries or with ministers who have attained eminence.

"By royalty" means by princes who have not yet been consecrated.

A public discussion is like: "In such and such a place, it is fitting to make a pond *taḷākaṃ vā mātikaṃ vā*, or in such and such a village, market town *nigamaṃ vā*, or city *nagaraṃ vā*, it is fitting to establish [something]."

"That very discussion" means that which was discussed by the king, just that.

One should discuss with such gestures as raising the head, raising the eyebrows, and so forth (*sīsukkhepabhamukkhepādīhi ākārehi*).

"The king's speech" means just as it was spoken by the king, capable of accomplishing that purpose (*tassatthassa sādhanasamatthaṃ*).

And he speaks what is spoken, which is capable of accomplishing that purpose; that is the meaning (*sopi tassatthassa sādhanasamatthameva bhaṇitaṃ bhaṇatīti attho*).

mula_pali: 285. ‘‘Evameva kho tvaṃ, ambaṭṭha, ye te ahesuṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ, tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi yamadaggi (ka.) aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu – ‘tyāhaṃ mante adhiyāmi sācariyako’ti, tāvatā tvaṃ bhavissasi isi vā isitthāya vā paṭipannoti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english: Just so, Ambaṭṭha, those ancient *ṛṣis* (sages) of the *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins), the makers of *mantras* (hymns), the expounders of *mantras* (hymns)—whose ancient *mantra-padas* (hymn verses) are sung, uttered, compiled, which *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) at present still sing, still chant, repeating what was said, repeating what was spoken—that is to say, Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, Bhagu—by merely saying, “I study the *mantras* (hymns) with a teacher,” you will not become a *ṛṣi* (sage), nor one who has entered the path of a *ṛṣi* (sage). Such a thing is not possible.
commentary_pali: 285.Pavattāroti pavattayitāro. Yesanti yesaṃ santakaṃ. Mantapadanti vedasaṅkhātaṃ mantameva . Gītanti aṭṭhakādīhi dasahi porāṇakabrāhmaṇehi sarasampattivasena sajjhāyitaṃ. Pavuttanti aññesaṃ vuttaṃ, vācitanti attho. Samihitanti samupabyūḷhaṃ rāsikataṃ, piṇḍaṃ katvā ṭhapitanti attho. Tadanugāyantīti etarahi brāhmaṇā taṃ tehi pubbe gītaṃ anugāyanti anusajjhāyanti. Tadanubhāsantīti taṃ anubhāsanti, idaṃ purimasseva vevacanaṃ. Bhāsitamanubhāsantīti tehi bhāsitaṃ sajjhāyitaṃ anusajjhāyanti. Vācitamanuvācentīti tehi aññesaṃ vācitaṃ anuvācenti. Seyyathidanti te katamehi attho. Aṭṭhakotiādīni tesaṃ nāmāni. Te kira dibbena cakkhunā oloketvā parūpaghātaṃ akatvā kassapasammāsambuddhassa bhagavato pāvacanena saha saṃsanditvā mante ganthiṃsu. Aparāpare pana brāhmaṇā pāṇātipātādīni pakkhipitvā tayo vede bhinditvā buddhavacanena saddhiṃ viruddhe akaṃsu. Netaṃṭhānaṃ vijjatīti yena tvaṃ isi bhaveyyāsi, etaṃ kāraṇaṃ na vijjati. Idha bhagavā yasmā – ‘‘esa pucchiyamānopi, attano avattharaṇabhāvaṃ ñatvā paṭivacanaṃ na dassatī’’ti jānāti, tasmā paṭiññaṃ agahetvāva taṃ isibhāvaṃ paṭikkhipi.
commentary_english:
285. Pravattāroti: They are the promoters.
Yesanti: That which belongs to them.
Mantapadanti: The *mantra*-words are indeed the *mantra* known through the Vedas. (*vedasaṅkhātaṃ mantameva*)
Gītanti: It was recited with the attainment of melody by the ten ancient Brahmins, beginning with Aṭṭhaka.
Pavuttanti: It is said by others; its meaning is 'caused to be spoken.'
Samihitanti: Having heaped together and made a pile, having made a lump and placed it; this is the meaning.
Tadanugāyantīti: Nowadays, Brahmins sing and repeat what was previously sung by them.
Tadanubhāsantīti: They speak after that; this is merely another word for the former.
Bhāsitamanubhāsantīti: They repeat and recite what was spoken by them.
Vācitamanuvācentīti: They cause to recite what was caused to be spoken by others.
Seyyathidanti: What is the meaning of those?
Aṭṭhakotiādīni: These are their names.
Te kira: Having surveyed with divine vision, without harming others, and having compared with the teaching of the Blessed One, Kassapa, the Perfectly Awakened One, they strung together the *mantras*.
Aparāpare pana brāhmaṇā: But other Brahmins, having inserted things such as killing living beings, having broken the three Vedas, did things contradictory to the Buddha's teaching.
Netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatīti: This is not the place whereby you might become a seer; this is not the reason.
Idha bhagavā yasmā: Here, the Blessed One, because he knows that "even when questioned, he will not give an answer, knowing his state of being scattered," therefore, without accepting his assertion, rejected that state of being a seer.

mula_pali: 286. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭha, kinti te sutaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vuddhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ – ye te ahesuṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ  etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ, tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, evaṃ su te sunhātā suvilittā kappitakesamassū āmukkamaṇikuṇḍalābharaṇā āmuttamālābharaṇā (sī. syā. pī.) odātavatthavasanā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārenti, seyyathāpi tvaṃ etarahi sācariyako’’ti? ‘‘No  hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘…Pe… evaṃ su te sālīnaṃ odanaṃ sucimaṃsūpasecanaṃ vicitakāḷakaṃ anekasūpaṃ anekabyañjanaṃ paribhuñjanti, seyyathāpi tvaṃ etarahi sācariyako’’ti ? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘…Pe… evaṃ su te veṭhakanatapassāhi nārīhi paricārenti, seyyathāpi tvaṃ etarahi sācariyako’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘…Pe… evaṃ su te kuttavālehi vaḷavārathehi dīghāhi patodalaṭṭhīhi vāhane vitudentā  vipariyāyanti, seyyathāpi tvaṃ etarahi sācariyako’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘…Pe… evaṃ su te ukkiṇṇaparikhāsu okkhittapalighāsu nagarūpakārikāsu dīghāsivudhehi dīghāsibaddhehi (syā. pī.) purisehi rakkhāpenti, seyyathāpi tvaṃ etarahi sācariyako’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Iti kho, ambaṭṭha, neva tvaṃ isi na isitthāya paṭipanno sācariyako. Yassa kho pana, ambaṭṭha, mayi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā so maṃ pañhena, ahaṃ veyyākaraṇena sodhissāmī’’ti.
mula_english:
286. "What do you think, Ambaṭṭha? What have you heard from Brahmins who are old, aged, teachers of teachers, as they speak: ‘Those former ṛṣis (seers) of the Brahmins, the makers of mantras and the expounders of mantras, whose ancient verse is now chanted, recited, and collected by the Brahmins, they sing after it, they speak after it, they speak after what was spoken, they recite after what was recited, such as Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, Bhagu—did they, thus well-bathed, well-anointed, with trimmed hair and beards, adorned with necklaces of jewels and earrings, adorned with garlands (sī.
syā.
pī.), wearing white clothes, indulging in and united with the five strands of sense pleasure, live like that, as you and your teacher do now?’" "No, revered Gotama."

"…Furthermore, did they enjoy fine rice and curry with sauces of pure meat, selected black lentils, and various soups and curries, as you and your teacher do now?" "No, revered Gotama."

"…Furthermore, are they attended by women who are wrapped in shawls, as you and your teacher are now?" "No, revered Gotama."

"…Furthermore, do they go around urging on their vehicles with braided tails, drawn by mares, with long goad-sticks, as you and your teacher do now?" "No, revered Gotama."

"…Furthermore, do they have themselves guarded in fortified towns with dug-out moats, with lowered crossbars, with town ramparts, by men with long swords (syā.
pī.), as you and your teacher do now?" "No, revered Gotama."

"Thus, Ambaṭṭha, neither you nor your teacher are a seer, nor are you practicing the way of a seer. But if you have any doubt or perplexity concerning me, Ambaṭṭha, ask me a question, and I will clarify it for you with an explanation."
commentary_pali: 286. Idāni  yasmā te porāṇā dasa brāhmaṇā nirāmagandhā anitthigandhā rajojalladharā brahmacārino araññāyatane pabbatapādesu vanamūlaphalāhārā vasiṃsu. Yadā katthaci gantukāmā honti, iddhiyā ākāseneva gacchanti, natthi tesaṃ yānena kiccaṃ. Sabbadisāsu ca nesaṃ mettādibrahmavihārabhāvanāva ārakkhā hoti, natthi tesaṃ pākārapurisaguttīhi attho. Iminā ca ambaṭṭhena sutapubbā tesaṃ paṭipatti; tasmā imassa sācariyakassa tesaṃ paṭipattito ārakabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ – ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasi, ambaṭṭhā’’tiādimāha. Tattha vicitakāḷakanti vicinitvā apanītakāḷakaṃ. Veṭhakanatapassāhīti dussapaṭṭadussaveṇi ādīhi veṭhakehi namitaphāsukāhi. Kuttavālehīti sobhākaraṇatthaṃ kappetuṃ, yuttaṭṭhānesu kappitavālehi. Ettha ca vaḷavānaṃyeva vālā kappitā, na rathānaṃ, vaḷavapayuttattā pana rathāpi ‘‘kuttavālā’’ti vuttā. Ukkiṇṇaparikhāsūti khataparikhāsu. Okkhittapalighāsūti ṭhapitapalighāsu. Nagarūpakārikāsūti ettha upakārikāti paresaṃ ārohanivāraṇatthaṃ samantā nagaraṃ pākārassa adhobhāge katasudhākammaṃ vuccati. Idha pana tāhi upakārikāhi yuttāni nagarāneva ‘‘nagarūpakārikāyo’’ti adhippetāni. Rakkhāpentīti tādisesu nagaresu vasantāpi attānaṃ rakkhāpenti. Kaṅkhāti ‘‘sabbaññū, na sabbaññū’’ti evaṃ saṃsayo. Vimatīti tasseva vevacanaṃ, virūpā  mati, vinicchinituṃ asamatthāti attho. Idaṃ bhagavā ‘‘ambaṭṭhassa iminā attabhāvena maggapātubhāvo natthi, kevalaṃ divaso vītivattati, ayaṃ kho pana lakkhaṇapariyesanatthaṃ āgato, tampi  kiccaṃ nassarati. Handassa satijananatthaṃ nayaṃ demī’’ti āha.
commentary_english:
286. Now, because those ancient ten *brāhmaṇas* were without the smell of raw flesh, without the smell of women, wearing matted hair from dust and dirt, celibates, they dwelt in forest retreats, at the foot of mountains, eating roots, fruits, and produce of the forest.

When they wished to go anywhere, they went by their psychic power, as if through the sky; they had no need of a vehicle.

And in all directions, they had the protection only of cultivating loving-kindness and other divine abodes; they had no need of a wall, a man, or guards.

And this conduct of theirs was previously heard by Ambaṭṭha. Therefore, to show the brass-like state of that teacher from their conduct, [the Buddha] spoke beginning with, "What do you think, Ambaṭṭha?"

There, *vicitakāḷakan* means having sorted out and removed the dark spots.

*Veṭhakanatapassāhīti* means with wrappings of bent ribs made of cloths, woolen cloths, braided cloths, and so forth.

*Kuttavālehīti* means in order to arrange for beautification, with tails arranged in suitable places.

And here, only the tails of the young mares were arranged, not those of the chariots; however, because the chariots were yoked to young mares, the chariots too were called "*kuttavālā*."

*Ukkiṇṇaparikhāsūti* means in moats that have been dug out.

*Okkhittapalighāsūti* means in barriers that have been set in place.

*Nagarūpakārikāsūti* means here, *upakārikā* is said to be the cement work done all around the city on the lower part of the wall, in order to prevent others from climbing up.

Here, however, only the cities equipped with those *upakārikās* are intended by "*nagarūpakārikāyo*."

*Rakkhāpentīti* means even those living in such cities protect themselves.

*Kaṅkhāti* means "Is [he] all-knowing? Is [he] not all-knowing?"—thus is doubt.

*Vimatīti* means that itself is a synonym, a distorted thought, meaning incapable of deciding.

The Blessed One [said,] "Ambaṭṭha, with this state of self, there is no manifestation of the path for Ambaṭṭha; the day merely passes by. But this one has come to search for the marks, and even that task is ruined.

I will give a method for the generation of mindfulness for him," he said.

mula_pali: 287. Atha kho bhagavā vihārā nikkhamma caṅkamaṃ abbhuṭṭhāsi. Ambaṭṭhopi māṇavo vihārā nikkhamma caṅkamaṃ abbhuṭṭhāsi. Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ caṅkamantaṃ anucaṅkamamāno bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi. Addasā kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavato kāye  dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve . Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati – kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya ca.
mula_english:
287. Then, descending from his lodging, the Lord started to walk up and down.
Ambattha the youth also, descending from his lodging, started to walk up and down.
And as he walked along with the Lord, Ambattha looked out for the thirty-two marks of a Great Man (dvātriṃśatmahāpuruṣalakṣaṇāni) on the Lord’s body.
And he could see all of them except for two.
He was in doubt and perplexity about two of these marks: he could not make up his mind or be certain about the sheathed genitals (kosohite ca vatthaguyhe) or the large tongue (pahūtajivhatāya ca).
commentary_pali: 287. Evaṃ vatvā pana yasmā buddhānaṃ nisinnānaṃ vā nipannānaṃ vā koci lakkhaṇaṃ pariyesituṃ na sakkoti, ṭhitānaṃ pana caṅkamantānaṃ vā sakkoti. Āciṇṇañcetaṃ buddhānaṃ lakkhaṇapariyesanatthaṃ āgatabhāvaṃ ñatvā uṭṭhāyāsanā caṅkamādhiṭṭhānaṃ nāma, tena bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā bahi nikkhanto. Tasmā atha kho bhagavātiādi vuttaṃ. Samannesīti  gavesi, ekaṃ dveti vā gaṇayanto samānayi. Yebhuyyenāti pāyena, bahukāni addasa, appāni na addasāti attho. Tato yāni na addasa tesaṃ dīpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ – ‘‘ṭhapetvā dve’’ti. Kaṅkhatīti ‘‘aho vata passeyya’’nti patthanaṃ uppādeti. Vicikicchatīti tato tato tāni vicinanto kicchati na sakkoti daṭṭhuṃ. Nādhimuccatīti tāya vicikicchāya sanniṭṭhānaṃ na gacchati. Na sampasīdatīti tato – ‘‘paripuṇṇalakkhaṇo aya’’nti bhagavati pasādaṃ nāpajjati. Kaṅkhāya vā dubbalā vimati vuttā, vicikicchāya majjhimā, anadhimuccanatāya balavatī, asampasādena tehi tīhi dhammehi cittassa kālusiyabhāvo. Kosohiteti vatthikosena paṭicchanne. Vatthaguyheti aṅgajāte bhagavato hi varavāraṇasseva kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ padumagabbhasamānaṃ. Taṃ so vatthapaṭicchannattā apassanto, antomukhagatāya ca jivhāya pahūtabhāvaṃ asallakkhento tesu dvīsu lakkhaṇesu kaṅkhī ahosi vicikicchī.
commentary_english:
287. Having spoken thus, because no one can search for the marks of the Buddhas whether they are sitting or lying down, but [one] can when they are standing or walking.

Moreover, knowing that this coming to search for the marks of the Buddhas is their established practice, the Blessed One arose from his seat and went forth for a walk.

Therefore, it was said, "Then, the Blessed One..." and so forth.

"He examined closely" means he searched, counting and bringing together, "one or two" or whatever.

"By far the greater part" means mostly, he saw many, the meaning is that he did not see a few.

Then, to explain those which he did not see, it was said: "Except for two."

"He is doubtful" means he produces the wish, "Oh, that I might see!"

"He is skeptical" means searching for those things here and there, he struggles, he is not able to see.

"He is not convinced" means by that skepticism, he does not reach a conclusion.

"He is not pleased" means then – "This one is of perfect marks" – he does not attain pleasure in the Blessed One.

It is said that doubt is weak, skepticism is middling, non-conviction is strong, and by non-acceptance, the mind is sullied by these three things.

"Kosohita" means covered by the sheath of the penis.

"Vatthaguyha" means in the organ of generation, indeed, the Blessed One's hidden organ of generation is like that of an excellent elephant, golden in color, like the inside of a lotus.

Not seeing that it was covered by the cloth, and not considering the abundance of the tongue that was turned inwards, he was doubtful and skeptical about those two marks.

mula_pali: 288. Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi – ‘‘passati kho me ayaṃ ambaṭṭho māṇavo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve. Dvīsu  mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati – kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya cā’’ti. Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā addasa ambaṭṭho māṇavo bhagavato kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ. Atha kho bhagavā jivhaṃ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṃ jivhāya chādesi. Atha kho ambaṭṭhassa māṇavassa etadahosi – ‘‘samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi, no aparipuṇṇehī’’ti. Bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bho gotama, gacchāma, bahukiccā mayaṃ bahukaraṇīyā’’ti . ‘‘Yassadāni tvaṃ, ambaṭṭha, kālaṃ maññasī’’ti. Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo vaḷavārathamāruyha pakkāmi.
mula_english:
Then it occurred to the Blessed One: "This young Brahmin Ambaṭṭha sees in me the thirty-two marks of a great man, except for two.

He is doubtful and perplexed about two of the marks; he cannot decide and make up his mind about the concealed genitals (*kosohite vatthaguyhe*) and the large tongue (*pahūtajivhatāya*)."

Then the Blessed One performed such a feat of supernormal power (*iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi*) that the young Brahmin Ambaṭṭha saw the Blessed One’s genitals enclosed in a sheath (*kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ*).

Then the Blessed One extended his tongue (*jivhaṃ ninnāmetvā*) and touched and rubbed both ear-holes (*kaṇṇasotāni anumasi paṭimasi*), and both nostrils (*nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi*), and also covered the whole forehead (*nalāṭamaṇḍalaṃ*) with his tongue (*jivhāya chādesi*).

Then it occurred to the young Brahmin Ambaṭṭha: "The ascetic Gotama is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a great man (*dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato*), complete in every way, not incomplete."

He said to the Blessed One: "Well, then, Master Gotama (*bho Gotama*), we must go now (*gacchāma*). We are busy and have much to do (*bahukiccā mayaṃ bahukaraṇīyā*)."

"Do, Ambaṭṭha, what you think it is now time to do (*yassadāni tvaṃ kālaṃ maññasī*)."

Then the young Brahmin Ambaṭṭha mounted his chariot drawn by mares (*vaḷavārathamāruyha*) and departed (*pakkāmi*).
commentary_pali: 288.Tathārūpanti taṃ rūpaṃ. Kimettha aññena vattabbaṃ? Vuttametaṃ nāgasenatthereneva milindaraññā puṭṭhena – ‘‘dukkaraṃ, bhante, nāgasena, bhagavatā katanti. Kiṃ mahārājāti? Mahājanena hirikaraṇokāsaṃ brahmāyu brāhmaṇassa ca antevāsi uttarassa ca, bāvarissa antevāsīnaṃ soḷasabrāhmaṇānañca , selassa brāhmaṇassa ca antevāsīnaṃ tisatamāṇavānañca dassesi, bhanteti. Na, mahārāja, bhagavā guyhaṃ dassesi. Chāyaṃ bhagavā dassesi. Iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā nivāsananivatthaṃ kāyabandhanabaddhaṃ cīvarapārutaṃ chāyārūpakamattaṃ dassesi mahārājāti. Chāyaṃ diṭṭhe sati diṭṭhaṃyeva nanu, bhanteti? Tiṭṭhatetaṃ, mahārāja, hadayarūpaṃ disvā  bujjhanakasatto bhaveyya, hadayamaṃsaṃ nīharitvā dasseyya sammāsambuddhoti. Kallosi, bhante, nāgasenā’’ti. Ninnāmetvāti nīharitvā. Anumasīti kathinasūciṃ viya katvā anumajji, tathākaraṇena cettha mudubhāvo, kaṇṇasotānumasanena dīghabhāvo, nāsikasotānumasanena tanubhāvo, nalāṭacchādanena puthulabhāvo pakāsitoti veditabbo.
commentary_english:
288.
Such is that form.

What else is to be said here? This was said by the Elder Nāgasena himself, when asked by King Milinda: "It is difficult, venerable Nāgasena, what the Blessed One has done."

"What, your majesty?" He showed the opportunity for shame to the great multitude, to Brahmāyu the Brāhman and to Uttara his disciple, to the sixteen Brāhmans who were disciples of Bāvari, and to the three hundred youths who were disciples of Sela the Brāhman, venerable sir.

No, your majesty, the Blessed One did not show a secret.

The Blessed One showed a shadow.

Having arranged by means of his power, he showed a shadow-image clothed in an undergarment, bound with a body-band, and covered with a robe, your majesty.

Surely, venerable sir, when a shadow is seen, it is indeed seen, is it not? Let that be, your majesty. Having seen the heart-form, one might become an awakened being. Having removed the heart-flesh, he might show it, [saying,] "This is a *sammāsambuddha* (perfectly awakened Buddha)."

"You are skilled, venerable Nāgasena."

'Having taken out' means 'having removed'.

'He rubbed' means having made [the needle] like a stiff needle, he rubbed [it] in. By that act, softness here, by rubbing the ear-passage, length, by rubbing the nose-passage, thinness, by covering the forehead, breadth is made manifest, it should be understood.

mula_pali: 289. Tena kho pana samayena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ukkaṭṭhāya nikkhamitvā mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṃ sake ārāme nisinno hoti ambaṭṭhaṃyeva māṇavaṃ paṭimānento. Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yena sako ārāmo tena pāyāsi. Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā brāhmaṇaṃ pokkharasātiṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mula_english:
At that time, the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti, having gone out to Ukkaṭṭhā, was sitting in his own park with a large group of *brāhmaṇas*, waiting for the youth Ambaṭṭha.
Then, the youth Ambaṭṭha went to his own park.
As far as the ground was suitable for vehicles, he went by vehicle; then, getting down from the vehicle, he approached the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti on foot; having approached, he greeted the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti and sat down to one side.
commentary_pali: 289.Paṭimānentoti  āgamento, āgamanamassa patthento udikkhantoti attho.
commentary_english: 289. *Paṭimānento* means awaiting, anticipating his arrival, looking forward to his coming, is the meaning.

mula_pali: 290. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ  brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti etadavoca – ‘‘kacci, tāta ambaṭṭha, addasa taṃ bhavantaṃ gotama’’nti? ‘‘Addasāma kho mayaṃ, bho, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotama’’nti. ‘‘Kacci, tāta ambaṭṭha, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ tathā santaṃyeva  saddo abbhuggato no aññathā; kacci pana so bhavaṃ gotamo tādiso no aññādiso’’ti ? ‘‘Tathā santaṃyeva, bho, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saddo abbhuggato no aññathā, tādisova so bhavaṃ gotamo no aññādiso. Samannāgato ca so bhavaṃ gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi no aparipuṇṇehī’’ti. ‘‘Ahu pana te, tāta ambaṭṭha, samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo’’ti? ‘‘Ahu kho me, bho, samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo’’ti. ‘‘Yathā kathaṃ pana te, tāta ambaṭṭha, ahu samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo’’ti? Atha kho ambaṭṭho māṇavo yāvatako yāvatiko (ka. pī.) ahosi bhagavatā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo, taṃ sabbaṃ brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa ārocesi.
mula_english:
290.

Then the brāhmaṇa Pokkharasāti said this to the young Ambaṭṭha, who was sitting to one side: "Well, dear Ambaṭṭha, did you see the esteemed Gotama?" "Yes, sir, we saw the esteemed Gotama."

"And, dear Ambaṭṭha, is the report that has spread about the esteemed Gotama true and not otherwise? And is that esteemed Gotama of such a nature and not otherwise?" "Yes, sir, the report that has spread about the esteemed Gotama is true and not otherwise, and that esteemed Gotama is of such a nature and not otherwise.

And the esteemed Gotama is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a great man (*dvātriṃśat-mahāpuruṣa-lakṣaṇehi*), complete in every way, not incomplete."

"And did you have any conversation with the *śramaṇa* Gotama, dear Ambaṭṭha?" "Yes, sir, I had some conversation with the *śramaṇa* Gotama."

"And what was the conversation like that you had with the *śramaṇa* Gotama, dear Ambaṭṭha?" Then the young Ambaṭṭha told the brāhmaṇa Pokkharasāti all the conversation that he had had with the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*).
commentary_pali: 290.Kathāsallāpoti kathā ca sallāpo ca, kathanaṃ paṭikathananti attho.
commentary_english: 290. *Kathāsallāpo* means *kathā* "speech" and *sallāpa* "conversation", and *kathanaṃ* "telling" and *paṭikathanaṃ* "retelling"; that is the meaning.

mula_pali: 291. Evaṃ vutte, brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘aho vata re amhākaṃ paṇḍitaka paṇḍitakā, aho vata re amhākaṃ bahussutaka bahussutakā, aho vata re amhākaṃ tevijjaka tevijjakā, evarūpena kira, bho, puriso atthacarakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyya. Yadeva kho tvaṃ, ambaṭṭha, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ āsajja āsajja avacāsi, atha kho so bhavaṃ gotamo amhepi evaṃ  upaneyya upaneyya avaca. Aho vata re amhākaṃ paṇḍitaka, aho vata re amhākaṃ bahussutaka, aho vata re amhākaṃ tevijjaka, evarūpena kira, bho, puriso atthacarakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjeyyā’’ti, kupito so kupito (pī.) anattamano ambaṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ padasāyeva pavattesi. Icchati ca tāvadeva bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ.
mula_english:
291. When this was said, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti said this to the youth Ambaṭṭha: "Oh, you are indeed our little scholar, oh, you are indeed our very learned one, oh, you are indeed our master of the three Vedas ( *tevijjaka*)! A man of such kind, indeed, sir, by acting with a purpose, after death, at the breaking up of the body ( *kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā*), would be reborn in the state of loss (*apāyaṃ*), a bad destination (*duggatiṃ*), ruin (*vinipātaṃ*), hell (*nirayaṃ*).
Indeed, Ambaṭṭha, you have insulted the esteemed Gotama in such a way that the esteemed Gotama has repeatedly brought up more and more things against us.
Oh, you are indeed our little scholar, oh, you are indeed our very learned one, oh, you are indeed our master of the three Vedas (*tevijjaka*)! A man of such kind, indeed, sir, by acting with a purpose, after death, at the breaking up of the body (*kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā*), would be reborn in the state of loss (*apāyaṃ*), a bad destination (*duggatiṃ*), ruin (*vinipātaṃ*), hell (*nirayaṃ*)!" Being angry, very angry, displeased, he kicked Ambaṭṭha, the youth, with his foot.
And he desired to go at once to see the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*) for a vision (*dassanāya*).
commentary_pali: 291.Aho vatāti garahavacanametaṃ. Reti idaṃ hīḷanavasena āmantanaṃ. Paṇḍitakāti tameva jigucchanto āha. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Evarūpena kira bho puriso atthacarakenāti idaṃ yādiso tvaṃ, edise atthacarake hitakārake sati puriso nirayaṃyeva gaccheyya, na aññatrāti imamatthaṃ sandhāya vadati. Āsajja āsajjāti ghaṭṭetvā ghaṭṭetvā. Amhepi evaṃ upaneyya upaneyyāti brāhmaṇo kho pana ambaṭṭha pokkharasātītiādīni vatvā evaṃ upanetvā upanetvā paṭicchannaṃ kāraṇaṃ āvikaritvā suṭṭhu dāsādibhāvaṃ āropetvā avaca, tayā amhe akkosāpitāti adhippāyo. Padasāyeva pavattesīti pādena paharitvā bhūmiyaṃ pātesi. Yañca so pubbe ācariyena saddhiṃ rathaṃ āruhitvā sārathi hutvā agamāsi , tampissa ṭhānaṃ acchinditvā rathassa purato padasā yevassa gamanaṃ akāsi.
commentary_english:
291. Alas, what a reproachful statement this is!

"Re," this is an address by way of contempt.

Reviling him, he said, "You are just a Paṇḍitaka!"

And the same method applies to the other two instances.

In this way, he says, "Indeed, sir, by a man who acts for his own advantage in such a manner as this--that is, if you are such a person, in such a pursuit of advantage, while being a benefactor, that man would go to hell and nowhere else." He speaks intending this meaning.

"Touching, touching," means having rubbed and rubbed.

"And we too, having thus brought near, having brought near," thus the *brāhmaṇa*, indeed, having spoken such words as "Ambaṭṭha is a descendant of Pokkharasāti," and having thus brought near, having brought near, and having revealed the covered cause, and having thoroughly brought about the condition of being a slave, etc., said, "By you, we have been reviled," this is the idea.

"He knocked him down with his foot," means having struck him with his foot, he threw him to the ground.

And as he formerly, having ascended the chariot together with his teacher, went as a charioteer, having cut off that place of his, he made him go on foot in front of the chariot.

mula_pali: 292. Atha  kho te brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ pokkharasātiṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘ativikālo kho, bho, ajja samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Svedāni dāni sve (sī. ka.) bhavaṃ pokkharasāti samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’ti. Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā yāne āropetvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu  ukkaṭṭhāya niyyāsi, yena icchānaṅgalavanasaṇḍo tena pāyāsi. Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā, yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami. Upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mula_english:
Then the Brahmins said this to the Brahmin Pokkharasāti: “It is too late, sir, to visit the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama today."

"Tomorrow, the revered Pokkharasāti should visit the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama to see him."

Then the *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) Pokkharasāti, after preparing fine hard and soft food in his own dwelling, had it loaded onto a vehicle. With torches being held aloft, he set out for Ukkaṭṭha, proceeding to the grove in Icchānaṅgala.

As far as the ground was suitable for vehicles, he traveled by vehicle; then, dismounting from the vehicle, he went on foot to where the Blessed One was.

Having approached the Blessed One, he exchanged courteous greetings, and after exchanging pleasantries, he sat down to one side.
commentary_pali: 292-296.Ativikāloti suṭṭhu vikālo, sammodanīyakathāyapi kālo natthi. Āgamā nu khvidha bhoti āgamā nu kho idha bho. Adhivāsetūti sampaṭicchatu. Ajjatanāyāti yaṃ me tumhesu kāraṃ karoto ajja bhavissati puññañca pītipāmojjañca tadatthāya. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvenāti bhagavā kāyaṅgaṃ vā vācaṅgaṃ vā acopetvā abbhantareyeva khantiṃ dhārento tuṇhībhāvena adhivāsesi. Brāhmaṇassa anuggahaṇatthaṃ manasāva sampaṭicchīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
292-296.
*Ativikālo* means it is truly *vikāla*, and there is no time for pleasant talk either.
Do the *āgamas* come here? O, do the *āgamas* come here?
Let him accept, meaning let him receive.
Because of today, whatever merit, joy, and gladness will be mine today as I perform the act for you, is for that purpose.
*Bhagavā* accepted in silence, meaning the Exalted One, without stirring body or speech, enduring patience within, accepted in silence.
It is said that he accepted it with his mind for the sake of favoring the *brāhmaṇa*.

mula_pali: 293. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘āgamā nu kho idha, bho gotama, amhākaṃ antevāsī ambaṭṭho māṇavo’’ti? ‘‘Āgamā kho te tedha (syā.), te idha (pī.), brāhmaṇa, antevāsī ambaṭṭho māṇavo’’ti. ‘‘Ahu pana te, bho gotama, ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo’’ti? ‘‘Ahu kho me, brāhmaṇa, ambaṭṭhena māṇavena  saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo’’ti. ‘‘Yathākathaṃ pana te, bho gotama, ahu ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo’’ti? Atha kho bhagavā yāvatako ahosi ambaṭṭhena māṇavena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo, taṃ sabbaṃ brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa ārocesi. Evaṃ vutte, brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘bālo, bho gotama, ambaṭṭho māṇavo, khamatu bhavaṃ gotamo ambaṭṭhassa māṇavassā’’ti. ‘‘Sukhī hotu, brāhmaṇa, ambaṭṭho māṇavo’’ti.
mula_english:
293. Having sat down to one side, the brāhmaṇa Pokkharasāti said this to the Blessed One: "Venerable Gotama, did not our pupil, Ambaṭṭha the youth, come here?" "He did come here, brāhmaṇa, Ambaṭṭha the youth."

"And was there any conversation (kathāsallāpo) between you and Ambaṭṭha the youth?" "There was indeed a conversation (kathāsallāpo) between me and Ambaṭṭha the youth, brāhmaṇa."

"And what was that conversation (kathāsallāpo) about, Venerable Gotama, that occurred with Ambaṭṭha the youth?" Then the Blessed One told the brāhmaṇa Pokkharasāti everything that the conversation (kathāsallāpo) with Ambaṭṭha the youth had been about.

When this was said, the brāhmaṇa Pokkharasāti said this to the Blessed One: "Ambaṭṭha the youth is a fool, Venerable Gotama. May the Venerable Gotama forgive Ambaṭṭha the youth."

"May Ambaṭṭha the youth be happy (sukhī hotu), brāhmaṇa."
commentary_pali: 292-296.Ativikāloti suṭṭhu vikālo, sammodanīyakathāyapi kālo natthi. Āgamā nu khvidha bhoti āgamā nu kho idha bho. Adhivāsetūti sampaṭicchatu. Ajjatanāyāti yaṃ me tumhesu kāraṃ karoto ajja bhavissati puññañca pītipāmojjañca tadatthāya. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvenāti bhagavā kāyaṅgaṃ vā vācaṅgaṃ vā acopetvā abbhantareyeva khantiṃ dhārento tuṇhībhāvena adhivāsesi. Brāhmaṇassa anuggahaṇatthaṃ manasāva sampaṭicchīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
292-296.

"Ativikālo" means it is very much the wrong time; there is no time even for polite conversation.

"Āgamā nu khvidha bhoti āgamā nu kho idha bho"

"Adhivāsetūti" means let him accept.

"Ajjatanāyāti yaṃ me tumhesu kāraṃ karoto ajja bhavissati puññañca pītipāmojjañca tadatthāya"

"Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvenāti" means the Exalted One accepted with silence; the Exalted One, without stirring bodily action or speech, enduring patience within, accepted with silence.

"Brāhmaṇassa anuggahaṇatthaṃ manasāva sampaṭicchīti" means it is said that he accepted it in his mind for the sake of the brahmin's support.

mula_pali: 294. Atha  kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni samannesi. Addasā kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato kāye dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve. Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati – kosohite ca vatthaguyhe pahūtajivhatāya ca.
mula_english:
Then the brahmin Pokkharasāti examined the Blessed One’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man (*dvātriṃśatmahāpuruṣalakṣaṇāni*).

And the brahmin Pokkharasāti saw nearly all the thirty-two marks of a great man on the Blessed One's body, except for two.

He was doubtful and perplexed about two of these marks and could not decide or be certain about them: about the male organ being enclosed in a sheath (*kosohite ca vatthaguyhe*) and about the largeness of the tongue (*pahūtajivhatāya ca*).
commentary_pali: 292-296.Ativikāloti suṭṭhu vikālo, sammodanīyakathāyapi kālo natthi. Āgamā nu khvidha bhoti āgamā nu kho idha bho. Adhivāsetūti sampaṭicchatu. Ajjatanāyāti yaṃ me tumhesu kāraṃ karoto ajja bhavissati puññañca pītipāmojjañca tadatthāya. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvenāti bhagavā kāyaṅgaṃ vā vācaṅgaṃ vā acopetvā abbhantareyeva khantiṃ dhārento tuṇhībhāvena adhivāsesi. Brāhmaṇassa anuggahaṇatthaṃ manasāva sampaṭicchīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
Very late means exceedingly late; there is no time even for polite conversation.

Do the Āgamas exist here? Are there Āgamas here, sir?

Let him accept, meaning: may he consent.

'For today' means: whatever merit (puṇya) and joy-and-gladness will arise today for me, while I am doing an act of worship for you, is for that purpose.

'The Exalted One consented in silence' means: the Exalted One, without stirring either his bodily action (kāyaṅga) or his speech-action (vācaṅga), enduring patience within himself, consented in silence.

'He accepted it in his mind for the sake of favouring the *brāhmaṇa*'—this is what is said.

mula_pali: 295. Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi – ‘‘passati kho me ayaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇāni yebhuyyena ṭhapetvā dve. Dvīsu mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati – kosohite ca vatthaguyhe, pahūtajivhatāya cā’’ti. Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā addasa brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ. Atha kho  bhagavā jivhaṃ ninnāmetvā ubhopi kaṇṇasotāni  anumasi paṭimasi, ubhopi nāsikasotāni anumasi paṭimasi, kevalampi nalāṭamaṇḍalaṃ jivhāya chādesi.
mula_english:
295. Then it occurred to the Blessed One: "This Brahmin Pokkharasāti sees in me the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, for the most part, except for two.

He doubts and is uncertain about two of the marks of a Great Man, he cannot decide and is not confident about them: about the male organ being enclosed in a sheath *(*kosohite vatthaguyhe*)*, and about the largeness of the tongue *(*pahūtajivhatāya*)*."

Then the Blessed One worked such a feat of supernormal power that the Brahmin Pokkharasāti saw that the Blessed One’s male organ was enclosed in a sheath *(*kosohitaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ*)*.

Next the Blessed One extended his tongue, and he repeatedly touched both ear holes and both nostrils, and he covered the whole circle of his forehead with his tongue.
commentary_pali: 292-296.Ativikāloti suṭṭhu vikālo, sammodanīyakathāyapi kālo natthi. Āgamā nu khvidha bhoti āgamā nu kho idha bho. Adhivāsetūti sampaṭicchatu. Ajjatanāyāti yaṃ me tumhesu kāraṃ karoto ajja bhavissati puññañca pītipāmojjañca tadatthāya. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvenāti bhagavā kāyaṅgaṃ vā vācaṅgaṃ vā acopetvā abbhantareyeva khantiṃ dhārento tuṇhībhāvena adhivāsesi. Brāhmaṇassa anuggahaṇatthaṃ manasāva sampaṭicchīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
Very late is indeed quite late; there is no time even for words of greeting.

Are the *āgamas* coming here? Are the *āgamas* coming here, sir?

Let him accept it, meaning let him receive it well.

For today, whatever merit, joy, and delight will be mine through performing the act of reverence toward you.

The Exalted One accepted with silence, meaning the Exalted One, without stirring bodily or vocal action, enduring patience within himself, accepted with silence.

It is said that he accepted it in his mind for the sake of favoring the *brāhmaṇa*.

mula_pali: 296. Atha kho brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa etadahosi  – ‘‘samannāgato kho samaṇo gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi paripuṇṇehi no aparipuṇṇehī’’ti. Bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo ajjatanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’’ti. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
mula_english:
Then the brahmin Pokkharasāti thought: “The ascetic Gotama is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a great man (*dvātriṃśat-mahāpuruṣa-lakṣaṇa*), complete and not incomplete.”

He said to the Blessed One: “May the venerable Gotama accept a meal from me today, together with the *bhikkhu-saṅgha* (community of monks).”

The Blessed One consented by silence (*tuṇhībhāvena*).
commentary_pali: 292-296.Ativikāloti suṭṭhu vikālo, sammodanīyakathāyapi kālo natthi. Āgamā nu khvidha bhoti āgamā nu kho idha bho. Adhivāsetūti sampaṭicchatu. Ajjatanāyāti yaṃ me tumhesu kāraṃ karoto ajja bhavissati puññañca pītipāmojjañca tadatthāya. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvenāti bhagavā kāyaṅgaṃ vā vācaṅgaṃ vā acopetvā abbhantareyeva khantiṃ dhārento tuṇhībhāvena adhivāsesi. Brāhmaṇassa anuggahaṇatthaṃ manasāva sampaṭicchīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
292-296.
*Ativikāla* means very much *vikāla*; there is no time even for pleasant conversation.
Are there *āgamas* here? Are there *āgamas* here, sir?
Let him accept, saying, "May he consent."
For today, whatever merit, joy, and delight will be mine as I perform acts of kindness for you today, is for that purpose.
The Exalted One consented in silence. The Exalted One, without arousing bodily or verbal action, enduring patience inwardly, consented in silence.
It is said that he accepted it in his mind for the sake of favoring the *brāhmaṇa*.

mula_pali: 297. Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocesi – ‘‘kālo, bho gotama, niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta’’nti. Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi, māṇavakāpi bhikkhusaṅghaṃ. Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mula_english:
Then, the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti, knowing the Blessed One's acceptance, announced the time to the Blessed One, saying: “It is time, Reverend Gotama, the meal is ready.”

Then, the Blessed One, having dressed in the morning, taking his bowl (*patta*) and robe (*cīvara*), together with the community of monks (*bhikkhusaṅgha*), went to the residence (*nivesanaṃ*) of the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti; having arrived, he sat down on the prepared seat (*āsana*).
