Then, the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti personally satisfied and served the Blessed One with choice staple and non-staple food (*khādanīya bhojanīya*), and the young men also served the community of monks (*bhikkhusaṅgha*).

Then, the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti, when the Blessed One had finished eating and removed his hand from the bowl, took a low seat (*nīcaṃ āsanaṃ*) and sat down to one side.
commentary_pali: 297.Paṇītenāti  uttamena. Sahatthāti sahatthena. Santappesīti suṭṭhu tappesi paripuṇṇaṃ suhitaṃ yāvadatthaṃ akāsi. Sampavāresīti  suṭṭhu pavāresi, alaṃ alanti hatthasaññāya paṭikkhipāpesi. Bhuttāvinti bhuttavantaṃ. Onītapattapāṇinti pattato onītapāṇiṃ, apanītahatthanti vuttaṃ hoti. Onittapattapāṇintipi pāṭho. Tassattho – onittaṃ nānābhūtaṃ vinābhūtaṃ pattaṃ pāṇito assāti onittapattapāṇi, taṃ onittapattapāṇiṃ. Hatthe ca pattañca dhovitvā ekamante pattaṃ nikkhipitvā nisinnanti attho. Ekamantaṃ nisīdīti bhagavantaṃ evaṃ bhūtaṃ ñatvā ekasmiṃ okāse nisīdīti attho.
commentary_english:
297.
*paṇītena* means with the best or excellent (*uttamena*).
*sahatthā* means with his own hand (*sahatthena*).
*santappesi* means he satisfied him well, he made him full, happy, and to his heart's content (*suṭṭhu tappesi paripuṇṇaṃ suhitaṃ yāvadatthaṃ akāsi*).
*sampavāresi* means he forbade him well, he rejected him with a gesture of the hand, saying "Enough! Enough!" (*suṭṭhu pavāresi, alaṃ alanti hatthasaññāya paṭikkhipāpesi*).
*bhuttāviṃ* means one who has eaten (*bhuttavantaṃ*).
*onītapattapāṇiṃ* means one who has removed his hand from the bowl, it is said that he has removed his hand (*pattato onītapāṇiṃ, apanītahatthanti vuttaṃ hoti*).
There is also the reading *onittapattapāṇiṃ*.
Its meaning is: *onittaṃ* means different, separate, the bowl is without the hand, therefore *onittapattapāṇi*, him the *onittapattapāṇiṃ*.
The meaning is: Having washed his hands and the bowl, and having placed the bowl aside, he sat down (*hatthe ca pattañca dhovitvā ekamante pattaṃ nikkhipitvā nisinnanti attho*).
*ekamantaṃ nisīdīti* means, having known the Blessed One to be thus, he sat down in a certain place (*bhagavantaṃ evaṃ bhūtaṃ ñatvā ekasmiṃ okāse nisīdīti attho*).

mula_pali: 298. Ekamantaṃ nisinnassa kho brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa  bhagavā anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ – dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ; kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi. Yadā bhagavā aññāsi brāhmaṇaṃ pokkharasātiṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi – dukkhaṃ samudayaṃ nirodhaṃ maggaṃ. Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya; evameva brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa tasmiññeva  āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi – ‘‘yaṃ kiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma’’nti.
mula_english:
And as the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti was seated to one side, the Blessed One delivered a graduated discourse, that is to say, a talk on generosity (*dānakathā*), a talk on morality (*sīlakathā*), a talk on heaven (*saggakathā*), showing the danger (*ādīnava*), degradation (*okāra*), and corruption (*saṃkilesa*) of sense-desires, and the profit (*ānisaṃsa*) of renunciation (*nekkhamma*).

When the Blessed One knew that the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti’s mind was ready (*kallacittaṃ*), pliable (*muducittaṃ*), free from hindrances (*vinīvaraṇacittaṃ*), joyful (*udaggacittaṃ*), and calm (*pasannacittaṃ*), then he preached the teaching special to the Buddhas (*buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā*)— suffering (*dukkhaṃ*), its origin (*samudayaṃ*), its cessation (*nirodhaṃ*), and the path (*maggaṃ*).

Just as a clean cloth, free from stains (*apagatakāḷakaṃ*), would readily take dye, so too, as the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti sat in that very seat, there arose in him the spotless, immaculate eye of the Dharma (*virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ*): “Whatever is subject to arising (*samudayadhammaṃ*) is all subject to cessation (*nirodhadhammaṃ*).”
commentary_pali: 298.Anupubbiṃ kathanti anupaṭipāṭikathaṃ. Ānupubbikathā nāma dānānantaraṃ sīlaṃ, sīlānantaraṃ saggo, saggānantaraṃ maggoti etesaṃ atthānaṃ dīpanakathā. Teneva – ‘‘seyyathidaṃ dānakatha’’ntiādimāha. Okāranti avakāraṃ lāmakabhāvaṃ. Sāmukkaṃsikāti sāmaṃ ukkaṃsikā, attanāyeva uddharitvā gahitā, sayambhūñāṇena diṭṭhā, asādhāraṇā aññesanti attho. Kā pana sāti? Ariyasaccadesanā. Tenevāha – ‘‘dukkhaṃ, samudayaṃ, nirodhaṃ, magga’’nti. Dhammacakkhunti  ettha sotāpattimaggo adhippeto. Tassa uppattiākāradassanatthaṃ – ‘‘yaṃ kiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma’’nti āha. Tañhi nirodhaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā kiccavasena evaṃ sabbasaṅkhataṃ paṭivijjhantaṃ uppajjati.
commentary_english:
298.

"Speaking gradually" means speaking sequentially.

The gradual teaching is so called because it is a talk that clarifies these meanings: giving (*dāna*) followed by morality (*śīla*), morality (*śīla*) followed by heaven (*svarga*), and heaven (*svarga*) followed by the path (*mārga*).

Therefore, he said, "For example, a talk on giving (*dānakatha*)," and so on.

"Okāra" means contempt, a base state.

"Sāmukkaṃsikā" means "one who raises oneself up," taken up by oneself, seen by self-born wisdom ( *sayambhūñāṇa*), not common to others, is the meaning.

What is that called "sāti"? It is the teaching of the noble truths (*ariyasaccadesanā*).

Therefore, he said, "Suffering (*duḥkha*), origination (*samudaya*), cessation (*nirodha*), path (*mārga*)."

"Dhammacakkhu" here means the path of stream-entry (*sotāpattimagga*) is intended.

To show its manner of arising, he said, "Whatever is of the nature of arising, all that is of the nature of ceasing."

For that arises thus, making cessation (*nirodha*) its object (*ārammaṇa*), penetrating all conditioned things (*sarvasaṅkhata*) according to its function.

mula_pali: 299. Atha kho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṃkatho vesārajjappatto  aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama. Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya , andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya, ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ, bho gotama, saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ. Yathā ca bhavaṃ gotamo ukkaṭṭhāya aññāni upāsakakulāni upasaṅkamati, evameva bhavaṃ gotamo pokkharasātikulaṃ upasaṅkamatu. Tattha ye te māṇavakā vā māṇavikā vā bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhivādessanti vā paccuṭṭhissanti paccuṭṭhassanti (pī.) vā āsanaṃ vā udakaṃ vā dassanti cittaṃ vā pasādessanti, tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’’ti. ‘‘Kalyāṇaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā’’ti.
mula_english:
Then the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, having seen the *dharma*, attained the *dharma*, understood the *dharma*, fathomed the *dharma*, having crossed beyond doubt, transcended uncertainty, having gained perfect confidence in the Teacher’s doctrine without relying on others, said this to the Blessed One: “Excellent, venerable Gotama, excellent, venerable Gotama!

Just as, venerable Gotama, one might set upright what has been overturned, or reveal what has been hidden, or point out the way to one who is lost, or hold up an oil lamp in the darkness so that those with eyes might see forms, in the same way the *dharma* has been made clear by venerable Gotama in many ways.

I, along with my son, my wife, my retinue, and my ministers, go to venerable Gotama for refuge, to the *dharma*, and to the monastic community (*bhikkhusaṅgha*).

May venerable Gotama remember me as a lay follower (*upāsaka*) who has gone for refuge from this day forth, as long as life shall last (*pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ*).

And just as venerable Gotama visits other families of lay followers (*upāsakakulāni*) in Ukkaṭṭha, may venerable Gotama also visit the family of Pokkharasāti!

And whatever young men or maidens there are who will greet venerable Gotama or rise up to meet him, or offer a seat or water, or gladden their hearts, that will be for their long-term welfare and happiness."

"Well said, Brahmin!" (*kalyāṇaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇā*).
commentary_pali: 299. Diṭṭho ariyasaccadhammo etenāti diṭṭhadhammo.  Esa nayo sesapadesupi. Tiṇṇā vicikicchā anenāti tiṇṇavicikiccho. Vigatā kathaṃkathā assāti vigatakathaṃkatho. Vesārajjappattoti visāradabhāvaṃ patto. Kattha? Satthusāsane. Nāssa paro paccayo, na parassa saddhāya ettha vattatīti aparappaccayo. Sesaṃ sabbattha vuttanayattā uttānatthattā ca pākaṭamevāti.
commentary_english:
299. Because the noble truth of the Dharma has been seen by this, it is called *diṭṭhadhamma*.

The same method of explanation applies to the other clauses too.

Because doubt (*vicikicchā*) has been overcome by this, it is called *tiṇṇavicikiccho*.

Because questioning (*kathaṃkathā*) has vanished from him, he is called *vigatakathaṃkatho*.

He has attained confidence (*vesārajja*), therefore he has attained the state of confidence (*visāradabhāvaṃ patto*).

Where? In the Teacher's Dispensation (*satthusāsane*).

There is no other condition for him, nor does it proceed here by the faith of another, therefore it is independent of others (*aparappaccayo*).

The rest is clear everywhere because of the method already stated and because the meaning is plain.

mula_pali: 518. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena manasākaṭaṃ nāma kosalānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari. Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā manasākaṭe viharati uttarena manasākaṭassa aciravatiyā nadiyā tīre ambavane.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion, the Blessed One was wandering in Kosala with a large Saṅgha of approximately five hundred monks, and he arrived at a Kosalan Brahmin village called Manasākaṭa.

There, it seems, the Blessed One was staying near Manasākaṭa, in a mango grove on the bank of the Aciravatī river, north of Manasākaṭa.
commentary_pali: 518.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… kosalesūti tevijjasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ anuttānapadavaṇṇanā. Manasākaṭanti tassa gāmassa nāmaṃ. Uttarena manasākaṭassāti manasākaṭato avidūre uttarapasse. Ambavaneti taruṇaambarukkhasaṇḍe, ramaṇīyo kira so bhūmibhāgo, heṭṭhā rajatapaṭṭasadisā vālikā vippakiṇṇā, upari maṇivitānaṃ viya ghanasākhāpattaṃ ambavanaṃ. Tasmiṃ buddhānaṃ anucchavike pavivekasukhe ambavane viharatīti attho.
commentary_english:
Thus have I heard... in Kosala, namely the Tevijja Sutta.

Herein is an explanation of the terms that are not obvious.

"Manasākaṭa" is the name of that village.

"To the north of Manasākaṭa" means not far from Manasākaṭa, on the northern side.

"Ambavana" means in a grove of young mango trees; that place is delightful. Below, sand is scattered like silver plates; above, the mango grove is like a jeweled canopy with dense branches and leaves.

The meaning is that he dwelt in that mango grove, which was suitable for Buddhas, secluded, and pleasant in its solitude.

mula_pali: 519. Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā manasākaṭe paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṃ – caṅkī brāhmaṇo tārukkho brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti brāhmaṇo jāṇusoṇi brāhmaṇo todeyyo brāhmaṇo aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā brāhmaṇamahāsālā.
mula_english: And at that time, many well-known and wealthy Brahmins were living in Manasakata, namely the Brahmin Caṅkī, the Brahmin Tārukkha, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, the Brahmin Jāṇusoṇi, the Brahmin Todeyya, and other well-known and wealthy Brahmins.
commentary_pali: 519.Abhiññātā abhiññātāti kulacārittādisampattiyā tattha tattha paññātā. Caṅkītiādīni tesaṃ nāmāni. Tattha caṅkī opāsādavāsiko. Tārukkho icchānaṅgalavāsiko. Pokkharasātī ukkaṭṭhavāsiko. Jāṇusoṇī sāvatthivāsiko. Todeyyo tudigāmavāsiko. Aññe cāti aññe ca bahujanā. Attano attano nivāsaṭṭhānehi āgantvā mantasajjhāyakaraṇatthaṃ tattha paṭivasanti. Manasākaṭassa kira ramaṇīyatāya te brāhmaṇā tattha nadītīre gehāni kāretvā parikkhipāpetvā aññesaṃ bahūnaṃ pavesanaṃ nivāretvā antarantarā tattha gantvā vasanti.
commentary_english:
519. *Abhiññātā abhiññāta* means well-known, recognized in various places due to their accomplishments in lineage, conduct, etc.

Caṅkī and the others are their names.

Among them, Caṅkī resides in Opasāda.

Tārukkha resides in Ichānaṅgala.

Pokkharasātī resides in Ukkaṭṭha.

Jāṇusoṇī resides in Sāvatthi.

Todeyya resides in Tudigāma.

*Aññe ca* means and also other many people.

Having come from their own respective places of residence, they dwell there to recite mantras.

It seems that due to the beauty of Manasākaṭa, those Brahmins, having built and enclosed houses on the riverbank there, prevent the entry of many others, and occasionally go and live there.

mula_pali: 520. Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājānaṃ māṇavānaṃ jaṅghavihāraṃ anucaṅkamantānaṃ anuvicarantānaṃ maggāmagge kathā udapādi. Atha kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo evamāha – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya, yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena pokkharasātinā’’ti. Bhāradvājopi māṇavo evamāha – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano  niyyāniko, niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya, yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā’’ti. Neva kho asakkhi vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhāradvājaṃ māṇavaṃ saññāpetuṃ, na pana asakkhi bhāradvājo māṇavopi vāseṭṭhaṃ māṇavaṃ saññāpetuṃ.
mula_english:
520. Then, while the young Brahmins Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were strolling and wandering about, a discussion arose between them about the right and wrong paths.

Then the young Brahmin Vāseṭṭha said: "This is the only straight path (*ujumagga*), this is the direct path (*añjasāyana*), the path of salvation (*niyyānika*) that leads one who follows it to union with *brahman*, as is taught by the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti!"

And the young Brahmin Bhāradvāja said: "This is the only straight path (*ujumagga*), this is the direct path (*añjasāyana*), the path of salvation (*niyyānika*) that leads one who follows it to union with *brahman*, as is taught by the *brāhmaṇa* Tārukkha!"

And Vāseṭṭha could not convince Bhāradvāja, nor could Bhāradvāja convince Vāseṭṭha.
commentary_pali: 520-521.Vāseṭṭhabhāradvājānanti vāseṭṭhassa ca pokkharasātino antevāsikassa, bhāradvājassa ca tārukkhantevāsikassa. Ete kira dve jātisampannā tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū ahesuṃ. Jaṅghavihāranti aticiranisajjapaccayā kilamathavinodanatthāya jaṅghacāraṃ. Te kira divasaṃ sajjhāyaṃ katvā sāyanhe vuṭṭhāya nhānīyasambhāragandhamālateladhotavatthāni gāhāpetvā attano parijanaparivutā nhāyitukāmā  nadītīraṃ gantvā rajatapaṭṭavaṇṇe vālikāsaṇḍe aparāparaṃ caṅkamiṃsu. Ekaṃ caṅkamantaṃ itaro anucaṅkami, puna itaraṃ itaroti. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘anucaṅkamantānaṃ anuvicarantāna’’nti. Maggāmaggeti magge ca amagge ca. Katamaṃ nu kho paṭipadaṃ pūretvā katamena maggena sakkā sukhaṃ brahmalokaṃ gantunti evaṃ maggāmaggaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesunti attho. Añjasāyanoti ujumaggassetaṃ vevacanaṃ, añjasā  vā ujukameva etena āyanti āgacchantīti  añjasāyano niyyāniko niyyātīti niyyāyanto niyyāti, gacchanto gacchatīti attho. Takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyāti yo taṃ maggaṃ karoti paṭipajjati, tassa brahmunā saddhiṃ sahabhāvāya, ekaṭṭhāne pātubhāvāya gacchatīti attho. Yvāyanti yo ayaṃ. Akkhātoti kathito dīpito. Brāhmaṇena pokkharasātināti attano ācariyaṃ apadisati. Iti vāseṭṭho sakameva ācariyavādaṃ thometvā paggaṇhitvā vicarati. Bhāradvājopi sakamevāti. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘neva kho asakkhi vāseṭṭho’’tiādi. Tato vāseṭṭho ‘‘ubhinnampi amhākaṃ kathā aniyyānikāva, imasmiñca loke maggakusalo nāma bhotā gotamena sadiso natthi, bhavañca gotamo avidūre vasati, so no tulaṃ gahetvā nisinnavāṇijo viya kaṅkhaṃ chindissatī’’ti cintetvā tamatthaṃ bhāradvājassa ārocetvā ubhopi gantvā attano kathaṃ bhagavato ārocesuṃ. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘atha kho vāseṭṭho…pe… yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā’’ti.
commentary_english:
520-521.
Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja know Vāseṭṭha as the resident disciple of Pokkharasāti, and Bhāradvāja as the resident disciple of Tārukkha.

It is said that these two were accomplished in birth and had mastered the three Vedas.

*Jaṅghavihāra* means walking meditation, for the purpose of alleviating fatigue due to prolonged sitting.

It is said that in the evening, having finished their recitation during the day, they would rise, take bathing requisites, fragrances, garlands, oil, and washed clothes, and surrounded by their own attendants, desiring to bathe, they would go to the riverbank and stroll back and forth on the sandy shore the color of a silver plate.

When one was strolling, the other would follow; then the other would [stroll] and the one would follow.

Therefore it was said, "while those strolling back and forth, wandering about..."

*Maggāmaggeti* means on the path and off the path.

What practice, when completed, and by which path is it possible to easily go to the world of Brahmā? Thus, what is the meaning of initiating a discussion concerning the path and the non-path?

*Añjasāyano* is a synonym for the straight path; by this, people come and approach directly, therefore *añjasāyano* is a means of departure; one who departs, therefore one who is departing departs; one who goes, goes, is the meaning.

*Takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyāti*: whoever does and practices that path, for him, to be together with Brahmā, to go to the manifestation in one place, is the meaning.

*Yvāyanti yo ayaṃ*: That which is such.

*Akkhāto ti kathito dīpito*: *Akkhāto* means spoken and revealed.

*Brāhmaṇena pokkharasātināti*: [He] attributes his teacher to the *brāhmaṇa* Pokkharasāti.

Thus, Vāseṭṭha praises and upholds only his own teacher's doctrine and wanders about.

Bhāradvāja [does] likewise.

Therefore it was said, "Vāseṭṭha was not able..." etc.

Then Vāseṭṭha, thinking, "The talk of both of us is truly without issue, and in this world, there is no one named skilled in the path like the venerable Gotama, and the venerable Gotama dwells not far away; he, having taken a scale, like a merchant sitting [in his shop], will cut off our doubt," having announced that matter to Bhāradvāja, both of them went and announced their talk to the Blessed One.

Therefore it was said, "Then, indeed, Vāseṭṭha... yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā" etc.

mula_pali: 521. Atha  kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhāradvājaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘ayaṃ kho, bhāradvāja, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito manasākaṭe viharati uttarena manasākaṭassa aciravatiyā nadiyā tīre ambavane. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā  devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’’ti . Āyāma, bho bhāradvāja, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pucchissāma. Yathā no samaṇo gotamo byākarissati, tathā naṃ dhāressāmā’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho bhāradvājo māṇavo vāseṭṭhassa māṇavassa paccassosi.
mula_english:
Then Vāseṭṭha, the student, addressed Bhāradvāja, the student, saying: "This ascetic Gotama (Gautama), the son of the Śākya (Sākya) clan, who went forth from the Śākya (Sākya) family, is dwelling in Manasākaṭa (Manasakata), in the mango grove on the bank of the Aciravatī (Aciravati) River, north of Manasākaṭa (Manasakata).

Now, concerning the esteemed Gotama (Gautama), such a fine reputation has spread: "Indeed, that Blessed One is an Arhat (Arahant), a Fully Enlightened One (sammāsambuddha), endowed with knowledge and conduct (vijjācaraṇasampanno), a Well-Farer (sugata), Knower of the World (lokavidū), unsurpassed trainer of beings (anuttaro purisadammasārathi), teacher of gods and humans (satthā devamanussānaṃ), the Awakened One (buddha), the Blessed One (bhagavā)."

Come, Bhāradvāja (Bharadvaja), let us go to the ascetic Gotama (Gautama); having gone, let us ask the ascetic Gotama (Gautama) about this matter. As the ascetic Gotama (Gautama) explains to us, so shall we remember it."

"So it is, sir (evaṃ bho)," replied Bhāradvāja (Bharadvaja), the student, to Vāseṭṭha (Vasettha), the student.
commentary_pali: 520-521.Vāseṭṭhabhāradvājānanti vāseṭṭhassa ca pokkharasātino antevāsikassa, bhāradvājassa ca tārukkhantevāsikassa. Ete kira dve jātisampannā tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū ahesuṃ. Jaṅghavihāranti aticiranisajjapaccayā kilamathavinodanatthāya jaṅghacāraṃ. Te kira divasaṃ sajjhāyaṃ katvā sāyanhe vuṭṭhāya nhānīyasambhāragandhamālateladhotavatthāni gāhāpetvā attano parijanaparivutā nhāyitukāmā  nadītīraṃ gantvā rajatapaṭṭavaṇṇe vālikāsaṇḍe aparāparaṃ caṅkamiṃsu. Ekaṃ caṅkamantaṃ itaro anucaṅkami, puna itaraṃ itaroti. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘anucaṅkamantānaṃ anuvicarantāna’’nti. Maggāmaggeti magge ca amagge ca. Katamaṃ nu kho paṭipadaṃ pūretvā katamena maggena sakkā sukhaṃ brahmalokaṃ gantunti evaṃ maggāmaggaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesunti attho. Añjasāyanoti ujumaggassetaṃ vevacanaṃ, añjasā  vā ujukameva etena āyanti āgacchantīti  añjasāyano niyyāniko niyyātīti niyyāyanto niyyāti, gacchanto gacchatīti attho. Takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyāti yo taṃ maggaṃ karoti paṭipajjati, tassa brahmunā saddhiṃ sahabhāvāya, ekaṭṭhāne pātubhāvāya gacchatīti attho. Yvāyanti yo ayaṃ. Akkhātoti kathito dīpito. Brāhmaṇena pokkharasātināti attano ācariyaṃ apadisati. Iti vāseṭṭho sakameva ācariyavādaṃ thometvā paggaṇhitvā vicarati. Bhāradvājopi sakamevāti. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘neva kho asakkhi vāseṭṭho’’tiādi. Tato vāseṭṭho ‘‘ubhinnampi amhākaṃ kathā aniyyānikāva, imasmiñca loke maggakusalo nāma bhotā gotamena sadiso natthi, bhavañca gotamo avidūre vasati, so no tulaṃ gahetvā nisinnavāṇijo viya kaṅkhaṃ chindissatī’’ti cintetvā tamatthaṃ bhāradvājassa ārocetvā ubhopi gantvā attano kathaṃ bhagavato ārocesuṃ. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘atha kho vāseṭṭho…pe… yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā’’ti.
commentary_english:
520-521.

Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja knew of Vāseṭṭha's resident disciple Pokkharasāti, and of Bhāradvāja's resident disciple Tārukkha.

It is said that these two were accomplished in birth and had mastered the three Vedas.

*Jaṅghavihāra* means *jaṅghacāraṃ*, walking back and forth to dispel weariness due to sitting for a very long time.

It is said that during the day, having made a recitation (*sajjhāyaṃ katvā*), in the evening, having risen up, having had bathing preparations, perfumes, garlands, oil, and washed cloths taken, surrounded by their own attendants, wanting to bathe, having gone to the bank of the river, on a sandbank the color of a silver plate, they walked back and forth, one after another.

When one is walking back and forth, the other walks along, then the other [walks along with] the other.

Therefore, it was said, "Of those walking back and forth, of those walking through."

*Maggāmaggeti* means on the path and on the non-path.

What practice should be fulfilled, by which path is it possible to happily go to the Brahmā world? Thus, what is the meaning of initiating a discussion concerning the path and the non-path (*maggāmaggaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesunti attho*)?

*Añjasāyanoti* is a synonym for the straight path (*ujumaggassetaṃ vevacanaṃ*); by this they come and go straight, therefore, *añjasāyano* is a means of egress (*niyyāniko*); he goes out (*niyyātīti*), one going out, goes out (*niyyāyanto niyyāti*), one going, goes (*gacchanto gacchati*), this is the meaning (*attho*).

*Takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyāti* means he who does and undertakes that path (*yo taṃ maggaṃ karoti paṭipajjati*), for him there is companionship with Brahmā (*tassa brahmunā saddhiṃ sahabhāvāya*), he goes to manifestation in one place (*ekaṭṭhāne pātubhāvāya gacchati*), this is the meaning (*attho*).

*Yvāyanti yo ayaṃ*—whoever goes.

*Akkhātoti* means told, illuminated (*kathito dīpito*).

*Brāhmaṇena pokkharasātināti* means he indicates his teacher (*attano ācariyaṃ apadisati*) as the Brāhmin Pokkharasāti.

Thus, Vāseṭṭha, praising and approving only his own teacher's doctrine (*sakameva ācariyavādaṃ thometvā paggaṇhitvā*), wanders about (*vicarati*).

Bhāradvāja [does] likewise (*bhāradvājopi sakamevāti*).

Therefore, it was said, "Indeed, Vāseṭṭha did not manage," etc. (*‘‘neva kho asakkhi vāseṭṭho’’tiādi*).

Then Vāseṭṭha [thought], "Indeed, the talk of both of us is not a means of egress (*aniyyānikāva*); and in this world, there is no one skilled in the path (*maggakusalo*) like the honored Gotama (*bhotā gotamena sadiso natthi*), and the honored Gotama lives not far away (*avidūre vasati*), he, like a merchant who has taken a scale, sitting, will cut off our doubt (*kaṅkhaṃ chindissati*)"; having thought this, having announced that matter to Bhāradvāja, both having gone, they announced their talk to the Blessed One (*bhagavato ārocesuṃ*).

Therefore it was said, "Then indeed, Vāseṭṭha…pe…he is declared by the Brahmin Tārukkha (*‘‘atha kho vāseṭṭho…pe… yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā’’ti*)."

mula_pali: 522. Atha kho vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā māṇavā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘idha, bho gotama, amhākaṃ jaṅghavihāraṃ anucaṅkamantānaṃ anuvicarantānaṃ maggāmagge kathā udapādi. Ahaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya, yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena pokkharasātinā’ti. Bhāradvājo māṇavo evamāha – ‘ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya, yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā’ti. Ettha, bho gotama, attheva viggaho, atthi vivādo, atthi nānāvādo’’ti.
mula_english:
Then the two brahmin students, Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja, went to see the Lord.

After exchanging polite and courteous greetings, they sat down to one side.

Seated to one side, Vāseṭṭha said to the Blessed One: “Here, Master Gotama, as we were strolling and wandering about, a discussion arose between us about the path and the non-path.

I say: ‘This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with Brahmā, as is taught by the Brahmin Pokkharasāti!’

And Bhāradvāja says: ‘This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with Brahmā, as is taught by the Brahmin Tārukkha!’

Here, Master Gotama, there is indeed disagreement, there is dispute, there is divergence of views."
commentary_pali: 522.Ettha bho gotamāti etasmiṃ maggāmagge. Viggaho vivādotiādīsu pubbuppattiko viggaho. Aparabhāge vivādo. Duvidhopi eso nānāācariyānaṃ vādato nānāvādo.
commentary_english:
522.
Here, sir Gotama, in this path of the path.
Dispute is a quarrel, and in the beginning, a dispute.
In the other part, a dispute.
Although twofold, this is a diverse doctrine from the speech of various teachers.

mula_pali: 523. ‘‘Iti  kira , vāseṭṭha, tvaṃ evaṃ vadesi – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya, yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena pokkharasātinā’’ti. Bhāradvājo māṇavo evamāha – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya, yvāyaṃ akkhāto brāhmaṇena tārukkhenā’’ti. Atha kismiṃ pana vo, vāseṭṭha, viggaho, kismiṃ vivādo, kismiṃ nānāvādo’’ti?
mula_english:
‘So, Vāseṭṭha, you say: "This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with Brahmā (brahmasahabyatāya), as is taught by the Brahmin Pokkharasāti."’

Bharadvāja the youth says: "This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with Brahmā (brahmasahabyatāya), as is taught by the Brahmin Tārukkha."’

Then what is the dispute, Vāseṭṭha, what is the quarrel, what is the difference all about?
commentary_pali: 523.Atha kismiṃ pana voti tvampi ayameva maggoti attano ācariyavādameva paggayha tiṭṭhasi, bhāradvājopi attano ācariyavādameva, ekassāpi ekasmiṃ saṃsayo natthi. Evaṃ sati kismiṃ vo viggahoti pucchati.
commentary_english:
Furthermore, upon what then do you also, thinking "This alone is the path," firmly rely on your own teacher's doctrine, and Bhāradvāja also on his own teacher's doctrine, when not even one of you has doubt about a single thing?
If this is so, upon what do you have a disagreement? Thus he asks.

mula_pali: 524. ‘‘Maggāmagge, bho gotama. Kiñcāpi, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā nānāmagge paññapenti, addhariyā brāhmaṇā tittiriyā brāhmaṇā chandokā brāhmaṇā bavhārijjhā brāhmaṇā, atha kho sabbāni tāni niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāya. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , bho gotama, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre bahūni cepi nānāmaggāni bhavanti, atha kho sabbāni tāni gāmasamosaraṇāni bhavanti; evameva kho, bho gotama, kiñcāpi brāhmaṇā nānāmagge paññapenti, addhariyā brāhmaṇā tittiriyā brāhmaṇā  chandokā brāhmaṇā bavhārijjhā brāhmaṇā, atha kho sabbāni tāni niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’’ti.
mula_english:
524. “Right and wrong paths, venerable Gotama.

Even though, venerable Gotama, the *brāhmaṇas* teach different paths, the *Adhvaryu brāhmaṇas*, the *Tittiriya brāhmaṇas*, the *Chandoka brāhmaṇas*, the *Bavhārijjha brāhmaṇas*, do all of these, in truth, lead to union with Brahma (*brahmasahabyatā*)?

“Just as, venerable Gotama, near a village or town there may be many different paths, yet all of them converge on the village; in the same way, venerable Gotama, even though the *brāhmaṇas* teach different paths, the *Adhvaryu brāhmaṇas*, the *Tittiriya brāhmaṇas*, the *Chandoka brāhmaṇas*, the *Bavhārijjha brāhmaṇas*, do all of these, in truth, lead to union with Brahma (*brahmasahabyatā*)?”
commentary_pali: 524.Maggāmagge, bho gotamāti magge bho gotama amagge ca, ujumagge ca anujumagge cāti attho. Esa kira ekabrāhmaṇassāpi maggaṃ ‘‘na maggo’’ti na vadati. Yathā pana attano ācariyassa maggo ujumaggo, na  evaṃ aññesaṃ anujānāti, tasmā tamevatthaṃ dīpento ‘‘kiñcāpi bho gotamā’’tiādimāha. Sabbāni tānīti liṅgavipallāsena vadati, sabbe teti vuttaṃ hoti. Bahūnīti aṭṭha vā dasa  vā. Nānāmaggānīti mahantāmahantajaṅghamaggasakaṭamaggādivasena nānāvidhāni sāmantā gāmanadītaḷākakhettādīhi āgantvā gāmaṃ pavisanamaggāni.
commentary_english:
524.
"The path and the non-path, sir Gotama" means the path, sir Gotama, and the non-path, and the straight path, and the non-straight path—this is the meaning.
Indeed, he does not say that even a single Brahmin's path is "not a path."
Just as one does not approve of the straight path of one's own teacher for others in this way, therefore, revealing that very meaning, he said, "Even though, sir Gotama," and so on.
"All those" he says by gender displacement; "all those" is what is said.
"Many" means eight or ten.
"Various paths" means various kinds of paths, such as great and small footpaths, cart paths, etc., paths for entering the village, coming from all sides by villages, rivers, ponds, fields, etc.

mula_pali: 525. ‘‘Niyyantīti vāseṭṭha vadesi’’? ‘‘Niyyantīti, bho gotama, vadāmi’’. ‘‘Niyyantīti, vāseṭṭha, vadesi’’? ‘‘Niyyantīti, bho gotama, vadāmi’’. ‘‘Niyyantīti, vāseṭṭha, vadesi’’? ‘‘Niyyantī’’ti, bho gotama, vadāmi’’. ‘‘Kiṃ  pana, vāseṭṭha, atthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ekabrāhmaṇopi, yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’ . ‘‘Kiṃ pana, vāseṭṭha, atthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ekācariyopi, yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Kiṃ pana, vāseṭṭha, atthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ekācariyapācariyopi, yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Kiṃ pana, vāseṭṭha, atthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ yāva sattamā ācariyāmahayugā sattamācariyamahayugā (syā.) yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
525.
"Do you say 'they lead on', Vāseṭṭha?" "I say 'they lead on', sir Gotama."
"Do you say 'they lead on', Vāseṭṭha?" "I say 'they lead on', sir Gotama."
"Do you say 'they lead on', Vāseṭṭha?" "I say 'they lead on', sir Gotama."
"But what do you think, Vāseṭṭha, is there even one single *brāhmaṇa* among the *brāhmaṇas* learned in the three Vedas who has seen Brahmā face to face?" "No, indeed, sir Gotama."
"But what do you think, Vāseṭṭha, is there even one teacher among the *brāhmaṇas* learned in the three Vedas who has seen Brahmā face to face?" "No, indeed, sir Gotama."
"But what do you think, Vāseṭṭha, is there even one teacher of teachers among the *brāhmaṇas* learned in the three Vedas who has seen Brahmā face to face?" "No, indeed, sir Gotama."
"But what do you think, Vāseṭṭha, has the ancestor seven generations back of the teacher of one of them seen Brahmā face to face?" "No, indeed, sir Gotama."
commentary_pali: 525-526.‘‘Niyyantīti vāseṭṭha vadesī’’ti bhagavā tikkhattuṃ vacībhedaṃ katvā paṭiññaṃ kārāpesi. Kasmā? Titthiyā hi paṭijānitvā pacchā niggayhamānā avajānanti. So tathā kātuṃ na sakkhissatīti.
commentary_english:
"The Blessed One three times made a change of word and made him promise, saying, 'They lead out, Vāseṭṭha, you will declare.'"
Why? Because the sectarians, after promising, despise being refuted later on.
He will not be able to do that.

mula_pali: 526. ‘‘Kiṃ pana, vāseṭṭha, yepi tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ etarahi tevijjā brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ samīhitaṃ (syā.), tadanugāyanti, tadanubhāsanti, bhāsitamanubhāsanti, vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu. Tepi evamāhaṃsu – ‘mayametaṃ jānāma, mayametaṃ passāma, yattha vā brahmā, yena vā brahmā, yahiṃ vā brahmā’’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
‘Well then, Vāseṭṭha, what about those early sages (ṛṣi) of the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjā), the makers of the mantras (mantrakartāraḥ), the expounders of the mantras (mantrapravartāraḥ), whose ancient verses (porāṇaṃ mantrapadaṃ) are chanted, pronounced and collected by the Brahmins (brāhmaṇā) of today, and sung and spoken about — such as Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, Bhagu?

Did they ever declare: ‘We know this, we see this: when, how and where is Brahmā?’
‘‘No indeed, Gotama."
commentary_pali: 525-526.‘‘Niyyantīti vāseṭṭha vadesī’’ti bhagavā tikkhattuṃ vacībhedaṃ katvā paṭiññaṃ kārāpesi. Kasmā? Titthiyā hi paṭijānitvā pacchā niggayhamānā avajānanti. So tathā kātuṃ na sakkhissatīti.
commentary_english:
"‘‘They lead forth, Vāseṭṭha, you will declare,’’ thus, the Blessed One, having made a verbal distinction three times, caused a pledge to be made.
Why? Because the sectarians, having acknowledged, afterwards, when being refuted, they despise (it).
He will not be able to do that."

mula_pali: 527. ‘‘Iti  kira, vāseṭṭha, natthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ekabrāhmaṇopi, yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Natthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ekācariyopi, yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho . Natthi koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ekācariyapācariyopi, yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Natthi  koci tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ yāva sattamā ācariyāmahayugā yena brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Yepi  kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ etarahi tevijjā brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ, tadanugāyanti, tadanubhāsanti, bhāsitamanubhāsanti, vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamāhaṃsu – ‘mayametaṃ jānāma, mayametaṃ passāma, yattha vā brahmā, yena vā brahmā, yahiṃ vā brahmā’ti. Teva tevijjā brāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘yaṃ na jānāma, yaṃ na passāma, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ desema. Ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko, niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’’’ti.
mula_english:
527. Thus, Vāseṭṭha, not even one of these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas has seen Brahmā face to face.

Nor has one of their teachers seen Brahmā face to face.

Nor has the teacher's teacher of any one of them seen Brahmā face to face.

Nor even the ancestor seven generations back of one of their teachers has seen Brahmā face to face.

And those ancient seers of the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, the composers of the *mantras*, the founders of the *mantras*, whose ancient *mantra* verses are now chanted, uttered, and compiled by the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, they follow after, they repeat, they repeat what was spoken, they recite what was recited, such as Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu—even they did not say, "We know this, we see this, where Brahmā is, how Brahmā is, or where Brahmā is."

So what these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas say is: "We teach this path to union with Brahmā that we do not know or see."

"This is the only straight path, this is the direct path, the path of salvation that leads one who follows it to union with Brahmā."
commentary_pali: 527-529.Teva tevijjāti te tevijjā. Vakāro āgamasandhimattaṃ. Andhaveṇīti andhapaveṇī, ekena cakkhumatā gahitayaṭṭhiyā koṭiṃ eko andho gaṇhati, taṃ andhaṃ añño taṃ aññoti evaṃ paṇṇāsasaṭṭhi andhā paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā andhaveṇīti vuccati. Paramparasaṃsattāti aññamaññaṃ laggā, yaṭṭhigāhakenapi cakkhumatā virahitāti attho. Eko kira dhutto andhagaṇaṃ disvā ‘‘asukasmiṃ nāma gāme khajjabhojjaṃ sulabha’’nti ussāhetvā ‘‘tena hi tattha no sāmi nehi, idaṃ nāma te demā’’ti vutte, lañjaṃ gahetvā antarāmagge maggā okkamma mahantaṃ gacchaṃ anuparigantvā purimassa hatthena pacchimassa kacchaṃ gaṇhāpetvā ‘‘kiñci kammaṃ atthi, gacchatha tāva tumhe’’ti vatvā palāyi, te divasampi gantvā maggaṃ avindamānā ‘‘kuhiṃ no cakkhumā, kuhiṃ maggo’’ti paridevitvā maggaṃ avindamānā tattheva mariṃsu. Te sandhāya vuttaṃ ‘‘paramparasaṃsattā’’ti. Purimopīti purimesu dasasu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Majjhimopīti  majjhimesu ācariyapācariyesu ekopi. Pacchimopīti idāni tevijjesu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Hassakaññevāti hasitabbameva. Nāmakaññevāti lāmakaṃyeva. Tadetaṃ atthābhāvena rittakaṃ, rittakattāyeva tucchakaṃ. Idāni brahmaloko tāva tiṭṭhatu, yo tevijjehi na diṭṭhapubbova. Yepi candimasūriye tevijjā passanti, tesampi sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ nappahontīti dassanatthaṃ ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasī’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
527-529.
"Just as the *tevijja*, so are they *tevijja*."
The letter *va* is merely a euphonic addition (*āgamasandhimattaṃ*).
"*Andhaveṇī* is *andhapaveṇī*: One blind man holds the end (*koṭiṃ*) of a stick held by a seeing man. That blind man is followed by another, and so on. Thus, fifty or sixty blind men, connected in succession (*paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā*), are called an *andhaveṇī*."
"*Paramparasaṃsattā* means mutually connected (*aññamaññaṃ laggā*), lacking even a seeing man holding the stick. This is the meaning."
"It is said that a rogue, seeing a crowd of blind men, induced them by saying, “In such and such a village, food and provisions are easily available.” When they said, “Then lead us there, master, and we will give you this,” he took the bribe and, deviating from the path in the middle of the road (*antarāmagge maggā okkamma*), went around a large thicket (*mahantaṃ gacchaṃ anuparigantvā*), made the first man grasp the skirt (*kacchaṃ gaṇhāpetvā*) of the last man with his hand (*purimassa hatthena pacchimassa*), and saying, “There is some work to be done, you go ahead,” ran away. Even after going that day, not finding the way (*maggaṃ avindamānā*), lamenting, “Where is our seeing man, where is the way?” not finding the way, they died there."
"With reference to them, it was said, "*paramparasaṃsattā*."
"*Purimopi* means even one of the first ten *brāhmaṇa*s."
"*Majjhimopi* means even one of the intermediate teachers and sub-teachers."
"*Pacchimopi* means even one of the later *tevijja brāhmaṇa*s."
"*Hassakaññeva* means just laughable."
"*Nāmakaññeva* means just contemptible."
"Therefore, this is empty due to the absence of meaning (*atthābhāvena rittakaṃ*); just because of being empty, it is void (*tucchakaṃ*)."
"Now, let the *brahmaloka*, which has never been seen by the *tevijja*s, remain as it is."
"Even those *tevijja*s who see the sun and moon are not able to teach the path for companionship. Therefore, to show this, he said, “What do you think?” etc."

mula_pali: 528. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, nanu evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bho gotama, evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, te vata teva (ka.), vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā yaṃ na jānanti, yaṃ na passanti, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ desessanti. ‘Ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko, niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
528.
“What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Such being the case, does not what these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas declare turn out to be ill-founded?”
“Indeed, sir Gotama, such being the case, what these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas declare does turn out to be ill-founded.”
“That is right, Vāseṭṭha. Well, Vāseṭṭha, these *brāhmaṇas* learned in the three Vedas teach a path to union (*sahabyatā*) with *brahman* that they do not know and do not see.
‘This is the only straight path (*ujumaggo*)…,’ this cannot possibly be right.
commentary_pali: 527-529.Teva tevijjāti te tevijjā. Vakāro āgamasandhimattaṃ. Andhaveṇīti andhapaveṇī, ekena cakkhumatā gahitayaṭṭhiyā koṭiṃ eko andho gaṇhati, taṃ andhaṃ añño taṃ aññoti evaṃ paṇṇāsasaṭṭhi andhā paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā andhaveṇīti vuccati. Paramparasaṃsattāti aññamaññaṃ laggā, yaṭṭhigāhakenapi cakkhumatā virahitāti attho. Eko kira dhutto andhagaṇaṃ disvā ‘‘asukasmiṃ nāma gāme khajjabhojjaṃ sulabha’’nti ussāhetvā ‘‘tena hi tattha no sāmi nehi, idaṃ nāma te demā’’ti vutte, lañjaṃ gahetvā antarāmagge maggā okkamma mahantaṃ gacchaṃ anuparigantvā purimassa hatthena pacchimassa kacchaṃ gaṇhāpetvā ‘‘kiñci kammaṃ atthi, gacchatha tāva tumhe’’ti vatvā palāyi, te divasampi gantvā maggaṃ avindamānā ‘‘kuhiṃ no cakkhumā, kuhiṃ maggo’’ti paridevitvā maggaṃ avindamānā tattheva mariṃsu. Te sandhāya vuttaṃ ‘‘paramparasaṃsattā’’ti. Purimopīti purimesu dasasu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Majjhimopīti  majjhimesu ācariyapācariyesu ekopi. Pacchimopīti idāni tevijjesu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Hassakaññevāti hasitabbameva. Nāmakaññevāti lāmakaṃyeva. Tadetaṃ atthābhāvena rittakaṃ, rittakattāyeva tucchakaṃ. Idāni brahmaloko tāva tiṭṭhatu, yo tevijjehi na diṭṭhapubbova. Yepi candimasūriye tevijjā passanti, tesampi sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ nappahontīti dassanatthaṃ ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasī’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
527-529. Thus are the *tevijja*, thus are they *tevijja*.

The letter "va" is merely an augment in euphonic combination (*āgamasandhimattaṃ*).

"Andhaveṇī": "blind braid". One blind man grasps the end of a stick held by one who has eyes (*cakkhumatā*), another [blind man] [grasps] him, another [grasps] him, and thus fifty or sixty blind men, connected in a line, are called an "andhaveṇī".

"Connected in succession" (*paramparasaṃsattā*): clinging to one another, even the one holding the stick is without sight (*cakkhumatā virahitāti*); that is the meaning.

It is said that once a rogue, seeing a crowd of blind men, induced them, saying, "In such-and-such a village, food and delicacies are easily obtained." When they said, "Then, sir, lead us there; we will give you this," he took the bribe and, deviating from the path in the middle of the road, went around a large thicket, and making the first one grasp the hem of the last one's garment, said, "There is some work to be done; you go first," and fled. They, even going that day, not finding the path, lamented, "Where is our sighted one? Where is the path?" and not finding the path, they died right there.

With reference to that, it was said, "Connected in succession" (*paramparasaṃsattā*).

"The former": even one among the former ten *brāhmaṇa*s.

"The middle": even one among the middle teachers and instructors (*ācariyapācariyesu*).

"The latter": now, even one among the *tevijja* *brāhmaṇa*s.

"Just laughable": it is just something to be laughed at.

"Just contemptible": it is just contemptible.

Therefore, this is empty due to the absence of meaning (*atthābhāvena rittakaṃ*), and just because of its emptiness, it is vain (*tucchakaṃ*).

Now, let the world of Brahmā (*brahmaloko*) remain as it is, which has never been seen by the *tevijja*.

Even those *tevijja* who see the moon and the sun are not able to point out the path for companionship (*sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ nappahontīti*); to show that, he said, beginning with "What do you think?" (*taṃ kiṃ maññasī*).

mula_pali: 529. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, vāseṭṭha, andhaveṇi  paramparasaṃsattā purimopi na passati, majjhimopi na passati, pacchimopi na passati. Evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, andhaveṇūpamaṃ maññe tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ bhāsitaṃ, purimopi na passati, majjhimopi na passati, pacchimopi na passati. Tesamidaṃ tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ bhāsitaṃ  hassakaññeva sampajjati, nāmakaññeva sampajjati, rittakaññeva sampajjati, tucchakaññeva sampajjati.
mula_english:
Just as, Vāseṭṭha, a file of blind men are connected one after the other, the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, the last one does not see.

In the same way, Vāseṭṭha, I consider the speech of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas to be like a file of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, the last one does not see.

The talk of these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas turns out to be laughable, mere words, empty and vain.
commentary_pali: 527-529.Teva tevijjāti te tevijjā. Vakāro āgamasandhimattaṃ. Andhaveṇīti andhapaveṇī, ekena cakkhumatā gahitayaṭṭhiyā koṭiṃ eko andho gaṇhati, taṃ andhaṃ añño taṃ aññoti evaṃ paṇṇāsasaṭṭhi andhā paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā andhaveṇīti vuccati. Paramparasaṃsattāti aññamaññaṃ laggā, yaṭṭhigāhakenapi cakkhumatā virahitāti attho. Eko kira dhutto andhagaṇaṃ disvā ‘‘asukasmiṃ nāma gāme khajjabhojjaṃ sulabha’’nti ussāhetvā ‘‘tena hi tattha no sāmi nehi, idaṃ nāma te demā’’ti vutte, lañjaṃ gahetvā antarāmagge maggā okkamma mahantaṃ gacchaṃ anuparigantvā purimassa hatthena pacchimassa kacchaṃ gaṇhāpetvā ‘‘kiñci kammaṃ atthi, gacchatha tāva tumhe’’ti vatvā palāyi, te divasampi gantvā maggaṃ avindamānā ‘‘kuhiṃ no cakkhumā, kuhiṃ maggo’’ti paridevitvā maggaṃ avindamānā tattheva mariṃsu. Te sandhāya vuttaṃ ‘‘paramparasaṃsattā’’ti. Purimopīti purimesu dasasu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Majjhimopīti  majjhimesu ācariyapācariyesu ekopi. Pacchimopīti idāni tevijjesu brāhmaṇesu ekopi. Hassakaññevāti hasitabbameva. Nāmakaññevāti lāmakaṃyeva. Tadetaṃ atthābhāvena rittakaṃ, rittakattāyeva tucchakaṃ. Idāni brahmaloko tāva tiṭṭhatu, yo tevijjehi na diṭṭhapubbova. Yepi candimasūriye tevijjā passanti, tesampi sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ nappahontīti dassanatthaṃ ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasī’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
527-529.
"They are indeed the *tevijja*, they are the *tevijja*."
The letter "va" is merely a euphonic addition (*āgamasandhimattaṃ*).
*Andhaveṇīti*: an "andha paveṇī," one blind man grasps the end (*koṭiṃ*) of a stick held by a sighted person (*ekena cakkhumatā gahitayaṭṭhiyā*), another blind man [grasps] that blind man, and another [grasps] him— thus, fifty or sixty blind men, arranged in order (*paṭipāṭiyā ghaṭitā*), are called an *andhaveṇī*.
*Paramparasaṃsattāti*: they are clinging to one another (*aññamaññaṃ laggā*); the meaning (*attho*) is that even the one holding the stick (*yaṭṭhigāhakenapi*) is without sight (*cakkhumatā virahitāti*).
It is said that once a rogue, seeing a crowd of blind men (*andhagaṇaṃ disvā*), incited them, saying, "In such-and-such a village (*asukasmiṃ nāma gāme*), food and provisions (*khajjabhojjaṃ*) are easily obtained (*sulabhaṃ*)." Having encouraged them, when they said, "Well then (*tena hi*), lead us there, master (*tattha no sāmi nehi*), we will give you this (*idaṃ nāma te demā*)," he took a bribe (*lañjaṃ gahetvā*) and, leading them off the path (*antarāmagge maggā okkamma*) and around a large thicket (*mahantaṃ gacchaṃ anuparigantvā*), made the first man grasp the back of the last man (*purimassa hatthena pacchimassa kacchaṃ gaṇhāpetvā*) and, saying, "There is some work to be done (*kiñci kammaṃ atthi*), go on ahead (*gacchatha tāva tumhe*)," he fled (*palāyi*). They, even going the whole day (*te divasampi gantvā*), not finding the path (*maggaṃ avindamānā*) and lamenting, "Where is our sighted one (*kuhiṃ no cakkhumā*)? Where is the path (*kuhiṃ maggo*)?" and not finding the path (*maggaṃ avindamānā*), died right there (*tattheva mariṃsu*).
With that in mind (*te sandhāya*), it was said, "*paramparasaṃsattā*."
*Purimopīti*: even one of the first ten *brāhmaṇa*s (*purimesu dasasu brāhmaṇesu ekopi*).
*Majjhimopīti*: even one of the middle teachers and sub-teachers (*majjhimesu ācariyapācariyesu ekopi*).
*Pacchimopīti*: even one of the present-day *tevijja brāhmaṇa*s (*idāni tevijjesu brāhmaṇesu ekopi*).
*Hassakaññevāti*: it is just laughable (*hasitabbameva*).
*Nāmakaññevāti*: it is simply wretched (*lāmakaṃyeva*).
Therefore (*tadetaṃ*), being without meaning (*atthābhāvena*), it is empty (*rittakaṃ*); precisely because of its emptiness (*rittakattāyeva*), it is hollow (*tucchakaṃ*).
Now (*idāni*), let the Brahma-world (*brahmaloko*) remain as it is (*tāva tiṭṭhatu*), [a world] that has never been seen by the *tevijja*s (*yo tevijjehi na diṭṭhapubbova*).
Even those *tevijja*s who see the moon and the sun (*yepi candimasūriye tevijjā passanti*), they are not capable of teaching the path to companionship (*tesampi sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ nappahontīti*). To show this (*dassanatthaṃ*), he began by saying, "What do you think (*taṃ kiṃ maññasī*)?"

mula_pali: 530. ‘‘Taṃ  kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, passanti tevijjā brāhmaṇā candimasūriye, aññe cāpi bahujanā, yato ca candimasūriyā uggacchanti, yattha ca ogacchanti, āyācanti thomayanti pañjalikā namassamānā anuparivattantī’’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama, passanti tevijjā brāhmaṇā candimasūriye, aññe cāpi bahujanā, yato  ca candimasūriyā uggacchanti, yattha ca ogacchanti, āyācanti thomayanti pañjalikā namassamānā anuparivattantī’’ti.
mula_english: ‘What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Do these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas see the sun (candi-masūriye) and moon just as other people do, and when the sun (candi-masūriyā) and moon rise and set do they pray, sing praises, and worship with clasped hands?’ ‘They do, Reverend Gotama.’
commentary_pali: 530. Tattha yato candimasūriyā uggacchantīti yasmiṃ kāle uggacchanti. Yattha ca oggacchantīti yasmiṃ kāle atthamenti, uggamanakāle ca atthaṅgamanakāle ca passantīti attho. Āyācantīti ‘‘udehi bhavaṃ canda, udehi bhavaṃ sūriyā’’ti evaṃ āyācanti. Thomayantīti ‘‘sommo cando, parimaṇḍalo cando, sappabho cando’’tiādīni vadantā pasaṃsanti. Pañjalikāti paggahitaañjalikā. Namassamānāti ‘‘namo namo’’ti vadamānā.
commentary_english:
530.
"There, from where the moon and sun rise" means at what time they rise.
"And there they set" means at what time they set; the meaning is that they observe the time of rising and the time of setting.
"They entreat" means they entreat thus: "Rise, O revered Moon, rise, O revered Sun!".
"They praise" means they praise, speaking thus: "Gentle Moon, perfectly round Moon, radiant Moon," and so forth.
"With hands folded" means with hands raised in añjali.
"Paying homage" means speaking thus: "Homage, homage!".

mula_pali: 531. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, yaṃ passanti tevijjā brāhmaṇā candimasūriye, aññe cāpi bahujanā, yato ca candimasūriyā uggacchanti, yattha ca ogacchanti, āyācanti thomayanti pañjalikā namassamānā anuparivattanti, pahonti tevijjā brāhmaṇā candimasūriyānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko, niyyāti takkarassa candimasūriyānaṃ sahabyatāyā’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Iti kira, vāseṭṭha, yaṃ passanti tevijjā brāhmaṇā candimasūriye, aññe cāpi bahujanā, yato ca candimasūriyā uggacchanti, yattha  ca ogacchanti, āyācanti thomayanti pañjalikā namassamānā anuparivattanti, tesampi nappahonti candimasūriyānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko, niyyāti takkarassa candimasūriyānaṃ sahabyatāyā’’ti.
mula_english:
531. “What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Can those Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas ( *tevijjā brāhmaṇā* ), who see the moon and the sun ( *candimasūriye* ) just as other people do, and who entreat, praise, reverently salute with joined hands, and walk around the sun and moon ( *candimasūriyā* ) from where they rise and where they set, can those Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas point out a path to union ( *sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ* ) with the sun and moon, saying, “This is the only straight path ( *ujumaggo* ), this is the direct way, which leads to union with the sun and moon ( *candimasūriyānaṃ sahabyatāyā* ) for whoever practices it?”

“No, indeed, Venerable Gotama.”

“So, Vāseṭṭha, those Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, who see the sun and moon ( *candimasūriye* ) just as other people do, and who entreat, praise, reverently salute with joined hands, and walk around the sun and moon ( *candimasūriyā* ) from where they rise and where they set, even they cannot point out a path to union ( *sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetuṃ* ) with the sun and moon, saying, “This is the only straight path ( *ujumaggo* ), this is the direct way, which leads to union with the sun and moon ( *candimasūriyānaṃ sahabyatāyā* ) for whoever practices it.”
commentary_pali: 531-532.Yaṃ passantīti ettha yanti nipātamattaṃ. Kiṃ pana na kirāti ettha idha pana  kiṃ vattabbaṃ. Yattha kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi na brahmā sakkhidiṭṭhoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
commentary_english:
531-532.
"yaṃ passantīti" here, "yanti" is merely a particle.
But what is not done here? What should be said here?
"yattha kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi na brahmā sakkhidiṭṭhoti", such is the meaning to be seen.

mula_pali: 532. ‘‘Iti pana kiṃ pana (sī. syā. pī.) na kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ācariyehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ  ācariyapācariyehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ yāva sattamā sattamehi (?) ācariyāmahayugehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Yepi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ etarahi tevijjā brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ, tadanugāyanti, tadanubhāsanti, bhāsitamanubhāsanti, vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo  vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘mayametaṃ jānāma, mayametaṃ passāma, yattha vā brahmā, yena vā brahmā, yahiṃ vā brahmā’’ti. Teva tevijjā brāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘yaṃ na jānāma, yaṃ na passāma, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ desema – ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’’ti.
mula_english:
532.

“But what is that? And too, none of the *tevijja* Brahmins have seen Brahmā face to face. Nor have the teachers of the *tevijja* Brahmins seen Brahmā face to face. Nor have the teachers of teachers of the *tevijja* Brahmins seen Brahmā face to face. Nor have the ancestors seven generations back of the *tevijja* Brahmins seen Brahmā face to face. And those former *ṛṣis* of the *tevijja* Brahmins, the creators of the *mantras*, the promulgators of the *mantras*, whose ancient *mantra* verses are now chanted, recited, and compiled by the *tevijja* Brahmins, they sing along with them, they speak along with them, they repeat what was spoken, they recite what was recited, such as Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, Bhagu, even they did not say thus: “We know this, we see this, where Brahmā is, how Brahmā is, where Brahmā is.”

Indeed the *tevijja* Brahmins said thus: “We teach the path to companionship with that which we do not know, that which we do not see – this is the straight path, this is the direct way, the means of escape that leads the one who acts, to companionship with Brahmā.”
commentary_pali: 531-532.Yaṃ passantīti ettha yanti nipātamattaṃ. Kiṃ pana na kirāti ettha idha pana  kiṃ vattabbaṃ. Yattha kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi na brahmā sakkhidiṭṭhoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
commentary_english:
531-532.

*yaṃ passantīti ettha yanti nipātamattaṃ:* "Yaṃ passantīti," here, *yanti* is merely a particle.

*kiṃ pana na kirāti ettha idha pana kiṃ vattabbaṃ:* But what is not done here? What should be said about this?

*yattha kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi na brahmā sakkhidiṭṭhoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo:* It should be understood that, indeed, Brahmā is not directly seen by the *tevijja* (threefold knowledge) *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins).

mula_pali: 533. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, nanu evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ  bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bho gotama , evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, te vata, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā yaṃ na jānanti, yaṃ na passanti, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ desessanti – ‘‘ayameva ujumaggo, ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko, niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
533.
“What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Such being the case, does not what these Brahmins learned in the three Vedas declare turn out to be ill-founded?”
“Indeed, sir Gotama, that being so, what these Brahmins learned in the three Vedas declare does turn out to be ill-founded.”

“That is right, Vāseṭṭha. When these Brahmins learned in the three Vedas teach a path that they do not know and see, they will show the path to fellowship with Brahmā—‘This alone is the straight path, this the direct way, the means of escape, leading him who acts according to it to fellowship with Brahmā’—this cannot possibly be the case.

mula_pali: 534. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, vāseṭṭha, puriso evaṃ vadeyya – ‘‘ahaṃ yā imasmiṃ janapade janapadakalyāṇī, taṃ icchāmi, taṃ kāmemī’’ti. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ icchasi kāmesi, jānāsi taṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ – khattiyī vā brāhmaṇī vā vessī vā suddī vā’’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘‘no’’ti vadeyya. ‘‘Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ icchasi kāmesi, jānāsi taṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ  – evaṃnāmā evaṃgottāti vā, dīghā vā rassā vā majjhimā vā kāḷī vā sāmā vā maṅguracchavī vāti, amukasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā’’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘no’ti vadeyya. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi, taṃ tvaṃ icchasi kāmesī’’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘‘āmā’’ti vadeyya.
mula_english:
"Vāseṭṭha, it is just as if a man were to say: “I am going to seek out and love the most beautiful girl in the country.”

Then they would say to him: “Good man, that most beautiful girl in this country with whom you are in love - do you know whether she is from the noble class (*kṣatriya*) or the Brahmin class (*brāhmaṇī*) or the merchant class (*vaiśya*) or the worker class (*śūdra*)?” And when asked this, he would say, “No.”

Then they would say to him, “Good man, that most beautiful girl in this country with whom you are in love - do you know her name and clan? Whether she is tall or short or of middle height? Whether she is dark or brown or golden-skinned? What village or town or city she lives in?” And when asked this, he would say, “No.”

Then they would say to him: “Good man, do you then love a girl you have never known or seen?” And when asked this, he would say, "Yes."

mula_pali: 535. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, nanu evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bho gotama, evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english: “What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Surely, in such a case, doesn't the talk of that man turn out to be foolish?” “Indeed, sir Gotama, in such a case, the talk of that man turns out to be foolish.”

mula_pali: 536. ‘‘Evameva  kho, vāseṭṭha, na kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho, napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ācariyehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho, napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ācariyapācariyehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ yāva sattamā ācariyāmahayugehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Yepi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ etarahi tevijjā brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ, tadanugāyanti, tadanubhāsanti, bhāsitamanubhāsanti, vācitamanuvācenti , seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘mayametaṃ jānāma, mayametaṃ passāma, yattha vā brahmā, yena vā brahmā, yahiṃ vā brahmā’’ti. Teva tevijjā brāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘yaṃ na jānāma, yaṃ na passāma, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ desema – ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’’ti.
mula_english:
536.

Thus it is, Vāseṭṭha, none of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas have seen Brahmā face to face; nor have their teachers, nor their teachers' teachers.

Nor have the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas seen Brahmā face to face as far back as the seventh generation of teachers.

And those ancient seers of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas, the composers of hymns (mantra), the founders of hymns, whose ancient verses, hymns, sayings, and compilations the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas now follow, repeat, recite, and cause to be recited—namely, Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu—even they did not say, "We know this, we see this: where Brahmā is, how Brahmā is, and in what manner Brahmā is."

Yet these Brahmins versed in the three Vedas say, "We teach the path to union with that which we do not know and do not see. This is the direct path, the straightforward way, the means of deliverance, leading to union with Brahmā."

mula_pali: 537. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, nanu evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bho gotama, evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, te vata, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā yaṃ na jānanti, yaṃ na passanti, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ  desessanti – ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyāti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
"What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Such being the case, does not what these Brahmins learned in the three Vedas declare turn out to be ill-founded?" "Indeed, Gotama, such being the case, what these Brahmins learned in the three Vedas declare turns out to be ill-founded."

"Good, Vāseṭṭha. Indeed, Vāseṭṭha, these Brahmins learned in the three Vedas, teach a path to companionship with Brahma of that which they do not know and do not see—'this is the straight path, this is the direct way, the means of escape, which leads him who acts according to it into companionship with Brahma'—that is not possible (netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati)."

mula_pali: 538. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , vāseṭṭha, puriso cātumahāpathe nisseṇiṃ kareyya – pāsādassa ārohaṇāya. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘‘ambho purisa, yassa tvaṃ yaṃ tvaṃ (syā.) pāsādassa ārohaṇāya nisseṇiṃ karosi, jānāsi taṃ pāsādaṃ – puratthimāya vā disāya dakkhiṇāya vā disāya pacchimāya  vā disāya uttarāya vā disāya ucco vā nīco vā majjhimo vā’’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘‘no’’ti vadeyya. ‘‘Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi, na passasi, tassa tvaṃ pāsādassa ārohaṇāya nisseṇiṃ karosī’’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘‘āmā’’ti vadeyya.
mula_english:
538.

"Just as, Vāseṭṭha, a man might build a staircase at a crossroads to ascend to a palace (pāsādassa ārohaṇāya).

Then they might say to him, "Good man, the palace for which you are building this staircase, do you know that palace – whether it faces the eastern direction (puratthimāya disāya), or the southern direction (dakkhiṇāya disāya), or the western direction (pacchimāya disāya), or the northern direction (uttarāya disāya), whether it is high (ucco), low (nīco), or of medium height (majjhimo)?" Being asked thus, he would say, "No."

"Then they might say to him, "Good man, the palace that you do not know (na jānāsi) and do not see (na passasi), for that are you building a staircase to ascend to it?" Being asked thus, he would say, "Yes."

mula_pali: 539. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, nanu evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bho gotama, evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
539.

"What do you think, Vāseṭṭha, does not the talk of that man turn out to be foolish when things are like this?"

"Indeed, sir Gotama, when things are like this, the talk of that man turns out to be foolish."

mula_pali: 540. ‘‘Evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, na kira tevijjehi brāhmaṇehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho, napi  kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ācariyehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho, napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ ācariyapācariyehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho, napi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ yāva sattamā ācariyāmahayugehi brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho. Yepi kira tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pubbakā isayo mantānaṃ kattāro mantānaṃ pavattāro, yesamidaṃ etarahi tevijjā brāhmaṇā porāṇaṃ mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihitaṃ, tadanugāyanti, tadanubhāsanti, bhāsitamanubhāsanti, vācitamanuvācenti, seyyathidaṃ – aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamāhaṃsu – mayametaṃ jānāma , mayametaṃ passāma, yattha vā brahmā, yena vā brahmā, yahiṃ vā brahmāti. Teva tevijjā brāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘yaṃ na jānāma, yaṃ na passāma, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ  desema, ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasahabyatāyā’’ti.
mula_english:
“So it is, Vāseṭṭha, none of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas have seen Brahmā face to face (brahmā sakkhidiṭṭho), nor have their teachers, nor the teachers of their teachers, nor even the seventh generation of teachers back.

And those ancient seers of the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas, the composers of the *mantras* (mantānaṃ kattāro), the promulgators of the *mantras* (mantānaṃ pavattāro), whose ancient *mantra* verses (mantapadaṃ) – which are recited, uttered, and compiled – the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas now follow, repeat, reiterate what was spoken, and recite what was recited, such as Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu, even they did not say, ‘We know this, we see this: where Brahmā is, how Brahmā is, or in what manner Brahmā is.’

Yet the Brahmins versed in the three Vedas say, ‘We do not know, we do not see, but we teach the path to union with that: This is the straight path, this is the direct way, which leads to union with Brahmā (brahmasahabyatāyā).’”

mula_pali: 541. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, nanu evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bho gotama, evaṃ sante tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha. Te vata, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā yaṃ na jānanti, yaṃ na passanti, tassa sahabyatāya maggaṃ desessanti. Ayameva ujumaggo ayamañjasāyano  niyyāniko niyyāti takkarassa brahmasabyatāyāti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
“What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Such being the case, does not what these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas declare turn out to be ill-founded?”

“Certainly, venerable Gotama, such being the case, what these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas declare turns out to be ill-founded.”

“Well said, Vāseṭṭha.

Indeed, Vāseṭṭha, these Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, teach a path to companionship with Brahmā (brahmasabyatā), which they neither know nor see.

'This is the direct path (ujumaggo), this is the most direct way, which leads out, and leads the one who acts according to it to companionship with Brahmā,' this cannot possibly be the case."

mula_pali: 542. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, vāseṭṭha, ayaṃ aciravatī nadī pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā. Atha puriso āgaccheyya pāratthiko pāragavesī pāragāmī pāraṃ taritukāmo. So orime tīre ṭhito pārimaṃ tīraṃ avheyya – ‘‘ehi pārāpāraṃ, ehi pārāpāra’’nti.
mula_english: ‘It is just as if this River Aciravatī, Vāseṭṭha, were brimful of water so that a crow could drink out of it. And a man should come along wishing to cross over, to get to the other side, to get across, and, standing on this bank, were to call out: “Come here, other bank (pārāpāraṃ), come here!”
commentary_pali: 542.Samatittikāti samabharitā. Kākapeyyāti yattha katthaci tīre ṭhitena kākena sakkā pātunti kākapeyyā. Pāraṃ taritukāmoti nadiṃ atikkamitvā paratīraṃ gantukāmo. Avheyyāti pakkoseyya. Ehi pārāpāranti ambho pāra apāraṃ ehi, atha maṃ sahasāva gahetvā gamissasi, atthi me accāyikakammanti attho.
commentary_english:
542.

"Samatittikā" means completely filled.

"Kākapeyyā" means that it is possible for a crow to drink, standing at whatever bank or shore, therefore it is called *kākapeyyā*.

"Pāraṃ taritukāmo" means desiring to cross over to the further shore, having gone beyond the river, desiring to go to the other shore.

"Avheyyā" means he should call out.

"Ehi pārāpāraṃ" means: "O water, come to this shore and the other shore, come! Then you will suddenly take me and go, because I have urgent business"—this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 543. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, api nu tassa purisassa avhāyanahetu vā āyācanahetu vā patthanahetu vā abhinandanahetu vā aciravatiyā nadiyā pārimaṃ tīraṃ orimaṃ tīraṃ āgaccheyyā’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english: What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Would the far bank of the Aciravatī River come to this near bank on account of that man's calling, or begging, or requesting, or praising? "No, indeed, venerable Gotama."

mula_pali: 544. ‘‘Evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā ye dhammā brāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme pahāya  vattamānā, ye dhammā abrāhmaṇakārakā te  dhamme samādāya vattamānā evamāhaṃsu – ‘‘indamavhayāma, somamavhayāma, varuṇamavhayāma, īsānamavhayāma, pajāpatimavhayāma, brahmamavhayāma, mahiddhimavhayāma, yamamavhayāmā’’ti. ‘‘Te vata, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā  ye dhammā brāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme pahāya vattamānā, ye dhammā abrāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme samādāya vattamānā avhāyanahetu vā āyācanahetu vā patthanahetu vā abhinandanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmānaṃ sahabyūpagā bhavissantī’’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
544.
"Indeed, Vāseṭṭha, those Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjā brāhmaṇā), who, neglecting those things that make one a Brahmin (ye dhammā brāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme pahāya vattamānā), instead undertake those things that do not make one a Brahmin (ye dhammā abrāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme samādāya vattamānā), say thus: ‘We call upon Indra (indamavhayāma), we call upon Soma (somamavhayāma), we call upon Varuṇa (varuṇamavhayāma), we call upon Īsāna (īsānamavhayāma), we call upon Prajāpati (pajāpatimavhayāma), we call upon Brahma (brahmamavhayāma), we call upon Mahiddhi (mahiddhimavhayāma), we call upon Yama (yamamavhayāmā).’

“But that those Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas (tevijjā brāhmaṇā), who, neglecting those things that make one a Brahmin (ye dhammā brāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme pahāya vattamānā), instead undertake those things that do not make one a Brahmin (ye dhammā abrāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme samādāya vattamānā), will, as a result of their calling (avhāyanahetu vā), begging (āyācanahetu vā), requesting (patthanahetu vā), or rejoicing (abhinandanahetu vā), attain union with Brahma (brahmānaṃ sahabyūpagā bhavissantī) after death, at the breaking up of the body (kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā)—that is simply not possible (netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati)."
commentary_pali: 544.Ye dhammā brāhmaṇakārakāti ettha pañcasīladasakusalakammapathabhedā dhammā brāhmaṇakārakāti veditabbā , tabbiparītā abrāhmaṇakārakā. Indamavhāyāmāti indaṃ avhāyāma pakkosāma. Evaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ avhāyanassa niratthakataṃ dassetvā punapi bhagavā aṇṇavakucchiyaṃ sūriyo viya jalamāno pañcasatabhikkhuparivuto aciravatiyā tīre nisinno aparampi nadīupamaṃyeva āharanto ‘‘seyyathāpī’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
544.
"Those qualities that make one a *brāhmaṇa*": here, the distinctions of the five precepts, the ten wholesome courses of action are to be understood as qualities that make one a *brāhmaṇa*, and the opposite of those are qualities that do not make one a *brāhmaṇa*.
"We call upon Indra": "Indraṃ avhāyāma pakkosāma": we call upon Indra, we summon him.
Having shown in this way the futility of calling upon *brāhmaṇas*, again the Blessed One, shining like the sun in the ocean’s cavity, surrounded by five hundred monks, sitting on the bank of the Aciravatī river, bringing forth yet another river simile, said, "Just as..." and so forth.

mula_pali: 545. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, vāseṭṭha, ayaṃ aciravatī nadī pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā. Atha puriso āgaccheyya pāratthiko pāragavesī pāragāmī pāraṃ taritukāmo. So orime tīre daḷhāya anduyā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ baddho. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, api nu so puriso aciravatiyā nadiyā orimā tīrā pārimaṃ tīraṃ gaccheyyā’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
545.
'It is just as if, Vāseṭṭha, this Aciravatī River were full of water, filled to the brim, so that a crow could drink from it.
And a man should come along wishing to cross over, seeking the far shore, going to the far shore, desiring to cross to the other side (pāraṃ taritukāmo).
But he was bound and pinioned on this side by a strong chain, with his hands behind his back.
'What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Would that man be able to get to the far shore (pārimaṃ tīraṃ) of the Aciravatī River from this shore (orimā tīrā)?' 'No, indeed, Master Gotama.'

mula_pali: 546. ‘‘Evameva  kho, vāseṭṭha, pañcime kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye andūtipi vuccanti, bandhanantipi vuccanti. Katame pañca? Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā. Sotaviññeyyā saddā…pe… ghānaviññeyyā gandhā… jivhāviññeyyā rasā… kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā. ‘‘Ime kho, vāseṭṭha, pañca kāmaguṇā ariyassa vinaye andūtipi vuccanti, bandhanantipi vuccanti . Ime kho vāseṭṭha pañca kāmaguṇe tevijjā brāhmaṇā gadhitā mucchitā ajjhopannā anādīnavadassāvino anissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti. Te vata, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā ye dhammā brāhmaṇakārakā, te dhamme pahāya vattamānā, ye dhammā  abrāhmaṇakārakā, te dhamme samādāya vattamānā pañca kāmaguṇe gadhitā mucchitā ajjhopannā anādīnavadassāvino anissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjantā kāmandubandhanabaddhā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmānaṃ sahabyūpagā bhavissantī’’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
546.

‘In just the same way, Vāseṭṭha, in the Ariyan discipline these five strands of sense-desire (*kāmaguṇā*) are called bonds and fetters.

Which five? Forms cognizable by the eye that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust.

Sounds cognizable by the ear… Odours cognizable by the nose…Flavours cognizable by the tongue… Tangibles cognizable by the body that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust.

These five in the Ariyan discipline are called bonds and fetters.

And, Vāseṭṭha, those Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas are enslaved, in­fatuated by these five strands of sense-desire, which they enjoy guiltily, unaware of danger, knowing no way out.

‘But that such Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, who persistently neglect what a Brahmin should do,… who are enslaved by these five strands of sense-desire,… knowing no way out, should attain after death, at the break­ing-up of the body, to union with Brahmā — that is just not possible.
commentary_pali: 546.Kāmaguṇāti kāmayitabbaṭṭhena kāmā, bandhanaṭṭhena guṇā. ‘‘Anujānāmi bhikkhave, ahatānaṃ vatthānaṃ diguṇaṃ saṅghāṭi’’nti (mahāva. 348) ettha hi paṭalaṭṭho guṇaṭṭho. ‘‘Accenti kālā tarayanti rattiyo, vayoguṇā anupubbaṃ jahantī’’ti ettha rāsaṭṭho guṇaṭṭho. ‘‘Sataguṇā dakkhiṇā pāṭikaṅkhitabbā’’ti  (ma. ni. 3.379) ettha ānisaṃsaṭṭho guṇaṭṭho. ‘‘Antaṃ antaguṇaṃ (khu. pā. 3.1) kayirā mālāguṇe bahū’’ti (dha. pa. 53) ca ettha bandhanaṭṭho guṇaṭṭho. Idhāpi eseva adhippeto. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘bandhanaṭṭhena guṇā’’ti. Cakkhuviññeyyāti cakkhuviññāṇena passitabbā. Etenupāyena sotaviññeyyādīsupi attho veditabbo. Iṭṭhāti pariyiṭṭhā vā hontu, mā vā, iṭṭhārammaṇabhūtāti attho. Kantāti kāmanīyā. Manāpāti manavaḍḍhanakā. Piyarūpāti piyajātikā. Kāmūpasañhitāti ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjamānena kāmena upasañhitā. Rajanīyāti rañjanīyā, rāguppattikāraṇabhūtāti attho. Gadhitāti gedhena abhibhūtā hutvā. Mucchitāti mucchākārappattāya adhimattakāya taṇhāya abhibhūtā. Ajjhopannāti adhiopannā ogāḷhā ‘‘idaṃ sāra’’nti pariniṭṭhānappattā hutvā. Anādīnavadassāvinoti  ādīnavaṃ apassantā. Anissaraṇapaññāti idamettha nissaraṇanti, evaṃ parijānanapaññāvirahitā, paccavekkhaṇaparibhogavirahitāti attho.
commentary_english:
546.

*Kāmaguṇā* means *kāmā* because of the state of being desired, and *guṇā* because of the state of being a bond ( *bandhana*).

“I allow you, monks, a double *saṅghāṭi* of unwashed cloths” (Mahāva).

348) Here, *paṭalaṭṭho* is *guṇaṭṭho*.

“The seasons pass, the nights hurry on, the qualities of youth gradually abandon” here *rāsaṭṭho* is *guṇaṭṭho*.

“A hundredfold offering is to be expected” (Ma.

Ni.

3.

379) Here, *ānisaṃsaṭṭho* is *guṇaṭṭho*.

“The end is the end quality (Khu.

Pa.

3.

1) One should make many garlands" (Dha.

Pa.

53) And here, *bandhanaṭṭho* is *guṇaṭṭho*.

Here too, this is what is intended.

Therefore, it was said, “*Guṇā* because of the state of being a bond (*bandhana*).”

*Cakkhuviññeyyā* means to be seen by visual consciousness (*cakkhuviññāṇena*).

By this method, the meaning should also be understood in the case of auditory consciousness, etc.

*Iṭṭhā* means whether they are very desirable or not, it means having the nature of a desirable object (*iṭṭhārammaṇa*).

*Kantā* means desirable (*kāmanīyā*).

*Manāpā* means increasing the mind (*manavaḍḍhanakā*).

*Piyarūpā* means having a dear nature (*piyajātikā*).

*Kāmūpasañhitā* means associated with desire (*kāma*) arising by making an object (*ārammaṇa*).

*Rajanīyā* means *rañjanīyā*, having the nature of the cause of the arising of passion (*rāga*).

*Gadhitā* means having been overcome by greed (*gedha*) .

*Mucchitā* means having been overcome by intense craving (*taṇhā*) that has attained the state of bewilderment (*mucchākāra*).

*Ajjhopannā* means having entered into and plunged into, having become those who have attained the conclusion "this is the essence."

*Anādīnavadassāvino* means not seeing the fault (*ādīnavaṃ*).

*Anissaraṇapaññā* means this is escape here, thus devoid of the wisdom of complete knowledge, devoid of the enjoyment of reflection.

mula_pali: 547. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , vāseṭṭha, ayaṃ aciravatī nadī pūrā udakassa samatittikā kākapeyyā. Atha puriso āgaccheyya pāratthiko pāragavesī pāragāmī pāraṃ taritukāmo. So orime tīre sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nipajjeyya. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, api nu so puriso aciravatiyā nadiyā orimā tīrā pārimaṃ tīraṃ gaccheyyā’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
547. It is just as if, Vāseṭṭha, this Aciravatī River were full of water, filled to the brim, so that a crow could drink from it.

And a man should come along wishing to cross over, seeking the further shore (*pāragavesī*), reaching the further shore (*pāragāmī*), desiring to cross to the other side (*pāraṃ taritukāmo*).

And were he to lie down on this bank, covering his head with a shawl.

What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Would that man be able to get to the other side of the Aciravatī River?" "No, indeed, venerable Gotama."

mula_pali: 548. ‘‘Evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, pañcime nīvaraṇā ariyassa vinaye āvaraṇātipi vuccanti, nīvaraṇātipi vuccanti, onāhanātipi vuccanti, pariyonāhanātipi vuccanti. Katame pañca? Kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ, byāpādanīvaraṇaṃ, thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ, uddhaccakukkuccanīvaraṇaṃ, vicikicchānīvaraṇaṃ. Ime kho, vāseṭṭha, pañca nīvaraṇā ariyassa vinaye āvaraṇātipi vuccanti, nīvaraṇātipi vuccanti, onāhanātipi vuccanti, pariyonāhanātipi vuccanti.
mula_english:
