‘In the same way, Vāseṭṭha, in the Noble Discipline, these five hindrances are called obstacles (*āvaraṇa*), hindrances (*nīvaraṇa*), coverings-up (*onāhana*), envelopings (*pariyonāhana*).

Which five? The hindrance of sensual desire (*kāmacchandanīvaraṇa*), the hindrance of ill will (*byāpādanīvaraṇa*), the hindrance of sloth and torpor (*thinamiddhanīvaraṇa*), the hindrance of restlessness and remorse (*uddhaccakukkuccanīvaraṇa*), and the hindrance of doubt (*vicikicchānīvaraṇa*).

These five, Vāseṭṭha, are called obstacles (*āvaraṇa*), hindrances (*nīvaraṇa*), coverings-up (*onāhana*), envelopings (*pariyonāhana*) in the Noble Discipline.
commentary_pali: 548.Āvaraṇātiādīsu  āvarantīti āvaraṇā. Nivārentīti nīvaraṇā. Onandhantīti onāhanā. Pariyonandhantīti pariyonāhanā. Kāmacchandādīnaṃ vitthārakathā visuddhimaggato gahetabbā.
commentary_english: 548. In "āvaraṇātiādi," *āvaraṇā* means "they obstruct." *Nīvaraṇā* means "they hinder." *Onāhanā* means "they bind." *Pariyonāhanā* means "they completely bind." The detailed explanation of *kāmacchanda*, etc., should be taken from the *Visuddhimagga*.

mula_pali: 549. ‘‘Imehi  kho, vāseṭṭha, pañcahi nīvaraṇehi tevijjā brāhmaṇā āvuṭā nivuṭā onaddhā ophuṭā (sī. ka.), ophutā (syā.) pariyonaddhā. Te vata, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā ye  dhammā brāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme pahāya vattamānā, ye dhammā abrāhmaṇakārakā te dhamme samādāya vattamānā pañcahi nīvaraṇehi āvuṭā nivuṭā onaddhā pariyonaddhā pariyonaddhā, te (syā. ka.) kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmānaṃ  sahabyūpagā bhavissantī’’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
549.

"Indeed, Vāseṭṭha, the *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) who are learned in the three Vedas are covered, concealed, bound, and completely bound by these five hindrances (*nīvaraṇa*). But that those *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) who are versed in the three Vedas, abandoning those qualities which make one a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin), adopting those qualities which do not make one a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin), covered, concealed, bound, and completely bound by the five hindrances (*nīvaraṇa*), will, at the dissolution of the body, after death, become united with Brahmā—this is not possible."
commentary_pali: 549-550.Āvutā nivutā onaddhā pariyonaddhāti padāni āvaraṇādīnaṃ vasena vuttāni. Sapariggahoti itthipariggahena sapariggahoti pucchati. Apariggaho bho gotamātiādīsupi kāmacchandassa abhāvato itthipariggahena apariggaho. Byāpādassa abhāvato kenaci saddhiṃ veracittena avero. Thinamiddhassa abhāvato cittagelaññasaṅkhātena byāpajjena abyāpajjo. Uddhaccakukkuccābhāvato uddhaccakukkuccādīhi saṃkilesehi asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto suparisuddhamānaso. Vicikicchāya abhāvato cittaṃ vase vatteti. Yathā ca brāhmaṇā cittagatikā hontīti, cittassa vasena vattanti, na tādisoti vasavattī.
commentary_english:
549-550. The words "āvuṭā, nivutā, onaddhā, and pariyonaddhā" are stated in terms of covering, etc.

"Sapariggaho" means he asks, "Is he 'with possessions' (sapariggaho) due to possession of women (itthipariggaha)?"

"Apariggaho bho gotama" and so forth [means] due to the absence (abhāvato) of desire for sensual pleasures (kāmacchanda), he is "without possessions" (apariggaho) through the non-possession of women (itthipariggaha).

Due to the absence (abhāvato) of ill-will (byāpādassa), he is "without enmity" (avero) towards anyone with a hostile mind (veracittena saddhiṃ).

Due to the absence (abhāvato) of sloth and torpor (thinamiddhassa), he is "not afflicted" (abyāpajjo) by affliction (byāpajjena) described as sickness of the mind (cittagelaññasaṅkhātena).

Due to the absence (abhāvato) of excitement and remorse (uddhaccakukkuccābhāvato), his mind is "untainted" (asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto) by defilements (saṃkilesehi) such as excitement and remorse (uddhaccakukkuccādīhi), and he has a "very pure mind" (suparisuddhamānaso).

Due to the absence (abhāvato) of doubt (vicikicchāya), he turns (vatteti) the mind (cittaṃ) to his will (vase).

Just as the Brahmins are "mind-goers" (cittagatikā), they proceed (vattanti) according to the will (vasena) of the mind (cittassa), but he is not like that, therefore he is "one who has power over the will" (vasavattī).

mula_pali: 550. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, kinti te sutaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vuddhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ, sapariggaho vā brahmā apariggaho vā’’ti? ‘‘Apariggaho, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Saveracitto vā averacitto vā’’ti? ‘‘Averacitto, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sabyāpajjacitto vā abyāpajjacitto vā’’ti? ‘‘Abyāpajjacitto, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Saṃkiliṭṭhacitto vā asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto vā’’ti? ‘‘Asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Vasavattī vā avasavattī vā’’ti? ‘‘Vasavattī, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, sapariggahā vā tevijjā brāhmaṇā apariggahā vā’’ti? ‘‘Sapariggahā, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Saveracittā vā averacittā vā’’ti? ‘‘Saveracittā, bho gotama’’ . ‘‘Sabyāpajjacittā vā abyāpajjacittā vā’’ti? ‘‘Sabyāpajjacittā, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Saṃkiliṭṭhacittā vā asaṃkiliṭṭhacittā vā’’ti? ‘‘Saṃkiliṭṭhacittā, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Vasavattī vā avasavattī vā’’ti? ‘‘Avasavattī, bho gotama’’.
mula_english:
550.
‘What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? What have you heard said by Brahmins, who are venerable, aged, the teachers of teachers? Is Brahmā encumbered or unencumbered?’ ‘Unencumbered, Master Gotama.’
‘Is he full of hate (*saveracitto*) or without hate (*averacitto*)?’ ‘Without hate (*averacitto*), Master Gotama.’
‘Is he full of ill-will (*sabyāpajjacitto*) or without ill-will (*abyāpajjacitto*)?’ ‘Without ill-will (*abyāpajjacitto*), Master Gotama.’
‘Is he impure (*saṃkiliṭṭhacitto*) or pure (*asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto*)?’ ‘Pure (*asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto*), Master Gotama.’
‘Is he disciplined (*vasavattī*) or undisciplined (*avasavattī*)?’ ‘Disciplined (*vasavattī*), Master Gotama.’
‘And what do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Are the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas (*tevijjā brāhmaṇā*) encumbered or unencumbered?’ ‘Encumbered, Master Gotama.’
‘Are they full of hate (*saveracittā*) or without hate (*averacittā*)?’ ‘Full of hate (*saveracittā*), Master Gotama.’
‘Are they full of ill-will (*sabyāpajjacittā*) or without ill-will (*abyāpajjacittā*)?’ ‘Full of ill-will (*sabyāpajjacittā*), Master Gotama.’
‘Are they impure (*saṃkiliṭṭhacittā*) or pure (*asaṃkiliṭṭhacittā*)?’ ‘Impure (*saṃkiliṭṭhacittā*), Master Gotama.’
‘Are they disciplined (*vasavattī*) or undisciplined (*avasavattī*)?’ ‘Undisciplined (*avasavattī*), Master Gotama.’
commentary_pali: 549-550.Āvutā nivutā onaddhā pariyonaddhāti padāni āvaraṇādīnaṃ vasena vuttāni. Sapariggahoti itthipariggahena sapariggahoti pucchati. Apariggaho bho gotamātiādīsupi kāmacchandassa abhāvato itthipariggahena apariggaho. Byāpādassa abhāvato kenaci saddhiṃ veracittena avero. Thinamiddhassa abhāvato cittagelaññasaṅkhātena byāpajjena abyāpajjo. Uddhaccakukkuccābhāvato uddhaccakukkuccādīhi saṃkilesehi asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto suparisuddhamānaso. Vicikicchāya abhāvato cittaṃ vase vatteti. Yathā ca brāhmaṇā cittagatikā hontīti, cittassa vasena vattanti, na tādisoti vasavattī.
commentary_english:
549-550. The words "āvuṭā, nivuṭā, onaddhā, pariyonaddhā" are stated in terms of covering, etc.

"[Is he] with possessions?" he asks, "[Is he] with possessions by means of possessions regarding women?"

"Without possessions, O Gotama," even in the case of these and others, because of the absence of desire for sensual pleasures, he is without possessions by means of possessions regarding women.

Because of the absence of ill-will, he is without enmity towards anyone with a hostile mind.

Because of the absence of sloth and torpor, he is without affliction by means of affliction described as sickness of mind (cittagelañña).

Because of the absence of agitation and remorse, his mind is uncorrupted by defilements such as agitation and remorse, and he is of a very pure mind (suparisuddhamānasa).

Because of the absence of doubt (vicikicchā), he turns his mind (cittaṃ) to control (vase).

Just as Brahmins are of a mind-led nature, that is, they behave according to the mind (cittassa vasena vattanti), he is not like that; therefore, he is one who has power over the mind (vasavattī).

mula_pali: 551. ‘‘Iti  kira, vāseṭṭha, sapariggahā tevijjā brāhmaṇā apariggaho brahmā. Api nu kho sapariggahānaṃ tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ apariggahena brahmunā saddhiṃ saṃsandati sametī’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, te vata, vāseṭṭha, sapariggahā tevijjā brāhmaṇā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apariggahassa  brahmuno sahabyūpagā bhavissantī’’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati. ‘‘Iti kira, vāseṭṭha, saveracittā tevijjā brāhmaṇā, averacitto brahmā…pe… sabyāpajjacittā tevijjā brāhmaṇā abyāpajjacitto brahmā… saṃkiliṭṭhacittā tevijjā brāhmaṇā asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto brahmā… avasavattī tevijjā  brāhmaṇā vasavattī brahmā, api nu kho avasavattīnaṃ tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vasavattinā brahmunā saddhiṃ saṃsandati sametī’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, te vata, vāseṭṭha, avasavattī tevijjā brāhmaṇā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā vasavattissa brahmuno sahabyūpagā bhavissantī’’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
551.
"Thus it is, Vāseṭṭha, the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas are encumbered, but Brahmā is unencumbered.
Do the encumbered Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas have communion or association with the unencumbered Brahmā?" "No, indeed, Gotama."
"Good, Vāseṭṭha. These encumbered Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas, will they, upon the dissolution of the body after death, be united with the unencumbered Brahmā?" "That is not possible."
"Thus it is, Vāseṭṭha, the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas are with hateful thoughts, but Brahmā is without hateful thoughts... with thoughts of ill-will, but Brahmā is without ill-will... with defiled thoughts, but Brahmā is without defiled thoughts... the Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas are undisciplined, but Brahmā is disciplined. Do the undisciplined Brahmins learned in the Three Vedas have communion or association with the disciplined Brahmā?" "No, indeed, Gotama."
"Good, Vāseṭṭha. These undisciplined *brāhmaṇas* learned in the Three Vedas, will they, upon the dissolution of the body after death, be united in the company of the disciplined Brahmā?" "That is not possible."

mula_pali: 552. ‘‘Idha kho pana te, vāseṭṭha, tevijjā brāhmaṇā āsīditvā ādisitvā (ka.) saṃsīdanti, saṃsīditvā visāraṃ visādaṃ (sī. pī.), visattaṃ (syā.) pāpuṇanti, sukkhataraṃ sukkhataraṇaṃ (ka.) maññe taranti. Tasmā idaṃ tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ tevijjāiriṇantipi vuccati, tevijjāvivanantipi vuccati, tevijjābyasanantipi vuccatī’’ti.
mula_english: But, Vāseṭṭha, these *tevijja* Brahmins, having sat down, sink down despairingly, and having sunk down, they reach disappointment; I think they imagine they will find a drier way across. Therefore, this threefold knowledge (*tevijja*) of the Brahmins is also called the threefold desert, the threefold wilderness, and the threefold destruction.
commentary_pali: 552.Idhakho panāti idha brahmalokamagge. Āsīditvāti amaggameva ‘‘maggo’’ti upagantvā. Saṃsīdantīti ‘‘samatala’’nti saññāya paṅkaṃ otiṇṇā viya anuppavisanti. Saṃsīditvā visāraṃ pāpuṇantīti evaṃ paṅke viya saṃsīditvā visāraṃ aṅgamaṅgasaṃbhañjanaṃ pāpuṇanti. Sukkhataraṃ maññe tarantīti marīcikāya vañcetvā ‘‘kākapeyyā nadī’’ti saññāya ‘‘tarissāmā’’ti hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamamānā sukkhataraṇaṃ maññe taranti. Tasmā yathā hatthapādādīnaṃ saṃbhañjanaṃ paribhañjanaṃ, evaṃ apāyesu saṃbhañjanaṃ paribhañjanaṃ pāpuṇanti. Idheva ca sukhaṃ vā sātaṃ vā na labhanti. Tasmā idaṃ tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānanti tasmā idaṃ brahmasahabyatāya maggadīpakaṃ tevijjakaṃ pāvacanaṃ tevijjānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ. Tevijjāiriṇanti tevijjāaraññaṃ iriṇanti hi agāmakaṃ mahāaraññaṃ vuccati. Tevijjāvivananti pupphaphalehi aparibhogarukkhehi sañchannaṃ nirudakaṃ araññaṃ . Yattha maggato ukkamitvā parivattitumpi na sakkā honti, taṃ sandhāyāha ‘‘tevijjāvivanantipi vuccatī’’ti. Tevijjābyasananti tevijjānaṃ pañcavidhabyasanasadisametaṃ. Yathā hi ñātirogabhoga diṭṭhi sīlabyasanappattassa sukhaṃ nāma natthi, evaṃ tevijjānaṃ tevijjakaṃ pāvacanaṃ āgamma sukhaṃ nāma natthīti dasseti.
commentary_english:
552.

"He praises thus; here, on the path to the world of Brahmā."
Having sat down, that is, having approached what is not the path, thinking, "This is the path."
"They sink down," that is, thinking "it is level ground," they enter just like those who have sunk into the mud.
"Having sunk down, they reach expansion," that is, having sunk down in the mud in this way, they reach expansion, the breaking of limb upon limb.
"I think it is easier to cross over," deceiving [themselves] with a mirage, thinking "This is the Crow-Drink River," striving with hands and feet, they think, "I think it is easier to cross over."
Therefore, just as there is breaking and complete breaking of hands, feet, etc., so also in the woeful states, they reach breaking and complete breaking.
And here, they do not obtain happiness or pleasure.
Therefore, this is for the three Vedic knowledges of the Brahmins, therefore, this is the path-illuminating statement for companionship with Brahmā, for the three kinds of Vedic knowledge of the Brahmins.
"The three-knowledge waste land," that is, the three-knowledge forest is a waste land, for a non-village, great forest is called that.
"The three-knowledge wilderness," that is, a forest covered with trees with flowers and fruits not for enjoyment, without water.
Where it is not possible to step off the path and turn around, referring to that, he said, "It is also called a three-knowledge wilderness."
"The three-knowledge misfortune," that is, similar to the five kinds of misfortune of the three knowledges.
Just as there is no happiness for one who has attained the misfortune of relatives, disease, possessions, views, or morality, so too, having come to the statement for the three knowledges of the three Vedic knowledges, he shows that there is no happiness.

mula_pali: 553. Evaṃ  vutte, vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, samaṇo gotamo brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ jānātī’’ti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha. Āsanne ito manasākaṭaṃ, na ito dūre manasākaṭa’’nti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama, āsanne ito manasākaṭaṃ, na ito dūre manasākaṭa’’nti.
mula_english:
When this was said, the young man Vāseṭṭha said this to the Blessed One: "I have heard it said, revered Gotama, that the ascetic Gotama knows the path to companionship with Brahmā." (brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ jānātīti).
"What do you think, Vāseṭṭha?
Is Manasākaṭa near here, or is Manasākaṭa not far from here?" "Yes, revered Gotama, Manasākaṭa is near here, it is not far from here."

mula_pali: 554. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, idhassa puriso manasākaṭe jātasaṃvaddho. Tamenaṃ manasākaṭato tāvadeva avasaṭaṃ  manasākaṭassa maggaṃ puccheyyuṃ. Siyā nu kho, vāseṭṭha, tassa purisassa  manasākaṭe jātasaṃvaddhassa manasākaṭassa maggaṃ puṭṭhassa dandhāyitattaṃ vā vitthāyitattaṃ vā’’ti? ‘‘No hidaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Taṃ kissa hetu’’? ‘‘Amu hi, bho gotama, puriso manasākaṭe jātasaṃvaddho, tassa sabbāneva manasākaṭassa maggāni suviditānī’’ti. ‘‘Siyā kho, vāseṭṭha, tassa purisassa manasākaṭe jātasaṃvaddhassa manasākaṭassa maggaṃ puṭṭhassa dandhāyitattaṃ vā vitthāyitattaṃ vā, na tveva tathāgatassa brahmaloke vā brahmalokagāminiyā vā paṭipadāya puṭṭhassa dandhāyitattaṃ vā vitthāyitattaṃ vā. Brahmānaṃ cāhaṃ, vāseṭṭha, pajānāmi brahmalokañca brahmalokagāminiñca paṭipadaṃ, yathā paṭipanno ca brahmalokaṃ upapanno, tañca pajānāmī’’ti.
mula_english:
554.

"What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Suppose there were a man here born and brought up in Manasākaṭa.

And someone who had come from Manasākaṭa and had missed the road should ask him the way to Manasākaṭa.

Would that man, born and bred in Manasākaṭa, be in a state of confusion or perplexity if asked the way?" "No, indeed, Gotama."

"What is the reason for that?" "Because that man, Gotama, was born and brought up in Manasākaṭa, and all the paths to Manasākaṭa are well-known to him."

"It might be said, Vāseṭṭha, that such a man on being asked the way to Manasākaṭa might be confused or perplexed—but the *Tathāgata*, on being asked about the *Brahma* world (*brahmaloka*) and the way leading to the *Brahma* world, would certainly not be confused or perplexed.

For, Vāseṭṭha, I know *Brahmā* and the world of *Brahmā* (*brahmaloka*) and the practice leading to the world of *Brahmā*, and as I have practiced, I have attained to the world of *Brahmā*, and I know that."
commentary_pali: 554.Jātasaṃvaḍḍhoti jāto ca vaḍḍhito ca, yo hi kevalaṃ tattha jātova hoti, aññattha  vaḍḍhito, tassa samantā gāmamaggā na sabbaso paccakkhā honti, tasmā jātasaṃvaḍḍhoti āha. Jātasaṃvaḍḍhopi yo ciranikkhanto, tassa na sabbaso paccakkhā honti. Tasmā ‘‘tāvadeva avasaṭa’’nti āha, taṅkhaṇameva nikkhantanti attho. Dandhāyitattanti ayaṃ nu kho maggo, ayaṃ na nukhoti kaṅkhāvasena cirāyitattaṃ. Vitthāyitattanti yathā sukhumaṃ atthajātaṃ sahasā pucchitassa kassaci sarīraṃ thaddhabhāvaṃ gaṇhāti, evaṃ thaddhabhāvaggahaṇaṃ. Na tvevāti iminā sabbaññutaññāṇassa appaṭihatabhāvaṃ dasseti. Tassa hi purisassa mārāvaṭṭanādivasena siyā ñāṇassa  paṭighāto. Tena so dandhāyeyya vā vitthāyeyya vā. Sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ pana appaṭihataṃ, na sakkā tassa kenaci antarāyo kātunti dīpeti.
commentary_english:
554.

*Jātasaṃvaḍḍhoti* means both born and raised. For someone who is only born there, but raised elsewhere, the village paths all around are not entirely clear. Therefore, it is said, "*jātasaṃvaḍḍhoti*."

Even if someone is *jātasaṃvaḍḍha* who has been gone for a long time, the village paths are not entirely clear to him.

Therefore, he says, "He should wait only that long." The meaning is that he left at that very moment.

*Dandhāyitattanti* means: "Is this the path, or is it not?" is a state of prolonged doubt.

*Vitthāyitattanti* means: Just as when someone is suddenly asked about a subtle matter, his body becomes stiff, so too, there is this stiffening.

"Not even that" (*na tvevāti*)—with this, he shows the unobstructed nature (*appaṭihatabhāva*) of all-knowing knowledge (*sarvajñuta-jñāna*).

For that person, there might be an obstruction (*paṭighāta*) to knowledge (*jñāna*) due to things like the turning back by Māra.

Therefore, he might be slow (*dandhāyeyya*) or expansive (*vitthāyeyya*).

But all-knowing knowledge (*sarvajñuta-jñāna*) is unobstructed (*appaṭihataṃ*); it is not possible for anyone to cause an obstruction (*antarāyo kātuṃ*) to it, he clarifies.

mula_pali: 555. Evaṃ  vutte, vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, samaṇo gotamo brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetī’’ti. ‘‘Sādhu no bhavaṃ gotamo brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ desetu  ullumpatu bhavaṃ gotamo brāhmaṇiṃ paja’’nti. ‘‘Tena hi, vāseṭṭha, suṇāhi; sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ bho’’ti kho vāseṭṭho māṇavo bhagavato paccassosi.
mula_english:
555. When this was said, the youth Vāseṭṭha said this to the Blessed One: “I have heard it said, venerable Gotama, that the ascetic Gotama teaches the path to union with Brahmā.”

“It would be good if the venerable Gotama were to teach us the path to union with Brahmā. May the venerable Gotama uplift the people of Brahmā!”

“Then, Vāseṭṭha, listen, pay proper attention, and I will speak.”

“Very good, Reverend Sir,” said the youth Vāseṭṭha to the Blessed One.
commentary_pali: 555.Ullumpatu bhavaṃ gotamoti uddharatu bhavaṃ gotamo. Brāhmaṇiṃ pajanti brāhmaṇadārakaṃ, bhavaṃ gotamo mama brāhmaṇaputtaṃ apāyamaggato uddharitvā brahmalokamagge patiṭṭhapetūti attho. Athassa bhagavā buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā saddhiṃ pubbabhāgapaṭipadāya mettāvihārādibrahmalokagāmimaggaṃ desetukāmo ‘‘tena hi vāseṭṭhā’’tiādimāha. Tattha ‘‘idha tathāgato’’tiādi sāmaññaphale vitthāritaṃ. Mettāsahagatenātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge brahmavihārakammaṭṭhānakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Seyyathāpi vāseṭṭha balavā saṅkhadhamotiādi pana idha apubbaṃ. Tattha balavāti balasampanno. Saṅkhadhamoti  saṅkhadhamako. Appakasirenāti akicchena adukkhena. Dubbalo hi saṅkhadhamo saṅkhaṃ dhamantopi na sakkoti catasso disā sarena viññāpetuṃ, nāssa saṅkhasaddo sabbato pharati. Balavato pana vipphāriko hoti, tasmā ‘‘balavā’’tiādimāha. Mettāya cetovimuttiyāti ettha mettāti vutte upacāropi appanāpi vaṭṭati, ‘‘cettovimuttī’’ti vutte pana appanāva vaṭṭati. Yaṃ pamāṇakataṃ kammanti pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ nāma kāmāvacaraṃ vuccati. Appamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ nāma rūpārūpāvacaraṃ. Tañhi pamāṇaṃ atikkamitvā odissakaanodissakadisāpharaṇavasena vaḍḍhetvā katattā appamāṇakatanti vuccati. Na taṃ tatrāvasissati na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhatīti taṃ kāmāvacarakammaṃ tasmiṃ rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakamme na ohīyati, na tiṭṭhati. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti – taṃ kāmāvacarakammaṃ tassa rūpārūpāvacarakammassa antarā laggituṃ vā ṭhātuṃ vā rūpārūpāvacarakammaṃ pharitvā pariyādiyitvā attano okāsaṃ gahetvā patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti. Atha kho rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakammameva kāmāvacaraṃ mahogho viya parittaṃ udakaṃ pharitvā pariyādiyitvā attano okāsaṃ gahetvā tiṭṭhati. Tassa vipākaṃ paṭibāhitvā sayameva brahmasahabyataṃ upanetīti. Evaṃvihārīti evaṃ mettādivihārī.
commentary_english:
555.
'May the revered Gotama uplift [us],' meaning 'May the revered Gotama uplift [us]!'
The people think of [a certain] young Brāhmin girl as 'a *brāhmaṇi*,' [thinking] 'May the revered Gotama, having uplifted my Brāhmin son from the path of misfortune, establish [him] on the path to the world of Brahmā,' is the meaning.
Then, the Blessed One, wishing to show the arising of a Buddha, together with the preliminary practice, the path leading to the world of Brahmā, such as loving-kindness, said, "Therefore, O Vāseṭṭha," and so on.
There, "Here, the *Tathāgata*," and so on, is extensively explained in the fruits of monastic life.
Whatever needs to be said in connection with "accompanied by loving-kindness," and so forth, all of that has been said in the Visuddhimagga, in the section on the practice of the Brahmā-vihāras.
Just as, O Vāseṭṭha, "a strong conch-blower," and so forth, is not new here.
There, "strong" means endowed with strength (*balasampanno*).
"*Saṅkhadhamo*," means a conch-blower (*saṅkhadhamako*).
"*Appakasirena*," means without difficulty (*akicchena*), without suffering (*adukkhena*).
For a weak conch-blower, even while blowing the conch, is not able to make the four directions known with the sound; the sound of his conch does not pervade everywhere.
But for a strong one, it is far-reaching; therefore, he said, "strong," and so on.
In "*mettāya cetovimuttiyā*," here, when "*mettā*" is said, both access (*upacāra*) and attainment (*appanā*) are suitable; but when "*cettovimuttī*" is said, only attainment (*appanā*) is suitable.
What is karma that has measure (*pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ*)? Karma that has measure is called karma belonging to the desire realm (*kāmāvacaraṃ*).
Karma that does not have measure (*appamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ*) is called karma belonging to the form and formless realms (*rūpārūpāvacaraṃ*).
Indeed, because it has exceeded measure, having increased through the way of touching the directed and undirected directions, it is called karma that does not have measure (*appamāṇakataṃ*).
"It does not remain there, it does not persist there," thus, that karma belonging to the desire realm (*kāmāvacarakammaṃ*) does not diminish in that karma belonging to the form and formless realms (*rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakamme*), it does not stay.
What is said is this: that karma belonging to the desire realm (*kāmāvacarakammaṃ*) is not able to either latch onto or stand in between that karma belonging to the form and formless realms (*rūpārūpāvacarakammassa*), having pervaded and completely consumed the karma belonging to the form and formless realms (*rūpārūpāvacarakammaṃ*), having taken its own opportunity, it is not able to establish itself.
But rather, the karma belonging to the form and formless realms (*rūpāvacarārūpāvacarakammameva*), having pervaded and completely consumed the karma belonging to the desire realm (*kāmāvacaraṃ*), like a great flood (*mahogho*), [having pervaded and completely consumed] a small amount of water (*parittaṃ udakaṃ*), having taken its own opportunity, it stands.
Having repelled its result, it itself leads to association with Brahmā.
"*Evaṃvihārīti*," means one who dwells in loving-kindness (*mettādivihārī*) in this way.

mula_pali: 556. Bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘idha, vāseṭṭha, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ, sammāsambuddho…pe…  (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, vāseṭṭha, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti…pe… tassime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati. ‘‘So mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati . Tathā dutiyaṃ. Tathā tatiyaṃ. Tathā  catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, vāseṭṭha, balavā saṅkhadhamo appakasireneva catuddisā viññāpeyya; evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, evaṃ bhāvitāya mettāya cetovimuttiyā yaṃ pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ na taṃ tatrāvasissati, na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhati. Ayampi kho, vāseṭṭha, brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggo. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, vāseṭṭha, bhikkhu karuṇāsahagatena cetasā…pe… muditāsahagatena cetasā…pe… upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṃ. Tathā tatiyaṃ. Tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena  cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , vāseṭṭha, balavā saṅkhadhamo appakasireneva catuddisā viññāpeyya. Evameva kho, vāseṭṭha, evaṃ bhāvitāya upekkhāya cetovimuttiyā yaṃ pamāṇakataṃ kammaṃ na taṃ tatrāvasissati, na taṃ tatrāvatiṭṭhati. Ayaṃ kho, vāseṭṭha, brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggo.
mula_english:
556. The Blessed One said this: "Here, Vāseṭṭha, a *Tathāgata* arises in the world, an *Arhat*, a perfectly enlightened Buddha…pe… (as it should be explained in sections 190-212 in this way, in detail).

In this way, Vāseṭṭha, a *bhikkhu* is accomplished in virtue…pe… Seeing these five hindrances abandoned within himself, gladness (*pāmojja*) arises; for one who is gladdened, rapture (*pīti*) arises; when the mind is filled with rapture (*pīti*), the body grows tranquil; the body being tranquil, he experiences happiness (*sukha*); being happy, the mind becomes concentrated (*samādhiyati*).

“He dwells, pervading one direction with a mind imbued with loving-kindness (*mettāsahagatena cetasā*).

Likewise the second direction.

Likewise the third direction.

Likewise the fourth direction.

Thus, above, below, across, everywhere, identifying himself with all, he dwells pervading the entire world with a mind imbued with loving-kindness (*mettāsahagatena cetasā*), abundant, exalted, measureless, free from enmity, and free from affliction.

"Just as, Vāseṭṭha, a mighty trumpeter could make himself heard without difficulty in the four directions; so too, Vāseṭṭha, by this development, by this liberation of the heart through loving-kindness (*mettā*), no limiting action remains there, none persists there.

This, too, Vāseṭṭha, is the path to companionship with Brahmā.

"Furthermore, Vāseṭṭha, a *bhikkhu* dwells pervading one direction with a mind imbued with compassion (*karuṇāsahagatena cetasā*)…pe… with a mind imbued with sympathetic joy (*muditāsahagatena cetasā*)…pe… with a mind imbued with equanimity (*upekkhāsahagatena cetasā*).

Likewise the second direction.

Likewise the third direction.

Likewise the fourth direction.

Thus, above, below, across, everywhere, identifying himself with all, he dwells pervading the entire world with a mind imbued with equanimity (*upekkhāsahagatena cetasā*), abundant, exalted, measureless, free from enmity, and free from affliction.

"Just as, Vāseṭṭha, a mighty trumpeter could make himself heard without difficulty in the four directions.

So too, Vāseṭṭha, by this development, by this liberation of the heart through equanimity (*upekkhā*), no limiting action remains there, none persists there.

This, too, Vāseṭṭha, is the path to companionship with Brahmā.

mula_pali: 557. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, vāseṭṭha, evaṃvihārī bhikkhu sapariggaho vā apariggaho vā’’ti? ‘‘Apariggaho, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Saveracitto vā averacitto vā’’ti? ‘‘Averacitto, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sabyāpajjacitto vā abyāpajjacitto vā’’ti? ‘‘Abyāpajjacitto, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Saṃkiliṭṭhacitto vā asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto vā’’ti? ‘‘Asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Vasavattī vā avasavattī vā’’ti? ‘‘Vasavattī, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Iti  kira, vāseṭṭha, apariggaho bhikkhu, apariggaho brahmā. Api nu kho apariggahassa bhikkhuno apariggahena brahmunā saddhiṃ saṃsandati sametī’’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, so vata vāseṭṭha apariggaho bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apariggahassa brahmuno sahabyūpago bhavissatī’’ti, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
mula_english:
‘What do you think, Vāseṭṭha? Is a monk dwelling thus encumbered with possessions (*sapariggaha*) or unencumbered with possessions (*apariggaha*)?’ ‘Unencumbered, Venerable Gotama.’

‘Is he with hatred (*saveracitto*) or without hatred (*averacitto*)?’ ‘Without hatred, Venerable Gotama.’

‘Is he full of ill-will (*sabyāpajjacitto*) or without ill-will (*abyāpajjacitto*)?’ ‘Without ill-will, Venerable Gotama.’

‘Is he with defiled mind (*saṃkiliṭṭhacitto*) or without defiled mind (*asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto*)?’ ‘Without defiled mind, Venerable Gotama.’

‘Is he disciplined (*vasavattī*) or undisciplined (*avasavattī*)?’ ‘Disciplined, Venerable Gotama.’

‘Then, Vāseṭṭha, the monk is unencumbered with possessions (*apariggaha*), and Brahmā is unencumbered with possessions (*apariggaha*).

Has that unencumbered monk anything in common with the unencumbered Brahmā?’ ‘Yes, Venerable Gotama.’

‘That is right, Vāseṭṭha. Then that an unencumbered monk, after death, at the breaking-up of the body, should attain to union with the unencumbered Brahmā - that is possible.’

mula_pali: 558. ‘‘Iti kira, vāseṭṭha, averacitto bhikkhu, averacitto brahmā…pe… abyāpajjacitto bhikkhu, abyāpajjacitto brahmā… asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto bhikkhu, asaṃkiliṭṭhacitto  brahmā… vasavattī bhikkhu, vasavattī brahmā, api nu kho vasavattissa bhikkhuno vasavattinā brahmunā saddhiṃ saṃsandati sametī’’ti ? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sādhu, vāseṭṭha, so vata, vāseṭṭha, vasavattī bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā vasavattissa brahmuno sahabyūpago bhavissatīti, ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
"Thus, Vāseṭṭha, a monk with a mind free from enmity, Brahmā with a mind free from enmity... a monk with a mind free from ill-will, Brahmā with a mind free from ill-will... a monk with a mind free from defilement, Brahmā with a mind free from defilement... a monk who has mastered his mind, Brahmā who has mastered his mind, could it be possible that a monk who has mastered his mind communes and unites with Brahmā who has mastered his mind?" "Yes, Venerable Gotama."

"Excellent, Vāseṭṭha, that a monk who has mastered his mind, after death, at the breaking up of the body, should attain union with Brahmā who has mastered his mind – that is indeed possible."

mula_pali: 559. Evaṃ vutte, vāseṭṭhabhāradvājā māṇavā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama! Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti. Evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito . Ete mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma, dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsake no bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṃ gate’’ti. Tassuddānaṃ –
mula_english:
559.
When this was said, the youths Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja said this to the Blessed One: "Excellent, Venerable Gotama, excellent! It is as if, Venerable Gotama, one were to set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or hold up an oil lamp in the dark, so that those with eyes might see forms."

Just so, the Dharma has been made clear by Venerable Gotama in many ways (anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito).

We go to the esteemed Gotama for refuge (saraṇaṃ gacchāma), and to the Dharma, and to the Saṃgha of monks.

May the esteemed Gotama remember us as lay followers (upāsake) who have gone for refuge from this day forth, as long as life lasts."

This is the summary (tassuddānaṃ).
commentary_pali: 559.Etemayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamanti idaṃ tesaṃ dutiyaṃ saraṇagamanaṃ. Paṭhamameva hete majjhimapaṇṇāsake vāseṭṭhasuttaṃ sutvā saraṇaṃ gatā, imaṃ pana tevijjasuttaṃ sutvā dutiyampi saraṇaṃ gatā. Katipāhaccayena pabbajitvā aggaññasutte upasampadañceva arahattañca alatthuṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
559. This is their second refuge-going, saying, "We go to you, Master Gotama."

Having previously gone for refuge after hearing the *Vāseṭṭha Sutta* in the *Majjhimapaṇṇāsa*, they went for refuge a second time after hearing this *Tevijja Sutta*.

After some time, having gone forth and having attained full ordination (*upasampadā*) and arahantship in the *Aggañña Sutta*.

The rest is clear throughout.

mula_pali: 501. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena sālavatikā tadavasari. Tena kho pana samayena lohicco brāhmaṇo sālavatikaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā pasenadinā kosalena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ, brahmadeyyaṃ.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. Once the Lord was touring Kosala with a large company of some five hundred monks, and he arrived at Sālavatikā.

And at that time, the Brahmin Lohicca was living at Sālavatikā, a populous place, full of grass, timber, water and corn, which had been given to him by King Pasenadi of Kosala as a royal gift and with royal powers, a sacred grant.
commentary_pali: 501.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… kosalesūti lohiccasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ anuttānapadavaṇṇanā. Sālavatikāti tassa gāmassa nāmaṃ, so kira vatiyā viya samantato sālapantiyā parikkhitto. Tasmā sālavatikāti vuccati. Lohiccoti tassa brāhmaṇassa nāmaṃ.
commentary_english:
Thus have I heard…pe… the *Lohiccasutta* in Kosala.

Herein is an explanation of terms that are not obvious (*anuttānapadavaṇṇanā*).

Sālavatikā is the name of that village, because it was surrounded on all sides by a row of *sāla* trees, like a fence (*vatiyā*).

Therefore it is called Sālavatikā.

Lohicca is the name of that *brāhmaṇa* (*brāhmaṇassa nāmaṃ*).

mula_pali: 502. Tena kho pana samayena lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti – ‘‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati. Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā aññaṃ navaṃ bandhanaṃ kareyya, evaṃsampadamidaṃ pāpakaṃ lobhadhammaṃ vadāmi, kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’’ti.
mula_english:
At that time, this evil view arose in the mind of the Brahmin Lohicca: "If a *śramaṇa* or a *brāhmaṇa* were to attain a wholesome *dharma*, having attained it, he should not reveal it to another. Indeed, what can one person do for another?"

It is just as if someone, having cut off an old bond (*bandhana*), would make another new bond. I declare that such is an evil deed rooted in greed (*lobhadhamma*): "Indeed, what can one person do for another?"
commentary_pali: 502-503.Pāpakanti parānukampā virahitattā lāmakaṃ, na pana ucchedasassatānaṃ aññataraṃ. Uppannaṃ hotīti jātaṃ hoti, na kevalañca citte jātamattameva. So kira tassa vasena parisamajjhepi evaṃ bhāsatiyeva. Kiñhi paro parassāti paro yo anusāsīyati, so tassa anusāsakassa kiṃ karissati. Attanā paṭiladdhaṃ kusalaṃ dhammaṃ attanāva sakkatvā garuṃ katvā vihātabbanti vadati.
commentary_english:
502-503. "Evil" is wretched because it lacks compassion for others; however, it is not one of annihilation or eternity.

"It comes into existence," means it is born; but it is not merely born in the mind alone.

It seems that because of this, he speaks in this way even in the midst of the assembly.

Indeed, what will one who instructs another—that is, the one who is instructed—do for his instructor?

He says that one should honor, respect, and abide by the wholesome Dharma obtained by oneself.

mula_pali: 503. Assosi kho lohicco brāhmaṇo – ‘‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sālavatikaṃ anuppatto. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ  abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ  sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī’’ti.
mula_english:
503. Lohicca the Brahman heard: "The ascetic Gotama, the son of the Śākyas, who went forth from the Śākya clan, while wandering in the Kosala country, has arrived at Sālavatika with a large Saṅgha of monks, with about five hundred monks.

And concerning that venerable Gotama such a good report has spread about: 'Indeed, that Blessed One is an *arhat* (worthy one), a perfectly enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), accomplished in knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a Well-Farer (*sugato*), Knower of the worlds (*lokavidū*), unsurpassed trainer of persons to be tamed (*anuttaro purisadammasārathi*), teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a Buddha (awakened one), a Blessed Lord (*bhagavā*).'

He, having directly realized this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its Māras (*samārakaṃ*), and its Brahmās (*sabrahmakaṃ*), its generation with its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ*), its gods and humans (*sadevamanussaṃ*), makes it known.

He teaches the Dharma (*dhammaṃ*) that is good in the beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), and good in the end (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*), with its meaning (*sātthaṃ*) and with its expression (*sabyañjanaṃ*); he reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaṃ*) that is utterly perfect (*kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ*) and pure (*parisuddhaṃ*).

Indeed, it is good to see such *arhats* (worthy ones)."
commentary_pali: 502-503.Pāpakanti parānukampā virahitattā lāmakaṃ, na pana ucchedasassatānaṃ aññataraṃ. Uppannaṃ hotīti jātaṃ hoti, na kevalañca citte jātamattameva. So kira tassa vasena parisamajjhepi evaṃ bhāsatiyeva. Kiñhi paro parassāti paro yo anusāsīyati, so tassa anusāsakassa kiṃ karissati. Attanā paṭiladdhaṃ kusalaṃ dhammaṃ attanāva sakkatvā garuṃ katvā vihātabbanti vadati.
commentary_english:
502-503. Evil is wretched because it is devoid of compassion for others; however, it is not one of annihilation or eternity.

"It comes into existence," means it is born; however, it is not merely born in the mind alone.

Indeed, he speaks thus in the midst of the assembly due to that habit of his.

For what [can] one person do to another? The one who is instructed, what will he do to his instructor?

He says that one should honor, respect, and relinquish the wholesome *dharma* that has been attained by oneself.

mula_pali: 504. Atha  kho lohicco brāhmaṇo rosikaṃ bhesikaṃ (sī. pī.) nhāpitaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘ehi tvaṃ, samma rosike, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama ; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha – lohicco, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’’ti. Evañca vadehi – ‘‘adhivāsetu kira bhavaṃ gotamo lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’’ti.
mula_english:
Then, Lohicca the Brahmin addressed the barber Rosika Bhesika: "Come, good Rosika, go to the ascetic Gotama; having gone there, ask the ascetic Gotama, in my words, whether he is free from illness (*appābādhaṃ*), free from affliction (*appātaṅkaṃ*), quick to rise, strong, and living in comfort (*phāsuvihāraṃ*) – 'Lohicca, good Gotama, the Brahmin, asks Gotama whether you are free from illness, free from affliction, quick to rise, strong and living in comfort.' "

And also say this: "May the esteemed Gotama accept tomorrow's meal from Lohicca the Brahmin, together with the community of monks (*bhikkhusaṅghena*)."

mula_pali: 505. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti evaṃ bhanteti (sī. pī.) kho rosikā nhāpito lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘lohicco, bhante, brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati; evañca vadeti – adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’’ti. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
mula_english:
505.
“Yes, sir,” yes, venerable sir, (Sv. 10|505.)
Then Rosika the barber, having agreed to the words of the *brāhmaṇa* Lohicca, approached the Blessed One; having approached, he paid homage to the Blessed One and sat down to one side.
Seated to one side, Rosika the barber said this to the Blessed One: "Lohicca, venerable sir, the *brāhmaṇa*, asks after the Blessed One’s health, freedom from illness, lightness of movement, strength and easeful abiding, and says thus: ‘May the Blessed One accept tomorrow’s meal from Lohicca, the *brāhmaṇa*, together with the *bhikkhu-saṅgha.*’"
The Blessed One consented by silence ( *tuṇhībhāvena*).

mula_pali: 506. Atha kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena lohicco brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā lohiccaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘avocumhā kho mayaṃ bhoto mayaṃ bhante tava (sī. pī.) vacanena taṃ bhagavantaṃ – ‘lohicco, bhante, brāhmaṇo  bhagavantaṃ appābādhaṃ  appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati; evañca vadeti – adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’ti. Adhivutthañca pana tena bhagavatā’’ti.
mula_english: 506. Then, Rosika the barber, having understood the Blessed One's acceptance (adhivāsanaṃ viditvā), rose from his seat (uṭṭhāyāsanā), respectfully saluted the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā), circumambulated him (padakkhiṇaṃ katvā), and approached the place where Lohicca the Brahmin was (yena lohicco brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami). Having approached, he said this to Lohicca the Brahmin (lohiccaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca): "We have said according to your words, venerable sir (avocumhā kho mayaṃ bhoto), we have said to that Blessed One (taṃ bhagavantaṃ): 'Lohicca, venerable sir (lohicco, bhante), the Brahmin asks about the Blessed One's (bhagavantaṃ) freedom from disease (appābādhaṃ), freedom from affliction (appātaṅkaṃ), ease of movement (lahuṭṭhānaṃ), strength (balaṃ), and comfortable abiding (phāsuvihāraṃ). And he says this (evañca vadeti): "May the Blessed One accept (adhivāsetu kira), venerable sir (bhante), tomorrow's meal (svātanāya bhattaṃ) from Lohicca the Brahmin (lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa), together with the community of monks (saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’ti)."' and that it has been accepted by the Blessed One (adhivutthañca pana tena bhagavatā’ti."

mula_pali: 507. Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā rosikaṃ nhāpitaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘ehi tvaṃ, samma rosike, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇassa gotamassa kālaṃ ārocehi – kālo bho, gotama, niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta’’nti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho rosikā nhāpito lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi . Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavato kālaṃ ārocesi – ‘‘kālo, bhante, niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta’’nti.
mula_english:
Then, as the night was ending, the Brahmin Lohicca had excellent *khādanīya* (hard food) and *bhojanīya* (soft food) prepared in his own house. Then he addressed the barber Rosika: "Come, good Rosika, go to where the *Śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama is. Having gone there, inform the *Śramaṇa* Gotama that it is time: 'It is time, Gotama, the meal is ready.'"

"Very well, sir," replied Rosika the barber to the Brahmin Lohicca. He then went to where the Blessed One was, and having approached, respectfully greeted the Blessed One and stood to one side.

Standing to one side, Rosika the barber informed the Blessed One of the time: "It is time, venerable sir, the meal is ready."

mula_pali: 508. Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena  sālavatikā tenupasaṅkami. Tena kho pana samayena rosikā nhāpito bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho hoti. Atha kho rosikā nhāpito bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘lohiccassa, bhante, brāhmaṇassa evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ – ‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya – kiñhi paro parassa karissati. Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā aññaṃ navaṃ bandhanaṃ kareyya, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ  pāpakaṃ lobhadhammaṃ vadāmi – kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’ti. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā lohiccaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā vivecetū’’ti. ‘‘Appeva nāma siyā rosike, appeva nāma siyā rosike’’ti. Atha kho bhagavā yena lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi . Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
mula_english:
508. Then the Lord, having risen early and taken his robe and bowl (pattacīvara), went with his order of monks to Sālavatikā.

And at that time, the barber Rosika was following the Lord closely behind.

Then the barber Rosika said to the Lord: "Lord (bhante), such an evil view (pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ) has arisen in Lohicca the Brahmin (brāhmaṇassa): ‘If an ascetic (samaṇo) or a Brahmin (brāhmaṇo) were to attain a wholesome doctrine (kusalaṃ dhammaṃ), having attained a wholesome doctrine, he should not declare it to another; for what can one man do for another?

Just as if, having cut through an old fetter (purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ), one were to make a new one (navaṃ bandhanaṃ), I declare that this is an evil doctrine (pāpakaṃ dhammaṃ) rooted in attachment (lobhadhammaṃ), for what can one man do for another?"

"Truly, Lord (bhante), may the Blessed One (bhagavā) dissuade Lohicca the Brahmin from this evil view (pāpakā diṭṭhigatā)."

"It may well be so, Rosika, it may well be so."

Then the Lord went to Lohicca the Brahmin’s dwelling (nivesanaṃ); and having arrived, he sat down on the prepared seat (paññatte āsane).

Then Lohicca the Brahmin personally served (sahatthā) the Saṅgha of monks, with the Buddha at its head (buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ), with choice hard and soft food (paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena) until they were satisfied (santappesi sampavāresi).
commentary_pali: 508.Piṭṭhito piṭṭhitoti kathāphāsukatthaṃ pacchato pacchato anubandho hoti. Vivecetūti vimocetu, taṃ diṭṭhigataṃ vinodetūti vadati. Ayaṃ kira upāsako lohiccassa brāhmaṇassa piyasahāyako. Tasmā tassa atthakāmatāya evamāha. Appeva nāma siyāti ettha paṭhamavacanena bhagavā gajjati, dutiyavacanena anugajjati. Ayaṃ kirettha  adhippāyo – rosike etadatthameva mayā cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni. Kappasatasahassañca vividhāni dukkarāni karontena pāramiyo pūritā , etadatthameva sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, na me lohiccassa diṭṭhigataṃ bhindituṃ bhāroti, imamatthaṃ dassento paṭhamavacanena bhagavā gajjati. Kevalaṃ rosike  lohiccassa mama santike āgamanaṃ vā nisajjā vā allāpasallāpo vā hotu, sacepi lohiccasadisānaṃ satasahassassa kaṅkhā hoti, paṭibalo ahaṃ vinodetuṃ lohiccassa pana ekassa diṭṭhivinodane mayhaṃ ko bhāroti imamatthaṃ dassento dutiyavacanena bhagavā anugajjatīti veditabbo.
commentary_english:
508.
"Repeating and repeating" means that the connection follows again and again for the sake of ease of speaking.

"Let him discern" means "let him liberate." He says, "Let him dispel that adherence to views."

This lay follower, it seems, is a dear friend of the *brāhmaṇa* Lohicca.

Therefore, out of a desire for his welfare, he spoke thus.

"Perhaps it may be so." Here, with the first statement, the Blessed One roars; with the second statement, he roars in agreement.

The meaning here, it seems, is this: "O Rosikā, it was for this very purpose that I [practiced for] four incalculable *kalpas*."

"And by performing various difficult deeds for a hundred thousand *kalpas*, the *pāramīs* were fulfilled; it was for this very purpose that omniscience was attained. It is not a burden for me to shatter Lohicca's adherence to views." Thus, showing this meaning, with the first statement, the Blessed One roars.

"Only, O Rosikā, whether Lohicca comes into my presence, or sits down, or engages in friendly conversation, even if a hundred thousand doubts arise for those similar to Lohicca, I am capable of dispelling them. But what burden is it for me to dispel the view of even one Lohicca?" Thus, showing this meaning, with the second statement, the Blessed One roars in agreement, it should be understood.

mula_pali: 509. Atha kho lohicco brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho lohiccaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘saccaṃ kira te, lohicca, evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ – ‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya – kiñhi paro parassa karissati. Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā aññaṃ navaṃ bandhanaṃ kareyya, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ pāpakaṃ lobhadhammaṃ vadāmi, kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’’’ ti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi lohicca nanu tvaṃ sālavatikaṃ ajjhāvasasī’’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Yo nu kho, lohicca, evaṃ vadeyya – ‘lohicco brāhmaṇo sālavatikaṃ ajjhāvasati. Yā sālavatikāya samudayasañjāti lohiccova taṃ brāhmaṇo  ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṃ dadeyyā’ti. Evaṃ vādī so ye taṃ upajīvanti, tesaṃ antarāyakaro  vā hoti, no vā’’ti? ‘‘Antarāyakaro, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Antarāyakaro samāno hitānukampī vā tesaṃ hoti ahitānukampī vā’’ti? ‘‘Ahitānukampī, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Ahitānukampissa mettaṃ vā tesu cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sapattakaṃ vā’’ti? ‘‘Sapattakaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite  micchādiṭṭhi vā hoti sammādiṭṭhi vā’’ti? ‘‘Micchādiṭṭhi, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṃ, lohicca, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi – nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā’’.
mula_english:
509. Then the Brahmin Lohicca, when the Blessed One had finished eating and had removed his hand from the bowl, took a low seat and sat down to one side.

As Lohicca the Brahmin was sitting to one side, the Blessed One said to him, "Lohicca, is it true that such an evil view has arisen in you: 'Here, if a *śramaṇa* or a *brāhmaṇa* were to attain a wholesome principle (*kuśalaṃ dhammaṃ*), having attained a wholesome principle, he should not announce it to another, for what can one person do for another?'"

"It is as if, having cut an old bond, one should make another new bond. Thus, I say that this attainment is an evil doctrine rooted in greed (*lobhadhammaṃ*). For what can one person do for another?" "Indeed, venerable Gotama."

"What do you think, Lohicca? Do you not reside at Sālavatikā?" "Indeed, venerable Gotama."

"If someone were to say, 'Lohicca the *brāhmaṇa* resides at Sālavatikā.

Lohicca alone, the *brāhmaṇa*, should enjoy the entire yield and revenue (*samudayasañjāti*) of Sālavatikā, and should not give to others,'

would not someone who says this be a source of danger (*antarāyakaro*) to those who depend on him, or not?" "He would be a source of danger, venerable Gotama."

"Being a source of danger, would he be sympathetic (*hitānukampī*) to them, or unsympathetic (*ahitānukampī*)?" "Unsympathetic, venerable Gotama."

"Being unsympathetic, would a heart full of loving-kindness (*mettā*) be present in his mind towards them, or a heart full of hostility (*sapattakaṃ*)?" "A heart full of hostility, venerable Gotama."

"With a heart full of hostility present, would there be wrong view (*micchādiṭṭhi*) or right view (*sammādiṭṭhi*)?" "Wrong view, venerable Gotama."

"I declare that for one with wrong view (*micchādiṭṭhi*), there are two possible destinies (*gati*): hell (*niraya*) or the animal realm (*tiracchānayoni*)."
commentary_pali: 509.Samudayasañjātīti samudayassa sañjāti bhoguppādo, tato uṭṭhitaṃ dhanadhaññanti attho. Ye taṃ upajīvantīti ye ñātiparijanadāsakammakarādayo janā taṃ nissāya jīvanti. Antarāyakaroti lābhantarāyakaro. Hitānukampīti ettha hitanti vuḍḍhi. Anukampatīti anukampī, icchatīti attho, vuḍḍhiṃ icchati vā no vāti vuttaṃ hoti. Nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vāti sace sā micchādiṭṭhi sampajjati, niyatā hoti, ekaṃsena niraye nibbattati, no ce, tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbattatīti attho.
commentary_english:
509. "Samudayasañjātīti" means the arising of enjoyment from the coming together (samudaya), that is, the wealth and grain that arise from that.

"Ye taṃ upajīvantīti" means those people, such as relatives, attendants, slaves, and laborers, who live relying on that.

"Antarāyakaroti" means he makes an obstruction, [he is] an obstructor of gain (lābhāntarāyakaro).

"Hitānukampīti ettha hitanti vuḍḍhi" means here, "hita" means growth.

"Anukampatīti anukampī, icchatīti attho," means "He has compassion, therefore he is compassionate, that is, he desires," that is, it is said that he desires growth or not.

"Nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vāti" means if that wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) is accomplished, it is certain (niyatā), he is reborn in hell (niraye) without a doubt; if not, he is reborn in the animal realm (tiracchānayoniyaṃ), this is the meaning.

mula_pali: 510. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, lohicca, nanu rājā pasenadi kosalo kāsikosalaṃ ajjhāvasatī’’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Yo nu kho, lohicca, evaṃ vadeyya – ‘rājā pasenadi kosalo kāsikosalaṃ ajjhāvasati; yā kāsikosale samudayasañjāti, rājāva taṃ pasenadi kosalo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṃ dadeyyā’ti. Evaṃ vādī so ye rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ upajīvanti tumhe ceva aññe ca, tesaṃ antarāyakaro vā hoti, no vā’’ti? ‘‘Antarāyakaro, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Antarāyakaro samāno hitānukampī vā tesaṃ hoti ahitānukampī vā’’ti? ‘‘Ahitānukampī, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Ahitānukampissa mettaṃ vā tesu cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sapattakaṃ vā’’ti? ‘‘Sapattakaṃ, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi vā hoti sammādiṭṭhi vā’’ti? ‘‘Micchādiṭṭhi, bho gotama’’. ‘‘Micchādiṭṭhissa  kho ahaṃ, lohicca, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi – nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā’’.
mula_english:
510.
‘What do you think, Lohicca? Does King Pasenadi of Kosala reside at Kasi-Kosala?’ ‘Yes, Venerable Gotama.’

‘Well, if anyone should say: “King Pasenadi of Kosala resides at Kasi-Kosala, and King Pasenadi of Kosala alone should enjoy the entire fruits and revenue (samudayasañjāti) of Kosala, not giving anything away to others” —

would not anyone who spoke like that be a source of danger (antarāyakaro) to those who depend on King Pasenadi of Kosala, both you and others?’ ‘He would be a source of danger (antarāyakaro), Venerable Gotama.’

‘And as such, would he be solicitous for their welfare (hitānukampī) or not (ahitānukampī)?’ ‘Not solicitous for their welfare (ahitānukampī), Venerable Gotama.’

‘And, by not being solicitous for their welfare, would he have a heart full of loving-kindness (mettā) for them, or of hatred (sapattakaṃ)?’ ‘Of hatred (sapattakaṃ), Venerable Gotama.’

‘And in a heart full of hatred (sapattake citte), is there wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) or right view (sammādiṭṭhi)?’ ‘Wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi), Venerable Gotama.’

‘But Lohicca, I declare that wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi) leads to one of two destinies (gatīnaṃ): hell (nirayaṃ) or an animal rebirth (tiracchānayoniṃ).’
commentary_pali: 510-512. Idāni yasmā yathā attano lābhantarāyena sattā saṃvijjanti na tathā paresaṃ, tasmā suṭṭhutaraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ pavecetukāmo ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasī’’ti dutiyaṃ upapattimāha. Ye cimeti ye ca ime tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā ariyabhūmiṃ okkamituṃ asakkontā kulaputtā dibbā gabbhāti upayogatthe paccattavacanaṃ, dibbe gabbheti attho. Dibbā, gabbhāti ca channaṃ devalokānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Paripācentīti devalokagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pūrayamānā dānaṃ, dadamānā, sīlaṃ rakkhamānā, gandhamālādīhi, pūjaṃ kurumānā bhāvanaṃ bhāvayamānā pācenti vipācenti paripācenti pariṇāmaṃ gamenti. Dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyāti dibbabhavā nāma devānaṃ vimānāni , tesaṃ nibbattanatthāyāti attho. Atha vā dibbā gabbhāti dānādayo puññavisesā. Dibbā bhavāti devaloke vipākakkhandhā, tesaṃ nibbattanatthāya tāni puññāni karontīti attho. Tesaṃ antarāyakaroti tesaṃ maggasampattiphalasampattidibbabhavavisesānaṃ antarāyakaro. Iti bhagavā ettāvatā aniyamiteneva opammavidhinā yāva bhavaggā  uggataṃ brāhmaṇassa mānaṃ bhinditvā idāni codanārahe tayo satthāre dassetuṃ ‘‘tayo kho me, lohiccā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
510-512.
Now, because beings perceive existence in relation to their own obstructions to gain, but not so for others, therefore, wishing to persuade the *brāhmaṇa* even better, he spoke the second reason, "What do you think of that?".

Those sons of good family who, having heard the *Tathāgata's* teaching of the Dharma, are unable to attain the noble state, [are reborn] as divine beings. "Divine wombs" is a term used in the sense of application; the meaning is "in a divine womb."

"Divine wombs" is also a designation for the six *devalokas* (heavenly realms).

"Ripening" means fulfilling the path leading to the *devaloka*, giving gifts (*dāna*), practicing morality (*śīla*), performing worship (*pūjā*) with garlands of fragrance, etc., cultivating meditation (*bhāvanā*), causing [merit] to ripen, causing [it] to fully ripen, causing [it] to transform.

"The arising of divine states" means that divine abodes (*vimāna*) of the gods (*deva*) are called divine states; the meaning is for the sake of their arising.

Or alternatively, "divine wombs" are special merits such as giving (*dāna*), and so forth.

"Divine states" are the aggregates of fruition (*vipākakkhandha*) in the *devaloka*; the meaning is that they perform those meritorious deeds for the sake of their arising.

He creates obstacles for them; he creates obstacles for those attainments of the path (*magga*), the attainments of the fruit (*phala*), the special divine states (*dibba-bhava-visesa*).

Thus, the Blessed One (*Bhagavā*), having in this way shattered the *brāhmaṇa's* pride which was raised up to the peak of existence (*bhavagga*), by means of an analogy that was, in a way, unrestricted, now, in order to show the three teachers who are worthy of censure, he spoke the *sūtra* beginning with, "There are three, Lohicca."

mula_pali: 511. ‘‘Iti  kira, lohicca, yo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘‘lohicco brāhmaṇo sālavatikaṃ ajjhāvasati; yā sālavatikāya samudayasañjāti, lohiccova taṃ brāhmaṇo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṃ dadeyyā’’ti. Evaṃvādī so ye taṃ upajīvanti, tesaṃ antarāyakaro hoti. Antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṃ cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti. Evameva kho, lohicca, yo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘‘idha samaṇo  vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati. Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā aññaṃ navaṃ bandhanaṃ kareyya…pe… karissatī’’ti. Evaṃvādī so ye te kulaputtā tathāgatappaveditaṃ dhammavinayaṃ āgamma evarūpaṃ uḷāraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchanti, sotāpattiphalampi sacchikaronti, sakadāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, anāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, arahattampi sacchikaronti, ye cime dibbā gabbhā paripācenti dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyā, tesaṃ antarāyakaro hoti, antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti , ahitānukampissa sapattakaṃ cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti. Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṃ, lohicca, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi – nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā.
mula_english:
511.

'Thus, Lohicca, if anyone should say: "The *brāhmaṇa* Lohicca dwells in Sālavatikā; whatever arises from Sālavatikā, the *brāhmaṇa* Lohicca alone should enjoy it, and he should give none to others."'

Speaking in this way, he becomes an obstacle to those who depend on him.

Being an obstacle, he is uncompassionate. Because of his uncompassionate nature, hostile thoughts arise in his mind, and with hostile thoughts arisen in his mind, he has wrong view (*mithyā-dṛṣṭi*).

In the same way, Lohicca, if anyone should say: "Suppose an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa* were to attain a wholesome doctrine (*kuśalaṃ dharmaṃ*), having attained a wholesome doctrine, he should not declare it to others, for what can one man do for another?"

It is just as if a man, having cut through an old fetter, were to make a new one...

Speaking in this way, he becomes an obstacle to those young men of good family who, having come to the *dharma-vinaya* proclaimed by the *Tathāgata*, attain such excellent distinction, realize the fruit of stream-entry (*sotāpatti-phala*), realize the fruit of once-returning (*sakadāgāmi-phala*), realize the fruit of non-returning (*anāgāmi-phala*), and realize even *arhatship*. To those who ripen divine seeds for rebirth in the divine realms, he is a source of danger. Being a source of danger, he is uncompassionate, and his heart is grounded in hostility, and that constitutes wrong view (*mithyā-dṛṣṭi*).

But Lohicca, I declare that wrong view (*mithyā-dṛṣṭi*) leads to one of two destinies—hell (*niraya*) or an animal rebirth (*tiracchānayoni*).
commentary_pali: 510-512. Idāni yasmā yathā attano lābhantarāyena sattā saṃvijjanti na tathā paresaṃ, tasmā suṭṭhutaraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ pavecetukāmo ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasī’’ti dutiyaṃ upapattimāha. Ye cimeti ye ca ime tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā ariyabhūmiṃ okkamituṃ asakkontā kulaputtā dibbā gabbhāti upayogatthe paccattavacanaṃ, dibbe gabbheti attho. Dibbā, gabbhāti ca channaṃ devalokānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Paripācentīti devalokagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pūrayamānā dānaṃ, dadamānā, sīlaṃ rakkhamānā, gandhamālādīhi, pūjaṃ kurumānā bhāvanaṃ bhāvayamānā pācenti vipācenti paripācenti pariṇāmaṃ gamenti. Dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyāti dibbabhavā nāma devānaṃ vimānāni , tesaṃ nibbattanatthāyāti attho. Atha vā dibbā gabbhāti dānādayo puññavisesā. Dibbā bhavāti devaloke vipākakkhandhā, tesaṃ nibbattanatthāya tāni puññāni karontīti attho. Tesaṃ antarāyakaroti tesaṃ maggasampattiphalasampattidibbabhavavisesānaṃ antarāyakaro. Iti bhagavā ettāvatā aniyamiteneva opammavidhinā yāva bhavaggā  uggataṃ brāhmaṇassa mānaṃ bhinditvā idāni codanārahe tayo satthāre dassetuṃ ‘‘tayo kho me, lohiccā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
510-512.
Now, because beings perceive gain and loss differently for themselves than for others, therefore, wishing to thoroughly persuade the *brāhmaṇa*, he stated a second reason, "What do you think of that?".

"Those who are celestial wombs" (*dibbā gabbhā*)—this is an expression of individual usage with regard to the purpose of those sons of good family who, having heard the *dharmadeśana* (teaching of the *dharma*) of the *Tathāgata*, are unable to attain the noble state (*ariyabhūmi*). The meaning is, 'in a celestial womb'.

"Celestial wombs" (*dibbā gabbhā*) is also an appellation for the six heavens (*devaloka*).

"They bring to maturity" means that they perfect the practice leading to the world of the gods (*devaloka*), giving gifts (*dāna*), practicing morality (*śīla*), making offerings (*pūjā*) with incense, garlands, and so on, cultivating meditation (*bhāvanā*); they cause [merit] to ripen, they cause it to fully ripen, they cause it to completely ripen, they cause it to result.

"The arising of celestial existences (*dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbatti*)": *dibbabhava* (celestial existences) means the celestial abodes (*vimāna*) of the gods (*deva*); the meaning is, 'for the sake of their arising'.

Or else, "celestial wombs" (*dibbā gabbhā*) are distinguished meritorious deeds (*puññavisesā*) such as generosity (*dāna*), and so on.

"Celestial existences" (*dibbā bhava*) are the aggregates of fruition (*vipākakkhandhā*) in the world of the gods (*devaloka*); the meaning is, "they perform those meritorious deeds (*puññāni*) for the sake of their arising."

He creates obstacles for them; he creates obstacles to their attainment of the path (*magga*), the fruition (*phala*), the prosperity, and the distinguished celestial existences (*dibbabhavavisesānaṃ*).

Thus, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), having in this way broken the pride (*māna*) of the *brāhmaṇa*, which had risen all the way to the peak of existence (*bhavaggā*), by means of an unrestricted method of comparison (*opammavidhinā*), now, in order to show the three teachers (*satthāre*) worthy of censure (*codanārahe*), said, "These three, Lohicca, are mine," and so on.

mula_pali: 512. ‘‘Iti kira, lohicca, yo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘‘rājā pasenadi kosalo kāsikosalaṃ ajjhāvasati; yā kāsikosale samudayasañjāti, rājāva taṃ  pasenadi kosalo ekako paribhuñjeyya, na aññesaṃ dadeyyā’’ti. Evaṃvādī so ye rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ upajīvanti tumhe ceva aññe ca, tesaṃ antarāyakaro hoti. Antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṃ cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti. Evameva kho, lohicca, yo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘‘idha samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigaccheyya, kusalaṃ dhammaṃ adhigantvā na parassa āroceyya, kiñhi paro parassa karissati. Seyyathāpi nāma…pe… kiñhi  paro parassa karissatī’’ti, evaṃ vādī so ye te kulaputtā tathāgatappaveditaṃ dhammavinayaṃ āgamma evarūpaṃ uḷāraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchanti, sotāpattiphalampi sacchikaronti, sakadāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, anāgāmiphalampi sacchikaronti, arahattampi sacchikaronti. Ye cime dibbā gabbhā paripācenti dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyā, tesaṃ antarāyakaro hoti, antarāyakaro samāno ahitānukampī  hoti, ahitānukampissa sapattakaṃ cittaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti, sapattake citte paccupaṭṭhite micchādiṭṭhi hoti. Micchādiṭṭhissa kho ahaṃ, lohicca, dvinnaṃ gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ vadāmi – nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā.
mula_english:
512.

‘Thus, it is said, Lohicca, if anyone should say: “King Pasenadi of Kosala dwells in Kāsi-Kosala; and the entire revenue (samudayasañjāti) that arises in Kāsi-Kosala, King Pasenadi of Kosala alone should enjoy, not giving to others.”’

Speaking thus, he would be an obstructer to those who depend on King Pasenadi of Kosala, both you and others.

Being an obstructer, he is unsympathetic to their welfare (ahitānukampī). Because he is unsympathetic to their welfare, a hostile thought (sapattakaṃ cittaṃ) is present in his mind. When a hostile thought is present in his mind, he has wrong view (micchādiṭṭhi).

‘Even so, Lohicca, if anyone should say: “Here, an ascetic (samaṇo) or a Brahmin should attain a wholesome (kusalaṃ) teaching (dhammaṃ), and having attained a wholesome teaching, he should not announce it to others, for what can one person do for another?”’

Just as…what indeed can one person do for another?”, speaking thus, he obstructs those noble (kulaputtā) ones who, having come to the Teaching and Discipline (dhammavinayaṃ) proclaimed by the Tathāgata, attain such excellent distinction, and realize the fruit of stream-entry (sotāpattiphala), realize the fruit of once-returning (sakadāgāmiphala), realize the fruit of non-returning (anāgāmiphala), and realize even arhatship (arahatta).

And he is an obstructer to those celestial wombs which ripen for the arising of celestial states of existence (dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyā). Being an obstructer, he is unsympathetic to their welfare, because he is unsympathetic to their welfare, a hostile thought is present in his mind, when a hostile thought is present in his mind, he has wrong view.

"But Lohicca, I declare that for one with wrong view (micchādiṭṭhissa), there is one of two destinations (gatīnaṃ aññataraṃ gatiṃ): hell (nirayaṃ) or the animal realm (tiracchānayoniṃ)."

Paripācentīti devalokagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pūrayamānā dānaṃ, dadamānā, sīlaṃ rakkhamānā, gandhamālādīhi, pūjaṃ kurumānā bhāvanaṃ bhāvayamānā pācenti vipācenti paripācenti pariṇāmaṃ gamenti. Dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyāti dibbabhavā nāma devānaṃ vimānāni , tesaṃ nibbattanatthāyāti attho. Atha vā dibbā gabbhāti dānādayo puññavisesā. Dibbā bhavāti devaloke vipākakkhandhā, tesaṃ nibbattanatthāya tāni puññāni karontīti attho. Tesaṃ antarāyakaroti tesaṃ maggasampattiphalasampattidibbabhavavisesānaṃ antarāyakaro. Iti bhagavā ettāvatā aniyamiteneva opammavidhinā yāva bhavaggā  uggataṃ brāhmaṇassa mānaṃ bhinditvā idāni codanārahe tayo satthāre dassetuṃ ‘‘tayo kho me, lohiccā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
510-512.
Now, because beings perceive gain and loss for themselves differently than for others, therefore, wishing to persuade the *brāhmaṇa* more effectively, he spoke a second reason, saying, "What do you think about that?"

"Those who accumulate merit (ye cimeti) and those who, having heard the *Tathāgata's* teaching of the *dharma*, are unable to attain the noble plane (*ariyabhūmiṃ*), these sons of good families (kulaputtā) [are reborn in] divine wombs (dibbā gabbhā)," is a specific expression in the sense of use. The meaning is "in divine wombs."

"Divine wombs (dibbā, gabbhā)" is a designation (adhivacanaṃ) for the six *devalokas* (channaṃ devalokānaṃ).

"Perfecting" (paripācentīti) means fulfilling the path (paṭipadaṃ) leading to the world of the gods (*devaloka-gāminiṃ*), giving gifts (*dānaṃ dadamānā*), maintaining morality (*sīlaṃ rakkhamānā*), making offerings (*pūjaṃ kurumānā*) with garlands of flowers (*gandhamālādīhi*), cultivating meditation (*bhāvanaṃ bhāvayamānā*), causing to ripen (pācenti), fully ripening (vipācenti), thoroughly ripening (paripācenti), bringing about transformation (pariṇāmaṃ gamenti).

"The arising of divine existences (dibbānaṃ bhavānaṃ abhinibbattiyāti)" means divine existences (dibbabhavā) are the celestial mansions (devānaṃ vimānāni), for the sake of their arising, this is the meaning (tesaṃ nibbattanatthāyāti attho).

Or alternatively, "divine wombs (dibbā gabbhā)" are special merits (puññavisesā) such as giving (*dāna*), and so on (ādayo).

"Divine existences (dibbā bhavā)" means aggregates of *vipāka* in the world of the gods (devaloke vipākakkhandhā), for the sake of their arising, they do those meritorious deeds (tesaṃ nibbattanatthāya tāni puññāni karonti), this is the meaning.

He creates obstacles for them (tesaṃ antarāyakaroti), [he] is a creator of obstacles (antarāyakaro) to the attainment of their path (*maggasampatti*), the attainment of their fruit (*phalasampatti*), and the distinctiveness of their divine existences (*dibbabhavavisesānaṃ*).

Thus, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), having in this way broken the pride (*mānaṃ bhinditvā*) of the *brāhmaṇa* that had risen up to the peak of existence (*yāva bhavaggā uggataṃ brāhmaṇassa mānaṃ*), by means of an analogy (opammavidhinā) that was not precisely defined (aniyamiteneva), now, in order to show three teachers worthy of censure (codanārahe tayo satthāre dassetuṃ), said, "These three, Lohicca,..." (*‘‘tayo kho me, lohiccā’’tiādimāha*).

mula_pali: 513. ‘‘Tayo  khome, lohicca, satthāro, ye loke codanārahā; yo ca panevarūpe satthāro codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā . Katame tayo? Idha, lohicca, ekacco satthā yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, svāssa sāmaññattho ananuppatto hoti. So taṃ sāmaññatthaṃ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti – ‘‘idaṃ vo hitāya idaṃ vo sukhāyā’’ti. Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā  vattanti. So evamassa codetabbo – ‘‘āyasmā kho yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, so te sāmaññattho ananuppatto, taṃ tvaṃ sāmaññatthaṃ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ desesi – ‘idaṃ vo hitāya idaṃ vo sukhāyā’ti . Tassa te sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti. Seyyathāpi nāma osakkantiyā vā ussakkeyya, parammukhiṃ vā āliṅgeyya, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ pāpakaṃ lobhadhammaṃ vadāmi – kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’’ti. Ayaṃ kho, lohicca, paṭhamo satthā, yo loke codanāraho; yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
mula_english:
513.
"These three, Lohicca, are blameworthy teachers in the world; and if someone blames such teachers, that blame is true, factual, in accordance with the Dhamma, and faultless.

Which three? Here, Lohicca, a certain teacher goes forth from the household life into homelessness for some purpose, but his goal of asceticism (sāmaññattha) is not attained.

And without having attained that goal of asceticism (sāmaññattha), he teaches his disciples the Dharma (dhamma), saying: "This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness."

His disciples do not listen, do not lend an ear, do not apply their minds to understanding, and deviate from the Teacher's instruction (satthusāsanā) and conduct themselves accordingly.

He should be reproached thus: "Venerable sir, for whatever purpose you went forth from the household life into homelessness, that goal of asceticism (sāmaññattha) has not been attained by you, and without attaining that goal of asceticism (sāmaññattha), you teach your disciples the Dharma (dhamma), saying: 'This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness.'"

His disciples do not listen, do not lend an ear, do not apply their minds to understanding, and deviate from the Teacher's instruction (satthusāsanā) and conduct themselves accordingly.

It is just as if one were to persist with a rejecting woman or embrace a woman who turns away. Thus, I declare this to be an evil doctrine based on greed (lobhadhamma) - for what can one person do for another?"

This, Lohicca, is the first teacher who is deserving of blame in the world; and if someone blames such a teacher, that blame is true, factual, in accordance with the Dhamma, and faultless.
commentary_pali: 513. Tattha sā codanāti tayo satthāre codentassa codanā. Na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapentīti aññāya ājānanatthāya cittaṃ na upaṭṭhapenti. Vokkammāti nirantaraṃ tassa sāsanaṃ akatvā tato ukkamitvā vattantīti attho. Osakkantiyā vā ussakkeyyāti paṭikkamantiyā upagaccheyya, anicchantiyā iccheyya, ekāya sampayogaṃ anicchantiyā eko iccheyyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Parammukhiṃ vā āliṅgeyyāti daṭṭhumpi anicchamānaṃ parammukhiṃ ṭhitaṃ pacchato gantvā āliṅgeyya. Evaṃsampadamidanti imassāpi satthuno ‘‘mama ime sāvakā’’ti sāsanā vokkamma vattamānepi te lobhena anusāsato imaṃ lobhadhammaṃ evaṃsampadameva īdisameva vadāmi. Iti so evarūpo tava lobhadhammo yena tvaṃ osakkantiyā ussakkanto viya parammukhiṃ āliṅganto viya ahosītipi taṃ codanaṃ arahati. Kiñhi paro parassa karissatīti yena dhammena pare anusāsi, attānameva tāva tattha sampādehi, ujuṃ karohi. Kiñhi paro parassa karissatīti codanaṃ arahati.
commentary_english:
513.
There, that is an accusation, that is, an accusation of one who accuses the Teacher.
"They do not exert their minds to understand," means they do not exert their minds for the sake of understanding.
"Turning away," means without constantly doing his teaching, having turned away from that, they conduct themselves; that is the meaning.
"By withdrawing, or he might try," means, approaching one who is turning away, he might desire one who does not desire; one might desire union with one who does not desire it; it is said thus.
"He might embrace one who has turned away," means, even not wishing to be seen, having gone behind one standing with their face turned away, he might embrace [her].
"It is just such an attainment," means, even while these disciples of the Teacher are behaving having turned away from the teaching, instructing them with greed, I speak of this greedy teaching as being just such an attainment, just like this.
Thus, that greed of yours is just such that, because of it, though withdrawing, you were acting as if trying, as if embracing one who had turned away; therefore, you deserve that accusation.
"What indeed will another do for another?" By whatever teaching you instruct others, first accomplish yourself in that, make yourself upright.
"What indeed will another do for another?" Therefore, you deserve accusation.

mula_pali: 514. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, lohicca, idhekacco satthā yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, svāssa sāmaññattho ananuppatto hoti. So taṃ sāmaññatthaṃ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti – ‘‘idaṃ vo hitāya, idaṃ vo sukhāyā’’ti. Tassa sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṃ odahanti, aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti. So evamassa codetabbo – ‘‘āyasmā kho yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, so te sāmaññattho ananuppatto. Taṃ tvaṃ sāmaññatthaṃ ananupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ desesi – ‘idaṃ vo hitāya idaṃ vo sukhāyā’ti. Tassa te sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṃ odahanti , aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti. Seyyathāpi nāma sakaṃ khettaṃ ohāya paraṃ khettaṃ niddāyitabbaṃ maññeyya , evaṃ sampadamidaṃ pāpakaṃ lobhadhammaṃ vadāmi – kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’’ti. Ayaṃ kho, lohicca, dutiyo satthā, yo, loke codanāraho; yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
mula_english:
Again, Lohicca, here is a certain teacher who has gone forth from the household life into homelessness for a certain purpose, but who has not attained his goal of the ascetic life (*sāmaññattho ananuppatto hoti*).

And without having attained that goal of the ascetic life (*sāmaññatthaṃ ananupāpuṇitvā*), he teaches his disciples the Dharma, saying: "This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness."

His disciples wish to hear, they listen, they focus their minds, and they do not deviate from the Teacher’s Dispensation (*satthusāsanā*).

He should be reproached thus: “Venerable sir, the purpose for which you went forth from the household life into homelessness, that goal of the ascetic life (*sāmaññattho*) has not been attained by you.

Without having attained that goal of the ascetic life (*sāmaññatthaṃ ananupāpuṇitvā*), you teach your disciples the Dharma, saying: 'This is for your benefit, this is for your happiness.'"

His disciples wish to hear, they listen, they focus their minds, and they do not deviate from the Teacher’s Dispensation (*satthusāsanā*).

It is just as if, having abandoned his own field, he should think another's field needs weeding. I declare this to be an evil teaching rooted in greed (*lobhadhammaṃ*): "What indeed will one person do for another?"

This, Lohicca, is the second teacher who, in the world, is worthy of blame; and the reproach with which one reproaches such a teacher is true, factual, in accordance with the Dharma, and blameless.
commentary_pali: 514.Niddāyitabbanti sassarūpakāni tiṇāni uppāṭetvā parisuddhaṃ kātabbaṃ.
commentary_english: 514. "Niddāyitabbanti": the grass with roots should be pulled out and the area made perfectly clean.

mula_pali: 515. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, lohicca, idhekacco satthā yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito hoti, svāssa sāmaññattho anuppatto hoti. So taṃ sāmaññatthaṃ anupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti – ‘‘idaṃ vo hitāya idaṃ vo sukhāyā’’ti. Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti. So evamassa codetabbo – ‘‘āyasmā kho yassatthāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, so te sāmaññattho anuppatto. Taṃ tvaṃ sāmaññatthaṃ anupāpuṇitvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ desesi – ‘idaṃ vo hitāya idaṃ vo sukhāyā’ti. Tassa te sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhapenti , vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti. Seyyathāpi nāma purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā aññaṃ navaṃ bandhanaṃ kareyya, evaṃ sampadamidaṃ pāpakaṃ lobhadhammaṃ vadāmi, kiñhi paro parassa karissatī’’ti. Ayaṃ kho, lohicca, tatiyo satthā, yo loke codanāraho; yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjā.
