Ime  kho, lohicca, tayo satthāro, ye loke codanārahā, yo ca panevarūpe satthāro codeti, sā codanā bhūtā tacchā dhammikā anavajjāti.
mula_english:
Again, Lohicca, here is a certain teacher (satthā) who has gone forth from the household life into homelessness for a certain purpose (yassatthāya), and he has gained the goal of asceticism (sāmaññattho anuppatto hoti).

And without having attained (anupāpuṇitvā) that goal of asceticism (sāmaññatthaṃ), he teaches (deseti) the Dharma (dhammaṃ) to his disciples (sāvakānaṃ), saying: "This is for your good (hitāya), this is for your happiness (sukhāya)."

His disciples (sāvakā) do not want to hear (na sussūsanti), they do not listen (na sotaṃ odahanti), they do not direct (upaṭṭhapenti) their minds (cittaṃ) to understand (aññā), and they err and turn aside from the Teacher's Dispensation (satthusāsanā vattanti).

He should be blamed (codetabbo) thus: "Venerable one (āyasmā), the goal (attho) for which you went forth (pabbajito) from the household life (agārasmā) into homelessness (anagāriyaṃ), that goal of asceticism (sāmaññattho) has not been attained (anuppatto).

Without having attained (anupāpuṇitvā) that goal of asceticism (sāmaññatthaṃ), you teach (desesi) the Dharma (dhammaṃ) to your disciples (sāvakānaṃ), saying: 'This is for your good (hitāya), this is for your happiness (sukhāya).'

Your disciples (sāvakā) do not want to hear (na sussūsanti), they do not listen (na sotaṃ odahanti), they do not direct (upaṭṭhapenti) their minds (cittaṃ) to understand (aññā), and they err and turn aside from the Teacher's Dispensation (satthusāsanā vattanti)."

Just as if, having cut through an old bond (purāṇaṃ bandhanaṃ chinditvā), one were to make (kareyya) another new bond (navaṃ bandhanaṃ), so too, I declare (vadāmi) that this is an evil (pāpakaṃ) teaching (dhammaṃ) rooted in attachment (lobha), for what can one person (paro) do for another (parassa karissati)?"

This, Lohicca, is the third teacher (tatiyo satthā) who is blameworthy (codanāraho) in the world (loke); and if anyone blames (codeti) such a teacher (satthāraṃ), that blame (codanā) is proper (bhūtā), true (tacchā), in accordance with Dharma (dhammikā), and faultless (anavajjā).

These, Lohicca, are the three teachers (tayo satthāro) who are blameworthy (codanārahā) in the world (loke); and if anyone blames (codeti) such teachers (satthāro), that blame (codanā) is proper (bhūtā), true (tacchā), in accordance with Dharma (dhammikā), and faultless (anavajjā).
commentary_pali: 515. Tatiyacodanāya kiñhi paro parassāti anusāsanaṃ asampaṭicchanakālato paṭṭhāya paro anusāsitabbo, parassa  anusāsakassa kiṃ karissatīti nanu tattha appossukkataṃ āpajjitvā attanā paṭividdhadhammaṃ attanāva mānetvā pūjetvā vihātabbanti evaṃ codanaṃ arahatīti attho.
commentary_english: 515. Because of the third urging, why should one person instruct another, saying, "What will he do for the instructor of another person?", since from the time of non-acceptance of instruction, another person is to be instructed; indeed, having fallen into lack of eagerness there, having esteemed and venerated the Dharma realized by oneself, one should live; thus, this urging is worthy, such is the meaning.

mula_pali: 516. Evaṃ vutte, lohicco brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘atthi pana, bho gotama, koci satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho’’ti? ‘‘Atthi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho’’ti. ‘‘Katamo pana so, bho gotama, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho’’ti? ‘‘Idha, lohicca, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ, sammāsambuddho…pe… (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, lohicca, bhikkhu sīlasampanno  hoti…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…  yasmiṃ kho, lohicca, satthari sāvako evarūpaṃ uḷāraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho . Yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā abhūtā atacchā adhammikā sāvajjā…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe…  catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Yasmiṃ kho, lohicca, satthari sāvako evarūpaṃ uḷāraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho, yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā abhūtā atacchā adhammikā sāvajjā… ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe… yasmiṃ kho, lohicca, satthari sāvako evarūpaṃ uḷāraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke nacodanāraho, yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā abhūtā atacchā adhammikā sāvajjā… nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti. Yasmiṃ kho, lohicca, satthari sāvako evarūpaṃ uḷāraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchati, ayampi kho, lohicca, satthā, yo loke  nacodanāraho, yo ca panevarūpaṃ satthāraṃ codeti, sā codanā abhūtā atacchā adhammikā sāvajjā’’ti.
mula_english:
516.

When this had been said, the brahmin Lohicca said to the Blessed One: "But, Master Gotama, is there any teacher in the world who is not worthy of blame?" "There is, Lohicca, a teacher in the world who is not worthy of blame."

"But which teacher, Master Gotama, is not worthy of blame in the world?" "Here, Lohicca, the *Tathāgata* arises in the world, a worthy one, a *sammāsambuddha*…pe… (as at paragraphs 190-212, so it should be expounded in detail).

Thus, Lohicca, a *bhikkhu* is accomplished in virtue…pe…enters and abides in the first *jhāna*… Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple attains to such excellent distinction in a teacher, that is a teacher, Lohicca, who is not to be blamed in the world.

And if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is improper, untrue, not in accordance with *dharma*, and faulty…pe… the second *jhāna*…pe… the third *jhāna*…pe… enters and abides in the fourth *jhāna*.

Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple attains to such excellent distinction in a teacher, that is a teacher, Lohicca, who is not to be blamed in the world. And if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is improper, untrue, not in accordance with *dharma*, and faulty… he directs and inclines his mind to knowledge and vision…pe… Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple attains to such excellent distinction in a teacher, that is a teacher, Lohicca, who is not to be blamed in the world. And if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is improper, untrue, not in accordance with *dharma*, and faulty… he understands, ‘There is nothing further here.’

Whenever, Lohicca, a disciple attains to such excellent distinction in a teacher, that is a teacher, Lohicca, who is not to be blamed in the world. And if anyone blames that kind of teacher, that blame is improper, untrue, not in accordance with *dharma*, and faulty.’
commentary_pali: 516.Nacodanārahoti ayañhi yasmā paṭhamameva attānaṃ patirūpe patiṭṭhāpetvā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti. Sāvakā cassa assavā hutvā yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjanti, tāya ca paṭipattiyā mahantaṃ visesamadhigacchanti. Tasmā na codanārahoti.
commentary_english:
516.
He is not worthy of censure, for he first establishes himself in what is appropriate and then teaches the *dharma* to his disciples.
And his disciples, being obedient, practice according to his instructions, and by that practice they attain great distinction.
Therefore, he is not worthy of censure.

mula_pali: 517. Evaṃ vutte, lohicco brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘seyyathāpi, bho gotama, puriso purisaṃ narakapapātaṃ patantaṃ kesesu gahetvā uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhapeyya, evamevāhaṃ bhotā gotamena narakapapātaṃ papatanto uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpito. Abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya, ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti. Evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito . Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti.
mula_english:
517. When this was said, the Brahmin Lohicca said to the Blessed One: "Just as, venerable Gotama, a man might seize someone by the hair who had stumbled and was falling into a pit of hell ( *naraka-papāta*), and, having lifted him out, set him on firm ground—just so, I, who was falling into the pit of hell, have been saved by the venerable Gotama!
Excellent, venerable Gotama, excellent! Just as, venerable Gotama, one might set upright what has been overturned (*nikkujjitaṃ...ukkujjeyya*), or uncover what is hidden (*paṭicchannaṃ...vivareyya*), or show the way to one who is lost (*mūḷhassa...maggaṃ ācikkheyya*), or hold up an oil lamp (*telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya*) in the dark so that those with eyes could see forms (*cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī*).
Just so, venerable Gotama, the *dharma* has been made clear in many ways (*aneka-pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito*).
I go to the venerable Gotama for refuge (*saraṇaṃ gacchāmi*), and to the *dharma*, and to the *bhikkhu-saṅgha*.
May the venerable Gotama remember me as a lay follower (*upāsaka*) who has gone to him for refuge from this day forth, as long as life shall last."
commentary_pali: 517.Narakapapātaṃ papatantoti mayā gahitāya diṭṭhiyā ahaṃ narakapapātaṃ papatanto. Uddharitvāthale patiṭṭhāpitoti taṃ diṭṭhiṃ bhinditvā dhammadesanāhatthena apāyapatanato uddharitvā saggamaggathale ṭhapitomhīti vadati. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
commentary_english:
517. Because of the view that I held, "I am falling into the **hell-precipice** (narakapapātaṃ papatanto)," I was indeed falling into the **hell-precipice** (narakapapātaṃ papatanto).

Having lifted me up and established me on firm ground, having shattered that view and with the hand of the teaching of the Dharma, having rescued me from falling into the **lower realms** (apāya), I have been placed on the ground of the path to heaven," so he says.

The rest here is evident.

mula_pali: 300. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā aṅgesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena campā tadavasari. Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre. Tena kho pana samayena soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo campaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was traveling among the Aṅgas with a large Saṅgha of monks, about five hundred in all, and he arrived at Campā.

There, it is said, the Blessed One was staying near Campā, on the bank of the Gaggarā lotus pond.

At that time, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa was living in Campā, a place teeming with life, abundant in grass, timber, and water, and rich in grain. It was a royal domain, granted by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha as a royal gift (rājadāya) and a sacred grant (brahmadeyya).
commentary_pali: 300. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ…pe… aṅgesūti soṇadaṇḍasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Aṅgesūti aṅgā nāma aṅgapāsādikatāya evaṃ laddhavohārā jānapadino rājakumārā, tesaṃ nivāso ekopi janapado rūḷhisaddena aṅgāti vuccati, tasmiṃ aṅgesu janapade. Cārikanti idhāpi aturitacārikā ceva nibaddhacārikā ca adhippetā. Tadā kira bhagavato dasasahassilokadhātuṃ olokentassa soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo ñāṇajālassa anto paññāyittha. Atha bhagavā ayaṃ brāhmaṇo mayhaṃ ñāṇajāle paññāyati. ‘Atthi nu khvassupanissayo’ti vīmaṃsanto addasa. ‘Mayi tattha gate etassa antevāsino dvādasahākārehi brāhmaṇassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitvā mama santike āgantuṃ na dassanti. So pana tesaṃ vādaṃ bhinditvā ekūnatiṃsa ākārehi mama vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitvā maṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchissati. So pañhavissajjanapariyosāne saraṇaṃ gamissatī’ti, disvā pañcasatabhikkhuparivāro taṃ janapadaṃ paṭipanno. Tena vuttaṃ – aṅgesu cārikaṃ caramāno…pe… yena campā tadavasarīti. Gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti tassa campānagarassa avidūre gaggarāya nāma rājaggamahesiyā khaṇitattā gaggarāti laddhavohārā pokkharaṇī atthi. Tassā tīre samantato nīlādipañcavaṇṇakusumapaṭimaṇḍitaṃ  mahantaṃ campakavanaṃ. Tasmiṃ bhagavā kusumagandhasugandhe campakavane viharati. Taṃ sandhāya gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti vuttaṃ. Māgadhena seniyena bimbisārenāti ettha so rājā magadhānaṃ issarattā māgadho. Mahatiyā senāya samannāgatattā seniyo. Bimbīti suvaṇṇaṃ. Tasmā sārasuvaṇṇasadisavaṇṇatāya bimbisāroti vuccati.
commentary_english:
Thus I have heard…pe… Soṇadaṇḍasuttaṃ [ends] with "in Aṅga".

Here begins the explanation of unusual words.

"In Aṅga" means: the *jānapadino rājakumārā*, the princes of the countryside, who have obtained the designation *aṅga* because of their charming and pleasing limbs, their residence, even a single one, is called Aṅga with a conventional term; [that is], in that Aṅga country.

"*Cārika*" means: here, both unhurried wandering (*aturitacārikā*) and constant wandering (*nibaddhacārikā*) are intended.

Then, it seems that when the Blessed One was looking at the ten-thousand world-system, the brāhmaṇa Soṇadaṇḍa appeared within the net of his knowledge (*ñāṇajāla*).

Then the Blessed One [thought]: "This brāhmaṇa appears in my net of knowledge."

Reflecting, "'Does he have a supporting condition? (*upanissaya*)'," he saw.

"'When I go there, his pupils will not allow me to come near him, having spoken of the virtues (*vaṇṇa*) of the brāhmaṇa with twelve characteristics (*dvādasahākārehi*).

But, having broken their argument (*vādaṃ bhinditvā*), having spoken of my virtues (*vaṇṇaṃ bhāsitvā*) with twenty-nine characteristics (*ekūnatiṃsa ākārehi*), he will approach me (*upasaṅkamitvā*) and ask a question (*pañhaṃ pucchissati*).

He will go for refuge (*saraṇaṃ gamissati*) at the end of the question and answer (*pañhavissajjanapariyosāne*,'" having seen [this], he set out for that country accompanied by a retinue of five hundred monks (*pañcasatabhikkhuparivāro taṃ janapadaṃ paṭipanno*).

Therefore it was said: "wandering in Aṅga (*aṅgesu cārikaṃ caramāno*)…pe… to which Campā he arrived (*yena campā tadavasarīti*)."

"On the bank of Gaggara's lotus pond (*gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti*)" means: not far from that city of Campā there is a lotus pond (*pokkharaṇī*) named Gaggarā, having obtained the designation "Gaggarā" because it was dug by a chief queen (*rājaggamahesiyā*) named Gaggarā (*gaggarāya nāma*).

On its bank, all around, [is] a large *campaka* forest (*mahantaṃ campakavanaṃ*) adorned with flowers of blue (*nīla*), and other five colors (*pañcavaṇṇa*).

In that *campaka* forest, fragrant with the scent of flowers (*kusumagandhasugandhe campakavane*), the Blessed One stayed (*viharati*).

Referring to that, it was said, "On the bank of Gaggara's lotus pond (*gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīreti vuttaṃ*)."

"By Māgadha, Seniya, Bimbisāra (*māgadhena seniyena bimbisārenāti*)" here, that king is called *māgadha* because he is the lord (*issarattā*) of the Magadhas.

He is called Seniya because he is endowed with a great army (*mahatiyā senāya samannāgatattā seniyo*).

"*Bimbī*" means gold (*suvaṇṇaṃ*).

Therefore, he is called Bimbisāra because his complexion (*vaṇṇatāya*) is like excellent gold (*sārasuvaṇṇa*).

mula_pali: 301. Assosuṃ kho campeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā – ‘‘samaṇo khalu bho gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito aṅgesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi campaṃ anuppatto campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ  hotī’’ti. Atha  kho campeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā campāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī saṅghā saṅghī (sī. syā. pī.) gaṇībhūtā yena gaggarā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkamanti.
mula_english:
301. The *brāhmaṇa* householders of Campā heard: "The *śramaṇa* Gotama, a son of the Śākyas who went forth from the Śākya clan, is wandering in the land of the Aṅgas with a large *bhikkhu-saṅgha*, with about five hundred *bhikkhus*, and he has now arrived at Campā and is living on the banks of Gaggara's lotus pond.

Now, a good report of Master Gotama has been spread to this effect: ‘That Blessed One is an *arhat*, a fully-enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), perfected in knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a Well-Farer (*sugato*), Knower of the worlds (*lokavidū*), unequalled Trainer of men to be tamed (*anuttaro purisadammasārathi*), Teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a Buddha (*buddho*), a Blessed Lord (*bhagavā*)’."

He proclaims this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its Māras (*samārakaṃ*), and its Brahmās (*sabrahmakaṃ*), this generation with its *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ*), its rulers and its people, which he has himself realised by direct knowledge (*abhiññā*).

He teaches the *dharma* that is good at the beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), and good at the end (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*), with its true meaning (*sātthaṃ*) and well-articulated expression (*sabyañjanaṃ*); he reveals the spiritual life (*brahmacariyaṃ*) that is utterly perfect (*kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ*) and pure (*parisuddhaṃ*).

"It's good to see such *arhat*s."

Then the *brāhmaṇa* householders of Campā, leaving Campā in crowds, gathered together and went to Gaggara's lotus pond.
commentary_pali: 301-302. Bahū bahū hutvā saṃhatāti saṅghā. Ekekissāya disāya saṅgho etesaṃ atthīti saṅghī. Pubbe nagarassa anto agaṇā bahi nikkhamitvā gaṇataṃ pattāti gaṇībhūtā. Khattaṃ  āmantesīti. Khattā vuccati pucchitapañhe byākaraṇasamattho mahāmatto, taṃ āmantesi āgamentūti muhuttaṃ paṭimānentu, mā gacchantūti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
301-302.
*Saṅgha* means many coming together having sacrificed much.
*Saṅghī* means that each direction has a *saṅgha*.
*Gaṇībhūtā* means previously, those that were not a group inside the city, having exited outside, attained a group.
He addressed the steward (*khattaṃ āmantesi*).
*Khatta* means a great minister (*mahāmatta*) capable of answering a question that has been asked. He addressed him, meaning, "Let them come, wait a moment, do not let them go," is what was said.

mula_pali: 302. Tena kho pana samayena soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo uparipāsāde divāseyyaṃ upagato hoti. Addasā kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo campeyyake brāhmaṇagahapatike campāya nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī saṅghe saṅghī (sī. pī.) saṅghā saṅghī (syā.) gaṇībhūte yena gaggarā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkamante. Disvā khattaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘kiṃ nu kho, bho khatte, campeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā campāya  nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā yena gaggarā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkamantī’’ti? ‘‘Atthi kho, bho, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito aṅgesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi campaṃ anuppatto campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti. Tamete bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamantī’’ti. ‘‘Tena hi, bho khatte, yena campeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama, upasaṅkamitvā campeyyake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṃ vadehi – ‘soṇadaṇḍo, bho, brāhmaṇo evamāha – āgamentu kira bhavanto, soṇadaṇḍopi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho so khattā soṇadaṇḍassa  brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena campeyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā campeyyake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca – ‘‘soṇadaṇḍo  bho brāhmaṇo evamāha – ‘āgamentu kira bhavanto, soṇadaṇḍopi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’’ti.
mula_english:
Just then, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa had gone up to the upper story of his palace for his midday rest.

Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin saw the Brahmins and householders of Campā going out from Campā in crowds and groups, in large numbers, heading towards Gaggara's lotus pond.

Seeing this, he addressed his steward: "What is the reason, good steward, that the Brahmins and householders of Campā are leaving Campā in such crowds and numbers, heading towards Gaggara's lotus pond?" "There is, sir, the ascetic Gotama, a son of the Śākya clan, who has gone forth from the Śākya family. He is wandering in the Aṅga region with a large Saṅgha of monks, about five hundred monks, and has arrived at Campā and is staying near Gaggara’s lotus pond.

And concerning that Venerable Gotama, a good report has spread about: ‘Indeed, the Blessed One is an Arhat, a fully enlightened Buddha ( *sammāsambuddha* ), perfect in knowledge and conduct ( *vijjācaraṇasampanno* ), a Well-Farer ( *sugato* ), knower of the worlds ( *lokavidū* ), incomparable leader of persons to be tamed ( *anuttaro purisadammasārathi* ), teacher of gods and humans ( *satthā devamanussānaṃ* ), enlightened ( *buddho* ), blessed ( *bhagavā* ).

That is why they are going to see the Venerable Gotama.’"

"Then, good steward, go to the Brahmins and householders of Campā and tell them: 'The Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa says this: "Please wait, gentlemen, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa will also go to see the *samaṇa* Gotama."'"

"As you say, sir," the steward replied to Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, and then went to the Brahmins and householders of Campā. Approaching them, he said, "The Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa says this: 'Please wait, gentlemen, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa will also go to see the *samaṇa* Gotama.'"
commentary_pali: 301-302. Bahū bahū hutvā saṃhatāti saṅghā. Ekekissāya disāya saṅgho etesaṃ atthīti saṅghī. Pubbe nagarassa anto agaṇā bahi nikkhamitvā gaṇataṃ pattāti gaṇībhūtā. Khattaṃ  āmantesīti. Khattā vuccati pucchitapañhe byākaraṇasamattho mahāmatto, taṃ āmantesi āgamentūti muhuttaṃ paṭimānentu, mā gacchantūti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
301-302.
saṅgha means many coming together, offering many sacrifices.
saṅghī means each direction has a community/assemblage for them.
gaṇībhūtā means previously, those who were not a group inside the city, went outside and attained the state of being a group.
He addressed the steward.
*khattā* means a great minister capable of explaining questions that are asked. He addressed him, meaning, "Let them come; let them wait a moment; let them not go," that is what was said.

mula_pali: 303. Tena kho pana samayena nānāverajjakānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ pañcamattāni brāhmaṇasatāni campāyaṃ paṭivasanti kenacideva karaṇīyena. Assosuṃ kho te brāhmaṇā – ‘‘soṇadaṇḍo kira brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’ti. Atha kho te brāhmaṇā yena soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā soṇadaṇḍaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘saccaṃ kira bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ kho me, bho, hoti – ‘ahampi samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmī’’’ti. ‘‘Mā bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkami. Na arahati bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Sace bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissati, bhoto  soṇadaṇḍassa yaso hāyissati, samaṇassa gotamassa yaso abhivaḍḍhissati. Yampi bhoto soṇadaṇḍassa yaso hāyissati, samaṇassa gotamassa yaso abhivaḍḍhissati , imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ; samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ soṇadaṇḍaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Yampi bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ; samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ soṇadaṇḍaṃ dassanāya  upasaṅkamituṃ. ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo ajjhāyako , mantadharo, tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī brahmaḍḍhī (sī.), brahmavaccasī (pī.) akhuddāvakāso dassanāya…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya aneḷagalāya (sī. pī.), anelagaḷāya (ka) atthassa viññāpaniyā…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo tīṇi māṇavakasatāni mante vāceti. Bahū kho pana nānādisā nānājanapadā māṇavakā āgacchanti  bhoto soṇadaṇḍassa santike mantatthikā mante adhiyitukāmā  …pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto; samaṇo gotamo taruṇo ceva taruṇapabbajito ca…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi  soṇadaṇḍo rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo campaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ, raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ, rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ. Yampi bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo campaṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ, raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ, rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ. Imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ; samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ soṇadaṇḍaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitu’’nti.
mula_english:
Now at that time, some five hundred Brahmins from various provinces were residing in Campā (Campā) on some business.

The Brahmins heard, "It is said that the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa (Śoṇadaṇḍa) will visit the ascetic Gotama (Gautama) to see him."

Then those Brahmins approached the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa; having approached, they said this to the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa: "Is it true, sir, that you, Soṇadaṇḍa, will visit the ascetic Gotama to see him?" "Yes, indeed, sirs, it occurs to me: 'I too will visit the ascetic Gotama to see him.'"

"Sir, do not visit the ascetic Gotama to see him.

It is not proper that you, Soṇadaṇḍa, should visit the ascetic Gotama to see him.

If you, Soṇadaṇḍa, visit the ascetic Gotama to see him, your, Soṇadaṇḍa's, fame will decrease, and the ascetic Gotama's fame will increase.

Moreover, your, Soṇadaṇḍa's, fame will decrease, and the ascetic Gotama's fame will increase; for this reason, it is not proper that you, Soṇadaṇḍa, should visit the ascetic Gotama to see him; rather, the ascetic Gotama should visit you, Soṇadaṇḍa, to see you.

"For you, Soṇadaṇḍa, are well-born on both sides, from mother and father, of pure descent up to the seventh generation of ancestors, unblemished, irreproachable in regard to birth.

Moreover, because you, Soṇadaṇḍa, are well-born on both sides, from mother and father, of pure descent up to the seventh generation of ancestors, unblemished, irreproachable in regard to birth, for this reason it is not proper that you, Soṇadaṇḍa, should visit the ascetic Gotama to see him; rather, the ascetic Gotama should visit you, Soṇadaṇḍa, to see you.

"For you, Soṇadaṇḍa, are rich, with great wealth and great possessions... Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is a scholar, versed in the mantras, accomplished in the Three Vedas (Tri-veda), a skilled expounder of the rules and rituals, the lore of sounds and meanings and, fifthly, oral tradition — an expounder, fully versed in natural philosophy and the marks of a Great Man… Moreover, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is handsome, comely, and graceful, possessing supreme beauty of complexion, with sublime beauty and sublime presence...

)... irreproachable in appearance... Moreover, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is virtuous, mature in virtue, endowed with mature virtue... Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is of good speech, speaks pleasantly, endowed with polished speech, fluent, without hesitation, understandable in meaning...

Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is the teacher of many teachers, he teaches the *mantras* (mantra) to three hundred young Brahmins.

Moreover, many young men from various regions and various districts come to the presence of the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa, desiring *mantras*, wishing to learn the *mantras*... Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is old, aged, advanced in years, having reached the end of his life, advanced in age; the ascetic Gotama is young, newly gone forth... Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is honored, respected, esteemed, venerated, and revered by King Seniya Bimbisāra (Śreṇika Bimbisāra) of Magadha (Magadha)... Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa is honored, respected, esteemed, venerated, and revered by the Brahmin Pokkharasāti (Pauṣkarasāti)... Furthermore, the Reverend Soṇadaṇḍa resides in Campā, which is populous, with grass, timber, water and grain in abundance, a royal appanage, given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, a royal grant, a *brahmadeyya* (brahmadeyya) gift.

Moreover, because you, Soṇadaṇḍa, reside in Campā, which is populous, with grass, timber, water and grain in abundance, a royal appanage, given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, a royal grant, a *brahmadeyya* gift.

For this reason, it is not proper that you, Soṇadaṇḍa, should visit the ascetic Gotama to see him; rather, the ascetic Gotama should visit you, Soṇadaṇḍa, to see you."
commentary_pali: 303.Nānāverajjakānanti  nānāvidhesu rajjesu, aññesu aññesu kāsikosalādīsu rajjesu jātā, tāni vā tesaṃ nivāsā, tato vā āgatāti nānāverajjakā, tesaṃ nānāverajjakānaṃ. Kenacideva karaṇīyenāti tasmiṃ kira nagare dvīhi karaṇīyehi brāhmaṇā sannipatanti – yaññānubhavanatthaṃ vā mantasajjhāyanatthaṃ vā. Tadā ca tasmiṃ nagare yamaññā natthi. Soṇadaṇḍassa pana santike mantasajjhāyanatthaṃ ete sannipatitā. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – ‘‘kenacideva karaṇīyenā’’ti. Te tassa gamanaṃ sutvā cintesuṃ – ‘‘ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo uggatabrāhmaṇo yebhuyyena ca aññe brāhmaṇā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā, ayameva na gato. Svāyaṃ sace tattha gamissati, addhā samaṇassa gotamassa āvaṭṭaniyā māyāya āvaṭṭito, taṃ saraṇaṃ gamissati. Tato etassāpi gehadvāre brāhmaṇānaṃ sannipāto na bhavissatī’’ti. ‘‘Handassa gamanantarāyaṃ karomā’’ti sammantayitvā tattha agamaṃsu. Taṃ sandhāya – atha kho te brāhmaṇātiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha imināpaṅgenāti imināpi kāraṇena. Evaṃ etaṃ kāraṇaṃ vatvā puna – ‘‘attano vaṇṇe bhaññamāne atussanakasatto nāma natthi. Handassa vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanena gamanaṃ nivāressāmā’’ti cintetvā bhavañhi soṇadaṇḍo ubhato sujātotiādīni kāraṇāni āhaṃsu. Ubhatoti dvīhi pakkhehi. Mātito ca pitito cāti bhoto mātā brāhmaṇī, mātumātā brāhmaṇī, tassāpi mātā brāhmaṇī; pitā brāhmaṇo, pitupitā brāhmaṇo, tassāpi pitā brāhmaṇoti, evaṃ bhavaṃ ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca. Saṃsuddhagahaṇikoti saṃsuddhā te mātugahaṇī kucchīti attho. Samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyāti ettha pana kammajatejodhātu ‘‘gahaṇī’’ti vuccati. Yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti ettha pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṃ pitāmahayugaṃ. Yuganti āyuppamāṇaṃ vuccati. Abhilāpamattameva cetaṃ. Atthato pana pitāmahoyeva pitāmahayugaṃ. Tato uddhaṃ sabbepi pubbapurisā pitāmahaggahaṇeneva gahitā. Evaṃ yāva sattamo puriso , tāva saṃsuddhagahaṇiko. Atha vā akkhitto anupakuṭṭho jātivādenāti dassenti. Akkhittoti – ‘‘apanetha etaṃ, kiṃ iminā’’ti evaṃ akkhitto anavakkhitto. Anupakuṭṭhoti na upakuṭṭho, na akkosaṃ vā nindaṃ vā laddhapubbo. Kena kāraṇenāti? Jātivādena. Itipi – ‘‘hīnajātiko eso’’ti evarūpena vacanenāti attho. Aḍḍhoti issaro. Mahaddhanoti mahatā dhanena samannāgato. Bhavato hi gehe pathaviyaṃ paṃsuvālikā viya bahudhanaṃ, samaṇo pana gotamo adhano bhikkhāya udaraṃ pūretvā yāpetīti dassenti. Mahābhogoti pañcakāmaguṇavasena mahāupabhogo. Evaṃ yaṃ yaṃ guṇaṃ vadanti, tassa tassa paṭipakkhavasena bhagavato aguṇaṃyeva dassemāti maññamānā vadanti. Abhirūpoti aññehi manussehi abhirūpo adhikarūpo. Dassanīyoti divasampi passantānaṃ atittikaraṇato dassanayoggo. Dassaneneva cittapasādajananato pāsādiko. Pokkharatā  vuccati sundarabhāvo, vaṇṇassa pokkharatā vaṇṇapokkharatā, tāya vaṇṇasampattiyā yuttoti attho. Porāṇā panāhu – ‘‘pokkharanti sarīraṃ vadanti, vaṇṇaṃ vaṇṇamevā’’ti. Tesaṃ matena vaṇṇañca pokkharañca vaṇṇapokkharāni. Tesaṃ bhāvo vaṇṇapokkharatā. Iti paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāyāti uttamena parisuddhena vaṇṇena ceva sarīrasaṇṭhānasampattiyā cāti attho. Brahmavaṇṇīti seṭṭhavaṇṇī. Parisuddhavaṇṇesupi seṭṭhena suvaṇṇavaṇṇena samannāgatoti attho. Brahmavacchasīti mahābrahmuno sarīrasadiseneva sarīrena samannāgato. Akhuddāvakāso dassanāyāti ‘‘bhoto sarīre dassanassa okāso na khuddako mahā, sabbāneva te aṅgapaccaṅgāni dassanīyāneva, tāni cāpi mahantānevā’’ti dīpenti. Sīlamassa atthīti sīlavā. Vuddhaṃ vaddhitaṃ sīlamassāti vuddhasīlī. Vuddhasīlenāti vuddhena vaddhitena sīlena. Samannāgatoti yutto. Idaṃ vuddhasīlīpadasseva vevacanaṃ. Sabbametaṃ pañcasīlamattameva sandhāya vadanti. Kalyāṇavācotiādīsu kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā vācā assāti kalyāṇavāco. Kalyāṇaṃ madhuraṃ vākkaraṇaṃ assāti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo. Vākkaraṇanti udāharaṇaghoso. Guṇaparipuṇṇabhāvena pure bhavāti porī. Pure vā bhavattā porī. Poriyā nāgarikitthiyā sukhumālattanena sadisāti porī, tāya poriyā. Vissaṭṭhāyāti apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭhavilambitādidosarahitāya. Anelagalāyāti elagaḷenavirahitāya. Yassa kassaci hi kathentassa  elā gaḷanti, lālā vā paggharanti, kheḷaphusitāni vā nikkhamanti, tassa vācā elagaḷaṃ nāma hoti, tabbiparitāyāti attho. Atthassa viññāpaniyāti ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā bhāsitatthassa viññāpanasamatthāya. Jiṇṇoti  jarājiṇṇatāya jiṇṇo. Vuddhoti aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ vuddhibhāvamariyādappatto. Mahallakoti jātimahallakatāya samannāgato. Cirakālappasutoti vuttaṃ hoti. Addhagatoti addhānaṃ gato, dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe atītoti adhippāyo. Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ sampatto, pacchimavayo nāma vassasatassa pacchimo tatiyabhāgo. Api ca jiṇṇoti porāṇo, cirakālappavattakulanvayoti vuttaṃ hoti. Vuddhoti sīlācārādiguṇavuddhiyā yutto. Mahallakoti vibhavamahantāya samannāgato. Addhagatoti maggappaṭipanno brāhmaṇānaṃ vatacariyādimariyādaṃ avītikkamma caraṇasīlo. Vayoanuppattoti jātivuddhabhāvampi antimavayaṃ anuppatto.
commentary_english:
303.

*Nānāverajjakānanti* means born in various kingdoms, in different kingdoms like Kāśi, Kosala, etc.; or those kingdoms are their residences, or from there they have come, therefore *nānāverajjakā*; to those various foreigners.

*Kenacideva karaṇīyenāti* means in that city, brahmins gather for two reasons—either for experiencing sacrifice, or for the purpose of reciting mantras.

Then in that city, there was no *yamaññā*.

But near Soṇadaṇḍa, they gathered for the purpose of reciting mantras.

Referring to that, it was said, "*kenacideva karaṇīyenā*."

Having heard of his going, they thought, "This Soṇadaṇḍa is a well-known *brāhmaṇa*, and most of the other *brāhmaṇas* have gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama for refuge; only he has not gone.

If he goes there himself, surely he will be captivated by the captivating illusion of the *śramaṇa* Gotama, and he will go to him for refuge.

Then there will be no gathering of *brāhmaṇas* even at his house-door."

"Let us create an obstacle to his going," having conferred, they went there.

Referring to that, it was said, "*atha kho te brāhmaṇātiādi vuttaṃ*."

There, *imināpaṅgenāti* means also by this reason.

Thus, having spoken this reason, again, "There is no one named *atussanakasatto* when his own qualities are being spoken.

We will prevent his going by speaking about Handa's qualities," thinking thus, indeed, Soṇadaṇḍa is well-born on both sides, they spoke such reasons.

*Ubhatoti* means by two sides.

"*Mātito ca pitito cāti* means Bhoto's mother is a *brāhmaṇī*, his mother's mother is a *brāhmaṇī*, even her mother is a *brāhmaṇī*; his father is a *brāhmaṇa*, his father's father is a *brāhmaṇa*, even his father is a *brāhmaṇa*. Thus, Bhavaṃ is well-born on both sides, from the mother's side and from the father's side.

*Saṃsuddhagahaṇikoti* means their mothers' wombs are pure, this is the meaning.

"*Samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyāti*" here, however, the *kammajatejodhātu* is called "*gahaṇī*."

*Yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti* here, the father's father is the paternal grandfather, the grandfather's lineage is the paternal grandfather's lineage.

*Yuganti* means it is called the measure of life.

This is merely a verbal expression.

In reality, however, the paternal grandfather himself is the *pitāmahayuga*.

From that upward, all the former men are included by the term *pitāmahaggahaṇeneva*.

Thus, up to the seventh person, he is *saṃsuddhagahaṇiko*.

Or else, they show that he is *akkhitto anupakuṭṭho jātivādenāti*.

*Akkhittoti* means "*apanetha etaṃ, kiṃ iminā*," thus, *akkhitto anavakkhitto*.

*Anupakuṭṭhoti* means he is not *upakuṭṭho*, he has never received abuse or scorn.

By what reason? By reason of caste.

*Itipi* means "*hīnajātiko eso*," the meaning is by such words.

*Aḍḍhoti* means he is powerful ( *īśvara*).

*Mahaddhanoti* means he is endowed with great wealth.

Indeed, in Bhavaṃ's house, there is much wealth like gravel on the earth, but the *śramaṇa* Gotama is without wealth, filling his stomach with alms food and maintaining himself, they show.

*Mahābhogoti* means having great enjoyment, having great experience of the five desirable qualities.

Thus, whatever qualities they speak of, thinking, "We will show the opposite of those qualities, indeed, the lack of qualities of the Bhagavat," they speak.

*Abhirūpoti* means he is more handsome, more beautiful than other men.

*Dassanīyoti* means he is fit to be seen, since he does not cause satiety even to those who see him for a day.

*Dassaneneva cittapasādajananato pāsādiko* means he is pleasing since he produces clarity of mind just by being seen.

*Pokkharatā vuccati sundarabhāvo*, *vaṇṇassa pokkharatā vaṇṇapokkharatā*, by that, he is endowed with excellence of complexion, this is the meaning.

The ancients, however, said, "*pokkharanti sarīraṃ vadanti*, they say *vaṇṇa* is complexion itself."

In their opinion, *vaṇṇa* and *pokkhara* are *vaṇṇapokkharāni*.
Their state is *vaṇṇapokkharatā*.

Thus, *vaṇṇapokkharatā* refers to the supreme, excellent, and utterly pure complexion, as well as the perfection of the body's form. This is the meaning.

*Brahmavaṇṇī* means having the finest complexion.

*Parisuddhavaṇṇesupi seṭṭhena suvaṇṇavaṇṇena samannāgato* means possessing a golden complexion that is superior even among pure complexions. This is the meaning.

*Brahmavacchasī* means possessing a body similar to that of Mahābrahmā.

"*Akhuddāvakāso dassanāyāti* means the opportunity to see the Blessed One's body is not small but great; all his limbs and features are beautiful; they are also very large," thus they illuminate.

*Sīlamassa atthīti sīlavā* means he possesses virtue, therefore he is virtuous ( *śīlavā*).

*Vuddhaṃ vaddhitaṃ sīlamassāti vuddhasīlī* means his virtue is grown and increased, therefore he is one whose virtue is developed ( *vuddhasīlī*).

*Vuddhasīlenāti vuddhena vaddhitena sīlena* means by virtue that is grown and increased.

*Samannāgatoti yutto* means associated, therefore connected.

*Idaṃ vuddhasīlīpadasseva vevacanaṃ* This is a synonym for the term *vuddhasīlī*.

*Sabbametaṃ pañcasīlamattameva sandhāya vadanti* means they speak with reference to just the five precepts.

*Kalyāṇavācotiādīsu kalyāṇā sundarā parimaṇḍalapadabyañjanā vācā assāti kalyāṇavāco* means, among those beginning with "having auspicious speech", *kalyāṇavāco* is someone whose speech is auspicious, beautiful, and endowed with perfectly rounded words and expressions.

*Kalyāṇaṃ madhuraṃ vākkaraṇaṃ assāti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo* means someone whose speech is auspicious and sweet, therefore he has auspicious speech (*kalyāṇavākkaraṇo*).

*Vākkaraṇanti udāharaṇaghoso* means speech is the sound of an example.

*Guṇaparipuṇṇabhāvena pure bhavāti porī* means she exists completely full of qualities in the city, therefore she is a city woman (*porī*).

*Pure vā bhavattā porī* means or, because she exists in the city, she is a city woman (*porī*).

*Poriyā nāgarikitthiyā sukhumālattanena sadisāti porī, tāya poriyā* means, a city woman (*porī*) is similar to a delicate city woman (*porī*), because of that city woman (*poriyā*).

*Vissaṭṭhāyāti apalibuddhāya sandiṭṭhavilambitādidosarahitāya* means articulate, without confusion, and free from defects such as being hurried or slow.

*Anelagalāyāti elagaḷenavirahitāya* means without impediment in the throat.

If while someone is speaking, saliva drips, spittle flows, or phlegm comes out, that speech is called impeded (*elagaḷaṃ*). The meaning is the opposite of that (*tabbiparitāyāti*).

*Atthassa viññāpaniyāti ādimajjhapariyosānaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā bhāsitatthassa viññāpanasamatthāya* means capable of making the meaning known, making clear the meaning of what is spoken by making the beginning, middle, and end evident.

*Jiṇṇoti jarājiṇṇatāya jiṇṇo* means aged, old due to old age.

*Vuddhoti aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ vuddhibhāvamariyādappatto* means increased, having attained the limit of the state of growth of the limbs and features.

*Mahallakoti jātimahallakatāya samannāgato* means elderly, possessing the elderyness of birth.

*Cirakālappasutoti vuttaṃ hoti* means it is said to be long-lived.

*Addhagatoti addhānaṃ gato, dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe atītoti adhippāyo* means aged, he has traveled the road, the intention is that two or three reigns have passed.

*Vayoanuppattoti pacchimavayaṃ sampatto, pacchimavayo nāma vassasatassa pacchimo tatiyabhāgo* means he has attained the last age, the last age is the last third part of a hundred years.

Moreover, *jiṇṇoti porāṇo, cirakālappavattakulanvayoti vuttaṃ hoti* means aged, ancient, it is said to be a lineage of a family that has long existed.

*Vuddhoti sīlācārādiguṇavuddhiyā yutto* means elder, endowed with an increase in virtue, conduct, and other qualities.

*Mahallakoti vibhavamahantāya samannāgato* means elderly, possessing great power.

*Addhagatoti maggappaṭipanno brāhmaṇānaṃ vatacariyādimariyādaṃ avītikkamma caraṇasīlo* means one who has gone the way, one who has undertaken the path, one whose conduct is such that he does not transgress the customs beginning with the observances of the Brahmins.

*Vayoanuppattoti jātivuddhabhāvampi antimavayaṃ anuppatto* means having attained the state of old age, he has also attained the final age.

mula_pali: 304. Evaṃ vutte, soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo te brāhmaṇe etadavoca – ‘‘Tena  hi, bho, mamapi suṇātha, yathā mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ; natveva arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā, akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Yampi bho samaṇo gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā  pitāmahayugā, akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ ; atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo mahantaṃ ñātisaṅghaṃ ohāya pabbajito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajito bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhaṃ ca…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo  khalu, bho, gotamo daharova samāno yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ assumukhānaṃ rudantānaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato, brahmavaṇṇī, brahmavacchasī, akhuddāvakāso dassanāya…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sīlavā ariyasīlī kusalasīlī kusalasīlena samannāgato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khīṇakāmarāgo vigatacāpallo…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kammavādī kiriyavādī apāpapurekkhāro brahmaññāya pajāya…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo uccā kulā pabbajito asambhinnakhattiyakulā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo aḍḍhā  kulā pabbajito mahaddhanā mahābhogā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ  khalu, bho, gotamaṃ tiroraṭṭhā tirojanapadā pañhaṃ pucchituṃ āgacchanti…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ anekāni devatāsahassāni pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gatāni…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ  khalu, bho, gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ ti…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ehisvāgatavādī sakhilo sammodako abbhākuṭiko uttānamukho pubbabhāsī…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo catunnaṃ parisānaṃ sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇe khalu, bho, gotame bahū devā ca manussā ca abhippasannā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo yasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā paṭivasati, na tasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā amanussā manusse viheṭhenti…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo saṅghī gaṇī gaṇācariyo puthutitthakarānaṃ aggamakkhāyati. Yathā kho pana, bho, etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathā vā tathā vā yaso samudāgacchati, na hevaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato. Atha kho anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saputto sabhariyo sapariso  sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ  khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo  khalu, bho, gotamo rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo  khalu, bho, gotamo campaṃ anuppatto, campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre. Ye kho pana, bho, keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amhākaṃ gāmakhettaṃ āgacchanti atithī no te honti. Atithī kho panamhehi sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā apacetabbā. Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo campaṃ anuppatto campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre, atithimhākaṃ samaṇo gotamo; atithi kho panamhehi sakkātabbo garukātabbo mānetabbo pūjetabbo apacetabbo. Imināpaṅgena na arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Ettake kho ahaṃ, bho, tassa bhoto gotamassa vaṇṇe pariyāpuṇāmi, no ca kho so bhavaṃ gotamo ettakavaṇṇo. Aparimāṇavaṇṇo hi so bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti.
mula_english:
304.

When this was said, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa told those Brahmins: “Therefore, sirs, listen to me as to why it is fitting for us to visit the esteemed Gotama for an audience, and why it is not fitting for that esteemed Gotama to visit us for an audience.

“Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is well-born on both sides, from his mother's side and from his father's side, of pure lineage going back seven generations of ancestors, unassailable and irreproachable with respect to his birth.

And since the *śramaṇa* Gotama is well-born on both sides, from his mother's side and from his father's side, of pure lineage going back seven generations of ancestors, unassailable and irreproachable with respect to his birth, for this reason it is not fitting for that esteemed Gotama to visit us for an audience; but rather, it is fitting for us to visit that esteemed Gotama for an audience.

“Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has gone forth, abandoning a large circle of relatives…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has gone forth, abandoning abundant gold and silver, both buried in the ground and in the sky…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, while still young, a youth with black hair, endowed with the beauty of youth, in his early years, went forth from the household life into homelessness…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, against the wishes of his weeping parents with tear-filled faces, shaving off his hair and beard, putting on the ochre robes, went forth from the household life into homelessness…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is handsome, lovely, and inspires confidence, endowed with the utmost beauty of complexion, with a divine color, a divine luster, and is not secretive in giving an audience…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is virtuous, possessing noble virtue, wholesome virtue, endowed with wholesome virtue…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has auspicious speech, auspicious utterance, endowed with refined speech, fluent, without impediment, capable of making known its meaning…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is the teacher of many teachers…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has extinguished passion and is free from restlessness…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is an advocate of action (*karmavādī*), an advocate of deeds (*kiriyavādī*), with pure intention towards those of the Brahmic race…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has gone forth from a high family, from an unmixed warrior family…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has gone forth from a wealthy family, abounding in riches and possessions…pe… “Sirs, people from foreign lands and foreign districts come to the *śramaṇa* Gotama to ask questions…pe… “Sirs, thousands of deities have gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama for refuge with their lives…pe… “Sirs, such a good reputation has gone forth about the *śramaṇa* Gotama: ‘Indeed, the esteemed one is an *arhat*, a perfectly awakened one (*sammāsambuddho*), accomplished in knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a well-gone one (*sugato*), a knower of the world (*lokavidū*), unsurpassed, a guide for those who wish to be tamed (*purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a Buddha, an esteemed one’ ti…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a great man (*dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato*)…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is one who speaks welcoming words, friendly, courteous, without frowns, with an open face, and is a speaker first…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is honored, respected, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated by the four assemblies (*catunnaṃ parisānaṃ*)…pe… “Sirs, many gods and humans are greatly pleased with the *śramaṇa* Gotama…pe… “Sirs, in whatever village or town the *śramaṇa* Gotama resides, non-humans do not harm humans in that village or town…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is the head of an order (*saṅghī*), a group (*gaṇī*), the teacher of a group (*gaṇācariyo*), renowned as the foremost of many sectarians (*puthutitthakarānaṃ*).

“Sirs, the fame that the *śramaṇas* and Brahmins have, in whatever way it arises, the fame of the *śramaṇa* Gotama does not arise in that way.

But rather, the fame of the *śramaṇa* Gotama arises from the unsurpassed accomplishment of knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampadāya*)…pe… “Sirs, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, along with his son, his wives, his retinue, and his ministers, has gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama for refuge with his life…pe… “Sirs, King Pasenadi of Kosala, along with his son, his wives, his retinue, and his ministers, has gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama for refuge with his life…pe… “Sirs, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, along with his son, his wives, his retinue, and his ministers, has gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama for refuge with his life…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is honored, respected, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is honored, respected, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated by King Pasenadi of Kosala…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is honored, respected, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated by the Brahmin Pokkharasāti…pe… “Sirs, the *śramaṇa* Gotama has arrived at Campā, and dwells in Campā on the bank of Gaggara’s lotus pond.

“And whatever *śramaṇas* or Brahmins come to our village territory, they are our guests.

And guests should be honored, respected, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated by us.

And since the *śramaṇa* Gotama has arrived at Campā, and dwells in Campā on the bank of Gaggara’s lotus pond, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is our guest; and guests should be honored, respected, esteemed, worshipped, and venerated by us.

For this reason, it is not fitting for that esteemed Gotama to visit us for an audience.

But rather, it is fitting for us to visit that esteemed Gotama for an audience.

As much as I understand the virtues of the esteemed Gotama, that esteemed Gotama is not limited to those virtues.

Indeed, the esteemed Gotama’s virtues are immeasurable.”
commentary_pali: 304.Evaṃ vutteti evaṃ tehi brāhmaṇehi vutte. Soṇadaṇḍo – ‘‘ime brāhmaṇā jātiādīhi mama vaṇṇaṃ vadanti, na kho pana metaṃ yuttaṃ attano vaṇṇe rajjituṃ. Handāhaṃ etesaṃ vādaṃ bhinditvā samaṇassa gotamassa mahantabhāvaṃ ñāpetvā etesaṃ tattha gamanaṃ karomī’’ti cintetvā tena hi – bho mamapi suṇāthātiādimāha. Tattha yepi ubhato sujātoti ādayo attano guṇehi sadisā guṇā tepi ; ‘‘ko cāhaṃ ke ca samaṇassa gotamassa jātisampattiādayo guṇā’’ti attano guṇehi uttaritareyeva maññamāno, itare pana ekanteneva bhagavato mahantabhāvadīpanatthaṃ pakāseti. Mayameva arahāmāti evaṃ niyāmentovettha idaṃ dīpeti – ‘‘yadi guṇamahantatāya upasaṅkamitabbo nāma hoti. Yathā hi sineruṃ upanidhāya sāsapo, mahāsamuddaṃ upanidhāya gopadakaṃ, sattasu mahāsaresu udakaṃ upanidhāya ussāvabindu paritto lāmako. Evameva samaṇassa gotamassa jātisampattiādayopi guṇe upanidhāya amhākaṃ guṇā parittā lāmakā; tasmā mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitu’’nti. Mahantaṃñātisaṃghaṃ ohāyāti mātipakkhe asītikulasahassāni , pitipakkhe asītikulasahassānīti evaṃ saṭṭhikulasatasahassaṃ ohāya pabbajito. Bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhañcāti ettha rājaṅgaṇe ceva uyyāne ca sudhāmaṭṭhapokkharaṇiyo sattaratanānaṃ pūretvā bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapitaṃ dhanaṃ bhūmigataṃ nāma. Pāsādaniyūhādayo paripūretvā ṭhapitaṃ vehāsaṭṭhaṃ nāma. Etaṃ tāva kulapariyāyena āgataṃ. Tathāgatassa pana jātadivaseyeva saṅkho, elo, uppalo, puṇḍarīkoti cattāro nidhayo uggatā. Tesu saṅkho gāvutiko, elo aḍḍhayojaniko, uppalo tigāvutiko, puṇḍarīko yojaniko. Tesupi gahitaṃ gahitaṃ pūratiyeva, iti bhagavā pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajitoti veditabbo. Daharova samānoti taruṇova samāno. Susukāḷakesoti suṭṭhu kāḷakeso, añjanavaṇṇasadisakeso hutvā vāti attho. Bhadrenāti bhaddakena. Paṭhamena vayasāti tiṇṇaṃ vayānaṃ paṭhamavayena. Akāmakānanti anicchamānānaṃ. Anādaratthe sāmivacanaṃ. Assūni mukhe etesanti assumukhā, tesaṃ assumukhānaṃ, assūhi kilinnamukhānanti attho. Rudantānanti  kanditvā rodamānānaṃ. Akhuddāvakāsoti ettha bhagavato aparimāṇoyeva dassanāya okāsoti veditabbo. Tatridaṃ vatthu – rājagahe kira aññataro brāhmaṇo samaṇassa gotamassa pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkotīti sutvā bhagavato piṇḍāya pavisanakāle saṭṭhihatthaṃ veḷuṃ gahetvā nagaradvārassa bahi ṭhatvā sampatte bhagavati veḷuṃ gahetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi. Veḷu bhagavato jāṇukamattaṃ pāpuṇi. Puna divase dve veḷū ghaṭetvā samīpe aṭṭhāsi. Bhagavāpi dvinnaṃ veḷūnaṃ upari kaṭimattameva paññāyamāno – ‘‘brāhmaṇa, kiṃ karosī’’ti āha. Tumhākaṃ pamāṇaṃ gaṇhāmīti. ‘‘Brāhmaṇa, sacepi tvaṃ sakalacakkavāḷagabbhaṃ pūretvā ṭhite veḷū ghaṭetvā  āgamissasi, neva me pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ sakkhissasi. Na hi mayā cattāri asaṅkhyeyāni kappasatasahassañca tathā pāramiyo pūritā, yathā me paro pamāṇaṃ gaṇheyya, atulo, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato appameyyo’’ti vatvā dhammapade gāthamāha – Gāthāpariyosāne  caturāsītipāṇasahassāni amataṃ piviṃsu. Aparampi vatthu – rāhu kira asurindo cattāri yojanasahassāni aṭṭha ca yojanasatāni ucco. Bāhantaramassa dvādasayojanasatāni. Bahalantarena cha yojanasatāni. Hatthatalapādatalānaṃ puthulato tīṇi yojanasatāni. Aṅgulipabbāni paṇṇāsayojanāni. Bhamukantaraṃ paṇṇāsayojanaṃ. Mukhaṃ dviyojanasataṃ tiyojanasatagambhīraṃ tiyojanasataparimaṇḍalaṃ. Gīvā tiyojanasataṃ. Nalāṭaṃ tiyojanasataṃ. Sīsaṃ navayojanasataṃ. ‘‘So ahaṃ uccosmi, satthāraṃ onamitvā oloketuṃ na sakkhissāmī’’ti cintetvā nāgacchi. So ekadivasaṃ bhagavato vaṇṇaṃ sutvā – ‘‘yathākathañca olokessāmī’’ti āgato. Atha bhagavā tassajjhāsayaṃ viditvā – ‘‘catūsu iriyāpathesu katarena dassessāmī’’ti cintetvā ‘‘ṭhitako nāma nīcopi ucco viya paññāyati. Nipannovassa  attānaṃ dassessāmī’’ti ‘‘ānanda, gandhakuṭipariveṇe mañcakaṃ paññāpehī’’ti vatvā tattha sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi. Rāhu āgantvā nipannaṃ bhagavantaṃ gīvaṃ unnāmetvā nabhamajjhe puṇṇacandaṃ viya ullokesi. Kimidaṃ asurindāti ca vutte – ‘‘bhagavā onamitvā oloketuṃ na sakkhissāmī’’ti nāgacchinti. Na mayā, asurinda, adhomukhena pāramiyo pūritā. Uddhaggameva katvā dānaṃ dinnanti. Taṃ divasaṃ rāhu saraṇaṃ agamāsi. Evaṃ bhagavā akhuddāvakāso dassanāya. Catupārisuddhisīlena  sīlavā, taṃ pana sīlaṃ ariyaṃ uttamaṃ parisuddhaṃ. Tenāha – ‘‘ariyasīlī’’ti. Tadetaṃ anavajjaṭṭhena kusalaṃ. Tenāha – ‘‘kusalasīlī’’ti. Kusalasīlenāti idamassa vevacanaṃ. Bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyoti bhagavato ekekāya dhammadesanāya caturāsītipāṇasahassāni aparimāṇāpi devamanussā maggaphalāmataṃ pivanti, tasmā bahūnaṃ ācariyo. Sāvakaveneyyānaṃ pana pācariyoti. Khīṇakāmarāgoti ettha kāmaṃ bhagavato sabbepi kilesā khīṇā. Brāhmaṇo pana te na jānāti. Attano jānanaṭṭhāneyeva guṇaṃ katheti. Vigatacāpalloti – ‘‘pattamaṇḍanā cīvaramaṇḍanā  senāsanamaṇḍanā imassa vā pūtikāyassa…pe… kelanā paṭikelanā’’ti (vibha. 854) evaṃ vuttacāpallā virahito. Apāpapurekkhāroti apāpe nava lokuttaradhamme purato katvā vicarati. Brahmaññāya pajāyāti sāriputtamoggallānamahākassapādibhedāya brāhmaṇapajāya, etissāya ca pajāya purekkhāro. Ayañhi pajā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ purakkhatvā caratīti attho. Api ca apāpapurekkhāroti na pāpaṃ purekkhāro na pāpaṃ purato katvā carati, na pāpaṃ icchatīti attho. Kassa? Brahmaññāya pajāya. Attanā saddhiṃ paṭiviruddhāyapi brāhmaṇapajāya aviruddho hitasukhatthiko yevāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tiroraṭṭhāti pararaṭṭhato. Tirojanapadāti parajanapadato. Pañhaṃ pucchituṃ āgacchantīti khattiyapaṇḍitādayo ceva devabrahmanāgagandhabbādayo ca  – ‘‘pañhe abhisaṅkharitvā pucchissāmā’’ti āgacchanti. Tattha keci pucchāya vā dosaṃ vissajjanasampaṭicchane vā asamatthataṃ sallakkhetvā apucchitvāva tuṇhī nisīdanti. Keci pucchanti. Kesañci bhagavā pucchāya ussāhaṃ janetvā vissajjeti. Evaṃ sabbesampi tesaṃ vimatiyo tīraṃ patvā mahāsamuddassa ūmiyo viya bhagavantaṃ patvā bhijjanti. Ehisvāgatavādīti devamanussapabbajitagahaṭṭhesu taṃ taṃ attano santikaṃ āgataṃ – ‘‘ehi svāgata’’nti evaṃ vadatīti attho. Sakhiloti tattha katamaṃ sākhalyaṃ? ‘‘Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā’’tiādinā nayena vuttasākhalyena samannāgato, muduvacanoti attho. Sammodakoti paṭisanthārakusalo, āgatāgatānaṃ catunnaṃ parisānaṃ – ‘‘kacci, bhikkhave, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīya’’ntiādinā nayena sabbaṃ addhānadarathaṃ vūpasamento viya paṭhamataraṃ sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ kattāti attho. Abbhākuṭikoti yathā ekacce parisaṃ patvā thaddhamukhā saṅkuṭitamukhā honti, na ediso, parisadassanena panassa bālātapasamphassena viya padumaṃ mukhapadumaṃ vikasati puṇṇacandasassirikaṃ hoti. Uttānamukhoti yathā ekacce nikujjitamukhā viya sampattāya parisāya na kiñci kathenti, atidullabhakathā honti, na evarūpo. Samaṇo pana gotamo sulabhakatho. Na tassa santikaṃ āgatāgatānaṃ – ‘‘kasmā mayaṃ idhāgatā’’ti vippaṭisāro uppajjati dhammaṃ pana sutvā attamanāva hontīti dasseti. Pubbabhāsīti bhāsanto ca paṭhamataraṃ bhāsati, tañca kho kālayuttaṃ pamāṇayuttaṃ atthanissitameva bhāsati, na niratthakakathaṃ. Natasmiṃ gāme vāti yattha kira bhagavā paṭivasati, tattha mahesakkhā devatā ārakkhaṃ gaṇhanti, taṃ nissāya manussānaṃ upaddavo na hoti, paṃsupisācakādayoyeva hi manusse viheṭhenti, te tāsaṃ ānubhāvena dūraṃ apakkamanti. Api ca bhagavato mettābalenapi na amanussā manusse viheṭhenti. Saṅghītiādīsu anusāsitabbo sayaṃ vā uppādito saṅgho assa atthīti saṅghī. Tādiso cassa gaṇo atthīti gaṇī. Purimapadasseva vā vevacanametaṃ. Ācārasikkhāpanavasena gaṇassa ācariyoti gaṇācariyo. Puthutitthakarānanti bahūnaṃ titthakarānaṃ. Yathāvā tathā vāti yena vā tena vā acelakādimattakenāpi kāraṇena. Samudāgacchatīti samantato upagacchati abhivaḍḍhati. Atithi no te hontīti te amhākaṃ āgantukā, navakā pāhunakā hontīti attho. Pariyāpuṇāmīti jānāmi. Aparimāṇavaṇṇoti tathārūpeneva sabbaññunāpi appameyyavaṇṇo – ‘‘pageva mādisenā’’ti dasseti. Vuttampi cettaṃ –
commentary_english:
304.
Thus was it said, thus was it said by those Brahmins.

Soṇadaṇḍa: "These Brahmins declare my worth according to birth and so forth, but it is not fitting to be attached to one's own worth.

Come now, I will break their argument, make known the greatness of the renunciate Gotama, and bring them to go there," thinking thus, he then said, "Sirs, listen to me too," and so forth.

There, those qualities, beginning with being well-born on both sides, are similar to his own qualities; thinking, "Who am I, and who are the qualities of the renunciate Gotama, such as birth and prosperity?", he esteems himself as even more superior by his own qualities; but the others reveal only for the purpose of illuminating the greatness of the Blessed One.

"We alone are worthy," thus directing, he reveals this: "If it is to be approached because of greatness of qualities,

just as a mustard seed placed near Mount Sineru, a cow's footprint placed near the great ocean, a drop of water placed near the seven great lakes is small and insignificant,

even so, placing the qualities of the renunciate Gotama, such as birth and prosperity, near [our own], our qualities are small and insignificant; therefore, we alone are worthy to approach that Blessed Gotama for a sight."

"Having abandoned a great assembly of relatives," means having abandoned eighty thousand families on the mother's side, eighty thousand families on the father's side, thus having abandoned one hundred sixty thousand families, he went forth.

"Ground-bound and air-bound," means that wealth placed on the ground, filling the levelled ponds in the royal courtyard and garden with the seven jewels, is called ground-bound wealth.

Having completely filled and placed palaces and mansions, etc., it is called air-bound wealth.

This, however, has come by way of family lineage.

Moreover, for the Tathāgata, on the very day of his birth, four treasures arose: Saṅkha, Elo, Uppala, Puṇḍarīka.

Among them, Saṅkha is one gāvuta, Elo is half a yojana, Uppala is three gāvuta, Puṇḍarīka is one yojana.

Even among those, whatever is taken is completely filled, thus, the Blessed One, having abandoned abundant gold and silver, is to be known as having gone forth.

"Being young," means being youthful.

"Susukāḷakeso," means having very black hair, having hair similar to the color of ointment, such is the meaning.

"Bhadrena," means by the auspicious one.

"Paṭhamena vayasāti," by the first age, by the first age of the three ages.

"Akāmakānaṃ," means of those who do not desire.

"Anādaratthe sāmivacanaṃ," a statement of disregard.

"Assūni mukhe etesanti assumukhā," those whose faces are with tears, of those tearful ones, those with faces moistened by tears, such is the meaning.

"Rudantānaṃ," means having cried, weeping.

"Akhuddāvakāsoti," here, the Blessed One has an immeasurable opportunity for seeing, thus it is to be known.

There, this story: In Rājagaha, a certain Brahmin, having heard that he is not able to grasp the measure of the renunciate Gotama, taking a sixty-hand bamboo, standing outside the city gate at the time of the Blessed One's entry for alms, having reached the Blessed One, taking the bamboo, he stood nearby.

The bamboo reached the Blessed One's knee.

Again, on another day, having fashioned two bamboos, he stood nearby.

The Blessed One, appearing only waist-high above the two bamboos, said, "Brahmin, what are you doing?"

"I am grasping your measure," he said.

"Brahmin, even if you were to fashion bamboos and come, having filled the entire womb of the universe, you would not be able to grasp my measure.

For indeed, I have fulfilled the four incalculable hundreds of thousands of aeons of perfections, such that another might grasp my measure; the Tathāgata is unequaled, immeasurable," having said this, he spoke a verse in the Dhammapada - at the end of the verse, eighty-four thousand beings drank the nectar of immortality.

Another story: Rāhu, it is said, the chief of the Asuras, is four thousand eight hundred yojanas tall.

The extent of his arm is twelve hundred yojanas.

The space between is six hundred yojanas.

The breadth of the palms of his hands and the soles of his feet is three hundred yojanas.

The segments of his fingers are fifty yojanas.

The space between his eyebrows is fifty yojanas.

His face is two hundred yojanas, three hundred yojanas deep, three hundred yojanas in circumference.

His neck is three hundred yojanas.

His forehead is three hundred yojanas.
His head was 900 *yojanas*.

"Since I am tall, I will not be able to bow and look at the Teacher," thinking thus, he did not come.

One day, having heard of the Blessed One's excellence, he came, thinking, "Somehow or other, I will look at him."

Then, the Blessed One, knowing his inclination, thinking, "In which of the four postures shall I show myself?", thought, "Indeed, one who is standing, even though short, appears tall."

"If lying down, I will show myself," [and] said, "Ānanda, prepare a couch in the Perfumed Chamber enclosure," and there he assumed the lion's posture.

Rāhu, having come, raised the neck of the Blessed One who was lying down and looked at him like the full moon in the middle of the sky.

When it was said, "What is this, Asurinda?", [they] did not come, [saying,] "The Blessed One will not be able to bow and look."

"Not by me, Asurinda, have the perfections been fulfilled with face downwards.

Having made giving upwards, alms were given."

That day, Rāhu went for refuge.

Thus, the Blessed One was unrestricted in opportunity for showing himself.

Possessing morality with fourfold purity, he is virtuous, and that morality is noble, supreme, and perfectly pure.

Therefore he said, "Possessing noble morality."

Therefore that is wholesome because of being faultless.

Therefore he said, "Possessing wholesome morality."

*Kusalasīlena* means this is his designation.

Because for each discourse of the Blessed One, eighty-four thousand beings, even immeasurable gods and humans, drink the nectar of the path and its fruit, therefore he is a teacher of many.

Moreover, *pācariya* of those who are to be guided among disciples.

In *khīṇakāmarāga*, here, indeed, all the defilements of the Blessed One are destroyed.

But the *brāhmaṇa* does not know you.

He praises his own place of knowing.

*Vigatacāpalla* means devoid of frivolousness, "[Adornment] of the bowl, adornment of the robe, adornment of the lodging, or of this foul body...*pe*...disgusting, utterly disgusting" (Vibha.

854) Thus, he is devoid of that which is said to be frivolous.

*Apāpapurekkhāra* means he lives having put the sinless nine supramundane *dharmas* before him.

*Brahmaññāya pajāya* means for the *brāhmaṇa* community which is distinguished by Sāriputta, Moggallāna, Mahākassapa, and others, he is preeminent for this community.

The meaning is that this community lives honoring the *samaṇa* Gotama.

Moreover, *apāpapurekkhāra* means not evil is preeminent, he does not live having put evil before him, he does not desire evil.

For whom? For the *brahmaññāya pajāya*.

It is said that even to the *brāhmaṇa* community that is opposed to himself, he is unopposed, wishing for benefit and happiness.

*Tiroraṭṭha* means from another country.

*Tirojanapada* means from another district.

"They come to ask a question" means *khattiya* (warrior caste), learned men, gods, Brahmās, Nāgas, Gandharvas, and others, thinking, "Having prepared a question, we will ask," come.

There, some, having considered the fault in questioning or the inability in answering or accepting, sit down silently without asking.

Some ask.

To some, the Blessed One generates enthusiasm for the question and lets it go.

Thus, for all of them, the doubts having reached the shore, like waves of the great ocean, having reached the Blessed One, are shattered.

*Ehissvāgatavādī* means to those gods, humans, renunciants, householders, who have come to his presence, he says, "Come, welcome!" Thus, is the meaning.

*Sakhilo* means what is friendliness there? He is endowed with that which is said to be friendly in the way beginning with "That speech is smooth, pleasing to the ear," and so on, the meaning is soft-spoken.

*Sammodako* means skilled in courteous conversation, to the four assemblies of those who have come, in the way beginning with "*Kacci, bhikkhave*, is it bearable, is it livable?" and so on, as if appeasing all the weariness of the journey, the meaning is how to make preliminary pleasing conversation.

*Abbhākuṭiko* means as some, having reached the assembly, are stiff-faced, with constricted faces, he is not like that, but by the sight of the assembly, as a lotus by the touch of the heat of the young sun, his face-lotus blossoms, he is resplendent with the full moon.
"Uttānamukha": As some, with mouths turned down, do not speak at all to an assembled company, and are very difficult to talk to, he is not like that.

But the ascetic Gotama is easy to talk to.

To those who come and go to him, no remorse arises, thinking, "Why have we come here?" But having heard the Dhamma, he shows that they are delighted.

"Speaking first": He speaks and speaks before others, and that too, he speaks what is timely, measured, and based on meaning, not idle talk.

In that village where the Blessed One dwells, powerful deities maintain guard. Relying on that, no harm befalls humans. For only dust-demons and the like harm humans, and they retreat far away by the power of those deities.

Moreover, even by the power of the Blessed One's loving-kindness, non-humans do not harm humans.

"Sanghi": He should be instructed in the Sangha, or a Sangha has been established by himself, therefore he is a "Sanghi" (one with a Sangha).

"Gani": Such a group exists for him, therefore he is a "Gani" (one with a group).

Or it is a synonym for the previous word.

"Gaṇācariya": Because of teaching conduct and training, he is the teacher (ācariya) of the group (gaṇa), therefore he is a "Gaṇācariya."

"Pututitthakarana": Of the many makers of fords (titthakara).

However it may be, by whatever cause, even a little bit like the Ācelakas (naked ascetics) and others.

"Samudagacchati": He approaches from all sides and increases.

"Atithi no te honti": They are our guests, newcomers, visitors. That is the meaning.

"Pariyāpuṇāmi": I understand.

"Aparimāṇavaṇṇoti": Even with such a form, even the all-knowing one has immeasurable color – "Even with someone like me," he shows.

Moreover, it is said:

mula_pali: 305. Evaṃ  vutte, te brāhmaṇā soṇadaṇḍaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘yathā kho bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇe bhāsati ito cepi so bhavaṃ gotamo yojanasate viharati, alameva saddhena kulaputtena dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ api puṭosenā’’ti. ‘‘Tena hi, bho, sabbeva mayaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā’’ti.
mula_english:
305. When this was said, the Brahmins said to the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa, "Sir, since the esteemed Soṇadaṇḍa speaks in praise of the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama, even if the esteemed Gotama were dwelling a hundred *yojanas* away, it would be sufficient for a faithful clansman to approach him for a visit, even with a shoulder bag."

"Then, sir, let us all go to visit the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama."
commentary_pali: 305. Imaṃ pana satthu guṇakathaṃ sutvā te brāhmaṇā cintayiṃsu – yathā soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇe bhaṇati, anomaguṇo so bhavaṃ gotamo; evaṃ tassa guṇe jānamānena kho pana ācariyena aticiraṃ adhivāsitaṃ, handa naṃ anuvattāmāti anuvattiṃsu. Tasmā evaṃ vutte ‘‘te brāhmaṇā’’tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha alamevāti yuttameva. Api puṭosenāti puṭosaṃ vuccati pātheyyaṃ, taṃ gahetvāpi upasaṅkamituṃ yuttamevāti attho. Puṭaṃsenātipi pāṭho, tassattho, puṭo aṃse assāti puṭaṃso, tena puṭaṃsena. Aṃsena hi pātheyyapuṭaṃ vahantenāpīti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
305.

Having heard this story of the Teacher’s virtues, those *brāhmaṇas* thought: "As Soṇadaṇḍa, the *brāhmaṇa*, speaks of the virtues of the *śramaṇa* Gotama, that venerable Gotama has extraordinary qualities. Thus, their teacher, knowing his virtues, resided [with him] for a very long time." Then, they followed him, thinking, "Let us follow him."

Therefore, having said this, the statement "those *brāhmaṇas*," etc., was said.

There, "it is indeed sufficient" is indeed fitting.

Moreover, "with provisions" means *pātheyya*, provisions for the journey. The meaning is that it is indeed fitting to approach, even having taken that.

"With a *puṭaṃsa*" is also a reading. Its meaning is: a *puṭaṃsa* is that which has a *puṭa* on its shoulder (aṃsa). By that *puṭaṃsa*.

For it is said that even by carrying a bundle (*puṭa*) of provisions (*pātheyya*) on his shoulder (aṃsa), it is so.

mula_pali: 306. Atha  kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṃ yena gaggarā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkami. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍassa brāhmaṇassa tirovanasaṇḍagatassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi – ‘‘ahañceva kho pana samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pañhaṃ puccheyyaṃ; tatra ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘na kho esa, brāhmaṇa, pañho evaṃ pucchitabbo, evaṃ nāmesa, brāhmaṇa , pañho pucchitabbo’ti, tena maṃ ayaṃ parisā paribhaveyya  – ‘bālo soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo abyatto, nāsakkhi samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ yoniso pañhaṃ pucchitu’nti. Yaṃ kho panāyaṃ parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha. Yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ. Yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā. Mamañceva kho pana samaṇo gotamo pañhaṃ puccheyya, tassa cāhaṃ pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ na ārādheyyaṃ; tatra ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘na kho esa, brāhmaṇa, pañho evaṃ byākātabbo, evaṃ nāmesa, brāhmaṇa, pañho byākātabbo’ti, tena maṃ ayaṃ parisā paribhaveyya – ‘bālo soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo abyatto, nāsakkhi  samaṇassa gotamassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādhetu’nti. Yaṃ kho panāyaṃ parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha. Yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ. Yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā. Ahañceva kho pana evaṃ samīpagato samāno adisvāva samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ nivatteyyaṃ, tena maṃ ayaṃ parisā paribhaveyya – ‘bālo soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo abyatto mānathaddho bhīto ca, no visahati samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ, kathañhi nāma evaṃ samīpagato samāno adisvā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ nivattissatī’ti. Yaṃ kho panāyaṃ parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha. Yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ, yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā’’ti.
mula_english:
306.
And so, Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, together with a large company of Brahmins, went to the Gaggara lotus-pond.

Then this thought arose in the mind of Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, who had gone into the forest thicket: “If I were to ask the ascetic Gotama a question, and if the ascetic Gotama were to say to me, ‘That is not the way to ask the question, this is the way to ask the question, Brahmin,’ then this assembly would despise me, saying, ‘Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin is a fool, he is incompetent, he is unable to ask the ascetic Gotama a question properly.’

And if anyone were despised by this assembly, his reputation would suffer.

And if a man’s reputation suffers, his income would suffer.

For our income depends on the gaining of a reputation (yaśoladdhā).

If the ascetic Gotama were to ask me a question, and I could not satisfy his mind with an explanation of that question, and if the ascetic Gotama were to say to me, ‘That is not the way to answer the question, this is the way to answer the question, Brahmin,’ then this assembly would despise me, saying, ‘Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin is a fool, he is incompetent, he is unable to satisfy the mind of the ascetic Gotama with an explanation of his question.’

And if anyone were despised by this assembly, his reputation would suffer.

And if a man’s reputation suffers, his income would suffer.

For our income depends on the gaining of a reputation (yaśoladdhā).

And if, having come so near, I were to turn back without even seeing the ascetic Gotama, then this assembly would despise me, saying, ‘Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin is a fool, he is incompetent, he is arrogant and frightened, and he cannot bring himself to approach the ascetic Gotama for an audience; how could he, having come so near, turn back without seeing the ascetic Gotama?’

And if anyone were despised by this assembly, his reputation would suffer.

And if a man’s reputation suffers, his income would suffer, for our income depends on the gaining of a reputation (yaśoladdhā).
commentary_pali: 306-308.Tirovanasaṇḍagatassāti  antovanasaṇḍe gatassa, vihārabbhantaraṃ paviṭṭhassāti attho. Añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti ete ubhatopakkhikā, te evaṃ cintayiṃsu – ‘‘sace no micchādiṭṭhikā codessanti – ‘kasmā tumhe samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vanditthā’ti? Tesaṃ – ‘kiṃ añjalimattakaraṇenāpi vandanaṃ nāma hotī’ti vakkhāma. Sace no sammādiṭṭhikā codessanti – ‘kasmā tumhe bhagavantaṃ na vanditthā’ti. ‘Kiṃ sīsena bhūmiyaṃ paharanteneva vandanaṃ nāma hoti, nanu añjalikammampi vandanaṃ evā’ti  vakkhāmā’’ti. Nāmagottanti  ‘‘bho, gotama, ahaṃ asukassa putto datto nāma, mitto nāma, idhāgato’’ti vadantā nāmaṃ sāventi nāma. ‘‘Bho, gotama, ahaṃ vāseṭṭho nāma, kaccāno nāma, idhāgato’’ti vadantā gottaṃ sāventi nāma. Ete kira daliddā jiṇṇā kulaputtā ‘‘parisamajjhe nāmagottavasena pākaṭā bhavissāmā’’ti evamakaṃsu. Ye pana tuṇhībhūtā nisīdiṃsu, te kerāṭikā ceva andhabālā ca. Tattha kerāṭikā – ‘‘ekaṃ dve kathāsallāpepi karonto vissāsiko hoti, atha vissāse sati ekaṃ dve bhikkhā adātuṃ na yutta’’nti tato attānaṃ mocetvā tuṇhī nisīdanti. Andhabālā aññāṇatāyeva avakkhittamattikāpiṇḍo viya yattha katthaci tuṇhībhūtā nisīdanti.
commentary_english:
306-308.

*Tirovanasaṇḍagatassāti* means having gone to an inner grove, that is, having entered inside the monastery.

*Añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti*: These were of two opinions, so they thought, "If those of wrong view should rebuke us, saying, 'Why do you venerate the ascetic Gotama?' to them we will say, 'Is worship only done by making a joined-hand salutation?'

If those of right view should rebuke us, saying, 'Why do you not venerate the Blessed One?'

'Is worship only done by striking the head on the ground? Surely, even the action of joining the hands is worship,' we will say."

*Nāmagottanti*: "Good sir, Gotama, I am the son of so-and-so, named Datta, named Mitta, I have come here," thus, speaking their name, they announce their name.

"Good sir, Gotama, I am named Vāseṭṭha, named Kaccāna, I have come here," thus, speaking their lineage (*gotta*), they announce their lineage.

These poor, old sons of good families thought, "We will become known in the assembly through [mentioning] our name and lineage."

Those, however, who sat silent, were cunning and also blindly foolish.

There, the cunning [thought], "Even while engaging in one or two conversational exchanges, one becomes trustworthy; then, if there is trust, it is not fitting not to give one or two alms," thus, freeing themselves, they sit silent.

The blindly foolish, due to their very ignorance, like a lump of clay thrown away, sit silent wherever [they are].

mula_pali: 307. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Campeyyakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā  appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu; sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mula_english:
Then the *brāhmaṇa* Soṇadaṇḍa approached the Blessed One, and having approached, exchanged greetings with him. Having concluded their conversation with friendly greetings and courtesies, he sat down to one side.
