Moreover, some *brāhmaṇas* and householders from Campeyya, having bowed down to the Blessed One, sat down to one side; some exchanged greetings with the Blessed One; having concluded their conversation with friendly greetings and courtesies, they sat down to one side; some, raising their joined palms towards the Blessed One, sat down to one side; some, announcing their name and clan, sat down to one side; some sat down to one side in silence.
commentary_pali: 306-308.Tirovanasaṇḍagatassāti  antovanasaṇḍe gatassa, vihārabbhantaraṃ paviṭṭhassāti attho. Añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti ete ubhatopakkhikā, te evaṃ cintayiṃsu – ‘‘sace no micchādiṭṭhikā codessanti – ‘kasmā tumhe samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vanditthā’ti? Tesaṃ – ‘kiṃ añjalimattakaraṇenāpi vandanaṃ nāma hotī’ti vakkhāma. Sace no sammādiṭṭhikā codessanti – ‘kasmā tumhe bhagavantaṃ na vanditthā’ti. ‘Kiṃ sīsena bhūmiyaṃ paharanteneva vandanaṃ nāma hoti, nanu añjalikammampi vandanaṃ evā’ti  vakkhāmā’’ti. Nāmagottanti  ‘‘bho, gotama, ahaṃ asukassa putto datto nāma, mitto nāma, idhāgato’’ti vadantā nāmaṃ sāventi nāma. ‘‘Bho, gotama, ahaṃ vāseṭṭho nāma, kaccāno nāma, idhāgato’’ti vadantā gottaṃ sāventi nāma. Ete kira daliddā jiṇṇā kulaputtā ‘‘parisamajjhe nāmagottavasena pākaṭā bhavissāmā’’ti evamakaṃsu. Ye pana tuṇhībhūtā nisīdiṃsu, te kerāṭikā ceva andhabālā ca. Tattha kerāṭikā – ‘‘ekaṃ dve kathāsallāpepi karonto vissāsiko hoti, atha vissāse sati ekaṃ dve bhikkhā adātuṃ na yutta’’nti tato attānaṃ mocetvā tuṇhī nisīdanti. Andhabālā aññāṇatāyeva avakkhittamattikāpiṇḍo viya yattha katthaci tuṇhībhūtā nisīdanti.
commentary_english:
306-308.
*tirovanasaṇḍagatassāti* means having gone into a grove out of sight, that is, having gone into a grove within, having entered the monastery; this is the meaning.
*añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti:* These two were of two minds. They thought thus: "If those of wrong view (*micchādiṭṭhikā*) should question us, 'Why do you salute the *samaṇa* Gotama?', to them we will say, 'Is worship only done by striking one’s head on the ground (*bhūmi*)? Even doing *añjali* is worship.”
If those of right view (*sammādiṭṭhikā*) should question us, 'Why do you not salute the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ*)?', we will say, 'Is worship only done by striking one’s head on the ground? Surely, even doing *añjali-kamma* is worship!'"
*nāmagottanti:* “Sir (*bho*), Gotama, I am the son of so-and-so, named Datta, named Mitta, I have come here," thus saying, they announce their name (*nāma*).
"Sir (*bho*), Gotama, I am named Vāseṭṭha, named Kaccāna, I have come here," thus saying, they announce their clan (*gotta*).
These poor, old sons of good families thought, "In the midst of the assembly (*parisā*), we will become known by means of our name and clan (*nāmagotta*)." Thus they did.
Those who sat in silence were both shrewd and foolish (*andhabālā*).
There, the shrewd ones thought, "Even doing one or two conversational greetings creates confidence (*vissāsiko*), and when there is confidence, it is not proper to give one or two alms," and so, freeing themselves, they sit silently.
The foolish (*andhabālā*), simply due to ignorance (*aññāṇatā*), sit silently anywhere, like a clod of mud thrown away (*avakkhittamattikāpiṇḍo viya*).

mula_pali: 308. Tatrapi  sudaṃ soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo etadeva bahulamanuvitakkento nisinno hoti – ‘‘ahañceva kho  pana samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pañhaṃ puccheyyaṃ; tatra ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘na kho esa, brāhmaṇa, pañho evaṃ pucchitabbo, evaṃ nāmesa, brāhmaṇa, pañho pucchitabbo’ti, tena maṃ ayaṃ parisā paribhaveyya – ‘bālo soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo abyatto, nāsakkhi samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ yoniso pañhaṃ pucchitu’nti. Yaṃ kho panāyaṃ parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha. Yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ. Yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā. Mamañceva kho pana samaṇo gotamo pañhaṃ puccheyya, tassa cāhaṃ pañhassa veyyākaraṇena  cittaṃ na ārādheyyaṃ; tatra ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo evaṃ vadeyya – ‘na kho esa, brāhmaṇa, pañho evaṃ byākātabbo, evaṃ nāmesa, brāhmaṇa, pañho byākātabbo’ti, tena maṃ ayaṃ parisā paribhaveyya – ‘bālo soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo abyatto, nāsakkhi samaṇassa gotamassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādhetu’nti. Yaṃ kho panāyaṃ parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha. Yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ. Yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā. Aho vata maṃ samaṇo gotamo sake ācariyake tevijjake pañhaṃ puccheyya, addhā vatassāhaṃ cittaṃ ārādheyyaṃ pañhassa veyyākaraṇenā’’ti.
mula_english:
308. Moreover, Soṇadaṇḍa the *brāhmaṇa* sat there, dwelling on this very thought: "If I were to ask the *samaṇa* Gotama a question, and Gotama were to say to me, 'That, *brāhmaṇa*, is not how the question should be asked; rather, this is how the question should be asked,' then this assembly would despise me, saying, 'Soṇadaṇḍa the *brāhmaṇa* is a fool, he is incompetent, he could not ask the *samaṇa* Gotama a question properly.'"

And if anyone were to be despised by this assembly, his reputation (*yaso*) would decline.

And if anyone’s reputation (*yaso*) were to decline, his income (*bhoga*) would also decline.

For our income (*bhoga*) depends on the gaining of a reputation (*yaso*).

"And further, if the *samaṇa* Gotama were to ask me a question, and I were not to satisfy his mind (*citta*) with my explanation (*veyyākaraṇa*) of the question, and Gotama were to say to me, 'That, *brāhmaṇa*, is not how the question should be explained (*byākatabbo*); rather, this is how the question should be explained (*byākatabbo*)', then this assembly would despise me, saying, 'Soṇadaṇḍa the *brāhmaṇa* is a fool, he is incompetent, he could not satisfy the mind (*citta*) of the *samaṇa* Gotama with his explanation (*veyyākaraṇa*) of the question.'"

And if anyone were to be despised by this assembly, his reputation (*yaso*) would decline.

And if anyone’s reputation (*yaso*) were to decline, his income (*bhoga*) would also decline.

For our income (*bhoga*) depends on the gaining of a reputation (*yaso*).

"Oh, if only the *samaṇa* Gotama would ask me a question about my own teaching, the Three Vedas (*tevijjaka*)! Surely, I would satisfy his mind (*citta*) with my explanation (*veyyākaraṇa*) of the question!"
commentary_pali: 306-308.Tirovanasaṇḍagatassāti  antovanasaṇḍe gatassa, vihārabbhantaraṃ paviṭṭhassāti attho. Añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti ete ubhatopakkhikā, te evaṃ cintayiṃsu – ‘‘sace no micchādiṭṭhikā codessanti – ‘kasmā tumhe samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vanditthā’ti? Tesaṃ – ‘kiṃ añjalimattakaraṇenāpi vandanaṃ nāma hotī’ti vakkhāma. Sace no sammādiṭṭhikā codessanti – ‘kasmā tumhe bhagavantaṃ na vanditthā’ti. ‘Kiṃ sīsena bhūmiyaṃ paharanteneva vandanaṃ nāma hoti, nanu añjalikammampi vandanaṃ evā’ti  vakkhāmā’’ti. Nāmagottanti  ‘‘bho, gotama, ahaṃ asukassa putto datto nāma, mitto nāma, idhāgato’’ti vadantā nāmaṃ sāventi nāma. ‘‘Bho, gotama, ahaṃ vāseṭṭho nāma, kaccāno nāma, idhāgato’’ti vadantā gottaṃ sāventi nāma. Ete kira daliddā jiṇṇā kulaputtā ‘‘parisamajjhe nāmagottavasena pākaṭā bhavissāmā’’ti evamakaṃsu. Ye pana tuṇhībhūtā nisīdiṃsu, te kerāṭikā ceva andhabālā ca. Tattha kerāṭikā – ‘‘ekaṃ dve kathāsallāpepi karonto vissāsiko hoti, atha vissāse sati ekaṃ dve bhikkhā adātuṃ na yutta’’nti tato attānaṃ mocetvā tuṇhī nisīdanti. Andhabālā aññāṇatāyeva avakkhittamattikāpiṇḍo viya yattha katthaci tuṇhībhūtā nisīdanti.
commentary_english:
306-308.

*tirovanasaṇḍagatassāti* means having gone to a thicket out of sight, meaning having gone to a thicket inside the forest, meaning having entered inside the monastery.

*añjaliṃ paṇāmetvāti* These were double-dealers. They thought thus: “If those of wrong view should rebuke us, saying, ‘Why did you venerate the ascetic Gotama (Gautama)?’ we will say to them, ‘Is only prostration by striking the head on the ground worship? Even making a gesture of reverence with joined palms is worship.’”

“If those of right view should rebuke us, saying, ‘Why did you not venerate the Blessed One (Bhagavantam)?’ [we will say,] ‘Is only prostration by striking the head on the ground worship? Indeed, even the action of reverently joining the palms is worship.’”

*nāmagottanti* They, saying “Sir, Gotama (Gautama), I am the son of so-and-so, named Datta, named Mitta, I have come here,” announce their name.

They, saying “Sir, Gotama (Gautama), I am named Vāseṭṭha, named Kaccāna, I have come here,” announce their clan (*gotta*).

These poor, old sons of good families thought thus: “We will become well-known in the assembly by means of our name and clan.”

But those who sat silently were both tricksters (*kerāṭikā*) and veritable fools (*andhabālā*).

Therein, the tricksters think, “Even someone who engages in one or two friendly conversations becomes trustworthy, but when there is trust, it is not fitting to give one or two alms,” and so, freeing themselves, they sit silently.

The veritable fools, just because of their ignorance, sit silently wherever, like a lump of clay that has been thrown away.

mula_pali: 309. Atha kho bhagavato soṇadaṇḍassa brāhmaṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya etadahosi – ‘‘vihaññati kho ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo  sakena cittena. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ soṇadaṇḍaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ sake ācariyake tevijjake pañhaṃ puccheyya’’nti. Atha kho bhagavā soṇadaṇḍaṃ  brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘katihi pana, brāhmaṇa, aṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti?
mula_english:
309. Then, the Lord, knowing with his mind the deliberation in the mind of the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa, it occurred to him: "Indeed, this Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa is troubled in his own mind."

"Suppose I were to ask the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa a question about his own teaching, about the three Vedas (tevijja)!"

Then the Lord said this to the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa: "By how many qualities, O Brahmin, do Brahmins designate one as a Brahmin, so that one who declares, 'I am a Brahmin' would speak truthfully and not incur falsehood?"
commentary_pali: 309-310.Cetasā cetoparivitakkanti bhagavā – ‘‘ayaṃ brāhmaṇo āgatakālato paṭṭhāya adhomukho thaddhagatto kiṃ cintayamāno nisinno, kiṃ nu kho cintetī’’ti āvajjanto attano cetasā tassa cittaṃ aññāsi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāyā’’ti. Vihaññatīti vighātaṃ āpajjati. Anuviloketvā parisanti bhagavato sakasamaye pañhapucchanena udake miyamāno ukkhipitvā thale ṭhapito viya samapassaddhakāyacitto hutvā parisaṃ saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ diṭṭhisañjāneneva ‘‘upadhārentu me bhonto vacana’’nti vadanto viya anuviloketvā parisaṃ bhagavantaṃ etadavoca.
commentary_english:
309-310.

The Blessed One, with his mind (cetasā) , perceived (aññāsi) the mental deliberations (cetoparivitakkaṃ) of the brahmin, thinking (cintayamāno): "This brahmin, since the time he arrived (āgatakālato paṭṭhāya), sits with his face down (adhomukho), his body stiff (thaddhagatto), what is he contemplating (kiṃ cinteti)?" Thus, with his own mind (attano cetasā), he understood (aññāsi) his thought (cittaṃ).

Therefore (tena), it was said (vuttaṃ): "Through the mind (cetasā), [he understood] the mental deliberations (cetoparivitakkamaññāyā)."

Because it is tormented (vihaññatīti), one encounters (āpajjati) destruction (vighātaṃ).

Looking around (anuviloketvā) at the assembly (parisaṃ), it was as if someone drowning (miyamāno) in water (udake) was lifted up (ukkhipitvā) and placed (ṭhapito) on dry land (thale); having a body and mind calmed (samapassaddhakāyacitto hutvā), as if with the understanding (diṭṭhisañjāneneva) for the purpose of gathering (saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ) the assembly (parisaṃ), saying (vadanto) "Pay attention (upadhārentu), good sirs (bhonto), to my words (vacanaṃ)," looking around (anuviloketvā) at the assembly (parisaṃ), he said (etadavoca) this to the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ).

mula_pali: 310. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi – ‘‘yaṃ  vata no ahosi icchitaṃ, yaṃ ākaṅkhitaṃ, yaṃ adhippetaṃ, yaṃ abhipatthitaṃ – ‘aho vata maṃ samaṇo gotamo sake ācariyake tevijjake pañhaṃ puccheyya, addhā vatassāhaṃ cittaṃ ārādheyyaṃ pañhassa veyyākaraṇenā’ti, tatra maṃ samaṇo gotamo sake ācariyake tevijjake pañhaṃ pucchati. Addhā vatassāhaṃ cittaṃ ārādhessāmi pañhassa veyyākaraṇenā’’ti.
mula_english: Then it occurred to the *brāhmaṇa* Soṇadaṇḍa: "What I wanted, what I hoped for, what I intended, what I longed for has now come to pass—'If only the *śramaṇa* Gotama would ask me a question regarding my own teachers, the *tevijjakas*! Indeed, I could satisfy his mind with my explanation of the question.' Now the *śramaṇa* Gotama is asking me a question about my own *tevijjaka* teachers. Indeed, I will satisfy his mind with an explanation of the question."
commentary_pali: 309-310.Cetasā cetoparivitakkanti bhagavā – ‘‘ayaṃ brāhmaṇo āgatakālato paṭṭhāya adhomukho thaddhagatto kiṃ cintayamāno nisinno, kiṃ nu kho cintetī’’ti āvajjanto attano cetasā tassa cittaṃ aññāsi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāyā’’ti. Vihaññatīti vighātaṃ āpajjati. Anuviloketvā parisanti bhagavato sakasamaye pañhapucchanena udake miyamāno ukkhipitvā thale ṭhapito viya samapassaddhakāyacitto hutvā parisaṃ saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ diṭṭhisañjāneneva ‘‘upadhārentu me bhonto vacana’’nti vadanto viya anuviloketvā parisaṃ bhagavantaṃ etadavoca.
commentary_english:
309-310.

The Blessed One, with his mind (cetasā) knowing the pondering of another's mind (cetoparivitakkanti), contemplated, "This *brāhmaṇa*, since the time he arrived, sits with his face down, his body stiff, what is he thinking? What indeed is he contemplating?" Thus, with his own mind, he understood his thought (cittaṃ aññāsi).

Therefore, it was said: "Through the mind (cetasā), [he knows] the pondering of another's mind (cetoparivitakkamaññāyā)."

Because he is injured (vihaññatī), he encounters destruction (vighātaṃ āpajjati).

Having looked around at the assembly, it was as if, at the Blessed One’s own time, when questioned with a question, someone dying in the water was lifted up, placed on dry land, and became composed, with a calmed body and mind; with the understanding of insight, as if saying, "Pay attention, good sirs, to my words (vacana)," having looked around at the assembly, he said this to the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ etadavoca).

mula_pali: 311. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo abbhunnāmetvā kāyaṃ anuviloketvā parisaṃ bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘pañcahi, bho gotama, aṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyya. Katamehi pañcahi? Idha, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca, saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena; ajjhāyako hoti mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo; abhirūpo hoti  dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya; sīlavā hoti vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato; paṇḍito ca hoti medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imehi kho, bho gotama, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti. ‘‘Imesaṃ pana, brāhmaṇa, pañcannaṃ aṅgānaṃ sakkā ekaṃ aṅgaṃ ṭhapayitvā catūhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapetuṃ; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti? ‘‘Sakkā , bho gotama. Imesañhi, bho gotama, pañcannaṃ aṅgānaṃ vaṇṇaṃ ṭhapayāma. Kiñhi vaṇṇo karissati? Yato kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā  akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena; ajjhāyako ca hoti mantadharo ca tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo; sīlavā ca hoti vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato; paṇḍito ca hoti medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imehi kho bho gotama catūhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno  sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti.
mula_english:
311.
Then Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, straightening up, looked around at the assembly and said to the Blessed One: "It is by these five qualities, Reverend Gotama, that Brahmins designate a Brahmin; and in saying ‘I am a Brahmin,’ he would be speaking rightly, and would not incur falsehood.

What are the five? Here, Reverend Gotama, a Brahmin is well-born on both sides, from the mother and from the father, of pure descent to the seventh generation, unimpeached and irreproachable in regard to birth; he is a scholar (*ajjhāyaka*) and reciter of mantras (*mantadharo*), who has reached the further shore of the three Vedas (*veda*), with their vocabularies (*nighaṇḍu*) , etymology (*keṭubha*), phonology (*sākkharappabheda*), and as a fifth, the traditions (*itihāsa*); he is skilled in verses (*padako*) and grammar (*veyyākaraṇo*), and is not deficient in speculative systems of the world (*lokāyata*) and the characteristics of a great man (*mahāpurisalakkhaṇa*); he is handsome, good to look upon, inspiring confidence, possessed of the highest beauty of complexion, of a Brahmin-like hue and a Brahmin-like radiance, not limited in his range of vision; he is virtuous, of advanced virtue, endowed with advanced virtue; he is learned and wise, and is the first or second in wielding the sacrificial ladle (*sujaṃ*).

It is by these five qualities, Reverend Gotama, that Brahmins designate a Brahmin; and in saying ‘I am a Brahmin,’ he would be speaking rightly, and would not incur falsehood.”

“But, Brahmin, could one of these five qualities be set aside, and could Brahmins designate a Brahmin as possessing four qualities; and in saying ‘I am a Brahmin,’ would he be speaking rightly, and would not incur falsehood?” “Yes, Reverend Gotama.

For in these five qualities, Reverend Gotama, we would set aside appearance (*vaṇṇaṃ*).

For what can appearance do? For, Reverend Gotama, a Brahmin is well-born on both sides, from the mother and from the father, of pure descent to the seventh generation, unimpeached and irreproachable in regard to birth; he is a scholar and reciter of mantras, who has reached the further shore of the three Vedas, with their vocabularies, etymology, phonology, and as a fifth, the traditions; he is skilled in verses and grammar, and is not deficient in speculative systems of the world and the characteristics of a great man; he is virtuous, of advanced virtue, endowed with advanced virtue; he is learned and wise, and is the first or second in wielding the sacrificial ladle.

It is by these four qualities, Reverend Gotama, that Brahmins designate a Brahmin; and in saying ‘I am a Brahmin,’ he would be speaking rightly, and would not incur falsehood.”
commentary_pali: 311-313.Sujaṃ paggaṇhantānanti yaññayajanatthāya sujaṃ gaṇhantesu brāhmaṇesu paṭhamo vā dutiyo vāti attho. Sujāya diyyamānaṃ mahāyāgaṃ paṭiggaṇhantānanti porāṇā. Iti brāhmaṇo sakasamayavasena sammadeva pañhaṃ vissajjesi. Bhagavā pana visesato uttamabrāhmaṇassa dassanatthaṃ  – ‘‘imesaṃ panā’’tiādimāha. Etadavocunti sace jātivaṇṇamantasampanno brāhmaṇo na hoti, atha ko carahi loke brāhmaṇo  bhavissati? Nāseti no ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo, handassa vādaṃ paṭikkhipissāmāti cintetvā etadavocuṃ. Apavadatīti  paṭikkhipati. Anupakkhandatīti anupavisati. Idaṃ – ‘‘sace tvaṃ pasādavasena samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gantukāmo, gaccha; mā brāhmaṇassa samayaṃ bhindī’’ti adhippāyena āhaṃsu.
commentary_english:
311-313.
"Sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ" means: Among the *brāhmaṇas* who accept the *sujā* for the purpose of sacrifice and offering, [he is] either the first or the second.
"Sujāya diyyamānaṃ mahāyāgaṃ paṭiggaṇhantānaṃ" [means]: the ancients.
Thus, the *brāhmaṇa* answered the question correctly according to his own tradition.
But the Blessed One (bhagavā), especially for the sake of showing the highest *brāhmaṇa*, said, "Among these..." and so on.
They said: "If a *brāhmaṇa* endowed with birth, lineage, and *mantras* does not exist, then who indeed will be a *brāhmaṇa* in the world? This Soṇadaṇḍa will destroy [us]. Come, let us refute his doctrine," having thought thus, they said this.
"Apavadatīti" [means:] he rejects.
"Anupakkhandatīti" [means:] he enters.
This [means]: "If you, due to faith, wish to go to the *śramaṇa* Gotama for refuge, go; do not break the tradition of the *brāhmaṇas*," with this intention they said.

mula_pali: 312. ‘‘Imesaṃ pana, brāhmaṇa, catunnaṃ aṅgānaṃ sakkā ekaṃ aṅgaṃ ṭhapayitvā tīhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapetuṃ; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti? ‘‘Sakkā, bho gotama. Imesañhi, bho gotama, catunnaṃ aṅgānaṃ mante ṭhapayāma. Kiñhi mantā karissanti? Yato kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena; sīlavā ca hoti vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato; paṇḍito ca hoti medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imehi kho, bho gotama, tīhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti. ‘‘Imesaṃ pana, brāhmaṇa, tiṇṇaṃ aṅgānaṃ sakkā ekaṃ aṅgaṃ ṭhapayitvā dvīhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapetuṃ; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana  musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti? ‘‘Sakkā, bho gotama. Imesañhi, bho gotama, tiṇṇaṃ aṅgānaṃ jātiṃ ṭhapayāma. Kiñhi jāti karissati? Yato kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo sīlavā hoti vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato; paṇḍito ca hoti  medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imehi  kho, bho gotama, dvīhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti.
mula_english:
312.
“But, Brahmin, could not one of these four qualities ( *aṅga*) be omitted, leaving three qualities whereby one could be recognized as a true *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin); and truthfully declare, ‘I am a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin),’ without incurring falsehood?” “It is possible, venerable Gotama.”
“Indeed, venerable Gotama, we would omit the *mantras* (sacred verses) from these four qualities (*aṅga*).”
“But what will the *mantras* (sacred verses) do? Because, venerable Gotama, a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) is well-born on both the mother’s and the father’s side, of pure descent to the seventh generation, unimpeached and irreproachable in regard to his birth; and he is virtuous, of increasing virtue; and he is learned and wise, and is the first or second to hold the sacrificial ladle.”
“If he had the other three qualities he could be recognized as a true *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin); and truthfully declare, ‘I am a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin),’ without incurring falsehood.”
“But, Brahmin, could not one of these three qualities (*aṅga*) be omitted, leaving two qualities (*aṅga*) whereby one could be recognized as a true *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin); and truthfully declare, ‘I am a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin),’ without incurring falsehood?” “It is possible, venerable Gotama.”
“Indeed, venerable Gotama, we would omit birth (*jāti*) from these three qualities (*aṅga*).”
“But what will birth (*jāti*) do? Because, venerable Gotama, a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) is virtuous, of increasing virtue; and he is learned and wise, and is the first or second to hold the sacrificial ladle."
"on account of these two points that he can truthfully declare: “I am a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin)".
commentary_pali: 311-313.Sujaṃ paggaṇhantānanti yaññayajanatthāya sujaṃ gaṇhantesu brāhmaṇesu paṭhamo vā dutiyo vāti attho. Sujāya diyyamānaṃ mahāyāgaṃ paṭiggaṇhantānanti porāṇā. Iti brāhmaṇo sakasamayavasena sammadeva pañhaṃ vissajjesi. Bhagavā pana visesato uttamabrāhmaṇassa dassanatthaṃ  – ‘‘imesaṃ panā’’tiādimāha. Etadavocunti sace jātivaṇṇamantasampanno brāhmaṇo na hoti, atha ko carahi loke brāhmaṇo  bhavissati? Nāseti no ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo, handassa vādaṃ paṭikkhipissāmāti cintetvā etadavocuṃ. Apavadatīti  paṭikkhipati. Anupakkhandatīti anupavisati. Idaṃ – ‘‘sace tvaṃ pasādavasena samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gantukāmo, gaccha; mā brāhmaṇassa samayaṃ bhindī’’ti adhippāyena āhaṃsu.
commentary_english:
311-313.
"Sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ": This means, among the *brāhmaṇas* who accept *sujaṃ* for the purpose of *yañña* and *yajana*, whether it is the first or the second.
"Sujāya diyyamānaṃ mahāyāgaṃ paṭiggaṇhantānaṃ": The ancient ones.
Thus, the *brāhmaṇa*, according to his own agreement, skillfully answered the question.
But the Blessed One (Bhagavā), especially for the sake of showing the highest *brāhmaṇa*, said, "For these..." and so on.
They said this: "If a *brāhmaṇa* endowed with birth (*jāti*), lineage (*vaṇṇa*), and *mantras* does not exist, then who indeed will be a *brāhmaṇa* in the world? This Soṇadaṇḍa destroys us, come, let us refute his argument," thinking thus, they said this.
"Apavadatīti": He rejects it.
"Anupakkhandatīti": He enters.
This: "If you, through faith, are desirous of going for refuge to the ascetic Gotama, go; do not break the agreement of the *brāhmaṇa*," with this intention they spoke.

mula_pali: 313. Evaṃ  vutte, te brāhmaṇā soṇadaṇḍaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘mā bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo evaṃ avaca, mā bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo evaṃ avaca. Apavadateva bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo vaṇṇaṃ, apavadati mante, apavadati jātiṃ ekaṃsena. Bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo samaṇasseva gotamassa vādaṃ anupakkhandatī’’ti.
mula_english:
When this was said, those Brahmins spoke thus to the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa: "Do not say that, Venerable Soṇadaṇḍa, do not say that!
The esteemed Soṇadaṇḍa is, indeed, disparaging appearance (*varṇa*), he is disparaging the *mantras*, he is disparaging birth (*jāti*) in every way.
The esteemed Soṇadaṇḍa is adopting the ascetic Gotama's own words (*vāda*)!"
commentary_pali: 311-313.Sujaṃ paggaṇhantānanti yaññayajanatthāya sujaṃ gaṇhantesu brāhmaṇesu paṭhamo vā dutiyo vāti attho. Sujāya diyyamānaṃ mahāyāgaṃ paṭiggaṇhantānanti porāṇā. Iti brāhmaṇo sakasamayavasena sammadeva pañhaṃ vissajjesi. Bhagavā pana visesato uttamabrāhmaṇassa dassanatthaṃ  – ‘‘imesaṃ panā’’tiādimāha. Etadavocunti sace jātivaṇṇamantasampanno brāhmaṇo na hoti, atha ko carahi loke brāhmaṇo  bhavissati? Nāseti no ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo, handassa vādaṃ paṭikkhipissāmāti cintetvā etadavocuṃ. Apavadatīti  paṭikkhipati. Anupakkhandatīti anupavisati. Idaṃ – ‘‘sace tvaṃ pasādavasena samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gantukāmo, gaccha; mā brāhmaṇassa samayaṃ bhindī’’ti adhippāyena āhaṃsu.
commentary_english:
311-313.
"Sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ" means that among the *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) who receive the *sujaṃ* for the purpose of sacrifice and offering, whether the first or the second.
"Sujāya diyyamānaṃ mahāyāgaṃ paṭiggaṇhantānaṃ" is what the ancients say.
Thus, the *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) answered the question properly, according to his own tradition.
The Blessed One, however, spoke specifically for the purpose of showing the highest *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin), beginning with "imesaṃ panā."
They said: "If a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) is not accomplished in birth, lineage, *mantras*, then who indeed will be a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) in the world? This Soṇadaṇḍa destroys us. Come, let us refute his doctrine," thinking thus, they said this.
"Apavadatīti" means he rejects.
"Anupakkhandatīti" means he approaches.
This they said with the intention: "If you, through faith, desire to go for refuge to the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama, go; do not break the tradition of the *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins)."

mula_pali: 314. Atha kho bhagavā te brāhmaṇe etadavoca – ‘‘sace kho tumhākaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ evaṃ hoti – ‘appassuto ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, akalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, duppañño ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, na ca pahoti soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ asmiṃ vacane paṭimantetu’nti, tiṭṭhatu soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, tumhe mayā saddhiṃ mantavho asmiṃ vacane. Sace pana tumhākaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ evaṃ hoti – ‘bahussuto ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, kalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, paṇḍito ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo, pahoti ca soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ asmiṃ vacane paṭimantetu’nti, tiṭṭhatha tumhe, soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo mayā saddhiṃ paṭimantetū’’ti.
mula_english:
Then, the Blessed One said to those Brahmins: "If it occurs to you Brahmins: 'The Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa is unlearned ( *appassuto* ), the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa speaks unskilfully (*akalyāṇavākkaraṇo*), the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa is unwise (*duppañño*), and the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa is not capable (*na ca pahoti*) of engaging in conversation with the ascetic Gotama in this matter,' then let the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa remain silent, and you confer with me on this matter.

But if it occurs to you Brahmins: 'The Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa is learned (*bahussuto*), the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa speaks skilfully (*kalyāṇavākkaraṇo*), the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa is wise (*paṇḍito*), and the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa is capable (*pahoti*) of engaging in conversation with the ascetic Gotama in this matter,' then you remain silent, and let the Brāhmin Soṇadaṇḍa engage in conversation with me."
commentary_pali: 314.Etadavocāti imesu brāhmaṇesu evaṃ ekappahāreneva viravantesu ‘‘ayaṃ kathā pariyosānaṃ na gamissati, handa ne nissadde katvā soṇadaṇḍeneva saddhiṃ kathemī’’ti cintetvā – ‘‘etaṃ sace kho tumhāka’’ntiādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca.
commentary_english: He said this when these Brahmins were thus loudly proclaiming with a single outburst: "This talk will not come to an end, come, having made them silent, shall I speak together with Soṇadaṇḍa," thinking thus, he spoke the words beginning with "If this is so for you."

mula_pali: 315. Evaṃ vutte, soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘tiṭṭhatu bhavaṃ gotamo, tuṇhī bhavaṃ gotamo hotu, ahameva tesaṃ sahadhammena  paṭivacanaṃ karissāmī’’ti. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo te brāhmaṇe etadavoca – ‘‘mā bhavanto evaṃ avacuttha, mā bhavanto evaṃ avacuttha – ‘apavadateva bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo vaṇṇaṃ, apavadati mante, apavadati jātiṃ ekaṃsena. Bhavaṃ soṇadaṇḍo  samaṇasseva gotamassa vādaṃ anupakkhandatī’ti. Nāhaṃ, bho, apavadāmi vaṇṇaṃ vā mante vā jātiṃ vā’’ti.
mula_english:
When this was said, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa said this to the Blessed One: "Let venerable Gotama remain, let venerable Gotama be silent; I myself will answer on this matter in accordance with the Dhamma."

Then the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa said this to the Brahmins: "Do not speak thus, do not speak thus: 'Venerable Soṇadaṇḍa indeed disparages appearance ( varṇa ), he disparages mantras, he disparages birth ( jāti ) entirely.'

'Venerable Soṇadaṇḍa is actually adopting the ascetic Gotama's own words!'"

"I, sir ( bho ), do not disparage appearance ( varṇa ), nor mantras, nor birth ( jāti )".
commentary_pali: 315-316.Sahadhammenāti sakāraṇena. Samasamoti ṭhapetvā ekadesasamattaṃ samabhāvena samo, sabbākārena samoti attho. Ahamassa mātāpitaro jānāmīti bhaginiyā puttassa mātāpitaro kiṃ na jānissati, kulakoṭiparidīpanaṃ sandhāyeva vadati. Musāvādampi bhaṇeyyāti atthabhañjanakaṃ musāvādaṃ katheyya. Kiṃ vaṇṇo karissatīti abbhantare guṇe asati kiṃ karissati? Kimassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ rakkhituṃ sakkhissatīti attho. Athāpi siyā puna – ‘‘pakatisīle ṭhitassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ sādhentī’’ti evampi sīlameva sādhessati, tasmiṃ hissa asati brāhmaṇabhāvo nāhosīti sammohamattaṃ vaṇṇādayo. Idaṃ pana sutvā te brāhmaṇā – ‘‘sabhāvaṃ ācariyo āha, akāraṇāva mayaṃ ujjhāyimhā’’ti tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
commentary_english:
315-316.

*Sahadhammena* means with a cause (*sakāraṇena*).

*Samasamo ti ṭhapetvā* means having established equality, to be equal by means of a fraction that is equal, meaning equal in every way, is its significance.

"I know his parents," meaning won't she know the parents of her sister's son? He speaks intending to illuminate the family lineage.

*Musāvādampi bhaṇeyyāti* means he would speak a falsehood, he would utter a false statement which is destructive of meaning.

*Kiṃ vaṇṇo karissatīti* means what will color do? What will it do when there is no inner quality (*guṇe asati*)? What can it do? What will it be capable of doing to protect his state of being a *brāhmaṇa*? This is the meaning.

Even so, it could be again - "'She establishes the state of being a *brāhmaṇa* for one established in natural virtue,'" - even in this way, she will establish virtue, in his absence, the state of being a *brāhmaṇa* does not exist - the colors, etc. are merely a delusion (*sammohamattaṃ*).

Having heard this, those *brāhmaṇas* - "The teacher spoke truthfully, we were needlessly offended" - were silent.

mula_pali: 316. Tena  kho pana samayena soṇadaṇḍassa brāhmaṇassa bhāgineyyo aṅgako nāma māṇavako tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo te brāhmaṇe etadavoca  – ‘‘passanti no bhonto imaṃ aṅgakaṃ māṇavakaṃ amhākaṃ bhāgineyya’’nti? ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’. ‘‘Aṅgako kho, bho, māṇavako abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya, nāssa imissaṃ parisāyaṃ samasamo atthi vaṇṇena ṭhapetvā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ. Aṅgako kho māṇavako ajjhāyako mantadharo, tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo. Ahamassa mante vācetā. Aṅgako kho māṇavako ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Ahamassa mātāpitaro jānāmi. Aṅgako kho māṇavako pāṇampi haneyya, adinnampi ādiyeyya , paradārampi gaccheyya, musāvādampi bhaṇeyya, majjampi piveyya, ettha dāni, bho, kiṃ vaṇṇo karissati, kiṃ mantā, kiṃ jāti? Yato kho, bho, brāhmaṇo sīlavā ca hoti vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato, paṇḍito ca hoti medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imehi kho, bho, dvīhaṅgehi samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapenti; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti.
mula_english:
316. Now at that time, Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin’s nephew, a young man named Aṅgaka, was sitting in that assembly.

Then Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin said to those Brahmins: “Do you see this young man Aṅgaka, our nephew?” “Yes, sir.”

“Aṅgaka, sir, is handsome, good-looking, pleasing, possessed of the utmost beauty of complexion, with a complexion like Brahmā, with the voice of Brahmā, of no mean appearance. There is no one in this assembly equal to him in appearance, except the ascetic Gotama.

Aṅgaka is a student, a reciter of mantras (mantradhara), a master of the Three Vedas (tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū) with their vocabularies (sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ), liturgy, phonology and etymology (sākkharappabhedānaṃ), and the histories as the fifth (itihāsapañcamānaṃ); skilled in philology (padako) and grammar (veyyākaraṇo), he is fully versed in natural philosophy (lokāyata) and in the marks of a Great Man (mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo).

I was his mantra-teacher.

Aṅgaka is well-born on both sides, from his mother and from his father, of pure descent to the seventh generation, unbroken, of irreproachable birth (ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena).

I know his parents.

Aṅgaka might even kill a living being (pāṇampi haneyya), take what is not given (adinnampi ādiyeyya), go to another’s wife (paradārampi gaccheyya), tell a lie (musāvādampi bhaṇeyya), drink intoxicants (majjampi piveyya). What then, sir, will complexion do, what will mantras do, what will birth do? Whereas, sir, a Brahmin is virtuous (sīlavā), of developed virtue (vuddhasīlī), possessed of developed virtue (vuddhasīlena samannāgato), and wise (paṇḍito), intelligent (medhāvī), whether first or second among those who take up the sacred thread.

It is on account of these two qualities that Brahmins recognize a Brahmin; and truthfully declare: “I am a Brahmin (brāhmaṇosmī),” without falling into falsehood."
commentary_pali: 315-316.Sahadhammenāti sakāraṇena. Samasamoti ṭhapetvā ekadesasamattaṃ samabhāvena samo, sabbākārena samoti attho. Ahamassa mātāpitaro jānāmīti bhaginiyā puttassa mātāpitaro kiṃ na jānissati, kulakoṭiparidīpanaṃ sandhāyeva vadati. Musāvādampi bhaṇeyyāti atthabhañjanakaṃ musāvādaṃ katheyya. Kiṃ vaṇṇo karissatīti abbhantare guṇe asati kiṃ karissati? Kimassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ rakkhituṃ sakkhissatīti attho. Athāpi siyā puna – ‘‘pakatisīle ṭhitassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ sādhentī’’ti evampi sīlameva sādhessati, tasmiṃ hissa asati brāhmaṇabhāvo nāhosīti sammohamattaṃ vaṇṇādayo. Idaṃ pana sutvā te brāhmaṇā – ‘‘sabhāvaṃ ācariyo āha, akāraṇāva mayaṃ ujjhāyimhā’’ti tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
commentary_english:
315-316.

*Sahadhammena* means with a reason (*sakāraṇena*).

*Samasamo ti ṭhapetvā* means considering something to be equal, meaning it is equal with equality in one aspect, it is equal in every way (*sabbākārena samo ti attho*).

"I know his parents," meaning, why would she not know the parents of her sister's son? He speaks intending to illuminate the lineage (*kulakoṭiparidīpanaṃ sandhāyeva vadati*).

"He might speak falsehood," meaning, he would speak a falsehood that destroys the meaning (*atthabhañjanakaṃ musāvādaṃ katheyya*).

"What will complexion do?" meaning, what will it do when there is no inner quality (*abbhantare guṇe asati kiṃ karissati*)? What does it mean that he will be able to preserve his state of being a *brāhmaṇa* (*kimassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ rakkhituṃ sakkhissatīti attho*)?

Even if it were to be again – "establishing the state of being a *brāhmaṇa* for one established in natural virtue" (*pakatisīle ṭhitassa brāhmaṇabhāvaṃ sādhentīti*), even in this way, he would only establish virtue (*sīlameva sādhessati*), for without that, his state of being a *brāhmaṇa* would not exist (*tasmિં hissa asati brāhmaṇabhāvo nāhosīti*), so the qualities like complexion are merely bewildering (*sammohamattaṃ vaṇṇādayo*).

Having heard this, those *brāhmaṇas* – "The teacher speaks truthfully (*sabhāvaṃ ācariyo āha*), we criticized him for no reason (*akāraṇāva mayaṃ ujjhāyimhā*)" – were silent (*tuṇhī ahesuṃ*).

mula_pali: 317. ‘‘Imesaṃ pana, brāhmaṇa, dvinnaṃ aṅgānaṃ sakkā ekaṃ aṅgaṃ ṭhapayitvā ekena aṅgena samannāgataṃ brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṃ paññapetuṃ; ‘brāhmaṇosmī’ti ca vadamāno sammā vadeyya, na ca pana musāvādaṃ āpajjeyyā’’ti? ‘‘No  hidaṃ, bho gotama. Sīlaparidhotā hi, bho gotama, paññā; paññāparidhotaṃ sīlaṃ. Yattha sīlaṃ tattha paññā, yattha paññā tattha sīlaṃ. Sīlavato paññā, paññavato sīlaṃ. Sīlapaññāṇañca pana lokasmiṃ aggamakkhāyati. Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, hatthena vā hatthaṃ dhoveyya, pādena vā pādaṃ dhoveyya; evameva kho, bho gotama, sīlaparidhotā paññā, paññāparidhotaṃ  sīlaṃ. Yattha sīlaṃ tattha paññā, yattha paññā tattha sīlaṃ. Sīlavato paññā, paññavato sīlaṃ. Sīlapaññāṇañca pana lokasmiṃ aggamakkhāyatī’’ti. ‘‘Evametaṃ, brāhmaṇa, evametaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sīlaparidhotā hi, brāhmaṇa, paññā, paññāparidhotaṃ sīlaṃ. Yattha sīlaṃ tattha paññā, yattha paññā tattha sīlaṃ. Sīlavato paññā, paññavato sīlaṃ. Sīlapaññāṇañca pana lokasmiṃ aggamakkhāyati. Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇa, hatthena vā hatthaṃ dhoveyya, pādena vā pādaṃ dhoveyya; evameva kho, brāhmaṇa, sīlaparidhotā paññā, paññāparidhotaṃ  sīlaṃ. Yattha sīlaṃ tattha paññā, yattha paññā tattha sīlaṃ. Sīlavato paññā, paññavato sīlaṃ. Sīlapaññāṇañca pana lokasmiṃ aggamakkhāyati .
mula_english:
“But, Brahmin, could brahmins, having omitted one of these two qualities and possessing the other, designate another as a Brahmin, and would he who says ‘I am a Brahmin’ be speaking correctly, and would he not incur falsehood?”

“No, Master Gotama. For wisdom (*prajñā*) is purified by morality (*śīla*), and morality (*śīla*) is purified by wisdom (*prajñā*). Where there is morality (*śīla*), there is wisdom (*prajñā*), and where there is wisdom (*prajñā*), there is morality (*śīla*). The moral person has wisdom (*prajñāvat*) and the wise person has morality (*śīlavat*). And the combination of morality (*śīla*) and wisdom (*prajñā*) is called the highest thing in the world. Just as, Master Gotama, one hand washes the other, or one foot washes the other, so too, Master Gotama, wisdom (*prajñā*) is purified by morality (*śīla*), and morality (*śīla*) is purified by wisdom (*prajñā*). Where there is morality (*śīla*), there is wisdom (*prajñā*), and where there is wisdom (*prajñā*), there is morality (*śīla*). The moral person has wisdom (*prajñāvat*) and the wise person has morality (*śīlavat*). And the combination of morality (*śīla*) and wisdom (*prajñā*) is called the highest thing in the world.”

“So it is, Brahmin, so it is, Brahmin. Wisdom (*prajñā*) is purified by morality (*śīla*), and morality (*śīla*) is purified by wisdom (*prajñā*). Where there is morality (*śīla*), there is wisdom (*prajñā*), and where there is wisdom (*prajñā*), there is morality (*śīla*). The moral person has wisdom (*prajñāvat*) and the wise person has morality (*śīlavat*). And the combination of morality (*śīla*) and wisdom (*prajñā*) is called the highest thing in the world. Just as, Brahmin, one hand washes the other, or one foot washes the other, so too, Brahmin, wisdom (*prajñā*) is purified by morality (*śīla*), and morality (*śīla*) is purified by wisdom (*prajñā*). Where there is morality (*śīla*), there is wisdom (*prajñā*), and where there is wisdom (*prajñā*), there is morality (*śīla*). The moral person has wisdom (*prajñāvat*) and the wise person has morality (*śīlavat*). And the combination of morality (*śīla*) and wisdom (*prajñā*) is called the highest thing in the world."
commentary_pali: 317. Tato bhagavā ‘kathito brāhmaṇena pañho, kiṃ panettha patiṭṭhātuṃ sakkhissati, na sakkhissatī’ti? Tassa vīmaṃsanatthaṃ – ‘‘imesaṃ pana brāhmaṇā’’tiādimāha. Sīlaparidhotāti sīlaparisuddhā. Yattha sīlaṃ tattha paññāti yasmiṃ puggale sīlaṃ, tattheva paññā, kuto dussīle paññā? Paññārahite vā jaḷe eḷamūge kuto sīlanti? Sīlapaññāṇanti sīlañca paññāṇañca sīlapaññāṇaṃ. Paññāṇanti paññāyeva. Evametaṃ brāhmaṇāti  bhagavā brāhmaṇassa vacanaṃ  anujānanto āha. Tattha sīlaparidhotā paññāti catupārisuddhisīlena dhotā. Kathaṃ pana sīlena paññaṃ dhovatīti? Yassa puthujjanassa sīlaṃ saṭṭhiasītivassāni akhaṇḍaṃ hoti, so maraṇakālepi sabbakilese ghātetvā sīlena paññaṃ dhovitvā arahattaṃ gaṇhāti. Kandarasālapariveṇe mahāsaṭṭhivassatthero viya. There kira maraṇamañce nipajjitvā balavavedanāya nitthunante , tissamahārājā ‘‘theraṃ passissāmī’’ti gantvā pariveṇadvāre ṭhito taṃ saddaṃ sutvā pucchi – ‘‘kassa saddo aya’’nti? Therassa nitthunanasaddoti. ‘‘Pabbajjāya saṭṭhivassena vedanāpariggahamattampi na kataṃ, na dāni naṃ vandissāmī’’ti nivattitvā mahābodhiṃ vandituṃ gato. Tato upaṭṭhākadaharo theraṃ āha – ‘‘kiṃ no, bhante, lajjāpetha, saddhopi rājā vippaṭisārī hutvā na vandissāmī’’ti gatoti. Kasmā āvusoti? Tumhākaṃ nitthunanasaddaṃ sutvāti. ‘‘Tena hi me okāsaṃ karothā’’ti vatvā vedanaṃ vikkhambhitvā arahattaṃ patvā daharassa saññaṃ adāsi – ‘‘gacchāvuso, idāni rājānaṃ amhe vandāpehī’’ti. Daharo gantvā – ‘‘idāni kira theraṃ, vandathā’’ti āha. Rājā saṃsumārapatitena theraṃ vandanto – ‘‘nāhaṃ ayyassa arahattaṃ vandāmi, puthujjanabhūmiyaṃ pana ṭhatvā rakkhitasīlameva vandāmī’’ti āha, evaṃ sīlena paññaṃ dhovati nāma. Yassa pana abbhantare sīlasaṃvaro natthi, ugghāṭitaññutāya pana catuppadikagāthāpariyosāne paññāya sīlaṃ dhovitvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Ayaṃ paññāya sīlaṃ dhovati nāma. Seyyathāpi santatimahāmatto.
commentary_english:
317. Then, the Blessed One said, "The question was asked by the *brāhmaṇa*: ‘Will it be possible to establish oneself here, or will it not be possible?’" For the purpose of examining that, he spoke beginning with, "But to these *brāhmaṇas*."

*Śīlaparidhotā* means purity of virtue.

Where there is virtue (*śīla*), there is wisdom (*prajñā*); in whatever person there is virtue, there is wisdom; where is wisdom in an immoral person (*dussīle*)? Where is virtue in one devoid of wisdom, or in a dull, mute person? *Śīlapaññāṇa* means both virtue and wisdom are *śīlapaññāṇa*.

*Paññāṇa* is simply wisdom.

"So it is, *brāhmaṇa*," the Blessed One said, assenting to the words of the *brāhmaṇa*.

There, *śīlaparidhotā paññā* means cleansed by the fourfold purity of virtue (*catupārisuddhi-sīla*).

How does one cleanse wisdom with virtue? If a common person's (*puthujjanassa*) virtue is unbroken for sixty or eighty years, at the time of death, even after destroying all defilements (*sabba-kilese*), having cleansed wisdom with virtue, he attains arahantship (*arahattaṃ*).

Like the elder (*thero*) Mahāsaṭṭhivassa in the Kandarasāla enclosure.

It is said that while the elder was lying on his deathbed groaning with intense pain (*balavavedanāya nitthunante*), King Tissa Mahārāja, thinking "I will see the elder," went to the enclosure gate. Hearing that sound, he asked, "Whose sound is this?" "It is the sound of the elder's groaning."

Thinking, "For sixty years since ordination, he has not even made an end to the perception of pain (*vedanāpariggahamattampi na kataṃ*), I will not pay homage to him now," he turned back and went to pay homage to the Great Bodhi Tree (*mahābodhiṃ vandituṃ gato*).

Then the young attendant (*upaṭṭhākadaharo*) said to the elder, "Why, venerable sir (*bhante*), do you shame us? Even the believing king (*saddhopi rājā*), becoming remorseful, has gone without paying homage."

"Why, friend (*āvuso*)?" "Having heard your groaning sound."

"Then make an opportunity for me," he said. Having suppressed the pain and attained arahantship, he gave a sign to the young one: "Go, friend, have the king pay homage to me now."

The young one went and said, "Now, indeed, pay homage to the elder."

As the king, having fallen with a crocodile-like fall (*saṃsumārapatitena*), was paying homage to the elder, he said, "I do not pay homage to the arahantship of the venerable one (*ayyassa arahattaṃ vandāmi*), but having stood on the ground of a common person (*puthujjanabhūmiyaṃ*), I only pay homage to the virtue that was protected (*rakkhitasīlameva vandāmī*)," he said. Thus, it is called cleansing wisdom with virtue (*sīlena paññaṃ dhovati nāma*).

For whomever there is no restraint of virtue (*sīlasaṃvaro*) within, but by means of awakened understanding (*ugghāṭitaññutāya*), at the end of the four-lined verse (*catuppadikagāthāpariyosāne*), having cleansed virtue with wisdom (*paññāya sīlaṃ dhovitvā*), together with the analytical insights (*paṭisambhidāhi*), he attains arahantship (*arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti*).

This is called cleansing virtue with wisdom (*paññāya sīlaṃ dhovati nāma*).

Just like Santati Mahāmatta.

mula_pali: 318. ‘‘Katamaṃ pana taṃ, brāhmaṇa, sīlaṃ? Katamā sā paññā’’ti? ‘‘Ettakaparamāva mayaṃ, bho gotama, etasmiṃ atthe. Sādhu vata bhavantaṃyeva gotamaṃ paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho’’ti. ‘‘Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇohi; sādhukaṃ manasikarohi; bhāsissāmī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi. Bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘idha, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu tathā vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti. Idaṃ kho taṃ, brāhmaṇa, sīlaṃ…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati…pe… ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati, abhininnāmeti. Idampissa hoti paññāya…pe…  nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti, idampissa hoti paññāya ayaṃ kho sā, brāhmaṇa, paññā’’ti.
mula_english:
318.
“But what, brahmin, is that morality? What is that wisdom?”
“Reverend Gotama, our understanding of this matter extends only this far.
It would be well if the Reverend Gotama were to explain the meaning of this utterance.”
“Then listen, brahmin, pay proper attention, and I will speak.”
“Yes, sir”, said Soṇadaṇḍa the brahmin in reply to the Blessed One.
The Blessed One said this: “Here, brahmin, a *Tathāgata* appears in the world, a worthy one, a fully enlightened one… (as in sections 190-212, so it should be expanded in detail).
Thus, brahmin, a *bhikkhu* is perfected in morality.
That, brahmin, is morality… he attains the first *jhāna*, dwells in it… the second *jhāna*… the third *jhāna*… he attains the fourth *jhāna* and dwells in it… he directs and inclines his mind to knowledge and vision.
Furthermore, he has wisdom… he understands, ‘There is nothing beyond this.’ Furthermore, he has wisdom. That, brahmin, is wisdom.”
commentary_pali: 318.Katamaṃ pana taṃ brāhmaṇāti kasmā āha? Bhagavā kira cintesi – ‘‘brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇasamaye pañcasīlāni ‘sīla’nti paññāpenti, vedattayauggahaṇapaññā paññāti. Uparivisesaṃ  na jānanti. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ brāhmaṇassa uttarivisesabhūtaṃ maggasīlaṃ, phalasīlaṃ, maggapaññaṃ, phalapaññañca dassetvā arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhapeyya’’nti. Atha naṃ kathetukamyatāya pucchanto – ‘‘katamaṃ pana taṃ, brāhmaṇa, sīlaṃ katamā sā paññā’’ti āha. Atha brāhmaṇo – ‘‘mayā sakasamayavasena pañho vissajjito. Samaṇo pana maṃ gotamo puna nivattitvā pucchati, idānissāhaṃ cittaṃ paritosetvā vissajjituṃ  sakkuṇeyyaṃ vā na vā? Sace na sakkhissaṃ paṭhamaṃ uppannāpi me lajjā bhijjissati. Asakkontassa pana na sakkomīti vacane doso natthī’’ti puna nivattitvā bhagavatoyeva bhāraṃ karonto ‘‘ettakaparamāva maya’’ntiādimāha. Tattha ettakaparamāti ettakaṃ sīlapaññāṇanti vacanameva paramaṃ amhākaṃ, te mayaṃ ettakaparamā, ito paraṃ etassa bhāsitassa atthaṃ na jānāmāti attho. Athassa bhagavā sīlapaññāya mūlabhūtassa tathāgatassa uppādato pabhuti sīlapaññāṇaṃ dassetuṃ – ‘‘idha brāhmaṇa, tathāgato’’tiādimāha. Tassattho sāmaññaphale vuttanayeneva veditabbo, ayaṃ pana viseso, idha tividhampi sīlaṃ – ‘‘idampissa hoti sīlasmi’’nti evaṃ sīlamicceva niyyātitaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīni cattāri jhānāni atthato paññāsampadā. Evaṃ  paññāvasena pana aniyyātetvā vipassanāpaññāya padaṭṭhānabhāvamattena dassetvā vipassanāpaññāto paṭṭhāya paññā niyyātitāti.
commentary_english:
318.
Why did he ask, "What is that, O brāhmaṇa?" The Blessed One considered, "Brāhmaṇas, at the time of brāhmaṇas, teach the five precepts as 'virtue' (*śīla*), and the wisdom of grasping the three Vedas as 'wisdom' (*prajñā*).

They do not know the superior distinction.

Suppose I were to show the *brāhmaṇa* the path virtue (*maggasīla*), the fruit virtue (*phalasīla*), the path wisdom (*maggapaññaṃ*), the fruit wisdom (*phalapaññaṃ*), which are superior and distinct, and conclude the teaching with the pinnacle of *arhatship*."

Then, asking with the desire to speak, he said, "What is that, O *brāhmaṇa*, virtue (*śīla*) and what is that wisdom (*prajñā*)?"

Then the *brāhmaṇa* said, "The question was dismissed by me according to my own tradition.

The *śramaṇa* Gotama, however, asks me again, having returned. Now, can I satisfy my mind and dismiss it, or not? If I cannot, even the shame that arose before will be broken."

"There is no fault in saying 'I cannot' for one who cannot," having returned again, carrying the burden only of the Blessed One, he said, beginning with "We are limited to this."

There, "limited to this" means, "This much is the virtue-wisdom (*sīlapaññāṇa*) the word itself is supreme for us, we are limited to this; beyond this, we do not know the meaning of this speech," is the meaning.

Then the Blessed One, in order to show the virtue-wisdom (*sīlapaññāṇa*) from the arising of the *Tathāgata*, which is the root of virtue-wisdom (*sīlapaññā*), said, beginning with "Here, O *brāhmaṇa*, is the *Tathāgata*."

Its meaning should be understood in the same way as said in the common fruit. This, however, is the distinction: here, even the threefold virtue (*śīla*)—"This also exists in virtue (*śīlasmi*)"—thus, virtue (*śīla*) itself is imparted; the four *jhānas*, beginning with the first *jhāna* (*paṭhamajjhāna*), are, in meaning, the perfection of wisdom (*paññāsampadā*).

Thus, by the power of wisdom (*paññā*), without imparting it, showing it merely by the state of being the foundation of insight wisdom (*vipassanāpaññā*), from insight wisdom (*vipassanāpaññā*) onwards, wisdom (*paññā*) is imparted.

mula_pali: 319. Evaṃ vutte, soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ , bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama . Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya, ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ . Adhivāsetu ca me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’’ti. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
mula_english:
319. When this was said, the Brahmin Soṇadaṇḍa said this to the Blessed One: “Excellent, Master Gotama, excellent!

It is as if, Master Gotama, one were to set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or hold an oil lamp in the dark, so that those with eyes might see forms. In the same way, the *dharma* has been made clear in many ways by Master Gotama.

I go to Master Gotama for refuge, and to the *dharma*, and to the *bhikkhu-saṃgha*.

May Master Gotama accept me as a lay follower (*upāsaka*) who has gone for refuge, from this day forth, as long as life shall last.

May Master Gotama consent to accept tomorrow's meal from me, together with the *bhikkhu-saṃgha*."

The Blessed One consented by remaining silent.
commentary_pali: 319-322.Svātanāyāti padassa attho ajjatanāyāti ettha vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Tena maṃ sā parisā paribhaveyyāti tena tumhe dūratova disvā āsanā vuṭṭhitakāraṇena maṃ sā parisā – ‘‘ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo pacchimavaye ṭhito mahallako, gotamo pana daharo yuvā nattāpissa nappahoti, so nāma attano nattumattabhāvampi appattassa āsanā vuṭṭhātī’’ti paribhaveyya. Āsanā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānanti mama agāravena avuṭṭhānaṃ  nāma natthi, bhoganāsanabhayena pana na vuṭṭhahissāmi, taṃ tumhe hi ceva mayā ca ñātuṃ vaṭṭati. Tasmā āsanā me etaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānaṃ dhāretūti, iminā kira sadiso kuhako dullabho, bhagavati panassa agāravaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā bhoganāsanabhayā kuhanavasena evaṃ vadati. Parapadesupi eseva nayo. Dhammiyā kathāyātiādīsu taṅkhaṇānurūpāya dhammiyā kathāya diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaṃ atthaṃ sandassetvā kusale dhamme samādapetvā gaṇhāpetvā. Tattha naṃ samuttejetvā saussāhaṃ katvā tāya ca saussāhatāya aññehi ca vijjamānaguṇehi sampahaṃsetvā dhammaratanavassaṃ vassitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā  pakkāmi. Brāhmaṇo pana attano kuhakatāya evampi bhagavati dhammavassaṃ vassite visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi. Kevalamassa āyatiṃ nibbānatthāya vāsanābhāgiyāya ca sabbā purimapacchimakathā ahosīti.
commentary_english:
319-322.
The meaning of the word *svātanāyāti* should be understood in the same way as *ajjatanāyāti* was explained here.

"Lest that assembly should despise me," (that is,) "because seeing you from afar, due to the reason of rising from the seat, that assembly should despise me, (saying): 'This Soṇadaṇḍa is old, standing in his old age, but Gotama is young, even his grandson is not able (to rise); he, indeed, rises from the seat for one who has not even attained the state of being merely his grandson.'"

"That the venerable Gotama should rise up for me from (my) seat," (means) there is no rising up out of disrespect for me; but I will not rise out of fear of ruining the seat; that you both and I should know.

"Therefore, let the venerable Gotama retain that rising up from the seat for me," (means,) truly, a deceiver like him is rare; but there is no disrespect for the Blessed One in him; therefore, he speaks thus by way of deceit out of fear of spoiling the seat.

And the same rule applies in other passages.

In the case of "through talk consistent with the *dharma*," and so on, having shown the meaning relating to what is visible in this life and what relates to the future life through talk consistent with the *dharma* and corresponding to the occasion, having caused (them) to be established and to take up the skillful qualities.

There, having encouraged him, having made him enthusiastic, and having gladdened him with that enthusiasm and with other existing good qualities, having rained down a rain of the jewel of the *dharma*, he rose from his seat and departed.

But the *brāhmaṇa* was not able to produce a distinction even in the *dharma* rain having been rained down by the Blessed One, because of his own deceit.

Only for him, all the previous and subsequent talk was for the sake of future attainment, for the sake of the potential for *nirvāṇa*.

mula_pali: 320. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi – ‘‘kālo, bho gotama, niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta’’nti. Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena soṇadaṇḍassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami ; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
mula_english:
Then Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, knowing the Blessed One's acceptance, rose from his seat, respectfully saluted the Blessed One, circumambulated him keeping him on his right, and departed.

Then Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, at the end of that night, in his own dwelling, had exquisite staple and non-staple food prepared, and had the time announced to the Blessed One, saying: "It is time, Master Gotama, the meal is ready."

Then the Blessed One, having dressed in the morning, taking his bowl and robe, together with the monastic community (bhikkhusaṅgha), went to the dwelling of Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin; having arrived, he sat down on the prepared seat.

Then Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahmin, with his own hands, satisfied and served the monastic community (bhikkhusaṅgha), with the Buddha at their head, with exquisite staple and non-staple food.

Tena maṃ sā parisā paribhaveyyāti tena tumhe dūratova disvā āsanā vuṭṭhitakāraṇena maṃ sā parisā – ‘‘ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo pacchimavaye ṭhito mahallako, gotamo pana daharo yuvā nattāpissa nappahoti, so nāma attano nattumattabhāvampi appattassa āsanā vuṭṭhātī’’ti paribhaveyya. Tattha naṃ samuttejetvā saussāhaṃ katvā tāya ca saussāhatāya aññehi ca vijjamānaguṇehi sampahaṃsetvā dhammaratanavassaṃ vassitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā  pakkāmi. Brāhmaṇo pana attano kuhakatāya evampi bhagavati dhammavassaṃ vassite visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi. Kevalamassa āyatiṃ nibbānatthāya vāsanābhāgiyāya ca sabbā purimapacchimakathā ahosīti.
commentary_english:
319-322.

The meaning of the word *svātanāyāti* should be understood in the same way as *ajjatanāyāti* was explained here.

"Because that assembly might despise me," therefore, seeing you from afar, because I rise from my seat, that assembly would despise me, saying: "This Soṇadaṇḍa is old and advanced in years, but Gotama is young and youthful and not even his grandson. He rises from his seat even for one who has not attained the state of being merely his grandson."

"Gotama, the revered one, rising from the seat is respect for me," there is no such thing as my not rising due to disrespect, but I will not rise out of fear of ruining my meal and seat, this you and I should know.

Therefore, "Let Gotama, the revered one, hold rising from the seat as respect for me," it is rare to find a deceiver similar to him, there is no disrespect for the Blessed One, therefore he speaks thus due to deceitfulness arising from fear of ruining his meal and seat.

And the same rule applies in other instances as well.

In the *dhammiyā kathāyātiādīsu*, having shown the benefit of the *diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyika* (visible here and in the future) with a *dhārmī kathā* (discourse on the Dharma) that is appropriate to the occasion, having encouraged and caused to take up skillful *dharmas* (qualities).

There, having encouraged him, having made (him) enthusiastic, and having delighted (him) with that enthusiasm and with other existing good qualities, having rained down a shower of the jewel of the Dharma, he rose from his seat and departed.

But the *brāhmaṇa* was unable to bring about a distinction even when the Blessed One rained down a shower of the Dharma due to his own deceitfulness.

Only all the previous and subsequent talk of his was for the sake of future, for the sake of *nirvāṇa* (extinguishment), partaking of the disposition of *vāsanā* (latent impressions).

mula_pali: 321. Atha kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ  nisinno kho soṇadaṇḍo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘ahañceva kho pana, bho gotama, parisagato samāno āsanā vuṭṭhahitvā bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhivādeyyaṃ, tena maṃ sā parisā paribhaveyya. Yaṃ kho pana sā parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha. Yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ. Yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā. Ahañceva kho pana, bho gotama, parisagato samāno añjaliṃ paggaṇheyyaṃ, āsanā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānaṃ dhāretu. Ahañceva  kho pana, bho gotama, parisagato samāno veṭhanaṃ omuñceyyaṃ, sirasā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo abhivādanaṃ dhāretu. Ahañceva kho pana, bho gotama, yānagato samāno yānā paccorohitvā bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhivādeyyaṃ, tena maṃ sā parisā paribhaveyya. Yaṃ kho pana sā parisā paribhaveyya, yasopi tassa hāyetha, yassa kho pana yaso hāyetha, bhogāpi tassa hāyeyyuṃ. Yasoladdhā kho panamhākaṃ bhogā. Ahañceva kho pana, bho gotama, yānagato samāno patodalaṭṭhiṃ abbhunnāmeyyaṃ, yānā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccorohanaṃ dhāretu. Ahañceva  kho pana, bho gotama, yānagato samāno chattaṃ apanāmeyyaṃ, sirasā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo abhivādanaṃ dhāretū’’ti.
mula_english:
321. Then, Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahman, after the Blessed One had finished eating and had removed his hand from the bowl, took a low seat and sat down to one side.

Sitting to one side, Soṇadaṇḍa the Brahman said this to the Blessed One: "If, venerable Gotama, when I have entered the assembly, I were to rise from my seat and salute the venerable Gotama, that assembly would despise me.

And if that assembly were to despise me, my reputation (*yaśas*) would suffer.

And if my reputation (*yaśas*) were to suffer, my income (*bhoga*) would also suffer.

For our income (*bhoga*) depends on gaining a reputation (*yaśas*).

And if, venerable Gotama, when I have entered the assembly, I were to join my palms in greeting (*añjali*), may the venerable Gotama take it as if I had risen from my seat.

And if, venerable Gotama, when I have entered the assembly, I were to take off my turban (*veṭhanaṃ*), may the venerable Gotama take it as if I had bowed my head (*sirasā*) in salutation (*abhivādanaṃ*).

Or if, venerable Gotama, when riding in my carriage (*yāna*), I were to alight from the carriage (*yāna*) to salute the venerable Gotama, that assembly would despise me.

And if that assembly were to despise me, my reputation (*yaśas*) would suffer, and if my reputation (*yaśas*) were to suffer, my income (*bhoga*) would also suffer.

For our income (*bhoga*) depends on the gaining of a reputation (*yaśas*).

And if, venerable Gotama, when riding in my carriage (*yāna*), I were to raise my goad (*patodalaṭṭhiṃ*), may the venerable Gotama take it as if I had alighted from my carriage (*yāna*).

And if, venerable Gotama, when riding in my carriage (*yāna*), I were to lower my parasol (*chattaṃ*), may the venerable Gotama take it as if I had bowed my head (*sirasā*) in salutation (*abhivādanaṃ*)."
commentary_pali: 319-322.Svātanāyāti padassa attho ajjatanāyāti ettha vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Tena maṃ sā parisā paribhaveyyāti tena tumhe dūratova disvā āsanā vuṭṭhitakāraṇena maṃ sā parisā – ‘‘ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo pacchimavaye ṭhito mahallako, gotamo pana daharo yuvā nattāpissa nappahoti, so nāma attano nattumattabhāvampi appattassa āsanā vuṭṭhātī’’ti paribhaveyya. Āsanā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānanti mama agāravena avuṭṭhānaṃ  nāma natthi, bhoganāsanabhayena pana na vuṭṭhahissāmi, taṃ tumhe hi ceva mayā ca ñātuṃ vaṭṭati. Tasmā āsanā me etaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānaṃ dhāretūti, iminā kira sadiso kuhako dullabho, bhagavati panassa agāravaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā bhoganāsanabhayā kuhanavasena evaṃ vadati. Parapadesupi eseva nayo. Dhammiyā kathāyātiādīsu taṅkhaṇānurūpāya dhammiyā kathāya diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaṃ atthaṃ sandassetvā kusale dhamme samādapetvā gaṇhāpetvā. Tattha naṃ samuttejetvā saussāhaṃ katvā tāya ca saussāhatāya aññehi ca vijjamānaguṇehi sampahaṃsetvā dhammaratanavassaṃ vassitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā  pakkāmi. Brāhmaṇo pana attano kuhakatāya evampi bhagavati dhammavassaṃ vassite visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi. Kevalamassa āyatiṃ nibbānatthāya vāsanābhāgiyāya ca sabbā purimapacchimakathā ahosīti.
commentary_english:
319-322.
The meaning of the word *svātanāyāti* should be understood in the same way as the word *ajjatanāyāti* was explained here.

"Lest that assembly despise me," thinking thus, "because you, seeing me from afar, [think,] 'This Soṇadaṇḍa is old, having lived a long time; Gotama, however, is young and youthful, not even his grandson is a match for him.' That one rises from his seat for someone who has not even attained the status of his own grandson!" thus, they would despise me.

"Gotama rises to greet me from (his) seat" means there is no non-rising of mine due to disrespect; however, I will not rise due to fear of disturbing my meal, this you should know, indeed, both you and I.

Therefore, "Let Gotama retain (his) rising to greet me from (his) seat," thus (he thought). Truly, a cheat like this is hard to find; however, there is no disrespect for the Blessed One in him, therefore he speaks thus through pretense due to fear of disturbing the meal.

And the same rule applies to other instances.

In the case of "through talk consistent with the Dharma," and so on, having shown the benefit that is visible in this life and the benefit in the future life through talk consistent with the Dharma appropriate to the occasion, having induced (him) in wholesome principles, having made (him) grasp (them).

There, having roused him, having made (him) enthusiastic, and having gladdened (him) with that enthusiasm and with other existing virtues, having rained down a rain of the jewel of the Dharma, having risen from his seat, he departed.

However, the *brāhmaṇa* was unable to bring about a distinction in the Blessed One, even in this way, when the rain of the Dharma was rained down, due to his own deceitfulness.

The entire previous and subsequent talk of his was only for the sake of inclination towards the element of aspiration for liberation in the future.

mula_pali: 322. Atha kho bhagavā soṇadaṇḍaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
mula_english: Then the Blessed One, having instructed the Brahman Sonadanda with a talk on Dhamma, inspired him, encouraged him, gladdened him, rose from his seat and departed.
commentary_pali: 319-322.Svātanāyāti padassa attho ajjatanāyāti ettha vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Tena maṃ sā parisā paribhaveyyāti tena tumhe dūratova disvā āsanā vuṭṭhitakāraṇena maṃ sā parisā – ‘‘ayaṃ soṇadaṇḍo pacchimavaye ṭhito mahallako, gotamo pana daharo yuvā nattāpissa nappahoti, so nāma attano nattumattabhāvampi appattassa āsanā vuṭṭhātī’’ti paribhaveyya. Āsanā me taṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānanti mama agāravena avuṭṭhānaṃ  nāma natthi, bhoganāsanabhayena pana na vuṭṭhahissāmi, taṃ tumhe hi ceva mayā ca ñātuṃ vaṭṭati. Tasmā āsanā me etaṃ bhavaṃ gotamo paccuṭṭhānaṃ dhāretūti, iminā kira sadiso kuhako dullabho, bhagavati panassa agāravaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā bhoganāsanabhayā kuhanavasena evaṃ vadati. Parapadesupi eseva nayo. Dhammiyā kathāyātiādīsu taṅkhaṇānurūpāya dhammiyā kathāya diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaṃ atthaṃ sandassetvā kusale dhamme samādapetvā gaṇhāpetvā. Tattha naṃ samuttejetvā saussāhaṃ katvā tāya ca saussāhatāya aññehi ca vijjamānaguṇehi sampahaṃsetvā dhammaratanavassaṃ vassitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā  pakkāmi. Brāhmaṇo pana attano kuhakatāya evampi bhagavati dhammavassaṃ vassite visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi. Kevalamassa āyatiṃ nibbānatthāya vāsanābhāgiyāya ca sabbā purimapacchimakathā ahosīti.
commentary_english:
319-322.
The meaning of the word *svātanāyāti* should be understood in the same way as *ajjatanāyāti* was explained here.

"Lest that assembly should slight me," thinking, "because of seeing you from afar, that assembly would slight me because of the reason for rising from my seat, [thinking] – 'This Soṇadaṇḍa is old, standing in his declining years, but Gotama is young and youthful, even his grandson is not capable, indeed, why does he rise from his seat for one who has not even attained the state of being his grandson?'"

"That venerable Gotama offered a welcome by rising from his seat for me," there is indeed no non-rising due to disrespect for me, but I will not rise from fear of losing the seat for eating; it is fitting that you and I should know that.

Therefore, [Soṇadaṇḍa said,] "Let the venerable Gotama hold the welcome by rising from the seat for me,” like this deceiver is rare, but there is indeed no disrespect in the Blessed One for him, therefore he speaks thus out of deceit because of fear of losing the seat for eating.

And in other instances, the same rule applies.

In the case of "through talk consistent with the Dharma," and so on, having shown the meaning relating to what is visible in this life and the life to come, through talk consistent with the Dharma, appropriate for the occasion, having encouraged and established them in wholesome qualities.

There, having inspired him, having made him enthusiastic, and having delighted him with that enthusiasm and with the existing good qualities of others, having rained down a shower of the jewel of the Dharma, he rose from his seat and departed.

But the *brāhmaṇa* was not able to bring about any distinction, even when a shower of the Dharma was rained down by the Blessed One because of his own deceit.

Only all his past and future talk was for the sake of Nibbāna in the future, and conducive to inclination.

mula_pali: 444. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme aciraparinibbute bhagavati. Tena kho pana samayena subho māṇavo todeyyaputto sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion, the venerable Ānanda was staying near Śrāvastī, in the Jetavana, at Anāthapindika’s monastery, not long after the Blessed One's *parinirvāṇa*.

And at that time, Subha, the young *brāhmaṇa* Todeyyaputta, was staying in Śrāvastī on some business or other.
commentary_pali: 444.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… sāvatthiyanti subhasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ anuttānapadavaṇṇanā. Aciraparinibbute bhagavatīti aciraṃ parinibbute bhagavati, parinibbānato uddhaṃ māsamatte kāle. Nidānavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ ādāya āgantvā khīravirecanaṃ pivitvā vihāre nisinnadivasaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Todeyyaputtoti todeyyabrāhmaṇassa putto, so kira sāvatthiyā avidūre tudigāmo nāma atthi, tassa adhipatittā todeyyoti saṅkhyaṃ gato. Mahaddhano pana hoti pañcacattālīsakoṭivibhavo, paramamaccharī – ‘‘dadato bhogānaṃ aparikkhayo nāma natthī’’ti cintetvā kassaci kiñci na deti, puttampi āha – Evaṃ adānameva sikkhāpetvā kāyassa bhedā tasmiṃyeva ghare sunakho hutvā nibbatto. Subho taṃ sunakhaṃ ativiya piyāyati. Attano bhuñjanakabhattaṃyeva bhojeti, ukkhipitvā varasayane sayāpeti. Atha bhagavā ekadivasaṃ nikkhante māṇave taṃ gharaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi. Sunakho bhagavantaṃ disvā bhukkāraṃ karonto bhagavato samīpaṃ gato. Tato naṃ bhagavā avoca ‘‘todeyya tvaṃ pubbepi maṃ ‘bho, bho’ti paribhavitvā sunakho jāto, idānipi bhukkāraṃ katvā avīciṃ gamissasī’’ti. Sunakho taṃ kathaṃ sutvā vippaṭisārī hutvā uddhanantare chārikāya nipanno, manussā naṃ ukkhipitvā sayane sayāpetuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu . Subho āgantvā ‘‘kenāyaṃ sunakho sayanā oropito’’ti āha. Manussā ‘‘na kenacī’’ti  vatvā taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesuṃ. Māṇavo sutvā ‘‘mama pitā brahmaloke nibbatto, samaṇo pana gotamo me pitaraṃ sunakhaṃ karoti yaṃ kiñci esa mukhārūḷhaṃ bhāsatī’’ti kujjhitvā bhagavantaṃ musāvādena  codetukāmo vihāraṃ gantvā taṃ pavattiṃ pucchi. Bhagavā tassa tatheva vatvā avisaṃvādanatthaṃ āha – ‘‘atthi pana te, māṇava, pitarā na akkhātaṃ dhana’’nti. Atthi, bho gotama, satasahassagghanikā suvaṇṇamālā, satasahassagghanikā suvaṇṇapādukā, satasahassagghanikā suvaṇṇapāti, satasahassañca kahāpaṇanti. Gaccha taṃ sunakhaṃ appodakaṃ madhupāyāsaṃ bhojetvā sayanaṃ āropetvā īsakaṃ niddaṃ okkantakāle puccha, sabbaṃ te ācikkhissati, atha naṃ jāneyyāsi – ‘‘pitā me eso’’ti. So tathā akāsi. Sunakho sabbaṃ ācikkhi, tadā naṃ – ‘‘pitā me’’ti ñatvā bhagavati pasannacitto gantvā bhagavantaṃcuddasa pañhe pucchitvā vissajjanapariyosāne bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gato, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ ‘‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto’’ti. Sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasatīti attano bhogagāmato āgantvā vasati.
commentary_english:
Thus have I heard…pe… the Subha-sūtra in Śrāvastī.

Herein is an elucidation of the terms that are not clear.

"When the Blessed One had recently attained complete extinction": [This means] when the Blessed One had recently attained complete extinction, [that is,] in the period of about a month after the complete extinction.

This is said in connection with the day the Blessed One, having gone to the place for the explanation of the origin, taking his bowl and robe, and having drunk a purgative made with milk, was sitting in the monastery.

"Todeyya's son": [He was] the son of the *brāhmaṇa* Todeyya. It seems that near Śrāvastī there was a village named Tuḍi, and because he was the chief of that, he was called Todeyya.

Moreover, he was very wealthy, possessing forty-five *koṭis* of riches, [and] extremely miserly, [thinking,] “There is no such thing as the exhaustion of enjoyment in giving,” he gave nothing to anyone. He even instructed his son, teaching only nongiving. After the breakup of his body, he was reborn as a dog in that very house.

Subha was very fond of that dog.

He would feed it with the same rice and curry that he himself ate, and lifting it up, would make it sleep on a fine bed.

Then, one day when the youth had gone out, the Blessed One entered that house for alms.

The dog, seeing the Blessed One, barking, went near the Blessed One.

Then the Blessed One said to him, “Todeyya, in the past too, having slighted me, [saying,] ‘Hey, you!’ you were born as a dog. Now too, having barked, you will go to Avīci hell.”

The dog, having heard that speech, remorseful, lay down on a heap of ashes nearby. The people were not able to lift it up and make it sleep on the bed.

Subha came and said, “By whom was this dog taken down from the bed?”

The people, saying, “By no one,” reported that happening.

The youth, having heard, [thinking,] “My father was reborn in the Brahma-world, [but] the *śramaṇa* Gotama makes my father into a dog, whatever he says that comes to his mouth,” angry, wanting to accuse the Blessed One with a lie, going to the monastery, asked about that happening.

The Blessed One, having spoken to him just as before, for the sake of non-deception, said, “Is there any wealth, youth, that was not declared to you by your father?”

“There is, O Gotama, a golden garland worth a hundred thousand, golden sandals worth a hundred thousand, a golden bowl worth a hundred thousand, and a hundred thousand *kahāpaṇas*.”

"Go, feed that dog with little water and honey-rice, and lifting it up, placing it on the bed, at the time when sleep has overcome it a little, ask [it]. It will tell you everything. Then you will know him: ‘This is my father.’"

He did so.

The dog told everything. Then, knowing him – “This is my father,” his mind pleased with the Blessed One, going to the Blessed One, having asked the Blessed One fourteen questions, at the end of the explanation, he went for refuge to the Blessed One. With reference to that it was said, “Subha, the youth, Todeyya’s son.”

"He dwells in Śrāvastī": [This means that] having come from his own village of enjoyment, he dwells [there].

mula_pali: 445. Atha kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto aññataraṃ māṇavakaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘ehi tvaṃ, māṇavaka, yena samaṇo ānando tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena samaṇaṃ ānandaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha – ‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṃ ānandaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’ti. Evañca vadehi – ‘sādhu kira bhavaṃ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’’’ti.
mula_english:
445. Then, Subha, the young Brahmin of the Todeyya clan, addressed a certain young man: "Come, young man, go to where the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Ānanda is; having gone, ask the *śramaṇa* (ascetic) Ānanda, in my words, if he is free from illness (*appābādhaṃ*), free from affliction (*appātaṅkaṃ*), of light rising (*lahuṭṭhānaṃ*), strong (*balaṃ*), and living in comfort (*phāsuvihāraṃ*)—‘Subha, the young Brahmin of the Todeyya clan, asks the venerable Ānanda if he is free from illness, free from affliction, of light rising, strong, and living in comfort.’"

And say thus: ‘It would be good if the venerable Ānanda would, out of compassion (*anukampaṃ upādāya*), visit the dwelling (*nivesanaṃ*) of Subha, the young Brahmin of the Todeyya clan.’"
commentary_pali: 445-446.Aññataraṃ māṇavakaṃ āmantesīti satthari parinibbute ‘‘ānandatthero kirassa pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā āgato, mahājano taṃ dassanatthāya upasaṅkamatī’’ti sutvā ‘‘vihāraṃ kho pana gantvā mahājanamajjhe na sakkā sukhena paṭisanthāraṃ vā kātuṃ, dhammakathaṃ vā sotuṃ gehaṃ āgataṃyeva naṃ disvā sukhena paṭisanthāraṃ karissāmi, ekā ca me kaṅkhā atthi, tampi naṃ pucchissāmī’’ti cintetvā aññataraṃ māṇavakaṃ āmantesi. Appābādhantiādīsu ābādhoti visabhāgavedanā vuccati, yā ekadese uppajjitvā cattāro iriyāpathe ayapaṭṭena ābandhitvā viya gaṇhati, tassā abhāvaṃ pucchāti vadati. Appātaṅkoti  kicchajīvitakaro rogo vuccati, tassāpi abhāvaṃ pucchāti vadati. Gilānasseva ca uṭṭhānaṃ nāma garukaṃ hoti, kāye balaṃ na hoti, tasmā niggelaññabhāvañca balañca pucchāti vadati. Phāsuvihāranti gamanaṭhānanisajjasayanesu catūsu iriyāpathesu sukhavihāraṃ pucchāti vadati. Athassa pucchitabbākāraṃ dassento ‘‘subho’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
445-446. "He addressed a certain youth," means that when the Teacher had attained *parinirvāṇa*, having heard that "The venerable Ānanda has arrived, taking his bowl and robe, and the great multitude is approaching him to see him," thinking, "Having gone to the monastery, it is not possible to exchange friendly greetings with ease or hear the *dharma* talk in the midst of the great multitude. Having seen him when he has come to my house, I will exchange friendly greetings with ease, and I have a certain doubt, and I will ask him about that," he addressed a certain youth.

In "appābādha and so on," *ābādha* means a dissimilar feeling. Having arisen in one place, it seizes one as if binding the four postures (*iriyāpatha*) with an iron band. He asks about its absence, he says.

"Appātaṅka" means a disease that makes living difficult. He asks about the absence of that also, he says.

And for the sick, rising up is difficult, and there is no strength in the body. Therefore, he asks about the state of being without sickness (*niggelaññabhāva*) and strength (*bala*), he says.

"Phāsuvihāra" means he asks about pleasant abiding (*sukhavihāra*) in the four postures (*catūsu iriyāpathesu*) of going (*gamana*), standing (*ṭhāna*), sitting (*nisajja*), and lying down (*sayana*), he says.

Then, showing the manner of questioning him, he said, "Subha," and so on.

mula_pali: 446. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho so māṇavako subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so māṇavako āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṃ ānandaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati; evañca vadeti – ‘sādhu kira bhavaṃ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa  nivesanaṃ  tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’’’ti.
mula_english: 446. "So be it, sir," the young man replied to Subha, the student, the son of Todeyya.
