Then he approached the venerable Ānanda, and after exchanging greetings with the venerable Ānanda, he sat down at one side after concluding their conversation with courteous and amiable talk. Having sat down to one side, that young man said to the venerable Ānanda: "Subha, the student, the son of Todeyya, inquires about your health, freedom from illness, lightness of body, strength and comfortable living, and further says: ‘May the venerable Ānanda be so kind as to visit the dwelling of Subha, the student, the son of Todeyya, out of compassion.’"
commentary_pali: 445-446.Aññataraṃ māṇavakaṃ āmantesīti satthari parinibbute ‘‘ānandatthero kirassa pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā āgato, mahājano taṃ dassanatthāya upasaṅkamatī’’ti sutvā ‘‘vihāraṃ kho pana gantvā mahājanamajjhe na sakkā sukhena paṭisanthāraṃ vā kātuṃ, dhammakathaṃ vā sotuṃ gehaṃ āgataṃyeva naṃ disvā sukhena paṭisanthāraṃ karissāmi, ekā ca me kaṅkhā atthi, tampi naṃ pucchissāmī’’ti cintetvā aññataraṃ māṇavakaṃ āmantesi. Appābādhantiādīsu ābādhoti visabhāgavedanā vuccati, yā ekadese uppajjitvā cattāro iriyāpathe ayapaṭṭena ābandhitvā viya gaṇhati, tassā abhāvaṃ pucchāti vadati. Appātaṅkoti  kicchajīvitakaro rogo vuccati, tassāpi abhāvaṃ pucchāti vadati. Gilānasseva ca uṭṭhānaṃ nāma garukaṃ hoti, kāye balaṃ na hoti, tasmā niggelaññabhāvañca balañca pucchāti vadati. Phāsuvihāranti gamanaṭhānanisajjasayanesu catūsu iriyāpathesu sukhavihāraṃ pucchāti vadati. Athassa pucchitabbākāraṃ dassento ‘‘subho’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
445-446. Having heard that when the Teacher had attained *parinirvāṇa*, "The venerable Ānanda has arrived, carrying his bowl and robes, and a great crowd is approaching him to see him," he thought, "It is not easy to go to the monastery and exchange greetings comfortably or hear the *dharma* talk in the midst of a large crowd. Having seen him when he has come to my house, I will greet him comfortably. And I have a question; I will ask him that as well." Having thought this, he addressed a certain youth ( *aññataraṃ māṇavakaṃ āmantesi*).

In "freedom from disease," disease (*ābādha*) is said to be disagreeable feeling (*visabhāgavedanā*), which, having arisen in one place, seizes one as if binding one with iron bands in the four postures (*cattāro iriyāpathe*). He asks about the absence of that.

In "freedom from sickness" (*appātaṅko*), sickness (*roga*) is said to be that which makes life difficult (*kicchajīvitakaro*). He asks about the absence of that as well.

For one who is ill, rising up is difficult, and there is no strength (*balaṃ*) in the body (*kāye*). Therefore, he asks about freedom from illness (*niggelaññabhāvaṃ*) and strength (*balaṃ*).

In "comfortable abiding" (*phāsuvihāraṃ*), he asks about a pleasant abiding (*sukhavihāraṃ*) in the four postures (*catūsu iriyāpathesu*) of going, standing, sitting, and lying down (*gamanaṭhānanisajjasayanesu*).

Then, showing the way he should be asked, he said, "Well-born" (*subho*), and so forth.

mula_pali: 447. Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando taṃ māṇavakaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘akālo kho, māṇavaka . Atthi me ajja bhesajjamattā pītā. Appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho so māṇavako āyasmato ānandassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena subho māṇavo todeyyaputto tenupasaṅkami ; upasaṅkamitvā subhaṃ māṇavaṃ todeyyaputtaṃ etadavoca, ‘‘avocumhā kho mayaṃ bhoto vacanena taṃ bhavantaṃ ānandaṃ – ‘subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhavantaṃ ānandaṃ appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati, evañca vadeti – ‘‘sādhu kira bhavaṃ ānando yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’’’ti. Evaṃ vutte, bho, samaṇo ānando maṃ etadavoca – ‘akālo kho, māṇavaka. Atthi me ajja bhesajjamattā pītā. Appevanāma svepi upasaṅkameyyāma kālañca samayañca upādāyā’ti. Ettāvatāpi kho, bho, katameva etaṃ, yato kho so bhavaṃ ānando okāsamakāsi svātanāyapi upasaṅkamanāyā’’ti.
mula_english:
447. When this was said, the venerable Ānanda said to that young man: "It is not the right time, young man.
Today I have taken some medicine (bhesajjamattā pītā).
Perhaps it will be possible to come tomorrow when the time (kāla) and the occasion (samaya) are suitable."
"Yes, sir," the young man replied to the venerable Ānanda, and rising from his seat, he went to where Subha, the son of Todeyya, was. Having approached, he said to Subha, the son of Todeyya: "We have told that Reverend Ānanda, according to your words, that Subha, the son of Todeyya, asks about the Reverend Ānanda's freedom from illness (appābādhaṃ), freedom from disease (appātaṅkaṃ), quickness of recovery (lahuṭṭhānaṃ), strength (balaṃ), and comfortable living (phāsuvihāraṃ), and also says: 'It would be good if the Reverend Ānanda would come to the residence (nivesanaṃ) of Subha, the son of Todeyya, out of compassion (anukampaṃ).'"
When this was said, sir, the *śramaṇa* Ānanda said to me: "It is not the right time, young man.
Today I have taken some medicine (bhesajjamattā pītā).
Perhaps it will be possible to come tomorrow when the time (kāla) and the occasion (samaya) are suitable."
"Even so far, sir, this has been accomplished, that the Reverend Ānanda has probably made an opportunity even for coming tomorrow."
commentary_pali: 447.Kālañca samayañca upādāyāti kālañca samayañca paññāya gahetvā upadhāretvāti attho. Sace amhākaṃ sve gamanakālo bhavissati, kāye balamattā ceva pharissati, gamanapaccayā ca añño aphāsuvihāro  na bhavissati, athetaṃ kālañca gamanakāraṇasamavāyasaṅkhātaṃ samayañca upadhāretvā – ‘‘api eva nāma sve āgaccheyyāmā’’ti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
447. Taking into consideration both time (*kāla*) and circumstance (*samaya*), means taking time (*kāla*) and circumstance (*samaya*) with wisdom (*paññā*), grasping and considering them, this is the meaning.

If for us tomorrow will be the time for going (*gamanakāla*), and strength and measure will pervade the body (*kāya*), and another uncomfortable abiding (*aphāsuvihāra*) will not arise from the causes of going (*gamanapaccaya*), then considering this time (*kāla*), reckoned as the collection of causes of going (*gamanakāraṇasamavāya-saṅkhāta*), and also the circumstance (*samaya*), it is said, "Even so, may we come tomorrow."

mula_pali: 448. Atha kho āyasmā ānando tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya cetakena bhikkhunā pacchāsamaṇena yena subhassa māṇavassa todeyyaputtassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho subho  māṇavo todeyyaputto yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘bhavañhi  ānando tassa bhoto gotamassa dīgharattaṃ upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaro samīpacārī. Bhavametaṃ ānando jāneyya, yesaṃ so bhavaṃ gotamo dhammānaṃ vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi. Katamesānaṃ kho, bho ānanda, dhammānaṃ so bhavaṃ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi; kattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī’’ti?
mula_english:
448. Then, as that night ended, the venerable Ānanda, having dressed in the early morning, took his bowl and robe, and accompanied by the venerable Cetaka, a monk who was his attendant, went to the dwelling of Subha, the young man, the son of Todeyya; having arrived, he sat down on the seat that was prepared.

Then Subha, the young man, the son of Todeyya, approached the venerable Ānanda; having approached, he exchanged greetings with the venerable Ānanda.

Having concluded their conversation of courteous greetings, he sat down to one side.

Seated to one side, Subha, the young man, the son of Todeyya, said this to the venerable Ānanda: “For a long time, venerable Ānanda, you have been the attendant of the esteemed Gotama, dwelling in his presence and near him.

Venerable Ānanda, you would know what things the esteemed Gotama was an advocate of, and with which he encouraged, exhorted, and established the people.

Which of those things, venerable Ānanda, was the esteemed Gotama an advocate of; and with what did he encourage, exhort, and establish these people?”
commentary_pali: 448.Cetakenabhikkhunāti cetiraṭṭhe jātattā cetakoti evaṃ laddhanāmena. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyanti bho, ānanda, dasabalassa ko nāma ābādho ahosi, kiṃ bhagavā paribhuñji. Api ca satthu parinibbānena tumhākaṃ soko udapādi, satthā nāma na kevalaṃ tumhākaṃyeva parinibbuto, sadevakassa lokassa mahājāni, ko dāni añño maraṇā muccissati, yatra so sadevakassa lokassa aggapuggalo parinibbuto, idāni kaṃ aññaṃ disvā maccurājā lajjissatīti evamādinā nayena maraṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā therassa hiyyo pītabhesajjānurūpaṃ āhāraṃ datvā bhattakiccāvasāne ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaroti upaṭṭhāko hutvā santikāvacaro, na randhagavesī. Na vīmaṃsanādhippāyo. Samīpacārīti idaṃ purimapadasseva vevacanaṃ. Yesaṃ so bhavaṃ gotamoti kasmā pucchati? Tassa kira evaṃ ahosi ‘‘yesu dhammesu bhavaṃ gotamo imaṃ lokaṃ patiṭṭhapesi, te tassa accayena naṭṭhā nu kho, dharanti nu kho, sace dharanti, ānando jānissati, handa naṃ pucchāmī’’ti, tasmā pucchi.
commentary_english:
448. Because the *bhikkhu* (monk) was born in the Ceti country, he was named Cetaka in this way.

"What kind of comforting and স্মরণীয় speech [should be given]?"  "Sir, Ānanda, what sickness did the Ten-Powered One have? What did the Blessed One consume?"

Furthermore, did sorrow arise in you because of the Teacher's *parinirvāṇa*? The Teacher is not merely *parinirvāṇa*-ed for you alone, [but is] a great loss to the world with its *devas*. Who else now will be freed from death? Where that foremost individual of the world with its *devas* is *parinirvāṇa*-ed, now seeing whom else will the king of death be ashamed?" Having dismissed the comforting and স্মরণীয় speech connected with death in this way, giving food suitable for the medicine drunk yesterday to the *thera* (elder), he sat down in a secluded place at the end of the meal duty.

"*Upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaro* means being an attendant and being one who frequents his presence, not seeking faults."

"Not with the intention of investigation."

"*Samīpacārīti* is a synonym for the former expression."

"Why does he ask, 'Whose was that venerable Gotama?'" It occurred to him, "In which *dharmas* did the venerable Gotama establish this world? Have they perished at his passing away, or do they endure? If they endure, Ānanda will know. Come, let me ask him." Therefore, he asked.

mula_pali: 449. ‘‘Tiṇṇaṃ kho, māṇava, khandhānaṃ so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi; ettha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi. Katamesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ? Ariyassa sīlakkhandhassa, ariyassa samādhikkhandhassa, ariyassa paññākkhandhassa. Imesaṃ kho, māṇava, tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi; ettha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī’’ti.
mula_english:
449. "Subha, there were three divisions of things which the Lord praised, and with which he aroused, exhorted, and established people.

What three? The division of Ariyan morality (*āriyassa sīlakkhandhassa*), the division of Ariyan concentration (*āriyassa samādhikkhandhassa*), and the division of Ariyan wisdom (*āriyassa paññākkhandhassa*).

These were the three divisions of things which the Lord praised, and with which he aroused, exhorted, and established people."
commentary_pali: 449. Athassa  thero tīṇi piṭakāni tīhi khandhehi saṅgahetvā dassento ‘‘tiṇṇaṃ kho’’tiādimāha. Māṇavo saṅkhittena kathitaṃ asallakkhento – ‘‘vitthārato pucchissāmī’’ti cintetvā ‘‘katamesaṃ tiṇṇa’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
449. Then, the elder, showing the three baskets ( *ṭripiṭaka*) by gathering them with the three aggregates (*khandha*), said, "Of the three..." etc.
The youth, not considering what was said concisely, thinking, "I will ask in detail," said, "Which three?" etc.

mula_pali: 450. ‘‘Katamo  pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho, yassa so bhavaṃ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī’’ti? ‘‘Idha, māṇava, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā. So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Taṃ dhammaṃ  suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto. So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati. So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati – ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya’nti. So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati. So evaṃ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati, ācāragocarasampanno, anumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo, sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
mula_english:
450.

"But what, friend Ānanda, is that noble aggregate of morality ( *ariya-sīlakkhandha* ) of which the esteemed Gotama was a proponent, and wherein he exhorted, established, and grounded this populace?"

"Here, young man, a *Tathāgata* arises in the world, a worthy one (*arahaṃ*), a rightly self-awakened one (*sammāsambuddho*), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a fortunate one (*sugato*), a knower of the world (*lokavidū*), unsurpassed (*anuttaro*), a guide for those who need taming (*purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), awakened (*buddho*), blessed one (*bhagavā*).

He, having realized it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*), proclaims this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), *Māras* (*samārakaṃ*) and *Brahmās* (*sabrahmakaṃ*), its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ*), its princes and people (*sadevamanussaṃ*).

He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), and good in the end (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*), with the spirit and the letter (*sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ*), and displays the fully perfected and purified holy life (*brahmacariyaṃ*).

A householder (*gahapati*) or a householder's son (*gahapatiputto*), or one born in some other clan, hears that Dhamma.

Having heard this Dhamma, he gains faith (*saddhaṃ*) in the *Tathāgata*.

Endowed with that gain of faith, he reflects thus: ‘The household life is crowded, a dusty path; the life of homelessness is open. It is not easy, while living in a house, to lead the holy life utterly perfect, utterly pure, like a polished shell.

Suppose I were to shave off my hair and beard, put on the ochre robes (*kāsāyāni vatthāni*), and go forth from the household life into homelessness (*agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya*)?’

Then, after some time, abandoning a small or a large fortune, abandoning a small or a large circle of relatives, he shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the ochre robes, and goes forth from the household life into homelessness.

Having thus gone forth, he dwells restrained by the restraint of the monastic rules (*pātimokkhasaṃvara*), possessed of proper behavior and resort, seeing danger in the slightest faults, undertaking and training himself in the rules of training, endowed with wholesome bodily and verbal action, his livelihood is purified, he is possessed of moral discipline (*sīlasampanno*), with the sense-doors guarded, endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, and content.
commentary_pali: 450-453. Tato therena ‘‘ariyassa sīlakkhandhassā’’ti tesu dassitesu puna ‘‘katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho’’ti ekekaṃ pucchi. Theropissa buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ desento anukkamena bhagavatā vuttanayeneva sabbaṃ vissajjesi. Tattha atthicevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na sīlameva sāro, kevalañhetaṃ patiṭṭhāmattameva hoti. Ito uttari pana aññampi kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dassesi. Ito bahiddhāti buddhasāsanato bahiddhā.
commentary_english:
450-453.

Then, when the elder showed them "the noble aggregate of morality" (*ariyassa sīlakkhandhassa*), he asked again, "But, venerable Ānanda, which is that noble aggregate of morality?" (*katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho*), asking about each one.

The elder, having shown the arising of the Buddha (*buddhuppādaṃ*), teaching the doctrine of the continuous tradition (*tantidhammaṃ*), gradually explained everything in accordance with the method spoken by the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*).

There, "there is something further to be done" (*atthicevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti*). Here, in the Blessed One's Dispensation (*bhagavato sāsane*), morality (*sīla*) alone is not the essence (*sāro*); rather, this is merely the basis (*patiṭṭhāmattameva hoti*).

"Moreover, there is still something else to be done" (*ito uttari pana aññampi kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti*), he showed.

"Outside of this" (*ito bahiddhā*), means outside of the Buddha's Dispensation (*buddhasāsanato bahiddhā*).

mula_pali: 451. ‘‘Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti? Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati. Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī  viharati; idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ. (Yathā 194 yāva 210 anucchedesu evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya  tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ – santikammaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ bhūtakammaṃ bhūrikammaṃ vassakammaṃ vossakammaṃ vatthukammaṃ vatthuparikammaṃ ācamanaṃ nhāpanaṃ juhanaṃ vamanaṃ virecanaṃ uddhaṃvirecanaṃ adhovirecanaṃ sīsavirecanaṃ kaṇṇatelaṃ nettatappanaṃ natthukammaṃ añjanaṃ paccañjanaṃ sālākiyaṃ sallakattiyaṃ dārakatikicchā mūlabhesajjānaṃ anuppadānaṃ osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti, seyyathidaṃ, santikammaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ…pe… osadhīnaṃ paṭimokkho iti vā iti evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṃ.
mula_english:
451.

“And how, young man, is a *bhikkhu* accomplished in virtue (*śīlasampanno* *hoti*)? Here, young man, a *bhikkhu*, abandoning the killing of living beings (*pāṇātipātaṃ* *pahāya*), abstains from killing living beings (*pāṇātipātā* *paṭivirato* *hoti*); with rod and weapon laid aside (*nihitadaṇḍo* *nihitasattho*), scrupulous (*lajjī*), compassionate (*dayāpanno*), he dwells compassionate for the welfare of all living beings (*sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī* *viharati*).

And that the *bhikkhu*, abandoning the killing of living beings (*pāṇātipātaṃ* *pahāya*), abstains from killing living beings (*pāṇātipātā* *paṭivirato* *hoti*), with rod and weapon laid aside (*nihitadaṇḍo* *nihitasattho*), scrupulous (*lajjī*), compassionate (*dayāpanno*), he dwells compassionate for the welfare of all living beings (*sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī* *viharati*); this, too, pertains to his virtue (*idam* *pi* *assa* *hoti* *sīlasmiṃ*).

(As at sections 194 up to 210, so it should be explained in detail (*yathā...evaṃ* *vitthāretabbaṃ*)).

“Or, some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaṇabrāhmaṇā*), while living on the food offered by the faithful (*saddhādeyyāni* *bhojanāni* *bhuñjitvā*), earn their living by wrong means of livelihood (*micchājīvena* *jīvitaṃ* *kappenti*), by such debased arts (*tiracchānavijjāya*) as: appeasing the deities (*santikammaṃ*), redeeming vows to them (*paṇidhikammaṃ*), making earth-house spells (*bhūtakammaṃ*), causing virility or impotence (*bhūrikammaṃ*), preparing and consecrating building sites (*vassakammaṃ*), giving ritual rinsings and bathings (*ācamanaṃ* *nhāpanaṃ*), offering sacrifices (*juhanaṃ*), administering emetics (*vamanaṃ*), purgatives (*virecanaṃ*), expectorants (*uddhaṃvirecanaṃ*) and phlegmagogues (*adhovirecanaṃ*), giving ear medicine (*kaṇṇatelaṃ*), eye medicine (*netta-tappanaṃ*), nose medicine (*natthukammaṃ*), ointments (*añjanaṃ*) and counter-ointments (*paccañjanaṃ*), eye-surgery (*sālākiyaṃ*), surgery (*sallakattiyaṃ*), pediatric treatment (*dārakatikicchā*), giving concoctions from root medicine (*mūlabhesajjānaṃ* *anuppadānaṃ*), medicine (*osadhīnaṃ* *paṭimokkho*); thus he abstains from wrong means of livelihood (*micchājīvā* *paṭivirato* *hoti*) by such debased arts (*tiracchānavijjāya*).

And that the *bhikkhu*, like some ascetics and Brahmins (*samaṇabrāhmaṇā*) who, while living on the food offered by the faithful (*saddhādeyyāni* *bhojanāni* *bhuñjitvā*), earn their living by wrong means of livelihood (*micchājīvena* *jīvitaṃ* *kappenti*) through such debased arts (*tiracchānavijjāya*) as: appeasing the deities (*santikammaṃ*), redeeming vows to them (*paṇidhikammaṃ*) ... medicine (*osadhīnaṃ* *paṭimokkho*); thus he abstains from wrong means of livelihood (*micchājīvā* *paṭivirato* *hoti*) by such debased arts (*tiracchānavijjāya*).

This, too, pertains to his virtue (*idam* *pi* *assa* *hoti* *sīlasmiṃ*).
commentary_pali: 450-453. Tato therena ‘‘ariyassa sīlakkhandhassā’’ti tesu dassitesu puna ‘‘katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho’’ti ekekaṃ pucchi. Theropissa buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ desento anukkamena bhagavatā vuttanayeneva sabbaṃ vissajjesi. Tattha atthicevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na sīlameva sāro, kevalañhetaṃ patiṭṭhāmattameva hoti. Ito uttari pana aññampi kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dassesi. Ito bahiddhāti buddhasāsanato bahiddhā.
commentary_english:
450-453. Then, when the elder showed them, saying, "Of the Noble aggregate of morality (ariya sīlakkhandha)," he again asked each one, "Which, Ānanda, is that Noble aggregate of morality (ariya sīlakkhandha)?"

The elder, having shown the arising of the Buddha and teaching the Dharma of the string (tantidhamma), gradually explained everything according to the method stated by the Blessed One.

There, it is said that there are further things to be done, for in the Blessed One's Dispensation (bhagavato sāsane), morality (sīla) alone is not the essence (sāro); this is merely the foundation (patiṭṭhāmattameva).

Moreover, he showed that there is indeed something else to be done beyond this.

"Outside of this" means outside of the Buddha's Dispensation (buddhasāsanato bahiddhā).

mula_pali: 452. ‘‘Sa kho so ayaṃ kho so (ka.), māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato. Seyyathāpi, māṇava, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nihatapaccāmitto na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ paccatthikato. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato. So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ  paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti.
mula_english:
452. 'That is he; this is he.'

Young man, a *bhikṣu* (monk) who is thus perfected in virtue (*śīlasampanno*) sees no fear from anywhere, because of his restraint of virtue (*śīlasaṃvarato*).

Just as, young man, a *kṣatriya* (warrior) king who has been consecrated by having water poured over his head (*muddhāvasitto*), having defeated his enemies (*nihatapaccāmitto*), sees no fear from anywhere, because of his adversaries (*paccatthikato*).

In the same way, young man, a *bhikṣu* (monk) who is thus perfected in virtue (*śīlasampanno*) sees no fear from anywhere, because of his restraint of virtue (*śīlasaṃvarato*).

Possessing this noble aggregate of virtue (*arīyena sīlakkhandhena*), he experiences within himself blameless happiness (*anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti*).

In this way, young man, a *bhikṣu* (monk) is perfected in virtue (*śīlasampanno hoti*).
commentary_pali: 450-453. Tato therena ‘‘ariyassa sīlakkhandhassā’’ti tesu dassitesu puna ‘‘katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho’’ti ekekaṃ pucchi. Theropissa buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ desento anukkamena bhagavatā vuttanayeneva sabbaṃ vissajjesi. Tattha atthicevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na sīlameva sāro, kevalañhetaṃ patiṭṭhāmattameva hoti. Ito uttari pana aññampi kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dassesi. Ito bahiddhāti buddhasāsanato bahiddhā.
commentary_english:
450-453. Then, when the Elder had pointed out "the noble aggregate of morality" (ariyassa sīlakkhandha), he asked again, "But, venerable Ānanda, which is that noble aggregate of morality (ariya sīlakkhandha)?" asking each one individually.

The Elder, having shown the arising of the Buddha (buddhuppāda) and explaining the doctrine of the string (tantidhamma), gradually expounded everything in the very same way as the Blessed One (bhagavatā) had spoken.

There, [it is said that] "there is further work to be done here." In the Blessed One's (bhagavato) dispensation (sāsane), morality (sīla) alone is not the essence (sāro); rather, this is merely the basis (patiṭṭhāmattameva).

"Moreover, there is still something else to be done beyond this (ito uttari pana aññampi kattabbaṃ atthi yeva)," he showed.

"Outside of this (ito bahiddhā)" means outside of the Buddha's dispensation (buddhasāsanato bahiddhā).

mula_pali: 453. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho so, māṇava, ariyo sīlakkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi. Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīya’’nti. ‘‘Acchariyaṃ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṃ, bho ānanda! So cāyaṃ, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo. Evaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ cāhaṃ, bho, ānanda, ariyaṃ sīlakkhandhaṃ  ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na  samanupassāmi. Evaṃ paripuṇṇañca, bho ānanda, ariyaṃ sīlakkhandhaṃ ito bahiddhā aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇā attani samanupasseyyuṃ, te tāvatakeneva attamanā assu – ‘alamettāvatā, katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttarikaraṇīya’nti. Atha ca pana bhavaṃ ānando evamāha – ‘atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīya’’’nti imassa anantaraṃ sī. pī. potthakesu ‘‘paṭhamabhāṇavāraṃ’’ti pāṭho dissati.
mula_english:
453.

“That, O youth (māṇava), is the division of Ariyan morality (ariya sīlakkhandha) that the Lord (bhagavā) praised, and with which he aroused, exhorted, and established people.
But something more remains to be done."
“Wonderful, O Ānanda, amazing, O Ānanda! This division of Ariyan morality (ariya sīlakkhandha) is perfectly fulfilled (paripuṇṇo), not incomplete.
And I, O Ānanda, do not see this division of Ariyan morality (ariyaṃ sīlakkhandhaṃ) thus perfectly fulfilled (paripuṇṇaṃ) anywhere among the ascetics (samaṇa) and Brahmins (brāhmaṇa) of other schools.
And if any ascetics (samaṇabrāhmaṇā) and Brahmins (brāhmaṇā) were to find this division of Ariyan morality (ariyaṃ sīlakkhandhaṃ) thus perfectly fulfilled (paripuṇṇaṃ) in themselves, they would be so delighted that they would say: 'Enough has been done! The goal of our asceticism has been reached! There's nothing more to be done!'
Then again, the venerable (bhavaṃ) Ānanda said: ‘But something more remains to be done.’" After this, sī.
pī.
In some books (potthakesu) the reading (pāṭho) "first recitation section (paṭhamabhāṇavāraṃ)" is found.
commentary_pali: 450-453. Tato therena ‘‘ariyassa sīlakkhandhassā’’ti tesu dassitesu puna ‘‘katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo sīlakkhandho’’ti ekekaṃ pucchi. Theropissa buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ desento anukkamena bhagavatā vuttanayeneva sabbaṃ vissajjesi. Tattha atthicevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na sīlameva sāro, kevalañhetaṃ patiṭṭhāmattameva hoti. Ito uttari pana aññampi kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dassesi. Ito bahiddhāti buddhasāsanato bahiddhā.
commentary_english:
450-453. Then, when the Elder had shown them, saying, "of the noble aggregate of morality ( *ariyassa sīlakkhandhassa*)," he again asked, "Which one, Ānanda, is that noble aggregate of morality ( *ariyo sīlakkhandho*)?" He questioned each one.

The Elder, having shown the arising of the Buddha (*buddhuppādaṃ*), teaching the doctrine of the string (*tantidhammaṃ*), in due order, explained everything in accordance with the method stated by the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*).

Therein, there is something further to be done. Here, in the Blessed One's dispensation (*bhagavato sāsane*), morality (*sīla*) alone is not the essence (*sāro*); indeed, this is only the basis (*patiṭṭhāmattameva*) .

"Furthermore (*uttari*), there is something else to be done," he showed.

"Outside of this (*ito bahiddhā*) " means outside the Buddha's teaching (*buddhasāsanato bahiddhā*).

mula_pali: 454. ‘‘Katamo  pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho, yassa so bhavaṃ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī’’ti? ‘‘Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti? Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī; yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati. Sotena  saddaṃ sutvā…pe… ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā… jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā… kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā… manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī; yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati. So iminā ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ abyāsekasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
mula_english:
454.

"But what, Ānanda, is that noble aggregate of concentration (*ariya samādhikkhandha*) about which the esteemed Gotama was an advocate, and in which he encouraged, established, and grounded this populace?"

"And how, young man, does a *bhikkhu* become one who guards the doors of the senses (*indriyesu guttadvāro hoti*)? Here, young man, a *bhikkhu*, upon seeing a form (*rūpa*) with the eye (*cakkhunā*), does not grasp at its marks (*nimittaggāhī*) or its details (*anubyañjanaggāhī*). Because if he dwells with the faculty of the eye (*cakkhundriyaṃ*) unrestrained, evil, unwholesome qualities of longing (*abhijjhā*) and dejection (*domanassā*) might invade him, he practices restraint for its control, he guards the faculty of the eye (*cakkhundriyaṃ*), he undertakes the restraint (*saṃvaraṃ*) of the faculty of the eye (*cakkhundriye*).

Having heard a sound (*saddaṃ*) with the ear (*sotena*)…and so on… Having smelled an odor (*gandhaṃ*) with the nose (*ghānena*)… Having tasted a taste (*rasaṃ*) with the tongue (*jivhāya*)… Having felt a tactile object (*phoṭṭhabbaṃ*) with the body (*kāyena*)… Having cognized a mental phenomenon (*dhammaṃ*) with the mind (*manasā*), he does not grasp its marks (*nimittaggāhī*) and features (*anubyañjanaggāhī*). Since, if he left the mind faculty (*manindriyaṃ*) unrestrained, bad unwholesome states of longing (*abhijjhā*) and dejection (*domanassā*) might invade him, he practices restraint (*saṃvara*) over it, he guards the mind faculty (*manindriyaṃ*), he undertakes the restraint of the mind faculty (*manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati*).

Endowed with this noble restraint of the sense faculties (*indriyasaṃvarena*), he experiences within himself an unblemished happiness (*abyāsekasukhaṃ*).

In this way, young man, a *bhikkhu* is a guardian of the doors of the senses (*indriyesu guttadvāro hoti*)."
commentary_pali: 454.Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hotīti idamāyasmā ānando ‘‘katamo pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho’’ti evaṃ samādhikkhandhaṃ puṭṭhopi ye te ‘‘sīlasampanno indriyesu guttadvāro satisampajaññena samannāgato santuṭṭho’’ti evaṃ sīlānantaraṃ indriyasaṃvarādayo sīlasamādhīnaṃ antare ubhinnampi upakārakadhammā uddiṭṭhā, te niddisitvā samādhikkhandhaṃ dassetukāmo ārabhi. Ettha ca rūpajjhānāneva āgatāni, na arūpajjhānāni, ānetvā pana dīpetabbāni. Catutthajjhānena hi asaṅgahitā arūpasamāpatti nāma natthiyeva.
commentary_english:
454.

And how, young man, is a *bhikkhu* guarded in his senses? In this connection, venerable Ānanda, even when asked, "What is the noble aggregate of *samādhi*?" he began by pointing out those qualities such as, "virtuous, guarded in his senses, possessed of mindfulness and clear comprehension, content," and after virtue, the virtues that are helpful to both, such as restraint of the senses, etc., which are between virtue and *samādhi*, desiring to show the aggregate of *samādhi*.

And here, only the *rūpajhānas* ("form" *jhānas*) are included, not the *arūpajhānas* ("formless" *jhānas*), but they should be brought in and shown.

Indeed, there is no such thing as a *arūpasamāpatti* (formless attainment) that is not connected with the fourth *jhāna*.

mula_pali: 455. ‘‘Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti? Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne  sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti. Evaṃ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti.
mula_english:
“And how, young man, is a *bhikkhu* endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension (*satisampajañña*)? Here, young man, a *bhikkhu* acts with full awareness (*sampajānakārī*) when going forward and returning; acts with full awareness when looking ahead and looking away; acts with full awareness when flexing and extending his limbs; acts with full awareness when wearing his robes (*saṅghāṭipattacīvara*) and carrying his bowl; acts with full awareness when eating, drinking, consuming food, and tasting; acts with full awareness when defecating or urinating (*uccārapassāvakamme*); acts with full awareness when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and remaining silent.

In this way, young man, a *bhikkhu* is endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension (*satisampajañña*).

mula_pali: 456. ‘‘Kathañca, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti? Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati. Seyyathāpi, māṇava, pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti ; evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati. Evaṃ kho, māṇava, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti.
mula_english:
456.
And how, young man (*māṇava*), is a monk (*bhikkhu*) content (*santuṭṭho hoti*)? Here, young man, a monk is content with robes (*cīvara*) to protect his body (*kāyaparihārikena*), and with alms-food (*piṇḍapāta*) to protect his stomach (*kucchiparihārikena*).

Wherever he goes, he sets out taking only that along with him.

Just as, young man, a bird (*pakkhī sakuṇo*), wherever it flies (*ḍeti*), flies with its wings as its only burden, so too, young man, the monk (*bhikkhu*) is content with robes (*cīvara*) to protect his body (*kāyaparihārikena*) and with alms-food (*piṇḍapāta*) to maintain his stomach (*kucchiparihārikena*).

Wherever he goes, he sets out taking only that along with him.

In this way, young man, the monk (*bhikkhu*) is content (*santuṭṭho hoti*).

mula_pali: 457. ‘‘So  iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ. So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā, ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mula_english:
Endowed with this noble aggregate of moral virtue ( *arīyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato*), this noble restraint of the senses (*indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato*), this noble mindfulness and clear comprehension (*satisampajaññena samannāgato*), and this noble contentment (*santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato*), he resorts to a secluded dwelling: a forest (*araññaṃ*), the foot of a tree (*rukkhamūlaṃ*), a mountain (*pabbataṃ*), a ravine (*kandaraṃ*), a hillside cave (*giriguhaṃ*), a charnel ground (*susānaṃ*), a jungle thicket (*vanapatthaṃ*), an open space (*abbhokāsaṃ*), or a heap of straw (*palālapuñjaṃ*).

Then, having eaten after his return from the alms-round (*piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto*), he sits down cross-legged (*pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā*), holding his body erect (*ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya*), and establishing mindfulness before him (*parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā*).

mula_pali: 458. ‘‘So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti. Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti. Thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti. Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti. Vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṃkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mula_english: Abandoning covetousness (abhijjhaṃ) for the world, he dwells with a mind free from covetousness; he purifies his mind from covetousness (abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti). Abandoning ill will and hatred (byāpādapadosaṃ), he abides with a mind free from ill will, compassionate for the welfare of all living beings (sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī); he purifies his mind from ill will and hatred (byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti). Abandoning sloth and torpor (thinamiddhaṃ), he abides free from sloth and torpor, percipient of light (ālokasaññī), mindful (sato) and fully aware (sampajāno); he purifies his mind from sloth and torpor (thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti). Abandoning restlessness and remorse (uddhaccakukkuccaṃ), he abides unagitated with a mind inwardly peaceful (ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto); he purifies his mind from restlessness and remorse (uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti). Abandoning doubt (vicikicchaṃ), he abides having gone beyond doubt (tiṇṇavicikiccho), without uncertainty as to what things are wholesome (kusalesu dhammesu); he purifies his mind from doubt (vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti).

mula_pali: 459. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso iṇaṃ ādāya kammante payojeyya. Tassa te kammantā samijjheyyuṃ. So yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantiṃ kareyya, siyā cassa uttariṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ  dārabharaṇāya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe iṇaṃ ādāya kammante payojesiṃ . Tassa me te kammantā samijjhiṃsu. Sohaṃ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantiṃ akāsiṃ, atthi ca me uttariṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ dārabharaṇāyā’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
Just as, young man, a man might take a loan (*iṇa*) and apply it to his business;
and his business were to succeed;
so that he could pay back his old debts (*iṇamūlāni*) and would have enough money left over to maintain a wife.
He might think: “Before this I developed my business by borrowing.
And my business prospered.
I have paid off all the money of the old loans (*iṇamūlāni*), and I still have enough left over to maintain my wife.”
And as a result he would obtain joy (*prāmojja*) and experience gladness (*saumanassa*).

mula_pali: 460. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā. So aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā mucceyya, bhattañcassa chādeyya, siyā cassa kāye balamattā. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṃ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi kāye balamattā. Somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto bhattañca me chādeti, atthi ca me kāye balamattā’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
460.

Just as, young man, a person might be afflicted, suffering, and severely ill (*ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno*); his food would not appeal to him, and there would be no strength in his body.

After some time, he might recover from that illness (*ābādhā mucceyya*), his food would appeal to him, and there would be strength in his body.

He might think: "Formerly, I was afflicted, suffering, and severely ill; food did not appeal to me, and there was no strength in my body."

But now I am free from that illness, food appeals to me, and there is strength in my body.’

As a result of that, he would gain joy (*pāmojjaṃ*) and experience gladness (*somanassaṃ*).

mula_pali: 461. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso bandhanāgāre baddho assa. So aparena samayena tamhā bandhanāgārā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena, na cassa kiñci bhogānaṃ vayo. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe bandhanāgāre baddho ahosiṃ. Somhi etarahi tamhā bandhanāgārā mutto  sotthinā abbhayena, natthi ca me kiñci bhogānaṃ vayo’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
"Suppose, young man, a man were imprisoned in a prison (bandhanāgāra).
After some time, he might be freed from that prison (bandhanāgāra), safe and secure, with no loss of his possessions (bhogānaṃ vayo).
He might think: “Formerly, I was imprisoned in a prison (bandhanāgāra).
Now I am freed from that prison (bandhanāgārā), safe and secure, and I have lost none of my possessions (bhogānaṃ vayo.”
And as a result, he would find joy (pāmojjaṃ) and experience gladness (somanassaṃ).

mula_pali: 462. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso dāso assa anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṃgamo. So aparena samayena tamhā dāsabyā mucceyya, attādhīno  aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṃgamo. Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe dāso ahosiṃ anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṃgamo. Somhi etarahi tamhā dāsabyā mutto attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṃgamo’ti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english:
“Just as, young man, suppose a person were a slave (*dāsa*), not self-dependent (*anattādhīna*), dependent on others (*parādhīna*), unable to go where he wants.

After some time, he would be released from that slavery, self-dependent (*attādhīna*), independent of others (*aparādhīna*), a free man (*bhujissa*) able to go where he wants.

He might think: “Before this, I was a slave (*dāsa*), not self-dependent (*anattādhīna*), dependent on others (*parādhīna*), unable to go where I wanted.

Now, at this time, I am freed from that slavery, self-dependent (*attādhīna*), independent of others (*aparādhīna*), a free man (*bhujissa*) able to go where I want.”

And as a result of that, he would obtain joy (*pāmojjaṃ*) and experience gladness (*somanassaṃ*).

mula_pali: 463. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṃ paṭipajjeyya dubbhikkhaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ. So aparena samayena taṃ kantāraṃ nitthareyya, sotthinā gāmantaṃ anupāpuṇeyya khemaṃ appaṭibhayaṃ. Tassa evamassa  – ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṃ paṭipajjiṃ dubbhikkhaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ. Somhi etarahi kantāraṃ nitthiṇṇo, sotthinā gāmantaṃ anuppatto khemaṃ appaṭibhaya’nti. So tatonidānaṃ labhetha pāmojjaṃ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṃ.
mula_english: 463. Just as, young man, a man with wealth and possessions might set out on a road through a desert, a place of scarcity and danger. After some time, he would cross that desert and arrive safely at a village, a place of security and freedom from danger. He might think: "Before, I set out on a road through a desert, a place of scarcity and danger, with wealth and possessions. Now, I have crossed the desert and arrived safely at a village, a place of security and freedom from danger." As a result of that, he would obtain joy *pāmojja* and attain gladness *somanassa*.

mula_pali: 464. ‘‘Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṃ yathā rogaṃ yathā bandhanāgāraṃ yathā dāsabyaṃ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṃ, evaṃ ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
mula_english:
464.
“Just so, young man, when a *bhikṣu* sees these five hindrances unabandoned within himself, he regards them as a debt (*iṇaṃ*), as a disease (*rogaṃ*), as a prison (*bandhanāgāraṃ*), as slavery (*dāsabyaṃ*), and as a road through a desert (*kantāraddhānamaggaṃ*).

mula_pali: 465. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, yathā āṇaṇyaṃ yathā ārogyaṃ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṃ yathā bhujissaṃ yathā khemantabhūmiṃ. Evameva bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
mula_english: Just as, young man, [it is] like freedom from debt (*āṇaṇya*), like good health (*ārogya*), like release from bondage (*bandhanāmokkha*), like freedom from slavery (*bhujissa*), like a safe land (*khemantabhūmi*), even so, a *bhikkhu* sees these five hindrances (*pañca nīvaraṇe*) abandoned in himself.

mula_pali: 466. ‘‘Tassime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
mula_english: 466. "When he sees these five hindrances abandoned within himself, gladness (*prāmojja*) arises. When gladdened, rapture (*prīti*) arises. When his mind is filled with rapture, his body becomes tranquil (*passambhati*); tranquil in body, he experiences happiness (*sukhaṃ vedeti*); being happy, his mind becomes concentrated (*samādhiyati*)."

mula_pali: 467. ‘‘So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So  imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena  abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṃsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṃ paripphosakaṃ sandeyya. Sāyaṃ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā snehaparetā santarabāhirā phuṭā snehena, na ca paggharaṇī. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa  vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampissa hoti samādhismiṃ.
mula_english:
467.
“Quite secluded from sense pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, he enters and remains in the first *jhāna*, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion (*vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati*).

He drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this body with the rapture and happiness born of seclusion (*vivekajena pītisukhena*), so that there is no part of his entire body which is not suffused by this rapture and happiness.

“Just as, young man, a skilled bath attendant or his apprentice, having poured bath powder into a metal basin, would sprinkle it with water and knead it bit by bit,

so that the ball of bath powder, pervaded with moisture, saturated with moisture, is suffused with moisture inside and out, yet does not trickle.

In the same way, young man, a *bhikkhu* drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this body with the rapture and happiness born of seclusion (*vivekajena pītisukhena*), so that there is no part of his entire body which is not suffused by this rapture and happiness.

Furthermore, young man, quite secluded from sense pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, a *bhikkhu* enters and remains in the first *jhāna*, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

He drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this body with the rapture and happiness born of seclusion (*vivekajena pītisukhena*), so that there is no part of his entire body which is not suffused by this rapture and happiness.

This comes to him through concentration (*samādhismiṃ*).

mula_pali: 468. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, māṇava, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , māṇava, udakarahado gambhīro ubbhidodako. Tassa nevassa puratthimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, na pacchimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṃ, na uttarāya disāya udakassa  āyamukhaṃ, devo ca na kālena kālaṃ sammā dhāraṃ anupaveccheyya. Atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṃ sītena vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā… pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati, so imameva kāyaṃ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampissa hoti samādhismiṃ.
mula_english:
468.
“Furthermore, young man, with the subsiding of applied and sustained thought (*vitakka-vicārānaṃ vūpasamā*), a *bhikkhu* enters and dwells in the second *jhāna*, which is accompanied by internal confidence (*ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ*) and unification of mind (*cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ*), is without applied thought (*avitakkaṃ*) and sustained thought (*avicāraṃ*), and is filled with the rapture (*pīti*) and happiness (*sukhaṃ*) born of concentration (*samādhijaṃ*).

He drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses his body (*kāyaṃ*) with this rapture (*pīti*) and happiness (*sukhaṃ*) born of concentration (*samādhijena*), so that there is no part of his entire body which is not suffused by this rapture and happiness.

“Just as, young man, there were a deep lake whose waters welled up from below.

It would have no inlet for water from the east, west, north, or south, nor would the rain-god send moderate showers from time to time.

Then the cool fount of water welling up in the lake would make the cool water drench, steep, fill, and pervade the lake, so that there would be no part of the whole lake unpervaded by cool water.

Even so, young man, a *bhikkhu*… and that, young man, a *bhikkhu*, with the subsiding of thinking and pondering… enters and remains in the second *jhāna*; he drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this body with the rapture and happiness born of concentration, so that there is no part of his entire body which is not suffused with the rapture and happiness born of concentration.

This comes to him through concentration (*samādhismiṃ*).

mula_pali: 469. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, māṇava, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno , sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti – ‘‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’’ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni paripūrāni paripphuṭāni, nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṃ uppalānaṃ vā padumānaṃ vā puṇḍarīkānaṃ vā  sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampissa hoti samādhismiṃ.
mula_english:
469. Furthermore, young man, with the fading away of rapture ( *pītiyā ca virāgā*), a monk abides in equanimity ( *upekkhako ca viharati*), mindful and fully aware ( *sato sampajāno*), and experiences pleasure with the body ( *sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti*). That state, of which the noble ones declare, "Equanimous, mindful, he dwells in pleasure ( *upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī*)," he enters and abides in the third *jhāna* ( *tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati*).

He drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this very body ( *so imameva kāyaṃ*) with happiness free from rapture ( *nippītikena sukhena*), so that there is no part of his entire body ( *sabbāvato kāyassa*) which is not suffused by this happiness free from rapture ( *nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṃ hoti*).

Just as, young man, in a pond of blue lotuses ( *uppaliniyaṃ vā*), or red lotuses ( *paduminiyaṃ vā*), or white lotuses ( *puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā*), some blue lotuses ( *uppalāni vā*), or red lotuses ( *padumāni vā*), or white lotuses ( *puṇḍarīkāni vā*) are born in the water ( *udake jātāni*), grow in the water ( *udake saṃvaḍḍhāni*), thrive without rising out of the water ( *udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni*). Cool water drenches, steeps, fills, and pervades them from their tips to their roots ( *tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni paripūrāni paripphuṭāni*), so that there is no part of all those blue lotuses, red lotuses, or white lotuses ( *sabbāvataṃ uppalānaṃ vā padumānaṃ vā puṇḍarīkānaṃ vā*), that is not suffused with cool water ( *sītena vārinā apphuṭaṃ assa*).

Even so, young man, a monk… (etc.)… And also, young man, with the fading away of rapture, a monk… (etc.)… he enters and abides in the third *jhāna*.

He drenches, steeps, saturates, and suffuses this very body with happiness free from rapture, so that there is no part of his entire body which is not suffused by this happiness free from rapture.

This comes to him through concentration ( *samādhismiṃ*).

mula_pali: 470. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṃ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṃ assa. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. So imameva kāyaṃ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti; nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṃ hoti. Idampissa hoti samādhismiṃ.
mula_english:
"Furthermore, young man, a *bhikkhu*, with the abandonment of pleasure (*sukha*) and with the abandonment of pain (*duḥkha*), and with the previous disappearance of joy (*saumanassa*) and grief (*daumanassa*), enters upon and abides in the fourth *jhāna* (*catutthaṃ jhānaṃ*), which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure (*adukkhamasukhaṃ*) and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity (*upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ*).

He sits pervading this body with a pure, bright mind, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the pure bright mind.

"Just as, young man, a man were sitting covered from the head down with a white cloth, so that there would be no part of his whole body not covered by the white cloth.

Even so, young man, a *bhikkhu*… and further, young man, a *bhikkhu*, with the abandonment of pleasure and with the abandonment of pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, enters upon and abides in the fourth *jhāna*, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

He sits pervading this body with a pure, bright mind, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the pure bright mind.

This comes to him through concentration (*samādhi*).

mula_pali: 471. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho so, māṇava, ariyo samādhikkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi , yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi. Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīya’’nti. ‘‘Acchariyaṃ, bho ānanda, abbhutaṃ, bho  ānanda! So cāyaṃ, bho ānanda, ariyo samādhikkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo. Evaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ cāhaṃ, bho ānanda, ariyaṃ samādhikkhandhaṃ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi. Evaṃ paripuṇṇañca, bho ānanda, ariyaṃ samādhikkhandhaṃ ito bahiddhā aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇā attani samanupasseyyuṃ, te tāvatakeneva attamanā assu – ‘alamettāvatā, katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttarikaraṇīya’nti. Atha ca pana bhavaṃ ānando evamāha – ‘atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīya’’’nti.
mula_english:
471.
"That, young man, is the division of the noble concentration (ariya samādhikkhandha) which the Blessed One (bhagavā) praised, and with which he aroused, exhorted, and established these people.
But something more remains to be done."
"Wonderful, Ānanda, amazing, Ānanda! This division of noble concentration (ariya samādhikkhandha) is perfectly complete, not incomplete.
And in this way, Ānanda, I do not see this division of noble concentration (ariyaṃ samādhikkhandhaṃ) fulfilled anywhere outside this, among other ascetics and Brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇesu).
And if any other ascetics and Brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇā) were to perceive this division of noble concentration (ariyaṃ samādhikkhandhaṃ) as complete in themselves, they would be delighted with just that much, saying, 'Enough has been done, the goal of our asceticism (sāmaññattho) has been attained, there is nothing more to be done.'
And yet the Venerable Ānanda declares: 'But something more remains to be done!'"
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.

"'There is still something further to be done' (*atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti*): In the Blessed One’s teaching (*bhagavato sāsane*), the attainment of the final goal (*pariyosānappatti*) is not merely through one-pointedness of mind (*cittekaggatāmattakena*). It shows that there is indeed something else to be done beyond this (*itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti*)."

"'There is no further need to do anything' (*natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti*): In the Blessed One’s teaching (*bhagavato sāsane*), there is nothing further to be done (*ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva*), because the Blessed One's teaching (*bhagavato sāsanaṃ*) culminates in Arhatship (*arahattapariyosānañhi dasseti*)."

The rest is clear throughout (*sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti*).

mula_pali: 472. ‘‘Katamo  pana so, bho ānanda, ariyo paññākkhandho, yassa bho bhavaṃ gotamo vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesī’’ti? ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So evaṃ pajānāti – ‘ayaṃ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo; idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddha’nti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatrāssa suttaṃ āvutaṃ nīlaṃ vā pītaṃ vā lohitaṃ vā odātaṃ vā paṇḍusuttaṃ vā. Tamenaṃ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya – ‘ayaṃ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṃso  suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno. Tatridaṃ suttaṃ āvutaṃ nīlaṃ vā pītaṃ vā lohitaṃ vā odātaṃ vā paṇḍusuttaṃ vā’ti. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So evaṃ pajānāti – ‘ayaṃ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko  mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedana-viddhaṃsanadhammo. Idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddha’nti. Yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte…pe…  āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So evaṃ pajānāti…pe… ettha paṭibaddhanti. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
472.
"But what, Ānanda, is that noble aggregate of wisdom (ariya paññākkhandho) of which the esteemed Gotama was a proponent, and in which he encouraged, established, and grounded this populace?"

"It is when a monk, with his mind well-concentrated (samāhite citte), purified (parisuddhe), cleansed (pariyodāte), without blemish (anaṅgaṇe), rid of defilements (vigatūpakkilese), softened (mudubhūte), workable (kammaniye), firm (ṭhite), and having attained imperturbability (āneñjappatte), directs (abhinīharati) and inclines (abhininnāmeti) his mind towards knowledge and vision (ñāṇadassanāya).

He understands thus (evaṃ pajānāti): ‘This body of mine (ayaṃ kho me kāyo) is material (rūpī), made up of the four great elements (cātumahābhūtiko), born of mother and father (mātāpettikasambhavo), fed on rice and gruel (odanakummāsūpacayo), subject to impermanence (anicca), to being worn and rubbed away (ucchādanaparimaddana), to dissolution and disintegration (bhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo); and this consciousness of mine (idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ) is supported by it (ettha sitaṃ) and bound up with it (ettha paṭibaddha)’nti.

"Suppose, young man (māṇava), there were a beautiful beryl gem (maṇi veḷuriyo), pure (subho), of fine quality (jātimā), with eight facets (aṭṭhaṃso), well-cut (suparikammakato), clear (accho), bright (vippasanno), unflawed (anāvilo), perfect in every respect (sabbākārasampanno).

And through it would run a thread (suttaṃ āvutaṃ), blue (nīlaṃ) or yellow (pītaṃ) or red (lohitaṃ) or white (odātaṃ) or brown (paṇḍusuttaṃ).

Then a man with good sight (cakkhumā puriso), taking it in his hand (hatthe karitvā), might review it thus (paccavekkheyya): ‘This is a beautiful beryl gem (ayaṃ kho maṇi veḷuriyo), pure (subho), of fine quality (jātimā), with eight facets (aṭṭhaṃso), well-cut (suparikammakato), clear (accho), bright (vippasanno), unflawed (anāvilo), perfect in every respect (sabbākārasampanno).

And through it runs a thread (suttaṃ āvutaṃ), blue (nīlaṃ) or yellow (pītaṃ) or red (lohitaṃ) or white (odātaṃ) or brown (paṇḍusuttaṃ)’ti.

In the same way (evameva kho), young man (māṇava), a monk (bhikkhu), with his mind well-concentrated (evaṃ samāhite citte), purified (parisuddhe), cleansed (pariyodāte), without blemish (anaṅgaṇe), rid of defilements (vigatūpakkilese), softened (mudubhūte), workable (kammaniye), firm (ṭhite), and having attained imperturbability (āneñjappatte), directs (abhinīharati) and inclines (abhininnāmeti) his mind towards knowledge and vision (ñāṇadassanāya).

He understands thus (so evaṃ pajānāti): ‘This body of mine (ayaṃ kho me kāyo) is material (rūpī), made up of the four great elements (cātumahābhūtiko), born of mother and father (mātāpettikasambhavo), fed on rice and gruel (odanakummāsūpacayo), subject to impermanence (anicca), to being worn and rubbed away (ucchādanaparimaddana-bhedana), to dissolution and disintegration (viddhaṃsanadhammo).

And this consciousness of mine (idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ) is supported by it (ettha sitaṃ) and bound up with it (ettha paṭibaddha)’nti.

Furthermore (yampi), young man (māṇava), a monk (bhikkhu), with his mind well-concentrated (evaṃ samāhite citte)…pe… having attained imperturbability (āneñjappatte), directs (abhinīharati) and inclines (abhininnāmeti) his mind towards knowledge and vision (ñāṇadassanāya).

He understands thus (so evaṃ pajānāti)…pe… bound up with it (ettha paṭibaddhanti).

This also comes to him through wisdom (idampissa hoti paññāya).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.

"'There is still something further to be done here (atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti)'—here, it shows that in the Blessed One's teaching (bhagavato sāsane), the attainment of final goal (pariyosānappatti) is not merely through one-pointedness of mind (cittekaggatāmattakeneva), there is indeed something else further to be done (itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti)."

"'There is nothing further to be done here (natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti)'—here, it shows that in the Blessed One's teaching (bhagavato sāsane), there is nothing else to be done beyond this (ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva), for the Blessed One's teaching has the attainment of Arhatship as its final goal (arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti)."

The rest is clear throughout (sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti).

mula_pali: 473. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmānāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmināti rūpiṃ manomayaṃ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriyaṃ. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , māṇava, puriso muñjamhā īsikaṃ pavāheyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ muñjo ayaṃ īsikā; añño muñjo aññā īsikā; muñjamhā tveva īsikā pavāḷhā’ti. Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, puriso asiṃ kosiyā pavāheyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ asi, ayaṃ kosi; añño asi, aññā kosi; kosiyā tveva asi pavāḷho’ti. Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, puriso ahiṃ karaṇḍā uddhareyya. Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ ahi, ayaṃ karaṇḍo; añño ahi, añño karaṇḍo; karaṇḍā tveva ahi ubbhato’ti . Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmānāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe…. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
473.
"When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, without blemish, rid of defilements, softened, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the creation of a mind-made body.

From this body, he creates another body, having form, mind-made, complete in all its limbs, lacking no faculty ( *ahīnindriyaṃ*).

"Just as, young man, a man might draw a reed (*īsikaṃ*) from its sheath (*muñjamhā*).

He would think, 'This is the sheath (*muñjo*), this is the reed (*īsika*); the sheath (*muñjo*) is one thing, the reed (*īsika*) is another; it is from the sheath (*muñjamhā*) that the reed (*īsika*) has been drawn out.'

Or just as, young man, a man might draw a sword (*asiṃ*) from its scabbard (*kosiyā*).

He would think, 'This is the sword (*asi*), this is the scabbard (*kosi*); the sword (*asi*) is one thing, the scabbard (*kosi*) is another; it is from the scabbard (*kosiyā*) that the sword (*asi*) has been drawn out.'

Or just as, young man, a man might draw a snake (*ahiṃ*) from its slough (*karaṇḍā*).

He would think, 'This is the snake (*ahi*), this is the slough (*karaṇḍo*); the snake (*ahi*) is one thing, the slough (*karaṇḍo*) is another; it is from the slough (*karaṇḍā*) that the snake (*ahi*) has been drawn out.'

In the same way, young man, a *bhikkhu*... and so on... when, young man, a *bhikkhu* has his mind thus concentrated, purified, bright, without blemish, rid of defilements, softened, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the creation of a mind-made body... and so on...

This too, he understands through wisdom (*paññāya*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.
"If there is still something further to be done," means that in the Blessed One's teaching, the attainment of final cessation does not occur through mere one-pointedness of mind alone. It shows that there is indeed something else to be done even beyond this.

"If there is nothing further to be done," means that in the Blessed One's teaching, there is indeed nothing further to be done beyond this, because the Blessed One's teaching culminates in *arhatship*.

The rest is clear throughout.

mula_pali: 474. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti. Ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti, bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti. Āvibhāvaṃ tirobhāvaṃ tirokuṭṭaṃ tiropākāraṃ tiropabbataṃ asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse. Pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṃ karoti, seyyathāpi udake. Udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṃ. Ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo. Imepi candimasūriye evaṃ mahiddhike evaṃ mahānubhāve pāṇinā parāmasati parimajjati. Yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi , māṇava, dakkho kumbhakāro vā kumbhakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatāya mattikāya yaññadeva bhājanavikatiṃ ākaṅkheyya, taṃ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya. Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, dakkho dantakāro vā dantakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṃ dantasmiṃ yaññadeva dantavikatiṃ ākaṅkheyya, taṃ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya. Seyyathā vā pana, māṇava, dakkho suvaṇṇakāro vā suvaṇṇakārantevāsī vā suparikammakatasmiṃ suvaṇṇasmiṃ  yaññadeva suvaṇṇavikatiṃ ākaṅkheyya, taṃ tadeva kareyya abhinipphādeyya. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu  …pe… yampi māṇava bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte iddhividhāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti. Ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti …pe… yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṃ vatteti. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
474.

'And he, with mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of imperfections, malleable, workable, established, and having attained imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind to the modes of supernormal power ( *iddhi-vidhāya cittam abhiniharati abhininnāmeti*).

He experiences various kinds of supernormal power (*aneka-vihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti*).

Having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one.

He appears and vanishes; he goes unimpeded through walls, ramparts, and mountains as if through space.

He dives in and out of the earth as if it were water.

He walks on water without sinking as if it were dry land.

Sitting cross-legged he travels through space like a winged bird.

He even touches and strokes with his hand the sun and moon, mighty and powerful as they are.

He wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā- world.

'Just as, Māṇava, a skilled potter or his apprentice could make and fashion out of well-prepared clay whatever kind of vessel he might desire.

Or just as, Māṇava, a skilled ivory-worker or his apprentice could make and fashion out of well-prepared ivory whatever kind of ivory object he might desire.

Or just as, Māṇava, a skilled goldsmith or his apprentice could make and fashion out of well-prepared gold whatever kind of gold article he might desire.

In the same way, Māṇava, a monk … and that monk, Māṇava, with mind thus concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of imperfections, malleable, workable, established, and having attained imperturbability, directs and inclines his mind to the modes of supernormal power (*iddhi-vidhāya cittam abhiniharati abhininnāmeti*).

He experiences various kinds of supernormal power (*aneka-vihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhoti*).

Having been one, he becomes many … and he wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahmā- world.

This comes to him through wisdom (*idaṃpissa hoti paññāya*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.
"If there is still something further to be done" means that in the Blessed One's teaching, the attainment of finality is not merely through one-pointedness of mind; it shows that there is indeed something else further to be done.

"If there is no further work to be done" means that in the Blessed One's teaching, there is nothing further to be done; it shows that the Blessed One's teaching culminates in arhatship.

The rest is clear throughout.

mula_pali: 475. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca. Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno. So suṇeyya bherisaddampi mudiṅgasaddampi saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddampi. Tassa evamassa – ‘bherisaddo itipi mudiṅgasaddo itipi saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddo iti’pi itipīti (ka.). Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe…. Yampi māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti  dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
“When his mind is thus concentrated… and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the divine ear-element ( *dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti*).

With the divine ear-element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, the divine and the human, those which are distant and those which are near (*so dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca*).

Suppose, young man, a man is travelling along a highway (*seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso addhānamaggappaṭipanno*).

He might hear the sound of a kettledrum, the sound of a *mṛdaṅga* drum, the sound of a conch, the sound of a cymbal, and the sound of a drum (*so suṇeyya bherisaddampi mudiṅgasaddampi saṅkhapaṇavadindimasaddampi*).

It would occur to him: ‘This is the sound of a kettledrum; this is the sound of a *mṛdaṅga* drum; this is the sound of a conch, the sound of a cymbal, and the sound of a drum.’

In the same way, young man, a *bhikṣu*…

And furthermore, young man, when a *bhikṣu*'s mind is thus concentrated… and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the divine ear-element (*dibbāya sotadhātuyā cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti*).

With the divine ear-element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, the divine and the human, those which are distant and those which are near (*so dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca*).

This is known to him by wisdom (*idampissa hoti paññāya*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.
"If there is further work to be done," here, in the Blessed One's teaching, there is no attainment of completion by mere one-pointedness of mind; it shows that there is indeed something else to be done beyond this.
"If there is no further work to be done," here, in the Blessed One's teaching, there is indeed nothing further to be done beyond this, for the Blessed One's teaching culminates in *arhatship*.
The rest is clear throughout.

mula_pali: 476. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So parasattānaṃ parapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti, ‘sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ vītarāgaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘sadosaṃ vā cittaṃ sadosaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘vītadosaṃ vā cittaṃ vītadosaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘samohaṃ vā cittaṃ samohaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘vītamohaṃ vā cittaṃ vītamohaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ saṅkhittaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ vikkhittaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘mahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ mahaggataṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘amahaggataṃ vā cittaṃ amahaggataṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘sauttaraṃ vā cittaṃ sauttaraṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘anuttaraṃ vā cittaṃ anuttaraṃ citta’nti  pajānāti, ‘samāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ samāhitaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘asamāhitaṃ vā cittaṃ asamāhitaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘vimuttaṃ  vā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ citta’nti pajānāti, ‘avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ citta’nti pajānāti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udakapatte sakaṃ mukhanimittaṃ paccavekkhamāno sakaṇikaṃ vā sakaṇikanti  jāneyya, akaṇikaṃ vā akaṇikanti jāneyya. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite…pe… āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So parasattānaṃ purapuggalānaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti, sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ sarāgaṃ cittanti pajānāti…pe… avimuttaṃ vā cittaṃ avimuttaṃ cittanti pajānāti. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
476.

"When his mind is thus concentrated, pure, bright, spotless, free from defilements, malleable, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability ( *āneñjappatte* ), he directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of encompassing the minds (*cetopariyañāṇa*).

He understands the minds of other beings and other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind. He understands a mind with lust ( *sarāgaṃ cittaṃ* ) as a mind with lust and a mind without lust ( *vītarāgaṃ cittaṃ* ) as a mind without lust; he understands a mind with hatred (*sadosaṃ cittaṃ*) as a mind with hatred and a mind without hatred (*vītadosaṃ cittaṃ*) as a mind without hatred; he understands a mind with delusion (*samohaṃ cittaṃ*) as a mind with delusion and a mind without delusion (*vītamohaṃ cittaṃ*) as a mind without delusion; he understands a contracted mind (*saṅkhittaṃ cittaṃ*) as a contracted mind and a distracted mind (*vikkhittaṃ cittaṃ*) as a distracted mind; he understands an exalted mind ( *mahaggataṃ cittaṃ* ) as an exalted mind and an unexalted mind ( *amahaggataṃ cittaṃ* ) as an unexalted mind; he understands a surpassable mind (*sauttaraṃ cittaṃ*) as a surpassable mind and an unsurpassed mind ( *anuttaraṃ cittaṃ* ) as an unsurpassed mind; he understands a concentrated mind (*samāhitaṃ cittaṃ*) as a concentrated mind and an unconcentrated mind (*asamāhitaṃ cittaṃ*) as an unconcentrated mind; he understands a liberated mind (*vimuttaṃ cittaṃ*) as a liberated mind and an unliberated mind (*avimuttaṃ cittaṃ*) as an unliberated mind.

"Just as, young man, a woman or a man, young, youthful, fond of ornaments, examining the image of their own face in a clear, bright mirror or in a bowl of clear water, would know if there were a spot thus: 'There is a spot,' or would know if there were no spot thus: 'There is no spot';
