"Even so, young man, a bhikkhu... directs his mind to the knowledge of encompassing the minds (*cetopariyañāṇa*).

He understands the minds of other beings, other individuals, having encompassed it with his own awareness: a mind with passion as a mind with passion… an unliberated mind as an unliberated mind.

This comes to him through wisdom ( *paññāya*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.
"If there is further work to be done," this shows that in the Blessed One's teaching, the attainment of the final goal is not merely through one-pointedness of mind; there is indeed further work to be done beyond this.

"If there is no further work to be done," this shows that in the Blessed One's teaching, there is nothing further to be done beyond this, for the Blessed One's teaching culminates in Arhatship.

The rest is clear throughout. (seṣaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti)

mula_pali: 477. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ, ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe – ‘amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṃgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṃ gāmaṃ gaccheyya; tamhāpi gāmā aññaṃ gāmaṃ gaccheyya; so tamhā gāmā sakaṃyeva gāmaṃ paccāgaccheyya . Tassa evamassa – ‘ahaṃ kho sakamhā gāmā amuṃ gāmaṃ agacchiṃ, tatra evaṃ aṭṭhāsiṃ evaṃ nisīdiṃ evaṃ abhāsiṃ evaṃ tuṇhī ahosiṃ. So tamhāpi gāmā amuṃ gāmaṃ gacchiṃ, tatrāpi evaṃ aṭṭhāsiṃ evaṃ nisīdiṃ evaṃ abhāsiṃ evaṃ tuṇhī ahosiṃ. Somhi tamhā gāmā sakaṃyeva gāmaṃ paccāgato’ti. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ  samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti . So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Seyyathidaṃ – ekampi jātiṃ…pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
477.

"When his mind is thus concentrated…and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of recollecting past lives ( *pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇa*).

He recollects his manifold past lives.

That is to say, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many aeons of world-contraction ( *saṃvaṭṭakappa*), many aeons of world-expansion (*vivaṭṭakappa*), many aeons of world-contraction and expansion (*saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappa*)—’There I was so named, of such a clan, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life-term.

Passing away from there, I arose there; there I was so named, of such a clan, with such an appearance, such was my food, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such my life-term; passing away from there, I was reborn here.’

Thus he remembers various past births, their conditions and details (*sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ*).

"Just as, young man ( *māṇava*), a man might go from his own village to another village, and from that village he might go to still another village, and then from that village he would return to his own village.

He might think: ‘I went from my own village to that village, and there I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, and remained silent in such a way.

From that village I went to that other village, and there too I stood in such a way, sat in such a way, spoke in such a way, and remained silent in such a way.

From that village I have returned to my own village.’

Even so, young man, a monk… when his mind is thus concentrated…and attained to imperturbability, he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of recollecting past lives.

He recollects his manifold past lives.

That is to say, one birth…Thus he remembers various past births, their conditions and details.

That is known to him by wisdom (*paññāya*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.
"'There is still something further to be done (uttarikaraṇīya)' means that in the Blessed One's teaching (sāsana), the attainment of the final goal (pariyosānappatti) is not merely through one-pointedness of mind (cittekaggatā); it shows that there is indeed something else to be done beyond this (itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yeva)."

"'There is nothing further to be done (uttarikaraṇīya)' means that in the Blessed One's teaching (sāsana), there is nothing further to be done beyond this (ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva), for the Blessed One's teaching (bhagavato sāsanaṃ) culminates in Arahantship (arahattapariyosānañhi)."

The rest is clear throughout (sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti).

mula_pali: 478. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti – ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā  vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṃ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, majjhesiṅghāṭake pāsādo, tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya manusse gehaṃ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikāyapi vīthiṃ sañcarante majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnepi. Tassa evamassa – ‘ete manussā gehaṃ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikāya vīthiṃ sañcaranti, ete majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnā’ti. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti. Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
478.

When his mind is thus concentrated…attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

With the divine eye (*dibbaṃ cakkhu*), which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearing—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate—and he understands how beings fare according to their *kamma* (actions), thus: ‘These beings— who were endowed with bad conduct of body (*kāyaduccarita*), speech (*vacīduccarita*), and mind (*manoduccarita*), who reviled the noble ones (*ariyānaṃ upavādakā*), held wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhikā*), and undertook actions governed by wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā*)—

at the breaking up of the body (*kāyassa bhedā*), after death (*paraṃ maraṇā*), have reappeared in the plane of misery (*apāyaṃ*), the bad destinations (*duggatiṃ*), the lower realms (*vinipātaṃ*), in hell (*nirayaṃ upapannā*).

But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body (*kāyasucarita*), speech (*vacīsucarita*), and mind (*manosucarita*), who did not abuse the noble ones (*ariyānaṃ anupavādakā*), who held right view (*sammādiṭṭhikā*) and acted accordingly (*sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā*),

at the breaking up of the body (*kāyassa bhedā*), after death (*paraṃ maraṇā*), have reappeared in a good destination (*sugatiṃ*), in the world of heaven (*saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā*.’)

Thus, with the divine eye (*dibbena cakkhunā*)… he sees beings passing away and realizing.

“Just as, Māṇava, if there were a palace in the middle of a crossroads (*majjhesiṅghāṭake pāsādo*), and a man with sight (*cakkhumā puriso*) stood there, he might see people entering a house, leaving, walking along the street (*rathikāya vīthiṃ sañcarante*), or sitting in the middle of the crossroads (*majjhesiṅghāṭake nisinnepi*).

He might think: ‘These people are entering the house, these are leaving, these are walking along the street, and these are sitting in the middle of the crossroads.’

In the same way, Māṇava, a *bhikkhu* (monk)…when his mind is thus concentrated…attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

With the divine eye (*dibbena cakkhunā*)… he sees beings passing away and realizing.

That is known to him by wisdom (*paññāya*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.
"atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti." means: And it shows that in the Blessed One’s Dispensation, it’s not just reaching the end through mere one-pointedness of mind, there *is* something more to be done beyond this.
"natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti." means: And it shows that in the Blessed One’s Dispensation, there is nothing further to do, for the Blessed One’s Dispensation culminates in Arhatship.
"sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti." means: The rest is clear in meaning throughout.

mula_pali: 479. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya  cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti  yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti; ime āsavāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ āsavasamudayoti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ āsavanirodhoti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti , ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti. ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, māṇava, pabbatasaṅkhepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tattha cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito passeyya sippikasambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiṭṭhantampi. Tassa evamassa – ‘ayaṃ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tatrime sippikasambukāpi sakkharakathalāpi macchagumbāpi carantipi tiṭṭhantipī’ti. Evameva kho, māṇava, bhikkhu…pe… yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti. So idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti…pe… āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti. Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti, ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti . Idampissa hoti paññāya.
mula_english:
479.
When his mind is thus concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defilements, pliable, workable, steady, and has attained imperturbability, he directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the *āsavas* (cankers or defilements).

He understands as it actually is: ‘This is suffering (*duḥkha*)’; he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the origin of suffering (*duḥkhasamudaya*)’; he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering (*duḥkhanirodha*)’; he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering (*duḥkhanirodhagāminī pratipadā*)’; he understands as it actually is: ‘These are the *āsavas*’; he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the origin of the *āsavas*’; he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the cessation of the *āsavas*’; he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the path leading to the cessation of the *āsavas*.’

As he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the *āsava* of sensual desire (*kāmāsava*), from the *āsava* of existence (*bhavāsava*), and from the *āsava* of ignorance (*avijjāsava*). When liberated, there is the knowledge that it is liberated.

He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’

Just as, young man, there were a lake in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed.

There a man with good eyes standing on the bank might see shells and gravel, and shoals of fish swimming about and resting.

He might think: 'This lake is clear, limpid, and undisturbed.

There are these shells, gravel and shoals of fish swimming about and resting.’

Just so, young man, a *bhikkhu*… and further…just as, young man, a *bhikkhu* with mind thus concentrated…and further…attained to imperturbability, directs and applies his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the *āsavas*.

He understands as it actually is: ‘This is suffering (*duḥkha*)’…and further… he understands as it actually is: ‘This is the path leading to the cessation of the *āsavas*.’

As he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the *āsava* of sensual desire (*kāmāsava*), from the *āsava* of existence (*bhavāsava*), and from the *āsava* of ignorance (*avijjāsava*). When liberated, there is the knowledge that it is liberated. He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’

This comes to him through wisdom (*prajñā*).
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.

"atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti" means that in the Blessed One's teaching, the attainment of the final goal is not merely through one-pointedness of mind (cittekaggatā). It shows that there is indeed something else to be done beyond this.

"natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti" means that in the Blessed One's teaching, there is nothing further to be done beyond this, as the teaching of the Blessed One culminates in Arhatship (arahattapariyosāna).

The rest is clear throughout (sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthameva).

mula_pali: 480. ‘‘Ayaṃ kho, so māṇava, ariyo paññākkhandho yassa so bhagavā vaṇṇavādī ahosi, yattha ca imaṃ janataṃ samādapesi nivesesi patiṭṭhāpesi. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīya’’nti. ‘‘Acchariyaṃ , bho ānanda, abbhutaṃ, bho ānanda! So cāyaṃ, bho ānanda, ariyo paññākkhandho paripuṇṇo, no aparipuṇṇo. Evaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ cāhaṃ, bho ānanda, ariyaṃ paññākkhandhaṃ ito bahiddhā aññesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu na samanupassāmi. Natthi  cevettha na samanupassāmi…pe… natthi no kiñci (syā. ka.) uttarikaraṇīyaṃ uttariṃ karaṇīyanti (sī. syā. pī.) uttarikaraṇīyanti (ka.). Abhikkantaṃ, bho ānanda, abhikkantaṃ, bho ānanda! Seyyathāpi, bho ānanda, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti. Evamevaṃ bhotā ānandena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ, bho ānanda, taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ ānando dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti.
mula_english:
480. 'That, young man, is the noble aggregate of wisdom (*ariya paññākkhandha*) which the Blessed One (*bhagavā*) praised, with which he aroused, exhorted, and established people.

Beyond that, there is nothing further to be done.'

'It is wonderful, Reverend Ānanda, it is marvelous, Reverend Ānanda! This noble aggregate of wisdom (*ariya paññākkhandha*) is perfectly fulfilled (*paripuṇṇo*), not incomplete.

And I, Reverend Ānanda, do not see this aggregate of noble wisdom (*ariyaṃ paññākkhandhaṃ*) so completely fulfilled anywhere among the ascetics (*samaṇa*) and Brahmins (*brāhmaṇa*) of other schools.

Beyond that I see nothing... beyond that... there is nothing at all (perhaps).
What?
There is further work to be done, there is more to do (perhaps).
There is work to be done (perhaps).

Excellent, Reverend Ānanda, excellent, Reverend Ānanda! It is as if, Reverend Ānanda, someone were to set upright what had been overturned (*nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya*), or to reveal what was hidden (*paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya*), or to point out the way to one who had gone astray (*mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya*), or to hold up an oil lamp in the darkness (*andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya*), so that those with eyes could see forms (*‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti*).

Just so has the Dhamma been made clear in many ways by Reverend Ānanda (*evamevaṃ bhotā ānandena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito*).

I go to the Blessed Gotama (*bhagavantaṃ gotamaṃ*) for refuge (*saraṇaṃ gacchāmi*), and to the Dhamma, and to the Saṅgha of monks (*bhikkhusaṅghañca*).

May the esteemed Ānanda remember me as a lay follower (*upāsakaṃ*) who has gone for refuge (*saraṇaṃ gata’’nti*) from this day forward, as long as life shall last.'
commentary_pali: 471-480.Atthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane na cittekaggatāmattakeneva pariyosānappatti nāma atthi, itopi uttari pana aññaṃ kattabbaṃ atthi yevāti dasseti. Natthi cevettha uttarikaraṇīyanti ettha bhagavato sāsane ito uttari kātabbaṃ nāma natthiyeva, arahattapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsananti dasseti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
471-480.

"If indeed there is something further to be done," means that in the Blessed One's teaching, the attainment of the ultimate goal is not merely through one-pointedness of mind alone. It shows that even beyond this, there is indeed something else to be done.

"If indeed there is nothing further to be done," means that in the Blessed One's teaching, there is indeed nothing further to be done beyond this, for the Blessed One's teaching culminates in *arhatship*.

The rest is clear throughout.

mula_pali: 323. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena khāṇumataṃ nāma magadhānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari. Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ. Tena kho pana samayena kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo khāṇumataṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ. Tena kho pana samayena kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa mahāyañño upakkhaṭo hoti. Satta ca usabhasatāni satta ca vacchatarasatāni satta ca vacchatarīsatāni satta ca ajasatāni satta ca urabbhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was wandering in Magadha with a large *saṅgha* or community of monks, about five hundred in all, and he arrived at a *brāhmaṇa* village of the Magadhas called Khāṇumata.

And there the Blessed One stayed near Khāṇumata, in Ambalaṭṭhikā.

Now at that time, the *brāhmaṇa* Kūṭadanta was dwelling in Khāṇumata, a populous place, full of grass, timber, water, and corn, a royal estate given to him by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha as a royal gift (*rājadāya*) and a *brahmadeyya*, a gift to a Brahmin.

At that time, Kūṭadanta the *brāhmaṇa* was preparing for a great sacrifice (*mahāyañña*).

Seven hundred bulls (*usabha*), seven hundred bullocks (*vacchatarā*), seven hundred heifers (*vacchatarī*), seven hundred goats (*aja*), and seven hundred rams (*urabbha*) were tied to the sacrificial posts for the sacrifice (*yañña*).
commentary_pali: 323.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… magadhesūti kūṭadantasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Magadhesūti magadhā nāma jānapadino rājakumārā, tesaṃ nivāso ekopi janapado rūḷhīsaddena magadhāti vuccati, tasmiṃ magadhesu janapade. Ito paraṃ purimasuttadvaye vuttanayameva. Ambalaṭṭhikā brahmajāle vuttasadisāva. Kūṭadantoti tassa brāhmaṇassa nāmaṃ. Upakkhaṭoti sajjito. Vacchatarasatānīti vacchasatāni. Urabbhāti taruṇameṇḍakā vuccanti. Ete tāva pāḷiyaṃ āgatāyeva. Pāḷiyaṃ pana anāgatānampi anekesaṃ migapakkhīnaṃ sattasattasatāni sampiṇḍitānevāti veditabbāni. Sabbasattasatikayāgaṃ kiresa yajitukāmo hoti. Thūṇūpanītānīti bandhitvā ṭhapanatthāya yūpasaṅkhātaṃ thūṇaṃ upanītāni.
commentary_english:
323. Thus have I heard…pe… the *Kūṭadanta Sutta* in Magadha.

Here begins the explanation of words not previously appearing.

"In Magadha" means that the *rājakumāra*s (royal princes) of Magadha are known as *Magadhā*. Their residence, even a single district, is called Magadhā by common usage. In that district of Magadha.

From here on, the exposition is just according to the manner already stated in the two previous *sutta*s.

The *ambalaṭṭhikā* is just like what was stated in the *Brahmajāla*.

"Kūṭadanta" is the name of that *brāhmaṇa* (Brahman).

"*Upakkhaṭo*" means prepared (*sajjito*).

"*Vacchatarasatānī*" means hundreds of calves (*vacchasatāni*).

"*Urabbhā*" means young rams (*taruṇameṇḍakā* are called).

These, indeed, have already come in the *Pāḷi*.

Moreover, in the *Pāḷi*, it should be understood that hundreds upon hundreds of animals and birds not yet mentioned are included.

It seems that he intends to perform a *sabbasattasatikayāgaṃ* (sacrifice involving hundreds of all beings).

"*Thūṇūpanītāni*" means, having bound and brought (them) near to the posts (*thūṇaṃ*) for the purpose of erecting a sacrificial post (*yūpa*).

mula_pali: 324. Assosuṃ kho khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā – ‘‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi khāṇumataṃ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti . So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ  sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti. So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti. Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī’’ti.
mula_english:
The Brahmins and householders of Khāṇumata heard: "The ascetic Gotama, the son of the Śākyans, who went forth from the Śākya clan, while wandering in Magadha with a large Saṅgha of monks, with about five hundred monks, has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying in Ambalaṭṭhikā."

Now, concerning that venerable Gotama, such a good report has spread: "Indeed, that Blessed One is an *arhat* (worthy one), a fully enlightened Buddha (*sammāsambuddho*), perfected in knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampanno*), a *sugata* (well-gone), a knower of the worlds (*lokavidū*), an unsurpassed trainer of beings to be tamed (*anuttaro purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans (*satthā devamanussānaṃ*), a Buddha (awakened one), a Blessed One (*bhagavā*)."

He, having realized it by his own super-knowledge (*abhiññā*), proclaims this world with its gods (*sadevakaṃ*), its Māras (*samārakaṃ*), and its Brahmās (*sabrahmakaṃ*), this generation with its ascetics and Brahmins (*sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ*), its gods and humans (*sadevamanussaṃ*).

He teaches the Dharma (*dhammaṃ*) which is good in the beginning (*ādikalyāṇaṃ*), good in the middle (*majjhekalyāṇaṃ*), and good in the end (*pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ*), with meaning (*sātthaṃ*) and with phrasing (*sabyañjanaṃ*); he reveals the *brahmacariya* (holy life) which is utterly perfect (*kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ*) and pure (*parisuddhaṃ*).

"It is good to see such *arhats* (worthy ones)."

mula_pali: 325. Atha  kho khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā khāṇumatā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā yena ambalaṭṭhikā tenupasaṅkamanti.
mula_english: And then, the *brāhmaṇa* householders of Khāṇumata, having left Khāṇumata in crowds and large numbers, went to Ambalaṭṭhikā.

mula_pali: 326. Tena  kho pana samayena kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo uparipāsāde divāseyyaṃ upagato hoti. Addasā kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo khāṇumatake brāhmaṇagahapatike khāṇumatā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūte yena ambalaṭṭhikā tenupasaṅkamante. Disvā khattaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘kiṃ nu kho, bho khatte, khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā khāṇumatā nikkhamitvā saṅghasaṅghī gaṇībhūtā yena ambalaṭṭhikā tenupasaṅkamantī’’ti?
mula_english:
Just then, the Brahmin Kūṭadanta had gone up to his upper palace for his midday rest.

Kūṭadanta the Brahmin saw the Brahmin householders of Khāṇumata setting forth from Khāṇumata in groups and bands and heading to Ambalaṭṭhikā.

Seeing them, he addressed his charioteer: "Good charioteer, why are the Brahmin householders of Khāṇumata setting forth from Khāṇumata in groups and bands heading to Ambalaṭṭhikā?"

mula_pali: 327. ‘‘Atthi kho, bho, samaṇo gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito magadhesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi khāṇumataṃ anuppatto, khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ. Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti. Tamete bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamantī’’ti.
mula_english:
“Sir, there is the ascetic Gotama, a son of the Śākyans, gone forth from the Śākya clan, wandering in Magadha with a great community of monks, with about five hundred monks. He has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.

Now, concerning that venerable Gotama, such a good report has spread about: ‘Indeed, that Blessed One is an Arhat, a fully enlightened Buddha (sammāsambuddho), perfect in knowledge and conduct (vijjācaraṇasampanno), a Well-Farer (sugato), Knower of the worlds (lokavidū), unsurpassed trainer of persons to be tamed (anuttaro purisadammasārathi), teacher of gods and humans (satthā devamanussānaṃ), enlightened, blessed.’

That is why they are going to see the venerable Gotama."

mula_pali: 328. Atha kho kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi – ‘‘sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ – ‘samaṇo  gotamo tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ jānātī’ti. Na kho panāhaṃ jānāmi tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ. Icchāmi cāhaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ  samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ puccheyya’’nti.
mula_english:
328. Then the brahmin Kūṭadanta thought: "I have heard that the *śramaṇa* Gotama knows the threefold accomplishment of sacrifice ( *tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ*) with its sixteen accessories (*soḷasaparikkhāraṃ*)."

Now, I do not understand the threefold accomplishment of sacrifice with its sixteen accessories.

And I want to perform a great sacrifice (*mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ*).

Suppose I were to approach the *śramaṇa* Gotama and ask him about the threefold accomplishment of sacrifice with its sixteen accessories."
commentary_pali: 328.Tividhanti ettha vidhā vuccati ṭhapanā, tiṭṭhapananti attho. Soḷasaparikkhāranti soḷasaparivāraṃ.
commentary_english:
328. In "threefold," *vidhā* means establishment, that is, *tiṭṭhapana*.
"Sixteen accessories" means sixteen attendants.

mula_pali: 329. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo khattaṃ āmantesi – ‘‘tena hi, bho khatte, yena khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkama. Upasaṅkamitvā khāṇumatake brāhmaṇagahapatike evaṃ vadehi – ‘kūṭadanto, bho, brāhmaṇo evamāha – ‘‘āgamentu kira bhavanto, kūṭadantopi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho so khattā kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena khāṇumatakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā tenupasaṅkami. Upasaṅkamitvā khāṇumatake brāhmaṇagahapatike etadavoca – ‘‘kūṭadanto, bho, brāhmaṇo evamāha – ‘āgamentu kira bhonto, kūṭadantopi brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’’ti.
mula_english:
Then, the Brahmin Kūṭadanta addressed his steward (khatta): "Then, good steward (khatte), go to the Brahmins and householders (brāhmaṇagahapatika) of Khāṇumata.

Having gone, say this to the Brahmins and householders (brāhmaṇagahapatika) of Khāṇumata: 'The Brahmin Kūṭadanta, sir (bho), says thus: "Please wait, gentlemen (bhavanto). Kūṭadanta, the Brahmin (brāhmaṇo), will also go to see the ascetic (samaṇa) Gotama for a viewing (dassanāya)."'"

"Yes, sir (bho)," the steward (khatta) replied to the Brahmin Kūṭadanta, and went to the Brahmins and householders (brāhmaṇagahapatika) of Khāṇumata.

Having gone, he said this to the Brahmins and householders (brāhmaṇagahapatika) of Khāṇumata: "The Brahmin Kūṭadanta, sir (bho), says thus: 'Please wait, gentlemen (bhonto). Kūṭadanta, the Brahmin (brāhmaṇo), will also go to see the ascetic (samaṇa) Gotama for a viewing (dassanāya)."'"

mula_pali: 330. Tena  kho pana samayena anekāni brāhmaṇasatāni khāṇumate paṭivasanti – ‘‘kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa mahāyaññaṃ anubhavissāmā’’ti. Assosuṃ kho te brāhmaṇā – ‘‘kūṭadanto kira brāhmaṇo samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’ti. Atha kho te brāhmaṇā yena kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
mula_english:
330. At that time, many hundreds of *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) were dwelling at Khāṇumata, thinking, "We will partake in the great sacrifice (*mahāyañña*) of the *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) Kūṭadanta."

The *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) heard, "It is said that the *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) Kūṭadanta will visit the *samaṇa* (ascetic) Gotama for an audience."

Then, those *brāhmaṇas* (Brahmins) went to where the *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin) Kūṭadanta was.
commentary_pali: 330-336.Paṭivasantīti yaññānubhavanatthāya paṭivasanti. Bhūtapubbanti idaṃ bhagavā pathavīgataṃ nidhiṃ uddharitvā purato rāsiṃ karonto viya bhavapaṭicchannaṃ pubbacaritaṃ dassento āha. Mahāvijitoti so kira sāgarapariyantaṃ mahantaṃ pathavīmaṇḍalaṃ  vijini, iti mahantaṃ vijitamassāti mahāvijito tveva saṅkhyaṃ agamāsi. Aḍḍhotiādīsu yo koci attano santakena vibhavena aḍḍho hoti, ayaṃ pana na kevalaṃ aḍḍhoyeva, mahaddhano mahatā aparimāṇasaṅkhyena dhanena samannāgato. Pañcakāmaguṇavasena mahantā uḷārā bhogā assāti mahābhogo. Piṇḍapiṇḍavasena ceva suvaṇṇamāsakarajatamāsakādivasena ca jātarūparajatassa pahūtatāya pahūtajātarūparajato, anekakoṭisaṅkhyena jātarūparajatena samannāgatoti attho. Vittīti tuṭṭhi, vittiyā upakaraṇaṃ vittūpakaraṇaṃ tuṭṭhikāraṇanti attho. Pahūtaṃ nānāvidhālaṅkārasuvaṇṇarajatabhājanādibhedaṃ vittūpakaraṇamassāti pahūtavittūpakaraṇo. Sattaratanasaṅkhātassa  nidahitvā ṭhapitadhanassa sabbapubbaṇṇāparaṇṇasaṅgahitassa dhaññassa ca pahūtatāya pahūtadhanadhañño. Athavā idamassa devasikaṃ paribbayadānaggahaṇādivasena parivattanadhanadhaññavasena vuttaṃ. Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāroti koso vuccati bhaṇḍāgāraṃ, nidahitvā ṭhapitena dhanena paripuṇṇakoso, dhaññena paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāro cāti attho. Athavā catubbidho koso – hatthī, assā, rathā, pattīti. Koṭṭhāgāraṃ tividhaṃ – dhanakoṭṭhāgāraṃ, vatthakoṭṭhāgāraṃ, dhaññakoṭṭhāgāranti, taṃ sabbampi paripuṇṇamassāti paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro. Udapādīti uppajji. Ayaṃ kira rājā ekadivasaṃ ratanāvalokanacārikaṃ nāma nikkhanto. So bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ pucchi – ‘‘tāta, idaṃ evaṃ bahudhanaṃ kena saṅgharita’’nti? Tumhākaṃ pitupitāmahādīhi yāva sattamā kulaparivaṭṭāti. Idaṃ pana dhanaṃ saṅgharitvā te kuhiṃ gatāti? Sabbeva te, deva, maraṇavasaṃ pattāti. Attano dhanaṃ agahetvāva gatā, tātāti? Deva, kiṃ vadetha, dhanaṃ nāmetaṃ pahāya gamanīyameva, no ādāya gamanīyanti. Atha rājā nivattitvā sirīgabbhe nisinno – ‘adhigatā kho me’tiādīni cintesi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādī’’ti.
commentary_english:
330-336.

"They dwell," means they dwell for the purpose of experiencing the fruits of sacrifice.

"Having formerly existed," this the Blessed One, having raised up a treasure buried in the earth, as if making a heap in front, displaying the former conduct concealed by existence, said.

"Mahāvijita" means that he, it is said, conquered the great earth circle as far as the sea; thus, "a great conqueror," this was the designation he attained.

"Being rich" and so on, whoever is rich with his own property, this one is not only rich, but is endowed with great wealth, with a great immeasurable amount of wealth.

"Mahābhoga" means that he has great and abundant enjoyments because of the power of the five sense-objects.

"Pahūtajātarūparajata" means that because of the abundance of gold and silver by means of lumps and by means of gold *māsaka* coins, silver *māsaka* coins, and so on, he has abundant gold and silver, [and] is endowed with gold and silver of many *koṭi*s in number, this is the meaning.

"*Vitti*" means satisfaction, *vittiyā upakaraṇaṃ* means means of satisfaction, *vittūpakaraṇaṃ* means cause of satisfaction, this is the meaning.

"Pahūtavittūpakaraṇa" means that he has abundant means of satisfaction consisting of various kinds of ornaments, gold, silver, vessels, and so on.

"Pahūtadhanadhañña" means that because of the abundance of grain that is collected from all the former and latter crops, of wealth that has been deposited and stored, reckoned as the seven treasures.

Or, this was said in terms of wealth and grain that is daily, by means of expenditure, giving, receiving, and so on, transforming.

"Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra" means that *kosa* is said to be the storehouse, *paripuṇṇakoso* is full of wealth that has been deposited and stored, and *paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāro* is full of grain, this is the meaning.

Or, the *kosa* is of four kinds: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry.

*Koṭṭhāgāra* is of three kinds: wealth storehouse, cloth storehouse, grain storehouse; all of that is full, therefore *paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra*.

"*Udapādī*" means *uppajji* (arose).

This king, it is said, one day went out for the pleasure of viewing the jewels, by name *ratanāvalokanacārikaṃ*.

He asked the treasurer: "Sir, by whom was this so much wealth accumulated?" "By your fathers, grandfathers, and so on, up to the seventh generation of family lineage."

"Having accumulated this wealth, where have they gone?" "All of them, O King, have attained to the power of death."

"Without taking their wealth, have they gone, sir?" "O King, what do you say? Wealth, by name, is only to be left behind, it is only possible to go by leaving it, it is not possible to go by taking it."

Then the king, having returned, sitting in the *sirīgabbha* (auspicious chamber), thought: "'I have attained,' and so on."

By him it was said: "Thus, a reflection of the mind arose."

mula_pali: 331. Upasaṅkamitvā kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘saccaṃ kira bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissatī’’ti? ‘‘Evaṃ kho me, bho, hoti – ‘ahampi samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya  upasaṅkamissāmī’’’ti. ‘‘Mā bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkami. Na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Sace bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissati, bhoto kūṭadantassa yaso hāyissati, samaṇassa gotamassa yaso abhivaḍḍhissati. Yampi bhoto kūṭadantassa yaso hāyissati, samaṇassa gotamassa yaso abhivaḍḍhissati, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Samaṇo tveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ kūṭadantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ . ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Yampi bhavaṃ kūṭadanto ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Samaṇo tveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ kūṭadantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtajātarūparajato…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi  kūṭadanto abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso  dassanāya…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo tīṇi māṇavakasatāni mante vāceti, bahū kho pana nānādisā nānājanapadā māṇavakā āgacchanti bhoto kūṭadantassa santike mantatthikā mante adhiyitukāmā…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto. Samaṇo gotamo taruṇo ceva taruṇapabbajito ca…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi kūṭadanto brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Bhavañhi  kūṭadanto khāṇumataṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ. Yampi bhavaṃ kūṭadanto khāṇumataṃ ajjhāvasati sattussadaṃ satiṇakaṭṭhodakaṃ sadhaññaṃ rājabhoggaṃ, raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena dinnaṃ rājadāyaṃ brahmadeyyaṃ, imināpaṅgena na arahati bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Samaṇotveva gotamo arahati bhavantaṃ kūṭadantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitu’’nti.
mula_english:
Having approached the Brahmin Kūṭadanta, they said this: "Is it true, sir, that you, Kūṭadanta, will visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him?"

"Yes, friends, it occurs to me, 'I too will visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him.'"

"Sir, do not visit the *śramaṇa* Kūṭadanta to see him.

It is not fitting that you, Kūṭadanta, should visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him.

If you, Kūṭadanta, visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him, the fame of you, Kūṭadanta, will decrease, and the fame of the *śramaṇa* Gautama will increase.

And since the fame of you, Kūṭadanta, will decrease, and the fame of the *śramaṇa* Gautama will increase, for this reason it is not fitting that you, Kūṭadanta, should visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him.

But rather the *śramaṇa* Gautama should visit you, Kūṭadanta, to see you.

"For you, Kūṭadanta, are well-born on both sides, from your mother and from your father, of pure descent up to the seventh generation of ancestors, irreproachable and without criticism in regard to birth.

And since you, Kūṭadanta, are well-born on both sides, from your mother and from your father, of pure descent up to the seventh generation of ancestors, irreproachable and without criticism in regard to birth, for this reason it is not fitting that you, Kūṭadanta, should visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him.

But rather the *śramaṇa* Gautama should visit you, Kūṭadanta, to see you.

"For you, Kūṭadanta, are rich, with great wealth, with great possessions, with abundant resources and equipment, abundant gold and silver…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are a reciter, a holder of *mantras*, one who has gone to the other shore of the three *vedas* with their *nighaṇḍu* (glossary), *keṭubha* (commentary), *sākkharappabheda* (phonology), and as the fifth, the *itihāsa* (tradition), skilled in *pada* (grammar) and *veyyākaraṇa* (etymology), and unerring in *lokāyata* (cosmology) and the characteristics of a great man…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are handsome, attractive, pleasing, endowed with the utmost beauty of complexion, with a brahmin-like skin, a brahmin-like lustre, affording no opportunity for disparagement…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are virtuous, of advanced virtue, endowed with advanced virtue…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, have good speech, are skilled in good speech, endowed with polished speech, clear, unhesitating, capable of making known the meaning…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are the teacher of many teachers, you cause three hundred students to recite the *mantras*, and many students from various regions and various districts come to you, Kūṭadanta, seeking the meaning of the *mantras*, desiring to learn the *mantras*…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are old, aged, advanced in years, far gone in age, having reached old age.

The *śramaṇa* Gautama is young, and recently gone forth…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are honored, respected, esteemed, venerated, and revered by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, are honored, respected, esteemed, venerated, and revered by the Brahmin Pokkharasāti…pe… "For you, Kūṭadanta, dwell at Khāṇumata, a populous place, full of grass, timber, water, and grain, a royal domain given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, a royal gift, a brahminical grant.

And since you, Kūṭadanta, dwell at Khāṇumata, a populous place, full of grass, timber, water, and grain, a royal domain given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, a royal gift, a brahminical grant, for this reason it is not fitting that you, Kūṭadanta, should visit the *śramaṇa* Gautama to see him.

But rather the *śramaṇa* Gautama should visit you, Kūṭadanta, to see you."

Bhūtapubbanti idaṃ bhagavā pathavīgataṃ nidhiṃ uddharitvā purato rāsiṃ karonto viya bhavapaṭicchannaṃ pubbacaritaṃ dassento āha. Mahāvijitoti so kira sāgarapariyantaṃ mahantaṃ pathavīmaṇḍalaṃ  vijini, iti mahantaṃ vijitamassāti mahāvijito tveva saṅkhyaṃ agamāsi. Aḍḍhotiādīsu yo koci attano santakena vibhavena aḍḍho hoti, ayaṃ pana na kevalaṃ aḍḍhoyeva, mahaddhano mahatā aparimāṇasaṅkhyena dhanena samannāgato. Pañcakāmaguṇavasena mahantā uḷārā bhogā assāti mahābhogo. Piṇḍapiṇḍavasena ceva suvaṇṇamāsakarajatamāsakādivasena ca jātarūparajatassa pahūtatāya pahūtajātarūparajato, anekakoṭisaṅkhyena jātarūparajatena samannāgatoti attho. Vittīti tuṭṭhi, vittiyā upakaraṇaṃ vittūpakaraṇaṃ tuṭṭhikāraṇanti attho. Pahūtaṃ nānāvidhālaṅkārasuvaṇṇarajatabhājanādibhedaṃ vittūpakaraṇamassāti pahūtavittūpakaraṇo. Sattaratanasaṅkhātassa  nidahitvā ṭhapitadhanassa sabbapubbaṇṇāparaṇṇasaṅgahitassa dhaññassa ca pahūtatāya pahūtadhanadhañño. Athavā idamassa devasikaṃ paribbayadānaggahaṇādivasena parivattanadhanadhaññavasena vuttaṃ. Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāroti koso vuccati bhaṇḍāgāraṃ, nidahitvā ṭhapitena dhanena paripuṇṇakoso, dhaññena paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāro cāti attho. Athavā catubbidho koso – hatthī, assā, rathā, pattīti. Koṭṭhāgāraṃ tividhaṃ – dhanakoṭṭhāgāraṃ, vatthakoṭṭhāgāraṃ, dhaññakoṭṭhāgāranti, taṃ sabbampi paripuṇṇamassāti paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro. Udapādīti uppajji. Ayaṃ kira rājā ekadivasaṃ ratanāvalokanacārikaṃ nāma nikkhanto. So bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ pucchi – ‘‘tāta, idaṃ evaṃ bahudhanaṃ kena saṅgharita’’nti? Tumhākaṃ pitupitāmahādīhi yāva sattamā kulaparivaṭṭāti. Idaṃ pana dhanaṃ saṅgharitvā te kuhiṃ gatāti? Sabbeva te, deva, maraṇavasaṃ pattāti. Attano dhanaṃ agahetvāva gatā, tātāti? Deva, kiṃ vadetha, dhanaṃ nāmetaṃ pahāya gamanīyameva, no ādāya gamanīyanti. Atha rājā nivattitvā sirīgabbhe nisinno – ‘adhigatā kho me’tiādīni cintesi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādī’’ti.
commentary_english:
330-336.
"They reside" means they reside for the purpose of experiencing the sacrifice (*yajña*).

"Formerly existed" means that the Blessed One, having raised up a buried treasure, which had been hidden by existence (*bhava*), from the earth and piling it up in front, spoke, revealing his former conduct.

"Mahāvijita" [Great Conqueror]: It is said that he conquered a great earth-circle (*pathavī-maṇḍala*) extending to the sea. Thus, because he had a great victory, he went to the designation "Mahāvijita."

Among the "rich, etc.," whoever is rich with his own possessions is merely rich; but this one is not only rich, he is possessed of great wealth, with immense and incalculable riches (*dhana*).

Because he has great and abundant enjoyments (*bhoga*) through the power of the five strands of sense desire (*pañcakāmaguṇa*), he is a "Mahābhoga" [Great Enjoyer].

Moreover, because of the abundance of gold and silver (*jātarūparajata*) due to lumps and also due to gold coins, silver coins, etc., he is one with abundant gold and silver; meaning, he is endowed with gold and silver worth many *koṭis*.

" *Vitti*" means satisfaction (*tuṭṭhi*). *Vitti's upakaraṇa* [equipment] means *vittūpakaraṇa*, meaning the cause of satisfaction.

Because he has an abundance of equipment (*vittūpakaraṇa*) consisting of various kinds of ornaments, gold, silver vessels, and so on, he is *pahūtavittūpakaraṇa* [one with abundant equipment].

Because of the abundance of grain (*dhañña*) that is reckoned as the seven jewels, that has been stored and set aside, and that is gathered from all the earlier and later crops, he is *pahūtadhanadhañño* [one with abundant wealth and grain].

Or, this is said in terms of daily expenditure, in terms of wealth and grain that are exchanged (*parivattana*), through the means of offerings, gifts, acceptance, etc.

"*Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra* [one with full treasury and storehouse]" means *kosa* [treasury] is said to be *bhaṇḍāgāra* [storehouse]. *Paripuṇṇakosa* [one with a full treasury] means with wealth (*dhana*) that has been stored and set aside, the treasury is full. *Paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāra* [one with a full storehouse] means with grain (*dhañña*) the storehouse is full.

Or, there are four kinds of treasury (*kosa*): elephants (*hatthin*), horses (*assa*), chariots (*ratha*), and infantry (*patti*).

There are three kinds of storehouse (*koṭṭhāgāra*): a wealth storehouse (*dhana-koṭṭhāgāra*), a cloth storehouse (*vattha-koṭṭhāgāra*), and a grain storehouse (*dhañña-koṭṭhāgāra*). Because all of that is full, he is *paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra*.

"*Udapādi* [arose]" means *uppajji* [arose].

It is said that this king, one day, went out for what was called "a walk to view treasures (*ratanāvalokanacārika*)."

He asked the treasurer (*bhaṇḍāgārika*): "Dear one (*tāta*), by whom was this great wealth (*dhana*) accumulated?" [The treasurer replied:] "By your fathers, grandfathers, etc., up to the seventh generation of family succession."

"Having accumulated this wealth (*dhana*), where have they gone?" "All of them, your majesty (*deva*), have attained the sway of death (*maraṇa*)."

"Having gone without taking their wealth (*dhana*), dear one (*tāta*)?" "Your majesty (*deva*), what are you saying? Wealth (*dhana*) is such that it must be left behind; it cannot be taken along."

Then the king, having returned and sat in the *sirīgabbha* [auspicious chamber], thought, "I have attained," etc.

Therefore it was said: "Thus, a thought (*parivitakka*) of this sort arose in his mind (*cetas*)."

mula_pali: 332. Evaṃ  vutte kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo te brāhmaṇe etadavoca – ‘‘Tena  hi, bho, mamapi suṇātha, yathā mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ  gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ, na tveva arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, imināpaṅgena na arahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Atha kho mayameva arahāma taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo mahantaṃ ñātisaṅghaṃ ohāya pabbajito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ ohāya pabbajito bhūmigatañca vehāsaṭṭhaṃ ca…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo daharova samāno yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ assumukhānaṃ rudantānaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya  …pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sīlavā ariyasīlī kusalasīlī kusalasīlena samannāgato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo  khalu, bho, gotamo kalyāṇavāco kalyāṇavākkaraṇo poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya  anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo  khalu, bho, gotamo bahūnaṃ ācariyapācariyo…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khīṇakāmarāgo vigatacāpallo…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo kammavādī kiriyavādī apāpapurekkhāro brahmaññāya pajāya…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo uccā kulā pabbajito asambhinnakhattiyakulā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo aḍḍhā kulā pabbajito mahaddhanā mahābhogā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ tiroraṭṭhā tirojanapadā pañhaṃ pucchituṃ āgacchanti…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ anekāni devatāsahassāni pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gatāni…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato – ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ ti…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo ehisvāgatavādī sakhilo sammodako abbhākuṭiko uttānamukho pubbabhāsī…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo catunnaṃ parisānaṃ sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇe  khalu, bho, gotame bahū devā ca manussā ca abhippasannā…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo yasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā paṭivasati na tasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā amanussā manusse viheṭhenti…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo saṅghī gaṇī gaṇācariyo puthutitthakarānaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yathā kho pana, bho, etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ yathā  vā tathā vā yaso samudāgacchati, na  hevaṃ samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato. Atha kho anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saputto sabhariyo sapariso  sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇaṃ khalu, bho, gotamaṃ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṃ gato…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito…pe… ‘‘Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khāṇumataṃ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ. Ye kho pana, bho, keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amhākaṃ gāmakhettaṃ āgacchanti, atithī no  te honti. Atithī kho panamhehi sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā apacetabbā. Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo khāṇumataṃ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ, atithimhākaṃ samaṇo gotamo. Atithi kho panamhehi sakkātabbo garukātabbo mānetabbo pūjetabbo apacetabbo. Imināpaṅgena nārahati so bhavaṃ gotamo amhākaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Atha kho mayameva arahāma  taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ. Ettake kho ahaṃ, bho, tassa bhoto gotamassa vaṇṇe pariyāpuṇāmi, no ca kho so bhavaṃ gotamo ettakavaṇṇo. Aparimāṇavaṇṇo hi so bhavaṃ gotamo’’ti.
mula_english:
332.

When this was said, the Brahmin Kūṭadanta told those Brahmins: "Now listen, gentlemen, as to why it is fitting for us to visit the esteemed Gotama, and why it is not fitting for the esteemed Gotama to visit us.

"The *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is well-born on both sides, from the mother's and father's side, of pure descent up to the seventh generation of ancestors, unassailable and irreproachable in regard to his caste.

"Since the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is well-born on both sides, from the mother's and father's side, of pure descent up to the seventh generation of ancestors, unassailable and irreproachable in regard to his caste, for this reason, it is not fitting for the esteemed Gotama to come to visit us.

"But rather, it is fitting for us to go to visit the esteemed Gotama.

"The *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has gone forth, abandoning a large assembly of relatives... Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has gone forth, abandoning much gold and silver, both buried in the ground and stored in vaults... Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, though still young, a youth with black hair, endowed with the blessing of youth, in the prime of life, has gone forth from the householder's life into homelessness... Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, against the wishes of his weeping parents with tearful faces, shaving off his hair and beard, putting on the saffron robes, has gone forth from the householder's life into homelessness… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is handsome, pleasing to the eye, of impressive appearance, endowed with the highest beauty of complexion, of brahmin-like color, with a brahmin-like radiance, of a faultless build… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is virtuous, with noble virtue, skilled in virtue, endowed with skillful virtue… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is of auspicious speech, with auspicious articulation, endowed with refined speech, clear, without stammering, making the meaning intelligible… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is the teacher of many teachers… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has extinguished sensual desire and has overcome restlessness… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is a proponent of action (*karma*), a proponent of effort, with pure intentions for the brahminical people… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has gone forth from a high-ranking family, from an unmixed warrior family… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has gone forth from a wealthy family, very rich and affluent… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, ascetics from foreign lands and foreign territories come to ask questions… Furthermore, thousands of deities have gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, for refuge with their lives… Furthermore, the fair fame of the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has risen thus: ‘Indeed, the esteemed one is an *arhat*, a perfectly awakened one (*sammāsambuddha*), endowed with knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇa*), a well-gone one (*sugata*), a knower of the world (*lokavidū*), unsurpassed, a charioteer for taming men (*purisadammasārathi*), a teacher of gods and humans, a Buddha, an esteemed one.’… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is endowed with the thirty-two marks of a great man (*dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇa*)… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is friendly in welcoming, amiable, courteous, without frowns, with an open face, and speaks first… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is honored, respected, esteemed, worshiped, and venerated by the four assemblies… Furthermore, many gods and humans are very devoted to the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs… Furthermore, in whatever village or town the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, resides, non-human beings do not harm the humans in that village or town… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is the leader of an order, the head of a group, a teacher of a group, and is considered the foremost among the founders of various schools; but unlike the fame that may come to those *śramaṇas* and Brahmins, in one way or another, the fame of the *śramaṇa* Gotama has not arisen in that way.

"Rather, the fame of the *śramaṇa* Gotama has arisen through unsurpassed accomplishment in knowledge and conduct (*vijjācaraṇasampadā*)… Furthermore, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, together with his sons, wives, retinue, and ministers, has gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, for refuge with their lives… Furthermore, King Pasenadi Kosala, together with his sons, wives, retinue, and ministers, has gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, for refuge with their lives… Furthermore, the Brahmin Pokkharasāti, together with his sons, wives, retinue, and ministers, has gone to the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, for refuge with their lives… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is honored, respected, esteemed, worshiped, and venerated by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is honored, respected, esteemed, worshiped, and venerated by King Pasenadi Kosala… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, is honored, respected, esteemed, worshiped, and venerated by the Brahmin Pokkharasāti… Furthermore, the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying in Ambalaṭṭhikā.

"And whatever *śramaṇas* or Brahmins, sirs, come to our village territory, they are our guests.

"And we should revere, honor, esteem and worship guests.

"Since the *śramaṇa* Gotama, sirs, has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying in Ambalaṭṭhikā, the *śramaṇa* Gotama is our guest.

"And guests should be honored, respected, revered, and venerated by us.

"For this reason, it is not proper that the esteemed Gotama should come to us for a visit.

"But rather, it is we who should go to the esteemed Gotama for a visit.

"However much I might praise the esteemed Gotama, sirs, that praise is insufficient, for the esteemed Gotama is not limited to that praise.

"Indeed, the esteemed Gotama is of immeasurable glory."

commentary_english:
330-336.
"They dwell," means they dwell for the purpose of experiencing the fruits of sacrifice ( *yañña*).

"Formerly," the Blessed One, having lifted up a treasure buried in the earth and showing a heap in front as if revealing a previous life covered by existence, spoke this.

"Mahāvijita," it is said that he conquered a large territory extending to the ocean, thus, because he had conquered a great area, he came to be known as Mahāvijita.

Being wealthy and so on, whoever is wealthy with his own possessions, this one is not only wealthy, but is endowed with great wealth, with an immeasurable amount of riches.

Because he has great and abundant enjoyments due to the power of the five objects of desire, he is "Mahābhoga."

Because of the abundance of gold and silver due to lumps and gold coins, silver coins, and so on, he has abundant gold and silver, he is endowed with many hundreds of thousands of *koṭis* of gold and silver, this is the meaning.

"Vittī" means satisfaction, the means to satisfaction is *vittūpakaraṇa*, meaning the cause of satisfaction.

Because he has abundant means of satisfaction, various kinds of ornaments, gold, silver vessels, and so on, he is *pahūtavittūpakaraṇo*.

Because of the abundance of grain that is counted as the seven precious jewels, with wealth stored away and kept, and all the first and last grains gathered, he is *pahūtadhanadhañño*.

Or, this is said in terms of daily expenses, giving, receiving, and so on, in terms of changing wealth and grain.

"Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāroti," *kosa* is said to be the treasury, full of wealth stored away, and *koṭṭhāgāra* is full of grain, this is the meaning.

Or, there are four kinds of *kosa*: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry.

*Koṭṭhāgāra* is of three kinds: a wealth store, a cloth store, and a grain store, all of which are full, therefore he is *paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro*.

"Udapādīti," means *uppajji*.

It is said that this king went out one day for a pleasure trip to see the jewels, called *ratanāvalokanacārika*.

He asked the treasurer: "Sir, by whom was this great wealth accumulated?" "By your fathers, grandfathers, and so on, up to the seventh generation of family succession."

"But having accumulated this wealth, where have they gone?" "All of them, your majesty, have attained the state of death."

"Have they gone without taking their wealth, sir?" "Your majesty, what are you saying? This wealth is meant to be left behind, not to be taken along."

Then the king, having returned, sat in his chamber and thought: "I have understood," and so on.

Therefore it was said: "Thus, this thought arose in his mind."

mula_pali: 333. Evaṃ  vutte, te brāhmaṇā kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘yathā kho bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇe bhāsati, ito cepi so bhavaṃ gotamo yojanasate viharati, alameva saddhena kulaputtena dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ api puṭosenā’’ti. ‘‘Tena hi, bho, sabbeva mayaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā’’ti.
mula_english:
On hearing this, the Brahmins said to the Brahmin Kūṭadanta: “Sir, since the esteemed Kūṭadanta speaks so highly of the ascetic Gotama, even if that esteemed Gotama were dwelling a hundred *yojanas* from here, it would be quite fitting for a believing clansman to approach him for a visit, even with a shoulder bag."

"Then, sir, let us all go to see the ascetic Gotama."

Mahāvijitoti so kira sāgarapariyantaṃ mahantaṃ pathavīmaṇḍalaṃ  vijini, iti mahantaṃ vijitamassāti mahāvijito tveva saṅkhyaṃ agamāsi. Aḍḍhotiādīsu yo koci attano santakena vibhavena aḍḍho hoti, ayaṃ pana na kevalaṃ aḍḍhoyeva, mahaddhano mahatā aparimāṇasaṅkhyena dhanena samannāgato. Pañcakāmaguṇavasena mahantā uḷārā bhogā assāti mahābhogo. Piṇḍapiṇḍavasena ceva suvaṇṇamāsakarajatamāsakādivasena ca jātarūparajatassa pahūtatāya pahūtajātarūparajato, anekakoṭisaṅkhyena jātarūparajatena samannāgatoti attho. Idaṃ pana dhanaṃ saṅgharitvā te kuhiṃ gatāti? Sabbeva te, deva, maraṇavasaṃ pattāti. Attano dhanaṃ agahetvāva gatā, tātāti? Deva, kiṃ vadetha, dhanaṃ nāmetaṃ pahāya gamanīyameva, no ādāya gamanīyanti. Atha rājā nivattitvā sirīgabbhe nisinno – ‘adhigatā kho me’tiādīni cintesi. commentary_english:
330-336.

"They dwell," [means:] they dwell for the sake of experiencing the sacrifice.

"Formerly," this the Blessed One, having lifted up a treasure gone into the earth, and showing a former conduct concealed by becoming, as if making a heap in front, said.

"Mahāvijita," it is said that he conquered a great circle of the earth as far as the ocean; thus, "he conquered greatly," so he went to the designation "Mahāvijita."

Among the rich and so on, whoever is rich with his own property, this one is not only rich, but also endowed with much wealth, with a great, immeasurable amount of wealth.

Because of the power of the five sense qualities, he has great, abundant enjoyments, so he is a *mahābhoga* (one with great enjoyment).

Because of lumps and so on, and because of gold coins, silver coins and so on, and because of the abundance of gold and silver, he is one who possesses abundant gold and silver (*pahūtajātarūparajato*), [that is,] he is endowed with gold and silver in numbers of many *koṭis*, this is the meaning.

"Vittīti" is satisfaction; the equipment of *vitti* is *vittūpakaraṇa*, it is the cause of satisfaction, this is the meaning.

He has abundant equipment of satisfaction, which is abundant with various kinds of ornaments, gold, silver, vessels, etc., so he is one who possesses abundant equipment of satisfaction (*pahūtavittūpakaraṇo*).

Because of the abundance of grain that is collected from all the previous and subsequent harvests, of the treasure that has been deposited, consisting of the seven jewels (*sattaratanasaṅkhātassa*), he is one who possesses abundant wealth and grain (*pahūtadhanadhañño*).

Or, this was said as being daily, by way of expenditure, giving, receiving, etc., and by way of the changing wealth and grain.

"Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāroti": *kosa* is said to be a treasury (*bhaṇḍāgāraṃ*); he is *paripuṇṇakoso* (one with a full treasury) with the wealth that has been deposited, and he is *paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāro* (one with a full storehouse) with the grain, this is the meaning.

Or, there are four kinds of *kosa*: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry.

*Koṭṭhāgāraṃ* (the storehouse) is of three kinds: a storehouse of wealth (*dhana-koṭṭhāgāraṃ*), a storehouse of clothes (*vattha-koṭṭhāgāraṃ*), and a storehouse of grain (*dhañña-koṭṭhāgāraṃ*); all of that is full, so he is *paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro* (one with full treasuries and storehouses).

"Udapādīti" means it arose (*uppajji*).

It is said that this king went out one day for a pleasure excursion to see the jewels (*ratanāvalokanacārikaṃ nāma nikkhanto*).

He asked the treasurer (*bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ pucchi*): "Sir, by whom was this so much wealth collected?" "By your fathers, grandfathers, and so on, up to the seventh generation of family lineage."

"Having collected this wealth, where have they gone?" "All of them, O king, have attained the sway of death (*maraṇavasaṃ pattāti*)."

"Have they gone without taking their wealth?" "O king, what do you say? Wealth is such that it must be left behind; it cannot be taken along."

Then the king, having returned and sitting in the chamber of glory (*sirīgabbhe nisinno*), thought, "I have attained," etc.

Therefore, it was said: "Thus, a reflection of the mind arose."

mula_pali: 334. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṃ yena ambalaṭṭhikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi . Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Khāṇumatakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mula_english:
Then, the brahmin Kūṭadanta, together with a large company of brahmins, approached the Blessed One at Ambalaṭṭhikā; having approached, he exchanged greetings with the Blessed One.
When this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down at one side.
Some of the Brahmins and householders of Khāṇumata, having greeted the Blessed One, sat down on one side; some exchanged greetings with the Blessed One, and after exchanging polite and courteous greetings, sat down on one side; some saluted him with joined palms and sat down on one side; some announced their name and clan and sat down on one side; some sat down to one side in silence.

commentary_english:
330-336.

"They reside," means they reside for the purpose of experiencing the sacrifice.

"Having existed formerly," the Blessed One, having drawn up a treasure buried in the earth and making a heap in front, as if showing a former life covered by becoming, spoke this.

"Mahāvijita," it seems that he conquered a great terrestrial sphere as far as the ocean; thus, because a great victory was his, he went to the designation "Mahāvijita."

Someone is wealthy with his own property in *aḍḍhotiādi*, but this one is not only wealthy, he is endowed with much wealth, with a great immeasurable amount of riches.

Because great, excellent enjoyments are his through the power of the five strands of sense desire, [he is called] *mahābhogo* (possessing great enjoyment).

Because of abundance of gold and silver by way of lumps and by way of gold *māsaka* coins, silver *māsaka* coins, and so on, [he is called] possessing abundant gold and silver. Meaning, endowed with gold and silver to the extent of many *koṭi*s.

*Vitti* means satisfaction; that which is instrumental to satisfaction is *vittūpakaraṇa*, meaning the cause of satisfaction.

Because abundant wealth and implements consisting of various kinds of ornaments, gold vessels, silver vessels, and so on, are his, [he is called] possessing abundant wealth and implements.

Because of abundance of grain that consists of the seven jewels and is collected from all previous and subsequent harvests, [he is called] possessing abundant wealth and grain.

Or, this is said with reference to wealth and grain that is daily, by way of spending, giving alms, accepting, and so on, by way of changing.

"Possessing full storehouses and granaries," *kosa* means treasury, storehouse. Because his *kosa* is full with wealth that has been stored away, and his *koṭṭhāgāra* is full with grain, [the compound means that].

Or, the *kosa* is of four kinds: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry.

The *koṭṭhāgāra* is of three kinds: a wealth storehouse (*dhana-koṭṭhāgāra*), a cloth storehouse (*vattha-koṭṭhāgāra*), and a grain storehouse (*dhañña-koṭṭhāgāra*); since all of that is full for him, [he is called] *paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro*.

"It arose," means it came into being.

It seems that this king, one day, went out for a pleasure trip to see jewels, by the name of *ratanāvalokanacārika*.

He asked the treasurer: "Sir, by whom was this so much wealth collected?" "By your fathers, grandfathers, and so on, up to seven generations."

"But where have they gone, having collected this wealth?" "All of them, your majesty, have attained the sway of death."

"Did they go without taking their wealth?" "Your majesty, what are you saying? Wealth is something that one must leave behind; it is not something that one can take along."

Then the king, having returned, sat down in the *sirīgabbha* and thought, "I have attained [understanding]," and so on.

Therefore, it was said: "Thus, a consideration of the mind arose."

mula_pali: 335. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama – ‘samaṇo gotamo tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ jānātī’ti. Na kho panāhaṃ jānāmi tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ. Icchāmi cāhaṃ mahāyaññaṃ  yajituṃ. Sādhu me bhavaṃ gotamo tividhaṃ yaññasampadaṃ soḷasaparikkhāraṃ desetū’’ti.
mula_english:
335.
Having sat down to one side, the Brahmin Kuṭadanta said this to the Blessed One: “I have heard this, venerable Gotama: ‘The ascetic Gotama understands the threefold accomplishment of sacrifice with its sixteen requisites.’”

“But I do not know the threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (tividhaṃ *yajñasampadaṃ*) with its sixteen requisites (soḷasaparikkhāraṃ).

And I wish to perform a great sacrifice (mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ).

It would be good if the venerable Gotama would explain to me the threefold accomplishment of sacrifice with its sixteen requisites."

commentary_english:
330-336.
"They reside" means they reside for the sake of experiencing the fruit of sacrifice.

"Formerly" means the Blessed One, after unearthing a treasure buried in the earth and heaping it up in front, reveals a former life concealed by existence, and speaks.

"Mahāvijita" means that he, it is said, conquered a great territory of the earth as far as the ocean; thus, because he had conquered greatly, he went to the designation "Mahāvijita."

Among those who are rich, whoever is rich with his own property, this one is not merely rich, but is endowed with great wealth, with a great immeasurable amount of wealth.

Because of the power of the five sense pleasures, he has great and magnificent enjoyments; therefore, he is a *mahābhoga* (one with great enjoyment).

Because of the heaps and heaps of gold coins, silver coins and so on, there was an abundance of gold and silver; therefore, he had abundant gold and silver, [and] was endowed with gold and silver worth many *koṭis*; this is the meaning.

*Vitti* means satisfaction; the instrument of *vitti* is the equipment for satisfaction; *vittūpakaraṇa* is the cause of satisfaction; this is the meaning.

He has abundant equipment for satisfaction consisting of various kinds of ornaments, gold, silver vessels, etc.; therefore, he is one with abundant equipment for satisfaction (*pahūtavittūpakaraṇo*).

Because of the abundance of grain that was stored away, namely the seven precious things counted, all kinds of early grain and late grain collected, therefore, he was rich in wealth and grain (*pahūtadhanadhañño*).

Alternatively, this is said in terms of daily expenditures, giving alms, receiving taxes, etc., resulting in the conversion of wealth and grain.

*Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra* means that *kosa* is called a storehouse; *paripuṇṇakosa* means full of stored wealth, and *paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāra* means full of grain; this is the meaning.

Alternatively, there are four kinds of *kosa*: elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry.

*Koṭṭhāgāra* is of three kinds: a storehouse of wealth (*dhanakoṭṭhāgāra*), a storehouse of clothes (*vatthakoṭṭhāgāra*), and a storehouse of grain (*dhaññakoṭṭhāgāra*); all of these were full; therefore, he was *paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra*.

"It arose" means it arose (*uppajji*).

This king, it is said, went out one day for the pleasure of viewing jewels, called *ratanāvalokanacārika*.

He asked the treasurer, "Good sir, by whom was this so much wealth accumulated?" "[It was accumulated] by your fathers, grandfathers, etc., up to the seventh generation in the family line."

"But where have those who accumulated this wealth gone?" "All of them, O god, have met with death."

"Did they go without taking their wealth, good sir?" "O god, what do you say? Wealth is such that it must be left behind; it cannot be taken along."

Then the king, having returned, sat down in his splendid chamber and thought, "I have attained," etc.

Therefore, it was said, "Thus, a reflection arose in his mind."

mula_pali: 336. ‘‘Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi sādhukaṃ manasikarohi, bhāsissāmī’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, bho’’ti kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi. Bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa , rājā mahāvijito nāma ahosi aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro. Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rañño mahāvijitassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi – ‘adhigatā kho me vipulā mānusakā bhogā, mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi , yaṃnūnāhaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajeyyaṃ, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
mula_english:
“Then listen, oh Brahmin, pay close attention and I will speak" (tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi sādhukaṃ manasikarohi, bhāsissāmīti).
"Yes, sir," (evaṃ, bho’’ti) replied the Brahmin Kūṭadanta to the Blessed One.

The Blessed One said this: "Once upon a time, oh Brahmin (brāhmaṇa), there was a king named Mahāvijita. He was rich, with great wealth, great resources, with abundant gold and silver (jātarūparajata), abundant possessions and equipment (vittūpakaraṇa), abundant wealth and grain (dhanadhañña), with fully stocked treasury and storehouses (paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra).

Then, oh Brahmin (brāhmaṇa), when King Mahāvijita was alone and secluded, this thought arose in his mind: 'I have acquired extensive human wealth (mānusakā bhogā). I dwell having conquered a great territory (pathavimaṇḍala). What if I were to perform a great sacrifice (mahāyañña), which would be for my long-term benefit and happiness (hitāya sukhāya)?'"
commentary_pali: 330-336.Paṭivasantīti yaññānubhavanatthāya paṭivasanti. Bhūtapubbanti idaṃ bhagavā pathavīgataṃ nidhiṃ uddharitvā purato rāsiṃ karonto viya bhavapaṭicchannaṃ pubbacaritaṃ dassento āha. Mahāvijitoti so kira sāgarapariyantaṃ mahantaṃ pathavīmaṇḍalaṃ  vijini, iti mahantaṃ vijitamassāti mahāvijito tveva saṅkhyaṃ agamāsi. Aḍḍhotiādīsu yo koci attano santakena vibhavena aḍḍho hoti, ayaṃ pana na kevalaṃ aḍḍhoyeva, mahaddhano mahatā aparimāṇasaṅkhyena dhanena samannāgato. Pañcakāmaguṇavasena mahantā uḷārā bhogā assāti mahābhogo. Piṇḍapiṇḍavasena ceva suvaṇṇamāsakarajatamāsakādivasena ca jātarūparajatassa pahūtatāya pahūtajātarūparajato, anekakoṭisaṅkhyena jātarūparajatena samannāgatoti attho. Vittīti tuṭṭhi, vittiyā upakaraṇaṃ vittūpakaraṇaṃ tuṭṭhikāraṇanti attho. Pahūtaṃ nānāvidhālaṅkārasuvaṇṇarajatabhājanādibhedaṃ vittūpakaraṇamassāti pahūtavittūpakaraṇo. Sattaratanasaṅkhātassa  nidahitvā ṭhapitadhanassa sabbapubbaṇṇāparaṇṇasaṅgahitassa dhaññassa ca pahūtatāya pahūtadhanadhañño. Athavā idamassa devasikaṃ paribbayadānaggahaṇādivasena parivattanadhanadhaññavasena vuttaṃ. Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāroti koso vuccati bhaṇḍāgāraṃ, nidahitvā ṭhapitena dhanena paripuṇṇakoso, dhaññena paripuṇṇakoṭṭhāgāro cāti attho. Athavā catubbidho koso – hatthī, assā, rathā, pattīti. Koṭṭhāgāraṃ tividhaṃ – dhanakoṭṭhāgāraṃ, vatthakoṭṭhāgāraṃ, dhaññakoṭṭhāgāranti, taṃ sabbampi paripuṇṇamassāti paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro. Udapādīti uppajji. Ayaṃ kira rājā ekadivasaṃ ratanāvalokanacārikaṃ nāma nikkhanto. So bhaṇḍāgārikaṃ pucchi – ‘‘tāta, idaṃ evaṃ bahudhanaṃ kena saṅgharita’’nti? Tumhākaṃ pitupitāmahādīhi yāva sattamā kulaparivaṭṭāti. Idaṃ pana dhanaṃ saṅgharitvā te kuhiṃ gatāti? Sabbeva te, deva, maraṇavasaṃ pattāti. Attano dhanaṃ agahetvāva gatā, tātāti? Deva, kiṃ vadetha, dhanaṃ nāmetaṃ pahāya gamanīyameva, no ādāya gamanīyanti. Atha rājā nivattitvā sirīgabbhe nisinno – ‘adhigatā kho me’tiādīni cintesi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādī’’ti.
commentary_english:
330-336.
"They reside," [means] they reside for the sake of experiencing the fruits of sacrifice.

"Having formerly existed," this the Blessed One, after having raised up a treasure lying in the earth, as if making a heap in front, showing the former conduct covered by becoming, spoke.

"Mahāvijita": It is said that he conquered a great earth-circle bounded by the ocean; thus, because he had a great victory, he attained the designation "Mahāvijita."

Among those who are rich etc., whoever is rich with his own property, this one is not only rich, but is endowed with much wealth, with a great immeasurable amount of riches.

Because of the power of the five sense pleasures, he has great, abundant enjoyments; therefore, he is "Mahābhoga."

Because of the method of lumps, and also because of the method of gold coins, silver coins, etc., and because of the abundance of gold and silver, he is one with abundant gold and silver; the meaning is that he is endowed with gold and silver of many koṭis.

"Vitti" means satisfaction; the instrument of vitti is vittūpakaraṇa, the cause of satisfaction; this is the meaning.

Because he has abundant vittūpakaraṇa, which is abundant with various kinds of ornaments, gold, silver, vessels, etc., he is "Pahūtavittūpakaraṇa."

Because of the abundance of grain that is collected from all the former and latter crops, with the seven jewels counted, and with the wealth deposited and stored, he is "Pahūtadhanadhañña."

Or, this is said in terms of daily expenses, in terms of circulating wealth and grain, due to giving gifts, accepting loans, etc.

"Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra": kosa is said to be bhaṇḍāgāra, a treasury; because the kosa is full with wealth that is deposited and stored, and the koṭṭhāgāra is full with grain, this is the meaning.

Or, the kosa is fourfold: elephants, horses, chariots, infantry.

The koṭṭhāgāra is threefold: a wealth-koṭṭhāgāra, a cloth-koṭṭhāgāra, a grain-koṭṭhāgāra; because all of that is full, he is "Paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāra."

"Udapādi" means uppajji, it arose.

It is said that this king went forth one day for a pleasure trip to see jewels, named Ratanāvalokanacārika.

He asked the treasurer: "Sir, by whom was this so much wealth accumulated?" "By your fathers, grandfathers, etc., up to the seventh generation of family lineage."

"But after accumulating this wealth, where have they gone?" "All of them, O king, have attained the state of being under the power of death."

"Did they go without taking their wealth with them, sir?" "O king, what do you say? Wealth, by name, is only to be left behind, it is not possible to go taking it along."
