Then the king, having returned, sat down in the sīrigabbha — "I have attained [wisdom]," he reflected on these and other things.

Therefore, it was said: "Thus, a parivitakka of the mind arose."

mula_pali: 337. ‘‘Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āmantetvā etadavoca – ‘idha mayhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi – adhigatā kho me vipulā mānusakā bhogā , mahantaṃ pathavimaṇḍalaṃ abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajeyyaṃ yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti. Icchāmahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ. Anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’’’ti.
mula_english:
Then, Brāhmaṇa, King Mahāvijita addressed his family priest, the Brāhmaṇa, saying: 'Here, Brāhmaṇa, when I was alone and withdrawn, a thought arose in my mind: "I have acquired abundant human wealth, and I dwell having conquered a great territory on earth."

"Suppose I were to perform a great sacrifice (mahāyañña) that would lead to my lasting benefit and happiness (hitāya sukhāyā)."

"I desire, Brāhmaṇa, to perform a great sacrifice (mahāyañña)."

"Let the Venerable One instruct me in how this may be to my lasting benefit and happiness (hitāya sukhāyā)."'"
commentary_pali: 337.Brāhmaṇaṃāmantetvāti kasmā āmantesi? Ayaṃ kirevaṃ cintesi – ‘‘dānaṃ dentena nāma ekena paṇḍitena saddhiṃ mantetvā dātuṃ vaṭṭati, anāmantetvā katakammañhi pacchānutāpaṃ karotī’’ti. Tasmā āmantesi. Atha brāhmaṇo cintesi – ‘‘ayaṃ rājā mahādānaṃ dātukāmo, janapade cassa bahū corā, te avūpasametvā dānaṃ dentassa khīradadhitaṇḍulādike dānasambhāre āharantānaṃ nippurisāni gehāni corā vilumpissanti janapado corabhayeneva kolāhalo bhavissati, tato rañño dānaṃ na ciraṃ pavattissati, cittampissa ekaggaṃ na bhavissati, handa, naṃ etamatthaṃ saññāpemī’’ti tato tamatthaṃ saññāpento ‘‘bhoto, kho rañño’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
337.
Why did he address the *brāhmaṇa*, having summoned him? This person thought thus: "It is fitting to consult with a wise scholar when giving a gift (*dāna*), for if one does not consult, one will later regret the deed."
Therefore, he addressed him.
Then the *brāhmaṇa* thought: "This king intends to give a great gift (*mahādāna*), and there are many thieves in his kingdom (*janapada*). If he does not subdue them, the thieves will plunder the homes left unguarded by those bringing milk, yogurt, rice and other gifts (*dānasambhāra*). The kingdom (*janapada*) will be in uproar due to the fear of thieves. Therefore, the king’s giving (*dāna*) will not last long, and his mind will not be focused. Come, I will inform him of this matter." Then, informing him of this matter, he began by saying, "Your majesty..."

mula_pali: 338. ‘‘Evaṃ vutte, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rājānaṃ mahāvijitaṃ etadavoca – ‘bhoto kho rañño janapado sakaṇṭako sauppīḷo, gāmaghātāpi dissanti, nigamaghātāpi dissanti, nagaraghātāpi dissanti , panthaduhanāpi dissanti. Bhavaṃ kho pana rājā evaṃ sakaṇṭake janapade sauppīḷe balimuddhareyya, akiccakārī assa tena bhavaṃ rājā. Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño evamassa – ‘‘ahametaṃ dassukhīlaṃ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā samūhanissāmī’’ti, na kho panetassa dassukhīlassa evaṃ sammā samugghāto hoti. Ye te hatāvasesakā bhavissanti, te pacchā rañño janapadaṃ viheṭhessanti. Api ca kho idaṃ saṃvidhānaṃ āgamma evametassa dassukhīlassa sammā samugghāto hoti. Tena hi bhavaṃ rājā ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti kasigorakkhe, tesaṃ bhavaṃ rājā bījabhattaṃ anuppadetu. Ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti vāṇijjāya, tesaṃ bhavaṃ rājā pābhataṃ anuppadetu. Ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti rājaporise, tesaṃ bhavaṃ rājā bhattavetanaṃ pakappetu. Te ca manussā sakammapasutā rañño janapadaṃ na viheṭhessanti; mahā ca rañño rāsiko bhavissati. Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā. Manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe viharissantī’ti. ‘Evaṃ, bho’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā ye rañño janapade ussahiṃsu  kasigorakkhe, tesaṃ rājā mahāvijito bījabhattaṃ anuppadāsi. Ye  ca rañño janapade ussahiṃsu vāṇijjāya, tesaṃ rājā mahāvijito pābhataṃ anuppadāsi. Ye ca rañño janapade  ussahiṃsu  rājaporise, tesaṃ rājā mahāvijito bhattavetanaṃ pakappesi. Te ca manussā sakammapasutā rañño janapadaṃ na viheṭhiṃsu, mahā ca rañño rāsiko ahosi. Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe vihariṃsu. Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āmantetvā etadavoca – ‘samūhato kho me bhoto dassukhīlo, bhoto saṃvidhānaṃ āgamma mahā ca me rāsiko. Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe viharanti. Icchāmahaṃ brāhmaṇa mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ. Anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
mula_english:
338.

When this had been said, the chaplain ( *purohita*) said this to King Mahāvijita: ‘Your Majesty's country is beset by thieves ( *sakaṇṭako sauppīḷo*), villages are being destroyed, towns are being destroyed, cities are being destroyed, and there is robbery on the highways.

If Your Majesty were to levy taxes in such a troubled and lawless country, Your Majesty would be acting wrongly.

Suppose Your Majesty were to think: “I will eradicate this scourge of robbers (*dassukhīlaṃ*) by execution, imprisonment, confiscation, threats, or banishment,” the scourge of robbers (*dassukhīlassa*) would not be properly ended in that way.

Those who survive will later harm Your Majesty's realm (*janapadaṃ*).

However, this plan will completely eradicate this scourge of robbers (*dassukhīlassa*).

Therefore, let Your Majesty provide grain and fodder (*bījabhattaṃ*) to those in Your Majesty's realm (*janapada*) who are engaged in agriculture and cattle-rearing.

Let Your Majesty provide incentives (*pābhataṃ*) to those in Your Majesty's realm (*janapada*) who are engaged in trade.

Let Your Majesty fix proper wages and sustenance (*bhattavetanaṃ*) for those in Your Majesty's realm (*janapada*) who are in royal service.

Then those people, being occupied in their own work, will not harm Your Majesty's realm (*janapadaṃ*); and Your Majesty's revenue (*rāsiko*) will be great.

The realms (*janapadā*) will be secure, without thorns, and without oppression.

People will be joyful and happy, and I think they will live with open doors, dancing with their children on their laps.’

‘Yes, sir,’ said King Mahāvijita to the chaplain ( *brāhmaṇa*), and, promising to do so, King Mahāvijita provided grain and fodder (*bījabhattaṃ*) to those in his realm (*janapada*) who were engaged in agriculture and cattle-rearing.

And King Mahāvijita provided incentives (*pābhataṃ*) to those in his realm (*janapada*) who were engaged in trade.

And King Mahāvijita fixed proper wages and sustenance (*bhattavetanaṃ*) for those in his realm (*janapada*) who were in royal service.

Then those people, being occupied in their own work, did not harm Your Majesty's realm (*janapadaṃ*); and Your Majesty's revenue (*rāsiko*) was great.

The realms (*janapadā*) were secure, without thorns, and without oppression; and the people were joyful and happy, and I think they lived with open doors, dancing with their children on their laps.

Then King Mahāvijita, the *brāhmaṇa*, summoned the chaplain, the *brāhmaṇa*, and said this: ‘The scourge of robbers (*dassukhīlaḥ*) has been eradicated by you, and following your plan my revenue (*rāsiko*) has increased greatly.

The realms (*janapadā*) are secure, without thorns, and without oppression; and the people are joyful and happy, and I think they live with open doors, dancing with their children on their laps.

I wish to perform a great sacrifice (*mahāyaññaṃ*).

Instruct me, sir, how this may be to my lasting benefit and happiness.’
commentary_pali: 338. Tattha sakaṇṭakoti corakaṇṭakehi sakaṇṭako. Panthaduhanāti panthaduhā, panthaghātakāti attho. Akiccakārī assāti akattabbakārī  adhammakārī bhaveyya. Dassukhīlanti corakhīlaṃ. Vadhena vāti māraṇena vā koṭṭanena vā. Bandhanenāti addubandhanādinā. Jāniyāti hāniyā; ‘‘sataṃ gaṇhatha, sahassaṃ gaṇhathā’’ti evaṃ pavattitadaṇḍenāti attho. Garahāyāti pañcasikhamuṇḍakaraṇaṃ, gomayasiñcanaṃ, gīvāya kudaṇḍakabandhananti  evamādīni katvā garahapāpanena. Pabbājanāyāti raṭṭhato nīharaṇena. Samūhanissāmīti sammā hetunā nayena kāraṇena ūhanissāmi. Hatāvasesakāti matāvasesakā. Ussahantīti ussāhaṃ karonti. Anuppadetūti dinne appahonte puna aññampi bījañca bhattañca kasiupakaraṇabhaṇḍañca sabbaṃ detūti attho. Pābhataṃ anuppadetūti sakkhiṃ akatvā paṇṇe anāropetvā mūlacchejjavasena bhaṇḍamūlaṃ detūti attho. Bhaṇḍamūlassa hi pābhatanti nāmaṃ. Yathāha – Bhattavetananti devasikaṃ bhattañceva māsikādiparibbayañca  tassa tassa kusalakammasūrabhāvānurūpena ṭhānantaragāmanigamādidānena saddhiṃ detūti attho. Sakammapasutāti kasivāṇijjādīsu sakesu kammesu uyyuttā byāvaṭā. Rāsikoti dhanadhaññānaṃ rāsiko. Khemaṭṭhitāti khemena ṭhitā abhayā. Akaṇṭakāti corakaṇṭakarahitā. Mudā modamānāti modā modamānā. Ayameva vā pāṭho, aññamaññaṃ pamuditacittāti adhippāyo. Apārutagharāti corānaṃ abhāvena dvārāni asaṃvaritvā vivaṭadvārāti attho. Etadavocāti janapadassa sabbākārena iddhaphītabhāvaṃ ñatvā etaṃ avoca.
commentary_english:
338.

Herein, *sakaṇṭako* means *sakaṇṭako* [anything pointed] by means of *corakaṇṭakehi* [thorns].

*panthaduhanāti* means *panthaduhā* [waylayer], that is, *panthaghātaka* [waylayer].

*akiccakārī assāti* means one would be *akattabbakārī* [doing what should not be done], an *adhammakārī* [unrighteous doer].

*dassukhīlanti* means *corakhīlaṃ* [thief's post].

By means of *vadhena* [killing] or by means of *māraṇena* [death], or by means of *koṭṭanena* [pounding].

*bandhanenāti* means by means of *addubandhanādinā* [additional bonds] etc.

*jāniyāti hāniyā*; “Take a hundred, take a thousand,” thus, by means of a *pavattitadaṇḍenāti* [operative stick/punishment], is the meaning.

*garahāyāti* means by doing *pañcasikhamuṇḍakaraṇaṃ* [shaving the five tufts], *gomayasiñcanaṃ* [sprinkling with cow dung], *gīvāya kudaṇḍakabandhanaṃ* [binding the neck with a bad stick], doing *evamādīni katvā garahapāpanena* [such things] etc. to cause reproach.

*pabbājanāyāti* means by *raṭṭhato nīharaṇena* [removing from the kingdom].

*samūhanissāmīti* means *ūhanissāmi* [I will eliminate] by *sammā hetunā nayena kāraṇena* [right cause, method, and reason].

*hatāvasesakāti* means *matāvasesakā* [remaining of what is thought].

*ussahantīti* means *ussāhaṃ karonti* [they make effort].

*anuppadetūti* means if it is given but it is not enough, then *puna aññampi bījañca bhattañca kasiupakaraṇabhaṇḍañca sabbaṃ detūti* [again another seed, food, farming equipment, goods, everything should be given], is the meaning.

*pābhataṃ anuppadetūti* means without making a witness, without placing it on a leaf, *mūlacchejjavasena bhaṇḍamūlaṃ detūti* [the price of the goods should be given according to the cutting of the root], is the meaning.

*bhaṇḍamūlassa hi pābhatanti nāmaṃ* [indeed, the price of the goods is called *pābhata*].

As it was said – *bhattavetananti* means the daily food and also the monthly expenditure etc., along with giving places, villages, towns etc. according to the suitable nature of their skillful work, *tassa tassa kusalakammasūrabhāvānurūpena ṭhānantaragāmanigamādidānena saddhiṃ detūti* [should be given], is the meaning.

*sakammapasutāti* means *uyyuttā byāvaṭā* [engaged and occupied] in their own works such as farming, trade, etc., *kasivāṇijjādīsu sakesu kammesu*.

*rāsikoti* means *rāsiko* [possessor of wealth] of wealth and grain, *dhanadhaññānaṃ*.

*khemaṭṭhitāti* means *khemena ṭhitā abhayā* [standing safely, without fear].

*akaṇṭakāti* means *corakaṇṭakarahitā* [without thief's thorns].

*mudā modamānāti* means *modā modamānā* [rejoicing with joy].

*ayameva vā pāṭho, aññamaññaṃ pamuditacittāti adhippāyo* [this is the reading, the intention is that their minds are mutually delighted].

*apārutagharāti* means because of the absence of thieves, the doors are not closed, *corānaṃ abhāvena dvārāni asaṃvaritvā vivaṭadvārāti* [the doors are open], is the meaning.

*etadavocāti janapadassa sabbākārena iddhaphītabhāvaṃ ñatvā etaṃ avoca* [he said this, having known the prosperous state of the country in every way, he said this].

mula_pali: 339. ‘‘Tena hi bhavaṃ rājā ye bhoto rañño janapade khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca te bhavaṃ rājā āmantayataṃ – ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti. Ye bhoto rañño janapade amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca…pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca…pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te bhavaṃ rājā āmantayataṃ – ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti. ‘Evaṃ, bho’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā  ye rañño janapade khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te rājā mahāvijito āmantesi  – ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho, mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’’ti. ‘Yajataṃ bhavaṃ rājā yaññaṃ, yaññakālo mahārājā’ti. Ye rañño janapade amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca…pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca…pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te rājā mahāvijito āmantesi – ‘icchāmahaṃ, bho , mahāyaññaṃ yajituṃ. Anujānantu me bhavanto yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’ti. ‘Yajataṃ bhavaṃ rājā yaññaṃ, yaññakālo mahārājā’ti. Itime cattāro anumatipakkhā tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
mula_english:
“Therefore, Your Majesty, summon your nobles, *kṣatriyas* who are followers, townspeople and country folk in your realm, and say to them: ‘I wish to perform a great sacrifice *mahāyañña*. May you, gentlemen, consent to that which will be to my lasting benefit and happiness.’

Summon your ministers, attendants, townspeople and country folk… the influential *brāhmaṇas* and wealthy householders of your realm, and say to them: ‘I wish to perform a great sacrifice *mahāyañña*. May you, gentlemen, consent to that which will be to my lasting benefit and happiness.’

‘Yes, sir,’ the king Mahāvijita agreed, and after promising the *brāhmaṇa* chaplain, he summoned the nobles, *kṣatriyas* who were followers, townspeople and country folk in his realm, and King Mahāvijita said to them: ‘I wish to perform a great sacrifice *mahāyañña*. May you, gentlemen, consent to that which will be to my lasting benefit and happiness.’

‘Sire, let the sacrifice *yañña* begin, now is the time, Your Majesty.’

King Mahāvijita summoned the ministers, attendants, townspeople and country folk… the influential *brāhmaṇas* and wealthy householders of the realm, and said to them: ‘I wish to perform a great sacrifice *mahāyañña*.

May you, gentlemen, consent to that which will be to my lasting benefit and happiness.’

‘Sire, let the sacrifice *yañña* begin, now is the time, Your Majesty.’

These four assenting groups will be the accessories for that very sacrifice *yañña*.
commentary_pali: 339.Tena hi bhavaṃ rājāti brāhmaṇo kira cintesi – ‘‘ayaṃ rājā mahādānaṃ dātuṃ ativiya ussāhajāto. Sace pana attano anuyantā khattiyādayo anāmantetvā dassati. Nāssa te attamanā bhavissanti; yathā dānaṃ te attamanā honti, tathā karissāmī’’ti. Tasmā ‘‘tena hi bhava’’ntiādimāha. Tattha negamāti nigamavāsino. Jānapadāti janapadavāsino . Āmantayatanti āmantetu jānāpetu. Yaṃ mama assāti yaṃ tumhākaṃ anujānanaṃ mama bhaveyya. Amaccāti piyasahāyakā. Pārisajjāti sesā āṇattikārakā. Yajataṃ bhavaṃ rājāti yajatu bhavaṃ, te kira – ayaṃ rājā ‘‘ahaṃ issaro’’ti pasayha dānaṃ adatvā amhe āmantesi, ahonena suṭṭhu kata’’nti attamanā evamāhaṃsu. Anāmantite panassa yaññaṭṭhānaṃ dassanāyapi na gaccheyyuṃ. Yaññakālo mahārājāti deyyadhammasmiñhi asati mahallakakāle ca evarūpaṃ dānaṃ dātuṃ na sakkā, tvaṃ pana mahādhano ceva taruṇo ca, etena te  yaññakāloti dassentā vadanti. Anumatipakkhāti anumatiyā pakkhā, anumatidāyakāti attho. Parikkhārā bhavantīti parivārā bhavanti. ‘‘Ratho sīlaparikkhāro, jhānakkho cakkavīriyo’’ti (saṃ. ni. 5.4) ettha pana alaṅkāro parikkhāroti vutto.
commentary_english:
339. Then the brahmin thought, "This king is extremely enthusiastic to give a great gift (mahādāna)."

"If he gives without inviting his followers, the nobles (khattiya), and others, they will not be pleased. I will do it in such a way that they will be pleased with the giving (dāna)."

Therefore, he said, "Then, your honor," and so forth.

There, "negama" means town dwellers (nigamavāsino).

"Jānapada" means country dwellers (janapadavāsino).

"Āmantayata" means to invite and inform (jānāpetu).

"Yam mama assā" means "Whatever approval of yours (tumhākaṃ anujānanaṃ) might be mine."

"Amacca" means dear friends (piyasahāyakā).

"Pārisajja" means the remaining order-executors (āṇattikārakā).

"Yajataṃ bhavaṃ rājā" means "May your honor sacrifice." They, indeed, said with pleased minds, "This king, thinking 'I am the lord (issara),' invited us without giving a gift (dāna) forcibly. It is well done by him."

Even if uninvited, they would not go to see his place of sacrifice (yaññaṭṭhānaṃ).

"Yaññakālo mahārāja" means, "O great king (mahārāja), it is not possible to give such a gift (dāna) when the resources for giving (deyyadhamma) are lacking or in old age (mahallakakāle). But you are very rich (mahādhano) and young (taruṇo). Therefore, they speak showing that this is the time for sacrifice (yaññakālo)."

"Anumatipakkha" means "the side of approval (anumatīyā pakkhā)," the meaning being "a giver of approval (anumatidāyaka)."

"Parikkhārā bhavantīti" means "they are retinue (parivārā bhavanti)."

"The chariot has virtue (sīla) as its equipment (parikkhāro), meditation (jhāna) as its axle, and energy (vīriya) as its wheel" (Saṃ. Ni. 5.4). Here, embellishment (alaṅkāro) is said to be equipment (parikkhāro).

mula_pali: 340. ‘‘Rājā  mahāvijito aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato, ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya; aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro; balavā caturaṅginiyā senāya samannāgato assavāya ovādapaṭikarāya sahati patapati (sī. pī.), tapati (syā.) maññe paccatthike yasasā; saddho dāyako dānapati anāvaṭadvāro samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṃ opānabhūto puññāni karoti; bahussuto tassa tassa sutajātassa, tassa tasseva  kho pana bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānāti ‘ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho’ti; paṇḍito, viyatto, medhāvī, paṭibalo, atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ. Rājā mahāvijito imehi aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato. Iti imānipi aṭṭhaṅgāni tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
mula_english:
“King Mahāvijita is endowed with eight qualities. He is well-born on both sides, of pure lineage from mother and father, unblemished and irreproachable in terms of caste, up to the seventh generation of ancestors. He is handsome, pleasing to the eye, delightful, and possesses supreme beauty and complexion, with a god-like color and radiance, and a presence that is not insignificant to behold. He is rich, with great wealth and possessions, abundant in gold and silver, plentiful in resources and equipment, full of wealth and grain, with storehouses and granaries overflowing. He is powerful, possessing a four-branched army that is loyal and obedient to his commands, and he subdues his enemies with glory. He is faithful, a giver, a lord of generosity, with doors always open to ascetics (*śramaṇa*), Brahmins (*brāhmaṇa*), the poor, the needy, merchants, and beggars, a fountain of merit, constantly performing meritorious deeds. He is very learned, understanding the meaning of each and every teaching he has heard, knowing 'this is the meaning of this spoken word, this is the meaning of that spoken word.' He is wise, discerning, intelligent, capable, and able to contemplate the past, present, and future meanings.

King Mahāvijita is endowed with these eight qualities.

Thus, these eight factors are the requisites for that very sacrifice (*yajña*).
commentary_pali: 340.Aṭṭhahaṅgehīti  ubhato sujātādīhi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi. Yasasāti āṇāṭhapanasamatthatāya. Saddhoti dānassa phalaṃ atthīti saddahati. Dāyakoti dānasūro. Na saddhāmattakeneva tiṭṭhati, pariccajitumpi sakkotīti attho. Dānapatīti yaṃ dānaṃ deti, tassa pati hutvā deti, na dāso, na sahāyo. Yo hi attanā madhuraṃ bhuñjati, paresaṃ amadhuraṃ deti, so dānasaṅkhātassa deyyadhammassa dāso hutvā deti. Yo yaṃ attanā bhuñjati, tadeva deti, so sahāyo hutvā deti. Yo pana attanā yena kenaci yāpeti, paresaṃ madhuraṃ deti, so pati jeṭṭhako sāmī hutvā deti, ayaṃ tādisoti attho. Samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānanti ettha samitapāpā samaṇā, bāhitapāpā brāhmaṇā. Kapaṇāti duggatā daliddamanussā. Addhikāti pathāvino. Vaṇibbakāti ye – ‘‘iṭṭhaṃ dinnaṃ, kantaṃ, manāpaṃ, kālena anavajjaṃ dinnaṃ, dadaṃ cittaṃ pasādeyya, gacchatu bhavaṃ brahmaloka’’ntiādinā nayena dānassa vaṇṇaṃ thomayamānā vicaranti. Yācakāti ye – ‘‘pasatamattaṃ detha, sarāvamattaṃ dethā’’tiādīni vatvā yācamānā vicaranti. Opānabhūtoti udapānabhūto. Sabbesaṃ sādhāraṇaparibhogo, catumahāpathe khatapokkharaṇī  viya hutvāti attho. Sutajātassāti ettha sutameva sutajātaṃ. Atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetunti ettha – ‘‘atīte puññassa katattāyeva me ayaṃ sampattī’’ti, evaṃ cintento atītamatthaṃ cintetuṃ paṭibalo nāma hoti. ‘‘Idāni puññaṃ katvāva anāgate sakkā sampattiṃ pāpuṇitu’’nti cintento anāgatamatthaṃ cintetuṃ paṭibalo nāma hoti. ‘‘Idaṃ puññakammaṃ nāma sappurisānaṃ āciṇṇaṃ, mayhañca bhogāpi saṃvijjanti, dāyakacittampi atthi; handāhaṃ puññāni karomī’’ti  cintento paccuppannamatthaṃ cintetuṃ paṭibalo nāma hotīti veditabbo. Iti imānīti evaṃ yathā vuttāni etāni. Etehi kira aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgatassa dānaṃ sabbadisāhi mahājano upasaṅkamati. ‘‘Ayaṃ dujjāto kittakaṃ kālaṃ dassati, idāni vippaṭisārī hutvā upacchindissatī’’ti evamādīni cintetvā na koci upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññati. Tasmā etāni aṭṭhaṅgāni parikkhārā bhavantīti vuttāni.
commentary_english:
340.
"Aṭṭhahaṅgehīti" means with eight aspects, that is, with eight aspects beginning with being well-born on both sides ( *ubhato sujātādi*).
*Yasasāti* [means] for the sake of fame or glory ( *āṇāṭhapanasamatthatāya*).
*Saddhoti* means he believes that there is a karmic result of giving ( *dānassa phalaṃ atthīti saddahati*).
*Dāyakoti* means a hero in giving ( *dānasūro*).
He doesn't just stand with faith, but he is able to give up ( *na saddhāmattakeneva tiṭṭhati, pariccajitumpi sakkotīti attho*).
*Dānapatīti* means one who gives a gift, gives it as a master, not as a slave, not as a friend ( *yaṃ dānaṃ deti, tassa pati hutvā deti, na dāso, na sahāyo*).
Indeed, one who eats sweet things himself, and gives unsavory things to others, he, having become a slave of the gift-designated-as-worthy-to-be-given ( *dānasaṅkhātassa deyyadhammassa*), gives.
One who enjoys whatever he himself eats, gives that very thing, he gives as a friend ( *sahāyo hutvā deti*).
But one who lives on whatever he can get by with, and gives sweet things to others, he gives as a master, an elder, a lord ( *pati jeṭṭhako sāmī hutvā deti*), this is what it means ( *ayaṃ tādisoti attho*).
*Samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānanti* Here, *samaṇā* are those whose evil is calmed, *brāhmaṇā* are those whose evil is banished.
*Kapaṇāti* means wretched, impoverished people ( *duggatā daliddamanussā*).
*Addhikāti* means travelers ( *pathāvino*).
*Vaṇibbakāti* are those who, praising the virtues of giving in ways such as, "The desirable is given, the lovely, the pleasing, the faultless is given at the right time, the giving gladdens the mind, may you go to the Brahma world," wander about.
*Yācakāti* are those who, saying things such as, "Give a *pasata*-measure, give a *sarāva*-measure," wander about begging.
*Opānabhūtoti* means having become a well ( *udapānabhūto*).
Common enjoyment for all, like a well-dug pond on a four-way highway, this is the meaning ( *sabbesaṃ sādhāraṇaparibhogo, catumahāpathe khatapokkharaṇī viya hutvāti attho*).
*Sutajātassāti* here, only the heard is well-born ( *sutameva sutajātaṃ*).
*Atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetunti* Here, thinking, "In the past, this attainment of mine was because of the merit I did," thus thinking, he is said to be capable of thinking about the past ( *atītamatthaṃ cintetuṃ paṭibalo nāma hoti*).
Thinking, "Now, having done merit, it will be possible to attain prosperity in the future," thus thinking, he is said to be capable of thinking about the future ( *anāgatamatthaṃ cintetuṃ paṭibalo nāma hoti*).
Thinking, "This meritorious act is habitual for good people, and I also have possessions, and I also have a giving mind; come, let me do meritorious deeds," thus thinking, he should be understood as being capable of thinking about the present ( *paccuppannamatthaṃ cintetuṃ paṭibalo nāma hotīti veditabbo*).
*Iti imānīti* means these are as they have been described ( *evaṃ yathā vuttāni etāni*).
Indeed, a great multitude approaches from all directions the giving of one who is endowed with these eight aspects ( *etehi kira aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgatassa dānaṃ sabbadisāhi mahājano upasaṅkamati*).
Thinking, "This one who is difficult to please, how long will he give? Now, having become regretful, he will cut it off," thus thinking, no one considers approaching ( *ayaṃ dujjāto kittakaṃ kālaṃ dassati, idāni vippaṭisārī hutvā upacchindissatīti evamādīni cintetvā na koci upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññati*).
Therefore, these eight aspects are said to be requisites ( *tasmā etāni aṭṭhaṅgāni parikkhārā bhavantīti vuttāni*).

mula_pali: 341. ‘‘Purohito purohitopi (ka. sī. ka.) brāhmaṇo catuhaṅgehi samannāgato. Ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena; ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo; sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena  samannāgato; paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Purohito brāhmaṇo imehi catūhaṅgehi samannāgato. Iti imāni cattāri aṅgāni tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
mula_english: 341. “The *purohita*, the *purohita* also (ka. sī. ka.) the *brāhmaṇa* is endowed with four qualities (*catuhaṅgehi samannāgato*). He is well-born (*sujāto*) on both sides, from the mother (*mātito*) and from the father (*pitito*), of pure descent to the seventh generation of ancestors, unblemished, irreproachable in regard to his birth; he is a reciter (*ajjhāyako*) who holds the *mantras* (*mantadharo*), is master (*pāragū*) of the three *Vedas* (*tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ*) with their *Nighaṇḍu*, *Keṭubha*, phonology, and the *itihāsa* as fifth, is skilled in grammar (*veyyākaraṇo*), and is not deficient in the *Lokāyata* and the 32 marks of a great man (*mahāpurisalakkhaṇesu*); he is virtuous (*sīlavā*), of advanced virtue (*vuddhasīlī*), endowed with advanced virtue; he is learned (*paṇḍito*), accomplished (*viyatto*), wise (*medhāvī*), and is the first or second to accept the sacrificial ladle (*sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ*). The *purohita* *brāhmaṇa* is endowed with these four qualities (*imehi catūhaṅgehi samannāgato*). Thus, these four qualities are the requisites for that sacrifice (*yaññassa parikkhārā*).
commentary_pali: 341.Sujaṃpaggaṇhantānanti mahāyāgapaṭiggaṇhanaṭṭhāne dānakaṭacchuṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imehi catūhīti etehi sujātādīhi. Etesu hi asati – ‘‘evaṃ dujjātassa saṃvidhānena pavattadānaṃ kittakaṃ kālaṃ pavattissatī’’tiādīni vatvā upasaṅkamitāro na honti. Garahitabbābhāvato pana upasaṅkamantiyeva. Tasmā imānipi parikkhārā bhavantīti vuttāni.
commentary_english:
341. "Sujaṃpaggaṇhantānaṃ" means those who take up the alms-bowl at the place of receiving a great sacrifice, those who take up the giving-spoon (dānakaṭacchuṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ).

"Imehi catūhi" means with these four, that is, with these such as the well-born (sujāta) and so on.

If these do not exist, people would not approach, saying things like, "How long will the donation continue in this way with the arrangement of such a poorly-born person?"

But since there is no reason to criticize, they approach.

Therefore, it is said that these are the requisites (parikkhārā bhavantīti vuttāni).

mula_pali: 342. ‘‘Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā tisso vidhā desesi. Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ  yiṭṭhukāmassa yiṭṭhakāmassa (ka.) kocideva vippaṭisāro – ‘mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigacchissatī’ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo. Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vippaṭisāro – ‘mahā  vata me bhogakkhandho vigacchatī’ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo. Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yiṭṭhassa kocideva vippaṭisāro – ‘mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigato’ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo’’ti. Imā kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā tisso vidhā desesi.
mula_english:
“Then, O Brahmin, prior to the sacrifice, the Brahmin chaplain taught King Mahāvijita three modes (tisso vidhā) (of conduct).

It might be that Your Majesty has some regret about intending to perform the great sacrifice (mahāyaññaṃ yiṭṭhukāmassa): ‘I am going to lose a great mass of wealth (bhogakkhandho vigacchissatī),’ In such a case, Your Majesty should not have such regret.

It might be that Your Majesty, while performing the great sacrifice (mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa), has some regret: ‘I am losing a great mass of wealth (bhogakkhandho vigacchati),’ In such a case, Your Majesty should not have such regret.

It might be that Your Majesty, after performing the great sacrifice (mahāyaññaṃ yiṭṭhassa), has some regret: ‘I have lost a great mass of wealth (bhogakkhandho vigato),’ In such a case, Your Majesty should not have such regret.”

These, O Brahmin, are the three modes (tisso vidhā) that the Brahmin chaplain taught King Mahāvijita prior to the sacrifice.
commentary_pali: 342.Tisso vidhā desesīti tīṇi ṭhapanāni desesi. So kira cintesi – ‘‘dānaṃ dadamānā nāma tiṇṇaṃ ṭhānānaṃ aññatarasmiṃ calanti handāhaṃ imaṃ rājānaṃ tesu ṭhānesu paṭhamataraññeva niccalaṃ karomī’’ti. Tenassa tisso vidhā desesīti. So bhoto raññoti idaṃ karaṇatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Bhotā raññāti vā pāṭho. Vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyoti ‘‘bhogānaṃ vigamahetuko pacchānutāpo na kattabbo, pubbacetanā pana acalā patiṭṭhapetabbā, evañhi dānaṃ mahapphalaṃ hotī’’ti dasseti. Itaresupi dvīsu ṭhānesu eseva nayo. Muñcacetanāpi hi pacchāsamanussaraṇacetanā  ca niccalāva kātabbā. Tathā akarontassa dānaṃ na mahapphalaṃ hoti, nāpi uḷāresu bhogesu cittaṃ namati, mahāroruvaṃ upapannassa seṭṭhigahapatino viya.
commentary_english:
342.

Because he revealed these three methods, he revealed three placements.

He thought: "Those who give gifts move in one of three places. Let me make this king fixed in those places in the very first place."

Therefore, he revealed these three methods to him.

"He is your king" - this is a word of deference in the sense of doing.

Or the reading is "By the king".

"Regret should not be done" - he shows that "subsequent remorse, caused by the cessation of possessions, should not be done; but the prior intention should be firmly established, for thus giving is of great fruit."

In the other two places also, this is the same method.

Indeed, the intention of relinquishing and the intention of subsequent recollection should both be made unwavering.

Thus, for one who does not do, giving is not of great fruit, nor does the mind incline to excellent possessions, like that of a wealthy householder who has attained Mahāroruva.

mula_pali: 343. ‘‘Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā dasahākārehi paṭiggāhakesu vippaṭisāraṃ paṭivinesi. ‘Āgamissanti kho bhoto yaññaṃ pāṇātipātinopi pāṇātipātā paṭiviratāpi. Ye tattha pāṇātipātino, tesaññeva tena. Ye tattha pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā, te ārabbha yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu. Āgamissanti kho bhoto yaññaṃ adinnādāyinopi adinnādānā paṭiviratāpi…pe…  kāmesu micchācārinopi kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratāpi… musāvādinopi musāvādā paṭiviratāpi… pisuṇavācinopi pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratāpi… pharusavācinopi pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratāpi… samphappalāpinopi samphappalāpā  paṭiviratāpi … abhijjhālunopi anabhijjhālunopi… byāpannacittāpi abyāpannacittāpi… micchādiṭṭhikāpi sammādiṭṭhikāpi…. Ye tattha micchādiṭṭhikā, tesaññeva tena. Ye tattha sammādiṭṭhikā, te ārabbha yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetū’ti. Imehi kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā dasahākārehi paṭiggāhakesu vippaṭisāraṃ paṭivinesi.
mula_english:
“Then, O Brahmin, prior to the sacrifice, the Brahmin chaplain dispelled the qualms of King Mahāvijita with ten conditions for the recipients.

‘Sire, there will come to the sacrifice those who take life (*prāṇātipātin*) and those who abstain from taking life (*prāṇātipātā paṭiviratā*).

To those who take life, so will be to them;

but those who abstain from taking life will have a successful sacrifice and will rejoice in it, and their hearts may be calmed within.

There will come those who take what is not given and those who refrain…, those who indulge in sexual misconduct and those who refrain…, those who tell lies…, indulge in calumny, harsh and frivolous speech…, those who are covetous and those who are not, those who harbor ill-will and those who do not, those who have wrong views (*micchādiṭṭhika*) and those who have right views (*sammādiṭṭhika*).

To those who have wrong views it will turn out accordingly,

but those who have right views will have a successful sacrifice and will rejoice in it, and their hearts may be calmed within.”

So the chaplain dispelled the King’s doubts with ten conditions.
commentary_pali: 343.Dasahākārehīti dasahi kāraṇehi. Tassa kira evaṃ ahosi – sacāyaṃ rājā dussīle disvā – ‘‘nassati vata me dānaṃ, yassa me evarūpā dussīlā bhuñjantī’’ti sīlavantesupi vippaṭisāraṃ uppādessati, dānaṃ na mahapphalaṃ bhavissati. Vippaṭisāro ca nāma dāyakānaṃ paṭiggāhakatova uppajjati , handassa paṭhamameva taṃ vippaṭisāraṃ vinodemīti. Tasmā dasahākārehi upacchijjituṃ yuttaṃ paṭiggāhakesupi vippaṭisāraṃ vinodesīti. Tesaññeva tenāti tesaññeva tena pāpena aniṭṭho vipāko bhavissati, na aññesanti dasseti. Yajataṃ bhavanti detu bhavaṃ. Sajjatanti vissajjatu. Antaranti abbhantaraṃ.
commentary_english:
343.
"In ten ways" means with ten reasons.
The thought occurred to him thus: "If this king sees those of bad conduct, he will think, 'My giving is being destroyed, because those of bad conduct are enjoying it,' and he will cause remorse even in those of good conduct. The giving will not be of great fruit."
For indeed, remorse arises in the givers from the receivers themselves. "Come now, I will dispel that remorse right from the start."
Therefore, it is fitting to cut it off in ten ways, so that he may dispel the remorse even in the receivers.
"By that to them alone" means that the undesirable result will befall them alone because of that evil, and not others. This he shows.
Let the revered ones sacrifice; let them give being.
Let him be attached; let him be released.
"Inner" means inside.

mula_pali: 344. ‘‘Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa soḷasahākārehi cittaṃ sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā – ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, no ca kho tassa āmantitā khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca; atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti . Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi. Bhotā kho pana raññā āmantitā khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca . Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu. ‘‘Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā – ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, no ca kho tassa āmantitā amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca…pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca…pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti. Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi. Bhotā kho pana raññā āmantitā gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca. Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu. ‘‘Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā – ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, no ca kho ubhato  sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti. Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi. Bhavaṃ kho pana rājā ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā  akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu. ‘‘Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā – ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati no ca kho abhirūpo dassanīyo pāsādiko paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgato brahmavaṇṇī brahmavacchasī akhuddāvakāso dassanāya…pe… no ca kho aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro…pe… no ca kho balavā caturaṅginiyā senāya samannāgato assavāya ovādapaṭikarāya sahati maññe paccatthike yasasā…pe… no ca kho saddho dāyako dānapati anāvaṭadvāro samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṃ opānabhūto puññāni karoti…pe… no ca kho bahussuto tassa tassa sutajātassa…pe… no ca kho tassa tasseva kho pana bhāsitassa atthaṃ jānāti ‘‘ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho, ayaṃ imassa bhāsitassa attho’’ti…pe… no ca kho paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti . Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi. Bhavaṃ kho pana rājā paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭibalo atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ. Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu , yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu. ‘‘Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā – ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati. No ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko  yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena; atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti. Evampi  bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi. Bhoto kho pana rañño purohito brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṃsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena. Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetu. ‘‘Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa kocideva vattā – ‘rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati. No ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo ajjhāyako mantadharo tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sākkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo…pe… no ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo sīlavā vuddhasīlī vuddhasīlena samannāgato…pe… no ca khvassa purohito brāhmaṇo paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ, atha ca pana bhavaṃ rājā  evarūpaṃ mahāyaññaṃ yajatī’ti. Evampi bhoto rañño vattā dhammato natthi. Bhoto kho pana rañño purohito brāhmaṇo paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī paṭhamo vā dutiyo vā sujaṃ paggaṇhantānaṃ. Imināpetaṃ bhavaṃ rājā jānātu, yajataṃ bhavaṃ, sajjataṃ bhavaṃ, modataṃ bhavaṃ, cittameva bhavaṃ antaraṃ pasādetūti. Imehi kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa mahāyaññaṃ yajamānassa soḷasahi ākārehi cittaṃ sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
mula_english:
344.
Then, brahmin, the chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, with sixteen considerations showed the king Mahāvijita, who was performing the great sacrifice, induced, roused, and gladdened his mind: "Someone might say of the great sacrifice that King Mahāvijita is performing, 'The *kṣatriyas* who should be invited are not following, nor are the townsfolk (*negama*) and country people (*jānapada*); and yet this king is performing such a great sacrifice!'"
But such words would not be in accordance with the truth for the king.
The *kṣatriyas* who should be invited, the townsfolk, and country people are following the king.
By this, may the honored king know that he will have a successful sacrifice, may the honored one be prepared, may the honored one rejoice, may the honored one calm his heart within.

"Someone might say of the great sacrifice that King Mahāvijita is performing, 'The advisors (*amacca*) and courtiers (*pārisajja*) who should be invited are not following, nor are the townsfolk and country people... the wealthy *brāhmaṇas* are not following, nor are the townsfolk and country people... the householders (*gahapati*) who are leaders (*necayika*) are not following, nor are the townsfolk and country people; and yet this king is performing such a great sacrifice!'"
But such words would not be in accordance with the truth for the king.
The householders who are leaders, the townsfolk, and the country people are following the king.
By this, may the honored king know that he will have a successful sacrifice, may the honored one be prepared, may the honored one rejoice, may the honored one calm his heart within.

"Someone might say of the great sacrifice that King Mahāvijita is performing, 'He is not well-born (*sujāta*) on both sides, from the mother's side (*mātito*) and the father's side (*pitito*), of pure lineage (*saṃsuddhagahaṇika*) for seven generations (*pitāmahayugā*), unblemished (*akkhitto*) and irreproachable (*anupakkuṭṭho*) with regard to his caste (*jāti-vāda*); and yet this king is performing such a great sacrifice!'"
But such words would not be in accordance with the truth for the king.
The honored king is well-born on both sides, from the mother's side and the father's side, of pure lineage for seven generations, unblemished and irreproachable with regard to his caste.
By this, may the honored king know that he will have a successful sacrifice, may the honored one be prepared, may the honored one rejoice, may the honored one calm his heart within.

"Someone might say of the great sacrifice that King Mahāvijita is performing, 'He is not handsome (*abhirūpa*), pleasing (*dassanīya*), delightful (*pāsādika*), endowed with the highest beauty (*vaṇṇa-pokkharatāya*), of *brahmaṇa* complexion (*brahmavaṇṇī*) and radiance (*brahmavacchasī*), accessible to behold... He is not rich (*aḍḍha*), of great wealth (*mahaddhana*) and possessions (*mahābhoga*), with plenty of gold and silver (*pahūtajātarūparajato*), plenty of resources (*pahūtavittūpakaraṇo*), plenty of wealth and grain (*pahūtadhanadhañño*), storehouses fully stocked (*paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro*)... He is not strong (*balavā*), endowed with a four-division army (*caturaṅginiyā senāya*), capable of enduring the exhortation and instruction (*assavāya ovādapaṭikarāya sahati maññe*) to overcome his enemies (*paccatthike*) by his fame (*yasasā*)... He is not faithful (*saddha*), a giver (*dāyako*), a patron of generosity (*dānapati*), with open doors, a source of refreshment (*opānabhūto*) for ascetics (*samaṇa*), *brāhmaṇas*, the poor, travelers, beggars, and mendicants, and does not perform meritorious deeds (*puññāni karoti*)... He is not learned (*bahussuta*) in the various subjects he has heard... He does not understand the meaning (*atthaṃ jānāti*) of what is spoken, saying, "This is the meaning of this saying, this is the meaning of that saying"... He is not wise (*paṇḍito*), intelligent (*viyatto*), discerning (*medhāvī*), capable (*paṭibalo*) of reflecting on past, future and present matters (*atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṃ*); and yet this king is performing such a great sacrifice!'"
But such words would not be in accordance with the truth for the king.
The honored king is wise, intelligent, discerning, capable of reflecting on past, future, and present matters.
By this, may the honored king know that he will have a successful sacrifice, may the honored one be prepared, may the honored one rejoice, may the honored one calm his heart within.

"Someone might say of the great sacrifice that King Mahāvijita is performing, 'King Mahāvijita is performing a great sacrifice, but his chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, is not well-born on both sides, from the mother's side and the father's side, of pure lineage for seven generations, unblemished and irreproachable with regard to his caste; and yet this king is performing such a great sacrifice!'"
But such words would not be in accordance with the truth for the king.
The honored king's chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, is well-born on both sides, from the mother's side and the father's side, of pure lineage for seven generations, unblemished and irreproachable with regard to his caste.
By this, may the honored king know that he will have a successful sacrifice, may the honored one be prepared, may the honored one rejoice, may the honored one calm his heart within.

"Someone might say of the great sacrifice that King Mahāvijita is performing, 'King Mahāvijita is performing a great sacrifice, but his chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, is not a reciter (*ajjhāyako*), a master of *mantras* (*mantadharo*), a master of the three *Vedas* (*tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū*), with Nighaṇḍu and Keṭubha, and the divisions of the letters (*sākkharappabhedānaṃ*), and with the *Itihāsa* as the fifth, skilled in the words (*padako*), a grammarian (*veyyākaraṇo*), blameless (*anavayo*) in the Lokāyata and the characteristics of a great man (*mahāpurisa-lakkhaṇesu*)... his chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, is not virtuous (*sīlavā*), of mature virtue (*vuddhasīlī*), endowed with mature virtue... his chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, is not wise, intelligent, discerning, the first or second to understand a point when it is raised; and yet this king is performing such a great sacrifice!'"
But such words would not be in accordance with the truth for the king.
The honored king's chaplain, a *brāhmaṇa*, is wise, intelligent, discerning, the first or second to understand a point when it is raised.
By this, may the honored king know that he will have a successful sacrifice, may the honored one be prepared, may the honored one rejoice, may the honored one calm his heart within."

With these sixteen considerations, brahmin, the chaplain showed, induced, roused, and gladdened the mind of King Mahāvijita, who was performing the great sacrifice.
commentary_pali: 344.Soḷasahi ākārehi cittaṃ sandassesīti idha brāhmaṇo rañño mahādānānumodanaṃ nāma āraddho. Tattha sandassesīti – ‘idaṃ dānaṃ dātā evarūpaṃ sampattiṃ labhatī’ti dassetvā dassetvā kathesi. Samādapesīti tadatthaṃ samādapetvā kathesi. Samuttejesīti vippaṭisāravinodanenassa cittaṃ vodāpesi. Sampahaṃsesīti ‘sundaraṃ te kataṃ, mahārāja, dānaṃ dadamānenā’ti thutiṃ katvā kathesi. Vattā dhammato natthīti dhammena samena kāraṇena vattā natthi.
commentary_english:
344. "He showed the mind in sixteen ways": here, the *brāhmaṇa* began the king's great dāna-anumodana.

"There, he showed": he told, showing and showing, "The giver of this gift obtains such an attainment."

"He induced": having induced for that purpose, he told.

"He encouraged": he purified his mind with the removal of remorse.

"He delighted": having praised, he told, "It is beautifully done by you, great king, with the giving of a gift."

"There is no speaker from the Dhamma": there is no speaker by a cause equal to the Dhamma.

mula_pali: 345. ‘‘Tasmiṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññe neva gāvo haññiṃsu, na ajeḷakā haññiṃsu, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṃsu, na vividhā pāṇā saṃghātaṃ āpajjiṃsu, na rukkhā chijjiṃsu yūpatthāya, na dabbhā lūyiṃsu barihisatthāya parihiṃsatthāya (syā. ka. sī. ka.), parahiṃsatthāya (ka.). Yepissa ahesuṃ dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi na daṇḍatajjitā na  bhayatajjitā na assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni  akaṃsu. Atha kho ye icchiṃsu, te akaṃsu, ye na icchiṃsu, na te akaṃsu; yaṃ icchiṃsu, taṃ akaṃsu, yaṃ na icchiṃsu, na taṃ akaṃsu. Sappitelanavanītadadhimadhuphāṇitena ceva so yañño niṭṭhānamagamāsi.
mula_english:
345. “In that sacrifice, O Brahmin, neither were cows slain (gāvo haññiṃsu), nor goats or sheep (ajeḷakā haññiṃsu), nor cocks and pigs (kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṃsu), nor were various living beings (vividhā pāṇā) subjected to slaughter (saṃghātaṃ āpajjiṃsu), nor were trees (rukkhā) cut down for sacrificial posts (yūpatthāya), nor were grasses (dabbhā) mown for the sacrificial grass, nor for harming (parihiṃsatthāya).

And those who were his slaves (dāsā) or messengers (pessā) or workmen (kammakarā), they too were not driven by fear of the stick (daṇḍatajjitā), nor by fear (bhayatajjitā), nor with tearful faces (assumukhā) weeping (rudamānā) did they perform their tasks (parikammāni akaṃsu).

Then those who wanted to (ye icchiṃsu), did (te akaṃsu), those who did not want to (ye na icchiṃsu), did not do (na te akaṃsu); what they wanted to (yaṃ icchiṃsu), they did (taṃ akaṃsu), what they did not want to (yaṃ na icchiṃsu), they did not do (na taṃ akaṃsu).

That sacrifice (so yañño) came to completion (niṭṭhānamagamāsi) with clarified butter, oil, fresh butter, curd, honey, and molasses (sappitelanavanītadadhimadhuphāṇitena).
commentary_pali: 345.Narukkhā chijjiṃsu yūpatthāya na dabbhā lūyiṃsu barihisatthāyāti ye yūpanāmake mahāthambhe ussāpetvā – ‘‘asukarājā asukāmacco asukabrāhmaṇo evarūpaṃ nāma mahāyāgaṃ yajatī’’ti nāmaṃ likhitvā ṭhapenti. Yāni ca dabbhatiṇāni lāyitvā vanamālāsaṅkhepena yaññasālaṃ parikkhipanti, bhūmiyaṃ vā pattharanti, tepi na rukkhā chijjiṃsu, na dabbhā lūyiṃsu. Kiṃ pana gāvo vā ajādayo vā haññissantīti dasseti. Dāsāti antogehadāsādayo. Pessāti ye pubbameva dhanaṃ gahetvā kammaṃ karonti. Kammakarāti ye bhattavetanaṃ gahetvā karonti. Daṇḍatajjitā  nāma daṇḍayaṭṭhimuggarādīni gahetvā – ‘‘kammaṃ karotha karothā’’ti evaṃ  tajjitā. Bhayatajjitā nāma – sace kammaṃ karosi, kusalaṃ. No ce karosi, chindissāma vā bandhissāma vā māressāma vāti evaṃ bhayena tajjitā. Ete pana na daṇḍatajjitā, na bhayatajjitā, na assumukhā rodamānā parikammāni akaṃsu. Atha kho piyasamudācāreneva samudācariyamānā akaṃsu. Na hi tattha dāsaṃ vā dāsāti, pessaṃ vā pessāti, kammakaraṃ vā kammakarāti ālapanti. Yathānāmavaseneva pana piyasamudācārena ālapitvā itthipurisabalavantadubbalānaṃ anurūpameva kammaṃ dassetvā – ‘‘idañcidañca karothā’’ti vadanti. Tepi attano rucivaseneva karonti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘ye icchiṃsu, te akaṃsu; ye na icchiṃsu, na te akaṃsu. Yaṃ icchiṃsu, taṃ akaṃsu; yaṃ na icchiṃsu, na taṃ akaṃsū’’ti. Sappitelanavanītadadhimadhuphāṇitena ceva so yañño niṭṭhānamagamāsīti rājā kira bahinagarassa catūsu dvāresu antonagarassa ca majjheti pañcasu ṭhānesu mahādānasālāyo kārāpetvā ekekissāya sālāya satasahassaṃ satasahassaṃ katvā divase divase pañcasatasahassāni vissajjetvā sūriyuggamanato paṭṭhāya tassa tassa kālassa anurūpehi sahatthena suvaṇṇakaṭacchuṃ gahetvā paṇītehi sappitelādisammisseheva yāgukhajjakabhattabyañjanapānakādīhi mahājanaṃ santappesi. Bhājanāni pūretvā gaṇhitukāmānaṃ tatheva dāpesi. Sāyaṇhasamaye pana vatthagandhamālādīhi sampūjesi. Sappiādīnaṃ pana mahācāṭiyo pūrāpetvā – ‘‘yo yaṃ paribhuñjitukāmo, so taṃ paribhuñjatū’’ti anekasatesu ṭhānesu ṭhapāpesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – ‘‘sappitelanavanītadadhimadhuphāṇitena ceva so yañño niṭṭhānamagamāsī’’ti.
commentary_english:
345.
"Trees were not felled for sacrificial posts, nor *dabbha* grass cut for spreading," meaning they would erect great pillars with the name *yūpa*, writing upon them, "King so-and-so, minister so-and-so, *brāhmaṇa* so-and-so performs a great sacrifice of such and such a kind."

Also, they would surround the sacrificial hall with *dabbha* grass intertwined to resemble a garland of forest flowers or would spread it on the ground; yet, no trees were felled, no *dabbha* grass cut.

Does this mean cattle, goats, and the like will be slain? It shows this.

"Slaves" means household slaves and the like.

"Servants" means those who, having received money beforehand, perform work.

"Workmen" means those who, having received food and wages, perform work.

"Threatened with sticks" means having taken sticks, staffs, clubs, and the like, they are threatened thus: "Do the work, do the work!"

"Threatened with fear" means, "If you do the work, [it will be] good."

"If you do not do [it], we will cut [you], or bind [you], or kill [you]," thus, they are threatened with fear.

But these were not threatened with sticks, nor threatened with fear, nor did they perform their tasks weeping with tearful faces.

Rather, they performed [them] being treated with affection and courtesy.

There, they do not address [anyone] as "slave," "servant," or "workman."

But as is proper, they treat [them] with affection and courtesy, showing to men, women, strong, and weak the work that is suitable, saying, "Do this and that!"

Even so, they do according to their own inclination.

Therefore, it was said, "Those who wished [to do something], did [it]; those who did not wish [to do something], did not do [it].

What they wished [to do], they did; what they did not wish [to do], they did not do."

"That sacrifice reached completion with clarified butter, oil, fresh butter, yogurt, honey, and molasses." The king, it is said, having had great alms-halls built at the four gates of the city and in the middle of the city, in five places, and having spent one hundred thousand, one hundred thousand at each hall, five hundred thousand each day, from sunrise onward, taking a golden ladle in his own hand, gratified the multitude with fine gruel, cakes, rice, curries, drinks, and the like, mixed with clarified butter, oil, and so on, in accordance with the time.

Having filled the vessels, he gave in the same way to those wishing to take [them].

In the evening, he honored [them] with clothes, perfumes, garlands, and the like.

Having had great bowls filled with clarified butter and so on, he had [them] placed in hundreds of places, [saying]: "Whoever wishes to partake of whatever, let him partake of that!"

With reference to that, it was said: "That sacrifice reached completion with clarified butter, oil, fresh butter, yogurt, honey, and molasses."

mula_pali: 346. ‘‘Atha  kho, brāhmaṇa, khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, gahapatinecayikā negamā  ceva jānapadā ca pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ ādāya rājānaṃ mahāvijitaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṃsu – ‘idaṃ, deva, pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ devaññeva uddissābhataṃ, taṃ devo paṭiggaṇhātū’ti. ‘Alaṃ, bho, mamāpidaṃ pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ dhammikena balinā abhisaṅkhataṃ; tañca vo hotu, ito ca bhiyyo harathā’ti. Te raññā paṭikkhittā ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ – ‘na kho etaṃ amhākaṃ patirūpaṃ, yaṃ mayaṃ imāni sāpateyyāni punadeva sakāni gharāni paṭihareyyāma. Rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṃ yajati, handassa mayaṃ anuyāgino homā’ti.
mula_english:
346. “Then, O Brahmin, the *kṣatriyas* who followed him, along with the town and country dwellers, the ministers and courtiers, along with the town and country dwellers, the wealthy Brahmins along with the town and country dwellers, the opulent householders along with the town and country dwellers, having brought an abundance of wealth (*sāpateyya*) to King Mahāvijita, approached him and said, ‘This abundant wealth (*sāpateyya*) has been brought specifically for Your Majesty; may Your Majesty accept it.’

‘Enough, good sirs, I too have collected abundant wealth (*sāpateyya*) through legitimate means (*dhammikena balinā abhisaṅkhataṃ*); let that be yours, and take even more from here.’

Being refused by the king (*raññā paṭikkhittā*), they withdrew to one side and considered thus: ‘It is not proper for us to take these riches back to our own homes.

King Mahāvijita is performing a great sacrifice (*mahāyaññaṃ yajati*); come, let us follow his example."
commentary_pali: 346.Pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ ādāyāti bahuṃ dhanaṃ gahetvā. Te kira cintesuṃ – ‘‘ayaṃ rājā sappitelādīni janapadato anāharāpetvā attano santakameva nīharitvā mahādānaṃ deti. Amhehi pana ‘rājā na kiñci āharāpetī’ti na yuttaṃ tuṇhī bhavituṃ. Na hi rañño ghare dhanaṃ akkhayadhammameva, amhesu ca adentesu ko añño rañño dassati, handassa dhanaṃ upasaṃharāmā’’ti  te gāmabhāgena ca nigamabhāgena  ca nagarabhāgena ca sāpateyyaṃ saṃharitvā sakaṭāni pūretvā rañño upahariṃsu. Taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘pahūtaṃ sāpateyya’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
346. Taking abundant possessions, that is, taking much wealth.

They thought, "This king, without having ghee, oil, etc., brought from the countryside, extracts and gives a great gift only from his own property.

But it is not proper for us to be silent, saying, 'The king does not have anything brought.'"

Indeed, wealth in the king's house is not inexhaustible. And if we do not give, who else will give to the king? Come, let us collect wealth." They, collecting possessions by shares from the villages, market towns, and cities, filling carts, offered them to the king.

Referring to that, he said, "Abundant possessions," and so forth.

mula_pali: 347. ‘‘Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, puratthimena yaññavāṭassa yaññāvāṭassa (sī. pī. ka.) khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ. Dakkhiṇena yaññavāṭassa amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ. Pacchimena yaññavāṭassa brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ. Uttarena yaññavāṭassa gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṃ. ‘‘Tesupi kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññesu neva gāvo haññiṃsu, na ajeḷakā haññiṃsu, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṃsu, na vividhā pāṇā saṃghātaṃ āpajjiṃsu, na rukkhā chijjiṃsu yūpatthāya, na dabbhā lūyiṃsu barihisatthāya. Yepi nesaṃ ahesuṃ dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi na daṇḍatajjitā na bhayatajjitā na assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni  akaṃsu. Atha kho ye icchiṃsu, te akaṃsu, ye na icchiṃsu, na te akaṃsu; yaṃ icchiṃsu, taṃ akaṃsu, yaṃ na icchiṃsu na taṃ akaṃsu. Sappitelanavanītadadhimadhuphāṇitena ceva te yaññā niṭṭhānamagamaṃsu. ‘‘Iti  cattāro ca anumatipakkhā, rājā mahāvijito aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato, purohito  brāhmaṇo catūhaṅgehi samannāgato; tisso ca vidhā ayaṃ vuccati brāhmaṇa tividhā yaññasampadā soḷasaparikkhārā’’ti.
mula_english:
347. "Then, O Brahmin, to the east of the *yajña-vāṭa*, the *kṣatriyas* following along, along with the townspeople (*negama*) and country folk (*jānapada*), set out their gifts (*dānāni*).

To the south of the *yajña-vāṭa*, the ministers (*amacca*) and attendants (*pārisajja*), along with the townspeople (*negama*) and country folk (*jānapada*), set out their gifts (*dānāni*).

To the west of the *yajña-vāṭa*, the great Brahmin households (*brāhmaṇa-mahāsālā*), along with the townspeople (*negama*) and country folk (*jānapada*), set out their gifts (*dānāni*).

To the north of the *yajña-vāṭa*, the wealthy householders (*gahapati-necayikā*), along with the townspeople (*negama*) and country folk (*jānapada*), set out their gifts (*dānāni*).

"And in these sacrifices (*yajña*), O Brahmin, no cows (*gāvo*) were slain (*haññiṃsu*), no goats or sheep (*ajeḷakā*) were slain (*haññiṃsu*), no cocks or pigs (*kukkuṭasūkarā*) were slain (*haññiṃsu*), no various living beings (*pāṇā*) were subjected to slaughter (*saṃghātaṃ āpajjiṃsu*), no trees (*rukkha*) were cut down for sacrificial posts (*yūpatthāya*), nor was *dabbha* grass mown for the sacrificial grass (*barihisatthāya*).

And those who were their slaves (*dāsa*), servants (*pessa*), or workers (*kammakara*), they too did not perform their tasks with faces full of tears, weeping, for fear of blows or threats (*daṇḍatajjitā*, *bhayatajjitā*).

Then those who wanted to do something, did it; those who did not want to do something, did not do it; whatever they wanted to do, they did; whatever they did not want to do, they did not do.

And these sacrifices (*yajña*) were brought to completion with clarified butter (*sappi*), oil (*tela*), fresh butter (*navanīta*), curds (*dadhi*), honey (*madhu*), and molasses (*phāṇita*).

"Thus, there were the four assenting groups (*anumatipakkhā*), and King *Mahāvijita* was endowed (*samannāgato*) with eight qualities (*aṭṭhahaṅgehi*), and the chaplain *brāhmaṇa* was endowed (*samannāgato*) with four qualities (*catūhaṅgehi*); this, O Brahmin, is called the threefold successful sacrifice (*tividhā yaññasampadā*) with sixteen accessories (*soḷasaparikkhārā*)."
commentary_pali: 347.Puratthimenayaññavāṭassāti puratthimato nagaradvāre dānasālāya puratthimabhāge. Yathā puratthimadisato āgacchantā khattiyānaṃ dānasālāya yāguṃ pivitvā rañño dānasālāya bhuñjitvā nagaraṃ pavisanti. Evarūpe ṭhāne paṭṭhapesuṃ. Dakkhiṇena yaññavāṭassāti dakkhiṇato nagaradvāre dānasālāya vuttanayeneva dakkhiṇabhāge paṭṭhapesuṃ. Pacchimuttaresupi eseva nayo.
commentary_english:
347. *Puratthimenayaññavāṭassa* means on the eastern side of the *dāna-sālā* (alms-hall) at the eastern city gate.

Just as those coming from the eastern direction, after drinking rice-gruel at the *dāna-sālā* for the *khattiyas* (warriors), and after eating at the king's *dāna-sālā*, enter the city.

They established (it) in such a place.

*Dakkhiṇena yaññavāṭassa* means they established (it) on the southern side of the *dāna-sālā* at the southern city gate, according to the same method as stated above.

The same rule (*nayo*) applies also to the west and north.

mula_pali: 348. Evaṃ vutte, te brāhmaṇā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṃ – ‘‘aho yañño, aho yaññasampadā’’ti! Kūṭadanto pana brāhmaṇo tūṇhībhūtova nisinno hoti. Atha kho te brāhmaṇā kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ – ‘‘kasmā pana bhavaṃ kūṭadanto samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodatī’’ti? ‘‘Nāhaṃ, bho, samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodāmi. Muddhāpi tassa vipateyya, yo samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyya. Api ca me, bho, evaṃ hoti – samaṇo gotamo na evamāha – ‘evaṃ me suta’nti vā ‘evaṃ arahati bhavitu’nti vā; api ca samaṇo gotamo – ‘evaṃ tadā āsi, itthaṃ tadā āsi’ tveva bhāsati. Tassa mayhaṃ bho evaṃ hoti – ‘addhā samaṇo gotamo tena samayena rājā vā ahosi mahāvijito yaññassāmi purohito vā brāhmaṇo tassa yaññassa yājetā’ti. Abhijānāti pana bhavaṃ gotamo evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ yajitvā vā  yājetvā vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjitāti’’? ‘‘Abhijānāmahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ yajitvā vā yājetvā vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjitā, ahaṃ tena samayena purohito brāhmaṇo ahosiṃ tassa yaññassa yājetā’’ti.
mula_english:
348.

When this was said, those Brahmins were shouting, making a great noise and a loud noise, saying, "Oh, the sacrifice! Oh, the success of the sacrifice!" But the Brahmin Kūṭadanta was sitting silently.

Then those Brahmins said to the Brahmin Kūṭadanta, "Why, sir, does the esteemed Kūṭadanta not applaud the well-spoken words of the ascetic Gotama?" "I, sirs, do not applaud the well-spoken words of the ascetic Gotama.

The head of anyone who would not applaud the well-spoken words of the ascetic Gotama would fall off.

But it strikes me, sirs, that the ascetic Gotama does not say: ‘I have heard this,’ or ‘It should have been like this’; but the ascetic Gotama says: ‘It was like this at that time, it was like that at that time.’"

And so it seems to me, sirs, that the ascetic Gotama must have been at that time either King Mahāvijita, the lord of the sacrifice, or else the *brāhmaṇa* chaplain ( *purohita brāhmaṇa*) who conducted the sacrifice for him.

"Does the esteemed Gotama remember performing or having performed a sacrifice of such a kind, that after the body's dissolution, after death, one is reborn in a good destination, a heavenly world ( *sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ* )?" "I do remember, Brahmin, performing or having performed a sacrifice of such a kind, that after the body's dissolution, after death, one is reborn in a good destination, a heavenly world; I was at that time the *brāhmaṇa* chaplain ( *purohito brāhmaṇaḥ* ) who conducted that sacrifice."
commentary_pali: 348.Aho yañño, aho yaññasampadāti brāhmaṇā sappiādīhi niṭṭhānagamanaṃ sutvā – ‘‘yaṃ loke madhuraṃ, tadeva samaṇo gotamo katheti, handassa yaññaṃ pasaṃsāmā’’ti tuṭṭhacittā pasaṃsamānā evamāhaṃsu. Tuṇhībhūtova nisinno hotīti upari vattabbamatthaṃ cintayamāno nissaddova nisinno hoti. Abhijānāti pana bhavaṃ gotamoti idaṃ brāhmaṇo parihārena pucchanto āha. Itarathā hi – ‘‘kiṃ pana tvaṃ, bho gotama, tadā rājā ahosi, udāhu purohito brāhmaṇo’’ti evaṃ ujukameva pucchayamāno agāravo viya hoti.
commentary_english:
348. "Oh, what a sacrifice! Oh, what a successful sacrifice!" Thus, the *brāhmaṇas*, hearing of the completion with ghee and so on, with delighted minds, praising, said thus: "That which is sweet in the world, the ascetic Gotama speaks of that very thing. Come, let us praise the sacrifice!"

Thinking, "He is sitting as if he has become silent," he sits silently, considering what further needs to be said.

"Does the esteemed Gotama recognize...?" Thus, the *brāhmaṇa* asked with circumlocution.

Otherwise, indeed, asking directly, "Well then, Gotama, were you the king then, or the family priest, a *brāhmaṇa*?" he would be as if disrespectful.

mula_pali: 349. ‘‘Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya tividhayaññasampadāya (ka.) soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro appatthataro (syā. kaṃ.) ca appasamārambhataro appasamārabbhataro (sī. pī. ka.) ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Atthi  kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti. ‘‘Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya  appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Yāni kho pana tāni, brāhmaṇa, niccadānāni anukulayaññāni sīlavante pabbajite uddissa diyyanti; ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti. ‘‘Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo, yena taṃ niccadānaṃ anukulayaññaṃ imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcā’’ti ? ‘‘Na kho, brāhmaṇa, evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā. Taṃ kissa hetu? Dissanti hettha, brāhmaṇa, daṇḍappahārāpi galaggahāpi, tasmā evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ na upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā. Yāni kho pana tāni, brāhmaṇa, niccadānāni anukulayaññāni sīlavante pabbajite uddissa diyyanti; evarūpaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā. Taṃ kissa hetu? Na hettha, brāhmaṇa, dissanti daṇḍappahārāpi galaggahāpi, tasmā evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena taṃ niccadānaṃ anukulayaññaṃ imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcā’’ti.
mula_english:
‘And, Reverend Gotama, is there any other sacrifice ( *yajña*) that is simpler, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold sacrifice (*tividha-yajña-sampadā*) with its sixteen attributes (*ṣoḷasa-parikkhārāya*)?’

‘There is, Brahmin, another sacrifice (*yajña*) that is simpler, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold sacrifice (*tividha-yajña-sampadā*) with its sixteen attributes (*ṣoḷasa-parikkhārāya*).’

‘What is it, Reverend Gotama, that sacrifice (*yajña*) which is simpler, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold sacrifice (*tividha-yajña-sampadā*) with its sixteen attributes (*ṣoḷasa-parikkhārāya*)?’

‘Those regular gifts (*nicca-dānāni*) and appropriate sacrifices (*anukula-yajñāni*) that are given specifically to virtuous renunciates (*śīlavante pravrajite*), that sacrifice (*yajña*) is simpler, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold sacrifice (*tividha-yajña-sampadā*) with its sixteen attributes (*ṣoḷasa-parikkhārāya*).’

‘But why, Reverend Gotama, what is the reason, what is the cause, that those regular gifts (*nicca-dānaṃ*) and appropriate sacrifices (*anukula-yajñaṃ*) are simpler, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold sacrifice (*tividha-yajña-sampadāya*) with its sixteen attributes (*ṣoḷasa-parikkhārāya*)?’

‘Brahmin, *arhats* or those who have attained the path to *arhatship* do not attend sacrifices (*yajñaṃ*) of that kind.

Why is that? Because there, Brahmin, beatings with sticks (*daṇḍa-pahārāpi*) and seizing by the throat (*galaggahāpi*) are seen. Therefore, *arhats* or those who have attained the path to *arhatship* do not attend sacrifices (*yajñaṃ*) of that kind.

Those regular gifts (*nicca-dānāni*) and appropriate sacrifices (*anukula-yajñāni*) that are given specifically to virtuous renunciates (*śīlavante pravrajite*), *arhats* or those who have attained the path to *arhatship* attend sacrifices (*yajñaṃ*) of that kind.

Why is that? Because there, Brahmin, beatings with sticks (*daṇḍa-pahārāpi*) and seizing by the throat (*galaggahāpi*) are not seen. Therefore, *arhats* or those who have attained the path to *arhatship* attend sacrifices (*yajñaṃ*) of that kind.

This, Brahmin, is the reason (*hetu*), this is the cause (*pratyayo*), why those regular gifts (*nicca-dānaṃ*) and appropriate sacrifices (*anukula-yajñaṃ*) are simpler, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold sacrifice (*tividha-yajña-sampadāya*) with its sixteen attributes (*ṣoḷasa-parikkhārāya*).’
commentary_pali: 349.Atthi pana, bho gotamāti – idaṃ brāhmaṇo ‘‘sakalajambudīpavāsīnaṃ uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya dānaṃ nāma dātuṃ garukaṃ sakalajanapado ca attano kammāni akaronto nassissati, atthi nu kho amhākampi imamhā yaññā añño yañño appasamārambhataro ceva mahapphalataro cā’’ti etamatthaṃ pucchanto āha. Niccadānānīti dhuvadānāni niccabhattāni. Anukulayaññānīti – ‘‘amhākaṃ pitupitāmahādīhi pavattitānī’’ti katvā pacchā duggatapurisehipi vaṃsaparamparāya pavattetabbāni yāgāni, evarūpāni kira sīlavante uddissa nibaddhadānāni tasmiṃ kule daliddāpi na upacchindanti. Tatridaṃvatthu – anāthapiṇḍikassa kira ghare pañca niccabhattasatāni dīyiṃsu. Dantamayasalākāni pañcasatāni ahesuṃ. Atha taṃ kulaṃ anukkamena dāliddiyena abhibhūtaṃ, ekā tasmiṃ kule dārikā ekasalākato uddhaṃ dātuṃ nāsakkhi. Sāpi pacchā setavāhanarajjaṃ gantvā khalaṃ sodhetvā laddhadhaññena taṃ salākaṃ adāsi. Eko thero rañño  ārocesi. Rājā taṃ  ānetvā aggamahesiṭṭhāne ṭhapesi. Sā tato paṭṭhāya puna pañcapi salākabhattasatāni pavattesi. Daṇḍappahārāti – ‘‘paṭipāṭiyā tiṭṭhatha tiṭṭhathā’’ti ujuṃ gantvā gaṇhatha gaṇhathāti ca ādīni vatvā dīyamānā daṇḍappahārāpi galaggāhāpi dissanti. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu…pe… mahānisaṃsatarañcāti. Ettha yasmā mahāyaññe viya imasmiṃ salākabhatte na bahūhi veyyāvaccakarehi vā upakaraṇehi vā attho atthi, tasmā etaṃ appaṭṭhataraṃ. Yasmā cettha na bahūnaṃ kammacchedavasena pīḷāsaṅkhāto samārambho atthi, tasmā appasamārambhataraṃ. Yasmā cetaṃ saṅghassa yiṭṭhaṃ pariccattaṃ, tasmā yaññanti vuttaṃ, yasmā pana chaḷaṅgasamannāgatāya dakkhiṇāya mahāsamudde udakasseva na sukaraṃ puññābhisandassa pamāṇaṃ kātuṃ, idañca tathāvidhaṃ. Tasmā taṃ mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcāti veditabbaṃ. Idaṃ sutvā brāhmaṇo cintesi – idampi niccabhattaṃ uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya dadato divase divase ekassa kammaṃ nassati. Navanavo ussāho ca janetabbo hoti, atthi nu kho itopi añño yañño appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro cāti. Tasmā ‘‘atthi pana, bho gotamā’’tiādimāha. Tattha yasmā salākabhatte kiccapariyosānaṃ natthi, ekena uṭṭhāya samuṭṭhāya aññaṃ kammaṃ akatvā saṃvidhātabbameva. Vihāradāne pana kiccapariyosānaṃ atthi. Paṇṇasālaṃ vā hi kāretuṃ koṭidhanaṃ vissajjetvā mahāvihāraṃ vā, ekavāraṃ dhanapariccāgaṃ katvā kāritaṃ sattaṭṭhavassānipi vassasatampi vassasahassampi gacchatiyeva. Kevalaṃ jiṇṇapatitaṭṭhāne paṭisaṅkharaṇamattameva kātabbaṃ  hoti. Tasmā idaṃ vihāradānaṃ salākabhattato appaṭṭhataraṃ appasamārambhatarañca hoti. Yasmā panettha suttantapariyāyena yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāyāti ādayo navānisaṃsā vuttā, khandhakapariyāyena. Sattarasānisaṃsā vuttā. Tasmā etaṃ salākabhattato mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcāti veditabbaṃ. Saṅghassa pana pariccattattāva yaññoti vuccati. Idampi sutvā brāhmaṇo cintesi – ‘‘dhanapariccāgaṃ katvā vihāradānaṃ  nāma dukkaraṃ, attano santakā hi kākaṇikāpi parassa duppariccajā, handāhaṃ itopi appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca yaññaṃ pucchāmī’’ti. Tato taṃ pucchanto – ‘‘atthi pana bho’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
349.

"But sir, Gotama," thus began the Brahman, inquiring, "Is giving a gift by rising up and making an effort so difficult for those dwelling in all of Jambudvīpa that the entire populace, not doing their own work, will perish? Is there any other sacrifice that is less elaborate and more fruitful than this sacrifice?"

*Niccadānāni* means continuous giving, constant food.

*Anukulayaññāni* means sacrifices that are perpetuated by one's fathers, grandfathers, and so on, and which should be continued in lineage by even poor men. It seems that in such families, even the poor do not cut off these regular gifts dedicated to the virtuous.

Here is a story: It seems that in Anāthapiṇḍika's house, five hundred continuous food offerings were given.

There were five hundred ivory toothpicks.

Then, that family was gradually overcome by poverty, and one girl in that family was unable to give even a single toothpick.

Later, she went to the kingdom of Setavāhana, threshed the grain, and with the grain she obtained, she gave that toothpick.

One elder (thera) announced it to the king.

The king brought her and placed her in the position of chief queen (*aggamahesi*).

From then on, she again established five hundred toothpick food offerings.

*Daṇḍappahārā* means, saying things like, "Stand in order! Stand in order!" and "Go straight and take! Take!" whippings and seizing by the neck are seen being given.

This, Brahman, is the reason…pe… and more greatly beneficial.

Here, since in this toothpick-food-offering, unlike in a great sacrifice, there is no need for many assistants or equipment, therefore this is less elaborate.

Since here there is no disturbance, reckoned as oppression, due to the cutting off of the work of many, therefore it is less troublesome.

And since this is sacrificed and given to the *saṃgha*, therefore it is called a sacrifice (*yañña*). Furthermore, since it is not easy to measure the abundance of merit from a donation endowed with six qualities, like the water in the great ocean, and this is of such a kind,

therefore it should be known as more fruitful and more greatly beneficial.

Having heard this, the Brahman thought: "Even with this continuous food offering, the work of one is destroyed day by day by rising up and making an effort to give.

And a fresh, new effort must be generated. Is there any other sacrifice that is less elaborate and less troublesome than this?"

Therefore, he said, "Sir, is there," and so on.

There, since in the toothpick-food-offering there is no end to the task, having risen up and made an effort, one must manage it without doing any other work.

But in the giving of a *vihāra*, there is an end to the task.

For having spent a koṭi of wealth to build a leaf hut or a great *vihāra*, having made a donation of wealth once, it goes on for seven or eight years, even a hundred years, even a thousand years.

Only a repair of the dilapidated places has to be done.

Therefore, this giving of a *vihāra* is less elaborate and less troublesome than the toothpick-food-offering.

Furthermore, here, by way of the Sūtra, nine benefits beginning with "just for the warding off of cold" are stated, and by way of the *Khandhaka*,

seventeen benefits are stated.

Therefore, it should be known that this is more fruitful and more greatly beneficial than the toothpick-food-offering.

Indeed, it is called a sacrifice (*yañña*) simply because of being relinquished to the *saṃgha*.

Having heard this also, the Brahman thought: "Having made a relinquishment of wealth, giving a *vihāra* is difficult, for even a *kākaṇikā* belonging to oneself is difficult to relinquish to another. Come, let me ask about a sacrifice that is even less elaborate and less troublesome than this."

Then, inquiring of him, he said, "Sir, is there," and so on.

mula_pali: 350. ‘‘Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro  ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Atthi  kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti. ‘‘Katamo  pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ uddissa vihāraṃ karoti, ayaṃ kho , brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti.
mula_english:
‘But, Reverend Gotama, is there any other sacrifice (*yajña*) that is more profitable than either of these, with this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yaññasampadā*), with these sixteen accessories (*soḷasaparikkhārāya*), with this constant giving (*niccadānena*), with this continuous sacrifice (*anukulayaññena*) , less troublesome, more fruitful, and of greater benefit?’

’ ‘There is, Brahmin, another sacrifice (*yajña*) more profitable than either of these, with this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yaññasampadā*), with these sixteen accessories (*soḷasaparikkhārāya*), with this constant giving (*niccadānena*), with this continuous sacrifice (*anukulayaññena*) , less troublesome, more fruitful, and of greater benefit.’

‘But, Reverend Gotama, which sacrifice (*yajña*) is more profitable than either of these, with this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yaññasampadā*), with these sixteen accessories (*soḷasaparikkhārāya*), with this constant giving (*niccadānena*), with this continuous sacrifice (*anukulayaññena*) , less troublesome, more fruitful, and of greater benefit?’

’ ‘Brahmin, if anyone provides shelter (*vihāraṃ*) for the *Saṅgha* coming from the four quarters (*cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ uddissa*), that constitutes a more profitable sacrifice (*yajña*) than either of these, with this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yaññasampadā*), with these sixteen accessories (*soḷasaparikkhārāya*), with this constant giving (*niccadānena*), with this continuous sacrifice (*anukulayaññena*) , less troublesome, more fruitful, and of greater benefit.’
commentary_pali: 350-351. Tattha yasmā sakiṃ pariccattepi vihāre punappunaṃ chādanakhaṇḍaphullappaṭisaṅkharaṇādivasena kiccaṃ atthiyeva, saraṇaṃ pana ekabhikkhussa vā santike saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā sakiṃ gahitaṃ gahitameva hoti, natthi tassa punappunaṃ kattabbatā, tasmā taṃ vihāradānato appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca hoti. Yasmā ca saraṇagamanaṃ nāma tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ jīvitapariccāgamayaṃ puññakammaṃ saggasampattiṃ deti, tasmā mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcāti veditabbaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ pana ratanānaṃ jīvitapariccāgavasena yaññoti vuccati.
commentary_english:
350-351.
