There, since even in a monastery that has been once given away, there is still work to be done again and again in the way of repairing roofs, broken parts, flowers, and so on, but a refuge, once taken by a single *bhikṣu* or near the *saṃgha* or the *gaṇa*, is taken once and for all; there is no need to take it again and again; therefore, that [taking refuge] is less troublesome and less laborious than the gift of a monastery.

And since taking refuge, which is called meritorious action (*puṇyakarma*) consisting of the giving up of life to the three jewels (*ratna*), gives heavenly success (*svargasampatti*), therefore it should be understood as having a greater result (*mahāphalatara*) and being more beneficial (*mahānisaṃsatara*).

Moreover, the sacrifice (*yajña*) consisting of giving up life to the three jewels (*ratna*) is spoken of.

mula_pali: 351. ‘‘Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti. ‘‘Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, pasannacitto buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchati; ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena appaṭṭhataro  ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti.
mula_english:
351.
“But, venerable Gotama, is there any other sacrifice that is superior to this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yaññasampadā), with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhāra), this constant giving (niccadāna), this continuous sacrifice (anukulayañña), and this gift of a monastery (vihāradāna)—one that is less troublesome, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial?”

“There is, Brahmin, another sacrifice that is superior to this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yaññasampadā), with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhāra), this constant giving (niccadāna), this continuous sacrifice (anukulayañña), and this gift of a monastery (vihāradāna)—one that is less troublesome, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial.”

“But what is that sacrifice, venerable Gotama, that is superior to this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yaññasampadā), with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhāra), this constant giving (niccadāna), this continuous sacrifice (anukulayañña), and this gift of a monastery (vihāradāna)—one that is less troublesome, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial?”

“Brahmin, if anyone with a serene mind goes for refuge to the Buddha, goes for refuge to the Dharma, and goes for refuge to the Sangha, that sacrifice is superior to this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yaññasampadā), with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhāra), this constant giving (niccadāna), this continuous sacrifice (anukulayañña), and this gift of a monastery (vihāradāna)—one that is less troublesome, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial.”
commentary_pali: 350-351. Tattha yasmā sakiṃ pariccattepi vihāre punappunaṃ chādanakhaṇḍaphullappaṭisaṅkharaṇādivasena kiccaṃ atthiyeva, saraṇaṃ pana ekabhikkhussa vā santike saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā sakiṃ gahitaṃ gahitameva hoti, natthi tassa punappunaṃ kattabbatā, tasmā taṃ vihāradānato appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca hoti. Yasmā ca saraṇagamanaṃ nāma tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ jīvitapariccāgamayaṃ puññakammaṃ saggasampattiṃ deti, tasmā mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañcāti veditabbaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ pana ratanānaṃ jīvitapariccāgavasena yaññoti vuccati.
commentary_english:
350-351.
Since, even after a monastery (*vihāra*) has been once given away, there is still need for repeated tasks such as repairing the roof, broken parts, flowers, and so on; while taking refuge (*śaraṇa*) once, either near a single *bhikṣu*, or the *saṅgha*, or a group (*gaṇa*), is simply to have taken it, there is no repeated duty in that. Therefore, that [taking refuge] is less established and involves less undertaking than the giving of a monastery.
And since going for refuge (*śaraṇagamana*), which is a meritorious action (*puṇyakarma*) consisting of giving up one's life to the three jewels (*tri-ratna*), gives heavenly success (*svargasampatti*), therefore, it should be understood as having a greater result (*mahāphala*) and a greater reward (*mahānisaṃsa*).
Moreover, [the act of] sacrifice (*yajña*) is called [the act of] giving up one's life to the three jewels (*tri-ratna*).

mula_pali: 352. ‘‘Atthi  pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Atthi  kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti. ‘‘Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, pasannacitto sikkhāpadāni samādiyati – pāṇātipātā veramaṇiṃ, adinnādānā veramaṇiṃ, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiṃ, musāvādā veramaṇiṃ, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā veramaṇiṃ. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño  imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti.
mula_english:
“But, Reverend Gotama, is there another sacrifice (yajña) that is superior, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yajñasampadā), along with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhārāya), this constant giving (niccadānena), the sacrifice to the lineage (anukulayaññena), this gift of a monastery (vihāradānena), and these going for refuge (saraṇagamanehi)?”

“There is, Brahmin, another sacrifice (yajña) that is superior, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yajñasampadā), along with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhārāya), this constant giving (niccadānena), the sacrifice to the lineage (anukulayaññena), this gift of a monastery (vihāradānena), and these going for refuge (saraṇagamanehi).”

“But what, Reverend Gotama, is that sacrifice (yajña) that is superior, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yajñasampadā), along with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhārāya), this constant giving (niccadānena), the sacrifice to the lineage (anukulayaññena), this gift of a monastery (vihāradānena), and these going for refuge (saraṇagamanehi)?”

“That sacrifice, Brahmin, is when one, with a serene mind, undertakes the precepts of training (sikkhāpadāni), refraining from killing living beings (pāṇātipātā veramaṇiṃ), refraining from taking what is not given (adinnādānā veramaṇiṃ), refraining from sexual misconduct (kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiṃ), refraining from false speech (musāvādā veramaṇiṃ), refraining from intoxicants that cause negligence (surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā veramaṇiṃ).”

“This, Brahmin, is the sacrifice (yajña) that is superior, less elaborate, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (yajñasampadā), along with its sixteen accessories (soḷasaparikkhārāya), this constant giving (niccadānena), the sacrifice to the lineage (anukulayaññena), this gift of a monastery (vihāradānena), and these going for refuge (saraṇagamanehi).”
commentary_pali: 352. Idaṃ  sutvā brāhmaṇo cintesi – ‘‘attano jīvitaṃ nāma parassa pariccajituṃ dukkaraṃ, atthi nu kho itopi appaṭṭhataro yañño’’ti tato taṃ pucchanto puna ‘‘atthi pana, bho gotamā’’tiādimāha. Tattha pāṇātipātā veramaṇītiādīsu veramaṇī nāma virati. Sā tividhā hoti – sampattavirati, samādānavirati setughātaviratīti. Tattha yo sikkhāpadāni agahetvāpi kevalaṃ attano jātigottakulāpadesādīni anussaritvā – ‘‘na me idaṃ patirūpa’’nti  pāṇātipātādīni na karoti, sampattavatthuṃ pariharati. Tato ārakā viramati. Tassa sā virati sampattaviratīti veditabbā. ‘‘Ajjatagge jīvitahetupi pāṇaṃ na hanāmī’’ti vā ‘‘pāṇātipātā viramāmī’’ti vā ‘‘veramaṇiṃ samādiyāmī’’ti vā evaṃ sikkhāpadāni gaṇhantassa pana virati samādānaviratīti veditabbā. Ariyasāvakānaṃ pana maggasampayuttā virati setughātavirati nāma. Tattha purimā dve viratiyo yaṃ voropanādivasena vītikkamitabbaṃ jīvitindriyādivatthu, taṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattanti. Pacchimā nibbānārammaṇāva. Ettha ca yo pañca sikkhāpadāni ekato gaṇhati, tassa ekasmiṃ bhinne sabbāni bhinnāni honti. Yo ekekaṃ gaṇhati, so yaṃ vītikkamati, tadeva  bhijjati. Setughātaviratiyā pana bhedo nāma natthi, bhavantarepi hi ariyasāvako jīvitahetupi neva pāṇaṃ hanati na suraṃ pivati. Sacepissa surañca khīrañca missetvā mukhe pakkhipanti, khīrameva pavisati, na surā. Yathā kiṃ? Koñcasakuṇānaṃ khīramissake udake khīrameva pavisati? Na udakaṃ. Idaṃ yonisiddhanti ce, idaṃ dhammatāsiddhanti ca veditabbaṃ. Yasmā pana saraṇagamane diṭṭhiujukakaraṇaṃ nāma bhāriyaṃ. Sikkhāpadasamādāne pana viratimattakameva. Tasmā etaṃ yathā vā tathā vā gaṇhantassāpi sādhukaṃ gaṇhantassāpi appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca. Pañcasīlasadisassa pana dānassa abhāvato ettha mahapphalatā mahānisaṃsatā ca veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ – Idañca pana sīlapañcakaṃ – ‘‘attasinehañca jīvitasinehañca pariccajitvā rakkhissāmī’’ti samādinnatāya yaññoti vuccati. Tattha kiñcāpi pañcasīlato saraṇagamanameva jeṭṭhakaṃ, idaṃ pana saraṇagamaneyeva patiṭṭhāya rakkhitasīlavasena mahapphalanti vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
352. Having heard this, the *brāhmaṇa* thought, "Indeed, it is difficult to give up one's own life for another. Is there a sacrifice (*yajña*) that is even less demanding than this?" Then, asking him, he further said, "Is there, venerable *Gautama*?" and so forth.

There, in the context of refraining from killing living beings (*prāṇātipātā veramaṇī*) etc., *veramaṇī* means abstinence (*virati*).

It is of three kinds: abstinence in the presence of opportunity (*sampattavirati*), abstinence because of an undertaking (*samādānavirati*), and abstinence because of eradication (*setughātavirati*).

There, someone who, even without taking the training precepts (*śikṣāpadāni*), simply recalling their own birth, lineage, family, pretext, etc., does not commit killing living beings (*prāṇātipātādīni*), [thinking,] "This is not proper for me," avoids the occasion for it (*sampattavatthuṃ pariharati*).

From that, one abstains (*viramati*) from evil.

That abstinence (*virati*) of his should be understood as abstinence in the presence of opportunity (*sampattaviratīti veditabbā*).

For one undertaking the training precepts (*śikṣāpadāni*), [saying,] "From today onward, even for the sake of my life, I will not kill a living being (*prāṇaṃ na hanāmi*)," or "I abstain from killing living beings (*prāṇātipātā viramāmī*)," or "I undertake abstinence (*veramaṇiṃ samādiyāmī*)," the abstinence (*virati*) should be understood as abstinence because of an undertaking (*samādānaviratīti veditabbā*).

Furthermore, for noble disciples (*ariyasāvakānaṃ*), the abstinence (*virati*) associated with the path (*maggasampayuttā*) is called abstinence because of eradication (*setughātavirati nāma*).

There, the former two kinds of abstinence (*viratiyo*) occur by making as their object (*ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattanti*) the things—such as the life faculty (*jīvitindriya*)—that should be transgressed by means of depriving them, etc. (*voropanādivasena vītikkamitabbaṃ*).

The latter has only *nirvāṇa* as its object (*nibbānārammaṇāva*).

And here, if someone takes the five training precepts (*pañca sikkhāpadāni*) together (*ekato gaṇhati*), when one is broken (*ekasmiṃ bhinne*), all are broken (*sabbāni bhinnāni honti*).

One who takes them individually (*ekekaṃ gaṇhati*), that which he transgresses (*yaṃ vītikkamati*), only that is broken (*tadeva bhijjati*).

But for abstinence because of eradication (*setughātaviratiyā*), there is no breaking (*bhedo nāma natthi*). For even in another existence (*bhavantarepi hi*), a noble disciple (*ariyasāvako*), even for the sake of his life (*jīvitahetupi*), neither kills a living being (*pāṇaṃ hanati*) nor drinks intoxicants (*suraṃ pivati*).

If they mix intoxicants (*surañca*) and milk (*khīrañca*) and put it in his mouth (*mukhe pakkhipanti*), only the milk (*khīrameva*) enters, not the intoxicants (*na surā*).

Like what? For *koñca* birds, in water mixed with milk (*khīramissake udake*), only the milk (*khīrameva*) enters, not the water (*na udakaṃ*).

If this [is] accomplished by skillful means (*yonisiddhanti ce*), this should also be understood as accomplished by the nature of things (*idaṃ dhammatāsiddhanti ca veditabbaṃ*).

Since, furthermore, in going for refuge (*saraṇagamane*), straightening views (*diṭṭhiujukakaraṇaṃ*) is weighty (*bhāriyaṃ nāma*).

In undertaking the training precepts (*śikṣāpadasamādāne*), however, there is only a mere abstaining (*viratimattakameva*).

Therefore, even for one who takes it casually (*yathā vā tathā vā gaṇhantassāpi*), and even for one who takes it seriously (*sādhukaṃ gaṇhantassāpi*), it is both less demanding (*appaṭṭhatarañca*) and less involving of effort (*appasamārambhatarañca*).

Furthermore, because of the absence (*abhāvato*) of a donation (*dānassa*) like the five precepts (*pañcasīlasadisassa*), great fruitfulness (*mahapphalatā*) and great benefit (*mahānisaṃsatā*) should be understood here (*ettha veditabbā*).

And it has been said that this group of five precepts (*idañca pana sīlapañcakaṃ*) is called a sacrifice (*yañño*) because of its being undertaken (*samādinnatāya*), [thinking,] "Having given up affection for myself (*attasinehañca*) and affection for my life (*jīvitasinehañca*), I will protect [them] (*rakkhissāmi*)."

There, although going for refuge (*saraṇagamanameva*) is superior to the five precepts (*pañcasīlato kiñcāpi*), it has been said that this [five precepts], by means of maintaining the precepts (*rakkhitasīlavasena*) while relying on going for refuge itself (*saraṇagamaneyeva patiṭṭhāya*), is of great fruit (*mahapphalanti vuttaṃ*).

mula_pali: 353. ‘‘Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi imehi ca sikkhāpadehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca saraṇagamanehi imehi ca sikkhāpadehi appaṭṭhataro  ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti. ‘‘Katamo  pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena iminā ca vihāradānena imehi ca  saraṇagamanehi imehi ca sikkhāpadehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cā’’ti? ‘‘Idha, brāhmaṇa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho…pe… (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu, evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Ayaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro  ca…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro cāti. Ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe… ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro ca…pe…  nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti. Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño purimehi yaññehi appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṃsataro ca. Imāya ca, brāhmaṇa, yaññasampadāya aññā yaññasampadā uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā natthī’’ti.
mula_english:
353.
“But, Reverend Gotama, is there any sacrifice (*yajña*) that is more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yajñasampadā*) with its sixteen accessories, this constant giving, this ancestral sacrifice (*anukulayañña*), this gift of a monastery (*vihāradāna*), these going for refuge (*saraṇagamana*), and these precepts (*śikṣāpada*)?”

“There is, Brahmin, another sacrifice (*yajña*) more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yajñasampadā*) with its sixteen accessories, this constant giving, this ancestral sacrifice (*anukulayañña*), this gift of a monastery (*vihāradāna*), these going for refuge (*saraṇagamana*), and these precepts (*śikṣāpada*).”

“Which sacrifice (*yajña*) is it, Reverend Gotama, that is more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than this threefold accomplishment of sacrifice (*yajñasampadā*) with its sixteen accessories, this constant giving, this ancestral sacrifice (*anukulayañña*), this gift of a monastery (*vihāradāna*), these going for refuge (*saraṇagamana*), and these precepts (*śikṣāpada*)?”

“Here, Brahmin, the *Tathāgata* arises in the world, an *Arhat*, a perfectly awakened Buddha…pe… (as in sections 190-212, so it should be explained in detail).

Thus, Brahmin, a monk is perfected in morality…pe… he attains to and abides in the first *jhāna*.

That, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (*yajña*) more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (*yajña*)…pe…the second *jhāna*…pe…the third *jhāna*…pe…he attains to and abides in the fourth *jhāna*.

That, too, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (*yajña*) more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (*yajña*).

He directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge and vision (ñāṇadassana)…pe…That, too, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (*yajña*) more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (*yajña*)…pe…he understands, ‘There is nothing further here.’

That, too, Brahmin, is a sacrifice (*yajña*) more excellent, less arduous, more fruitful, and more beneficial than the previous sacrifices (*yajña*).

And beyond this accomplishment of sacrifice (*yajñasampadā*), Brahmin, there is no other accomplishment of sacrifice (*yajñasampadā*) that is greater or more sublime.”
commentary_pali: 353. Idampi  sutvā brāhmaṇo cintesi – ‘‘pañcasīlaṃ nāma rakkhituṃ garukaṃ, atthi nu kho aññaṃ kiñci īdisameva hutvā ito appaṭṭhatarañca mahapphalatarañcā’’ti. Tato taṃ pucchanto punapi – ‘‘atthi pana, bho gotamā’’tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā tividhasīlapāripūriyaṃ ṭhitassa paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ yaññānaṃ appaṭṭhatarañca mahapphalatarañca dassetukāmo buddhuppādato paṭṭhāya desanaṃ ārabhanto ‘‘idha brāhmaṇā’’tiādimāha. Tattha yasmā heṭṭhā vuttehi guṇehi samannāgato paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ, paṭhamajjhānādīsu ṭhito dutiyajjhānādīni nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā tāni appaṭṭhāni appasamārambhāni. Yasmā panettha paṭhamajjhānaṃ ekaṃ kappaṃ brahmaloke āyuṃ deti. Dutiyaṃ aṭṭhakappe. Tatiyaṃ catusaṭṭhikappe. Catutthaṃ pañcakappasatāni. Tadeva ākāsānañcāyatanādisamāpattivasena  bhāvitaṃ vīsati, cattālīsaṃ, saṭṭhi, caturāsīti ca kappasahassāni āyuṃ deti; tasmā mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṃsatarañca. Nīvaraṇādīnaṃ pana paccanīkānaṃ dhammānaṃ pariccattattā taṃ yaññanti veditabbaṃ. Vipassanāñāṇampi yasmā catutthajjhānapariyosānesu guṇesu patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā appaṭṭhaṃ appasamārambhaṃ; vipassanāsukhasadisassa pana sukhassa abhāvā mahapphalaṃ. Paccanīkakilesapariccāgato yaññoti. Manomayiddhipi yasmā vipassanāñāṇe patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā appaṭṭhā appasamārambhā; attano sadisarūpanimmānasamatthatāya mahapphalā. Attano paccanīkakilesapariccāgato yañño. Iddhividhañāṇādīnipi yasmā manomayañāṇādīsu patiṭṭhāya nibbattento na kilamati, tasmā appaṭṭhāni appasamārambhāni, attano attano paccanīkakilesappahānato yañño. Iddhividhaṃ panettha nānāvidhavikubbanadassanasamatthatāya. Dibbasotaṃ devamanussānaṃ saddasavanasamatthatāya; cetopariyañāṇaṃ  paresaṃ soḷasavidhacittajānanasamatthatāya; pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ icchiticchitaṭṭhānasamanussaraṇasamatthatāya; dibbacakkhu icchiticchitarūpadassanasamatthatāya; āsavakkhayañāṇaṃ atipaṇītalokuttaramaggasukhanipphādanasamatthatāya mahapphalanti veditabbaṃ. Yasmā pana arahattato visiṭṭhataro añño yañño nāma natthi, tasmā arahattanikūṭeneva desanaṃ samāpento – ‘‘ayampi kho, brāhmaṇā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
353. Having heard this too, the *brāhmaṇa* thought, "The five precepts (*pañcasīlaṃ*) are difficult to maintain. Is there perhaps something else that is similar to this, but easier to undertake (*appaṭṭhatarañca*) and more fruitful (*mahapphalatarañca*)?"

Then, asking him, he said again, "But is there, Master Gotama...?" and so on.

Then the Blessed One, wishing to show him, who was established in the complete fulfillment of the threefold morality (*tividhasīlapāripūriyaṃ*), sacrifices such as the first absorption (*paṭhamajjhāna*) and so on, which are easier to undertake and more fruitful, beginning his teaching from the arising of a Buddha (*buddhuppādato paṭṭhāya*), said "Here, *brāhmaṇa*..." and so on.

There, since the first absorption (*paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ*), endowed with the qualities mentioned below, does not weary when producing the second absorption (*dutiyajjhāna*) and so on, while established in the first absorption and so on, therefore those are easy to undertake, requiring little effort (*appasamārambhāni*).

Since, moreover, here the first absorption gives life for one eon (*kappaṃ*) in the Brahma world (*brahmaloke*), the second eight eons, the third sixty-four eons, the fourth five hundred eons.

The same, developed as the attainment of the sphere of infinite space (*ākāsānañcāyatana*) and so on, gives life for twenty, forty, sixty, and eighty-four thousand eons; therefore it is more fruitful and of greater benefit.

But it should be understood that it is a sacrifice (*yaññanti veditabbaṃ*) because of the abandonment (*pariccattattā*) of opposing states such as the hindrances (*nīvaraṇādīnaṃ*).

Since insight knowledge (*vipassanāñāṇaṃ*), too, does not weary when producing [results] while established in the qualities at the end of the fourth absorption (*catutthajjhāna*), therefore it is easy to undertake, requiring little effort; but since there is no happiness like the happiness of insight, it is very fruitful.

It is a sacrifice because of the abandonment of opposing defilements (*paccanīkakilesapariccāgato*).

Since the mind-made power (*manomayiddhi*), too, does not weary when producing [results] while established in insight knowledge, therefore it is easy to undertake, requiring little effort; it is very fruitful because of the ability to create a form similar to oneself (*attano sadisarūpanimmānasamatthatāya*).

It is a sacrifice because of the abandonment of defilements opposing oneself.

Since the kinds of power knowledge (*iddhividhañāṇādīni*), too, do not weary when producing [results] while established in the mind-made knowledge and so on, therefore they are easy to undertake, requiring little effort, it is a sacrifice because of the abandonment of the defilements opposing oneself, one's own.

Here, power is the ability to show various transformations (*nānāvidhavikubbanadassanasamatthatāya*).

Divine hearing (*dibbasotaṃ*) is the ability to hear the sounds of gods and humans; knowledge of the minds of others (*cetopariyañāṇaṃ*) is the ability to know the sixteen kinds of minds of others; the recollection of former abodes (*pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ*) is the ability to remember places as one wishes; divine vision (*dibbacakkhu*) is the ability to see forms as one wishes; it should be understood that the knowledge of the destruction of the taints (*āsavakkhayañāṇaṃ*) is very fruitful because of the production of the most refined supramundane path happiness.

Since, however, there is no other sacrifice more excellent than arhatship (*arahattato visiṭṭhataro añño yañño nāma natthi*), therefore, concluding the teaching with the peak of arhatship, he said "This too, *brāhmaṇa*..." and so on.

mula_pali: 354. Evaṃ vutte, kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama! Seyyathāpi bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo  pakāsito. Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gataṃ. Esāhaṃ bho gotama  satta ca usabhasatāni satta ca vacchatarasatāni satta ca vacchatarīsatāni satta ca ajasatāni satta ca urabbhasatāni muñcāmi, jīvitaṃ demi, haritāni ceva tiṇāni khādantu, sītāni ca pānīyāni pivantu, sīto ca nesaṃ vāto upavāyatū’’ti.
mula_english:
354.
When this was said, the Brahmin Kūṭadanta said to the Blessed One: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent, Master Gotama! Just as, Master Gotama, one might turn upright what had been overthrown, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or hold up an oil lamp in the dark so that those with eyes might see forms; even so has the Dhamma (dharma) been made clear in many ways by Master Gotama.

I go to the esteemed Gotama for refuge (śaraṇaṃ gacchāmi), and to the Dhamma (dharma), and to the Sangha (saṃgha) of monks.

May the esteemed Gotama accept me as a lay follower (upāsakaṃ) who has gone for refuge (saraṇaṃ gataṃ) from this day forth, as long as life shall last.

And I, Reverend Gotama, release seven hundred bulls (usabhasatāni), seven hundred bullocks (vacchatarasatāni), seven hundred heifers (vacchatarīsatāni), seven hundred goats (ajasatāni), and seven hundred rams (urabbhasatāni). I grant them life, let them eat green grass (haritāni tiṇāni), and drink cool water (sītāni pānīyāni), and let a cool breeze blow upon them."
commentary_pali: 354-358.Evaṃvutteti evaṃ bhagavatā vutte desanāya pasīditvā saraṇaṃ gantukāmo kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo – ‘etaṃ abhikkantaṃ bho, gotamā’tiādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca. Upavāyatūti upagantvā sarīradarathaṃ nibbāpento tanusītalo vāto vāyatūti. Idañca pana vatvā brāhmaṇo purisaṃ pesesi – ‘‘gaccha, tāta, yaññavāṭaṃ pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayo bandhanā mocehī’’ti. So ‘‘sādhū’’ti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā ‘‘muttā bho, te pāṇayo’’ti ārocesi. Yāva  brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi, na tāva bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi. Kasmā? ‘‘Brāhmaṇassa citte ākulabhāvo atthī’’ti. Sutvā panassa ‘‘bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā’’ti cittacāro vippasīdati. Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā’’tiādi vuttaṃ. Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi ānupubbikathānubhāvena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
354-358.

*Evaṃvutteti:* Thus, when the Blessed One had spoken, Kuṭadanta the *brāhmaṇa*, pleased with the discourse and wishing to go for refuge, spoke these words, beginning with, "Excellent, Venerable Gotama."

*Upavāyatūti:* Approaching, may a cool, gentle breeze blow, allaying the heat of the body-chariot.

*Idañca pana vatvā:* And having said this, the *brāhmaṇa* sent a man, saying, "Go, dear one, enter the sacrificial ground and release all those creatures from their bonds."

*So ‘‘sādhū’’ti paṭissuṇitvā:* He, having agreed, saying "Very well," and having done so, came and announced, "The creatures are released, sir."

*Yāva brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi:* As long as the *brāhmaṇa* did not hear of that event, the Blessed One did not teach the *dharma*.

*Kasmā?:* Why? "Because there was agitation in the *brāhmaṇa*'s mind."

*Sutvā panassa ‘‘bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā’’ti cittacāro vippasīdati:* But having heard, the movement of his mind becomes clear, thinking, "Indeed, many beings have been freed by me."

*Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi:* The Blessed One, knowing his mind to be cleared and inclined, began the teaching of the *dharma*.

*Taṃ sandhāya:* Referring to that, it was said, "Then, indeed, the Blessed One..." etc.

*Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi:* Again, 'with a pliant mind,' etc., referring to the suppression of hindrances through the power of gradual discourse.

*Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti:* The rest is but clear.

mula_pali: 355. Atha kho bhagavā kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ, dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ; kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ  nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi. Yadā bhagavā aññāsi kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi – dukkhaṃ samudayaṃ nirodhaṃ maggaṃ. Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya, evameva  kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa tasmiññeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi – ‘‘yaṃ kiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma’’nti.
mula_english:
Then the Lord delivered a graduated discourse to Kūṭadanta the Brahmin, that is, talk on generosity (*dānakathā*), talk on morality (*śīlakathā*) and talk on heaven (*saggakatha*); showing the danger (*ādīnava*), degradation (*okāra*) and corruption (*saṃkilesa*) of sense-desires (*kāmānaṃ*), and the profit (*ānisaṃsa*) of renunciation (*nekkhamme*).

And when the Lord knew that Kūṭadanta the Brahmin's mind was ready (*kallacittaṃ*), pliable (*muducittaṃ*), free from the hindrances (*vinīvaraṇacittaṃ*), joyful (*udaggacittaṃ*) and calm (*pasannacittaṃ*), then he preached a sermon on Dhamma (*dhammadesanā*) in brief, which is unique to the Buddhas (*buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā*) : on suffering (*dukkhaṃ*), its origin (*samudayaṃ*), its cessation (*nirodhaṃ*), and the path (*maggaṃ*).

Just as a clean cloth from which all stains have been removed receives the dye perfectly, so in the Brahmin Kūṭadanta, as he sat there, there arose the pure and spotless *dhamma*-eye (*virajaṃ vītimalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ*), and he knew: ‘Whatever things have an origin (*samudayadhammaṃ*) must come to cessation (*nirodhadhammaṃ*).’
commentary_pali: 354-358.Evaṃvutteti evaṃ bhagavatā vutte desanāya pasīditvā saraṇaṃ gantukāmo kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo – ‘etaṃ abhikkantaṃ bho, gotamā’tiādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca. Upavāyatūti upagantvā sarīradarathaṃ nibbāpento tanusītalo vāto vāyatūti. Idañca pana vatvā brāhmaṇo purisaṃ pesesi – ‘‘gaccha, tāta, yaññavāṭaṃ pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayo bandhanā mocehī’’ti. So ‘‘sādhū’’ti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā ‘‘muttā bho, te pāṇayo’’ti ārocesi. Yāva  brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi, na tāva bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi. Kasmā? ‘‘Brāhmaṇassa citte ākulabhāvo atthī’’ti. Sutvā panassa ‘‘bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā’’ti cittacāro vippasīdati. Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā’’tiādi vuttaṃ. Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi ānupubbikathānubhāvena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
354-358.

*Evaṃvutteti*: Thus, when the Blessed One had spoken, Kuṭadanta the *brāhmaṇa*, pleased with the teaching and desiring to go for refuge, spoke the words beginning with "This is excellent, O Gotama."

*Upavāyatūti*: Approaching, may a thin, cool breeze blow, soothing the chariot of the body.

Having said this, the *brāhmaṇa* sent a man, saying, "Go, dear fellow, enter the sacrificial enclosure and release all those living beings from their bonds."

He, having agreed, saying "Good," and having done so, came and announced, "The living beings are released, sir."

As long as the *brāhmaṇa* did not hear of that event, the Blessed One did not teach the *dharma*.

Why? "Because there is a state of agitation in the *brāhmaṇa*'s mind."

Having heard it, the movement of his mind becomes very clear, thinking, "Many living beings have indeed been released by me."

The Blessed One, knowing that his mind was very clear and unbent, began the teaching of the *dharma*.

Referring to that, it was said, "Then, indeed, the Blessed One..." etc.

Furthermore, referring to the calming of the hindrances by the power of the graduated teaching, beginning with "pliant mind," it was said.

The rest is but clear.

mula_pali: 356. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṃkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’’ti. Adhivāsesi bhagavā tuṇhībhāvena.
mula_english:
Then the Brahman Kuṭadanta, having seen the Dharma, attained the Dharma, understood the Dharma, fathomed the Dharma, having crossed beyond doubt, having dispelled uncertainty, having attained confidence (*vaiśārajyapraptaḥ*), being independent of others in the Teacher’s Dispensation, said this to the Blessed One: "May the venerable Gotama accept tomorrow's meal from me, together with the community of monks (bhikkhusaṅgha)."

The Blessed One accepted by silence (*tuṇhībhāvena*).
commentary_pali: 354-358.Evaṃvutteti evaṃ bhagavatā vutte desanāya pasīditvā saraṇaṃ gantukāmo kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo – ‘etaṃ abhikkantaṃ bho, gotamā’tiādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca. Upavāyatūti upagantvā sarīradarathaṃ nibbāpento tanusītalo vāto vāyatūti. Idañca pana vatvā brāhmaṇo purisaṃ pesesi – ‘‘gaccha, tāta, yaññavāṭaṃ pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayo bandhanā mocehī’’ti. So ‘‘sādhū’’ti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā ‘‘muttā bho, te pāṇayo’’ti ārocesi. Yāva  brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi, na tāva bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi. Kasmā? ‘‘Brāhmaṇassa citte ākulabhāvo atthī’’ti. Sutvā panassa ‘‘bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā’’ti cittacāro vippasīdati. Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā’’tiādi vuttaṃ. Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi ānupubbikathānubhāvena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
354-358.
*Evaṃvutteti:* Thus, when the Blessed One had spoken, Kuṭadanta the *brāhmaṇa*, pleased with the teaching and desiring to go for refuge, spoke these words, beginning with, "This is excellent, Master Gotama."
*Upavāyatūti:* May a cool, gentle breeze blow, approaching and refreshing the chariot of the body.
Having said this, the *brāhmaṇa* sent a man, saying, "Go, dear one, enter the sacrificial enclosure and release all those beings from their bonds."
He, having agreed with "Good," and having done so, came and announced, "The beings have been released, sir."
As long as the *brāhmaṇa* had not heard of that event, the Blessed One did not teach the *dharma*.
Why? "Because there is a disturbed state of mind in the *brāhmaṇa's* mind."
Having heard it, however, the movement of his mind becomes very clear, thinking, "Many beings have been freed by me!"
The Blessed One, knowing that his mind was very clear and unbent, began the teaching of the *dharma*.
Referring to that, it was said, "Then, indeed, the Blessed One..."
Again, referring to the calming of hindrances through the power of the graduated teaching, beginning with 'pliant mind', it was said.
The rest is but clear.

mula_pali: 357. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo tassā rattiyā accayena sake yaññavāṭe paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi – ‘‘kālo, bho gotama; niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta’’nti.
mula_english:
Then, Kuṭadanta, the *brāhmaṇa*, knowing the Blessed One's acceptance (*adhivāsanaṃ viditvā*), rose from his seat, respectfully saluted the Blessed One (*bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā*), circumambulated him to the right (*padakkhiṇaṃ katvā*), and departed.

Then, at the end of that night, Kuṭadanta, the *brāhmaṇa*, had prepared exquisite food (*paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ*) at his sacrificial site (*yaññavāṭe*) and announced the time to the Blessed One: "It is time, Master Gotama; the meal is ready (*niṭṭhitaṃ bhatta*)."
commentary_pali: 354-358.Evaṃvutteti evaṃ bhagavatā vutte desanāya pasīditvā saraṇaṃ gantukāmo kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo – ‘etaṃ abhikkantaṃ bho, gotamā’tiādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca. Upavāyatūti upagantvā sarīradarathaṃ nibbāpento tanusītalo vāto vāyatūti. Idañca pana vatvā brāhmaṇo purisaṃ pesesi – ‘‘gaccha, tāta, yaññavāṭaṃ pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayo bandhanā mocehī’’ti. So ‘‘sādhū’’ti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā ‘‘muttā bho, te pāṇayo’’ti ārocesi. Yāva  brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi, na tāva bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi. Kasmā? ‘‘Brāhmaṇassa citte ākulabhāvo atthī’’ti. Sutvā panassa ‘‘bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā’’ti cittacāro vippasīdati. Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā’’tiādi vuttaṃ. Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi ānupubbikathānubhāvena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
354-358.
*Evaṃvutteti:* Thus, when the Blessed One had spoken, Kuṭadanta the Brahmin, pleased with the teaching and desiring to go for refuge, spoke the words beginning with, “This is excellent, O Gotama.”
*Upavāyatūti:* May a cool, gentle breeze blow, approaching and soothing the chariot of the body.
Having said this, the Brahmin sent a man, saying, “Go, dear fellow, enter the sacrificial enclosure and release all those creatures from their bonds!”
He agreed, saying, "Good," and having done so, he came and announced, "The creatures have been released, sir."
As long as the Brahmin had not heard of this event, the Blessed One did not teach the *dharma*.
Why? Because there was agitation in the Brahmin’s mind (*brāhmaṇassa citte ākulabhāvo atthīti*).
But having heard it, his mind became very clear, thinking, "Many lives have been freed by me!"
The Blessed One, knowing that his mind was very clear and unbent, began the teaching of the *dharma*.
With reference to that, it was said, "Then, indeed, the Blessed One..."
Furthermore, with reference to calming the hindrances through the power of the progressive discourse, beginning with ‘pliant mind’ (*kallacitta*), it was said.
The rest is but clear.

mula_pali: 358. Atha  kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa yaññavāṭo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo  buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi. Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho kūṭadantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
mula_english:
And then the Blessed One, having dressed in the morning, taking his bowl and robe, went together with the Saṅgha of monks to the sacrificial ground (yajñavāṭa) of the Brahmin Kūṭadanta; having arrived, he sat down on the prepared seat.

Then the Brahmin Kūṭadanta personally served the Saṅgha of monks, headed by the Buddha, with choice hard food (khādanīya) and soft food (bhojanīya) until they were satisfied.

And when the Lord had eaten and taken his hand from the bowl, the Brahmin Kūṭadanta took a low seat and sat down to one side.

Then the Lord, having instructed, roused, inspired, and gladdened the Brahmin Kūṭadanta, who was sitting to one side, with a Dhamma talk, rose from his seat and departed.

Upavāyatūti upagantvā sarīradarathaṃ nibbāpento tanusītalo vāto vāyatūti. Idañca pana vatvā brāhmaṇo purisaṃ pesesi – ‘‘gaccha, tāta, yaññavāṭaṃ pavisitvā sabbe te pāṇayo bandhanā mocehī’’ti. So ‘‘sādhū’’ti paṭissuṇitvā tathā katvā āgantvā ‘‘muttā bho, te pāṇayo’’ti ārocesi. Yāva  brāhmaṇo taṃ pavattiṃ na suṇi, na tāva bhagavā dhammaṃ desesi. Kasmā? ‘‘Brāhmaṇassa citte ākulabhāvo atthī’’ti. Sutvā panassa ‘‘bahū vata me pāṇā mocitā’’ti cittacāro vippasīdati. Bhagavā tassa vippasannamanataṃ ñatvā dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi. Taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā’’tiādi vuttaṃ. Puna ‘kallacitta’ntiādi ānupubbikathānubhāvena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
354-358.

*Evaṃvutteti*: Thus, when the Blessed One had spoken, Kuṭadanta the *brāhmaṇa*, pleased with the teaching and wishing to go for refuge, spoke the words beginning, "This is excellent, sir, Gotama."

*Upavāyatūti*: May a cool, gentle breeze blow, approaching and soothing the chariot of the body.

Having said this, the *brāhmaṇa* sent a man, saying, "Go, dear, enter the sacrificial enclosure and release all those living beings from their bonds."

He, having replied "Good," and having done so, came and announced, "The living beings are released, sir."

As long as the *brāhmaṇa* had not heard of that event, the Blessed One did not teach the Dharma.

Why? "Because there is agitation in the *brāhmaṇa*'s mind."

Having heard it, the movement of his mind becomes clear, thinking, "Many living beings have indeed been freed by me."

The Blessed One, knowing his mind to be clear and unbent, began the teaching of the Dharma.

With reference to that, the saying beginning "Then, indeed, the Blessed One" was spoken.

Furthermore, with reference to the calming of hindrances through the power of a graduated discourse, the saying beginning "pliant mind" was spoken.

The rest is clear in meaning.

mula_pali: 381. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruññāyaṃ ujuññāyaṃ (sī. syā. kaṃ. pī.) viharati kaṇṇakatthale migadāye. Atha kho acelo kassapo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama – ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī’ti. Ye te, bho gotama, evamāhaṃsu – ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī’ti, kacci te bhoto gotamassa vuttavādino, na ca bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchati? Anabbhakkhātukāmā hi mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotama’’nti.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was living at Uruññā, or Ujuññā (Sī., Syā., Kaṃ., Pī.) in the deer park of Kaṇṇakatthala.

Then the naked ascetic Kassapa approached the Blessed One, and exchanged greetings with him. After an exchange of friendly greetings and courtesies, he stood to one side.

Standing to one side, the naked ascetic Kassapa said to the Blessed One: "I have heard it said, Venerable Gotama, that 'The *śramaṇa* Gotama disparages all austerity (*tapas*), and entirely reviles and condemns all ascetics who lead a rough life.'"

"Now, concerning those who say this, Venerable Gotama—'The *śramaṇa* Gotama disparages all austerity (*tapas*), and entirely reviles and condemns all ascetics who lead a rough life'—are they stating what the Venerable Gotama has said, and not misrepresenting the Venerable Gotama with what is untrue? Do they explain the *dharma* in accordance with the *dharma*, and does no co-religionist's criticism reach a justifiable ground? For we do not wish to misrepresent the Venerable Gotama."
commentary_pali: 381.Evaṃme sutaṃ…pe… uruññāyaṃ viharatīti mahāsīhanādasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Uruññāyanti uruññāti tassa raṭṭhassapi nagarassapi etadeva nāmaṃ, bhagavā uruññānagaraṃ upanissāya viharati. Kaṇṇakatthale migadāyeti tassa nagarassa avidūre kaṇṇakatthalaṃ nāma eko ramaṇīyo bhūmibhāgo atthi. So migānaṃ abhayatthāya dinnattā ‘‘migadāyo’’ti vuccati, tasmiṃ kaṇṇakatthale migadāye. Aceloti naggaparibbājako. Kassapoti tassa nāmaṃ. Tapassinti tapanissitakaṃ. Lūkhājīvinti acelakamuttācārādivasena lūkho ājīvo assāti lūkhājīvī, taṃ lūkhājīviṃ. Upakkosatīti upaṇḍeti. Upavadatīti hīḷeti vambheti. Dhammassa ca anudhammaṃ byākarontīti bhotā gotamena vuttakāraṇassa anukāraṇaṃ kathenti. Sahadhammiko vādānuvādoti parehi vuttakāraṇena sakāraṇo hutvā tumhākaṃ vādo vā anuvādo vā viññūhi garahitabbaṃ, kāraṇaṃ koci appamattakopi kiṃ na āgacchati. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti, ‘‘kiṃ sabbākārenapi tava vāde gārayhaṃ kāraṇaṃ  natthī’’ti. Anabbhakkhātukāmāti na abhūtena vattukāmā.
commentary_english:
381. Thus have I heard…pe… the Great Lion's Roar Discourse, [which] he lived in Uruññā.
Herein is an explanation of unusual terms.
"Uruññāyaṃ" means Uruññā is the name of that country and city. The Blessed One lived depending on the city of Uruññā.
"Kaṇṇakatthale Migadāye" means not far from that city, there is a delightful place called Kaṇṇakatthala Migadāya.
Since it was given for the safety of the animals, it is called "Migadāya." [He was] in that Kaṇṇakatthala Migadāya.
"Aceloti" means a naked ascetic.
"Kassapoti" was his name.
"Tapassinti" means dependent on austerity.
"Lūkhājīvinti" means a rough livelihood, that is, he is one whose livelihood is rough because of being a naked ascetic and having unrestrained conduct, etc.; [therefore,] [he is called] a rough-liver, that rough-liver.
"Upakkosatīti" means he scorns.
"Upavadatīti" means he despises and reviles.
"Dhammassa ca anudhammaṃ byākarontīti" means they explain a reason similar to the reason spoken by the venerable Gotama.
"Sahadhammiko vādānuvādoti" means having a reason based on the reason spoken by others, your argument or counter-argument is blameworthy by the wise; why does even a small reason not come about?
"Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti" means this was said: "In every way, is there no blameworthy reason in your argument?"
"Anabbhakkhātukāmāti" means they do not desire to speak what is untrue.

mula_pali: 382. ‘‘Ye te, kassapa, evamāhaṃsu – ‘samaṇo gotamo sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahati, sabbaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosati upavadatī’ti, na me te vuttavādino, abbhācikkhanti ca pana maṃ te asatā abhūtena. Idhāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannaṃ. Idha panāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā  visuddhena  atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ.
mula_english:
“Kassapa, those who say: ‘The *śramaṇa* Gotama disparages all asceticism, he categorically reviles and denounces all ascetics who live a coarse life,’ they are not speaking according to what I have said, and they are misrepresenting me with what is false and untrue.

Here, Kassapa, I see one ascetic who lives a coarse life, and with the divine eye (*divyacakṣus*), which is purified and surpasses the human, I see him arising after death, at the breaking up of the body, in a place of misery (*apāya*), in a bad destination (*durgati*), in a place of ruin (*vinipāta*), in hell (*niraya*).

Again, Kassapa, I see one ascetic who lives a coarse life, and with the divine eye (*divyacakṣus*), which is purified and surpasses the human, I see him arising after death, at the breaking up of the body, in a good destination (*sugati*), in a heavenly world (*svarga loka*).
commentary_pali: 382.Ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ lūkhājīvintiādīsu idhekacco acelakapabbajjāditapanissitattā tapassī ‘‘lūkhena jīvitaṃ kappessāmī’’ti tiṇagomayādibhakkhanādīhi nānappakārehi attānaṃ kilameti, appapuññatāya ca sukhena jīvitavuttimeva na labhati, so tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā niraye nibbattati. Aparo tādisaṃ tapanissitopi puññavā hoti, labhati lābhasakkāraṃ. So ‘‘na dāni mayā sadiso atthī’’ti attānaṃ ucce ṭhāne sambhāvetvā ‘‘bhiyyosomattāya lābhaṃ uppādessāmī’’ti  anesanavasena tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā niraye nibbattati. Ime dve sandhāya paṭhamanayo vutto. Aparo tapanissitako lūkhājīvī appapuñño hoti, na labhati sukhena jīvitavuttiṃ. So ‘‘mayhaṃ pubbepi akatapuññatāya sukhajīvikā nuppajjati , handadāni puññāni karomī’’ti tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā sagge nibbattati. Aparo lūkhājīvī puññavā hoti, labhati sukhena jīvitavuttiṃ. So – ‘‘mayhaṃ pubbepi katapuññatāya sukhajīvikā uppajjatī’’ti cintetvā anesanaṃ pahāya tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā sagge nibbattati. Ime dve sandhāya dutiyanayo vutto. Eko pana tapassī appadukkhavihārī hoti bāhirakācārayutto tāpaso vā channaparibbājako vā, appapuññatāya ca manāpe paccaye na labhati. So anesanavasena tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā attānaṃ sukhe ṭhapetvā niraye nibbattati. Aparo  puññavā hoti, so – ‘‘na dāni mayā sadiso atthī’’ti mānaṃ uppādetvā anesanavasena lābhasakkāraṃ vā uppādento micchādiṭṭhivasena – ‘‘sukho imissā paribbājikāya daharāya mudukāya lomasāya samphasso’’tiādīni cintetvā kāmesu pātabyataṃ vā āpajjanto tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā niraye nibbattati. Ime dve sandhāya tatiyanayo vutto. Aparo pana appadukkhavihārī appapuñño hoti, so – ‘‘ahaṃ pubbepi akatapuññatāya sukhena jīvikaṃ na labhāmī’’ti tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā sagge nibbattati. Aparo puññavā hoti, so – ‘‘pubbepāhaṃ katapuññatāya sukhaṃ labhāmi, idāni puññāni karissāmī’’ti tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā sagge nibbattati. Ime dve sandhāya catutthanayo vutto. Idaṃ titthiyavasena āgataṃ, sāsanepi pana labbhati. Ekacco hi dhutaṅgasamādānavasena lūkhājīvī hoti, appapuññatāya vā sakalampi gāmaṃ vicaritvā udarapūraṃ na labhati. So – ‘‘paccaye uppādessāmī’’ti vejjakammādivasena vā anesanaṃ  katvā, arahattaṃ vā paṭijānitvā, tīṇi vā kuhanavatthūni paṭisevitvā niraye nibbattati. Aparo  ca tādisova puññavā hoti. So tāya puññasampattiyā mānaṃ janayitvā uppannaṃ lābhaṃ thāvaraṃ kattukāmo anesanavasena tīṇi duccaritāni pūretvā niraye uppajjati. Aparo samādinnadhutaṅgo appapuññova hoti, na labhati sukhena jīvitavuttiṃ. So – ‘‘pubbepāhaṃ akatapuññatāya kiñci na labhāmi, sace idāni anesanaṃ karissaṃ, āyatimpi dullabhasukho bhavissāmī’’ti tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā arahattaṃ pattuṃ asakkonto sagge nibbattati. Aparo puññavā hoti, so – ‘‘pubbepāhaṃ katapuññatāya etarahi sukhito, idānipi puññaṃ karissāmī’’ti anesanaṃ pahāya tīṇi sucaritāni pūretvā arahattaṃ pattuṃ asakkonto sagge nibbattati.
commentary_english:
382. In the category of ascetics who live a rough life, etc., here, one ascetic, due to relying on ascetic practices such as going forth as a naked ascetic, torments himself in various ways with food such as grass, cow dung, etc., and due to having little merit, does not obtain a livelihood with ease. He, having filled up three evil deeds, is reborn in hell.

Another, though relying on such asceticism, is meritorious and obtains gain and honor.

He, esteeming himself in a high position, thinking, "I will produce gain to a greater extent," having filled up three evil deeds by improper means, is reborn in hell.

With reference to these two, the first method is stated.

Another ascetic practicing austerity is unmeritorious, and does not obtain a livelihood with ease.

He, thinking, "Even in the past, I did not have a pleasant livelihood due to lack of merit, now I will perform meritorious deeds," having filled up three good deeds, is reborn in heaven.

Another ascetic who lives a rough life is meritorious, and obtains a livelihood with ease.

He, thinking, "Even in the past, I had a pleasant livelihood due to merit," having abandoned improper means, and having filled up three good deeds, is reborn in heaven.

With reference to these two, the second method is stated.

Moreover, one ascetic is one who dwells without suffering, endowed with external conduct, either a renunciate or a wandering ascetic, and due to lack of merit, does not obtain agreeable requisites.

He, having filled up three evil deeds by improper means, having established himself in pleasure, is reborn in hell.

Another is meritorious, he, generating pride, thinking, "Now there is no one like me," either producing gain and honor by improper means, or by wrong view - thinking, "Pleasant is the touch of this wandering female ascetic, young, tender, hairy," etc., or undergoing addiction to sensual pleasures, having filled up three evil deeds, is reborn in hell.

With reference to these two, the third method is stated.

Moreover, one who dwells without suffering is unmeritorious, he, thinking, "Even in the past, I did not obtain a livelihood with ease due to lack of merit," having filled up three good deeds, is reborn in heaven.

Another is meritorious, he, thinking, "In the past, I obtained happiness due to merit, now I will perform meritorious deeds," having filled up three good deeds, is reborn in heaven.

With reference to these two, the fourth method is stated.

This has come about through the way of the sectarians, but it is also obtained in the Dispensation.

One is indeed a rough-living person through undertaking ascetic practices, but due to lack of merit, even having wandered through the entire village, he does not obtain enough to fill his belly.

He - thinking, "I will produce requisites" - either having committed improper means through medical practices etc., or having falsely claimed to be an *arhat*, or having practiced three deceitful things, is reborn in hell.

Another is indeed just like that, meritorious.

He, having generated pride by that meritorious accomplishment, desiring to make the arisen gain permanent, having filled up three evil deeds by improper means, is reborn in hell.

Another, undertaking asceticism, is indeed unmeritorious, he does not obtain a livelihood with ease.

He - "In the past too, I did not obtain anything because of lack of merit. If I now use improper means, I will in the future experience little happiness," - having filled up three good deeds, and being unable to attain *arhat*-ship, is reborn in heaven.

Another is meritorious, he - "In the past too, I was happy due to meritorious actions. Now, too, I will do meritorious actions!" - abandoning improper means, having filled up three good deeds, and being unable to attain *arhat*-ship, is reborn in heaven.

mula_pali: 383. ‘‘Idhāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ appadukkhavihāriṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ  nirayaṃ upapannaṃ. Idha panāhaṃ, kassapa, ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ appadukkhavihāriṃ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannaṃ. Yohaṃ, kassapa, imesaṃ tapassīnaṃ evaṃ āgatiñca gatiñca cutiñca upapattiñca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāmi , sohaṃ kiṃ sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahissāmi, sabbaṃ vā tapassiṃ lūkhājīviṃ ekaṃsena upakkosissāmi upavadissāmi?
mula_english:
383. "Here, Kassapa, I see with the divine eye ( *dibyena cakṣunā*), which is purified and surpasses the human, a certain ascetic who practices little austerity, arising after death, at the breaking up of the body, in a state of deprivation (*apāyaṃ*), in an unhappy destination (*duggatiṃ*), in perdition (*vinipātaṃ*), in hell (*nirayaṃ*).

Here again, Kassapa, I see with the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, a certain ascetic who practices little austerity, arising after death, at the breaking up of the body, in a good destination (*sugatiṃ*), in a heavenly world (*saggaṃ lokaṃ*).

Since I understand as it truly is the coming (*āgatiṃ*), the going (*gatiṃ*), the deceasing (*cutiṃ*), and the arising (*upapattiṃ*) of these ascetics, how could I disapprove of all austerity (*tapaṃ*), and censure and blame all ascetics who lead a harsh life (*lūkhājīviṃ*) in every respect?"
commentary_pali: 383.Āgatiñcāti – ‘‘asukaṭṭhānato nāma ime āgatā’’ti evaṃ āgatiñca. Gatiñcāti idāni gantabbaṭṭhānañca. Cutiñcāti tato cavanañca. Upapattiñcāti tato cutānaṃ puna upapattiñca. Kiṃ sabbaṃ tapaṃ garahissāmīti – ‘‘kena kāraṇena garahissāmi, garahitabbameva hi mayaṃ garahāma, pasaṃsitabbaṃ pasaṃsāma, na bhaṇḍikaṃ karonto mahārajako viya dhotañca adhotañca ekato karomā’’ti dasseti. Idāni tamatthaṃ pakāsento – ‘‘santi kassapa eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
383.

*Āgatiñca* means "arrival," as in, "These have arrived from such and such a place; thus, *āgatiñca*."

*Gatiñca* now means the place to be gone to.

*Cutiñca* means the falling away from that.

*Upapattiñca* means the arising again after the falling away from that.

What, shall I censure all asceticism? He shows this by saying, "For what reason should I censure? Indeed, we censure what should be censured, we praise what should be praised. We do not act like a great dyer, making a mixed lot of what is washed and what is not washed."

Now, revealing that meaning, he said, "There are some ascetics and Brahmins, Kassapa..." and so on.

mula_pali: 384. ‘‘Santi, kassapa, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā paṇḍitā nipuṇā kataparappavādā vālavedhirūpā. Te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni. Tehipi me saddhiṃ ekaccesu ṭhānesu sameti, ekaccesu ṭhānesu na sameti. Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti, mayampi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti. Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti, mayampi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti. Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti, mayaṃ taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti. Yaṃ te ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti, mayaṃ taṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti. ‘‘Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti, parepi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti. Yaṃ  mayaṃ  ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti, parepi taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti. Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘na sādhū’ti, pare taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘sādhū’ti. Yaṃ mayaṃ ekaccaṃ vadema ‘sādhū’ti, pare taṃ ekaccaṃ vadanti ‘na sādhū’ti.
mula_english:
384.

“Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins (samaṇabrāhmaṇā) who are wise (paṇḍitā), skilled (nipuṇā), practiced in disputation (kataparappavādā), and appear like splitters of hairs (vālavedhirūpā).

They wander about, as it were, demolishing the views (diṭṭhigatāni) of others with their sharp wits (paññāgatena).

Sometimes their views accord with mine, sometimes they do not.

What they sometimes applaud (sādhū), we also sometimes applaud (sādhū).

What they sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū), we also sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū).

What they sometimes applaud (sādhū), we sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū).

What they sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū), we sometimes applaud (sādhū).

What we sometimes applaud (sādhū), others also sometimes applaud (sādhū).

What we sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū), others also sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū).

What we sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū), others sometimes applaud (sādhū).

What we sometimes applaud (sādhū), others sometimes do not applaud (na sādhū).
commentary_pali: 384.Yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcavidhaṃ sīlaṃ, tañhi loke na koci ‘‘na sādhū’’ti vadati. Puna yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcavidhaṃ veraṃ, taṃ na  koci ‘‘sādhū’’ti vadati. Puna yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcadvāre asaṃvaraṃ, te kira – ‘‘cakkhu nāma na nirundhitabbaṃ, cakkhunā manāpaṃ rūpaṃ daṭṭhabba’’nti vadanti, esa nayo sotādīsu. Puna yaṃ te ekaccanti pañcadvāre saṃvaraṃ. Evaṃ paresaṃ vādena saha attano vādassa samānāsamānataṃ dassetvā idāni attano vādena  saha paresaṃ vādassa samānāsamānataṃ dassento ‘‘yaṃ maya’’ntiādimāha. Tatrāpi pañcasīlādivaseneva attho veditabbo.
commentary_english:
384.
Again, as for those who have the fivefold virtue (pañcavidhaṃ sīlaṃ) that one may embrace, no one in the world would say, "That is not good (sādhu)."
Again, as for those who have the fivefold enmity (pañcavidhaṃ veraṃ) that one may embrace, no one would say, "That is good (sādhu)."
Again, as for those who embrace lack of restraint (asaṃvaraṃ) at the five sense-doors (pañcadvāre), they say, "Indeed, the eye (cakkhu) should not be restrained (nirundhitabbaṃ); agreeable forms (manāpaṃ rūpaṃ) should be seen with the eye (cakkhunā)," this is their method concerning the ear (sota) and the others.
Again, as for those who embrace restraint (saṃvaraṃ) at the five sense-doors (pañcadvāre).
Thus, having shown the similarity and dissimilarity of one's own doctrine (vādassa) together with the doctrine (vādena) of others, now, showing the similarity and dissimilarity of the doctrine (vādassa) of others together with one's own doctrine (vādena), he begins by saying, "yaṃ maya."
There also, the meaning (attho) should be understood just as in the case of the five precepts (pañcasīla) and so on.

mula_pali: 385. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi – yesu no, āvuso, ṭhānesu na sameti, tiṭṭhantu tāni ṭhānāni. Yesu ṭhānesu sameti, tattha viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ – ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā, na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā. Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, samaṇo vā gotamo, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyā’ti?
mula_english:
‘Then, approaching them, I say thus: “In those points where we do not agree, dear friends, let those points stand aside.

In those points where we agree, there the wise should question, investigate, and discuss with the teacher (*śāstṛ*) or the teacher's followers, or with the *saṃgha* or the *saṃgha*'s members, saying: ‘Those things that are unskillful (*akuśala*) and reckoned as unskillful, blameworthy (*sāvajja*) and reckoned as blameworthy, not to be cultivated (*asevitavyā*) and reckoned as not to be cultivated, not befitting a noble one (*analamariyā*) and reckoned as not befitting a noble one, dark (*kṛṣṇa*) and reckoned as dark—

Who is there who has completely abandoned these things and lives accordingly, the ascetic (*śramaṇa*) Gautama, or other venerable teachers (*gaṇācārya*)?’”
commentary_pali: 385.Samanuyuñjantanti  samanuyuñjantu, ettha ca laddhiṃ pucchanto samanuyuñjati nāma, kāraṇaṃ pucchanto samanugāhati nāma, ubhayaṃ pucchanto samanubhāsati nāma. Satthārā vā satthāranti satthārā vā saddhiṃ satthāraṃ upasaṃharitvā – ‘‘kiṃ te satthā te dhamme sabbaso pahāya vattati, udāhu samaṇo gotamo’’ti. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Idāni tamatthaṃ yojetvā dassento – ‘‘ye imesaṃ bhavata’’ntiādimāha. Tattha akusalā akusalasaṅkhātāti akusalā ceva ‘‘akusalā’’ti ca saṅkhātā ñātā koṭṭhāsaṃ vā katvā ṭhapitāti attho. Esa nayo sabbapadesu. Api cettha sāvajjāti sadosā. Na alamariyāti niddosaṭṭhena ariyā bhavituṃ nālaṃ asamatthā.
commentary_english:
385.
*Samanuyuñjanti* means *samanuyuñjantu*; here, *samanuyuñjati* means asking about views; *samanugāhati* means asking about the cause; *samanubhāsati* means asking about both.

*Satthārā vā satthāranti*: Approaching the teacher ( *satthāraṃ*) either with a teacher (*satthārā saddhiṃ*) or alone (*satthārā vā*), [and asking]: "Does your teacher (*te satthā*) conduct himself by completely abandoning these teachings (*te dhamme sabbaso pahāya vattati*), or is he a mendicant, Gotama (*udāhu samaṇo gotamo*)?"

And the same rule applies to the second expression (*dutiyapadepi eseva nayo*).

Now, showing the connection to that meaning (*tamatthaṃ yojetvā dassento*), he said beginning with "those who are of these, become (*ye imesaṃ bhavata*)."

There, *akusalā akusalasaṅkhātāti*: *akusalā* are those who are designated as *akusalā*; *akusalā ceva ‘‘akusalā’’ti ca saṅkhātā ñātā koṭṭhāsaṃ vā katvā ṭhapitāti attho* means they are known and designated as *akusalā* and kept set apart.

This same method applies to all expressions (*esa nayo sabbapadesu*).

Moreover, here *sāvajjāti* means *sadosā* (with faults).

*Na alamariyāti* means they are not able or capable (*nālaṃ asamatthā*) to become *ārya* with a faultless meaning (*niddosaṭṭhena ariyā bhavituṃ*).

mula_pali: 386. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā, na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā . Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyā’ti. Itiha, kassapa, viññū  samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
mula_english:
386.

“It is possible, Kassapa, that the wise, when questioning, investigating, and discussing, might say this: ‘Those things of yours are unwholesome (*akuśala*) and considered unwholesome, blameworthy (*sāvajja*) and considered blameworthy, not to be cultivated (*asevitabba*) and considered not to be cultivated, not worthy of the noble ones (*ariya*) and considered not worthy of the noble ones, dark (*kṛṣṇa*) and considered dark. The *śramaṇa* Gotama has completely abandoned these things and lives accordingly, unlike the other venerable teachers.’

In this case, Kassapa, the wise, when questioning, investigating, and discussing, would mostly give praise to us."
commentary_pali: 386-392.Yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantāti yena viññū amhe ca aññe ca pucchantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ, taṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati, atthi taṃ kāraṇanti attho. Yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyāti pare pana bhonto gaṇācariyā yaṃ vā taṃ vā appamattakaṃ pahāya vattantīti attho. Amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti idaṃ bhagavā satthārā satthāraṃ samanuyuñjanepi āha – saṅghena saṃghaṃ samanuyuñjanepi. Kasmā? Saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito. Pasīdamānāpi hi buddhasampattiyā saṅghe, saṅghasampattiyā ca buddhe pasīdanti, tathā hi bhagavato sarīrasampattiṃ  disvā, dhammadesanaṃ vā sutvā bhavanti vattāro – ‘‘lābhā vata bho sāvakānaṃ ye evarūpassa satthu santikāvacarā’’ti, evaṃ buddhasampattiyā saṅghe pasīdanti. Bhikkhūnaṃ panācāragocaraṃ abhikkamapaṭikkamādīni ca disvā bhavanti vattāro – ‘‘santikāvacarānaṃ vata bho sāvakānaṃ ayañca upasamaguṇo satthu kīva rūpo bhavissatī’’ti, evaṃ saṅghasampattiyā buddhe pasīdanti. Iti yā satthupasaṃsā, sā saṅghassa. Yā saṅghassa pasaṃsā, sā satthūti saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito bhagavā dvīsupi nayesu – ‘‘amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyu’’nti āha. Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyātiādīsupi panettha ayamadhippāyo – sampattasamādānasetughātavasena  hi tisso viratiyo. Tāsu sampattasamādāna viratimattameva aññesaṃ hoti, setughātavirati pana sabbena sabbaṃ  natthi. Pañcasu pana tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇappahānesu aṭṭhasamāpattivasena ceva vipassanāmattavasena ca tadaṅgavikkhambhanappahānamattameva aññesaṃ hoti. Itarāni tīṇi pahānāni sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Tathā sīlasaṃvaro, khantisaṃvaro, ñāṇasaṃvaro, satisaṃvaro, vīriyasaṃvaroti pañca saṃvarā, tesu pañcasīlamattameva adhivāsanakhantimattameva ca aññesaṃ hoti, sesaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Pañca kho panime uposathuddesā, tesu pañcasīlamattameva aññesaṃ hoti. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Iti akusalappahāne ca kusalasamādāne ca, tīsu viratīsu, pañcasu pahānesu, pañcasu saṃvaresu, pañcasu uddesesu, – ‘‘ahameva ca mayhañca sāvakasaṅgho loke paññāyati, mayā hi sadiso satthā nāma, mayhaṃ sāvakasaṅghena sadiso saṅgho nāma natthī’’ti bhagavā sīhanādaṃ nadati.
commentary_english:
386-392.
"Which the wise inquire about" means: the wise, both ourselves and others, ask and thus they would say, "That reason exists; that is the cause," is the meaning.

"Or whatever venerable ones, other group-teachers..." means: the other venerable ones, group-teachers, abandoning whatever trifling thing, continue on, is the meaning.

"We ourselves should mostly praise there" - the Blessed One spoke this even while inquiring of the Teacher by the Teacher, and even while inquiring of the *saṃgha* by the *saṃgha*.

Why? Because the praise of the *saṃgha* is also accomplished by the praise of the Teacher alone.

Indeed, even while being pleased by the Buddha's accomplishment in the *saṃgha*, and while being pleased by the *saṃgha*'s accomplishment in the Buddha, thus, having seen the Blessed One's bodily accomplishment, or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, the speakers become – ‘‘Indeed, what gain for the disciples who frequent the presence of such a Teacher!’’ Thus, they are pleased by the Buddha's accomplishment in the *saṃgha*.

Having seen the conduct and range of behavior of the monks, such as going forward and backward, the speakers become – “Indeed, what a peaceful quality for the disciples who frequent the presence, how beautiful the form of the Teacher will be!” Thus, they are pleased by the *saṃgha*'s accomplishment in the Buddha.

Thus, whatever is the Teacher's praise, that is the *saṃgha*'s.

Whatever is the *saṃgha*'s praise, that is the Teacher's—because the praise of the *saṃgha* is also accomplished by the praise of the Teacher alone, the Blessed One in both ways – spoke, "We ourselves should mostly praise there."

"The *śramaṇa* Gautama lives having abandoned these *dharmas* completely, or whatever venerable ones, other group-teachers..." In these and other instances, this is the intention: because the three abstinences (*virati*) are due to the power of attainment, undertaking, and destroying the dam (*setughāta*).

Among those, mere abstinence by attainment and undertaking occurs for others, but abstinence by destroying the dam (*setughāta*) is entirely non-existent.

Among the five abandonings, namely, abandoning by temporary suppression ( *tadaṅga-vikkhambhana-pahāna*), abandoning by complete destruction (*samuccheda-pahāna*), abandoning by tranquilization (*paṭipassaddhi-pahāna*), abandoning by escape (*nissaraṇa-pahāna*), and abandoning by complete eradication (*pahāna*)—only abandoning by temporary suppression (*tadaṅga-vikkhambhana-pahāna*) occurs for others, through the force of the eight attainments (*aṭṭhasamāpatti*) and through the force of mere insight (*vipaśyanā*).

The remaining three abandonings are entirely non-existent.

Similarly, the five restraints (*saṃvara*)— restraint of morality (*śīla-saṃvara*), restraint of patience (*khānti-saṃvara*), restraint of knowledge (*jñāna-saṃvara*), restraint of mindfulness (*smṛti-saṃvara*), restraint of vigor (*vīrya-saṃvara*)—among those, only mere morality and mere tolerance of endurance occur for others; the rest is entirely non-existent.

Indeed, these five *uposatha* observances, among those, only mere five precepts occur for others.

Morality consisting of the restraint of the *prātimokṣa* is entirely non-existent.

Thus, in the abandonment of the unwholesome and in the undertaking of the wholesome, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonings, in the five restraints, in the five observances, – "I alone and my community of disciples are known in the world; there is no Teacher like me, there is no *saṃgha* like my community of disciples," thus, the Blessed One roars the lion's roar.

mula_pali: 387. ‘‘Aparampi no, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ – ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ  dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā. Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, samaṇo vā gotamo, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyā’ ti?
mula_english: 387. Furthermore, the wise, when questioning, investigating, or discussing with a teacher ( *sattharā*) or a community (*saṃgha*), might say, ‘Those things of yours that are skillful (*kusalā*) and considered skillful (*kusalasaṅkhātā*), blameless (*anavajjā*) and considered blameless (*anavajjasaṅkhātā*), should be cultivated (*sevitabbā*) and considered as things to be cultivated (*sevitabbasaṅkhātā*), are worthy of a Noble One (*alamariyā*) and considered worthy of a Noble One (*alamariyasaṅkhātā*), are bright (*sukkā*) and considered bright (*sukkasaṅkhātā*). Who completely masters these things (*dhammā*) and lives accordingly—the ascetic Gotama (*samaṇo Gotamo*) or other venerable teachers (*gaṇācariyā*)?’
commentary_pali: 386-392.Yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantāti yena viññū amhe ca aññe ca pucchantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ, taṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati, atthi taṃ kāraṇanti attho. Yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyāti pare pana bhonto gaṇācariyā yaṃ vā taṃ vā appamattakaṃ pahāya vattantīti attho. Amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti idaṃ bhagavā satthārā satthāraṃ samanuyuñjanepi āha – saṅghena saṃghaṃ samanuyuñjanepi. Kasmā? Saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito. Bhikkhūnaṃ panācāragocaraṃ abhikkamapaṭikkamādīni ca disvā bhavanti vattāro – ‘‘santikāvacarānaṃ vata bho sāvakānaṃ ayañca upasamaguṇo satthu kīva rūpo bhavissatī’’ti, evaṃ saṅghasampattiyā buddhe pasīdanti. Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyātiādīsupi panettha ayamadhippāyo – sampattasamādānasetughātavasena  hi tisso viratiyo. commentary_english:
386-392.

"Because the wise inquire," means that the wise, both ourselves and others, asking, would say thus: "That reason exists, there is a cause for it," is the meaning.

"Or those venerable ones, the teachers of groups..." means that those venerable ones, the teachers of groups, abandoning some trifling thing, live according to it, is the meaning.

"We ourselves would praise mostly there": the Blessed One said this even while inquiring about a teacher by a teacher, and even while inquiring about a Saṃgha by a Saṃgha.

Why? Because the praise of the Saṃgha is also from the accomplishment of the praise of the teacher.

For even while being pleased, they are pleased with the Saṃgha through the Buddha's accomplishment, and with the Buddha through the Saṃgha's accomplishment. For indeed, having seen the Blessed One's bodily accomplishment, or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, they become speakers, "Indeed, gains are for those disciples who frequent a teacher of such a form." Thus, they are pleased with the Saṃgha through the Buddha's accomplishment.

Having seen the conduct and range of conduct of the monks, such as going forward and going back, they become speakers, "Indeed, what sort will be the form of the teacher, since this quality of pacification is for those disciples who frequent [him]?" Thus, they are pleased with the Buddha through the Saṃgha's accomplishment.

Thus, that which is the teacher's praise, that is for the Saṃgha.

That which is the Saṃgha's praise, that is for the teacher. Thus, from the accomplishment of the praise of the teacher through the Saṃgha's praise, the Blessed One, in both ways, said, "We ourselves would praise mostly there."

"The ascetic Gotama lives abandoning these dharmas without remainder, or those venerable ones, the teachers of groups..." In these and other [phrases] also, this is the intention here: for indeed, the three abstinences are by way of accomplishment, undertaking, and destroying the dam.

Among those, only the abstinence of accomplishment and undertaking exists for others, but the abstinence of destroying the dam does not exist at all.

Among the five abandonings, namely, temporary abandonment, abandonment by cutting off, abandonment by tranquility, abandonment by escape, and abandonment by destruction, only temporary abandonment and abandonment by destruction exist for others, both by way of the eight attainments and by way of mere insight.

The other three abandonments do not exist at all.

Likewise, restraint by morality ( *śīla-saṃvara*), restraint by patience (*khānti-saṃvara*), restraint by knowledge (*jñāna-saṃvara*), restraint by mindfulness (*smṛti-saṃvara*), and restraint by energy (*vīrya-saṃvara*)—these are the five restraints. Among them, only the mere five moralities and the mere patience of endurance exist for others; the remainder does not exist at all.

There are these five *uposatha* observances; among them, only the mere five moralities exist for others.

Restraint by the morality of the *prātimokṣa* does not exist at all.

Thus, in the abandonment of unwholesome [qualities] and in the undertaking of wholesome [qualities], in the three abstinences, in the five abandonments, in the five restraints, in the five *uddesas*, the Blessed One roars the lion's roar, "I alone, and my Saṃgha of disciples, are known in the world. For there is no teacher named like me, there is no Saṃgha named like my Saṃgha of disciples."

mula_pali: 388. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ  – ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā. Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyā’ti. Itiha, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
mula_english:
It is indeed possible, Kassapa, that the wise, when questioning, examining, and discussing, might say this: ‘These things of yours, reverend sir, are considered wholesome (*kuśala*), reckoned as blameless (*anavajja*), regarded as worthy of cultivation (*sevitabba*), deemed sufficient for the noble path (*alamariya*), and are counted as pure (*sukka*).’ The ascetic Gotama has completely mastered these things, unlike other venerable teachers with their groups."

In this case, Kassapa, the wise, when questioning, examining, and discussing, would mostly give us praise.

Yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyāti pare pana bhonto gaṇācariyā yaṃ vā taṃ vā appamattakaṃ pahāya vattantīti attho. Amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti idaṃ bhagavā satthārā satthāraṃ samanuyuñjanepi āha – saṅghena saṃghaṃ samanuyuñjanepi. Kasmā? Saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito.
