commentary_english:
386-392.

"Because the wise inquire," means that the wise, both ourselves and others, ask and say thus: "That ground exists, that is the reason." This is the meaning.

"Or those venerable group-teachers" means that those venerable group-teachers abandon some trifling thing and behave thus. This is the meaning.

"We ourselves would praise there for the most part" – the Blessed One said this even when the Teacher was questioning the Teacher, and even when the Saṅgha was questioning the Saṅgha.

Why? Because praise of the Saṅgha also results in praise of the Teacher.

For even when they are pleased, they are pleased with the Saṅgha because of the Buddha's attainment, and with the Buddha because of the Saṅgha's attainment. For having seen the Blessed One's bodily perfection, or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, they become speakers, saying: "Truly, the disciples have gained much, those who attend upon a Teacher of such a form!" Thus, they are pleased with the Saṅgha because of the Buddha's attainment.

And having seen the monks' conduct and range, their going forward and returning, etc., they become speakers, saying: "Truly, the disciples who attend upon [him] have gained much! How beautiful will be the Teacher's quality of tranquility!" Thus, they are pleased with the Buddha because of the Saṅgha's attainment.

Thus, whatever praise is of the Teacher is [also praise] of the Saṅgha.

Whatever praise is of the Saṅgha is [also praise] of the Teacher. Because praise of the Saṅgha also results in praise of the Teacher, the Blessed One said in both ways: "We ourselves would praise there for the most part."

"The ascetic Gotama lives abandoning these things entirely," or "Those venerable group-teachers," etc. In this connection, this is the intention: for there are three kinds of abstinences by way of attainment, undertaking, and destroying the dam.

Among these, only the abstinence of attainment and undertaking exists for others, but the abstinence of destroying the dam does not exist at all.

Among the five kinds of abandonment – abandonment by temporary suppression (tad-aṅga-vikkhambhana), abandonment by eradication (samuccheda), abandonment by tranquility (paṭipassaddhi), abandonment by escape (nissaraṇa), and abandonment by complete cessation (pahāna) – only abandonment by temporary suppression exists for others, both by way of the eight attainments and only by way of insight.

The other three kinds of abandonment do not exist at all.

Likewise, the five kinds of restraint are: restraint by morality (śīla-saṃvara), restraint by patience (khanti-saṃvara), restraint by knowledge (jñāna-saṃvara), restraint by mindfulness (smṛti-saṃvara), and restraint by vigor (vīrya-saṃvara). Among these, only adherence to the five precepts and only patience and acceptance exists for others; the remainder does not exist at all.

Of these five aims of the *uposatha* observance, only adherence to the five precepts exists for others.

Morality consisting of restraint according to the *prātimokṣa* does not exist at all.

Thus, in abandoning the unwholesome and undertaking the wholesome, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonments, in the five restraints, in the five aims [of the *uposatha*], the Blessed One roars the lion's roar: "Only I and my Saṅgha of disciples are known in the world. There is no Teacher like me; there is no Saṅgha like my Saṅgha of disciples!"

mula_pali: 389. ‘‘Aparampi no, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ – ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā, sāvajjā sāvajjasaṅkhātā, asevitabbā asevitabbasaṅkhātā , na alamariyā na alamariyasaṅkhātā, kaṇhā kaṇhasaṅkhātā. Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, gotamasāvakasaṅgho vā, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti?
mula_english:
Furthermore, Kassapa, discerning people might question, investigate, and discuss a teacher with a teacher, or a *saṃgha* with a *saṃgha*, saying: ‘These things of yours, are unwholesome (*akuśala*), reckoned as unwholesome, blameworthy (*sāvajja*), reckoned as blameworthy, not to be cultivated (*asevitabba*), reckoned as not to be cultivated, not noble (*ariya*), reckoned as not noble, dark (*kaṇha*), reckoned as dark.’

Who is it that has completely abandoned these things and lives accordingly: the community of disciples of Gotama, or other venerable teachers and their communities of disciples?”

commentary_english:
386-392.

Because the wise inquire, meaning that the wise, both ourselves and others, ask, "Is that condition found? Is there a cause for that?"
Or, "Venerable sirs, other teachers of groups..." meaning that other venerable sirs, teachers of groups, give up even a very small thing and act.
"We ourselves should mostly praise there" - the Blessed One said this even while the Teacher was cross-examining the Teacher, and even while the Sangha was cross-examining the Sangha.
Why? Because even in the Sangha's praise, the Teacher's praise is accomplished.
Indeed, even while rejoicing in the Buddha's attainment in the Sangha, they rejoice in the Buddha's attainment in the Buddha. Thus, having seen the Blessed One's bodily accomplishment or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, they become speakers, "Indeed, gain is for the disciples who frequent the presence of such a Teacher." Thus, they rejoice in the Sangha through the Buddha's attainment.
Having seen the conduct and range of behavior of the monks, such as going forward and retreating, they become speakers, "Indeed, what is this quality of peacefulness for the disciples who frequent his presence? How will the Teacher's form be?" Thus, they rejoice in the Buddha through the Sangha's attainment.
Thus, whatever is the Teacher's praise, that is the Sangha's.
Whatever is the Sangha's praise, that is the Teacher's. Because even in the Sangha's praise, the Teacher's praise is accomplished, the Blessed One, in both these ways, said, "We ourselves should mostly praise there."
"The ascetic Gotama abstains, having completely abandoned these things. Or, venerable sirs, other teachers of groups..." Even in these and other cases, this is the intention: indeed, the three abstinences are by way of attainment, undertaking, and destroying the dam.
Among those, only the abstinence of attainment and undertaking exists for others, but the abstinence of destroying the dam does not exist entirely.
Among the five abandonings—abandoning by parts, abandoning by destruction, abandoning by tranquility, abandoning by escape, and abandoning by removal—only abandoning by parts and abandoning by interruption exists for others, by way of the eight attainments and only by way of insight.
The other three abandonings do not exist entirely.
Similarly, morality restraint (śīlasaṃvara), patience restraint (khantisaṃvara), knowledge restraint (jñānasaṃvara), mindfulness restraint (smṛtisaṃvara), and effort restraint (vīryasaṃvaroti) are the five restraints (pañca saṃvarā). Among these, only the five moralities (pañca-śīla) and only dwelling in patience (adhivāsanakhanti) exists for others; the rest does not exist entirely.
There are five uposatha observances. Among these, only the five moralities exist for others.
Morality restraint of the Prātimokṣa does not exist entirely.
Thus, in abandoning the unwholesome and undertaking the wholesome, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonings, in the five restraints, in the five objectives, "I myself and also my community of disciples are known in the world. Indeed, there is no teacher like me by name, there is no Sangha like my community of disciples by name," thus the Blessed One roars the lion's roar (sīhanādaṃ nadati).

The Saṅgha of Gotama's disciples lives having completely abandoned these teachings; or the Saṅghas of disciples of other venerable teachers."

commentary_english:
386-392.

"Yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantāti" means: because wise people, both ourselves and others, ask and say thus, that situation exists, that is the cause.

"Amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti," the Blessed One said this even while questioning the teacher with the teacher, even while questioning the Saṃgha with the Saṃgha.

Why? Because even praise of the Saṃgha results from the praise of the Teacher.

Indeed, even while being pleased, they are pleased with the Saṃgha through the Buddha's attainment, and with the Buddha through the Saṃgha's attainment. For, having seen the Blessed One's bodily accomplishment or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, they become speakers: "Indeed, what gain is there for the disciples who frequent such a Teacher!" Thus, they are pleased with the Saṃgha through the Buddha's attainment.

And having seen the conduct and range of practice of the monks, such as going forward and backward, they become speakers: "Indeed, what a quality of peace there is for the disciples who frequent [the Teacher]! How beautiful the Teacher will be!" Thus, they are pleased with the Buddha through the Saṃgha's attainment.

Thus, whatever is praise of the Teacher, that is of the Saṃgha.

Whatever is praise of the Saṃgha, that is of the Teacher. Because even praise of the Saṃgha results from the praise of the Teacher, the Blessed One said in both ways: "We would mostly praise there."

"Samaṇo Gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyātiādīsupi panettha ayamadhippāyo" – the meaning here also in these and other statements such as "The ascetic Gautama abandons these things entirely and behaves," is that there are three kinds of abstinence due to the power of success, undertaking, and destroying the dam ( sampattasamādānasetughātavasena hi tisso viratiyo).

Among them, only abstinence through success and undertaking exists for others, but abstinence through destroying the dam does not exist at all.

Among the five abandonings – abandoning by means of temporary suppression ( tadaṅgavikkhambhana), abandoning by cutting off ( samuccheda), abandoning by tranquility ( paṭipassaddhi), abandoning by escape ( nissaraṇa), and abandoning by eradication ( pahāna) – only abandoning by means of temporary suppression exists for others, whether through the power of the eight attainments or through the power of mere insight ( vipassanā).

The other three abandonings do not exist at all.

Similarly, the five restraints ( pañca saṃvarā) are restraint of morality ( sīlasaṃvaro), restraint of patience ( khantisaṃvaro), restraint of knowledge ( ñāṇasaṃvaro), restraint of mindfulness ( satisaṃvaro), and restraint of energy ( vīriyasaṃvaroti). Among these, only the mere five moral precepts and the mere acceptance of patience exist for others; the rest does not exist at all.

These are the five aims of the *uposatha*, only the mere five moral precepts exist for others.

The morality of the *prātimokṣa* restraint does not exist at all.

Thus, in abandoning the unwholesome and undertaking the wholesome, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonings, in the five restraints, in the five aims, "Only I and my Saṃgha of disciples are known in the world. Indeed, there is no teacher like me, there is no Saṃgha like my Saṃgha of disciples," the Blessed One roars the lion's roar.

mula_pali: 391. ‘‘Aparampi  no, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantaṃ samanugāhantaṃ  samanubhāsantaṃ satthārā vā satthāraṃ saṅghena vā saṅghaṃ. ‘Ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā. Ko ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, gotamasāvakasaṅgho vā, pare vā pana bhonto gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti?
mula_english:
"Furthermore, Kassapa, the wise, when questioning, investigating, or discussing, might say to a teacher ( *satthā* ) or the Sangha ( *saṅgha* ):

'Those things of yours, are they wholesome ( *kusala* ) and considered wholesome ( *kusalasaṅkhāta* ), blameless ( *anavajja* ) and considered blameless ( *anavajjasaṅkhāta* ), to be cultivated ( *sevitabba* ) and considered to be cultivated ( *sevitabbasaṅkhāta* ), worthy of the noble ones ( *alamariya* ) and considered worthy of the noble ones ( *alamariyasaṅkhāta* ), bright ( *sukka* ) and considered bright ( *sukkasaṅkhāta* )?'

Who is it that completely adheres to these qualities ( *dhamme* )? Is it the Sangha of Gotama's disciples, or other venerable teachers and their disciples?"
commentary_pali: 386-392.Yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantāti yena viññū amhe ca aññe ca pucchantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ, taṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati, atthi taṃ kāraṇanti attho. Yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyāti pare pana bhonto gaṇācariyā yaṃ vā taṃ vā appamattakaṃ pahāya vattantīti attho. Amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyunti idaṃ bhagavā satthārā satthāraṃ samanuyuñjanepi āha – saṅghena saṃghaṃ samanuyuñjanepi. Kasmā? Saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito. Pasīdamānāpi hi buddhasampattiyā saṅghe, saṅghasampattiyā ca buddhe pasīdanti, tathā hi bhagavato sarīrasampattiṃ  disvā, dhammadesanaṃ vā sutvā bhavanti vattāro – ‘‘lābhā vata bho sāvakānaṃ ye evarūpassa satthu santikāvacarā’’ti, evaṃ buddhasampattiyā saṅghe pasīdanti. Bhikkhūnaṃ panācāragocaraṃ abhikkamapaṭikkamādīni ca disvā bhavanti vattāro – ‘‘santikāvacarānaṃ vata bho sāvakānaṃ ayañca upasamaguṇo satthu kīva rūpo bhavissatī’’ti, evaṃ saṅghasampattiyā buddhe pasīdanti. Iti yā satthupasaṃsā, sā saṅghassa. Yā saṅghassa pasaṃsā, sā satthūti saṅghapasaṃsāyapi satthuyeva pasaṃsāsiddhito bhagavā dvīsupi nayesu – ‘‘amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyu’’nti āha. Samaṇo gotamo ime dhamme anavasesaṃ pahāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyātiādīsupi panettha ayamadhippāyo – sampattasamādānasetughātavasena  hi tisso viratiyo. Tāsu sampattasamādāna viratimattameva aññesaṃ hoti, setughātavirati pana sabbena sabbaṃ  natthi. Pañcasu pana tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇappahānesu aṭṭhasamāpattivasena ceva vipassanāmattavasena ca tadaṅgavikkhambhanappahānamattameva aññesaṃ hoti. Itarāni tīṇi pahānāni sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Tathā sīlasaṃvaro, khantisaṃvaro, ñāṇasaṃvaro, satisaṃvaro, vīriyasaṃvaroti pañca saṃvarā, tesu pañcasīlamattameva adhivāsanakhantimattameva ca aññesaṃ hoti, sesaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Pañca kho panime uposathuddesā, tesu pañcasīlamattameva aññesaṃ hoti. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ natthi. Iti akusalappahāne ca kusalasamādāne ca, tīsu viratīsu, pañcasu pahānesu, pañcasu saṃvaresu, pañcasu uddesesu, – ‘‘ahameva ca mayhañca sāvakasaṅgho loke paññāyati, mayā hi sadiso satthā nāma, mayhaṃ sāvakasaṅghena sadiso saṅgho nāma natthī’’ti bhagavā sīhanādaṃ nadati.
commentary_english:
386-392.

"Because the wise inquire" means: the meaning is, the place exists, the cause exists, because the wise, both ourselves and others, ask and thus speak.

"Or whatever venerable *gaṇācariyas* abandon a small matter" means: the meaning is, whatever venerable *gaṇācariyas* abandon this or that small matter and behave accordingly.

"We ourselves would mostly praise there" – the Blessed One spoke this even when teacher was cross-examining the teacher, and even when the Saṃgha was cross-examining the Saṃgha.

Why? Because even praising the Saṃgha is indeed the accomplishment of praising the teacher.

Although they are pleased, they are pleased with the Saṃgha through the Buddha's accomplishment, and they are pleased with the Buddha through the Saṃgha's accomplishment. Thus, having seen the Blessed One's bodily accomplishment, or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, the speakers say, "Indeed, gains for the disciples are those who frequent the presence of a teacher of such a form!" Thus, they are pleased with the Saṃgha through the Buddha's accomplishment.

Having seen the monks' range of conduct, such as going forward, going back, etc., the speakers say, "Indeed, what kind of form will the teacher have, this quality of calm for the disciples who frequent his presence!" Thus, they are pleased with the Buddha through the Saṃgha's accomplishment.

Thus, whatever praise is for the teacher, that is for the Saṃgha.

Whatever praise is for the Saṃgha, that is for the teacher, because even praising the Saṃgha is indeed the accomplishment of praising the teacher. The Blessed One spoke in both ways: "We ourselves would mostly praise there."

The ascetic Gotama behaves abandoning these *dharmas* completely. Or, whatever venerable *gaṇācariyas*... Even in these and other [statements], this is the intention here - indeed, the three abstinences [are understood] by way of accomplishment, undertaking, and destruction of the bridge.

Among those, only the mere abstinence of accomplishment and undertaking exists for others, but the abstinence of destroying the bridge does not exist at all.

Among the five kinds of abandonment, namely, temporary abandonment, destruction, calming, escape, and elimination, only the temporary abandonment and elimination exist for others, by way of the eight attainments and by way of mere insight.

The other three abandonments do not exist at all.

Similarly, *sīla-saṃvara* (restraint of morality), *khanti-saṃvara* (restraint of patience), *ñāṇa-saṃvara* (restraint of knowledge), *sati-saṃvara* (restraint of mindfulness), *vīriya-saṃvara* (restraint of energy)—these are the five restraints. Among these, only the mere five moral precepts and the mere acceptance and patience exist for others; the rest does not exist at all.

Indeed, these are the five *uposatha* observances; among these, only the mere five moral precepts exist for others.

*Pātimokkha-saṃvara-sīla* (morality consisting of the restraint of the *Pātimokkha*) does not exist at all.

Thus, in abandoning the unwholesome and in undertaking the wholesome, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonments, in the five restraints, in the five *uddesas*, – "I alone and the Saṃgha of my disciples are known in the world. Indeed, there is no teacher like me, there is no Saṃgha like the Saṃgha of my disciples," thus the Blessed One roars the lion's roar.

mula_pali: 392. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ye imesaṃ bhavataṃ dhammā kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā, anavajjā anavajjasaṅkhātā, sevitabbā sevitabbasaṅkhātā, alamariyā alamariyasaṅkhātā, sukkā sukkasaṅkhātā. Gotamasāvakasaṅgho ime dhamme anavasesaṃ samādāya vattati, yaṃ vā pana bhonto pare gaṇācariyasāvakasaṅghā’ti. Itiha, kassapa, viññū samanuyuñjantā samanugāhantā samanubhāsantā amheva tattha yebhuyyena pasaṃseyyuṃ.
mula_english: Furthermore, it is possible, Kassapa, that the wise, when questioning, investigating, and discussing the matter, might say this: ‘These things of yours are considered wholesome (*kuśala*), considered blameless (*anavadya*), considered fit to be cultivated (*sevitabba*), considered sufficient for the holy life (*alamariya*), considered pure (*sukka*). The community (*saṃgha*) of the disciples (*sāvakasaṃgha*) of Gotama (*gotama*) completely masters (*samādāya vattati*) these things, but the other venerable teachers only in part.’ In this case, Kassapa, the wise, when questioning, investigating, and discussing the matter, would give us the greatest share of praise.

commentary_english:
386-392.
"Because the wise inquire" means: because the wise, both ourselves and others, ask, saying, "That ground exists, that is the cause." That is the meaning.

"Or whatever venerable ones, other group-teachers..." means: other venerable ones, group-teachers, giving up whatever trifling thing, live... That is the meaning.

"We indeed should praise there for the most part" - the Blessed One said this even while the Teacher was questioning the Teacher, even while the Saṅgha was questioning the Saṅgha.

Why? Because the praise of the Saṅgha also results in the praise of the Teacher.

For even while taking pleasure in the Buddha's attainment in the Saṅgha, they take pleasure in the Buddha through the Saṅgha's attainment. For, having seen the Blessed One's bodily perfection or having heard the teaching of the Dharma, they become speakers, saying, "Truly, what gain is it to the disciples who attend upon a Teacher of such a form!" Thus, through the Buddha's attainment, they take pleasure in the Saṅgha.

And having seen the monks' range of conduct, going forward, going back, and so on, they become speakers, saying, "Truly, what an appeasing quality is this of the disciples who attend upon [the Teacher]! How will the Teacher's form be?" Thus, through the Saṅgha's attainment, they take pleasure in the Buddha.

Thus, whatever is the Teacher’s praise, that is the Saṅgha's.

Whatever is the Saṅgha’s praise, that is the Teacher's. Because the praise of the Saṅgha also results in the praise of the Teacher, the Blessed One said in both ways, "We indeed should praise there for the most part."

"The ascetic Gautama lives having abandoned these things entirely; or whatever venerable ones, other group-teachers..." Even in these and other instances, this is the intention here: for indeed, the three abstinences are by way of the attainment of success, undertaking, and destroying the dam ( *sampattasamādānasetughātavasena*).

Among those, only the abstinence consisting of the attainment of success and undertaking belongs to others; but the abstinence consisting of destroying the dam, by all, in every way, does not exist.

Moreover, among the five abandonings: abandoning by temporary suppression (*tadaṅgavikkhambhana*), abandoning by complete cutting off (*samuccheda*), abandoning by tranquility (*paṭipassaddhi*), abandoning by escape (*nissaraṇa*), and abandoning by destruction (*pahāna*) only abandoning by temporary suppression belongs to others by way of the eight attainments, and only abandoning by temporary suppression belongs to others by way of insight ( *vipassanā*).

The other three abandonings, by all, in every way, do not exist.

Likewise, restraint by morality (*sīlasaṃvara*), restraint by patience (*khantisaṃvara*), restraint by knowledge (*ñāṇasaṃvara*), restraint by mindfulness (*satisaṃvara*), restraint by vigor (*vīriyasaṃvara*), these are the five restraints (*pañca saṃvarā*). Among those, only the elements of the five moralities and only the elements of acceptance and patience belong to others; the rest, by all, in every way, does not exist.

Moreover, these are the five *uposatha* observances; among those, only the elements of the five moralities belong to others.

Restraint by the *Prātimokṣa* morality, by all, in every way, does not exist.

Thus, in abandoning the unwholesome and undertaking the wholesome, in the three abstinences, in the five abandonings, in the five restraints, in the five observances, "Both I and my Saṅgha of disciples are known in the world; for there is no teacher like me, there is no Saṅgha like my Saṅgha of disciples," thus the Blessed One roars the lion's roar.

mula_pali: 393. ‘‘Atthi, kassapa, maggo atthi paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipanno sāmaṃyeva ñassati sāmaṃ dakkhati dakkhiti (sī.) – ‘samaṇova gotamo kālavādī  bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī’ti. Katamo ca, kassapa, maggo, katamā ca paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipanno sāmaṃyeva ñassati sāmaṃ dakkhati – ‘samaṇova gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī’ti? Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo. Seyyathidaṃ – sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi. Ayaṃ kho, kassapa, maggo, ayaṃ paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipanno sāmaṃyeva ñassati sāmaṃ dakkhati ‘samaṇova gotamo kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī’’’ti.
mula_english:
“Kassapa, there is a path (maggo), there is a course of training (paṭipadā), whereby one who has followed it will know (ñassati) and see (dakkhati) for himself: “The ascetic Gotama speaks at the proper time (kālavādī), speaks what is true (bhūtavādī), speaks to the point (atthavādī) — the Dhamma (dhammavādī) and the Discipline (vinayavādī).”

What is this path (maggo) and this course of training (paṭipadā), whereby one who has followed it will know (ñassati) and see (dakkhati) for himself: “The ascetic Gotama speaks at the proper time (kālavādī), speaks what is true (bhūtavādī), speaks to the point (atthavādī) — the Dhamma (dhammavādī) and the Discipline (vinayavādī)?"

This very noble eightfold path (ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo): namely right view (sammādiṭṭhi), right intention (sammāsaṅkappo), right speech (sammāvācā), right action (sammākammanto), right livelihood (sammāājīvo), right effort (sammāvāyāmo), right mindfulness (sammāsati), right concentration (sammāsamādhi).

This is the path (maggo), Kassapa, this is the course of training (paṭipadā), whereby one who has followed it will know (ñassati) and see (dakkhati) for himself: “The ascetic Gotama speaks at the proper time (kālavādī), speaks what is true (bhūtavādī), speaks to the point (atthavādī) — the Dhamma (dhammavādī) and the Discipline (vinayavādī).”
commentary_pali: 393. Evaṃ sīhanādaṃ  naditvā tassa sīhanādassa aviparītabhāvāvabodhanatthaṃ – ‘‘atthi, kassapa, maggo’’tiādimāha. Tattha maggoti lokuttaramaggo. Paṭipadāti pubbabhāgapaṭipadā. Kālavādītiādīni brahmajāle vaṇṇitāni. Idāni taṃ duvidhaṃ maggañca paṭipadañca ekato katvā dassento – ‘‘ayameva ariyo’’tiādimāha. Idaṃ pana sutvā acelo cintesi – ‘‘samaṇo gotamo mayhaṃyeva maggo ca paṭipadā ca atthi, aññesaṃ natthīti maññati, handassāhaṃ amhākampi maggaṃ kathemī’’ti. Tato acelakapaṭipadaṃ kathesi. Tenāha – ‘‘evaṃ vutte acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca…pe… udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharatī’’ti.
commentary_english:
393. Having thus roared a lion's roar, in order to explain the undeviating nature of that lion's roar, he said, "There is, Kassapa, a path," and so forth.

There, "path" means the supramundane path (lokuttaramagga).

"Practice" means the preliminary practice (pubbabhāgapaṭipadā).

"Eternalists" and so on are described in the *Brahmajāla*.

Now, showing that the twofold path and practice are made one, he said, "This is the noble one," and so forth.

Having heard this, the naked ascetic thought, "The ascetic Gotama thinks, 'The path and the practice exist only for me, and not for others.' Well then, I will also declare our path."

Then he declared the practice of the naked ascetics (acelakapaṭipadā).

Therefore he said, "When this was said, the naked ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One…pe…he lives devoted to the practice of water-ablutions."

mula_pali: 394. Evaṃ  vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘imepi kho, āvuso gotama, tapopakkamā etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ  sāmaññasaṅkhātā ca brahmaññasaṅkhātā ca. Acelako  hoti, muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano, na ehibhaddantiko, na tiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṃ, na uddissakataṃ, na nimantanaṃ sādiyati. So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṃ, na daṇḍamantaraṃ, na musalamantaraṃ, na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṃ, na maṃsaṃ, na suraṃ, na merayaṃ, na thusodakaṃ pivati. So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko…pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko ; ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti… sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti; ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti… sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti. Iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
mula_english:
394. When this was said, the naked ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One: "These ascetic practices of these *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s are considered their own *sāmañña* and *brahmañña*.

He is a naked ascetic (*acelaka*), rejecting conventions (*muttācāra*), licking his hands (*hatthāpalekhana*), not coming when asked (*na ehibhaddantiko*), not stopping when asked (*na tiṭṭhabhaddantiko*); he does not accept food brought (*nābhihaṭaṃ*), food specially made (*na uddissakataṃ*), or an invitation (*na nimantanaṃ sādiyati*).

He does not accept food from a pot (*na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti*), nor from a bowl (*na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti*), nor between the threshold (*na eḷakamantaraṃ*), nor between sticks (*na daṇḍamantaraṃ*), nor between pestles (*na musalamantaraṃ*), nor from two people eating together (*na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ*), nor from a pregnant woman (*na gabbhiniyā*), nor from a nursing woman (*na pāyamānāya*), nor from a woman living with a man (*na purisantaragatāya*), nor from where food is dispensed (*na saṅkittīsu*), nor from where a dog is waiting (*na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti*), nor from where flies are swarming (*na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī*); he eats no fish (*na macchaṃ*), nor meat (*na maṃsaṃ*), nor liquor (*na suraṃ*), nor spirits (*na merayaṃ*), nor fermented rice water (*na thusodakaṃ pivati*).

He may be a one-house man (*ekāgāriko*) eating one mouthful (*ekālopiko*), or a two-house man (*dvāgāriko*) eating two mouthfuls (*dvālopiko*)…pe… or a seven-house man (*sattāgāriko*) eating seven mouthfuls (*sattālopiko*); he lives on one offering (*ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti*), or two offerings (*dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti*)… or seven offerings (*sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti*); he takes food once a day (*ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti*), or once every two days (*dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti*)… or once every seven days (*sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti*).

Thus, he lives pursuing the practice of taking food at stated intervals, even up to once every half-month (*iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati*)."
commentary_pali: 394. Tattha tapopakkamāti tapārambhā, tapakammānīti attho. Sāmaññasaṅkhātāti samaṇakammasaṅkhātā. Brahmaññasaṅkhātāti brāhmaṇakammasaṅkhātā. Acelakoti niccolo, naggoti attho. Muttācāroti visaṭṭhācāro, uccārakammādīsu lokiyakulaputtācārena virahito  ṭhitakova uccāraṃ karoti, passāvaṃ karoti, khādati, bhuñjati ca. Hatthāpalekhanoti hatthe piṇḍamhi ṭhite jivhāya hatthaṃ apalikhati, uccāraṃ vā katvā hatthasmiññeva daṇḍakasaññī hutvā hatthena apalikhati. ‘‘Bhikkhāgahaṇatthaṃ ehi, bhante’’ti vutto na etīti na ehibhaddantiko. ‘‘Tena hi  tiṭṭha, bhante’’ti vuttopi na tiṭṭhatīti natiṭṭhabhaddantiko. Tadubhayampi kira so – ‘‘etassa vacanaṃ kataṃ bhavissatī’’ti na karoti. Abhihaṭanti puretaraṃ gahetvā āhaṭaṃ bhikkhaṃ, uddissakatanti ‘‘imaṃ tumhe uddissa kata’’nti evaṃ ārocitaṃ bhikkhaṃ. Na nimantananti ‘‘asukaṃ nāma kulaṃ vā vīthiṃ vā gāmaṃ vā paviseyyāthā’’ti evaṃ nimantitabhikkhampi na sādiyati, na gaṇhati. Nakumbhimukhāti kumbhito uddharitvā diyyamānaṃ bhikkhaṃ na gaṇhati. Na kaḷopimukhāti kaḷopīti ukkhali vā pacchi vā, tatopi na gaṇhati. Kasmā? Kumbhikaḷopiyo maṃ nissāya kaṭacchunā pahāraṃ labhantīti. Na eḷakamantaranti ummāraṃ antaraṃ katvā diyyamānaṃ na gaṇhati. Kasmā? ‘‘Ayaṃ maṃ nissāya antarakaraṇaṃ labhatī’’ti. Daṇḍamusalesupi eseva nayo. Dvinnanti dvīsu bhuñjamānesu ekasmiṃ uṭṭhāya dente na gaṇhati. Kasmā? ‘‘Ekassa kabaḷantarāyo hotī’’ti. Na gabbhiniyātiādīsu pana ‘‘gabbhiniyā kucchiyaṃ dārako kilamati. Pāyantiyā dārakassa khīrantarāyo hoti, purisantaragatāya ratiantarāyo hotī’’ti na gaṇhati. Saṃkittīsūti saṃkittetvā katabhattesu, dubbhikkhasamaye kira acelakasāvakā acelakānaṃ atthāya tato tato taṇḍulādīni samādapetvā bhattaṃ pacanti. Ukkaṭṭho acelako tatopi na paṭiggaṇhati. Na yattha sāti yattha sunakho – ‘‘piṇḍaṃ labhissāmī’’ti upaṭṭhito hoti, tattha tassa adatvā āhaṭaṃ na gaṇhati. Kasmā? Etassa piṇḍantarāyo hotīti. Saṇḍasaṇḍacārinīti samūhasamūhacārinī, sace hi acelakaṃ disvā – ‘‘imassa bhikkhaṃ dassāmā’’ti manussā bhattagehaṃ pavisanti, tesu ca pavisantesu kaḷopimukhādīsu nilīnā makkhikā uppatitvā saṇḍasaṇḍā caranti, tato āhaṭaṃ bhikkhaṃ na gaṇhati. Kasmā? Maṃ nissāya makkhikānaṃ gocarantarāyo jātoti. Thusodakanti  sabbasassasambhārehi kataṃ sovīrakaṃ. Ettha ca surāpānameva sāvajjaṃ, ayaṃ pana sabbesupi sāvajjasaññī. Ekāgārikoti yo ekasmiṃyeva gehe bhikkhaṃ labhitvā nivattati . Ekālopikoti yo ekeneva ālopena yāpeti. Dvāgārikādīsupi eseva nayo. Ekissāpi dattiyāti ekāya dattiyā. Datti nāma ekā khuddakapāti hoti, yattha aggabhikkhaṃ pakkhipitvā ṭhapenti. Ekāhikanti ekadivasantarikaṃ. Addhamāsikanti addhamāsantarikaṃ. Pariyāyabhattabhojananti vārabhattabhojanaṃ, ekāhavārena dvīhavārena sattāhavārena aḍḍhamāsavārenāti evaṃ divasavārena āgatabhattabhojanaṃ.
commentary_english:
394.
There, *tapopakkama* means the beginning of austerity (tapa), that is, the actions of austerity.
*Sāmaññasaṅkhāta* means designated as the work of a *samaṇa* (ascetic).
*Brahmaññasaṅkhāta* means designated as the work of a *brāhmaṇa*.
*Acelaka* means *niccola*, that is, naked.
*Muttācāra* means behaving without restraint (*visaṭṭhācāra*), being without the customary behavior of noble sons in worldly matters, such as evacuating bowels and bladder: he evacuates his bowels, urinates, eats, and consumes [food] just as he is.
*Hatthāpalekhana* means that when food (*piṇḍa*) is in his hand, he licks his hand with his tongue; or, having defecated, he wipes his hand while regarding it as a stick.
"Come here, venerable sir (*bhante*), for the purpose of taking almsfood (*bhikkhā*)"—if he does not come when he is told this, he is a "non-comer-respectful one" (*na ehibhaddantiko*).
"In that case, stay here, venerable sir"—even when told this, if he does not stay, he is a "non-stayer-respectful one" (*natiṭṭhabhaddantiko*).
Even both of those, it seems, he does not do, [thinking,] "This statement will be done for me."
*Abhihaṭanti*: almsfood (*bhikkhā*) brought having taken [it] beforehand; *uddissakatanti*: almsfood announced thus, "This was done having designated you."
*Na nimantananti*: he does not approve of, nor does he accept, almsfood to which he was invited thus, "You should enter such-and-such a family or street or village."
*Nakumbhimukhāti*: he does not accept almsfood being given having drawn [it] out from a pot (*kumbhi*).
*Na kaḷopimukhāti*: *kaḷopīti* is a pot (*ukkhali*) or a dish (*pacchi*); he does not accept [almsfood] even from that.
Why? [He thinks,] "The pot and dish receive a blow with a ladle because of me."
*Na eḷakamantaranti*: he does not accept [almsfood] being given having made a door-bolt (*ummāra*) in between.
Why? "This one obtains inner actions because of me."
The same method applies in the case of staffs and pestles too.
*Dvinnanti*: among two eating, he does not accept from one who, having risen, is giving.
Why? "There is an obstruction to the morsel (*kabala*) of one."
*Na gabbhiniyātiādīsu*: moreover, regarding a pregnant woman (*gabbhinī*) etc., [he does not accept almsfood thinking,] "A child is exhausted in the belly of the pregnant woman.
There is an obstruction of milk for a nursing child; there is an obstruction of pleasure for one gone between men."
*Saṃkittīsūti*: at jointly agreed upon meals, it seems that, in times of famine, disciples of the naked ascetics, having gathered rice (*taṇḍula*) etc. from here and there for the sake of the naked ascetics, cook food.
An extreme naked ascetic does not accept even from that.
He does not accept almsfood brought without giving to a dog or a jackal (*sunakha*)—"I will obtain almsfood (*piṇḍa*)"—that is waiting nearby.
Why? "There is an obstruction to the almsfood (*piṇḍa*) of that one."
*Saṇḍasaṇḍacārinīti*: moving in a crowd, in a group; if, indeed, having seen a naked ascetic, people enter a food-hall [thinking,] "We will give almsfood to this one," and, with those entering, flies hidden in the mouths of pots (*kaḷopimukhādīsu*) fly up and move in crowds, he does not accept almsfood brought from that.
Why? "Because of me, there is an obstruction to the range of the flies."
*Thusodakanti*: *sovīraka* made from all collections of crops (*sabbasassasambhārehi*).
And here, indeed, drinking alcohol (*surā*) itself is blameworthy (*sāvajja*); but this one regards everything as blameworthy.
*Ekāgārika* means one who, having obtained almsfood in one house alone, turns back.
*Ekālopika* means one who lives on one morsel (*ālopa*) alone.
The same method applies in the case of two-house-goers etc. too.
*Ekissāpi dattiyāti*: by one gift (*datti*) also.
A *datti* is a small bowl in which they put the best almsfood (*aggabhikkhaṃ*) and keep [it].
*Ekāhika* means one day intervening.
*Addhamāsika* means half a month intervening.
*Pariyāyabhattabhojana* means food taken in turn, that is, food taken according to a turn every day, a turn every two days, a turn every seven days, a turn every half-month; thus, food taken that has come by a turn of days.

mula_pali: 395. ‘‘Imepi kho, āvuso gotama, tapopakkamā etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sāmaññasaṅkhātā ca brahmaññasaṅkhātā ca. Sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
mula_english:
"And these, friend Gotama, are practices of asceticism that are considered acts of a *śramaṇa* and acts of a *brāhmaṇa*.

He might be an eater of greens (*śākabhakṣa*), or an eater of millet (*śāmākabhakṣa*), or an eater of wild rice (*nīvārabhakṣa*), or an eater of water plants (*daddulabhakṣa*), or an eater of moss (*haṭabhakṣa*), or an eater of rice bran (*kaṇabhakṣa*), or an eater of rice scum (*ācāmabhakṣa*), or an eater of oil-cake (*piññākabhakṣa*), or an eater of grass (*tiṇabhakṣa*), or an eater of cow dung (*gomayabhakṣa*); he lives on forest roots and fruits, he feeds on fallen fruit."
commentary_pali: 395.Sākabhakkhoti  allasākabhakkho. Sāmākabhakkhoti sāmākataṇḍulabhakkho. Nīvārādīsu nīvāro nāma araññe sayaṃjātā vīhijāti. Daddulanti cammakārehi cammaṃ likhitvā chaḍḍitakasaṭaṃ. Haṭaṃ vuccati silesopi sevālopi. Kaṇanti kuṇḍakaṃ. Ācāmoti bhattaukkhalikāya laggo jhāmakaodano, taṃ chaḍḍitaṭṭhānatova gahetvā khādati, ‘‘odanakañjiya’’ntipi vadanti. Piññākādayo pākaṭā eva. Pavattaphalabhojīti patitaphalabhojī.
commentary_english:
395. *Sākabhakkho* means one who eats fresh herbs.

*Sāmākabhakkho* means one who eats *sāmāka* rice.

Among *nīvāra* and others, *nīvāra* is a type of rice that grows wild in the forest.

*Daddulanti* means the discarded waste after leather has been scraped by leather workers.

*Haṭaṃ* is called *silesa* and also *sevāla*.

*Kaṇanti* means a pot (*kuṇḍakaṃ*).

*Ācāmo* means the burnt rice that sticks to the cooking pot. They take it from the place it was thrown away and eat it, they also call it rice gruel (*odana-kañjiya*).

*Piññāka* and others are well known.

*Pavattaphalabhojī* means one who eats fallen fruit (*patitaphalabhojī*).

mula_pali: 396. ‘‘Imepi kho, āvuso gotama, tapopakkamā etesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ sāmaññasaṅkhātā ca brahmaññasaṅkhātā ca. Sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṃsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi  dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhikampi dhāreti, kesamassulocakopi hoti kesamassulocanānuyogamanuyutto, ubbhaṭṭhakopi ubbhaṭṭhikopi (ka.) hoti āsanapaṭikkhitto, ukkuṭikopi hoti ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyutto, kaṇṭakāpassayikopi hoti kaṇṭakāpassaye seyyaṃ kappeti, phalakaseyyampi kappeti, thaṇḍilaseyyampi kappeti, ekapassayikopi hoti rajojalladharo, abbhokāsikopi hoti yathāsanthatiko , vekaṭikopi hoti vikaṭabhojanānuyogamanuyutto, apānakopi hoti apānakattamanuyutto, sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharatī’’ti.
mula_english:
396.
"Furthermore, friend Gotama, these practices of austerity are considered ascetic practices ( *sāmaññasaṅkhātā*) and practices leading to Brahman (*brahmaññasaṅkhātā*) by those ascetics and Brahmins.

He wears coarse hemp garments (*sāṇāni*), mixed hemp garments (*masāṇāni*), shrouds taken from corpses (*chavadussāni*), rags from dust heaps (*paṃsukūlāni*), *tirīṭa* garments, antelope skins (*ajina*), antelope skin fragments (*ajinakkhipa*), garments of *kusa* grass (*kusacīra*), garments of bark (*vākacīra*), garments of wood shavings (*phalakacīra*), blankets of human hair (*kesakambala*), blankets of animal hair (*vāḷakambala*), or owl’s wings (*ulūkapakkhika*). He is one who plucks out his hair and beard (*kesamassulocaka*), devoted to the practice of plucking out his hair and beard. He is one who remains standing (*ubbhaṭṭhaka*), rejecting seats; he is one who constantly squats (*ukkuṭika*), devoted to the practice of squatting. He is one who uses a bed of thorns (*kaṇṭakāpassayika*), making a bed of thorns; he uses a plank bed (*phalakaseyya*), or a bare-ground bed (*thaṇḍilaseyya*). He dwells practicing bathing in water three times daily including the evening (*sāyatatiyaka*)."
commentary_pali: 396.Sāṇānīti sāṇavākacoḷāni. Masāṇānīti missakacoḷāni. Chavadussānīti matasarīrato chaḍḍitavatthāni, erakatiṇādīni vā ganthetvā katanivāsanāni. Paṃsukūlānīti pathaviyaṃ chaḍḍitanantakāni. Tirīṭānīti rukkhatacavatthāni. Ajinanti ajinamigacammaṃ. Ajinakkhipanti tadeva majjhe phālitakaṃ. Kusacīranti kusatiṇāni ganthetvā katacīraṃ. Vākacīraphalakacīresupi eseva nayo. Kesakambalanti manussakesehi katakambalaṃ. Yaṃ sandhāya  vuttaṃ – Vāḷakambalanti  assavālehi katakambalaṃ. Ulūkapakkhikanti ulūkapakkhāni ganthetvā katanivāsanaṃ. Ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyuttoti ukkuṭikavīriyaṃ anuyutto, gacchantopi ukkuṭikova hutvā uppatitvā uppatitvā gacchati. Kaṇṭakāpassayikoti ayakaṇṭake vā pakatikaṇṭake vā bhūmiyaṃ koṭṭetvā tattha cammaṃ attharitvā ṭhānacaṅkamādīni karoti. Seyyanti sayantopi tattheva seyyaṃ kappeti. Phalakaseyyanti rukkhaphalake seyyaṃ. Thaṇḍilaseyyanti thaṇḍile ucce bhūmiṭhāne seyyaṃ. Ekapassayikoti ekapasseneva sayati. Rajojalladharoti sarīraṃ telena makkhitvā rajuṭṭhānaṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati, athassa sarīre rajojallaṃ laggati, taṃ dhāreti. Yathāsanthatikoti laddhaṃ āsanaṃ akopetvā yadeva labhati, tattheva nisīdanasīlo. Vekaṭikoti vikaṭakhādanasīlo. Vikaṭanti gūthaṃ vuccati. Apānakoti paṭikkhittasītudakapāno. Sāyaṃ tatiyamassāti sāyatatiyakaṃ. Pāto, majjhanhike, sāyanti divasassa tikkhattuṃ pāpaṃ pavāhessāmīti udakorohanānuyogaṃ anuyutto viharatīti.
commentary_english:
396. *Sāṇāni* means *sāṇa-vāka-coḷāni*.
*Masāṇāni* means *missaka-coḷāni*.
*Chavadussāni* means discarded clothes from a dead body (matasarīrato chaḍḍitavatthāni), or dwellings made by stringing together *eraka* grass and so on (erakatiṇādīni vā ganthetvā katanivāsanāni).
*Paṃsukūlāni* means abandoned cloths on the ground (pathaviyaṃ chaḍḍitanantakāni).
*Tirīṭāni* means clothes made of tree bark (rukkhatacavatthāni).
*Ajinaṃ* means the skin of an antelope (*ajinamigacammaṃ*).
*Ajinakkhipanti* means the same thing split in the middle (*tadeva majjhe phālitakaṃ*).
*Kusacīraṃ* means a garment made by stringing together *kusa* grass (*kusatiṇāni ganthetvā katacīraṃ*).
The same rule applies to garments made of bark (*vākacīra*), and garments made of leaf (*phalakacīra*)—*vākacīraphalakacīresupi eseva nayo*.
*Kesakambalaṃ* means a blanket made of human hair (*manussakesehi katakambalaṃ*).
With reference to which it was said: *Vāḷakambalaṃ* means a blanket made of horsehair (*assavālehi katakambalaṃ*).
*Ulūkapakkhikaṃ* means a dwelling made by stringing together owl feathers (*ulūkapakkhāni ganthetvā katanivāsanaṃ*).
*Ukkuṭikappadhānamanuyutto* means devoted to *ukkuṭika* effort (*ukkuṭikavīriyaṃ anuyutto*), even while walking, he goes along hopping and jumping as if he were in the *ukkuṭika* position (*gacchantopi ukkuṭikova hutvā uppatitvā uppatitvā gacchati*).
*Kaṇṭakāpassayiko* means having pressed into the ground either iron thorns (*ayakaṇṭake vā*) or natural thorns (*pakatikaṇṭake vā*), and having spread a hide there, he does walking and pacing and so on (*bhūmiyaṃ koṭṭetvā tattha cammaṃ attharitvā ṭhānacaṅkamādīni karoti*).
*Seyyanti* means even while lying down, he arranges his bed right there (*sayantopi tattheva seyyaṃ kappeti*).
*Phalakaseyyaṃ* means sleeping on a wooden plank (*rukkhaphalake seyyaṃ*).
*Thaṇḍilaseyyaṃ* means sleeping on the bare ground, on high ground (*thaṇḍile ucce bhūmiṭhāne seyyaṃ*).
*Ekapassayiko* means he sleeps only on one side (*ekapasseneva sayati*).
*Rajojalladharo* means having smeared his body with oil, he stands in a dusty place (*sarīraṃ telena makkhitvā rajuṭṭhānaṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati*), then the dirt adheres to his body, and he bears it (*athassa sarīre rajojallaṃ laggati, taṃ dhāreti*).
*Yathāsanthatiko* means without spoiling whatever seat he has obtained (*laddhaṃ āsanaṃ akopetvā*), whatever he obtains, he is in the habit of sitting right there (*yadeva labhati, tattheva nisīdanasīlo*).
*Vekaṭiko* means one who is in the habit of eating in a grotesque manner (*vikaṭakhādanasīlo*).
*Vikaṭaṃ* means feces is called (*gūthaṃ vuccati*).
*Apānako* means one who has refused cold water (*paṭikkhittasītudakapāno*).
*Sāyaṃ tatiyamassa* means *sāyatatiyakaṃ*.
“In the morning, at midday, and in the evening, I will wash away my sins three times a day” (*pāto, majjhanhike, sāyanti divasassa tikkhattuṃ pāpaṃ pavāhessāmīti*)—thus he dwells devoted to the practice of descending into the water (*udakorohanānuyogaṃ anuyutto viharatīti*).

mula_pali: 397. ‘‘Acelako  cepi, kassapa, hoti, muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano…pe… iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati. Tassa cāyaṃ sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā abhāvitā hoti asacchikatā. Atha kho so ārakāva sāmaññā ārakāva brahmaññā. Yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaṃ abyāpajjaṃ mettacittaṃ bhāveti, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati. Ayaṃ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaṇo itipi brāhmaṇo itipi. ‘‘Sākabhakkho cepi, kassapa, hoti, sāmākabhakkho…pe… vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī. Tassa cāyaṃ sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā abhāvitā hoti asacchikatā. Atha kho so ārakāva sāmaññā ārakāva brahmaññā. Yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaṃ abyāpajjaṃ mettacittaṃ bhāveti, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme  sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati. Ayaṃ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaṇo itipi brāhmaṇo itipi. ‘‘Sāṇāni cepi, kassapa, dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti…pe… sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto  viharati. Tassa cāyaṃ sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā abhāvitā hoti asacchikatā. Atha kho so ārakāva sāmaññā ārakāva brahmaññā . Yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaṃ abyāpajjaṃ mettacittaṃ bhāveti, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati. Ayaṃ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaṇo itipi brāhmaṇo itipī’’ti.
mula_english:
"Kassapa, a naked ascetic may be one who follows a lax code, who licks his hands…pe…and he may live committed to the practice of taking food on alternate days or half-monthly.

But if his virtue, his mind, and his wisdom are undeveloped and unrealized, then indeed he is still far from being an ascetic or a *brāhmaṇa*.

But, Kassapa, when a *bhikṣu* develops non-enmity, non-ill-will, and a heart full of loving-kindness and, through the destruction of the *āsavas*, realizes and dwells in the undefiled deliverance of mind (*cetovimutti*), the deliverance through wisdom (*prajñāvimutti*), having realized it in this very life by his own insight, then, Kassapa, that *bhikṣu* is termed an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) and a *brāhmaṇa*."

commentary_pali: 397. Atha  bhagavā sīlasampadādīhi vinā tesaṃ tapopakkamānaṃ niratthakataṃ dassento – ‘‘acelako cepi kassapa hotī’’tiādimāha. Tattha ārakā vāti dūreyeva. Averanti  dosaveravirahitaṃ. Abyāpajjanti domanassabyāpajjarahitaṃ.
commentary_english:
397. Then, the Blessed One, showing the futility of their ascetic practices without the accomplishment of virtuous conduct (*śīlasampad*), and so on, spoke as follows: "Even if Kassapa is naked..." and so on.

There, they are far, far away.

They are without enmity, free from the harm of enmity (*dosaveravirahita*).

They are without ill will, free from the distress and ill will (*domanassabyāpajjarahita*).

mula_pali: 398. Evaṃ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘dukkaraṃ, bho gotama, sāmaññaṃ dukkaraṃ brahmañña’’nti. ‘‘Pakati kho esā, kassapa, lokasmiṃ ‘dukkaraṃ sāmaññaṃ dukkaraṃ brahmañña’nti. Imāya ca, kassapa, mattāya iminā tapopakkamena sāmaññaṃ  vā abhavissa brahmaññaṃ vā dukkaraṃ sudukkaraṃ, netaṃ abhavissa kallaṃ vacanāya – ‘dukkaraṃ sāmaññaṃ dukkaraṃ brahmañña’nti. ‘‘Sakkā ca panetaṃ abhavissa kātuṃ gahapatinā vā gahapatiputtena vā antamaso kumbhadāsiyāpi – ‘handāhaṃ sāṇānipi dhāremi, masāṇānipi dhāremi…pe… sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharāmī’ti. ‘‘Yasmā ca kho, kassapa, aññatreva imāya mattāya aññatra iminā tapopakkamena sāmaññaṃ vā hoti brahmaññaṃ vā dukkaraṃ sudukkaraṃ, tasmā etaṃ kallaṃ vacanāya – ‘dukkaraṃ sāmaññaṃ dukkaraṃ brahmañña’nti. mula_english:
398.

When this had been said, the naked ascetic Kāśyapa said to the Blessed One: “It is difficult, venerable Gotama, to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.”

“That is what people say, Kāśyapa, in the world: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

Even a naked ascetic, Kāśyapa, who is of loose conduct, a hand-licker…lives, devoted to the practice of taking food at stated intervals, even doing so every half-month.

If asceticism or the Brahman life could be attained by this measure, by this practice of austerity, it would not be right to say: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

It would be possible for a householder, a householder’s son, or even a slave-girl who fetches water to do this, saying: ‘Come, let me become a naked ascetic, of loose conduct, a hand-licker…I will live devoted to the practice of taking food at stated intervals, even doing so every half-month.’

But, Kāśyapa, because there is a very different kind of asceticism, a very different kind of practice of austerity, whereby asceticism or the Brahman life is very difficult to attain, therefore it is right to say: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

When, Kāśyapa, a *bhikṣu* (monk) cultivates a mind of loving-kindness, without enmity, without ill-will, and, through the destruction of the *āsavas* (influxes), realizes for himself, through direct knowledge, and dwells in the *anāsrava* (influx-free) liberation of mind, liberation through wisdom, in this very life.

That one, Kāśyapa, is called a *śramaṇa* (ascetic), that one is called a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin).

Even one who eats greens, Kāśyapa, or eats millet…lives on roots and fruits of the forest, eating fallen fruit.

If asceticism or the Brahman life could be attained by this measure, by this practice of austerity, it would not be right to say: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

It would be possible for a householder, a householder’s son, or even a slave-girl who fetches water to do this, saying: ‘Come, let me become an eater of greens, or an eater of millet…I will live on roots and fruits of the forest, eating fallen fruit.’

But, Kāśyapa, because there is a very different kind of asceticism, a very different kind of practice of austerity, whereby asceticism or the Brahman life is very difficult to attain, therefore it is right to say: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

When, Kāśyapa, a *bhikṣu* (monk) cultivates a mind of loving-kindness, without enmity, without ill-will, and, through the destruction of the *āsavas* (influxes), realizes for himself, through direct knowledge, and dwells in the *anāsrava* (influx-free) liberation of mind, liberation through wisdom, in this very life.

That one, Kāśyapa, is called a *śramaṇa* (ascetic), that one is called a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin).

Even one who wears hempen clothes, Kāśyapa, or wears clothes of hemp mixed with other materials... lives devoted to the practice of bathing in water every evening as the third act of the day.

If asceticism or the Brahman life could be attained by this measure, by this practice of austerity, it would not be right to say: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

It would be possible for a householder, a householder’s son, or even a slave-girl who fetches water to do this, saying: ‘Come, let me wear hempen clothes, or wear clothes of hemp mixed with other materials…I will live devoted to the practice of bathing in water every evening as the third act of the day.’

But, Kāśyapa, because there is a very different kind of asceticism, a very different kind of practice of austerity, whereby asceticism or the Brahman life is very difficult to attain, therefore it is right to say: ‘It is difficult to be an ascetic; it is difficult to be a Brahmin.’

When, Kāśyapa, a *bhikṣu* (monk) cultivates a mind of loving-kindness, without enmity, without ill-will, and, through the destruction of the *āsavas* (influxes), realizes for himself, through direct knowledge, and dwells in the *anāsrava* (influx-free) liberation of mind, liberation through wisdom, in this very life.

That one, Kāśyapa, is called a *śramaṇa* (ascetic), that one is called a *brāhmaṇa* (Brahmin).
commentary_pali: 398.Dukkaraṃ, bho gotamāti idaṃ kassapo ‘‘mayaṃ pubbe ettakamattaṃ sāmaññañca brahmaññañcāti vicarāma, tumhe pana aññaṃyeva sāmaññañca brahmaññañca vadathā’’ti dīpento āha. Pakati kho esāti pakatikathā esā. Imāya ca, kassapa, mattāyāti ‘‘kassapa yadi iminā pamāṇena evaṃ parittakena paṭipattikkamena sāmaññaṃ vā brahmaññaṃ vā dukkaraṃ sudukkaraṃ nāma abhavissa, tato netaṃ abhavissa kallaṃ vacanāya dukkaraṃ sāmañña’’nti ayamettha padasambandhena saddhiṃ attho. Etena nayena sabbattha padasambandho veditabbo.
commentary_english:
398. "Difficult it is, O Gotama!" Thus Kassapa, revealing, spoke, "We formerly practiced only this much asceticism (*sāmañña*) and holy life (*brahmañña*), but you declare another asceticism and holy life entirely."

"This indeed is nature," this is a statement of nature.

"And by this measure, Kassapa," [he said,] "Kassapa, if by this limited standard, by such a slight course of practice, asceticism or holy life were difficult, extremely difficult indeed, then it would not be fitting to call this difficult asceticism." Here, this is the meaning together with the connection of the words.

By this method, the connection of words should be understood everywhere.

mula_pali: 399. Evaṃ  vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘dujjāno, bho gotama, samaṇo, dujjāno brāhmaṇo’’ti. ‘‘Pakati kho esā, kassapa, lokasmiṃ ‘dujjāno samaṇo dujjāno brāhmaṇo’ti. Yato kho, kassapa, bhikkhu averaṃ abyāpajjaṃ mettacittaṃ bhāveti , āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati. Ayaṃ vuccati, kassapa, bhikkhu samaṇo itipi brāhmaṇo itipi. ‘‘Sāṇāni  cepi, kassapa, dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti…pe… sāyatatiyakampi udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati. mula_english:
399. When this was said, the ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One: "Difficult to understand, venerable Gotama, is an ascetic ( *śramaṇa*), difficult to understand is a *brāhmaṇa*."

"It is indeed the nature of this, Kassapa, in the world: 'Difficult to understand is an ascetic (*śramaṇa*), difficult to understand is a *brāhmaṇa*.'

Even if an ascetic, Kassapa, lives naked, is of loose conduct, and licks his hands…pe… thus living committed to the practice of taking food at stated intervals of half a month.

And if by this measure, Kassapa, by this ascetic practice, an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa* would be difficult to understand, very difficult to understand, it would not be right to say: 'Difficult to understand is an ascetic (*śramaṇa*), difficult to understand is a *brāhmaṇa*.'

"And it would be possible for a householder or a householder's son or even a water-carrying slave girl to know: 'This ascetic is naked, is of loose conduct, and licks his hands…pe… thus living committed to the practice of taking food at stated intervals of half a month.'

"But because, Kassapa, there is a very different kind of asceticism (*samaṇa*) and Brahmanism beside this, it is right to say: “It is hard to understand an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa*.”

When, Kassapa, a monk ( *bhikkhu*) cultivates a mind of loving-kindness (*mettācitta*) free from enmity (*averaṃ*) and ill-will (*abyāpajjaṃ*), and through the destruction of the *āsavas* realizes by himself with direct knowledge, here and now, the liberation of mind (*cetovimuttiṃ*) and liberation by wisdom (*paññāvimuttiṃ*) which are free from *āsavas*, and having attained it, abides therein.

This one, Kassapa, is called a monk (*bhikkhu*), an ascetic (*samaṇa*), and a *brāhmaṇa*.

Even if he is a vegetable eater, Kassapa, or an eater of *sāmāka* grains...pe... he lives on forest roots and fruits, eating fallen fruits.

And if by this measure, Kassapa, by this ascetic practice, an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa* would be difficult to understand, very difficult to understand, it would not be right to say: 'Difficult to understand is an ascetic (*śramaṇa*), difficult to understand is a *brāhmaṇa*.'

"And it would be possible for a householder or a householder's son or even a water-carrying slave girl to know: 'This one is a vegetable eater or an eater of *sāmāka* grains...pe... he lives on forest roots and fruits, eating fallen fruits.'

"But because, Kassapa, there is a very different kind of asceticism (*samaṇa*) and Brahmanism beside this, it is right to say: “It is hard to understand an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa*.”

When, Kassapa, a monk ( *bhikkhu*) cultivates a mind of loving-kindness (*mettācitta*) free from enmity (*averaṃ*) and ill-will (*abyāpajjaṃ*), and through the destruction of the *āsavas* realizes by himself with direct knowledge, here and now, the liberation of mind (*cetovimuttiṃ*) and liberation by wisdom (*paññāvimuttiṃ*) which are free from *āsavas*, and having attained it, abides therein.

This one, Kassapa, is called a monk (*bhikkhu*), an ascetic (*samaṇa*), and a *brāhmaṇa*.

Even if, Kassapa, he wears hempen clothes (*sāṇāni*), or clothes of hemp mixed with other material (*masāṇāni*)...pe...he dwells, committed to the practice of bathing three times a day including the evening.

And if by this measure, Kassapa, by this ascetic practice, an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa* would be difficult to understand, very difficult to understand, it would not be right to say: 'Difficult to understand is an ascetic (*śramaṇa*), difficult to understand is a *brāhmaṇa*.'

"And it would be possible for a householder or a householder's son or even a water-carrying slave girl to know: 'This one wears hempen clothes (*sāṇāni*), or clothes of hemp mixed with other material (*masāṇāni*)...pe...he dwells, committed to the practice of bathing three times a day including the evening.'

"But because, Kassapa, there is a very different kind of asceticism (*samaṇa*) and Brahmanism beside this, it is right to say: “It is hard to understand an ascetic (*śramaṇa*) or a *brāhmaṇa*.”

When, Kassapa, a monk ( *bhikkhu*) cultivates a mind of loving-kindness (*mettācitta*) free from enmity (*averaṃ*) and ill-will (*abyāpajjaṃ*), and through the destruction of the *āsavas* realizes by himself with direct knowledge, here and now, the liberation of mind (*cetovimuttiṃ*) and liberation by wisdom (*paññāvimuttiṃ*) which are free from *āsavas*, and having attained it, abides therein.

This one, Kassapa, is called a monk (*bhikkhu*), an ascetic (*samaṇa*), and a *brāhmaṇa*."
commentary_pali: 399.Dujjānoti  idampi so ‘‘mayaṃ pubbe ettakena samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā hotīti vicarāma, tumhe pana aññathā vadathā’’ti idaṃ sandhāyāha. Athassa bhagavā taṃ pakativādaṃ paṭikkhipitvā sabhāvatova dujjānabhāvaṃ āvikaronto punapi – ‘‘pakati kho’’tiādimāha. Tatrāpi vuttanayeneva padasambandhaṃ katvā attho veditabbo.
commentary_english:
399. Because it is difficult to know, he says this, implying, "We formerly roamed about as ascetics or Brahmins to this extent, but you speak differently."

Then, the Blessed One, having rejected that theory of inherent nature and revealing the state of being difficult to know even by its own nature, again spoke, beginning with, "Indeed, inherent nature..."

There also, having made the connection of words according to the method already stated, the meaning should be understood.

mula_pali: 400. Evaṃ vutte, acelo kassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘katamā pana sā, bho gotama, sīlasampadā, katamā cittasampadā, katamā paññāsampadā’’ti? ‘‘Idha, kassapa, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ, sammāsambuddho…pe… (yathā 190-193 anucchedesu, evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ) bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno indriyesu guttadvāro satisampajaññena samannāgato santuṭṭho.
mula_english:
400.

When this was said, the naked ascetic Kassapa said this to the Blessed One: "But which, good Gotama, is the accomplishment of morality (*śīlasampadā*), which the accomplishment of mind (*cittasampadā*), which the accomplishment of wisdom (*prajñāsampadā*)?"

"Here, Kassapa, the *tathāgata* arises in the world, an *arhat*, a fully enlightened one…pe… (as in sections 190-193, so it should be expanded) seeing danger, he undertakes and trains himself in the precepts, endowed with skillful bodily and verbal action, his livelihood is perfectly pure, accomplished in morality (*śīlasampanna*), with guarded doors in the senses, endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension, content.
commentary_pali: 400-401.Katamā pana sā, bho gotamāti kasmā pucchati. Ayaṃ kira paṇḍito bhagavato kathentasseva kathaṃ uggahesi, atha attano paṭipattiyā niratthakataṃ viditvā samaṇo gotamo – ‘‘tassa ‘cāyaṃ sīlasampadā, cittasampadā, paññāsampadā abhāvitā hoti asacchikatā, atha kho so ārakāva sāmaññā’tiādimāha. Handa dāni naṃ tā sampattiyo pucchāmī’’ti sīlasampadādivijānanatthaṃ pucchati. Athassa bhagavā buddhuppādaṃ dassetvā tantidhammaṃ kathento tā sampattiyo dassetuṃ – ‘‘idha kassapā’’tiādimāha. Imāya ca kassapa sīlasampadāyāti idaṃ arahattaphalameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Arahattaphalapariyosānañhi bhagavato sāsanaṃ. Tasmā arahattaphalasampayuttāhi sīlacittapaññāsampadāhi  aññā uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā sīlādisampadā natthīti āha.
commentary_english:
400-401. But why does he ask, "Which one is that, sir Gotama?"
It seems this learned man grasped the Blessed One's teaching as he was expounding it. Then, realizing the meaninglessness of his own practice, the ascetic Gotama said, "His virtue, concentration, and wisdom are uncultivated and unrealized, but he is far from the ascetic life."
He asks to understand virtue and other attainments, saying, "Come now, let me ask him about those attainments."
Then the Blessed One, showing him the arising of a Buddha and explaining the Dharma of the string, spoke to show those attainments, saying, "Here, Kassapa."
And this, "Kassapa, with this virtue," was said with reference to the fruit of Arahantship (arahattaphala).
Indeed, the dispensation of the Blessed One culminates in the fruit of Arahantship (arahattaphala).
Therefore, he said, "There is no other attainment of virtue, concentration, and wisdom that is higher or more excellent than the attainments of virtue, concentration, and wisdom associated with the fruit of Arahantship (arahattaphala)."

mula_pali: 401. ‘‘Kathañca, kassapa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti? Idha, kassapa, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati. Idampissa hoti sīlasampadāya  …pe… (yathā 194 yāva 210 anucchedesu) ‘‘Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvena jīvitaṃ kappenti . Seyyathidaṃ – santikammaṃ paṇidhikammaṃ…pe… (yathā 211 anucchede) osadhīnaṃ patimokkho iti vā iti, evarūpāya tiracchānavijjāya micchājīvā paṭivirato hoti. Idampissa hoti sīlasampadāya. ‘‘Sa kho so ayaṃ kho (ka.), kassapa, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato. Seyyathāpi, kassapa, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nihatapaccāmitto na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ paccatthikato. Evameva kho, kassapa, bhikkhu evaṃ sīlasampanno na kutoci bhayaṃ samanupassati, yadidaṃ sīlasaṃvarato. So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Evaṃ kho, kassapa, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti. Ayaṃ kho, kassapa, sīlasampadā…pe…  paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Idampissa hoti cittasampadāya…pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Idampissa hoti cittasampadāya. Ayaṃ kho, kassapa, cittasampadā. ‘‘So evaṃ samāhite citte…pe… ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti…pe…  idampissa hoti paññāsampadāya…pe… nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti…pe… idampissa hoti paññāsampadāya. Ayaṃ kho, kassapa, paññāsampadā. ‘‘Imāya  ca, kassapa, sīlasampadāya cittasampadāya paññāsampadāya aññā sīlasampadā cittasampadā paññāsampadā uttaritarā vā paṇītatarā vā natthi.
mula_english:
401.
“And how, Kassapa, is a monk perfected in morality (sīlasampanno)? Here, Kassapa, a monk, abandoning the taking of life (pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya), abstains from taking life (pāṇātipātā paṭivirato), with his staff laid aside, his weapon laid aside, scrupulous, full of kindness, he dwells compassionate to all living beings (sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati).

This pertains to his perfection of morality (sīlasampadāya)… and so on… (as in sections 194 up to 210) “Whereas some ascetics and Brahmins, feeding on the food of the faithful, make their living by such base arts, such wrong means of livelihood.

For example: pacifying work, dedicating work… and so on… (as in section 211) the *prātimokṣa* of herbs, and so on, he abstains from wrong livelihood by such debased arts.

This pertains to his perfection of morality (sīlasampadāya).

“And then, Kassapa, that monk who is thus perfected in morality (sīlasampanno) sees no danger from any side owing to his being restrained by morality (sīlasaṃvarato).

Just as, Kassapa, a Kṣatriya king, a head-anointed noble warrior who has defeated his enemies sees no danger anywhere from his enemies (paccatthikato).

Just so, Kassapa, the monk who is thus possessed of moral discipline sees no danger anywhere in regard to his restraint by moral discipline (sīlasaṃvarato).

Possessing this noble aggregate of virtue (arīyena sīlakkhandhena), he experiences within himself a blameless happiness (anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti).

In this way, Kassapa, a monk is perfected in morality (sīlasampanno hoti).

That, Kassapa, is the perfection of morality (sīlasampadā)… and so on… he attains to and dwells in the first *jhāna* (paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati).

This pertains to his perfection of mind (cittasampadāya)… and so on… the second *jhāna* (dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ)… and so on… the third *jhāna* (tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ)… and so on… he attains to and dwells in the fourth *jhāna* (catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati).

This pertains to his perfection of mind (cittasampadāya).

That, Kassapa, is the perfection of mind (cittasampadā).

“When his mind is thus concentrated (samāhite citte)… and so on… he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge and vision (*ñāṇadassanāya cittaṃ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti*)… and so on… this pertains to his perfection of wisdom (*paññāsampadāya*)… and so on… ‘there is nothing further here’ (*nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāti*)… and so on… this pertains to his perfection of wisdom (*paññāsampadāya*).

That, Kassapa, is the perfection of wisdom (*paññāsampadā*).

“And, Kassapa, there is no other perfection of morality (sīlasampadāya), perfection of mind (cittasampadāya), or perfection of wisdom (paññāsampadāya) that is higher or more excellent than this perfection of morality (sīlasampadā), perfection of mind (cittasampadā), or perfection of wisdom (paññāsampadā).

commentary_english:
400-401. But which is that, sir Gotama, why do you ask?

It seems that this learned man grasped the Blessed One's teaching, but having realized the futility of his own practice, the ascetic Gotama said, "His morality, mental accomplishment, and wisdom are undeveloped and unrealized, and he is far from being an ascetic."

"Come now, I will ask him about those accomplishments," he asks, intending to understand morality and so on.

Then the Blessed One, having shown him the arising of the Buddha, while explaining the Dhamma of the string, to show those accomplishments, said, "Here, Kassapa."

And this, Kassapa, regarding the accomplishment of morality, was spoken with reference to the fruit of arahantship itself.

For the dispensation of the Blessed One culminates in the fruit of arahantship.

Therefore, he said, "There is no other accomplishment of morality, mind, and wisdom that is higher or more excellent than those connected with the fruit of arahantship."

mula_pali: 402. ‘‘Santi, kassapa, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavādā. Te anekapariyāyena sīlassa vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyaṃ paramaṃ sīlaṃ, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo! Atha kho ahameva  tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhisīlaṃ. ‘‘Santi, kassapa, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā tapojigucchāvādā. Te anekapariyāyena tapojigucchāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyā paramā  tapojigucchā, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo! Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhijegucchaṃ. ‘‘Santi, kassapa, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā paññāvādā. Te anekapariyāyena paññāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyā paramā paññā, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo! Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhipaññaṃ. ‘‘Santi, kassapa, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā vimuttivādā. Te anekapariyāyena vimuttiyā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti. Yāvatā, kassapa, ariyā paramā vimutti, nāhaṃ tattha attano samasamaṃ samanupassāmi, kuto bhiyyo! Atha kho ahameva tattha bhiyyo, yadidaṃ adhivimutti.
mula_english:
‘Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach morality (śīlavādā).
They praise morality (śīlassa vaṇṇaṃ) in various ways (anekapariyāyena).
But as regards the highest Ariyan morality (ariyaṃ paramaṃ sīlaṃ), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. Indeed, I surpass even that, namely, higher morality (adhisīlaṃ).

‘Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach self-mortification and scrupulous austerity (tapojigucchāvādā).
They praise self-mortification and scrupulous austerity (tapojigucchāya vaṇṇaṃ) in various ways (anekapariyāyena).
But as regards the highest Ariyan self-mortification and austerity (ariyā paramā tapojigucchā), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. Indeed, I surpass even that, namely, higher scrupulous austerity (adhijegucchaṃ).

‘Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach wisdom (paññāvādā).
They praise wisdom (paññāya vaṇṇaṃ) in various ways (anekapariyāyena).
But as regards the highest Ariyan wisdom (ariyā paramā paññā), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. Indeed, I surpass even that, namely, higher wisdom (adhipaññaṃ).

‘Kassapa, there are some ascetics and Brahmins who preach liberation (vimuttivādā).
They praise liberation (vimuttiyā vaṇṇaṃ) in various ways (anekapariyāyena).
But as regards the highest Ariyan liberation (ariyā paramā vimutti), Kassapa, I do not see any who have surpassed me in this. Indeed, I surpass even that, namely, higher liberation (adhivimutti).
commentary_pali: 402. Evañca  pana vatvā idāni anuttaraṃ mahāsīhanādaṃ nadanto – ‘‘santi kassapa eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā’’tiādimāha. Tattha ariyanti nirupakkilesaṃ paramavisuddhaṃ. Paramanti uttamaṃ, pañcasīlāni hiādiṃ katvā yāva pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlā sīlameva, lokuttaramaggaphalasampayuttaṃ pana paramasīlaṃ nāma. Nāhaṃ tatthāti tattha sīlepi paramasīlepi ahaṃ attano samasamaṃ mama sīlasamena sīlena mayā samaṃ puggalaṃ na passāmīti attho. Ahameva tattha bhiyyoti ahameva tasmiṃ sīle uttamo. Katamasmiṃ? Yadidaṃ adhisīlanti yaṃ etaṃ uttamaṃ sīlanti attho. Iti imaṃ paṭhamaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati. Tapojigucchavādāti  ye tapojigucchaṃ vadanti. Tattha tapatīti tapo, kilesasantāpakavīriyassetaṃ nāmaṃ, tadeva te kilese jigucchatīti jigucchā. Ariyā paramāti ettha niddosattā ariyā, aṭṭhaārambhavatthuvasenapi uppannā vipassanāvīriyasaṅkhātā tapojigucchā tapojigucchāva, maggaphalasampayuttā paramā nāma. Adhijegucchanti idha jigucchabhāvo jegucchaṃ, uttamaṃ jegucchaṃ adhijegucchaṃ, tasmā yadidaṃ adhijegucchaṃ, tattha ahameva bhiyyoti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Paññādhikārepi kammassakatāpaññā ca vipassanāpaññā ca paññā nāma, maggaphalasampayuttā paramā paññā nāma. Adhipaññanti ettha liṅgavipallāso veditabbo, ayaṃ panetthattho – yāyaṃ adhipaññā nāma ahameva tattha bhiyyoti vimuttādhikāre  tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttiyo vimutti nāma, samucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇavimuttiyo pana paramā vimuttīti veditabbā. Idhāpi ca yadidaṃ adhivimuttīti yā ayaṃ adhivimutti, ahameva tattha bhiyyoti attho.
commentary_english:
402.
And further, after saying this, now uttering an unsurpassed great lion's roar, he said, "There are some ascetics and Brahmins, Kassapa," and so on.

There, *ariya* means utterly pure, free from defilements (nirupakkilesaṃ paramavisuddhaṃ).

*Parama* means highest (uttamaṃ). Beginning with the five precepts (*pañcasīlāni*), and going as far as the morality of the *pātimokkhasaṃvara*, is merely morality (*sīla*). But that which is connected with the supramundane path and its fruit is called supreme morality (*paramasīlaṃ nāma*).

"I am not there (nāhaṃ tatthā ti)." The meaning (attho) is: "Even in that morality (*sīlepi*), and even in the supreme morality (*paramasīlepi*), I do not see a person (puggalaṃ) who is equal to myself (attano samasamaṃ), with morality similar to my morality (mama sīlasamena sīlena), with myself (mayā samaṃ)."

"I am far greater there (ahameva tattha bhiyyo ti)." That means, "I alone am the highest (*uttamo*) in that morality (*tasmiṃ sīle*)."

In which one (*katamasmiṃ*)? The meaning (attho) is: "In that which is called higher morality (*adhisīlanti*)", that is, "in that which is the highest morality (*yat etaṃ uttamaṃ sīlanti*)."

Thus, he utters this first lion's roar (*paṭhamaṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati*).

"Those who speak of disgust with austerity (tapojigucchavādā ti)" means those who speak of disgust with austerity (ye tapojigucchaṃ vadanti).

There, *tapo* means austerity, because it burns (*tapatīti tapo*). This is a name for the energy that inflames the defilements (*kilesasantāpakavīriyassetaṃ nāmaṃ*). *Jigucchā* means disgust, because it is this that feels disgust with those defilements (tadeva te kilese jigucchatīti jigucchā).

*Ariyā paramā ti*, here, *ariyā* is because of being without fault (*niddosattā ariyā*). *Tapojigucchā*, which is known as the energy of insight (*vipassanāvīriyasaṅkhātā*), arisen through the power of the eight grounds of effort (*aṭṭhaārambhavatthuvasenapi uppannā*) is simply disgust with austerity (tapojigucchāva). That which is connected with the path and its fruit (*maggaphalasampayuttā*) is called supreme (*paramā nāma*).

*Adhijegucchaṃ ti*. Here, *jegucchaṃ* is the state of disgust (*jigucchābhāvo jegucchaṃ*), *adhijegucchaṃ* is the highest disgust (*uttamaṃ jegucchaṃ adhijegucchaṃ*). Therefore (tasmā), the meaning here (evamettha attho) should be understood (daṭṭhabbo) thus: "that which is this higher disgust (*yadidaṃ adhijegucchaṃ*), I alone am far greater there (tattha ahameva bhiyyo ti)."

Even in the sphere of wisdom (*paññādhikārepi*), what is called wisdom (*paññā nāma*) is wisdom concerning one's ownership of one's *karma* (*kammassakatāpaññā*) and insight wisdom (*vipassanāpaññā ca*). That which is connected with the path and its fruit (*maggaphalasampayuttā*) is called supreme wisdom (*paramā paññā nāma*).

*Adhipaññaṃ ti*. Here, a change of gender (liṅgavipallāso) should be understood (veditabbo). This is the meaning here (*ayaṃ panetthattho*): "That which is this higher wisdom (*yāyaṃ adhipaññā nāma*), I alone am far greater there (*ahameva tattha bhiyyo ti*)." In the context of liberation (*vimuttādhikāre*), the liberations of temporary suppression of its factors (*tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttiyo*) are called liberation (*vimutti nāma*). But the liberations of complete destruction, tranquility, and escape (*samucchedapaṭipassaddhinissaraṇavimuttiyo*) are to be understood (veditabbā) as supreme liberation (*paramā vimuttīti*).

And here also (idhāpi ca), "that which is this higher liberation (*yadidaṃ adhivimuttī ti*)", that which is this higher liberation (*yā ayaṃ adhivimutti*), the meaning (attho) is "I alone am far greater there (*ahameva tattha bhiyyo ti*)."

mula_pali: 403. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ  kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘sīhanādaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo nadati, tañca kho suññāgāre nadati, no parisāsū’ti. Te – ‘mā heva’ntissu vacanīyā. ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadatī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, no  ca kho visārado nadatī’ti . Te – ‘mā heva’ntissu vacanīyā. ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadatī’’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā. ‘‘Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṃ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadati, no ca kho naṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti…pe… pañhañca naṃ pucchanti; no ca kho nesaṃ pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti…pe… pañhañca nesaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti; no ca kho pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti…pe… pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti; no ca kho sotabbaṃ maññanti…pe… sotabbañcassa maññanti; no ca kho sutvā pasīdanti…pe… sutvā cassa pasīdanti ; no ca kho pasannākāraṃ karonti…pe… pasannākārañca karonti; no ca kho tathattāya paṭipajjanti…pe… tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti; no ca kho paṭipannā ārādhentī’ti. Te – ‘mā heva’ntissu vacanīyā. ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadati, pañhañca naṃ pucchanti, pañhañca nesaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti, pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti, sotabbañcassa maññanti, sutvā cassa pasīdanti, pasannākārañca karonti, tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti, paṭipannā ca ārādhentī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā.
mula_english:
403.

“Kassapa, it is possible that wanderers of other sects might say: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars the lion’s roar (sīhanādaṃ), but he only roars it in empty places, not in company.’”

They should be told: “That is not so (mā heva).”

“The ascetic Gotama roars the lion’s roar (sīhanādañca), and he roars it in company (parisāsu ca nadatī)” That, Kassapa, is what they should be told.

“Kassapa, it is possible that wanderers of other sects might say: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars the lion’s roar (sīhanādañca), and he roars it in company (parisāsu ca nadati), but he does not roar it confidently (visārado nadatī).’”

They should be told: “That is not so (mā heva).”

“The ascetic Gotama roars the lion’s roar (sīhanādañca), and he roars it in company (parisāsu ca nadati), and he roars it confidently (visārado ca nadatī)” That, Kassapa, is what they should be told.

“Kassapa, it is possible that wanderers of other sects might say: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars the lion’s roar (sīhanādañca), and he roars it in company (parisāsu ca nadati), and he roars it confidently (visārado ca nadati), but they do not question him’… and so on … ‘they do question him; but when questioned he does not answer’ … and so on … ‘he does answer, but he does not win them over with his explanation of the question’ … and so on … ‘they do not think it worth listening to’ … and so on … ‘when they have heard it, they are not satisfied’ … and so on … ‘they do not show a sign of satisfaction’ … and so on … ‘they do show a sign of satisfaction; they do not set out for the realness’ … and so on … ‘they do set out for the realness; those who have set out do not satisfy him.’”

They should be told: “That is not so (mā heva).”
