“The ascetic Gotama roars the lion’s roar (sīhanādañca), and he roars it in company (parisāsu ca nadati), and he roars it confidently (visārado ca nadati), and they question him (pañhañca naṃ pucchanti), and when questioned he answers (pañhañca nesaṃ puṭṭho byākaroti), and he wins them over with his explanation of the question (pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheti), and they think it worth listening to (sotabbañcassa maññanti), and when they have heard it, they are satisfied (sutvā cassa pasīdanti), and they show a sign of satisfaction (pasannākārañca karonti), and they set out for the realness (tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti), and those who have set out satisfy him (paṭipannā ca ārādhentī)” That, Kassapa, is what they should be told.
commentary_pali: 403.Suññāgāreti suññe ghare, ekakova nisīditvāti adhippāyo. Parisāsu cāti aṭṭhasu parisāsu. Vuttampi cetaṃ – Pañhañca naṃ pucchantīti paṇḍitā devamanussā naṃ pañhaṃ abhisaṅkharitvā pucchanti. Byākarotīti  taṅkhaṇaññeva vissajjesi. Cittaṃ ārādhetīti pañhāvissajjanena mahājanassa cittaṃ paritosetiyeva. No ca kho sotabbaṃ maññantīti cittaṃ ārādhetvā kathentassapissa vacanaṃ pare sotabbaṃ na maññantīti, evañca vadeyyunti attho. Sotabbañcassa maññantīti devāpi manussāpi mahanteneva ussāhena sotabbaṃ maññanti. Pasīdantīti supasannā kallacittā muducittā honti. Pasannākāraṃ karontīti na muddhappasannāva honti, paṇītāni cīvarādīni veḷuvanavihārādayo ca mahāvihāre pariccajantā pasannākāraṃ karonti. Tathattāyāti yaṃ so dhammaṃ deseti tathā bhāvāya, dhammānudhammapaṭipattipūraṇatthāya paṭipajjantīti attho. Tathattāya ca paṭipajjantīti tathabhāvāya paṭipajjanti, tassa hi  bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā keci saraṇesu keci pañcasu sīlesu patiṭṭhahanti, apare nikkhamitvā pabbajanti. Paṭipannā ca ārādhentīti tañca pana paṭipadaṃ paṭipannā pūretuṃ sakkonti, sabbākārena pana pūrenti, paṭipattipūraṇena  tassa bhoto gotamassa cittaṃ ārādhentīti vattabbā. Imasmiṃ panokāse ṭhatvā sīhanādā samodhānetabbā. Ekaccaṃ tapassiṃ niraye nibbattaṃ passāmīti hi bhagavato eko sīhanādo. Aparaṃ sagge nibbattaṃ passāmīti eko. Akusaladhammappahāne ahameva seṭṭhoti eko. Kusaladhammasamādānepi ahameva seṭṭhoti eko. Akusaladhammappahāne mayhameva sāvakasaṅgho seṭṭhoti eko. Kusaladhammasamādānepi mayhaṃyeva sāvakasaṅgho seṭṭhoti eko. Sīlena mayhaṃ sadiso natthīti eko. Vīriyena mayhaṃ sadiso natthīti eko. Paññāya…pe… vimuttiyā…pe… sīhanādaṃ nadanto parisamajjhe nisīditvā nadāmīti eko. Visārado hutvā nadāmīti eko. Pañhaṃ maṃ pucchantīti eko. Pañhaṃ puṭṭho vissajjemīti eko. Vissajjanena parassa cittaṃ ārādhemīti eko. Sutvā sotabbaṃ maññantīti eko. Sutvā me pasīdantīti eko. Pasannākāraṃ karontīti eko. Yaṃ paṭipattiṃ desemi, tathattāya paṭipajjantīti eko. Paṭipannā ca maṃ ārādhentīti eko. Iti purimānaṃ dasannaṃ ekekassa – ‘‘parisāsu ca nadatī’’ti ādayo dasa dasa parivārā. Evaṃ te dasa purimānaṃ dasannaṃ parivāravasena sataṃ purimā ca dasāti dasādhikaṃ sīhanādasataṃ hoti. Ito aññasmiṃ pana sutte ettakā sīhanādā dullabhā, tenidaṃ suttaṃ mahāsīhanādanti vuccati. Iti bhagavā ‘‘sīhanādaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo nadati, tañca kho suññāgāre nadatī’’ti evaṃ vādānu vādaṃ paṭisedhetvā idāni parisati naditapubbaṃ sīhanādaṃ dassento ‘‘ekamidāha’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
403.
"Suññāgāra" means in an empty house, the idea is sitting alone.
Also in assemblies, in the eight assemblies.
It was also said that wise gods and humans ask him questions, contemplating and asking questions.
"He explains" means he immediately released [the answer] in that moment.
"He gladdens the mind" means by answering questions, he pleases the minds of the great multitude.
"They do not consider it worth listening to" means even when he gladdens the mind and speaks, others do not consider his words worth listening to. This is the meaning of how they might speak.
"They consider it worth listening to" means gods and humans alike consider it worth listening to with great enthusiasm.
"They are pleased" means they are very pleased, with clear minds and gentle minds.
"They make an appearance of pleasure" means they are not merely superficially pleased. Rather, they make an appearance of pleasure by giving away excellent robes and such things in the great monastery such as the Veḷuvana monastery.
"For suchness" means he teaches that Dharma for the sake of suchness, so that they practice for the sake of completing the practice of Dharma in accordance with the Dharma; this is the meaning.
And because they practice for suchness, they practice for that state of being. Hearing the Dharma of that blessed one, some take refuge in the refuges, some commit to the five precepts, others leave home and become renunciates.
And those who are practicing please [me], meaning those who are practicing that practice are able to complete it. Indeed, they complete it in every way. They are to be spoken of as pleasing the mind of that Gotama by completing the practice.
Having stood in this suitable place, the lion's roars are to be manifested.
"I see some ascetics reborn in hell" is one lion's roar of the Blessed One.
"I see others reborn in heaven" is one.
"I alone am the best in abandoning unwholesome dharmas" is one.
"I alone am the best in undertaking wholesome dharmas" is one.
"My community of disciples alone is the best in abandoning unwholesome dharmas" is one.
"My community of disciples alone is the best in undertaking wholesome dharmas" is one.
"There is no one like me in virtue" is one.
"There is no one like me in vigor" is one.
"In wisdom...in liberation... having roared the lion's roar, sitting in the midst of the assembly, I roar" is one.
"Having become confident, I roar" is one.
"They ask me questions" is one.
"Having been asked a question, I explain" is one.
"By explaining, I please the minds of others" is one.
"Having heard, they consider it worth listening to" is one.
"Having heard, they are pleased with me" is one.
"They make an appearance of pleasure" is one.
"The practice that I teach, they practice for suchness" is one.
"And those who are practicing please me" is one.
Thus, for each of the former ten, there are ten attendants beginning with "and he roars in the assemblies."
Thus, those ten and the former ten, by way of attendants, become a hundred. The former and ten are ten more than a hundred lion's roars.
But in another discourse, so many lion's roars are difficult to find. Therefore, this discourse is called the Great Lion's Roar (Mahāsīhanāda).
Thus, the Blessed One, having refuted the statement "The ascetic Gotama roars the lion's roar, and he roars it in an empty house," now showing the lion's roar that he had roared before in the assembly, said, "I said one thing," and so on.

mula_pali: 404. ‘‘Ekamidāhaṃ, kassapa, samayaṃ rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate. Tatra maṃ aññataro tapabrahmacārī  nigrodho nāma adhijegucche  pañhaṃ apucchi. Tassāhaṃ adhijegucche pañhaṃ puṭṭho byākāsiṃ. Byākate ca pana me attamano ahosi paraṃ viya mattāyā’’ti. ‘‘Ko hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā na attamano assa paraṃ viya mattāya? Ahampi hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā attamano paraṃ viya mattāya. Abhikkantaṃ, bhante, abhikkantaṃ, bhante. Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya – ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampada’’nti.
mula_english:
404. Once, Kassapa, I was staying at Rājagaha on Vulture Peak Mountain.

There, a certain ascetic student of Brahman, by the name of Nigrodha, asked me a question regarding the highest disgust.

When asked a question about the highest disgust, I explained it to him.

And when I explained, he was delighted with my explanation beyond all measure.’

“Lord, who on hearing the Dhamma of the Blessed One would not be delighted beyond all measure? Even I, Lord, on hearing the Dhamma of the Blessed One, am delighted beyond all measure.

Excellent, venerable sir! Excellent, venerable sir!

Just as, venerable sir, one might set upright what has been overturned, or reveal what has been hidden, or point out the way to one who is lost, or hold up an oil lamp in the darkness so that those with eyes might see forms, even so has the Dhamma been made clear by the Blessed One in many ways.

I go to the Blessed One for refuge, venerable sir, and to the Dhamma, and to the Order of monks (bhikkhusaṅgha).

May I receive the going forth in the Blessed One’s presence, venerable sir, may I receive the full admission.”
commentary_pali: 404. Tattha tatra maṃ aññataro tapabrahmacārīti tatra rājagahe gijjhakūṭe pabbate viharantaṃ maṃ aññataro tapabrahmacārī nigrodho nāma paribbājako . Adhijeguccheti vīriyena pāpajigucchanādhikāre pañhaṃ pucchi. Idaṃ yaṃ taṃ bhagavā gijjhakūṭe mahāvihāre nisinno udumbarikāya deviyā uyyāne nisinnassa nigrodhassa ca paribbājakassa sandhānassa ca upāsakassa dibbāya sotadhātuyā kathāsallāpaṃ sutvā ākāsenāgantvā tesaṃ santike paññatte āsane nisīditvā nigrodhena adhijegucche puṭṭhapañhaṃ vissajjesi, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Paraṃ viya mattāyāti paramāya mattāya, atimahanteneva pamāṇenāti attho. Ko hi, bhanteti ṭhapetvā andhabālaṃ diṭṭhigatikaṃ añño paṇḍitajātiko ‘‘ko nāma bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā na attamano assā’’ti vadati. Labheyyāhanti idaṃ so – ‘‘ciraṃ vata me aniyyānikapakkhe yojetvā attā kilamito, ‘sukkhanadītīre nhāyissāmī’ti samparivattentena viya thuse koṭṭentena viya na koci attho nipphādito. Handāhaṃ attānaṃ yoge yojessāmī’’ti cintetvā āha. Atha bhagavā yo anena khandhake titthiyaparivāso paññatto, yo aññatitthiyapubbo sāmaṇerabhūmiyaṃ ṭhito – ‘‘ahaṃ bhante, itthannāmo aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhāmi upasampadaṃ, svāhaṃ, bhante, saṃghaṃ cattāro māse parivāsaṃ yācāmī’’tiādinā (mahāva. 86) nayena samādiyitvā parivasati, taṃ sandhāya – ‘‘yo kho, kassapa, aññatitthiyapubbo’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
404.

There, there, someone said to me, "A wandering ascetic": There, in Rājagṛha, on Vulture Peak mountain, while I was dwelling, a wandering ascetic named Nigrodha.

"Adhijeguccha?" He asked a question concerning the undertaking of disgust for evil with vigor.

This was said referring to the fact that the Blessed One, sitting at Vulture Peak in the great monastery, having heard the conversation of Nigrodha the wandering ascetic, who was sitting in the park of the goddess Udumbarikā, and of Sandhāna the lay follower, by means of his divine faculty of hearing, came through the sky, sat down on the seat prepared in their presence, and answered the question asked by Nigrodha, "Adhijeguccha?"

"Paraṃ viya mattāyāti paramāya mattāya": "By a measure that is supreme," meaning by a measure that is very great; that is the meaning.

Who, except a blind fool, a follower of wrong views, would say, after hearing the Blessed One's Dharma, "Who is not delighted in mind?"

"I might obtain it." This is what he thought: "For a long time, indeed, has my self been exhausted by attaching myself to the side of non-deliverance, like one who, while turning over and over, thinks, 'I will bathe on the bank of a dry river,' or like one who pounds chaff, no purpose is accomplished."

Thinking, "Come, I will apply myself to yoga," he said.

Then the Blessed One, regarding the probation for those of other sects that has been prescribed in this section, for someone who was formerly of another sect, standing on the ground of a novice: "I, venerable sir, of such and such a name, formerly of another sect, desire ordination in this Dharma-vinaya; therefore, venerable sir, I ask the Saṃgha for four months of probation," etc. (Mahāva.)

(86) Having undertaken and observed it according to the rule, referring to that, he said, "Someone who, Kaśyapa, was formerly of another sect," etc.

mula_pali: 405. ‘‘Yo  kho, kassapa, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ, so cattāro māse parivasati, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya. Api ca mettha puggalavemattatā viditā’’ti. ‘‘Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhanti pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhanti upasampadaṃ, cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya. Ahaṃ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi, catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu, upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā’’ti. Alattha  kho acelo kassapo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ , alattha upasampadaṃ. Acirūpasampanno  kho panāyasmā kassapo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto na cirasseva – yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ – brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi. ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti – abbhaññāsi. Aññataro kho panāyasmā kassapo arahataṃ ahosīti.
mula_english:
“Kassapa, whoever, having formerly belonged to another sect, desires the going forth ( *pabbajjaṃ*) in this *Dhamma*-Discipline and desires the higher ordination ( *upasampadaṃ*), undergoes probation for four months. At the end of the four months, the monks, being satisfied in their minds, grant him the going forth and the higher ordination into the state of a *bhikkhu*.

Moreover, in this matter, there is a distinction of individuals known."

“Venerable sir, if those who formerly belonged to other sects desire the going forth ( *pabbajjaṃ*) in this *Dhamma*-Discipline and desire the higher ordination ( *upasampadaṃ*), and undergo probation for four months, and at the end of four months the monks, being satisfied in their minds, grant them the going forth and the higher ordination into the state of a *bhikkhu*, then I will undergo probation for four years, and at the end of four years, the monks, being satisfied in their minds, should grant me the going forth and the higher ordination into the state of a *bhikkhu*."

Then the naked Kassapa obtained the going forth ( *pabbajjaṃ*) in the presence of the Blessed One, and he obtained the higher ordination ( *upasampadaṃ*).

And the Venerable Kassapa, not long after his higher ordination ( *acirūpasampanno*), dwelling alone, secluded, diligent, ardent, and resolute, before long attained, by realizing it with his own super-knowledge ( *abhiññā*) here and now, that unsurpassed goal of the holy life ( *brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ*) for which young men of good family rightly go forth from home to homelessness:

'Destroyed is birth ( *khīṇā jāti*), the holy life has been lived ( *vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ*), what had to be done has been done ( *kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ*), there is no more coming to any state of being ( *nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti*)’ – thus he knew.

And the Venerable Kassapa became another one of the *arahants*.
commentary_pali: 405. Tattha pabbajjanti vacanasiliṭṭhatāvaseneva vuttaṃ, aparivasitvāyeva hi pabbajjaṃ labhati. Upasampadatthikena pana nātikālena gāmappavesanādīni aṭṭha vattāni pūrentena parivasitabbaṃ. Āraddhacittāti aṭṭhavattapūraṇena  tuṭṭhacittā, ayamettha saṅkhepattho. Vitthārato panesa titthiyaparivāso samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pabbajjakhandhakavaṇṇanāya vuttanayena veditabbo. Api ca metthāti api ca me ettha. Puggalavemattatā viditāti puggalanānattaṃ viditaṃ. ‘‘Ayaṃ puggalo parivāsāraho, ayaṃ na parivāsāraho’’ti idaṃ mayhaṃ pākaṭanti dasseti. Tato kassapo cintesi – ‘‘aho acchariyaṃ buddhasāsanaṃ, yattha evaṃ ghaṃsitvā koṭṭetvā yuttameva gaṇhanti, ayuttaṃ chaḍḍentī’’ti, tato suṭṭhutaraṃ pabbajjāya sañjātussāho – ‘‘sace bhante’’tiādimāha. Atha  kho bhagavā tassa tibbacchandataṃ viditvā – ‘‘na kassapo parivāsaṃ arahatī’’ti aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi – ‘‘gaccha bhikkhu kassapaṃ nhāpetvā pabbājetvā ānehī’’ti. So  tathā katvā taṃ pabbājetvā bhagavato santikaṃ āgamāsi. Bhagavā taṃ gaṇamajjhe nisīdāpetvā upasampādesi. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘alattha kho acelo kassapo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampada’’nti. Acirūpasampannoti upasampanno hutvā nacirameva. Vūpakaṭṭhoti vatthukāmakilesakāmehi kāyena ceva cittena ca vūpakaṭṭho. Appamattoti kammaṭṭhāne satiṃ avijahanto. Ātāpīti kāyikacetasikasaṅkhātena vīriyātāpena ātāpī. Pahitattoti kāye ca jīvite ca anapekkhatāya pesitacitto vissaṭṭhaattabhāvo. Yassatthāyāti yassa atthāya. Kulaputtāti ācārakulaputtā. Sammadevāti hetunāva kāraṇeneva. Tadanuttaranti taṃ anuttaraṃ. Brahmacariyapariyosānanti maggabrahmacariyassa pariyosānabhūtaṃ arahattaphalaṃ. Tassa hi atthāya kulaputtā pabbajanti. Diṭṭheva dhammeti imasmiṃyeva attabhāve. Sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvāti attanāyeva paññāya paccakkhaṃ  katvā, aparappaccayaṃ katvāti attho. Upasampajja vihāsīti pāpuṇitvā sampādetvā vihāsi, evaṃ viharanto ca khīṇā jāti…pe… abbhaññāsīti. Evamassa paccavekkhaṇabhūmiṃ dassetvā arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpetuṃ ‘‘aññataro kho panāyasmā kassapo arahataṃ ahosī’’ti vuttaṃ. Tattha aññataroti eko. Arahatanti arahantānaṃ, bhagavato sāvakānaṃ arahantānaṃ abbhantaro ahosīti ayamettha adhippāyo. Yaṃ yaṃ pana antarantarā na vuttaṃ, taṃ taṃ tattha tattha vuttattā pākaṭamevāti.
commentary_english:
405.
There, "going forth" ( *pabbajjā*) is spoken of merely due to the elegance of the words, for one obtains the going forth without having to observe the probationary period (*parivāsa*).

However, one seeking full ordination (*upasampadā*) should observe the probationary period by fulfilling the eight duties, such as not spending the night in a village, without undue delay.

"With aroused minds" means with minds gladdened by the fulfillment of the eight duties; this is the meaning in brief here.

But this probationary period for those of other views (*titthiya-parivāsa*) should be understood in detail according to the method stated in the *Pabbajjakkhandhaka* commentary of the *Samantapāsādikā* Vinaya.

Furthermore, "with me here" means, "also with me here."

"The distinctness of individuals is known" means the diversity of individuals is known.

“This individual is worthy of probation (*parivāsa*), this one is not worthy of probation" – this shows that this is evident to me.

Then Kassapa thought, "Indeed, the Buddha's teaching is wonderful! Here, having examined and scrutinized, they accept only what is fitting and reject what is unfitting." Then, with even greater enthusiasm for the going forth, he said, "If, venerable sir," and so on.

Then, the Blessed One, knowing his intense desire, said, "Kassapa is not deserving of probation." He addressed a certain monk, "Go, monk, bathe Kassapa, give him the going forth, and bring him here."

That monk did so, gave him the going forth, and came to the Blessed One.

The Blessed One seated him in the midst of the assembly and conferred full ordination (*upasampadā*).

Therefore, it was said, "Then the naked Kassapa received the going forth (*pabbajja*) in the presence of the Blessed One, and he obtained full ordination (*upasampadā*)."

"Recently fully ordained" means having been fully ordained, not long ago.

"Secluded" means secluded from sense objects, defilements, and sensual pleasures by body and also by mind.

"Diligent" means not abandoning mindfulness in the meditation subject (*kammaṭṭhāna*).

"Ardently striving" means ardently striving with the energy and heat characterized by bodily and mental exertion.

"Having a dedicated self" means having a mind directed without regard for body and life, having relinquished self-concern.

"For whose sake" means for whose benefit.

"Young men of good families" means young men of good conduct (*ācārakulaputtā*).

"Through right reason" means through the very cause, through reason itself.

*Tadanuttaraṃ* means that unsurpassed, that superior.

"The culmination of the holy life" means the fruit of *arhatship* (*arahattaphalaṃ*), which is the culmination of the holy life of the path (*magga-brahmacariya*).

Indeed, for that benefit, young men of good families go forth.

*Diṭṭhe va dhamme* means in this very existence, in this very lifetime.

*Sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā* means having realized directly by one's own wisdom, the meaning is having understood without dependence on others.

Having been fully ordained, he dwelt: having attained and accomplished, he dwelt. Thus dwelling, destruction of birth…pe…he realized.

In this way, after showing him the basis for reflection and completing the teaching with the pinnacle of *arhatship*, it was said, "A certain venerable Kassapa became one of the *arhats*."

There, "a certain one" means one.

"*Arhataṃ*" means among the *arhats*; the meaning here is that he was among the Blessed One's disciples, the *arhats*.

Whatever was not said in between, that is quite evident because it was said in those places.

mula_pali: 406. Evaṃ  me sutaṃ – ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme. Tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṃ tiṃsamattehi paribbājakasatehi. Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mula_english:
Thus have I heard. On one occasion, the Blessed One (bhagavā) was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta's Grove, Anāthapindika’s Park (jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme).

Now on that occasion, Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer (poṭṭhapādo paribbājako) was staying in the debating hall (samayappavādake) near the Tiṇḍuka tree (tindukācīre) in the single-pavilion park (ekasālake) of Queen Mallikā (mallikāya ārāme), together with a large following (mahatiyā) of about three hundred wanderers (tiṃsamattehi paribbājakasatehi).

Then, early in the morning (pubbaṇhasamayaṃ), the Blessed One (bhagavā), having dressed and taken his bowl and robe (pattacīvaramādāya), went into Sāvatthī for alms (sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi).
commentary_pali: 406.Evaṃme suttaṃ…pe… sāvatthiyanti poṭṭhapādasuttaṃ. Tatrāyaṃ apubbapadavaṇṇanā. Sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmeti sāvatthiṃ upanissāya yo jetassa kumārassa vane anāthapiṇḍikena gahapatinā ārāmo kārito, tattha viharati. Poṭṭhapādo paribbājakoti nāmena poṭṭhapādo nāma channaparibbājako. So kira gihikāle brāhmaṇamahāsālo kāmesuādīnavaṃ disvā cattālīsakoṭiparimāṇaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya pabbajitvā titthiyānaṃ gaṇācariyo jāto. Samayaṃ pavadanti etthāti samayappavādako, tasmiṃ kira ṭhāne caṅkītārukkhapokkharasātippabhutayo brāhmaṇā nigaṇṭhaacelakaparibbājakādayo ca pabbajitā sannipatitvā attano attano samayaṃ vadanti kathenti dīpenti, tasmā so ārāmo samayappavādakoti vuccati. Sveva ca tindukācīrasaṅkhātāya timbarūrukkhapantiyā parikkhittattā tindukācīro. Yasmā panettha paṭhamaṃ ekāva sālā ahosi, pacchā mahāpuññaṃ paribbājakaṃ nissāya bahū sālā katā. Tasmā tameva ekaṃ sālaṃ upādāya laddhanāmavasena ekasālakoti vuccati. Mallikāya pana pasenadirañño deviyā uyyānabhūto so pupphaphalasampanno ārāmoti katvā mallikāya ārāmoti saṅkhyaṃ gato. Tasmiṃ samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme. Paṭivasatīti nivāsaphāsutāya vasati. Athekadivasaṃ bhagavā paccūsasamaye sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ  pattharitvā lokaṃ pariggaṇhanto ñāṇajālassa antogataṃ paribbājakaṃ disvā – ‘‘ayaṃ poṭṭhapādo mayhaṃ ñāṇajāle paññāyati, kinnu kho bhavissatī’’ti upaparikkhanto addasa – ‘‘ahaṃ ajja tattha gamissāmi, atha maṃ poṭṭhapādo nirodhañca nirodhavuṭṭhānañca pucchissati, tassāhaṃ sabbabuddhānaṃ ñāṇena saṃsanditvā tadubhayaṃ kathessāmi, atha so katipāhaccayena  cittaṃ hatthisāriputtaṃ gahetvā mama  santikaṃ āgamissati, tesamahaṃ dhammaṃ desessāmi, desanāvasāne poṭṭhapādo maṃ saraṇaṃ gamissati, citto hatthisāriputto mama santike pabbajitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇissatī’’ti. Tato pātova sarīrapaṭijagganaṃ katvā surattadupaṭṭaṃ nivāsetvā vijjulatāsadisaṃ kāyabandhanaṃ bandhitvā yugandharapabbataṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitamahāmeghaṃ viya meghavaṇṇaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ ekaṃsavaragataṃ katvā paccagghaṃ selamayapattaṃ vāmaaṃsakūṭe laggetvā sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisissāmīti sīho viya himavantapādā vihārā nikkhami. Imamatthaṃ sandhāya – ‘‘atha kho bhagavā’’tiādi vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
406. Thus have I heard. ...at Sāvattha, this is the Poṭṭhapāda Sutta.

Herein is an explanation of uncommon words.

He dwells at Sāvatthi, in the Jeta Grove, in Anāthapiṇḍika's Park: that is, relying on Sāvatthi, he dwells in the park that Anāthapiṇḍika the householder had built in the Jeta Prince's Grove.

"Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer" means Poṭṭhapāda, by name, was a hidden wanderer.

It is said that in his householder days, he was a wealthy Brāhman, who, seeing the danger in sensual pleasures, renounced a fortune of forty *koṭis*, went forth, and became a teacher of a group of sectarians.

"They proclaim a doctrine here," therefore it is a place where doctrines are proclaimed. In that place, it is said, Brahmans such as Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, and others, as well as ascetics, naked ascetics, wanderers, and others who have gone forth, having assembled, proclaim, relate, and expound their own doctrines; therefore, that park is called a place where doctrines are proclaimed.

Moreover, because it is surrounded by a row of *tinduka* trees called *tindukācīra*, it is called *tindukācīra*.

Because at first there was only one hall here, but later many halls were built relying on a very meritorious wanderer.

Therefore, because of taking up that one hall according to the name received, it is called "single-hall".

Moreover, because it was a pleasure garden of Queen Mallikā of King Pasenadi, and because it was a park full of flowers and fruits, it was called "Mallikā's Park," and it went to the designation of Mallikā's Park.

In that place where doctrines are proclaimed, in Tindukācīra, in the single-hall, in Mallikā's Park.

"He dwells" means he lives in a dwelling that is comfortable for dwelling.

Then, one day, the Blessed One, in the early morning, having spread forth his all-knowing knowledge, surveying the world, seeing the wanderer within the net of knowledge – "This Poṭṭhapāda appears in my net of knowledge; what will happen?" – examining, he saw – "Today I will go there, and then Poṭṭhapāda will ask me about cessation and the rising from cessation, and then I, having conferred with the knowledge of all Buddhas, will explain both of those things. Then, after a few days, Citta Hatthīsariputta, having taken his mind, will come to my presence, and to them I will teach the Dharma, and at the end of the teaching, Poṭṭhapāda will go to me for refuge, and Citta Hatthīsariputta, having gone forth in my presence, will attain arahantship."

Then, in the morning, having attended to his bodily needs, having put on a fine red double-cloth, having tied on a body-band resembling a lightning flash, having circled Mount Yugandhara, making the *pāṃsukūla* robe of cloud color one-shouldered like a great cloud standing, having hung the invaluable bowl made of stone on the peak of his left shoulder, thinking, "I will enter Sāvatthi for alms," he went forth from the monastery like a lion from the foothills of the Himalayas.

Referring to this meaning, it was said, "Then, indeed, the Blessed One..." and so on.

mula_pali: 407. Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi – ‘‘atippago kho tāva sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya carituṃ. Yaṃnūnāhaṃ yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo, yena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyya’’nti. Atha kho bhagavā yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
mula_english:
Then the thought occurred to the Blessed One: "It is still too early to go into Sāvatthī for alms. Suppose I were to visit Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer at the debating hall near the *Tiṇḍuka* tree in the single-pavilion park of Queen Mallikā?"

Then the Blessed One went to the debating hall near the *Tiṇḍuka* tree in the single-pavilion park of Queen Mallikā.
commentary_pali: 407.Etadahosīti nagaradvārasamīpaṃ gantvā attano rucivasena sūriyaṃ oloketvā atippagabhāvameva disvā etaṃ ahosi. Yaṃnūnāhanti saṃsayaparidīpano viya nipāto, buddhānañca saṃsayo nāma natthi – ‘‘idaṃ karissāma, idaṃ na karissāma, imassa dhammaṃ desessāma, imassa na desessāmā’’ti evaṃ parivitakkapubbabhāgo panesa sabbabuddhānaṃ labbhati. Tenāha – ‘‘yaṃnūnāha’’nti, yadi panāhanti attho.
commentary_english:
407.

Thus it occurred to him: "Having gone near the city gate, and having looked at the sun according to his own liking, and having seen an exceedingly bright state..."

Since it is like a word that dispels doubt, but for the Buddhas there is no such thing as doubt - "We will do this, we will not do this, we will teach the Dharma to this person, we will not teach it to this person" - thus, this kind of prior thought is obtained by all Buddhas.

Therefore he said, "Because...", if that is the meaning.

mula_pali: 408. Tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṃ nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentiyā. Seyyathidaṃ – rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ mahāmattakathaṃ senākathaṃ bhayakathaṃ yuddhakathaṃ annakathaṃ pānakathaṃ vatthakathaṃ sayanakathaṃ mālākathaṃ gandhakathaṃ ñātikathaṃ yānakathaṃ gāmakathaṃ nigamakathaṃ nagarakathaṃ janapadakathaṃ  itthikathaṃ sūrakathaṃ visikhākathaṃ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṃ pubbapetakathaṃ nānattakathaṃ lokakkhāyikaṃ samuddakkhāyikaṃ itibhavābhavakathaṃ iti vā.
mula_english: Now at that time, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda was sitting with a large assembly of wanderers, who were making a great noise and commotion, engaged in various kinds of trivial talk. Specifically, they were talking about kings (rājakathā), robbers (corakathā), ministers of state (mahāmattakathā), armies (senākathā), dangers (bhayakathā), wars (yuddhakathā), food (annakathā), drink (pānakathā), clothing (vatthakatha), beds (sayanakatha), garlands (mālākathā), perfumes (gandhakathā), relatives (ñātikathā), vehicles (yānakathā), villages (gāmakathā), towns (nigamakathā), cities (nagarakathā), countries (janapadakatha), women (itthikathā), heroes (sūrakathā), street gossip (visikhākatha), well gossip (kumbhaṭṭhānakatha), departed ancestors (pubbapetakatha), various trivialities (nānattakatha), world-stories (lokakkhāyika), sea-stories (samuddakkhāyika), and talk about being and non-being (itibhavābhavakatha)—and so on.
commentary_pali: 408.Unnādiniyāti uccaṃ nadamānāya, evaṃ nadamānāya cassā uddhaṃ gamanavasena ucco, disāsu patthaṭavasena mahā saddoti uccāsaddamahāsaddāya, tesañhi paribbājakānaṃ pātova vuṭṭhāya kattabbaṃ nāma cetiyavattaṃ vā bodhivattaṃ vā ācariyupajjhāyavattaṃ  vā yoniso manasikāro vā natthi. Tena te pātova vuṭṭhāya bālātape nisinnā – ‘‘imassa hattho sobhano, imassa pādo’’ti evaṃ aññamaññassa hatthapādādīni vā ārabbha, itthipurisadārakadārikādīnaṃ vaṇṇe vā, aññaṃ vā kāmassādabhavassādādivatthuṃ ārabbha kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā anupubbena rājakathādianekavidhaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathenti. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ kathentiyā’’ti. Tato poṭṭhapādo paribbājako te paribbājake oloketvā – ‘‘ime paribbājakā ativiya aññamaññaṃ agāravā, mayañca samaṇassa gotamassa pātubhāvato paṭṭhāya sūriyuggamane khajjopanakūpamā jātā, lābhasakkāropi no parihīno. Sace panimaṃ ṭhānaṃ samaṇo gotamo vā gotamassa sāvako vā gihī upaṭṭhāko vā tassa āgaccheyya , ativiya lajjanīyaṃ bhavissati, parisadoso kho pana parisajeṭṭhakasseva upari ārohatī’’ti itocito ca vilokento bhagavantaṃ addasa. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘addasā kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako…pe… tuṇhī ahesu’’nti.
commentary_english:
408.
"Unnādiniyā" means on account of loudly sounding. Thus, on account of sounding in this way, "ucco" is because of going upwards, and "mahā saddo" is because of being spread in the directions. Therefore, (it is) "uccāsaddamahāsaddāya." For those wanderers, there is no required practice, such as worship of a *cetiya* shrine, a *bodhi* tree, or paying respects to their teacher or preceptor, nor wise reflection after rising early in the morning.

Therefore, having risen early in the morning, they sit in the sunshine, (saying,) "This one's hand is beautiful, this one's foot," and thus, concerning each other's hands, feet, and so on, or concerning the beauty of women, men, boys, girls, and so on, or concerning other things related to the enjoyment of sensual pleasures and the enjoyment of existence, having stirred up a conversation, they expound various kinds of pointless talk, such as talk of kings, and so forth, in due order.

Therefore, it was said, "On account of loudly sounding with a great and noisy sound, they expound various kinds of pointless talk."

Then, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda, having looked at those wanderers, (thought,) "These wanderers are exceedingly disrespectful to each other, and we, since the appearance of the ascetic Gotama, have become like fireflies at sunrise, and our gain and honor have declined.

If, indeed, the ascetic Gotama, or a disciple of Gotama, or a householder supporter of his, should come to this place, it would be exceedingly shameful. Indeed, the fault of the assembly rises upon the elder of the assembly himself." Thus, looking here and there, he saw the Blessed One.

Therefore, it was said, "The wanderer Poṭṭhapāda saw... and was silent."

mula_pali: 409. Addasā kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ  dūratova āgacchantaṃ; disvāna sakaṃ parisaṃ saṇṭhapesi – ‘‘appasaddā bhonto hontu, mā bhonto saddamakattha. Ayaṃ samaṇo gotamo  āgacchati. Appasaddakāmo kho so āyasmā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī. Appeva nāma appasaddaṃ parisaṃ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
mula_english:
409. Then Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer saw the Blessed One coming from afar, and on seeing him, he quieted his following: “Be quiet, good sirs. Don’t make any noise.
Here comes the *śramaṇa* Gotama.
He, the venerable one, is fond of quietude and speaks in praise of quietude (*appasaddakāmo kho so āyasmā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī*).
Maybe, if he perceives our group as quiet, he will consider it worthwhile to come our way."
When this was said, the wanderers fell silent (*evaṃ vutte te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṃ*).
commentary_pali: 409. Tattha saṇṭhapesīti sikkhāpesi, vajjamassā paṭicchādesi. Yathā susaṇṭhitā hoti, tathā naṃ ṭhapesi. Yathā nāma parisamajjhaṃ pavisanto puriso vajjapaṭicchādanatthaṃ nivāsanaṃ saṇṭhapeti, pārupanaṃ saṇṭhapeti, rajokiṇṇaṭṭhānaṃ puñchati; evamassā vajjapaṭicchādanatthaṃ – ‘‘appasaddā bhonto’’ti sikkhāpento yathā susaṇṭhitā hoti, tathā naṃ ṭhapesīti attho. Appasaddakāmoti appasaddaṃ icchati, eko nisīdati, eko tiṭṭhati, na gaṇasaṅgaṇikāya yāpeti. Upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññeyyāti idhāgantabbaṃ maññeyya. Kasmā panesa bhagavato upasaṅkamanaṃ paccāsīsatīti? Attano vuddhiṃ patthayamāno. Paribbājakā kira buddhesu vā buddhasāvakesu vā attano santikaṃ āgatesu – ‘‘ajja amhākaṃ santikaṃ samaṇo gotamo āgato , sāriputto āgato, na kho pana te yassa vā tassa vā santikaṃ gacchanti, passatha amhākaṃ uttamabhāva’’nti attano upaṭṭhākānaṃ santike attānaṃ ukkhipanti, ucce ṭhāne ṭhapenti, bhagavatopi upaṭṭhāke gaṇhituṃ vāyamanti. Te kira bhagavato upaṭṭhāke disvā evaṃ vadanti – ‘‘tumhākaṃ satthā bhavaṃ gotamopi gotamasāvakāpi amhākaṃ santikaṃ āgacchanti, mayaṃ aññamaññaṃ samaggā. Tumhe pana amhe akkhīhipi passituṃ na icchatha, sāmīcikammaṃ na karotha, kiṃ vo amhehi aparaddha’’nti. Athekacce manussā – ‘‘buddhāpi etesaṃ santikaṃ gacchanti kiṃ amhāka’’nti tato paṭṭhāya te disvā nappamajjanti. Tuṇhī ahesunti poṭṭhapādaṃ parivāretvā nissaddā nisīdiṃsu.
commentary_english:
409. There he settled = he trained [him], he concealed his fault.

Just as it is well-settled, so he placed him.

Just as, for example, a man entering an assembly settles his lower robe for the purpose of concealing faults, settles his outer robe, wipes off a dusty place; likewise, for the purpose of concealing his fault, teaching, "Let there be little noise, good sirs," just as it is well-settled, so he placed him, is the meaning.

"Desiring little noise" means he wants little noise. He sits alone, he stands alone, he does not spend [his time] in a crowd or company.

He would think it fit to approach = he would think it fit to come here.

Why then does he expect to approach the Blessed One? Desiring his own growth.

Wanderers, when Buddhas or disciples of the Buddha have come to their presence, [say,] "Today the ascetic Gotama has come to our presence, Sāriputta has come. But they do not go to the presence of just anyone. See our superior state!" Thus, in the presence of their attendants, they exalt themselves, they place [themselves] in a high position, they strive to get even the Blessed One's attendants.

They, having seen the Blessed One's attendants, say thus: "Your teacher, venerable Gotama, and Gotama's disciples come to our presence. We are harmonious with one another.

But you do not wish to see us even with [your] eyes, you do not do proper service. What wrong has been done to you by us?"

Then some people [think,] "Even Buddhas go to their presence, what [need is there] for us?" From then on, having seen them, they are not negligent.

"They were silent" means having surrounded Poṭṭhapāda, they sat down silently.

mula_pali: 410. Atha  kho bhagavā yena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako tenupasaṅkami. Atha kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘etu kho, bhante, bhagavā. Svāgataṃ, bhante, bhagavato. Cirassaṃ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi, yadidaṃ idhāgamanāya. Nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā, idaṃ āsanaṃ paññatta’’nti. Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Poṭṭhapādopi kho paribbājako aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho poṭṭhapādaṃ paribbājakaṃ bhagavā etadavoca – ‘‘kāya nuttha kāya nottha (syā. ka.), poṭṭhapāda, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā’’ti?
mula_english:
Then the Blessed One went to the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda.

Then the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said to the Blessed One: “Come, Blessed One. Welcome, Blessed One! It’s been a long time, venerable sir, since the Blessed One has gone out of his way to come here. Please, be seated, Blessed One; this seat has been prepared.”

The Blessed One sat down on the prepared seat.

And Poṭṭhapāda, taking a lower seat, sat down at one side.

As he was sitting there, the Blessed One said to the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda, "For what topic of conversation are you gathered together here now, Poṭṭhapāda? And what was your discussion that was interrupted?"
commentary_pali: 410.Svāgataṃ, bhanteti suṭṭhu āgamanaṃ, bhante, bhagavato; bhagavati hi no āgate ānando hoti, gate sokoti dīpeti. Cirassaṃ kho, bhanteti kasmā āha? Kiṃ bhagavā pubbepi tattha gatapubboti, na gatapubbo. Manussānaṃ pana – ‘‘kuhiṃ gacchantā, kuto āgatattha, kiṃ maggamūḷhattha, cirassaṃ āgatatthā’’ti evamādayo piyasamudācārā  honti, tasmā evamāha. Evañca pana vatvā na mānathaddho hutvā nisīdi, uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavato paccuggamanamakāsi. Bhagavantañhi upagataṃ disvā āsanena animantento vā apacitiṃ akaronto vā dullabho. Kasmā? Uccākulīnatāya. Ayampi paribbājako attano nisinnāsanaṃ papphoṭetvā bhagavantaṃ āsanena nimantento – ‘‘nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā idamāsanaṃ paññatta’’nti āha. Antarākathā vippakatāti nisinnānaṃ vo ādito paṭṭhāya yāva mamāgamanaṃ, etasmiṃ antare kā nāma kathā vippakatā, mamāgamanapaccayā katamā kathā pariyantaṃ na gatā, vadatha, yāva naṃ pariyantaṃ netvā demīti sabbaññupavāraṇaṃ pavāresi. Atha paribbājako – ‘‘niratthakakathā esā nissārā vaṭṭasannissitā, na tumhākaṃ purato vattabbataṃ arahatī’’ti dīpento ‘‘tiṭṭhatesā , bhante’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
410.
Welcome, venerable one; it is a good arrival, venerable one, of the Blessed One; for with the Blessed One having arrived, there is joy for us, and with [him] having departed, there is sorrow," he indicates.

Why does he say, "After a long time, venerable one?" [It is because] the Blessed One had never been there before.

But for humans – "Where are you going? From where have you come? Are you lost on the road? Have you come after a long time?" – such are the expressions of affection that exist; therefore, he spoke thus.

And having said this, he sat down without being haughty, and rising from his seat, he went to greet the Blessed One.

For one who, having seen the Blessed One approaching, does not invite [him] with a seat or does not pay respects, is rare.

Why? Because of high birth.

This wanderer too, having clapped his own sitting seat, inviting the Blessed One with a seat – "Sit down, venerable one, the Blessed One; this seat is prepared" – he said.

"The conversation has been interrupted," thus, for you who are seated, from the beginning until my arrival, in this interval, what conversation has been interrupted? Because of my arrival, what conversation has not reached its conclusion? Speak, so that I may lead it to its conclusion," he announced the invitation to omniscience.

Then the wanderer – indicating, "This is a meaningless conversation, insubstantial, dependent on the cycle [of rebirths], it is not worthy to be spoken in front of you" – said, "Let it stay there, venerable one," and so on.

mula_pali: 411. Evaṃ vutte poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘tiṭṭhatesā, bhante, kathā, yāya mayaṃ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā. Nesā, bhante, kathā bhagavato dullabhā bhavissati pacchāpi savanāya. Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni, nānātitthiyānaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ kotūhalasālāya sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ abhisaññānirodhe  kathā udapādi – ‘kathaṃ nu kho, bho, abhisaññānirodho hotī’ti? Tatrekacce evamāhaṃsu  – ‘ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi. Yasmiṃ samaye uppajjanti, saññī tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Yasmiṃ samaye nirujjhanti, asaññī tasmiṃ samaye hotī’ti. Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṃ paññapenti. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘na kho pana metaṃ na kho nāmetaṃ (sī. pī.), bho, evaṃ bhavissati. Saññā hi, bho, purisassa attā. Sā ca kho upetipi apetipi. Yasmiṃ samaye upeti, saññī tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Yasmiṃ samaye apeti, asaññī tasmiṃ samaye hotī’ti. Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṃ paññapenti. ‘‘Tamañño  evamāha – ‘na kho pana metaṃ, bho, evaṃ bhavissati. Santi hi, bho, samaṇabrāhmaṇā mahiddhikā mahānubhāvā. Te imassa purisassa saññaṃ upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipi. Yasmiṃ samaye upakaḍḍhanti, saññī tasmiṃ samaye  hoti. Yasmiṃ samaye apakaḍḍhanti, asaññī tasmiṃ samaye hotī’ti. Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṃ paññapenti. ‘‘Tamañño evamāha – ‘na kho pana metaṃ, bho, evaṃ bhavissati. Santi hi, bho, devatā mahiddhikā mahānubhāvā. Tā imassa purisassa saññaṃ upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipi. Yasmiṃ samaye upakaḍḍhanti, saññī tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Yasmiṃ samaye apakaḍḍhanti, asaññī tasmiṃ samaye hotī’ti. Ittheke abhisaññānirodhaṃ paññapenti. ‘‘Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃyeva ārabbha sati udapādi – ‘aho nūna bhagavā, aho nūna sugato, yo imesaṃ dhammānaṃ sukusalo’ti. Bhagavā, bhante, kusalo, bhagavā pakataññū abhisaññānirodhassa. Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, abhisaññānirodho hotī’’ti?
mula_english:
When this was said, Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer said to the Blessed One: "Let that conversation rest, venerable sir, for which we have gathered here.
It won’t be difficult for the Blessed One to hear about that later.
Some time ago, venerable sir, when ascetics and Brahmins from various sects were sitting and gathered together in the assembly hall, a discussion arose about the cessation of perception (**abhisaññānirodha**): ‘How, sir, does the cessation of perception occur?’
There some said: ‘A person’s perception arises and ceases without cause or condition.
When it arises, one is percipient.
When it ceases, one is not percipient.’
That’s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception.

Then someone else said, ‘No, that’s not how it is.
Perception is a person’s self.
And that comes and goes.
When it comes, one is percipient.
When it goes, one is not percipient.’
That’s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception.

Then someone else said, ‘No, that’s not how it is.
For there are ascetics and Brahmins of great power and great potency.
They draw perception in and out of a person.
When they draw it in, one is percipient.
When they draw it out, one is not percipient.’
That’s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception.

Then someone else said, ‘No, that’s not how it is.
For there are gods of great power and great potency.
They draw perception in and out of a person.
When they draw it in, one is percipient.
When they draw it out, one is not percipient.’
That’s how one group described the ultimate cessation of perception.

Then the memory of the Blessed One arose within me: ‘Ah, the Blessed One! Ah, the One Well-Gone—who surely is well-skilled in these matters.’
The Blessed One is skilled and expert in the ultimate cessation of perception.
So what, lord, is the ultimate cessation of perception?”
commentary_pali: 411.Tiṭṭhatesā, bhanteti sace bhagavā sotukāmo bhavissati, pacchāpesā kathā na dullabhā bhavissati, amhākaṃ panimāya kathāya attho natthi. Bhagavato panāgamanaṃ labhitvā mayaṃ aññadeva sukāraṇaṃ pucchāmāti dīpeti. Tato taṃ pucchanto – ‘‘purimāni, bhante’’tiādimāha. Tattha kotūhalasālāyanti kotūhalasālā nāma paccekasālā natthi. Yattha pana nānātitthiyā samaṇabrāhmaṇā nānāvidhaṃ kathaṃ pavattenti, sā bahūnaṃ – ‘‘ayaṃ kiṃ vadati, ayaṃ kiṃ vadatī’’ti kotūhaluppattiṭṭhānato kotūhalasālāti vuccati. Abhisaññānirodheti ettha abhīti upasaggamattaṃ. Saññānirodheti cittanirodhe, khaṇikanirodhe kathā uppannāti attho. Idaṃ pana tassā uppattikāraṇaṃ. Yadā kira bhagavā jātakaṃ vā katheti, sikkhāpadaṃ vā paññapeti tadā sakalajambudīpe bhagavato kittighoso pattharati, titthiyā taṃ sutvā – ‘‘bhavaṃ kira gotamo pubbacariyaṃ kathesi, mayaṃ kiṃ na sakkoma tādisaṃ kiñci kathetu’’nti bhagavato paṭibhāgakiriyaṃ karontā ekaṃ bhavantarasamayaṃ kathenti – ‘‘bhavaṃ gotamo sikkhāpadaṃ paññapesi, mayaṃ kiṃ na sakkoma paññapetu’’nti attano sāvakānaṃ kiñcideva sikkhāpadaṃ paññapenti. Tadā pana  bhagavā aṭṭhavidhaparisamajjhe nisīditvā nirodhakathaṃ kathesi. Titthiyā taṃ sutvā – ‘‘bhavaṃ kira gotamo nirodhaṃ nāma kathesi, mayampi taṃ kathessāmā’’ti sannipatitvā kathayiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ – ‘‘abhisaññānirodhe kathā udapādī’’ti. Tatrekacceti tesu ekacce. Purimo cettha yvāyaṃ bāhire titthāyatane pabbajito cittappavattiyaṃ dosaṃ disvā acittakabhāvo santoti samāpattiṃ bhāvetvā ito cuto pañca kappasatāni asaññībhave ṭhatvā puna idha uppajjati. Tassa saññuppāde ca nirodhe ca hetuṃ apassanto – ahetū appaccayāti āha. Dutiyo  naṃ nisedhetvā migasiṅgatāpasassa asaññakabhāvaṃ gahetvā – ‘‘upetipi apetipī’’ti āha. Migasiṅgatāpaso kira attantapo ghoratapo paramadhitindriyo ahosi. Tassa sīlatejena sakkavimānaṃ uṇhaṃ ahosi. Sakko devarājā ‘‘sakkaṭṭhānaṃ nu kho tāpaso patthetī’’ti alambusaṃ nāma devakaññaṃ – ‘tāpasassa tapaṃ bhinditvā ehī’ti pesesi. Sā tattha gatā. Tāpaso paṭhamadivase taṃ disvāva palāyitvā paṇṇasālaṃ pāvisi. Dutiyadivase kāmacchandanīvaraṇena bhaggo taṃ hatthe aggahesi, so tena dibbaphassena phuṭṭho visaññī hutvā tiṇṇaṃ  saṃvaccharānaṃ accayena saññaṃ paṭilabhi. Taṃ so diṭṭhigatiko – ‘‘tiṇṇaṃ saṃvaccharānaṃ accayena nirodhā vuṭṭhito’’ti maññamāno evamāha. Tatiyo naṃ nisedhetvā āthabbaṇapayogaṃ sandhāya ‘‘upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipī’’ti āha. Āthabbaṇikā kira āthabbaṇaṃ payojetvā sattaṃ sīsacchinnaṃ viya hatthacchinnaṃ viya mataṃ viya ca katvā dassenti. Tassa puna pākatikabhāvaṃ disvā so diṭṭhigatiko – ‘‘nirodhā vuṭṭhito aya’’nti maññamāno evamāha. Catuttho naṃ nisedhetvā yakkhadāsīnaṃ madaniddaṃ sandhāya ‘‘santi hi bho devatā’’tiādimāha. Yakkhadāsiyo kira sabbarattiṃ devatūpahāraṃ kurumānā naccitvā gāyitvā aruṇodaye ekaṃ surāpātiṃ pivitvā  parivattitvā supitvā divā vuṭṭhahanti. Taṃ disvā so diṭṭhigatiko – ‘‘suttakāle nirodhaṃ samāpannā, pabuddhakāle nirodhā vuṭṭhitā’’ti maññamāno evamāha. Ayaṃ pana poṭṭhapādo paribbājako paṇḍitajātiko. Tenassa taṃ kathaṃ sutvā vippaṭisāro uppajji. ‘‘Imesaṃ kathā eḷamūgakathā viya cattāro hi nirodhe ete paññapenti, iminā ca nirodhena nāma ekena bhavitabbaṃ, na bahunā. Tenāpi ekena aññeneva bhavitabbaṃ, so pana aññena ñātuṃ na  sakkā aññatra sabbaññunā. Sace bhagavā idha abhavissa ‘ayaṃ nirodho ayaṃ na nirodho’ti dīpasahassaṃ viya ujjāletvā ajjameva pākaṭaṃ akarissā’’ti dasabalaññeva anussari. Tasmā ‘‘tassa mayhaṃ bhante’’tiādimāha. Tattha aho nūnāti anussaraṇatthe nipātadvayaṃ, tena tassa bhagavantaṃ anussarantassa etadahosi ‘‘aho nūna bhagavā aho nūna sugato’’ti. Yo imesanti yo etesaṃ nirodhadhammānaṃ sukusalo nipuṇo cheko, so bhagavā aho nūna katheyya, sugato aho nūna katheyyāti ayamettha adhippāyo. Pakataññūti ciṇṇavasitāya pakatiṃ sabhāvaṃ jānātīti pakataññū. Kathaṃ nu khoti idaṃ paribbājako ‘‘mayaṃ bhagavā na jānāma, tumhe jānātha, kathetha no’’ti āyācanto vadati. Atha bhagavā kathento ‘‘tatra poṭṭhapādā’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
411. "It remains, venerable sir," [he said.] "If the Blessed One is inclined to listen, that talk will not be difficult [to obtain] later. But for us, there is no meaning in this talk."

Having obtained the arrival of the Blessed One, [he] indicates, "We will ask another, very good reason."

Then, asking him, he spoke, beginning with “Formerly, venerable sir.”

There, the term *kotūhalasālā* means that there is no individual hall called *kotūhalasālā*.

But where various sectarians, *śramaṇa*s, and *brāhmaṇa*s set forth various kinds of talk, that is called *kotūhalasālā* because it is the place of origin of curiosity for many, [thinking,] "What does this one say? What does that one say?"

In *abhisaññānirodha*, *abhi* is merely a prefix.

*Saññānirodha* means the cessation of thought; the meaning is that the talk arose concerning momentary cessation.

But this is the cause of its arising.

When, it is said, the Blessed One relates a *jātaka* or promulgates a training rule (*śikṣāpada*), then the sound of the Blessed One's fame spreads throughout all of Jambudvīpa. Hearing that, sectarians, doing a counter-performance to the Blessed One, [thinking,] “The esteemed Gotama related a former teaching; why can't we be able to relate something like that?" relate a fabricated, alternative religious tenet. [Thinking,] “The esteemed Gotama promulgated a training rule; why can't we be able to promulgate [one]?" they promulgate some training rule or other for their own disciples.

Then, indeed, the Blessed One, sitting in the midst of an eightfold assembly, related talk about cessation (*nirodhakatha*).

Hearing that, sectarians, having gathered together, declared, "The esteemed Gotama related something called cessation; we too will declare that."

Therefore it was said: “In the cessation of perception, talk arose.”

*Tatrekacca* means some among those.

The former one here, having gone forth in an external sectarian hermitage, seeing fault in the activity of thought, cultivating concentration (*samāpatti*) [thinking,] "The state of being without thought is peace," fallen from here, having remained in a state of non-perception for five hundred eons, again arises here.

Not seeing a cause for the arising of thought or for its cessation, he says, "Without a cause, without a condition."

The second one, having rejected him, taking up the state of non-perception of a *mṛgaśṛṅgatāpasa* – he said, "It both approaches and does not approach."

It is said that the *mṛgaśṛṅgatāpasa* was an ascetic who tormented himself, a fierce ascetic, one with supreme resolution of the senses.

By the power of his virtue, the heaven of Śakra became hot.

Śakra, the king of gods, [thinking,] "Does this ascetic desire the place of Śakra?" sent a divine maiden named Alambusā, [saying,] "Go, disrupt the ascetic's austerity!"

She went there.

On the first day, the ascetic, having seen her, fled and entered his leaf hut.

On the second day, broken by the hindrance of sensual desire, he seized her hand. Touched by that divine touch, having become unconscious, with the passing of three years he regained consciousness.

That sectarian, assuming, "He has arisen from cessation with the passing of three years," spoke thus.

The third one, having rejected him, referring to the use of an Atharva Veda spell, said, "They both pull near and pull away."

It is said that Atharva Veda practitioners, having applied an Atharva Veda spell, make a being appear as if his head has been cut off, as if his hand has been cut off, as if he is dead.

Having seen his natural state again, that sectarian, assuming, "He has arisen from cessation," spoke thus.

The fourth one, having rejected him, referring to the intoxicating sleep of the *yakṣa* women, spoke, beginning with "For gods exist, sir."

It is said that *yakṣa* women, all night long, making offerings to the deities, dancing, singing, at sunrise, having drunk a cup of liquor, having turned around, having slept, arise during the day.

Having seen that, that sectarian, assuming, "They have attained cessation at the time of sleep, they have arisen from cessation at the time of awakening," spoke thus.

Now, this Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer is one who is born intelligent.

Therefore, having heard that talk, regret arose in him.

"This talk of theirs is like the talk of a mute sheep; for these four promulgate cessation in various ways. But one should have that cessation with just one cessation, not with many.

Also, that should be with just one, a different one; but that is not possible to know by another, except by the all-knowing one.

If the Blessed One were here, having illuminated [it] like a thousand lamps, ‘This is cessation, this is not cessation,’ he would make it manifest today." He recollected the one with the ten powers.

Therefore he spoke, beginning with, "Therefore, venerable sir, to me."

There, *aho nūna* is a pair of particles in the sense of recollection. Therefore, to him, recollecting the Blessed One, this occurred: "Oh, truly the Blessed One! Oh, truly the Well-Gone One!"

That, namely, he who is very skilled, clever, and expert in these, namely, these teachings of cessation, that Blessed One would declare, the Well-Gone One would declare, this is the meaning here.

*Pakataññū* means one who knows the nature (*pakati*) and inherent state (*sabhāva*) by means of habitual association.

"How now?" Thus, the wanderer, requesting, says, "We do not know the Blessed One, you know, relate [it] to us."
Then the Blessed One, speaking, said, "There, Poṭṭhapāda," and so on, beginning.

mula_pali: 412. ‘‘Tatra , poṭṭhapāda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evamāhaṃsu – ‘ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipī’ti, āditova tesaṃ aparaddhaṃ. Taṃ kissa hetu? Sahetū hi, poṭṭhapāda, sappaccayā purisassa saññā  uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi. Sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati’’.
mula_english:
“In this regard, Poṭṭhapāda, those *śramaṇas* and *brāhmaṇas* who say thus: ‘A person’s perception (*saṃjñā*) arises and ceases without a cause (*hetu*) or condition (*pratyaya*)’ are wrong from the very beginning.

What is the reason for that? Because, Poṭṭhapāda, a person’s perception (*saṃjñā*) arises and ceases with a cause (*sahetu*) and with a condition (*sapratyaya*).

With training (*śikṣā*) one perception (*saṃjñā*) arises, with training (*śikṣā*) another perception (*saṃjñā*) ceases."
commentary_pali: 412. Tattha tatrāti tesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu. Āditova tesaṃ aparaddhanti tesaṃ ādimhiyeva  viraddhaṃ, gharamajjheyeva pakkhalitāti dīpeti. Sahetū sappaccayāti ettha hetupi paccayopi kāraṇasseva nāmaṃ, sakāraṇāti attho. Taṃ pana kāraṇaṃ dassento ‘‘sikkhā ekā’’ti āha. Tattha sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjantīti sikkhāya ekaccā saññā jāyantīti attho.
commentary_english:
412.
"There, there" means among those *śramaṇa*s and *brāhmaṇa*s.

From the beginning, the offense against them is a failure even at their origin, like a leak in the middle of the house; this is what it indicates.

"With a cause, with a condition" means here that both cause (*hetu*) and condition (*pratyaya*) are simply names for cause (*kāraṇa*); the meaning is "with a cause" (*sakāraṇa*).

But in showing that cause (*kāraṇa*), he said, "The training (*śikṣā*) is one."

There, the understanding (*saṃjñā*) that arises is the single training (*śikṣā*), meaning that from the training (*śikṣā*), a certain understanding (*saṃjñā*) is born.

mula_pali: 413. ‘‘Kā ca sikkhā’’ti? Bhagavā avoca – ‘‘idha, poṭṭhapāda, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ, sammāsambuddho…pe…  (yathā 190-212 anucchedesu, evaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ). Evaṃ kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti…pe… tassime pañcanīvaraṇe pahīne  attani samanupassato pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati. So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā kāmasaññā, sā nirujjhati. Vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ samaye hoti, vivekajapītisukhasukhuma-saccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayaṃ sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca. ‘‘Puna  caparaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati. Samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ  samaye hoti , samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayampi sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti – ‘‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’’ti, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati. Upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ samaye hoti, upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayampi sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati. Adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ samaye hoti, adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayampi sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā  nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto  ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā rūpasaññā purimasaññā (ka.), sā nirujjhati. Ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ samaye hoti, ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayampi sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca. ‘‘Puna  caparaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ  samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇa’nti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati. Viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ samaye hoti, viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayampi sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca. ‘‘Puna caparaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati. Tassa yā purimā viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati. Ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṃ samaye hoti, ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hoti. Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati. Ayampi sikkhā’’ti bhagavā avoca.
mula_english:
“And what is training?” The Blessed One said, “Here, Poṭṭhapāda, a *tathāgata* arises in the world, a worthy one, a rightly self-awakened one… (as in sections 190-212, so it should be expanded).

“This is how, Poṭṭhapāda, a monk is accomplished in virtue... Seeing these five hindrances abandoned in himself, joy (*pāmojja*) arises; to one who is joyful, rapture (*pīti*) arises; when the mind is enraptured, the body grows tranquil (*passambhati*); his body tranquil, he feels pleasure (*sukhaṃ vedeti*); feeling pleasure, his mind becomes concentrated (*samādhiyati*).

“Quite secluded from sensual pleasures (*kāmehi*), secluded from unwholesome states (*akusalehi dhammehi*), he enters and remains in the first *jhāna*: rapture and pleasure (*pītisukhaṃ*) born of seclusion (*vivekajaṃ*), accompanied by directed thought (*savitakkaṃ*) and evaluation (*savicāraṃ*).

“His earlier perception of sensuality (*kāmasaññā*) ceases.

“On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion (*vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

“And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is training.” the Blessed One said.

“Again, Poṭṭhapāda, with the stilling of directed thoughts and evaluations, the monk enters and remains in the second *jhāna*: rapture and pleasure (*pītisukhaṃ*) born of concentration (*samādhijaṃ*), unification of awareness free from directed thought and evaluation (*avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ*)—internal assurance (*ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ*).

“His earlier perception of a refined truth of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion ceases.

“On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of rapture and pleasure born of concentration (*samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

“And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is also training," the Blessed One said.

“Again, Poṭṭhapāda, with the fading of rapture (*pītiyā ca virāgā*), the monk remains equanimous (*upekkhako*) and mindful and fully aware (*sato ca sampajāno*), still feeling pleasure (*sukhaṃ*) with the body. He enters and remains in the third *jhāna*, of which the noble ones (*ariyā*) declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, he has a pleasant abiding (*upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī*)’."

"His earlier perception of a refined truth of rapture & pleasure born of concentration (*samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā*), ceases."

"On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of equanimity (*upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of equanimity."

"And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is also training," the Blessed One said.

“Again, Poṭṭhapāda, with the abandoning of pleasure (*sukha*) and pain (*dukkha*), and with the previous disappearance of joy (*somanassa*) and grief (*domanassa*), the monk enters and remains in the fourth *jhāna*: purity of equanimity and mindfulness (*upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ*), which has neither pleasure nor pain (*adukkhamasukhaṃ*).

"His earlier perception of a refined truth of equanimity (*upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā*) ceases."

"On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of neither pleasure nor pain (*adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of neither pleasure nor pain."

“And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is also training," the Blessed One said.

“Again, Poṭṭhapāda, with the complete transcending of perceptions of form (*rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā*), with the disappearance of perceptions of resistance (*paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā*), and not heeding perceptions of multiplicity (*nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā*), ‘Infinite space’ (*ananto ākāso*)—the monk enters and remains in the dimension of the infinitude of space (*ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ*).

“His earlier perception of form (*rūpasaññā*) ceases.

“On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of space (*ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of space.

“And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is also training," the Blessed One said.

“Again, Poṭṭhapāda, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of space (*ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma*), ‘Infinite consciousness’ (*anantaṃ viññāṇa*)—the monk enters and remains in the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ*).

“His earlier perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of space (*ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā*) ceases.

“On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness.

“And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is also training," the Blessed One said.

“Again, Poṭṭhapāda, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma*), ‘There is nothing’ (*natthi kiñcī*)—the monk enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness (*ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ*).

“His earlier perception of a refined truth of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness (*viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā*) ceases.

“On that occasion there is a perception of a refined truth of the dimension of nothingness (*ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā*). On that occasion he is one who is percipient of a refined truth of the dimension of nothingness.

“And thus it is that with training one perception arises and with training another perception ceases. This is also training," the Blessed One said.
commentary_pali: 413.Kā ca sikkhāti bhagavā avocāti katamā ca sā sikkhāti bhagavā vitthāretukamyatāpucchāvasena avoca. Atha yasmā adhisīlasikkhā adhicittasikkhā adhipaññāsikkhāti tisso sikkhā honti. Tasmā tā dassento bhagavā saññāya sahetukaṃ uppādanirodhaṃ dīpetuṃ buddhuppādato pabhuti tantidhammaṃ ṭhapento ‘‘idha poṭṭhapāda, tathāgato loke’’tiādimāha. Tattha adhisīlasikkhā  adhicittasikkhāti dve eva sikkhā sarūpena āgatā, tatiyā pana ‘‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho poṭṭhapāda mayā ekaṃsiko dhammo desito’’ti ettha sammādiṭṭhisammāsaṅkappavasena pariyāpannattā āgatāti veditabbā. Kāmasaññāti pañcakāmaguṇikarāgopi asamuppannakāmacāropi . Tattha pañcakāmaguṇikarāgo anāgāmimaggena samugghātaṃ gacchati, asamuppannakāmacāro pana imasmiṃ ṭhāne vaṭṭati. Tasmā tassa yā purimā kāmasaññāti tassa paṭhamajjhānasamaṅgino yā pubbe uppannapubbāya kāmasaññāya sadisattā purimā kāmasaññāti vucceyya, sā nirujjhati, anuppannāva nuppajjatīti attho. Vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṃ samaye hotīti tasmiṃ paṭhamajjhānasamaye vivekajapītisukhasaṅkhātā sukhumasaññā saccā hoti, bhūtā hotīti attho. Atha vā kāmacchandādioḷārikaṅgappahānavasena sukhumā ca sā bhūtatāya saccā ca saññāti sukhumasaccasaññā, vivekajehi pītisukhehi sampayuttā sukhumasaccasaññāti vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā sā assa atthīti vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Esa nayo sabbattha. Evampi sikkhāti ettha yasmā paṭhamajjhānaṃ samāpajjanto adhiṭṭhahanto, vuṭṭhahanto ca sikkhati, tasmā taṃ evaṃ sikkhitabbato sikkhāti vuccati. Tenapi sikkhāsaṅkhātena paṭhamajjhānena evaṃ ekā vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā uppajjati. Evaṃ ekā kāmasaññā nirujjhatīti attho. Ayaṃ sikkhāti bhagavā avocāti ayaṃ paṭhamajjhānasaṅkhātā ekā sikkhāti, bhagavā āha. Etenupāyena sabbattha attho daṭṭhabbo. Yasmā pana aṭṭhamasamāpattiyā aṅgato sammasanaṃ buddhānaṃyeva hoti, sāvakesu sāriputtasadisānampi  natthi, kalāpato sammasanaṃyeva pana sāvakānaṃ hoti, idañca ‘‘saññā saññā’’ti, evaṃ aṅgato sammasanaṃ uddhaṭaṃ. Tasmā  ākiñcaññāyatanaparamaṃyeva saññaṃ dassetvā puna tadeva saññagganti dassetuṃ ‘‘yato kho poṭṭhapāda…pe… saññaggaṃ phusatī’’ti āha.
commentary_english:
413.
“What is the training?” When the Blessed One said this, he spoke in response to a question expressing a desire to elaborate: “What is that training?”
Furthermore, because there are three trainings, namely the higher training in discipline (*adhisīlasikkhā*), the higher training in mind (*adhicittasikkhā*), and the higher training in wisdom (*adhipaññāsikkhā*).
Therefore, while pointing them out, the Blessed One, establishing the continuum of phenomena from the arising of a Buddha in order to illuminate the arising and cessation together with its cause through perception (*saññā*), said "Here, Poṭṭhapāda, the *Tathāgata* in the world," and so on.
Therein, the two trainings, the higher training in discipline and the higher training in mind, have come in their own form. But the third one, "This is the practice leading to the cessation of suffering (*dukkha*), Poṭṭhapāda, the teaching (*dhamma*) taught by me is one-sided," here, because it is included through right view (*sammādiṭṭhi*) and right intention (*sammāsaṅkappa*), it should be understood that it has come.
"Perception of desire (*kāmasaññā*)" means both the attachment consisting of the five strands of sense pleasure and unarisen sensual intention.

Therein, the attachment consisting of the five strands of sense pleasure is eradicated by the path of a non-returner (*anāgāmi*), but the unarisen sensual intention remains in this place.
Therefore, that prior perception of desire (*kāmasaññā*)—that which, because of being similar to the perception of desire that formerly arose for one possessing the first *jhāna*, could be called the prior perception of desire—that ceases; the meaning is that what has not arisen does not arise.
Because at that time he is one who possesses the subtle and true perception (*sukhumasaccasaññī*) consisting of the bliss of detachment, joy, and happiness, therefore, at that time of the first *jhāna*, the subtle perception, reckoned as the bliss of detachment, joy, and happiness, is true; the meaning is that it is real.
Or alternatively, because of abandoning the coarse factors beginning with sensual desire, that subtle perception which is true because it is real is subtle true perception (*sukhumasaccasaññā*). *Sukhumasaccasaññā* conjoined with the joy and happiness born of detachment is the subtle true perception consisting of the bliss of detachment, joy, and happiness (*vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā*). Because that exists for him, he is one who possesses the subtle true perception consisting of the bliss of detachment, joy, and happiness (*vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññī*). Thus, the meaning here should be seen.
This method applies to all the other cases.
Even so, "training (*sikkhā*)," here, because one trains when attaining the first *jhāna*, when undertaking it, and when emerging from it, therefore, because that is to be trained in in this way, it is called training (*sikkhā*).

Thus, through the first *jhāna* reckoned as training (*sikkhā*), in this way a single subtle true perception consisting of the bliss of detachment, joy, and happiness (*vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā*) arises.
Thus, the meaning is that a single perception of desire (*kāmasaññā*) ceases.
"This is training (*sikkhā*)," when the Blessed One said this, the Blessed One said, "This is a single training (*sikkhā*) reckoned as the first *jhāna*."
The meaning everywhere should be seen by this method.
Furthermore, since scrutiny (*sammasana*) in terms of its parts (*aṅgato*) in the eighth attainment (*aṭṭhamasamāpatti*) belongs only to Buddhas, and does not exist even in disciples similar to *Śāriputta*, but scrutiny only in terms of aggregates (*kalāpato*) exists for disciples, and this, "perception, perception," thus, scrutiny in terms of its parts is removed.
Therefore, having shown perception (*saññaṃ*) as merely the ultimate of the sphere of nothingness (*ākiñcaññāyatana*), again, in order to show that same cessation of perception (*saññaggaṃ*), he said, "Because, Poṭṭhapāda…pe…touches the cessation of perception (*saññaggaṃ phusatī*)."

mula_pali: 414. ‘‘Yato kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu idha sakasaññī hoti, so tato  amutra tato amutra anupubbena saññaggaṃ phusati. Tassa saññagge ṭhitassa evaṃ hoti – ‘cetayamānassa me pāpiyo, acetayamānassa me seyyo. Ahañceva kho pana ceteyyaṃ, abhisaṅkhareyyaṃ, imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyuṃ, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyuṃ; yaṃnūnāhaṃ na ceva ceteyyaṃ na ca abhisaṅkhareyya’nti. So na ceva ceteti, na ca abhisaṅkharoti. Tassa acetayato anabhisaṅkharoto tā ceva saññā nirujjhanti, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti. So nirodhaṃ phusati. Evaṃ kho, poṭṭhapāda, anupubbābhisaññānirodha-sampajāna-samāpatti hoti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, api nu te ito pubbe evarūpā anupubbābhisaññānirodha-sampajāna-samāpatti sutapubbā’’ti? ‘‘No hetaṃ, bhante. Evaṃ kho ahaṃ , bhante, bhagavato bhāsitaṃ ājānāmi – ‘yato kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu idha sakasaññī hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saññaggaṃ phusati, tassa saññagge ṭhitassa evaṃ hoti – ‘‘cetayamānassa  me pāpiyo, acetayamānassa me seyyo. Ahañceva kho pana ceteyyaṃ  abhisaṅkhareyyaṃ, imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyuṃ, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyuṃ; yaṃnūnāhaṃ na ceva ceteyyaṃ, na ca abhisaṅkhareyya’’nti. So na ceva ceteti, na cābhisaṅkharoti, tassa acetayato anabhisaṅkharoto tā ceva saññā nirujjhanti, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti . So nirodhaṃ phusati. Evaṃ kho, poṭṭhapāda, anupubbābhisaññānirodha-sampajāna-samāpatti hotī’’’ti. ‘‘Evaṃ, poṭṭhapādā’’ti.
mula_english:
“Now, Poṭṭhapāda, when a monk here is percipient of himself, then from here to there, step by step, he touches the peak of perception (saññaggaṃ phusati).

As he remains at the peak of perception, the thought occurs to him: ‘Thinking is bad for me. Not thinking is better for me.’

If I were to think and will, these perceptions of mine would cease, and other, grosser perceptions would arise. What if I were neither to think nor to will?’

So he neither thinks nor wills.

As he is neither thinking nor willing, those very perceptions cease, and other, grosser perceptions do not arise.

He touches cessation (nirodhaṃ phusati).

Thus, Poṭṭhapāda, there is the step-by-step cessation of perception with knowledge (anupubbābhisaññānirodha-sampajāna-samāpatti hoti).

“What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda? Have you ever before heard of such a step-by-step cessation of perception with knowledge?” “No, venerable sir.”

“And here is how I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One: ‘When the monk is percipient of himself here, then from there to there, step by step, he touches the peak of perception. As he remains at the peak of perception, the thought occurs to him: “Thinking is bad for me. Not thinking is better for me.”

If I were to think and will, these perceptions of mine would cease, and other, grosser perceptions would arise. What if I were neither to think nor to will?”

So he neither thinks nor wills. As he is neither thinking nor willing, those very perceptions cease, and other, grosser perceptions do not arise.

He touches cessation (nirodhaṃ phusati).

Thus, Poṭṭhapāda, there is the step-by-step cessation of perception with knowledge.’”

“So it is, Poṭṭhapāda.”
commentary_pali: 414. Tattha yato kho poṭṭhapāda bhikkhūti yo nāma poṭṭhapāda bhikkhu. Idha sakasaññī hotīti idha sāsane sakasaññī hoti, ayameva vā pāṭho, attano paṭhamajjhānasaññāya saññavā hotīti attho. So tato amutra tato amutrāti so bhikkhu tato paṭhamajjhānato amutra dutiyajjhāne, tatopi amutra tatiyajjhāneti evaṃ tāya tāya jhānasaññāya sakasaññī sakasaññī hutvā anupubbena saññaggaṃ phusati. Saññagganti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ vuccati. Kasmā? Lokiyānaṃ kiccakārakasamāpattīnaṃ aggattā. Ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattiyañhi ṭhatvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanampi nirodhampi samāpajjanti. Iti sā lokiyānaṃ kiccakārakasamāpattīnaṃ aggattā saññagganti vuccati, taṃ phusati pāpuṇātīti attho. Idāni abhisaññānirodhaṃ dassetuṃ ‘‘tassa saññagge ṭhitassā’’tiādimāha. Tattha ceteyyaṃ, abhisaṅkhareyyanti padadvaye ca jhānaṃ samāpajjanto ceteti nāma, punappunaṃ kappetīti attho. Uparisamāpattiatthāya nikantiṃ kurumāno abhisaṅkharoti nāma. Imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyunti imā ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā nirujjheyyuṃ. Aññā ca oḷārikāti aññā ca oḷārikā bhavaṅgasaññā uppajjeyyuṃ. So na ceva ceteti na abhisaṅkharotīti ettha kāmaṃ cesa cetentova na ceteti, abhisaṅkharontova nābhisaṅkharoti. Imassa bhikkhuno ākiñcaññāyatanato vuṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā ‘‘ekaṃ dve cittavāre ṭhassāmī’’ti ābhogasamannāhāro natthi. Uparinirodhasamāpattatthāya eva pana ābhogasamannāhāro atthi, svāyamattho puttagharācikkhaṇena dīpetabbo. Pitugharamajjhena kira gantvā pacchābhāge puttassa gharaṃ hoti, tato paṇītaṃ bhojanaṃ ādāya āsanasālaṃ āgataṃ daharaṃ thero – ‘‘manāpo piṇḍapāto kuto ābhato’’ti pucchi. So ‘‘asukassa gharato’’ti laddhagharameva ācikkhi. Yena panassa pitugharamajjhena gatopi āgatopi  tattha ābhogopi natthi. Tattha āsanasālā viya ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpatti  daṭṭhabbā, pitugehaṃ viya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti, puttagehaṃ viya nirodhasamāpatti, āsanasālāya ṭhatvā pitugharaṃ amanasikaritvā puttagharācikkhaṇaṃ viya ākiñcaññāyatanato vuṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā ‘‘ekaṃ dve cittavāre ṭhassāmī’’ti pitugharaṃ amanasikaritvāva  uparinirodhasamāpattatthāya manasikāro, evamesa cetentova na ceteti, abhisaṅkharontova nābhisaṅkharoti. Tā ceva saññāti tā jhānasaññā nirujjhanti. Aññā cāti aññā ca oḷārikā bhavaṅgasaññā nuppajjanti. So nirodhaṃ phusatīti so evaṃ paṭipanno bhikkhu saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ phusati vindati paṭilabhati. Anupubbābhisaññānirodhasampajānasamāpattinti ettha abhīti upasaggamattaṃ, sampajānapadaṃ nirodhapadena antarikaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Anupaṭipāṭiyā sampajānasaññānirodhasamāpattīti ayaṃ panetthattho. Tatrāpi sampajānasaññānirodhasamāpattīti sampajānantassa ante saññā nirodhasamāpatti sampajānantassa vā paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno saññānirodhasamāpattīti ayaṃ visesattho. Idāni idha ṭhatvā nirodhasamāpattikathā kathetabbā. Sā panesā sabbākārena visuddhimagge paññābhāvanānisaṃsādhikāre kathitā, tasmā tattha kathitatova gahetabbā. Evaṃ bhagavā poṭṭhapādassa paribbājakassa nirodhakathaṃ kathetvā – atha naṃ tādisāya kathāya aññattha abhāvaṃ paṭijānāpetuṃ ‘‘taṃ kiṃ maññasī’’tiādimāha. Paribbājakopi ‘‘bhagavā ajja tumhākaṃ kathaṃ ṭhapetvā na mayā evarūpā kathā sutapubbā’’ti paṭijānanto, ‘‘no hetaṃ bhante’’ti vatvā puna sakkaccaṃ bhagavato kathāya uggahitabhāvaṃ dassento ‘‘evaṃ kho ahaṃ bhante’’tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā ‘‘suuggahitaṃ tayā’’ti anujānanto ‘‘evaṃ poṭṭhapādā’’ti āha.
commentary_english:
414.

There, because Poṭṭhapāda is a monk, anyone named Poṭṭhapāda is a monk.

Here, "he is conscious of his own": here, in this teaching, he is conscious of his own. Or rather, this is the reading: it means "he is endowed with the perception of his own first jhāna-perception."

"So, from there to yonder, from there to yonder": that monk, from that first jhāna, to yonder, the second jhāna, and from there also to yonder, the third jhāna; thus, with each jhāna-perception, being conscious of his own, being conscious of his own, gradually he touches the peak of perception.

"The peak of perception" is said to be the *ākiñcaññāyatana*.

Why? Because it is the peak of mundane efficacious attainments.

For, having stood in the attainment of the *ākiñcaññāyatana*, they attain even the *nevasaññānāsaññāyatana* and also cessation.

Thus, that is said to be the peak of perception because it is the peak of mundane efficacious attainments; it means "he touches that, he reaches [it]."

Now, to show the cessation of perception, he said "For him standing at the peak of perception," etc.

There, in the two phrases "should I cognize, should I construct," he who is attaining jhāna, cognizes, namely, repeatedly plans; this is the meaning.

"He constructs" means he makes a desire for the sake of a higher attainment.

"These perceptions of mine would cease" means these *ākiñcaññāyatana* perceptions would cease.

"Another, grosser" means another, grosser life-continuum perception would arise.
