"So he neither cognizes nor constructs": here, though he may wish, he does not cognize; though he may construct, he does not construct.

For this monk, having emerged from the *ākiñcaññāyatana* and having attained the *nevasaññānāsaññāyatana*, there is no directing of the mind, no application, thinking, "I will remain for one or two mind-moments."

But there is a directing of the mind, an application, thinking, only for the sake of the higher attainment of cessation; this meaning should be illustrated by the explanation of the son's house.

Having gone through the middle of the father's house, in the rear portion there is the son's house; then, a young *thera*, having taken fine food and having come to the alms hall, asked, "From where was this delightful alms-food brought?"

He pointed out only the house he had obtained, saying "From such-and-such a house."

But by whichever [path] he had gone and come through the middle of the father's house, there was no directing of the mind there either.

There, the attainment of the *ākiñcaññāyatana* should be seen as like the alms hall, the attainment of the *nevasaññānāsaññāyatana* as like the father's house, the cessation attainment as like the son's house. Just as, having stood in the alms hall, not attending to the father's house, the explanation of the son's house [is given], so too, having emerged from the *ākiñcaññāyatana* and having attained the *nevasaññānāsaññāyatana*, not attending to the father's house, thinking "I will remain for one or two mind-moments," there is a directing of the mind only for the sake of the higher attainment of cessation; thus, though he may wish, he does not cognize; though he may construct, he does not construct.

"Those perceptions cease" means those jhāna-perceptions cease.

"Another" means another gross life-continuum perception does not arise.

"So he touches cessation" means that monk, thus practicing, touches, finds, obtains the cessation of perception and feeling.

In "gradual cessation of perception, attainment with full awareness," here *abhi* is merely a prefix; the term "with full awareness" is stated having made the term "cessation" internal.

"Attainment of cessation of perception with full awareness in due order": this is the meaning here.

There too, in "attainment of cessation of perception with full awareness," "for him who is fully aware, at the end, perception is the attainment of cessation"; or rather, "for the wise monk who is fully aware, the attainment of cessation of perception": this is a distinguishing meaning.

Now, having stood here, the talk of the attainment of cessation should be spoken.

But that, in every way, in the *Visuddhimagga*, in the section on the advantages of the cultivation of wisdom, has been spoken; therefore, it should be taken only as it has been spoken there.

Thus, the Blessed One, having spoken of cessation to the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda, then, in order to cause him to acknowledge the absence of that [cessation] elsewhere by means of such talk, said "What do you think?" etc.

The wanderer too, acknowledging [it], "Venerable sir, setting aside the talk of you today, such talk has never been heard by me," having said "No, venerable sir," then, showing that he had carefully grasped the Blessed One's talk, said "Thus, venerable sir," etc.

Then, the Blessed One, approving of him, "Well grasped by you," said "Thus, Poṭṭhapāda."

mula_pali: 415. ‘‘Ekaññeva nu kho, bhante, bhagavā saññaggaṃ paññapeti, udāhu puthūpi saññagge paññapetī’’ti? ‘‘Ekampi kho ahaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, saññaggaṃ paññapemi, puthūpi saññagge paññapemī’’ti. ‘‘Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā ekampi saññaggaṃ paññapeti, puthūpi saññagge paññapetī’’ti? ‘‘Yathā yathā kho, poṭṭhapāda, nirodhaṃ phusati, tathā tathāhaṃ saññaggaṃ paññapemi. Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, ekampi saññaggaṃ paññapemi, puthūpi saññagge paññapemī’’ti.
mula_english:
“But, lord, does the Blessed One describe one *saññagga* (peak of perception) or many *saññagga*s?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, I describe one *saññagga* and many *saññagga*s.”

“But in what way, lord, does the Blessed One describe one *saññagga* and many *saññagga*s?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, in whatever way one experiences cessation (*nirodha*), in that way I describe *saññagga*. Thus, Poṭṭhapāda, I describe one *saññagga* and many *saññagga*s.”
commentary_pali: 415. Atha paribbājako ‘‘bhagavatā ‘ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ saññagga’nti vuttaṃ. Etadeva nu kho saññaggaṃ, udāhu avasesasamāpattīsupi  saññaggaṃ atthī’’ti cintetvā tamatthaṃ pucchanto ‘‘ekaññeva nu kho’’tiādimāha. Bhagavāpissa vissajjesi. Tattha puthūpīti bahūnipi. Yathā yathā kho, poṭṭhapāda, nirodhaṃphusatīti pathavīkasiṇādīsu yena yena kasiṇena, paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ vā yena yena jhānena. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – sace hi pathavīkasiṇena karaṇabhūtena pathavīkasiṇasamāpattiṃ ekavāraṃ samāpajjanto purimasaññānirodhaṃ phusati ekaṃ saññaggaṃ, atha dve vāre, tayo vāre, vārasataṃ, vārasahassaṃ, vārasatasahassaṃ vā samāpajjanto purimasaññānirodhaṃ phusati, satasahassaṃ, saññaggāni. Esa nayo sesakasiṇesu. Jhānesupi sace paṭhamajjhānena karaṇabhūtena ekavāraṃ purimasaññānirodhaṃ phusati ekaṃ saññaggaṃ. Atha dve vāre , tayo vāre, vārasataṃ, vārasahassaṃ, vārasatasahassaṃ vā purimasaññānirodhaṃ phusati, satasahassaṃ saññaggāni. Esa nayo sesajjhānasamāpattīsupi. Iti ekavāraṃ samāpajjanavasena vā sabbampi sañjānanalakkhaṇena saṅgahetvā vā ekaṃ saññaggaṃ hoti, aparāparaṃ samāpajjanavasena bahūni.
commentary_english:
415. Then, the wandering mendicant [said,] "The Blessed One has said, 'The sphere of nothingness is a designation ( *saññagga* ).'
Is just this a designation, or is there a designation even in the remaining attainments (*avasesasamāpatti*)?" Thinking this, and asking about that meaning, he said, "Is it just one?" etc.
The Blessed One explained to him.
There, "distinct," also means "many."
Just as, Poṭṭhapāda, one touches cessation, so it is with earth *kasiṇa*, etc.; with whichever *kasiṇa* , or with whichever *jhāna* of the first *jhāna*, etc.
This is what is said: If, using earth *kasiṇa* as the instrumental cause, one attains to the attainment of earth *kasiṇa* once, one touches the cessation of prior perceptions, [and thus there is] one designation ( *ekaṃ saññaggaṃ* ); then, if one attains [it] two times, three times, a hundred times, a thousand times, a hundred thousand times, one touches the cessation of prior perceptions, [and thus there are] a hundred thousand designations ( *satasahassaṃ saññaggāni* ).
This is the method for the remaining *kasiṇas*.
Likewise, with the *jhānas*: if, using the first *jhāna* as the instrumental cause, one touches the cessation of prior perceptions once, [there is] one designation ( *ekaṃ saññaggaṃ* ).
Then, if one attains [it] two times, three times, a hundred times, a thousand times, a hundred thousand times, one touches the cessation of prior perceptions, [and thus there are] a hundred thousand designations ( *satasahassaṃ saññaggāni* ).
This is the method for the remaining *jhānas* and attainments ( *jhānasamāpatti* ) as well.
Thus, either through the force of attaining [it] one time, or by gathering everything together by way of the characteristic of perception, there is one designation ( *ekaṃ saññaggaṃ* ); through the force of repeatedly attaining [it], [there are] many.

mula_pali: 416. ‘‘Saññā nu kho, bhante, paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṃ, udāhu ñāṇaṃ paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, pacchā saññā, udāhu saññā ca ñāṇañca apubbaṃ acarimaṃ uppajjantī’’ti? ‘‘Saññā kho, poṭṭhapāda, paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṃ, saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hoti. So evaṃ pajānāti – ‘idappaccayā kira me ñāṇaṃ udapādī’ti. Iminā kho etaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ – yathā saññā paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṃ, saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hotī’’ti.
mula_english:
“Venerable sir, does perception (*saññā*) arise first, and then knowledge (*ñāṇa*), or does knowledge (*ñāṇa*) arise first, and then perception (*saññā*), or do perception (*saññā*) and knowledge (*ñāṇa*) arise simultaneously, without precedence?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, perception (*saññā*) arises first, and then knowledge (*ñāṇa*). And the arising of knowledge (*ñāṇa*) comes from the arising of perception (*saññā*).

One discerns, ‘It’s in dependence on this that my knowledge (*ñāṇa*) has arisen.’

Through this line of reasoning, Poṭṭhapāda, one can realize how perception (*saññā*) arises first, and then knowledge (*ñāṇa*), and how the arising of knowledge (*ñāṇa*) comes from the arising of perception (*saññā*).”
commentary_pali: 416.Saññā nu kho, bhanteti bhante nirodhasamāpajjanakassa bhikkhuno ‘‘saññā nu kho paṭhamaṃ uppajjatī’’ti pucchati. Tassa bhagavā ‘‘saññā kho, poṭṭhapādā’’ti byākāsi. Tattha saññāti jhānasaññā. Ñāṇanti vipassanāñāṇaṃ. Aparo nayo, saññāti vipassanā saññā. Ñāṇanti maggañāṇaṃ. Aparo nayo, saññāti maggasaññā. Ñāṇanti phalañāṇaṃ. Tipiṭakamahāsivatthero panāha – Kiṃ ime bhikkhū bhaṇanti, poṭṭhapādo heṭṭhā bhagavantaṃ nirodhaṃ pucchi. Idāni nirodhā vuṭṭhānaṃ pucchanto ‘‘bhagavā nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa kiṃ paṭhamaṃ arahattaphalasaññā uppajjati, udāhu paccavekkhaṇañāṇa’’nti vadati. Athassa bhagavā yasmā phalasaññā paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, pacchā paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ . Tasmā ‘‘saññā kho poṭṭhapādā’’ti āha. Tattha saññuppādāti arahattaphalasaññāya uppādā, pacchā ‘‘idaṃ arahattaphala’’nti evaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇuppādo hoti. Idappaccayā kira meti phalasamādhisaññāpaccayā kira mayhaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ uppannanti.
commentary_english:
416.

“Is it perception (*saññā*), venerable sir?”—venerable sir, [he] asks the *bhikṣu* who attains cessation, “Does perception arise first?”.

To him, the Blessed One explained, “It is perception, Poṭṭhapāda.”

There, perception (*saññā*) is the perception of *jhāna*.

Knowledge (*ñāṇa*) is knowledge of insight (*vipassanāñāṇaṃ*).

Another method: perception (*saññā*) is insight perception (*vipassanā saññā*).

Knowledge (*ñāṇa*) is the knowledge of the path (*maggañāṇaṃ*).

Another method: perception (*saññā*) is the perception of the path (*maggasaññā*).

Knowledge (*ñāṇa*) is the knowledge of the fruit (*phalañāṇaṃ*).

But Tipiṭaka Mahāsiva Thera said: “What are these *bhikkhus* saying? Poṭṭhapāda formerly asked the Blessed One about cessation.

Now, asking about arising from cessation, he says, “Venerable sir, for one arising from cessation, what arises first, the perception of the fruit of *arhatship* (*arahattaphalasaññā*), or the knowledge of reviewing (*paccavekkhaṇañāṇa*)?”

Then, to him, the Blessed One [said], “Since the perception of the fruit arises first, afterwards [arises] the knowledge of reviewing (*paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ*), therefore, he said, “It is perception, Poṭṭhapāda.”

There, the arising of perception (*saññuppādā*) is the arising of the perception of the fruit of *arhatship* (*arahattaphalasaññāya uppādā*); afterwards, the arising of the knowledge of reviewing (*paccavekkhaṇañāṇuppādo*) occurs thus: “This is the fruit of *arhatship*.”

“Indeed, the knowledge of reviewing (*paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ*) arose for me because of this condition, because of the perception of the fruition-attainment (*phalasamādhi*).”

mula_pali: 417. ‘‘Saññā nu kho, bhante, purisassa attā, udāhu aññā saññā añño attā’’ti? ‘‘Kaṃ pana tvaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, attānaṃ paccesī’’ti ? ‘‘Oḷārikaṃ  kho ahaṃ, bhante, attānaṃ paccemi rūpiṃ cātumahābhūtikaṃ kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkha’’nti kabaḷīkārabhakkhanti (syā. ka.). ‘‘Oḷāriko ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho. Evaṃ santaṃ kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā. Tadamināpetaṃ, poṭṭhapāda , pariyāyena veditabbaṃ  yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā. Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṃ tiṭṭhatevāyaṃ (sī. pī.), poṭṭhapāda, oḷāriko attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti. Iminā kho etaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā’’ti.
mula_english:
“Is perception, venerable sir, the self of a person, or is perception one thing and the self another?” “But what kind of self do you assume, Poṭṭhapāda?” “I assume, venerable sir, a gross self, possessed of form, made up of the four great elements, feeding on physical food.”

“Then, Poṭṭhapāda, your self would be gross, possessed of form, made up of the four great elements, feeding on physical food ( *oḷāriko attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho*). That being the case, then for you perception would be one thing and self another. And it’s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another. Even as there remains this gross self—possessed of form, made up of the four great elements, and feeding on food—one perception arises for that person as another perception passes away. It’s through this line of reasoning that one can realize how perception will be one thing and self another.”
commentary_pali: 417. Idāni paribbājako yathā nāma gāmasūkaro gandhodakena nhāpetvā gandhehi anulimpitvā mālādāmaṃ piḷandhitvā sirisayane āropitopi  sukhaṃ na vindati, vegena gūthaṭṭhānameva gantvā sukhaṃ vindati. Evameva bhagavatā saṇhasukhumatilakkhaṇabbhāhatāya desanāya nhāpitavilittamaṇḍitopi nirodhakathāsirisayanaṃ āropitopi tattha sukhaṃ na vindanto gūthaṭṭhānasadisaṃ attano laddhiṃ gahetvā tameva pucchanto ‘‘saññā nu kho, bhante, purisassa attā’’tiādimāha. Athassānumatiṃ gahetvā byākātukāmo bhagavā – ‘‘kaṃ pana tva’’ntiādimāha. Tato so ‘‘arūpī attā’’ti evaṃ laddhiko samānopi ‘‘bhagavā desanāya sukusalo, so me āditova laddhiṃ mā viddhaṃsetū’’ti cintetvā attano laddhiṃ pariharanto ‘‘oḷārikaṃ kho’’tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā tattha dosaṃ dassento ‘‘oḷāriko ca hi te’’tiādimāha . Tattha evaṃ santanti evaṃ sante. Bhummatthe hi etaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Evaṃ santaṃ attānaṃ paccāgacchato tavāti ayaṃ vā ettha attho. Catunnaṃ khandhānaṃ ekuppādekanirodhattā kiñcāpi yā saññā uppajjati, sāva nirujjhati. Aparāparaṃ upādāya pana ‘‘aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhantī’’ti vuttaṃ.
commentary_english:
417.
Just as now, a wandering mendicant, like a village pig, even having been bathed with scented water, anointed with perfumes, adorned with a garland, and placed on a luxurious couch, does not find happiness, but, rushing with speed to a dung-heap, finds happiness.

Even so, even having been bathed, anointed, and adorned by the Blessed One with a discourse that is delicate, subtle, characterized by mindfulness, placed on the luxurious couch of the cessation of talk, not finding happiness there, taking hold of his own doctrine, similar to a dung-heap, he asks that very question, saying, "Is perception, indeed, venerable sir, the self of a person?" and so on.

Then, having taken his consent, the Blessed One, desiring to explain, said, "What, then, are you?" and so on.

Then he, even though being one who holds such a view, "The self is formless" thinking, "The Blessed One is very skilled in discourse; may he not destroy my view from the beginning," warding off his own view, said, "It is coarse," and so on.

Then the Blessed One, showing the fault there, said, "And coarse, indeed, is your..." and so on.

There, "when it is thus," means when it is thus.

Here, this is a statement of use in the sense of the earth.

Or, "Thus, to you who are returning to yourself," this is the meaning here.

Because of the four aggregates having one arising and one cessation, even though whatever perception arises, that very thing ceases.

Moreover, depending on another and another, it is said, "Another perception arises, and another perception ceases."

mula_pali: 418. ‘‘Manomayaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, attānaṃ paccemi sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṃ ahīnindriya’’nti. ‘‘Manomayo ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo, evaṃ santampi kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā. Tadamināpetaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā. Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, manomayo attā sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti. Imināpi kho etaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā’’ti.
mula_english:
“Then, venerable sir, I posit a self (ātman) made of mind (*manomaya*), complete in all its parts (*sabbaṅgapaccaṅgin*), with faculties not deficient (*ahīnindriya*).”

“And if, Poṭṭhapāda, your self (ātman) were made of mind (*manomaya*), complete in all its parts (*sabbaṅgapaccaṅgin*), with faculties not deficient (*ahīnindriya*), then, Poṭṭhapāda, perception (*saññā*) would be one thing, and the self (ātman) another.

And it is through this reasoning, Poṭṭhapāda, that it should be understood how perception (*saññā*) will be one thing and the self (ātman) another.

“Even as there remains, Poṭṭhapāda, this self (ātman) made of mind (*manomaya*), complete in all its parts (*sabbaṅgapaccaṅgin*), with faculties not deficient (*ahīnindriya*), one perception (*saññā*) arises for that person as another perception (*saññā*) ceases.

“It’s through this line of reasoning too, Poṭṭhapāda, that one can realize how perception (*saññā*) will be one thing and the self (ātman) another.”
commentary_pali: 418-420. Idāni aññaṃ laddhiṃ dassento – ‘‘manomayaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante’’tiādiṃ vatvā tatrāpi dose dinne yathā nāma ummattako yāvassa saññā nappatiṭṭhāti, tāva aññaṃ gahetvā aññaṃ vissajjeti, saññāpatiṭṭhānakāle pana vattabbameva vadati, evameva  aññaṃ gahetvā aññaṃ vissajjetvā idāni attano laddhiṃyeva vadanto ‘‘arūpī kho’’tiādimāha. Tatrāpi yasmā so saññāya uppādanirodhaṃ icchati, attānaṃ pana sassataṃ maññati. Tasmā tathevassa dosaṃ dassento bhagavā ‘‘evaṃ santampī’’tiādimāha. Tato paribbājako micchādassanena abhibhūtattā bhagavatā vuccamānampi taṃ nānattaṃ ajānanto ‘‘sakkā panetaṃ, bhante, mayā’’tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā yasmā so saññāya uppādanirodhaṃ passantopi saññāmayaṃ attānaṃ niccameva maññati. Tasmā ‘‘dujjānaṃ kho’’tiādimāha. Tatthāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – tava aññā diṭṭhi, aññā khanti, aññā ruci, aññathāyeva te dassanaṃ pavattaṃ, aññadeva ca te khamati ceva ruccati ca, aññatra  ca te āyogo, aññissāyeva paṭipattiyā yuttapayuttatā, aññattha ca te ācariyakaṃ, aññasmiṃ titthāyatane ācariyabhāvo. Tena tayā evaṃ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena dujjānaṃ etanti. Atha paribbājako – ‘‘saññā vā purisassa attā hotu, aññā vā saññā, taṃ sassatādi bhāvamassa pucchissa’’nti puna ‘‘kiṃ pana bhante’’tiādimāha. Tattha lokoti attānaṃ sandhāya vadati. Na hetaṃ poṭṭhapāda atthasañhitanti poṭṭhapāda etaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ na idhalokaparalokaatthanissitaṃ, na attatthaparatthanissitaṃ. Na dhammasaṃhitanti na navalokuttaradhammanissitaṃ. Nādibrahmacariyakanti sikkhattayasaṅkhātassa sāsanabrahmacariyakassa na ādimattaṃ, adhisīlasikkhāmattampi na hoti. Na nibbidāyāti saṃsāravaṭṭe nibbindanatthāya na saṃvattati. Navirāgāyāti vaṭṭavirāgatthāya na saṃvattati. Na nirodhāyāti vaṭṭassa nirodhakaraṇatthāya na saṃvattati. Na upasamāyāti vaṭṭassa vūpasamanatthāya na saṃvattati. Na abhiññāyāti vaṭṭābhijānanāya paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati. Na sambodhāyāti vaṭṭasambujjhanatthāya na  saṃvattati. Na nibbānāyāti amatamahānibbānassa paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati. Idaṃ dukkhantiādīsu taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā tebhūmakā pañcakkhandhā dukkhanti, tasseva dukkhassa pabhāvanato sappaccayā taṇhā dukkhasamudayoti. Ubhinnaṃ appavatti dukkhanirodhoti, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti mayā byākatanti attho. Evañca pana vatvā bhagavā ‘‘imassa paribbājakassa maggapātubhāvo vā phalasacchikiriyā vā natthi, mayhañca bhikkhācāravelā’’ti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi. Paribbājakopi taṃ ākāraṃ ñatvā bhagavato gamanakālaṃ ārocento viya ‘‘evameta’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
418-420. Now, while demonstrating another view, [the wanderer,] having said something like, "Indeed, venerable sir, I am mind-made," and when a fault was pointed out in that as well, just as a madman, as long as his perception (saññā) is not established, having taken one thing, discards another; but when perception is established, he speaks just what should be spoken; just so, having taken one thing, and discarded another, now, while stating just his own view, he said something like, "Indeed, I am formless."

Even there, since he desires the arising and cessation of perception (saññā), but considers the self to be eternal (sassata).

Therefore, the Blessed One (bhagavā), while showing the fault in that very way, said something like, "Even while it is thus..."

Then, the wanderer (paribbājako), his mind overcome by wrong view (micchādassana), not understanding that diversity (nānatta), even while it was being spoken by the Blessed One, said something like, "But is this possible for me, venerable sir?"

Then, to him, the Blessed One, since he considers the self to be always of the nature of perception (saññāmayaṃ), even while seeing the arising and cessation of perception (saññā),

therefore, said something like, "Indeed, it is difficult to know (dujjānaṃ kho)."

There, this is the meaning in brief (saṅkhepattho): your (tava) view (diṭṭhi) is different (aññā), your tolerance (khanti) is different (aññā), your liking (ruci) is different (aññā), your seeing (dassanaṃ) is occurring (pavattaṃ) in a different way (aññathāyeva), and something different (aññadeva) is pleasing (khamati) and liking (ruccati) to you (te), and your application (āyogaḥ) is in another place (aññatra), the fitness and unfitness of your practice (paṭipattiyā) is through another (aññissāyeva), your teaching (ācariyakaṃ) is in another place (aññattha), [and] the state of being a teacher (ācariyabhāvo) is in another (aññasmiṃ) sectarian (titthāyatane) residence.

Therefore, by you (tayā), thus, with different views (aññadiṭṭhikena), with different tolerance (aññakhantikena), with different liking (aññarucikena), with application in another place (aññatrāyogena), with teaching in another place (aññatrācariyakena), this is difficult to know (dujjānaṃ etanti).

Then the wanderer (paribbājako) [said] – "Whether perception (saññā) be the self (attā) of a person (purisassa), or another perception (aññā vā saññā), I will ask him about that eternal (sassata) etc. state (bhāvam)" – again he said something like, "But what, venerable sir?"

There, "world" (loko) means he speaks in reference to the self (attānaṃ).

"Not connected with the meaning (attha)”, Poṭṭhapāda, means, Poṭṭhapāda, this is something taken up by view (diṭṭhigataṃ), not based on the meaning (attha) of this world (idhaloka) or the other world (paraloka), not based on one's own benefit (attattha) or another's benefit (parattha).

"Not connected with the Dharma (dhamma)", [means] not based on the nine supramundane Dharmas (lokuttara-dhamma).

"Not the beginning of the holy life (brahmacariya)," [means] it is not even the mere beginning of the holy life (brahmacariyakassa) of the Teaching (sāsana), which is reckoned as the threefold training (sikkhattayasaṅkhātassa), nor even just the training in higher morality (adhisīlasikkhāmattampi).

"Not for disenchantment (nibbidāya)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to the purpose of disenchantment (nibbindanatthāya) in the round of rebirth (saṃsāravaṭṭe).

"Not for dispassion (virāgāya)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to the purpose of dispassion (virāgatthāya) from the round (vaṭṭa).

"Not for cessation (nirodhāya)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to the purpose of making cessation (nirodhakaraṇatthāya) of the round (vaṭṭassa).

"Not for appeasement (upasamāyāti)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to the purpose of the appeasement (vūpasamanatthāya) of the round (vaṭṭassa).

"Not for direct knowledge (abhiññāya)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to direct realization (paccakkhakiriyāya) through the direct knowing (abhijānanāya) of the round (vaṭṭa).

"Not for enlightenment (sambodhāya)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to the purpose of awakening (sambujjhanatthāya) from the round (vaṭṭa).

"Not for *nirvāṇa* (nibbānāya)," [means] it does not lead (na saṃvattati) to the direct realization (paccakkhakiriyāya) of the deathless great *nirvāṇa* (amatamahānibbānassa).

In "This is suffering" (idaṃ dukkhanti) etc., having established craving (taṇhaṃ), the five aggregates (pañcakkhandhā) that are of the triple world (tebhūmakā) are suffering (dukkhanti), from the arising (pabhāvanato) of that very suffering (dukkhassa), craving (taṇhā) with its conditions (sappaccayā) is the origin of suffering (dukkhassa samudayoti).

The non-occurrence (appavatti) of both (ubhinnaṃ) is the cessation of suffering (dukkhanirodhoti), the Noble Eightfold Path (ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo) is the practice (paṭipadāti) leading to the cessation of suffering (dukkhanirodhagāminī). This is the meaning (attho) as declared (byākatanti) by me (mayā).

And thus, having spoken, the Blessed One (bhagavā), thinking, "There is no arising of the path (maggapātubhāvo) or realization of the fruit (phalasacchikiriyā) for this wanderer (paribbājakassa), and it is my time for alms round (bhikkhācāravelā)," became silent (tuṇhī ahosi).

The wanderer (paribbājakopi) too, knowing (ñatvā) that (taṃ) manner (ākāraṃ), as if announcing the time for the Blessed One's (bhagavato) departure (gamanakālaṃ), said something like (viya), "Indeed, it is so (evameta)."

mula_pali: 419. ‘‘Arūpiṃ  kho ahaṃ, bhante, attānaṃ paccemi saññāmaya’’nti. ‘‘Arūpī ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa saññāmayo, evaṃ santampi kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā. Tadamināpetaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā. Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, arūpī attā saññāmayo, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti. Imināpi kho etaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā’’ti.
mula_english:
“Then, lord, I posit a formless self (*arūpiṃ attānaṃ*) made of perception (*saññāmaya*).”

“Then, Poṭṭhapāda, your self (*attā*) would be formless (*arūpī*) and made of perception (*saññāmayaḥ*). That being the case, then for you perception (*saññā*) would be one thing (*aññā*) and self (*attā*) another (*añño*).

And it’s through this line of reasoning (*pariyāyena*) that one can realize (*veditabbaṃ*) how perception (*saññā*) will be one thing (*aññā*) and self (*attā*) another (*añño*):

”even as there remains this formless self (*arūpī attā saññāmayo*), Poṭṭhapāda, one perception (*saññā*) arises (*uppajjanti*) for that person (*purisassa*) as another perception (*saññā*) passes away (*nirujjhanti*).

It’s through this line of reasoning (*pariyāyena*) that one can realize (*veditabbaṃ*) how perception (*saññā*) will be one thing (*aññā*) and self (*attā*) another (*añño*).
commentary_pali: 418-420. Idāni aññaṃ laddhiṃ dassento – ‘‘manomayaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante’’tiādiṃ vatvā tatrāpi dose dinne yathā nāma ummattako yāvassa saññā nappatiṭṭhāti, tāva aññaṃ gahetvā aññaṃ vissajjeti, saññāpatiṭṭhānakāle pana vattabbameva vadati, evameva  aññaṃ gahetvā aññaṃ vissajjetvā idāni attano laddhiṃyeva vadanto ‘‘arūpī kho’’tiādimāha. Tatrāpi yasmā so saññāya uppādanirodhaṃ icchati, attānaṃ pana sassataṃ maññati. Tasmā tathevassa dosaṃ dassento bhagavā ‘‘evaṃ santampī’’tiādimāha. Tato paribbājako micchādassanena abhibhūtattā bhagavatā vuccamānampi taṃ nānattaṃ ajānanto ‘‘sakkā panetaṃ, bhante, mayā’’tiādimāha. Athassa bhagavā yasmā so saññāya uppādanirodhaṃ passantopi saññāmayaṃ attānaṃ niccameva maññati. Tasmā ‘‘dujjānaṃ kho’’tiādimāha. Tatthāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – tava aññā diṭṭhi, aññā khanti, aññā ruci, aññathāyeva te dassanaṃ pavattaṃ, aññadeva ca te khamati ceva ruccati ca, aññatra  ca te āyogo, aññissāyeva paṭipattiyā yuttapayuttatā, aññattha ca te ācariyakaṃ, aññasmiṃ titthāyatane ācariyabhāvo. Tena tayā evaṃ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena dujjānaṃ etanti. Atha paribbājako – ‘‘saññā vā purisassa attā hotu, aññā vā saññā, taṃ sassatādi bhāvamassa pucchissa’’nti puna ‘‘kiṃ pana bhante’’tiādimāha. Tattha lokoti attānaṃ sandhāya vadati. Na hetaṃ poṭṭhapāda atthasañhitanti poṭṭhapāda etaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ na idhalokaparalokaatthanissitaṃ, na attatthaparatthanissitaṃ. Na dhammasaṃhitanti na navalokuttaradhammanissitaṃ. Nādibrahmacariyakanti sikkhattayasaṅkhātassa sāsanabrahmacariyakassa na ādimattaṃ, adhisīlasikkhāmattampi na hoti. Na nibbidāyāti saṃsāravaṭṭe nibbindanatthāya na saṃvattati. Navirāgāyāti vaṭṭavirāgatthāya na saṃvattati. Na nirodhāyāti vaṭṭassa nirodhakaraṇatthāya na saṃvattati. Na upasamāyāti vaṭṭassa vūpasamanatthāya na saṃvattati. Na abhiññāyāti vaṭṭābhijānanāya paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati. Na sambodhāyāti vaṭṭasambujjhanatthāya na  saṃvattati. Na nibbānāyāti amatamahānibbānassa paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati. Idaṃ dukkhantiādīsu taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā tebhūmakā pañcakkhandhā dukkhanti, tasseva dukkhassa pabhāvanato sappaccayā taṇhā dukkhasamudayoti. Ubhinnaṃ appavatti dukkhanirodhoti, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti mayā byākatanti attho. Evañca pana vatvā bhagavā ‘‘imassa paribbājakassa maggapātubhāvo vā phalasacchikiriyā vā natthi, mayhañca bhikkhācāravelā’’ti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi. Paribbājakopi taṃ ākāraṃ ñatvā bhagavato gamanakālaṃ ārocento viya ‘‘evameta’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
418-420. Now, while showing another doctrine, saying, "Indeed, I am mind-made, venerable sir," etc., and when a fault was pointed out there as well, just as a madman, for as long as his perception does not become steady, takes one thing and throws away another, but at the time when perception becomes steady, he speaks only what should be spoken; just so, having taken one thing and thrown away another, now, while speaking of his own doctrine, he said, "Indeed, I am formless," etc.

There too, because he desires the arising and cessation of perception, but he considers the self to be eternal.

Therefore, the Blessed One, while showing a fault in that very way, said, "Even though it is so," etc.

Then, the wandering ascetic, because his mind was overcome by wrong views, not understanding that diversity even when it was being spoken by the Blessed One, said, "Is this possible, venerable sir, by me?" etc.

Then the Blessed One [thought], since even while seeing the arising and cessation of perception, he still considers the self to be always made of perception.

Therefore, he said, "It is difficult to know," etc.

There, this is the meaning in brief: Your view is different, your patience is different, your inclination is different, your perception proceeds differently, and something else is pleasing and agreeable to you, and your application [of mind] is elsewhere, the suitability and unsuitability [of things] are by a different practice, and your teaching is elsewhere, [your] state of being a teacher is in a different sectarian institution.

Therefore, by you, with such a different view, different patience, different inclination, different application [of mind], [and] a different teaching, this is difficult to know.

Then the wandering ascetic [thought]: "Let perception be the self of a person, or let there be a different perception, I will ask him about that eternal state," and again he said, "What then, venerable sir?" etc.

There, "world" he speaks referring to self.

"This is not connected with the meaning," O Poṭṭhapāda, this view is not based on the benefit of this world or the next world, nor is it based on one's own benefit or the benefit of others.

"It is not connected with the Dhamma," [meaning] it is not based on the nine supramundane Dhammas.

"It is not the beginning of the holy life," [meaning] it is not even the mere beginning of the holy life, which is reckoned as the threefold training, [nor] is it merely the training in higher morality.

"It does not lead to disenchantment," [meaning] it does not lead to the purpose of being disenchanted with the round of rebirth.

"It does not lead to dispassion," [meaning] it does not lead to the purpose of dispassion for the round [of rebirth].

"It does not lead to cessation," [meaning] it does not lead to the purpose of doing cessation of the round [of rebirth].

"It does not lead to appeasement," [meaning] it does not lead to the purpose of appeasement of the round [of rebirth].

"It does not lead to direct knowledge," [meaning] it does not lead to the direct action of knowing about the round [of rebirth].

"It does not lead to enlightenment," [meaning] it does not lead to the purpose of awakening about the round [of rebirth].

"It does not lead to *Nirvāṇa*," [meaning] it does not lead to the direct action of the deathless great *Nirvāṇa*.

In "This is suffering," etc., having established craving, the five aggregates of the three realms are suffering, from the origin of that very suffering, craving is the origin of suffering with conditions.

The non-occurrence of both is the cessation of suffering; the Noble Eightfold Path is the practice leading to the cessation of suffering, [this] is the meaning I have explained.

And having spoken thus, the Blessed One, thinking, "For this wandering ascetic, there is no appearance of the path or the realization of the fruit, and it is my time for alms-gathering," became silent.

The wandering ascetic also, knowing that demeanor, as if announcing the Blessed One's time to leave, said, "So it is," etc.

mula_pali: 420. ‘‘Sakkā panetaṃ, bhante, mayā ñātuṃ – ‘saññā purisassa attā’ti vā ‘aññāva saññā añño attāti vā’ti? ‘‘Dujjānaṃ kho etaṃ evaṃ (ka.), poṭṭhapāda, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena – ‘saññā purisassa attā’ti vā, ‘aññāva saññā añño attāti vā’’’ti. ‘‘Sace  taṃ, bhante, mayā dujjānaṃ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena – ‘saññā purisassa attā’ti vā, ‘aññāva saññā añño attā’ti vā; ‘kiṃ pana, bhante, sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña’nti? Abyākataṃ kho etaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, mayā – ‘sassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña’nti. ‘‘Kiṃ  pana, bhante, ‘asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña’’’nti ? ‘‘Etampi kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā abyākataṃ – ‘asassato loko, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña’’’nti. ‘‘Kiṃ pana, bhante, ‘antavā loko…pe… ‘anantavā loko … ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ… ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ… ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā… ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā… ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā… ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña’’’nti? ‘‘Etampi kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā abyākataṃ – ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamañña’’’nti. ‘‘Kasmā panetaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā abyākata’’nti? ‘‘Na hetaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṃhitaṃ na dhammasaṃhitaṃ  nādibrahmacariyakaṃ, na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati, tasmā etaṃ mayā abyākata’’nti. ‘‘Kiṃ pana, bhante, bhagavatā byākata’’nti? ‘‘Idaṃ dukkhanti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṃ. Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṃ. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṃ. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākata’’nti. ‘‘Kasmā panetaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā byākata’’nti? ‘‘Etañhi, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṃhitaṃ, etaṃ dhammasaṃhitaṃ, etaṃ ādibrahmacariyakaṃ, etaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati; tasmā etaṃ mayā byākata’’nti. ‘‘Evametaṃ, bhagavā, evametaṃ, sugata . Yassadāni, bhante, bhagavā kālaṃ maññatī’’ti. Atha kho bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
mula_english:
420.
“Is it possible for me to know, venerable sir, whether perception (*saññā*) is a person's self (*ātmā*), or if perception is one thing and the self (*ātmā*) another?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, it is difficult for you, having other views, other practices, other preferences, other trainings, other teachers, to know whether perception (*saññā*) is a person's self (*ātmā*), or if perception is one thing and the self (*ātmā*) another.”

“Well then, venerable sir, if it is difficult for me, having other views, other practices, other preferences, other trainings, other teachers, to know whether perception (*saññā*) is a person's self (*ātmā*), or if perception is one thing and the self (*ātmā*) another, is the cosmos eternal (*śāśvata*), is only this true, and is anything else worthless?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, this has not been declared by me, that the cosmos is eternal (*śāśvata*), only this is true, and anything else is worthless."

“Well then, venerable sir, is the cosmos not eternal (*aśāśvata*), is only this true, and is anything else worthless?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, this too has not been declared by me, that the cosmos is not eternal (*aśāśvata*), only this is true, and anything else is worthless."

“Well then, venerable sir, is the cosmos finite (*antavā*) … or infinite (*anantavā*) … is the soul (*jīva*) the same as the body (*śarīra*)… is the soul (*jīva*) one thing and the body (*śarīra*) another … does the *Tathāgata* exist after death (*maraṇā*) … does the *Tathāgata* not exist after death (*maraṇā*)… does the *Tathāgata* both exist and not exist after death (*maraṇā*)… does the *Tathāgata* neither exist nor not exist after death (*maraṇā*), is only this true, and is anything else worthless?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, this too has not been declared by me, that the *Tathāgata* neither exists nor not exist after death (*maraṇā*), only this is true, and anything else is worthless."

“Why then, venerable sir, has this not been declared by the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*)?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, this is not connected with the goal (*artha*), not connected with the *Dharma*, not fundamental to the holy life (*ādibrahmacariyakaṃ*), and does not lead to disenchantment (*nirbidā*), to dispassion (*virāga*), to cessation (*nirodha*), to stilling (*upaśama*), to direct knowledge (*abhijñā*), to self-awakening (*sambodha*), to *Nirvana*. Therefore, this has not been declared by me.”

“What then, venerable sir, has the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*) declared?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, I have declared that this is suffering (*duḥkha*).

“Poṭṭhapāda, I have declared that this is the origin of suffering (*duḥkhasamudaya*).

“Poṭṭhapāda, I have declared that this is the cessation of suffering (*duḥkhanirodha*).

“Poṭṭhapāda, I have declared that this is the path (*pratipadā*) of practice leading to the cessation of suffering (*duḥkhanirodhagāminī*)."

“Why then, venerable sir, has this been declared by the Blessed One (*bhagavatā*)?”

“Poṭṭhapāda, this is connected with the goal (*artha*), connected with the *Dharma*, fundamental to the holy life (*ādibrahmacariyakaṃ*), and leads to disenchantment (*nirbidā*), to dispassion (*virāga*), to cessation (*nirodha*), to stilling (*upaśama*), to direct knowledge (*abhijñā*), to self-awakening (*sambodha*), to *Nirvana*. Therefore, this has been declared by me.”

“So it is, Blessed One (*bhagavā*), so it is, Well-Gone (*sugata*)."

“Well now, venerable sir, it’s time for the Blessed One (*bhagavā*) to do as he sees fit.”

Then the Blessed One (*bhagavā*) got up from his seat (*āsana*) and left.
