Na abhiññāyāti vaṭṭābhijānanāya paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati. Na sambodhāyāti vaṭṭasambujjhanatthāya na  saṃvattati. Na nibbānāyāti amatamahānibbānassa paccakkhakiriyāya na saṃvattati. Idaṃ dukkhantiādīsu taṇhaṃ ṭhapetvā tebhūmakā pañcakkhandhā dukkhanti, tasseva dukkhassa pabhāvanato sappaccayā taṇhā dukkhasamudayoti. Ubhinnaṃ appavatti dukkhanirodhoti, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti mayā byākatanti attho. Evañca pana vatvā bhagavā ‘‘imassa paribbājakassa maggapātubhāvo vā phalasacchikiriyā vā natthi, mayhañca bhikkhācāravelā’’ti cintetvā tuṇhī ahosi. Paribbājakopi taṃ ākāraṃ ñatvā bhagavato gamanakālaṃ ārocento viya ‘‘evameta’’ntiādimāha.
commentary_english:
418-420.
Now, while pointing out another doctrine, saying, "I am mind-made, venerable sir," and when a fault was pointed out even there, just as a madman, as long as his perception does not become stable, keeps grasping one thing and rejecting another, but when his perception becomes stable, he speaks only what should be spoken, just so, having grasped one thing and rejected another, now, while declaring his own doctrine, he says, "I am formless, venerable sir."

Even there, because he desires the origination and cessation of perception, but considers himself to be eternal.

Therefore, showing the fault in that very way, the Bhagavān said, "Even though it is so..."

Then, the wandering ascetic, his mind overwhelmed by wrong views, not understanding that diversity even when being told by the Bhagavān, said, "Is it possible, venerable sir, for me...?"

Then, the Bhagavān, because he sees the origination and cessation of perception, but considers himself, made of perception, to be eternal.

Therefore, he said, "It is difficult to know."

There, this is the meaning in brief: your view is different, your patience is different, your liking is different, your seeing proceeds in a different way, and something else is pleasing and agreeable to you, and your effort is in a different direction, the suitability and unsuitability are according to a different practice, and your teaching is in a different place, the state of a teacher is in a different place of teaching.

Therefore, it is difficult for you, with such a different view, different patience, different liking, effort in a different direction, and teaching in a different place, to understand this.

Then the wandering ascetic said, "Let perception be the self of a person, or a different perception, I will ask him about that eternal state," and again he said, "What then, venerable sir?"

There, "world" refers to speaking with reference to self.

"It is not connected with meaning, Poṭṭhapāda," means, Poṭṭhapāda, this is based on view, not based on the benefit of this world and the next world, not based on one's own benefit and the benefit of others.

"It is not connected with the Dhamma," means, it is not based on the nine supramundane Dhammas.

"It is not the beginning of the holy life," means, it is not even the mere beginning of the holy life consisting of the three trainings, it is not even the mere training in higher morality.

"It does not lead to disenchantment," means, it does not lead to disenchantment with the round of rebirth.

"It does not lead to dispassion," means, it does not lead to dispassion for the round.

"It does not lead to cessation," means, it does not lead to making an end of the round.

"It does not lead to peace," means, it does not lead to the stilling of the round.

"It does not lead to direct knowledge," means, it does not lead to the direct realization of the round.

"It does not lead to enlightenment," means, it does not lead to the perfect awakening from the round.

"It does not lead to *nirvāṇa*," means, it does not lead to the direct realization of the deathless great *nirvāṇa*.

"This is suffering," etc., setting aside craving, the five aggregates of the three realms are suffering, and craving, with its conditions, is the origin of suffering, because of the manifestation of that very suffering.

The non-occurrence of both is the cessation of suffering, the noble eightfold path is the practice leading to the cessation of suffering, this is the meaning as declared by me.

And so, having said this, the Bhagavān, thinking, "For this wandering ascetic, there is neither the appearance of the path nor the realization of the fruit, and it is time for my alms round," became silent.

The wandering ascetic, knowing that sign, as if announcing the time for the Bhagavān's departure, said, "So it is," and so forth.

mula_pali: 421. Atha  kho te paribbājakā acirapakkantassa bhagavato poṭṭhapādaṃ paribbājakaṃ samantato vācā vācāya (syā. ka.) sannitodakena sañjhabbharimakaṃsu – ‘‘evameva panāyaṃ bhavaṃ poṭṭhapādo yaññadeva samaṇo gotamo bhāsati, taṃ tadevassa abbhanumodati – ‘evametaṃ bhagavā evametaṃ, sugatā’ti. Na kho pana mayaṃ kiñci kañci (pī.) samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṃsikaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāma – ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ‘antavā loko’ti vā, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti vā, ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti vā , ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti  vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā’’ti. Evaṃ vutte poṭṭhapādo paribbājako te paribbājake etadavoca – ‘‘ahampi kho, bho, na kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṃsikaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi – ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā…pe… ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā; api ca samaṇo gotamo bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ tathaṃ paṭipadaṃ paññapeti dhammaṭṭhitataṃ dhammaniyāmataṃ. Bhūtaṃ kho pana tacchaṃ tathaṃ paṭipadaṃ paññapentassa dhammaṭṭhitataṃ dhammaniyāmataṃ, kathañhi nāma mādiso viññū samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyyā’’ti?
mula_english:
421. Then, not long after the Blessed One had departed, those wanderers taunted Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer from all sides with sneering and sarcastic words, saying, "Indeed, whatever the *śramaṇa* Gotama speaks, the esteemed Poṭṭhapāda rejoices in it, saying, 'So it is, Blessed One (Bhagavā). So it is, O Well-Gone One (Sugata).'

"But we do not understand that the *śramaṇa* Gotama teaches any definitive doctrine, saying: 'The world is eternal (*śassato loko*)', or 'The world is not eternal (*asassato loko*)', or 'The world is finite (*antavā loko*)', or 'The world is infinite (*anantavā loko*)', or 'The soul (*jīva*) is the same as the body (*sarīra*)', or 'The soul (*jīva*) is different from the body (*sarīra*)', or 'The *Tathāgata* exists after death (*hoti tathāgato param maraṇā*)', or 'The *Tathāgata* does not exist after death (*na hoti tathāgato param maraṇā*)', or 'The *Tathāgata* both exists and does not exist after death (*hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato param maraṇā*)', or 'The *Tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death (*neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato param maraṇā*)'."

When this was said, Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer said to those wanderers: "Even I, dear sirs, do not understand that the *śramaṇa* Gotama teaches any definitive doctrine, saying: 'The world is eternal (*śassato loko*)', or 'The world is not eternal (*asassato loko*)' ... etc. ... 'The *Tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death (*neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato param maraṇā*)'. However, the *śramaṇa* Gotama proclaims a genuine, authentic, and truthful practice, a teaching grounded in the Dharma (*dhammaṭṭhitataṃ*) and in accordance with the law of Dharma (*dhammaniyāmataṃ*).

"Since he teaches a genuine, authentic, and truthful practice, a teaching grounded in the Dharma (*dhammaṭṭhitataṃ*) and in accordance with the law of Dharma (*dhammaniyāmataṃ*), how could someone like me, being wise, not rejoice in the well-spoken words of the *śramaṇa* Gotama’s well-spoken words?"
commentary_pali: 421.Vācāsannitodakenāti vacanapatodena. Sañjhabbharimakaṃsūti sañjhabbharitaṃ nirantaraṃ phuṭṭhaṃ akaṃsu, upari vijjhiṃsūti vuttaṃ hoti. Bhūtanti sabhāvato vijjamānaṃ. Tacchaṃ, tathanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Dhammaṭṭhitatanti navalokuttaradhammesu  ṭhitasabhāvaṃ. Dhammaniyāmatanti lokuttaradhammaniyāmataṃ. Buddhānañhi catusaccavinimuttā kathā nāma natthi. Tasmā sā edisā hoti.
commentary_english:
421. *vācāsannitodakenāti vacanapatodena*: By *vācāsannitodakena* is meant by the goad of speech (*vacanapatodena*).
*sañjhabbharimakaṃsūti sañjhabbharitaṃ nirantaraṃ phuṭṭhaṃ akaṃsu, upari vijjhiṃsūti vuttaṃ hoti*: "They made it constantly full, touched, and pierced above," is what is meant by *sañjhabbharimakaṃsūti sañjhabbharitaṃ*.
*bhūtanti sabhāvato vijjamānaṃ*: *Bhūta* means existing by nature (*sabhāvato vijjamānaṃ*).
*tacchaṃ, tathanti tasseva vevacanaṃ*: *Tacchaṃ* and *tathaṃ* are synonyms (*vevacanaṃ*) for that same thing.
*dhammaṭṭhitatanti navalokuttaradhammesu ṭhitasabhāvaṃ*: *Dhammaṭṭhitata* means having a nature established in the nine supramundane dharmas (*navalokuttaradhammesu ṭhitasabhāvaṃ*).
*dhammaniyāmatanti lokuttaradhammaniyāmataṃ*: *Dhammaniyāmata* means the supramundane law (*lokuttaradhammaniyāmataṃ*).
*buddhānañhi catusaccavinimuttā kathā nāma natthi*: Indeed, there is no speech (*kathā nāma natthi*) of the Buddhas that is devoid of the four noble truths (*catusaccavinimuttā*).
*tasmā sā edisā hoti*: Therefore, that is how it is.

mula_pali: 422. Atha kho dvīhatīhassa accayena citto ca hatthisāriputto poṭṭhapādo ca paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā citto hatthisāriputto bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Poṭṭhapādo  pana paribbājako bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘tadā maṃ, bhante, te paribbājakā acirapakkantassa bhagavato samantato vācāsannitodakena sañjhabbharimakaṃsu – ‘evameva panāyaṃ bhavaṃ poṭṭhapādo yaññadeva samaṇo  gotamo bhāsati, taṃ tadevassa abbhanumodati – ‘evametaṃ bhagavā evametaṃ sugatā’’ti. Na kho pana mayaṃ kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṃsikaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāma – ‘‘sassato loko’’ti vā, ‘‘asassato loko’’ti vā, ‘‘antavā loko’’ti vā, ‘‘anantavā loko’’ti vā, ‘‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’’nti vā, ‘‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’’nti vā, ‘‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’’ti vā, ‘‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’’ti vā, ‘‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato  paraṃ maraṇā’’ti vā, ‘‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’’ti vā’ti. Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, te paribbājake etadavocaṃ – ‘ahampi kho, bho, na kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṃsikaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi – ‘‘sassato loko’’ti vā, ‘‘asassato loko’’ti vā…pe… ‘‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’’ti vā; api ca samaṇo gotamo bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ tathaṃ paṭipadaṃ paññapeti dhammaṭṭhitataṃ dhammaniyāmataṃ. Bhūtaṃ  kho pana tacchaṃ tathaṃ paṭipadaṃ paññapentassa dhammaṭṭhitataṃ dhammaniyāmataṃ, kathañhi nāma mādiso viññū samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṃ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyyā’’ti?
mula_english:
Then, after two or three days, Citta Hatthasāriputta and Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer went to the Blessed One; having arrived, Citta Hatthasāriputta bowed to the Blessed One and sat down to one side.

Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer exchanged greetings with the Blessed One.

Having concluded their courteous and amiable talk, he sat down to one side.

Seated to one side, Poṭṭhapāda the wanderer said this to the Blessed One: "Some time ago, venerable sir, those wanderers, with speech like piercing barbs, overwhelmed me from all sides, saying: 'It is just that venerable Poṭṭhapāda approves of whatever the *samaṇa* Gotama says, assenting to each and every word: "So it is, Blessed One; so it is, O Well-gone One!"'

But, indeed, we do not understand the *samaṇa* Gotama to have taught any definitive doctrine, such as "The world is eternal" (*sassato loko*) or "The world is not eternal" (*asassato loko*) or "The world is finite" (*antavā loko*) or "The world is infinite" (*anantavā loko*) or "The life-principle (*jīva*) is the same as the body" (*taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra*) or "The life-principle is one thing, the body another" (*aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra*) or "The *tathāgata* exists after death" (*hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*) or "The *tathāgata* does not exist after death" (*na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*) or "The *tathāgata* both exists and does not exist after death" (*hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*) or "The *tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death" (*neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*)."

When this was said, venerable sir, I replied to those wanderers, saying: 'Indeed, I, too, do not understand the *samaṇa* Gotama to have taught any definitive doctrine, such as "The world is eternal" (*sassato loko*) or "The world is not eternal" (*asassato loko*)…or "The *tathāgata* neither exists nor does not exist after death" (*neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*); but rather the *samaṇa* Gotama teaches a genuine, accurate, and truthful practice, grounded in the Dhamma and conforming to the nature of the Dhamma.

When a genuine, accurate, and truthful practice, grounded in the Dhamma and conforming to the nature of the Dhamma is being taught, how could a wise person like myself not approve of the well-spoken words of the *samaṇa* Gotama?'"
commentary_pali: 422.Citto ca hatthisāriputtoti so kira sāvatthiyaṃ hatthiācariyassa putto bhagavato santike pabbajitvā tīṇi piṭakāni uggahetvā sukhumesu atthantaresu kusalo ahosi, pubbe katapāpakammavasena pana sattavāre vibbhamitvā gihi jāto. Kassapasammāsambuddhassa kira sāsane dve sahāyakā ahesuṃ, aññamaññaṃ samaggā ekatova sajjhāyanti. Tesu eko anabhirato gihibhāve cittaṃ uppādetvā itarassa ārocesi. So gihibhāve ādīnavaṃ pabbajjāya ānisaṃsaṃ  dassetvā taṃ ovadi. So taṃ sutvā abhiramitvā punekadivasaṃ tādise citte uppanne taṃ etadavoca ‘‘mayhaṃ āvuso evarūpaṃ cittaṃ uppajjati – ‘imāhaṃ pattacīvaraṃ tuyhaṃ dassāmī’ti’’. So pattacīvaralobhena tassa gihibhāve ānisaṃsaṃ dassetvā pabbajjāya ādīnavaṃ kathesi. Athassa taṃ sutvāva gihibhāvato cittaṃ virajjitvā pabbajjāyameva abhirami. Evamesa tadā sīlavantassa bhikkhuno gihibhāve ānisaṃsakathāya kathitattā idāni cha vāre vibbhamitvā sattame vāre pabbajito. Mahāmoggallānassa, mahākoṭṭhikattherassa ca abhidhammakathaṃ kathentānaṃ antarantarā kathaṃ opāteti. Atha naṃ mahākoṭṭhikatthero apasādeti. So  mahāsāvakassa kathite patiṭṭhātuṃ asakkonto vibbhamitvā gihi jāto. Poṭṭhapādassa panāyaṃ gihisahāyako hoti. Tasmā vibbhamitvā dvīhatīhaccayena poṭṭhapādassa santikaṃ gato. Atha naṃ so disvā ‘‘samma kiṃ tayā kataṃ, evarūpassa nāma satthu sāsanā apasakkantosi, ehi pabbajituṃ idāni te vaṭṭatī’’ti taṃ gahetvā bhagavato santikaṃ agamāsi. Tena vuttaṃ ‘‘citto ca hatthisāriputto poṭṭhapādo ca paribbājako’’ti.
commentary_english:
422. It is said that Citta, also known as Hatthasāriputta, was the son of an elephant trainer in Sāvatthi. Having gone forth near the Blessed One, mastering the three baskets (Tipitaka), he was skilled in subtle meanings. However, due to previous evil deeds, he vacillated seven times, becoming a householder.

It is said that in the dispensation of Kassapa, the Perfectly Awakened One, there were two companions, harmonious and reciting together.

Of those, one, being displeased with the householder's life, aroused his mind and told the other.

He, showing the misery of the householder's life and the benefit of going forth, advised him.

Having heard that, and rejoicing, one day when such a thought arose in his mind, he said to him, "Friend, such a thought arises in me – 'I will give this bowl and robe to you.'"

He, out of greed for the bowl and robe, showed the benefits of the householder's life, and spoke of the misery of going forth.

Then, having heard that, his mind turned away from the householder's life, and he rejoiced in going forth.

In this way, because of the benefits of the householder's life being spoken by that virtuous monk at that time, now, having vacillated six times, he went forth on the seventh time.

While Mahāmoggallāna and Mahākoṭṭhikatthera were discussing the Abhidhamma, how did he interject in between?

Then Mahākoṭṭhikatthera rejected him.

Unable to establish himself in what was said by the great disciple, he vacillated and became a householder.

Now, he was a householder friend of Poṭṭhapāda.

Therefore, having vacillated, after two or three days, he went near Poṭṭhapāda.

Then, having seen him, he said, "Friend, what have you done? Having turned away from the teaching of such a teacher? Come, it is fitting for you to go forth now!" Having taken him, he went to the Blessed One.

Therefore it was said, "Citta, also known as Hatthasāriputta, and Poṭṭhapāda, the wanderer."

mula_pali: 423. ‘‘Sabbeva kho ete, poṭṭhapāda, paribbājakā andhā acakkhukā; tvaṃyeva nesaṃ eko cakkhumā. Ekaṃsikāpi hi kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā dhammā desitā paññattā; anekaṃsikāpi hi kho , poṭṭhapāda, mayā dhammā desitā paññattā. ‘‘Katame ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṃsikā dhammā desitā paññattā? ‘Sassato loko’ti lokoti vā (sī. ka.) kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṃsiko dhammo desito paññatto; ‘asassato loko’ti lokoti vā (sī. ka.) kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṃsiko dhammo desito paññatto; ‘antavā loko’ti lokoti vā (sī. ka.) kho poṭṭhapāda…pe… ‘anantavā loko’ti lokoti vā (sī. ka.) kho poṭṭhapāda… ‘taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra’nti kho poṭṭhapāda… ‘aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīra’nti kho poṭṭhapāda… ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho poṭṭhapāda… na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho poṭṭhapāda… ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho poṭṭhapāda… ‘neva  hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṃsiko dhammo desito paññatto. ‘‘Kasmā ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṃsikā dhammā desitā paññattā? Na hete, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṃhitā na dhammasaṃhitā na ādibrahmacariyakā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattanti. Tasmā te mayā anekaṃsikā dhammā desitā paññattā’’.
mula_english:
423. The Buddha: "Poṭṭhapāda, all those wanderers are blind and have no eyes. You alone among them have eyes.

I have taught and declared some teachings to be categorical (*ekaṃsikā*), and some teachings to be not categorical (*anekaṃsikā*).

"And what are the teachings that I have taught and declared to be not categorical? 'The cosmos is eternal' (*sassato loko*)… 'The cosmos is not eternal' (*asassato loko*)… 'The cosmos is finite' (*antavā loko*)… 'The cosmos is infinite' (*anantavā loko*)… 'The soul and the body are the same' (*taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ*)… 'The soul is one thing and the body another' (*aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ*)… 'After death a Tathāgata exists' (*hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*)… 'After death a Tathāgata does not exist' (*na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*)… 'After death a Tathāgata both exists and does not exist' (*hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*)… 'After death a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist' (*neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā*) I have taught and declared to be not categorical teachings.

"And why, Poṭṭhapāda, have I taught and declared these teachings to be not categorical? Because they are not conducive to the goal, are not conducive to the Dharma, are not basic to the holy life. They don’t lead to disenchantment (*nibbidā*), to dispassion (*virāga*), to cessation (*nirodha*), to calm (*upasama*), to direct knowledge (*abhiññā*), to self-awakening (*sambodha*), to unbinding (*nibbāna*).

That’s why I have taught and declared them to be not categorical."
commentary_pali: 423.Andhāti paññācakkhuno natthitāya andhā, tasseva abhāvena acakkhukā. Tvaṃyeva nesaṃ eko cakkhumāti subhāsitadubbhāsitajānanabhāvamattena paññācakkhunā cakkhumā. Ekaṃsikāti ekakoṭṭhāsā. Paññattāti  ṭhapitā. Anekaṃsikāti na ekakoṭṭhāsā ekeneva koṭṭhāsena sassatāti vā asassatāti vā na vuttāti attho.
commentary_english:
423.

"Blind" means blind due to the non-existence of the eye of wisdom (paññācakkhu); due to the absence of that very thing, they are without the eye (acakkhukā).

"You alone are their one who has the eye" (eko cakkhumā) means having the eye (cakkhumā) of wisdom (paññācakkhu) merely by the fact of knowing what is well-spoken (subhāsita) and what is ill-spoken (dubbhāsita).

"Ekaṃsikā" means having a single part (ekakoṭṭhāsā).

"Paññattā" means established (ṭhapitā).

"Anekaṃsikā" means not having a single part; it means that it is not said whether with a single part it is eternal (sassatā) or non-eternal (asassatā).

mula_pali: 424. ‘‘Katame ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṃsikā dhammā desitā paññattā ? Idaṃ dukkhanti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṃsiko  dhammo desito paññatto. Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṃsiko dhammo desito paññatto. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṃsiko dhammo desito paññatto. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṃsiko dhammo desito paññatto. ‘‘Kasmā ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṃsikā dhammā desitā paññattā? Ete, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṃhitā , ete dhammasaṃhitā, ete ādibrahmacariyakā ete nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattanti. Tasmā te mayā ekaṃsikā dhammā desitā paññattā.
mula_english:
"And what are the teachings that I have taught and declared to be categorical? 'This is suffering (idaṃ dukkhaṃ)' I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. 'This is the origination of suffering (ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo)' I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. 'This is the cessation of suffering (ayaṃ dukkhanirodho)' I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching. 'This is the path of practice leading to the cessation of suffering (ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā)' I have taught and declared to be a categorical teaching.

"And why have I taught and declared these teachings to be categorical? Because, Poṭṭhapāda, they are connected with meaning (atthasaṃhitā), connected with the Dhamma (dhammasaṃhitā), the beginning of the holy life (ādibrahmacariyakā), and they lead to disillusionment (nibbidāya), dispassion (virāgāya), cessation (nirodhāya), peace (upasamāya), direct knowledge (abhiññāya), self-awakening (sambodhāya), and to nirvāṇa (nibbānāya). That’s why I have taught and declared them to be categorical."
commentary_pali: 424-425.Santi poṭṭhapādāti idaṃ bhagavā kasmā ārabhi? Bāhirakehi paññāpitaniṭṭhāya aniyyānikabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Sabbe hi titthiyā yathā bhagavā amataṃ nibbānaṃ, evaṃ attano attano samaye lokathupikādivasena niṭṭhaṃ paññapenti, sā ca na niyyānikā. Yathā paññattā  hutvā na niyyāti na gacchati, aññadatthu paṇḍitehi paṭikkhittā nivattati, taṃ dassetuṃ bhagavā evamāha. Tattha ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passanti puratthimāya disāya ekantasukho loko pacchimādīnaṃ vā aññatarāyāti evaṃ jānantā evaṃ passantā viharatha. Diṭṭhapubbāni kho tasmiṃ loke manussānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānādīnīti. Appāṭihīrakatanti appāṭihīrakataṃ paṭiharaṇavirahitaṃ, aniyyānikanti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
424-425. Why did the Blessed One begin with "There are footpads"? It is to show the non-leading nature of the final goal proclaimed by outsiders.

Indeed, all sectarians proclaim the end (niṭṭhaṃ) as the immortal *nirvāṇa* (amataṃ nibbānaṃ), just as the Blessed One does, each in their own time, in terms of world-pillars (lokathupika), etc., but that is not leading.

Just as what has been proclaimed, having been, does not lead out (*niyyāti*), does not go (*gacchati*), but rather, being rejected by the wise, turns back, the Blessed One said this to show that.

There, knowing and seeing the world as utterly pleasant, thinking, "The world is utterly pleasant in the eastern direction (*puratthimāya disāya*)," or in any other of the western directions, etc., live thus, knowing thus, seeing thus.

Indeed, things such as the bodily structures of humans in that world have been seen before.

"Non-miraculous (appāṭihīrakata)" means non-miraculous, devoid of counteraction. "Non-leading" (aniyyānika) is said to be that.

mula_pali: 425. ‘‘Santi, poṭṭhapāda, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino – ‘ekantasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā’ti. Tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi – ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino – ‘‘ekantasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā’ti? Te ce me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti. Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharathā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekaṃ vā rattiṃ ekaṃ vā divasaṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā rattiṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā divasaṃ ekantasukhiṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’ti sampajānāthāti (sī. syā. ka.)? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto  jānātha – ‘‘ayaṃ maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā’’’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto yā tā devatā ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā, tāsaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ saddaṃ suṇātha – ‘‘suppaṭipannāttha, mārisā, ujuppaṭipannāttha, mārisā, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya; mayampi hi, mārisā, evaṃpaṭipannā ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti ? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante tesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
“425.

“There are, Poṭṭhapāda, some ascetics and Brahmins who maintain and hold the view that: ‘The self is exclusively happy and free from disease after death.’

Then I approached them and said: ‘Is it true, friends, that you maintain and hold the view that: “The self is exclusively happy and free from disease after death”?’ And if they, being asked by me thus, acknowledge ‘Yes.’

Then I say this: ‘But do you, venerable sirs, dwell having known and seen an exclusively happy world ( *ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ* )?’ When asked this, they say ‘No.’

“Then I say this: ‘But have you, venerable sirs, ever been aware of a self exclusively happy for a day or a night, or for half a day or half a night?’ When asked this, they say ‘No.’

Then I say this: ‘But do you, venerable sirs, know that “This is the path, this is the practice for the realization of an exclusively happy world ( *ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya* )”?’ When asked this, they say ‘No.’

“Then I say this: ‘But have you, venerable sirs, heard the voices of devas ( *devatā* ) reborn in an exclusively happy world ( *ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā* ), saying, “Practice well, my dears. Practice straightforwardly, my dears, for the realization of an exclusively happy world ( *ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya* ); because it was through such a practice that we ourselves have been reborn in an exclusively happy world ( *ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā* )”?’ When asked this, they say ‘No.’

“What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda? When this is the case, don’t the words of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing?” “Indeed, venerable sir, when this is the case, the words of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing.”
commentary_pali: 424-425.Santi poṭṭhapādāti idaṃ bhagavā kasmā ārabhi? Bāhirakehi paññāpitaniṭṭhāya aniyyānikabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Sabbe hi titthiyā yathā bhagavā amataṃ nibbānaṃ, evaṃ attano attano samaye lokathupikādivasena niṭṭhaṃ paññapenti, sā ca na niyyānikā. Yathā paññattā  hutvā na niyyāti na gacchati, aññadatthu paṇḍitehi paṭikkhittā nivattati, taṃ dassetuṃ bhagavā evamāha. Tattha ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passanti puratthimāya disāya ekantasukho loko pacchimādīnaṃ vā aññatarāyāti evaṃ jānantā evaṃ passantā viharatha. Diṭṭhapubbāni kho tasmiṃ loke manussānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānādīnīti. Appāṭihīrakatanti appāṭihīrakataṃ paṭiharaṇavirahitaṃ, aniyyānikanti vuttaṃ hoti.
commentary_english:
424-425. Why did the Blessed One begin with "There are footpads"? It is to show that the final attainment taught by outsiders does not lead out [of saṃsāra].

Indeed, all the sectarians proclaim the immortal *nirvāṇa* just as the Blessed One does, and in their own systems, they teach a final goal by means of world-pillar-like things, but that does not lead out [of *saṃsāra*].

As that which has been taught, having become, does not lead out, nor does it go, but rather, being rejected by the wise, it turns back; to show that, the Blessed One said this.

There, knowing and seeing the world as utter bliss in the eastern direction, [and saying] "The world is utter bliss in the western direction, etc.," thus knowing, thus seeing, live.

For the forms of bodies, etc., of humans in that world have been seen before.

"Without counter-action" means without a counter-action, devoid of resistance; it is said to be "not leading out."

mula_pali: 426. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, poṭṭhapāda, puriso evaṃ vadeyya – ‘ahaṃ yā imasmiṃ janapade janapadakalyāṇī, taṃ icchāmi taṃ kāmemī’ti. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ icchasi kāmesi, jānāsi taṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ khattiyī vā brāhmaṇī vā vessī vā suddī vā’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘no’ti vadeyya. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ambho purisa , yaṃ tvaṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ icchasi kāmesi, jānāsi taṃ janapadakalyāṇiṃ evaṃnāmā evaṃgottāti vā, dīghā vā rassā vā majjhimā vā kāḷī vā sāmā vā maṅguracchavī vāti, amukasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā nagare vā’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘no’ti vadeyya. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi, taṃ tvaṃ icchasi kāmesī’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘āmā’ti vadeyya. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi , poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti. ‘‘Evameva kho, poṭṭhapāda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino – ‘ekantasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā’ti. Tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi – ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino  – ‘‘ekantasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā’’’ti? Te ce me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti. Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharathā’ti? Iti  puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekaṃ vā rattiṃ ekaṃ vā divasaṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā rattiṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā divasaṃ ekantasukhiṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto jānātha – ‘‘ayaṃ maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto yā tā devatā ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā, tāsaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ saddaṃ suṇātha – ‘‘suppaṭipannāttha, mārisā, ujuppaṭipannāttha, mārisā, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya; mayampi hi, mārisā, evaṃpaṭipannā ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’’’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante tesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ  sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
426.

“Poṭṭhapāda, it’s as if a man were to say, ‘I’m in love with the most beautiful woman in this country,’

Then they would say to him, ‘Good man, this most beautiful woman in this country with whom you are in love: do you know if she’s of the *kṣatriya* (warrior) caste, the *brāhmaṇa* (priestly) caste, the *vaiśya* (merchant) caste, or the *śūdra* (laborer) caste?’ And when asked this, he would say, ‘No.’

Then they would say to him, ‘Good man, this most beautiful woman in this country with whom you are in love, do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall, short, or of medium height? Whether she’s dark, fair, or ruddy-skinned? Do you know what village or town or city she’s from?’ And when asked this, he would say, ‘No.’

Then they would say to him, ‘Good man, do you then love a girl you have never known or seen?’ And when asked this, he would say, ‘Yes.’

“So what do you think, Poṭṭhapāda? When this is the case, don’t the words of that man turn out to be unconvincing?” “Certainly, venerable sir, when this is the case, the words of that man turn out to be unconvincing.”

“In the same way, Poṭṭhapāda, there are some ascetics and Brahmins with a doctrine and view like this: ‘After death, the *ātman* (self) is exclusively happy and free from disease.’

I approach them and say, ‘Is it true that you have a doctrine and view like this: “After death, the self is exclusively happy and free from disease”?’ And if they say yes when asked this, they acknowledge it.

Then I say, ‘But do you dwell having known or seen an exclusively happy world?’ And when asked this, they say no.

“Then I say, ‘But have you ever been aware of a self exclusively happy for a day or a night, or for half a day or half a night?’ And when asked this, they say no.

Then I say, ‘But do you know that “This is the path, this is the practice for the realization of an exclusively happy world”?’ And when asked this, they say no.

“Then I say, ‘But have you heard the voices of devas reborn in an exclusively happy world, saying, “Practice well, my dears. Practice straightforwardly, my dears, for the realization of an exclusively happy world, because it was through such a practice that we ourselves have been reborn in an exclusively happy world”?’ And when asked this, they say no.

“So what do you think, Poṭṭhapāda? When this is the case, don’t the words of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing?” “Certainly, venerable sir, when this is the case, the words of those ascetics and Brahmins turn out to be unconvincing.”
commentary_pali: 426-427.Janapadakalyāṇīti janapade aññāhi itthīhi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānavilāsākappādīhi asadisā.
commentary_english: *Janapadakalyāṇī* means dissimilar in terms of complexion, figure, charm, deportment, etc., from other women in the country.

mula_pali: 427. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, poṭṭhapāda, puriso cātumahāpathe nisseṇiṃ kareyya pāsādassa ārohaṇāya. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ambho purisa, yassa tvaṃ yaṃ tvaṃ (sī. ka.) pāsādassa ārohaṇāya nisseṇiṃ karosi, jānāsi taṃ pāsādaṃ puratthimāya vā disāya dakkhiṇāya vā disāya pacchimāya vā disāya uttarāya vā disāya ucco vā nīco vā majjhimo vā’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘no’ti vadeyya. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ambho purisa, yaṃ tvaṃ na jānāsi na passasi, tassa tvaṃ pāsādassa ārohaṇāya nisseṇiṃ karosī’ti? Iti puṭṭho ‘āmā’ti vadeyya. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tassa purisassa appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti. ‘‘Evameva  kho, poṭṭhapāda, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino – ‘ekantasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā’ti. Tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi – ‘saccaṃ kira tumhe āyasmanto evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino – ‘‘ekantasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā’ti ? Te ce me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti. Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharathā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekaṃ  vā rattiṃ ekaṃ vā divasaṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā rattiṃ upaḍḍhaṃ vā divasaṃ ekantasukhiṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto jānātha ayaṃ maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘no’ti vadanti. ‘‘Tyāhaṃ evaṃ vadāmi – ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto yā tā devatā ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ tāsaṃ devatānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ saddaṃ suṇātha- ‘‘suppaṭipannāttha, mārisā, ujuppaṭipannāttha , mārisā, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya; mayampi hi, mārisā, evaṃ paṭipannā ekantasukhaṃ lokaṃ upapannā’ti? Iti puṭṭhā ‘‘no’’ti vadanti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante tesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tesaṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ appāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
427.

“Poṭṭhapāda, it is just as if a man were to build a staircase for ascending to a palace at a crossroads.

And they might say to him: ‘Good man, do you know whether the palace for which you are building this staircase faces east, south, west, or north? Whether it is high, low, or in between?’ And if he, being asked this, should say, ‘No.’

And they might say to him: ‘Good man, you are building a staircase to ascend to a palace that you don't know or see?’ And if he, being asked this, should say, ‘Yes.’

“What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda, wouldn’t that man's speech, in such a case, be unconvincing?” “Certainly, venerable sir, that man's speech would be unconvincing in such a case.”

“Just so, Poṭṭhapāda, those ascetics and Brahmins who hold such views and doctrines, saying, ‘After death, the self is exclusively happy and free from disease.’

I approach them and say: ‘Is it true, venerable sirs, that you hold such views and doctrines, saying, “After death, the self is exclusively happy and free from disease”?’ And if they, being asked this, should acknowledge, ‘Yes.’

Then I say to them: ‘But do you, venerable sirs, dwell knowing and seeing an exclusively happy world?’ And if they, being asked this, should say, ‘No.’

‘Then I say to them: ‘But do you, venerable sirs, recognize a self that is exclusively happy for even a day or a night, or half a day or half a night?’ And if they, being asked this, should say, ‘No.’

Then I say to them: ‘But do you, venerable sirs, know that this is the path, this is the practice for the realization of an exclusively happy world?’ And if they, being asked this, should say, ‘No.’

Then I say to them: ‘But have you heard the voices of those deities who have been reborn in an exclusively happy world, proclaiming, “We practice well, good sirs, we practice directly for the realization of an exclusively happy world; indeed, good sirs, having practiced in this way, we have been reborn in an exclusively happy world”?’ And if they, being asked this, should say, ‘No.’

“What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda, wouldn’t the speech of those ascetics and Brahmins, in such a case, be unconvincing?” “Certainly, venerable sir, that the speech of those ascetics and Brahmins would be unconvincing in such a case.”
commentary_pali: 426-427.Janapadakalyāṇīti janapade aññāhi itthīhi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānavilāsākappādīhi asadisā.
commentary_english: *Janapadakalyāṇī* means unmatched in the country (*janapada*) compared to other women due to her complexion, figure, charm, deportment, and so on.

mula_pali: 428. ‘‘Tayo kho me, poṭṭhapāda, attapaṭilābhā – oḷāriko attapaṭilābho, manomayo attapaṭilābho, arūpo attapaṭilābho. Katamo ca, poṭṭhapāda, oḷāriko attapaṭilābho? Rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho kabaḷīkārabhakkho (syā. ka.), ayaṃ oḷāriko attapaṭilābho. Katamo manomayo attapaṭilābho? Rūpī manomayo sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo, ayaṃ manomayo attapaṭilābho. Katamo arūpo attapaṭilābho? Arūpī saññāmayo, ayaṃ arūpo attapaṭilābho.
mula_english:
“Poṭṭhapāda, I have these three acquisitions of self (*attapaṭilābhā*): the gross acquisition of self (*oḷāriko attapaṭilābho*), the mind-made acquisition of self (*manomayo attapaṭilābho*), and the formless acquisition of self (*arūpo attapaṭilābho*).

And what, Poṭṭhapāda, is the gross acquisition of self (*oḷāriko attapaṭilābho*)? Possessed of form (*rūpī*), made of the four great elements (*cātumahābhūtiko*), feeding on solid food (*kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho*), this is the gross acquisition of self (*ayaṃ oḷāriko attapaṭilābho*).

What is the mind-made acquisition of self (*manomayo attapaṭilābho*)? Possessed of form (*rūpī*), mind-made (*manomayo*), complete in all its parts (*sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī*), with faculties not deficient (*ahīnindriyo*), this is the mind-made acquisition of self (*ayaṃ manomayo attapaṭilābho*).

What is the formless acquisition of self (*arūpo attapaṭilābho*)? Formless (*arūpī*), made of perception (*saññāmayo*), this is the formless acquisition of self (*ayaṃ arūpo attapaṭilābho*).
commentary_pali: 428. Evaṃ bhagavā paresaṃ niṭṭhāya aniyyānikattaṃ dassetvā attano niṭṭhāya niyyānikabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ ‘‘tayo kho me poṭṭhapādā’’tiādimāha. Tattha attapaṭilābhoti attabhāvapaṭilābho, ettha ca bhagavā tīhi attabhāvapaṭilābhehi tayo bhave dassesi. Oḷārikattabhāvapaṭilābhena  avīcito paṭṭhāya paranimmitavasavattipariyosānaṃ kāmabhavaṃ dassesi. Manomayaattabhāvapaṭilābhena paṭhamajjhānabhūmito paṭṭhāya akaniṭṭhabrahmalokapariyosānaṃ rūpabhavaṃ dassesi. Arūpaattabhāvapaṭilābhena ākāsānañcāyatanabrahmalokato paṭṭhāya nevasaññānāsaññāyatanabrahmalokapariyosānaṃ arūpabhavaṃ dassesi. Saṃkilesikā dhammā nāma dvādasa akusalacittuppādā. Vodāniyā dhammā nāma samathavipassanā.
commentary_english:
428. Thus, the Blessed One, having shown the futility of others' aims and to show the attainability of his own aim, spoke beginning with, "These three, Poṭṭhapāda..."

There, *attapaṭilābho* means the attainment of selfhood (*attabhāva*). Here, the Blessed One, through three attainments of selfhood, demonstrated the three realms of existence (*bhava*).

Through the attainment of coarse selfhood (*oḷārikattabhāva*), he showed the desire realm (*kāmabhava*), extending from Avīci hell up to the Paranimmita-vasavatti heavens.

Through the attainment of mind-made selfhood (*manomayaattabhāva*), he showed the form realm (*rūpabhava*), extending from the first *jhāna* level up to the Akaniṭṭha Brahma-loka.

Through the attainment of formless selfhood (*arūpaattabhāva*), he showed the formless realm (*arūpabhava*), extending from the Ākāsānañcāyatana Brahma-loka up to the Nevasaññānāsaññāyatana Brahma-loka.

Defiling states (*saṃkilesikā dhammā*) are the twelve unwholesome thought-arising moments (*akusalacittuppādā*).

Purifying states (*vodāniyā dhammā*) are serenity (*samatha*) and insight (*vipassanā*).

mula_pali: 429. ‘‘Oḷārikassapi  kho ahaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, attapaṭilābhassa pahānāya  dhammaṃ desemi – yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathāti. Siyā kho pana te, poṭṭhapāda, evamassa – saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva  dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihāroti, na kho panetaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saṃkilesikā ceva dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā ca dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, pāmujjaṃ ceva bhavissati pīti ca passaddhi ca sati ca sampajaññañca sukho ca vihāro.
mula_english:
“Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, I teach the Dhamma for the abandoning of the gross appropriation of self ( *attapaṭilābha* ), such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities (*saṃkilesikā dhammā*) will be abandoned, bright mental qualities (*vodāniyā dhammā*) will grow, and you will enter and remain in the culmination and abundance of wisdom (*paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca*), having known and realized it for yourself in the here and now.

If the thought should occur to you, Poṭṭhapāda, that when defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of wisdom, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, one’s abiding is stressful, you should not see it in that way.

When defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of wisdom, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, there will be joy (*pāmujjaṃ*), rapture (*pīti*), calm (*passaddhi*), mindfulness (*sati*), alertness (*sampajaññañca*), and a pleasant abiding (*sukho ca vihāro*).
commentary_pali: 429.Paññāpāripūriṃvepullattanti maggapaññāphalapaññānaṃ pāripūriñceva vipulabhāvañca. Pāmujjanti taruṇapīti. Pītīti balavatuṭṭhi. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Yaṃ avocumha ‘‘sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihiratī’’ti, tattha tassa evaṃ viharato taṃ pāmojjañceva bhavissati, pīti ca nāmakāyapassaddhi ca sati ca sūpaṭṭhitā uttamañāṇañca sukho ca vihāro. Sabbavihāresu ca ayameva vihāro ‘‘sukho’’ti vattuṃ yutto ‘‘upasanto paramamadhuro’’ti. Tattha  paṭhamajjhāne pāmojjādayo chapi dhammā labbhanti, dutiyajjhāne dubbalapītisaṅkhātaṃ pāmojjaṃ nivattati, sesā pañca labbhanti. Tatiye pīti nivattati, sesā cattāro labbhanti. Tathā catutthe. Imesu catūsu jhānesu sampasādanasutte suddhavipassanā pādakajjhānameva kathitaṃ. Pāsādikasutte catūhi maggehi saddhiṃ vipassanā kathitā. Dasuttarasutte catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpatti kathitā. Imasmiṃ poṭṭhapādasutte pāmojjaṃ pītivevacanameva katvā dutiyajjhānikaphalasamāpattināma kathitāti veditabbā.
commentary_english:
429. The perfection and abundance of wisdom means the perfection and abundance of the wisdom of the path (maggapaññā) and the wisdom of the fruit (phalapaññā).

*Pāmujjanti* is youthful joy (*taruṇapīti*).

Joy (*pīti*) is strong satisfaction (*balavatuṭṭhi*).

What does it mean? What we said, "Having directly realized with his own higher knowledge, he dwells having attained," there, for him thus dwelling, there will be delight (*pāmojjañceva*), joy (*pīti ca*), tranquility of the mental body (*nāmakāyapassaddhi ca*), mindfulness well-established (*sati ca sūpaṭṭhitā*), supreme knowledge (*uttamañāṇañca*), and a happy dwelling (*sukho ca vihāro*).

And among all dwellings, this dwelling is fit to be called "happy" (*sukho*), "peaceful, supremely sweet" (*upasanto paramamadhuro*).

There, in the first *jhāna*, delight (*pāmojja*) and the six qualities beginning with it are obtained; in the second *jhāna*, delight (*pāmojja*) reckoned as weak joy (*dubbalapīti*) ceases, the remaining five are obtained.

In the third, joy (*pīti*) ceases, the remaining four are obtained.

Thus in the fourth.

In these four *jhānas*, in the *Sampasādana Sutta*, only pure insight (*suddhavipassanā*) is spoken of as the basis *jhāna* (*pādakajjhāna*).

In the *Pāsādika Sutta*, insight (*vipassanā*) is spoken of together with the four paths (*catūhi maggehi saddhiṃ*).

In the *Dasuttara Sutta*, the attainment of the fruit of the fourth *jhāna* (*catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpatti*) is spoken of.

In this *Poṭṭhapāda Sutta*, it should be understood that delight (*pāmojja*) is spoken of, having made joy (*pīti*) just a synonym, namely the attainment of the fruit of the second *jhāna* (*dutiyajjhānikaphalasamāpattināma*).

mula_pali: 430. ‘‘Manomayassapi kho ahaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, attapaṭilābhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ desemi yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathāti . Siyā kho pana te, poṭṭhapāda, evamassa – ‘saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihāro’ti, na kho panetaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saṃkilesikā ceva dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā ca dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti , paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, pāmujjaṃ ceva bhavissati pīti ca passaddhi ca sati ca sampajaññañca sukho ca vihāro.
mula_english:
“Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, I teach the Dharma for the abandoning of the mind-made acquisition of self (manomayassa attapaṭilābhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ desemi), such that, when you practice it, defiling qualities (saṃkilesikā dhammā) will be abandoned, purifying qualities (vodāniyā dhammā) will grow, and you will enter and remain in the culmination and abundance of wisdom (paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca), having known and realized it for yourself in the here and now (diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathāti).

If the thought should occur to you, Poṭṭhapāda, that ‘defiling qualities will be abandoned, purifying qualities will grow, and one will enter and remain in the culmination and abundance of wisdom, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, but the abiding will be painful,’ you should not see it in that way, Poṭṭhapāda.

When defiling qualities are abandoned and purifying qualities have grown, and one enters and remains in the culmination and abundance of wisdom, having known and realized it for oneself in the here and now, there will be joy, rapture, calm, mindfulness, alertness, and a pleasant abiding."

mula_pali: 431. ‘‘Arūpassapi kho ahaṃ, poṭṭhapāda, attapaṭilābhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ desemi yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti , paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathāti. Siyā kho pana te, poṭṭhapāda, evamassa – ‘saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihāro’ti, na kho panetaṃ , poṭṭhapāda, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saṃkilesikā ceva dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā ca dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, pāmujjaṃ ceva bhavissati pīti ca passaddhi ca sati ca sampajaññañca sukho ca vihāro.
mula_english:
“Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, I teach the Dharma for the abandoning of the formless appropriation of a self ( *arūpassa attapaṭilābhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ desemi*), such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities (*saṃkilesikā dhammā*) will be abandoned, bright mental qualities (*vodāniyā dhammā*) will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment (*paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca*), having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now.

If the thought should occur to you that, when defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters & remains in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for oneself in the here & now, one’s abiding is stressful, you should not see it in that way.

When defiling mental qualities are abandoned and bright mental qualities have grown, and one enters & remains in the culmination & abundance of discernment, having known & realized it for oneself in the here & now, there will be joy (*pāmujjaṃ*), rapture (*pīti*), calm (*passaddhi*), mindfulness (*sati*), alertness (*sampajañña*), and a pleasant abiding (*sukho vihāro*)."

mula_pali: 432. ‘‘Pare ce, poṭṭhapāda, amhe evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘katamo pana so, āvuso , oḷāriko attapaṭilābho, yassa tumhe pahānāya dhammaṃ desetha, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti, tesaṃ mayaṃ evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākareyyāma – ‘ayaṃ vā so, āvuso, oḷāriko attapaṭilābho, yassa mayaṃ pahānāya dhammaṃ desema, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti.
mula_english: “Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, if they should ask us thus: ‘But what, friend (*āvuso*), is that gross ( *oḷāriko*) obtaining of self ( *attapaṭilābho*) for whose abandoning (*pahānāya*) you teach the Dhamma, such that, when you practice (*yathāpaṭipannānaṃ*) it, defiling (*saṃkilesikā*) mental qualities (*dhammā*) will be abandoned (*pahīyissanti*), bright (*vodāniyā*) mental qualities (*dhammā*) will grow (*abhivaḍḍhissanti*), and you will enter and remain (*upasampajja viharissatha*) in the culmination (*pāripūriṃ*) and abundance (*vepullattañca*) of discernment (*paññā*), having known and realized (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*) it for yourself (*sayaṃ*) in the here and now (*diṭṭheva dhamme*)?’ When asked this, we would answer thus: ‘This, friend, is that gross (*oḷāriko*) obtaining of self (*attapaṭilābho*) for whose abandoning (*pahānāya*) we teach the Dhamma, such that, when you practice (*yathāpaṭipannānaṃ*) it, defiling (*saṃkilesikā*) mental qualities (*dhammā*) will be abandoned (*pahīyissanti*), bright (*vodāniyā*) mental qualities (*dhammā*) will grow (*abhivaḍḍhissanti*), and you will enter and remain (*upasampajja viharissatha*) in the culmination (*pāripūriṃ*) and abundance (*vepullattañca*) of discernment (*paññā*), having known and realized (*abhiññā sacchikatvā*) it for yourself (*sayaṃ*) in the here and now (*diṭṭheva dhamme*)?’”
commentary_pali: 432-437.Ayaṃ vā soti ettha vā saddo vibhāvanattho hoti. Ayaṃ soti evaṃ vibhāvetvā pakāsetvā byākareyyāma. Yathāpare ‘‘ekantasukhaṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’’ti puṭṭhā ‘‘no’’ti vadanti, na evaṃ vadāmāti attho. Sappāṭihīrakatanti sappāṭiharaṇaṃ, niyyānikanti attho. Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi, attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ ‘‘yasmiṃ citta samaye’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
432-437.
Here, in "this or that," the word "or" serves the purpose of distinguishing.
"This is it" means having distinguished it thus, we would explain and illuminate it.
Just as others, when asked, "Do you perceive the self as exclusively happy?" answer "No," that is not what we say—that is the meaning.
"Accomplished with a miracle" means accomplishing with a miracle; the meaning is "leading out."
"It is vain" means it is empty; the intention is that it does not exist at that time.
"It is true" means it is real; the meaning is that it is true at that very time.
Here, Citta, due to his own lack of omniscience, having spoken of three attainments of self, was not able to extract that the attainment of self is merely a designation; however, he only inferred the attainment of self.
Then, the Blessed One [Bhagavān], wishing to show that form and the like are the things here, that "attainment of self" is merely a name, that such usages occur when those forms and the like exist, having taken up that very account, spoke the verse beginning with "At whatever time the mind..." for the purpose of inferring by way of nominal designation.

mula_pali: 433. ‘‘Pare ce, poṭṭhapāda, amhe evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘katamo pana so, āvuso, manomayo attapaṭilābho, yassa tumhe pahānāya dhammaṃ desetha, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā  pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti? Tesaṃ mayaṃ evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākareyyāma – ‘ayaṃ vā so, āvuso, manomayo attapaṭilābho yassa mayaṃ pahānāya dhammaṃ desema, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti , paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti.
mula_english: “Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, if they should ask us thus: ‘But what, friend, is the mind-made appropriation of a self (*manomayo attapaṭilābho*) for whose abandoning you teach the Dhamma, such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities (*saṃkilesikā dhammā*) will be abandoned, bright mental qualities (*vodāniyā dhammā*) will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment (*paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca*), having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now?’ When asked this, we would answer thus: ‘This, friend, is that mind-made appropriation of a self (*manomayo attapaṭilābho*) for whose abandoning we teach the Dhamma, such that, when you practice it, defiling mental qualities (*saṃkilesikā dhammā*) will be abandoned, bright mental qualities (*vodāniyā dhammā*) will grow, and you will enter & remain in the culmination & abundance of discernment (*paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca*), having known & realized it for yourself in the here & now.’"
commentary_pali: 432-437.Ayaṃ vā soti ettha vā saddo vibhāvanattho hoti. Ayaṃ soti evaṃ vibhāvetvā pakāsetvā byākareyyāma. Yathāpare ‘‘ekantasukhaṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’’ti puṭṭhā ‘‘no’’ti vadanti, na evaṃ vadāmāti attho. Sappāṭihīrakatanti sappāṭiharaṇaṃ, niyyānikanti attho. Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi, attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ ‘‘yasmiṃ citta samaye’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
432-437.
"This or that"—here, the word "or" has the function of distinguishing.
"This or that"—in this way, having distinguished and revealed, we would explain.
Just as others, when asked, "Do you perceive the self as exclusively happy?" answer "No," that is not what we say, is the meaning.
"Accomplished by a miracle" means accomplishment by a miracle; "leading out" is the meaning.
"It is vain" means it is empty; the intention is that it does not exist at that time.
"It is true" means it is real; at that very time, it is true, is the meaning.
Here, this Citta, due to his non-omniscience, having spoken of three self-attainments, was not able to extract that self-attainment is merely a designation; he only brought forth self-attainment.
Then, the Blessed One, wanting to show that here, these *dharmas* such as form, self-attainment, are merely a name, and such usages occur when those forms and so on are present, taking that very statement, spoke the beginning, "At whatever time the mind..." for the purpose of conveying [the meaning] by way of nominal designation.

mula_pali: 434. ‘‘Pare ce, poṭṭhapāda, amhe evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘katamo pana so, āvuso, arūpo attapaṭilābho, yassa tumhe pahānāya dhammaṃ desetha , yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti, tesaṃ mayaṃ evaṃ puṭṭhā  evaṃ byākareyyāma – ‘ayaṃ vā so, āvuso, arūpo attapaṭilābho yassa mayaṃ pahānāya dhammaṃ desema, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante sappāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante sappāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
"Furthermore, Poṭṭhapāda, if they were to ask us thus: ‘But what, friend, is the formless appropriation of self, for the abandoning of which you teach the Dhamma, such that when you practice accordingly, your defiling qualities will be abandoned, your purifying qualities will grow, and having directly known and realized for yourselves here and now the full perfection and abundance of wisdom, you will dwell having attained it?’ Being asked thus, we would answer thus: ‘This, friend, is that formless appropriation of self for the abandoning of which we teach the Dhamma, such that when you practice accordingly, your defiling qualities will be abandoned, your purifying qualities will grow, and having directly known and realized for yourselves here and now the full perfection and abundance of wisdom, you will dwell having attained it.’

“What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda? When this is the case, does speech endowed with convincingness not result?” “Indeed, venerable sir, when this is the case, speech endowed with convincingness does result.”
commentary_pali: 432-437.Ayaṃ vā soti ettha vā saddo vibhāvanattho hoti. Ayaṃ soti evaṃ vibhāvetvā pakāsetvā byākareyyāma. Yathāpare ‘‘ekantasukhaṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’’ti puṭṭhā ‘‘no’’ti vadanti, na evaṃ vadāmāti attho. Sappāṭihīrakatanti sappāṭiharaṇaṃ, niyyānikanti attho. Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi, attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ ‘‘yasmiṃ citta samaye’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
432-437.
"'This or that'—here, the word 'or' has the meaning of distinguishing."
"’This’ is how we may distinguish, reveal, and explain it."
"As others, when asked, “Do you perceive the self as exclusively pleasurable?” answer “No,” this is not what we say—that is the meaning."
"Sappāṭihīrakatanti means sappāṭiharaṇaṃ, the meaning is leading out."
"’Mogho hoti’ means it is empty; the meaning is that it does not exist at that time."
"'Sacco hoti' means it is real; the meaning is, it is real at that very time."
"Here, however, this Citta, due to his lack of omniscience, having spoken of three attainments of self, was not able to extract that attainment of self is merely a designation, but he only inferred the attainment of self."
"Then, the Blessed One, desiring to show that here, the phenomena beginning with form, the term 'attainment of self' is, however, merely a name, and such usages occur when those forms, etc., exist, took up that very account and spoke the verse beginning with “yasmiṃ citta samaye” in order to infer it as nominal designation."

mula_pali: 435. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, poṭṭhapāda, puriso nisseṇiṃ kareyya pāsādassa ārohaṇāya tasseva pāsādassa heṭṭhā. Tamenaṃ evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – ‘ambho purisa, yassa tvaṃ pāsādassa ārohaṇāya nisseṇiṃ karosi, jānāsi taṃ pāsādaṃ, puratthimāya vā disāya dakkhiṇāya vā disāya pacchimāya vā disāya uttarāya vā disāya ucco vā nīco vā majjhimo vā’ti? So evaṃ vadeyya – ‘ayaṃ vā so, āvuso, pāsādo, yassāhaṃ ārohaṇāya nisseṇiṃ karomi, tasseva pāsādassa heṭṭhā’ti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante tassa purisassa sappāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante tassa purisassa sappāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
435.
“Poṭṭhapāda, it is just as if a man were to build a staircase (nisseṇiṃ) for ascending to a palace (pāsādassa) right under that very palace.

And people were to say to him, ‘Well, my good man (ambho purisa), this palace (pāsādassa) for which you are building a staircase (nisseṇiṃ): do you know that palace (pāsādaṃ), whether it's east (puratthimāya disāya), west (pacchimāya disāya), north (uttarāya disāya), or south (dakkhiṇāya disāya) of here? Whether it's high (ucco), low (nīco), or in between (majjhimo)?’ And he would say, ‘This, friends (āvuso), is the palace (pāsādo) to which I am building a staircase (nisseṇiṃ); the staircase (nisseṇiṃ) is right under that very palace (pāsādassa).’

“So what do you think, Poṭṭhapāda, when this is the case, don’t the words (bhāsitaṃ) of that man turn out to be convincing (sappāṭihīrakataṃ sampajjatī)?” “Indeed, venerable sir (bhante), when this is the case, the words (bhāsitaṃ) of that man turn out to be convincing (sappāṭihīrakataṃ sampajjatī).”

Yathāpare ‘‘ekantasukhaṃ attānaṃ sañjānāthā’’ti puṭṭhā ‘‘no’’ti vadanti, na evaṃ vadāmāti attho. Sappāṭihīrakatanti sappāṭiharaṇaṃ, niyyānikanti attho. Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi, attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ ‘‘yasmiṃ citta samaye’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
432-437.
"'This or that'—here, the word 'or' has the meaning of distinction."
"'This is that'—in this way, having distinguished, having revealed, we would explain."
"Just as others, when asked, “Do you perceive the self as exclusively happy?” answer “No,” the meaning is, we do not speak thus."
"'Accomplished with a counter-miracle' means accomplishing a counter-miracle, [it is] definitive," is the meaning.
"'It is vain' means it is empty; there is nothing in that time," is the intention.
"'It is true' means it is real; only in that time is it true," is the meaning.
"Here, indeed, this Citta, due to his own non-omniscience, having spoken of three acquisitions of self, was not able to extract that 'acquisition of self' is merely a designation, this is it; he only definitively stated 'acquisition of self'."
"Then, for him, the Blessed One, these things here, such as form, are the *dharmas*; but 'acquisition of self' is merely a name; when those things such as form are present, such usages occur," wishing to show this, having taken up that same account, for the purpose of definitive statement in terms of nominal designation, he said, "In whatever time the mind..." and so on.

mula_pali: 436. ‘‘Evameva  kho, poṭṭhapāda, pare ce amhe evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘katamo pana so, āvuso, oḷāriko attapaṭilābho…pe… katamo pana so, āvuso, manomayo attapaṭilābho…pe… katamo pana so, āvuso, arūpo attapaṭilābho, yassa tumhe pahānāya dhammaṃ desetha, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti, tesaṃ mayaṃ evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākareyyāma – ‘ayaṃ vā so, āvuso, arūpo attapaṭilābho, yassa mayaṃ pahānāya dhammaṃ desema, yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ  vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti. ‘‘Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, poṭṭhapāda, nanu evaṃ sante sappāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti? ‘‘Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante sappāṭihīrakataṃ bhāsitaṃ sampajjatī’’ti.
mula_english:
“In the same way, Poṭṭhapāda, if others were to ask us: ‘What, friend, is the gross appropriation of self… the mind-made appropriation of self… the formless appropriation of self, for the abandonment of which you teach the Dhamma, such that when they practice, defiling qualities will be abandoned, bright qualities will grow, and they will live having realized for themselves the culmination and abundance of wisdom, having directly experienced it with their own insight in this very life?’ If we were asked this, we would answer: ‘This, friend, is that formless appropriation of self for the abandonment of which we teach the Dhamma, such that when they practice, defiling qualities will be abandoned, bright qualities will grow, and they will live having realized for themselves the culmination and abundance of wisdom, having directly experienced it with their own insight in this very life.’

“What do you think, Poṭṭhapāda? When this is the case, doesn’t what is spoken become convincing?”

“Certainly, venerable sir, when this is the case, what is spoken becomes convincing.”

Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi, attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ ‘‘yasmiṃ citta samaye’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
432-437.
"This or that": here, the word "or" (*vā*) has the meaning of distinction (*vibhāvana*).
"This": thus, having distinguished and revealed, we would explain.
Just as others, when asked, "Do you perceive the self as exclusively happy?" answer "No," that is not what we say.
"Accomplished by a miracle" means "accomplishment by a miracle," the meaning is "leading out."
"It is vain" means "it is empty," the idea (*adhiprāyo*) is, "it does not exist at that time."
"It is true" means "it is real," the meaning is, "it is true at that very time."
Here, however, Citta, due to his lack of omniscience (*asabbaññutāya*), having spoken of three acquisitions of self (*attapaṭilābhe*), was not able to extract that "the acquisition of self (*attapaṭilābho*) is merely a designation (*paññattimattaṃ*)," but he definitely inferred an acquisition of self (*attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi*).
Then, the Blessed One (*bhagavā*), wanting to show that "form (*rūpa*), etc., are the principles here, but 'acquisition of self (*attapaṭilābhoti*)' is merely a name (*nāmamattaṃ*), such expressions occur when those forms (*rūpādīsu*), etc., are present," having taken up that very discussion, for the purpose of inferring in terms of nominal designation (*nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ*), said "At whatever time the mind..." and so forth.

mula_pali: 437. Evaṃ vutte citto hatthisāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘yasmiṃ, bhante, samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, moghassa tasmiṃ samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti, mogho arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti; oḷāriko vāssa attapaṭilābho tasmiṃ samaye sacco hoti. Yasmiṃ, bhante, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti, moghassa tasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, mogho arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti; manomayo vāssa attapaṭilābho tasmiṃ samaye sacco hoti. Yasmiṃ, bhante, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, moghassa tasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, mogho manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti; arūpo vāssa attapaṭilābho tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotī’’ti. ‘‘Yasmiṃ, citta, samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ  gacchati, na arūpo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati ; oḷāriko attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Yasmiṃ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na arūpo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati; manomayo attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Yasmiṃ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati; arūpo attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
mula_english:
437. When this was said, Citta the elephant trainer’s son said to the Blessed One: “Venerable sir (bhante), when there is a gross (oḷārika) appropriation of self (attapaṭilābha), is it the case that at that time the mind-made (manomaya) appropriation of self is null (mogha), the formless (arūpa) appropriation of self is null; and only the gross appropriation of self is true (sacca) at that time?

And venerable sir (bhante), when there is a mind-made (manomaya) appropriation of self, is it the case that at that time the gross (oḷārika) appropriation of self is null (mogha), the formless (arūpa) appropriation of self is null; and only the mind-made appropriation of self is true (sacca) at that time?

And venerable sir (bhante), when there is a formless (arūpa) appropriation of self, is it the case that at that time the gross (oḷārika) appropriation of self is null (mogha), the mind-made (manomaya) appropriation of self is null; and only the formless appropriation of self is true (sacca) at that time?”

“Citta, when there is a gross (oḷārika) appropriation of self (attapaṭilābha), at that time it is not classified (saṅkhaṃ gacchati) as a mind-made (manomaya) appropriation of self, nor is it classified as a formless (arūpa) appropriation of self; it is classified (saṅkhaṃ gacchati) only as a gross appropriation of self at that time.

Citta, when there is a mind-made (manomaya) appropriation of self, at that time it is not classified (saṅkhaṃ gacchati) as a gross (oḷārika) appropriation of self, nor is it classified as a formless (arūpa) appropriation of self; it is classified (saṅkhaṃ gacchati) only as a mind-made appropriation of self at that time.

Citta, when there is a formless (arūpa) appropriation of self, at that time it is not classified (saṅkhaṃ gacchati) as a gross (oḷārika) appropriation of self, nor is it classified as a mind-made (manomaya) appropriation of self; it is classified (saṅkhaṃ gacchati) only as a formless appropriation of self at that time."
