Mogho hotīti tuccho hoti, natthi so tasmiṃ samayeti adhippāyo. Sacco hotīti bhūto hoti, sveva tasmiṃ samaye sacco hotīti attho. Ettha panāyaṃ citto attano asabbaññutāya tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā attapaṭilābho nāma paññattimattaṃ etanti uddharituṃ nāsakkhi, attapaṭilābho tveva niyyātesi. Athassa bhagavā rūpādayo cettha dhammā, attapaṭilābhoti pana nāmamattametaṃ, tesu tesu rūpādīsu sati evarūpā vohārā hontīti dassetukāmo tasseva kathaṃ gahetvā nāmapaññattivasena niyyātanatthaṃ ‘‘yasmiṃ citta samaye’’tiādimāha.
commentary_english:
432-437.
"This or that": here, the word "or" is for distinction.
"This or that": in this way, having distinguished and clarified, we would explain.
Just as others, being asked, "Do you perceive the self as exclusively happy?" answer "No," the meaning is, "We do not say thus."
"Sappāṭihīrakata" means "sappāṭiharaṇa," the meaning is "niyyānika."
"Mogha hoti" means "tuccho hoti," the intention is, "It does not exist at that time."
"Sacco hoti" means "bhūto hoti," the meaning is, "It is true at that very time."
Here, this Citta, due to his lack of omniscience, having spoken of three attainments of self, was not able to extract that attainment of self is merely a designation; he only inferred attainment of self.
Then, the Blessed One, wanting to show that here these are the *dharmas* beginning with form (*rūpa*), and that "attainment of self" is merely a name, and that such usages occur when those forms, etc., are present, taking up that very account, he said "In whatever mental time," etc., in order to infer according to the way of name-designation.

mula_pali: 438. ‘‘Sace  taṃ, citta, evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘ahosi tvaṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, na tvaṃ nāhosi; bhavissasi tvaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, na tvaṃ na bhavissasi; atthi tvaṃ  etarahi, na tvaṃ natthī’ti, evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, citta, kinti byākareyyāsī’’ti? ‘‘Sace maṃ, bhante, evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘ahosi tvaṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, na tvaṃ na ahosi; bhavissasi tvaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, na tvaṃ na bhavissasi; atthi tvaṃ etarahi, na tvaṃ natthī’ti. Evaṃ puṭṭho ahaṃ, bhante, evaṃ byākareyyaṃ – ‘ahosāhaṃ atītamaddhānaṃ, nāhaṃ na ahosiṃ; bhavissāmahaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, nāhaṃ na bhavissāmi; atthāhaṃ etarahi, nāhaṃ natthī’ti. Evaṃ puṭṭho ahaṃ, bhante, evaṃ byākareyya’’nti. ‘‘Sace pana taṃ, citta, evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘yo te ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho, sova sveva (sī. pī.), soyeva (syā.) te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno? Yo yo vā (pī.) te bhavissati anāgato attapaṭilābho, sova  te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho paccuppanno? Yo yo vā (pī.) te etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova so ca (ka.) te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti. Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, citta, kinti byākareyyāsī’’ti? ‘‘Sace pana maṃ, bhante, evaṃ puccheyyuṃ – ‘yo te ahosi  atīto attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno. Yo te bhavissati anāgato attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho paccuppanno. Yo te etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova te attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti. Evaṃ puṭṭho ahaṃ, bhante, evaṃ byākareyyaṃ – ‘yo me ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho tasmiṃ samaye sacco ahosi, mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno. Yo me bhavissati anāgato attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho tasmiṃ samaye sacco bhavissati, mogho atīto, mogho paccuppanno. Yo me etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti. Evaṃ puṭṭho ahaṃ, bhante, evaṃ byākareyya’’nti.
mula_english:
438.
“Suppose they were to ask you: ‘Citta, did you exist in the past (*atītamaddhānaṃ*)? Did you not not exist? Will you exist in the future (*anāgatamaddhānaṃ*)? Will you not not exist? Do you exist now (*etarahi*)? Do you not not exist?’ Citta, if asked thus, what would you answer?”

“Suppose they were to ask me: ‘Venerable sir (*bhante*), did you exist in the past (*atītamaddhānaṃ*)? Did you not not exist? Will you exist in the future (*anāgatamaddhānaṃ*)? Will you not not exist? Do you exist now (*etarahi*)? Do you not not exist?’

If I were asked thus, venerable sir (*bhante*), I would answer: ‘I existed in the past (*atītamaddhānaṃ*). I did not not exist. I will exist in the future (*anāgatamaddhānaṃ*). I will not not exist. I exist now (*etarahi*). I do not not exist.’

If I were asked thus, venerable sir (*bhante*), that is how I would answer.”

“Suppose, Citta, they were to ask you: ‘Whatever past appropriation of self (*atīto attapaṭilābho*) you had, is that alone your true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the future (*anāgato*) and present (*paccuppanno*) are null and void? Or whatever future appropriation of self (*anāgato attapaṭilābho*) you will have, is that alone your true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the past (*atīto*) and present (*paccuppanno*) are null and void? Or whatever present appropriation of self (*paccuppanno attapaṭilābho*) you now have (*etarahi*), is that alone your true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the past (*atīto*) and future (*anāgato*) are null and void?’

Citta, if asked thus, what would you answer?”

“Suppose they were to ask me: ‘Venerable sir (*bhante*), whatever past appropriation of self (*atīto attapaṭilābho*) you had, is that alone your true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the future (*anāgato*) and present (*paccuppanno*) are null and void?

Whatever future appropriation of self (*anāgato attapaṭilābho*) you will have, is that alone your true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the past (*atīto*) and present (*paccuppanno*) are null and void?

Whatever present appropriation of self (*paccuppanno attapaṭilābho*) you now have (*etarahi*), is that alone your true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the past (*atīto*) and future (*anāgato*) are null and void?’

If I were asked thus, venerable sir (*bhante*), I would answer: ‘Whatever past appropriation of self (*atīto attapaṭilābho*) I had, that alone, at that time (*tasmiṃ samaye*), was my true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the future (*anāgato*) and present (*paccuppanno*) were null and void.

Whatever future appropriation of self (*anāgato attapaṭilābho*) I will have, that alone, at that time (*tasmiṃ samaye*), will be my true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the past (*atīto*) and present (*paccuppanno*) will be null and void.

Whatever present appropriation of self (*paccuppanno attapaṭilābho*) I now have (*etarahi*), that alone is my true appropriation of self (*attapaṭilābho sacco*), while the past (*atīto*) and future (*anāgato*) are null and void.’

If I were asked thus, venerable sir (*bhante*), that is how I would answer.”
commentary_pali: 438. Evañca pana vatvā paṭipucchitvā vinayanatthaṃ puna ‘‘sace taṃ, citta, evaṃ puccheyyu’’ntiādimāha . Tattha yo me ahosi atīto attapaṭilābho , sveva me attapaṭilābho, tasmiṃ samaye sacco ahosi, mogho anāgato mogho paccuppannoti  ettha tāva imamatthaṃ dasseti – yasmā ye te atītā dhammā, te etarahi natthi, ahesunti pana saṅkhyaṃ gatā, tasmā sopi me attapaṭilābho tasmiṃyeva samaye sacco ahosi. Anāgatapaccuppannānaṃ pana dhammānaṃ tadā abhāvā tasmiṃ samaye ‘‘mogho anāgato, mogho paccuppanno’’ti, evaṃ atthato nāmamattameva attapaṭilābhaṃ paṭijānāti. Anāgatapaccuppannesupi eseva nayo.
commentary_english:
438.
And further, having spoken thus, having questioned and cross-examined for the sake of discipline, he then says, "If they should ask you thus, O mind," and so forth.

Therein, "That which was my past attainment of self ( *attapaṭilābho*), that was indeed my attainment of self; at that time it was real, the future is vain, the present is vain." Here, first of all, he shows this meaning: Because those past phenomena, they are not here now, but have gone into the count of "they were," therefore that attainment of self of mine was real at that very time.

But due to the absence then of future and present phenomena, at that time, “the future is vain, the present is vain,” thus, in terms of meaning, he acknowledges the attainment of self as merely a name ( *nāmamatta*).

And the same method ( *nayo*) applies in the case of the future and the present as well.

mula_pali: 439. ‘‘Evameva  kho, citta, yasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na arūpo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Oḷāriko attapaṭilābho tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Yasmiṃ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho  hoti…pe… yasmiṃ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva  tasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati; arūpo attapaṭilābho tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
mula_english:
439.
“In the same way, Citta, when there is a gross appropriation of a self, at that time it is not classified as a mind-made appropriation of a self, nor is it classified as a formless appropriation of a self. It is classified just as a gross appropriation of a self ( *oḷāriko attapaṭilābho tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati*).

When, Citta, there is a mind-made appropriation of a self...and when, Citta, there is a formless appropriation of a self, at that time it is not classified as a gross appropriation of a self, nor is it classified as a mind-made appropriation of a self. It is classified just as a formless appropriation of a self.
commentary_pali: 439-443. Atha bhagavā tassa byākaraṇena saddhiṃ attano byākaraṇaṃ saṃsandituṃ ‘‘evameva kho cittā’’tiādīni vatvā puna opammato tamatthaṃ sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi citta gavā khīra’’ntiādimāha. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho, yathā gavā khīraṃ, khīrādīhi ca dadhiādīni bhavanti, tattha yasmiṃ samaye khīraṃ hoti, na tasmiṃ samaye dadhīti vā navanītādīsu vā aññataranti saṅkhyaṃ niruttiṃ nāmaṃ vohāraṃ gacchati. Kasmā? Ye dhamme upādāya dadhītiādi vohārā honti, tesaṃ abhāvā. Atha kho khīraṃ tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhyaṃ gacchati. Kasmā? Ye dhamme upādāya khīranti saṅkhyā nirutti nāmaṃ vohāro hoti, tesaṃ bhāvāti. Esa nayo sabbattha. Imā kho cittāti oḷāriko attapaṭilābho iti ca manomayo attapaṭilābho iti ca arūpo attapaṭilābho iti ca imā kho citta lokasamaññā loke samaññāmattakāni samanujānanamattakāni etāni. Tathā lokaniruttimattakāni vacanapathamattakāni vohāramattakāni nāmapaṇṇattimattakāni etānīti. Evaṃ bhagavā heṭṭhā tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā idāni sabbametaṃ vohāramattakanti vadati. Kasmā? Yasmā paramatthato satto nāma natthi, suñño tuccho esa loko. Buddhānaṃ pana dve kathā sammutikathā ca paramatthakathā ca. Tattha ‘‘satto poso devo brahmā’’tiādikā ‘‘sammutikathā’’ nāma. ‘‘Aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā khandhā dhātuyo āyatanāni satipaṭṭhānā sammappadhānā’’tiādikā paramatthakathā nāma. Tattha yo sammutidesanāya ‘‘satto’’ti  vā ‘‘poso’’ti vā ‘‘devo’’ti vā ‘‘brahmā’’ti vā vutte vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ  arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa bhagavā āditova ‘‘satto’’ti vā ‘‘poso’’ti vā ‘‘devo’’ti vā ‘‘brahmā’’ti vā katheti, yo paramatthadesanāya ‘‘anicca’’nti vā ‘‘dukkha’’nti vātiādīsu aññataraṃ sutvā vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa ‘‘anicca’’nti vā ‘‘dukkha’’nti vātiādīsu aññatarameva katheti. Tathā sammutikathāya  bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Sammutikathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā sammutikathaṃ katheti. Pakatiyā pana paṭhamameva paramatthakathaṃ kathentassa desanā lūkhākārā hoti, tasmā buddhā paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ kathetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ kathenti. Sammutikathaṃ kathentāpi saccameva sabhāvameva amusāva kathenti. Paramatthakathaṃ kathentāpi saccameva sabhāvameva amusāva kathenti. Yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasanti yāhi lokasamaññāhi lokaniruttīhi tathāgato taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparāmāsānaṃ abhāvā aparāmasanto voharatīti desanaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā arahattanikūṭena niṭṭhāpesi. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
439-443.
Then, the Blessed One, in order to compare his explanation with that explanation, having said, "It is just so, Citta," and so forth, again, illustrating that meaning by simile, said, "Just as, Citta, from a cow comes milk," and so forth.

Here, this is the condensed meaning: Just as from a cow comes milk (*khīra*), and from milk etc. come curds (*dadhi*) etc., at the time when it is milk, it does not go under the reckoning, expression, name, or designation as curds, or butter, or any other.

Why? Because the designations "curds" and so on, arise dependent on certain conditions, and those conditions are absent [when it is milk].

But at that time, it goes under the reckoning of just milk.

Why? Because the reckoning, expression, name, and designation “milk” arises dependent on certain conditions, and those conditions are present.

This method applies everywhere.

“These, Citta, are the gains of coarse self," and "these are the gains of mind-made self," and "these are the gains of formless self" -- these, Citta, are merely worldly designations, merely worldly expressions, merely worldly communications.

Likewise, they are merely worldly expressions, merely paths of speech, merely designations, merely name-based concepts.

Thus, the Blessed One, having spoken of the three gains of self lower down, now says that all of this is merely designation.

Why? Because ultimately there is no being (*satta*) by name; this world is empty and void.

Now, for the Buddhas, there are two kinds of discourse: conventional discourse (*sammutikathā*) and ultimate discourse (*paramatthakathā*).

There, "a being (*satta*), a person (*posa*), a god (*deva*), Brahmā," and so forth, is called conventional discourse (*sammutikathā*).

"Impermanence (*anicca*), suffering (*dukkha*), non-self (*anattā*), the aggregates (*khandha*), the elements (*dhātu*), the sense-bases (*āyatana*), the foundations of mindfulness (*satipaṭṭhāna*), the right efforts (*sammappadhāna*)," and so forth, is called ultimate discourse (*paramatthakathā*).

There, the Blessed One from the outset speaks of "a being (*satta*)," "a person (*posa*)," "a god (*deva*)," or "Brahmā" to whomever is capable of understanding, penetrating, and emerging from conventional discourse – who, when "a being (*satta*)," "a person (*posa*)," "a god (*deva*)," or "Brahmā" is mentioned, can grasp the supreme victory of arhatship. And to whomever is capable of understanding, penetrating, and emerging from ultimate discourse – who, having heard one of "impermanent (*anicca*)," "suffering (*dukkha*)," and so forth, can grasp the supreme victory of arhatship – to that person, he speaks only of one of "impermanent (*anicca*)," "suffering (*dukkha*)," and so forth.

Likewise, for a being capable of understanding conventional discourse, he does not first speak of ultimate discourse.

But having awakened them with conventional discourse, he speaks of ultimate discourse later.

For a being capable of understanding ultimate discourse, he does not first speak of conventional discourse.

But having awakened them with ultimate discourse, he speaks of conventional discourse later.

If someone, by nature, speaks only of ultimate discourse from the outset, the teaching is rough in form. Therefore, the Buddhas first speak of conventional discourse and then speak of ultimate discourse later.

Even when speaking conventional discourse, they speak only the truth, only reality, and not falsely.

Even when speaking ultimate discourse, they speak only the truth, only reality, and not falsely.

The Tathāgata uses what he uses without clinging. The Tathāgata, because of the absence of craving (*taṇhā*), conceit (*māna*), views (*diṭṭhi*), and attachment (*parāmāsa*), uses what he uses by means of worldly designations (*lokasamaññā*) and worldly expressions (*lokaniruttī*) without clinging (*aparāmasanti*). Having concluded the teaching by withdrawing from this, he ended it with the pinnacle of arhatship.

The rest is clear throughout.

mula_pali: 440. ‘‘Seyyathāpi, citta, gavā khīraṃ, khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṃ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍo. Yasmiṃ samaye khīraṃ hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye dadhīti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na navanītanti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na sappīti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na sappimaṇḍoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati; khīraṃ tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Yasmiṃ samaye dadhi hoti…pe… navanītaṃ hoti… sappi hoti… sappimaṇḍo hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye khīranti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na dadhīti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na navanītanti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na sappīti saṅkhaṃ gacchati; sappimaṇḍo tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Evameva  kho, citta, yasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti…pe… yasmiṃ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti…pe… yasmiṃ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṃ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṃ gacchati; arūpo attapaṭilābho tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Imā kho citta, lokasamaññā lokaniruttiyo lokavohārā lokapaññattiyo , yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasa’’nti.
mula_english:
“Just as, Citta, from a cow comes milk (khīraṃ), from milk curds (dadhi), from curds butter (navanītaṃ), from butter ghee (sappi), and from ghee the skimmings of ghee (sappimaṇḍa).

When there is milk (khīraṃ), at that time it is not reckoned as curds (dadhi), nor reckoned as butter (navanītaṃ), nor reckoned as ghee (sappi), nor reckoned as skimmings of ghee (sappimaṇḍa); at that time, it is reckoned only as milk (khīraṃ).

When there are curds (dadhi)…pe… when there is butter (navanītaṃ)… when there is ghee (sappi)… when there are the skimmings of ghee (sappimaṇḍa), at that time it is not reckoned as milk (khīraṃ), nor reckoned as curds (dadhi), nor reckoned as butter (navanītaṃ), nor reckoned as ghee (sappi); at that time, it is reckoned only as skimmings of ghee (sappimaṇḍa).

In the same way, Citta, when there is a gross appropriation of a self (oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti)…pe… when, Citta, there is a mind-made appropriation of a self (manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti)…pe… when, Citta, there is a formless appropriation of a self (arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti), at that time it is not reckoned as a gross appropriation of a self (oḷāriko attapaṭilābho), nor reckoned as a mind-made appropriation of a self (manomayo attapaṭilābho); at that time, it is reckoned only as a formless appropriation of a self (arūpo attapaṭilābho).

These, Citta, are the world’s designations (lokasamaññā), the world’s expressions (lokaniruttiyo), the world’s ways of speaking (lokavohārā), the world’s descriptions (lokapaññattiyo), with which the Tathāgata expresses himself but without adhering to them.”

Tattha yo sammutidesanāya ‘‘satto’’ti  vā ‘‘poso’’ti vā ‘‘devo’’ti vā ‘‘brahmā’’ti vā vutte vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ  arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa bhagavā āditova ‘‘satto’’ti vā ‘‘poso’’ti vā ‘‘devo’’ti vā ‘‘brahmā’’ti vā katheti, yo paramatthadesanāya ‘‘anicca’’nti vā ‘‘dukkha’’nti vātiādīsu aññataraṃ sutvā vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa ‘‘anicca’’nti vā ‘‘dukkha’’nti vātiādīsu aññatarameva katheti. Tathā sammutikathāya  bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Sammutikathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā sammutikathaṃ katheti. Pakatiyā pana paṭhamameva paramatthakathaṃ kathentassa desanā lūkhākārā hoti, tasmā buddhā paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ kathetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ kathenti. Yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasanti yāhi lokasamaññāhi lokaniruttīhi tathāgato taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparāmāsānaṃ abhāvā aparāmasanto voharatīti desanaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā arahattanikūṭena niṭṭhāpesi. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
439-443.

Then, the Blessed One, to compare his own explanation with that person's explanation, said, "It is just so, Citta," and so forth. Then, while establishing that meaning through analogy, he spoke the passage beginning, "Just as, Citta, from a cow comes milk," and so forth.

Here is a concise explanation: Just as from a cow comes milk, and from milk and so on come curds and so on. There, at whatever time it is milk, at that time, the reckoning, the expression, the name, the designation, applies to it as "curds" or "fresh butter" or any other.

Why is that? Because the qualities that, having relied upon, the designations "curds" and so on exist, are absent.

But then, at that time, it is indeed milk that the reckoning applies to.

Why is that? Because the qualities that, having relied upon, the reckoning, the expression, the name, the designation, are "milk," are present.

This method applies to all cases.

"These, Citta, are the gross attainment of self," and so forth. "These, Citta, are the mind-made attainment of self," and so forth. "These, Citta, are the formless attainment of self," and so forth. These, Citta, are worldly designations, merely designations in the world, merely instances of common understanding.

Likewise, merely worldly expressions, merely paths of speech, merely designations, merely name-concepts.

In this way, the Blessed One, having spoken of the three attainments of self below, now says that all of this is merely designation.

Why is that? Because, in ultimate reality, there is no being called "self"; this world is empty and void.

For Buddhas, there are two kinds of discourse: conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*) and ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*).

There, the passage beginning "a being (*satto*), a person (*poso*), a god (*devo*), Brahmā," is called "conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*)."

The passage beginning "impermanent (*aniccaṃ*), suffering (*dukkham*), without self (*anattā*), aggregates (*khandhā*), elements (*dhātuyo*), sense bases (*āyatanāni*), foundations of mindfulness (*satipaṭṭhānā*), right efforts (*sammappadhānā*)" is called "ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*)."

There, the Blessed One speaks from the beginning of "a being (*satto*)", "a person (*poso*)", "a god (*devo*)", or "Brahmā" to someone who, when spoken to according to conventional discourse (*sammuti-desanā*) with "a being (*satto*)," "a person (*poso*)", "a god (*devo*)", or "Brahmā," is able to understand, penetrate, go forth, and grasp the victory of *arhat*-ship. To someone who, having heard according to ultimate discourse (*paramattha-desanāya*) "impermanent (*anicca*)," "suffering (*dukkha*)," or any other, is able to understand, penetrate, go forth, and grasp the victory of *arhat*-ship, to that person, he speaks only of "impermanent (*anicca*)," "suffering (*dukkha*)," or any other.

Likewise, for a being capable of understanding by conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*), he does not speak first of ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*).

Having taught by conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathāya*), he speaks afterward of ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*).

For a being capable of understanding by ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*), he does not speak first of conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*).

Having taught by ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*), he speaks afterward of conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*).

For someone who, by nature, speaks first of ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*), the teaching is harsh in character. Therefore, the Buddhas, having spoken first of conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*), speak afterward of ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*).

Even when speaking of conventional discourse (*sammuti-kathā*), they speak truly, naturally, and without falsehood.

Even when speaking of ultimate discourse (*paramattha-kathā*), they speak truly, naturally, and without falsehood.

The Tathāgata uses whatever he uses, without attachment. Because the Tathāgata is without craving (*taṇhā*), conceit (*māna*), views (*diṭṭhi*), and attachments (*parāmāsānaṃ*), he uses the worldly conventions (*lokasamaññāhi*) and worldly expressions (*lokaniruttīhi*) without attachment (*aparāmasanto*). Having turned the teaching around in this way, he concluded it with the acme of *arhat*-ship.

The rest is clear in meaning throughout.

mula_pali: 441. Evaṃ vutte, poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bhante! Abhikkantaṃ, bhante, seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya – ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti. Evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gata’’nti.
mula_english:
441.
When this was said, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said this to the Blessed One: “Excellent, venerable sir! Excellent, venerable sir! Just as, venerable sir, one might set upright what has been overturned, or reveal what has been hidden, or show the way to one who is lost, or carry an oil lamp into the darkness, so that ‘those with eyes will see forms.’

Just so, in many ways, has the Dhamma (dharma) been made clear by the Blessed One.

I go to the Blessed One for refuge (śaraṇa), and to the Dhamma (dharma) and the Saṅgha (saṃgha) of monks.

May the Blessed One remember me as a lay follower (upāsaka) who has gone to him for refuge (śaraṇa), from this day forward, for life.”
commentary_pali: 439-443. Atha bhagavā tassa byākaraṇena saddhiṃ attano byākaraṇaṃ saṃsandituṃ ‘‘evameva kho cittā’’tiādīni vatvā puna opammato tamatthaṃ sādhento ‘‘seyyathāpi citta gavā khīra’’ntiādimāha. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho, yathā gavā khīraṃ, khīrādīhi ca dadhiādīni bhavanti, tattha yasmiṃ samaye khīraṃ hoti, na tasmiṃ samaye dadhīti vā navanītādīsu vā aññataranti saṅkhyaṃ niruttiṃ nāmaṃ vohāraṃ gacchati. Kasmā? Ye dhamme upādāya dadhītiādi vohārā honti, tesaṃ abhāvā. Atha kho khīraṃ tveva tasmiṃ samaye saṅkhyaṃ gacchati. Kasmā? Ye dhamme upādāya khīranti saṅkhyā nirutti nāmaṃ vohāro hoti, tesaṃ bhāvāti. Esa nayo sabbattha. Imā kho cittāti oḷāriko attapaṭilābho iti ca manomayo attapaṭilābho iti ca arūpo attapaṭilābho iti ca imā kho citta lokasamaññā loke samaññāmattakāni samanujānanamattakāni etāni. Tathā lokaniruttimattakāni vacanapathamattakāni vohāramattakāni nāmapaṇṇattimattakāni etānīti. Evaṃ bhagavā heṭṭhā tayo attapaṭilābhe kathetvā idāni sabbametaṃ vohāramattakanti vadati. Kasmā? Yasmā paramatthato satto nāma natthi, suñño tuccho esa loko. Buddhānaṃ pana dve kathā sammutikathā ca paramatthakathā ca. Tattha ‘‘satto poso devo brahmā’’tiādikā ‘‘sammutikathā’’ nāma. ‘‘Aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā khandhā dhātuyo āyatanāni satipaṭṭhānā sammappadhānā’’tiādikā paramatthakathā nāma. Tattha yo sammutidesanāya ‘‘satto’’ti  vā ‘‘poso’’ti vā ‘‘devo’’ti vā ‘‘brahmā’’ti vā vutte vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ  arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa bhagavā āditova ‘‘satto’’ti vā ‘‘poso’’ti vā ‘‘devo’’ti vā ‘‘brahmā’’ti vā katheti, yo paramatthadesanāya ‘‘anicca’’nti vā ‘‘dukkha’’nti vātiādīsu aññataraṃ sutvā vijānituṃ paṭivijjhituṃ niyyātuṃ arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ sakkoti, tassa ‘‘anicca’’nti vā ‘‘dukkha’’nti vātiādīsu aññatarameva katheti. Tathā sammutikathāya  bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Sammutikathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya bujjhanakasattassāpi na paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ katheti. Paramatthakathāya pana bodhetvā pacchā sammutikathaṃ katheti. Pakatiyā pana paṭhamameva paramatthakathaṃ kathentassa desanā lūkhākārā hoti, tasmā buddhā paṭhamaṃ sammutikathaṃ kathetvā pacchā paramatthakathaṃ kathenti. Sammutikathaṃ kathentāpi saccameva sabhāvameva amusāva kathenti. Paramatthakathaṃ kathentāpi saccameva sabhāvameva amusāva kathenti. Yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasanti yāhi lokasamaññāhi lokaniruttīhi tathāgato taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparāmāsānaṃ abhāvā aparāmasanto voharatīti desanaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā arahattanikūṭena niṭṭhāpesi. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
439-443.

Then, in order to reconcile his own explanation with that explanation, the Lord, having said, "It is just so, Citta," and so forth, again, while establishing that meaning by means of a simile, said, "Just as, Citta, from a cow [comes] milk," and so forth.

Here, this is the meaning in brief: Just as from a cow [comes] milk, and from milk and so forth, curds and so forth come into being, there, at whatever time there is milk, at that time there is not curds, or butter, or any other [product]; the designation, term, name, or convention goes to it.

Why? Because of the absence of those *dharmas* by relying on which the convention "curds" and so forth exists.

But rather, it is just milk that, at that time, the designation goes to.

Why? Because the existence of those *dharmas* by relying on which the designation, term, name, and convention "milk" exists.

This method [applies] everywhere.

These, Citta, are the gross attainment of selfhood, and this is the mind-made attainment of selfhood, and this is the formless attainment of selfhood, and these, Citta, are worldly designations; in the world, these are merely designations, merely consensual agreements.

Likewise, these are merely worldly terms, merely paths of speech, merely conventions, merely name-giving designations.

Thus, the Lord, having spoken of three attainments of selfhood earlier, now says that all of this is merely convention.

Why? Because, ultimately, there is no being (*sattva*) named, this world is empty and void.

But for the Buddhas, there are two kinds of speech: conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*) and ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*).

There, that which begins with "a being (*sattva*), a person (*posa*), a god (*deva*), Brahmā" is called conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*).

That which begins with "impermanent (*anitya*), suffering (*duḥkha*), without self (*anātmā*), aggregates (*skandha*), elements (*dhātu*), sense bases (*āyatana*), mindfulness (*smṛti*), perfect exertion (*samyakpradhāna*)" is called ultimate speech (*paramārtthakathā*).

There, the Lord speaks first of "a being (*sattva*)," "a person (*posa*)," "a god (*deva*)," or "Brahmā" to someone who, when it is said in conventional teaching "a being (*sattva*)," or "a person (*posa*)," or "a god (*deva*)," or "Brahmā," is able to understand, penetrate, and proceed to take hold of the victory over the stronghold of *arhatship*; to someone who, having heard from the ultimate teaching "impermanent (*anitya*)," or "suffering (*duḥkha*)," and so forth, is able to understand, penetrate, and proceed to take hold of the victory over the stronghold of *arhatship*, the Lord speaks only of "impermanent (*anitya*)" or "suffering (*duḥkha*)," and so forth.

Likewise, to a being who is able to understand conventional speech (*sammutikathā*), he does not speak of ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*) first.

But having enlightened [him] with conventional speech (*sammutikathā*), he speaks of ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*) afterwards.

To a being who is able to understand ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*), he does not speak of conventional speech (*sammutikathā*) first.

But having enlightened [him] with ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*), he speaks of conventional speech (*sammutikathā*) afterwards.

For someone who, by nature, speaks of ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*) first, the teaching is harsh in nature; therefore, the Buddhas, having spoken of conventional speech (*sammutikathā*) first, speak of ultimate speech (*paramatthakathā*) afterwards.

Even while speaking of conventional speech (*sammutikathā*), they speak only of truth, only of reality, not falsely.

Even while speaking of ultimate speech (*paramārtthakathā*), they speak only of truth, only of reality, not falsely.

"The *tathāgata* speaks by means of whatever he speaks; he does not cling; the *tathāgata*, without clinging because of the absence of clinging to craving (*tṛṣṇā*), pride (*māna*), views (*dṛṣṭi*)," having turned the teaching away from "the worldly designations, the worldly terms," he brought it to completion with the subtlety of *arhatship*.

The rest is clear in every respect.

mula_pali: 442. Citto  pana hatthisāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca – ‘‘abhikkantaṃ, bhante; abhikkantaṃ, bhante! Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya – ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti. Evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito. Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ  saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca. Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampada’’nti.
mula_english:
442.
Then Citta Hatthasāriputta said this to the Blessed One: "Excellent, venerable sir! Excellent, venerable sir! Just as, venerable sir, one might set upright what has been overturned (nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya), or open up what has been closed (paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya), or show a path to one who is lost (mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya), or carry an oil lamp (telapajjotaṃ) into the darkness (andhakāre) so that those with eyes (cakkhumanto) could see forms (rūpāṇi), in the same way has the Blessed One (bhagavatā) made the Dhamma (dhammo) clear in many ways (anekapariyāyena).

I go to the Blessed One (bhagavantaṃ) for refuge (saraṇaṃ gacchāmi), and to the Dhamma (dhammañca) and the Saṅgha (bhikkhusaṅghañca) of monks.

May I receive the going forth (pabbajjaṃ), venerable sir, in the Blessed One’s (bhagavato) presence (santike)? May I receive the full admission (upasampada)?”

commentary_english:
439-443.

Then, the Blessed One, in order to compare his own explanation with that explanation, said, "It is just so, Citta," and so on. Again, while establishing that meaning through simile, he said, "Just as, Citta, from a cow comes milk," and so on.

Here, this is the concise meaning: just as from a cow comes milk (*khīra*), and from milk etc. come curds (*dadhi*) etc., there, at whatever time there is milk, at that time there is not curds—or any other such as fresh butter (*navanīta*)—it goes into reckoning (*saṅkhyaṃ*), expression (*niruttiṃ*), name (*nāmaṃ*), and usage (*vohāraṃ*).

Why? Because of the absence of those *dharmas* taking hold of which the usages "curds" etc. exist.

But then, at that time, just milk itself goes into reckoning.

Why? Because of the existence of those *dharmas* taking hold of which the reckoning (*saṅkhyā*), expression (*nirutti*), name (*nāmaṃ*), and usage (*vohāra*), is "milk."

This method applies everywhere.

These, Citta, are gross attainment of self (*oḷāriko attapaṭilābho*)—and mental attainment of self (*manomayo attapaṭilābho*)—and formless attainment of self (*arūpo attapaṭilābho*). These, Citta, are worldly designations (*lokasamaññā*), worldly conventionalities (*samaññāmattakāni*), worldly understandings (*samanujānanamattakāni*).

Likewise, these are worldly expressions (*lokaniruttimattakāni*), pathways of speech (*vacanapathamattakāni*), conventional usages (*vohāramattakāni*), designations of names (*nāmapaṇṇattimattakāni*).

Thus, the Blessed One, having described below the three attainments of self, now says that all of this is merely usage (*vohāramattakaṃ*).

Why? Because, in ultimate truth (*paramatthato*), there is no being (*satto*) by the name, this world is empty (*suñño*), void (*tuccho*).

For Buddhas, however, there are two kinds of talk (*kathā*): conventional talk (*sammutikathā*) and ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathā*).

There, “A being (*satto*), a person (*poso*), a god (*devo*), Brahmā (*brahmā*)" etc. are called "conventional talk (*sammutikathā*)."

"Impermanent (*aniccaṃ*), suffering (*dukkham*), without self (*anattā*), aggregates (*khandhā*), elements (*dhātuyo*), sense-bases (*āyatanāni*), mindfulness (*satipaṭṭhānā*), right efforts (*sammappadhānā*)" etc. are called "ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathā*)."

There, the Blessed One initially speaks of "a being (*satto*)," "a person (*poso*)," "a god (*devo*)," or "Brahmā (*brahmā*)" etc. to someone who, having heard in conventional teaching (*sammutidesanāya*) "a being (*satto*)," or "a person (*poso*)," or "a god (*devo*)," or "Brahmā (*brahmā*)," is able to understand (*vijānituṃ*), penetrate (*paṭivijjhituṃ*), go forth (*niyyātuṃ*), and take hold of the grasp of *arhat*-hood (*arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ*). To someone who, having heard in ultimate-meaning teaching (*paramatthadesanāya*) "impermanent (*anicca*)" or "suffering (*dukkha*)" etc., is able to understand (*vijānituṃ*), penetrate (*paṭivijjhituṃ*), go forth (*niyyātuṃ*), and take hold of the grasp of *arhat*-hood (*arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ*), he speaks only of "impermanent (*anicca*)" or "suffering (*dukkha*)" etc.

Likewise, to a being (*sattassa*) capable of understanding (*bujjhanaka*) conventional talk (*sammutikathāya*), one does not initially speak ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathaṃ*).

But having awakened him with conventional talk (*sammutikathāya*), one speaks ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathaṃ*) afterwards.

To a being (*sattassa*) capable of understanding (*bujjhanaka*) ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathāya*), one does not initially speak conventional talk (*sammutikathaṃ*).

But having awakened him with ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathāya*), one speaks conventional talk (*sammutikathaṃ*) afterwards.

However, for someone who, by nature (*pakatiyā*), initially speaks only ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathaṃ*), the teaching (*desanā*) is harsh (*lūkhākārā*). Therefore, Buddhas, having initially spoken conventional talk (*sammutikathaṃ*), speak ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathaṃ*) afterwards.

Even while speaking conventional talk (*sammutikathaṃ*), they speak only the truth (*saccameva*), only reality (*sabhāvaṃeva*), [and] not falsely (*amusāva*).

Even while speaking ultimate-meaning talk (*paramatthakathaṃ*), they speak only the truth (*saccameva*), only reality (*sabhāvaṃeva*), [and] not falsely (*amusāva*).

With whatever [designations] the *Tathāgata* speaks, without clinging (*aparāmasanti*), with whatever worldly designations (*lokasamaññāhi*) and worldly expressions (*lokaniruttīhi*) the *Tathāgata*, because of the absence of clinging to craving, pride, and views (*taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparāmāsānaṃ abhāvā*), speaks without clinging (*aparāmasanto voharatīti*)—having turned the teaching (*desanaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā*) with the subtlety of *arhat*-hood (*arahattanikūṭena*), he concluded (*niṭṭhāpesi*).

The rest is clear throughout (*sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti*).

mula_pali: 443. Alattha kho citto hatthisāriputto bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ. Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto na cirasseva – yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ  pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ – brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi. ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti – abbhaññāsi. Aññataro kho panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto arahataṃ ahosīti.
mula_english:
And so, Citta, the son of the elephant trainer, received the going forth (pabbajjaṃ) in the Blessed One's (bhagavato) presence (santike), and he received the acceptance (upasampadaṃ).

Then the venerable (āyasmā) Citta, the son of the elephant trainer, not long after his acceptance (acirūpasampanno), dwelling alone (eko), secluded (vūpakaṭṭho), heedful (appamatto), ardent (ātāpī), and resolute (pahitatto), in no long time reached and remained in that unsurpassed (anuttaraṃ) culmination (pariyosānaṃ) of the holy life (brahmacariya) for which clansmen (kulaputtā) rightly (sammadeva) go forth (pabbajanti) from home (agārasmā) into homelessness (anagāriyaṃ), realizing (sacchikatvā) it for himself (sayaṃ) with direct knowledge (abhiññā) in this very life (diṭṭheva dhamme).

He directly knew (abbaññāsi): “Destroyed (khīṇā) is birth (jāti), the holy life (brahmacariyaṃ) has been lived (vusitaṃ), what had to be done (karaṇīyaṃ) has been done (kataṃ), there is no more (nāparaṃ) coming to any state of being (itthattāyā’ti).”

And thus the venerable (āyasmā) Citta, the son of the elephant trainer, became another one of the arahants (arahataṃ ahosīti).

Yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasanti yāhi lokasamaññāhi lokaniruttīhi tathāgato taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparāmāsānaṃ abhāvā aparāmasanto voharatīti desanaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā arahattanikūṭena niṭṭhāpesi. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
commentary_english:
439-443.

Then the Blessed One, in order to compare his own explanation with that of the other person, said, "It is just so, Citta," and so on. Again, while establishing that meaning by way of simile, he spoke the words beginning, "Just as, Citta, from a cow comes milk."

Here, this is the gist: Just as from a cow comes milk, and from milk, curd and so on arise, at that time when there is milk, at that time it does not go by the reckoning, expression, name, or designation of curd or butter or any other.

Why is that? It is because those things, taking which as a basis the designations such as "curd" are used, are absent.

But at that time, it is just milk that goes by the reckoning.

Why is that? It is because the things taking which as a basis the reckoning, expression, name, and designation "milk" are used are present.

This method applies to all cases.

"These, Citta, are coarse attainments of self," thus, and "These are mind-made attainments of self," thus, and "These are formless attainments of self," thus. These, Citta, are worldly designations. In the world, these are mere designations, mere ways of understanding.

Likewise, they are mere worldly expressions, mere paths of speech, mere designations, mere namings.

In this way, the Blessed One, after speaking of the three attainments of self mentioned previously, now says, "All this is mere designation."

Why is that? Because, from the perspective of the ultimate meaning (*paramārtha*), there is no being (*sattva*) named; this world is empty and void.

For the Buddhas, there are two kinds of speech: conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*) and ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*).

There, the designation "conventional speech" (*saṃmutikathā*) refers to things like "a being (*sattva*), a person (*poṣa*), a god (*deva*), Brahmā," and so on.

The designation "ultimate-meaning speech" (*paramārthakathā*) refers to things like "impermanent (*anitya*), suffering (*duḥkha*), without self (*anātman*), aggregates (*skandha*), elements (*dhātu*), sense-bases (*āyatana*), mindfulness practices (*satipaṭṭhāna*), right efforts (*sammappadhāna*)," and so on.

There, the Blessed One speaks of "a being (*sattva*)", "a person (*poṣa*)", "a god (*deva*)", or "Brahmā" from the outset to one who, by way of conventional teaching (*saṃmutideśanā*), is able to understand, penetrate, and attain the seizing of the victory of *arhat*-ship (*arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ*). To one who, by way of ultimate-meaning teaching (*paramārthadeśanā*), after hearing "impermanent (*anitya*)", "suffering (*duḥkha*)", and so on, is able to understand, penetrate, and attain the seizing of the victory of *arhat*-ship (*arahattajayaggāhaṃ gahetuṃ*), he speaks only of "impermanent (*anitya*)", "suffering (*duḥkha*)", and so on.

Likewise, to a being (*sattva*) capable of understanding conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*), one does not speak of ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*) at first.

But after enlightening [him] with conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*), one speaks of ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*) later.

To a being (*sattva*) capable of understanding ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*), one does not speak of conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*) at first.

But after enlightening [him] with ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*), one speaks of conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*) later.

For one who speaks of ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*) from the outset, the teaching is naturally rough in form. Therefore, the Buddhas first speak of conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*) and later speak of ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*).

Even while speaking of conventional speech (*saṃmutikathā*), they speak truthfully, factually, and not falsely.

Even while speaking of ultimate-meaning speech (*paramārthakathā*), they speak truthfully, factually, and not falsely.

The *Tathāgata* (*Tathāgata*) makes use of whatever is current without attachment. Because of the absence of craving (*taṇhā*), conceit (*māna*), views (*diṭṭhi*), and attachments (*parāmāsa*), the *Tathāgata* (*Tathāgata*) makes use of whatever worldly conventions and worldly expressions there are without attachment. Thus, by turning the teaching away with the subtlety of *arhat*-ship, he brought it to completion.

The rest is clear in meaning throughout.
